superEntry.entry:
alphabetical letter r c
The tenth letter of the alphabet: called raMCN and raA: pl. [of the former] raAMtN and [of the latter] OarowaMCN. (TA in bAb AlAlf AllyRnh.) It is one of the letters termed majohuwrap [or vocal, i. e. pronounced with the voice, not with the breath only]; and of the letters termed culoq, which are, and l and n, [also termed cawolaqiyRap, or pronounced with the extremity of the tongue, and b and f and m which are also termed XafahiyRap, or pronounced with the lips:] these letters which are pronounced with the tip of the tongue and with the lips abound in the composition of Arabic words: (L:) and hence r is termed, in a vulgar prov., HimaAru AlXuEaraMCi [“ the ass of the poets ”]. (TA in bAb AlAlf AllRynp.) r is substituted for l, in navorapN for navolapN, and in raEalRa for laEalRa, and in wajirN and Oawojaru for wajilN and Oawojalu; and this substitution is a peculiarity of the dial. of Keys; wherefore some assert that the r in these cases is an original radical letter. (MF.) ＝ -A2- [As a numeral, it denotes Two hundred..]

ra c
ra is an imperative of raOaI [q. v.]. (AZ, T and S and M in art. rOI.)

raA c
raA and raMCN: see the preceding paragraph, and arts. rwO and rI. ＝ -A2- raA is also said by some for raOaI [q. v.]. (M in art. rOI.)

R. Q. 1 raOoraOa AlsRaraAbu c
R. Q. 1. raOoraOa AlsRaraAbu, (Sgh, and so in a copy of the S,) or AlsRaHaAbu, (M, and so in a copy of the S,) or both, (K,) The mirage, or the clouds, or both, shone, or glistened. (S, M, Sgh, K.) ― -b2- [Hence, probably,] raOoraOato EayonaAhu [app. meaning His eyes glanced] is said when one turns his eyes: (AZ, S:) or raOoraOoti AlEayonu means the eye was restless, turning [in various directions]: or was in a state of motion, or commotion, by reason of its weakness. (El-Ghooree, Har p. 85.) And raOoraOa (K,) inf. n. raOoraOapN, (M,) said of a man, (TA,) He moved about the black of his eye: (M, K, TA:) or he turned it about (K, TA) much: (TA:) and he looked sharply, or intently. (M, K, TA.) You say also, huwa yuraOoriYu biEayonayohi [He moves about the blacks of his eyes: &c.]. (TA. [See also OaroOaI, in art. rOI.]) And raOoraOoto, said of a woman, She glistened with her eyes, by reason of looking hard, or intently: (K:) or, said of a fornicatress, or an adulteress, she moved about the blacks of her eyes [as a sign] to the man seeking her: (T:) or rOrOt biEayonihaA, said of a woman, (S, M,) she glistened with her eye, by reason of looking hard, or intently: (S:) or she opened her eye wide, and looked sharply, or intently. (M.) Also, said of a woman, She looked at her face in a mirror. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- raOoraOoti AlZRibaMCu The gazelles wagged their tails: (K:) or so rOrOto biOaconaAbihaA; like laOolaOato. (T.) ＝ -A2- raOoraOa, (K,) or raOoraOa biAlganami, (T, M,) inf. n. raOoraOapN, (T,) He called the sheep, or goats, to water: (T:) or he called the sheep, or goats, (M, K,) by the cry UirRoUirRo or [rather, as in the present day,] UirRa [i. e. UirRa UirRa,] (M,) or by the cry OaroOaro: (K:) accord. to analogy, the verb [derived from the cry] should be OaroOaro: (M:) TaroTaba bihaA, inf. n. TaroTabapN, signifies “ he called them [to be milked by making a sound] with his lips. ” (T.)

rajulN raOoraON c
rajulN raOoraON and raOoraMCN↓, (T,) or raOoraOuAlEayoni (S, M) and raOoraAWuhaA↓, (Kr, M,) A man who turns about the black of the eye much. (T, S, * M.) And AimoraOapN raOoraMCN↓, (T, M, K,) with medd. and without p, (T,) and raOoraON and raOoraOapN, (M, K,) A woman who opens her eye wide, (M,) or who glistens with her eyes, (K,) looking sharply, or intently. (M, K.)

raOoraMCN c
raOoraMCN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

1 raOaba c
1. raOaba, (T, S, M, A, K,) aor.
raAa^a
, (M, A, K,) inf. n. raOobN. (M, TA,) He repaired, or mended, (T, S, M, A, K,) a [cracked, or broken,] vessel, (S,) or a crack, or fissure; (M, A, K;) as also rORb↓, (M, TA,) in some copies of the K ArtOb↓, [agreeably with an explanation of murotaOabN, its pass. part. n., which see below,] and in others [and in a copy of the A] OaroOaba↓, but the right reading is rORb. (TA.) It is related of AHát, that he heard rabN said, [as the imperative, for AiroOabo,] and that it is a good dial. var., like salo for AisoOalo. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) He rectified, repaired, mended, or amended, anything. (M.) You say, raOaba bayona Alqawomi, (M, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) (assumed tropical:) He effected a reconciliation, or made peace, between the people, or company of men. (M, K.) And AallRehumRa QroOabo bayonahumo (S, A) (assumed tropical:) O God, effect a reconciliation, or make peace, between them: (S:) or (tropical:) rectify the matter, or affair, between them. (A.) And AallRehumRa QroOabo HaAlanaA (tropical:) [O God, rectify, or amend, our state, or condition]. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) He collected a thing together, and bound it gently. (TA.) ― -b4- And raOabati AlOaroDu (assumed tropical:) The land produced its [trefoil called] raTobap, or ruTobap, [so accord. to different copies of the K,] after the cutting [of a crop thereof]. (K.)

2 raARa^a
2: and 4 and 8: see above, first sentence.

raOobN c
raOobN an inf. n. used in the sense of [the act. part. n.] raAYibN↓: so in the saying, kafaI bifulaAnK raOobFA liOamorika (tropical:) [Such a one is sufficient as a rectifier, or an amender, of thine affair, or thy case]. (A.) You say also, fulaAnN raOobu Oamori, and raWuwbu↓ OumuwrK, (tropical:) Such a one is a rectifier, or an amender, of an affair, and [a skilful rectifier or amender] of affairs. (A.) [See also ruWobapN: and miroOabN.] ― -b2- Also (tropical:) A chief who rectifies, or amends, the affair, or case, of a people, or party. (A.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A big, bulky, portly, or corpulent, chief. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- A herd of seventy camels. (K.)

ruWobapN c
ruWobapN A piece, (S, Msb, K,) or piece of wood, with which a large wooden bowl, (T, TA,) or with which a vessel, (S, Msb, K,) is repaired, or mended: (T, S, Msb, K:) or a thing, (T,) or piece of wood, (TA,) with which a breach, or broken place, (T, TA,) in a vessel, (T,) or in a bowl, (TA,) is stopped up: (T, TA:) a piece that is inserted in a vessel, to repair, or mend, it: (M:) and a piece of stone with which a buromap [or cooking-pot of stone or other material] is repaired, or mended: (T, TA:) and a patch, or piece, with which a camel's saddle (raHol) is patched, or pieced, when it is broken: (M, TA:) some of its meanings are mentioned also in art. rwb: (TA:) pl. ruWabN (T) and riYaAbN. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, huwa ruWobapu SadoEi AlSRafaMCi (tropical:) [He is the means of repairing the breach of sincere affection]. (A.) And huwa riYaAbu baniI fulaAnK (tropical:) [app. a mistranscription for humo: i. e. They are the means of rectifying, or amending, the affair, or case, of the sons of such a one]. (A.) [See also raOobN and miroOabN.]

raWuwbN c
raWuwbN: see raOobN.

rORLb c
rORLb: see miroOabN.

raAYibN c
raAYibN: see raOobN.

OaroMbN c
OaroMbN, for MraAbN, pl. of UirobN, q. v.

miroOabN c
miroOabN An instrument with which cracks, or fissures, in a vessel, are repaired, or mended; syn. miXoEabN. (M, TA.) ― -b2- [And hence,] the same word, and raORLbN↓, (T, A, K,) A man who repairs, or mends, cracks, or fissures, (T, K,) of bowls [&c.]: (T:) or who repairs, or mends, things well. (A.) And [hence,] (assumed tropical:) A man who effects reconciliation, or makes peace, between people. (T.) Pl. [of the former] maraAYiybu [as though the sing. were miroMbN also]. (T, A, TA.)

murotaOabN c
murotaOabN i. q. mugotafarN [Forgiven: or, accord. to the TK, (assumed tropical:) rectified, or repaired, in a suitable manner]: (K, TA:) [in one copy of the K, muEotafarN: and] in one copy, mEtfn. (TA.)

Q. 1 raOobala c
Q. 1. raOobala. inf. n. raOobalapN, He was, or became, wicked, crafty, or cunning; as also taraOobala↓. (T in art. rbl.) ＝ -A2- raOobalapN (M, K) inf. n. of raOobala, said of a man; (T, K;) [also signifies] The walking (M, K) of a man (M) inclining (M, K) to either side, (M,) or to one side, (K,) as though having the feet attenuated, and chafed, or abraded. (M, K. [yatawaxRaI in the CK is a mistake for yatawajRaI, which is expressly said in the TA to be with jym.])

Q. 2 taraOobala c
Q. 2. taraOobala: see above. ― -b2- Also He made a raid, or a sudden attack, upon people, and acted like the lion: (S and TA in art. rbl:) and so, accord. to Fr, tarayobala. (TA in that art.) And taraOobaluwA They practised theft, (M, K, TA,) and made raids, or sudden attacks, upon people, and acted like the lion. (TA.) And (so in the M, but in the K “ or, ”) They went on a hostile, or hostile and plundering, expedition, upon their feet, and alone, without any commander over them. (M, K. [See rabiylN and riybaAlN, in art. rbl.]) ― -b3- [trObl, said of a lion, occurs in the “ Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen, ” accord. to Freytag, as meaning He had perfect teeth.]

raOobalapN c
raOobalapN Wickedness, craftiness, or cunning, (M, * K, TA,) and boldness, and insidiousness for the purpose of doing evil, or mischief. (TA.) So in the saying, faEala celika mino raOobalatihi He did that by reason of his wickedness, &c. (M, K, TA.) It is the inf. n. of Q. 1 [q. v.]. (T, TK.)

riYobaAlN c
riYobaAlN, a quadriliteral word [as to its root], (M, K,) of the measure fiEolaAlN, as is shown by their saying taraOobaluwA; (M;) and also without C, (M, K,) sometimes, (K,) the C being suppressed, and I substituted for it; (M;) The lion: (S in art. rbl, and M and K:) and the wolf: (M, K:) or a malignant, guileful, or crafty, wolf: and accord. to Skr, a fleshy and young beast of prey: (TA:) and applied as an epithet to a thief, because of his boldness: (M:) and also, (K,) as some say, (M,) one who is the only offspring of his mother: (M, K:) pl. raMbiylu (S in art. rbl, and K) and raMbilu, (K,) [the latter, probably, contracted by poetic license,] and raMbilapN (TA.) [See also riyobaAlN, in art. rbl.]

1 raWuda c
1. raWuda: ― -b2- and raOada: see the next paragraph.

5 trORd c
5. trORd It (a branch, or twig,) was, or became, in its most fresh, or supple, and. soft, or tender, state, [in the first year of its growth; see ruWodN;] as also raWuda↓: (M, L:) or it bent, in a languid manner; syn. tafayRaOa; (T, M, L, K;) and inclined limberly from side to side; syn. tacabRala, (K,) or tacayRala: (M and L:) or it bent: (T:) or it inclined this way and that: (A:) and taraMCada↓ it waved, or inclined to the right and left. (M, L.) It, or (tropical:) he, (a man, TA,) shook by reason of softness, or tenderness, (S, K, TA,) and bent from side to side; (TA;) as also ArtOd↓: (S, K, TA:) and in like manner one says of a girl, (TA,) trORdt, meaning she affected a bending of her body from side to side by reason of softness, or tenderness. (T.) (assumed tropical:) It (the neck) twisted, or bent- (K.) (assumed tropical:) It (a thing) moved to and fro: (TA:) or it twisted, or bent, and moved to and fro. (M.) ― -b2- (tropical:) He (an old man) was, or became, affected with a trembling, and inclined this way and that, in his rising: (A:) or he (a man) rose, and was, or became, affected with a trembling, (T, M, L, K,) in his bones, (M,) in rising, until he stood up. (T, L.) ― -b3- trORdt AlHayRapu (tropical:) The serpent shook, in going, or passing, quickly along. (M, A. *) ― -b4- trORdt AlrRiyHu (assumed tropical:) The wind was, or became, in state of commotion, (K, TA,) and inclined to the right and left. (TA.) ― -b5- trORd AlDRuHaI; (T, M, A, L;) and trMCd↓; (M, L;) and raOada↓, [in Golius's Lex. raYida,] inf. n. raOodN; (A, L;) (tropical:) The DuHaI [or period after sunrise] reached the stage that is termed the XabaAb of the- day; (A;) i. e., when the sun had risen high, (T, A, TA,) one fifth of the day having passed: (A, TA:) or became bright: or advanced beyond the spreading of the sunshine and the time when the sun had become high. (M.)

6 taraARa^a
6: see 5, in two places.

8 UirotaAa^a
8: see 5.

raOodN c
raOodN: see ruWodN. ― -b2- [Hence,] raOodu AlDRuHaI (T, S, M, A, L, K) and raAYiduhu↓ (K) (tropical:) The stage of the DuHaI [or period after sunrise] that is termed the XabaAb of the day; (A;) i. e., when the sun has risen high, (T, S, A, K, TA,) one fifth of the day having passed: (A, TA:) or the brightness thereof: or the period after the spreading of the sunshine and the time when the sun has become high. (M.) ＝ -A2- Also AlrRaOodu (S, M, A, and so accord. to some copies of the K) and AlrRuWodu↓, (S, M, and so accord. to some copies of the K,) or raOodu AllRaHoIi, (T,) and AlrRaOodapu↓ and AlrRuWodapu↓ likewise, (accord. to some copies of the K, [but these I do not find in this sense in any other lexicon,]) or AlruWodapu only of all these, (accord. to other copies of the K, in some of which it is written without C,) The root of the jaw-bone (OaSolu AllRaHoIi), (T, S, M, A, K,) that projects beneath the ear: (T:) or the part of the jaw-bone whence the molar teeth (AlOaDoraAs) grow: or the raOodaAni are the two thin extremities of the laHoyaAni [meaning the two sides of the lower jaw-bone], which are in their upper part, sharp, and curved, and suspended in two holes beneath the two ears: (M:) pl. OaroMdN. (S.) ＝ -A3- Also raOodN A vacant tract (xalaMC) of land. (K.)

ruWodN c
ruWodN (T, L, TA; in a copy of the M ruWuwdN↓ [perhaps a mistranscription for raWuwdN if not for ruWodN; but more probably for the former, which see in art. rwd]; in the L, in one place, raWudN↓; and in a copy of the A raAYidN↓ [which is probably correct, as is also ruWodN];) A branch, or twig, in the most fresh, or supple, and soft, or tender, state, (T, M, A, L,) in the first year of its growth: (T, A, L:) [being also used as a coll. gen. n.,] it has for its n. un. ruWodapN↓: (T, L:) some say that ruWodN signifies the extremity of any branch or twig: the pl. is OaroMdN and OaraAYidu; the latter of which is extr.; and is not a pl. pl.; for, were it so, it would be OaraAYiydu (M, L.) ― -b2- Also, (T, S,M, A, K,) from the same word applied to a branch, or twig, (T,) and raOodN↓, (S, K,) each with C, (AZ, S,) and ruWdapN↓ (S, M, K) and raOodapN↓ (T, S, M, A, K) and raAdapN, (A, K,) without C, (A,) [in the CK repeated with C,] and raWuwdapN↓ (M, K, in the CK raWudapN) and raAYidapN↓ (A) and in some copies of the K ruwdapN without C, [which is in some copies written with C, and] to which the signification there next given (OaSolu AllRaHoIi) is in other copies made to belong, (TA,) and some add raAdN, without C, (MF,) (tropical:) A youthful girl: (T:) or a soft, or tender, girl or woman: (A:) and (T) a woman goodly, or beautiful, (T, S, K,) and youthful: (T, K:) or one who soon attains to youthfulness with good food: (M:) pl. of the first OaroMdN. (T, M.) You say gayoru raAdapi AimoraOapN raOodapN↓, in which the former rAdp may be without C, and the latter must be so, meaning (tropical:) A soft, or tender, woman; not one that roves about. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also ruWodN i. q. tuWadapN [Moderation; gentleness; a leisurely manner of proceeding; &c.] (M, K. [In the latter, the form of the word having this signification is not plainly indicated.]) A poet says,
kaOanRahu vamilN yamoXiI EalaIruwdi
[As though he were one intoxicated, walking in a gentle, or leisurely, manner]; for ElIruWdi; suppressing the C for the sake of the rhyme: but he who regards the word as that of which ruwayodN is the dim. does not regard it as originally with C. (M, TA.) ＝ -A3- See also raOodN.

raWudN c
raWudN: see the first sentence in the next preceding paragraph.

riYodN c
riYodN A sucker, an offset, or a shoot from the root, of a tree: (M, K:) or a soft, or tender, branch, or twig, thereof: pl. riYodaAnN. (M.) ― -b2- Also i. q. tirobN, (T, S, M, K,) i. e. (TA) (tropical:) An
equal in age, (A, TA,) of a female, (T,) and of a man, but mostly used in relation to females: (M:) sometimes, [in poetry,] riydN, with the C suppressed, (T, S, M,) for the sake of the rhyme; (M;) as in in a verse of Kutheiyir cited voce OuSodapN: (T, S:) pl. OaroMdN. (M.) ＝ -A2- Also Straitness: (K, TA: [in the CK, AlDRyRiqu is erroneously put for AlDRiyqu:]) you say, waqaEa fiIAlrRiYodi He fell into straitness. (TK.) But [SM says,] I have not found this in any of the lexicons that I have. (TA.)

raOodapN c
raOodapN: see ruWodN, each in two places: ＝ -A2- and raOodN.

ruWodapN c
ruWodapN: see rWodN, each in two places: ＝ -A2- and raOodN.

raWuwdN c
raWuwdN: see raAdN, in art. rwd.

ruWuwdN c
ruWuwdN [or raWuwdN?]: see ruWodN.

raWuwdapN c
raWuwdapN: see ruWodN.

raAYidN c
raAYidN: see ruWodN. ― -b2- raAYidu AlDRuHaI: see raOodN. ＝ -A2- [See also art. rwd.]

raAYidapN c
raAYidapN: see ruWodN.

1 raOasahu c
1. raOasahu, (S, M, K,) aor.
raAa^a
, (K, TA, [in a copy of the M
raAu^a
,]) inf. n. raOosN, (M, TA,) He (a man, S) hit, or hurt, his head. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- raOasotuhu biAlEaSaI I struck his head with the staff, or stick. (A.) ― -b3- raOasahu AlbirosaAmu The disease called brsAm affected, or overcame, (Oaxaca,) his head. (A.) [And hence,] ruYisa, (M, A,) inf. n. raOosN, (M,) His (a man's) head was, or became, affected, or overcome, by the disease called brsAm, or otherwise: (A:) or he had a complaint of his head. (M, TA.) ＝ -A2- raOasa Alqawoma, (S, M, A,) and raOasa Ealayohimo, (M,) aor.
raAa^a
, (S, M,) inf. n. riYaAsapN, (S, M, A,) (tropical:) He was, or became, head, chief, commander, governor, ruler, lord, master, prince, or king, of, or over, the people; he headed them; (M, A; *) he was, or became, their superior, (M.) [See also 5.] ― -b2- Also raOasa, alone, aor.
raAa^a
, inf. n. riYaAsapN, (tropical:) He was, or became, high in rank or condition. (Msb.) ― -b3- And, with the same aor. and inf. n., (tropical:) He strove for riYaAsap [or headship, or command,] (zaAHama EalayohaA,) and desired it. (IAar, TA.)

2 rORs AlDRabRu AlOafoEaI c
2. rORs AlDRabRu AlOafoEaI The [lizard called] DbR turned his head towards the viper, or met the viper head-foremast, in coming forth from his hole: for the viper comes to the hole of the DbR, and hunts after it, and sometimes the latter comes forth with its head towards the former, and is said to be maraYRis: and sometimes a man hunts after the DbR, and puts a stick into the mouth of its hole, and it imagines it to be a viper, and comes forth head-foremost or tail-foremost, i. e., muraYRisFA Oawo mucanRibFA. (TA.) ＝ -A2- [The verb is also used intransitively, as meaning It (a DabR) put its head foremost in coming forth from its hole: contr. of canRaba.] ＝ -A3- raORasotuhu, inf. n. taroYiysN, (tropical:) I made, or appointed, him raYiys [i. e. head, chief, commander, governor, ruler, lord, master, prince, or king], (S, K,) EalaI Alqawomi over the people. (S, TA.) And raORasuwhu EalaIOanofusihimo, (M, A,) seen by Az, in the book of Lth, written rawRasuwhu, but the former is the regular form, (TA,) (tropical:) They made him head, chief, commander, &c., over themselves. (M, A.)

5 trORs EalaIAlqawomi c
5. trORs EalaIAlqawomi (tropical:) He became made, or appointed, head, chief, commander, governor, ruler, lord, master, prince, or king, over the people; (S, M, A;) as also Ealayohimo ArtOs↓: (S:) or both signify [like raOasa ElI Alqwm,] he was, or became, raYiys [i. e. head, chief, &c.] (K, TA) over the people. (TA.)

8 ArtOs AlXRaIoCa c
8. ArtOs AlXRaIoCa He, or it, became mounted, or fixed, upon the head of the thing. (M, TA. *) In the saying, yarotaAsu AlsRinaAna fayuqotalu [He becomes fixed upon the point of the spear-head, and is slain], in a verse cited by Th, yarotaAsu is for yarotaYisu. (M.) ＝ -A2- See also 5. ＝ -A3- ArtOs zayodFA He took Zeyd by the neck, and lowered it to, or towards, the ground. (K, from the “ Nawádir el-Aaráb. ”) ― -b2- Hence, (assumed tropical:) He occupied Zeyd so as to divert his attention: (K, from the same:) and AikotaAsahu and Airotakasahu and AiEotakasahu also signify the same [app. in the former sense, or perhaps in both senses.] (TA, from the same.)

raOosN c
raOosN, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) generally with C, except in the dial. of Benoo-Temeem, who constantly suppress the C, (Msb,) [The head of a man and of any animal;] a certain part of an animal, (Msb,) well known: (Msb, K:) masc., (Msb, TA,) by common consent: (TA:) and (K) the highest or uppermost part, or top, or summit, (M, A, K,) of a thing, (M,) or of anything; (A, K;) as, for instance, of a mountain, &c.; (the Lexicons, passim;) and the upper, or uppermost, part of a valley: (TA: see raAYisN:) pl. (of pauc., S, TA) OaroWusN, (S, M, Msb, K,) and, by transposition, MrusN, (M, TA, * [originally OaOorusN, in the L, erroneously, OLArAs,]) and (of mult., S, TA) ruWuwsu, (S, M, Msb, K, [by some carelessly written ruWusN, and by some, allowably, ruWuLsN,]) which is not transposed, and ruwosN, which is elliptical. (M, TA.) A poet uses the pl. for the dual, saying,
ruWuwsu kabiyrayohinRa yanotaTiHaAni
[The heads of the two great ones, or old ones, of them, smite each other with their horns]. (M.) ― -b2- OumRu AlrRaOosi: see OumRN. ― -b3- yawomu AlrRuWuwsi [The day of the heads] is applied by the people of Mekkeh to the day called yawomu AlqarRi, because then they eat the heads of the animals sacrificed. (A, TA.) ― -b4- OaSaAba raOosahu (tropical:) He kissed his head: a metonymical phrase. (TA.) ― -b5- rumiIa fulaAnN minohu fiI AlrRaOosi [lit., Such a one was shot by him in the head; meaning,] (assumed tropical:) he turned away from him, and did not look towards him nor pay any regard or attention to him, and deemed him troublesome. (S, TA.) You say also, rumiytu minoka fiI AlrRaOosi, meaning, (assumed tropical:) Thou hast an evil opinion of me (S, K) so that thou canst not look towards me. (S.) ― -b6- rakiba raOosahu: see art. rkb. ― -b7- waladato waladahaA EalaI raOosK waAHidK (assumed tropical:) She brought forth her children one after, or near after, another. (IAar, M.) In like manner you say, wulida lahu valaAvapu OawolaAdK raOosFA EalaI Uivori raOosK, (M,) or raOosFA EalaI raOosK, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He had three children born to him one after, or near after, another. (M, TA.) And AijoEalo hecaA AlXRaIoCa raOosFA waAHidFA (assumed tropical:) Make thou this thing to be [uniform, or] of one way, or mode, or manner. (ISK, TA in art. bOj.) ― -b8- EinodiI raOosu mina Alganami (tropical:) [I have one head of sheep or goats]: and EidRapN mino OaroWusK (tropical:) [a number of head thereof]. (A, TA.) It is said in a trad. of' Omar, waQjoEaluwA AlrRaOosa raOosayoni (tropical:) And make ye the one head two head, by buying two animals with the price of one, that, when one dies, the second may remain. (Mgh in art. frq.) And you say, fulaAnN yarotabiTu kacaA raOosFA mina AldRawaAbRi [Such a one ties so many head of beasts]. (S in art. rbT.) ― -b9- OaEoTiniI raOosFA mino vuwmK wa sinRFA minohu (tropical:) [Give thou to me a head of garlic, and a clove thereof]: and kamo fiI raOosika mino sinRi (tropical:) [How many cloves are there in thy head of garlic?]. (A, TA.) ― -b10- raOosN also signifies The extremity of a thing: or, as some say, the end, or last, thereof. (MF. TA.) ― -b11- [A head, head-land, cape, or promontory.] ― -b12- The hilt of a sword; (A;) and so riYaAsN↓; (S, M, K; [in a copy of the A riyaAsapN;]) or this signifies its pommel, (Sgh, K,) more correctly; (Sgh;) and is also written riyaAsN, but whether for riYaAsN or originally with I is doubtful. (M.) [From the first of the above-mentioned significations arise several others, which are tropical. ― -b13- Hence, AlrRaOosu waAlcRanabu (assumed tropical:) The two nodes of a planet: see tinRiynN. ― -b14- Hence likewise,] raOosN is also (tropical:) syn. with raYiysN, q. v. infrà. (M, K.) You say, maA Ouriyduhu raOosFA (tropical:) [I do not desire him as a rYys, i. e. head, chief, &c.]. (A.) And it is said in a trad., raOosu Alkufori mino qibali AlmaXoriqi (tropical:) [The head, or leader, of infidelity is from the direction of the place of sunrise]: indicating that Ed-Dejjál or some other of the heads of error will come forth in the east. (TA.) ― -b15- raOosu AlmaAli (tropical:) The capital, or principal, of property. (Msb, K.) [Hence the saying,] OaqoraDatoniI EaXarapF biraWuwsihaA (tropical:) She lent me ten [pieces of money] as a loan whereof the principal was to be repaid without interest. (Mgh, TA. *) ― -b16- AlqaAfiyapu AlrOosu Albayoti (assumed tropical:) [The rhyme is the principal, or most essential, part of the verse]: said by one of the tribe of' Okeyl, to IJ. (M.) ― -b17- raOosu AldRiyni AlxaXoyapu (tropical:) [The principal part, or the beginning, of religion is fear of God]. (A, TA.) ― -b18- raOosu AlXRahori (assumed tropical:) The beginning of the month. (Msb.) [And in like manner, raOosu AlsRanapi (assumed tropical:) The beginning, or first day, of the year.] ― -b19- raOosu AlOamori, (K, TA,) or riYaAs↓, (so in the CK,) [both correct, as will be seen from what follows,] (tropical:) The beginning of the affair; the first thereof. (K, TA.) ― -b20- OaEido EalaIRa kalaAmaka mino raOosK, (S, M,) and mina AlrRaOosi, but this is less common, (M,) or is a vulgar phrase, not allowable, (S,) (tropical:) [Repeat thou to me thy speech
from the beginning:] said by a person to one talking to him. (TA.) One also says to a person talking to him, xucohu mino raOosK (tropical:) [Take thou it from the beginning]. (A.) ― -b21- Oanota EalaIraOosi Oamorika, and ElI riYaAsihi↓ (assumed tropical:) Thou art on the point of accomplishing thine affair: (M, TA:) or Oanota EalaI Oamorika riYaAsi↓ signifies (assumed tropical:) thou art at the beginning of thine affair; and the vulgar say, EalaI raOosi Oamorika (S, TA.) ― -b22- OaDoraEato EalaI raOosi Alwaladi: see art. DrE. ― -b23- kaAna celika EalaI raOosi fulaAnK (tropical:) That was in the time of such a one; in his life-time: like the phrase EalaI rijoli fulaAnK. (TA in art. rjl.) ― -b24- raOosN also signifies (tropical:) A numerous and strong company of people. (As, S, M, K.) You say, humo raOosN (tropical:) They are a numerous and strong company of people. (S.) And humo raOosN EaZiymN (tropical:) They are an army by themselves, not needing any aid. (A, TA.) 'Amr Ibn-Kulthoom says, (S,)
biraOosK mino baniI juXami boni bikorK
naduqRu bihi AlsRuhuwlapa waAlHuzuwnaA
[as though meaning, With a numerous and strong company of Benoo-Jusham-Ibn-Bekr, with which we beat the plains and the rugged tracts]: (S, M:) but [J says,] I think that he means raYiys, [i. e. head, chief, &c.,] because he says ndqR bihi, not bihimo (S.)

ruWaAsN c
ruWaAsN: see OaroOasu.

riYaAsN c
riYaAsN: see raOosN, in the middle of the paragraph: and again, in three places, in the latter part thereof.

raWuwsN c
raWuwsN: see raAYisN. ― -b2- Also A camel having no fatness (Tiroq) remaining except in the head; (S, K;) and so muraAYisN↓, (S, TA,) incorrectly said in the K to be muraORasN↓, like muEaZRamN; (TA;) mentioned by A' Obeyd, from Fr.; (S;) so too miroMsN↓. (K.)

raYiysN c
raYiysN Hit, or hurt, in the head; as also maroWuwsN↓. (S.) Hence, XaApN raYiysN A sheep or goat, or a ewe or she-goat, hit, or hurt, in her head: pl. raMsaI: (S, M, K:) you say ganamN raMsaI. (S, K.) ― -b2- Having his head broken, its skin being cleft. (TA.) ― -b3- Having his head affected, or overcome, by the disease called birosaAm; as also maroWuwsN↓: (A:) or ↓the latter, a man afflicted with that disease: (M, TA:*) and ↓the same, also, a man having a complaint of his head. (TA.) ＝ -A2- (tropical:) The head, or headman, chief, commander, governor, ruler, lord, master, prince, or king, of a people; a person of authority; (S, M, A, * K;) as also rayRisN↓ (S, K) and raOosN↓ [q. v.]; (M, A, K;) and [in like manner] raAYisN↓, syn. of this last, waAlK: (K:) or raYiysN signifies, [or rather signifies also,] a person high in rank or condition: (Msb:) its pl. is ruWasaMhu, (M, Msb,) pronounced by the vulgar ruwasaMC: (TA:) in El-Yemen, rayRisN↓ is applied to one who shaves the head. (TA in art. rys.) ― -b2- raYiysu AlkilaAbi (S, M, A,) and raAYisuhaA↓, (M, TA,) (tropical:) [The chief, or leader, of the dogs;] the dog that is' among the other dogs, as the raYiys among a people: (S:) the chief of the dogs, that is not preceded by them in the chase. (M, TA.) ― -b3- AlOaEoDaMCu AlrRaYiysapu (tropical:) [The capital parts of an animal] are, with physicians, four; (Mgh, TA;) namely, the heart, the brain, the liver, and the testicles: (Mgh, K, TA:) the first three, because without every one of them the person cannot exist; and the last, because privation thereof is a privation of nawoE [properly species]: the assertion that they are the nose, and the tongue, and the penis, is erroneous. (Mgh, TA.)

ruWaAsiIRN c
ruWaAsiIRN: see OaroOasu.

ruWuwsN ruwRasN c
ruWuwsN ruwRasN: see miroOasN.

raORLsN c
raORLsN A seller of heads: (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K:) rawRaAsN, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or rawRaAsiIRN, (K, TA,) with w and with the relative I, (TA,) is vulgar, (S,) or incorrect, (Mgh, K,) or post-classical. (Msb.)

riYRiysN c
riYRiysN One who is often made or appointed, or who often becomes, raYiys [i. e. head, chief, &c.]. (K, TA.)

raAYisN c
raAYisN [act. part. n. of 1.] ― -b2- kalobapN raAYisN, (M,) or raAYisapN, (TA,) A bitch that takes the object of the chase by the head. (M, TA.) And [in like manner] kalobapN raWuwsN↓ A bitch that springs upon the head of the object of the chase. (TA.) ＝ -A2- raAYisN also signifies Anything elevated, or rising above the part or parts adjacent to it. (M, TA.) The head (raOos↓) of a valley: (M, TA:) pl. rawaAYisu, (TA,) which signifies the upper, or uppermost, parts of valleys. (K, TA.) ＝ -A3- saHaAbapN raAYisN, (M,) or raAYisapN, (TA,) and muraAYisN↓, (M,) (assumed tropical:) A cloud preceding the other clouds: (M: [but perhaps saHaAbapN in the copy of the M from which this is taken is a mistake for saHaAbN, i. e. clouds:]) pl. rawaAYisu. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- See also raYiysN, in two places.

rayRisN c
rayRisN: see raYiysN, in two places.

OaroOasN c
OaroOasN Having a large head; (S, M, A, Mgh, K; *) applied to a man, (S, A, Mgh,) and to a sheep or goat, (S, TA,) and to a stallion; (TA; [but fHl, there, is perhaps a mistake for rajulN;]) as also ruWaAsiIRN↓; (S, M, A, K;) which is likewise applied to a man, (S, A,) and to a stallion, (TA,) but not to a sheep or goat; (ISk, S;) and rawRaAsiIRN; (TA in art. rws;) and ruWaAsN↓; (M, TA;) applied to a stallion; (TA;) and maroWuwsN↓: (K, * TA:) fem. of the first, raOosaMCu. (M.) ― -b2- Also raOosaMCu A ewe, (S, M, K,) or she-goat, (M,) having a black head (A'Obeyd, S, M, K) and face, (S, M, K,) the rest of her being white. (S.)

raOosN miroOasN c
raOosN miroOasN, incorrectly written in the K maroOasN, like maqoEadN, (TA,) i. q. miSakRN lilrRuWuwsi [app. meaning A head strong to butt, or knock, against other heads]: pl. ruWuwsN maraAYiysu, (K, TA,) or maraAYisu; (CK;) and ruWuwsN ruWRasN↓ [signifies the same]. (K, * TA.)

muraORasN c
muraORasN: see raWuwsN.

muraYRisN c
muraYRisN A [lizard of the kind called] DbR coming forth from his hole having his head foremost: opposed to mucanRibN. (TA.) ― -b2- AlmuraYRisu The lion. (K.)

miroMsN c
miroMsN A horse that bites the heads of other horses when running with them in a race: (M, K: *) or [so in some copies of the K, but in others “ and, ”] that takes precedence of the other horses in a race. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- See also raWuwsN.

maroWuwsN c
maroWuwsN: see raYiysN, in four places: ― -b2- and see OaroOasu. ― -b3- Also One whose desire (Xahowap) is in his head only. (Fr, Sgh, K.) ＝ -A2- (tropical:) Subjects [of a raYiys]. (K.)

muraAYisN c
muraAYisN: see raAYisN: ― -b2- and raWuwsN. ＝ -A2- Also One holding back (Sgh, K) from the party [to which he belongs] (Sgh, TA) in fight, or battle. (Sgh, K.)

1 raWufa bihi c
1. raWufa bihi, (AZ, T, S, M, O, K,) aor.
raAu^a
; (AZ, T, S, O;) and raOafa, (AZ, T, S, M, K,) aor.
raAa^a
; (AZ, T, S;) and raYifa; (AZ, S, M, O, K;) inf. n. raOofapN and raMfapN (AZ, T, S, M, O, K) and raOafN (AZ, S, K) and raOofN, (O,) the first and second being inf. ns. of raWufa, [or the first is of raOafa,] and the third being inf. n. of raYifa, (AZ, S, O,) and the fourth being of raOafa; (O;) said of God, (K,) and of a man; (AZ, T, S;) [He pitied, or compassionated, him: or he pitied him, or compassionated him, tenderly; or in the utmost degree; or most tenderly: for] raOafopN is syn. with raHomapN: (Fr, T, M, K: *) or it denotes a more special and more tender affection than raHomapN; (T;) or the utmost degree thereof; (S, K;) or the most tender thereof: (K:) and raAfa [in the CK raOafa, as before, and in Freytag's Lex. raACafa,] and raAwafa signify the same: (K:) [the right reading here appears to be raAfa; (for it is said in the K in art. rwf that raAfa, aor. yaraAfu, is a dial. var. of raOafa, aor. yaroOafu;) and raAwafa is-doubtful; (for it is not there mentioned;)] or raAfa, inf. n. rawofN, signifies sakana [he, or it, was, or became, still, &c.]; and raOafa is a dial. var. thereof [signifying thus]; and is not from raWuwfN syn. with raHiymN. (M in art. rwf.)

raOofN c
raOofN (M, O, K) and raAYifN↓ and raYifN↓ (K) and raWuwfN↓ [which is the most common of all] and raWufN↓ (T, S, M, O, K) are epithets from the verbs above: (T, S, M, K:) [the first from raWufa, like DaxomN from DaxumN; the second from raOafa; and the third from raYifa; signifying Exercising, or having, the affection termed raOofap, i. e. pity, or compassion; &c.; pitying, or compassionating; &c.; or pitiful, or compassionate; &c.: the fourth and fifth having an intensive signification; very pitiful or compassionate, &c.: or] the first and fourth and fifth all signify the same, i. q. raHymN: (K:) [and OaroOafiIRN↓ has a similar (most probably
an intensive) signification; as appears from what here follows:] in the saying [of a poet],
wa kaAna cuw AlEaroXi binaA OaraAfiI
[app. meaning And the Lord of the empyrean was, or is, to us, very merciful], by the last word is meant OaroOafiyRFA, [OaroOafiIRN being] like OaHomariIRN [and OaroyaHiIRN, q. v.]. (M.) ＝ -A2- raOofN also signifies Wine; (O, K;) and raAfN is a dial. var. thereof. (TA in art. rwf.)

raWufN c
raWufN: see the next preceding paragraph.

raYifN c
raYifN: see the next preceding paragraph.

raWuwfN c
raWuwfN: see raOofN. ― -b2- AlrRaWuwfN is one of the epithets applied to God; meaning AlrRaHiymN [The Merciful: or rather it has an intensive signification, i. e. The Very Merciful]. (T.)

raAYifN c
raAYifN: see raOofN.

OaroOafiIRN c
OaroOafiIRN: see raOofN. [This art. is wanting in the copies of the Land TA to which I have had access.]

10 AstrOlt AlrRiYolaAnu c
10. AstrOlt AlrRiYolaAnu The young ostriches became big, or advanced in age; syn. kabirat, (O,) or kaburat, (so in one of my copies of the S, in the other kavurat [which is a mistranscription],) or kaburato OasonaAnuhaA. (K: so in my MS. copy and in the CK.) ― -b2- And [hence,] AstrOl AlnRabaAtu (assumed tropical:) The plant, or herb, became tall; likened to the neck of the young ostrich. (S, O, K.)

raOolN c
raOolN The young one of the ostrich: (T, S, M, K:) or a young ostrich in its first year, or a year old: (M, K:) it occurs in a verse of Imra-el-Keys written rAl, without C: (M:) fem. with p: (S, M, K:) pl. (of pauc., TA) OarowulN (K, TA, [in the TT, as from the M, written AroOal, probably for OaroOulN,]) and (of mult., TA) riYolaAnN and riYaAlN (S, M, K) and riYaAlapN. (M, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AlrRiYaAlu [which seems to be the most common of the plso] (assumed tropical:) Certain stars: (S, Sgh, K:) [probably certain small stars in the neighbourhood of those called AlnRaEaAYimu, or of those called AlnRaEaAmaAtu (in Cetus), and regarded as the young ones of these.] ― -b3- [Hence also,] zafRa raOoluhu (tropical:) He was, or became, light of intellect, lightwitted, or irresolute. (S and Z and TA in art. zf.) And zafRa raOoliI (assumed tropical:) I was, or became, affected with sadness, or disquietude of mind, like the young ostrich by reason of fear, or fright; a phrase like XaAlato naEaAmatuhumo meaning “ They were frightened, and fled. ” (M.) And zafRa raOoluhumo (assumed tropical:) They perished, or died. (TA.) And xawRada raOoluhu (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, frightened. (Ham p. 179.)

ruWaAlN c
ruWaAlN and raAWuwlN↓, (As, T, M, K, [the latter in the CK raAWul,]) with C accord to ISk, and without C accord. to A'Obeyd, (M,TA,) The slaver of a horse (As, ISk, T, M, K, TA) or similar beast, (ISk, T,) that drops from him: (TA:) or his froth, or foam: (K:) accord. to Lth, ruwaAlN [q. v. in art. rwl, thus without C,] signifies the spittle of a horse or similar beast. (T.) ＝ -A2- Also the former, (M,) or ↓the latter, (K,) A redundance in [the number of] the teeth of a horse or similar beast: (M, K:) but As denies that these two words have this meaning. (T. [See what next follows.])

raAYilN c
raAYilN and raAYilapN↓, accord. to Lth, signify A tooth that grows to a horse or similar beast, preventing him from drinking [with ease] and from [eating in the manner termed] qaDom: and accord. to En-Nadr, [the pl.] rawaAYilu signifies small teeth that grow at the roots of the large teeth, and excavate the roots of the latter so that these fall out: (T:) but As disallows this. (TA. [See also art. rwl: and see the latter sentence of the next preceding paragraph.])

raAYilapN c
raAYilapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

raAWuwlN c
raAWuwlN: see ruWaAlN, in two places.

naEaAmapN muroYilapN c
naEaAmapN muroYilapN An ostrich having riYaAl [or young ones]. (M, K.)

marRa muraAYilFA c
marRa muraAYilFA He (a man, S) passed along quickly. (S, K.)

1 raYimato waladahaA c
1. raYimato waladahaA, (T, S, M, K,) aor.
raAa^a
, (T,) inf. n. riYomaAnN, (T, S, M, K *) and raOomN (M, K *) and raOamaAnN, (TA,) She (a camel) loved, (T, S,) or affected, or inclined to, and kept to, or clave to, (M, K,) her young one. (T, S, M, K.) And taroOamu biOanofihaA is also said of a she-camel [as meaning She makes a show of affection with her nose, by smelling her young one; not having true love]. (S, M, K, all in art. cOr; &c. [See mucaAYirN, and see also muEaAriDN.]) A poet says,
Oamo kayofa yanofaEu maA tuEoTiI AlEaluwqu bihi
riYomaAnN OanofK UicaA maA DunRa biAllRabani
or rYmAnu, or rYmAni, accord. to different relaters: [i. e. Or how profits what she that smells a young one but refuses to yield her milk to it gives, (the b in bihi being redundant,) showing affection with the nose, (accord. to the first reading,) or a showing of affection with the nose, (accord. to the second and third readings,) when there is niggardliness with the milk?] he who says rYmAna uses this word as an inf. n.: he who says rYmAnu makes it a substitute for mA: and he who says rYmAni makes it a substitute for the h [in bihi]. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] raYima AlXRaIoCa (tropical:) He loved the thing, (S, K, TA,) and (S, K, TA) kept, or clave, to it. (S, M, K, TA.) One says, raYimati AlOavaAfiI AlrRamaAda (tropical:) [The three stones whereon the cooking-pot was placed clave to the ashes]: as though the ashes were their young. (T, K, TA.) ― -b3- And raYima AljuroHu, inf. n. riYomaAnN (AZ, T, S, M) and raOomN, (M, K,) (tropical:) The wound coalesced, or closed; (AZ, T, S, TA;) the mouth of the wound drew together, or closed, preparatively to healing. (M, K, * TA.) ＝ -A2- raOama, (T, S, M, K,) aor.
raAa^a
, (T, K,) inf. n. raOomN, (T, M,) He repaired (T, S, M, K) a crack, or fissure, (M,) or a bowl, (T, K,) or a crack, or fissure, of a bowl: (S:) like raOaba: (T, M:) so says Esh-Sheybánee: and [raMCamahu↓ signifies the same; for] he cites the following verse:
waqatolaI biHiqofK mino OuwaArapa judRiEato
SadaEona quluwbFA lamo turaMCamo XuEuwbuhaA
[And slain men in a winding tract of sand of Uwáreh, (a certain water, or mountain, of Temeem,) that had been mutilated, broke hearts of which the rifts have not been repaired]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And He twisted a rope hard, or strongly; as also ArOm↓. (M, K.)

3 raARa^a
3: see the last sentence but one above.

4 ArOm AlnRaAqapa c
4. ArOm AlnRaAqapa He made the she-camel to affect, or incline to, (ISk, T, S, K,) her raOom [q. v.], (ISk, T,) or the raOom, (S,) or one that was not her young one: (K:) or ArOmhA EalaI waladihaA he made her to affect, or incline to, her young one. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ArOmhu EalaI AlOamori, (ISk, T,) or ElI AlXRaIoCi, (M, K,) (assumed tropical:) He compelled him against his will to do the thing: (ISk, T, M, K:) and so AzOmhu Ealayohi. (TA.) And ArOmhu UilaIkacaA (assumed tropical:) He, or it, caused him to want such a thing. (AA, TA in art. cmg.) ― -b3- ArOm AljuroHa, (inf. n. UirMmN, T,) (assumed tropical:) He dressed, or treated curatively, the wound, (T, S, M, K,) in order that it might heal, or close, (S,) or so that it closed. (M, K.) ― -b4- See also 1, last sentence.

5 trORmt EalaI waladihaA c
5. trORmt EalaI waladihaA, said of a she-camel, i. q. taEaTRafato Ealayohi [app. meaning, as quasi-pass. of EaTRafahaA Ealayohi, She was made to affect, or incline to, her young one]. (TT, from the M. [There written trMmt, which is, in my opinion, a mistranscription.]) ― -b2- taraORamotuhu i. q. taraHRamotu Ealayohi (tropical:) [I pitied, or compassionated, him; or did so much; or affected, or expressed, pity, or compassion, or much pity or compassion, for him; or expressed a wish that God would have mercy on him]. (K, TA.)

8 ArtOm c
8. ArtOm, said by Golius to signify It (a wound) closed, or became consolidated, as on the authority of the S and K, I do not find in any copy of either of those lexicons, nor in any other lexicon.]

raOomN c
raOomN A she-camel's young one; (T, S;) accord. to IAar: (T:) or a she-camel's young one which she affects, or to which she inclines: (M:) and, (S, M,) accord. to Lth, (T,) i. q. bawRN [which has the former of the meanings above, but more commonly signifies a skin of a young unweaned camel stuffed with straw or with panic grass or with dry herbage, to which a she-camel is made to incline when her young one has died; it being brought near to the mother of a young camel that has died, in order that she may incline to it and yield her milk]: (T, S, M, K:) or a young one to which she that is not its mother is made to incline. (T.)

fulaAnN ruWomN lilDRayomi c
fulaAnN ruWomN lilDRayomi [evidently, I think, a mistranscription, for raWuwmN↓, which is also written raWuLmN,]
(tropical:) Such a one is abject, or ignominious; content to endure injury.. (TA.)

rivomN c
rivomN [The antilope leucoryx, or white antelope;] an antelope (ZaboIN) that is purely white; (T, [in which only the pl. is mentioned,] S, M, K;) so accord. to As; (T, S;) and AZ says the like; (T;) inhabiting the sands: (As, T, S:) or, as some say, the young one of the ZaboI [here app. meaning gazelle]: the female is called riYomapN: (M:) pl. OaroMmN (T, S, M, K) and MraAmN; (M, K;) the latter pl. formed by transposition. (M.) [Whether the Hebrew ??? or ??? or ??? mean the same animal as the Arabic riYom is doubtful.] ― -b2- [Hence,] marRato binaAAlMraAmu (tropical:) The beautiful, or pretty, women passed, or went, by us: so called by way of comparison. (TA.)

ruYimN c
ruYimN, (K, TA,) or AlrRuYimu, thus accord. to Kr, with Al, (M,) i. q. AlAisotu [The podex, or the anus]: (Kr, M, K:) [said to be] the only word of its measure except AldRuYilu, which means “ a certain small beast. ” (M. [But see this last word.])

AlrRaOomapN c
AlrRaOomapN The xazarp [i. e. bead, or the like, that is worn as an amulet, and] that is [held to be] a cause of love, or affection. (K.)

ruWomapN c
ruWomapN Glue, with which a thing is stuck: (S:) accord. to the K, [following A'Obeyd, (see art. rwm,)] it is ruwmapN only, without C: but Th mentions it with C also; and both are correct. (MF, TA.)

ruWaAmN c
ruWaAmN Slaver: (T, K:) like ruwaAlN. (T.) [See also ruwaAmN, in art. rwm.]

rawuwmN c
rawuwmN: see raAYimN. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) A ewe, or she-goat, (El-Umawee, T, S, K,) that is very familiar, (K,) that licks the clothes of him who passes by her. (El-Umawee, T, S, K.) ― -b3- See also ruWomN.

raAYimN c
raAYimN, (T, M,) or raAYimapN, (S,) or both, (K,) and raWuwmN↓, (T, S, M, K,) [but the last has probably an intensive signification,] A she-camel that loves, (T, S,) or affects, or inclines to, and keeps to, or cleaves to, (M, K,) her young one, (T, S, M, K,) or the young one of another: if she do not so, but smells it, and does not yield her milk to it, she is termed EaluwqN: so says A'Obeyd, on the authority of As: (T: [see the former of the two verses cited in the first paragraph of this art.:]) the pl. of raAYimapN is rawaAYimu. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, AlrRawaAYimu signifies (tropical:) The three stones whereon the cooking-pot is placed; what are called AlOavaAfiI; (T, M, K, TA;) that have remained cleaving to the ashes: (T, K:) because of their cleaving to the ashes: (M:) the ashes being as though they were their young. (T, K.)

4 OaroOaI c
4. OaroOaI, in one of its senses belonging to this art.: see 4 in the art. next following.

raOowapN c
raOowapN: see the next art., in which it is mentioned in the S.

raOaI c
raOaI, (S, M, &c.,) for which some say raA [suppressing the C and the I,] (M,) and some say raMCa, (T in art. bwO, and M and K in art. ryO,) like xaAfa, (TA in the latter art.,) formed by transposition, (T in art. bwO,) first pers. raOayotu, (M, Msb, K, &c.,) for which some say rayotu, without C, (T, S, M,) but the former is that which is general and preferred, (T, M,) aor. yaraI (T, S, M,) for which yaroOaI, agreeably with the root, is said by none except [the tribe of] Teym-erRibáb, (T, M,) or by such as require this form in poetry, (S,) sec. pers. fem. sing. and pl., alike, tarayona, so that you say tarayonaniI [with an affixed pronoun], and if you will you may say tarayonRiI, incorporating one n into the other by teshdeed, (S,) imperative ra and UiroCa (AZ, T, S, M,) the people of El-Hijáz saying ra dual rayaA, pl. masc. rawoA and fem. rayona, and Teym saying AiroCa &c., (T, M,) inf. n. ruWoyapN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and riyRapN, (T, M, K,) the former being altered to ruwoyapN and then to ruyRapN and then to riyRapN, (T, M,) and raOoIN (T, S, K) and raMCapN, (S, M, K, [in the CK raOap,]) like raAEapN [in measure], (S,) in which the p is not necessarily a restrictive to unity, (M,) and raAyapN (K [but this I do not find elsewhere]) and riYoyaAnN, (Lh, M, TA,) for which last we find in the copies of the K ruWoyaAn, (TA,) He saw [a person or thing] with the eye: (S:) in this sense the verb has [only] one objective complement: (S, Msb:) you say, raOayotuhu (T, M, Msb, K) and AistaroOayotuhu↓, (T, M, K,) for which some say Aisotarayotuhu, (T, M,) and AirotaOayotuhu↓, (T, M, K,) for which some say Airotayotuhu, (T, M,) all signifying the same, (T, M, K,) I saw him, or it, (a person and a thing, Msb) with the eye; (T, M, Msb, K, TA;) [or so,] and also, with the mind. (M and K in relation to the first, and K in relation to all.) ruWoyapN is of several sorts: (TA:) first, it signifies The seeing with the eye: (M, K, TA:) and with what serves for the same purpose as the organ of sight; as in the saying in the Kur [ix. 106], waquli QEomaluwA fasayaraIQllRehu Eamalakumo [And Say thou, Work ye, for God will see your work]; because the sense of sight cannot be attributed to God: (TA:) [and similar to this is the phrase, raOaI fiyhi kacaA He saw in him such a thing: and raOaI minohu kacaA He experienced from him such a thing.] Secondly, The seeing by supposition, or fancy; as in the saying, OaraI OanRa zayodFA munoTaliqN [I suppose, or fancy, that Zeyd is going away]. (TA.) Thirdly, The seeing by reflection, or consideration; as in the saying [in the Kur viii. 50], UinRiI OaraI maA laA tarawona [Verily I see by reflection, or consideration, what ye see not]. (TA.) Fourthly, The seeing with the mind, or mentally; [the opining, or judging, a thing; a sense in which the inf. n. raOoIN is more commonly used;] (M, * K, * TA;) as in the saying in the Kur [liii. 11], maA kacaba AlfuWaAdu maA raOaI [The heart did not belie what he mentally saw]. (TA.) [Of these meanings, other exs. here follow; with exs. of similar meanings.] ― -b2- An ex. of raA for raOaI occurs in the saying of a poet,
mano raA mivola maEodaAna boni aHoyaI
[Who has seen the like of Maadán the son of Yahyà? the measure being waAfir, with the first foot reduced to mufoEalotuno]. (M.) AlHamodulilRehi EalaI riyRatiki, for ruWoyatika, altered in the manner explained above, [meaning Praise be to God for the seeing of thee,] (M, K, *) is a saying mentioned by IAar. (M.) SuwmuwA liruWoyatihi means [Fast ye] at the time of seeing it; [referring to the new moon of Ramadán;] i. e., when ye see it. (Mgh.) In the phrase raOayotuhu qaAYimFA [I saw him standing], qAYmA is in the accus. case as a denotative of state. (Msb.) raOoIu EayoniI zayodFA faEala caAka [My eye saw (lit. my eye's seeing) Zeyd do that] is held by Sb to be an instance of an anomalous use of an inf. n., and is [said to be] the only instance of the kind, among inf. ns. of trans. verbs except samoEu OucuniI. (M, TA: but in a copy of the former written raOoIa EynI and samoEaAcnI.) raOayotuhu raOoIa AlEayoni means [I saw him, or it,] where the eye, or sight, fell upon him, or it. (TA.) biEayonK mRaA OarayanRaka [lit. With some eye I will assuredly see thee] is a saying mentioned by AZ as meaning hasten thou, (AiEojalo thus in copies of the S and in the TA, or EajRilo as in one copy of the S,) or work thou, (AiEomalo, thus in two copies of the S,) and be as though I were looking at thee: (S, TA:) it is said to one whom you send, and require to be quick; and means pause not for anything, for it is as though I were looking at thee. (TA in art. Eyn.) raOaI AlmakaAnu AlmakaAna (tropical:) The place faced [or (as we say) looked upon] the place, as though seeing it, (M, TA,) is tropical: (TA:) [and in like manner you say,] daAriI taraI daArahu (tropical:) My house faces [or looks upon] his house. (T, IAth, TA.) ― -b3- raOaIfiI manaAmihi ruWoyaA [He saw, i. e. fancied that he saw, in his sleep, a vision, or dream]. (S, Msb, K. *) ― -b4- Oalamo tara UilaI kacaA [Has thou not considered such a thing, so as to be admonished thereby?] is a phrase used on an occasion of wonder (IAth, K, TA) at a thing, and in rousing the attention of the person to whom it is addressed; as in the saying in the Kur [ii. 244], Oalamo tara UilaI QlRaciyna xarajuwA mino diyaArihimo [Hast thou not considered those who went forth from their houses, so as to be admonished by their case?]; meaning, hast thou not wondered at their act, and has not their case come to thy knowledge? and so in other instances in the same: (IAth, TA:) Er-Rághib says that, when raOayot is made trans. by means of UilaI, it denotes consideration that leads to the becoming admonished. (TA.) In like manner also, (IAth, K,) OaraOayotaka and OaraOayotakumaA and OaraOayotakumo, (T, IAth, K,) and to a woman OaraOayotaki, and to a pl. number of women OaraOayotakunRa, (T,) [which may be lit. rendered Hast thou, and have ye two, &c., considered?] are expressions used to arouse attention, (IAth, TA,) meaning tell thou me and tell ye two me &c.; (T, IAth, K;) as in the saying in the Kur [xvii. 64], qaAla OaraOayotaka hecaA QlRaciI karRamotu EalaIRa [He
said, Hast thou considered? meaning tell me, respecting this whom Thou hast honoured above me]; and in the same [vi. 40 and 47], qalo OaraOayotakumo Uino OataAkumo EacaAbu QllRehi [Say thou, Have ye considered? meaning tell me, if the punishment of God come upon you]; and occurring without the k in other places thereof: (IAth, TA:) you say also, OaraOayota zayodFA and OaraOayotaka zayodFA, meaning Tell thou me [respecting Zeyd]: (Mgh:) and for OaraOayota and OaraOayotaka [&c.] some say Oarayota and Oarayotaka: (S:) the pronunciation without C is the more common: the t in OaraOayotaka &c. is always with fet-h; and accord. to the grammarians of accredited science, the k in these cases is redundant; (T;) [i. e.] it is a particle of allocution, to corroborate the pronoun [t, which it therefore immediately follows in every case, distinguishing the genders and numbers by its own variations, which are the same as those of the pronominal affix of the second person]: (Bd in vi. 40:) [IHsh says,] the correct opinion is that of Sb; that the t is an agent, and the k is a particle of allocution: (Mughnee in art. k:) but sometimes OaraOayotaka &c. mean halo raOayota nafosaka &c.; the k being in this case an objective complement [and the verb being differently rendered according as it has not, or has, a second objective complement, as is shown here by what precedes and what follows]. (T.) In OaturaAka, also, [from OuriIa↓, not from ruYiIa,] meaning AtZnR [i. e. OataZunRu, Thinkest thou?], the pronoun [as some term it, but properly the final particle,] is [a particle of allocution] like that in OaraOayotaka in the Kur vi. 40 and 47 [cited above; and in the same sense as this latter phrase, OaturaAka is used, as meaning tell thou me]. (Har p. 570.) ― -b5- When raOaI means He knew, (S, Msb,) or he thought, (Msb,) it has two objective complements: (S, Msb:) or when it has two objective complements, it necessarily means knowing [or the like]. (Er-Rághib, TA.) [In this case, raMhu may be rendered He saw, or knew, him, or it, to be: and he thought, or judged, or held, him, or it, to be; or he regarded, or held, him, or it, as.] You say, raOayotu zayodFA EaAlimFA, (S, Msb, *) or HaliymFA, (M,) I knew [or saw Zeyd to be learned, or forbearing]; (S, M, Msb;) as though seeing him to be so with the eye: (M:) and I thought him [&c.] to be so. (Msb.) In like manner, also, taraMCayotuhu↓ signifies I thought him to be. (Har p. 211.) yarawonahumo mivolayohimo raOoIa QlEayoni, in the Kur [iii. 11], means They [who were the unbelievers] thinking them [who were fighting in the cause of God] twice as many as they, according to the evidence of the sight of the eye. (TA.) The pass. form of raOaI has [only] one objective complement: you say, ruYiIa zayodN EaAqilFA, meaning Zeyd was thought [to be intelligent]: (TA:) and AalRaciI OuraAhu, with the verb in the pass. form, means AlcIAZnR [i. e. OuZanRu, He whom I am thought to be; if from ruYiIa: or AlcIOaZunRu, what I think, if from OuriIa↓: it is often used in the latter sense]. (Msb.) ― -b6- You say also, raOaI fiI AlOamori raOoyFA [He formed, or held, an opinion, or a persuasion, or a belief, respecting the affair, or case]: (Msb:) and so fiIAlfiqohi [in the science of the law]. (S.) And AlRaciI OaraAhu That to which I take, or which I hold, as my opinion, or persuasion, or belief. (Msb.) And fulaAnN yaraI raOoIa AlXRuraApi Such a one holds, or believes, the tenets, or belief, of the XrAp [a certain sect of schismatics; pl. of XaArK]. (M.) When raOaI is [thus] used as meaning He held, or believed, it has [only] one objective complement. (Msb.) ― -b7- laA tara maA (T, K, TA, [mentioned also in the K in art. trm, in which art. in the CK CK it is written lA taromA,]) and laA taraI maA, and lawo tara maA, and lawo taraImaA, (T, TA, [in copies of the K Oawotara maA, which I think a mistranscription, and for which is put in the TA, as on the authority of IAar, Ac tr mA, app. a mistranscription of a mistranscription, i. e. of AwtrmA,]) and lamo tara maA, (T, K, TA,) in this last case with tara [only, agreeably with a general rule], are forms of expression meaning laA siyRamaA [i. e., virtually, Above all, or especially]: (T, K, TA:) you say, UinRahu laxabiyvN walaA tara maA fulaAnN and wa laA taraI maA fulaAnN and wa lawo tara maA fulaAnN and walawo taraI maA fulaAnN and .alamo tara maA fulaAnN [i. e. Verily he is bad, or base, or wicked; and above all, or especially, such a one: walaA tara maA fulaAnN, or walaA taraImaA fulaAnN, properly meaning walaA taraImivola AlRaciI huwa fulaAnN and thou will not see the like of him who is such a one; mivola and huwa being understood: and in like manner are to be explained the other forms of expression here mentioned]: in all of these forms, flAn is in the nom. case: all are mentioned by Lh, on the authority of Ks. (T, TA.) ― -b8- raOato is also said of a woman, as meaning She saw what is termed AltRaroYiyap and AltRariyRap, i. e., a little yellowness or whiteness or blood on the occasion of menstruation. (M.) ＝ -A2- raOayotuhu [form AlrRiYapu] I hit, or hurt, (S, M, Msb, K, *) or struck, or smote, (Er-Rághib, TA,) his riYap [or lungs]: (S, M, Msb, K, Er-Rághib:) and so warayotuhu. (Msb.) ― -b2- And ruYiIa He had a complaint of his riYap [or lungs]; (M;) as also OaroOaI↓. (T, K.) ＝ -A3- raOayotu raAyapF I stuck, or fixed, a banner, or standard, (T in art. rI, and K in the present art.,) into the ground; (TA;) as also OaraOayotuhaA↓, (T, K,) as some say: (T:) the latter is mentioned by Lh; but [ISd says,] I hold that it is anomalous, and is properly only OarayayotuhaA. (M in art. rI, and TA.) ＝ -A4- raOaIAlzRanodu [like waraI and wariIa] The znd [or piece of wood for producing fire] became kindled. (Kr, M, K.) ― -b2- And raOayotu AlzRanoda I kindled the znd. (M, K.)

2 raORayotuhu c
2. raORayotuhu, inf. n. taroYiyapN, I held for him, or to him, (AZ, T, S,) or I showed, or presented, to him, (M, K,) or I withheld, or retained, or restricted, for him, [i. e. for his use,] (AZ, * T, * S, * M, K,) the mirror, in order that he might look in it, (AZ, T, S, K,) or in order that he might see himself in it; (M;) as also AlmiroMpa Oarayotuhu↓. (M.) ― -b2- See also 3.

3 raMCayotuhu c
3. raMCayotuhu, (M, K,) inf. n. muraAMpN and riYaMCN, (M,) I faced, so that I saw, him, or it; (M, K;) as also taraMCayotuhu↓. (M.) ― -b2- Also, inf. ns. as above, [I acted hypocritically, or with simulation, towards him;] I pretended to him that I was otherwise than I really was; (M, K; *) as also raORayotuhu↓, inf. n. taroYiyapN: (K:) both are mentioned by Fr: (T:) [accord. to J,] raMCaI fulaAnN AlnRaAsa, aor. yuraAYiyhimo, inf. n. muraAMpN, and raAyaAhumo, inf. n. muraAyaApN, the latter formed by transposition, [which indicates, though written as above in my copies of the S, that we should read raAyaOahumo, inf. n. muraAyaOapN,] signify the same: (S:) [but it is said in the Mgh that raAyaA (perhaps thus written for raAyaOa) in the sense of raMCaI is a mistake: and] raMCaI signifies [he acted ostentatiously; i. e.] he did a deed in order that men might see it: (Mgh:) or riYaMCN signifies the making a show of what one does to men, in order that they may see it and think well of it: and the acting otherwise than for the sake of God: (Msb, TA:) and it is said in the S to be a subst. [as distinguished from an inf. n.; but why so, I do not see]. (TA.) Hence, in the Kur [cvii. 6], AalRaciyna humo yuraAWuwna Who act hypocritically; when the believers pray, praying with them, pretending to them that they follow the same way [of religion] as they: (M, TA:) or who make a show of their works to men, in order to be praised by them. (Bd.) And mano raMCaI raMCaI QllRehu bihi He who does a deed in order that men may see it, God will expose his doing so on the day of resurrection. (Mgh) And faEala celika riYaMCF wasumoEapF [He did that in order to make others to see it and hear of it]. (S.) [See also 4.] ― -b3- In the saying of El-Farezdak, satirizing a people, and charging one of their women with that which is not comely,
wa baAta yuraAMhaA HaSaAnFA wa qado jarato
lanaA burataAhaA biAlRaciI Oana XaAkiruho
[And he passed the night thinking her chaste, when her two anklets had run to us with that for which I was thankful], by yuraAMhaA [with HaSaAnFA following it] he means yaZunRu OanRahaA HaSaAnN, i. e. EafiyfapN; and by jarato lanaA burataAhaA he means OanRahaA Oamokanatohu mino rijolayohaA HatRaI gaXiyahaA. (T.) ― -b4- raMCayotuhu also signifies I consulted with him; or asked his counsel, or advice: (T, K: *) and fiI AlrRaOoIi AisotaroOayotuhu↓ I consulted him, or asked his counsel, or advice, respecting the opinion. (T, K.) 'Imrán Ibn- Hittán says,
faUino nakuno naHonu XaAwaronaAka qulota lanaA
biAlnRuSoHi minoka lanaA fiymaA nuraAYiykaA
i. e. [And if we ask thy counsel, or advice, thou pronouncest to us, with honesty on thy part towards us, concerning that] respecting which we ask thy counsel, or advice. (T.)

4 Oarayotuhu AlXRaIoCa c
4. Oarayotuhu AlXRaIoCa, (IAar, T, S, M, K,) originally OaraOayotuhu, (S,) inf. n. UiraMCapN (Sb, IAar, T, M, K) and UiraAyapN (IAar, T) and UiraMCN, (Sb, IAar, T, M, K,) [the last originally UiroOaACN,] the p in the first inf. n. being a substitute [for the suppressed O, and in like manner in the second], and the last inf. n. being without any substitution, (Sb, M,) [I made him to see the thing; i. e. I showed him the thing:]
you say, Oarayotuhu AlXRaIoCa faraMhu [I showed him the thing, and he saw it[. (S.) See also 8. Aboo-'Amr read OaronaA manaAsikanaA, [in the Kur ii. 122, for OarinaA i. e. Show Thou to us our religious rites and caremonies of the pilgrimage, or our places where those rites and ceremonies are to be performed,] which is anomalous. (M.) ― -b2- One says also, OaraI QllRehu bifulaAnK, meaning God showed men by [the example of] such a one punishment and destruction: (K:) or God showed by [the example of] such a one that which would cause his enemy to rejoice at his misfortune: a saying of the Arabs: (T in art. rI:) said only in relation to evil. (Sh, TA.) ― -b3- And OariniI AlXRaIoCa Give thou, or hand thou, to me the thing. (M, TA.) ― -b4- OaraI in the sense of OaEolama [as meaning He made such a one to know a thing, or person, to be, as in the saying, Oarayotu zayodFA EamorFAmunoTaliqFA I made Zeyd to know “ Amr to be going away, which may be rendered I showed Zeyd that 'Amr was going away,] requires [as this ex. shows] three objective complements. (M, and Bd in iv. 106. [See I “ AK, p. 117.]) ― -b5- This is not the case in the saying in the Kur [iv. 106], litaHokuma bayona AlnRaAsa bimaA OaraAka QllRehu; (M, Bd;) for here it has but two objective complements, namely, the k in ArAk, and the suppressed pronoun hu in OaraAkahu: it is in this instance from AlrRaOoIu in the sense of AlUiEotiqaAdu: (M:) the meaning is, [That thou mayest judge between men] by means of that which God hath taught thee, syn. EarRafaka, (Ksh, Bd,) or EalRamaka, (Jel,) and revealed to thee. (Ksh, Bd.) ― -b6- See also 1, in the latter half of the paragraph, in two places, in which the pass., OuriIa, is mentioned. ＝ -A2- OaroOaI [as an intrans. v., preserving the original form, inf. n. UiroMCN, as below,] He looked in the mirror; (T, K;) and so fiI AlmiroMpi taraORaI↓ and fiyhaA taraMCaI↓: (T, M, K:) or taraMCaI↓ signifies he (a man) looked at his face in the mirror or in the sword: (S:) and fiI AlmaMCi tamaroOaI↓ he looked at his face in the water; the doing of which is forbidden in a trad; of the measure tamafoEala [from AlmiroMpu]; mentioned by Sb; like tamasokana from Almisokiynu, and tamadoraEa from AlmidoraEapu, and tamanodala from Alminodiylu. (M.) ― -b2- He (a man) had many dreams. (T, K. *) ― -b3- He moved his eyelids, (K,) or made much motion with his eyes, (T,) in looking: (T, K:) you say, huwa yuroYiIbiEayonayohi, (TA,) and yuraOoriYN biEayonayohi. (T, TA. *) ― -b4- He acted (T, K) well, or righteously, (T,) in order to make others see what he did, and hear of it. (T, K.) [See also 3.] ― -b5- He possessed, or became possessed of, intelligence (K, TA) and judgment and forecast: (TA:) inf. n. UiroMCN. (K, TA. [The inf. n. is mentioned with this signification, in the K, app. because it is the first there explained, and therefore as applying to the verb in all its senses.]) ― -b6- And He had the appearance, or evidence, of foolishness, or stupidity, in his face: (T, K, TA: [the words by which Az explains this meaning are tabayRanato MrAWhu fI wajohihi whI AlHmAqpu, accord. to one copy of the T; in another copy of the same, AlrWAh: the TA follows the former reading: but the right reading is AlrRaOowapN; mentioned in the T, thus correctly written, in art. rOrO; in the S, in the present art; and in the M, in art. rOw, which is its proper art., and therefore the proper art. of the verb in the sense thus explained:]) thus it bears two contr. meanings. (K. [But it is added in the TA that this requires consideration.]) ― -b7- Also He had what is termed a raYiIR, of the jinn, or genii; (T, K, TA;) i. e., a follower, of the jinn. (TA.) ― -b8- And He followed the opinion, or belief, of some one, or more, of the lawyers (K, TA) in the science of the law. (TA.) ― -b9- OaroOato said of a she-camel and of a ewe or she-goat, (M,) and of any female in a state of pregnancy, except a solidhoofed animal and a beast of prey, Her udder showed her to be pregnant: (M, K:) and in like manner it is said of a woman: (M:) or, said of a ewe or she-goat, she was, or became, big in her udder: (S:) and accord. to IAar, said of a she-goat, she was, or became, swollen in her vulva, and her being so became apparent, or evident. (M.) And OaroOaI said of a man, His ewe, or she-goat, was, or became, black in her udder. (T.) ＝ -A3- See also 1, in two places, near the end of the paragraph. ＝ -A4- [It is also said in the K and TA that OarOaI, said of a camel, means Ainotakava xaTomuhu EalaI Haloqihi; in the CK Anotakaba; and in the TA this is said to be on the authority of En-Nadr: but in a copy of the T, I find it stated, on the authority of ISh, (i. e. En-Nadr,) that AlArM (i. e. AlUiroMCu) signifies AntkAvu xTm AlbaEyri ElI Haloqih: in another copy of the T, on the authority of En-Nadr, that AlrM (a mistranscription for AlUiroMCu) signifies AntkAv xTm AlbEyr xilqp: and it is added that the epithet applied to a camel is murOI (as in one copy, i. e. muroOaI↓, and thus it is written in the TA, but in the other copy of the T mrAoI, an obvious mistranscription); and to camels, murMAtN (as in one copy, for muroOaAtN, i. e. muroMtN, in the other copy of the T erroneously written muraOAp, and in the TA mrAyAt): therefore the verb is evidently OuroYiIa, in the pass. form, inf. n. UiroMCN; and I think that the correct explanation is Ainotakava xaTomuhu xiloqapF, app. meaning His muzzle was thin, or lean, by nature: see art. nkv: and see also muroOFI below.]

5 trORI fiI AlmiroMpi c
5. trORI fiI AlmiroMpi: see 4, in the former half of the paragraph. ― -b2- trORI liI: see the paragraph here following.

6 taraMCawoA c
6. taraMCawoA They saw one another: (M, K:) dual taraMCayaA. (TA.) And taraMCaI AljamoEaAni, (S, TA,) in the Kur [xxvi. 61], (TA,) The two bodies of people saw each other: (S:) or approached and faced each other so that each was able to see the other. (TA.) And taraMCayonaA We met and saw each other. (A'Obeyd, T.) See also 3, first sentence. It is said in a trad, (T,) laAtaraAMnaArAhumaA, [for tataraAM, as it is written in some copies of the K,] (T, K,) [i. e. (tropical:) Their two fires shall not be within sight of each-other;] meaning that the Muslim may not dwell in the country of the believers in a plurality of gods, and be with them so that each of them shall see the fire of the other: (T, K *) so says A'Obeyd: or, accord. to AHeyth, it means that the Muslim may not mark himself with the mark of the believer in a plurality of gods, nor assimilate himself to him in conduct and guise, nor assume his manners, or dispositions; from the phrase maA naAru baEiyrika, meaning “ What is the brand of thy camel? ” (T:) IAth explains it similarly to A'Obeyd; and says that the verb is thus used tropically. (TA.) ― -b2- trMCI liI He addressed, or presented, himself [to my sight, or] in order that I might see him; as also lI trORI↓. (M, K.) And trMCI lahu XaIoCN mina AljinRi [Somewhat of the jinn, or genii, presented itself to his sight]. (S.) ― -b3- trMCI AlnRaxolu The palm-trees showed the colours of their unripe dates. (AHn, M, K.) ― -b4- taraMCayonaA AlhilaAla We tasked the sight by trying whether or not we could see the new moon: or, as some say, we looked [together, at, or for, the new moon]: (Sh, * T, TA:) or we lowered our eyes towards the new moon in order that we might see it. (Msb.) [See also 6 in art. nqD.] ― -b5- See also 4, in the former half of the paragraph, in two places. ― -b6- taraMCayonaA fiIAlOamori or trMCynA AlOamora: see 8. ― -b7- huwa yataraMCaI biraOoIi fulaAnK He takes to, or holds, the opinion, or persuasion, or belief, of such a one; and inclines to it; and conforms to it. (T, TA.) ― -b8- See also 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.

8 AirotaMhu c
8. AirotaMhu [is syn. with raMhu as signifying He saw him, or it, with the eye; and also, with the mind]: see 1, first sentence: or it is [syn. with raMhu in the latter sense only, being] from AlrRaOoIu and AltRadobiyru: (S, TA:) or AirotaOaI is from raOoIu Alqalobi, (Lth, T,) or from ruWoyapuAlqalobi, or from AlrRaOoIu, and means he thought, reflected, or considered, and acted deliberately, or leisurely. (IAth, TA.) You say, AirotaOayonaA fiI AlOamori, and taraMCayonaA↓ [i. e. trMCynA fiyhi] or taraMCayonaAhu, (accord. to different copies of the K,) meaning naZaronaAhu [or naZaronaAhunaZaronaA fyh, i. e. We looked into, examined, or considered, the affair, or case]. (K.) And AirotaMhu waQEotaqadahu [He saw it with his mind, looked into it, examined it, or considered it, and believed it]. (Mgh.)

10 AstrMhu c
10. AstrMhu He, or it, called for, demanded, or required, the seeing of it; (M, K;) i. e., a thing. (M.) ― -b2- See also 1, first sentence. ― -b3- And see 3, last sentence but one. ― -b4- You say also, yusotaroOaI fulaAnN [Such a one is counted, accounted, or esteemed, hypocritical, or ostentatious], from AlrRiYaMCu [inf. n. of 3]; like as you say, yusotaHomiqu, and yusotaEoqalu. (AA, S.)

Q. Q. 2 tamaroOaI c
Q. Q. 2. tamaroOaI: see 4, in the former half of the paragraph.

raOoIN c
raOoIN is an inf. n. of raOaI [q. v.]: (T, S, K:) [and is also a subst.: used as a subst.,] it means The raOoI of the eye; (Lth, T, Msb;) i. e. the sight thereof; like ruWoyapN, q. v.: (Msb:) and also, of the mind; (Lth, T;) [i. e.,] it signifies also mental perception: (Msb:) [conception: idea: nation:] belief; (M, K;) as a subst., not as inf. n.: (M:)
[or judgment: or persuasion: or opinion; i. e.] a preponderating belief of one of two things that are inconsistent, each with the other: (Er-Rághib, TA:) a thing that a man has seen with his mind, looked into, examined, or considered, (maA QrotaMhu,) and believed: (Mgh:) [a tenet:] also intelligence: and forecast: and skill in affairs: (Msb:) [and hence it often means counsel, or advice:] pl. OaroMCN (T, S, K &c.) and MraMCN, (S, M, K,) the latter formed by transposition, [being for OaOoraMCN,] (S,) and OaroICK [originally OaroWuIN, like as OaZobK is originally OaZobuIN,] (Lh, M, K, TA, in some copies of the K OaroIN) and ruYiIRN and riYiIRN [both originally ruWuwIN], (Lh, M, TA,) in the K ruIRN, with damm, [in the CK raIRN,] and riIRN, with kesr, (TA,) and [quasipl. n.] raYiIRN↓, (S, K,) of the measure faEiylN, like DaYiynN. (S.) One says, maAOaDalRa raOoyahu [How erroneous is his mental perception, &c.!], and maAOaDalRa OaruMhu [How erroneous are his mental perceptions, &c.!]. (Lth, T.) OaSoHaAbu AlrRaOoIi, [often meaning The speculatists, or theorists,] as used by those who treat of the traditions, means the followers of analogy; because they pronounce according to their raOoI [or belief, &c.,] in relation to that concerning which they have not found any [tradition such as is termed] Hadiyv or Oavar, (IAth, K, TA,) or in relation to that which is dubious to them in a tradition. (IAth, TA.) But accord. to the usage of others, one says, fulaAnN mino Oahuli AlrRaOoI meaning Such a one holds the belief, or opinion, &c., of the [heretics, or schismatics, called] xawaArij, and says according to their persuasion. (TA.) [Sometimes, also, this phrase means Such a one is of the people of intelligence; or of counsel, or advice.] See also raYiIRN. And rajulN cuw raOoIK means A man having mental perception, and skill in affairs. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph.

OataAhumo Hiyna janRa ruWoIN c
OataAhumo Hiyna janRa ruWoIN and ruWoyFA and raOoIN↓ and raOoyFA (M, K *) [He came to them] when the darkness had become confused so that they did not see one another. (M, K.)

riYoIN c
riYoIN, (M, TA,) in the K said to be ruYiIRN↓, like SuliIRN, (TA, [but the former is the right, as will be shown by a citation from the Kur in what follows,]) and ruWaMCN↓ and maroMpN↓ Aspect, look, or outward appearance: (M, K:) [and so ruWoyapN↓; used in this sense in the S and K in explanation of TaloEapN:] or the first and second (i. e. riYoIN and ruWaMCN↓, M) signify beauty of aspect or outward appearance; (M, K;) or so does this last; (T, S;) [and so ruwaMCN, with w, mentioned in the S in art. rwI, and there explained as syn. with manoZarN;] and maroMpN↓ signifies aspect, or outward appearance, absolutely, (M, K, *) whether beautiful or ugly: (M:) or this (mrMp) signifies a beautiful aspect or outward appearance: and riYoIN signifies what the eye sees, of goodly condition and clean apparel; as in the phrase in the Kur [xix. 75], humN OaHsanu OavaAvFA wawiYoyFA [they being better in respect of goods, or property, and of appearance of goodly condition and outward apparel], accord. to him who reads it [thus] with C; and read without C it may be from the same, or from rawiyato OalowaAnuhumo wajuluwduhumo meaning “ their colours and skins became full and beautiful ” [or rather “ beautiful and full ”]: (S:) for Náfi' and Ibn-'Ámir read riyRFA, by conversion of the C [into I] and incorporating it [into the radical I], or from AlrRiIRN meaning AlnRaEomapu; and Aboo-Bekr read riYFA, by transposition; and another reading is riyFA, with the C suppressed; and another ziyRFA, from AlzRaIRu. (Bd.) One says AimoraOapN Hasanapu AlmaroMpi↓ and AlmaroOaI↓ [A woman beautiful of aspect]; like as you say Hasanapu AlmanoZarapi and AlmanoZari: (T, S:) and fulaAnN HasanN AlEayoni fiI maroMpi↓ Such a one is beautiful in aspect: and it is said in a prov., tuxobiru Eano majohuwlihi maroMtuhu↓ His outward appearance indicates [what would otherwise be his unknown character, meaning,] his inward state. (S.) [See also tariYyapN]

riYapN c
riYapN (T, S, M, Msb, K,) with C, (T, S, Msb,) and riyapN without C, (T, Msb,) The saHor [or lungs, or lights]; (S;) the place of the breath and wind (M, K) of a man &c., (M,) [i. e.] of an animal: (K:) the p is a substitute for the I (S, Msb,) which is suppressed: (Msb:) pl. riYuwna, (S, M, Msb, K,) agreeably with a general rule relating to words of this class, (M,) and riYaAtN: (M, Msb, K:) dim. ruWayRapN↓ and ruwayRapN (T.) Some say that the suppressed letter [in riyapN] is w; and that it is originally wiroyapN like as EidapN is originally wiEodapN: and warayotuhu signifies “ I hit, or hurt, his riyap ” (Msb.) [hence caAtu AlrRiYapi Inflammation of the lungs.]

raOowapN c
raOowapN An indication of a thing. (M in art. rOw [to which it belongs: but in the S and TA mentioned in the present art.; and in the T, in art. rO: in one copy of the S written raMwapN; and in one place in the TA, written rWAwp, and said to be like vumaAmapN, app. from the author's having found it written ruMwapN for raOowapN].) You say, EalaI fulaAnK raOowapu AlHumoqi [Upon such a one is the indication of foolishness, or stupidity]. (M.) And EalaI wajohihi raOowapu AlHumoqi [Upon his face is the indication of foolishness, or stupidity], when you know foolishness, or stupidity, to be in him before you test him. (Lh, T, S.) And UinRa fiI wajohihi laraOowapF Verily in his face is an ugliness. (T.) [See also an explanation of OaroOaI, above. J seems to have regarded the w as substituted for I.]

raOoyapN c
raOoyapN, originally thus, with C; (T, Msb;) but the Arabs prefer omitting it, [saying raAyapN,] and some of them say that it has not been heard with C; (Msb;) [Az says,] the Arabs did not pronounce it with C: accord. to Lth, its radical letters are rII: (T:) A banner, or standard, (T, Msb,) of an army: (Msb:) pl. raAyaAtN (T, Msb.) [See also art. rI.]

ruWoyapN c
ruWoyapN an inf. n. of raOaI [q. v.]: (T, S, M, Msb, K:) [and also a subst.: used a as subst.,) it means The sight of the eye; as also raOoIN↓: [and accord. to the M and K, it is with the mind also; like raOoIN:] pl. ruwFI. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also riYoIN ― -b3- [Also The phasis of the moon.]

ruWoyaA c
ruWoyaA, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) with C, (T, M,) of the measure fuEolaI, (S, Msb,) without tenween, (S,) [i. e.] imperfectly decl., because the A is that which is the sign of the fem. gender, (Msb,) also pronounced ruwyaA, without C, (Fr, T, M,) and ruyRaA, [which is anomalous, like ruIRN, for riIRN,] mentioned by El-Fárisee on the authority of Abu-l- Hasan, (M,) and riyRaA, (T, M,) heard by Ks from an Arab of the desert, (T,) A dream, or vision in sleep; (T, * S, * M, K;) accord. to most of the lexicologists, syn. with HulomN; or the former is such as is good, and the latter is the contr.: (MF voce HulomN, q. v.:) accord. to Lth, it has no pl.; but accord, to others, (T,) its pl. is ruWFI, (T, S, M, K,) with tenween. (S.) One says, raOayotu Eanoka ruWFI HasanapF I dreamt, of thee, good dreams. (M.)

ruCaMCN c
ruCaMCN: see riYoIN, in two places.

riYaMCN c
riYaMCN an inf. n. of 3 [q. v.]. (M. [Said in the S to be a subst.]) ― -b2- [Hence,] qawomN riYaMCN A party, or company of men, facing one another. (S.) And in like manner, buyuwtuhumo riYaMCN [Their tents, or houses, are facing one another]. (S.) And manaAziluhumo riYaMCN Their places of alighting, or abode, are facing, or opposite, one to another. (T.) ― -b3- And duwru Alqawomi minRaA riYaMWN The houses of the people, or party, are as far as the eye reaches, where we see them, namely, the people. (M.) ― -b4- And humo riYaMCu OalofK They are as many as a thousand in the sight of the eye. (K, * TA.)

raYiIRN c
raYiIRN and riYiIRN↓ (Lth, T, M, K, TA) A jinnee, or genie, that presents himself to a man, and shows him, or teaches him, divination or enchantment or the like: (Lth, T, TA:) or a jinnee whom a man sees: or, accord. to Lh, one whom a person loves, and with whom he becomes familiar: (M:) or a jinnee that is seen and loved: or the latter word means such as is loved: (K:) and the former word, some other than this: (TA:) or the former means a follower, who is of the jinn; of the measure faEiylN or faEuwlN; [if the latter, originally raWuwI;] so called because he presents himself to the sight of him of whom he is the follower; or from the saying, fulaAnN raYiIRu qawomihi, meaning, SaAHibu raOoyihimo↓ [i. e. Such a one is the counsellor, or adviser, of his people, or party]: and sometimes it is pronounced riYiIRN (IAth, TA.) You say, lahu raYiIRN He has a jinnee &c. (Lh, M, TA.) And maEahu riYiIRN With him is a jinnee &c. (Lth, T, TA.) And bihi raYiIRN mina AljinRi, meaning masRN [i. e. In him is a touch, or stroke, from the jinn, or genii]. (S.) ― -b2- Also, both words, A great serpent, (K, TA,) that presents itself to the sight of a man; (TA;) so called as being likened to a jinnee; (K, TA;) or because they assert that the serpent is a transformed jinnee, wherefore they call it
XayoTaAnN and jaAnRN. (IAth, TA.) ― -b3- And A garment, or piece of cloth, that is spread out for sale. (Aboo-'Alee, M, K.) ＝ -A2- For the former word, see also raOoIN [of which it is a quasi-pl. n.].

ruYiIRN c
ruYiIRN: see riYoIN [for which it is app. a mistranscription].

riYiIRN c
riYiIRN: see raYiIRN.

ruWayRapN c
ruWayRapN dim. of riYapN, q. v.; also prounced ruwayRapN. (T.)

raORLCN c
raORLCN, or raORaCN, A man (M) who sees much. (M, K.)

raMCK c
raMCK [act. part. n. of raOaI; Seeing: &c. ＝ -A2- ] Still, or motionless: as also raAhK. (TA.)

OaroOaI c
