OaroOaI More, and most, apt, meet, suited, suitable, fitted, fit, proper, competent, or worthy. (M, K, TA.) You say, OanaA OaroOaI Oano OafoEala celika I am more, or most, apt, &c., to do that. (K, * TA.) And huwa OaroMhumo liOano yafoEala celika He is the most apt, &c., of them to do that. (M.)

taroYiyapN c
taroYiyapN inf. n. of 2. (AZ, T, S.) ― -b2- [Also,] as a subst., not an inf. n., (M,) Beauty, or goodliness; beauty of aspect. (M, K.) [See also riYoIN.] ― -b3- Also, (M, Mgh,) and tariyRapN (S, M, Mgh) and tiriyRapN, the former of these two words extr., (M,) A slight yellowness and dinginess (S, Mgh) which a woman sees after washing herself in consequence of menstruation: what is in the days of menstruation is termed HayoDN [app. for damu HayoDK]; not tryRp: (S:) or a little yellowness or whiteness or blood which a woman sees on the occasion of menstruation: or, as some say, tarayRapN signifies the piece of rag by means of which she knows her state of menstruation from her state of purity: it is from AlrRuWoyapu. (M.) ― -b4- See also what next follows.

tiroYiyapN c
tiroYiyapN A man who practises evasions or elusions, shifts, wiles, or artifices; as also taroYiyapN↓. (Ibn-Buzurj, T.)

maroOFI c
maroOFI: see riYoIN ― -b2- You say also, huwa minRiI maroOFI wamasomaEN, and maroOFI wamasomaEFA, (M, K,) accord. to Sb, as adv. ns. having a special, or particularized, meaning, used as though they had not such a meaning, (M,) and sometimes they said marFI, (TA in art. smE,) He is where I see him and hear him. (M, K.) And fulaAnN minRiI bimaroOFI wamasomaEK Such a one is where I see him and hear what he says. (S.)

muroOFI c
muroOFI, applied to a [camel's] head, Long in the xaTomK [or muzzle], (As, T, M, K,) in which is taSowiyb [i. e. a bending down], (M, K, [in the CK, erroneously, taSowiytN,]) or in which is the like of AltRaSowiyb, like the form of the [vessel called] Uiboriyq: (As, T:) Nuseyr likens ruWuws muroOayaAt to qawaAriyr [i. e. flasks, or bottles]: I know not [says ISd] any verb belonging to this word, [though OuroYiI seems to be its verb,] nor any art. to which it belongs. (M.) See 4, last sentence.

muroICK c
muroICK, applied to a she-camel, and a ewe or she-goat, (M,) and any female in a state of pregnancy, except a solid-hoofed animal and a beast of prey, Whose udder shows her to be pregnant; as also muroYiyapN: (M, K:) and in like manner applied to a woman: (M:) or, applied to a ewe or she-goat, big in her udder. (S.)

maroMpN c
maroMpN: see riYoIN, in five places. ― -b2- You say also, huwa maroMpN bikacaA He is apt, meet, suited, suitable, fitted, fit, proper, or competent, for such a thing; or worthy of such a thing. (K, TA. [In the CK, erroneously, maroAapN.]) And huwa maroMpN Oano yafoEala kacaA He is apt, meet, suited, &c., to do such a thing: and in like manner you say of two, and of a pl. number, and of a female. (Lh, M.)

miroMpN c
miroMpN A mirror: (T, S, M, K:) originally miroOayapN: (Msb:) pl. maraMCK and maraAyaA; (T, S, Msb;) the latter formed by transmutation [of the C into I]. (T. [It is said in the S, that the former pl. is used in speaking of three; and the latter, in speaking of many; but for this distinction I see no reason: and in the Msb it is said that, accord. to Az, the latter pl. is a mistake; but this I do not find in the T.])

muraMCK c
muraMCK [act. part n. of 3, q. v.:] A hypocrite: [&c.:] (T, S: *) pl. muraAWuwna. (S.)

1 rabRahu c
1. rabRahu, (M, K,) aor.
rabuba
, inf. n. rabRN, (M,) [He was, or became, its rabR, or lord, possessor, owner, &c.;] he possessed, or owned, it; had possession of it, and command, or authority, over it; (M, K;) namely, a thing; (K;) syn. malakahu. (M, K.) [And in like manner, He was, or became, his rabR, or lord, &c.] You say, rababotu Alqawoma, [inf. n. as above and marabRapN and ribaAbapN,] I ruled, or governed, the people; syn. susotuhumo; i. e. I was, or became, over them [as their lord, master, or chief]. (S.) And TaAlato marabRatuhumu AlnRaAsa and ribaAbatuhum Their ruling, or governing, the people continued long. (M, K. *) The saying of Safwán, (T, S,) on the day of Honeyn, (T,) laOano yarubRaniI rajulN mino qurayoXK OaHabRu UilaIRa mino Ouno yarubRaniI rajulN mino hawaAzina means [Assuredly that a man of Kureysh] should be over me (T, S) as rabR [or lord, &c.], and as master, or chief, having command, or authority, over me, (T,) [is more pleasing to me than that a man of Hawázin should be lord, &c., over me.] ― -b2- Also, (S, M, Mgh, K,) aor.
rabuba
, (S, M,) inf. n. rabRN, (S, Mgh, M,) He reared, fostered, brought up, fed, or nourished, him; i. q. rabRaAhu; (S, M, Mgh, K;) namely, his child, (S,) or a child, (M, K,) either his own or another's; taking good care of him, and acting as his guardian, (M,) until he attained to puberty, or to the utmost term of youth: (M, K:) and so rbRbhu↓, (Lh, S, M, Mgh, K,) or this has a more emphatic signification, (TA,) inf. n. tarbiybN (Lh, M, Mgh, K) and taribRapN; (Lh, M, K;) and trbRbh↓; (S, M, K;) and ArtbRhu↓: (M, K:) [in like manner, also,] raboraba↓ signifies he reared, fostered, or brought up, an orphan: (AA, T:) and accord. to IDrd, (M,) rabibotuhu is a dial. var. [of rababoLtuhu]: (M, K:) he says also that the verb is used in like manner in relation to the young one of an animal other than man; and he used to cite this ex.:
kaAna lanaA wahowa faluwRN nirobibuho
[He belonged to us when he was a young weaned, or one-year-old, colt, we rearing him]; with the letter characteristic of the aor. meksoor, to show that the second letter of the preterite is meksoor, accord to the opinion of Sb in respect of a case of this kind; and this, he says, is peculiar to the dial. of Hudheyl in this species of verb. (M, TA.) rabRati AlmaroOapu SabiyRahaA, used tropically, means (tropical:) The woman patted her child repeatedly on its side in order that it might sleep. (A, TA.) [See 2 in art. rbt.] [It is said that] the primary signification of AlrRabRu is AltRarobiyapu; i. e. The bringing a thing to a state of completion by degrees. (Bd in i. l.) A poet says, (S,) namely, Hassán Ibn-Thábit, (TA,)
mino durRapK bayoDaMCa SaAfiyapK
HaAYiru AlbaHori mimRaA tarabRaba↓
[Than a white, clear, pearl, of those which the depth of the sea has brought to maturity]; meaning a pearl which the shell has reared, or brought to maturity in the bottom of the water. (S, TA.) And the phrase laka niEomapN tarubRuhaA occurs in a trad., meaning [Thou hast wealth] which thou preservest, and of which thou takest care, and which thou fosterest like as the man fosters his child. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] AlmaTaru yarubRu AlnRabaAta waAlvRaraI The rain causes the plants, or herbage, and the moisture [of the earth] to increase. (M.) And AlsRaHaAbu yarubRu AlmaTara The clouds collect and increase the rain. (M.) And rabRa, (T, S, M, K, TA,) aor.
rabuba
, inf. n. rabRN and ribaAbN and ribaAbapN; (Lh, M, TA;) and rbRb↓; (M, TA;) (tropical:) He increased, (M, K, TA,) or rightly disposed, and completed, (T, S,) a benefit, or benefaction. (T, S, M, TA.) ― -b4- rabRa AlOamora, (M, Msb, K,) aor.
rabuba
, inf. n. rabRN (M, Msb) and ribaAbapN, (M,) (tropical:) He put the affair into a right, or proper, state; adjusted it, arranged it, ordered it, or rightly disposed it; (M, K;) and established it firmly: (M:) or he managed, conducted, or regulated, the affair: (Msb:) [perhaps from rabRa signifying “ he reared, ” &c.; but more probably, I think, from what next follows.] ― -b5- rabRa, (T, S, M, K,) aor.
rabuba
, (T, M,) inf. n. rabRu (T, M, K) and rubRN; (K) and rbRb↓; (M;) He seasoned a skin (T, S, K) for clarified butter (T, S) with rubR [i. e. rob, or inspissated juice], (T, S, K,) of dates, (TA,) which imparts a good odour to it, (S, TA,) and prevents the flavour and odour of the butter from being spoiled: (TA:) or he seasoned a skin with rubR, and a jar with tar or pitch: or, as some say, rababotuhu signifies I smeared it over, and prepared it properly. (M.) rabRa↓ and rbRb↓, (K,) or the latter, but the former also is allowable, (M,) (tropical:) He made oil, or ointment, good, and sweet, or fragrant, or he perfumed it, (M, K, * TA,) accord. to Lh, by infusing in it jasmine or some other sweet-smelling
plant. (M, TA.) See also murabRabN, below. ― -b6- rabRa also signifies He collected, or congregated, (K, TA,) people: (TA:) [and so, probably, rbRb↓: see rababN.] You say, fulaAnN yarubRu AlnRaAsa Such a one collects, or congregates, to him the people. (T, S, M.) ＝ -A2- rabRa, aor.
rabiba
: see 4 ＝ -A3- rabRato, (Lh, M, K,) aor.
rabuba
, (so in the M,) or
rabiba
, (MF, TA,) inf. n. rabRN, (M, TA,) or ribaAbN, (S, K, [in each of which this is mentioned as the inf. n. whence the epithet rubRaI,]) said of a ewe or she-goat, She brought forth: (Lh, M, K:) or, as some say, she conceived: or, accord. to some, there is no verb to the epithet rubRaI: (M:) AZ says that it has no verb: (Msb:) [but] ribaAbN↓ is an inf. n. used in relation to a ewe or she-goat as meaning her being in the state of such as is termed rubRaI [q. v.]: (S, M, * Msb, * K: *) and in relation to a she-camel, as in the ex. cited by Munteji' Ibn-Nebhán to As,
Haniyna OumRi AlbawRifiI ribaAbihaA
[The yearning cry of the mother of the young camel in the time of her having recently brought forth]: (S:) and used also in relation to a woman as meaning her having recently brought forth: or her state within two months after having brought forth: or within twenty days: whence the phrase, in a trad., HamoluhaA ribaAbN, meaning She becomes pregnant soon after having brought forth. (TA.)

2 rbRb c
2. rbRb: see 1, in five places. ― -b2- [Also He preserved with rubR, i. e., rob, or inspissated juice: see murabRabN.]

4 ArbR biAlmakaAni c
4. ArbR biAlmakaAni, (T, M, A, K, *) inf. n. UirobaAbN; (T;) and rabRa↓, (M, K,) aor.
rabiba
; (MF, TA;) He remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in the place, (T, M, A, K, *) not quitting it; (T;) like OalabRa: (T, A:) and the former, [or each,] he kept, or clave, to the place. (M.) And ArbRti AlUibilu biAlmawoDiEi (T,) or bimakaAni kacaA, (S,) The camels kept, or clave, (T, S,) to the place, (T,) or to such a place, and remained in it. (S.) And ArbRt AlnRaAqapu, (S,) or ArbRt AlnaAqp biAlfaHoli, and biwaladihaA, (M,) The she-camel kept to the stallion, (S, M,) and to her young one, (M,) and affected it. (TA.) And ArbRt AlsRaHaAbapu (S, M, A) biOaroDihimo (A) (tropical:) The cloud continued raining [in their land]. (S, * M.) And ArbRt Aljanuwbu (assumed tropical:) The south, or southerly, wind continued. (T, S.) ― -b2- AlUirobaAbu also signifies The drawing near, or approaching, (S, M, K,) a thing, (S, M,) of any kind. (M.)

5 trbRb AlOaroDa c
5. trbRb AlOaroDa, (M, A, K,) and AlrRajula, (M, K,) He asserted himself to be the rbR [or lord, &c.,] of the land, (M, A, K,) and of the man. (M, K.) ― -b2- See also 1, in two places, in the former half of the paragraph. ＝ -A2- trbRbwA They collected themselves together, or congregated; or they became collected or congregated. (S.)

6 trAbRwA c
6. trAbRwA They united in a confederacy, league, or covenant. (M, TA.) [App. from the fact of some confederates dipping their hands into rubR: see ribaAbN.]

8 ArtbRhu c
8. ArtbRhu: see 1. ― -b2- tarotabRu AlXRaEara [She adjusts, or arranges, and composes, or collects together, the hair], said of a woman, is from [AlrRabRu signifying] AlUiSolaAHu and AljamoEu. (M.) ― -b3- AurotubRa AlEinabu The grapes were cooked so as to become rubR [or rob], used to give a relish to bread. (AHn, M.)

R. Q. 1 raboraba c
R. Q. 1. raboraba: see 1.

rabo c
rabo: see raOaba, of which it is an imperative.

ruba c
ruba and raba and rubu and rubo and rabo; and rubamaA and rabamaA &c.: see rubRa.

rabN c
rabN: see the next paragraph, last sentence but one.

rabRN c
rabRN A lord, a possessor, an owner, or a proprietor, syn. maAlikN, (T, IAmb, S, M, A, Msb, K,) of a thing, (T,) of anything, (S, M, A, K,) or of an irrational thing; (Msb;) a person who has a right, or just title or claim, to the possession of anything; or its SaAHib [which is syn. with maAlik]; (M, A, K;) rabRN and maAlikN and SaAHibN all signifying in Pers. xudaAwanod: (KL:) and a lord, master, or chief; (Msb, TA;) or a lord, master, or chief, to whom obedience is paid: (IAmb, TA:) and a lord, ruler, governor, regulator, or disposer; (TA;) an orderer, a rectifier, or a reformer: (IAmb, TA:) a rearer, fosterer, bringer-up, feeder, or nourisher: and a completer, or an accomplisher: (TA:) it is an epithet, like namRN from namRa: or an inf. n. used as an intensive epithet; like EadolN; (Ksh and Bd * in i. l;) originally signifying the “ bringing (a thing) to a state of completion by degrees;” (Bd, ibid.;) then used in the sense of maAlikN: (Ksh and Bd ibid.:) the pl. [of pauc.] is OarobaAbN and [of mult.] rubuwbN, (M, K,) and accord. to Sh, ribaAbN also, (TA,) signifying OaSoHaAbN, (K,) and rabuwbN↓ is app. a quasi-pl. n.: (M:) the fem. is rabRapN↓; of which the pl. is rabRaAtN. (T.) Whoever possesses a thing is its rabR: you say, huwa rabRu AldRaAbRapi [He is the possessor, or owner, or master, of the beast], and AldRaAri [of the house], (T,) and AlmaAli [of the property, or cattle]; (Msb;) and Albayoti hiIa rabRapu↓ [She is the owner, or mistress, of the house or tent]. (T.) With the article Al, it is [properly] applied only to God: (T, S, M, A, Msb, K:) He is rabRu AlOarobaAbi [The Lord of lords]. (T. [Thus the pl. with the article Al is applied to created beings.]) To any other being it is not [properly] applied but as a prefixed noun governing another noun as its complement in the gen. case [or in a similar manner]. (S.) The pagan Arabs, however, sometimes applied it to A king, (S,) or to a lord as meaning a master or chief: (Msb:) El- Hárith says, (S, Msb,) i. e. Ibn-Hillizeh, (S,)
wahuwa AlrRabRu waAlXRahiydu EalaI yuwo
mi AlHiyaArayoni waAlbalaMCu balaMCu
(S, Msb,) i. e. And he (meaning El-Mundhir Ibn-Má-es-Semà, or, as some say, 'Amr Ibn-Hind,) was the king [or lord] and witness of our fighting on the day of El-Hiyárán (the name of a place), and the trial was a hard trial. (EM, p. 285: [in which AlHayaArayoni is erroneously put for AlHiyaArayoni.]) Some forbid that a man should be called the rabR of his slave: (Msb:) it is said in a trad. that the slave shall not say to his master, rabRI, because it is like attributing a partner to God: (TA:) but rabR is sometimes used in the sense of lord as meaning master or chief prefixed to a noun signifying a rational being governed by it in the gen. case: thus in the saying of the Prophet, HatRaI talida AlOamapu rabRahaA [So that the female slave shall bring forth him who will become her master], or rabRatahaA↓ [her mistress], accord. to different transmitters; (Msb;) relating to the signs of the hour of resurrection: i. e., the female slave shall bring forth to her master a child that shall be as a master [or mistress] to her because like his [or her] father in rank: meaning that captives and concubines shall be numerous. (TA.) As to the phrase in the Kur [xii. 42], AucokuroniI Einoda rabRika [Mention thou me in the presence of thy lord], Joseph thus addressed his fellow-prisoner agreeably with the acceptation in which he [the latter] understood the words. (TA.) A similar instance also occurs in the same chapter, in the verse immediately preceding. (Msb.) In another verse, [23 of the same ch.,] UinRahu rabRiI [Verily he is my lord] may refer to Joseph's master or to God. (M, TA.) The words of the Kur [lxxxix. 28 and 29], AirojiEiI UilaI rabRiki raADiyapF maroDiyRapF faQdoxuliI fiI EabodIi, as some read, [instead of EibaAdiI,] may mean Return to thine owner, [approving, approved,] and enter into my servant. (M, TA.) ― -b2- Without the article Al, as some say, (L, TA,) it is sometimes written and pronounced rabN↓, without teshdeed; (L, K;) as in the following verse, cited by El-Mufaddal,
waqado Ealima AlOaqowaAmu Oano layosa fawoqahu
rabN gayoru mano yaEoTiI AlHuZuwZa wayarozuqu
[And the peoples have known that there is not above him a lord beside Him who gives the portions of mankind and of others and grants the means of subsistence]. (L.) And Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà [i. e. Th] mentions the phrase laA warabiyka laA OafoEalu, for laA warabRika [i. e. No, by thy Lord, I will not do such a thing]; the [latter] b being changed into I because of the reduplication. (M, K: * in the CK raboyika.)

rubRa c
rubRa is a word of which there are seventy dial. vars., all mentioned by Zekereeyà El-Ansáree in his great Expos. of the “ Munferijeh, ” but only eighteen of which are mentioned in the K, including some that are formed with the affix t, some with the affix maA, and some with both these affixes together; as follows: (TA:) rubRa (T, S, M, Msb, Mughnee, K, &c.) and rabRa (T, M, Mughnee, K) and rubRu, (Mughnee,) and ruba↓ (T, S, M, Mughnee, K) and raba (T, M, Mughnee, K) and rubu and rubo (Mughnee, K) and rabo; (Mughnee;) and rubRata↓ (T, S, M, Msb, Mughnee, K) and rabRata (M, Mughnee, K) and rubRuta and rubRatu and rabRatu and rubRutu and rubRati and rabRati and rubRuti and rabRut (TA)
and rubRato and rabRato (Mughnee) and rubRuto, (TA,) and rubata↓ (T, Mughnee, K) and rabata (Mughnee, K) and rubuta and rubota and rabota and rubatu and rabatu and rubutu and rubotu and rabotu and rubati and rabati and rubuti and rabuti and ruboti and raboti (TA) and rubato and rabato (Mughnee) and rubuto; (TA;) and rubRamaA (T, S, M, K) and rabRamaA (M, K) and rubRumaA, (TA,) and rubamaA↓ (T, K) and rabamaA (K) and rubumaA and rubomaA and rabomaA; (TA;) and rubRatamaA↓ (T, S, M, K) and rabRatamaA (M, K) and rubRutamaA and rubRatumaA and rabRatumaA and rubRutumaA and rubRatomaA and rabRatomaA and rubRutomaA, (TA,) and rubatamaA↓ and rabatamaA (M, K) and rubutamaA and rubotamaA and rabotamaA and rubatumaA and rabatumaA and rubutumaA and rubotumaA and rabotumaA and rubatomaA and rabatomaA and rubutomaA: (TA:) [of all these, the most common are rubRa and rubRamaA: and] rubRata↓ is the most common of the forms that have the affix t: (Mughnee and K on the letter t:) and the forms with teshdeed are more common than the [corresponding] forms without teshdeed. (M.) It is a word, (M,) or particle, (T, S, Mughnee, K,) governing the gen. case: (S, M, Mughnee, K:) or a noun, (K, TA,) [i. e. an indecl. noun,] in the opinion of the Koofees and some others; but this opinion is rejected by Ibn-Málik in the Tesheel and its Expos., and by AHei, and by IHsh in the Mughnee. (TA.) Accord. to some, (K, TA,) it is used to denote a small number, (T, M, Msb, K, TA,) always, (TA,) or mostly: (Msb, TA:) [thus it may be rendered Few if we render the noun following it as a pl.; and scarce any if we render the noun following as a sing. or a pl.:] it is the contr. of kamo when this latter is not used interrogatively: (T:) [and with maA affixed, restricting it from government, it may be rendered Few times, or seldom:] or it is used to denote a large number; (K, TA;) i. e. always: so says IDrst: (TA:) [thus used, but such is not always the case, it may be rendered Many, whether we render the noun following it as a sing. or as a pl.: and with maA affixed, Many times, many a time, oftentimes, ofttimes, often, or frequently:] or it is used to denote a small and a large number; (Mughnee, K;) often the latter, and seldom the former: (Mughnee:) or it is used in a case of boasting, or glorying, (K, TA,) exclusively of other cases, (TA,) to denote a large number: (K, TA:) or it does not denote by itself either a small number or a large number; but one or the other of these meanings is inferred from the context: (K:) [but sometimes neither of these meanings can be clearly inferred from the context: in these cases, it may be rendered Some: and with maA affixed, Sometimes:] accord. to Er-Radee, its primary meaning is to denote a small number, but it has been so much used to denote a large number as to be in this latter sense as though it were proper, and in the former sense as though it were tropical, requiring context [to explain it]. (Marginal note in my copy of the Mughnee.) [Without the affix mA,] it governs an indeterminate noun (T, * S, Msb, Mughnee, K) only, (T, S, K,) and a pronoun. (S, M, Mughnee.) You say, rubRa yawomK bakRarotu fiyhi [Few, or many, days have I gone forth early therein]: (T:) and rubRa rajulK qaAYimN [Few, or many, men are standing]: (M:) and rubRa rajulK qaAma [Few, or many, men stood]: (Msb:) and in like manner, rajulK rubRata↓; (Msb;) for the t in this case is not a denotative of the fem. gender. (Msb.) The pronoun affixed to it is of the third pers., (S, M,) and is [generally] sing. and masc., (S, Mughnee,) though it may be followed by a fem. and by a dual and by a pl.: (S:) notwithstanding its being determinate in the utmost degree, its use in this manner is allowable because it resembles an indeterminate noun in its being used without the previous mention of the noun to which it relates; and hence it requires a noun to explain it: (IJ, M:) it annuls the government of rubRa; (TA;) and the indeterminate noun that follows it is put in the accus. case as a specificative: (S, Mughnee:) thus you say, rubRahu rajulFA qado Darabotu [Few, or many, men I have beaten]: (S, M: *) but accord. to the Koofees, you say rubRahu rajulFA, (S,) and rubRahaA QmoraOapF, (M,) and rubRahumaA rajulayonX, and rubRahumo rijaAlFA, and rubRahunRa nisaMCF: he who puts the pronoun in the sing. [in all cases] holds it to be allusive to something unknown; and he who does not put it in the sing. [when it is not followed by a sing. noun] holds it to be used in reply to a question, as though it were said to a man, “ Hast thou not any young women? ” and he answered, rubRahunRa jawaArK qado malakotu [Few, or many, young women have I possessed]: Ibn-Es-Sarráj says that the grammarians are as though they were of one consent in holding rubRa to be a replicative [app. meaning in a case of this kind, with an affixed pronoun]: (S:) [but it is not always a replicative in a case of this kind; though perhaps it was originally:] AHeyth cites as an ex.
warubRahu EaTibFA Oanoqacotu mi AlEaTabi
[And many a perishing man have I saved from perdition]. (TA. [But the reading commonly found in grammars is mino EaTabiho from his state of perdition.]) The following is an ex. of the use of rubRa to denote a small number, [or rather to denote singleness,]
OalaA rubRa mawoluwdK walayosa lahu OabN
waciI waladK lamo yalodihi OabawaAni
[Now surely scarce an instance is there of anyone born not having a father, and of anyone having offspring whom two parents have not procreated]; meaning [our Lord] Jesus and Adam: (Mughnee: [but I have substituted yalodihi for yalodahu, the reading in my copy of that work: lamo yalodihi is for lamo yalidohu, for the sake of the metre; like as limo Oajodi is for lamo Oajido:]) and among the many exs. of its use to denote a large number, is the saying, in a trad., yaA rubRa kAasiyapK fiI AldRunoyaA EaAriyapN yawoma Alqiyemapi [O, many a female having clothing in the present state of existence will be naked on the day of resurrection!]; and the saying of an Arab of the desert, after the ending of Ramadán, yaA rubRa SaAYimihi lano yaESuwmahu wayaA rubRa qaAYimihi lano yaquwmahu [O, many a keeper of its fast shall not keep its fast again! and O, many a passer of its nights in prayer, or per- former of its taraAwiyH, shall not pass its nights in prayer, or perform its trAwyH, again!]. (Mughnee.) [But in this last ex., and in others, it relates to few in comparison with others, though many abstractedly.] ― -b2- maA is affixed to rubRa &c. in order that a verb may follow it; (S, Mughnee;) and the verb that follows it is generally a preterite, (T, Mughnee,) as to the letter and the meaning: (Mughnee:) you say, rubRamaA jaMCaniI fulaAnN [Seldom, or often, such a one came to me, or has come to me]: (T:) sometimes the verb is a future; (T, Mughnee;) but only when it expresses an event of which one is certain: (T:) so in the saying in the Kur [xv. 2], rubRamaA yawadRu QlRacyna kafaruwA lawo kaAnuwA musolimiyna, (T, S, M, Mughnee), meaning Often [will those who have disbelieved wish that they had been Muslims]; (Mughnee, Jel;) or seldom, (Zj, T, M, Jel,) because terrors will bereave them of their reason so that they will but seldom recover reason to wish this; (Jel;) for God's threat is true, as though it had come to pass, and therefore the verb here is equivalent to a preterite [which is often used in the Kur and elsewhere in this manner]. (T.) maA is also sometimes affixed when a noun follows, (T, Mughnee,) or a nominal proposition, and generally restricts rubRa &c. from governing: thus, Aboo-Duwád says,
rubRamaA AljaAmilu AlmuWabRalu fiyhimo
waEanaA jiyju bayonahunRa AlmihaAru
[Sometimes, or often, the numerous herd of camels is among them, and there are swift horses, among which are the colts]: another says, making rubRa, with maA affixed, to govern,
rubRamaA DarobapK bisayofK SaqiylK
qayoni buSoraI waTaEonapK najolaMCa
[Many a stroke with a polished sword of the forging of Busrà, (the Bozrah of the Bible, a city famous for its sword-blades,) and many a wide spear-wound; or, perhaps, few strokes &c.]: (Mughnee: [but I have substituted qayoni for bayona, which is the reading in my copy of the Mughnee, an evident mistranscription:]) and another, cited by IAar, says,
gaArapK maAwiIRa yaA rubRatamaA↓
XaEowaMCa kaQllRacoEapi biQlomiysami
[Máweeyeh, (maAwiIRa being an apocopated proper name of a woman, originally maAwiyRapu,) O, many a raid spreading widely and dispersedly, like the burn with the branding-iron]. (T. [In the TT, as from the T, I find, here, balo in the place of yA, which I find in a copy of the T, and which is the reading commonly known.])

rubRN c
rubRN Rob, or inspissated juice, (dibos,) of any fruit; i. e., (M, TA,) the first, or clear, juice of the thick residuum of any fruit after it has been pressed (M, K, TA) and cooked: (M, TA:) thick TilaMC [or expressed juice; such as the inspissated juice of dates, with which a skin for clarified butter is seasoned; see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph]: (S:) or what flows from fresh ripe
dates, like honey, when it has been cooked [and so rendered thick]; before which it is called SaqorN: (Msb in the present art. and in art. Sqr:) what is prepared by coction from, or of, dates: (TA:) expressed juice of grapes, and of apples, &c., cooked and [so] thickened: (KL:) and dregs, (K,) or black dregs, (IDrd, M,) of clarified butter, (IDrd, M, K,) and of olive-oil: (IDrd, M:) pl. rubuwbN and ribaAbN (S) [and pl. pl. (i. e. pl. of rubuwbN) rubuwbaAtN, which means sorts, or species, of rubR] ＝ -A2- See also rubRaI.

rabRapN c
rabRapN: see rabRN, in three places. ― -b2- AlrRabRapu was also the name of A Kaabeh [or square temple], (M, K,) in Nejrán, (M,) belonging to [the tribe of] Medh-hij (M, K) and Benu-l-Hárith-Ibn-Kaab, who held it in honour. (M.) In a trad. of 'Orweh (K, TA) Ibn-Mes'ood Eth-Thakafee, (TA,) it is applied to El-Lát (AllRaAtu), (K, TA,) the rock which [the tribe of] Thakeef worshipped, at Et-Táïf. (TA.) And in another trad., it is said to be the name of A temple of [the tribe of] Thakeef, which, when they became Muslims, was demolished by El-Mugheereh. (TA.) ― -b3- And rabRapN, (K,) or daArN rabRapN, (M,) signifies A large house or mansion. (M, K.) ＝ -A2- See also rubRaI.

rubRapN c
rubRapN A party, division, sect, or distinct body or class, of men: (M:) or a large assembly or company: (K:) or a myriad; i. e. ten thousand: (M, K:) or thereabout: (M:) and ribRpN↓ signifies the same: (M, K:) or this signifies a company [of men]: (T:) the pl. of the former is ribaAbN: (S, M:) and that of the latter is OaribRapN: (T, K:) by Th [and in the K], the former pl. is said to be a pl. of ribRapN; but this is a mistake. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence, the pl.] ribaAbN signifies Companions. (K.) ― -b3- And hence [also], i. e., as pl. of AlrRubapu, (S, M,) AlrRibaAbu is an appellation of The [confederate] tribes of Dabbeh; (M, K, TA;) or Teym and 'Adee and 'Okl; (T, TA;) or Teym and 'Adee and 'Owf and Thowr and Ashyab; (TA; [but for the orthography of the last of these names I have found no authority; it is written in the TA AXyb, without any syll. signs;]) and Dabbeh was their paternal uncle; (TA;) or five tribes which united in a confederacy, consisting of Dabbeh and Thowr and 'Okl and Teym and 'Adee: (S:) they were thus called because of their division into distinct bodies; (M;) or because they collected themselves (As, Th, S, TA) in distinct bodies: (Th, M, TA:) or because they united in a confederacy against Temeem Ibn-Murr: (AO, M, TA:) or because they dipped their hands in some rubR, and formed a confederacy over it: (As, T, M, K:) or, as some say, because they congregated, and became like the ribaAb [or bundle] of arrows [used in the game called Almayosir]: (TA:) the rel. n. is rubRiIRN↓, formed from the sing., (Sb, S, M,) accord. to a rule generally observed except when a [single] man has a pl. word for his name, as kilaAbN &c. (S, TA.) ― -b4- The sing. (rubRapN) also signifies Plenty, or abundance, of the means of subsistence: (K:) and constant, or inseparable, prosperity. (Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also rubRaI.

ribRapN c
ribRapN: see the next preceding paragraph, first sentence. ― -b2- [Hence its pl.] OaribRapN signifies Confederates; (S, IB, K;) [or] it is for cawuw OaribRapK having covenants; OaribRapN being said by AAF to be pl. of ribaAbN in the sense of EahodN. (IB, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A species of plant, (S, M, Msb, K,) of the [season called] Sayof, (M,) remaining in the end of the Sayof: (Msb:) or the name of a number of plants which do not dry up in the Sayof, remaining green in the winter and the Syf [or summer]; among which are the HulRab and the ruxaAmaI and the makor and the EaloqaI or EaloqFI: [see rabolN:] or a certain soft, or tender, herb, or leguminous plant: (TA:) or any plant that is green in the hot season: or certain species of trees, or of plants, undefined: (M:) pl. ribabN. (S, Msb.) [In the dial. of Egypt, Alexandrian trefoil (birosiym, q. v.,) of the second and third crops.] ― -b2- Also A certain tree: as some say, the tree of the xarRuwb [an appellation generally applied to the carob, or locust-tree]. (M, K.)

rababN c
rababN, (S, M, K,) or maMCN rababN, (S, TA,) Much water, (S, M, K,) collected together: (M:) or sweet-water: (S, K:) accord. to Th, it means maA rabRabahu AlTiynu [app. such (water) as the clay has collected; for tarabRaba signifying tajamRaEa is probably quasi-pass. of rabRaba, so that this last seems to signify jamRaEa]. (M.)

rubata c
rubata and rabata &c.; and rubatamaA and rabatamaA &c.: see rubRa.

rabaAbN c
rabaAbN Clouds: (M:) or white clouds: (S, K:) or clouds that one sees beneath other clouds, (S,) or clouds suspended beneath other clouds, (M,) sometimes white and sometimes black: (S, M:) this latter is said by IB to be the signification commonly known: (TA:) or clouds consisting of an accumulation of parts: (A 'Obeyd, T:) n. un. with p. (A 'Obeyd, S, K.) Hence AlrRabaAbu as a proper name of a woman. (A 'Obeyd, T, S.) ＝ -A2- Also A certain instrument of diversion, [meaning, of music,] (K,) having strings, (TA,) with which one plays [lit. beats]. (K.) [The rbAb in common use among the Arabs in the present day is a kind of viol. A specimen of it is figured and described in my work on the Modern Egyptians. Being an instrument of remarkable simplicity, it is probably similar to the ancient rbAb.] Memdood Ibn-'Abd-Allah El-Wásitee Er-Rabábee became proverbial for his musical skill with the rbAb. (K.) ＝ -A3- See also rubRaAnN.

rubaAbN c
rubaAbN: see rubRaI, of which it is an anomalous pl.: ＝ -A2- and see also rubRaAnN.

ribaAbN c
ribaAbN: see ribaAbapN, in two places. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) Tithes, or tenths; syn. EuXuwrN: (S, M, K:) from the same word signifying “ a covenant. ” (S.) ― -b3- In the phrase yuEoTiyhaA AlOamaAna ribaAbuhaA, ending a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb, describing some asses, ribaAb is said to signify An oath, or a promise, which the owner of the asses takes of a people to permit those asses to water: or the poet means that the person giving those asses permission to water gives to their owner an arrow, of those used in the game called Almayosir, [as a token,] to show that they have received permission to water, and that no one may offer them any opposition: (TA:) some say that ribaAbuhaA here means their owners: (M:) [holding this last opinion,] Sh says that ribaAb in this verse is a pl. of rabRN. (TA.) ＝ -A2- It is also a pl. of rubRapN; (S, M;) not of ribRapN, as it is said to be by Th [and in the K]. (M.) ＝ -A3- See also 1, last sentence. ＝ -A4- And see rubRaAnN.

rabuwbN c
rabuwbN: see rabiybN. ＝ -A2- See also rabRN, of which it is said in the M to be app. a quasi-pl. n.

rabiybN c
rabiybN Reared, fostered, brought up, fed, or nourished; [and taken good care of, until the age of puberty; (see 1;)] as also marobuwbN↓; (S, M, K;) both applied to a boy: (S, M:) and in like manner applied to a horse: (M:) or the latter epithet, applied to a horse, (tropical:) tended well, or taken good care of: (A:) the former is also applied to a gazelle; (IAar, K in art. dxl;) [as meaning (assumed tropical:) brought up in, or near, the house or tent, and there fed;] like OaholiIRN: (TA in that art.:) and [its fem.] rabiybapN is applied to a ewe or she-goat, (XaApN, K,) meaning (assumed tropical:) brought up in the tent, or house, for the sake of her milk; (S, K; [see also rubRaI;]) pl. rabaAYibu; (S;) this last being applied to sheep or goats that are tied near to the tents, or houses, and there fed, and that do not go forth to pasture; (M, TA;) of which it is said that none are to be taken for the poor-rate. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, A step-son,] a man's wife's son (T, S, M, A, Msb, K) by another husband; (T, S, M, A, K;) as also rabuwbN↓: (T, K:) pl. OaribRaMCu. (Msb.) And rabiybapN [A step-daughter;] a woman's husband's daughter by another wife: (S:) or a man's wife's daughter (T, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K) by another husband; (T, M, A;) because he rears her: (Mgh:) pl. rabaAYibu (A, Mgh, Msb) and sometimes rabiybaAtN. (Msb.) ― -b3- Also, and raAbRN↓, (T, M, K,) both syn., like XahiydN and XaAhidN, and xabiyrN and xaAbirN, (TA,) or the latter, (T, S,) mentioned by IAar, is the correct term, (T,) [A step-father;] the husband of a mother (T, S, M, K) who has a child by another husband. (T.) And rabiybapN and raAbRapN↓, (T,) or the latter [only], (S, K,) [A stepmother;] the wife of a father (T, S, K) who has a child by another wife. (T.) rabiybapN also signifies [A foster-mother;] a woman who has the charge of a child, who carries him, and takes care of him, and rears, or fosters, him; (Th, S, M, Msb, K;) like raAbRapN↓; the former being of the measure faEilaypN in the sense of faAEilapN. (Msb.) OarbRaMCu AlnRabiIR [meaning The foster-fathers of the Prophet] is an appellation given to the people [of the tribe of Saad] among whom Mohammad was suckled; as though ArbRMC were pl. of rabiybN [as it is said to be in one of the senses mentioned above]. (TA.) ― -b4- And rabiybN signifies also A confederate; a person with whom one unites in a confederacy, league, or covenant. (M, K.) ― -b5- And A king. (M, K.)

ribaAbapN c
ribaAbapN: see rubuwbiyRapN. ＝ -A2- Also A covenant, compact, confederacy, or league; (S, M, K;) as also ribaAbN↓, (M, K,) of which latter, in this sense, the pl. is OaribRapN. (AAF, IB, TA.) [See ribRapN, second sentence.]) ＝ -A3- And A thing [or case] resembling a quiver (kinaAnap), in which the arrows of the game called Almayosir are enclosed together: (S:) or a piece of skin, (T,) or a piece of thin skin, (Lh, M, TA,) in which the arrows are enclosed, (Lh, T, M, TA,) resembling a quiver (knAnp): (TA:) or a piece of rag, (M, K, TA,) or of skin, (TA,) in which the arrows are enclosed (M, K, TA) or bound: (TA:) or a piece of thin skin which is bound upon the hand of the man who takes forth the arrows (K, TA) of that game, (TA,) lest he should know the feel of an arrow for the owner of which he has an affection: (K, TA:) or a small cord with which the arrows are bound [together]: or the arrows [themselves] collectively: (M, K:) sometimes it is used in this last sense: (S:) and ribaAbN↓ also seems to be used in like manner; as meaning the ribaAbap of the arrows of the game of Almysr. (TA.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce OafaADa in art. fyD.]

rubuwbapN c
rubuwbapN: see rubuwbiyRapN.

rabaAbIRN c
rabaAbIRN A player on the rabaAb [q. v.]. (MA, K.)

rabuwbiIRN c
rabuwbiIRN, (M, K,) with fet-h [to the r], (K,) a rel. n. from AlrRabRu, deviating from rule: so in the phrase EilomN rabuwbiIRN [Knowledge, science, or doctrine, relating to the Lord, i. e., to God]. (M, K.)

rubuwbiyRapN c
rubuwbiyRapN [Lordship; or the state, or quality, of such as is termed rabRN i. e. a lord, a possessor, an owner, or a proprietor; &c.: and, with the article Al particularly godship, godhead, or deity:] a subst. from AlrRabRu; (T, * S, * M, K;) as also ribaAbapN↓ [which seems to be properly an inf. n. of 1 in the sense first explained]. (M, K.) ＝ -A2- Also, (M, K,) or rubuwbapN↓, (so in a copy of the K,) The state, or condition, of a mamoluwk [or slave]. (M, K.)

rubRata c
rubRata and rabRata &c.; and rubRatamaA and rabRatamaA &c.: see rubRa, in five places.

rubRaI c
rubRaI, applied to a ewe or she-goat (XaApN), (S, M, &c.,) That has brought forth: (M, Msb, K:) and so if her young one has died: (M, K:) or that has recently brought forth: (Lh, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K:) or that has brought forth twenty days before: (M:) or that has brought forth two months before: (El-Umawee, S, M:) or that is followed, (M,) or accompanied, (As, Mgh,) by her young one: (As, M, Mgh:) or that is confined in the tent, or house, for the sake of her milk: (Msb: [see also rabiybapN, voce rabiybN:]) accord. to AZ, (S, Msb,) it is applied to a she-goat, (S, M, Msb,) and raguwvN is applied to a ewe: (M:) accord. to others, the former is applied to a she-goat and a ewe, and sometimes to a she-camel: (S, Msb:) the pl. is rubaAbN↓, (As, T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) which is extr. [in form]: (M, K:) Lh mentions the phrase ganamN rubaAbN, or ribaAbN, which, he says, is rare. (M.) ― -b2- See also rubRaAnN, in two places. ＝ -A2- A benefit, favour, boon, or good. (AA, T, K.) [See an ex. in the first paragraph of art. jXO.] ― -b2- A want; (AA, T, K;) as in the saying, liI Einoda fulaAnK rubRaI [I have a want for such a one to supply, or accomplish]. (AA, T.) ＝ -A3- A child's nurse; syn. daAyapN. (AA, T. In one copy of the T bAbh; and in the TA rAyp. [Perhaps the right reading is raAbRapN, meaning a foster-mother.]) ＝ -A4- A firm knot: (AA, T, K:) [and so, app., rubRaAnN↓, if correctly written thus, in the instance here following.] You say, Uino kunota Uizorika biI taXhdRu Zahoraka faOaroxi birubRaAni↓, (TA,) or birubRaA Uizorika (so in the TT, as from the M, [as though for birubRaI,]) and minE rubRaI Uizorika, (T, TA,) a prov., meaning (assumed tropical:) If thou place thy reliance upon me, then let me weary myself, and enjoy thou relaxation and rest: (T, TA:) here rubRaI [properly] signifies a firm knot. (T.) [See also a similar prov. in Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 24.]) ＝ -A5- Also a name of Jumádà-l-Oolà [the fifth month of the Arabian calendar]; and so rubRN↓: (M, K:) and likewise, (K,) or accord. to Kr, (M,) a name of Jumádà-l-Ákhireh [the sixth month]; and so rubRapu↓: (M, K:) and this last likewise, (K, there expressly said to be with damm,) or rabRapu↓, (so accord. to the M as transcribed in the TT,) a name of Dhu-l-Kaadeh [the eleventh month]: (M, K:) thus these months were called in the Time of Ignorance. (M. [See also XahorN: and see runRaI or AlrRunRaI, in art. rn.])

rabRiIRN c
rabRiIRN: see rabRaAniIRN. ― -b2- And for its pl., rabRiyRuwna, see ribRiIRN, in two places.

rubRiIRN c
rubRiIRN rel. n. of rubRapN, q. v. (Sb, S, M.) ― -b2- See also its pl., rubRiyRuwna, in the next paragraph, in two places.

ribRiIRN c
ribRiIRN sing. of ribRiyRuwna (T, S, K,) which signifies Thousands (Fr, Th, T, S, K) of men: (S, K:) accord. to Akh, it is from AlrRabRu; and if so, it is rabRiyRuwna↓, with fet-h to the r: but accord. to Fr, it is from ribRapN, meaning “ a company: ” (Th, T:) Zj says that it is ribRiyRuwna and rubRiyRuwna↓, with kesr to the r and also with damm to the r, and signifies a numerous company: he adds that ribRapN is said by some to signify “ ten thousand; ” and that rbRyuwn is said to signify learned, pious, patient men; and that each of these sayings is good: accord. to Aboo-Tálib, it signifies numerous companies: (T:) [in the Kur iii. 140,] El-Hasan read rubRiyRuwna↓; and Ibn-' Abbas, rabRiyRuwna↓; the former with damm, and the latter with fet-h, to the r. (L, TA.) ― -b2- See also rabRaAniIRN.

rabRaAnN c
rabRaAnN: see the next paragraph, in four places.

rubRaAnN c
rubRaAnN The first, or beginning, or commencement, or the first and fresh state, of anything; (As, A 'Obeyd, T;) [and so rabRaAnN↓ &c., as appears from what follows.] You say, Oatayotuhu fiI rubRaAni XabaAbihi, (T,) and XbAbh rabRaAni↓, or XbAbh ribRaAni↓, (accord. to different copies of the T,) and XbAbh rubaAbi↓, (T,) and XbAbh rabaAbi↓, or XbAbh ribaAbi↓, (accord. to different copies of the T,) and XbAbh rubRaI↓, all meaning [I came to him] in the beginning, or first and fresh state, of his youth. (T.) And AifoEalo celika AlOamora birubRaAnihi Do thou that thing in its first and fresh state: so accord. to ISk: and hence, he says, XaApN rubRaI↓ [explained above]. (S.) And Oaxacotu AlXRaIoCa birubRaAnihi, (As, S, K, *) and birabRaAnihi↓, with damm and with fet-h, (K,) i. e. [I took the thing] in its first state: (K:) or altogether, (As, S, K,) not leaving of it aught. (As, S.) They said also, carohu birubRaAnK [app. meaning Leave thou him early, before he acquire more power]: and Th cites the following [as an ex.]:
facarohumo birubRaAnK waUilRaA tacarohumu
yuciyquwka maA fiyhimo waUino kaAna OakovaraA
[which seems to mean Then leave thou them early, before they acquire more power; for if thou do not, or wilt not, leave them, they will make thee to taste what is in them, though it be more]. (M.) ― -b2- Also, accord. to A 'Obeyd, The chief, or main, part or portion of a constellation: or, accord. to As, the aggregate thereof: or, accord. to AO, rabRaAnN↓, with fet-h, has this meaning: (T:) or both signify a company or an assembly, or an aggregate or assemblage. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A captain of sailors (Sh, K) in the sea; (Sh;) and so rubRaAniIRN↓: (Sh, K:) one skilled in navigation: pl. [or rather coll. n. of the latter] rubRaAniyRapN. (TA voce rahonaAmajN.) ＝ -A3- See also rubRaI, in two places.

ribRaAnN c
ribRaAnN: see the next preceding paragraph, second sentence.

rabRaAniIRN c
rabRaAniIRN (T, S, M, A, K) and ribRiIRN↓ (M,) or ribRiIRN↓, (A, KL,) One who devotes himself to religious services or exercises, or applies himself to acts of devotion; (S, A, K;) who possesses a knowledge of God: (T, S, K, KL:) or a learned man: (T:) or the first signifies, (M,) or signifies also, (K,) and so the second, (M,) i. q. HaborN [i. e. a learned man, or particularly of the Jews, &c.; or a good, or righteous, man]; (M, K;) and a lord, or master, of knowledge or science: or a worshipper of the Lord (AlrRabR): (M:) or a learned man, a teacher of others, who nourishes people with the small matters of knowledge, or science, before the great: (IAar, T:) or a learned man firmly grounded in knowledge, or science, and religion: or a learned man who practices what he knows and instructs others: or one of high rank in knowledge, or science: or learned with respect to what is lawful and what is unlawful, and what is commanded and what is forbidden: (TA:) rabRaAniIRN is a rel. n. from rabRaAnN; or from AlrRabRu meaning “ God: ” (TA, and some copies of the K:) the A and n being added to give intensiveness to the signification; (M;) or, as Sb says, to denote a special reference to the knowledge of the
Lord, as though the word signified one possessing a knowledge of the Lord exclusively of other branches of knowledge; (T;) so that it is like liHoyaAniIRN, (T, M, and so in some copies of the K,) meaning “ long-bearded, ” (T,) or “ largebearded, ” (M,) and raqabaAniIRN, “ thick-necked, ” and XaEoraAniIRN, “ having much hair: ” (T:) or it is a Syriac word; (TA, and some copies of the K;) or Hebrew; and was unknown to the [pagan] Arabs, and known only to the men of law and science: (TA:) the pl. is rabRaAniyRuwna, (T, S,) occurring in the Kur iii. 73 (S) [and v. 48 and 68].

rubRaAniIRN c
rubRaAniIRN: see rubRaAnN, last sentence but one.

rabRaAniyRapN c
rabRaAniyRapN The quality denoted by the epithet rabRaAniIRN [q. v.]. (A.)

raborabN c
raborabN A herd (T, S, M, K) of oxen, (T,) [i. e.] of wild oxen (baqar AlwaHoX): (S, M, K:) or, as some say, of gazelles: or, accord. to Kr, a number of [wild] oxen together, less than ten: it has no sing., or n. un. (M.)

raAbRN c
raAbRN; and its fem., with p: see rabiybN in three places.

OaribRapN c
OaribRapN said in the T and K to be pl. of ribRapN [q. v.]: and said by AAF to be pl. of ribaAbN.

marabRN c
marabRN A place of collecting (T, S, M, A) of people: (M, A:) a place of alighting: (M, K:) a place of abiding, or dwelling, and congregating. (M.) [Hence,] marabRu AlUibili The place where the camels keep, or remain. (T, S.) ― -b2- [Hence also,] fulaAnN marabRN (assumed tropical:) Such a one is a person who collects, or congregates, people. (T, S, M, K. *) [And hence,] fulaAnN marabRN libaniI fulaAnK (assumed tropical:) Such a one is an object of resort for his counsel and authority to the sons of such a one. (TA in art. jmE.) ＝ -A2- Also, and mirobaAbN↓, (M, K,) Land abounding with plants, or herbage; (K;) or with ribRap [q. v.]: (TA:) or land in which there ceases not to be moisture; and so marabRapN↓: or mrobaAbN↓ signifies land abounding with plants, or herbage, and with people. (M.)

muribRN c
muribRN Anything keeping, or cleaving, to a thing. (M. [See its verb, 4]) You say naAqapN muribRN A she-camel keeping to, and affecting, her young one, and the stallion. (AZ, TA.) And UibilN maraAbRu [originally maraAbibu, pl. of muribRN,] Camels keeping in a place; remaining in it. (T, S.) And faqorN muribRN (assumed tropical:) Constant, inseparable, poverty: occurring in a trad.: or the epithet there is mulibRN. (IAth.)

marabRapN c
marabRapN: see marabRN.

murabRabN c
murabRabN Made [or preserved] with rubR [or inspissated juice]; (S, K;) like as muEasRalN signifies “ made [or preserved] with Easal [or honey]: ” (S:) you say zanojabiylN murabRabN and murabRFI [ginger so preserved]: and murabRabaAtN↓ signifies Preserves, or confections, made with rubR; (S, K;) and in like manner murabRayaAtN, except that this is from AltRarobiyapu [inf. n. of rabRaI]. (S.) ― -b2- Also Oil of which the grain (HabR [perhaps a mistranscription for HubR i. e. jar]) whence it has been prepared, or taken, has been perfumed (rubRiba↓): (T, TA:) or oil perfumed with sweet-smelling plants; as also marobuwbN↓ and murabRFI. (A.)

murabRabaAtN c
murabRabaAtN: see the next preceding paragraph.

mirobaAbN c
mirobaAbN: see marabRN, in two places.

marobuwbN c
marobuwbN: see rabiybN. ― -b2- Also A slave; a bondman; syn. mamoluwkN [lit. possessed, and now particularly applied to a male white slave]. (M, K.) AlEibaAdu marobuwbuwna lilRehi means [Mankind (lit. the servants of God) are] bondmen (mamoluwkuwna) [to God]. (M.) ― -b3- A skin for clarified butter &c. seasoned with rubR [or inspissated juice]. (T, S.) [And A jar smeared with tar or pitch: see 1.] ― -b4- See also murabRabN.

murotabRN c
murotabRN One who confers a benefit, or benefits. (K.) ― -b2- And One on whom a benefit is conferred, or on whom benefits are conferred. (K.)

1 rabaOa c
1. rabaOa, [aor.
rabaAa
, inf. n. raboCN,] He, or it, was, or became, high, or elevated: (K:) [or] he, or it, was, or became, high, or elevated, so as to overtop, or overlook, what was around or adjacent; as also ArtbO↓. (M, K.) You say, rabaOati AlOaroDu, (M, TA,) inf. n. raboCN, (M,) The ground rose: and some read, in the Kur xxii. 5 and xli. 39, rabaOato instead of rabato; because, as Zj says, when a plant is about to appear, the earth rises thereat. (M, TA.) And you say also, rabaOa EalaI jabalK and ArtbO↓ and ArbO↓ He took a high and commanding position upon a mountain, or ascended upon it, (OaXorafa Ealayoh,) to look. (TA.) And maA Earafotu fulaAnFA liI HatRaI OarobaOa↓ I knew not such a one until he became within a commanding, or near, view of me; syn. OaXorafa. (T.) And rabaOa EalaI XarafK He ascended upon an eminence [to watch] lest an enemy should come unawares upon a party. (TA.) And rabaOotu AlmarobaOapa and AirotabaOotuhaA↓ I ascended upon the place of observation. (S.) And rabaOa Alqawoma, (S, M, K, *) aor.
rabaAa
, (M, K,) inf. n. raboCN; (S, M;) and rabaOalahumo; (T, M, K;) and AirotabaOahumo↓; (S;) He was, or became, [or acted as,] a scout to the party, (T, S, M, * K,) upon an eminence. (M.) And rabaOa lanaA fulaAnN, and ArtbO↓, Such a one was, or became, or acted as, a scout to us. (S.) ― -b2- rabaOotu bika Eano kacaA, aor. and inf. n. as above, means I exalted thee [or held thee] above such a thing: (M:) and rabaOotu bika OarofaEa AlOamori I exalted thee [in the highest degree]: (IJ, M:) and rabaOotu binafosiI Eano Eamali kacaA [I held myself above the doing such a thing]: (Har p. 265:) and UinRiI laOarobaOu bika Eano hecaA AlOamori Verily I exalt thee [or hold thee] above this thing, (S, Har ubi suprà, TA,) and do not approve of it for thee: (Har, TA:) as though properly signifying I betake myself with thee to an elevated place of observation, in honour of thee, and in care, or solicitude, for thee, and preserve thee and keep watch for thee as a scout and a watchman: (Har ubi suprà:) [this usage of the verb, as is shown in the TA, is what is meant by its being said that] rabaOa is also syn. with rafaEa. (K.) ― -b3- rabaOa AlmaAla He preserved, guarded, or took care of, (TA,) and put into a good, or right, state, (K, TA,) the property, or cattle. (TA.) ― -b4- See also 3. ― -b5- rabaOa fiI AlOamori He looked into the thing, or affair, and considered. (TA.) ― -b6- rabaOotu fiyhi, accord. to Fr, means Ealimotu Eilomahu [lit. I knew his knowledge, or what he knew; app. meaning I tried, proved, or tested, him, and so knew what he knew]. (TA. [See the phrase laOa xoburanRa xabaraka.]) ― -b7- maA rabaOa raboOahu He did not know, or had no knowledge of, nor did he desire, him, or it: (M:) or he did not know, or had no knowledge of, and did not prepare himself for, him, or it: (Lh, M:) or he did not care for, mind, heed, or regard, him, or it: (T:) or maA rabaOotu raboCa fulaAnK means I did not know such a one, nor care for, mind, heed, or regard, him. (S, K. *) ＝ -A2- rabaWuwA lahu They collected for him of every kind of food, (M, K, *) milk and dates &c. (M.) ＝ -A3- jaMCa yarobaOo fiI miXoyatihi He came bearing himself heavily, or sluggishly, in his gait. (M, K. * [Like yaronaOu.]) ＝ -A4- See also what next follows.

2 rbROhu c
2. rbROhu, inf. n. tarobiYapN, He made it to pass away; (K, TA;) namely, property: so in the Tekmileh: in the K, rabaOa↓ is likewise mentioned, in an earlier part of the art., as meaning Oacohaba; but the context in the K compared with that in the Tekmileh seems to show that this is a mistake. (TA.)

3 rAbO c
3. rAbO He watched, or observed, a thing; (M, K; *) as also rabaOa↓ and ArbO↓ and ArtbO↓: (TA:) he guarded (HaArasa, T, M, K) men, (M,) or a man, (T, K, *) being guarded by him. (T.) ― -b2- He was cautious of, or he feared, a thing, (T, * S, K, *) or a man; (M;) inf. n. muraAbaOapN. (T, S. [In one of my copies of the S, rabaOotu AlXRaIoCa marobaOapF is erroneously put for raAbaOotu AlXIC muraAbaOapF.])

4 OarobaAa
4: see 1, in two places, near the beginning: ＝ -A2- and see also 3.

8 ArtbO c
8. ArtbO He stationed himself, or stood, upon a place such as is called marobaON. (T.) See also 1, in five places. ＝ -A2- And see 3.

raboOapN c
raboOapN, (K,) written by El-Munáwee rabaOapN, but it is not certain, (TA,) The [kind of leathern vessel for water called] UidaAwap that is made of four skins; (K;) made of four skins because of its largeness. (MF.)

rabaMCN c
rabaMCN [High ground]. You say OaroDN laA rabaMCa fiyhaA walaA waTaMCa, with medd in each case, [A land in which is no high ground nor low ground.] (T.)

rabiIoCN c
rabiIoCN: see what next follows, in two places.

rabiyoYpN c
rabiyoYpN (T, S, M, O, K) and rabiIoCN↓ (S, O) and
murotabiICN↓ (T in art. rmI) A scout; (T, S, M, O, K;) but only (O, TA) such as is stationed upon a mountain or some elevated spot, (T, * O, TA,) whence he looks out: (O, TA:) [perhaps also signifying scouts; for the word TaliyEapN by which the first is explained in the S and M and O and K, and the second also in the S and O, means “ a scout ” and “ scouts: ”] pl. [of the first] rabaAyaA. (S, O.) The first is fem. because the TlyEp is also called EayonN, and Eyn is fem.: but Sb states that this last word in the sense of TlyEp is masc. and fem.; fem. originally, and masc. as being turned from [the signification of] a part [i. e. an eye] to [that of] the whole [person]. (M.) AA cites, as an ex. of rabiIoCN↓
faOarosalonaA OabaA EamorKw rabiyoYFA
[And we sent Aboo-' Amr as a scout]: (TA:) from a poem of 'Abd-Esh-Shárik El-Juhanee. (Ham pp. 218 et seqq.)

raAbiICu AlDRurabaMCi c
raAbiICu AlDRurabaMCi [The superintendent, or supervisor, of the players at the game called Almayosir, whose place is behind them]. (TA in art. rqb.)

marobaON c
marobaON and marobaOapN↓ (S, M, K) and murotabaON↓ (S, K) and mirpbaMCN↓ (TA as from the K [but not in the CK nor in my MS. copy of the K]) An elevated place of observation, or upon which a person is stationed to watch; (S, K;) the place of the rabiyoYap [or scout]. (M.) ― -b2- And hence, the first of these words, (S,) or ↓the second, (T, M,) The manaArap [or perch], (T,) or place, (S, M,) of the hawk, or falcon, (T, S, M,) upon which he stands, (S,) or upon which he mounts. (M.) A rájiz suppresses the C, saying,
muqayRadaA baAta EalaI marobaAtihi↓
[He passed the night upon his perch, shackled]. (T.)

marobaOapN c
marobaOapN and marobaApN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

marobaMCN c
marobaMCN, (M, and so in copies of the K,) accord. to IAar, with medd and fet-h, (M,) or mirobaMCN↓, (M, and so in the K accord. to the TA,) the latter preferred by Th, (M,) A stair, or ladder. (IAar, M, K.)

mirobaMCN c
mirobaMCN: see marobaON; and marobaMCN.

murotabaON c
murotabaON: see marobaON.

murotabiICN c
murotabiICN: see rabiyoYapN.

1 rabata c
1. rabata: see 2. ＝ -A2- rabita, aor.
rabata
, (TK,) inf. n. rabatN, (K,) It (a thing, TK) was, or became, closed; syn. Aisotagolaqa. (K, TK.)

2 rbRt c
2. rbRt, (T, S, M,) inf. n. tarobiytN, (T, S, K,) He fed, nourished, reared, or brought up, (T, S, M, K,) a child; (T, * S, M;) syn. rabRaI; (T, S, M, K;) as also rabata↓, (M,) aor.
rabita
, (TK,) inf. n. rabotN; (K;) and trbRt↓. (TA, and Ham p. 633.) ― -b2- And rbRt, (TK,) inf. n. as above, (K,) He patted a child (K, TA, TK) repeatedly (TA) on the side in order that it might sleep. (K, TA, TK.) [See rabRati AlmaroOapu SabiyRahaA, in art. rb.]
