5: see 2.

rubata c
rubata &c.: see rubRa, in art. rb.

rubRata c
rubRata &c.: see rubRa, in art. rb.

1 rabavahu c
1. rabavahu, aor.
rabuva
, inf. n. rabovN, (Ks, ISk, T,) He hindered, withheld, restrained, or prevented, him, and retarded him; or diverted him, by occupying him otherwise; (Ks, T, TA;) as also rbRvhu↓: (A:) and he kept him, or held him, back: (Ks, T, TA:) and he deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted, him. (ISk, T.) You say, rabavahu Eano HaAjatihi, (Sh, T, S, A, * K, *) and Oamorihi, (T, M,) aor. as above, (T, S, M,) and so the inf. n.; (T, S, M, A, K;) and rbRvhu↓, (M,) inf. n. tarobiyvN; (K;) He hindered, withheld, restrained, or debarred, him; (Sh, T, S, M, A, K;) and turned, or diverted, him; (M;) from the thing that he wanted, (Sh, T, S, A, K,) and from his affair, (T, M,) by pretexts. (T.) ＝ -A2- rabava He was, or became, slow, tardy, dilatory, late, or backward. (Sh, TA.) [See also 5.]

2 rbRvhu c
2. rbRvhu: see above, in two places. Also He made him to tarry, stay, or stop. (M.)

5 trbRv c
5. trbRv He tarried, stayed, or stopped, (S, K,) in his journeying. (S.)

8 Uirotabava
8: see the next paragraph.

9 ArbvRwA c
9. ArbvRwA They became separated, disunited, dispersed, or scattered. (TA.) And ArbvRt Alganamu The sheep, or goats, became dispersed, or scattered. (A, TA.) And ArbvRwA fiI manaAzilihimo, and raOoyihimo, They became separated, or disunited, in their places of alighting or abode, and their judgment or opinion. (A, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ArbvR Oamoruhumo, (S, TA,) or AirobaAvR↓ (K, TA,) or AirobaOavRa↓, (CK,) which last has been heard thus pronounced with C to avoid the conjunction of two quiescent letters, (MF,) (assumed tropical:) Their affair was, or became, weak, and slow, tardy, or dilatory, so that they became separated, disunited, dispersed, or scattered: (S, K:) or the first (ArbvR Amrhm) signifies, (T, M, A,) or signifies also, (K, * TA,) (tropical:) their affair, or state of affairs, was, or became, discomposed, dissipated, disorganized, disordered, or broken up; (T, M, A, K; *) as also Artbv↓. (K.)

11 AirobaAvRa c
11. AirobaAvRa, (K, TA,) or AirobaOavRa↓, (CK,) He was, or became, hindered, withheld, restrained, or debarred. (K, TA.) You say, danaA fulaAnN vumRa QrobaAvRa Such a one drew near, or approached: then became hindered, withheld, &c. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 9.

Q. Q. 4 AirobaOavRa c
Q. Q. 4. AirobaOavRa: see 11: ― -b2- and see also 9.

rabiyvN c
rabiyvN i. q. marobuwvN↓, (M, K,) Hindered, withheld, &c.: (M, * K:) the former, (T, M,) and the latter also, (M,) applied to an affair, or an event. (T, M.) One says, jaroyuhu kariyvN waOamoruhu rabiyvN [app. meaning His running is attended with difficulty, and the accomplishment of his affair is hindered]: (T: [in a copy of the A, as cited in the TA, Hizobuhu is put in the place of jaroyuhu, which appears to be the right reading, from what here follows:]) and
jaroIN kariyvN Oamoruhu rabiyvu
[app. meaning A running attended with difficulty, the affair of which is hindered]: (M:) kariyvN is [here] syn. with makoruwvN. (T.) ＝ -A2- It is also said to signify The jirRiyv [or eel]; and so rabiyvapN↓: and in the " Jámi" of El-Ghooree, ribRiyvaI↓ with kesr to the r and with teshdeed of the b, is said to mean a species of fish. (Mgh.)

rabiyvapN c
rabiyvapN, (T, S, M, K,) a subst. from rabavahu signifying as expl. in the second sentence of this art., (T,) and ribRiyvaI↓ (T, S, M, K,) [in like manner a subst.] from rabavahu signifying as expl. in the first sentence of this art., (T,) A thing, or an event, that hinders, withholds, restrains, or prevents, one [from a thing that he wants, and from his affair; and that turns, or diverts, one therefrom; and that deceives, or deludes, one]: (S, K:) or both signify deceit, or delusion; [in which sense, accord, to the TA, the former word is expl. in the K, but it is not so in my MS. copy of the K nor in the CK;] and hindrance, restraint, or prevention: (M, TA:) pl. of the former rabaAYivu. (TA.) You say, faEala celika lahu rabiyvapF and ribRiyvaI↓ He did that to him from a motive of deceit, or delusion, and hindrance, restraint, or prevention. (M.) And UinRamaA qulotu celika rabiyvapF minRiI I said that only from a motive of deceit, or delusion, on my part. (ISk, T.) It is said in a trad., taEotarDu AlXRayaATiynu AlnRaAsa yawoma AljumuEapi biAlRarbaAYivi, meaning [The devils go forth against men indiscriminately, on Friday,] with the means of hindering them, or withholding them, from prayer: (M:) or UicaA kaAna yawomu AljumuEapi baEava Uiboliysu junuwdahu UilaI AlnRaAsi faOaxacuwA Ealayohimo baAlrRabaAYivi, i. e. [When Friday is come, Iblees sends forth his forces to men, and] they remind them of the wants that hinder, or withhold, them [from the prayers of that day]: (S:) or, as some relate it, yaromuwna AlnRaAsa biAltRaraAbiyvi↓, which is said by El-Khattábee to be of no account; but it may mean [they assail men with] hindrances; for taraAbiyvu may be pl. of tarobiyvapN↓, inf. n. un. of rabRavahu. (MF.) ＝ -A2- See also rabiyvN last sentence.

ribRiyvaI c
ribRiyvaI: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places: ＝ -A2- and see also rabiyvN last sentence.

raAbivN c
raAbivN Slow, tardy, dilatory, late, or backward. (TA.)

tarobiyvapN c
tarobiyvapN, and its pl. taraAbiyvu: see rabiyvapN last sentence but one.

marobuwvN c
marobuwvN: see rabiyvN.

1 rabiHa fiI tijaAratihir c
1. rabiHa fiI tijaAratihir (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,)
aor.
rabaHa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. riboHN (Mgh, Msb, TA) and rabaHN and rabaAHN, (Msb, TA,) He gained; or made gain, or profit; in his traffic; (MA, KL, TK;) i. q. AisotaXafRa (S, K) or OafoDala. (Az, Msb.) The Arabs say to a man when he enters upon traffic, biAlrRabaAHi waAlsRamaAHi [With gaining and liberality.] (TA.) ― -b2- And rabiHato tijaAratuhu (tropical:) (A, Msb, TA) His traffic brought him gain, or profit. (Msb, TA.)

2 rbRHhu c
2. rbRHhu: see 4. ＝ -A2- Also rbRH, inf. n. tarobiyHN, He took to himself (AitRaxaca) an ape (rubRaAH, TA) in his place of abode. (K.)

3 OaEoTaAhu maAlFA muraAbaHapF c
3. OaEoTaAhu maAlFA muraAbaHapF He gave him property on the condition that the gain, or profit, should be [divided] between them two. (TA.) And biEotuhu AlmataAEa muraAbaHapF (S, * Msb) I sold him the commodity naming a certain gain, or profit, for every portion of the price: (Msb:) you say, biEotuhu AlsRiloEapa muraAbaHapF EalaI kulRi EaXarapi daraAhima dirohamN [I sold him the commodity on the condition of my receiving as gain, or profit, upon every ten dirhems, a dirhem]: (TA:) and AiXotarayotuhu minohu maraAbaHapF I bought it of him in like manner: (Msb, TA:) the gain, or profit, must be named. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 4.

4 ArbH fiI tijaAratihi c
4. ArbH fiI tijaAratihi He found a profitable market in [or for] his traffic. (Az, Msb.) ＝ -A2- ArbHhu He gave him gain, or profit: (Mgh, Msb:) rbRHhu↓ we have not heard; (Mgh;) [i. e.] rabRaHotuhu as meaning I gave him gain, or profit, has not been transmitted [from the Arabs of classical times]. (Msb.) You say, OarobaHotuhu EalaI siloEatihi, (S,) or EalayohaA raAbaHotuhu↓, (A, K,) or both, (TA,) I gave him a gain, or profit, upon his commodity. (S, A, K, TA.) And ArbHhu bimataAEihi [He made him to gain by his commodity]. (TA.) And ArbH QllRehu bayoEatahu [God made, or may God make, his sale to be productive of gain, or profit]. (S and K in art. rjE.) ＝ -A3- Also ArbH He slaughtered for his guests young weaned camels; (K, TA;) which are called rabaH. (TA.) ＝ -A4- And ArbH AlnRaAqapa He milked the she-camel in the early morning, or between the prayer of daybreak and sunrise, and at midday. (K.)

5 trbRH c
5. trbRH He sought gains, or profits. (A.) ＝ -A2- He (a man, TA) was, or became, confounded or perplexed, and unable to see his right course. (K.)

riboHN c
riboHN and rabaHN↓ and rabaAHN↓ [all originally inf. ns.] Gain, or profit; (IAar, S, A, K, and Mgh in explanation of the first and last;) increase [obtained] in traffic; (TA;) excess, or surplus, [obtained,] above the capital [expended]; wherefore it is also termed XifRN. (Ksh and Bd in explanation of the first in ii. 15.) [Hence,] AlbirRu xayoru tijaArapK rabaAHFA↓ (tropical:) [Piety is the best traffic in respect of gain, or profit.] (A.)

rabaHN c
rabaHN: see the next preceding paragraph. ― -b2- Horses and camels that are brought from one place to another for sale. (K.) ― -b3- And Fat, as a subst. (S, K.) A poet says, (S,) namely, Khufáf Ibn-Nudbeh, (TA,)
qarawoA OaDoyaAfahumo rabaHFA bibuHRK
yEiyXu bifaDolihinRa AlHaIRu sumori
[as though meaning They entertained their guests with fat, on the superabundant remains of which the tribe lived, by means of tawny-coloured gaming-arrows whereby the lots that determined who should afford the entertainment were divided]: (S, * TA:) but [this is inconsistent with the affixed pronoun relating to rbHA, wherefore], in this case, as some say, (S, TA,) it means young weaned camels; (S, K, TA;) [as a quasi-pl. n.;] and its sing. is raAbiHN↓; (K;) like as that of HarasN is HaArisN; and that of xaAdimN xadamN: (TA:) or a young weaned camel; [like rubaHN;] and its pl. is ribaAHN: (K:) or it means here the gain, or profit, obtained by means of the game called Alamyosir. (S, TA.) ― -b4- See also the next paragraph.

rubaHN c
rubaHN A young weaned camel; (S, K:) app. a dial. var. of rubaEN. (S.) [See also rabaHN and rubRaAHN.] ― -b2- A lamb, or kid: (ISd, TA in art. nSH:) or the latter: (K;) as also rubRaAHN↓. (IAar, K.) ― -b3- See also rubRaAHN, first sentence. ― -b4- Also A certain bird, (S, K,) resembling the raAmij [which is an owl employed for catching hawks]: or, accord. to Kr, the word is rabaHN↓, and signifies a certain bird resembling the zaAg[or rook]. (TA.)

rabaAHN c
rabaAHN: see riboHN in two places. ＝ -A2- Also A certain small animal, resembling the cat. (So in many copies of the S.) F observes that J says, AlrRabaAHu duwayobRapN yujolabu minohaA AlkaAfuwru; and that baladN has been substituted as an amendment for dwybRp in some of the copies [of the S]; but that each of these readings is erroneous: for yjlb we find [in copies of the S] in the handwriting of Aboo-Zekereeyà and that of Aboo-Sahl yuHolabu, with the unpointed H; and the substitution of bld for dwybap was made by IKtt: in the copies of the S, moreover, we find minohu instead of minohaA: and IB says that the passage in J's original copy, in his own handwriting, runs thus: AlrRabaAHu OayoDFA duwayobRapN kaAlsRinRawri yujolabu minohu AlkaAfuwru. (TA.) [But I find that, in five copies of the S, between AlsnRwr and yjlb, occur the words waAlrRabaAHu OayoDFA baladN, or balodapN or Qsomu baladK: and I think it most probable that J intended to have introduced these or similar words, and therefore wrote minohu instead of minohaA; meaning that rbAH is the appellation of a certain small animal, resembling the cat: and that AlrbAH is also the name of a country or town from which camphor is brought: this country or town is said in a marginal note in a copy of the S to be in India.]

rubaAHN c
rubaAHN: see rubRaAHN.

rabiyHN c
rabiyHN: see raAbiHN.

rabaAHiIRN c
rabaAHiIRN A certain kind of camphor: (K:) so called in relation to a certain country, or town, agreeably with what is [said to have been] asserted by J, or to a certain king named rabaAHN, who applied his mind to this kind of camphor, and discovered it. (TA.)

rubRaAHN c
rubRaAHN (A' Obeyd, S, A, L, K) and rubaAHN↓, (A, TA,) the latter of the dial. of El-Yemen, (TA,) and rubaHN↓, (L, TA,) The male ape; (S, A, L, K;) [simia caudata, clunibus nudis: (Forskål, "Descr. Animalium" &c., p. iii.:)] or the young one of an ape: (TA:) or apes [as a coll. gen. n.]: (TA in art. nSH, in explanation of the last, which is there said to be originally rubaAHN:) pl. of the first rabaAbiyHu. (TA.) One says OamolaHu mino rubRaAHK and rubaAHK, meaning [Prettier] than the ape. (A, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] rubRu rubRaAHK (Lth, A, K) or rubaAHK (A) A sort of dates (Lth, A, K) of ElBasrah. (Lth.) ― -b3- Also, (K,) accord. to some, (TA,) rubRaAHN signifies A small young weaned camel, (K,) and small young camels, syn. HaAXiyapN, (TA,) slender in the bones and meagre in the body: (K:) but A Heyth asks, How can it mean small young weaned camels, seeing that a poet applies to it the epithet vaniIR, and the vnIR is five years old? and Khidásh Ibn-Zuheyr, in a verse cited by Sh, speaks of a rbRAH breathing hard in labour, in order that her young one might come forth. (TA.) ― -b4- See also rubaHN.

matojarN raAbiHN c
matojarN raAbiHN and rabiyHN↓ (tropical:) Trafficking in which one makes gain, or profit; (TA;) and so tijaArapN raAbiHapN; (T, S, A, * Msb, K;) [lucrative, or profitable, traffic;] a phrase like layolN naAYimN and saAhirN meaning "a night in which one sleeps" and "in which one is wakeful:" (Az, TA:) and bayoEN murobiHN↓ a sale in which one makes gain, or profit. (TA.) And maAlN raAbiHN (assumed tropical:) Property having gain, or profit: rAbH in this case being like laAbinN and taAmirN: occurring in a trad.: but some read [raAYiHN, or, more probably, raAYijN, from raAja,] with I [or rather C]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also rabaHN.

murobiHN c
murobiHN: see the next preceding paragraph.

1 rabada c
1. rabada, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
rabuda
, (S, L,) or
rabida
, (Msb,) inf. n. rubuwdN, (S, L, K,) or rabodN, (Msb,) He remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, (S, M, L, Msb, K,) bimakaAnK in a place. (S, M, L, Msb.) ＝ -A2- rabada, (IAar, S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
rabuda
, (M,) inf. n. rabodN, (T, M, Msb,) He confined; kept close, or within certain limits; or shut up; (IAar, T, S, M, Msb, K;) him, or it; (IAar, S, M, Msb;) or camels [&c.]. (M.) ― -b2- He tied camels. (A, TA.) ― -b3- Also, (TA,) or rbRd↓, (so accord. to the TT, as from the T,) [or rbd AltRamora,] He stowed, or packed, dates, or the dates, in rabaAYid, i. e. oblong pieces of matting [of woven palm-leaves]. (AA, T, TA.) [From what here follows, and from the usage of the part. n. raAbidN (q. v.), it appears that the former verb is correct; but the latter may be so too, or may have an intensive signification.]
You say also, rabadotu tamoraka rabodFA HasanFA I stowed thy dates in the mirobad in a good manner. (A.)

2 rabRada
2: see 1. ＝ -A2- rabRadato, said of a ewe or she-goat, She secreted milk in her udder a little before her bringing forth (OaDoraEato), and her udder exhibited patches, or shining hues, of black (S, M, A) and white: (S:) or her udder exhibited patches, or shining hues, of faint blackness and whiteness: (T:) a dial. var. of ramRadato [q. v.]. (S.)

4 Arbd c
4. Arbd He (a man) marred, or wasted, or ruined, his property, and his goods. (M, TA. [See also Armd.])

5 trbRd c
5. trbRd It (the udder of a ewe or goat) exhibited patches, or shining hues, of black (M, A, L) and white, (L,) or of faint blackness and whiteness. (T.) He, or it, was, or became, marked, in oblong shapes, (kaAna muwalRaEFA,) with black and white; (TA;) and so ArbdR↓ and ArbAdR↓: (K, TA:) or all three signify it became of a red hue in which was blackness; (M and L and TA in explanation of the first and second, and TA in explanation of the third also;) said of a man's face, on an occasion of anger: (M, L:) or, said of a man's face, (S, TA,) trbRd signifies it became altered, (S, K, TA,) by reason of anger; (S;) and so ArbdR↓ and ArmdR: (As, T:) or it became like the colour of ashes; as also ArmdR: (TA:) or was as though parts of it became black, on an occasion of anger: (T, TA:) and ArbdR↓, said, in a trad., of the Prophet's face when revelations came down to him, it became altered to a dusty hue: (TA:) and trbRd said of a man's colour, it assumed various hues; appearing at one time red, and another time yellow, and another time OaxoDar [here meaning a dark, or an ashy, dustcolour], by reason of anger. (ISh, TA.) ― -b2- Also He (a man, S) looked sternly, austerely, or morosely. (S, K.) ― -b3- And trbRdt AlsRimaMCu The sky became clouded. (S, M, A, K.)

9 ArbdR c
9. ArbdR, (S, M, K,) or ArbdR lawonuhu, (T,) He (an ostrich, S, M) was, or became, of the colour termed rubodapN; (S, M, K;) as also ArbAdR↓. (K.) ― -b2- See also 5, in three places.

11 UirobaAodRa
11: see what next precedes: ― -b2- and see also 5.

rabodN c
rabodN or rabadN: see rubodapN.

rubadN c
rubadN [app. pl. of rubodapN] The diversified wavy marks, streaks, or grain, (firinod,) of a sword: (S, M, A, K:) of the dial, of Hudheyl. (M.) You say sayofN cuw rubadK A sword [having such marks;] xaXiybapN in which one sees what resembles dust, or the tracks of ants. (S, L.) [See an ex. in a verse of Sakhr, cited voce rubodapN.]

wuroqapN c
wuroqapN A colour like rumodapN, inclining to blackness; as also rumodapN: (T:) or dust-colour: (M:) or a colour inclining to that of dust: (S, K:) or a colour between blackness and dust-colour: (AO, TA:) or ash-colour; like rumodapN: (A:) or blackness mixed with dinginess, or duskiness: (Msb:) or, in the ostrich, (M, L,) as also rabadN↓, (M,) or rabodN↓, (L,) a mixed black colour: or, accord. to Lh, entire blackness. (M, L.) Also Dust-colour in the lip. (M, L.) [See also Oarobadu.]

rabiydN c
rabiydN Dates (tamorN) laid one upon another (S, M, K) in an earthen pot, (S,) or in jars, (M,) and then sprinkled with water. (S, M, K.) [See also rabiyTN.]

rabiydapN c
rabiydapN The [kind of repository termed] qimaTor [q. v.] of the [records termed] maHaADir, (K, TA,) i.e. sijilRaAt. (TA.) ― -b2- See also rabaAYidu.

rubayodaAnN c
rubayodaAnN A certain plant. (M, L.)

rabaAYidu c
rabaAYidu [a pl. of which the sing. (probably rabiydapN↓) is not indicated] Oblong pieces of matting [of woven palm-leaves], in which dates are stowed, or packed. (AA, T.)

raAbidN c
raAbidN One who reposits, stows, lays up, keeps, preserves, or guards, property &c.; a treasurer: (IAar, T, K:) fem. with p. (IAar, T.)

Oarobadu c
Oarobadu, and its fem. rabodaMCu, applied to an ostrich, Of the colour termed rubodapN; (S, M, A;) and so the former applied to dates (tamorN): (A:) accord. to Lh, (M,) the latter, applied to an ostrich, (T, M,) as also ramodaMCu, (T,) signifies black; (T, M;) entirely: (M:) or, (T, M,) as he says in one place, (M,) having, in its blackness, specks of white or red: (T, M:) pl. rubodN. (S.) Hence Oarobadu meaning A male ostrich. (T, L.) Also the fem., applied to a ewe (Msb, TA) or she-goat, (T, S, K,) to the latter specially, (S,) Speckled, and marked in the place of the girdle with red: (T, L:) or speckled with red and white or black: (L, TA:) or black, speckled with red (S, Msb, K) and white. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also A man, and a woman, having a dusty hue in the lips. (M, L.) ― -b3- AlOarobadu also signifies A species of serpent, (T, M, K, * TA,) of a foul, malignant, or noxious, nature, (T, K,) that bites so that the face in consequence alters to an ashy hue or the like (yatarabRadu), (M, [but this addition in the M seems to be founded upon a mistranscription in a passage in the T immediately following, but not relating to, what is said of this serpent,]) or that bites camels. (TA.) ― -b4- And The lion; as also AlmutarabRidu↓. (K.) ― -b5- [Hence also,] daAhiyapN rabodaMCu (tropical:) An abominable calamity. (S, A, K. *) And OumuwrN rubodN (assumed tropical:) Black calamities. (M.) ― -b6- And EaAmN Oarobadu (tropical:) A year of drought. (A.)

mirobadN c
mirobadN, a subst. like miTobaxN [q v.], (Sb, M,) from the trans. v. rabada, (Msb, TA,) [properly A thing with which one confines, &c.: and hence,] a place of confinement: (K:) [pl. maraAbidu. And particularly] Anything with which camels are confined; (As, T;) and also sheep or goats: (TA:) a place in which camels (T, S, M, A, Mgh, Msb) and other animals (S, Mgh) are confined (T, S, M, A, * Mgh) or stationed. (Msb.) In the phrase EaSaA mirobadK, used by a poet, the latter word is said to signify A piece of wood, or a staff, that is put across the breasts of camels to prevent them from going forth: (M:) or, accord. to As, by that word is meant a staff put across at the entrance [of an enclosure] to prevent the camels from going forth; wherefore it is thus called: but others disapprove of this; and say that the poet means [by the phrase] a staff put across at the entrance of the mirobad; not that the staff is a mirobad. (T.) ― -b2- Also The place of dates, (T, S, A, Mgh, Msb,) in which they are put to dry (S, A) in the sun; (A;) in the dial. of El-Medeeneh; (S;) i. q. misoTaHN (S, Msb) in the dial. of El-Yemen, (TA in art. sTH,) and jariynN (T, S, Mgh, K) in the dial. of Nejd: (S:) or mirobadu AltRamori signifies the jariyn of dates, [i. e. the place] in which they are put, after the cutting, in order that they may dry: (M:) accord. to A 'Obeyd, mirobadN and jariynN in this sense are both of the dial. of El-Hijáz, and OanodarN of that of Syria, and bayodarN of El-' Irák. (T.) ― -b3- Also A court, or yard, or spacious place, behind houses, of which use is made. (M.) ― -b4- And The like of a Hujorap [i. e. a chamber, or an upper chamber,] in a house. (M.)

murobadRN c
murobadRN Marked, in oblong shapes, (muwalRaEN,) with black and white. (Aboo-' Adnán, K.) [See also its verb, 9.]

AlmutarabRidu c
AlmutarabRidu: see Oarobadu.

1 rabica c
1. rabica, [aor.
rabaca
,] (M,) inf. n. rabacN, (Lth, T, M, K,) He was, or became, light, or active, (Lth, T, M, K,) in the arm, or hand, (M, K,) in working or in doing a thing, and in the leg, or foot, in walking or going, (M,) or in the legs in walking or going, and in the fingers in working or in doing a thing. (Lth, T.) And rabicato yaduhu biAlqidaAHi aor.
rabaca
, inf. n. as above, His hand was light, or active, with the qdAH [or gaming-arrows]. (S, A, * L, K.)

rabacN c
rabacN: see ribocapN: ― -b2- and see also rabacapN.

rabicN c
rabicN Light, or active, (Lth, T, S, M, K,) in the arm, or hand, in working or in doing a thing, and in the leg, or foot, in walking or going, (M,) or in the legs in walking or going, (Lth, T, S, K,) as also rabicu AlqawaAYimi; (A;) and light, or active, in the fingers in working or in doing a thing, (Lth, T,) as also rabicu AlOaSaAbiEi fiI Eamalihi. (A.) And A quick, or fleet, horse. (T.) And farasN lahu qawaAYimu rabicAtN A horse having light, or active, legs. (A.) ― -b2- jaMCa rabica AlEinaAni means (assumed tropical:) He came alone, put to flight. (IAar, M, K. *) But the saying of Hishám El-Mara-ee,
gadaApa tarakotahu rabica AlEinaAni
is explained by IAar as meaning (assumed tropical:) [In the morning] when thou leftest him exempt from satire. (M.) ― -b3- Accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed, (T,) livapN rabicN means A gum having little flesh. (T, K.)

ribocapN c
ribocapN (T, S, M, A, K) and rabacapN↓, (S. A, K,) the former of which is said to be the more chaste, (TA,) The wisp of wool, (T, S, M, A, K,) or piece of rag, (Ks, T, M,) with which one smears with tar a camel (Ks, T, S, M, A, K) that is
scabby or mangy: (Ks, T:) of the dial. of Temeem: (M:) also called wafiyEapN [and vamalapN]. (T.) One says, kaOanRa EiroDahu ribocapu AlhaAniICi [As though his honour, or reputation, were the rbcp of him who smears camels with tar]; and in like manner, ribocapu AlHaAYiDi [explained below]. (A.) And lamRaA OasomaEahumu AlHaqRa nabacuwhu kamaA yanobicu AlhaAniICu AlrRibocapa [When he made them to hear, or told them, the truth, they rejected it, like as he who smears camels with tar rejects the rbcp after using it]. (A.) ― -b2- Also The piece of rag with which the goldsmith polishes ornaments. (S, L, K, and Msb in explanation of the latter word.) ― -b3- And the former word, The rag of a menstruating woman; (M, A, L, K;) the thing that the menstruating woman throws away. (Lth, T.) ― -b4- And [hence,] (assumed tropical:) Anything unclean, dirty, or filthy, (M, L, K, TA,) and stinking. (TA.) ― -b5- And [hence likewise,] (assumed tropical:) A man in whom is no good or goodness, devoid of goodness, or worthless, (M, K,) and, accord. to Lh, stinking. (M.) ― -b6- Also The stopper (SimaAm) of a bottle, or flask. (IAar, T, M, K.) ― -b7- Also, (M, L, K,) and rabacapN↓ (Fr, A 'Obeyd, S, M, L,) of which latter rabacN↓ is pl., or rather a quasi-pl. n., (M,) [or more properly a coll. gen. n., rabacapN being its n. un.,] A single one of the rabac meaning tufts of dyed wool (Euhuwn) which are hung upon the necks of camels; (Fr, A 'Obeyd, S, L;) and which are likewise called maraAbicu↓ (A, TA,) an irreg. pl. like maHaAsinu [and malaAmaHu &c.]; (TA;) or which are hung upon a she-camel: (L:) or a tuft of dyed wool (EhonapN) which is hung upon the ear of a camel (M, L, K) &c., (K,) [i. e.,] upon the ear of a he-camel and she-camel, or of a sheep or goat. (M, L.) ― -b8- The pl. of ribocapN in all the senses expl. above is ribcN and ribaAcN (M, L, K.)

rabacapN c
rabacapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places. ― -b2- Also The Eacabap [app. as meaning the EilaAqap, or suspensory thong in the handle,] of a whip: (K:) [n. un. of rabacN↓: for you say] sawoTN cuw rabacK meaning A whip having thongs in the fore part of its jaloz [or handle]. (En-Nadr, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also Difficulty, or distress. (IAar, T, K.) So in the saying, kunRaA fiI rabacapK faQnojalato EanRaA [We were in difficulty, or distress, and it became removed, or cleared away, from us]. (IAar, T.)

cuw rabicaAtK c
cuw rabicaAtK [in one of my copies of the S rabacaAtK, and in a copy of the A rabocaAtK,] (tropical:) One who makes many mistakes in his speech. (S, A, L, K.) [See also mirobaAcN, below.]

rabacaAniIRN c
rabacaAniIRN: see mirobaAcN.

rabaAciyapN c
rabaAciyapN (assumed tropical:) Evil (ISk, T, S, M, K) that occurs between, or among, people. (ISk, T, S, * M. *) You say, bayona Alqawomi rabaAciyapN Between, or among, the people is evil. (S, M. *)

mirobaAcN c
mirobaAcN and rabacaAniIRN↓ (assumed tropical:) One who talks much, and irrationally, or erroneously, (K, TA,) making many mistakes in his speech. (TA.)

maraAbicu c
maraAbicu: see ribocapN.

1 rabaSa bifulaAnK c
1. rabaSa bifulaAnK, or biAlXRaIoCi: see 5. ＝ -A2- rabaSaniI (K) A thing, or an affair, or an event, put me in expectation. (TA.)

5 trbRS c
5. trbRS He expected; or awaited: (S:) he tarried; or tarried expecting. (IAth.) You say trbRS AlOamora He looked for, expected, awaited, or waited for, the thing, or event. (Msb.) And trbRS bihi AlXRaIoCa, (M,) or AlOamora, (Msb,) He looked for, expected, awaited, or waited for, the thing, or event, to befall him, or betide him. (M, Msb.) It is said in the Kur [ix. 52], halo tarabRaSuwna binaA UilRaA UiHodaI QloHusonayayoni [Do ye look for, &c., aught save one of the two best things (namely victory or martyrdom) to betide us?]. (M.) And a poet says,
tarabRaSo bihaA rayoba Almanuwni laEalRahaA
tuTalRaqu yawomFA Oawo yamuwtu HaliyluhaA
[Wait thou for the vicissitudes of fortune to befall her: perhaps she may be divorced some day, or her husband may die]. (TA.) You say also, trbRS bisiloEatihi AlgalaMCa [He looked for, &c., a time of dearness for his commodity, or article of merchandise]. (A.) And, [elliptically,) trbRS bifulaAnK, (K,) or biAlXRaIoCi; (M;) and bihi rabaSa↓, (M, A, K,) aor.
rabuSa
, (TK,) inf. n. raboSN; (M, A, K;) He looked for, expected, awaited, or waited for, [something] good or evil to befall, or betide, (M, A, K,) such a one, (A, K,) or the thing: (M:) or trbRF biAlXRaIoCa signifies he looked for, expected, awaited, or waited for, a day for the thing. (Lth.)

ruboSapN c
ruboSapN An expecting; an awaiting; a waiting: (AHát, S, A, Msb, K:) a tarrying; or tarrying in expectation. (M.) You say, liI fiI mataAEiI ruboSapN [I have to endure an expecting, &c., with respect to my goods, or commodities; app. meaning, I have to wait for a favourable opportunity to sell them]. (S, A.) And liI biAlbaSorapi ruboSapN [I have to endure an expecting, or a waiting, in ElBasrah]. (AHát, A.) And liI EalaI hecaA AlOamori ruboSapN [I have to endure a tarrying, or a tarrying in expectation, for, or on account of, this thing, or affair]. (M.) ― -b2- Also The period that is assigned to a husband when he has been pronounced incapable of sexual intercourse with his wife; so that if he go in to her [it is well with him, and he remains her husband]; but if not, a separation is made between them: so in the saying, OaqaAmati QlomaroOapu ruboSatahaA fiI bayoti zawojihaA [The woman abode during the period so assigned to her husband in the house, or tent, of her husband]. (ISk, K.) [In like manner ruboDapN (perhaps a mistranscription) is explained in the A and TA in art. rbD: and the period is there said to be a year.]

marobuwSN c
marobuwSN, applied to a man, (K,) Put in expectation. (TK.)

mutarabRiSu c
mutarabRiSu One who withholds, or collects and withholds, wheat or the like, waiting for a time of dearness; syn. muHotakrN. (S.)

1 rabaDa c
1. rabaDa, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
rabiDa
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. rubuwDN (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and raboDN (Msb, K) and raboDapN, (K,) [the last an inf. n. of un.,] said of the sheep and goat, (S, A, Mgh, K,) and of the gazelle, (S, A,) and of the ox-kind, and the horse, (S,) or beast, (Msb,) and of the dog, (S, A,) [signifying He lay down, or laid himself down, upon his breast,] is like baraka said of a camel, (S, Msb, K,) and javama said of a bird, (S, TA,) or jalasa said of a man. (Mgh.) Said of a man, it means [(assumed tropical:) He lay down: and he sat: or] he sat upon his knees: and it may also mean he sat upon his thighs and his buttocks. (Har p. 172.) [And hence, (assumed tropical:) He remained fixed, or stationary, like an animal lying upon its breast; as is shown by what here follows: whence a signification of rabRaDa, q. v.] The saying of Mohammad to Ed- Dahhák, when he sent him to his people, UicaA Oatayotahumo faQrobiDo fiI daArihimo ZaboyFA, means When thou comest to them, remain in their abode in security, or without fear, like the gazelle in his covert: (IAar, ISd, K:) or trust them not, but be vigilant, like a wild animal, ready to spring up, for thou wilt be in the midst of the unbelievers; (Az, ISd, K; *) so, if anything induce in thee suspicion, thou mayest flee from them like the gazelle: (Az, ISd, TA:) accord. to each interpretation, ZbyA is in the accus. case as a denotative of state; the subst. being put in the place of the act. part. n., as though for mataZabRiyFA: the former of the two explanations is said to be the more agreeable with the circumstances of the case. (TA.) You say also, rabaDa AlOasadu EalaI fariysatihi, and Alqironu EalaI qironihi, The lion laid himself down upon his breast (baraka) on his prey, and the adversary on his adversary. (K.) ― -b2- He (a beast) lodged, and abode, in a place. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) He (a man) became heavy, and slept, stretched upon the ground. (TA.) ― -b4- rabaDa Eani Alganami, (S, A, K,) inf. n. rubuwDN, (S,) (tropical:) He (a ram) abstained from tupping, or covering the ewes, and avoided it, (S, A, * K, *) or them, (TA,) being fatigued: (S:) or was unable to cover them: (K:) one does not say, of a ram, jafara. (S.) You say also of a ewe when she is pregnant, qado rubiDa EanohaA. (Ibn- 'Abbád, A.) And you say of a man, rabaDa Eano maEaAliI AlOumuwri (assumed tropical:) He abstained, or held back, from seeking the means of acquiring eminence, or nobility. (TA.) ― -b5- rabaDa AllRayolu (A, K) (tropical:) The night cast its darkness [lit. itself (expl. by OaloqaI bnafosihi) upon the earth]. (K.) ＝ -A2- rabaDahu, aor.
rabiDa
and
rabuDa
, (IAar, O, K,) but the latter aor. was afterwards rejected by IAar, (TA,) He betook himself, or repaired, to him for lodging, covert, or refuge. (IAar, O, K.) ＝ -A3- rabaDatohu, aor.
rabiDa
, and IAar is related to have said
rabuDa
also, but afterwards to have retracted it, (tropical:) She (a wife, or sister, or other woman,) undertook, or managed, his affairs, and gave him lodging, or refuge: (TA:) she was to him [as though she were] a rabaD, or place of abode: like Oabawotuhu “ I was to him a father, ” and Oamamotuhu “ I was to him a mother. ” (A, TA.) [The aor. occurs in the K, in the phrase tarobiDu zawojahaA: thus in the TA:
in the CK, turabRiDu: in the L, tarobuDu; and thus also the aor. is written in a copy of the A.]

2 rabRaDa
2: see 4. ― -b2- rabRaDotuhu biAlmakaAni, inf. n. tarobiyDN, (assumed tropical:) I fixed him, or made him to remain fixed, in the place. (TA.) ― -b3- rbRD AlsRiqaMCa biAlmaMCi, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (K, TA,) [He made the skin to cleave to the ground with water; i. e.] he put into the skin as much water as covered and concealed its bottom: (K, * TA:) mentioned by Sgh, from Ibn- 'Abbád. (TA.)

4 ArbD c
4. ArbD He made a sheep, or goat, [&c., (see 1,)] to lie down upon his breast; (S, K;) as also rbRD↓, inf. n. tarobiyDN. (TA.) ― -b2- OarobaDahumo (tropical:) It (a vessel, S, A, K, and beverage, or wine, A, TA) satisfied their thirst so that they became heavy, and slept, stretched upon the ground: (S, * A, * K:) (tropical:) it (milk) satiated them. (TA.) ― -b3- ArbDt AlXRamosu (tropical:) The sun became vehemently hot, (S, A, K,) so as to make the gazelle and the sheep or goat, (S,) or the wild animals, (A,) to lie down upon their breasts: (S, A:) or became still, like a beast lying upon its breast, having attained its utmost height and not begun to descend. (O.) ― -b4- ArbD Oaholahu, (O, K,) and OaSoHaAbahu, (O,) (assumed tropical:) He undertook, or managed, the expenses of his family, (O, K,) and of his companions; (O;) syn. qaAma bnafaqatihimo: (O, K:) so says Ibn- 'Abbád. (TA.)

raboDN c
raboDN: see rabaDN.

ruboDN c
ruboDN: see rabaDN, in five places. ― -b2- Also, accord. to Ks, (S,) and As, (Sgh, TA,) The middle of a thing: (S, Sgh, K:) but this is disapproved by Sh. (T, TA.) ― -b3- And A collection of trees of the kinds called TaloH and samur: (K:) or a collection of abundant and dense trees. (TA.)

riboDN c
riboDN: see rabiyDN: in three places.

rabaDN c
rabaDN The lodging-place of sheep or goats; (S, A, * K;) because they lie therein upon their breasts; and in like manner of wild animals: (TA:) the nightly lodging-place of sheep or goats: (Msb:) and marobiDN↓ signifies the same: (S, * A, Mgh, Msb:) pl. of the former OarobaADN: (S, A, * TA:) and of the latter maraAbiDu: (S, K: *) the mrAbD of sheep or goats are like the maEaATin of camels. (S.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A place of abode: a place of abode of a people by itself: (A, TA:) pl. as above. (A.) ― -b3- (tropical:) Anything to which a man betakes himself, or repairs, for lodging, covert, or refuge, (ISk, S, A, * Msb, K,) and at which, or with which, he finds rest, or ease; (K;) such as a house or tent, (S, A, K,) and the like, (S, K,) and a wife, (ISk, S, A, Msb,) or relations, (ISk, A, Msb,) or a family, and a relation, and property, (K,) and sheep or goats, and means of subsistence, and food; (TA;) and hence, (S,) milk which sustains a man, and suffices him for food: (S, K: *) pl. as above: (K:) rabaDN and raboDN↓ and ruboDN↓ (IAar, Sgh, K) and rubuDN↓ (K) are applied to a wife liOanRahaA tarobiDu zawojahaA, (so in copies of the K and in the TA, but in the CK turabRiDu,) i. e. because she undertakes, or manages, the affairs of her husband, and gives him lodging, or refuge; (TA;) or because she fixes him, (turabRiDuhu, i. e. tuvabRituhu,) so that he does not quit his place: (L, TA:) or to the mother; or the sister; who undertakes, or manages, the affairs of (tuEazRibu [so in copies of the K and in the TA, in the latter of which it is thus explained, but in the CK tuqarRibu,]) her relation. (K.) A poet says,
jaMCa AlXRitaMCu walamRaA OatRaxico rabaDFA
yaA wayoHa kafRaIRa mino Hafori AlqaraAmiySi
(S, Mgh) i. e. [The winter has come, and I have not yet made for myself] a lodging: [O, wo to my two-hands, in consequence of digging] hollows in which to sit for protection from the cold. (Mgh.) And from rabaDN applied to “ milk which sustains a man, and suffices him for food, ” originated the prov., (K, TA,) minoka rabaDuka waUino kaAna samaArFA, meaning (tropical:) Thy family and thy servants (S, K) and those to whom thou betakest thyself for lodging or refuge, (S,) are appertenances of thine, though they be persons falling short [of their duty]: (S, K:) or thy manager of affairs, &c., though he be not a good manager of thine affairs: (L, TA:) and rabaDN also signifies any woman who undertakes, or manages, the affairs of a house: but in the T we find ruboDuka↓, thus written, as by Th, on the authority of IAar, but not restricted by a measure, and explained as meaning the person who undertakes, or manages, the affairs of thy house; and so in the book of proverbs by As: and in the margin of a copy of the S, we find the above-cited prov. thus written, waUino kaAna samaArFA minoka rubuDuka↓, as from the “ Book on Goats ” by Ibn-Zeyd, and expl. as meaning the sons of thy father are appertenances of thine, though they be evil persons, in whom is no good. (TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) The wall of a city: (K, TA:) the environs of a city, (S, A, Mgh,) and of a qaSor [or palace &c.], (A,) consisting of houses or dwellings, (A, Mgh,) or of open country: (TA:) and ruboDN↓ signifies the same: (TA:) or this latter signifies the foundation, or basis, of a building; and of a city also: (K:) IKh writes it rubuDN↓: and some say that ruboDN↓ and rabaDN signify the same: (TA:) the former of these two signifies also the part, of a thing, that touches the ground: (K, TA:) so says Sh: accord. to ISh, AlOaroDi ruboDu↓ signifies what touches the ground, of a thing: (TA:) and rabaDN also signifies a lateral, or an outward or adjacent, part: (K:) or lateral, or outward or adjacent, parts of a thing: (Ks, S:) also the space immediately pertaining to a mosque: and [the pl.] OarobaADN is explained by El-Karkhee as applied to the quarters, or districts, of a town, or city. (Mgh.) ― -b5- rabaDN also signifies (tropical:) The rope of the [camel's saddle called] raHol, (A, K,) with which the rHl is bound; (A, TA;) one of the OarobaAD, or ropes of the raHol: (S, A:) or the part that is next the ground thereof; (K;) i. e., of the rope of the rHl; (TA;) not what is above the rHl: (K:) accord. to Lth, the part [of the belly] of the camel that is next the ground when he lies down; (L, TA; *) and the belly of the she-camel; and in like manner IAar explains the pl. OarobaADN as meaning the bellies of camels; but Az says that this is a mistake. (TA.) And (assumed tropical:) A girth of a raHol, like the niTaAq [q. v.], which is put upon the flanks of the she-camel, so as to have the haunches behind it, (K, TA,) on either side, having at its two ends two rings, to which are tied the [woven, or plaited, thongs called] OanosaAE: the rHl is bound with it. (TA.) ― -b6- Also (tropical:) The maSaAriyn [or guts, or intestines,] of the belly, that have a winding, or coiled, form; (Lth, A, TA;) such as are in the belly of a sheep or goat: (Lth, TA:) or the folding intestines of beasts: (AHat, TA:) or the guts, bowels, or intestines, into which the food passes from the stomach; syn. OamoEaMCN: (S, K:) or the contents of the belly, (K, TA,) consisting of the maSaAriyn &c., (TA,) except the heart (K, TA) and the lungs. (TA.) (assumed tropical:) The part that comprises the HawaAyaA [or winding, circling, or coiled, guts or intestines]; (IAar, TA;) as also rabiyDN↓ and marobiDN↓ and marobaDN↓: (IAar, K, TA:) some describe the rabaD as below the navel; and the marobaD↓, as beneath the navel and above the pubes. (TA.)

rubuDN c
rubuDN [(tropical:) Holding back, through indolence]. rubuDN Eani AlHaAjaAti, (A, K,) in [some of] the copies of the K, erroneously, EalaI AlHAjAt, (TA,) and AlOasofaAri, (A, TA,) means (tropical:) A man who does not rise to perform needful affairs, (A, K,) and journeys: (A, TA:) or who does not go forth to undertake them. (Lh, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also rabaDN, in three places.

ruboDapN c
ruboDapN, applied to a man, i q. mutarabRiDN↓; (K;) i. e. (tropical:) Remaining stationary, and impotent; (TA;) as also rubaDapN↓. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also riboDapN. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) A portion, (K,) or large portion, (IDrd,) of variyd [i. e. crumbled bread moistened with broth]. (IDrd, K.) ＝ -A3- See also ruboSapN, with the unpointed S.

riboDapN c
riboDapN A mode, or manner, of lying upon the breast: (K, and Har p. 382: [see 1, first signification:]) this is the primary meaning. (Har.) ― -b2- And A place thereof. (Har ibid. [See again rabaDN, first signification.]) ― -b3- See also rabiyDN, in three places. ― -b4- Also (assumed tropical:) A place of slaughter (maqotal) of any party, or company of men, slain in one plot of ground: (Lth, Sgh, K:) erroneously written by Sgh in the TS rabaDap; but in the O correctly. (TA.) [And accord. to the TA, it seems to be also applied to (assumed tropical:) The party so slain.] ＝ -A2- Also The body [of an animal] when lying upon the breast; particularly, of a hare, (A, K,) and of a lamb, (A, TA,) and of a she-goat; and so ruboDapN↓. (TA.) Hence the saying, OataAnaA bivariydK kaOanRahu riboDapu OaronabK [He brought us crumbled bread moistened with broth resembling in size and shape the body of a hare lying upon its breast]. (A, K. *)

daAbRapN Daxomapu AlrRabaDapi c
daAbRapN Daxomapu AlrRabaDapi A beast of which the traces of the place where it has been tied [and app. where it has lain] are large, or wide. (TA.)

rubaDapN c
rubaDapN: see ruboDapN.

rabuwDN c
rabuwDN: see raAbiDN. ― -b2- Applied to a [skin such as is termed] qirobap, (tropical:) Great, or large; hardly, or not at all, to be lifted; so that it remains fixed; or so that it causes him who desires to lift it to remain fixed. (A, TA.) ― -b3- Then, (A,) applied to a tree (Xajarap), meaning (tropical:) Great, or large, (A 'Obeyd, S, A, * K,) and thick, (S,) and, accord. to the K, wide, but [SM says,] I have not seen that any of the leading authorities applies it in this last sense to a tree: (TA:) pl. rubaDN. (K.) ― -b4- Applied to a chain (silosilap), (tropical:) Large, or big, (S, K, TA,) and heavy, cleaving to him upon whom it is put: it is of a measure having an intensive signification, and qualifying alike a masc. and a fem. n. (TA.) ― -b5- Applied to a coat of mail (diroE), (tropical:) Large, or big: (A, TA:) or wide. (K.) ― -b6- And, applied to a town (qaroyap), (assumed tropical:) Populous, (Sgh, K, TA,) and large. (TA.)

rabiyDN c
rabiyDN Sheep, or goats, with their pastors, collected together in their lodging-places; (S, A, K;) as though it were a quasi-pl. n.; as also riboDapN↓ and riboDN↓: (TA:) and hence, (L, TA,) ↓the former of these two, (assumed tropical:) a company of men: (L, K:) and ↓the latter of them, [accord. to the K,] a herd of bulls, or cows, in their lodgingplace; from the author of the book entitled kitaAbu Almuzodawiji mina AllRugaAti, only: (K, * TA:) but what this author says is, that riboDN↓ signifies the lodging-places of bulls or cows [app. with the beasts in them]: and that the primary application of this word (riboDN) and riboDapN↓ is to sheep or goats; and that by a subsequent usage they have been applied to bulls or cows and to men. (TA.) See also raAbiDN. ― -b2- One says also, SabRa QllRehu Ealayohi HumRaI rabiyDFA [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) May God send (lit. pour) upon him a fever that shall cleave to him like as an animal lying upon its breast cleaves to the ground]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also rabaDN, last sentence.

rabRaADN c
rabRaADN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

raAbiDN c
raAbiDN Lying upon his breast; applied to a sheep or goat [&c.]; and so rabuwDN↓ applied to a hare; so too rabRaADN↓ [but app. in an intensive or a frequentative sense] applied to a lion, as is also raAbiDN, and to a man lying on his adversary: (TA:) and [hence] AlrRabRaADu↓ is an appellation of the lion: (K:) the pl. [of raAbiDN] is rubRaDN and rubuwDN: and the phrase Alganami karabiyDapi↓, occurring in a trad., means kaAlganami AlrRubRaDi [Like the sheep, or goats, that are lying upon their breasts]. (TA.) It is said in a prov., kalobN jawRaAlN xayorN mino OasadK raAbiDK or rabaDa [A dog that roams about is better than a lion lying upon his breast or that has laid himself down upon his breast]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, because of his cleaving to the ground,] (tropical:) A sick man. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also the phrase,] Oaronabatuhu raAbiDapN EalaI wajohihi (tropical:) The end of his nose is flat, and spreading upon his face. (A.) ― -b4- AlrRaAbiDaAni is an appellation applied to The Turks and the Abyssinians. (K, TA.) These are meant in the trad. of Mo'áwiyeh, laA taboEavuwA AlrRaAbiDayoni, i. e. Rouse not ye against you the two [peoples] that are remaining quiet as long as they do not pursue you: it is like another trad., in which it is said, AutorukuwA AltRuroka maA tarakuwkumo wadaEuwA AlHabaXapa maA wadaEuwkumo [Leave ye alone the Turks as long as they leave you alone, and let ye alone the Abyssinians as long as they let you alone]. (TA.)

raAbiDapN c
raAbiDapN [as a subst. from raAbiDN, made so by the affix p, An animal lying upon its breast]. One says of a man who kills when he shoots, and more commonly of him who kills when he smites with the [evil] eye, fulaAnN maA taquwmu raAbiDatuhu [Such a one is so effective in his aim that his animal lying upon its breast does not rise]: (ISk, S, TA:) and in like manner, maA taquwmu lahu raAbiDapN: it is a prov. (TA.) ― -b2- It is said in a trad., faQnobaEava lahu waAHidN mina AlrRaAbiDapi [And there rose and went to him one of the raAbDp]: (Lth, A, TA:) AlrRaAbiDapu means (tropical:) certain angels who were sent down [from Paradise] with Adam, (Lth, A, K, TA,) who direct those that err from the right way: (Lth, A, TA:) perhaps (Lth, TA) so called from their remaining upon the earth: (Lth, * A, TA: *) and [so in the K, but correctly “ or, ”] the remainder of the Bearers of Evidence (Hamalapi AlHujRapi [meaning those angels whereof every individual of mankind has two appointed to attend him constantly for the purpose of their bearing evidence of his good and evil deeds, which two are termed in the Kur l. 16 AlmutalaqRiyaAni,]) whereof the earth will never be destitute. (S, K.) ― -b3- And in another trad., respecting the signs of the coming of the resurrection, the Prophet is related to have said that one of those signs will be, that the ruwayobiDap↓ will speak respecting the affairs of the community: (T, TA:) AlrRuwayobiDapu is the dim. of AlrRaAbiDapu (T, K, TA) signifying The pastor of rabiyD [q. v.]; (T, TA;) and means (assumed tropical:) the mean, contemptible man, (S, K,) who speaks respecting the affairs of the community: thus expl. by the Prophet himself: (K: [in the CK, AlnRAqihu is erroneously put for AltRaAfihu:]) or he explained it as meaning (assumed tropical:) the vitious, or wicked, who speaks respecting the affairs of the community: A 'Obeyd compares this trad. with another, in which it is said that one of the signs above mentioned will be, that the pastors of sheep or goats will be the heads of the people: and Az says that AlrwybDp means the pastor of sheep or goats: some say that it means (assumed tropical:) he who abstains, or holds back, from seeking the means of acquiring eminence, or nobility; and AlrRaAbiDapu signifies [the same, or] impotent to attain eminence: in this latter, the p is added to give intensiveness to the signification: and Az thinks it most probable that each of these is applied to the mean man because of his remaining in his house, or tent, and seldom rising and going forth to occupy himself in great affairs. (TA.)

ruwayobiDapN c
ruwayobiDapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

tirobaADN c
tirobaADN i. q. EuSofurN [Safflower, or bastard saffron]. (IAar, K.)

marobaDN c
marobaDN: see rabaDN, last sentence, in two places.

marobiDN c
marobiDN: see rabaDN, first sentence: ― -b2- and the same in the last sentence.

mutarabRiDo c
mutarabRiDo: see ruboDapN.

1 rabaTa c
1. rabaTa, (S, Mgh, &c.,) aor.
rabiTa
and
rabuTa
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. raboTN, (Msb, TA,) He tied, bound, or made fast, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) a thing, (S, Msb, * K, * TA,) and a beast; (Mgh, TA;) and in like manner ArtbT↓ he tied, or bound, a beast with a rope, in order that he might not run away. (TA.) You say, kacaA raOosFA mina AldRawaAbRi fulaAnN yarotabiTu↓ [Such a one ties so many head of beasts: or the verb may here have a different signification, explained below]. (S, TA.) And it is said in a prov., Aisotakoramota faQrobiTo, or, accord. to one relation, Oakoramota, i. e. Thou hast found a generous horse, therefore do thou preserve him; or, as some relate it, faQrotabiTo↓: relating to the duty of preservation. (TA.) See also 3. ― -b2- rabaTa Ealayohi (assumed tropical:) He held back, or drew back, from him, or it; as though he confined, and bound, himself. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b3- rabaTa jaOoXuhu, inf. n. ribaATapN, (assumed tropical:) His heart became strong, and firm, and resolute, (K, * TA,) so that he did not flee on the occasion of fear. (TA. [In the CK, rabaTa jaOoXahu, which would be more properly rendered (tropical:) He strengthened, or fortified, his heart.]) ― -b4- rabaTa licelika AlOamori jaOoXFA (tropical:) He constrained himself to be patient, and confined, or restricted, himself to that thing, or affair. (TA.) ― -b5- rabaTa QllRehu EalaI qalobihi (Msb, K) biAlSRabori (Msb) (tropical:) God inspired him with patience. (Msb, K.) Thus in the Kur [xviii. 13], warabaTonaA EalaI quluwbihimo (tropical:) And we inspired them with patience: (TA:) or strengthened them with patience. (Bd.) And in like manner in [viii. 11 and] xxviii. 9. (TA.)

3 AlmuraAbaTapu c
3. AlmuraAbaTapu signifies, (K, TA,) in its primary acceptation, (TA,) Two [hostile] parties' tying of their horses, each at their frontier, and each in preparation for the other: (K, TA:) and ribaATu Alxayoli and muraAbaTatuhaA signify the same [as above]. (S, TA.) [You say, raAbaTa AlfariyqaAni The two parties tied their horses at their respective frontiers, each in preparation for the other.] And one says, with reference to horses, rabaTa↓, inf. n. raboTN and ribaATN, as well as rAbT, inf. n. muraAbaTapN and ribaATN. (Bd in viii. 62.) Hence, (Sgh, L, K,) rAbT, (Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. ribaATN (S, Mgh, Sgh, L, K) and muraAbaTapN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) He, or it, (an army, Mgh) kept post, or remained, on, or at, the frontier (S, Mgh, Sgh, L, K) of the enemy, (S, Msb, K,) or over against the enemy. (Mgh.) And hence, i. e. from this latter application, (AAF, TA,) rAbT AlOamora, (TK,) inf. n. ribaATN (AAF, K) and muraAbaTapN, (TK,) (assumed tropical:) He kept, or applied himself, constantly, perseveringly, or assiduously, to the thing, or affair. (AAF, K, TK.) It is said in the Kur [ch. iii., last verse], QSobiruwA waSaAbiruwA waraAbiTuwA Be ye patient in endurance of what your religion requires, and vie ye in patience with your enemy, and persevere ye in fighting against your enemy, (Mgh, TA,) and in tying the horses
[at the frontier]: (TA:) or the last of these verbs means keep ye post, or remain ye, on, or at, the frontier [of the enemy]: (Az, K:) or (assumed tropical:) be ye mindful of the times of prayer: or (assumed tropical:) apply yourselves constantly, perseveringly, or assiduously, to prayer: (TA:) or (assumed tropical:) wait ye for prayer after prayer; the doing this being termed by the Prophet ribaATN; (Az, K, TA;) which word, thus used, is an inf. n. of raAbaTotu; or, as some say, a simple subst., meaning, in this case, a thing whereby one is tied from acts of disobedience, and restrained from forbidden deeds. (TA.) [See also SaAbara.]

entry.key: trAbT AlmaMCu fiI makaAni kacaA wakacaA

superEntry.entry:
6 trAbT AlmaMCu fiI makaAni kacaA wakacaA c
6. trAbT AlmaMCu fiI makaAni kacaA wakacaA (tropical:) The water remained in, or did not quit, or go forth from, such and such a place. (TA.)

8 UirotabaTa
8: see 1, in three places. ― -b2- ArtbT farasFA He took a horse for the purpose of tying him, or keeping post, on the enemy's frontier. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A2- [He, or it, became tied, bound, or made fast.] ― -b2- ArtbT fiI AlHaboli He became caught, or entangled, in the rope. (Lh.) ― -b3- AirotibaATN is also explained by AO and Ez-Zejjájee as syn. with AEotlaAqN. (TA.) [Thus, ArtbThu signifies He, or it, attached himself, or itself, or clung, or clave, to him, or it: (see a citation from Lebeed, voce baEoDN:) and app. also (assumed tropical:) he loved him.]

ribaATN c
ribaATN A thing with which one ties, binds, or makes fast, (S, Msb, K,) a skin, (S, Msb,) and a beast, (S,) &c.; (S, Msb;) a rope with which a beast is tied: (Mgh:) pl. rubuTN (S, Msb, K) and ruboTN; (S, TA;) the latter a contraction of the former: (TA:) and mirobaTN↓ and mirobaTapN↓ also signify a thing with which a beast is tied. (K.) It is said in a prov., Uino cahaba EayorN faEayorN fiI AlrRibaATi [If an ass is gone away, an ass is tied to the cord]: relating to contentment with what is present and relinquishment of what is absent. (Mgh.) [See also 3.] ― -b2- [Hence,] used by the vulgar in the sense of OuxocapN, meaning (assumed tropical:) A kind of fascination by which enchantresses withhold their husbands from other women. (TA in art. Axc.) ― -b3- A snare for catching game. (S, Mgh.) You say, qaTaEa AlZRaboIu ribaATahu [The gazelle rent his snare]. (S.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) The heart: (K:) as though the body were tied thereby. (TA.) Hence, (TA in art. qrD,) qaraDa rbaATahu (assumed tropical:) He died: (M and K in that art.:) or he was at the point of death. (K in that art.) And jaMCa fulaAnN waqado qaraDa ribaATahu (tropical:) Such a one came having turned away, or back, harassed, distressed, or fatigued, (S, TA, and AZ and Az in art. qrD,) and at the point of death: (AZ, Az:) or harassed, or distressed, by thirst, or by fatigue: (A in art. qrD:) or in a state of intense thirst and hunger. (M in that art.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) The spirit: as in the saying of El-'Ajjáj, describing a wild bull,
fabaAta wahowa vaAbitu AlrRibaATi
[And he passed the night firm in spirit]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also rabiyTN, (of which it is a pl., or pl. pl.,) in three places. ＝ -A3- A single building of those which are called ribaATaAtN: (S, K:) [a public building for the accommodation of travellers and their beasts; (see bariydN;) an application well known, and mentioned in the TK:] a religious house, or house inhabited by devotees; a dwelling for Soofees; (El-Makreezee's “ Khitat ” ii. 427;) [a hospice, or an asylum for poor Muslim students and others, like zaAwiyapN;] a building for the poor: in this sense post-classical: pl., accord. to analogy, rubuTN and ribaATaAtN. (Msb.)

rabiyTN c
rabiyTN Tied, bound, or made fast; as also marobuwTN↓; (K, TA;) applied to a horse, (Mgh,) or similar beast (daAbRap); as also marobuwTapN↓; (TA;) applied to the former, i. q. marobuwTN; (Mgh;) or maAyurotabaTu [which may perhaps signify the same; but more probably, taken to be tied, or for keeping post, on the enemy's frontier]; (S;) and [in like manner] rabiyTapN, applied to the latter, i. q. maAQrotubiTa: (K:) and rabiyTN applied to a horse also signifies tied and fed in the court of a house: (TA:) pl. rubuTN (TA) and ribaATN↓, (Mgh,) or the latter is a pl. pl., being pl. of rubuTN. (TA.) Alxayoli mino ribaATi↓, in the Kur [viii. 62], means Of horses that are tied; (Bd, Mgh;) ribaATN being of the measure fiEaAlN in the sense of the measure mafoEwlN; or an inf. n. used as a subst., being an inf. n. of rabaTa in the sense of raAbaTa; (Bd;) or it is an inf. n. of raAbaTa; and therefore [when used as an epithet, like any inf. n. so used,] is applied to one as well as to a pl. number; (Ham p. 222;) or pl. of rabiyTo: (Bd, Mgh:) or it means of mares: (Fr, TA:) and ribaATN signifies horses; five thereof, and upwards: (S, K:) or horses, themselves, that are taken to be tied, or for keeping post, on the enemy's frontier. (L.) And you say, lifulaAnK mina Alxayoli ribaATN↓ Such a one has a stud constituting the source of his horses; like as you say tlaAdN. (S.) raAbTapN↓, also, applied to horses, signifies Tied in a town or country or the like: occuring in a trad., in which it is said that upon every horse shall be levied a deenár; but upon the rAbTp, nothing: properly meaning, in this case, caAtu AlrRaboTi; being like raADiyapN in the phrase EiyXapN raADiyapN. (Mgh.) ― -b2- See also raAbiTN. ― -b3- Also, and raAbiTN↓, (assumed tropical:) A monk: one who abstains from worldly pleasures: a sage who restrains himself from worldly things. (K, TA.) [In the L and TA, AlrRabiyTu is also explained, as on the authority of Ez-Zejjájee, as signifying AlcRaAhibu; but this I think a mistranscription, for AlrRaAhibu.] ＝ -A2- (assumed tropical:) Unripe dates soaked [in water]: (S, K:) or (assumed tropical:) fresh ripe dates soaked with water; also called manoquwXN: (Sgh, TA in art. nqX:) or (tropical:) dried dates (A 'Obeyd, IF, A, K) put into jars (jiraAr), (A 'Obeyd, A,) and having water poured upon them, (A 'Obeyd, IF, K,) or moistened with water, in order that they may become like fresh ripe dates: (A:) but perhaps this is an adventitious term: (IF:) some say that it is rabiydN, and not original. (TA.)

rabRaATN c
rabRaATN One who ties bow-strings. (TA.)

raAbiTN c
raAbiTN [act. part. n. of 1]. ― -b2- xalRafa fulaAnN biAlvRagori jayoXFA raAbiTapF [Such a one left behind him on the frontier an army having their horses tied in preparation for the enemy; or keeping post]. (S.) And bibaladi kacaA raAbiTapN mina Alxayoli [In such a town, or country, or the like, is a company of horsemen having their horses tied at the frontier in preparation for the enemy; or keeping post on the frontier: or it may perhaps mean, a number of horses tied: see rabiyTN]. (S.) muraAbiTapN↓ also signifies A company of warriors; or of men warring against an enemy: (Mgh:) or a company of men having their horses tied at the frontier in preparation for the enemy; or keeping post on the frontier; and in like manner [its pl.] muraAbiTaAtN, a company of horsemen having their horses tied &c. (TA.) ― -b3- fulaAnN raAbiTu AljaOoXi, and AljaOoXi rabiyTu↓, (tropical:) Such a one is strong in heart: (S:) or courageous: (K:) as though he tied himself from flight, (S, TA,) and restrained himself. by his boldness and courage. (TA.) ― -b4- nafosN raAbiTN (assumed tropical:) A spirit [still attached to the body, and consequently not doomed, but] having ample power, or liberty, [and] capable of good; syn. waAsiEN OariyDN. (K.) An Arab is related by IAar to have said, AallRehumRa QgofiroliI waAljilodu baAridN waAlnRafosu raAbiTN waAlSRuHufu munotaXirapN waAltRawobapu maqobuwlapN [O God, forgive me while the skin is cool, not heated by fever, and the spirit is yet attached to my body, and is at liberty, and capable of good, and the volumes in which my actions are registered are still expanded, and repentance is accepted]: he meant thereby, while he was in health; before death. (TA.) ― -b5- See also rabiyTN, in two places.

raAbiTapN c
raAbiTapN [fem. of raAbiTN. ― -b2- Also] A tie, or connection, of any kind; syn. EuloqapN [q. v.] and wuSolapN. (TA.) [This meaning of rAbTp is well known, though omitted in the S and K &c. ― -b3- Hence, (assumed tropical:) The copula in a proposition.]

marobiTN c
marobiTN (S, Mgh, K) and marobaTN, (S K,) the former used by him who says OarobuTu, and the latter by him who says OarobuTu, (IB,) The place where a thing, (S,) or where a beast, (Mgh, K,) is tied, bound, or made fast: (S, Mgh, K:) a stable: pl. maraAbiTu. (Har p. 33.) You say, layosa lahu marobiaTu EanozK [He has not so much as, or even, a place where a she-goat is tied]. (S.) Each is a noun of place used in a definite manner; so that you may not say, huwa minRiI marobaTa Alfarasi, like manaATa AlvRurayRaA. (TA: [in which, however, the word mnAT has been inadvertently omitted.]) ― -b2- [Also A place where soldiers tie their horses at the frontier in preparation for the enemy; or where they keep post on the frontier; as also muraAbaTN↓. You say,] AlguzaApu fiI maraAbiTihimo and muraAbaTaAtihimo↓ The warriors are in their places where they tie their horses at the frontier in preparation for the enemy; or where they keep post on the frontier. (TA.)

mirobaTN c
mirobaTN: see ribaATN.

mirobaTapN c
mirobaTapN: see ribaATN. ― -b2- Also A slender plaited thong which is bound over the pad (HaXiyRap, for
which, in the copies of the K, we find erroneously substituted xaXabap, TA,) of the raHol [or camel's saddle]. (K, *, TA.)

marobuwTN c
marobuwTN, and its fem., with p: see rabiyTN.

muraAbaTN c
muraAbaTN: pl. muraAbaTaAtN: see marobiTN, in two places.

muraAbiTapN c
muraAbiTapN: see raAbiTN.

entry.key: huwa murotabiTN kacaA wakacaA mina Alxayoli

superEntry.entry:
huwa murotabiTN kacaA wakacaA mina Alxayoli c
huwa murotabiTN kacaA wakacaA mina Alxayoli He takes, or is taking, such and such [a number] of horses for the purpose of tying them, or keeping post, on the enemy's frontier. (TA.)

maMWN mutaraAbiTN c
maMWN mutaraAbiTN (tropical:) Water remaining in a place, not quitting it, or not going forth from it. (EshSheybánee, * S, * K, * TA.)

1. rabaEahumo, aor.
rabaEa
and

and
rabiEa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. raboEN, (TA,) He took the fourth part of their property, or possessions. (Msb, K.) And (so in the K, but in the Msb “ or, ”) rabaEahumo, (S, Sgh, Msb, K,) aor.
rabaEa
(S, Sgh, Msb) and
rabuEa
and

, (Sgh, Msb,) not, as is implied in the K,
rabiEa
only, (TA,) [or rather, not
rabaEa
only,] inf. n. as above, and rbAEp [most probably rbAEapN] also, (L,) He took the fourth part of their spoil: (S, Sgh, Msb, K:) i. e., of the spoil of an army: this was done in the Time of Ignorance, but El-Islám reduced it to a fifth part; (K;) as is declared in the Kur viii. 42. (TA.) It is said in a trad., Oalamo OajoEaloka tarobaEu watadosaEu, (S, * TA,) mentioned [and explained] in art. dsE, q. v.: the meaning [intended] is, Did I not make thee an obeyed chief? (TA.) ― -b2- And rabaEahumo, (S, Sgh, Msb,) or rabaEa AlvRalaAvapa, (K,) aor.
rabaEa
(S, Sgh, Msb, K) and
rabuEa
and
rabiEa
, (Sgh, Msb, K,) [inf. n., app., raboEN,] He became the fourth of them; (S, Sgh, Msb;) or, the fourth of the three: (TA:) or he made the three to be four by [adding to them] himself. (K.) And rabaEahumo also signifies He made them, by adding himself to them, forty: or, four and forty. (K, * TA.) And He made them (namely thirteen) to be fourteen. (T in art. vlv.) ― -b3- rabaEahu, aor.
rabaEa
, (S, K,) inf. n. rabEN, (S,) He twisted it (namely a bow-string, S, TA, and a rope, or cord, K, TA) of four twists, or strands. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- rabaEat AlUibilu, (S, K,) aor.
rabaEa
, inf. n. raboEN, (TA,) i. q. waradati AlrRiboEa↓; (S, K;) i. e., The camels, having been kept from the water three days [counting two portions of days as one of those days], or four days [counting two portions of days as two days (for the difference is only verbal)], and three [whole] nights, came to the water on the fourth day [counting the day of the next preceding watering as the first]. (K.) [See riboEN, below. Another meaning of this phrase will be found later in the present paragraph.] Hence, OarobaEa AlmariyDa: see 4. (TA.) ― -b2- rabaEato Ealayohi AlHumRaI, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
rabaEa
, inf. n. raboEN; (Msb;) and Ealayohi OarobaEato↓, (S, Msb, K,) and OarobaEatohu↓, but not rabaEatohu; (IAar;) or the phrase used by the Arabs is Elyh AlHmRI OarobaEato↓: (Az, TA:) The fever seized him on one day and left him two days and then came again on the fourth day [counting the day of the next preceding fit as the first], (S, Msb, K,) and so on. (Msb.) And rubiEa, and OorobiEa↓, (S, K,) and OarobaEa↓ is said to be also used in the same sense, (TA,) He had, or was seized by, a quartan fever; a fever of the kind described above. (S, K, TA.) ― -b3- rabaEa said of a horse, He came fourth in the race. (T, M, L, all in art. vlv.) ＝ -A3- rubiEa, said of a man, also signifies He was hit, or hurt, in the OarobaAE, meaning regions, of his head. (TA.) ＝ -A4- rabaEa AlmaTaru AlOaroDa [The rain watered the earth and made it to produce herbage: see rabiyEN]. (TA.) And rubiEati AlOaroDu The land was watered by the rain in the season called rabiyE. (S.) And rubiEuwA They were rained upon by the rain of the season called rabiyE; (K, * TA;) similar to qiyZuwA and SiyfuwA: (TA in art. qyZ:) and in like manner, rubiEati AlUibilu The camels were rained upon by that rain: and marobaEN may be an inf. n. thereof. (Ham p. 425.) ― -b2- Hence, i. e. from rabaEa AlmaTaruAlOaroDa, the phrase, rabaEa Alfarasu EalaI qawaAYimihi (assumed tropical:) The horse sweated in his legs. (TA.) ― -b3- And [hence also,] rabaEahu QllRehu (tropical:) God restored him from a state of poverty to wealth or competence or sufficiency; recovered him from his embarassment or difficulty, or from a state of perdition or destruction. (TA.) ＝ -A5- rabaEa AlrRabiyEu, aor.
rabaEa
, inf. n. rubuwEN, The [season called] rbyE commenced. (TA.) ― -b2- rabaEa biAlmakaAni, (K, TA,) aor.
rabaEa
, inf. n. raboEN, (TA,) in its primary acceptation, signifies He remained, abode, or dwelt, in the place in the [season called] rabiyE; (TA;) as also bihi ArtbE↓. (S, K.) ― -b3- And hence, (TA,) (tropical:) He remained, abode, or dwell, in the place, (K, TA,) in any circumstances, and at any time; (TA;) he took it as his home. (K.) ― -b4- Also He alighted and abode wherever he would, in the place, in abundance of herbage, and pasturage. (K, * TA.) ― -b5- rabaEati AlUibilu, (K,) aor.
rabaEa
, inf. n. raboEN, (TA,) The camels fed by themselves in the pasturage, and ate as they pleased, and drank. (K.) [Another meaning of this phrase has been mentioned before.] ― -b6- rabaEa fiI AlmaMCa He (a man, TA) acted according to his own opinion or judgment, or did what he judged fit, with respect to the water. (K.) ― -b7- rabaEa, (K,) aor.
rabaEa
, inf. n. raboEN, (TA,) said of a man, also signifies He had, or obtained, abundance of herbage (K, TA) [arising] from the [season, or rain, called] rabiyE. (TA.) ― -b8- Also, [app. from rabaEa biAlmakaAni in the second of the senses explained above, and if so, tropical, or doubly tropical,] aor.
rabaEa
, (assumed tropical:) He (a man, ISk, S) paused, (ISk, S, K,) and acted, or behaved, with deliberation or in a leisurely manner, (K,) and withheld himself. (ISk, S, K.) And [hence,] rabaEa Ealayohi, (K,) inf. n. raboEN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He was affectionate, or pitiful, or compassionate, towards him: (K:) or he acted gently towards him. (TA.) And rabaEa Eanohu (K,) inf. n. raboEN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He restrained himself, refrained, abstained, or desisted, from it. (K.) The phrases AirobaEo EalaI nafosika and ArbE ElI ZaloEika (S, K) and ArbE Ealayoka (K) are from rabaEa in the sense of “ he paused, ” &c., (S, K,) as explained by ISk, (S,) [or in one of the senses following that,] meaning (assumed tropical:) Deal thou gently with thyself; moderate thyself; restrain thyself: (S, TA:) or behave thou with deliberation, or in a leisurely manner: or the second of these phrases may mean continue thou notwithstanding thy slight lameness: or it may be from rabaEa AlHajara, [q. v. infrà,] meaning take thou it, or reach it, notwithstanding thy slight lameness. (TA.) The phrase AirobaEiI binafosiki, or EalaI nafosiki, in the trad. of Subey'ah El-Aslameeyeh, accord. to two different relations, admits of two interpretations: one is, (assumed tropical:) Pause thou, and wait for the completion of the EidRap [q. v.] of decease; and this is accord. to the persuasion of those who say that her EdRp is the more remote of the two periods, which is the persuasion of 'Alee and I'Ab: the second is, from rabaEa AlrRjulu signifying “ the man had, or obtained, abundance of herbage, ” and the meaning is, (assumed tropical:) relieve thou thyself, and release thyself from the straitness of the EdRp, and the evil of thy condition; and this is accord. to the persuasion of those who hold that her EdRp is the nearer of the two periods; and hence 'Omar said, “ If she bring forth when her husband is on his bier, meaning, not buried, it is allowable for her to marry. ” (TA.) It is also said, in another trad., laA yarobaEu EalaI ZaloEika mano laA yuHozinuhu Oamoruka, i. e. (assumed tropical:) He will not restrain himself, and be patient with thee, whom thy case does not grieve. (TA.) And it is said in a prov., HadRivi QmoraOapF Hadiyvayoni faUino Oabato faQrobaEo, i. e. (assumed tropical:) Speak thou to a woman twice; and if she refuse, abstain thou: or, accord. to one relation, it is faOarobiEo↓: and accord. to another, faQrobaEohu, i. e., then add; for she is very weak in understanding; if she understand not, then make thou the two speeches to be four: Aboo-Sa'eed says, faUino lamo tafohamo baEoda AlOarobaEapi faQlomirobaEap, i. e., [and if she understand not after the four, then] the stick [is to be used; or, then use thou the stick]: the prov. applies to the hearing and answering in an evil manner. (TA.) You say also, rabaEato EalaI Eaqoli fulaAnK wakasara fiyhaA ribaAEahu, inf. n. ribaAEapN, (tropical:) [app. She behaved in a gentle and coaxing manner so as to get the better of the reason, or understanding, of such a one, and he sold his houses one after another to expend upon her;] i. e., he expended upon her all that he possessed, so that he sold his dwellings. (TA. [The w before ksr is not in the TA; but as it seems to have been dropped by inadvertence, I have supplied it.]) ＝ -A6- rabaEa AlfaSiylu The young camel widened his stepping, and ran; as also ArtbE↓. (TA.) ＝ -A7- rabaEa AlHajara, (S, K,) aor.
rabaEa
, inf. n. raboEN; (TA;) and ArtbEhu↓; (S;) He raised, or lifted, the stone, (S, K, TA,) with the hand; (K, TA;) or carried it; (TA;) for trial of strength. (K.) It is said in a trad., marRa biqawomK yarobaEuwna HajarFA, [He passed by a company of men raising, &c., a stone]; and yarotabiEuwna↓ [signifies the same]; (S;) and yatarabRaEuwna↓. (Z, TA.) ― -b2- rabaEa AlHimola, (S, K,) aor.
rabaEa
, inf. n.
raboEN (TA,) He put the [staff, or small staff, called] mirobaEap beneath the load, and took hold of one end of the former, while another took hold of the other end, and then raised it, (S, K,) with the help of his companion, (K,) upon the camel, (S,) or upon the beast. (K,) [See also 3.] ＝ -A8- rabiEa biEayoXihi He (a man) approved his life; was satisfied, or content, with it. (TA.)

2 rbREhu c
2. rbREhu, inf. n. tarobiyEN, He made it four. (EshSheybánee, K voce waHRadahu.) ― -b2- He made it (a thing) murabRaE; (S, K;) i. e. he made it to have four portions [or sides or faces or angles &c.]: or he made it of the form of a thing having four legs; or of the form of a quadruped. (TA.) ― -b3- fulaAnN yuvalRivu walaA yurababREu Such a one counts three Khaleefehs, [namely, Aboo-Bekr and 'Omar and 'Othmán,] and [does not count a fourth, i. e.,] rejects [' Alee,] the fourth. (TA in art. vlv.) ― -b4- rabRaEato She brought forth her fourth offspring. (TA in art. bkr.) ― -b5- rbRE liQmoraOatihi, or EinodahaA, He remained four nights with his wife: and in like manner the verb is used in relation to any saying or action. (TA voce sabRaEa.) ― -b6- tarobiyEN also signifies [The watering of seed-produce on the fourth day, counting the day of the next preceding watering as the first;] the watering of seed-produce that is [next] after the tavoliyv. (TA.) [You say, rbRE AlzRaroEa He watered the seed-produce on the fourth day, &c.]

3 EaAmalahu muraAbaEapF c
3. EaAmalahu muraAbaEapF, (Ks, S, K,) or AisotaOojarahu muraAbaEapF, and ribaAEAF, (K,) [He bargained with him for work, or he hired him, or took him as a hireling, by, or for, the season called ribayE,] is from AlrRabiyE, (K,) like muXaAharapF (Ks, S, K) from AlXRahoru, (K,) and muSaAyafapF (Ks, S, TA) from AlSRayofu, &c. (TA.) ＝ -A2- muraAbaEapN also signifies The taking hold of the hand of another person beneath a load, and so raising it upon the camel, without a [staff, or small staff, such as is called] mirobaEap. (S, * K, * TA.) You say, raAbaEahu He took hold of his hand &c. (IAar.) [See also 1; last signification but one.]

4 ArbE Alqawomu c
4. ArbE Alqawomu The party of men (three in number, Msb) became four: (S, Msb, K: [but in the last of these, mentioned after another signification with which it is connected by the conjunction Oawo “ or ”]) or, became forty. (TA.) ＝ -A2- OarobaEato Ealayohi AlHumRaI, and OarobaEatohu, and OurobiEa, and OarobaEa: see rabaEato Elyh AlHmRI, [which is from rabaEati AlOibilu,] in three places; and rubiEa, in two places. ― -b2- OagibRuwA fiI EiyaAdapi AlmariyDi waOarobiEuwA, occurring in a trad., [Come ye every third day, and every fourth day, counting the day of the next preceding visit as the first, in visiting the sick; or, which is the same, leave ye him one day, and] leave ye him two days, and come to him on the third day, in visiting the sick; unless he be overcome [by his sickness]: (S, TA:) this is [in like manner] from the water-ing of camels termed riboEN. (TA.) You say also, OarobaEa AlmariyDa He omitted visiting the sick man two days, and came to him on the third; (O, K;) or, as in the L, and in [some of] the copies of the S, on the fourth [if counting the day of the next preceding visit as the first]. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] ArbE Ealayohi AlsRaAYilu The asker, or beggar, asked, or begged, then went away, and then returned. (Ibn-' Abbád, Sgh, K. *) ― -b4- And ArbE biAlomaroOapi He returned to the mujaAmaEap of the woman without langour: (L:) or ArbE alone, said of a man, multum coïvit. (Ibn-' Abbád, K.) ― -b5- And ArbE Alwirodu, (O, K,) i. e. OarobaEati AlUibilu biAlowirodi, (TA,) The camels quickly returned to watering, (O, * K, * TA,) so that they came to water without any appointed time: (TA:) mentioned by A 'Obeyd as written with the pointed g, which is a mistranscription. (L, TA.) ― -b6- And ArbE said of the water of a well, It [returned quickly so that it] became abundant, or copious. (K.) ― -b7- Said of a man, it also signifies waradato Uibiluhu ribogFA↓; (S;) [meaning] He was, or became, one whose camels came in the state in which they are termed rawaAbiE [i. e. being watered on the fourth day, counting the day of the next preceding watering as the first: from rabaEati AlUibilu: whence, likewise, what next follows]. (TA.) ― -b8- ArbE AlUibila He watered the camels in the manner termed riboEFA [i. e. on the fourth day, counting the day of the next preceding watering as the first]. (TA.) ― -b9- This last phrase, also, (K,) or ArbE AlUibila EalaI AlmaMCi, (As,) signifies He sent and left the camels to go to the water whenever they pleased. (As, K. *) [Another signification of the verb thus applied will be found below.] ＝ -A3- ArbE, (inf. n. UirobaAEN, S, Msb) He (a sheep or goat, a bull, a solid-hoofed beast, and a camel,) became what is termed rabaAEK: i. e., he shed the tooth called rabaAEiyap: (S, Msb, K:) it is when they do this that the camel and the horse begin to be strong. (TA.) ＝ -A4- ArbE Alqawomu The people, or company of men, entered the [season called] rabiyE: (S, K:) or [app. a mistake for “ and ”] it has the first of the significations mentioned in this paragraph. (K.) ― -b2- And (so in the S, but in the K “ or ”) The people, or company of men, remained in the place where they had alighted and taken up their abode in the [season called] rabiyE, abstaining from seeking after herbage; (S, K, TA;) the rain having been general, they remained where they were, because of the general fertility, not needing to remove for seeking after herbage. (TA.) [See also rabaEa biAlmakaAni.] ― -b3- And The people, or company of men, came to, or arrived at, land of seed-produce and fruitfulness, and water. (TA.) ― -b4- ArbE Algayovu The rain caused the [herbage called] rabiyE to grow: (TA:) or the rain confined the people in their ribaAE [or dwellings] by reason of its abundance. (Msb.) ― -b5- ArbEt AlOaroDu The earth, or land, produced herbage. (Msb in art. jmd.) ― -b6- ArbE said of a man, (tropical:) He had offspring born to him in the prime of his manhood: (S, TA:) this being likened to the [season called] rabiyE (TA.) ― -b7- ArbE Uibilahu bimakaAni kacaA He pastured his camels in the [season called] rabiyE in such a place. (S.) ― -b8- ArbEt AlnRaAqapu The she-camel's womb was, or became, closed, (Aisotagolaqato raHimuhaA,) so that it did not admit the seminal fluid; (Lth, K;) [perhaps because this commonly takes place in the season called rabiyE, meaning either the spring or the season called rabiyEu AlkalaOi; the usual season of the coupling of camels being winter;] as also ArtbEt↓. (TA.) ＝ -A5- ArbE lahaA biA lkalaAmi He made an abominable request to her; mentioned in the T in art. Ecm; (TA;) meaning saOalahaA AlwaToCa fiI AldRuburi. (TA in art. Ecm.) ＝ -A6- See also a prov. mentioned in the latter part of the first paragraph.

5 trbRE fiI juluwsihi c
5. trbRE fiI juluwsihi (S, K) [He crossed his legs in his sitting; i. e. he sat cross-legged; because a person who does so puts himself in such a posture as to occupy nearly a square space;] contr. of javaA and OaqoEaI. (K.) ＝ -A2- trbRE said of a camel, (S, K,) and of a horse, (TA,) He ate the [herbage called] rabiyE (S, K, TA,) and in consequence became brisk, lively, or sprightly, (TA,) and fat; (K, TA;) and ArtbE↓ signifies the same: (S, K:) or trbREwA and ArtbEwA↓ signify they lighted on, or found, [herbage called] rabiyE: or they lighted on it, or found it, and remained among it: and trbREt AlUibilu bimakaAni kacaA The camels remained, or abode, in such a place. (TA.) You say also, tarabRaEonaA fiI AlHazoni waAlSRamRaAni We pastured upon the herbs, or leguminous plants, during the winter, upon the rugged ground and the hard and stony ground by the side of sand. (TA.) ― -b2- trbREt AlnRaxiylu The palm-trees had their fruit cut off; (TA, and in some copies of the K;) [because this is done in the autumn, which is called AlrRbiyE.] ＝ -A3- See also 1, near the end of the paragraph. ― -b2- [Hence,] trbREt AlnRaAqapu sanaAmFA TawiylFA The she-camel carried a tall hump. (K.)

6 trAbEwA HajarFA c
6. trAbEwA HajarFA [They vied, one with another, in lifting a stone, for trial of strength: see rabaEa AlHajara]. (TA in art. jcw.)

8 ArtbE c
8. ArtbE He (a. camel) beat [the ground] with all his legs, in going along; (S;) and went quickly. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1, near the end of the paragraph. ＝ -A2- He (a man) was of middling stature, neither tall nor short. (S.) ＝ -A3- See also rabaEa biAlmakaAni: ― -b2- and see 5, in two places: ― -b3- and 4, near the end of the paragraph: ＝ -A4- see also rabaEa AlHajara, in two places, near the end of 1. ＝ -A5- ArtbE Oamora Alqawomi He looked for, expected, or awaited, his being made commander, or lord, over the people, or party of men. (TA.)

10 AstrbEhu c
10. AstrbEhu He had power, or ability, for it, to do it, or to bear or endure it: (IAar:) from rabaEa AlHajara. (Az.) ― -b2- [Hence also,] AstrbE said of a camel, He was, or became, strong, lilsRayori for journeying. (ISk, K.) ― -b3- It (sand) became heaped up. (AZ, K.) ― -b4- It (dust) rose; or rose high. (AZ, K.)

raboEN c
raboEN A place where people remain, abide, or dwell, in the [season called] rabiyE; (K, TA;) as also marobaEN↓, (S, Msb, K,) and murotabaEN↓: (K, TA:)
this is the primary signification: (TA:) and hence, (TA,) (tropical:) a place of alighting or abode, (Sh, S, Msb, K, TA,) of a people, or company of men; (Msb;) a settled place of abode; a place of constant residence; a dwelling; a home; whenever and wherever it be; as also marobaEN↓, and murotabaEN↓: (TA:) and (assumed tropical:) a house, wherever it be: (S, Mgh, K:) [in Egypt, a range of distinct lodgings over shops or magazines, separate from the shops or magazines, but generally having one common entrance and staircase:] pl. [of mult.] ribaAEN and rubuwEN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and [of pauc.] OarobaAEN and OarobuEN: (S, Msb, K:) and the pl. of marobaEN↓ is maraAbiEu. (S.) You say, maA OawosaEa raboEa baniI fulaAnK (tropical:) How ample, or spacious, is the place of alighting, or abode, of the sons of such a one!
