(S, TA.) ― -b2- Hence, also, (tropical:) The people of a place of alighting or abode; (Sh, Msb, TA;) the people of a house or tent: (Aboo-Málik, TA:) a company of men or people: (K:) a large number: (IB:) pl. as above: (Msb:) rubuwEN signifies the people of places of alighting or abode: (Sh:) and also tribes. (TA.) You say, Oakavara QllRehu raboEaka (tropical:) May God multiply the people of thy house or tent. (TA.) And humu Alyawoma raboEN (tropical:) They now, or to-day, [are a large number; or] have become many, and have increased. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence, also,] (assumed tropical:) A bier; or a bier with a corpse upon it; syn. naEoXN. (K, TA: [in the CK nafos.]) So in the saying, Hamalotu raboEahu (assumed tropical:) [I bore, or carried, his bier, or his bier with his corpse upon it]. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) The extremity of a mountain. (TA.) [App. because travellers often stop and rest there.] ＝ -A2- Also i. q. raboEapN↓, (L, Msb, K,) which signifies, (S, L, &c.,) as also rabaEapN↓, and marobuwEN↓, (L, Msb, K,) or Alxaloqi marobuwEu↓, (S, Mgh, L,) and murotabiEN↓, (S, L, K,) and murotabaEN↓, (L, K,) and mirobaAEN↓, (K, but this last [says SM] I have not seen in the lexicons, except applied by the author of the “ Mo- heet ” as an epithet to a rope, TA,) applied to a man, (S, L, &c.,) Of middling stature; (Msb;) neither tall nor short; (S, L;) between tall and short: (K:) and so, applied to a woman, raboEapN↓ (S, Mgh, L, Msb, K) and rabaEapN↓, (L, Msb,) though originally applied to a man, like xamosapN &c.: (L:) the pl. of raboEN is raboEuwna: (Fr:) and that of raboEapN↓ is rabaEaAtN, applied to men and to women, (S, Mgh, L, K,) and raboEaAtN also; (IAar, Fr, L, K) the former of these two pls. being anomalous, because a word of the measure faEolapN has not its medial radical movent when it is an epithet, but only when it is a subst. and has not w or y for that radical; (S, O, K;) or the medial radical is movent in this instance because raboEapN is originally a fem. subst. applied to a male and a female, and used as an epithet; (L;) or because it resembles a subst. in its being applied alike to a man and a woman. (Az.)

ruboEN c
ruboEN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and rubuEN↓, (S, Msb, K,) the former a contraction of the latter, (Msb,) [which is the more chaste, but the former is the more common,] A fourth part; (S, Msb, K;) one of four parts; (Mgh;;) as also rabiyEN↓, (Msb, K,) like EaXiyrN; (TA;) and mirobaAEN↓, like miEoXaArN: (Ktr, and S:) or the last signifies, (Msb, K,) or signifies also, (S,) the fourth part of the spoil, which the chief used to take (S, Msb, K) in the Time of Ignorance: (K:) the pl. of ruboEN and rubuEN↓ is OarobaAEN [a pl. of pauc.] (Msb, TA) and rubuwEN [a pl. of mult]: (TA:) and that of rabiyEN↓ is rubuEN (K.) ― -b2- AlrRuboEu AlhaAXimiIRu The same as the SaAE; because the qafiyz is twelve times what is termed manR: but AlrRuboEu AlHajRaAjiIRu is the same as the mudR, which is a quarter of what is termed AlSRaAEu AlHajRaAjiIRu. (Mgh.) [In Egypt, the ruboE is the fourth part of a wuyobap, q. v.] ― -b3- OarobaAEu AlrRaOosi The [four] regions of the head. (TA.)

riboEN c
riboEN The ZimoC [or interval between two water-ings, or keeping from water during that interval,] which is meant in the phrase rabaEati AlUibilu [q. v.]; (S;) a certain ZimoC of camels, respecting which authors differ: (TA:) it is when camels are kept from the water three days [counting two portions of days as one of those days], or four days [counting two portions of days as two days (for the difference is only verbal)], and three [whole] nights, and come to the water on the fourth day [counting the day of the next preceding watering as the first]; (K;) or [in other words] their coming to the water one day, and leaving it two days, and then coming to it on the fourth day; or a period of three [whole] nights and four days [of which the first and last are incomplete]; as is indicated in the K: or, as some say, [but this at variance with common usage,] their being kept from the water four [nights (for the n. of number is here fem.)], and then coming to it on the fifth [day (for the n. of number is here masc.)]. (TA.) You say, waradati AlUibilu AlrRiboEa: see rabaEati AlUibilu. (S, K.) And waradato Uibiluhu riboEFA: see 4. (S.) And Oaworada AlUibila riboEFA i. q. OarobaEa AlUibila [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Also, for sayoru riboEK, A journey in which the camels are watered only on the first and fourth days.] ― -b3- [In like manner,] with respect to fever, it signifies The seizing on one day and leaving two days and then coming again on the fourth day [counting the day of the next preceding fit as the first]. (S, K.) [The fever is termed] HumRaI AlrRiboEi [The quartan fever;] the fever that occurs on one day and intermits two days and then comes again on the fourth, and so on. (Msb.) And you say, jaMCatohu AlHumRaI riboEFA, i. q. rabaEato Ealayohi AlHumRaI [q. v.]. (K.) ― -b4- Also The fourth young one, or offspring. (A in art. vlv.)

rubaEa c
rubaEa: see rubaAEu. ＝ -A2- rubaEN A young camel brought forth in the [season called] rabiyE [here meaning autumn], which is the beginning of the breedingtime: (S, Msb, K:) so called because he widens his stepping, and runs: [see 1, near the end of the paragraph:] (TA:) fem. with p: pl. masc. ribaAEN [a pl. of mult.] and OarobaAEN [a pl. of pauc.]; (S, Msb, K;) both irreg.; for accord. to the rule given by Sb, the pl. should be riboEaAnN [like SrodaAnN pl. of SaradN]: (TA:) pl. fem. rubaEaAtN (S, Msb, K, TA [in the CK, erroneously, raboEAtN]) and ribaAEN. (K.) Hence the saying, maA lahu hubaEN walaA rubaEN He has not a young camel brought forth in the end of the breeding-time nor one brought forth in the beginning thereof. (S, TA.) [See another ex. voce bulaEN.] ― -b2- [Hence, also,] AlrRubaEi (assumed tropical:) A very small star in the midst of the EawaAYic, which are in the head of AltRinRiyn [or Draco]. (Kzw.)

rubuEN c
rubuEN: see ruboEN, in two places.

raboEapN c
raboEapN: see raboEN, last signification, in three places. ＝ -A2- [A small round basket, covered with leather, in which perfumes are kept by him who sells them;] the juwnap of the EaTRaAr; (S, Mgh, K;) which is a sulayolap covered with leather: (Mgh:) or a four-sided vessel, like the juwnap: said by El-Isbahánee to be so called because originally having four TaAqaAt [app. meaning compartments, one above another, for different kinds of perfume]; or because having four legs. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, app., A chest in which the volumes of a copy of the Kur-án are kept; (Sgh, K;) called raboEapu AlmuSoHafi: (Mgh:) but thus applied, it is post-classical, (Sgh, K,) belonging to the conventional language of the people of Baghdád. (Sgh.) ― -b3- Its application to A household utensil proper for women requires consideration. (Mgh.)

ribEapN c
ribEapN The beasts' collecting of themselves together in the [season called] rabiyE: [whence] a a country, or region, is said to be TayRibu AlrRiboEapi [good for the beasts' collecting of themselves together &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] tarakonaAhumo EalaI riboEatihimo We left them in their former, or first, or original, and right, or good, state, or condition. (TA.) rabaAEapN↓, also, and ribaAEapN↓, signify An affair, a business, or a concern, in which one continues occupied; or a case, a state, or a condition, in which one abides, or continues; (K, TA;) meaning a former, or first, affair, &c.; (TA;) and only relating to a good state or condition: (Yaakoob, K:) or one's way, course, mode, or manner, of acting, or conduct, or the like: (K:) or one's right, or good, state, or condition, (K, TA,) in which he has been before: (TA:) or his [tribe such as is termed] qabiylap: or [the portion thereof which is termed] his faxica: (K:) or humo EalaI ribaAEatihimo↓, (S, K,) and rabaAEatihimo↓, and rabaAEihimo↓, and rabaEaAtihimo↓, and rabiEaAtihimo↓, and ribaEatihimo↓, (K,) means They are in their right, or good, state, or condition: (K, TA:) or they are occupied in their affair, or business, or concern, in which they were occupied before; or they are in their case, or state, or condition, in which they were before: (S, K:) or ElI rabaEaAtihimo↓, (S, K,) and rabiEaAtihimo↓, (Fr, S, K,) signifies in their right, or good, state, or condition, and in their former, or first, case; or in their right, or good, state, or condition, and occupied in their former, or first, affair, or business, or concern: (S:) or it means in their places of abode. (Th, K.) You
say also, gayoru maAfiI baniI fulaAnK mano yaDobiTu ribaAEatahu↓ fulaAnK i. e. [There is not among the sons of such a one he who manages thoroughly, or soundly,] his case, or affair, or business, or concern, in which he is occupied [except such a one]. (S.) And [hence,] qawomihi huwa EalaI ribaAEapi↓ and huwa cuw ribaAEapi qawomihi He is the chief of his people. (Ham p. 313. [See also ribaAEapN below.])

rabaEapN c
rabaEapN A quick pace of a camel, in which he goes along beating the ground with his legs: (TA:) or the most vehement running: (K:) or the most vehement running of camels: (S and K:) or a kind of running of camels which is not vehement. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also raboEN, last signification, in two places. ― -b2- See also its pl., rabaEaAt, voce riboEapN, in two places.

rabiEapN c
rabiEapN: see its pl., rabiEaAt, voce riboEapN, in two places.

ribaEapN c
ribaEapN: see riboEapN.

riboEiIRN c
riboEiIRN Of, or relating to, the rabiyE; (S, Msb, K;) i. e., the season so called; [and the rain, and the herbage, so called;] a rel. n. irregularly formed. (Msb.) ― -b2- Born in the [season called] rabiyE; applied to a young camel: born in the beginning of the breeding-time; [which means the same;] so applied. (TA.) ― -b3- And hence, (TA,) (tropical:) A son born in the prime [or spring-time] of his father's manhood; (S, * TA;) because the rbyE is the beginning, and the most approved part, of the breeding-time: (TA:) pl. riboEiyRuwna. (S, TA.) Saad Ibn-Málik says, (TA,)
UinRa baniIRa SiboyapN SayofiyRuwno
OafolaHa mano kaAna lahu riboEiyRuwno
[Verily my sons are boys born in the summer of my age: happy is he who has sons born in the spring-time of his manhood.] (S, TA.) ― -b4- A palm-tree (siboTN, i. e. naxolapN,) of which the fruit ripens in the end of the summer, or hot season; AHn says, because then is the time of the [rain called] wasomiIR. (TA.) ― -b5- The Arabs say, SarafaAnapN riboEiyRaho tuSoramu biAlSRayofi watuWokalu biAlXRatiyRapo [A hard kind of date that would ripen in the season called rabiyE (meaning autumn) that is cut in the summer and eaten in the winter-season]. (TA.) ― -b6- naAqapN riboEiyRapN A she-camel that brings forth [in the season called rabiyE,] before others. (TA.) ― -b7- riboEiyRapN [used as a subst., or as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant, for miyrapN riboEiyRapN,] signifies The miyrap [or corn brought for provision, or the bringing thereof,] in the beginning of winter: (S, K:) or the miyrap of the [season called] rabiyE; which is the first myrp; next after. which is the SayofiyRap; and next after this, the dafaYiyRap; and next after this, the ramaDiyRap. (TA.) [See art. myr.] ― -b8- Also, the same, [used in like manner, for EiyrN riboEiyRapN,] Camels that bring provision of corn in the [season called] rabiyE; or, which means the same, in the beginning of the year: pl. rabaAEiIRu. (TA.) ― -b9- And [used in the same manner, for gazowapN riboEiyRapN,] A warring, or warring and plundering, expedition in the [season called] rabiyE. (TA.) ― -b10- riboEiIRN also signifies (tropical:) The first, or beginning, or former part, of anything; for instance, of youthfulness, or the prime of manhood; and of glory: and riboEiyRapN likewise, the beginning of breeding, and of summer. (TA.) ― -b11- riboEiIRu AlTRiEaAni (assumed tropical:) The sharpest kind of thrusting, or piercing. (Th, TA.)

riboEiyRapN c
riboEiyRapN fem. of riboEiIRN: [and also used as a subst., or as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates: see the latter word, in several places.]

rabaAEN c
rabaAEN: see an ex. in the phrase humo EalaI rabaAEihimo, voce riboEapN. ＝ -A2- rabaAEK, (S, Msb, K,) like vamaAnK (S, K) and yamaAnK [in the CK vamaAnN and vamaAnK] and XanaAHK and [pls. like] jawaArK, which are the only words of this form, (K,) and rabaAEN, (Kr, K,) accus. of the former rabaAEiyFA, (S, Msb, K,) and fem. rabaAEiyapN, (S, K,) Shedding its tooth called the rabaAEiyap, q. v.; applied to the sheep or goat in the fourth year, and to the bull and cow and the solid-hoofed animal in the fifth year, and to the camel in the seventh year: (S, Msb, K:) [see 4:] pl. [of pauc.] OarobaAEN (Az, K) and [of mult.] rubuEN (Az, S, Msb, K) and ruboEN, (Th, Az, K,) but the former is the more common, (Az,) and rubaEN (IAar, K) and riboEaAnN (S, Msb, K) and ribaAEN and rabaAEiyaAtN. (K.) You say, rakibotu birocawonFA rabaAEiyFA [I rode a hackney shedding his rabaAEiyap, or in his fifth year]. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- Hence, HarobN rabaAEiyapN (assumed tropical:) Vehement and youthful war. (TA.)

rubaAEu c
rubaAEu [Four and four: four and four together: or four at a time and four at a time:] is a deviation from the original form, (S, K,) or OarobaEapN OarobaEapN; for which reason, [and, accord. to general opinion, because it is at the same time an epithet, (see vulaAvu,)] it is imperfectly decl.: (K:) but the dim. is rubayRiEN↓, perfectly decl. (S voce vulaAvu, q. v.) [See exs. voce vulaAvu.] In the Kur iv. 3, El-Aamash read warubaEa↓ instead of warubaAEa. (IJ, K.)

rabuwEN c
rabuwEN A she-camel that yields four OaqodaAH [pl. of qadaHN] of milk. (IAar.) ＝ -A2- See also AlOarobiEaMCu.

rabiyEN c
rabiyEN: see ruboEN, in two places. ＝ -A2- It has also a twofold application; to months and to seasons: and it has a twofold application to months; denoting Two months, (S, Msb, K,) [next] after SafarN; (S, K;) and they say, (Msb,) one should only say, in speaking of them, Xahoru rabiyEK AlOawRalu and Xahoru rabiyEK AlMxirN; (S, Msb, K;) [but in the margin of the copy of the S which I have here followed, I find it stated that in the handwriting of the author the former is Xhr rbyEi AlAwl (with a single kesreh, and with no syll. sign to AlAwl); and in another copy of the S I find Xhru rbyE AlAwli and Xahru rabyE AlMxir;] with the addition of Xhr: but it is allowable to say also Xahoru rabiyEi AlOawRali and Xahoru rabiyEi AlMxiri: the word Xhr is necessarily added in order to discriminate between the months thus called and the season called rbyE: Az says, the Arabs mention all the months without the word Xhr except the two months of rbyE and the month of ramaDaAn: and they say also XahoraA rabiyEK and OaXohuru rabiyEK and Xuhuwru rabiyEK: (Msb:) these months were thus called because, when they received this name, they occurred in the season when the earth produced herbage. (Msb in art. jmd.) It has a twofold application also to seasons; AlrRabiyEu AlOawRalu being The season in which the truffles and the blossoms come, (S, Msb, K,) and this is [also called] rabiyEu AlkalaOi [the rabeea of the herbage, properly called the spring of Arabia]; (S;) and AlrRabiyEu AlvRaAniI The season in which fruits ripen; (S, Msb, K;) [also called rabiyEu AlvRimaAri;] but some people call this AlrRabiyEu AlOawRalu; (S, TA;) and the season which follows the winter, and in which the truffles and the blossoms come, they call AlrRabiyEu AlvRaAniI; but all of them agree that the xariyf [or autumn] is called AlrRabiyEu: AHn says, the two divisions of the winter [by which he means the half-year commencing at the autumnal equinox] are called rabiyEaAni; the former being rabiyEu AlmaMCi waAlOamoTaAr i [the rabeea of the water and the rains, in which the rain called AlwasomiIR, which is termed the first of the rains, commences]; and the second being rabiyEu AlnRabaAti [or rabiyEu AlkalaOi the rabeea of the herbage], because the herbage therein attains to its last stage: and he adds, that rabiyEN is applied by the Arabs to the whole winter, [meaning, again, the half-year commencing at the autumnal equinox,] because of the moisture, or rain: (TA:) or the year consists of six seasons; (so in the K; but in the S, “ and I heard Abu-l-Ghowth say, the Arabs make the year to be six seasons; ”) two months thereof are called AlrRabiyEu AlOawRalu; and two months, SayofN; and two months, qayoZN; (S, K;) and two months, rbyE AlvAnI, (so in a copy of the S,) or rabiyEN AlvRAnI, (so in another copy of the S, [but in the margin of this latter, I find it stated that in the handwriting of the author it is rbyEu AlvAnI, without tenween,]) or AlrRabiyEu AlvRaAniI; (K;) and two months, xariyfN; and two months, XitaMCN. (S, K.) Az relates, with respect to the seasons and divisions of the year, on the authority of Aboo-Yahyà Ibn-Kibáseh, who possessed very great knowledge thereof, that the year consists of four seasons; namely, AlrRabiyEu AlOawRalu, which the vulgar call Alxariyfu [The autumn]; then AlXRitaMCu [the winter]; then AlSRayofu, which is AlrRabiyEu AlMxiru [or AlvRaAniI, i. e. the spring]; then AlqayoZu [the summer, or hot season]: all this is what the Arabs in the desert say: the rbyE which is with the Persians the xryf, he says, commences on the third of Oayoluwl [September O. S.]; and the XitaMC, on the third of kaAnuwn AlOawRal [December O. S.]; and the Syf
which is with the Persians the rbyE. on the fifth of McaAr [March O. S.]; and the qyZ which is with the Persians the Syf, on the fourth of HaziyraAn [June O. S.]: and Aboo-Yahyà adds, the rbyE of the people of El-' Irák agrees with the rbyE of the Persians, which is after the XtAC [or winter], and which is the season of the flowers, or roses, and is the most temperate of the seasons: the people of El-' Irák, he says, have rain in all the winter, and have abundance of herbage in the xryf, which the Arabs call AlrbyE AlAwRl: and Az says, the quarter of the xryf is called xryf because the fruits are gathered therein; and the Arabs call it rbyE because the first rain [which is called AlwasomiIR] falls therein. (TA.) The pl. of rbyE is OarobiEapN [a pl. of pauc.] and OarobiEaMCu [a pl. of mult.] (S, Msb, K) and ribaAEN; (AHn, K;) or the first of these is pl. of rbyE AlklO (Fr, Yaakoob, S, Msb, K) and of the rbyE of the months; (Fr, Msb;) but the second is pl. of rbyE in the sense of jadowalN, to be explained below. (Fr, Yaakoob, S, Msb, K.) Hence the phrase in a supplication, mentioned in a trad., AallRehumRa QjoEali AlquroMna rabiyEa qalobiI [O God, make Thou the Kur-án to be the life, or ease, of my heart]; because the heart of man becomes lively, or at ease, in the season called rabiyE. (TA.) Hence also, (TA,) Oabuw AlrRabiyEi The hudohud [or hoopoe]; (K;) because it appears with the [season called] rbyE. (TA.) [See also, respecting the seasons &c., the word zamanN.] ― -b2- Also The rain in the [season called] rabyE [as meaning the half-year commencing at the autumnal equinox, (which includes what is really the spring of Arabia, called “ the rabeea of the herbage, ”) accord. to a statement of AHn cited above, and accord. to what is stated on the authority of AZ voce nawoCN]: (S, K:) or [only, accord. to some,] the rain which is after the wasomiIR, and after which is [that called] the Sayof, and then the Hamiym: or, accord. to AHn, rain whenever it comes: Az says, I have heard the Arabs call thus the first rain falling upon the earth in the days of the xariyf [or autumn]: (TA:) the pl. [of pauc.] is OarobiEapN and [of mult.] ribaAEN. (AHn, TA.) [See also, respecting the rains, the word zamanN.] ― -b3- Also Herbage; green herbage which the beasts eat; (TA;) [properly] the herbage that is produced by the first rain in the quarter which is called the rabiyE, and which is commonly called the xariyf [or autumn], (Msb in art. zmn,) [continuing its growth during the winter-quarter, which is also called the rabiyE, and which includes, as stated above, what is really the spring of Arabia, called “ the rabeea of the herbage, ” wherein, as AHn says, the herbage attains to its last stage: it seems generally to mean the spring-herbage, which is earlier or later in different latitudes:] pl. OaroibEapN. (TA.) [Hence,] a poet says,
yadaAka yadN rabiyEu AlnRaAsi fiyhaA
wafiI AlOuxoraI AlXRuhuwru mina AlHaraAmi
meaning (assumed tropical:) [Thy two hands are such that] one hand has in it the means of the plentiful subsistence of mankind, [and in the other are the sacred months, i. e.] in the other is [that which causes] security, and safeguard, and the preservation of what is to be regarded as sacred and inviolable. (TA.) [Compare Proverbs iii. 16.] ― -b4- Also (assumed tropical:) A rivulet, or streamlet; (Msb, K;) i. q. jadowalN: (S, Msb, K:) or i. q. nahorN: (Mgh:) or nahorN SagiyrN: (Har p. 402:) (tropical:) a rivulet, or streamlet, that runs to palmtrees: and rabiyEu AlsRaAqiI, a subst prefixed to its epithet, occurring in a trad., (assumed tropical:) the river [or rivulet] that waters seed-produce: (TA:) pl. OarobiEaMCu (Fr, Yaakoob, S, Msb, K) and riboEaAnN. (TA.) A poet says, describing one drinking much,
fuwhu rabiyEN wakafRuhu qadaHN
(assumed tropical:) His mouth is a river [and his hand is a bowl]. (TA.) ― -b5- Also A share, or portion, of water for [irrigating] land, (IDrd, K, TA,) whatever it be: or, as some say, a share, or portion, thereof for the quarter of a day or night; but this is not of valid authority. (TA.) You say, lifulaAnK mino hecaA AlmaMCi rabiyEN, (K, TA,) or, as in some copies of the K, fiI, instead of mino, i. e. To such a one belongs a share, or portion, of this water [for irrigating land]. (TA.) ― -b6- The dim. of rabiyEN is rubayRiEN↓. (Msb.)

rubayRiEN c
rubayRiEN: see rubaAEN: ＝ -A2- and see also rabiyEN, last sentence.

rabaAEapN c
rabaAEapN: see riboEapN, in two places.

ribaAEapN c
ribaAEapN: see riboEapN, in four places. ― -b2- It also signifies A kind of HamaAlap [meaning obligation, or responsibility, that must be discharged, or performed, taken upon himself by a person for others; and here, particularly, such as is taken upon himself by the head, or chief, of a people]. (S, K.) You say, huwa EalaI ribaAEapi qawomihi, [properly He is over the affairs of his people, as indicated above, voce riboEapN, last sentence,] meaning He is the head, or chief, of his people. (TA.) Abu-l- Kásim El-Isbahánee says, ribaAEapN is metaphorically used to signify (tropical:) The being a head, or chief; or the office of head, or chief; in consideration of the taking of the mirobaAE [or fourth part of the spoil, which was the share of the chief]: and hence one says, laAyuqiymu ribaAEapa Alqawomi gayoru fulaAnK (tropical:) [None will act vigorously in the office of head, or chief, of the people, except such a one]. (TA.)

rabiyEapN c
rabiyEapN A stone that is raised, or lifted, (S, K, TA,) for trial of strength: (K, TA:) applied only to a stone. (Az, TA.) ＝ -A2- A helmet of iron. (Lth, S, K.) ＝ -A3- A meadow; or a garden; syn. rawoDapN. (IAar, K.) ＝ -A4- A [leathern water-bag, such as is called] mazaAdap. (K.) ― -b2- A kind of receptacle for perfume and the like; syn. EatiydapN, q. v. (K.)

rubaAEiIRN c
rubaAEiIRN A boy four spans (OaXobaAr) in height. (S and Msb voce xumaAsiIRN, q. v.) It is also applied to a camel, like subaAEiIRN; [app. meaning Four cubits in height:] fem. with p. (TA in art. sbE.) ― -b2- [Also A word composed of four letters, radical only, or radical and augmentative.]

rabaAEiyapN c
rabaAEiyapN The tooth that is between the vaniyRap [or central incisor] and the naAb; (S, Msb, K;) i. e. each of the four teeth which are next to the vanaAyaA, (Mgh, * TA,) pertaining to man and to others: (TA:) pl. rabaAEiyaAtN: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) a man has, above, [two teeth called] vaniyRataAni, and [two called] rabaAEiyataAni, after them, and [two called] naAbaAni, and [two called] DaAHikaAni, and six OaroHaMC, on each side [three], and [two teeth called] naAjicaAni; and the like below: (As, TA:) and the solid-hoofed animal has, after the vanaAyaA, four rabaAEiyaAt, and four qawaAriH, and four OanoyaAb, and eight OaDoraAs. (AZ, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also fem. of rabaAEK [q. v.]. (S, K.)

rabRaAEN c
rabRaAEN One who often buys, or sells, ribaAE, meaning houses, or places of abode. (IAar, K.)

raAbiEN c
raAbiEN [act. part. n. of rabaEa]. ― -b2- The chief who used to take the fourth part of the spoil, in the Time of Ignorance. (Ham p. 336.) ― -b3- huwa raAbiEu OarobaEapK He is [the fourth of four, or] one of four. (TA.) ― -b4- [raAbiEa EaXara and raAbiEapa EaXorapa, the former masc. and the latter fem., meaning Fourteenth, are subject to the same rules as vaAliva EaXara and its fem., expl. in art. vlv, q. v.] ― -b5- UibilN rawaAbiEu [Camels coming to water, or being watered, on the fourth day, counting the day of the next preceding watering as the first: pl. of raAbiEapN]: from rabaEati AlUibilu, meaning waradati AlrRiboEa. (S, K.) In like manner, also, rawaAbEu is applied, metaphorically, to birds of the kind called qaTFA, as an epithet denoting their coming to water, by El- 'Ajjáj. (TA.) ＝ -A2- rabiyEN raAbiEN A fruitful, or plentiful, rbyE [meaning the season so called]. (ISk, K.) ― -b2- One does not say yawomN raAbiEN like as one says yawomN qaAYiZN &c., because there is no corresponding verb, like qaAZa, &c., for such a verb would have no meaning of heat nor of cold. (IB.) ＝ -A3- huwa raAbiEN EalaI HaAlihi He is abiding, or continuing, in his state, or condition. (TA.)

OarobaEN c
OarobaEN: see OarobaEapN. ＝ -A2- hiIa OarobaEuhunRa laqaAHFA She is the quickest of them in conceiving, or becoming pregnant. (Th.)

OarobaEapN c
OarobaEapN [Four;] a masc. n. of number; fem. OarobaEN↓. (S, K.) [Respecting a peculiar pronunciation of the people of El-Hijáz, and a case in which ArbEp is imperfectly decl., see valaAvapN. See also sitRapN.] ― -b2- cawaAtu AlOarobaEi The quadrupeds. (The Lexicons passim.) ― -b3- jaMCato EayonaAhu biOarobaEapK (tropical:) His two eyes shed tears running from their four sides: or it means, accord. to Z, he came weeping most vehemently. (TA.) [See another ex. voce vamaAniyapN.] ― -b4- OarobaEapa EaXara [indecl. in every case, meaning Fourteen,] is pronounced by some of the Arabs OarobaEapa EoXara: and [the fem.] OarobaEa EaXorapa, thus in the dial. of El-Hijáz [and of most of the Arabs], is pronounced OarobaEa EaXirapa in the dial. of Nejd. (S in art. EXr.)

AlOarobiEaMCu c
AlOarobiEaMCu, [also written without tenween when not rendered determinate by the article or otherwise accord. to most authorities, who make it fem., but with tenween when indeterminate accord. to those who make it masc.,] and AlOarobaEaMCu, (As, S, Msb, K,) the latter on the authority of some of the BenooAsad, (S, Msb,) and AlOarobuEaMCu, (As, Msb, K,) which is a form of the word seldom used, (Msb,) and AlUirobiEaMCu, and AlUirobaEaMCu, the last two mentioned by IHsh, the first of all the most chaste, (MF,) but it is the only sing. word of its measure, (El- Kutabee, Msb,) except OaromidaMCu, (AZ, O,) the name of A certain day; (S, Msb, K;) [namely Wednesday;] the fourth day of the week; (L;) as also AlrRabuwEu↓; but this is post-classical: (TA:) the dual of OarobiEaMC is OarobiEaAwaAni; (L;) and the pl. is OarobiEaAwaAtN, (S, L,) [accord. to those who make the sing. fem.;] or the dual is OarobiEaMCaAni, and the pl. is OarobiEaMCaAtN; (K;) thus says Aboo-Jukhádib, regarding the noun as masc.: (Fr:) Aboo-Ziyád used to say, maDaI AlOarobiEaMCu bimaA fiyhi [Wednesday passed with what (occurred) in it], making it sing. and masc. [because he meant thereby yawomu AlOarobiEaMCu]; but Abu-l-Jarráh used to say, maDati AlOarobiEaMCu bimaA fiyhinRa, making it fem. and pl., and employing it like a n. of number: (Lh:) Th is related to have mentioned OaraAbiyEu as a pl. of AlOarobiEaMCu; but ISd says, I am not sure of this. (TA.) The word has no dim. (Sb, S in art. Ams.)

OarobaEuwna c
OarobaEuwna [Forty;] a certain number, (TA,) after valaAvuwna. (S, K.) ― -b2- [Also Fortieth.]

OarobiEaAwiIRN c
OarobiEaAwiIRN One who fasts alone on the OarobiEaMC [or Wednesday]. (IAar.)

marobaEN c
marobaEN; see raboEN in three places.

murobaEN c
murobaEN, applied to a camel, [That is watered on the fourth day, counting the day of the next preceding watering as the first: (see 4:) and] that is brought to the water at any time. (TA.) ― -b2- See also marobuwEN.

murobiEN c
murobiEN: ― -b2- see marobuwEN. ＝ -A2- Applied to rain, (S, Msb, TA,) That comes in the [season called] rabiyE: [in the Ham p. 425, written marobaE:] or that induces the people to remain in their abodes and not to seek after herbage: (TA:) or that confines the people in their ribaAE [or dwellings] by reason of its abundance: (Msb:) or that causes the [herbage called] rabiyE to grow: (TA:) or that causes the growth of that in which the camels may pasture at pleasure. (S.) ― -b2- With p, applied to land (OaroDN), Abounding with [the herbage called] rabiyE; as also mirobaAEN↓. (TA.) ― -b3- Without p, applied to a she-camel, (As, S, K,) That brings forth in the [season called] rabiyE: (S, K:) or that has her young one with her; (As, S, K;) the young one being called rubaEN: (As, S:) as also mirobaAEN↓: (As, TA:) or the latter signifies one that usually brings forth in the [season called] rabiyE: (S, K:) or that brings forth in the beginning of the breeding-time: (As, S, K:) or that is early, or before others, in becoming pregnant: (TA:) and the former, so applied, signifies also one whose womb is, or becomes, closed, [app. in the season called rabiyE, (see 4,)] so that it does not admit the seminal fluid. (TA.) ― -b4- Applied to a man, (tropical:) Having offspring born to him in the prime of his manhood. (TA.) [See 4] ＝ -A3- Also The sail of a full ship: (AA, K:) that of an empty ship is called ruwmiIRN. (AA, TA.)

mirobaEN c
mirobaEN: see mirobaEapN.

murabRaEN c
murabRaEN (S, K,) Having four portions [or sides or faces or angles &c.; generally meaning either square or quadrilateral]: or of the form of a thing having four legs; or of the form of a quadruped. (TA.) [See also muvalRavN.] ― -b2- murabRaEu AlHaAjibayoni (assumed tropical:) A man whose eyebrows have much hair; as though he had four eyebrows. (TA.) ― -b3- murabRaEN Aljabohapi [Having a square forehead; meaning] (tropical:) a slave. (TA.)

OaroDN marobaEapN c
OaroDN marobaEapN A land containing, or having, yaraAbiyE [or jerboas]; (S, K;) as also OaroDN murotabiEN↓. (TA.)

mirobaEapN c
mirobaEapN A staff, (K,) or small staff, (S,) of which two men take hold of the two ends in order to raise a load (S, K) and put it upon the back of the camel, (S,) or upon the beast; (K;) as also mirobaEN↓: (K:) which latter is also expl. as signifying a piece of wood with which a thing is taken. (TA.) [See 1, last signification but one.]

mirobaAEN c
mirobaAEN: see ruboEN: ＝ -A2- and marobuwEN: ＝ -A3- and raboEN. ＝ -A4- Rain that comes in the beginning of the [season called] rabiyE: [an epithet used in this sense as a subst.:] pl. maraAbiyEu. (S, * K, * TA, * [in which only the pl. is mentioned,] and EM p. 140.) Hence, maraAbiyEu AlnRujuwmi, as used in a verse of Lebeed cited in the first paragraph of art. rzq; by the nujuwm being meant the OanowaMC; (S;) i. e. the Mansions of the Moon [which by their rising or setting at dawn were supposed to bring rain or wind or heat or cold]. (EM ubi suprà.) ― -b2- Applied to a place, That produces herbage in the beginning of the [season called] rabiyE. (K, TA.) ― -b3- Applied to land (OaroDN): see murobiEN. ― -b4- Applied to a she-camel: see murobiEN.

marobuwEN c
marobuwEN Twisted of four twists, or strands; (S, TA;) applied to a rope, (TA,) as also mirobaAEN↓, (Ibn-' Abbád, TA,) and to a bow-string, and a bridle. (S, TA.) ― -b2- Applied to a spear, Four cubits in length: (TA:) or neither long nor short; (S, TA;) and in like manner applied to a man: see raboEN, in two places: (S, Mgh, L, &c.:) and [hence its pl.] maraAbiyEu, applied to horses, compact in make. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, applied to a man, Having a fever which seizes him on one day and leaves him two days and then comes again on the fourth day [counting the day of the next preceding fit as the first; i. e. having, or seized by, a quartan fever]; as also murobaEN↓; (S, K;) and murobiEN↓ is said to be used in the same sense; but the Arabs say murobaEN. (Az, TA.) ＝ -A3- OaroDN marobuwEapF, and XajarN marobuwEN, Land, and trees, watered by the rain in the season called rabiyE. (S, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] marobuwEN, applied to a man, also signifies (tropical:) Restored from a state of poverty to wealth or competence or sufficiency; recovered from his embarassment or difficulty, or from a state of perdition or destruction. (TA.)

maraAbiyEu c
maraAbiyEu, pl. of marobuwEN [q. v.]: ＝ -A2- and pl. of mirobaAEN [q. v.].

murotabaEN c
murotabaEN: see raboEN, in three places.

murotabiEN c
murotabiEN, applied to a beast, That has pastured upon the [herbage called] rabiyE, and become fat, and brisk, lively, or sprightly. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also raboEN: ＝ -A3- and see OaroDN marobaEapN.

jalasa mutarabRiEFA c
jalasa mutarabRiEFA He sat cross-legged; i. q. tarabRaEa fiI juluwsihi. (TA.)

musotarobiEN XayoYFA c
musotarobiEN XayoYFA Having power, or ability, for, or to do, a thing; as, for instance, war, or battle; (IAar;) or to bear, or endure, a thing; (IAar, Sgh;) as when relating to an envier, meaning his envy. (Sgh.) You say also rajulN musotarobiEN biEamalihi A man who is able by himself to execute his work, having power, or strength, to do it, and very patient. (K.)

yarobuwEN c
yarobuwEN, in which the I is augmentative, (Kr, S, Msb,) because there is not in the language of the Arabs any word of the measure faEoluwlN, (Kr, S,) except what is extr., such as SaEofuwqN, (K,) which is a foreign word [introduced into their language], (S in art. SEfq,) [The jerboa;] a certain wellknown beast; (K;) a small beast like the faOorap [or rat], but longer in the tail and ears, and of which the hind legs are longer than the fore-legs, the reverse of what is the case in the zaraAfap [or giraffe]; called by the vulgar jarobuwE; (Msb;) a rat (faOorap) of which the burrow has four entrances; Az says, it is a small beast larger than the jurac, [q. v.; but in the L, in art. jrc, the reverse of this is said;] and the name is applied alike to the male and the female: (TA:) [Forskål (“ Descr. Animalium, ” p. iv.,) terms it mus jaculus: see the questions appended to Niebuhr's “ Descr. de l' Arabie, ” p. 177:] pl. yaraAbiyEu. (S, Msb.) [See cuw AlrRumayoHi, voce rumoHN.] ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) AlyarobuwEu also signifies laHomapu Almatoni (tropical:) [The portion of flesh and sinew next the back-bone, on either side]; (S * K;) as being likened to the fOarp [thus called]: (TA:) or this is with damm [AlyurobuwEu]: (K:) or the yaraAbiyEu of the maton are its portions of flesh; (T, S, K;) and the word has no sing.: (K:) Az says, I have not heard any sing. thereof. (TA.)

AljaAru AlyarobuwEiIRu c
AljaAru AlyarobuwEiIRu The neighbour that is variable in his actions [like the jerboa, which is noted for having recourse to various expedients, in the formation of its burrow, &c., to avoid capture]; like AljaAru AlbaraAqiXiIRu. (IAar, TA in art. jwr.)

1 rabaqahu c
1. rabaqahu, aor.
rabuqa
(S, Msb, K) and
rabaqa
, (S, K,) inf. n. raboqN, (JK, S, Msb,) He put his head (i. e. the head of a kid, S, K, or of a lamb, K, or of a sheep or goat, Msb) into the riboqop, (S, K,) or into the riboq: (Msb:) or, accord. to the M, he made fast, or bound or tied fast or firmly, him, or it, in the riboqap: (TA:) or he made fast, or bound or tied fast or firmly, his (a sheep's or goat's) neck with the riboq, or cord: (JK:) and rbRqhu↓, inf. n. tarobiyqN, he made fast, or bound or tied fast or firmly, him, or it, in the ribaAq [pl. of riboqN or of riboqapN]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] rabaqahu fiI AlOamori, (Msb, K,) aor.
rabuqa
, inf. n. raboqN, (Msb,) (assumed tropical:) He made him to fall into the thing, or affair. (Msb, K.) ― -b3- raboqN also signifies The act of making fast; or binding, or tying, fast, or firmly; and so riboqN; (K;) each as an inf. n. of rabaqahu. (TK.)

2 rbRq c
2. rbRq [He prepared the OarobaAq, pl. of riboqN]. One says, ramRaditi AlDRaOonu farabRqo rabRqo, i.e. [The ewes have secreted milk in their udders: therefore] prepare thou the OarobaAq: prepare thou the ArbAq: for they will bring forth soon: (S, K:) because they [begin to] secrete milk in their udders EalaI raOosi Alwaladi [i. e. at the time of bringing forth, or when about to produce the young]. (S.) It is not thus in the case of she-goats: therefore, (S,) in the case of these, one says ranRqo, with n, (S, K,) meaning “ wait thou: ” because they show sings of pregnancy in the state of their udders, and bring forth after some length of time: and [in the case of these] one says also ramRiqo, with m. (K. [See arts. rmq and rnq.]) ― -b2- One also says, rabRaqa OavonaMCa AlHaboli, meaning He made loops in the middle of the rope to put upon the necks of the young lambs or kids. (T in art. vnI.) ― -b3- See also 1. ― -b4- rabRaqotu AlkalaAma I interlarded, or embel-lished, the speech, or discourse, with falsehood; as also ramRaqotuhu; syn. lafRaqotu bayonahu; (JK;) [or lafRaqotuhu; for] tarobiyqu AlkalaAmi signifies talofiyquhu; (Ibn-'Abbád, K;) as also taromiyquhu. (Ibn-'Abbád.)

5 tarabRaqotu AlXRaIoCa c
5. tarabRaqotu AlXRaIoCa, (JK,) or trbRqthu mino EunuqiI, (Ibn-'Abbád, K,) (tropical:) I hung the thing upon my neck. (JK, Ibn-'Abbád, K, TA.)

8 Artbq c
8. Artbq He (a kid) had his head put into the riboqap. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Artbq fiI HibaAlatiI He (a gazelle, S, K) became caught in my snare. (Lh, JK, S, K.) ― -b3- And Artbqtu fiI HibaAlatihi (tropical:) I became caught in [the snare of] his deceit. (TA.) ― -b4- And Artbq fiI AlOamori (assumed tropical:) He fell into the thing, or affair. (Msb, K.) ＝ -A2- Airotabaqotuhu linafosiI I tied, bound, or made fast, him, or it, for myself. (TA.)

riboqN c
riboqN A cord having in it a number of loops wherewith lambs, or kids, are tied, or made fast; any one of which loops is termed riboqapN↓ (S, Msb, K) and raboqapN↓: (K:) or a cord which is doubled in the form of a ring, into which is put the head of a sheep or goat, and which is then tied, or made fast: so, says Az, I have heard from the Arabs of the desert of Benoo-Temeem: (TA:) pl. [of mult.] ribaAqN (S, Msb, K) and ribaqN and [of pauc.] OarobaAqN. (S, K.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) xalaEa AlUisolaAmi mino Eunuqihi riboqapa↓, (S, Msb, TA,) occurring in a trad., (S,) (tropical:) He cast off the tie of El-Islám, (Msb, TA,) with which he had bound himself, (TA,) [from his neck.] (Msb, TA. [See also xalaEa.]) And lakumu AlEahodu maA lamo taOokuluwA AlrRibaAqa, also occurring in a trad., (S,) meaning (tropical:) [The covenant is yours] as long as ye sever not the tie with which ye are bound; this tie being likened to the riboq upon the necks of lambs or kids; and the severing thereof, to the beast's eating its riboq, and severing it; for thereby the beast becomes free from the tie. (TA.) And in a trad. of 'Omar, HujRuwA biAlcRurRiyRapi laA taOokuluwA OarozaAqahaA watacaruwA OarobaAqahaA fiI OaEonaAqihaA [Perform ye the pilgrimage with the women: devour not their means of subsistence, while ye leave their ties upon their necks]: he likens the obligations imposed upon them to ArbAq. (TA.) One says also, HalRa riboqatahu↓, meaning (tropical:) He removed from him his anxiety: (K, TA:) and so qaTaEa riboqatahu↓. (TA.)

raboqapN c
raboqapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

riboqapN c
riboqapN: see riboqN, in four places. ― -b2- Also A thing woven of black wool, of the width of the tikRap [or band of the drawers or trowsers], in which is a red stripe of dyed wool: its extremities are tied together, and then it is hung upon the neck [or shoulder] of a boy, so that one of his arms comes forth from it like as when a man puts forth one of his arms from the suspensory of the sword: the Arabs of the desert hang the ribaq [pl. of riboqapN] upon the necks of their boys only as a preservative from the [evil] eye. (T, TA.)

ribiqRaAnN c
ribiqRaAnN and ribiqRaAnapN Evil in disposition: applied to a man; and in like manner to a woman: mentioned by As and in the K in art. Ebq [where, in some copies, it is written raboqaAnu]. (TA.)

rabiyqN c
rabiyqN, (TA,) or rabiyqapN, (S, Msb, K,) applied to a lamb or kid (bahomap), (ISk, S, K,) or to a sheep or goat (XaAp), (Msb, TA,) Having its head put into the riboqap; (ISk, S, Msb, K, TA;) as also marobuwqapN↓ (ISk, JK, S, Msb, K) and murabRaqapN↓. (JK, TA.)

OumRu AlrRubayoqi c
OumRu AlrRubayoqi Calamity, or misfortune: (JK, S, K:) whence the prov., jaMCanaA biOmRi AlrRubayoqi EalaI Ourayoqi, (TA,) meaning He brought us a great calamity, or misfortune: (K in art. Arq:) As says that the Arabs assert it to have been said by a man who saw the ghool upon a dusky white camel (jamal Oaworaq); (S in that art., and TA;) Ourayoq being the dim. of Oaworaq: (K in that art.:) or AmR Alrbyq is a name of war, or battle: or the viper: (JK, Ibn-'Abbád, TA:) this last signification is held to be correct by Z, because, he says, the viper is short, and when it folds itself it resembles the ribaq (TA.)

tirobiyqN c
tirobiyqN A cord with which a ewe, or goat, is tied (K, TA) by the neck. (TA.)

murobiqN c
murobiqN i. q. muToriqN [Silent: or lowering the eyes, looking towards the ground: &c.]. (JK, TA.)

murabRaqapN c
murabRaqapN: see rabiyqN. ＝ -A2- Also, [or xubozapN murabRaqapN,] A cake of bread, or one baked in ashes, into which fat has been put; syn. xubozapN muXaHRamapN. (K.)

marobuwqapN c
marobuwqapN: see rabiyqN

1 rabakahu c
1. rabakahu, (S, K,) [like labakahu,] aor.
rabuka
, inf. n. rabokN, (S, TA,) He mixed, or mingled, it. (S, K.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. n., (S, TA,) He made it good, or qualified it properly, namely, variyd [i. e. crumbled, or broken, bread, moistened with broth], (S, K, TA,) and mixed it with some other thing. (TA.) ― -b3- And rabaka rabiykapF, (K, TA,) [and rabaka alone,] aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He made rbykp [q. v.]. (K.) garovaAnu faQrobukuwA lahu [He is hungry, therefore make ye rbykp for him], (S, K,) or, as IDrd relates it, fiQbokuluwA lahu [i. e., “ therefore mix ye bakaAlap (a certain food) for him ”], (TA,) is a prov.; (S, K;) the origin of which was this: (S:) a certain Arab of the desert, (S, K,) said in the O to be Ibn-Lisán-el-Hommarah, (TA,) came to his family, or wife, (S, K,) from a journey, (TA,) and was congratulated with the annunciation that a boy was born to him: whereupon he said, “ What shall I do with him? Shall I eat him or shall I drink him? ” so his wife said, garovaAnu faQrobukuwA lahu: and when he was satiated, he said, “ How are the infant and his mother? ” (S, K:) the saying means, “ he is hungry, therefore prepare ye for him food, that his hunger may be allayed, and then congratulate him with the annunciation of the birth of the child: ” and IDrd says that it is applied to the case of him whose anxiety has departed and who has become unoccupied so that he may attend to other things. (TA.) ― -b4- And rabaka fulaAnFA, (Lth, K,) inf. n. as above, (Lth, TA,) He threw such a one into mire. (Lth, K.) ＝ -A2- rabika: see 8.

8 Artbk c
8. Artbk It was, or became, mixed, or mingled. (S, K.) ― -b2- He (a man) stuck fast in mire. (Lth, K, * TA.) And (tropical:) He (an animal of the chase) struggled in the snare. (K, TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) He (a man, TA) was, or became, in the condition of one whose affair, or case, is confused to him; as also rabika↓, aor.
rabaka
, (K, TA,) inf. n. rabakN. (TA.) And Artbk fiI AlOamori (assumed tropical:) He (a man) was, or became, entangled in the affair, and could hardly, or not at all, escape from it. (S.) And Artbk fiI AlhalakaAti (tropical:) He fell into cases of perdition, and could hardly, or not at all, escape from them. (TA from a trad. of 'Alee.) ― -b4- Artbk fiI kalaAmihi (tropical:) He reiterated in his speech, by reason of an impediment, or inability to say what he would; syn. tataEotaEa. (K, TA.)

11 ArbAkR raOoyuhu Ealayohi c
11. ArbAkR raOoyuhu Ealayohi, (K, * TA,) inf. n. AirobiykaAkN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) His opinion, or judgment, was, or became, confused to him. (Ibn-'Abbád, K, TA.) ― -b2- And ArbAkR Eani AlOamori (assumed tropical:) He (a man) paused, or stopped, from the affair. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

rabikN c
rabikN (assumed tropical:) A man (IDrd) weak in art, artifice,
cunning, ingenuity, or skill, in the management of affairs: (IDrd, K:) a possessive epithet. (IDrd.)

rubakN c
rubakN and ribakRN↓ and rabiykN↓ (assumed tropical:) A man in a state of confusion in respect of his affair, or case: (K:) the last is a possessive epithet. (TA.)

ribakRu c
ribakRu: see what next precedes.

rabuwku c
rabuwku Dates kneaded with clarified butter and [the preparation of dried curd called] OaqiT, after which it is eaten. (Sgh, TA.) [See also rabiykapu.]

rabiykN c
rabiykN: see the next paragraph: ― -b2- and see also rubakN.

rabiykapN c
rabiykapN (S, K) and rabiykN↓ (K) Dates with clarified butter and [the preparation of dried curd called] OaqiT, (S, K,) kneaded together, and then eaten; [like rabuwkN, as explained above;] and, as ISk says, sometimes water is poured upon it, and it is drunk: or, he adds, accord. to Ghaneeyeh Umm-El-Homáris, OaqiT and dates and clarified butter, made soft, not like what is called Hayos: (S:) or (accord. to Ed-Dubeyreeyeh, S) flour and OaqiT (S, K) ground, and then (S) mixed with clarified butter (S, K) and rubR [or inspissated juice]: (S:) or dates and OaqiT (K, TA) kneaded without clarified butter: (TA:) or inspissated juice (rubR, K, TA) mixed (TA) with flour or sawiyq [i. e. meal of parched barley]: (K, TA:) or a cooked compound of dates and wheat. (K.) ― -b2- Also the former word, A portion of fresh butter from which the milk will not separate, (Sgh, K,) so that it is mixed [therewith]. (Sgh.) ― -b3- And Water mixed with mud. (Sgh, K.) ― -b4- [Hence,] ramaAhu biAlrRabiykapi i. e. (assumed tropical:) [He accused him of] a thing that stuck fast upon him. (TA.)

1 rabaluwA c
1. rabaluwA, (T, S, M, K,) aor.
rabula
(T, S, K) and
rabila
, (K,) inf. n. rubuwlN, (T,) They multiplied; became many in number: (T, M, K:) they increased and multiplied: (S:) and their children multiplied, and their cattle, or property. (M, K.) See also 8. ― -b2- rabalato She (a woman) was, or became, fleshy; (M;) and so trbRlt↓. (S.) And you say also laHomuhu trbRl↓ [app. meaning His flesh was, or became, abundant]. (M in art. rObl.) ＝ -A2- rabalati AlOaroDu, (IDrd, M, K,) inf. n. rabolu; (IDrd, TA;) and Arblt↓; (IDrd, M, K;) The land produced rabol [q. v.]: (IDrd, K:) or abounded with rabol: (M:) or the latter signifies it ceased not to have in it rabol. (T.) And rabalati AlmaraAEiI The pasturages abounded with herbage. (T.) [See also 5.]

4 Oarobala
4: see above. ＝ -A2- Also Arbl He was, or became, wicked, crafty, or cunning; [like raOobala; see art. rObl;] and lay in wait for the purpose of doing evil, or mischief. (TA.)

5 tarabRala
5: see 1, in two places. ＝ -A2- trbRilt AlOaroDu The land had trees such as are termed rabol; i. e. breaking forth with green leaves, without rain, when the season had become cool to them, and the summer had retired: (As, A'Obeyd, T:) or the land became green after dryness, at the advent of autumn. (S.) And trbRl AlXRajaru The trees put forth leaves such as are termed rabol. (M, K. *) ― -b2- trbRl also signifies He ate rabol; (Ibn-'Abbád, K;) said of a gazelle. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.) And They (a company of men) pastured their cattle upon rabol. (M, K.) And He prosecuted a search after rabol. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b3- Also He took, captured, caught, snared, or trapped; or sought to take &c.; game, or wild animals, or the like. (M, K.) You say, xarajuwA yatarabRaluwna They went forth to take &c., or seeking to take &c., game &c. (M.)

8 Artbl maAluhu c
8. Artbl maAluhu His cattle, or property, multiplied; (Ibn-'Abbád, K;) like rabala↓. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.)

Q. Q. 2 tarayobala c
Q. Q. 2. tarayobala, originally taraOobala: see the latter, in art. rObl.

rabolN c
rabolN Fat, and soft, or supple: [perhaps, in this sense, a contraction, by poetic license, of rabilN:] an epithet applied to a man. (Ham p. 630.) ＝ -A2- Also A sort of trees which, when the season has become cool to them, and the summer has retired, break forth with green leaves, without rain: (As, A'Obeyd, T, S:) or certain sorts of trees that break forth [with leaves] in the end of the hot season, after the drying up, by reason of the coolness of the night, without rain: (K:) accord. to Aboo-Ziyád, a plant, or herbage, that scarcely, or never, grows but after the ground has dried up; as also rayRiHapN and xilofapN and ribRapN: (TA:) [and] leaves that break forth in the end of the hot season, after the drying up, by reason of the coolness of the night, without rain: (M:) pl. rubuwlN. (S, M, K.)

rabalN c
rabalN A certain plant, intensely green, abounding at Bulbeys [a town in the eastern province of Lower Egypt, commonly called Belbeys or Bilbeys,] (K) and its neighbourhood: (TA:) two drachms thereof are an antidote for the bite of the viper. (K.)

rabilN c
rabilN, applied to a man, Fleshy: (A'Obeyd, S, TA:) or fleshy and fat. (TA. [See also rabiylN.]) And [in like manner the fem.] rabilapN, as also matarabRilapN↓, Fleshy (M, K) and fat; applied to a woman. (M.) And rabilapN applied to a woman signifies also Large in the rabalaAt [pl. of rabalapN, q. v.]; (Lth, T, M, K;) as also rabolaOCu↓: (M, K:) or both signify rafogaMCu; (O, K; [in the CK, erroneously, raqoEACu;]) i. e. narrow in the OaroqaAg [or groins, or inguinal creases, or the like], as expl. in the 'Eyn: (TA:) or you say rabolaMCu rafogaMCu, meaning [app., as seems to be implied in the context, large in the rabalaAt and] narrow in the OarofaAg. (Lth, T.)

rabolapN c
rabolapN: see what next follows.

rabalapN c
rabalapN (AZ, T, S, M, K) and rabolapN↓, (S, M, K,) the former said by As to be the more chaste, (S,) The inner part of the thigh; (AZ, T, S, M, K;) i. e., of each thigh, of a man: (AZ, T:) or any large portion of flesh: (M, K:) or the parts (M, K) of the inner side of the thigh [or of each thigh] (M) that surround the udder (M, K) and the vulva: (K:) pl. rabalaAtN; (AZ, T, S, M, K;) which Th explains as meaning the roots of the thighs. (M, TA.)

rabaAlN c
rabaAlN Fleshiness and fatness. (IAar, T. [Thus in two copies of the T, without p. See also rabaAlapN.])

rabiylN c
rabiylN Fleshy; applied to a man: (T:) or corpulent, large in body, or big-bodied; so applied: (TA:) and with p fat; applied to a woman. (TT, as from the T; but wanting in a copy of the T. [See also rabilN.]) ― -b2- [Also] A thief who goes on a hostile, or hostile and plundering, expedition, (M, K,) against a party, (M,) by himself. (M, K. [See also riybaAlN; and see Q. 2 in art. rObl.])

rabaAlapN c
rabaAlapN Fleshiness, (A'Obeyd, S, M, K,) and some add and fatness. (TA. [See also rabaAlN.]) ― -b2- bYorN caAtu rabaAlapK A well of which the water is wholesome and fattening to the drinkers. (Ham p. 367.)

rabiylapN c
rabiylapN Fatness; (S, M, K;) and ease, or ampleness of the circumstances, or plentifulness and pleasantness, or softness or delicateness, of life: (M, K: [in the CK, AlnRiEomapu is erroneously put for AlnRaEomapN:]) or the primary signification is softness, or suppleness, and fatness. (Ham p. 367.)

rayobalN c
rayobalN, applied to a woman, Soft, or tender: (O, TA:) or fleshy: (TA:) or soft, or tender, and fleshy. (K. [In the CK, AlnRAqpu is erroneously put for AlnRaAEimapu.])

raAbilapN c
raAbilapN The flesh of the shoulder-blade. (Ibn- 'Abbád, TA.)

riybaAlN c
riybaAlN The lion; (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, K;). as also riYobaAlN, (S,) which is the original form, (M in art. rObl, q. v.,) derived from raOobalapN signifying “ wickedness, ” &c.: (TA in that art.:) Aboo-Sa'eed says that it is allowable to omit the C [and substitute for it I]: (S:) [and Az says,] thus I have heard it pronounced by the Arabs, without C: (T:) or, accord. to Skr, it signifies a fleshy and young lion: (TA:) the pl. is rayaAbilapN (T, TA) and rayaAbiylu: (S, TA:) and hence rayaAbiylu AlEarabi, meaning Those, of the Arabs, who used to go on hostile, or hostile and plundering, expeditions, upon their feet [and alone]. (TA. [See also rabiylN; and see Q. 2 in art. rObl.]) It is also applied as an epithet to a wolf: and to a thief: (T, S:) accord. to Lth, because of their boldness: (T:) or as meaning Malignant, guileful, or crafty. (TA.) Applied to an old, or elderly, man, (M, K,) it means Advanced in age, (M,) or weak, or feeble. (K.) Also One who is the only offspring of his mother. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.) ― -b2- Applied to herbage, Tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, and tall. (Fr, T, K.)

riybaAlapN c
riybaAlapN A cunning, or crafty, lion. (TA.)

rabolu Oarobalu c
rabolu Oarobalu means, (M, K,) app., (M,) Good, or
excellent, rabol. (M, K. *) ＝ -A2- rabolaMCu [its fem.]: see rabilN.

OaroDN mirobaAlN c
OaroDN mirobaAlN A land that ceases not to have in it rabol: (T:) or a land abounding therewith. (M, K.)

mutarabRilapN c
mutarabRilapN, applied to a woman: see rabilN.

1 rabaA c
1. rabaA, aor. yarobuw, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. rabowN, (so in copies of the S, [in one of my copies of the S not mentioned,]) or rubuwRN and rabaMCN, (M, K, TA,) the latter erroneously written in [some of] the copies of the K ribaMC, (TA,) It (a thing, T, S, Msb) increased, or augmented. (T, S, M, Msb, K.) Said, in this sense, of property: (Mgh:) or, said of property, It increased by usury. (M, TA.) liyarobuwa fiI OamowaAli QlnRaAsi falaA yarobuw wamaA Mtayotumo↓ Einoda QllRehi, in the Kur [xxx. 38], (T, Bd,) means And what ye give of forbidden addition in commercial dealing, [i. e. of usury,] (Bd,) or what ye give of anything for the sake of receiving more in return, (Zj, T, Bd,) and this is not forbidden accord. to most of the expositions, though there is no recompense [from God] for him who exceeds what he has received, (Zj, T,) in order that it may increase the possessions of men, (T, * Bd,) it shall not increase with God, (T, Bd,) nor will He bless it: (Bd:) some (namely, the people of El-Hijáz, T, or Náfi' and Yaakoob, Bd) read liturobuwA↓, (T, Bd,) meaning, in order that ye may increase [the property of men], or in order that ye may have forbidden addition [or usury therein]. (Bd.) ― -b2- Also It became high. (Msb, * TA.) ― -b3- rabaA, aor. as above; and rabiIa, aor. yarobaI; said of a child, He grew up. (Msb.) You say, rabawotu fiI baniI fulaAnK, (S,) or fiI Hajorihi, inf. n. rubuwRN (M, K, TA) and rubowN, (M, TA,) with damm, (TA,) this latter on the authority of Lh, (M, TA,) accord. to the K rabowN, with fet-h, but correctly with damm; (TA;) and rabiytu, (S, M, TA,) in the copies of the K erroneously written rabayotu, (TA,) inf. n. rabaMCK and rubiIRN; (M, K, TA; [the latter, accord. to the CK, rabiIRN, which is a mistranscription;]) I grew up [among the sons of such a one, or in his care and protection]. (S, M, K.) ― -b4- rabati AlOaroDu The ground [being rained upon] became large, and swelled. (M, TA.) In the Kur xxii. 5 and xli. 39, for warabato, some read warabaOatN: the former means and [becomes large, and swells; or] increases: the latter means “ and rises. ” (T. [See art. rbO.]) ― -b5- rabaA AlsRawiyqu, inf. n. rubuwRN, The swyq [or meal of parched barley] had water poured upon it, and in consequence swelled: (M, TA:) in the copies of the K, rabaA AlsRawiyqa, expl. as meaning he poured water on the swyq, and it consequently swelled. (TA.) ― -b6- rabaA said of a horse, (S, K,) aor. yarobuw, (TA,) inf. n. rabowN, (K,) He became swollen, or inflated, from running, or from fear, or fright (S, K.) ― -b7- He was, or became, affected with what is termed rabowN; (S, M, K;) i. e. he was, or became, out of breath; his breath became interrupted by reason of fatigue or running &c.; or he panted, or breathed shortly or uninterruptedly; syn. Ainobahara: (TA:) and so trbRI↓; for you say, TalabonaA AlSRayoda HatRaI tarabRayonaA, i. e. [We pursued the chase until] we became out of breath; &c.; syn. buhironaA. (M.) ― -b8- See also 4. ＝ -A2- rabawotu AlrRaAbiyapa I ascended, or mounted, upon the hill, or elevated ground. (S, K.)

2 rabRayotuhu c
2. rabRayotuhu, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. tarobiyapN, (S, K,) I reared him, fostered him, or brought him up; (M, Msb;) namely, a child: (Msb:) I fed, or nourished, him, or it; (S, Mgh, K;) namely, a child, (Mgh,) or anything of what grows, or increases, such as a child, and seedproduce, and the like; (S;) as also tarabRayotuhu↓: (Mgh, K:) the former is said to be originally rababotuhu. (Er-Rághib, TA. [See 1 in art. rb, in two places.]) [Thus rabRayotu signifies I reared, or cultivated, plants or trees.] And rbRI is said of earth, or soil, meaning It fostered plants or herbage. (L in art. rXH, &c.) And yunawRiru walaA yurabRiI is said of a tree [as meaning It produces blossoms, but does not mature its produce]. (AHn, M and L in art. mZ.) ― -b2- rabRayotu AlOotorujRa biEasalK (tropical:) [I preserved the citron with honey], and Alwaroda bisukRarK [the roses with sugar: like rabRabotuhu]. (TA.) ― -b3- rabRayotu Eano xinaAqihi [in the CK xunAqih, which I think a mistranscription,] (tropical:) I removed, or eased, [his cord with which he was being strangled; app. meaning, his straitness;] (K;) mentioned by Z. (TA.) [See a similar phrase in art. rxw, conj. 4.]

3 rAbAhu c
3. rAbAhu, (K in art. mjr, as syn. of maAjarahu,) inf. n. muraAbaApN, (TA ibid.,) [He practised usury, or the like, with him: used in this sense in the present day.] ― -b2- And raAbayotuhu, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) I treated him with gentleness, or blandishment; soothed, coaxed, wheedled, or cajoled, him. (K, * TA.)

4 Oarobayotuhu c
4. Oarobayotuhu (in [some of] the copies of the K, erroneously, Artbyth, TA) I increased, or augmented, it. (M, K, TA.) Hence, in the Kur [ii. 277], wayurobiI AlSRadaqaAti (M, TA) And He will increase, or augment, alms-deeds; (Jel;) will multiply the recompense thereof, (Bd, Jel,) and bless them. (Bd.) See also an ex. in the first paragraph. ＝ -A2- Oarobayotu I took more than I gave. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ArbI, said of a man, signifies [particularly] He engaged in, or entered upon, AlrRibaA [i. e. the practising, or taking, of usury or the like; he practised, or took, usury or the like; as also rabaA↓, aor. rabowN; for] UirobaMCN and rabowN, as inf. ns., both signify, in Pers., ribaA xwurodano. (KL. [In the TA, rabaA, said of a man, is expl. by the words HSl fI rbwp: but I think that the right reading must be HaSRala fiI ribFwA, or mino ribFwA; and the meaning, He acquired in the practice of usury or the like, or he acquired of usury or the like.]) See, again, an ex. in the first paragraph. ― -b3- ArbI EalaI Alxamosayna, (M, Msb,) wanaHowihaA, (M,) He exceeded [the age of fifty, and the like]. (M, Msb.) ― -b4- [OarobaI said of the Earofaj, in a copy of the S, in art rqT is a mistranscription for OadobaI, with dál.]

5 trbRI c
5. trbRI, said of a child, (Mgh, Msb,) He was, or became, fed, or nourished; (Mgh;) or reared, fostered, or brought up. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, near the end of the paragraph. ＝ -A3- tarabRayotuhu: see 2.

rabowN c
rabowN: see rubowapN. ― -b2- Also A company (IAar, T, K, TA) of men: (IAar, T, TA:) pl. OarobaMCu: (IAar, T, K, TA:) and ribowapN↓ likewise signifies a company; or, as some say, ten thousand; as also rubRapN; (M, TA;) or the former of these two words, (i. e. rbwp,) accord. to the A, signifies a great company of men, such as ten thousand. (TA.) It is said in the K that ribowapN↓ signifies Ten thousand dirhems; as also rubapN↓: but in this assertion are errors; for the former of these two words signifies as explained in the foregoing sentence; and the latter of them is with teshdeed, belonging to art. rb, and signifies a company [or great company] of men. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, (T, S, M, K, TA,) and rabowapN↓, (M, TA,) The state of being out of breath; interruption of the breath by reason of fatigue or running &c.: or a panting, or breathing shortly or uninterruptedly: syn. buhorN, (T, M, TA,) and AinobihaArN: (TA:) or a loud (lit. high) breathing: (S:) and a state of inflation of the jawof [or chest]. (M, TA.) [The former word is now often used as signifying Asthma.]

ribFA c
ribFA, (T, M, Msb, K,) or ribFwA↓, (S, Mgh,) [for it is often thus written, and generally thus in the copies of the Kur-án,] with the short A accord. to the pronunciation best known, (Msb,) [which implies that it is also pronounced ribaMCN↓,] An excess, and an addition: (Msb:) an addition over and above the principal sum [that is lent or expended]: but in the law it signifies an addition obtained in a particular manner: (Er-Rághib, TA:) [i. e. usury, and the like; meaning both unlawful, and lawful, interest or profit; and the practice of taking such interest or profit:] it is in lending, (Zj, T,) or in buying and selling, (S,) and in giving: and is of two kinds; unlawful, and lawful: the unlawful is any loan for which one receives more than the loan, or by means of which one draws a profit; [and the gain made by such means:] and the lawful is a gift by which a man invites more than it to be given to him, or a gift that he gives in order that more than it may be given to him; [and the addition that he so obtains:] (Zj, T:) [it generally means] an addition that is obtained by selling food [&c.] for food [&c.], or ready money for ready money, to be paid at an appointed period; or by exchanging either of such things for more of the same kind: (Bd in ii. 276:) or the taking of an addition in lending and in selling: (PS:) [it is said to be] i. q. EiynapN: (M, K:) [but although ribFA and EiynapN are both applicable sometimes in the same case, neither of them can be properly said to be generally explanatory of the other, or syn. therewith: ribaA AlnRasiyoYapi is a term specially employed to signify profit obtained in the case of a delay of payment: and ribaA AlfaDoli to signify profit obtained by the superior value of a thing received over that of a
thing given:] the dual of ribFA (M, Msb, K) or ribFwA (S) is ribawaAni and ribayaAni; (S, M, Msb, K;) the former being agreeable with the original; (M, Msb;) the I in the latter being because of the imáleh occasioned by the preceding kesreh. (M.) See an ex. near the beginning of the first paragraph of this art. ruboyapN↓, thus pronounced by the Arabs, but by the relaters of a trad., in which it occurs, rubRiyRapN↓, (Fr, T, S, Mgh,) or, as some say, rubayRapN↓, as though this were the dim. of ruboyapN, (Mgh,) is a dial. var. of ribFwA [or ribFA]; and by rule should be rubowapN: (Fr, T, S, Mgh:) or, accord. to Z, rubRyRapN may be of the measure fuERuwlapN from AlrRibaA. (TA.) [See also ramaMCN, in art. rmI.]

rubapN c
rubapN: see rabowN.

rabowapN c
rabowapN: see the next paragraph: ＝ -A2- and see also rabowN.

rubowapN c
rubowapN and rabowapN↓ and ribowapN↓; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) the first of which is preferred, (T,) or most common; (Msb;) and the second, of the dial. of Temeem; (T, Msb;) and rabowN↓ (M, K) and rabaAwapN↓ (T, S, M, K) and ribaAwapN↓ (M, K) and rubaAwapN↓ (IJ, K) and raAbiyapN↓ (T, S, M, Msb, K) and rabaMCapN↓; (M, K;) A hill; i. e. an elevation of ground, or elevated ground: (T, S, M, K:) or an elevated place: so called because it is high: (Msb, TA:) the pl. of rubowapN is rubFI (T, Msb) and rubiIRN: (T:) and the pl. of raAbiyapN↓ is rawaAbK; (T, Msb;) which ISh explains as meaning elevated sands, like the dakodaAkap [q. v.], but higher and softer than the latter; the latter being more compact and rugged; the rAbyp, he says, has in it depression and elevation; it produces the best and the most numerous of the herbs, or leguminous plants, that are found in the sands; and men alight upon it. (T.)

ribowapN c
ribowapN: see the next preceding paragraph: ― -b2- and see rabowN, in two places.

ruboyapN c
ruboyapN and rubayRapN and rubRiyRapN: see ribFA, last sentence: ＝ -A2- and see also art. rbI.

ribFwA c
ribFwA: see ribFA. [The w is silent, like the A.]

rabowaMCu c
rabowaMCu: see raAbK.

ribawiIRN c
ribawiIRN Of, or relating to, what is termed ribFA or ribFwA [i. e. usury and the like]: (Mgh, Msb:) rabawiIRN is said by Mtr to be wrong. (Msb.)

rabaMCN c
rabaMCN Excess, excellence, or superiority; syn. TawolN: (IDrd, S, K:) so in the saying, lifulaAnK EalaI fulaAnK rabaMCN [Such a one possesses excess, or excellence, or superiority, over such a one]. (IDrd, S.) ― -b2- And An obligation, a favour, or a benefit; syn. minRapN. (K.)

ribaMCN c
ribaMCN: see ribFA.

rabaMCapN c
rabaMCapN: see rubowapN.

rabaAwapN c
rabaAwapN and rubaAwapN and ribaAwapN: see rubowapN.

raAbK c
[raAbK Increasing, or augmenting: &c. ― -b2- Hence,] faOaxacahumo OaxocapF raAbiyapF, in the Kur [lxix. 10], And He punished them with a punishment exceeding other punishments; (Fr, * S, * M, * K, * Jel;) a vehement punishment. (K.) ＝ -A2- AimoraOapN raAbiyapN A woman affected with what is termed rabowN; [i. e., out of breath; &c.; (see 1, near the end of the paragraph;)] (T, TA;) as also rabowaMCu↓. (TA.)

raAbiyapN c
raAbiyapN [as a subst.]: see rubowapN, in two places.

OarobaI c
OarobaI in the Kur xvi. 94 means More numerous, (Bd, Jel,) and more abundant in wealth. (Bd.)

OurobiyRapN c
OurobiyRapN, originally OurobuwRapN, (S,) or of the measure fuEoliyRapN, (M,) The root of the thigh: (Ks, T, S, K:) or the part between the upper portion of the thigh and the lower portion of the baTon [or belly]: (ISh, T, K:) or the part between the upper portion of the thigh and the lower portion of the baZor [q. v.]: or, accord. to Lh, the root of the thigh, next the baZor: (M:) or, as in the A, a portion of flesh, in the root of the thigh, that becomes knotted in consequence of pain: (TA:) there are two parts, together called OurobiyRataAni. (S, TA.) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) A man's household, and the sons of the paternal uncle of a man; (T, M, K, TA;) not including any others: (T, M:) or the nearer members of the household of a man. (A, TA.) One says, jaMCa fulaAnN fiI OurobiyRatihi, and fiI OurobiyRapK mino qawomihi, (T,) or fiI OurobiyRapi qawomihi, (S,) (tropical:) Such a one came among his household, and the sons of his paternal uncle: (T, TA:) or among the people of his house consisting of the sons of his paternal uncles; not of any others. (S.)

UirobiyaAnN c
UirobiyaAnN: see art. rbI.

murobK c
murobK One who practises ribFA [i. e. usury or the like]. (M, K.) ― -b2- Oar oDN murobiyapN (assumed tropical:) Good land. (M.)

marobaApN c
marobaApN for marobaOapN: see the latter, in art. rbO.

murabRFI c
murabRFI [Reared, fostered, brought up, fed, or nourished: see 2. ― -b2- And] Made [or preserved] with rubR [or inspissated juice, &c. (see 2, last sentence but one)]: you say zanojabiylN murabRFI [Ginger so preserved]; as also murabRabN: (S, K:) and murabRayaAtN↓ signifies Preserves, or confections, made with rubR; like murabRabaAtN. (S in art. rb.)

murabRayaAtN c
murabRayaAtN: see what next precedes.

1 rabayotu c
1. rabayotu, in the copies of the K, in art. rbw, is a mistake for rabiytu. (TA in that art., q. v.)

laA warabiyka c
laA warabiyka for laA warabRika [as though rabK were a dial. var. of rabRN]: see rabRN (last sentence), in art. rb.

ribayaAni c
ribayaAni a dual of ribFA, mentioned in art. rbw.

ruboyapN c
ruboyapN A species. of the [small animals called] HaXaraAt [q. v.]: (AHát, S and K * in art. rbw:) pl. rubFI: (AHát, S:) accord. to IAar, the rat, or mouse: pl. as above: (T:) [or] a certain small beast, or reptile, between the rat, or mouse, and [what is called] OumRu HubayonK [q. v.]. (M.) And The cat. (K in art. rbw.) ＝ -A2- See also ribFA (last sentence), in art. rbw.

rubayRapN c
rubayRapN: see ribFA (last sentence), in art. rbw.

rubRiyRapN c
rubRiyRapN: see ribFA (last sentence), in art. rbw.

OurobiyRapN c
OurobiyRapN: see art. rbw.

UirobiyaAnN c
UirobiyaAnN A species of fish, (S and K in art. rbw, and M in the present art.,) white, (S,) resembling worms, (S, K,) found at El-Basrah. (S.) ― -b2- Accord. to Seer, A certain plant. (M.)

1 ratRa c
1. ratRa, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
ratata
, (Msb,) inf. n. ratatN; (S, * Msb;) or rutRa, inf. n. rutRapN; (so in the M;) He had, in his speech, or utterance, what is termed rutRapN, expl. below. (S, M, Msb, K.)

4 ArtRhu c
4. ArtRhu He (God) caused him to have, in his speech, or utterance, what is termed rutRapN. (S, K.)

R. Q. 1 ratorata c
R. Q. 1. ratorata He reiterated, by reason of an impediment in his speech, in uttering the letter t (IAar, T, K) &c. (IAar, T.)

ratRN c
ratRN The swine that assaults or attacks [men]: (T, TA:) or a thing [meaning an animal] resembling the wild swine: (M, TA:) pl. ritRapN, (T,) or ritatapN, (TA,) and rutuwtN: (S, M, TA:) or rutuwtN signifies [simply] swine: (S, K:) in some of the copies of the S, wild swine: (TA:) or boars: (M:) or boars in which is strength and boldness: (A:) it has been asserted that no one but Kh has mentioned it. (IDrd, M.) ― -b2- [Hence, (in the TA said to be bAlDmR, but this is a mistranscription for biAlfatoHi,]) (tropical:) A chief (IAar, T, S, A, K) in eminence, or nobility, and in bounty, or gifts: (IAar, T:) pl. rutuwtN (IAar, T, S, A, K) and rutRaAnN. (K.) You say, huwa mano rutuwti AlnRaAsi (tropical:) He is of the lords of mankind. (A.) And heWulaMCi rutuwtu Albaladi (tropical:) These are the lords of the town, or country. (TA.)

rutRapN c
rutRapN A vitiousness, or an impediment, in speech or utterance, so that one does not speak distinctly: (S, A, K:) or a hastiness therein, (M, Mgh,) and a want of distinctness: or the changing of l into I: (M:) or an impediment in speech or utterance: (Msb:) or, accord. to Mbr, what resembles wind, impeding the commencement of speech, until, when somewhat thereof comes forth, it becomes continuous: it is an inborn habit, and is often found in persons of elevated, or noble, rank: (T, Mgh, Msb:) or, as some say, it is a reiterating of a word, preceded by the breath: or the incorporating of one letter into another (UidogaAmN) when this should not be done: (Msb:) or a vitious and faulty kind of repetition, in the tongue. (AA, TA.)

rutRaI c
rutRaI A woman who changes, in pronunciation, s into v, or r into g or l, and the like; or who changes one letter into another; syn. lavogaMCu. (AA, T, K.) [See also what follows.]

OaratRu c
OaratRu A man having in his speech, or utterance, what is termed rutRapN: (T, S, A, Mgh, Msb:) accord. to 'Abd-Er-Rahmán, whose word, or speech, is held back, and is preceded by his breath: (Mgh:) or having an impediment in his speech, so that his tongue will not obey his will: (TA:) fem. ratRaMCu: (Msb:) and pl. rutRN. (A, Msb.) [See also rutRaI.]

1 rataba c
1. rataba, (T, S, M, &c.,) aor.
ratuba
, inf. n. rutuwbN, (S, M, Msb, K, *) It (a thing, S, M, Msb) was, or became, constant, firm, steady, steadfast, stable, fixed, fast, settled, established, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) and stationary, or motionless; (S, * M, A, * Msb, * K;) as also trtRb↓. (M, K.) Also, said of a thing, (T,) of a kaEob [i. e. cockal-bone, or die], [aor. and] inf. n. as above, (S, M, A, TA,) and of a man, (M, TA,) aor. as above, inf. n. ratobN, (M,) or ratabN, (K, * TA,) It, and he, stood erect, or upright; (T, S, M, A, TA; [but in some copies of the K, AlAinoSibaAbu is erroneously put for AlAinotiSaAbu as the explanation of AlrRatabu;]) and (TA) so Artb↓, (K, TA, [but this I rather think to be a mistranscription,]) said of a man: mentioned in the T as on the authority of IAar. (TA. [But in the T, I find only rataba in this sense.]) So in the saying, rataba rutuwba AlkaEobi fiI AlmaqAmi AlSRaEobi [He stood erect like as does the cockal-bone, or the die, in the difficult standingplace]: (S, * A, TA:) occurring in a trad. of Lukmán Ibn-'Ád. (TA.) And rataba fiI AlSRalaApi He stood erect in prayer. (A.) [Or] rataba said of a man, [aor.
ratuba
,] inf. n. ratobN and rutuwbN, signifies He remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in the town, or country: and also he stood firm. (Msb.) And you say also, rataba fiI AlOamori [He was constant, firm, &c., in the affair]. (A.)

2 rtRb c
2. rtRb, (S, M, A, &c.,) inf. n. tarotiybN, (S, K,) He made, or rendered, (a thing, S, M, or things, A,) constant, firm, steady, steadfast, stable, fixed, fast, settled, established, and stationary, or motionless. (S, * M, Msb, K.) You say, rtRb AlTRalaAYiEa fiI AlmaraAtibi [He stationed the scouts upon the mrAtb]. (A. See marotabapN.) ― -b2- He set things in order, disposed them regularly, arranged them, or classified them. (MA.) You say, rtRb AlrRutaba [He set in order, regularly disposed, arranged, classified, distributed, or appointed, the stations, posts of honour, &c.]. (TA voce OaSRala.) ― -b3- [Hence,] tarotiybN is sometimes used as signifying The mode of construction termed lafRN wanaXorN [when it is regularly disposed: see art. lf]. (Har p. 383.) ― -b4- [Also The prescribing, or observing, a particular order in any performance; as, for instance, in the ablution termed AlwuDuwoC.] ― -b5- And The drawing of omens, one after another. (KL.)

4 Artb AlkaEoba c
4. Artb AlkaEoba, (T, M, A,) inf. n. UirotaAbN, (T,) said of a boy, (T, M, A,) He made the kEb [i. e. cockal-bone, or die,] to stand erect, or upright: (T, * A:) or he made the kEb firm, or steady. (M.) ＝ -A2- Artb as an intrans. v.: see 1. ＝ -A3- Also, inf. n. as above, He became a beggar, after having been rich, or in a state of competence. (IAar, T, K. [Perhaps formed by transposition from Oatoraba.]) ＝ -A4- And He invited distinguished persons to his food, or banquet. (T.)

5 trtRb c
5. trtRb: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- [Also, as quasi-pass of 2, It was, or became, set in order, regularly disposed, arranged, or classified. ― -b3- And trtRb Ealayohi It was consequent upon it; it resulted, or accrued, from it.]

ratobN c
ratobN: see the next paragraph.

ratabN c
ratabN The steps of stairs. (M, TA.) ― -b2- Rocks near together, some of them higher than others: (M, K:) [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. ratabapN↓; mentioned on the authority of Yaakoob as [written rutabN↓,] with damm to the r and fet-h to the t. (M.) ― -b3- Elevated ground, (S, K,) like a barozax [or bar, or an obstruction, between two things: app. a coll. gen. n. in this sense also; n. un. with p; for] you say ratabapN↓ and ratabN like as you say darajapN and darajN. (S.) ― -b4- Hardness, or difficulty: (S, A, K:) coarseness, hardness, or difficulty, of life or living: (M, K: *) fatigue, weariness, embarrassment, or trouble; as also marotabapN↓. (M.) You say, maA fiI EayoXihi ratabN (T, S, M, A) There is no hardness, or difficulty, in his life or living: (S, A:) or no coarseness, hardness, or difficulty. (M.) And maA fiI hecaA AlOamori ratabN, and marotabapN↓, There is no fatigue, weariness, embarrassment, or trouble, in this affair. (M.) And maA fiI hecaA AlOamori ratabN walA EatabN There is not in this affair any hardness, or difficulty: (S:) or any fatigue, or trouble: (T:) i. e. it is easy, and rightly disposed. (T, A.) ＝ -A2- Also The space between the little finger and that next to it, namely, the third finger, [when they are extended apart:] and the space between the third finger and the middle finger [when they are so extended]: (M, K:) or the space between the fore finger and the middle finger [when they are so extended]: sometimes written and pronounced ratobN↓: (S, TA:) [or it is a coll. gen. n.; and] ratabapN↓ [is the n. un., and] signifies the space between [any two of] the fingers. (TA in art. rtq. [See also buSomN.]) It denotes also The [space that is measured by] putting the four fingers close together. (K. [See also EatabN.])

rutobapN c
rutobapN A single step of stairs or of a ladder; (MA;) [and so marotabapN↓, as appears from what follows:] pl. of the former rutabN (MA) [and rutabaAtN, for Az says that] rutobapN signifies one of the rutabaAt of stairs: (T:) [the pl. of marotabapN is maraAtibu.] You say, raqiIa fiI rutabi AldRaraji and maraAtibihaA↓ [He ascended the steps of the stairs]. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] also, (S, M, A, * Msb, K,) and marotabapN↓, (T, S, M, A, K, TA,) [or] from rataba signifying “ he stood erect, ” (TA,) (tropical:) A station, or standing; a post of honour; rank; condition; degree; dignity; or office; (T, S, M, A, Msb, K, TA;) with, or at the courts of, kings; and the like: (T, TA:) or a high station, &c.: (TA:) pl. of the former rutabN; (A, * Msb, TA;) and of the latter maraAtibu↓. (A, TA.) You say, huwa fiI OaEolaI AlrRutabi (tropical:) [He is in the highest of stations, &c.]: and Einoda lahu marotabapN↓ AlsRuloTaAni (tropical:) [He has a station, &c., or high station, &c., with, or at the court of, the Sultán]: and huwa mino Oaholi AlmaraAtibi↓ (tropical:) [He is of the people of high stations, &c.]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- [rutobapN also signifies The order of the proper relative places of things; as, for instance, of the words in a sentence.] ― -b4- See also the pl. rutabN in the next preceding paragraph.

ratabapN c
ratabapN n. un. of ratabN, which see in three places. (S, * M.)

ratobaMCu c
ratobaMCu A she-camel erect in her pace. (T, K.)

raAtibN c
raAtibN (Msb) and turotubN↓ and turotabN↓ (M, K) and tarotubN↓ (M) A thing constant, firm, steady, steadfast, stable, fixed, fast, settled, established, stationary, or motionless: (M, Msb, K: [the third of these words, in this sense, is mentioned in the T in art. trb: but see the next paragraph:]) and the first, standing erect, or upright; (T, TA;) applied to a thing, (T,) to a kaEob [i. e. cockal-bone, or die], and to a man. (TA.) You say OamorN raAtibN A thing, or an affair, continual, or uninterrupted, (daArRN.) constant, firm, steady, &c.: and OamorN turotabN↓, the latter word of the measure tufoEalN, with damm to the t and fet-h to the E, a thing, or an affair, constant, firm, steady, &c. (S.) And EizRN raAtibN Might, high rank or condition, or the like, constant, firm, &c. (A.) And EayoXN raAtibN Constant, or continual, (M, TA,) fixed, settled, or established, (TA,) means of subsistence. (M, TA.) And maA zilotu EalaI hecaA raAtibFA I ceased not to be, or to do, thus constantly; as also raAtimFA; in which, IJ says, the m is app. a substitute for b, because we have not heard ratama used like rataba; but it may be radical, from AlrRatiymapu. (M.) ― -b2- [raAtibN in the modern language, used as a subst., signifies A set pension, salary, and allowance; a ration; and any set office, or task: and so raAtibapN; pl. rawaAtibu.]

turotabN c
turotabN and turotubN and tarotubN: see the next preceding paragraph, in four places. ― -b2- You say also, jaAWuwA turotabFA and turotubFA, meaning They came all together. (K.) And a poet says, (M,) namely, Ziyád Ibn-Zeyd El-'Odharee, (TA,)
wakaAna lanaA faDolN EalaI AlnRaAsi turotabaA
meaning [And we possessed excellence above the people] all together: (M, TA:) thus accord. to the reading commonly known: but, as some relate it,
wakaAna lanaA HaqRFA EalaI AlnRaAsi turotabaA
i. e. [And it was a just claim that we had upon the people,] settled, or established. (TA.) The first t in turotabN is augmentative, because there is no word like juEofarN; and the derivation also is an evidence of this, for the word is from AlXRaIoCu AlrRaAtibu. (M.) ＝ -A2- Also the second of these three words, (T in art. trb, and M, and L,) or the first of them, (K,) A bad slave: (T, K:) or a slave whom three persons inherit, one after another;
because of his continuance in slavery: [it being a common custom for a man to make a good slave free at his death:] mentioned by Th. (M.) ― -b2- Also the second, (Th, M, K,) and the first, (K,) Dust, or earth; syn. turaAbN: (Th, M, K:) because of its long endurance. (Th, M.) ― -b3- And the first, i. q.
