OabadN [Time, or duration, or continuance, or existence, without end; &c.: or the right reading may perhaps be MbidN, i. e. remaining constantly, &c.]. (K.)

Oaxaca fulaAnN turotubRapF c
Oaxaca fulaAnN turotubRapF Such a one took what was like a road, to tread it. (K, * TA.)

marotabapN c
marotabapN, and its pl. maraAtibu: see rutobapN, in six places. ― -b2- Accord. to As, it signifies A place of observation, which is the summit of a mountain, or the upper part thereof: (S:) accord. to Kh, (S,) the maraAtib in mountains and in deserts (SaHaArK) are [structures such as are termed] OaEolaAm [pl. of EalamN, q. v.,] upon which are stationed (turabu↓) scouts, or spies: (T, S:) or places to which scouts ascend, in, or upon, mountains. (A.) ― -b3- The pl. also signifies Narrow and rugged parts of valleys. (TA from a trad.) ― -b4- And the sing., Any difficult station or position. (M.) ― -b5- See also ratabN, in two places. ― -b6- [In post-classical works, and in the language of the present day, it is applied to A mattress, upon which to sit or recline or lie; such as is spread upon a couch-frame or upon the ground.]

1 rataja c
1. rataja, inf. n. ratojN: see 4. ＝ -A2- ratija, (K,) or ratija fiI manoTiqahi, (S, A, Msb,) aor.
rataja
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. ratajN, (Msb, TA,) (tropical:) He was, or became, impeded in his speech, unable to speak, or tonguetied; (S, A, * Msb, K;) as also Ealayohi Ourotija↓, (A, K,) and Elyh Aurotutija↓, and Elyh Ausoturotija↓. (K.) You say, EalaI AlqaAriICi Ourotija↓, (S, Mgh, Msb,) and ElI AlxaTiybi, (Mgh,) (tropical:) The reader, or reciter, (S, Mgh, Msb,) and the orator, or preacher, (Mgh,) was unable to read, or recite, (S, Msb,) as though he were prevented doing so, (Msb,) or as though a thing were closed against him like as a door is closed; (S;) or was, or became, impeded in his reading, or recitation, and his oration, or sermon, and unable to complete it; (Mgh;) from Oarotaja AlbaAba: (Mgh, Msb: [see 4:]) and Ealayohi Aurotutija↓ signifies the same: (S: [in my copy of the Msb, “ Artyj, of the same measure as Aqtyl, in the pass. form: ” but this is evidently a mistranscription, for Aurotutija, of the same measure as Auqotutila:]) one should not say AurotujRa Elyh: (S: [but it seems that those who pronounced the verb with teshdeed said AirotajRa: see art. rj:]) this is sometimes said; but some disallow it: (Msb:) the vulgar say it; and accord. to some, it may be correct as meaning “ he fell into confusion. ” (Mgh.) You say also, Ealayohi SaEida Alminobara faOurotijaEalaI↓ (tropical:) He ascended the pulpit, and was, or became, impeded in his speech, unable to speak, or tonguetied. (A.) And EalaI fulaAnK Ourotija↓ (tropical:) Such a one was unable to finish a saying, or poetry, that he desired to utter. (TA.) And fiI kalaAmihi ratajN (tropical:) In his speech is a reiterating, by reason of an impediment, or inability to say what he would. (A, TA.) ＝ -A3- rataja, inf. n. ratajAnN, He (a child) walked a little, at his first beginning to walk; or walked with a weak gait; crept along; or walked slowly. (K, TA.)

4 Artj AlbaAba c
4. Artj AlbaAba, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. UirotaAjN; (Msb;) and ratajahu↓, (K,) inf. n. ratojN; but As allows only the former verb; (TA;) i. q. Oagolaqahu, [which means He locked the door, and also he shut, or closed, the door, but the former appears to be the signification here intended, from what follows,] (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) so as to make it fast, or firm: (A, Mgh, Msb:) so says Az, after Lth: and, by extension of the signification, he shut, or closed, the door, without locking it. (Mgh.) It is said in a trad., UinRa OabowaAba AlsRamaMCi tufotaHu Einoda zawaAli AlXRamosi falaA turotaju HatRaI yuSalRaI AlZRuhoru, (Mgh, * and “ Jámi' es-Sagheer ” of EsSuyootee,) i. e. [Verily the gates of Heaven are opened at the declining of the sun from the meridian,] and are not closed nor locked [until the noon-prayer has been performed]. (Mgh.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Ourotija Ealayohi AlOamoru (assumed tropical:) The affair was as though it were closed against him, so that he knew not the way to engage in it, or execute it; syn. Aisotabohama Ealayohi. (TA in art. bhm.) ― -b3- See also 1, in four places. ― -b4- [Hence also,] Oarotajato (tropical:) She (a camel) closed her womb against the seed (S, A, K, TA) of the stallion, (TA,) having become pregnant. (A.) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) She (an ass) became pregnant. (K.) ― -b6- And (tropical:) She (a hen) had her belly full of eggs. (S, A, * K.) ― -b7- Also Oarotaja (assumed tropical:) It (the sea) became raised into a state of commotion, and covered everything with the abundance of its water, (K, TA,) and the voyager upon it found no way of escape from it. (TA.) ― -b8- (assumed tropical:) It (snow) was continual, and covered [the land]. (K.) ― -b9- (assumed tropical:) It (abundance of herbage) was universal over the land, (K, TA,) leaving no part thereof wanting. (TA.) And Oarotajati AlsRanapu (assumed tropical:) The year of drought involved every part in sterility, (K, TA,) so that man found no way of escape. (TA.)

8 Uirotataja
8: see 1, in two places.

10 Uisotarotaja
10: see 1, second sentence.

sikRapN ritojN c
sikRapN ritojN (tropical:) [A street that is closed;] that has no place of egress. (A, K.) maAlN ritojN (tropical:) Property to which there is no access; (A, TA;) contr. of TiloqN, (K, TA,) which is likewise with kesr; (TA; [in the CK Taloq;]) as also giloqN. (K, TA.)

ratajN c
ratajN: see what next follows.

ritaAjN c
ritaAjN A door: (TA:) or a great door; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also ratajN↓: (S A, K:) or a door locked, or shut or closed, (S, Mgh, K,) having a small door, or wicket: (S, K:) or it signifies also a door that is locked, or shat or closed: (Msb:) pl. rutujN and rataAYiju, and, accord. to MF, OarotaAjN, but this is irreg., and he has given no authority for it. (TA.) Hence ritaAju AlkaEobapi [The door of the Kaabeh]: (S, TA:) and (tropical:) the Kaabeh itself: (A, * TA:) and [hence also] AlirRtaAju is (tropical:) a name of Mekkeh. (K, TA.) jaEala maAlahu fiI ritaAji AlkaEobapi, (A, Mgh, Msb, TA,) occurring in a trad., (Mgh, TA,) means, (A, Msb, TA,) or is said to mean, (Mgh,) (tropical:) He made his property, or cattle, a votive offering to be taken to the Kaabeh; (A, Mgh, Msb;) not the door itself; (Mgh;) the Kaabeh being thus called because by the door one enters it. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) The part of the womb that closes upon the fœtus; as being likened to a door. (L.) ― -b3- OaroDN caAtu ritaAjK occurs in a trad. [app. as meaning (assumed tropical:) A land having a place of ingress that is, or may be, closed: or it may mean a land having in it rocks: see ritaAjapN, of which ritaAjN may be a coll. gen. n.]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- naAqapN ritaAju AlSRalaA (assumed tropical:) A she-camel firm or compact [in the middle of the back, or in the part on either side of the tail, &c.]. (K.)

ritaAjapN c
ritaAjapN sing. of rataAYiju, which signifies Rocks. (K.) ― -b2- Also Any narrow XiEob [or mountainroad, &c.]; as though it were closed, by reason of its narrowness. (L.)

murotajN c
murotajN A door, and a chamber, or house, locked, or shut or closed, (mugolaqN,) so as to be made fast, or firm. (A.)

murotijN c
murotijN, applied to a she-camel, (tropical:) Pregnant; because the mouth of her womb becomes closed against the seed of the stallion: (T, A, * TA:) applied also to a she-ass, in the same sense: (TA:) pl. maraAtiju and maraAtiyju. (A, TA.)

mirotaAjN c
mirotaAjN A thing with which a door is closed, or made fast; syn. migolaAqN; (S;) [app. a kind of latch:] it is affixed behind the door, in the part next to the lock. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA in art. ErbD.)

maraAtiju c
maraAtiju Narrow roads or paths: (S, A, K:) the sing. is not mentioned. (TA.)

1 rataEa c
1. rataEa, aor.
rataEa
, inf. n. rutuwEN (S, Msb, K) and ratoEN (Msb, K) and ritaAEN, (IAar, K,) He (a beast) pastured at pleasure; (Msb;) he (a beast, S, TA) ate (S, K) and drank (K) what he pleased, (S, K,) and came and went in the pasturage, by day, (TA,) amid abundance of herbage, and plenty: (K:) or (tropical:) he ate and drank plentifully and pleasantly, in land of seed-produce and fruitfulness, of green herbs or leguminous plants and of waters: (Lth, K, TA:) or (tropical:) he ate (IAar, K) and drank (K) with great greediness. (IAar, K.) In its primary acceptation, it is said of a beast. (TA.) ― -b2- It is metaphorically said of a man, as meaning (tropical:) He ate much; accord. to El-Isbahánee in the Mufradát, and the A and the B. (TA.) ― -b3- You say, rataEa fulaAnN fiI maAli fulaAnK (tropical:) Such a one acted as he pleased in eating and drinking the property of such a one. (TA.) ― -b4- And xarajonaA naloEabu wanarotaEu (tropical:) We went forth [playing, or sporting, and enjoying ourselves; or] enjoying ourselves; and playing,
or sporting. (S, TA. *) It is said in the Kur [xii. 12], (TA,) accord. to different readings, (K, TA,) Oarosilohu maEanaA gadFA yarotaEo wayaloEabo (tropical:) [Send thou him with us to-morrow] that he may play, or sport, and enjoy himself: or the meaning is, that he may walk [abroad at his pleasure] and become cheerful in countenance, or dilated in heart: (TA:) and wayaloEabu nurotiEo↓ that we may put our beasts to eat and drink what they please, amid abundance of herbage, and plenty, [or to pasture at pleasure,] and he shall play: (K, TA:) and the reverse, (K,) yurotiEo wanaloEabu, (TA,) i. e. that he may put our beasts to eat and drink &c., and we will play together: (K, TA:) and with n in each case. (K.) ― -b5- And it is said in a trad., mano yarotaEo Hawola AlHimaI yuwXiko Oano yaxaAliTahu, i. e. (assumed tropical:) He who goes round about [the prohibited place of pasturage will soon enter into it]. (TA.) ― -b6- And in another trad., UicaA mararotumo biriyaADi AljanRapi faQrotaEuwA, meaning (tropical:) [When ye pass by a scene of] the commemoration of the praises of God, enter ye thereinto; the entering thereinto being thus likened to the eating and drinking what one pleases, amid abundance of herbage. (TA.)

4 ArtE c
4. ArtE He put his camels [to pasture at pleasure; (see 1;) or] to eat (S, K) and drink (K) what they pleased, (S, K,) amid abundance of herbage, and plenty: (K: [in which it is implied that the verb may have this signification or others agreeable with explanations in the first sentence of this art.:]) or he pastured his camels, or put them to pasture, by themselves. (TA.) See the ex. in the Kur-án cited above. ― -b2- Hence, (tropical:) He ruled, or governed, his subjects well; [as though] leaving them to satiate themselves in the pasturage. (TA.) ― -b3- It (a party of men) lighted upon abundance of herbage, and pastured. (TA.) ― -b4- It (rain) produced, or gave growth to, herbage in which the camels might pasture at pleasure, or eat and drink what they pleased, amid abundance thereof and plenty. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b5- ArtEt AlOaroDu The land became abundant in herbage. (TA.)

rataEN c
rataEN [app. an inf. n., of which the verb (ratiEa) is not mentioned, and perhaps not used,] The leading a plentiful and pleasant and easy life. (TA.) [See also ratoEapN.]

ratiEN c
ratiEN sing. of ratiEuwna, q. v. voce murotiEN: ― -b2- and applied to herbage: see murotiEN.

ratoEapN c
ratoEapN Abundance of herbage; or of the goods, conveniences, and comforts, of life; fruitfulness; plenty: and a state of ampleness in respect thereof: (K:) a subst. from 1. (TA.) Hence the prov., Alqayodu waAlrRatoEapu, and AlrRataEapu↓; (K;) the former on the authority of Fr, and the latter from some other, accord. to the O; but in the L, the latter is ascribed to Fr; (TA;) [Bonds and plenty; the latter word] meaning AlxaSobu: said by 'Amr Ibn-Es-Saak: he had been taken prisoner by Shákir Ibn-Rabee'ah, a tribe of Hemdán, who treated him well; and when he left his people, he was slender; then he fled from Shákir; and when he came to his people, they said, “ O 'Amr, thou wentest forth from us slender, and now thon art corpulent; ” and he replied in the words above. (K.)

rataEapN c
rataEapN: see what next precedes.

ratRaAEN c
ratRaAEN One who seeks, with his camels, after the places of pasturage abounding with herbage, one after another. (TA.)

raAtiEN c
raAtiEN A camel, (S, K,) or beast, pasturing at his pleasure; (Msb;) or eating (S, K,) and drinking (K) what he pleases, (S, K,) and coming and going in the pasturage, by day, (TA,) amid abundance of herbage, and plenty; (K;) [part. n. of 1, q. v.:] pl. ritaAEN (S, Msb, K) and rutRaEN and rutuEN and rutuwEN. (K.) ― -b2- You say also qawomN raAtiEuwna. (S.) See marotiEN.

raOayotu OarotaAEFA mina AlnRaAsi c
raOayotu OarotaAEFA mina AlnRaAsi I saw a multitude of men. (Sgh, K.)

marotaEN c
marotaEN A place of pasturing: (KL:) [or of unrestrained and plentiful pasturing;] a place where beasts pasture at pleasure; (Msb;) where they eat (S, K) and drink (K) what they please, (S, K,) going and coming therein, by day, (TA,) amid abundance of herbage, and plenty: (K:) [see 1:] pl. maraAtiEu. (Msb.) ― -b2- [And Pasture itself:] one says, OakaluwA marotaEa AlOaroDi [They consumed, or ate, the pasture of the land]. (M in art. rdm.)

murotiEN c
murotiEN One who leaves his travelling-camels to pasture at their pleasure, or to eat and drink what they please, coming and going in the pasturage, by day, amid abundance of herbage, and plenty. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A man having abundance of herbage, or of the goods or conveniences and comforts of life, not lacking anything that he may desire. (K, TA.) You say also qawomN murotiEuwna raAtiEuwna↓, meaning (assumed tropical:) A people, or company of men, who are scarcely ever without abundance of herbage, or of the goods or conveniences and comforts of life; syn. maxaASiybu; and qawomN ratiEuwna↓, after the manner of a rel. n., like TaEimN: and in like manner ratiEN↓ is applied to herbage [as meaning scarcely ever other than abundant, or generally abundant]. (TA.) ― -b3- Rain that produces, or gives growth to, herbage in which the camels may pasture at pleasure, or eat and drink what they please, amid abundance thereof and plenty. (S, Msb.) ― -b4- OaroDN murotiEapN Land in which the beasts eagerly desire to satiate themselves. (Sh.)

1 rataqa c
1. rataqa, aor.
ratuqa
(S, L, Msb) and
ratiqa
, (L,) inf. n. ratoqN, (S, M, L, Msb, K,) He closed up, (M, Msb, TA,) and repaired, (M, TA,) a rent: (S, M, Msb, TA:) [he sewed up, or together: see ritaAqN:] AlrRatoqu is the contr. of Alfatoqu. (S, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, rataqa fatoqahumo, meaning (tropical:) [He closed up the breach that was between them; he reconciled them; or] he reformed, or amended, the circumstances subsisting between them. (TA.) ＝ -A2- ratiqato, aor.
rataqa
, (IKoot, Msb, TA,) inf. n. rataqN, (S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) in the K, erroneously, rataqapN, (TA,) She was, or became, such as is termed ratoqaMC; (IKoot, S, Mgh, Msb, K;) said of a woman, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) or of a girl, and also of a camel. (IKoot, Msb.)

8 Arttq c
8. Arttq It was, or became, closed up, (S, Msb, K,) [and repaired; and sewed up, or together;] said of a rent: (S, Msb:) and also of the vulva of a woman. (S, * TA.)

ratoqN c
ratoqN i. q. marotuwqN↓ [and marotuwqapN, &c., being originally an inf. n.; i. e. Closed up, and repaired; applied to a rent; and so rataqN↓]. (TA.) kaAnataA ratoqFA fafataqonaAhumaA, in the Kur [xxi. 31, lit. They (the heavens and the earth) were closed up, and we rent them], is from AlrRatoqu as the contr. of Alfatoqu: (S:) accord. to Ibn-'Arafeh, it means they were closed up, without any interstice, and we rent them by the rain and by the plants: accord. to Az, it means they were a heaven closed up and an earth closed up, and we rent them into seven heavens and seven earths: Lth says that the heavens were closed up, no rain descending from them; and the earth was closed up, without any fissure therein; until God rent them by the rain and the plants: Zj says that ratoqFA is for cawaAtaIo ratoqK: (TA:) and he says that the heaven and the earth were united, and God rent them by the air, which He placed between them: (TA in art. ftq:) some read rataqFA↓, for XayoYFA rataqFA, meaning marotuwqFA. (Bd.)

rataqN c
rataqN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places. ＝ -A2- It is [also] pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of rataqapN↓, syn., accord. to the copies of the K, with rutobapN, but correctly with ratabapN, which signifies The space between [any two of] the fingers: mentioned [in the JK, where I find the correct reading, and] by Ibn-'Abbád. (TA.)

rataqapN c
rataqapN: see what next precedes.

ratoqaMCu c
ratoqaMCu, applied to a woman, (AHeyth, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) or to a girl, (Lth,) [and also to a she-camel, (see 1, last sentence,)] Impervia coëunti; (S, Msb, K;) having the meatus of the vagina closed up: (S, * Msb:) or having no aperture except the mabaAl [or meatus urinarius]: (Lth, Mgh, K:) or having the faroj so drawn together that the cakar can hardly, or not at all, pass. (AHeyth.)

ritaAqN c
ritaAqN [A garment composed of] two pieces of cloth sewed together (yurotaqaAni) by their borders. (Lth, S, K.) Hence the saying of a rájiz,
jaAriya bayoDaMCu fiI ritaAqi
tudiyru TarofFA OakoHala AlmaMqiI
[A fair girl in a rtAq, turning about eyes black in the inner angles.] (Lth, S. *)

rutuwqN c
rutuwqN Inaccessableness, or unapproachableness; (manaEapN, [in some copies of the K, AlxnEp is erroneously put for AlmanaEapu,]) and might; and high, or elevated, rank. (Ibn-'Abbád, K, TA.)

raAtiqN c
raAtiqN [for saHaAbN raAtiqN] Clouds closing up, or coalescing. (AHn, TA.) ― -b2- huwa AlfaAtiqu AlrRaAtiqu (assumed tropical:) He is the possessor of command or rule, so that he
opens and closes, and straitens and widens. (Har p. 208.) [See also mixolaTN.]

farojN Oarotaqu c
farojN Oarotaqu A vulva of which the sides stick together. (TA.)

marotuwqN c
marotuwqN: see ratoqN.

marotatiqN c
marotatiqN Herbage of which the blossoms have not yet come forth from their calyxes. (TA in art. SwH.) [See remarks on a verse cited voce murotafiqN.]

1 rataka c
1. rataka, (S, K,) aor.
ratuka
, (S,) thus it appears to be accord. to the K [also], and thus in the Deewán el-Adab of El-Farábee, but accord. to Sgh it is correctly
ratika
, (TA,) inf. n. ratokN and ratakaAnN (S, K) and ratakN, (K,) He (a camel) went with short steps (S, K) in his ramalaAn [or quick pacing, or going a kind of trotting pace, between a walk and a run], (S,) to which Kh adds, shaking himself: and accord. to him, and J, it is said only of a camel: but it is sometimes said of other animals, [perhaps tropically, or improperly,] as, for instance, of an ostrich: and accord. to Sgh, it is sometimes said of a human being. (TA.) [See also Hataka: and see naSaba AlsRayora, in art nSb.]

4 Artkhu c
4. Artkhu He made him (namely, a camel,) to go in the manner expl. above: (S, K:) or made him to go a quick pace. (TA.) ― -b2- And Artk AlDRaHika (assumed tropical:) He laughed languidly: (K:) and so OarotaOa AlDRaHika. (TA.)

raAtikapN c
raAtikapN A she-camel [going with short steps &c.: (see 1:) or] going as though she had shackles on her legs: or beating [the ground] with her fore legs: (As, TA:) pl. rawaAtiku. (TA.)

marotakN c
marotakN i. q. murodaAsanojN [from the Pers. murdaAsanoG, both of which signify Litharge in the present day, as in the classical dialect]: (K:) it is of two kinds; namely, cahabiIRN [i. e. red, or of gold], and fiDRiIRN [i. e. white, or of silver]. (TA.)

1 ratila AlvRagoru c
1. ratila AlvRagoru, aor.
ratala
, inf. n. ratalN, The front teeth were, or became, even in their growth, (Msb,) [or separate, one from another, and even in the manner of growth, well set together, and (accord. to some) very white and lustrous: see ratalN and ratilN, below.] ― -b2- And ratila AlXRaIoCu, aor. and inf. n. as above, The thing was, or became, well arranged or disposed. (TK.)

2 tarotiylN c
2. tarotiylN, in its original sense, relates to the teeth; signifying tafoliyj thereof [i. e., as inf. n. of the verb in its pass. form, Their being separate, one from another]. (Bd in xxv. 34.) ― -b2- [Hence,] rtRl AlkalaAma, (T, M, K,) inf. n. tarotiylN, (K,) He put together and arranged well the component parts of the speech, or saying, (M, K,) and made it distinct: and hence tarotiylu AlquroMni [explained in what follows]: (M:) or he proceeded in a leisurely manner in the speech, or saying, [making the utterance distinct,] and put together and arranged well its component parts: (T:) and ratRalotu AlquroMna inf. n. as above, I read, or recited, the Kur-án in a leisurely manner; without haste: (Msb:) or AltRarotiylu in reading, or reciting, [and particularly in the reading, or reciting, of the Kur-án,] is the proceeding in a leisurely manner, and uttering distinctly, without exceeding the proper bounds or limits: (S:) [and hence, conventionally, the chanting of the Kur-án in a peculiar, distinct, and leisurely, manner:] and fiI kalaAmihi trtRl↓, (T,) or fiI AlkalaAmi, (M, K,) signifies [in like manner] he proceeded in a leisurely manner (T, M, K) in his speech, or saying, (T,) or in the speech, or saying: (M, K:) Mujáhid explains AltRarotiyl as signifying the proceeding in a leisurely manner [in reading, or reciting], and as being consecutive in its parts, or portions; regarding it as etymologically relating to vagorN ratilN [q. v.]: (T:) accord. to Er-Rághib, it signifies the pronouncing the word [or words] with ease and correctness: this is the proper signification: but the conventional meaning, as verified by El-Munáwee, is the being regardful of the places of utterance of the letters, and mindful of the pauses, and the lowering of the voice, and making it plaintive, in reading, or reciting: (TA:) [accord. to Mtr,] the [proper] meaning of Altrtyl in [the reciting, or chanting, of the Kur-án and of] the call to prayer &c. is the pronouncing of the letters in a leisurely manner, and distinctly, and so giving them their proper full sound; from the phrase vagorN muratRalN and ratilN signifying “ front teeth separate, one from another, and even in the manner of growth, and well set together. ” (Mgh.) [See also tarosiylN.] waratRalonaAhu tarotiylFA, in the Kur [xxv. 34], means And we have sent it down unto thee in a leisurely manner: (M, TA:) or we have recited it to thee part after part, in a deliberate and leisurely manner; in [the course of] twenty years, or three and twenty: tarotiylN in its original sense relating to the teeth, and having the signification explained in the beginning of this paragraph. (Bd.)

5 taratRala
5: see the next preceding paragraph.

rtalN c
rtalN inf. n. of 1: (Msb:) [Evenness in the growth of the front teeth: or their being separate, one from another, and even in the manner of growth, and well set together: (see 1 and ratilN:) or] whiteness, [or much whiteness,] and much lustre, of the teeth. (M, K.) ― -b2- And A good, (M, K, TA,) and correct, or right, (TA,) state of arrangement or disposition of a thing. (M, K, TA.) ― -b3- The quality, in a man, of having the teeth separate, one from another, (S,) [and even in the manner of growth, &c.] ― -b4- And Coldness, or coolness, of water. (Kr, M, K.) ＝ -A2- See also the next paragraph, in three places.

ratilN c
ratilN (T, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and ratalN↓, (S, M, K,) [the latter an inf. n. used as an epithet,] applied to front teeth, (vagorN, T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) Well set together: (T, M:) or even in growth: (S, Msb:) or separate, one from another; or having interstices between them, not overlapping one another: (M:) or separate, one from another, and even in the manner of growth, and well set together; as also muratRalN↓: (Mgh:) or separate, one from another, well set together, very white, and very lustrous. (K.) ― -b2- And ratilN, (S,) or ratilu AlOasonaAni, (M,) [or AlvRagori,] A man having the teeth [or the front teeth] separate, one from another, (S, M,) &c. (M.) ― -b3- And ratalN↓ (S, M, K) and ratilN, (M, K,) applied to speech, or language, (S, M, K,) i. q. muratRalN↓; i. e. uttered in a leisurely manner, and distinctly, without exceeding the proper bounds or limits: (S:) or good, (M, K,) and uttered in a leisurely manner. (M.) ― -b4- And ratilN and ratalN↓, applied to anything, Good, sweet, or pleasant. (M, K.) ― -b5- And the former, applied to water, Cold, or cool. (Kr, M, K.)

rutayolaI c
rutayolaI and rutayolaMCu↓ A certain genus of hawaAmR [or venomous creeping things]; (S, M, K;) [the genus of insects called phalangium; applied thereto in the present day; and (perhaps incorrectly) to the tarantula:] there are several species thereof; (K;) many species; (TA;) the most commonly known thereof is [in its body, app.,] like the fly (cubaAb) that flies around the lamp; another is black speckled with white (sawodaMCu raqoTaMCu); another is yellow and downy; and the bite of all causes swelling and pain; (K;) and sometimes is deadly. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, the latter (rutayolaMCu↓), A certain plant, the flower of which resembles that of the lily; [app. the plant called (like the insect above mentioned) phalangium, (as Golius states it to be,) and, by Arabs in the present day, zahoru AlEanokabuwti;] good as a remedy against the bite of the venomous creature above mentioned, (K,) for which reason it is thus called, (TA,) and against the sting of the scorpion. (K.)

rutayolaMCu c
rutayolaMCu: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

raAtilapN c
raAtilapN Short; (K;) applied to a man. (TA.)

Oarotalu c
Oarotalu i. q. OaratRu [i. e. Having a vitiousness, or an impediment, in his speech, or utterance: see art. rt]. (O, K.)

muratRalN c
muratRalN: see ratilN, in two places.

1 ratama c
1. ratama, (T, S, M, K,) aor.
ratima
, (M, K,) inf. n. ratomN, (T, S, M, K,) He broke a thing: (ISk, T, S, M, K:) and bruised it, or crushed it, (ISk, T, M, K, TA,) much: (M, and so in the CK:) or, (M, K,) accord. to Lh, (M,) specially, (M, K,) he broke (M) the nose: (M, K: [but see ratomN, below:]) and ravama [q. v.] signifies the same: you say, ratama Oanofahu and ravamahu [He broke his nose]. (T, S.) ＝ -A2- See also 4. ＝ -A3- maA ratama bikalimapK He spoke not a word. (T, S, M, K.) ＝ -A4- ratamati AlmiEozaI The goats pastured upon the plant called AlrRatam [in the CK AlrRatom]. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- And ratama He became affected with swooning from eating the plant so called. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A5- ratama fiI baniI fulaAnK He grew up among the son of such a one. (K.)

4 Artm c
4. Artm, inf. n. UirotaAmN, [app. He tied a ratiymap, q. v.]. (T.) ratomN, also, as an inf. n., [i. e. of ratama↓,] signifies The tying a thread, or string, upon one's own finger for the purpose of remembering something. (KL.) ― -b2- And Artmhu, (inf. n. as above, S,) He tied upon his (a man's, T, S, Mgh) finger a thread, or string, such as is termed ratiymap. (T, S, M, Mgh, K.) ＝ -A2- Also He (a young camel) bore fat in his hump. (K.)

5 taratRama
5: see what next follows.

8 Arttm c
8. Arttm, (Mgh, K,) or Arttm biratiymapK or biratamapK, (M, TA,) and trtRm↓, (M, K,) He had a thread, or string, such as is termed ratiymap or ratamap tied upon his finger. (M, Mgh, K.)

ratomN c
ratomN (S, M, K) and ratiymN↓ (M, K) and marotuwmN↓ (S, K) signify the same; i. e. Broken: (S, M, K:) and bruised, or crushed, (M, K, TA,) much: (M, and so accord. to the CK:) the first being an inf. n. used as an epithet. (M, K.) Ows Ibn-Hajar says,
laOaSabaHa ratomFA duqaAqa AlHaSaI
makaAna AlnRabiIRi mina AlkaAvibi
(S, in the present art.,) i. e. It (referring to a mountain called AlSaAqib) would become [broken, having the pebbles crushed,] like the sands around the mountain El-Káthib. (S in art. nbw. [But there are other explanations of AlnbIR and AlkAvb as here used. In the T, in art. rvm, a different reading is given: lASbH ravomFA.]) ＝ -A2- See also ratiymapN. ― -b2- [Freytag, misled by the CK, has assigned to ratomN a signification that belongs to ratamN.]

ratamN c
ratamN [applied in the present day to The shrub broom; to several species thereof: spartium monospermum of Linn.: genista rætam of Forsk.: (Delile, Flor. Aegypt. Illustr., no. 657:) spartium: (Forskål, Flora Aegypt. Arab., p. lvi.:) and phalaris setacea: (Idem, p. lx.:)] a species of plant: (T:) or a species of tree; (Mgh;) or so ratamapN↓; of which the former is the pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.]: (S:) or the latter, (Lth, T,) or the former, (AHn, M, K,) the latter being its n. un., (K,) a certain plant, of the shrub-kind; (AHn, T, M, K;) as though by reason of its slenderness, it were likened to the thread, or string, called ratami: (AHn, T, * K, * TA: [see this word voce ratiymapN: in the CK, in the present instance, erroneously written raqom:]) and so ratiymapN↓: (AHn, T:) its flower is like the xiyriIR [or yellow gilliflower], and its seed is like the lentil: each of these (i. e. the flower and the seed, TA) strongly provokes vomiting: the drinking the expressed juice of its twigs, fasting, is a beneficial remedy for sciatica (Eiroqu AlnRasaA); and likewise the using as a clyster an infusion thereof in sea-water: and the swallowing twenty-one grains thereof, fasting, prevents the [pustules called] damaAmiyl. (K.) When a man was about to make a journey, he betook himself to two branches, or two trees, and tied one branch to another, and said, “ If my wife be faithful to the compact, this will remain tied as it is; otherwise, she will have broken the compact: ” so says As; and ISk says the like: (T:) or he betook himself to a tree, (S, K,) or to the species of tree called ratam, (ISk, Mgh,) and tied together two branches thereof, (ISk, S, Mgh, K,) or he tied together two trees; (M;) and if he returned and found them as he tied them, he said that his wife had not been unfaithful to him; but otherwise, that she had been so: (ISk, S, M, Mgh, K:) this [pair of branches or trees] is called AlrRatamu [in the CK, erroneously, AlrRatomu] and AlrRatiymapu↓: (K:) or this is what is meant by AlrRatiymapu↓: (M:) or this [action] is what is meant by taEoqaAdu AlrRatami in the following verse: (As, ISk, T, Mgh:) but IB says that AlrRataAYimu [pl. of AlrRatiymapu↓] does not mean peculiarly one kind of trees exclusively of others: and he cites this verse as an ex. of AlrRatamu meaning the threads, or strings, so called; (TA;) as does AZ. (Mgh.) A rájiz says,
halo yanofaEanoka Alyawoma Uino hamRato bihimo
kavorapu maA tuwSiI wataEoqaAdu AlrRatamo
[Will the muchness of thine enjoining, and the tying of the retem, be indeed of use to thee to-day, if she be desirous of them?]. (T, S, Mgh.) ― -b2- See also ratiymapN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also A [leathern water-bag such as is called] mazaAdap that is filled (IAar, T, K) with water: (IAar, T:) or a [water-skin such as is called] mazaAd. (M, TT.) ＝ -A3- And A road, or way; or the middle, or main part and middle, thereof; or a beaten track; syn. maHajRapN. (IAar, T, K.) ＝ -A4- And Suppressed, low-sounding, occult, or secret, speech or language. (IAar, T, K.) ＝ -A5- And Perfect shame or sense of shame or pudency. (IAar, T, K.)

ratomapN c
ratomapN: see ratiymapN.

ratamapN c
ratamapN: see ratamN [of which it is the n. un.]: ― -b2- and see also ratiymapN.

ratomaMCu c
ratomaMCu A she-camel that eats the plant called AlrRatam, and keeps to it, and is fond of it. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And That carries the filled mazaAdap (K, TA) called ratam. (TA.)

rutAmN c
rutAmN A thing broken in pieces, or into small pieces; crushed; or crumbled. (K, TA.)

ratiymN c
ratiymN: see ratomN: ＝ -A2- and see also ratiymapN. ＝ -A3- Also A slow pace. (K.)

ratiymapN c
ratiymapN (T, S, M, Mgh, K) and ratamapN↓, (T, M, L,) the latter written thus by IB on the authority of 'Alee Ibn-Hamzeh, (L, TA,) or ratomapN↓, (S, K, [in one copy of the S written ratamp, and in my copy of the Mgh without any syll. signs,] A thread, or string, that is tied upon the finger for the purpose of reminding one (T, S, M, Mgh, K) of some object of want: (T, S:) pl. of the first, rataAYimu (S, M, Mgh, K) and ritaAmN; (M, K;) and [coll. gen. n.] of the second, ratamN↓; (M, IB;) and of the third, [if it be correct,] ratomN↓: (K: in the CK rutomN:) IAar says that ratiymN↓ signifies the thread, or string, for reminding; but others say ratiympN: Lth says that ratimN↓ signifies a thread, or string, that is tied upon the finger, or upon the signet-ring, for a sign, or token: (T:) and IB cites the verse cited above voce ratamN as an ex. of this word in the sense here assigned to it as a pl. [or coll. gen. n.]; (TA;) and so does AZ. (Mgh.) The binding of rataAYim [upon the fingers] is forbidden in a trad.: and it is said that Almusotacokiru biAlrRataAYimi musotahodfN llXRataAYm [He who seeks to remember by means of the threads, or strings, that are tied upon the fingers for the purpose of reminding becomes a butt for revilings]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also ratamN, in four places.

rutaAmay c
rutaAmay [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned], like sukaAray, Persons affected with swooning from eating the plant called AlrRatam. (K.)

entry.key: maA zaAla raAtimFA Ealay hecaA AlOamori

superEntry.entry:
maA zaAla raAtimFA Ealay hecaA AlOamori c
maA zaAla raAtimFA Ealay hecaA AlOamori means He ceased not to be constantly occupied in this affair: (T, M, K, * TA:) Yaakoob asserts that the m of rAtmA is a substitute [for b], though ratama does not occur in the sense of rataba: (M, TA:) IJ says that this may be the case, or that the word may be from AlrRatamapu and AlrRatiymapu. (TA.) [See also raAtbN: and see turotumN, below.]

Oarotamu c
Oarotamu [app. Having his nose broken. ― -b2- And hence,] One who does not speak clearly, nor intelligibly; as though his nose were broken: occurring in a trad.: or, as some relate it, Oarovamu [q. v.]. (TA.)

XarRu turotumN c
XarRu turotumN and turotamN Continual, or constant, evil: (K, TA:) the m is a substitute for the b of turotuab; and the former t is augmentative, because there is no word like juEofarN consisting of radical letters. (TA.) [See also raAtimFA, above.]

marotuwmN c
marotuwmN: see ratomN.

1 ravRa c
1. ravRa, (T, S, M, &c.,) sec. pers. [ravavota and ravivota and] ravuvota, (Msb,) aor.
raviva
(T, S, M, K) and
ravava
(M) and
ravuva
, (Msb, TA,) the last being of ravRa of the class of qaruba, (Msb,) inf. n. ravaAvapN (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and ruvuwvapN; (M, Msb, K;) and ArvR↓; (S, M, Msb, K;) both authorized by AZ; the latter at first disallowed by As, but afterwards allowed by him; (M;) It was, or became, old, and worn out; (T, S, M, A, Mgh, Msb;) and mean, or bad; (M;) namely, a garment, (T, S, M, A, Mgh,) and a rope, (S, M, A,) or other thing, (S, Msb,) i. e. anything, but mostly said of what is worn as clothing, or spread as furniture: (M:) or he, or it, was, or became, threadbare, shabby, or mean. (M, K:) said of a man, it has for its aor. yaravRu, and inf. n. ravaAvapN. (M.) ravaAvapu AlhayoYapi means An old, worn-out, state of garb or apparel; and a bad condition. (Mgh.) And you say, fiy hayoYatihi ravaAvapN In his garb, or apparel, is threadbareness, shabbiness, or meanness. (S.) And ravRato hayoYapu AlXRaxoSi, and ArvRt↓, (assumed tropical:) The aspect, or state, or condition, of the person was, or became, weak, and vile, mean, paltry, or despicable. (Msb.) [And ravRa AlrRajulu (assumed tropical:) The man was, or became, old, and worn out; or weak,
&c.: see ravRN.] ― -b2- [And hence,] fiI hecaA Alxabari ravaAvapN (tropical:) In this information, announcement, piece of news, or narration, is unsoundness, invalidity, or incorrectness; and so, fiyhi rakaAkapN. (A, TA.)

4 ArvR c
4. ArvR: see above, in two places. ― -b2- Also, said of a man, His rope was, or became, old, and worn out. (M.) ＝ -A2- ArvRhu He, (K,) or it, i. e. wear, attrition, or wear and tear, (Th, M,) rendered it old, and worn out; and mean, or bad; (Th, M;) or threadbare, shabby, or mean; (K;) namely, anything, but mostly used in relation to what is worn as clothing, or spread as furniture. (M.)

8 AirotavavonaA rivRapa Alqawomi c
8. AirotavavonaA rivRapa Alqawomi We collected, (T, S, M,) or bought, (M,) the paltry, mean, or vile, chattels, or articles of furniture, of the people, or party, (T, S, M,) consisting of old and worn-out garments or pieces of cloth. (S, M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AurotuvRa (of the pass. form, S, K) (tropical:) He (a man) was carried off from the field of battle wounded (S, A, K) so as to be rendered weak, (A,) retaining remains of life: (S, K:) from rivRapN as meaning the “ weak ” of mankind, who are likened to the paltry, mean, or vile, chattels, or articles of furniture, termed rivRapN: (A:) or he, being smitten in battle, and wounded so as to be rendered weak, was carried off, retaining remains of life, and then died: (T:) or he (a wounded man) was carried off from the field of battle retaining remains of life; because, in that case, he is weak, or is thrown down like the chattels, or articles of furniture, termed rivRapN. (Mgh.) And marRabayonahumo faQrotavRahumo (tropical:) [He passed amid them, and carried them off from the field of battle wounded so as to be rendered weak, but retaining remains of life]. (A.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] AirotavRa (assumed tropical:) He slaughtered a she-camel belonging to him, (T, K,) or a sheep or goat, or the like, (T,) by reason of [its] emaciation. (T, K.)

ravRN c
ravRN Old, and worn out; (T, S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) and mean, or bad; (M;) and raviyvN↓ signifies the same, (M, A, K,) as does also OaravRu↓, (A, K,) and rivRapN↓: (M, TA: [but this last is app. a subst, as it is said to be in another place in the M and in the TA, meaning a thing that is old, and worn out; &c.:]) applied to a garment, (T, M, A, Mgh,) and a rope, (A,) or a thing (S, M, Msb) of any kind, but mostly to what is worn as clothing, or spread as furniture: (M:) the pl. of ravRN is rivaAvN. (S, M, Msb.) You say hayoYapN ravRapN An old, worn-out, state of garb or apparel; such as is in bad condition. (Mgh.) And rajulN ravRu AlhayoYapi A man whose garb, or apparel, is old, and worn out; (T, S, * M;) threadbare, shabby, or mean. (M.) This last phrase is [also] tropical [as meaning (tropical:) A man whose aspect, or state, or condition, is weak, and vile, mean, paltry, or despicable: see 1, last sentence but two]. (A.) And one says also rajulN ravRN (assumed tropical:) [A man old, and worn out; or weak, &c.]. (T.) ― -b2- And [hence,] kalaAmN ravRN (tropical:) Meagre, unsubstantial, or flimsy, speech or language. (A.) ― -b3- See also what next follows.

rivRapN c
rivRapN (T, S, M, Mgh, K) and ravRN↓ (T, M, K) The paltry, mean, or vile, chattels, or articles of furniture, (T, S, M, A, K,) of the house or tent, (S, M, A, K,) consisting of old and worn-out garments or pieces of cloth: (S, M:) or such are termed rivRapu AlmutaAEi: (Mgh:) the pl. of rivRapN is rivavN (T, S, K) and rivaAvN: (S, K:) it is a subst. from ravRa signifying “ it was, or became, old, and worn out, ” and “ mean, or bad; ” said of anything, but mostly of what is worn as clothing, or spread as furniture, and of a rope: (M:) [i. e. it means any such thing that is old, and worn out, and mean, or bad:] see also ravRN. ― -b2- Hence, (T, A, Mgh,) rivRapN signifies (tropical:) The weak of mankind; (T, S, M, A, Mgh, K;) [the old, and worn-out, thereof;] and the refuse, or lowest or basest or meanest sort, thereof: (S, M:) as being likened to the chattels, or articles of furniture, thus termed. (A, Mgh.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) A foolish, or stupid, woman; one who is unsound, or deficient, in intellect or understanding. (S, K.)

raviyvN c
raviyvN: see ravRN. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Wounded; and so murotavRN↓: (TA:) or wounded, but retaining remains of life. (S, K.) [See the latter epithet below.]

OaravRu c
OaravRu: see ravRN.

murivRN c
murivRN A man whose rope is old, and worn out. (K.)

murotavRN c
murotavRN (tropical:) One who is carried off from the field of battle (Th, S, M) wounded [so as to be rendered weak (see 8)], (S,) retaining remains of life; (Th, S, M;) if slain, he is not thus termed: (Th, M:) or one who is thrown prostrate, and wounded so as to be rendered weak, in battle, and is carried off alive, and then dies. (M.) See also raviyvN. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Falling down, and weak: from ravRN applied to a garment that is old, and worn out. (TA.)

1 ravaOa c
1. ravaOa, (S, M, K,) aor.
ravaAa
, (M, K,) inf. n. ravoCN, (S, M,) He drew milk from the udder upon sour milk, so that it thickened, (S, K,) and became what is termed raviyoYap: (K:) or he mixed fresh milk with sour milk: or, as some say, he made milk to become what is termed raviyoYap: (M:) or it has this last signification, and also signifies he mixed [in an absolute sense]. (K.) [Az says,] I heard an Arab of the desert, of Benoo-Mudarris, say to a servant of his, AirovaOo liI lubayonapF OaXorabuhaA [Mix thou for me a little milk so as to make raviyoYap, which I will drink]. (T.) And you say, ravaOa Alqawoma (M, K) and ravaOa lahumo (M) He made for the party raviyoYap. (M, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] humo yarovaWuwna raOoyahumo, (S,) and ravaWuwA raOoyahumo, (M,) inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) They confuse, or confound, and they confused, or confounded, their judgment, or opinion. (S, M. [See also 8.]) ― -b3- And [hence also, perhaps, as rvyYp is said to be beaten with a mijodaH in the mixing of it,] He beat (K) with a staff, or stick. (TA.) ＝ -A2- It (anger) became stilled, or appeased. (K.) ＝ -A3- He (a camel) became affected with the disease termed ravoOap. (K.) ＝ -A4- Also, (M, K,) inf. n. as above, (M,) a dial. var. of ravaI, meaning He eulogized a man after his death [in verse or otherwise; or he wept for him, or over him, enumerating his good qualities or actions]: (M, K: *) and in like manner one says of a woman eulogizing her husband after his death; inf. n. maroviYapN: (M:) ISk mentions an Arab woman's saying ravaOotu zawojiI biOaboyaAtK [I eulogized my husband after his death with verses]; pronouncing the verb with C; but it is originally without C: (S, Sgh:) Fr says that her doing this arose from her finding them to say ravaOotu AllRabana and her therefore supposing Almaroviyap to be from the same source: (TA in the present art.:) or, accord. to Fr, their chasteness of speech sometimes induced them to pronounce with C that which is [properly] without C; and thus they said ravaOotu AlmayRita and labRaOotu biAlHajRi and HalRaOotu AlsRawiyqa. (TA in art. rvw.)

4 OarovaAa
4: see the next paragraph.

8 ArtvO c
8. ArtvO It (milk) thickened, or became thick: (S, K:) and so ArvO↓, (M, K,) in some one or more of the dialects. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ArtvO Ealayohimo Oamoruhumo (assumed tropical:) Their case, or affair, became confused to them. (S, M.) And ArtvO fiI raOoyihi (assumed tropical:) He made a confusion in his judgment, or opinion. (S, K.) And humo yarotaviYuwna Oamorahumo (assumed tropical:) [app. for fiI Oamorihimo, and thus meaning They are confused, or they make a confusion, in their case, or affair: or, otherwise, they confuse their case, or affair]: from AlrRaviyoYap; (T, TA;) and if so, tropical. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also He drank what is termed raviyoYap. (T, K.)

ravoCN c
ravoCN: see ravoOapN.

ruvoCN c
ruvoCN: see ruvoOapN.

ravoOapN c
ravoOapN, (M, TA,) or ravoCN↓, (K, [probably a mistranscription,]) (assumed tropical:) Littleness of intelligence or sagacity: (M, K:) and (assumed tropical:) weakness of heart: (M, TA:) and (assumed tropical:) foolishness, or stupidity; (K;) and so raviyoYapN↓ (Th, M, K) and marovaON↓. (TA in art. wOb.) ― -b2- Hence, perhaps, (TA,) the first of these words (ravoOapN) signifies [also] (assumed tropical:) A certain disease in a camel's shoulder-joint, (K,) in consequence of which he limps. (TA.)

ruvoOapN c
ruvoOapN, (M, TA,) or ruvoCN↓, (K, [probably a mistranscription,]) Blackness mixed with speckles of white; or the reverse: syn. ruqoTapN. (M, K.)

raviyoYapN c
raviyoYapN Sour milk upon which fresh milk is drawn from the udder, so that it becomes thick: (Lh, S, M, K:) or fresh milk poured upon sour, (As, T, M, Mgh,) and then stirred about with a [wooden instrument called] mijodaH until it becomes thick: (Lh, M:) or fresh milk upon which sour milk is poured, then left a while, whereupon thin yellow water [or whey] comes forth, and is poured away from it, and then the thick is drunk. (Har p. 451.) One says, AlrRaviyoYapu tafovaOu AlgaDaba (S, TA) What is termed rvyYp stills, or appeases, anger: (TA:) alluding to [the effect produced
by] a small kindness: a saying which originated from a man's being incensed against some persons. and being hungry, and their giving him to drink some rvyYp, whereupon his anger became appeased: (S in art. fvO:) hence it became a proverb. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also ravoOapN.

OarovaOu c
OarovaOu, fem. ravoMCu, A ram, and a ewe, black speckled with white; or the reverse: syn. OaroqaTu, and raqoTaMCu. (M, K.)

marovaON c
marovaON: see ravoOapN.

marovuwoCN c
marovuwoCN (assumed tropical:) A man weak-hearted, and of little intelligence or sagacity. (M.) [See also marovuwRN, in art. rvw.]

1 ravada AlmataAEa c
1. ravada AlmataAEa, (T, S, M, A, K,) aor.
ravuda
, inf. n. ravodN; (S, M;) and Artvdhu↓, (K,) in some copies of the K Arvdhu↓ [which I doubt not to be a mistranscription]; (TA;) He put the goods, or household goods, or utensils and furniture, one upon another, or together, in regular order, or compactly, (T, S, M, A, K,) or side by side. (S.) ― -b2- ravadato bayoDahaA She (a hen) collected together her eggs. (IAar, M.) ― -b3- ruvidati AlqaSoEapu biAlvRariydi The bowl was heaped with the vryd [or crumbled, or broken, bread, moistened with broth,] put together and made even. (M, L.) ― -b4- ravada HaAjatahu (assumed tropical:) He deferred, delayed, postponed, or put off, his (another's) needful affairs; the sing. noun being used for the pl. (L, from a trad.) ＝ -A2- ravida, aor.
ravada
, (K,) inf. n. ravadN; (TK;) and Arvd↓; i. q. kadira; (K;) said of a man [as meaning He was, or became, disturbed, perturbed, or troubled, in mind]; (TA;) or said of water [as meaning it was, or became, turbid, thick, or muddy.] (TK.)

4 Oarovada
4: see 1, first sentence. ＝ -A2- ArvdwA They stayed, or abode [in a place; not journeying, or departing: see rivodapN]. (Ks, S, K.) ― -b2- And Arvd, said of one digging, He reached the moist earth. (ISk, S, K.) ＝ -A3- See also 1, last sentence.

8 Uirotavada
8: see 1, first sentence.

rivodN c
rivodN: see rivodapN.

ravadN c
ravadN: see raviydN. ― -b2- Also The goods, or utensils and furniture, of a house or tent, that are of a worthless, paltry, mean, or vile, kind, or that are held in little account. (M, L.) ― -b3- And Weak, or powerless, people: (S, L, K:) differing from murotviduwna [q. v.]. (S, L.) One says, tarakonaA EalaI AlmaMCi ravadFA maA yuTiyquwna taHamRulFA [We left at the water weak, or powerless, people, unable to take up their goods and to depart]. (S, L.)

rvodapN c
rvodapN, (IAar, T, S, M, L,) or rivodN↓, (K,) or both, (TA,) A company, (IAar, S,) or a numerous company, (T, L,) of men, (IAar, T, S, M, L,) staying, or abiding, [in a place,] (IAar, T, S, M, L, K,) not journeying, or departing, (S,) when the rest of them journey, or depart; (T;) as also livodapN. (T, L.)

mataAEN raviydN c
mataAEN raviydN (S, M, A, L, K) and marovuwdN↓ (S, M, L, K) Goods, or household-goods, or utensils and furniture, put one upon another, or together, in regular order, or compactly, (S, M, A, L, K,) or side by side; (S;) as also ravadN↓; (A, K;) or this last, [as a subst.,] household-goods, or utensils and furniture, so put. (T, S, M, L.) And TaEaAmN raviydN and marovuwdN↓ Food, or wheat, heaped up. (T, L.) And xubozN raviydN [Bread piled up]. (A.) And AlvRariydu fiI AlqaSoEapi [The crumbled, or broken, bread, moistened with broth, is heaped and put together and made even in the bowl]. (A.)

marovadN c
marovadN A generous man: (ISk, K:) from Oarovada signifying “ he reached the moist earth in digging. ” (ISk.) ― -b2- And Almarovadu is a name of The lion. (S, K.)

marovuwdN c
marovuwdN: see raviydN, in two places.

tarakotuhumo murotavidiyna maA taHamRaluwA baEodu c
tarakotuhumo murotavidiyna maA taHamRaluwA baEodu means I left them putting their goods, or utensils and furniture, one upon another, (T, * S, M, * L, K,) without having that whereon to remove them, (S, L,) [not having yet taken them up and departed:] thus murotaviduwna differs from ravadN [q. v.]. (S, L.)

1 ravama c
1. ravama, (T, S, M, K,) aor.
ravima
, (M, K,) inf. n. ravomN, (T, M,) He broke one's nose, (S, M, K,) or his mouth, (T, M, K,) so as to make it bleed, (S,) or so that the blood dropped from it: (M, K:) and ratama is a dial. var. thereof: (TA:) rutomN and ravamN signify also any breaking. (T, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ravamoto OanofahaA biAlTRiybi (assumed tropical:) She (a woman) smeared her nose with perfume. (S, M, K. [See marovuwmN, below.]) ― -b3- And ruvima, said of the manosim [or foot, or sole of the foot, or extremity of the fore foot,] of a camel, (T, M,) It was wounded so that the blood flowed from it: (T:) or it bled. (M.) ＝ -A2- ravima, (M, K,) aor.
ravama
, (K,) inf. n. ravamN; (M;) and ArvmR↓, inf. n. AirovimaAmN; (S, K;) said of a horse, He had what is termed ravamN↓ [in a copy of the M written ravom, but expressly said in the K to be muHarRakap,] and ruvomapN↓ [in a copy of the T written ravomp, and in a copy of the M rvamp, but said in the K to be with damm]; (S, K;) i. e. a whiteness in the upper lip: (AO, T, S:) if in the lower lip, it is termed lumoZapN: (AO, TA:) or a whiteness in the extremity of the nose: (M, K:) or any whiteness, (M, K,) little or much, (M,) upon the upper lip, reaching to the place of the halter: or a whiteness in the nose. (M, K.) The epithet applied to the horse in this case is Oarovamu↓ (T, S, M, K) [explained in the Mgh as signifying, thus applied, Of which the upper lip is white,] and ravimN↓; fem. of the former ravomaMCu. (M, K.) ― -b2- [ravima is also app. said of one's nose, as meaning It was much scratched, and slit, in its extremity, so that the blood issued from it and fell in drops: see ravamN, which seems to be its inf. n. in this sense, below.]

9 UirovamRa
9: see above.

ravomN c
ravomN: see raviymN: and see also a reading of a verse cited in art. rtm, voce ratomN.

ravamN c
ravamN: see 1. ― -b2- Also, [app. as inf. n. of ravima, q. v.,] A vehement scratching, and slitting, of the extremity of the nose, so that the blood issues from it and falls in drops. (T.)

ravimN c
ravimN: see 1.

ravomapN c
ravomapN A weak, or scanty, rain; as also ravamapN↓: pl. rivaAmN (K.) ― -b2- [Hence, perhaps,] halo Einodaka ravomapN mino xabarK (assumed tropical:) Hast thou somewhat of news, or tidings. (K, * TA. [In the CK, erroneously, mn xubozK.])

ruvomapN c
ruvomapN: see 1.

ravamapN c
ravamapN: see ravomapN.

raviymN c
raviymN: see marovuwmN, in two places. ― -b2- HaSFI raviymN Pebbles broken in pieces; as also ravomN↓: (T:) or ravymu AlHaSaI means what are crushed, of the pebbles, by the feet of camels. (TA.)

ravimapN c
ravimapN i. q. faOorapN: (K; and so in the M, accord. to the TT:) [or] correctly, qaArapN, with qAf. (TA. [But no evidence of the correctness of this reading is adduced in the TA.])

Oarovamu c
Oarovamu; fem. ravomaMCu: see 1; and see also OalomaZu. ― -b2- [Also, app., applied to a man, Having his nose much scratched, and slit, in its extremity, so that the blood issues from it and falls in drops. ― -b3- And hence,] One who does not speak clearly, nor correctly, [as though his nose were broken at the end and so closed, or] by reason of some evil affection of his tongue: occurring in a trad.: or, as some relate it, Oarotamu [q. v.] (TA.)

marovimN c
marovimN: see what next follows.

mirovamN c
mirovamN The nose; (M, K;) in some one or more of the dialects; (M;) as also marovimN↓. (K.)

OaroDN muravRamapN c
OaroDN muravRamapN Land rained upon [app. with such rain as is termed ravomapN]. (K.)

marovuwmN c
marovuwmN (T, S, M, K) and raviymN↓ (M, K) A nose, (T, S, M, K,) or mouth, (M, K,) broken, and smeared with blood: (T:) or broken so as to be made to bleed: (S:) or broken so that the blood drops from it: (M, K:) and anything smeared with blood, or (so in the M, but in the K “ and ”) broken. (M, K.) ― -b2- And the former, as being likened to a nose in the state above described, (assumed tropical:) A woman's nose smeared with perfume. (T, S.) ― -b3- Also A camel's foot wounded by stones, so that it bleeds; like malovuwmN; (S, TA;) and in like manner raviymN↓ applied to a manosim [see 1, third sentence]: or, accord. to Ibn-Hishám El-Lakhmee, OaxofaAfN marovuwmapN signifies camels' feet upon which the stones have had an effect, or made marks. (TA.)

1 ravawotu c
1. ravawotu: see 1 in art. rvI, passim.

ravowN c
ravowN Milk such as is termed raviyoYapN. (M, K. [See the latter word, in art. rvO.])

marovuwRN c
marovuwRN, meaning A man weak in intellect, is from AlrRavoyapu, [mentioned in art. rvI,] and [therefore]
by rule should be maroviIRN. (M.) And marovuwoCN [signifies the same, (see this word, in art. rvO,) and in like manner, accord. to ISd,] is from AlrRavoyapu, irreg., being with C (M in art. rvI.)

1 ravayotu AlmayRita c
1. ravayotu AlmayRita, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor. Oaroviyhi, (Msb,) inf. n. maroviyapN (S, M, Msb, K) and marovaApN and rivaAyapN and rivaMCN and ravoIN; (M, K;) and ravawotuhu; (S, M in art. rvw, * and K;) I wept for, or over, [or bewailed,] the dead man, and [eulogized him, or] enumerated his good qualities or actions; (S, K;) as also ravRayotuyhu↓, inf. n. taroviyapN; and taravRayotuhu↓: (K:) and also I composed verses on the dead man; (S, K;) [composed an elegy, a dirge, or an epicedium, on him;] eulogized him in verse: (TA:) or I eulogized the dead man, and wept for him or over him; as also ravRayotuhu↓: (M:) or, accord. to Lth, ravaI fulaAnFA, aor. yaroviyhi, inf. n. ravoIN and maroviyapN, signifies he wept for, or over, such a one after his death; and rvRAhu↓, inf. n. troviyapN, he eulogized him after his death: (T:) or ravayotu AlmayRita and lahu taravRayotu↓ signify I felt, or expressed, pity, or compassion, for the dead man. (Msb. [See also ravaI lahu, in what follows.]) You say also, ravati AlmaroOapu zawojahaA, (IAar, T,) or baEolahaA, (M,) aor. taroviyhi (IAar, T, M) and tarovuwhu, (IAar, T, and M in art. rvw,) inf. n. rivaAyapN [&c.]; (T;) and raviyatohu, aor. tarovaAhu, inf. n. rvaAyapN [&c.]; (Lh, M;) and taravRatohu↓; (M;) [The woman wept for, or over, her husband, &c., he being dead:] and ISk mentions an Arab woman's saying ravaOotu zawojiI biOaboyaAtK; pronouncing the verb with C (S. [See 1 (last sentence) in art. rvO.]) And you say, ravaI lahu He was, or became, tender, pitiful, or compassionate, towards him. (S, M, K.) And maA yaroviI fulaAnN liI Such a one does not lament, complain, or express pain or grief, for me; nor does he care for me: and UinRiI laA OaroviI lahu [Verily I do not lament, &c., for him], inf. n. marovaApN and ravoIN. (T.) ― -b2- ravayotu Eanohu HadiyvFA, (AA, Lh, T, S, M, K,) aor. OaroviI, inf. n. rivaAyapN, (AA, T, S, K,) I mentioned a story, or tradition, received from him: (AA, T, S, K:) and (K) I retained in my memory a story, or tradition, received from him: (Lh, M, K:) but the phrase that is well known is navayotu Eanohu xabarFA, meaning “ I bore information, or tidings, from him: ” (M:) and ravawotu Eanohu HadiyvFA also has the second of these meanings; (M and K * in art. rvw;) or the first of them: (K in that art.:) but the phrase that is well known is navawotu Eanohu xabarFA: (M in that art.:) accord. to E-'Okeylee, you say, ravawonaA bayonanaA HadiyvFA and ravayonaAhu [i. e. We mentioned among us a story, or tradition]; and tanaAvayonaAhu means the like thereof. (T.) ＝ -A2- raviIa, (IAar, M, K, [and accord. to the TA, ruviIa, but it appears from the context that this is taken from a copy of the M, and is wrong,]) inf. n. ravoIN, by rule ravFI, (IAar, M,) He was, or became, affected with what is termed ravoyapN, (IAar, M, K,) in all the senses of this word. (K.) ＝ -A3- [A meaning assigned to ravaA by Golius belongs to ravaOa, q. v.]

2 ravRaIa
2: see 1, in three places.

5 taravRaIa
5: see 1, in three places.

8 ArtvI c
8. ArtvI. The meanings assigned to this verb by Golius belong to ArtvO, q. v.]

ravoyapN c
ravoyapN A pain in the knees and [other] joints: (S:) or a pain in the joints, and in the arms and legs, or hands and feet, or fore and hind legs: (M, K:) or a swelling, (M, K,) and a [malady such as is termed] ZulaAE, (M,) in the legs of a beast: (M, K:) or anything that prevents a person from rising and going away, or going quickly, occasioned by old age or pain: (M, K, * TA: AlAilotifaAt in the K is a mistake for AlAinobiEaAv: TA:) pl. ravayaAtN. (S.) ― -b2- Also, and raviyRapN↓, Weakness. (Th, M, K. [Aw DaEofK in the CK is a mistake for waAlDRaEofu.]) ― -b3- And Foolishness, or stupidity. (Th, M, K.) And you say, fiI Oamorihi ravoyapN In his affair is a flagging, or remissness, or languor. (M.)

raviyRapN c
raviyRapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

ravRaMCapN c
ravRaMCapN and ravRaAyapN↓, epithets applied to a woman, (T, S, K,) Who wails much (T, * K, TA) for her husband: or who weeps much for, or over, another, of those whom she holds in honour. (TA.)

ravRaAyapN c
ravRaAyapN: see what next precedes.

OarovaI c
OarovaI A man who does not perform an affair firmly, soundly, or thoroughly, (M, K, TA,) by reason of his weakness. (TA.)

marovaApN c
marovaApN (M, K) and maroviyapN↓ (S, M, Msb, K) [see 1: used as simple substs., A lamentation for one dead; an elegy; a dirge; an epicedium: pl. miraAvK].

maroviyapN c
maroviyapN: see what next precedes.

1 rajRahu c
1. rajRahu, (S, A, Msb,) aor.
rajuja
, (S, Msb,) inf. n. rajRN, (S, Msb, K,) He put it in motion, or in a state of commotion or agitation: (S, A, Msb, K:) he put it in a state of convulsion, or violent motion; or made it to shake, quake, or quiver: (S, A, TA:) as also rajorajahu↓. (A.) Hence, in the Kur [lvi-4], UicaA rujRati AlOaroDu rajRFA When the earth shall be convulsed with violent convulsion. (TA.) And rajRa AlbaAba He shook the door violently. (TA from a trad.) ＝ -A2- See also 8.

4 OarajRato c
4. OarajRato She (a mare) was near to bringing forth, and the part on either side of her tail (SalaAhaA) quivered, or quaked; (K;) as also AirotajRato↓. (TA.) The part. n. applied to the mare in this case is murijRN↓ [without p]. (K.)

8 ArtjR c
8. ArtjR, (S, A,. Msb,) inf. n. AirotijaAjN, (K,) It was, or became, in a state of commotion or agitation; (S, A, Msb, * K;) or of convulsion, or violent motion; or it shook, quaked, or quivered; (S, A, K;) as also tarajoraja↓; (A, K;) and rajoraja↓ inf. n. rajorajapN; (S, K; but they mention only the inf. n. of this verb;) and so rajRa↓, inf. n. rajRN: (K, * TA; but of this verb, also, only the inf. n. is mentioned:) ArtjR is quasi-pass. of rajRahu; (T, A, Msb;) and is said of the sea, as meaning it was, or became, in a state of commotion or agitation (S, Msb) with its waves; and in like manner of other things: (S:) and tarajoraja↓ signifies it (a thing) went to and fro; and is said of a woman's flesh; (S;) or [particularly] of her hinder part; (A;) or of both. (TA.) It is said in a trad. respecting the blowing of the horn [on the day of resurrection], fatarotajRu AlOaroDu biOaholihaA And the earth shall be in a state of commotion or agitation, with its inhabitants. (TA.) See also 4. ― -b2- [Hence,] ArtjR AlZRalaAmu (assumed tropical:) The darkness became confused. (Msb.) ― -b3- And ArtjR AlkalaAmu (assumed tropical:) The speech, or language, became confused; mentioned by ISd in this art: (TA:) or AirotajRa Ealayohi AlkalaAmu (tropical:) the speech, or language, became conflicting and confused to him. (A.) [See also AurotujRa Ealayohi in the first paragraph of art. rtj.]

R. Q. 1 rajoraja c
R. Q. 1. rajoraja, inf. n. rajorajapN: see 1: ＝ -A2- and see also 8. ― -b2- rajorajapN also signifies The being fatigued, tired, weary, or jaded, (K, TA,) and weak [app. so as to shake, or totter]. (TA.)

R. Q. 2 tarajoraja c
R. Q. 2. tarajoraja: see 8, in two places.

rajRapN c
rajRapN [app. A confused, or murmuring, or rumbling, sound:] the confusion of the voices [or the confused voices] of a company of men: and the sound of thunder. (TA.) sumiEato rajRapu Sadorihi [app. meaning The rumbling of his chest was heard] occurs in a trad. as describing the result of [fright occasioned by] a cry, or shout. (TA.)

rujRapN c
rujRapN A state of confusion: so in the phrase, waqaEa fiI rujRapK [He fell into a state of confusion]. (Mgh in art. rtj.)

rajajN c
rajajN A state of commotion, agitation, convulsion, shaking, quaking, or quivering. (TA.)

rajaAjN c
rajaAjN Lean, or emaciated, sheep or goats, (S, K,) and camels: (TA:) and naEojapN rajaAjapN a lean, or an emaciated, ewe; (S, K;) or a weak ewe, that has no marrow in her bones. (As, TA.) And Weak men, and camels; (S, K;) and so rajoraAjN↓ applied to the latter, and to men as meaning weak, without understanding, intellect, or intelligence. (TA.) Hence, it is said of men who have become weak by reason of travel, and whose camels upon which they are riding have also become weak,
fahumo rajaAjN waEalaI rajaAji
[And they are weak men, and upon weak beasts]. (S.)

rijaAjapN c
rijaAjapN The covert, or retreat, of a lion. (TA.)

rajRaMCu c
rajRaMCu A she-camel having a large hump: (S:) or having a large, and shaking, quaking, or quiver-
ing, hump: (K:) IDrd says, in the Jm, They assert it to mean having a shaking, quaking, or quivering, hump; but I know not what is its true meaning. (TA.)

rajorajN c
rajorajN an epithet applied to that which is mutarajorij↓ [or In a state of commotion or agitation; or of convulsion, or violent motion; or shaking, quaking, or quivering, or going to and fro]; (S;) [and so rajoraAjN↓.]

rijorijN c
rijorijN: see rijorijapN. ― -b2- Also Slaver, or drivel. (TA. [See, again, rijorijapN.]) ― -b3- And i. q. maMCu qariysK [app. meaning The fluid of the gelatinous substance termed qariys, prepared from fish &c.]. (TA.) ― -b4- And Crumbled, or broken, bread, (variyd,) made soft with grease, or gravy: (TA:) and rijorijapN↓ [as its n. un.] signifies a mess of such bread (variydapN) so made soft; (Sudot;;) and variydapN rajoraAjapN [signifies the same, or] a mess of such bread made soft and compact. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, [said in the K and TA to be like qiloqilN, but in the CK like fulofulN,] A certain plant. (S, K.)

rijorijapN c
rijorijapN Remains of water in a watering-trough, or tank, (S, K,) turbid, and mixed with mud; (S;) as also rijorijN↓: in a trad., in which it occurs, accord. to one relation it is rajoraAjapN↓; but rijorijapN is the word commonly known: accord. to As, it is syn. with radohapN: the pl. is rajaAriju. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Water mixed with slaver, or drivel. (TA.) ― -b3- And Spittle, or saliva, that has gone forth from the mouth; or flowing saliva: (K, TA:) so in the saying, UinRa fulaAnFA kaviyru AlrRijorijapi [Verily such a one has much spittle, &c.: and rijorijN signifies nearly, or exactly, the same]. (TA.) ― -b4- See also rijorijN. ＝ -A2- Also A large company, or troop, in war. (K.) ＝ -A3- And [an epithet signifying] Devoid of understanding, intellect, or intelligence; (K:) and devoid of good: (TA:) or the evil, bad, or corrupt, of mankind, in a pl. sense: (Nh, TA:) or the low, base, vile, or mean, of mankind, or of the young thereof; or the lowest, basest, or meanest, sort, or refuse, of mankind, that have no understanding, intellect, or intelligence; as also rajoraAjapN↓: (Sh, TA:) or, in a pl. sense, such as have no understanding, intellect, or intelligence, of a people, or party. (El-Kilábee, TA.)

rajoraAjN c
rajoraAjN: see rajorajN. ― -b2- [Hence,] rajoraAjapN A woman, (S,) or girl, (A,) whose flesh, (S,) or hinder part, (A,) quivers, or quakes; (S, A;) [and so mutarajorijapN↓, occurring in the A and TA in art. dyS.] ― -b3- And variydapN rajoraAjapN: see rijorijN. ― -b4- And katiybapN rajoraAjapN (tropical:) And army, or a troop, agitated to and fro (A, L) in its march, (L,) scarcely moving onwards, (A, L,) by reason of its multitude: (L:) or as though agitated to and fro, and not moving onwards, by reason of its multitude. (S.) ― -b5- See also rajaAjN. ― -b6- Also A certain medicine, (L, K,) well known. (K.)

rajoraAjapN c
rajoraAjapN [fem. of rajoraAjN, q. v. ― -b2- Also, as a subst.,] A mess of the kind of food called faAluwc [q. v.]. (A.) ＝ -A2- See also rijorijapN, in two places.

raAjRN c
raAjRN Having a confusion of voices, by reason of the multitude of the people therein. (Aboo-Moosà, TA in art. zj)

murijRN c
murijRN: see 4.

mutarajorijN c
mutarajorijN; and its fem., with p: see rajorajN, and rajoraAjN

4 ArjO c
4. ArjO He postponed, put off, deferred, or delayed, (ISk, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) an affair, (ISk, S, Mgh, K,) and a person; (TA;) as also ArjI: (ISk, S, Mgh, Msb, K:) but the former is the better: the inf. n. is UirojaMCN. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [xxxiii. 51], accord. to different readings, turojiICu mano taXaMCu minohunRa or turojiI, meaning Thou mayest put off whom thou wilt of them: addressed peculiarly to the Prophet, exclusively of others of his people. (Zj, TA.) [See also an ex. in the Kur vii. 108 and xxvi. 35; and the various readings mentioned by Bd in the former instance.] ＝ -A2- OarojaOato She (a camel, S, K, and in like manner a pregnant female [of any kind], TA) was, or became, near to bringing forth; as also Oarojato: (S, K:) AA says the former. (S.) ＝ -A3- And ArjO He (a hunter or sportsman) was unsuccessful, getting no game; as also ArjI: (K, TA:) or you say, ArjO AlSRayoda, (TA in art. rjw,) and ArjI AlSRayoda. (K in that art.)

murojaON c
murojaON [pass. part. n. of 4]. It is said in the Kur [ix. 107], (S, K,) as some read, (S,) waMxaruwna, murojaWuwna liOamori QllRehi, (S, K,) or, as others read, murojawona, (S,) meaning [And others are] delayed [for the execution of the decree of God,] until God shall cause to betide them what He willeth. (S, K.)

murojiICN c
murojiICN [act. part. n. of OarojaOa], (S, K,) and murojK [act. part. n. of OarojaI], (S, [in which, however, it is not clearly shown whether the author means that this corresponds to murojiICN or that it is a rel. n. corresponding to murojiYiIRN, the former being certainly the case,]) or not thus, but murojiIRN, (K,) so some say, (TA,) but this is a rel. n. like mrojiYiIRN, (IB, TA,) A man who is one of [the sect called] AlmurojiYapu↓ (S, K) and Almurojiyapu, without teshdeed to the I (K,) accord. to J, AlmurojiyRapu, with teshdeed, (IB,) but this is incorrect, unless as meaning those who are called in relation to the murojiyap, for otherwise it is not allowable. (IB, TA.) The sect called the murojiYap↓ [and murojiyap] are [A sect of Muslim antinomians;] a sect of Muslims who assert that faith (AlUiymaAn) consists in words without works; as though they postponed works to words; asserting that if they do not pray nor fast, their faith will save them: (TA:) a sect who assert that disobedience, with faith, does not injure; and that obedience, with disbelief, does not profit: (KT:) or a sect who do not pronounce judgment upon any one for aught in the present life, but defer judgment to the day of resurrection: (Msb:) those who decide not, against the committers of great sins, aught as to pardon or punishment; deferring the judgment respecting such sins to the day of resurrection. (Mgh in art. jhm.) ― -b2- murojiICN is also applied to a she-camel, and a pregnant female [of any kind], as meaning Near to bringing forth; and so murojiYapN. (TA.)

AlmurojiYapu c
AlmurojiYapu: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

rajulN murojiYiIRN c
rajulN murojiYiIRN (S, IB) and murojiIRN (IB) A man called in relation to the murojiYap (S, IB) or murojiyap (IB.)

1 rajiba c
1. rajiba, aor.
rajaba
, (K,) inf. n. rajabN, (TA,) He (a man, TA) was frightened, or afraid, (K) minohu [at, or of, him or it]. (TK.) ― -b2- And also, (K,) aor. and inf. n. as above; (TA;) and rajaba, aor.
rajuba
, (K,) inf. n. rajobN; (TK;) He was ashamed, or bashful, or shy, (K,) minohu [with respect to him or it]. (TK.) ＝ -A2- rajibahu, (S, A, K,) aor.
rajaba
, (K,) inf. n. rajabN, (A,) He feared him or it: (A:) or he revered him, venerated him, regarded him with awe, and honoured him, or magnified him; (S, K;) namely, a man; [and in like manner, it; see rajabN;] as also rajabahu, (K,) aor.
rajuba
, (TA,) inf. n. rajobN and rujuwbN; and rjRbhu↓, (K,) inf. n. tarojiybN and tarojibapN; (TA;) and Arjbhu↓: (K:) or rjRbhu↓, (Msb,) inf. n. tarojiybN, (S,) signifies [simply] he honoured him, or magnified him. (S, * Msb.) You say, daxalotu faraHRaba biI warajRabaniI↓ [I entered, and he welcomed me with the greeting of maroHabFA, and treated me with honour]. (A.) And a poet says,
OaHomadu rabRiI faraqFA waOarojabuho
i. e. [I praise my Lord with fear,] and magnify Him. (TA.) ＝ -A3- rajaba said of a branch, or twig, It came forth singly. (K. [Perhaps from rajabN as the name of a month which is called “ Rejeb the separate. ”]) ＝ -A4- rajabahu biqawolK sayRiICK is like rajamahu bihi (K,) i. e. He reviled him with a foul, or an evil, saying. (Abu-l-'Omeythil, TA.)

2 rajRaba
2: see 1, in three places. ― -b2- Hence, (S,) tarojiybN signifies also The sacrificing a victim, or victims, in the month of Rejeb: (S, K:) for the [pagan] Arabs used to slaughter animals as sacrifices in that month. (TA.) The days of the said sacrifice were called OayRaAmu tarojiybK: and the victim was called EatiyrapN (S, TA) and rajabiyRapN↓. (TA.) ― -b3- rjbR AlXRajarapa, (Msb,) inf. n. tarojiybN, (S,) He propped up the tree, because of the abundance of its fruit, lest its branches should break; (S, Msb;) sometimes by building a wall, for it to rest upon, because of its weakness: (S:) or tarojiybu naxolapK signifies the building, at the foot of a palm-tree, a structure of the kind called dukRaAn, which is termed rujobapN, for it to rest upon, (K, TA,) because of its leaning, and its being valuable to him, and being weak: (TA:) or the propping up a valuable palm-tree, when it is feared that it will fall,
because of its tallness and the abundance of its fruit, by means of a structure of stones: and also the putting thorns round a palm-tree, lest any one should climb it, and pluck its fruit: (T, TA:) or [in the CK “ and ”] the attaching the racemes of a palm-tree to its branches, binding them with palm-leaves, lest the wind should shake off the fruit: (K, TA:) or the putting thorns round the racemes of a palm-tree, lest anyone should be able to take and eat them: (K, * TA:) and hence the saying cited below, voce murajRabN. (K.) You say [also], Oawoqarato naxoluhumo faOarojabuwhaA↓, meaning [Their palm-trees became laden, or heavily laden, with fruit,] and they consequently propped them up. (A. [But the verb, here, may perhaps be mistranscribed; for the verb commonly known in this sense is not mentioned in the copy of the A from which this i? taken.]) Selámeh Ibn-Jendel says, describing some horses,
kaOanRa OaEonaAqahaA OanoSaAbu tarojiybi
meaning As though their necks were propped palm-trees: or, as some say, the stones on which the victims slain in Rejeb are sacrificed. (TA.) ― -b4- tarojiybu karomK The disposing evenly the shoots of a grape-vine, and putting it in its [appropriate] places, (K, TA,) by means of props. (TA.)

4 Oarojaba
4: see 1: ＝ -A2- and see also 2.

8 Artjb c
8. Artjb is said by Freytag, as on the authority of Meyd, to signify He filled with reverence; was reverend.]

rujobN c
rujobN The part between the rib and the qaSR [or sternum]. (K.) ― -b2- See also OarojaAbN.

rijobN c
rijobN: see OarojaAbN.

rajabN c
rajabN One of the [Arabian] months; (Msb;) [namely, the seventh thereof;] so called because of the honour in which it was held in the Time of Ignorance, (S, A, * K, *) inasmuch as war, or fighting, during it was held unlawful: (S:) in a trad., (TA,) it is called rajabu muDara [Rejeb of Mudar], because Mudar most honoured it: (S, TA:) and it is further distinguished as being between jamaAdaI and XaEobaAn, to show that what is meant by it is not what the [pagan] Arabs called rjb according to the computation founded upon postponement; for they used to postpone it from month to month: (TA:) [it is also called rajabN Alfarodu Rejeb the separate; because it is the only sacred month that is not preceded nor followed by another sacred month; the other sacred months being AlmuHarRamu and cuw AlqaEodapi and cuw AlHajRapi:] the pl. is OirojaAbN (S, Msb, K) and OarojibapN and OarojubN [all pls. of pauc.] (Msb) and rujuwbN and rijaAbN and rajabaAtN (Msb, K) and rajuwbN [or rather this last is a quasi-pl. n.] (TA) and [pl. pl.] OaraAjibu [pl. of OarojubN] and OaraAjiybu [pl. of OarojaAbN]. (Msb.) The dual, rajabaAni, (S, Msb,) or AlrRajabaAni, (A,) [The two Rejebs] is applied to [the two months] rajabN and XaEobaAnu, (S, A, Msb,) by the attribution of predominance to the former. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- See also OarojaAbN.

rujobapN c
rujobapN A thing by means of which a tree is propped up, because of the abundance of its fruit, lest its branches should break: sometimes it is a wall built for it to rest upon, because of its weakness: (S:) a wall, or the like, built round a palm-tree, for it to rest upon, because of its heaviness or its weakness: (Mgh in art. Erw and ErI:) a kind of wide bench of stone or brick (dukRaAnN) built at the foot of a palm-tree, for it to rest upon, (K, TA,) because of its leaning, and being valuable to its owner, and being weak: (TA:) accord. to As, a structure of rock with which a palm-tree is supported by means of forked pieces of wood: (TA:) it is also called rujomapN: (K * and TA in art. rjm:) pl. rujabN. (S.) [See 2.] ― -b2- Also A structure by means of which (S, K) the wolf &c., (S,) or objects of the chase, (K,) are caught: (S, K:) a piece of flesh-meat is put in it, and tied with a small cord; and when the beast pulls it, the rjbp falls upon him. (S.) ＝ -A2- See also riAjibapN.

rajabiyRapN c
rajabiyRapN A victim, (Mgh, TA,) [i. e.] a sheep or goat, (Msb,) which the Arabs used to sacrifice, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) in the Time of Ignorance, to their gods (Msb) in Rejeb, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) the month thus called: (TA:) the doing of which is forbidden: (Msb:) it was abrogated by the ordinance of the OaDoHaI. (Mgh.) See 2.

naxolapN rujabiyRapN c
naxolapN rujabiyRapN A palm-tree having a rujobap to support it; (S, * Mgh in art. Erw and ErI, and K *;) as also rujRabiyRapN; each an extr. rel. n., (K, TA,) and the latter the more so. (TA.)

raAjibN c
raAjibN One who honours his lord, chief, or master. (AA, TA.)

raAjibapN c
raAjibapN sing. of rawaAjibu; (S, K;) or, accord. to Kr, the sing. of this latter is rujobapN↓ [also mentioned as a sing. in the K]; but the correctness of this is doubted: (TA:) the rwAjb are The finger-joints that are next to the ends of the fingers: (S, K:) next to these are the baraAjim: then, the OaXaAjiE, which are next to the kafR: (S:) or the joints of the lowest parts (OuSuwl) of the fingers: (K: [by which is meant the same as by the former explanation, accord. to the TA; though this seems to be more than doubtful:]) or the inner sides of those joints: or the bones of the fingers: (K:) or the finger-joints: (A, K:) or the backs of the sulaAmayaAt [generally meaning the phalanges of the fingers]: or the parts of the sulaAmayaAt between the baraAjim; (K;) which last word [commonly signifies the knuckles, and] is explained by IAar as signifying the wrinkled parts at the joints of the fingers; whereof each finger has three, except the thumb: or the rwAjb are the parts, of the inner sides, between the finger-joints: or [the knuckles next the metacarpal bones; i. e.] the parts that protuberate at the roots of the fingers when the hand is clinched. (TA.) [See also burojumapN, and OaXojaEu.] ― -b2- The raAjibap of a bird is The toe that is next to the daAbirap [or back toe], on the outer side of each foot. (Lth, TA.) ― -b3- rawaAjibu AlHimaAri The veins (Euruwq) of the passages of the voice of the ass. (IAar, K.)

OarojaAbN c
OarojaAbN The OamoEaMC [i. e. bowels, or intestines, into which the food passes from the stomach]: (As, S, K:) it has no pl. (S, K) known to A'Obeyd: (S:) or its sing. is rajabN↓, (Kr, K,) or rujobN↓, (K,) or rijobN↓. (Ibn-Hamdaweyh.)

murajRabN c
murajRabN Honoured, or magnified: (S:) or revered, venerated, regarded with awe, and honoured, or magnified; (A;) as also marojuwbN↓ (S.) ― -b2- The saying of Hobáb Ibn-El-Mundhir OanaA EucayoquhaA AlmurajRabu means I am their propped little palm-tree loaded with fruit; (S, * TA;) i. e. I have a family that will aid and defend me: so accord. to Yaakoob: or, as some say, I am their honoured little palm-tree &c. (TA. [See 2.]) [It is part of a prov., for which see jicolu.]

marojuwbN c
marojuwbN: see the next preceding paragraph.

1 rajaHa c
1. rajaHa, aor.
rajaHa
and
rajuHa
(Msb, TA) and
rajiHa
, (TA,) inf. n. rujuwHN (Msb, TA) and rajaHaAnN and rujoHaAnN, (TA,) or this last is a simple subst., (Msb,) It (a thing) exceeded another thing in weight; outweighed; preponderated. (Msb, TA. *) And rajaHa AlmyzaAnu, aor.
rajaHa
(S, A, Msb, K) and
rajuHa
(S, Msb, K, but omitted in some copies of the S) and
rajiHa
, (S, K,) inf. n. rujoHaAnN (S, A, K) and rujuwHN, (K,) [but see what is said of the former above,] The balance inclined; (S, Msb, K;) i. e. the scale, of the balance, in which was the thing weighed was heavier than the other; (Msb;) as also trjRH↓. (MA.) And rajaHato UiHodaI AlkafRatayoni EalaI AlOuxuriI [One of the two scales outweighed the other]. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] rajaHa OaHadu qawolayohi EalaI AlMxari (tropical:) [One of his two sayings outweighed the other; surpassed, excelled, was preferable to, or of more force or validity than, the other]. (A.) ― -b3- And rajaHa AlXRaIoCu The thing was, or became, heavy. (TA in art. rjHn [q. v.].) ― -b4- [Hence,] rajaHa fiI majolisihi (tropical:) He was, or became, heavy, [i. e. dull, torpid, or drowsy,] not light, [i. e. not lively or sprightly,] in his sitting-place. (TA.) ＝ -A2- It is also used transitively: one says, rajaHotuhu [I outweighed him]. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] rajaHahu (assumed tropical:) He surpassed him in gravity, staidness, sedateness, and forbearance, or clemency; was, or became, more grave, staid, sedate, and forbearing, or clement, (Oarozan, S, K, TA, and OaHolam, TA,) than he. (S, K, TA.) So in the saying, naAwaOonaA qawomFA farajaHonaAhumo (assumed tropical:) [We vied with a people, or party, and surpassed them in gravity, &c.]. (TA.) And farajaHotuhu raAjaHotuhu↓ (assumed tropical:) [I vied with him in gravity, &c., and surpassed him therein]. (S, K, TA.) ― -b3- You say also, rajaHa AlXRaIoCa biyadihi He weighed the thing with his hand, trying what was its weight: (TA:) or so rajaHahu alone. (A.)

2 rjRH hecaA EalaI caAka c
2. rjRH hecaA EalaI caAka He made this to outweigh that. (MA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] rjRH AlXRaIoCa (assumed tropical:) He
held, or pronounced, [and it made,] the thing [to outweigh, as meaning] to be more, or most, excel-lent or preferable, and of more, or most, force or validity. (Msb.) ― -b3- See also 4. ＝ -A2- And see 5.

3 raAjaHotuhu farajaHotuhu c
3. raAjaHotuhu farajaHotuhu: see 1.

4 ArjH AlmiyzaAna c
4. ArjH AlmiyzaAna He made the balance to incline, the scale in which was the thing weighed being heavier than the other. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- And ArjHhu, (Msb.) or ArjH lahu, (S, A, * K,) He gave him preponderating weight; (S, A, * Msb, K;) as also lh rjRH↓, (S, A, * K,) inf. n. tarojiyHN. (S.) One says, UicaA wazanota faOarojiHo [When thou weighest, give preponderating weight]. (A.)

5 trjRH c
5. trjRH: see 1, second sentence. ― -b2- Also i. q. tacabocaba [It moved to and fro; dangled; was, or became, in a state of motion or commotion; said of a thing hanging in the air, &c.; and so ArtjH↓].
