(K.) You say, trjRHt AlOurojuwHapu↓ The seesaw inclined, [or moved up and down,] (S, K,) bihi (K,) i. e., (TA,) biAlgulaAmi [with the boy], (S, TA,) or biAlgulaAmayoni [with the two boys]. (A. [There mentioned as tropical; but why, I see not.]) And ArtjH↓ He (a boy, TA) inclined, [or moved up and down,] upon a seesaw, (K, TA,) and [moved to and fro] upon a rope, or swing. (TA.) And rawaAdafuhaA ArtjHt↓ Her posteriors moved to and fro: (K:) and EalayohaA rawaAdifuhaA tarotajiHu↓ Her posteriors move to and fro upon her; said of a girl whose posteriors are heavy. (Az, TA.) And AlUibilu ArtjHt↓ and trjRHt The camels had a quivering [or vacillating] motion in going along with short steps. (K.) And falawaAtN kaOanRahaA tatarajRaHu bimano saArafiyhaA (assumed tropical:) [Deserts, or waterless deserts, seeming] as though they bandied him who journeyed therein to the right and left. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] trjRH bayona XayoYayoni (assumed tropical:) He wavered, or vacillated, between two things; (A in art. rnH, and TA;) [and so rjRH↓, for] AltRarojiyHu bayona XayoYayoni is like AltRamoyiylu bayonhumaA. (TA in art. myl.) And trjRH fiI Alqawoli i. q. tamayRala bihi (tropical:) [app. meaning He inclined, in the saying, now this way and now that]. (A, TA.)

8 UirotajaHa
8: see the next preceding paragraph, in five places.

10 AstrjH AlnRiEomapa c
10. AstrjH AlnRiEomapa (assumed tropical:) He held the benefit, or favour, &c., to be a thing of weight, or importance; contr. of AisotaxafRahaA. (A in art. bTr.)

rujoHaAnN c
rujoHaAnN an inf. n. of 1: (S, A, K, TA:) or a simple subst., signifying Excess in weight; preponderance. (Msb.)

rajaAHN c
rajaAHN (S, A, K) and raAjaHN↓, (K,) applied to a woman, (S, A, K,) (tropical:) Heavy in the posteriors; (TA;) large therein: (S, K:) pl. [of the former accord. to rule, and perhaps of the latter also,] rujuHN, (S, K,) [and of the latter accord. to rule, and perhaps of the former also, rujRaHN, and of the latter also rawaAjiHu, for] you say nisaMCN rawaAjiHu AlOakofaAli and rujRaHuhaA (tropical:) [women heavy, or large, in the posteriors]. (A.) ― -b2- kataAYibu rujuHN, (K,) or rujRaHN, (A,) (tropical:) Armies, or troops, marching heavily by reason of numbers, or dragging along the apparatus of war, heavily laden. (K.) ― -b3- jifaAnN rujuHN, (K,) or rujRaHN, (A,) (tropical:) [Large bowls] filled with variyd [or crumbled bread moistened with broth] and with flesh-meat: (K:) or correctly, as in the T, filled with fresh butter and flesh-meat. (TA.) ― -b4- qawomN rujRaHN and rujoHN, [the latter, thus in the TA, perhaps a pl. of raAjiHN, like as buzolN is of baAzilN, but more probably, I think, a mistranscription for rujuHN,] (tropical:) A people, or party, forbearing, or clement; or grave, sedate, or calm; (TA;) as also maraAjiyHu↓ (K, TA) and maraAjiHu↓; of which latter two pls., the sings. are mirojaAHN↓ and mirojaHN↓; or, accord. to some, these pls. have no proper sings.: HilomN [“ forbearance ” &c.] is described by the term viqalN, like as its contr. [safahN] is described by the terms xifRapN and Eajalu. (TA.) You say also fiI AlHilomi qawomN maraAjiyHu↓ (S) or maraAjiyHu AlHilomi (A) (tropical:) [A people, or party, grave in forbearance or clemency, or of much gravity, or sedateness, or calmness, so as not to be excited to lightness of deportment: see HilomN raAjaHN, below.]

rajaAHapN c
rajaAHapN (tropical:) Forbearance, or clemency; or gravity, sedateness, or calmness. (TA.) One says, fiI Eaqolihi rajaAHapN wafiI xuluqihi sajaAHapN (tropical:) [In his intellect is gravity, and in his natural disposition is gentleness]. (A.)

rujaAHapN c
rujaAHapN: see what next follows.

rujRaAHapN c
rujRaAHapN (K) and rujaAHapN↓, (TA, as from the K, but omitted in some copies of the latter,) the latter word without teshdeed, mentioned by IDrst., (TA,) A swing of rope; a rope suspended, (K, TA,) in, or upon, which one goes to and fro; (TA;) it is ridden by a boy: (K:) thought by MF to be what is called OurojuwHapN; he holding this last also to mean the rope [above mentioned]; but no other says this except IDrst. (TA.)

raAjiHN c
raAjiHN Outweighing, or preponderating; or heavy; or of full weight; syn. waAzinN. (TA.) You say, OaEoTaAhu rajiHFA [He gave him preponderating, or full, weight]. (S, K.) ― -b2- See also rajaAHN. ― -b3- [(assumed tropical:) Outweighing, preponderating, or preponderant, as meaning surpassing, excelling, or preferable, or of more force or validity; applied to a saying and the like: of frequent occurrence in this sense.] ― -b4- One says also, HilomN raAjiHN, meaning (assumed tropical:) Forbearance, or clemency, or gravity, sedateness, or calmness, that weighs down the person in whom it exists so that nothing renders him light [in deportment]. (TA.) And rajulN raAjaHu AlEaqoli (tropical:) [A man grave in respect of intellect]. (A.)

OurojuwHapN c
OurojuwHapN (S, Msb, K, &c.) and marojuwHapN↓, both signify the same, (Msb, K, TA,) but the latter is disapproved by the author of the “ Bári'; ” (Msb, TA;) A seesaw; i. e. a piece of wood [or a plank] the middle of which is placed upon a heap of earth or the like, then a boy sits upon one end of it and another boy upon its other end, (Msb, TA,) and it moves up and down with them: thus explained in the 'Eyn and its Abridgment, and in the Jámi' of Kz, and thus Th says on the authority of IAar: (TA:) [accord. to the CK and some MS. copies of the K, these two words signify the same as rujRaAHapN; but accord. to other copies of the K, and the TA, the meaning of this last word is different from that of the two preceding words: see also zuHoluwqapN:] the pl. of the first is OaraAjiyHu (Msb) [and that of the second, accord. to rule, maraAjiyHu]. See 5.

OaraAjiyHu c
OaraAjiyHu pl. of OurojuwHapN. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) Deserts, or waterless deserts: (A, K:) as though they bandied the travellers therein to the right and left. (TA.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) The quivering [or vacillating] motions of camels: (A, TA:) or the quivering [or vacillating] motion of camels in going along with short steps: (K, TA:) Abu-l- Hasan understands not how a pl. word can be thus explained by a sing. word: (TA: [but an inf. n., such as is here used, is often used in explanation of a sing. and of a dual and of a pl.])

mirojaHN c
mirojaHN: see rajaAHN.

mirojaAHN c
mirojaAHN: see rajaAHN. ― -b2- Also sing. of maraAjiyHu, (TA,) which signifies (tropical:) Camels having a quivering [or vacillating] motion in going along with short steps: (K:) the sing. is applied to the female, without p, and to the male. (TA.)

marojuwHN c
[marojuwHN Outweighed, or preponderated, in the proper sense: ― -b2- and also as meaning (assumed tropical:) surpassed, or excelled, and particularly in force, or validity; applied to a saying and the like: of frequent occurrence in this tropical sense.]

marojuwHapN c
marojuwHapN: see OurojuwHapN.

maraAjiHu c
maraAjiHu: see rajaAHN.

maraAjiyHu c
maraAjiyHu (tropical:) Palm-trees heavily laden with fruit: (A, K:) [because they are moved to and fro by the wind.] ― -b2- [Also pl. of marojuwHapN.] ― -b3- And pl. of mirojaAHN, expl. above. (TA.) See also rajaAHN, in two places.

Q. 4 AirojaHanRa c
Q. 4. AirojaHanRa It (a thing, S) inclined, bent, or declined. (S, K.) Hence the prov.,
UicaA QrojaHanRa XaASiyFA faQrofaEo yadFA
(S, Meyd,) or QrojaEanRa, or QjoraEanRa, accord. to different readings, the last being formed by transposition from the second, (Meyd,) i. e. When he (a man, Meyd) inclines, (S, Meyd,) or falls, (Meyd,) raising his legs, then hold thou back [thine arm, or thy hand,] from him; meaning, when he becomes lowly, humble, or submissive, to thee, hold thou back from him: (S, Meyd:) or it is said to a man fighting with another, and means when thou overcomest him, and he lies on his side, and
falls, and raises his legs, then hold thou back thine arm, or thy hand, from him: (TA in art. rjEn, in explanation of the second reading:) [or when he is prostrated, and stretched upon the ground: for,] accord. to As, ArjHnR and ArjEnR signify he was prostrated, and stretched upon the ground. (TA in art. rjEn.) And you say, ArjHnR AlsRaHaAbu baEoda tabasRuqK The clouds became heavy, and inclined [downwards], after being high. (TA.) ― -b2- Also It (a thing, S) fell at once. (S, K.) ― -b3- And It (a thing, S) shook; quivered; or was, or became, in a state of commotion. (S, K.) ― -b4- And ArjHnR AlsRaraAbu i. q. AirotafaEa [i. e. The mirage became upraised, withdrawn, or removed]. (K.)

murojaHinRN c
murojaHinRN [part. n. of the verb above]. You say, OanaA fiI hecaA AlOamori murojaHinRN I am wavering, or vacillating, and inclining, in this affair. (TA.) And AimoraOapN murojaHinRapN A fat woman, who, when she walks, bends in her gait. (TA.) And jayoXN murojaHinRu A heavy army. (S, K.) And rHFI murojaHinRapN A heavy round cloud. (S, * K, * and A in art. rjH. [In the S and K, only the latter word is explained; though the meaning of the former (i. e. saHaAbapN musotadiyrapN, as in the A,) is plainly indicated in the S by a verse there cited.]) And fulaAnN fiI dunoyaA murojaHinRapK Such a one is in an ample, abundant, state of worldly prosperity. (TA.) And layolN murojaHinRN Heavy, wide-spreading, night. (TA.) The author of the K follows ISd and J and Az in regarding the n in this case as radical: but IAth says that some hold it to be augmentative; and the derivation to be from rajaHa AlXRaIoCu, meaning “ the thing was, or became, heavy. ” (TA.)

1 rajiza c
1. rajiza, [aor.
rajaza
,] (S,) inf. n. rajazN, (TA,) He (a camel) had the disease termed rajazN [expl. below]. (S.) ＝ -A2- rajaza, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
rajuza
, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. rajozN, (TA,) He said, spoke, uttered, or recited, poetry, or verse, of the metre termed rajazN; [see this word below;] he spoke in verse of that metre; he poetized, or versified, in that metre; as also Artjz↓; (S, * Msb, K, * TA;) and in like manner Arjz↓, he composed verses of that metre. (Ibn-Buzurj, L in art. qSd.) You say also, rajazabihi He recited to him (OanoXadahu [so in more than one MS. copy of the K, and in the TA, but in the CK OanoXada, without the affixed pronoun, which is probably wrong,]) a poem of that metre; as also rjRzhu↓, (K, TA,) inf. n. tarojiyzN. (TA.) And trjRz↓ He urged, or excited, his camels by singing rajaz, or his rajaz: so accord. to different copies of the K. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] rajazati AlrRiyHu, inf. n. rajozN, (assumed tropical:) The wind was continuous, or lasting. (TA.) And AlrRaEodu Artjz↓ (tropical:) The thunder made uninterrupted sounds, like the recitation of the raAjiz: (A, TA:) or, as also trjRz↓, made a sound: (K:) or made consecutive sounds. (TA.) And baMciyRihi AlbaHoru yarotajizu↓ (tropical:) [The sea makes a continuous sound, or murmuring, with its waves]; as also yatarajRazu↓. (A, TA.) [And hence, perhaps,] trjRz↓ AlsRaHaAbu (tropical:) The clouds moved slowly by reason of the abundance of their water. (K, TA.) [See also 6.]

2 rjRzhu c
2. rjRzhu: see 1.

3 rAjz SaAHibahu c
3. rAjz SaAHibahu [He recited verses, or poetry, of the metre termed rajaz with his companion: or vied with him in doing so: see 6]. (A.)

4 Oarojaza
4: see 1.

5 tarajRaza
5: see 1, in four places.

6 trAjzwA c
6. trAjzwA i. q. tanaAzaEuwA AlrRajaza bayonahumo, (A, K,) and taEaATawohu, (TA,) i. e. They recited verses, or poetry, of the metre termed rajaz, one with another: (TK:) [or vied, one with another, in doing so.] ― -b2- [Hence,] trAjz AlsRaHaAbu (tropical:) [The clouds combined, one with another, in uninterrupted thundering]. (A.) [See also 1.]

8 Uirotajaza
8: see 1, in three places.

rujozN c
rujozN: see the next paragraph, in four places.

rijozN c
rijozN properly signifies Commotion, agitation, or convulsion; and consecutiveness of motions. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) Punishment (Aboo-Is-hák, S, Mgh, Msb, K) [like rijosN] that agitates by its vehemence, and occasions vehement consecutive commotions; (Aboo-Is-hák, Mgh, * TA;) as also rujozN↓: (K:) so in the Kur vii. 131; (Aboo-Is-hák;) and in ii. 56, and vii. 162, and xxix. 33. (S.) ― -b3- Conduct that leads to punishment: so, accord. to some, in the Kur lxxiv. 5; (TA;) where some read AlrRijoza and others AlrRujoza↓: (S, TA:) ↓the latter is also expl. as signifying sin: (TA:) and both, uncleanness; or filth: (S, K:) so in that instance: like rijosN: (S:) and polytheism; or the associating of another, or others, with the true God: (K, TA:) so, accord to some, in that instance: because he who worships what is not God is in doubt respecting his case, and unsettled in his belief: (TA:) and the worship of idols: (K:) so, accord. to some, in the same instance: (TA:) or the meaning there is and idol: (Mujáhid, S:) or ↓the latter word signifies a certain idol; being the name thereof: (Katádeh, TA:) and the devil: and his suggestions. (TA.) ― -b4- Also Plague, or pestilence; syn. TaAEuwnN. (Mgh.)

rajazN c
rajazN A certain disease which attacks camels, in the rump; (S, K;) so that when a she-camel rises, or is roused, her thighs tremble for a while, and then stretch out: (S:) or it is when there is a convulsive motion in the hind leg or the thighs of a camel, when he desires to stand up, or rises, or is roused, for a while, and then a stretching out of the same. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Hence, (S,) AlrRajazu is the name of A certain species [or kind] of verse or poetry; (S, A, K;) a species [or kind] of the metres of verse; (Msb;) consisting of the measure musotafoEiluno [primarily] six times: (K:) a metre easy to the ear and impressive to the mind; wherefore it may be reduced to a single hemistich, and also to two feet instead of six: (TA:) so called because it commences with a motion and a quiescence, [i. e., a movent and a quiescent letter,] followed by a motion and a quiescence; and so in the other feet; resembling the rajaz in a she-camel, which consists in her quivering and then being quiet: (TA:) or because of the contractedness of its feet, and the fewness of its letters: (S, K:) or because it is [characterized by] Suduwr without OaEojaAz [lit. breasts without rumps; for, as the two hemistichs generally rhyme with each other, the verse seems as though it had no Eajuz; i. e., as though its last foot should rather be called EaruwDN, like the last of the first hemistich, than EajuzN:] (TA:) Akh once said, rajazN, with the Arabs, is whatever consists of three feet; and it is that [kind of verse] which they sing in their work, and in driving their camels: [see bicolapN, last sentence:] ISd says that certain of those in whom he placed confidence related this on the authority of Kh. (TA.) Some say that it is not verse, or poetry, but a kind of rhyming prose; but Kh held it to be true verse, or poetry: so in the M: but in the T it is said [as in the K] that Kh asserted it to be not poetry, but halves or thirds of verses: one of his reasons for this assertion [the only one that seems to have had much weight with the Muslims] is, that Mo- hammad once said,
OanaA Qbonu Eabodi AlmuTRalibo
OanaA AlnRabiIRu laA kacibo
[which is an instance of a species of rajaz, meaning, “ I am the Prophet: it is no lie: I am the son of 'Abd-el-Muttalib ”]: and were this verse, he would not have said it, as is shown by what is said in the Kur., xxxvi. 69: but on this point, Akh has contended against him. (TA.)

rijaAzapN c
rijaAzapN A certain vehicle for women, (S, * TA,) a thing smaller than the hawodaj: (S, K, TA:) pl. rajaAYizu: (TA:) or a [garment of the kind called] kisaMC, (S, K, TA,) in which is a stone, (K, TA, [in the CK a while stone,]) or in which are put stones, (S,) and which is suspended to one of the two sides of the hwdj, to balance it, when it inclines: (S, TA:) so called because of its commotion: (TA:) or a thing consisting of a pillow and skins, or hides, put in one of its two sides for that purpose, and called rijaAzapu Almayoli: (T, TA:) or hair, (K,) or red hair, (TA,) or wool, suspended to the hwrj, (K, TA,) for ornament: pl. rajaAYizu, said to occur in a verse of EshShemmákh: but accord. to As, this is a mistake for jazaAYizu [pl. of jaziyzapN, q. v.]. (TA.)

rajRaAzN c
rajRaAzN and rajRaAzapN: see raAjizN; the latter, in two places.

raAjizN c
raAjizN One who utters, or recites, poetry, or verse, of the metre termed rajazN; who speaks in verse of that metre; who poetizes, or versifies, in that metre: and in like manner, murotajizN↓, and rajRaAzN↓ [which signifies one who does so much], and rajRaAzapN↓ [one who does so very much]. (TA.) El-'Ajjáj has been placed the highest in rank as a rAjz. (Mz, 49th nwE.) [His son, Ru-beh, seems
to occupy nearly an equal place. Each of them composed a complete deewán of rajaz.] ― -b2- [Hence,] saHaAbapN rajRaAzapN↓ (tropical:) [A cloud thundering much, or uninterruptedly]. (A, TA.) And gayovN murotajizN↓, and mutarajRizN↓, (tropical:) Rain accompanied by thunder. (TA.)

Oarojazu c
Oarojazu A camel having the disease termed rajazN: fem. rajozaMCu: (S, K:) the latter is explained as signifying weak in the rump, that does not move from her place unless after twice or thrice rising from the place where she lay: and that does not rise, when she desires to do so, unless after vehement trembling. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] UinRahaA larajozaMCu, said of the wind (AlrRiyH), (assumed tropical:) Verily it is continuous, or lasting. (TA.) And rajozaMCu AlqiyaAmi (tropical:) A great, heavy cooking-pot. (TA.)

OurojuwzapN c
OurojuwzapN A poem of the metre termed rajazN: (Msb, K:) pl. OaraAjiyzu. (A, K.)

murotajizN c
murotajizN: see raAjizN; the former, in two places.

mutarajRizN c
mutarajRizN: see raAjizN; the former, in two places.

1 rajasati AlsRamaMCu c
1. rajasati AlsRamaMCu, (S, A, K,) aor.
rajusa
, (S,) inf. n. rajosN, (S, A,) The sky thundered vehemently, (S, A, K,) and became in a state of commotion (S, K) preparatory to rain; (TA;) as also Artjst↓. (S, A, K, * TA.) ― -b2- rajasa AlbaEiyru, (K,) inf. n. as above, (A, TA,) The camel brayed: (K:) or made a vehement noise in braying. (A, * TA.) ― -b3- And rajasa, inf. n. as above and rajosapN and rajasaAnN, It (a confused and great thing, such as an army, and a torrent, and thunder,) made a sound or noise; as also Artjs↓. (TA: [but in this sense, only the inf. ns. are mentioned, and rajosapN is probably an inf. n. of un.]) ＝ -A2- rajasa, (K,) inf. n. rajosN, (TA,) He measured [the depth of] the water of a well with the mirojaAs; (K, * TA;) as also Arjs↓, (K,) inf. n. UirojaAsN. (TA.) ＝ -A3- rajasahu Eini AlOamori, aor. u and
rajisa
, (O, K,) inf. n. rajosN, (O, TA,) He hindered, withheld, or prevented, him from doing the thing. (O, K.) ＝ -A4- rajisa, aor.
rajasa
, inf. n. rajasN; (Msb;) and rajusa, aor.
rajusa
, inf. n. rajaAsapN; (A, Msb, TA;) It (a thing) was, or became, unclean, dirty, or filthy: (A, Msb, TA:) or stinking: or disliked, or hated, for its uncleanness, dirtiness, or filthiness. (Msb.) ― -b2- And both these verbs, (K,) inf. n. of the former, (TA,) and of the latter, (K,) as above, (K, TA,) He did a bad, an evil, an abominable, or a foul, action. (K, TA.)

4 Oarojasa
4: see 1.

8 Artjs c
8. Artjs: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- Also It (a building) became in a state of commotion, (K, TA,) so as to make a sound, or noise. (TA.)

rijosN c
rijosN Uncleanness, dirt, or filth: or an unclean, a dirty, or a filthy, thing: syn. qacarN: (S, A, Msb, K, TA: [in the CK, Alqadaru is put by mistake for AlqacarN:]) or XaIoCN qacirN: (TA:) anything that is disliked, or hated, for its uncleanness, dirtiness, or filthiness: stink, or foul odour: accord. to Az, filth that comes forth from the body of a man: En-Nakkásh says that it is syn. with nijosN; and it is said in the Bári' that sometimes they say AlrRajaAsapu waAlnRajaAsapu, meaning that they make these two words syn.: (Msb:) it is also written rajisN↓ and rajasN↓: (A, K:) you say rijosN nijosN, and rajisN najisN; and IDrd says, I think that they also said rajasN najasN: Pr says that when rjs is followed by njs, the j is with kesr; but when njs is mentioned without rjs, the j and n are with fet-h. (TA.) You say also XaIoCN rijosN [An unclean, a dirty, or a filthy, thing]. (A.) And marRabinaA jamaAEapN rajisuwna↓ najisuwna, meaning, A company of unbelievers passed by us. (IAar and TA.) As used in the Kur vi. 125, Mujáhid explains AlrRijos as meaning That in which is no good. (TA.) ― -b2- Any action that is disliked, or hated, for its uncleanness, dirtiness, or filthiness: (Zj, A, K:) a sin, or crime: (Ibn-El-Kelbee, A, K:) so in the Kur v. 92, and vi. 146: (Ibn-El-Kelbee:) an action that leads to punishment: (T, A, K:) as rajosN signifies “ vehemence of sound, ” [see 1,] rijosN seems to mean an action the mention whereof is evil, and highly evil: (TA:) sometimes it signifies a thing that is unlawful, or forbidden: and unbelief: infidelity: (L:) and doubt: (Aboo-Jaafar, A, K:) so in the Kur xxxiii. 33. (Aboo-Jaafar.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Punishment; (Fr, T, S, A, K;) a sense which Z makes tropical, as being the recompense of rijos [in the sense of “ sin ”], (TA;) and anger: (Fr, S, A, K:) so in the Kur x. 100: like rijozN, which is perhaps formed from it by the change of s into z: (Fr, S:) and sometimes, malediction, or execration. (L.) ＝ -A2- A light, or slight, motion. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Suggestion of the devil. (TA.)

rajasN c
rajasN: see rijosN; the latter, in two places.

rajisN c
rajisN: see rijosN; the latter, in two places.

rajuwsN c
rajuwsN: see raAjisN; the latter, in three places.

rajRaAsN c
rajRaAsN: see raAjisN; the latter, in three places.

raAjisN c
raAjisN and murotajisN↓ (A, K) and rajRaAsN↓ (S, A, K) A cloud making a loud, or vehement, sound; (S, A, K, TA;) and so thunder. (TA.) You say, [of a cloud,] hecaA raAjisN HasanN This is a goodly thunderer. (S.) And Eafati AldRiyaAra AlgamaAYimu AlrRawaAjisu waAlrRiyaAHu AlrRawaAmisu [The loudthundering clouds and the dust-spreading winds effaced the traces of the dwellings]. (A.) ― -b2- [And in like manner,] rajRaAsN↓ (S, K) and rajuwsN↓ and mirojasN↓ (K) A camel that brays vehemently. (S, K, * TA.) You say also AlHaniyni naAqapN rajosaMCu↓, [fem. of Oarojasu↓,] A she-camel that utters the [yearning cry termed] Haniyn consecutively, or continuously. (IAar, TA.) ― -b3- [And hence,] AlrajRaAsu↓ The sea: (K:) because of the sound of its waves; or because of its commotion. (TA.) ＝ -A2- raAjisN also signifies The thrower of the mirojaAs; (K;) and so murojisN↓. (TA.)

Oarojasu c
Oarojasu; and its fem. rajosaMCu: see raAjisN.

murojisN c
murojisN: see raAjisN, last sentence.

mirojasN c
mirojasN: see raAjisN.

mirojaAsN c
mirojaAsN A stone which is tied to the end of a rope, and which is then let down into a well, and stirs up its black mud, after which the water is drawn forth, and thus the well is cleansed: (S, K: *) or a stone which is thrown into a well in order that one may know, by the sound thereof, its depth; or that one may know whether there be in it water or not: (IAar, K:) or, accord. to ISd, the name by which this is known is mirodaAsN. (TA.)

UinRahu larijosN marojuwsN c
UinRahu larijosN marojuwsN and rjl marojuwsN [are phrases mentioned, but not explained, in the TA: but I think that rjl is a mistranscription for rijozN; and that mrjws, in each case, is a corroborative].

humo fiI marojuwsapK c
humo fiI marojuwsapK, (S, A, K,) and fI marojuwsaMCa↓, (TA,) They are in a state of confusion (S, A, K) and perturbation, (A,) mino Oamorihimo in respect of their affair, or case. (S, TA.)

marojuwsaMCu c
marojuwsaMCu: see what next precedes.

murotajisN c
murotajisN: see raAjisN.

narojisN c
narojisN (S, Msb, K) and nirojisN (AA, Sgh, Msb, K) [The narcissus;] a certain sweet-smelling flower, (Msb, * TA,) well known: (Msb, K:) the smell of which is beneficial for the cold rheum and the cold headache: (K:) the word is arabicized, (S, Msb, TA,) from [the Persian] naroGiso: (TA:) [this being the case, the n should be regarded as radical it is said, however, that] the n in narojisN is augmentative, because there is no word of the measure faEolilN, but there is of the measure nafoEilN, (S,) though only what is changed, in application, from a verb: (Msb:) but nirojisN is of the measure fiEolilu; (TA;) or it is of the measure nifoEilN, the augmentative letter being made to accord in its vowel with the radical letter in UicoxirN and that in UivomidN &c.: (Msb:) or, accord. to IDrd, narojisN is of the measure faEolilN, and the only instance of that measure. (TA in art. nrjs.) If you name a man narojis, you make it imperfectly decl., because it is like naDoribu: (S:) but if you name him nirojis, it is perfectly decl., because it is of the measure fiEolilN (TA) [or nifoEilN, neither of which is the measure of a verb]. ― -b2- narojisu AlmaAYidapi: see zumaAwarodN.

1 rajaEa c
1. rajaEa, aor.
rajiEa
, inf. n. rujuwEN (S, Msb, K, &c.) and rajoEN, (M, Msb,) but the former is that which commonly obtains and is agreeable with analogy as inf. n. of the intrans. v., and the latter as inf. n. of the trans. v., (MF, TA,) and marojaEN, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) which is anomalous, because inf. ns. [of this kind] of verbs of the measure faEala having the
aor. of the measure yafoEilu are [by rule] only with fet-h [to the medial radical], (S, K,) and marojiEapN, which is in like manner anomalous, (K,) and rujoEaI, (S, Msb, K,) [not rujoEFI as in the Lexicons of Golius and Freytag,] and rujoEaAnN, (K,) He returned; he went, or came, back [to the same place, or person, or (assumed tropical:) state, or (assumed tropical:) occupation, or (assumed tropical:) action, or (assumed tropical:) saying, &c.]; he reverted; contr. of cahaba; (ISk, Msb;) i. q. AnoSarafa: (K:) rujuwEN signifies the returning to a former place, or (assumed tropical:) quality, or (assumed tropical:) state; (Kull p. 196;) the returning to that from which was the commencement, or from which the commencement is supposed to have been, whether it be a place, or (assumed tropical:) an action, or (assumed tropical:) a saying, and whether the returning be by the [whole] person or thing, or by a part thereof, or by an action thereof. (Er-Rághib.) Hence the saying in the Kur [lxiii. 8], laYino rajaEonaA UilaI Almadiynapi [Verily if we return to the city]. (Er-Rághib.) And [in the same, xii. 63,] falamRaA rajaEuwA UilaI Oabiyhimo [And when they returned to their father]. (Idem.) And in the same, [vi. 164, and xxxix. 9,] vumRa UilaI rabRikumo marojiEukumo [Then unto your Lord shall be your return]: (S:) the like of which occurs in the same, vi. 60: but it may be either from [the intrans. inf. n.] rujuwEN or from [the trans.] rajoEN: (Er-Rághib:) it cannot be a n. of place, because it is made trans. by means of UilaI, and also because it occurs in the Kur [v. 53, &c.], followed by jamiyEFA, as a denotative of state: (L:) in like manner AlrRujoEaI also occurs in the Kur xcvi. 8. (TA.) You say also, rajaEati AlmaroOapu UilaI OaholihaA The woman returned to her family by reason of the death of her husband or by reason of divorcement. (Msb.) ― -b2- rajaEa UilaI AlSRiHRapi (assumed tropical:) [He returned to soundness, or health], or AlmaraDi [disease, or sickness]; and UilaI HaAlapi Alfaqori (assumed tropical:) [to the state of poverty], or AlginaI (assumed tropical:) [wealth, or competence, or sufficiency]. (Kull p. 196.) ― -b3- rajaEa Eawodahu EalaI badoYihi He returned in the way by which he had come. (Kull ibid.) ― -b4- rajaEa mino safarihi He returned from his journey. (Msb.) ― -b5- rajaEa Eani AlOimori (assumed tropical:) He returned [or reverted] from the affair. (Msb.) ― -b6- rajaEa Eani AlXRaIoCi (assumed tropical:) He left, or relinquished, the thing. (Kull p. 197.) ― -b7- rajaEa Eani AlcRanobi (assumed tropical:) [He relinquished sin; i. e.] he repented; and so rajaEa alone, agreeably with the usage in the Kur iii. 65, &c. (Er-Rághib.) ― -b8- [Several other phrases, in which this verb occurs, will be found in other arts.: as rajaEa EalaI Zahorihi in art. Zhr: rajaEotu AlqahoqaraI in art. qhqr: rajaEa darajahu, and variations thereof, in art. drj: &c.] ― -b9- rajaEa Uilayohi [sometimes signifies the same as rajaEa Ealayohi] He returned against him; he returned to attack him. (TA.) ― -b10- SaramRniI vumRa rajaEa yakalRimuniI (tropical:) [He cut me, or ceased to speak to me; then he returned to speaking to me]. (TA.) ― -b11- xaAlafaniI vumRa rajaEa UilaI qawoliI (tropical:) [He opposed me, or disagreed with me; then he returned, or had regard, to my saying]. (TA.) ― -b12- maA rujiEa Uilayohi fiI xaTobK UilRaA kafaI (tropical:) [Re course was not had to him in an affair, or an affliction, but he sufficed.] (TA.) [rajaEa Uilayohi often means He had recourse, or he recurred, to him, or it.] ― -b13- rajaEa bihi EalaI Xariykihi (assumed tropical:) He made a claim for restitution of it upon his co-partner. (IAth, TA in art. xlT.) And [in like manner you say,] EalaI Algariymi AirotajaEa↓, and AlmutRahami, (assumed tropical:) He sued, prosecuted, or made a demand upon, the debtor, and the suspected, for his right, or due. (TA: [in which it is said, immediately before this, that ArtjE is like rajaEa.]) ― -b14- rajaEa Alkalobu fiI qayoYihi The dog returned to his vomit, (Msb, TA,) and ate it. (Msb.) ― -b15- Hence, rajaEa fiI hibatihi (tropical:) He took back his gift; repossessed himself of it; restored it to his possession; (Msb;) as also ArtjEhA↓, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) and AstrjEhA↓. (Msb, TA.) And minohu AlXRaIoC AstrjE↓ (assumed tropical:) He took back from him the thing which he had given to him. (S, K.) ― -b16- [Hence also, rajaEa fiI qawolihi, and fiI Hukomihi (assumed tropical:) He retracted, or revoked, his saying, and his judgment, or sentence.] ― -b17- huwa yarojiEu UilaI manoSibi SidoqK (assumed tropical:) He traces back his lineage to an excellent origin. (TA in art. nSb.) ― -b18- [yarojiEu UilaI maEonaI kacaA (assumed tropical:) It (a word used in a certain sense) is referrible, or reducible, to such a meaning. And yurojiEu UilaI kacaA, said of a word, also means (assumed tropical:) It relates to such a thing; i. e., to such another word, in grammatical construction.] ― -b19- rajaEa UilaI qadori kacaA (assumed tropical:) It (wine when cooked) became reduced to such a quantity; syn. Mla. (S in art. Awl.) ― -b20- rajaEa AlHawoDu UilaI UizaAYihi The water of the trough, or tank, became much in quantity [so that it returned to the height of the place whence it poured in]. (TA.) ― -b21- rijaAEN↓, also, is an inf. n. of this verb, (L,) and is used as signifying The returning of birds after their migrating to a hot country. (S, L, K.) You say, rajaEati AlTRayoru AlqawaATiEu, inf. n. rijaAEN and rajoEN, The migratory birds returned. (L.) ― -b22- Also inf. n. of rajaEato said of a-she camel, and of a she-ass, signifying (assumed tropical:) She raised her tail, and compressed her two sides (quTorayohaA), and cast forth her urine in repeated discharges, so that she was imagined to be pregnant, (S, K,) and then failed of fulfilling her [apparent] promise: (S: [in some copies of which, as is said in the TA, the inf. n. of the verb in this sense is written rujuwE:]) or she conceived, and then failed of fulfilling her promise; because she who does so goes back from what is hoped of her: (TA:) or, said of a she-camel, she cast forth her fœtus in an imperfect state: (AZ, TA,) or, as some say, her embryo in a fluid state: (TA:) or in an unformed state; inf. n. rijaAEN. (Msb in art. xdj.) [See also raAjiEN, below.] ＝ -A2- , (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. rajaEahu, (Mgh,) inf. n. rajoEN and marojaEN and marojiEN, (K,) He made, or caused, him, or it, to return, go back, come back, or revert; sent back, turned back, or returned, him, or it; syn. radRahu; (Mgh, Msb, K;) and Sarafahu; (K;) Eani AlXRaIoCi from the thing; and Uilayohi to it; (Msb, K;) as also ArjEhu↓; (S, Msb, K;) but the former is the more chaste word, and is that which is used in the Kur-án, in ix. 84 [and other places]: (Msb:) the latter is of the dial. of Hudheyl; (S, Msb;) and is said by MF to be of weak authority, and bad; but [SM says,] I do not find this asserted by any of the leading authorities: (TA:) ArtjEhu↓, also, signifies [the same, i. e.] the same as radRahu in like manner followed by UilaI. (TA.) Thus in the Kur ix. 84, referred to above, faUino rajaEaka QllRehu [And if God make thee to return, or restore thee]. (Msb.) ― -b2- rajaEa fulaAnN EaliI Oanofi baEiyirhi Such a one put back, or restored, the nose-rein [AlxiTaAma being understood] upon the nose of his camel; it having become displaced. (TA.) ― -b3- rajaEa UilaIRa AljawaAba, aor.
rajiEa
, inf. n. rajoEN and rujoEaAnN, He returned to me the answer. (S, TA: [in the latter of which, this is said to be tropical; but when a written answer is meant, it is evidently not so.]) ― -b4- rajaEotu AlkalaAma (assumed tropical:) I returned the speech; or I repeated it; or I rebutted, or rejected, or repudiated, it, in reply, or replication; syn. radadotuhu. (Msb.) [In like manner,] yarojiEu baEoDuhumo UilaI baEoDK Alqawola, in the Kur [xxxiv. 30], means (assumed tropical:) Holding a colloquy, or a disputation, or debate, one with another: (Bd:) [or it means (assumed tropical:) rebutting one another's sayings:] or (assumed tropical:) blaming one another. (S.) ― -b5- AlrRajoEu, (K,) or rajoEu AldRaAbRapi yadayohaA fiI AlsRayori, (S,) (tropical:) The stepping of the beast, (S, K,) or her returning her fore legs, [drawing the fore feet backwards towards the body, by lifting them high,] in going; (K;) and AltRarojiyEu↓, (K,) or tarojiyEu AldRaAbRpi yadayohaA fiI AlsRayori, (S,) signifies the same: (S, K:) or rajoEN signifies a beast's elevating, or lifting high, the fore foot and hind foot, in going. (KL.) You say, AldRaAbRapu yadayohaA fiI rajRaEati↓ AlsRayori (tropical:) [The beast stepped, &c.; like as you say, rajaEat]. (TA.) ― -b6- rajoEu AlwaAXmapi, and tarojayEuhaA↓, (assumed tropical:) The female tattooer's making marks or lines [upon the skin]: (S, K: *) [or rather, as the former phrase is explained in the EM p. 143, “ her retracing ” those marks or lines, and renewing their blackness; for] you say also, AlnaqoXa rajRaEa↓, and AlwaXoma, [and rajaEahu,] (assumed tropical:) He retraced the marks, or lines, of the variegated work, and of the tattooing, and renewed their blackness, one time after another. (TA.) And AlkitaAbapa rajRaEa↓, [and rajaEahaA,] (assumed tropical:) He retraced, or renewed, the writing. (TA.) ― -b7- rajaEa naAqapF, and ArtjEhA↓, and trjREhA↓, He purchased a she-camel with the price of another that he sold: (S, TA:) or he purchased a she-camel with the price of a he-camel that he sold; and rijaEN↓, which is app. an inf. n., signifies the selling males and purchasing females: (TA:) or maAlFA ArtjE↓ signifies he sold the aged and the younglings of his came's, and purchased such as were in a state of youthful vigour: or, as some say, he sold the males, and purchased females: (Lh:) or AirotijaAEN↓ signifies the selling a thing, and purchasing in its place what one imagines to be more youthful, and better: (Lh in another place:) regard is bad, therein, to the meaning of a return, virtual, or understood, though not real: (Er-Rághib:) also UibilFA ArjE↓ he sold old and weak camels, and purchased such as were in a state of youthful vigour: or he sold male camels, and purchased females: (TA:) and UibilFA ArtjE↓ biUibilihi he took camels in exchange for his camels:
or, as some say, AirotijaAEN↓ signifies the taking one in the place, and with the price, of two. (Mgh.) ― -b8- rajaEa AlEalafu fiI AldRaAbRapi (tropical:) The fodder, or food, produced an effect, or showed its effect, upon the beast. (K, * TA.) And rajaEa kalaAmiI fiyhi (tropical:) My speech produced a beneficial effect upon him. (K, * TA.)

2 rjREhu c
2. rjREhu, inf. n. tarojiyEN, He, or it, made, or caused, him, or it, to return, go back, come back, or revert, again and again, or time after time; sent back, turned back, or returned, him, or it, again and again, or time after time; made, or caused, him, or it, to go, or move, repeatedly to and fro; so to go and come; to reciprocate: he repeated it; iterated it; or rather reiterated it: he reproduced it: he renewed it: syn. radRadahu. (Mgh.) [All these significations are well known, as pertaining to the two verbs here mentioned, and of frequent occurrence in classical and postclassical writings: and hence several phrases here following.] ― -b2- See 1, last quarter of the paragraph, in five places. ― -b3- Hence, (Mgh,) AltRarojiyEu fiI AlOacaAni, (S, Mgh, K,) because the two professions of the faith [for which see the word OacaAnN] are uttered in the AcAn [or call to prayer] in a low voice [and then repeated in a high voice]; (Mgh;) [for] this phrase means (tropical:) The repeating the two professions of the faith in a raised, or loud, voice, after uttering them in a low, or faint, voice; (Sgh, K, TA;) or the lowering of the voice in the AcAn in uttering the two professions of the faith, and then raising it in uttering them: (KT:) or rjRE fiI OacaAnihi signifies he uttered the two professions of the faith in his AcAn once to repeat them. (Msb: [but this is a strange explanation; and probably corrupted by a copyist: it seems that, instead of “ to repeat them, ” we should read “ and repeated them. ”]) ― -b4- [Hence also,] AltRarojiyEu, (K, TA,) or tarojiyEu AlSRawoti, (S,) (assumed tropical:) [The act of quavering, or trilling; rapidly repeating many times one very short note, or each note of a piece; a general characteristic of Arabian chanting and singing and piping, and often continued throughout the whole performance;] the reiterating (tarodiyd) of the voice in the throat, or fauces, (S, K, TA,) like [as is done in] chanting, (S,) or which is practised in reading or reciting, or singing, or piping, or other performances, of such as are accompanied with quavering, or trilling: (TA:) or, as some say, the mutual approximation of the various kinds of movements in the voice: 'Abd-Allah Ibn-Mughaffal, in his trjyE, by the prolonging of the voice, in reading, or reciting, imitated the like of MA MA MA. (TA.) You say also, rjRE AlHamaAmu fiI ginaAYihi (assumed tropical:) [The pigeons quavered in their singing, or cooing]; as also AstrjE↓. (TA.) And rjRE AlbaEiyru fiI XiqoXiqatihi (assumed tropical:) The camel brayed, or reiterated his voice, in his XqXqp [or bursa faucium]. (TA.) And rjREt AlnRaAqapu fiI HaniynihaA (assumed tropical:) The she-camel interrupted her yearning cry to, or for, her young one [and then, app., quickly repeated it, and did so again and again]. (TA.) And rjREt Alqawosu (assumed tropical:) The bow made a sound [by the vibration of its string; because the sound so made is a repeated sound]. (AHn.) ― -b5- See also 4. ― -b6- And see 10.

3 rAjE c
3. rAjE He (a man) returned to good or to evil. (TA.) [See also 6.] ― -b2- rAjEt AlnRaAqapu, (K,) inf. n. rijaAEN, (TA,) The she-camel returned, or reverted, from one kind of pace, which she had been going, to another pace. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- rAjEhu (assumed tropical:) It returned to him: said of pain [&c.]. (TA in art. Ed.) ― -b4- rAjE QmoraOatahu (tropical:) [He returned to his wife, or restored her to himself, or took her back by marriage or to the marriage-state, after having divorced her; (see also 6;)]; (S;) and ArtjEhA↓ signifies the same. (TA.) ― -b5- [See also a verse cited voce radaAdN; whence it seems that rAjE also signifies He restored, or brought back, anything.] ― -b6- rAjEhu signifies also He endeavoured to turn him [from, or to, a thing]; syn. raAwadahu, and raAdRahu. (L in art. rwd.) ― -b7- rAjEhu AlkalaAma, (S and K in this art., and A and Mgh and Msb in art. Hwr,) and fiI AlkalaAmi, (Bd in xviii. 32,) and simply raAjEhu, (Msb in this art., and Jel. in lviii. l,) inf. n. muraAjaEapN (S, TA) and rijaAEN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He returned him answer for answer, or answers for answers; held a dialogue, or colloquy, or conference, or a disputation, or debate, with him; bandied words with him; syn. HaAwarahu, (A and Mgh and Msb in art. Hwr, and Bd in xviii. 32,) [i. e.] HaAwarahu AlkalaAma; (TA;) or EaAwadahu; (S and Msb and K in this art.;) or jaAdalahu. (Jel in lviii. 1.) And rAjEhu, or rAjEhu Alqawola, (assumed tropical:) He disputed with him, rebutting, or rejecting, or repudiating, in reply to him, what he said; he bandied words with him; syn. raAdRahu Alqawola. (A in art. rd.) You say, rAjEhu fiI muhimRaAtihi He held a colloquy, or conference, or a disputation, or debate, with him respecting his affairs of difficulty; syn. HaAwarahu. (TA.) [And rAjEhu fiI kacaA He addressed him repeatedly, or time after time, respecting such a thing.] And raAjaEuwA Euquwlahumo [They consulted their understandings, or minds; as though they held a colloquy, or conference, or a disputation, or debate, therewith]. (Bd in xxi. 65.) [rAjE often signifies He consulted, or referred to, a person, a book, a passage in a book, &c.]

4 ArjEt AlnRaAqapu c
4. ArjEt AlnRaAqapu (assumed tropical:) [The she-camel returned to her former condition, either of leanness or fatness:] (assumed tropical:) the she-camel became lean [after having been fat]: and (assumed tropical:) became in good condition after leanness: (Ks, T, TA:) or ArjEt AlUibilu (assumed tropical:) the camels became lean and then became fat; (S, O, K;) so says Ks. (S.) You say also, AlXRayoxu yamoraDu yuwomayoni falaA yurojiEu XahorFA (assumed tropical:) i. e. [The old man is sick two days, and] does not return to a healthy state of body, and to strength, in a month. (K, TA: [in the CK, erroneously, flA yurojaEu.]) And [in like manner] AinotaqaSa Alfarasu vumRa taraAjaEa↓ (assumed tropical:) [The horse wasted, and then gradually returned to his former condition]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- ArjEhu: see rajaEahu, first signification. ― -b2- ArjEhu naAqatahu He gave him [back] his she-camel in order that he might return upon her, he [the latter] having sold her to him. (Lh.) ― -b3- ArjE UibilFA: see 1, near the end of the paragraph. ― -b4- ArjE QllRehu bayoEatahu (tropical:) God made his sale to be productive of gain, or profit. (S, K.) ― -b5- ArjE QllRehu hamRahu suruwrFA (assumed tropical:) God converted his grief, or disquietude of mind, into happiness or joy; and Sb mentions rajRaEahu↓ [in this sense]. (TA.) ― -b6- ArjE also signifies He extended, or stretched out, his arm, or hand, backwards, to reach, or take hold of, a thing. (S, K.) [In this case, yadahu seems to be understood: for] you say [also], ArjE AlrRajulu yadayohi The man put his arms, or hands, backwards in order to reach, or take hold of, a thing. (Lh.) And ArjE yadahu UilaI sayofihi liyasotalRahu He extended, or stretched out, his arm, or hand, to his sword, to draw it: or UilaI kinaAnatihi liyaOoxuca sahomFA to his quiver, to take an arrow. (TA.) ― -b7- Also (tropical:) He ejected excrement, or ordure; said of a man. (S, K.) [See rajiyEN.] ＝ -A3- See also 10.

5 trjRE fiI SadoriI kacaA c
5. trjRE fiI SadoriI kacaA (tropical:) Such a thing became agitated to and fro in my mind, or bosom; syn. taradRada. (TA.) ＝ -A2- trjRE naAqapF: see 1; in the last quarter of the paragraph.

6 taraAjaEaA c
6. taraAjaEaA (tropical:) They two (a man and his divorced wife) returned to each other by marriage; (Bd in ii. 230;) or returned together to the marriagestate. (Jel ibid.) ― -b2- trAjE AlXRaIoCu UilaI xalofK [The thing went backward or back, receded, retrograded, retired, retreated, or reverted, by degrees, gradually, by little and little, or part after part: and trAjE alone, He, or it, returned by degrees: the form of the verb denoting a gradual continuation, as in tasaAqaTa, and tazaAyada, and tanaAqaSa, &c.]. (S.) trAjE and taraAdRa and taradRada are syn. (M and L in art. rd.) You say, trAjEwA fiI masiyrK They returned, retired, or retreated, by degrees, or by little and little, in a journey, or march; syn. taraAdRuwA. (TA in art. vbjr.) And tafarRaquwA fiI OawRali AlnRahaAri vumRa taraAjaEuwA maEa AllRayoli i. e. [They separated, or dispersed themselves, in the first part of day; then] they returned, [one after an every one to his place of abode. (TA.) ― -b3- taraAjaEato OaHowaAlu fulaAnK (tropical:) [The circumstances of such a one gradually reverted to their former condition; meaning either a better condition, agreeably with an ex. mentioned above, see 4; or, as is most commonly the case, a worse condition; i. e. retrograded; or gradually went back to a worse state; contr. of advanced, or improved]: (TA:) [whence the saying,] zaAlato dawolatuhumo waOaxaca Oamoruhumo yataraAjaEu (assumed tropical:) [Their good fortune ceased, and their affairs began to retrograde, or gradually go back to a worse state]. (A in art. rkd.) And taraAjaEa AljuroHu UilRI AlburoCi (assumed tropical:) [The wound gradually recovered]. (Msb in art. dml.) ＝ -A2- taraAjaEaA bayonahumaA They two (copartners) made claims for restitution, each upon the other. (IAth, TA in art. xlT.) [See this more fully explained, and illustrated, voce xaliyTN.] ― -b2- trAjEwA AlkalaAma, (Msb and K in art. Hwr,) and fiI AlkalaAmi, (Bd in lviii. 1,) and simply trAjEwA, (Jel in lviii. 1,) (assumed tropical:) They returned one another answer for answer, or answers for answers; held a dialogue, or colloquy,
or conference, or a disputation, or debate, one with another; bandied words, one with another; syn. taHaAwaruwA. (Bd, Jel, Msb, K, in the places mentioned above.)

8 ArtjE EalaI Algariymi c
8. ArtjE EalaI Algariymi, and AlmutRahami: see rajaEa, with which it is syn. (TA.) ＝ -A2- ArtjEhu i. q. radRahu, like rajaEahu, q. v. (TA.) So in the phrase, ArtjEt AlmaroOapu jilobaAbahaA The woman put back her jlbAb [q. v.] upon her face, and covered herself with it. (TA.) ― -b2- ArtjE Alhibapa: see rajaEa fiI hibatihi. ― -b3- ArtjE QmoraOatahu: see 3. ― -b4- baAga Uibilahu faQrotajaEa minohaA rijoEapF↓ SaAliHapF He sold his camels, and obtained by the expenditure of their price a good return, or profit. (S, K.) ― -b5- ArtjE naAqapF, and the like: see 1, near the end of the paragraph, in five places. ― -b6- ArtjE UibilFA also signifies He (and Arab of the desert) purchased camels [app. in exchange for others] not of his own people's breeding nor bearing their marks. (TA.)

10 AstrjE Alhibapa c
10. AstrjE Alhibapa, and AstrjE minohu AlXRaIoCa: see rajaEa fiI hibatihi, and the sentence next following it. ― -b2- TaEaAmN yusotarojaEu Eanohu (assumed tropical:) Food, both of beasts and of men, from which profit, or advantage, [or a good return (rijoEap),] is obtained; which is found to be wholesome, or approved in its result; and from eating which one becomes fat. (TA.) ＝ -A2- AstrjE AlHamaAmu: see 2, near the end of the paragraph. ― -b2- AstrjE also signifies (tropical:) He said, on the occasion of an affliction, or a misfortune, [using the words of the Kur ii. 151,] UinRaA lilRehi waUinRaA Uilayohi raAjiEuwna, (S, K,) meaning Verily to God we belong as his property and his servants, so that He may do with us what He pleaseth, and verily unto Him we return in the ultimate state of existence, and He will recompense us; (Jel;) as also rjRE↓, (S, * K,) inf. n. tarojiyEN; (S; [accord. to the TA, only the former verb is mentioned in this sense by J; but I find the latter also in two copies of the S;]) and ArjE↓. (K.)

rajoEN c
rajoEN; originally an inf. n.: [see rajaEa and rajaEahu:] ― -b2- and see rajoEapN, in two places. ― -b3- (tropical:) Rain: so in the Kur [lxxxvi. 11], waAlsRamaMCi caAti AlrRajoEi [by the heaven that hath rain]: (S, Bd:) because God returns it time after time: or because the clouds raise the water from the seas and then return it to the earth; and if so, by AsmAC may be meant the clouds: (Bd:) or rain after rain; (K;) because it returns time after time; or because it is repeated, and returns, every year: (TA:) or the said words of the Kur mean by the heaven that returns in every revolution to the place whence it moved. (Bd.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) Hail; because it gives back the water that it takes. (TA.) ― -b5- Accord. to El-Asadee, as recorded by AHeyth, (assumed tropical:) Thunder. (Az.) ― -b6- Accord. to some, in the passage of the Kur cited above, (S, TA,) (assumed tropical:) Profit, benefit, advantage, or good return. (S, K, TA.) You say, layosa liI mino fulaAnK rajoEN (assumed tropical:) There is no profit to me from such a one. (TA.) And maA huwa UilRaA sajoEN layosa taHotahu rajoEN (assumed tropical:) [It is nothing but rhyming prose, beneath which is to be found no profit]. (TA.) [See also rijoEapN.] ― -b7- Accord. to Ks, in the ex. cited above from the Kur, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) The place that retains water: (K, TA:) pl. rujoEaAnN. (TA.) ― -b8- (assumed tropical:) A pool of water left by a torrent; (S, K;) because of the rain that is in it; or because of its fluctuating to and fro in its place; (Er-Rághib;) as also rajiyEN↓, and raAjiEapN↓: (K:) pl. as above: (S:) or (assumed tropical:) a place in which the torrent has extended itself, (AimotadRa, accord. to Lth and the O and K,) or in which it has returned, or reverted, (AirotadRa, accord. to AHn,) and then passed through: (Lth, AHn, O, K:) pl. rujoEaAnN and rijoEaAnN and rijaAEN; (K;) or this last, accord. to some, is a sing., having the signification next preceding the last here mentioned, and is found prefixed to its syn., namely gadiyr, to show that it is used in this sense, and is qualified by a sing. epithet, namely raAYiE; but some say that it is thus qualified becanse it has a form which is that of a sing. noun: (TA:) or rajoEN signifies (assumed tropical:) water, (AO, K,) in general; (K;) and a sword is likened to it, to denote its whiteness: (AO, S: [but accord. to the latter, in this case it signifies “ a pool of water left by a torrent ”:]) and also (assumed tropical:) a tract of ground, or land, in which the torrent has extended itself: (K:) but this, it should be observed, is a repetition of the saying of Lth mentioned above: (TA:) and (assumed tropical:) the part that is above a taloEap [q. v.]; (K, TA;) the upper, or highest, part thereof, before its water collects together: (TA:) pl. rujoEaAnN. (K.) ― -b9- (assumed tropical:) The herbage of the [season, or rain, called] rabiyE; (K;) [because it returns year after year;] as also rajiyEN↓. (TA.) ― -b10- (assumed tropical:) The [membrane called] girps which is in the belly of the woman, and which comes forth upon, or over, the head of the child. (TA.) ― -b11- See also rajiyEN, in three places, in the latter part of the paragraph. ― -b12- sayofN najiyHu AlrRajoEi, and AlrRajiyEi↓, A sword which penetrates into the thing that is struck with it [so that it is quickly drawn back]. (TA.) ― -b13- rajoEu Alkatifi: see marojiEN.

rijoEu safarK c
rijoEu safarK: see rajiyEu safarK.

rujaEN c
rujaEN: see rijoEapN.

rijaEN c
rijaEN: see rajaEa naAqapF: and see rijoEapN.

rajoEapN c
rajoEapN inf. n. of un. of 1; A return; a single act of returning, of going back, coming back, or reverting: (TA:) [and] i. q. rujuwEN, i. e. the act of returning, &c. (Msb.) ― -b2- The returning to the present state of existence (S, Msb, K) after death. (S, K.) So in the phrase, fulaAnN yuWominu biAlrRajoEapi [Such a one believes in the returning to the present state of existence after death]. (S, Msb, K. *) This was a tenet of some of the Arabs in the Time of Ignorance, and of a sect of Muslim innovators, and of a sect of the raAfiDap, who say that 'Alee the son of Aboo-Tálib is concealing himself in the clouds, to come forth when he shall be summoned to do so. (L.) ― -b3- The returning, or homeward course, of a military expedition; opposed to badoOapN, q. v. (T and Mgh in art. bdO.) ― -b4- The return of a party of warriors to war after their having come back from an expedition. (TA.) ― -b5- Also, and rijoEapN↓, (S, A, Nh, Mgh, Msb, K,) but the former is the more chaste, (S, Msb, TA,) though the latter is mentioned before the former in the K, (TA,) (tropical:) A man's returning to his wife, or restoring her to himself, or taking her back by marriage or to the marriage-state, after having divorced her; (IF, Msb;) the returning of the divorcer to the divorced woman: (K:) or the taking back to marriage a woman who has been divorced, but not by an absolutely-separating sentence, without a new contract. (Nh.) You say, lahu EalaI QmoraOatihi rajoEapN and rijoEapN↓ (tropical:) [He has a right of returning to, or taking back, his wife after having divorced her]: (S, Mgh:) and yamoliku AlrRajoEapa EalaI zawojatihi (tropical:) [He possesses the right of returning &c.]: (Msb:) and TalRaqa fulaAnN fulaAnapa TalaAqFA yamoliku fiyhi AlrRajoEapa (tropical:) [Such a man divorced such a woman by a divorce in which he possessed the right of returning &c.]. (TA.) ― -b6- Also the former, (S, Msb, TA,) and rijoEapN↓ likewise, (Msb,) and rujoEapN↓ (K) and rujoEaI↓ [which is originally an inf. n.] and rujoEaAnN↓ [which is also originally an inf. n.] and marojuwEN↓ (S, K) and marojuwEapN↓ and rajuwEapN↓ and rajoEN↓, (K,) the last of these is allowable, (TA,) [being an inf. n. used in the sense of a pass. part. n.,] (tropical:) The reply, or answer, of an epistle. (S, Msb, * K, TA.) You say, halo jaMCa rajoEapu kitaAbika (S, TA) and rujoEaAnuhu↓ (TA) (tropical:) Hath the reply, or answer, of thine epistle come:? (S, TA:) and Oarosaltu Uilayoka famaA jaMCaniI rujoEaI↓ risaAlatiI (tropical:) I sent to thee, and the reply, or answer, of my epistle came not to me; i. e. marojuwEuhaA↓: (S, K, * TA:) and fulaAnK Ealayoka maA kaAna mino marojuwEi↓ (tropical:) What was [the purport] of the reply, or answer, of such a one to thee? (S, TA.) And [in like manner] AlrRiXoq rajoEu↓ signifies (assumed tropical:) What is returned against, or in opposition to, [or in reply to,] the simultaneous discharge of a number of arrows in a particular direction. (TA.) ― -b7- See also rijoEapN.

rujoEapN c
rujoEapN: see rajoEapN, in the latter half of the paragraph.

rijoEapN c
rijoEapN: see rajoEapN, in three places. ― -b2- A return, or profit, obtained by the expenditure of the price of camels sold: see an ex. above, voce AirotajaEa: (S, K:) or camels taken in exchange for other camels: or one that is taken in the place, and with the price, of two: (Mgh:) also the young, or younglings, of camels, which are purchased from the market with the price of others, or taken from the market in exchange for others: (K:) or, as Khálid says, the [return obtained by] bringing bad camels into the market and taking back good ones: or, as some say, the [return obtained by] bringing in males and taking back females: (TA:) [the words which I have here twice inserted in brackets are perhaps not necessary to complete the sense intended, as will be seen at the close of this sentence; but they seem to be required in the opinion of SM, for he has
immediately added the further explanation which here next follows, and which is also, but less fully, given by J, immediately after the first explanation in this paragraph:] and rijoEapN has a similar meaning in relation to the poor-rates; being applied to camels taken by the collector of the poor-rates older or younger than those which their owner is bound to give: (S, * TA:) and camels which are purchased by the Arabs of the desert, [app. in exchange-for others,] not of their own breeding nor bearing their marks; as also rajoEapN↓: (TA, [see 8:]) IB says that the pl. of rijoEapN is rujaEN↓; and that it was said to a tribe of the Arabs, “ By what means have your beasts become many? ” and they answered, OawoSaAnaA OabuwnaA biAlnRujaEi waAlrRujaEi: but Th says, bAlnRijaEi wAlrRijaEi↓: [both are probably correct; for it seems that the original forms are AlnRujaE and AlrRijaE; and that, in one case, the latter is assimilated to the former; in the other, accord. to a usage less common, the former to the latter:] accord. to Th, the meaning is, [Our father charged us with the seekings after herbage in the places thereof, and] the selling the old and weak beasts and purchasing others in a state of youthful vigour: or, accord. to another explanation, the meaning is, the selling males and purchasing females: thus explained, rijaEN seems to be an inf. n. (TA. [See rajaEa naAqapF.]) [See also rajiyEa.] ― -b3- [(assumed tropical:) Any return, profit, or gain, accruing from a thing, or obtained by the sale or exchange thereof; as also marojuwEN↓; and rajoEN, q. v.] You say, jaMCato rijoEapu AlDRiyaAEi (assumed tropical:) The return, or increase, accruing to the owner of the lands came, or arrived. (Lh.) And jaMCa fulaAnN birijoEapK HasanapK (assumed tropical:) Such a one brought a good thing which he had purchased in the place of a bad thing; or in the place of a thing that was inferior to it. (TA.) And hecaA mataAEN lahu marojuwEN↓ (assumed tropical:) This is a commodity for which there will be a return, or profit, or gain. (S, * TA) And daAbRapN lahaA marojuwEN↓ (assumed tropical:) A beast that may be sold after having been used. (El-Isbahánee.) And layosa lihecaA AlbayoEi marojuwEN↓ (tropical:) There is not, or will not be, any return, or profit, or gain, for this sale. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) An argument, or allegation, by which one rebuts in a litigation, or dispute; a proof; an evidence. (Ibn-'Abbád.)

rujoEaI c
rujoEaI: see rajoEapN, in the latter half of the paragraph, in two places.

TalaAqN rajoEiIRN c
TalaAqN rajoEiIRN, and rijoEiIRN, (assumed tropical:) A divorce in which one reserves to himself the right of returning to his wife, or restoring her to himself, or taking her back to the marriage-state. (Mgh, * Msb.) ― -b2- rajoEiIRN applied to a beast: see rajiyEu safarK.

rajoEiyRapN c
rajoEiyRapN: see rajiyEapN.

rujoEaAnN c
rujoEaAnN: see rajoEapN, in the latter half of the paragraph, in two places.

rijaAEN c
rijaAEN The nose-rein of a camel: (IDrd, K:) or the part thereof which falls upon the nose of the camel: pl. [of pauc.] OarojiEapN and [of mult.] rujuEN: (K:) from rajaEa in the phrase rajaEa fulaAnN EalaI Oanofi baEiyrihi [q. v.]. (IDrd.) ― -b2- It is also an inf. n.: see 1, in the middle of the paragraph.

rajiyEN c
rajiyEN. [Made, or caused, to return, go back, come back, or revert; sent back, turned back, or returned: repeated: rebutted, rejected, or repudiated, in reply, or replication: like marojuwEN↓: and used in all these senses; as will be seen from what follows: and also, like murajRaEN↓,] made, or caused, to return, go back, come back, or revert, again and again, or time after time; sent back, turned back, or returned, again and again, or time after time; made, or caused, to go, or move, repeatedly to and fro; so to go and come; to reciprocate: reiterated: reproduced: renewed: syn. muradRadN: [in the CK maroduwdN:] applied to anything: (S, K:) or to anything that is said or done: (Msb, TA:) because meaning marojuwEN↓, i. e. maroduwdN: (S, Msb, TA:) or, applied to speech, (assumed tropical:) returned to its author; or repeated to him; or rebutted, rejected, or repudiated, in reply to him; syn. maroduwdN UilaI SaAHibihi: (Lth, K:) or, so applied, (tropical:) repeated: (A, TA:) or, so applied, (assumed tropical:) reiterated: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or, so applied, (assumed tropical:) disapproved, or disliked. (TA.) You say, UiyRaAka waAlrRajiyEa mina Alqawoli (tropical:) Avoid thou the saying that is repeated; (A, TA;) [or rebutted, &c.;] or disapproved. (TA.) ― -b2- Applied to a beast, (S, TA,) and [particularly] to a camel, (K,) it signifies Made to return from journey to journey: (S, TA:) and also means (assumed tropical:) fatigued, or jaded, (S, K,) by journeying: (K:) fem. with rujuEN (S, K:) or (tropical:) lean, or emaciated: (Er-Rághib, K:) in the K is here added, or which thou hast made to return from a journey, meaning from journey to journey; but this is identical with the first explanation of the word applied to a beast: (TA:) pl. rujuEN; (K;) or [app. of the fem., agreeably with analogy, and as seems to be indicated by J,] rajaAYiEu. (S.) rajiyEu safarK and safarK rijoEu↓ [in like manner] signify Made to return repeatedly, or several times, in journeying; applied to a she-camel: (K:) and the former signifies, applied to a beast, and [particularly] to a camel, a he-camel, (baEiyr,) which one makes to return again and again, or time after time, or to come and go repeatedly, in journeying, and drags along: (TA:) both also mean (tropical:) lean, or emaciated: and are in like manner applied to a man: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and rajoEiIRN↓ and marojaEaAniIRN↓, also, but the latter is vulgar, (assumed tropical:) lean, or emaciated, by journeying; applied to a beast. (TA.) You say also saforN rajiyEN Travellers returning from a journey. (TA.) And safarN rajiyEN A journey in which are repeated returnings. (IAar.) ― -b3- Any food returned to the fire [to be heated again], having became cold: (K:) [and particularly] roasted meat heated a second time. (As.) ― -b4- A rope, or cord, undone, and then twisted a second time: (L, K:) and, as some say, anything done a second time. (L.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) Writing retraced with the pen, in order that it may became more plain: (KL:) and marojuwEN↓ [signifies the same: and also] (assumed tropical:) tattooing repeated and renewed; (EM p. 108;) tattooing of which the blackness has been restored: (TA:) pl. of the latter maraAjiyEu. (TA, and EM ubi suprà.) ― -b6- (tropical:) Dung, ordure, or excrement, of a solid-hoofed animal; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also rajoEN↓; (K;) and of a man; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also ↓the latter word; (TA;) and of a beast of prey; as also ↓the latter: (S, TA:) because it returns from its first state, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) after having been food or fodder &c.; (TA;) having the meaning of an act. part. n., (Er-Rághib, Msb,) or, it may be, of a pass. part. n. (Er-Rághib.) ― -b7- (tropical:) The cud which is ruminated by camels and the like: (S, * K:) because it returns to be eaten. (TA.) So in the saying of El-Aashà,
wafalaApK kaOanRahaA Zahoru turosK
layosa UilRaA AlrRajiyEa fiyhaA EalaAqu
i. e. [Many a desert, or waterless desert, as though it were the back of a shield,] in which there is not found by the camels anything to serve for the support of life except the cud. (S.) ― -b8- (assumed tropical:) Sweat: (K:) because, having been water, it returns as sweat. (TA.) ― -b9- See also rajoEN, in three places. ― -b10- Also (assumed tropical:) The [part called] faOos of a bit: (Ibn-' Abbád, K:) [because of its returning motion.] ― -b11- And (assumed tropical:) Niggardly, tenacious, or avaricious; syn. baxiylN [in the CK and a MS. copy of the K, naxiyl]. (Ibn-' Abbád, K, TA.)

rajuwEapN c
rajuwEapN: see rajoEapN, in the latter half of the paragraph.

rajiyEapN c
rajiyEapN A she-camel that is purchased with the price of another she-camel; as also raAjiEapN↓: (S:) or a female that is purchased with the price of a male. (' Alee Ibn-Hamzeh.) [See also rijoEapN: and see rajiyEN, of which it is originally the fem.] Accord. to ISk, rajoEiyRapN↓ signifies A camel which one has purchased from men who have brought him from another place for sale; which is not of the district in which he is: [but this appears to be a mistranscription, for rajiyEapN; for he adds,] the pl. is rajaAYiEu. (TA.)

rajRaAEN c
rajRaAEN (assumed tropical:) One who returns much, or often, unto God. (TA.)

raAjiEN c
raAjiEN [act. part. n. of 1. Hence the saying, UinRaA lilRehi waUinRaA Uilayohi raAjiEuwna, explained above: see 10. ― -b2- Also, without p,] (assumed tropical:) A woman who returns to her family in consequence of the death of her husband (Az, S, Msb, K) or in consequence of divorcement; (Az, Msb;) as also muraAjiEN↓: (Az, K:) or, accord. to some, (Msb,) she who is divorced [and sent back to her family] is termed maroduwdapN. (S, Msb.) ― -b3- [In like manner without p,] applied to a she-camel, and to a she-ass, it signifies (assumed tropical:) That raises her tail, and compresses her two sides (quTorayohaA), and casts forth her urine in repeated discharges, so that she is imagined to be pregnant, (S, K,) and then fails of fulfilling her [apparent] promise: (S:) or (assumed tropical:) that conceives,
and then fails of fulfilling her promise; because she goes back from what is hoped of her: (TA:) or, applied to a she-camel, (assumed tropical:) that has appeared to have conceived, and is then found to be not pregnant: (As:) pl. rawaAjiEu. (S, TA.) [See also rajaEato.] ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) A sick man whose soul [or health] has returned to him after his being debilitated by disease: and (assumed tropical:) a man whose soul [or health] has returned to him after severe and constant illness. (TA.)

raAjiEapN c
raAjiEapN [originally fem. of raAjiEN, q. v.]: see rajiyEapN: ― -b2- and see rajoEN. ― -b3- Also, [app. from the returning of its water time after time,] (assumed tropical:) A water-course of a valley. (ISh, TA.) ― -b4- rawaAjiEu [is its pl., and] signifies Varying winds; because of their coming and going. (TA.) ― -b5- Hence also, rawaAjiEu AlOabowaAbi [The leaves of doors]. (TA.)

OarojaEu c
OarojaEu (tropical:) More [and most] productive of return, or profitable. (TA.) You say, hecaA OarojaEu fiI yadI mino hecaA (tropical:) This is more productive of return, or profitable, in my hand than this. (TA.)

marojiEN c
marojiEN an inf. n. of the intrans. verb rajaEa [q. v.]. (S, Msb, K, &c.) ― -b2- [Hence it signifies sometimes (assumed tropical:) Recourse. See manaAbN, in art. nwb.] ＝ -A2- [A place to which a person, or thing, returns after going or moving therefrom; agreeably with analogy. See an ex. voce maHoDarN.] ― -b2- [Hence,] marojiEu Alkatifi (tropical:) The lower part of the shoulderblade, (S, K, TA,) next the arm-pit, [that on the left side being] in the region where the heart beats; (TA;) as also Alkatifi rajoEu↓: (S, K:) and marojiEu Almirofaqi (tropical:) [the place to which the elbow returns when, after it has been removed from its usual place, it is brought back thereto; which place in a beast is next the arm-pit: see fariySN, in three places]: (TA:) pl. maraAjiEu. (TA.) ― -b3- [marojiEN also signifies (assumed tropical:) The place, or thing, to which a person, or thing, is referred, as his, or its, source: see manoSibN. ― -b4- Also, (assumed tropical:) A state, or condition, to which a person, or thing, returns. ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) The place, and the state, or condition, or result, to which a person, or thing, ultimately, or eventually, comes. A goal.] ＝ -A3- It is also an inf. n. of rajaEahu. (K.)

murojiEN c
murojiEN, [without p,] applied to a she-camel, (assumed tropical:) Becoming in good condition after leanness. (Ks, TA.) [See 4, of which it is the act. part. n.] ― -b2- hecaA mataAEN murojiEN (assumed tropical:) This is a commodity for which there will be a return, or profit, or gain. (S, * TA.) ― -b3- saforapN murojiEapN (tropical:) A journey having a recompense, or reward, and a good issue or result. (K, TA.)

murajRaEN c
murajRaEN: see rajiyEN; first sentence.

marojaEaAniIRN c
marojaEaAniIRN: see rajiyEN, in the latter half of the paragraph.

marojuwEN c
marojuwEN [pass. part. n. of rajaEahu]: see rajiyEN, in three places: ― -b2- and rajoEapN, in the latter half of the paragraph, in three places: ― -b3- and rijoEapN, near the end of the paragraph, in four places.

marojuwEapN c
marojuwEapN: see rajoEapN, in the latter half of the paragraph.

muraAjiEN c
muraAjiEN: see raAjiEN.

Q. 4 AirojaEanRa c
Q. 4. AirojaEanRa a dial. var. of AirojaHanR [q. v.] in the several senses of the latter. (K.) You say, Darabahu faQrojaEanRa He beat him, or struck him, and he lay on his side, and threw himself down. (Lh, TA.) And ArjEnRwA They lay on their sides and were overcome. (TA.) ― -b2- Also It became spread, expanded, or extended. (TA.)

1 rajafa c
1. rajafa, (O, Msb, K,) aor.
rajufa
, (Msb,) inf. n. rajofN and rajafaAnN (O, Msb, K) and rajiyfN (Msb, K) and rujuwfN; (O, K;) [and Arjf↓; (see the next sentence;) and Artjf↓; (see nagaDa, in two places;)] It (a thing, O, Msb) was, or became, in a state of motion, commotion, (O, Msb, K,) agitation, convulsion, tumult, or disturbance: (Msb, K: *) or in a state of violent motion, commotion, agitation, &c.; (K;) as the camel beneath the saddle, and the tree when put in motion by the wind, and the wabbling tooth, and the like. (O.) You say, rajafati AlOaroDu, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
rajufa
, inf. n. rajofN, (S,) The earth quaked; or was, or became, in a state of motion, commotion, agitation, &c., (S, O, Msb, K,) as above; (Msb;) and so Oarojafat↓, and Ourojifat↓; (K;) [for Arjf is both intrans. and trans.:] and AlrRajafaAnu signifies the being in a state of violent commotion, agitation, convulsion, tumult, or disturbance. (S.) And rajafato yaduhu His arm, or hand, trembled, by reason of disease, or old age. (Msb.) And rajafa Alqalobu The heart became agitated by reason of fright. (IDrd, O.) ― -b2- rajafa AlrRaEodu, (Lth, O, K,) inf. n. rajofN and rajiyfN, (Lth, O,) The thunder made a reiterated rumbling, or confused noise, in the clouds. (Lth, O, K.) ― -b3- rajafa Alqawomu The people, or party, prepared themselves for war, or battle. (Lth, O, K.) ＝ -A2- Also He put [a thing] into a state of motion, commotion, or agitation; (O, K;) [so too, app., rajafa bihi;] see 4, last sentence; [and so Oarojafa↓; for] Oarojafa AlOaroDa bihimo is said of God [as meaning He made the earth to quake with them]. (TA in art. dm.) And one says also, rajafatohu AlHumRaI The fever caused him to quake, or shiver. (Msb.)

4 Oarojafa
4: as an intrans. v.: see 1, in two places. ＝ -A2- And as a trans. v.; act. and pass.: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- [Hence,] Arjf bikacaA [originally He put another, or others, into a state of commotion, or agitation, by such a thing; meaning] he told of such a thing without truth, or not according to the true, or real, state of the case: [because he thereby caused commotion, or agitation; or] because the information was unsettled: from rajofapN meaning as explained below. (Ksh in xxxiii. 60.) And ArjfwA fiI AlXRaIoCi (S, Msb, K) and bihi, (Msb, K,) inf. n. UirojaAfN, (Msb,) i. q. xaADuwA fiyhi [mean- ing They said what was false respecting the thing]: (S, O, K:) or they told many evil tales, and uttered many discordant lying sayings, respecting the thing, in order that the people might become in a state of commotion, agitation, convulsion, tumult, or disturbance, in consequence thereof: whence, in the Kur [xxxiii. 60], fiI Almadiynapi waAlmurojifuwna↓ [and they who tell many evil tales, &c., in the city:] (O, * Msb:) or ArjfwA fiI Albaladi bikacaA they told, in the town, or country, of such a matter, in order that they might cause commotion, or agitation, &c., to befall the people, without there being aught [thereof] true in their estimation; from AlrRajafaAnu signifying “ violent commotion or agitation ” &c. (Har pp. 218, 219.) And ArjfwA, alone, They said what was false (xaADuwA) in [relating] tales of conflicts and factions, or seditions, or discords, or dissensions, and the like: whence, waAlmurojifuwnu↓ fiI Almadiynapi [cited above]. (K.) ― -b3- And Arjft AlnRaAqapu The she-camel came in a state of fatigue, with her ears flaccid, shaking them (bihimaA tarojufu↓). (O, K.)

8 Uirotajafa
8: see 1, first sentence.

rajoEapN c
rajoEapN i. q. zalozalapN (S, K) [meaning Commotion, agitation, or convulsion; or violent commotion &c.; and particularly an earthquake; or] a violent earthquake: and a vehement cry from heaven: (Jel in vii. 76:) or it signifies, in the Kur-án, any punishment that befalls a people. (Lth, O.)

rajuwfN c
[rajuwfN, accord. to Freytag, occurs in the Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen as meaning Put into a state of commotion.] ― -b2- saHaAbN rajuwfN Clouds in commotion with thunder, or with much water. (O.)

AlrRajRaAfu c
AlrRajRaAfu The sea; because of its commotion, or agitation. (S, O, K.) A poet says, (S,) namely, Matrood Ibn-Kaab, lamenting the death of ' Abdel-Muttalib, (IB, O,) the grandfather of the Prophet, and eulogizing him, (IB,)
AalomuToEimuwna AlXRaHoma kulRa EaXiyRapK
HatRaI tagiyba AlXRamosu fiI AlrRajRaAfi
[The feeders with fat every evening, until the sun disappeared in the sea]. (S, O.) ― -b2- And The day of resurrection: (Sh, O, K:) and the congregation [of the risen]. (K.) ― -b3- And rajRaAfN also signifies A certain kind of pace [app. with a jolting motion]. (O, K.)

raAjifN c
raAjifN [Putting into a state of motion, commotion, or agitation. ― -b2- And also, or HumRaI raAjifN,] A fever attended with quaking, or shivering: (O, Msb, K:) deviating from rule [because HumRaI is fem.]. (Msb.) ― -b3- [The fem., with p, app. applied to a she-camel or the like, occurs, accord. to Freytag, in the Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen, as meaning Moving the head in going along.]

AlrRaAjifapu c
AlrRaAjifapu, in the Kur lxxix. 6, means The first blast [of the horn on the day of resurrection]: and AlrRaAdifapu, in the next verse, “ the second blast: ” (O, Bd, Jel, K:) or the former means the motionless bodies that shall be in a state of violent motion
at the time here spoken of, such as the earth and the mountains; because of the saying in the Kur [lxxiii. 14], yawpma tarojufu QloOaroDu waQlojibaAlu: and the latter, “ the heaven, and the stars, which shall be cleft and scattered. ” (Bd.)

UirojaAfN c
UirojaAfN inf. n. of 4 [q. v.]. (Msb.) [And hence, as a simple subst.,] sing. of [OaraAjiyfu in the phrase] OaraAjiyfu AlOaxobaAri [meaning Tales without truth, or reality: or evil tales, and discordant lies, uttered in order that people may become in a state of commotion, agitation, convulsion, tumult, or disturbance, in consequence thereof: see 4]. (S.) You say, waqaEuwA fiI OaraAjiyfa [They fell into convulsing perplexities, arising from evil and discordant and false rumours or the like]. (AA, S and K in art. tE.)

AlmurojifaAni c
AlmurojifaAni The basin and ewer (AlTRasotu waAlUiboriyqu) [that are used for washing the hands before and after a meal]: because they produce a sound when one of them is knocked against the other: as though that sound told of the completion of the meal, and excited [the persons that had partaken thereof] to rise. (Har p. 228.) ― -b2- waAlmurojifuwna fiI Almadiynapi, in the Kur xxxiii. 60: see 4, in two places. [This art. is wanting in the copies of the L and TA to which I have had access.]

1 rajila c
1. rajila, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
rajala
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. rajalN (T, S, M, Msb) and rujolapN, (T, TA,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Msb,) He (a man) went on foot, in a journey, by himself, [i. e.] having no beast whereon to ride; (T, TA;) he had no beast whereon to ride, (M, K, TA,) in a journey, so went on his feet: (TA:) or he remained going on foot: so says AZ; and Ks says the like: (S:) or he was, or became, strong to walk, or go on foot: (Msb:) and trjRl↓ [in like manner] signifies he went on foot, (S, K, TA,) having alighted from his beast: (TA:) [used in the present day as meaning he alighted from his beast:] and trjulwA↓ they alighted [upon their feet, or dismounted,] in war, or battle, to fight: and Artjl↓ he (a man) went on his legs, or feet, for the purpose of accomplishing the object of his want. (TA.) ― -b2- rajila, (M, K,) aor.
rajala
, (K,) [inf. n. rajalN, being similar to rakiba, aor.
rajala
, inf. n. rakabN,] also signifies He (a man) was, or became, large in the rijol [i. e. leg, or foot]. (M, K: but omitted in some copies of the K.) ― -b3- And rujila, like EuniIa; and rajila, aor.
rajala
; inf. n. [of the former] rijolapN and [of the latter] rijolN; [so in the CK; but accord. to the rule of the K they should be rajolapN and rajolN, as neither is expressly said to be with kesr; or the latter may be correctly rijolN, as rajila is said to be like Ealima, of which the inf. n. is EilomN;] He had a complaint of his rijol [i. e. leg, or foot]: (CK; but omitted in other copies: both mentioned in the TA:) the latter verb is mentioned in this sense by El-Fárisee, and also on the authority of Kr. (TA.) ― -b4- And rajila mino rijolihi He was, or became, affected in his leg, or foot, by something that he disliked. (TA.) ― -b5- And rajila, aor.
rajala
, (K, TA,) inf. n. rajalN, (TA,) He (a beast, such as a horse or the like,) had a whiteness in one of his rijolaAni [i. e. hind legs or feet], (K, TA,) without a whiteness in any other part. (TA.) ＝ -A2- rajila, aor.
rajala
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. rajalN, (Msb, TA,) is also said of hair, (Msb, K,) meaning It was, or became, [wavy, or somewhat curly, i. e.] of a quality between lankness and crispness or curliness, (K,) or neither very crisp or curly, nor very lank, but between these two. (Msb, TA.) ＝ -A3- rajalahu, (CK, TA, omitted in some copies of the K,) [aor.
rajula
, as in similar verbs,] inf. n. rajolN, (TA,) He, or it, hit, or hurt, his rijoli [i. e. leg, or foot]. (CK, TA.) ― -b2- rajala AlXRaApa, (S, K,) or, accord. to the O and the Mufradát, rajala AlXRaApa birijolihaA, (TA,) and ArtjlhA↓, (K,) He suspended the sheep, or goat, by its hind leg or foot: (S, O, K:) or the meaning is EaqalahaA birijolayohi [app. he confined its shank and arm together with his feet, by pressing his feet upon its folded fore legs while it was lying on the ground], (K,) or, as in the M, birjolihi [with his foot]. (TA.) ― -b3- rajalato waladahaA, (K,) inf. n. rajolN; in the copies of the M written rajRalato↓, with teshdeed; (TA;) She (a woman) brought forth her child preposterously, so that its legs came forth before its head. (K.) ＝ -A4- rajalahaA, namely, the mother of a young camel, (K,) aor.
rajula
, inf. n. rajolN, (TA,) He sent the young one with her [to suck her whenever he would; as is implied by what immediately precedes]; as also OarojalahaA↓: (K:) or AlfaSiyla Oarojalotu↓ (so in two copies of the S and in the O) I left the young camel with his mother to such her whenever he pleased: (S, * O: [in one of my copies of the S rajalotu, which appears from what here follows to be a mistake:]) so says ISk: and he cites as an ex.,
HatRaI fuTimaA musarohadN Ourojila↓
[Fat, and well nourished: he was left with his mother to such her when he pleased until he was weaned]. (O.) [See also rajalN, below; where it is explained as though a quasi-inf. n. of Oarojalotu in the sense here assigned to it in the S and O, or inf. n. of rajalotu in the same sense.] ― -b2- And rajala OumRahu, (S, K,) aor.
rajula
, inf. n. rajolN, (S,) He (a young camel, S, or a lamb, or kid, or calf, K, TA) sucked his mother. (S, K.) ― -b3- rajalN also signifies The act of [the stallion's] leaping the mare: (O, K, TA:) [i. e., as inf. n. of rajala; for] one says, baAta AlHiSaAnu yurojulu Alxayola The stallion-horse passed the night leaping the mares. (TA; and so in the O, except that Alxyl is there omitted.) ― -b4- And rajala AlmaroOapa He compressed the woman. (TA.) ＝ -A5- [Golius says that rajula signifies Vir et virili animo fuit; as on the authority of J; and that rujolapN is its inf. n.: but it seems that he found AlrRujolapu incorrectly explained in a copy of the S as maSodaru rajula instead of maSodaru AlrRajuli: ISd expressly says that rujolapN and its syns. (explained below) are of the number of those inf. ns. that have no verbs.]

2 rajRalato waladahaA c
2. rajRalato waladahaA [app. a mistranscription]: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph. ＝ -A2- tarojiylN [the inf. n.] signifies The making, or rendering, strong.
