(Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ＝ -A3- rjRl AlXRaEara, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. tarojiylN, (S, Msb, K,) He made the hair to be [wavy, or somewhat curly, i. e.] not very crisp or curly, nor lank, (S,) or in a state between that of lankness and that of crispness or curliness: (K:) or he combed the hair; (Msb, TA;) either his own hair, [see 5,] or that of another: (Msb:) or he combed down the hair; i. e., let it down, or made it to hang down, by means of the comb: (Mgh:) Er-Rághib says, as though he made it to descend at the rijol [or foot], i. e. from its places of growth; but this requires consideration: (MF:) or he combed and anointed the hair: (TA voce EasibN:) or he washed and combed the hair. (Ham p. 356.)

4 Arjlhu c
4. Arjlhu He made him to go on foot; (S, K, TA;) to alight from his beast. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And He granted him some delay, or respite; let him alone, or left him, for a while. (S, K.) ― -b2- Oarojalotu AlHiSaAna fiI Alxayoli I sent-the stallion-horse among the mares. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 1, in the latter half of the paragraph, in three places.

5 tarajRala
5: see 1, first sentence, in two places. ― -b2- trjRl fiI AlbiYori, (S, Msb, K,) and trjRl AlbiYora, (K,) He descended into the well (S, Msb, K) [by means of his feet, or legs, alone, i. e.,] without his being let down, or lowered, or suspended [by means of a rope]. (S, Msb.) ― -b3- trjRl AlzRanoda, and Artjlhu↓, [or, more probably, Artjl AlzRanodapa, and trjRlhA, (see murotajilN,)] He put the znd [or the zndp; (the former meaning the upper, and the latter the lower, of the two pieces of wood used for producing fire,)] beneath his feet: (M, K:) or Artjl↓ signifies he (a man come from a distant country) struck fire, and held the zanod [here app. meaning (as in many other instances) the znd properly so called and the zndp] with his hands and his feet, [i. e. the znd with his hands and the zndp with his feet,] because he was alone. (TA. [See murotajilN.]) ＝ -A2- [trjRl He became a rajul, or man; he rose to manhood. (See an explanation of trjRl AlnRahaAru, in what follows.) And] trjRlt She (a woman, TA) became like a rajul [or man] (K, TA) in some of her qualities, or states, or predicaments. (TA.) ― -b2- trjRl AlnRahaAru i. q. AirotafaEa (tropical:) [i. e. The day became advanced, the sun being somewhat high]; (S, IAth, O, K, TA;) it being likened to the rising of a man from youth; (IAth, TA;) and so AlnhAr Artjl↓: or, accord. to Er-Rághib, the former means the sun went down from [or below] the walls; as though it alighted (kaOanRahaA tarajRalato [in a proper sense of this verb: see 1, first sentence]). (TA.) ＝ -A3- And trjRl He combed his own hair: (Msb:) or he combed down his own hair; i. e., let it down, or made it to hang down, by means of the comb: (Mgh:) or he anointed [or washed] and combed his own hair. (TA. [See 2.]) Hence, nahaI
Eani AltRarajRuli UilRaA gibRFA (Mgh, TA) He [Mohammad] forbade the anointing and combing of one's own hair except it be less frequent than every day. (TA.)

8 Artjl c
8. Artjl: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- Said of a horse, (in his running, TA,) He mixed the pace termed AlEanaq with that termed Alhamolajap, (T, TA,) or the former pace with somewhat of the latter, and thus, (S,) he went those two paces alternately, (S, K,) somewhat of the former and somewhat of the latter. (S.) ＝ -A2- He took a man by his rijol [i. e. leg, or foot]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- Artjl AlXRaApa: see 1, in the middle of the paragraph. ― -b3- Artjl AlrRanoda [or AlzRanodapa], and Artjl alone in a similar sense: see 5, in two places. ＝ -A3- [He extemporized a speech or verses; spoke it or them extemporaneously, impromptu, or without premeditation;] he began an oration (a xuTobap), and poetry, without his having prepared it beforehand; (S;) he spoke a speech (Msb, K) without consideration or thought, (Msb,) or without his having prepared it; (K;) he recited it, or related it, standing, without forecast, consideration, thought, or meditation; so accord. to Er-Rághib [who seems to have held this to be the primary signification of the verb when relating to a speech or the like]; or without reiteration, and without pausing, halting, or hesitating. (TA.) And Artjl AlXRaIoCa [He did, performed, or produced, the thing without premeditation, or previous preparation]. (TA in art. xrE.) [And Artjl QsomFA He coined a name.] ― -b2- Artjl biraOoyihi He was, or became, alone, or independent of others, with none to take part or share or participate with him, in his opinion, (Msb, K, TA,) without consulting any one respecting it, (Msb, TA,) and kept constantly, or perseveringly, to it. (Msb.) [Hence,] Oamoruka maA Qrotajalota Thine affair [to which thou shouldst keep] is that respecting which thou art alone [&c.] in thine opinion. (K.) And Airotajilo maA Qrotajalota mina AlOamori is explained in the T as meaning Airokabo maA rakibota minohu [i. e. Undertake thou what thou hast undertaken of the affair: but it may rather signify keep thou to what thou hast undertaken of the affair; agreeably with what here follows]. (TA.) One says also, Airotajilo rajolaka↓ Keep thou to thine affair: (IAar, M, K, TA:) in [some of] the copies of the K, erroneously, rajalaka. (TA.) ＝ -A4- He collected a detached number (qiToEap [or rijol]) of locusts, to roast, or fry, them. (S.) ＝ -A5- He set up a mirojal [q. v.], to cook food in it: (T, TA:) or he cooked food in a mirojal. (K.) ＝ -A6- Artjl AlnRahaAru: see 5.

10 Astrjl c
10. Astrjl He desired, or requested, to be, or to go, on foot. (KL.)

rajolN c
rajolN: see rajulN: ― -b2- and raAjilN; the latter in two places. ＝ -A2- See also rajilN, in two places. ＝ -A3- Airotajilo rajolaka, in some of the copies of the K, erroneously, rajalaka: see 8, near the end of the paragraph.

rijolN c
rijolN [The leg of a human being and of a bird, and the kind leg of a quadruped; in each of these senses opposed to yadN;] the part from the root of the thigh to the [sole of] the foot of a man [and of any animal]; (Mgh, Msb, K:) rijolu AlUinosaAni meaning that [limb] with which the man walks: (Msb:) or the foot of a man [and of a bird, and the kind foot of a quadruped: or rather it signifies thus in many instances; but generally as before explained: and sometimes, by a synecdoche, it is used in a yet larger sense, as will be explained below]: (K:) of the fem. gender: (Zj, Msb, TA:) pl. OarojulN: (S, Msb, K, &c.:) it has no other pl. (Msb, TA) known to Sb; (TA;) the pl. of pauc. being also used as a pl. of mult. in this instance. (IJ, TA.) [Hence,] AlrRijolu jubaArN [The hind leg or foot, or it may here mean the leg or foot absolutely, is a thing of which no account, or for which no retaliation or mulct, is taken]: i. e., if a beast tread upon a man with its rijol, there is no retaliation or mulct, if in motion; but if the beast be standing still in the road, or way, the rider is responsible, whether it strike with a yad or a rijol. (TA.) And huwa qaAYimN EalaI rijolK [lit. He is standing upon a single leg; meaning] (assumed tropical:) he is setting about, or betaking himself to, an affair that presses severely, or heavily, upon him, or that straitens him. (T, K, TA. [In the CK, Hazanahu is erroneously put for Hazabahu.]) And OanaA EalaI rijolK (assumed tropical:) I am in fear, or fright, lest a thing should escape me. (TA.) ― -b2- cuw AlrRijoli [as though meaning The onelegged;] a certain idol, of El-Hijáz. (TA.) ― -b3- rijolu AljabRaAri (assumed tropical:) The very bright star [3, called by our astronomers “ Rigel, ” and also called by the Arabs rijolu AljawozaMCi AlyusoraI,] upon the left foot of Orion. (Kzw.) [And rijolu AljawozaMCi AlyumonaI (assumed tropical:) The star k upon the right leg of Orion.] ― -b4- rijolu AlguraAbi (assumed tropical:) A certain plant, (K,) called also rijolu AlrRaAgi, the root, or lower part, of which, when cooked, is good for chronic diarrhœa; mentioned in art. grb [q. v.]. (TA.) Also A certain mode of binding the udder of a camel, so that the young one cannot suck, therewith, nor will it undo: (S, K:) whence the phrase SarRa rijola AlguraAbi, for SarRa SarRFA mivola SarRirijoli AlguraAbi. (TA.) El-Kumeyt says,
SarRa rijola AlguraAbi mulokuka fiI AlnRaA
si EalaI mano OaraAda fiyhi AlfujuwraA
(assumed tropical:) [Thy dominion among the people has bound with a bond not to be undone him who desires, within the scope of it, transgression]: (S, TA:) i. e. thy dominion has become firm so that it cannot be undone; like as what is termed rjl AlgrAb cannot be undone by the young camel. (TA.) And one says, SurRa Ealayohi rijolu AlguraAbi, meaning (tropical:) The affair was, or became, difficult to him: (K and TA in art. grb:) or his life, or subsistence, was, or became, difficult to him. (TA in that art.) ― -b5- rijolu AljaraAdi (assumed tropical:) A certain plant, like Albaqolapu AlyamaAniyRapu [see art. bql: accord. to Golius, the former appellation is applied to a species of atriplex, or orache]. (IAar, K.) ― -b6- [And several other plants have similar appellations in the present day.] ― -b7- rijolu AlTRaAYiri (assumed tropical:) A certain miysam [i. e. branding-instrument, or brand]. (S, K.) ― -b8- rijolu AlbaAbi (assumed tropical:) The foot, or heel, of the door, upon which it turns in a socket in the threshold. (MA.) ― -b9- rijolu Alqawosi (assumed tropical:) The lower curved extremity of the bow; (Kh, S, K;) the upper curved extremity being called its yad: (Kh, S:) or the part below its kabid [q. v.]: accord. to AHn, it is more complete, or perfect, than its yd: accord. to IAar, Oarojulu Alqawosi means, when the string is bound, or braced, the upper parts of the bow; and OayodiyhaA, its lower parts; and the former are stronger than the latter: and he cites the saying,
layota AlqisIRa kulRuhaA mino Oarojuli
[Would that the bows were all of them, or wholly, of what are termed Oarojul]: the two extremities of the bow, he says, are called its ZuforaAni; and its two notches, its furoDataAni; and its curved ends, its siYataAnX; and after the sYtAn are the TaAYifaAni; and after the TAYfAn, the OaboharaAni; and the portion between the AbhrAn is its kabid; this being between the two knots of the suspensory. (TA.) ― -b10- rijolaA AlsRahomi (assumed tropical:) The two extremities of the arrow. (K, * TA. [In the former it is implied that the phrase is rijolu AlsRahomi.]) ― -b11- rijolu baHorK (tropical:) A canal (xlyj) of a bHr [or large river]. (Kr, K, TA.) ― -b12- rijolN also signifies (tropical:) A part, or portion, of a thing: (K, TA:) of the fem. gender. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of 'Áïsheh, OahodaI lanaA Oabuw bakorK rijola XaApK maXowiyRapK faqasamotuhaA UilRaA katifihaA, meaning (tropical:) [Aboo-Bekr gave to us] the half of a roasted sheep, or goat, divided lengthwise [and I divided it into shares, except its shoulder-blade, or its shoulder]: she called the half thus by a synecdoche: (IAth, O, TA:) or she meant the leg (rjol) thereof, with what was next to it [for mmA yaliyhaA in the O and TA, I read bimaA yaliyhaA] of the lateral half: or she thus alluded to the whole thereof, like as one does by the term raOos. (O, TA. [But see what here next follows.]) And in another trad., the rijol of a [wild] ass is mentioned as a gift, meaning (tropical:) One of the two lateral halves: or, as some say, the thigh: (TA:) and it is explained as meaning the whole; but this is a mistake. (Mgh.) ― -b13- Also (assumed tropical:) The half of a raAwiyap [or pair of leathern bags, such as are borne by a camel, one on each side,] of wine, and of olive-oil. (AHn, K.) ― -b14- It is also applied by some to (assumed tropical:) A pair of trousers or drawers; and rijolu saraAwiyla occurs in this sense in a trad., for rijolaA saraAwiyla; like zawoju xufRK and zawoju naEolK, whereas each is properly zawojaAni; for the srAwyl are of the articles of clothing for the two legs: (IAth, TA:) this is what is meant by the saying in the K [and in the O likewise] that AlrRijolu also signifies AlsRaraAwiylu [app. for mina AlsRaraAwiyli AlTRaAqu]. (TA.) ― -b15- Also (assumed tropical:) A swarm, or numerous assemblage, of locusts: (S:) or a detached number (qiToEapN) thereof: (K:) [or] one says [or says also] rijolu jaraAdK, (S, TA,) and
rijolN mino jaraAdK: it is masc. and fem.: (TA:) a pl. without a proper sing.; like EaAnapN (a herd of [wild] asses, S) and xiyTN (a flock of ostriches, S) and SuiwaArN (a herd of [wild] bulls or cows, S): (S, K:) pl. OarojaAlN; (K:) and so in the next two senses here following. (TA.) ― -b16- And hence, as being likened thereto, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) An army: (K:) or a numerous army. (TA.) ― -b17- Also (assumed tropical:) A share in a thing. (IAar, K.) So in the saying, liI fiI maAlika rijolN (assumed tropical:) [To me belongs a share in thy property]. (TA.) ― -b18- And (tropical:) A time. (TA.) One says, kaAna celika EaliI rijoli fulaAnK (tropical:) That was in the time of such a one; (S, K, TA;) in his life-time: (K, TA:) like the phrase ElI raOosi fulaAnK. (TA.) ― -b19- Also (assumed tropical:) Precedence. (Abu-l- Mekárim, K.) When the files of camels are collected together, an owner, or attendant, of camels says, liIa AlrRijolu, i. e. (assumed tropical:) [The precedence belongs to me; or] I precede: and another says, laA bali AlrRijolu liI (assumed tropical:) [Nay, but the precedence belongs to me]: and they contend together for it, each unwilling to yield it to the other: (Abu-l-Mekárim, TA:) pl. OarojaAlN: (K:) and so in the senses here following. (TA.) ― -b20- And (assumed tropical:) Distress; straitness of the means of subsistence or of the conveniences of life; a state of pressing want; misfortune; or calamity; and poverty. (O, K.) ＝ -A2- Also A man who sleeps much: (O, K:) fem. with p. (TA.) ― -b2- And A man such as is termed qaAcuwrapN [which means foul in language; evil in disposition: one who cares not what he does or says: very jealous: one who does not mix, or associate as a friend, with others, because of the evilness of his disposition, nor alight with them: &c.: see art. qcr]. (O, K.) ＝ -A3- Also Blank paper; (O, K, * TA;) without writing. (TA.)

rajalN c
rajalN: see raAjilu, first sentence: ＝ -A2- and see also rajilN, in two places. ＝ -A3- [It is also explained as here follows, as though a quasi-inf. n. of 4 in a sense mentioned in the first paragraph on the authority of the S and O, or inf. n. of rajala in the same sense; thus:] The sending, (S, O,) or leaving, (K, TA,) a lamb or kid or calf, (S, O, TA,) or a young camel, (K, TA,) and a colt, (TA,) with its mother, to such her whenever it pleases: (S, O, K:) [but I rather think that this is a loose explanation of the meaning implied by rajalN used as an epithet; for it is added in the S and O immediately, and in the K shortly after, that] one says bahomapN rajalN (S, O, K) and rajilN↓ (K) [meaning, as indicated in the S and O, A lamb, or hid, or calf, sent with its mother to such her whenever it pleases, or, as indicated in the K, sucking, or that sucks, its mother]: pl. OarojaAlN. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- Also A horse [i. e. a stallion] sent upon the xayol [meaning mares, to leap them]: (K:) and in like manner one says xayolN rajalN, [using it as a pl., app. meaning horses so sent,] (K accord. to the TA,) or xayolN rajilapN↓. (CK, and so in my MS. copy of the K: [perhaps it should be rajalapN.])

rajulN c
rajulN (S, O, Mgh, Msb, K &c.) and rajolN↓, (O, K,) the latter a dial. var., (O,) or, accord. to Sb and El-Fárisee, a quasi-pl. n., [but app. of raAjilN, not of rajulN,] called by Abu-l-Hasan a pl., (TA,) A man, as meaning the male of the human species; (Msb;) the opposite of AimoraOapN: (S, O, Mgh:) applied only to one who has attained to puberty and manhood: (K, * TA:) or as soon as he is born, (K, TA,) and afterwards also: (TA:) pl. rijaAlN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) [applied in the Kur lxxii. 6 to men and to jinn (or genii), like naAsN and OunaAsN, and likewise a pl. of raAjilN, and of its syn. rajolaAnu,] and rjaAlaAtN, (S, K,) said by some to be a pl. pl., (TA,) and rajolapN↓, (Sb, Msb, K, TA, in the CK rijolapN, [which is a mistake, as is shown by what follows,]) of the measure faEolapN, with fet-h to the f, (Msb,) [but this is, properly speaking, a quasi-pl. n.,] said to be the only instance of its kind except kamoOapN, which, however, some say is a n. un. like others of the same form belonging to [coll.] gen. ns., (Msb,) used as a pl. of pauc. instead of OarojaAlN, (Sb, Ibn-Es-Serráj, Msb, TA,) because they assigned to rajulN no pl. of pauc., (Sb, TA,) not saying OarojaAlN (TA) [nor rijolapN], and rajilapN↓, mentioned by AZ as another pl., but this [also] is a quasi-pl. n., and of it Abu-l-' Abbás holds rajolapN↓ to be a contraction, (TA,) and rijalapN (Ks, K) and OaraAjilu (Ks, S, K) and [another quasi-pl. n. is] marojalN↓. (IJ, K.) Xahiydayoni mino rijaAlikumo, in the Kur [ii. 282], means [Two witnesses] of the people of your religion. (TA.) [rajulN also signifies A woman's husband: and the dual] rajulaAni [sometimes] means A man and his wife; predominance being thus attributed to the former. (IAar, TA.) And rajulapN↓ signifies A woman: (S, K:) or, accord. to Er-Rághib, a woman who is, or affects to be, or makes herself, like a man in some of her qualities, or states, or predicaments. (TA.) It is said of 'Áïsheh, (S, TA,) in a trad., which confirms this latter explanation, (TA,) kaAnato AlrRaOoIi, rajulapa↓, (S, TA,) meaning She was like a man in judgment. (TA. [See also marojalaAniyRapN.]) The dim. of rajulN is rujayolN↓ and ruwayojilN↓: (S, K:) the former reg.: (TA:) the latter irreg., as though it were dim. of raAjilN: (S, TA:) [but it seems that ruwayojilN is properly the dim. of raAjilN, though used as that of rajulN.] One says, huwa rajulu waHodihi [He is a man unequalled, or that has no second], (IAar, L in art. wHd,) and waHodihi rujayolu↓ [A little man (probably meaning the contrary) unequalled, &c.]. (S and L in that art.) And it is said in a trad., Uino Sadaqa OafolaHa AlrRuwayojilu↓ [The little man prospers if he speak truth] (TA.) ― -b2- Also One much given to coition: (Az, O, K:) used in this sense by the Arabs of ElYemen: and some of the Arabs term such a one EuSofuwriIRN. (O, TA.) ― -b3- And i. q. raAjilN, q. v. (Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b4- And Perfect, or complete [in respect of bodily vigour or the like]: ('Eyn, O, K, TA: [in the CK, wAlrRAjilu AlkaAmilu is erroneously put for wAlrAajl wAlkAml:]) or strong and perfect or complete: sometimes it has this meaning, as an epithet: and when thus used, Sb allows its being in the gen. case in the phrase, mararotu birajulK rajulK Oabuwhu [I passed by a man whose father is strong &c.]; though the nom. case is more common: he says, also, that when you say, huwa AlrRajulu, you may mean that he is perfect or complete, or you may mean any man that speaks and that walks upon two legs. (M, TA.) ＝ -A2- [In the CK, XaEarN rajulN is erroneously put for XaEarN rajolN: and, in the same, rajulu AlXRaEari, as syn. with rajilu AlXRaEari, is app. a mistake for rajolu AlXRaEari; but it is mentioned in this sense by 'Iyád:] see the paragraph here following.

rajilN c
rajilN; and its fem., with p: see raAjilN. ＝ -A2- XaEarN rajilN (ISk, S, Msb, K) and rajalN↓ (ISk, S, K) and rajolN↓, (Msb, K, [in the CK, erroneously, rajulN,]) Hair [that is wavy, or somewhat curly, i. e.] of a quality between [bayona, for which bayRinu is erroneously put in the CK,] lankness and crispness or curliness, (K,) or not very crisp or curly, nor lank, (ISk, S,) or neither very crisp or curly, nor very lank, but between these two. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- And rajilu AlXRaEari and rajaluhu↓ (ISd, Sgh, K) and rajoluhu↓ (ISd, K, TA, but accord. to the CK as next follows,] and rajuluhu↓, with damm to the j, added by 'Iyád, in the Meshárik, (MF, TA,) A man having hair such as is described above: pl. OarojaAlN and rajaAlaI; (M, K;) the former, most probably, accord. to analogy, pl. of rajolN; but both may be pls. of rajilN and rajalN: accord. to Sb, however, rajalN has no broken pl., its pl. being only rajaluwna. (M, TA.) ＝ -A3- See also rajalN, in two places.

rajolapN c
rajolapN: see rajulN, first sentence, in two places: ― -b2- and raAjilN. ＝ -A2- See also the next paragraph.

rujolapN c
rujolapN The going on foot; (T, S, * M, TA;) the act of the man who has no beast [to carry him]; (T, TA;) an inf. n. (T, S, TA) of rajila: (T, TA: [see 1, first sentence:]) or it signifies strength to walk, or go on foot; (Msb, K;) and is a simple subst.: (Msb:) and also excellence of a daAbRap [meaning horse or ass or mule] and of a camel in endurance of long journeying; in which sense [Az says] I have not heard any verb belonging to it except [by implication] in the epithets rajiylapN, applied to a she-camel, and rajiylN, applied to an ass and to a man: (T, TA:) and (M) rijolapN↓, with kesr, signifies vehemence, or strength, of walking or going on foot; (M, K;) as also rajolapN↓. (K. [In the K is then added, “ or with damm, strength to walk, or go on foot; ” but it seems evident that we should read “ and with damm, ” &c., agreeably with the passage in the M, in which the order of the two clauses is the reverse of their order in the K.]) One says, Hamalaka QllRehu Eani AlrRujolapi and mina AlrRujolapi, i. e. [May God give thee a beast to ride upon, and so relieve thee from going on foot, or] from the act of the man who has no beast. (T, TA.) And huwa cuw rujolapK He has strength to walk, or go on foot. (Msb.) ― -b2- And The state, or condition, of being a rajul [or man, or male human being; generally meaning manhood, or manliness, or manfulness]; (S, K;)
as also rujuwlapN↓ (Ks, S, TA) and rujuwliyRapN↓ (IAar, S, K) and rajuwliyRapN↓ (Ks, T, K) and rujoliyRapN↓; (K) of the class of inf. ns. that have no verbs belonging to them. (ISd, TA.) ＝ -A2- And The having a complaint of the rijol [i. e. leg, or foot]. (TA.) ― -b2- And in a horse, (S,) or beast, (daAbRap, K,) A whiteness, (K,) or the having a whiteness, (S,) in one of the rijolaAni [i. e. hind legs or feet], (S, K,) without a whiteness in any other part; (TA;) as also tarujiylN↓ (K.) This is disliked, unless there be in him some other [similar] waDaH. (S.)

rijolapN c
rijolapN: see the next preceding paragraph, first sentence. ＝ -A2- [Also, accord. to the K, a pl. of raAjlN or of one of its syns.] ＝ -A3- And A herd, or detached number collected together, of wild animals. (IB, TA.) ＝ -A4- And A place in which grow [plants, or trees, of the kind called] Earofaj, (K,) accord. to Az, in which grow many thereof, (TA,) in one rawoDap [or meadow]. (K.) ― -b2- And A water-course, or channel in which water flows, (S, K,) from a [stony tract such as is called] HarRap to a soft, or plain, tract: (K:) pl. rijalN; (S, K;) a term similar to macaAnibu [pl. of miconabN]: so says Er-Rághib: the waters (he says) pour to it, and it retains them: and on one occasion he says, the rijolap is like the qariyR; it is wide, and people alight in it: he says also, it is a water-course of a plain, or soft, tract, such as is mlbAv, or, as in one copy, minobaAt [which is app. the right reading, meaning productive of much herbage]. (TA.) ＝ -A5- Alrijolapu also signifies A species of the [kind of plants called] HayoD. (K.) ― -b2- And, accord. to [some of] the copies of the K [in this place], The Earofaj; but correctly the farofax [as in the CK here, and in the K &c. in art. frfx]; (TA;) i. q. Albaqolapu AlHamuqaMCu; (S, Msb, TA;) thus the people commonly called it; i. e. AlbqlpAlHmqMC; (TA;) [all of these three appellations being applied to Purslane, or purslain; and generally to the garden purslane:] it is [said to be] called AlHmqMC because it grows not save in a water-course: (S: [i. e. the wild sort: but see art. Hmq:]) whence the saying, OaHomaqu mino rijolapK [explained in art. Hmq], (S, K,) meaning this baqolap: (TA:) the vulgar say, mino rijolihi. (S, K, TA. [In the CK, erroneously, mn rajolapK.])

rajulapN c
rajulapN: see rajulN in two places.

rajilapN c
rajilapN a quasi-pl. n. of rajulN q. v. (TA.) ＝ -A2- [Also fem. of the epithet rajilN.]

rjolay c
rjolay fem. of rajolaAnu: see raAjilN near the end of the paragraph. ― -b2- HarRapN rajolay and rajolaMCu↓ A [stony tract such as is called] HarRap that is rough [or rugged], in which one goes on foot: or level, but abounding with stones: (K:) or rough and difficult, in which one cannot go except on foot: (TA:) or the latter signifies level, but abounding with stones, in which it is difficult to go along: (S:) or hard and rough, which horses and camels cannot traverse, and none can but a man on foot: (AHeyth, TA:) or that impedes the feet by its difficulty. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ＝ -A2- rajolay is also a pl. of rajolaAnu: (S:) [and app. of rajiylN also.]

rajolaMCu c
rajolaMCu fem. of Oarojalu [q. v.]. ― -b2- See also the next preceding paragraph.

rajaliyRN c
rajaliyRN sing. of rajaliyRuwna, which latter is applied, with the article Al to Certain men who used to run (kaAnuwA yaEoduwna, so in the O and K, but in the T yagozuwna [which is evidently a mistranscription], TA) upon their feet; as also rujayolaMCu↓, in like manner with the article Al: (O, K, TA:) in the T, the sing. is written rajoliyRN; and said to be a rel. n. from AlrRujolapu; which requires consideration: (TA:) they were Suleyk El-Makánib, (O, K, TA,) i. e. Ibn-Sulakeh, (TA,) and El-Munteshir Ibn-Wahb El-Báhilee, and Owfà Ibn-Matar ElMázinee. (O, K, TA. [All these were famous runners.])

rujoliyRapN c
rujoliyRapN: see rujolapN.

rajolaAnu c
rajolaAnu; and its fem., rajolay: see raAjilN.

rujaAlN c
rujaAlN [a quasi-pl. n.]: see raAjilN.

rajiylN c
rajiylN: see raAjilN, in two places. ― -b2- Also i. q. maXRaMCN; and so raAjilN↓; (K;) i. e. (TA) [That walks, or goes on foot, much; or a good goer; or] strong to walk, or go, or go on foot; (S, in explanation of the latter, and TA;) applied to a man, (S, K, TA,) and to a camel, and an ass: (TA:) or the latter, a man that walks, or goes on foot, much and well: and strong to do so,. with patient endurance: and a beast, such as a horse or an ass or a mule, and a camel, that endures long journeying with patience: fem. with p: (T, TA:) or, applied to a horse, that does not become attenuated, or chafed, abraded, or worn, in the hoofs [by journeying]: (S, O:) or, so applied, that does not sweat: and rendered submissive, or manageable; broken, or trained: (K, * TA:) the fem., with p is also applied to a woman, as meaning strong to walk, or go on foot: (TA:) pl. rajolay [most probably of rajiylN, agreeably with analogy,] and rajaAlay. (K.) ― -b3- Also A place of which the two extremities are far apart: (M, K, * TA:) in the copies of the K, AlTRariyqayoni is here erroneously put for AlTRarafayoni: and the M adds, trodden, or rendered even, or easy to be travelled: (TA:) or rugged and hard land or ground: (O, TA:) and a hard place: and a rugged, difficult, road, in a mountain. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, applied to speech, i. q. murotajalN↓ [i. e. Extemporized; spoken extemporaneously, impromptu, or without premeditation]. (O, K, TA.)

rujayolN c
rujayolN dim. of rajulN, which see, in two places.

rujuwlapN c
rujuwlapN: see rujolapN.

rajuwliyRapN c
rajuwliyRapN: see rujolapN.

rujuwliyRapN c
rujuwliyRapN: see rujolapN.

rujayolaMCu c
rujayolaMCu: see rajaliyRN ― -b2- waladatohaA AlrRujayolaMCa They (sheep or goats) brought them forth [i. e. their young ones] one after another. (El-Umawee, T, S, O, K.)

rajRaAlN c
rajRaAlN i. q. raAjilN, q. v. (Az, TA.)

rajRaAlapN c
rajRaAlapN: quasi-pl. ns. of raAjilN, q. v.

rujRaAlay c
rujRaAlay: quasi-pl. ns. of raAjilN, q. v.

raAjilN c
raAjilN (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.) and rajulN↓, (Mgh, Msb, K,) the latter of the dial. of El-Hijáz, (MF,) in copies of the M written rajalN↓, (TA,) and rajilN↓ (S, K) and rajiylN↓ [afterwards mentioned as a quasi-pl. n.] (K) and rajolaAnu↓ (S, K) and rajolN↓, (K,) but this last is said by Sb to be a quasi-pl. n., (TA,) Going, or a goer, on foot; a pedestrian; a footman; the opposite of faArisN; (S, Msb;) one having no beast whereon to ride, (K, TA,) in a journey, and therefore going on his feet: (TA:) see also rajiylN: pl. rajRaAlapN↓, (Ks, T, S, M, Msb, K,) [or rather this is a quasi-pl. n.,] written by MF rijaAlapN, as on the authority of AHei, but the former is the right, (TA,) and rujRaAlN (Ks, T, S, M, Msb, K) and rajolN↓, (S, Msb, TA,) this last mentioned before as being said by Sb to be a quasi-pl. n., (TA,) like SaHobN (S, Msb, TA) and rakobN, and occurring in the Kur xvii. 66, (TA,) all of raAjilN, (S, Msb,) and rijaAlN, (S, M, K,) of rajolaAnu (S) and of raAjilN, (TA,) [but more commonly of rajulN, q. v.,] and rajolay, (S, O, K,) of rajolaAnu, (S, O,) and rajaAlay, (S, M, K,) of rajilN, (S,) or of rajolaAnu, (TA,) and rujaAlay and rujolaAnN, (M, K,) which last is of raAjilN or of rajiylN, (TA,) and rijolapN [a pl. of pauc.], (M, K,) written by MF rajalapN, and if so, of raAjilN, like as katabapN is pl. of kaAtibN, (TA,) and rajolapN↓, (T, M, K,) [but this is a quasi-pl. n., mentioned before as of rajulN, q. v.,] and OarojilapN, (M, K,) which may be pl. of rijaAlN, which is pl. of raAjilN, (IJ,) and OaraAjilu, (M, K,) which may be pl. of the pl. OarojilapN, (IJ,) and OaraAjiylu, (M, K,) and to the foregoing pls. mentioned in the K are to be added (TA) rijalapN, (Ks, M, TA) which is of rajulN, (TA,) and rujRalN, like sukRarN, (AHei, TA,) and [the quasi-pl. ns.] rujRaAlay↓, (Ks, T, M, AHei, TA,) termed by MF an anomalous pl., (TA,) and rujaAlN↓, (AHei, TA,) said by MF to be extr., of the class of ruxaAlN, (TA,) and rajiylN↓, (AHei, TA,) said to be a quasi-pl. n. like maEiyzN and kaliybN. (TA.) Az says, I have heard some of them say rajRaAlN↓ as meaning raAjilN; and its pl. is rajaAjiylu. (TA.) And raAjilapN and rajilapN↓ are applied in the same sense to a woman, (Lth, TA,) and so is rajolay↓ [fem. of rajolaAnu, like gaDobay fem. of gaDobaAnu]: (S:) and the pl. [of the first] is rawaAjilu (TA) and ([of the first or second or] of the third, S) rijaAlN (Lth, S, TA) and rajaAlay. (S.) ― -b2- Lh mentions the saying, laA tafoEalo kacaA OumRuka raAjilN, but does not explain it: it seems to mean [Do not thus:] may thy mother mourn, and be bereft of thee. (TA.) ＝ -A2-
naAqapN raAjilN EalaI waladihaA means A she-camel [left to give suck to her young one,] not having her udder bound with the SiraAr [q. v.]. (K.)

raAjilapN c
raAjilapN The pastor's kaboX [or ram] upon which he conveys, or puts to be borne, his utensils. (AA, O, K.) So in the saying of a poet,
faZalRa yaEomitu fiI qawoTK waraAjilapK
yukafRitu AldRahora UilRaA rayova yahotabidu
(AA, TA,) meaning [And he passed the day] spinning from a portion of wool [wound in the form of a ring upon his hand], termed Eamiytah, [amid a flock of sheep, with a ram upon which he conveyed his utensils,] ever collecting [to himself], and coveting, or labouring to acquire, save when he was sitting cooking habiyd [i. e. colocynths or their seeds or pulp]. (T and TA in art. Emt: where rAjlp is likewise explained as above.)

ruwayojilN c
ruwayojilN: see rajulN, in two places.

Oarojalu c
Oarojalu A man large in the rijol [i. e. leg, or foot]: (S, K:) like Oarokabu “ large in the knee, ” and OaroOasu “ large in the head. ” (TA.) ― -b2- And A horse, (S,) or beast, (daAbRap, K,) having a whiteness in one of his rijolaAni [i. e. hind legs or feet], (S, K,) without a whiteness in any other part. (TA.) This is disliked, unless there be in him some other [similar] waDaH. (S. [See also 2 in art. xdm.]) The fem. is rajolaMCu, (S, K,) which is applied in like manner to a sheep or goat: (S:) or to a ewe as meaning whose rijolaAni [or hind legs] are white to the flanks, (M, TA,) or with the flanks, (T, TA,) the rest of her being black. (TA.) ― -b3- HarRapN rajolaMCu: see rajolaI. ＝ -A2- huwa Oarojalu AlrRajulayoni means [He is the more manly, or manful, of the two men; or] he has rujoliyRap that is not in the other [of the two men]: (T, TA:) or he is the stronger of the two men. (K.) ISd thinks Arjl in this case to be like OaHonaku, as having no verb. (TA.)

OaraAjiylu c
OaraAjiylu app. a pl. of OarojilapN, which may be pl. of rijaAlN, which is pl. of raAjilN [q. v.] (TA.) ― -b2- Also Men accustomed to, or in the habit of, taking, capturing, catching, snaring, or trapping, game or wild animals or the like, or birds, or fish; hunters, fowlers, or fishermen. (Sgh, K.)

tarojiylN c
tarojiylN: see rujolapN, last signification.

taraAjiylu c
taraAjiylu i. q. karafosN [q. v., i. e. The herb smallage]; (K;) of the dial. of the Sawád; one of the herbs, or leguminous plants, of the gardens. (TA.).

marojalN c
marojalN: see rajulN, of which it is a quasi-pl. n.: ＝ -A2- and mirojalN.

murjilN c
murjilN A woman that brings forth men-children; (M, TA;) i. q. mucokirN, (M, K, TA,) which is the epithet commonly known. (M, TA.)

mirojalN c
mirojalN A copper cooking-pot: (S, Mgh, Msb:) or a large copper cooking-pot: (Ham p. 469:) or a cooking-pot of stones [or stone], and of copper: (K:) or any cooking-pot (Mgh, Msb, TA, and Ham ubi suprà) or vessel in which one cooks: (TA:) of the masc. gender: (K:) pl. maraAjilu. (Ham ubi suprà.) ― -b2- And A comb. (Mgh, K.) ― -b3- Also, and marojalN↓, (K,) the latter on the authority of IAar alone, (TA,) A sort of [garment of the kind called] burod, of the fabric of El-Yemen: (K:) pl. as above, maraAjilu; with which maraAHil, occurring in a trad., is said in the T, in art. rHl, to be syn.: [and burodN mirojaliIRN↓ signifies the same as mirojalN:] it is said in a prov.,
HadiyvFA kaAna buroduka mirojaliyRaA
[Recently thy burod was of the sort called mirojaliIR;] i. e. thou hast only recently been clad with the maraAjil, and usedst to wear the EabaMC: [whence it appears that the mirojal may be thus called because worn only by full-grown men:] so says IAar: it is said in the M that vawobN mirojaliIRN is from Almmrjl [i. e. Almumarojalu, perhaps a mistranscription for Almarojalu]: (TA:) [but] mumarojalN↓ signifies a sort of garments, or cloths, variegated, or figured; (S and K in art. mrjl;) similar to the maraAjil, or similar to these in their variegation or decoration, or their figured forms; as explained by Seer and others; (TA in that art.;) [wherefore] Sb holds the m of maraAjilu to be an essential part of the word; (S in that art.;) and hence Seer and the generality of authors also say that it is a radical, though Abu-l-'Alà and some others hold it to be augmentative. (MF and TA in that art.)

mirojaliIRN c
mirojaliIRN A maker of cooking-pots [such as are called maraAjila, pl. of mirojalN]. (MA.) ― -b2- See also the next preceding paragraph.

marojalaAniyRapN c
marojalaAniyRapN A woman who is, or affects to be, or makes herself, like a man in guise or in speech. (TA. [See also rajulapN, voce rajulN.])

murajRalN c
murajRalN A skin, (Fr, TA,) or such as is termed a ziqR, (K,) that is stripped off [by beginning] from one riajol [or hind leg]; (Fr, K, TA;) or from the part where is the rijol (M, TA.) And XaApN murajRalapN A sheep, or goat, skinned [by beginning] from one rijol: (Ham p. 667:) and in like manner marojuwlN↓ applied to a ram. (Lh, K voce mazoquwqN, which signifies the contr. [like muzaqRaqN].) ― -b2- Also A [skin such as is termed] ziqR full of wine. (As, O, K.) ＝ -A2- A [garment of the kind called] burod upon which are the figures of men; (K;) or upon which are the figures of of men. (TA.) ― -b2- And A garment, or piece of cloth, (O, TA,) and a burod, (TA,) ornamented in the borders. (O, K, TA.) ＝ -A3- Combed hair. (O, TA. [See its verb, 2.]) ＝ -A4- jaraAdN murajRalN Locusts the traces of whose wings are seen upon the ground. (ISd, K.)

marojuwlN c
marojuwlN A gazelle whose rijol [or hind leg] has fallen [and is caught] in the snare: when his yad [or fore leg] has fallen therein, he is said to be mayodiIRN. (TA.) ― -b2- See also the next preceding paragraph.

murotajalN c
murotajalN: see rajiylN, last sentence.

murotajilN c
murotajilN A man holding the zanod with his hands and feet, (K, TA,) because he is alone: (TA:) [i. e.] one who, in producing fire with the zanod, holds the lower zanodap with his foot [or feet]. (AA, TA. [See 5.]) ＝ -A2- One who collects a detached number (qiToEap [or rijol]) of locusts, to roast, or fry, them: (S:) one who lights upon a rijol of locusts, and roasts, or fries, some of them, (K, TA,) or, as in the M, cooks. (TA.)

mumarojalN c
mumarojalN: see mirojalN.

1 rajomN c
1. rajomN signifies The throwing, or casting, of stones: (S, K:) this is its primary meaning: (S, TA:) you say, rajamahu, aor.
rajuma
, inf. n. rajomN, (S, Msb, TA,) He threw, or cast, stones at him; or pelted him with stones: (S, TA:) or he struck him, or smote him, with rajam, meaning stones: (Msb:) and rujuwmN is syn. with rajomN, as an inf. n.: thus some explain the saying, in the Kur [lxvii. 5], wajoEalonaAhaA rujuwmFA lilXRayaATiyni [And we have made them for casting at the devils; meaning shooting stars, which are believed to be hurled at the devils that listen by stealth, beneath the lowest heaven, to the words of the angels therein: but see other explanations below, voce rajomN]. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (S, TA,) The act of slaying [in any manner, but generally stoning, i. e. putting to death by stoning]. (S, K.) So in rajomu AlvRayRibayoni UicaA zanayaA [The slaying, or stoning, of the two married persons when they have committed adultery]. (TA.) ― -b3- [(assumed tropical:) The act of beating, or battering, the ground with the feet.] One says of a camel, yarojumu AlOaroDa (assumed tropical:) [He beats, or batters, the ground], i. e., with his feet; which implies commendation: (TA:) and so one says of a horse; (K;) or yurojumu fiI AlOaroDi. (S.) And one says also, jaMCa yarojumu, meaning (assumed tropical:) [He came beating, or battering, the ground; or] passing along with an ardent and a rapid running. (Lh, K, * TA.) [See also 8.] ― -b4- (tropical:) The act of cursing. (K, TA.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) The act of reviling. (K, TA.) laOarojumanRaka, in the Kur xix. 47, means (assumed tropical:) I will assuredly revile thee: (Bd, Jel, TA: see also another explanation below, in this paragraph:) or I will assuredly cast stones at thee, (Bd, Jel,) so that thou shalt die, or shalt remove far from me. (Bd.) And you say, rajamotuhu biAlqawoli, meaning (assumed tropical:) I uttered foul, or evil, speech against him. (Msb.) [See also rajabahu.] ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) The act of driving away; expelling; putting, or placing, at a distance, away, or far away. (K.) ― -b7- (assumed tropical:) The act of cutting off from friendly, or loving communion or intercourse; forsaking; or abandoning. (K.) ― -b8- Also [as being likened to the throwing of stones, in doing which one is not sure of hitting the mark,] i. q. qacofN (K, TA) biAlgayobi (assumed tropical:) [The act of speaking of that which is hidden, or which has not become apparent to the speaker;
and conjecturing]; (TA;) or speaking conjecturally: (S, TA:) and (K, TA) some say (TA) i. q. gayobN [as meaning (assumed tropical:) a doubting]: (K, TA: [in the CK, AlEayobu is erroneously put for Algayobu:] and ZanRN [which means (assumed tropical:) an opining, or a conjecturing]. (K, TA.) One says, rajama biAlgayobi (assumed tropical:) He spoke of that which he did not know. (Ham p. 494.) And rajama biAlZRanRi (Z, TA) (assumed tropical:) He spoke conjecturally: (MA:) or he conjectured, or opined. (Bd in xviii. 21.) Hence, qaAlahu rajomFA (assumed tropical:) He said it conjecturally. (Z, TA.) Hence also, (TA,) rajomFA baAlgayobi, in the Kur [xviii. 21], (S, TA,) (assumed tropical:) [Speaking conjecturally of that which is hidden, or unknown; as indicated in the S and TA: or] conjecturing in a case hidden from them. (Jel.) One says also, qaAla rajomFA biAlgayobi, i. e. (assumed tropical:) He said conjecturally, [or speaking of that which was hidden from him, or unknown by him,] without evidence, and without proof. (Msb.) And SaAra rajomFA laA yuwqafu EalaI Haqiyqapi Oamorihi (assumed tropical:) [It became a subject of conjecture, the real state of the case whereof one was not to be made to know]. (S, TA.) And laOarojumanRaka, in the Kur [xix. 47, of which two explanations have been mentioned above], means [accord. to some] I will assuredly say of thee, [though] speaking of that which is hidden [from me], or unknown [by me], what thou dislikest, or hatest. (TA.) ― -b9- lisaAnN yurojumu [if the latter word be not a mistranscription for mirojamN↓, q. v.,] means A tongue that is chaste, or perspicuous, and copious, in speech. (Msb in art. trjm.) ― -b10- See also the next paragraph, in three places.

2 rjRm Alqabora c
2. rjRm Alqabora, inf. n. tarojiymN, He placed upon the grave rujam [meaning large stones, to make a gibbous covering to it]. (TA.) It is related in a trad. of 'Abd-Allah Ibn-Mughaffal, that he said, laA turajRimuwA qaboriI, i. e. Place not ye upon my grave rujam; meaning thereby that they should make his grave even with the ground, not gibbous and elevated: the verb is thus correctly, with tesh-deed: but the relaters of trads. say, lA tarojumuwA↓ qbrI: (S:) [and it is said that] Alqabora rajama↓, (K, TA,) aor.
rajuma
, inf. n. rajomN, (TA,) signifies EalRamahu, (K,) i. e. He put a tombstone to the grave: (TK:) or he placed upon the grave rijaAm [a pl., like rujam, of rujomap]: (K:) or, accord. to Aboo-Bekr, laA qaboriI tarojumuwA↓ means Wail not ye at my grave; i. e. say not, at it, what is unseemly; from AlrRajomu signifying “ the act of reviling. ” (TA.)

3 muraAjamapN c
3. muraAjamapN [in its primary acceptation] is The mutual throwing, or casting, of stones; or the vying, or contending for superiority, in the throwing, or casting, of stones. (Mgh. [See also 6.]) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) The act of mutually reviling; or the vying in reviling; or so muraAjamapN biAlkalaAmi. (TA. [See, again, 6.]) ― -b3- And raAjm fiI AlkalaAmi, and AlEadowi, and AlHarobi, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) (tropical:) He exerted himself to the utmost in vying, or contending for superiority, in speech, and in running, and in war, or battle. (K, TA.) ― -b4- And rAjm Eanohu, (K,) or Eano qawomihi, (S,) (tropical:) He defended him, or his people; or spoke, or pleaded, or contended, in defence of him, or of them: (S, K, TA:) and so daAraI. (TA.)

6 trAjmwA baAlHijaArapi c
6. trAjmwA baAlHijaArapi They threw, or cast, stones, one at another; or vied, or contended for superiority, in throwing, or casting, stones, one at another: (S, TA:) and ArtjmwA↓ signifies the like of this. (IAar, TA. [See also 3.]) ― -b2- [Hence,] trAjmt AlUibilu: see 8. ― -b3- And trAjmwA biAlkalaAmi (tropical:) They reviled one another; or vied in reviling one another. (TA. [See, again, 3.])

8 Uirotajama
8: see 6. ― -b2- [Hence,] Artjmt AlUibilu, and trAjmt↓, (assumed tropical:) The camels beat [or battered] the ground (rajamati AlOaroDa) with their feet: or went heavily, without slowness. (TA.) [See mirojamN: and see also 1, in two places.] ― -b3- And Artjm (assumed tropical:) It (a thing) lay one part upon another; was, or became, heaped, or piled, up, or together, or accumulated, one part upon, or overlying, another; (Aboo-Sa'eed, K, TA;) as also Artjn. (Aboo-Sa'eed, TA.)

10 jaMCato tasotarojimu AlnRabiIRa c
10. jaMCato tasotarojimu AlnRabiIRa, said of a woman [who had committed adultery], means She came asking the Prophet for AlrRajom [i. e. to be stoned.] (TA.)

Q. Q. 1 tarojama kalaAmahu c
Q. Q. 1. tarojama kalaAmahu He interpreted, or explained in another language, his speech. (S.) See art. trjm.

rajomN c
rajomN, an inf. n. [of 1, q. v.], used as an appellative, (Bd in lxvii. 5,) A thing that is thrown, or cast, like as is a stone: pl. rujuwmN. (Bd ib., and K.) Hence, in the Kur (ubi suprà), wajaEalonaAhaA rujuwmFA lilXRayaATiyni And we have made them things to be cast at the devils; meaning shooting stars: [see also rujumo:] or, as some say, we have made them to be [means of] conjectures to the devils of mankind; i. e., to the astrologers. (Bd, TA. [See another explanation in the first sentence of this art.]) ＝ -A2- Also A friend; or a true, or sincere, friend; or a special, or particular, friend; syn. xaliylN: and a cup-companion, or compotator. (Th, K.) See also the last signification in the next paragraph.

rajamN c
rajamN Stones (Msb, TA) that are placed upon a grave. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (Msb, TA,) A grave; (S, Msb, K, TA;) because stones are collected together upon it; (Msb;) as also rajomapN↓ and rujomapN↓: (K:) the pl. of rajamN is OarjaAmN: you say, hecihi OarojaAmu EaAdK These are the graves of [the tribe of] 'Ád: (TA:) and rujomapN↓, of which the pl. is rujamN and rijaAmN, signifies also, like as does rujumN↓, stones, (K,) or high stones, (TA,) that are set up upon a grave: (K, TA:) or both these signify a sign [that is set up upon a grave; or a tombstone: see 2]: (K:) or the former of them (rujomapN) signifies stones collected together, (Lth, Msb, TA,) as though they were the graves of [the tribe of] 'Ád; (Lth, TA;) and its pl. is rijaAmN: (Msb:) or it is sing. of rujamN and rijaAmN which signify large stones, less then [such as are termed] riDaAm, (S,) or like riDaAm, (TA,) sometimes collected together upon a grave to form a gibbous covering to it. (S.) ― -b3- Also (i. e. rajamN) A well. (K.) ― -b4- And A [kind of oven such as is called] tanRuwr [q. v.]. (K.) ― -b5- And i. q. juforapN, with jym, accord. to the K, i. e. A round space in the ground: or, as in other lexicons, HuforapN [meaning a hollow, or cavity, in the ground, made by digging, or natural]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also Brothers, or brethren: [a quasipl. n.:] sing., accord. to Kr, rajomN↓ and rajamN; [so that the latter is used as a sing. and as a pl.;] but (ISd says, TA) I know not how this is. (K, TA.) [See also rajomN.]

rujumN c
rujumN The [shooting] stars that are cast [at the devils; like rujuwmN, as explained by some, pl. of rajomN, q. v.]. ― -b2- See also the second sentence of the next preceding paragraph.

rajomapN c
rajomapN: see rajamN, second sentence. ― -b2- [It is applied in the present day to Any heap of stones thrown together or piled up.] ― -b3- Also A [kind of turret, such as is called] manaArap, like a bayot [i. e. tent, or house, &c.], around which they used to circuit: a poet says,
kamaA TaAfa biAlrRajomapi Almurotajimo↓
[Like as when he who beat the ground circuited around the rjmp]. (TA.) ― -b4- rjmp [thus written, but perhaps it is rujomapN↓,] is also sing. of rijaAm signifying [Hills, or mountains, &c., such as are called] hiDaAb [pl. of haDobapN]. (AA, TA.)

rujomapN c
rujomapN: see rajamN, second sentence, in two places: ― -b2- and see also rajomapN. ― -b3- Also The hole, den, or subterranean habitation, of the hyena. (S, K.) ― -b4- And A thing by means of which a palm-tree that is held in high estimation is propped; (K;) also called rujobapN; i. e. a kind of wide bench of stone or brick (dukRaAnN) against which the palm-tree leans; as is said by Kr and AHn: the m is said to be a substitute for b; or, as ISd thinks, the word is a dial. var., like rujobapN. (TA.)

rijaAmN c
rijaAmN i. q. mirojaAsN; (S, K;) i. e. A stone which is tied to the end of a rope, and which is then let down into a well, and stirs up its black mud, after which the water is drawn forth, and thus the well is cleansed: (TA:) sometimes it is tied to the extremity of the cross piece of wood of the bucket, in order that it may descend more quickly. (S, K.) ― -b2- Also A thing that is constructed over a well, and across which is then placed the piece of wood for the bucket. (AA, K.) And [the dual] rijaAmaAni Two pieces of wood that are set up over a well, (S, K, TA,) at its head [or mouth], (S, TA,) and upon which is set the pulley, (S, K, TA,) or some similar thing by means of which one draws the water. (TA.) ― -b3- Also a pl. of rujomapN. (S, Msb, K.)

rajuwmN c
rajuwmN: see the next paragraph.

rajiymN c
rajiymN and marojuwmN↓ Thrown at, or cast at, with stones. (S.) The former is said to be applied to the devil because he is cast at (mrjwm) with [shooting] stars. (TA.) [In the MA, rajuwmN↓, as well as rajiymN, is explained as signifying Stoned: but it is probably a mistranscription for marojuwmN.]
― -b2- Slain [in any manner, but generally meaning put to death by being stoned]. (S.) latakuwnanRa mina Almarojuwmiyna, in the Kur [xxvi. 116], is explained as meaning Thou shalt assuredly be of those slain in the most evil manner of slaughter: (TA:) or the meaning is, of those smitten with stones: or, (assumed tropical:) reviled. (Bd, Jel.) ― -b3- Also the former, (tropical:) Cursed, or accursed; and in this sense, i. e. biAllRaEonapi marojuwmN↓, applied to the devil. (TA.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) Reviled; [and so marojuwmN↓, as shown above;] and in this sense, also, said to be applied to the devil: and so in the two senses here following. (TA.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) Driven away; expelled; put, or placed, at a distance, away, or far away. (TA.) ― -b6- And (assumed tropical:) Cut off from friendly or loving communion or intercourse; forsaken; or abandoned. (TA.)

rajiymapN c
rajiymapN sing. of rajaAYimu, which signifies Mountains at which stones are cast [app. from some superstitious motive, as is done by Arabs in the present day]. (TA.)

tarojamapN rjm trjm trjmh trjmp
tarojamapN; pl. taraAjimu: see art. trjm.

tarojumaAnN rjm trjmAn
tarojumaAnN and turojumaAnN and tarojamaAnN; pl. taraAjimu and taraAjimapN: see art. trjm.

mirojamN c
mirojamN (tropical:) A horse that beats [or batters] the ground (yurojumu fiI AlOaroDi, S, or yarojumu AlOaroDa, K) with his hoofs: (S, K:) or that is as though he did thus: (TA:) or that runs vehemently: (Ham p. 158:) applied also in the first sense to a camel; implying commendation: or, as some say, heavy, without slowness. (TA.) And (tropical:) A strong man: as though his enemy were cast at with him: (S, K:) or a defender of his jinos [i. e. hind, or kindred by the father's side]. (A, TA.) IAar says, A man pushed another man, whereupon he [the latter] said, latajidanRiI caA manokibK mirojamK warukonK midoEamK (assumed tropical:) [Thou shalt assuredly find me to be one having a strong shoulder-joint and a stay that is a means of support]. (TA: but there written without any syll. signs.) lisaAnN mirojamN means (assumed tropical:) A tongue copious in speech; or chaste, or perspicuous, therein; or eloquent: and strong, or potent. (TA. See also 1, last sentence but one.)

mirojamapN c
mirojamapN i. q. qacRaAfapN [or qucRaAfapN, which means A sling; and mirojaAmN, q. v., app. signifies the same]: pl. maraAjimu. (TA.)

murajRamN c
murajRamN A narrative, or story, of which one is not to be made to know the real state: (S, K, TA:) or, as in some of the copies of the S, of which one knows not, or will not know, whether it be true or false: (TA:) or respecting which conjectures are formed. (Ham p. 494.)

mirojaAmN c
mirojaAmN [app. A sling; like mirojamapN;] a thing with which stones are cast; (K, TA;) i. q. qacRaAfN [q. v.]: pl. maraAjiymu. (TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) A camel that stretches out his neck in going along: or that goes strongly, or vehemently; (K, TA;) as though beating the pebbles (kaOanRahu yurojumu AlHaSaI) with his feet. (TA.)

marojuwmN c
marojuwmN: see rajiymN, in three places.

maraAjimu c
maraAjimu pl. of mirojamapN [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Foul words: (M, K: *) a pl. of which no sing. is mentioned. (TA.)

muraAjimN c
muraAjimN One casting [stones] at thee, thou casting at him. (Har p. 567.)

murotajimN c
murotajimN: see rajomapN.

mutarojimN c
mutarojimN: see art. trjm.

1 rajana biAlmakaAni c
1. rajana biAlmakaAni, (S, K,) aor.
rajuna
, (S,) inf. n. rujuwnN, He remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in the place; (S, K;) as also Artjn↓; (K, * TK;) and kept to it, or became accustomed to it; (S, accord. to one copy;) and so dajana bihi. (S, * Msb, * K, * TA: all in art. djn.) ― -b2- And rajanato, (Fr, S, K,) aor.
rajuna
; (TA;) and rajinato, (Fr, S, K,) aor.
rajana
; (TA;) and rajunato; (K;) said of camels, (Fr, S, K,) &c.; (K;) They kept, or became accustomed, to the tents, or houses: (K, * TA:) and Arjnt↓ said of a she-camel, she remained in [or at] the house, or tent. (TA.) ― -b3- And rajanati AldRaAbRapu, (S, K,) aor.
rajuna
, (TA,) inf. n. rujuwnN, The beast was confined, kept close, or shut up, and badly fed, (S, K,) so that it became lean: (S:) or was confined to the fodder in the dwelling, or place of abode. (K.) ― -b4- And rajana fiI AlTRaEaAmi, (Lh, TA,) aor.
rajuna
, inf. n. rujuwnN, (L and TA in art. rmk,) [app. He kept constantly to the food;] he loathed nothing of the food; and so ramaka: and in like manner one says of the camel, rajana fiI AlEalafi [he kept constantly to the fodder; or loathed nothing thereof]. (Lh, TA.) ― -b5- And rujuwnN and rujuwnapN [inf. ns. of which the verb is not mentioned] A camel's feeding upon date-stones, and seeds, or grain. (TA.) ＝ -A2- rajana AlOibila, and ArjnhA↓, He confined the camels to feed them with fodder, not pasturing them, or not sending or driving or conducting them forth in the morning to the pasturage. (Fr, S.) And rajana raAHilatahu rajonFA XadiydFA He confined his riding-camel strictly in the house, making her to lie down upon her breast, and not feeding her with fodder. (ISh, TA.) And rajana daAbRatahu, (S, K,) inf. n. rajonN, (S,) He confined, kept close, or shut up, his beast, and fed it badly, (S, K,) so that it became lean: (S:) or confined his beast to the fodder in the dwelling, or place of abode; as also rjRnhA↓: (K:) or, accord. to J, [perhaps a mistake for Az, for it is not in either of my copies of the S,] on the authority of Fr, the former signifies he confined the beast from the pasturage, without fodder: and ↓the latter, inf. n. tarojiynN, he confined, or restricted, the beast to fodder. (TA.) ＝ -A3- rajana fulaAnFA He was ashamed for himself, or of himself, or was bashful, or shy, with respect to such a one; he was abashed at him, or shy of him; or he shrank from him. (AZ, K.)

2 rajRana
2: see 1, latter part, in two places.

4 Oarojana
4: as intrans. and trans.: see 1, in two places.

8 Artjn c
8. Artjn: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- Also It was, or became, heaped, or piled, up, or together, or accumulated, one part upon another; syn. Airotakama, (K,) and Airotajama. (Aboo-Sa'eed, TA in art. rjm.) ― -b3- And, said of fresh butter, It was cooked [for the purpose of clarifying it] without its becoming clear, and became bad, or spoiled: (S, K, TA:) or it turned in the skin containing the churned milk: (TA:) or it became bad, or spoiled, in the churning: (TA in art. xlT:) from AirotijaAnu AlUicowaAbapi meaning the fresh butter's coming forth from the skin mixed with the thick milk, and being in that state put upon the fire, so that, when it boils, the thick milk appears mixed with the clarified butter. (TA.) Airotajanati AlzRubodapu, meaning The piece of fresh butter became mixed up with the milk, is a prov., alluding to a difficult affair which one cannot find the way to adjust. (L in art. zbd.) ― -b4- Hence, (TA,) Artjn EalaI Alqawomi Oamoruhumo (assumed tropical:) The affair, or case, of the people, or party, became confused to them. (S, K. *)

raAjinN c
raAjinN That keeps to the tents, or houses; domesticated, familiar, or tame; (S, TA;) like daAjinN: (S:) applied in this sense to a bird: (TA:) and in like manner raAjinapN applied to camels: (S, * TA:) and to a sheep or goat (XaAp), and a she-camel, that remains in [or at] the houses, or tents. (TA.) ― -b2- And XaApN raAjinN A sheep, or goat, confined, shut up, or kept close, and badly fed, so that it becomes lean. (S.)

1 rajawotuhu c
1. rajawotuhu, aor. Oarojuwhu, (S, Msb,) inf. n. rajowN, (S, M, K,) or rujuwRN, (Msb,) and rajaMCN, (S, K, TA, &c., [in the CK erroneously written with the short A i. e., without the meddeh and C,]) or the latter is a simple subst., (Msb,) and rajaAwapN (S, K) and rajaApN, or rajaMCapN, (accord. to different copies of the K,) or both, (CK,) and marojaApN; (K;) and rajRayotuhu↓, (S,) inf. n. tarojiyapN; (K;) and tarajRayotuhu↓, (S, K, *) and Airotajayotuhu↓; (S, Msb, K; *) I hoped for him [or it; relating only to what is possible; syn. with Oamalotuhu; see rajaMCN, below]; all signify the same: (S:) and rajayotuhu, aor. Oarojiyhi, is a dial. var. of rajawotuhu: (Msb:) and rajiyahu, aor. yarojaAhu, like raDiyahu, is a dial. var. of rajaAhu, aor. yarojuwhu, accord. to Lth: it is disapproved by Az, because heard by him on no other authority than that of Lth; but it is mentioned also by ISd. (TA.) One says, maA Oatayotuka UilRaA rajaAwapa Alxayori [I did not, or have not, come to thee except hoping for that which is good]. (S.) No regard is to be paid to the assertion of Lth, that the saying faEalotu rajaApa kacaA [I did a thing hoping for such a thing] is a mistake, and that the correct word is only rajaMCa; for rajaApN occurs in a trad., and in the poetry of the Arabs. (TA.) ― -b2- Sometimes rajowN, (S,) or rujuwRN, (Msb,) has the meaning of xawofN; (S, Msb;) because the hoper fears that he may not attain the thing for which he hopes; (Msb;) and so rajaMCN; (T, S;) but only when there is with it a negative particle: (Fr, T, TA:) you say, maA rajawotuka (assumed tropical:) I feared not
thee: but you do not say, rajawotuka, meaning I feared thee: (TA:) the saying in the Kur [lxxi. 12], maA lakumo laA tarojuwna lilRehi waqaArFA means (assumed tropical:) [What aileth you] that ye will not fear the greatness, or majesty, of God? (S:) or the meaning is, that ye will not hope for God's magnifying of him who serves Him and obeys Him? or that ye will not believe in greatness, or majesty, belonging to God, so that ye may fear disobeying Him? (Bd:) another instance occurs in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb, cited in art. xlf, conj. 3: (S:) and ArtjAhu↓, also, signifies (tropical:) he feared him, or it; [but app. only when preceded by a negative particle, as in exs. cited in the TA;] (K, TA;) in which sense it is tropical. (TA.) Accord. to Lth, rajowN is also syn. with mubaAlaApN; and maA Oarojuw means maA OubaAliI [I do not care, mind, or heed]: but this is disapproved by Az. (TA.) ＝ -A2- rajiIa He broke off, or ceased, [app. by reason of inability,] from speaking: (K:) or, accord. to Az, he became confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course: or, as Fr says, he desired to speak, and was unable to do so: (TA:) and rujiIa Ealayohi, like EuniIa, he became unable to speak. (K.)

2 rajRawa
2: see 1, first sentence.

4 Oarojato c
4. Oarojato She (a camel, S, or a pregnant female [of any kind], TA) was, or became, near to bringing forth; (S, K, TA;) so that her bringing forth was hoped for: accord. to Er-Rághib, the proper signification is she made her owner to have hope in himself that her bringing forth was near: (TA:) and OarojaOato means the same. (S.) ― -b2- ArjI AlSRayoda He failed of getting any game; (K;) [as though he made the game to have hope;] and ArjOhu signifies the same: (TA:) or so ArjI [alone], and ArjO [alone]. (K and TA in art. rjO.) ＝ -A2- And Oarojayotuhu, (S, Msb,) inf. n. UirojaMCN, (K,) I postponed it, put it off, deferred it, or delayed it; (S, Msb, K; *) namely, an affair [&c.]; (S;) as also ArjOthu. (S, Msb.) [See the latter verb: and see also an ex. in the Kur vii. 108 and xxvi. 35; and the various readings mentioned by Bd in the former instance.] ＝ -A3- ArjI AlbiYora He made a side (rajFA) to the well. (S, K.)

5 tarajRawa
5: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- [In the present day, trjRI is often used as meaning He besought, entreated, petitioned, or prayed.]

8 Uirotajawa
8: see 1, first sentence: ― -b2- and again in the latter part of the paragraph.

rajFA c
rajFA The side, (K,) in a general sense: (TA:) or the side of a well, (S, Msb, K,) and of the sky, (Er-Rághib, TA,) and of anything; (S, Msb; *) and rajaMCN↓ signifies the same: (K:) the side of a well from its top to its bottom; (TA;) and the two sides thereof: which last is also [or properly] the meaning of the dual; which is rajawaAni: (S:) pl. OarojaMCN. (S, Msb, K.) Hence, in the Kur [lxix. 17], waQlomalaku EalaI OarojaAYihaA [The angels being at the sides thereof]. (S, TA.) They said, rumiIa bihi AlrRajawaAni, meaning (assumed tropical:) He was cast into places of destruction: (S:) or it is said of one who is held in mean estimation: (M, TA:) AisotihozaMCN in the K is a mistake for Ausotuhiyna bihi, the reading in the M: (TA:) as though the two [opposite] sides of the well were cast at with him. (K.) And one says of him who will not be deceived so as to be turned away from one course to another, laA turomaI bihi AlrRajawaAni (assumed tropical:) [lit. The two sides of the well will not be cast at with him]; in allusion to the well's two [opposite] sides' being cast at with the bucket. (Z, TA.)

rajaMCN c
rajaMCN [accord. to most an inf. n., (see 1, in two senses,) but accord. to the Msb a simple subst.,] Hope; syn. OamalN; (S and M and K in art Aml;) contr. of yaOosN; (K;) an opinion requiring the happening of an event in which will be a cause of happiness; (Er-Rághib, TA;) expectation of deriving advantage from an event of which a cause has already occurred: (El-Harállee, TA:) or, as Ibn-El-Kemál says, properly, i. q. OamalN: and conventionally, the clinging of the heart to the happening of a future loved event: (TA:) or hope, or eager desire, for a thing that may possibly happen; differing from tamanRK, which relates to what is possible and to what is impossible. (MF, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also rajFA.

rajiyRapN c
rajiyRapN [A thing hoped for]: you say, maAlaI fiI fulaAnK rajiyRapN There is nothing for me to hope for in such a one. (S.)

raAjK c
raAjK [Hoping: ― -b2- and Fearing]. (Msb.)

OurojiyRapN c
OurojiyRapN A thing postponed, put off, deferred, or delayed. (ISd, K.)

OurojuwaAnN c
OurojuwaAnN Redness: (Msb, K:) a certain red dye: (K:) or a certain dye, intensely red: (S:) accord. to A'Obeyd, (S,) what is called naXaAsotaj; (S, K;) and he says that the bahoramaAn is inferior to it (duwnahu [but this often has the contr. meaning]): it is said also that ArjwAn is an arabicized word, from the Pers. OarogawaAn, which means a sort of trees having a red blossom, of the most beautiful kind; and that every colour resembling it is termed ArjwAn. (S.) Also Red: (K:) and red garments or clothes. (IAar, K.) And one says OaHomaru OurojuwaAnN, mentioned by Seer has having an intensive meaning; (M, TA;) in the K, OaHomaru OurojuwaAniIRN↓; but this is wrong; (TA;) i. e. Intensely red. (K, TA.) And qaTiyfapN HamoraMCu OurojuwaAnN [A villous, or nappy, outer, or wrapping, garment, intensely red]: (S, M, A:) but IAth says that the most common practice is to prefix the word vawob or qaTiyfap to OurojuwaAn so as to govern the latter in the gen. case; [saying vawobu OurojuwaAnK or qaTiyfapu OurojuwaAnK;] and that the word [ArjwAn] is said by some to be Arabic, the A and n being augmentative. (TA.)

OurojuwaAniIRN c
OurojuwaAniIRN: see the next preceding paragraph.

murojFI c
[murojFI Postponed, put off, deferred, or delayed; as also murojaON.] Some read [in the Kur ix. 107] waMxaruwna murojawona liOamori QllRehi. (S: see mrjO, in art. rjO.)

murojK c
[murojK and murojiyapN and] murojiICN and murojiCapN A female near to bringing forth. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A2- murojK also signifies A man who is one of the people [or sect] called the murojiyap; (S;) or one of the murojiYap, mentioned in art. rjO; as also murojiICN; and so murojiIRN↓; (K;) or this is [properly speaking] a rel. n. from murojK; (S;) and murojiYiIRN also; (K;) or rather this is another rel. n., like murojiIRN. (IB and TA in art. rjO, q. v.)

murojiI c
murojiI: see what next precedes. You say rajulN murojiIRN [A man of, or belonging to, the sect called the murojiyap]. (S.)

1 rajayotuhu c
1. rajayotuhu: see 1 (first sentence) in art. rjw.

1 raHRa c
1. raHRa [sec. pers. raHiHota,] aor. yaraHRu, [inf. n., app., raHaHN,] It (a solid hoof, &c.,) had the quality termed raHaHN meaning as expl. below. (TA.)

R. Q. 1 raHoraHa c
R. Q. 1. raHoraHa He (a man, TA) did not exceed the usual bounds so as to reach the bottom, or utmost depth, of the object of his desire; (K, TA;) as, for instance, of a vessel: (TA:) [IbrD thinks that it signifies he sought, by his speech, the expression of a meaning which he failed to attain.] ― -b2- rHrH biAlkalaAmi He spoke, or expressed himself, obliquely, ambiguously, or equivocally; not plainly. (K, TA.) ― -b3- rHrH Eino fulaAnK i. q. sataraduwnahu [He protected such a one by intervening, or by interposing something]. (K.)

R. Q. 2 taraHoraHato c
R. Q. 2. taraHoraHato She (a mare) straddled, in order to stale. (S, A, K.)

raHRapN c
raHRapN [or HayRapN raHRapN] A serpent being, or becoming, like a Tawoq, or neck-ring, (mutaTawRiqapN, K, [see 5 in art. Twq,]) when folding itself: (TA:) originally raHoyapN; (K;) the I being changed into H. (TA.)

raHaHN c
raHaHN Width in a solid hoof: such is approved; (S, K;) being the contr. of that which is termed muSoTarRN: but when it spreads out much, it is a fault: (S:) or a spreading therein: (A:) or a spreading thereof; and width of a human foot: (Lth, TA:) or a spreading of a solid hoof, with thinness: or width of a human foot, with thinness: and in a solid hoof, which is a fault: or excessive width in a solid hoof. (TA.)

raHoraHN c
raHoraHN and raHoraAHN↓ and raHoraHaAnN↓ A thing wide and spreading, (K, TA,) not deep, like a Tsot and any similar vessel; as also rahorahN and rahorahaAnN: (TA:) [or ↓the third of these epithets signifies very wide &c.; as will be seen from what follows: and] ↓the second signifies a thing wide and thin. (S.) You say UinaMCN raHoraHN A wide and low vessel; as also rahorahN. (TA.) And qadaHN raHoraHN and raHoraAHN↓ A wide bowl. (A.) And qaSoEapN raHoraHN and raHoraHaAniyRapN↓ A bowl spreading widely [and very widely]. (AA, TA.) And it is said in a trad., buHobuwHupu AljanRapi raHoraHaAniyRapN↓ The middle of Paradise is [very] wide,
or ample: the A and n are added to give intensiveness to the signification. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] EayoXN raHoraHN (A) and raHoraAHN↓ (S, A) (tropical:) An ample and easy state of life. (S, TA.)

raHoraHaAnN c
raHoraHaAnN: see the next preceding paragraph, throughout.

raHoraHaAniyRapN c
raHoraHaAniyRapN: see the next preceding paragraph, throughout.

raHoraAHN c
raHoraAHN: see the next preceding paragraph, throughout.

OaraHRu c
OaraHRu Spreading, (Lth, TA,) or widely expanded; (TA;) applied to a solid hoof, (Lth, TA,) and to a foot such as is termed xufR: (TA:) and wide; applied to anything: thus qadamN raHRaMCu a wide human foot: (Lth, TA:) and a human foot having the middle of the sole even with the fore part; (L, TA;) flat-soled; i. e. having, in the sole, no hollow part that does not touch the ground: (S:) and kirokirRpN raHRaMCu a wide callous protuberance upon the breast of a camel: (TA:) and jafonapN raHRaMCu a wide [bowl such as is termed] jifnp; like rawoHaMCu; wide and not deep: (TA:) and jifaAnN ruHuHN wide jfAn [pl. of jafonapN]. (IAar, K.) Having a spreading hoof; (S, A, K;) applied to a horse, (A,) and to a mountain-goat: (S, A, K:) also, applied to a man, having a wide foot; (A;) or having, in the sole of his foot, no hollow part that does not touch the ground, (S, K,) as is the case in the feet of the Zinj; (S;) having the sole of the foot flat, so that all of it touches the ground: fem. raHRaMCu: you say AimoraOapN raHRaMCu Alqadamayoni: a high hollow to the sole of the foot is approved in a man and in a woman. (T, TA.) Also, applied to a camel, Having one foot cleaving to another. (TA.)

1 raHuba c
1. raHuba, (Msb, K,) said of a place, (Msb,) or of a thing, (TA,) and raHubato, said of a land, (OaroD, S,) or of a country, (bilaAd, A, TA,) aor.
raHuba
, inf. n. ruHobN (S, A, * Msb, K) and raHaAbapN; (S, K;) and raHiba, (Msb, K,) and raHibato, (TA,) aor.
raHaba
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. raHabN; (Msb, TA;) and ArHb↓, (Msb, K,) and ArHbt; (TA;) It was, or became, ample, spacious, wide, or roomy. (S, K, TA.) raHubati AldRaAru and OaroHabat↓ both signify the same, i.e. The house, or abode, was ample, &c.; or may the house, or abode, be ample, &c. (S, TA.) And they said, Ealayoka waTulRato OaroHabato↓, meaning May it (the country, AlbilaAdu,) be spacious to thee, and be moistened by gentle rain, or by dew: so accord. to Aboo-Is-hák. (TA.) DaAqato Ealayohimu AlOaroDu bimaA raHubato, in the Kur ix. 119, means The earth became strait to them with [i. e. notwithstanding] its spaciousness. (Bd, Jel.) ― -b2- raHuba, accord. to the original usage, is trans. by means of a particle; so that one says, raHuba bika AlmakaAnu [The place was, or may the place be, spacious with thee]: afterwards, by reason of frequency of usage, it became trans. by itself; and thus one said, raHubatoka AldRaAru [The house, or abode, was, or may the house, or abode, be, spacious with thee, or to thee]. (Msb.) ― -b3- [Hence the saying,] OaraHubakumu AldRuxuwlu fiI TaAEatihi (assumed tropical:) Was it proper, or allowable, for you [to enter among his obeyers? i. e., to become obedient to him?]: (S, K * TA:) referring to El-Kirmánee, (so in the S,) or Ibn-El-Kirmánee: (so in the TA:) mentioned by Kh, on the authority of Nasr Ibn-Seiyár; but he says, (S,) the verb thus used is anomalous; (S, K;) for a verb of the measure faEula is not trans., (K, TA,) accord. to the grammarians, (TA,) except with the tribe of Hudheyl, who, accord. to AAF, make it trans. (K, TA) when its meaning admits of its being so: (TA:) Kh mentions the phrase raHubatokumu AldRaAru [meaning The house, or abode, was, or may the house, or abode, be, spacious with, or to, you]; but it is thought that there is an ellipsis here, and that it is for raHubato bikumu AldRaAru: and ElJelál Es-Suyootee mentions, on the authority of AAF, the saying raHuba QllRehu jawofahu, as meaning wasRaEahu [i. e. May God make wide his belly]: (TA:) [J says, app. quoting Kh,] there is no sound verb of the measure faEula that is trans. except this; but as to the unsound, there is a difference of opinion: accord. to Ks, qulotuhu is originally qawulotuhu; but Sb says that this is not allowable, because it is trans.: (S:) Az says that raHubatokumo is not held to be allowable by the grammarians; and that Nasr is not an [approved] evidence. (TA.)

2 raHRaba
2: see 4. ― -b2- rHRb bihi (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. taroHiybN (S, A, K) and taroHaAbN (Har p. 579,) He said to him maroHabFA; (S, Msb;) [he welcomed him with the greeting of maroHabFA; or simply he welcomed him;] he invited him to ampleness, spaciousness, or roominess: (A, K:) and maroHaba↓, also, signifies he said maroHabFA; but the expression commonly known is raHRaba bihi. (Har pp. 422-3.) You say, laqytuhu biAltRaroHiybi [I met him with the greeting of maroHabFA; or with welcoming]. (A.) See also maroHabN

4 OaroHaba
4: see 1, in three places. ＝ -A2- ArHbhu He made it (a thing, S) ample, spacious, wide, or roomy; (S, K;) as also rHRbhu↓. (CK. [The latter is not in the TA, nor in my MS. copy of the K.]) El- Hajjáj said, when he slew Ibn-El-Kirreeyeh, OaroHibo yaA gulaAmu juroHahu [Make wide, O young man, his wound]. (S.) And one says, in chiding a horse or mare, OaroHibo (S, K) and OaroHibiI (S, A, K,) meaning Make room, and withdraw. (S, A, K.)

6 taraAoHaba
6: An instance of this verb occurs in the saying, hecaA AlOamoru Uino taraAHabato mawaAriduhu faqado taDaAyaqato maSaAdiruhu (tropical:) [This affair, or case, if the ways leading to it, or the ways of commencing it, be easy, the ways of return from it, or the ways of completing it, are difficult]. (A, TA.)

Q. Q. 1
Q. Q. 1: maroHaba: see 2.

raHobN c
raHobN (S, A, Msb, K) and raHiybN↓ (Msb, K) and ruHaAbN↓ (K) Ample, spacious, wide, or roomy; (S, A, K;) applied to a place, (Msb,) or a thing. (TA.) You say biladN raHobN, and OaroDN raHobapN, An ample, or a spacious, or wide, country, and land, (S,) and ArD raHiybapN↓ also: and manozilN raHobN and raHiybN↓ an ample, or a spacious, or wide, place of alighting or abode: and TariyqN raHobN a wide road. (TA.) And qidorN ruHaAbN↓ An ample cookingpot: (S:) and ruHaAbN alone is [elliptically] used as meaning a cooking-pot. (Ham p. 721.) And AimoraOapN ruHaAbN↓ A wide woman; (K;) meaning wide in respect of the faroj. (TK.) And rajulN Aljawofi raHiybu↓ A man ample, or wide, in the belly: and, as mentioned by Es-Suyootee, (assumed tropical:) a great eater; voracious; (TA;) and so raHiybN alone. (S, K, TA.) And rajulN raHobu AlSRador (TA) and AlSRadori ruHobu↓ and AlSRadori raHiybu↓, (S, TA) A man ample, or dilated, in the breast, or bosom; [meaning (assumed tropical:) free-minded; free from distress of mind; without care: and free from narrowness of mind; liberal, munificent, or generous.] (S, TA.) And raHobu AlcRiraAEi (tropical:) Liberal, munificent, or generous; as also raHobu AlbaAEi; and so AlcRiraAEi raHiybu↓ and AlbaAEi (A, TA.) And raHobu AlcRiraAEi means also (assumed tropical:) Having ample, or extensive, power, or strength, in cases of difficulty: (TA in the present art.:) or (tropical:) having ample strength, and power, and might in war or fight, courage, valour, or prowess. (TA in art. crE) And fulaAnN raHobu AlcRiraAEi likacaA (tropical:) Such a one has power, or ability, for that. (A.) ― -b2- See also raHabapN.

ruHobN c
ruHobN an inf. n. of raHuba [q.v.]. (S, Msb, K.) [Used as a simple subst.,] Ampleness, spaciousness, wideness, or roominess. (S A, Mgh, K.) You say, daEaAhu UilaI AlrRuHobi [He invited him to ampleness, &c.]. (A.) And hence the saying of Zeyd Ibn-Thábit to 'Omar, hehunaA biAlrRuHobi, meaning Advance to ampleness, &c. (Mgh.) See also maroHabN, in two places. ― -b2- [It is also used as an epithet:] see the next preceding paragraph.

raHabN c
raHabN: see the next following paragraph.

raHabapN c
raHabapN, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and raHobapN, (A, Mgh, Msb,) K,) the former of which is the more chaste, (A,) or the better, (Mgh,) or the more common, (Msb,) The court, open area, or spacious vacant part or portion, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) of a mosque, (S, A, Mgh, Msb,) and of a house, (A, TA,) or of a place; (K;) so called because of its ampleness: (TA:) and in like manner, between, or among, houses: (A:) a desert tract, (Fr, Mgh, TA,) or a spacious vacant tract, (A,) or a spacious piece of ground, (Msb,) between, or among, the yards of the houses of a people: (Fr, Mgh, Msb, TA:) and sometimes thus is termed an enclosure, or a [kind of wide bench of stone or brick such as is called] dukRaAn, that is made at the doors of some of the mosques in the towns and the rural districts, for prayer: hence the saying of Aboo-'Alee Ed-Dakkák, [in which it means an enclosure outside the door of a mosque,] “ It is not fit that the HaAYiD should enter the rHbop of the mosque of a people, whether the rHbp be contiguous or separate: ” and hence, also, in a trad. of 'Alee, by the rHbp of El-Koofeh is meant a dukRaAn in the midst of the mosque of El-Koofeh, upon which he used to sit and to preach, and upon which he is related to have cast the spoils that he obtained from the people of En-Nahrawán:
(Mgh:) pl. raHabN↓ (S, Msb, K) and raHobN↓ (K) [or rather these are coll. gen. ns. of which raHabapN and raHobapN are the ns. un.] and [the pl. is] riHaAbN and raHabaAtN (S, Msb, K) and raHobaAtN. (K.) ― -b2- Also, both words, An ample tract of land, that produces much herbage, and in which people alight, or abide, much, or often: (AHn, K:) pl. as above, accord. to the K; but accord. to IAar, raHobapN signifies an ample tract of land; (TA;) and he says that its pl. is ruHabN, like as qurFI is pl. of qaroyapN: Az says that this occurs as an anomalous pl. of words of the defective class, and that he had not heard a word of the perfect class of the measure faEolapN having a pl. of the measure fuEalN; but that IAar is an authority worthy of reliance. (L, Msb.) And raHabapu AlwaAdiI, and raHobatuhu The part of the valley in which its water flows into it from its two sides: (K, TA:) pl. riHaAbN (TA.) [Or the pl.] riHaAbN signifies Plain, smooth, or soft, places, in which water collects and stagnates: they are the places where vegetation is most rapid, and are at the extremity of a valley, and in its middle, and sometimes in an elevated place, where water collects and stagnates, surrounded by what is more elevated: if in a plain tract of land, people alight and sojourn there: if in the interior of water-courses, people do not alight and sojourn there: if in the interior of a valley, and retaining the water, not very deep, and in breadth equal to a bow-shot, people alight and sojourn by the side thereof: rHAb are not in sands; but they are in low and in elevated tracts of land. (L.) ― -b3- The place of aggregation and growth of the plant called vumaAm [i. e. panic grass]. (K, TA.) ― -b4- The place of grapes, (K,) [where they are dried,] like the jariyn for dates. (TA.)

ruHobaI c
ruHobaI The broadest rib (S, K) in the breast: (K:) and the ruHobayaAni, are the two ribs next to the armpits, among the upper ribs: (K:) or the place to which each elbow returns [when, after it has been removed from its usual place, it is brought back thereto; which place in a beast is next the arm pit]: (S, K:) it is there only that the camel's elbow wounds the callous protuberance upon his breast: (S:) or the rHbI is the place where the heart beats, (Az, K, TA,) in a beast and in a man: (Az, TA:) or, as some say, the part from the place where the neck is set on to the place where end the cartilages of the ribs, or the extremities of the ribs projecting over the belly: or the part between the two ribs of the base of the neck and the place to which the shoulder-blade returns [when, after it has moved from its usual position, it is brought back thereto, i. e. its lower part, next the armpit]: and the ruHobayaAni, also called the ruHobaAyaAwaAni↓ [perhaps a mistranscription for ruHobaAwaAni as though the sing. were ruHobaMCN,] of the horse, are the upper parts of the kaXoHaAni [or two flanks.] (TA.) ― -b2- Also A certain brand, or mark made with a hot iron, upon the side of a camel. (S, K.)

ruHobaAyaAwaAni c
ruHobaAyaAwaAni [or perhaps ruHobaAwaAni]: see the next preceding paragraph.

ruHaAbN c
ruHaAbN: see raHobN, in three places.

raHiybN c
raHiybN; and its fem., with p: see raHobN, in six places.

raHaAYibu AltRuxuwmi c
raHaAYibu AltRuxuwmi, (S, K,) in some copies of the K, erroneously, AlnRujuwm, (TA,) Ampleness [of the limits, or boundaries, and therefore] of the tracts, or regions, of the land, or earth. (S, K.)

najaAYibu OaroHabiyRaAtN c
najaAYibu OaroHabiyRaAtN Certain excellent she-camels, so called in relation to OaroHabu, the name of a tribe of Hemdán, (S, Msb, K,) or of a certain stallion (Az, K, TA) whence they originated, (Az, TA,) or of a place (K, TA) of El-Yemen called after that tribe. (TA.)

maroHabN c
maroHabN [is an inf. n., like ruHobN↓; or a n. of place].
