You say maroHabFA (T, S, Msb, TA) and maroHabFA bika (A, Msb) [and bika ruHobFA↓] meaning Thou hast come to, (T, S, TA,) or found, (T, A, TA,) ampleness, spaciousness, or roominess; (T, S, A, TA;) not straitness: (T, TA:) or alight thou, (Kh, Lth, TA,) or abide thou, (Kh, TA,) in ampleness, &c.; (Kh, Lth, TA;) for such we have for thee; (Lth, TA;) the word being put in the accus. case because of a verb understood: (Kh, TA:) or thou hast alighted in an ample, a spacious, or a roomy, place: (Msb:) [or welcome to ampleness, &c.; or to an ample, a spacious, or a roomy, place: or simply welcome:] and maroHabFA waOaholFA Thou hast come to [or found, &c.,] ampleness, spaciousness, or roominess, and [such as thine own] kinsfolk; therefore be cheerful, and be not sad: (S:) and maroHabFA wasaholFA Thou hast found ampleness [and ease]: (K:) or saholFA means thou hast alighted in a plain, smooth, not rugged, district: (T, TA:) and maroHabaka QllRehu wamasohalaka and maroHabFA bika QllRehu wamasohalFA [May God grant ampleness to thee, and ease]: (K:) Sh says, thus I heard IAar say: and the Arabs also say, laA maroHabFA bika, meaning May it [the land or country] not be ample, or spacious, to thee: maroHabFA, he says, is one of the inf. ns. that are used in calling down blessings or curses on a man; as saqoyFA and raEoyFA and jadoEFA and EaqorFA, for saqaAka QllRehu and raEaAka QllRehu &c.: and Fr says that the meaning [of maroHabFA or maroHabFA bika] is QllRehu bika maroHabFA raHRaba↓ [May God invite thee to ampleness, &c.]; as though the last word were put in the place of taroHiybFA. (TA.) ― -b2- Oabuw maroHabK means (assumed tropical:) The shade: so in the saying of a poet, (S,) namely, En-Nábighah El-Jaadee, (TA,)
wakayofa tuwaASilu mano OaSobaHato
xulaAlatuhu kaOabiI maroHabi
[And how wilt thou hold loving communion with him whose friendship has become like the shade?]. (S, TA.) It is also a surname of 'Orkoob, the man notorious for lying promises. (TA.) ― -b3- And maroHabN is the name of An idol that was in Hadramowt. (K.)

1 raHaDa c
1. raHaDa, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
raHaDa
, (A, Msb, K,) or
raHuDa
, (so in two copies of the S,) or both, (L, TA,) inf. n. raHoDN, (S, Msb) and taroHaADN, [but this is an intensive form,] (TA,) He washed (S, A, Msb, K) a thing, (A, K,) or garment, (S, A, Msb,) and his hand; (S;) as also ArHD↓ (IDrd, K,) which latter is of the dial. of El- Hijáz. (IDrd.) You say also, hecihi sawoCapN laA Eanoka XaIoCN yuroHiDuhaA↓ (tropical:) [This is a disgrace which nothing will wash from thee]. (A: [but the last word is not in the copy from which I quote.]) ― -b2- ruHiDa, (inf. n. as above, AZ, AAF,) (tropical:) He (a person suffering from fever) was, or became, affected with what is termed ruHaDaMC [q. v.]: (Lth, S, A, K:) or he sweated, and his sweat became abundant upon the sides of his forehead above the temples, in his sleeping or waking, but only in consequence of disease. (AZ, AAF.)

4 OaroHaDa
4: see above, in two places.

8 ArtHD c
8. ArtHD (tropical:) He became disgraced, or put to shame. (AA, O, K.)

raHoDN c
raHoDN A garment, or piece of cloth, washed until it has become worn out. (IAar.) ― -b2- A small worn-out skin: a worn-out mazaAdap [or leathern water-bag]. (Sgh, K.)

ruHaDaMCu c
ruHaDaMCu (tropical:) Sweat; absolutely: (TA:) or the sweat of fever: (Lth, A, TA:) or sweat following fever: (S, K:) or fever with sweating: (TA:) or sweat that washed the skin by reason of its abundance: (K:) often used to signify the sweat of fever and of disease. (TA.)

ruHaADN c
ruHaADN (tropical:) [The state of being affected with what is termed ruHaDaMC;] a subst. from ruHiDa, (K,) or from ruHaDaMC. (IDrd.)

raHiyDN c
raHiyDN Washed; (S, A, Msb, K;) applied to a garment [&c.]; (S, A;) as also maroHuwDN↓ (S, K) and muroHaDN↓. (TA.)

ruHaADapN c
ruHaADapN Washings. (Lh.)

muroHaDN c
muroHaDN: see raHiyDN.

miroHaDapN c
miroHaDapN A place [or tank] in which one washes his limbs, performing the ablution termed wuDuwoC: (A, TA: *) or a thing in which one performs that ablution, like the kaniyf: (Lth, K:) and miroHaADapN↓ a thing with which one performs that ablution, like the [kind of vessel called] tawor. (IAar.) ― -b2- See also miroHaADN.

miroHaADN c
miroHaADN A piece of wood with which a garment, or piece of cloth, is beaten (S, A, * K) when it is washed. (S, A. *) ― -b2- A vessel of the kind called UijRaAnap, or of the kind called Tasot, in which clothes are washed: (A:) and miroHaDapN↓ signifies a vessel of the kind called UijRaAnap; because clothes are washed in it. (Lh.) ― -b3- A place of washing: (Mgh, Msb:) or a place in which one washes himself. (S, K.) ― -b4- And hence, (tropical:) A privy: (S, * A, Mgh, Msb, K:) pl. maraAHiyDu (S, Mgh) and maraAHiDu. (TA.)

maroHuwDN c
maroHuwDN: see raHiyDN. ― -b2- Also part. n. of ruHiDa [q. v.]. (AZ, AAF, S.)

miroHaADapN c
miroHaADapN: see miroHaDapN.

ruHaAqN c
ruHaAqN: see what follows, in two places.

raHiyqN c
raHiyqN Wine: (A 'Obeyd, K:) or the choicest of wine: (S, TA:) or the sweetest of wine: or the most excellent thereof: (K:) or the oldest and most excellent thereof: (M, TA:) or unadulterated wine: (Zj, TA:) or wine that is easy to swallow: (TA:) or pure wine: or clear wine: as also ruHaAqN↓: (K:) in all of these senses the former word has been explained as used in the Kur lxxxiii. 25: (TA:) and ↓the latter occurs as syn. with the former in chaste poetry. (IDrd.) ― -b2- Also A sort of perfume. (K.) ― -b3- And Honey. (O, TA.) ― -b4- [And it is used as an epithet.] You say misokN raHiyqN (tropical:) Unadulterated musk. (TA.) And HasabN raHiyqN (tropical:) Pure, or genuine, grounds of pretension to respect. (TA.)

1 raHala AlbaEiyra c
1. raHala AlbaEiyra, aor.
raHala
, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. raHolN, (S, Msb,) [He saddled the camel;] he bound, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or put, (M, K,) the raHol upon the camel; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also ArtHlhu↓. (K.) And raHalahu raHolahu He bound upon him his apparatus. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, aor. and inf. n. as above, He mounted the camel: (T, TA:) and AlbaEiyra AirotaHalotu↓ I rode the camel, either with a qatab [or saddle] or upon his bare back. (Sh, TA.) ― -b3- [Both of these verbs are also used tropically.] You say, raHalotu lahu nafosiI [lit. I saddled for him myself;] meaning (assumed tropical:) I endured patiently his annoyance, or molestation. (S.) And raHala fulaAnN SaAHibahu bimaA yakorahu (assumed tropical:) [Such a one put upon, or did to, his companion that which he disliked, or hated]. (TA.) And [in like manner] trHRlhu↓ means rakibahu bimakoruwhK (tropical:) [He did to him an evil, or abominable, or odious, deed]. (K, TA.) And raHalahu bisayofihi (tropical:) He smote him with his sword. (K, TA.) ― -b4- And raHala fulaAnN fulaAnFA (assumed tropical:) Such a one mounted upon the back of such a one; as also EalaI Zahorihi ArtHlhu↓; [and ArtHlhu alone; for] it is said in a trad., UinRa QboniI QrotaHalaniI↓, meaning (assumed tropical:) Verily my son mounted upon my back, making me like the raAHilap: (TA:) and if a man throws down another prostrate, and sits upon his back, you say, raOayotuhu murotaHilahu (assumed tropical:) [I saw him sitting upon his back]. (Sh, TA.) And [hence] ArtHl↓ AlOamora (assumed tropical:) He embarked in the affair. (TA.) And fulaAnN OamorFA maA yuTiyquhu ArtHl↓ (assumed tropical:) [Such a one embarked, or has embarked, in an affair which he is unable to accomplish]. (TA.) And AlHumRaI AirotaHalatohu↓ (assumed tropical:) [The fever continued upon him]; a phrase similar to rakibatohu AlHmRI and AimotaTatohu and OagobaTatohu. (A and TA in art. gbT.) ＝ -A2- raHala (S, Mgh, Msb, K) Eani AlmakaAni, (TA,) or Eani Albaladi, (Mgh, Msb,) aor.
raHala
, (K,) inf. n. raHolN, (TA,) or raHiylN, (Msb,) or this latter is a simple subst.; (S, K, TA;) and ArtHl↓, and triHRl↓, (S, Msb, K,) Eani AlmakaAni, (K,) or Eani Alqawomi; (Msb;) all signify the same; (S, Msb;) He removed, (Mgh, K, TA,) went, went away, departed, went forth, or journeyed, (Mgh, TA,) from the place, (K, TA,) or from the country or the like, (Mgh, Msb,.) or from the people. (Msb.) See an ex. of the first of these verbs in a verse cited in the next paragraph. ArtHl↓ said of a camel, (K,) or ArtHl raHolahu, (TA,) signifies He journeyed, and went away: (K, TA:) [or he had his saddle put upon him:] and hence, ArtHl↓ Alqawomu The people, or party, removed. (TA.) ― -b2- raHala bihi: see 2.

2 raHRalotuhu c
2. raHRalotuhu, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. taroHiylN; (K;) and OaroHalotuhu↓ (Mgh;) I made him to remove, to go, go away, go forth, or journey, (S, Mgh, Msb, * K, *) from his place; and sent him [away]: (S:) and [in like manner] bihi raHala↓ he made him to remove, go away, depart, or journey: (L in art. xcrf:) and AlAirotiHaAlu↓ [if not a mistranscription for AlUiroHaAlu] signifies the making [one] to go, go away, depart, go forth, or journey; and the removing from one's place. (TA.) A poet says,
AlXRayobu Eano daArK yaHulRu bihaA laA yaroHalu↓
HatRaI yuraHRala EanohaA SaAHibu AldRaAri
[(assumed tropical:) Hoariness will not depart from a dwelling in which it alights until the owner of the dwelling be made to depart from it]. (TA.) And it is said in a trad. that, at the approach of the hour [of resurrection], AlnRaAsa taxoruju naArN mino Eadana turoHilu↓, i.e. [A fire shall issue from 'Adan] that shall remove with the people when they remove, and alight with them when they alight: so says EshShaabee; or, Sh says, as some relate it, turaHRilu AlnRaAsa, i.e. that shall make the people to alight at the maraAHil [or stations]: or, as some say, that shall make the people to remove, or depart. (TA.) ＝ -A2- taroHiylN also signifies The figuring, or embellishing, of garments or cloths [with the forms of riHaAl, or camels' saddles: see muraHRalN]. (TA.)

3 rAHlhu c
3. rAHlhu, (S, K,) inf. n. muraAHalapN, (TA,) He aided him to undertake, or perform, his riHolap [or journey]. (S, K.)

4 ArHl c
4. ArHl He broke, or trained, a she-camel, so that she became such as is termed raAHilap, meaning fit to be saddled; (K;) like Oamohara meaning “ he (a breaker, or trainer,) rendered ” her “ a mahoriyRap: ” (TA:) or he took a camel in an untractable state and rendered him such as is termed raAHilap. (AZ, TA.) ― -b2- And ArHlhu He gave him a raAHilap, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) that he might ride it. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 2, in two places. ＝ -A2- He (a camel) became strong in his back, [so as to be fit for the raHol (or saddle) or for journeying,] after weakness: (IDrd, K:) or he (a camel) became fat; as though there came [what resembled] a raHol upon his back, by reason of his fatness and his [large] hump: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and ArHlt AlUibilu The camels became fat after leanness, so as to be able to journey. (S K.) ― -b2- And He (a man, TA) had many [camels such as are termed] rawaAHil [pl. of raAHilapN]; (ISd, K;) like OaEoraba meaning “ he had horses such as are termed EiraAb ” (ISd, TA.)

5 taraHRala
5: trans. and intrans.: see 1, in two places.

6 trAHlwA UilaI AlHakami c
6. trAHlwA UilaI AlHakami They went, or journeyed, [together] to the Hakam [or judge]. (O, TA.)

8 UirotaHala
8: as a trans. v.; see 1, in seven places: ― -b2- and see also 2: ― -b3- and as an intrans. v.; see 1, in the latter part of the paragraph, in three places.

10 AstrHlhu c
10. AstrHlhu i. q. saOalahu Oano yaroHala lahu [which may be rendered He asked him to remove, or journey, to him: and also he asked him to bind, or put, the raHol (or saddle of the camel) for him: the former is the meaning accord. to the PS]. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- AstrHl AlnRaAsa nafosahu means (assumed tropical:) He abased himself to men, or to the people, so that they annoyed, or molested, him: or, as some say, he asked men, or the people, to take off from him his weight, or burden. (TA.)

raHolN c
raHolN A saddle for a camel; (S, * K;) as also raAHuwlN↓; (O, L, K;) for a he-camel and a she-camel; (TA;) the thing for the camel that is like the saroj for the horse or similar beast; (Mgh;) the thing that is put upon the camel for the purpose of riding thereon; (Er-Rághib, TA;) smaller than the qatab; (S, TA;) one of the vehicles of men, exclusively of women: (TA:) [this seems to be regarded as the primary signification by the authors of the Mgh and the K and by Er-Rághib: but see what follows:] or it signifies the camel's saddle together with his [girths called] rabaD and Haqab and his [cloth called] Hilos [that is put beneath the saddle], and all its other appertenances: and is applied also to the pieces of wood of the raHol, without any apparatus: (AO, Sh, TA:) or it signifies anything, or everything, that a man prepares for removing, or journeying; such as a bag, or receptacle, for goods or utensils or apparatus, and a camel's saddle, and a [cloth such as is called] Hilos [that is put beneath the saddle], and a rasan [or rope for leading his camel]: (Msb:) or it signifies as first explained above, and also the goods, or utensils, or apparatus, which a man takes with him [during a journey]: (S, K, TA:) [but accord. to the Msb, this signification is from another, mentioned below; and the same seems to be indicated in the S, which reverses the order in which I have mentioned the three significations that I quote from it:] this last signification is disapproved by El-Hareeree, in the “ Durrat el-Ghowwás: ” [but see two exs. voce HucaAfapN:] the pl. is OaroHulN and riHaAlN; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) the former a pl. of pauc.; (S, TA;) the latter, of mult. (TA.) One says, HaTRa raHolahu and OaloqaI raHolahu [He put down his camel's saddle]; meaning he stayed, or abode. (TA.) And hecaA maHaTRu AlrRiHaAli [This is the place where the camels' saddles are put down]. (TA.) And in reviling, one says, yaA Qbona muloqaIOaroHuli AlrRukobaAni [O son of the place in which are thrown down the camels' saddles of the riders; as though the person thus addressed were there begotten]; (S, O, TA;) meaning
yaA Qbona AlfaAjirapi [O son of the adulteress or fornicatress]: (TA in art. lqI:) or huwa Abn mlqI ArHl AlrkbAn [He is the son &c.]. (Msb.) ― -b2- Er-Rághib, after giving the explanation mentioned as on his authority above, says that it is then sometimes applied to The camel [itself]: and is sometimes used in the sense next following; i. e. ― -b3- A part, of a place of alighting or abode, upon which on sits: (TA:) or a man's dwelling, or habitation; (S, K, TA;) [in the first of which, this commences the art., app. showing that the author held this to be the primary signification;]) his house or tent; and his place of alighting or abode: (TA:) a place to which a man betakes himself, or repairs, for lodging, covert, or refuge; a man's place of resort; (Mgh, Msb;) in a region, district, or tract, of cities, towns, or villages, and of cultivated land: and then applied to the goods, utensils, or apparatus, of a traveller; because they are, in travelling, the things to which he betakes himself: (Msb:) pl. OaroHulN (TA) and riHaAlN [as above]. (Mgh, TA.) One says, daxalotu EalaI AlrRajuli raHolahu, i. e. [I went in to the man in] his dwelling, or place of abode. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., UicaA QbotalRati AlnRiEaAlu faSalRuwA fiI AlrRiHaAli, (TA,) or fiIlSRalaApu fiI AlrRiHaAli, (Mgh, and so in the TA in art. nEl,) i. e. [When the niEaAl are moistened by rain, then pray ye, or then prayer shall be performed,] in the houses, or habitations, or places of abode; the nEAl meaning here the HiraAr; (IAth, TA in the present art.;) or rugged and hard tracts of ground; which are here particularized because the least wet moistens them, whereas the soft tracts dry up the water: (IAth, TA in art. nEl:) Az says that the meaning is, when the hard grounds are rained upon, they become slippery to him who walks upon them; therefore pray ye in your abodes, and there shall not be anything brought against you for your not being present at the prayer in the mosques of the congregations: (TA in that art.:) or the trad. may mean, then pray ye [on the camels' saddles, i. e.] riding. (TA in the present art.) ― -b4- In another trad., it is related that 'Omar said to the Prophet, HawRalotu raHoliIa AlbaAriHapa; by the word raHol, as signifying [properly] either the “ place of abode and resort ” or the “ saddle upon which camels are ridden, ” alluding to his wife; meaning giXoyaAnuhaA fiI qubulihaA mino jihapi ZahorihaA (TA.) ― -b5- raHolu AlmuSoHafi means The thing [or desk] upon which the mSHf [or copy of the Kur-án] is put, in shape [somewhat] like the saddle. (TA.) [It is generally a small desk of which the front and back have the form of the letter X; commonly made of palm-sticks.] ＝ -A2- [The pl.] raHaAlN also signifies [Carpets, or cloths, or the like, such as are called] TanaAfis, of the fabric of El-Heereh. (S, K.)

ruHolapN c
ruHolapN Strength; [app. in a camel, such as renders fit for the saddle, or for journeying;] and fleetness, or swiftness, and excellence: (TA:) [and riHolapN↓ has a similar meaning, as appears from what follows:] or excellence of pace of a camel. (S voce HiDaArN.) You say baEiyrN cuw ruHolapK and riHolapK↓, and miroHalN↓, like minobarN, (K,) or muroHilN↓, and raHiylN↓, so in the T, (TA,) A strong he-camel: (T, K:) and (so in the K [but properly “ or ”]) bEyr cw ruHolapK (CK) or riHolapK↓ (K accord. to the TA) or both, and miroHalN↓, with kesr to the m (O,) and jamalN raHiylN↓, (AA, S, S, O, K, TA,) and naAqapN raHiylapN↓ (S, O) or raHiylN, (TA,) and caAtu ruHolapK, (S,) a he-camel, (S, O, K,) and a she-camel, (S, O,) strong to journey; (S, O, K, TA;) so says Fr: (O:) or strong to be saddled: (TA:) and naAqapN raHiylapN↓ and raHiylN and muroHilapN↓, accord. to the “ Nawádir el-Aaráb, ” a she-camel that is excellent, generous, of high breed; or strong, light, and swift; (TA;) and so musotaroHilapN↓. (K, TA. [See also raAHilapN.]) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph, in seven places.

riHolapN c
riHolapN The act of saddling of camels: (K, * TA:) [and also, agreeably with analogy, a mode, or manner, of saddling of camels:] so in the saying, UinRahu laHasanu AlrRiHolapi [Verily he is good in respect of the saddling, or the mode or manner of saddling, of camels]. (K.) ― -b2- Also A removal, departure, or journey; (AZ, S, Msb, K;) and so ruHolapN↓, (Lh, Msb, K,) and raHiylN↓: (S, K: [the last said in the Msb to be and inf. n.:]) you say danato riHolatunaA (S) or qarubato riHolatunaA (Msb) [Our removal, &c., drew near, or has drawn near]: and UinRahu lacuw riHolapK UilaI Almuluwki and riHolap↓ Verily he is one who journeys, or has journeyed, to the kings: (Lh, TA:) and in like manner ruHolapN is used in the Kur cvi. 2: (TA:) ― -b3- or riHolapN↓ with damm, (S, Msb, K,) signifies The thing to which one removes, departs, or journeys; (AZ, Msb;) or the direction, or point, or object, to which one desires to repair, or betakes himself: (AA, S, Msb, K:) and also, (K,) or ruHolapN, (TA,) a single journey; (K, TA;) as ISd says: (TA:) you say, makRapu ruHolatiI↓ Mekkeh is the point, or object, to which I desire to remove, or depart, or journey: (TA:) and Oanotumo ruHolatiI↓ Ye are they to whom I remove, or depart, or journey: (S, TA:) and Oanota ruHolatunaA↓ Thou art the object to which we repair, or betake ourselves. (Msb.) And hence ruHolapN↓ is applied to signify A noble, or an exalted, person, or a great man of learning, to whom one journeys for his [the latter's] need, or want, or for his [the former's] science. (TA.) ― -b4- See also the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

raHuwlN c
raHuwlN: see raAHilapN: ― -b2- and raHRaAlN.

raHiylN c
raHiylN A camel having the saddle (raHol [not rHAlp as in Freytag's Lex.]) put upon him; as also maroHuwlN↓. (K.) ― -b2- See also ruHolapN, in four places. ＝ -A2- As a simple subst, or, accord. to the Msb, an inf. n.: see riHolapN.

riHaAlapN c
riHaAlapN A saroj [or horse's saddle]: (K:) or a saroj of skins, (S, M, Msb, K,) in which is no wood; used for vehement running [of the horse]: (S, M, K:) ISd says also that it is one of the vehicles [or saddles] of women, like the raHol: but Az says that it is one of the vehicles [or saddles] of men, exclusively of women, i. e. not of women; as is also the raHol: and some say that it is larger than the saroj, covered with skins, and is for horses, and for excellent, or strong and light and swift, camels: (TA:) pl. raHaAYilu. (S.) When a man is hasty in doing evil to his companion, one says to him, Aisotaqodamato riHaAlatuka [lit. Thy saddle has got before thee, or shifted forwards]: (S in the present art.:) it is a prov., meaning that has preceded than which another was more fit to do so. (S in art. qdm.) In the following saying of Imra-el-Keys, addressing his wife,
faUimRaA tarayoniI fiI riHaAlapi jaAbirK
EalaI HarajK kaQloqarRitaxofiqu OakofaAniI
[And either thou wilt see me upon the saddle of Jábir, upon a bier like the vehicle called qarR, my grave-clothes fluttering], he means, by the word rHAlp, [merely] the Haraj; there being in this case no rHAlp in reality: it is like the saying, jaMCa fulaAnN EalaI naAqapi AlHacRaMCi, meaning [“ Such a one came upon] the sandal [or sandals]: ” Jábir is the name of a certain carpenter. (S.) ＝ -A2- Also A ewe. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.) [Hence,] riHaAlaho riHaAlaho is A call to the ewe, (Ibn-'Abbád, K,) on the occasion of milking. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.) ― -b2- And AlrRiHaAlapu is the name of A certain horse of 'Ámir Ibn-Et-Tufeyl; (K;) erroneously said by AO to be AlHmAlp. (TA.)

raHuwlapN c
raHuwlapN: see raAHilapN.

raHRaAlN c
raHRaAlN Skilled in the saddling of camels. (K.) ― -b2- Also A man who removes, or journeys, or travels, much; and so raHRaAlapN↓, [or rather this signifies one who removes, or journeys, or travels, very much,] and raHuwlN↓: and ruHRalN↓ [pl. of raAHilN, q. v.,] persons who remove, or journey, or travel, much. (TA.)

raHRaAlapN c
raHRaAlapN: see what next precedes.

raAHilN c
raAHilN Removing, (K, TA,) going, [going away, departing, going forth,] or journeying: (TA:) pl. ruHRalN. (TA.) For another meaning assigned to the pl., see raHRaAlN.

raAHilapN c
raAHilapN A she-camel that is fit to be saddled; (S, Msb, K;) thus some say; (Msb;) as also raHuwlN↓ (S, K) and raHuwlapN↓: (K:) or [generally a saddle-camel, or] a camel that is ridden, male or female: (S, Msb:) accord. to IKt, a she-camel that is strong to journey and to bear burdens; and such as a man chooses for his riding and his saddle on account of excellence, or generousness, or high breed, or of strength and lightness and swiftness, and of perfectness of make, and beauty of aspect: but this explanation is wrong: (Az, TA:) it signifies a he-camel, and a she-camel, that is excellent, or generous, or high-bred, or strong and light and swift: (Az, Mgh, TA:) the she-camel is not more entitled to this appellation than the he-camel: (Az, TA:) the p is added to give intensiveness to the signification; as in
daAhiyapN and baAqiEapN and EalRaAmapN, epithets applied to a man: or, as some say, the she-camel is so called because she is saddled; and it is like EiyXapN raADiyapN meaning maroDiyRapN, and maMCN daAfiqN meaning madofuwqN: or, as others say, because she is caAtu raHolK [one having a saddle]; and in like manner, EiyXapN raADiyapN means caAtu raDFI, and maMCN daAfiqN means cuw dafoqK: (TA:) the pl. is rawaAHilu. (S, Msb.) It is said in a trad., tajiduwna AlnRaAsa baEodiI kaUibilK miAYapK layosa fiyhaA raAHilapN [Thou wilt find the people, or mankind, after me, like a hundred camels among which there is not a rAHlp]: (Mgh, * TA:) because the rAHlo among a herd of camels is conspicuous and known. (TA.) ― -b2- maXato rawaAHiliI, a phrase used by the poet Dukeyn, means (tropical:) I have become hoary and weak: or, as some say, I have forsaken my ignorant, or foolish, behaviour, and have restrained myself from foul conduct, and become obedient to my censurers; like as the rAHlp obeys her chider, and goes. (TA.)

raAHuwlN c
raAHuwlN: see raHolN, first sentence.

raAHuwlaAtN c
raAHuwlaAtN A camel's saddle, (raHolN, Az, K,) or camel's saddles, so in the O, (TA,) variegated, figured, or embellished. (Az, O, K, TA.) [It is really, as well as literally, a pl.: for] a poet says,
EalayohinRa raAHuwlaAtu kulRi qaTiyfapK
[Upon them (referring evidently to she-camels) are variegated, figured, or embellished, saddles of every kind of villous, or nappy, cloth]. (TA.)

OaroHalu c
OaroHalu (tropical:) A horse white in the back; (S, Mgh, K;) because it is the place of the raHol [or rather of the riHaAlap]; (Mgh, TA;) the whiteness not reaching to the belly nor to the rump nor to the neck: (TA:) and a sheep or goat black in the back: accord. to Abu-l-Ghowth, the fem., raHolaMCu, applied to a mare, has the former meaning only: (S:) but XaApN raHolaMCu means a sheep or goat, or a ewe or she-goat, white in the back, and black in the other parts; and likewise black in the back, and white in the other parts: (S, K: *) so says Abu-l-Ghowth: (S:) and it is also explained as meaning black, but white in the place of the saddle, from the hinder parts of the shoulderblades: also as meaning white, but black in the back: Az adds that such as is white in one of the hind legs is termed rajolaMCu [with jym]. (TA.)

taroHiylN c
taroHiylN (assumed tropical:) A whiteness predominating over, or interrupted by, blackness, (XuhobapN,) or a redness, upon the shoulder-blades, (K, TA,) the place upon which lies the raHol [or camel's saddle]. (TA.)

taroHiylapN c
taroHiylapN A thing that makes thee to remove, go, go away, depart, go forth, or journey; expl. by maA yuraHRluka. (TA.)

muroHilN c
muroHilN One who breaks, or trains, and renders fit to be saddled, a camel or camels. (TA.) ― -b2- A man having many [camels such as are termed] rawaAHil [pl. of raAHilapN]; like muEoribN meaning “ having horses such as are termed EiraAb ” (A'Obeyd, S.) ＝ -A2- A camel strong in the back, [so as to be fit for the raHol,] after weakness. (IDrd, TA.) And A fat camel; though he be not excellent, or generous, or high-bred, or strong and light and swift: so in the “ Nawádir el-Aaráb. ” (TA.) See also ruHolapN, in two places.

miroHalN c
miroHalN: see ruHolapN, in two places.

maroHalapN c
maroHalapN [A station of travellers; i. e.] a place of alighting or abode, between two such places: (TA:) [and also a day's journey, or thereabout; or] the space which the traveller journeys in about a day: (Msb:) sing. of maraAHilu; (S, Msb, K;) which is also a pl. of muraHRalN as an epithet applied to a burod. (TA.) One says, bayoniI wabayona kacaA maroHalapN OawomaroHalataAni [Between me and such a place, or thing, is a station or a day's journey or thereabout, or are two stations &c.]. (S, TA.)

UibilN muraHRalapN c
UibilN muraHRalapN Camels having their riHaAl [or saddles] upon them: and also camels whose riHaAl have been put down from them: thus having two contr. meanings. (K.) ― -b2- And burodN muraHRalN A garment of the kind termed burod upon which are the figures of a raHol [or camels' saddle], (K,) and the like thereof; as in the T: (TA:) the explanation that J has given of it, [or rather of miroTN muraHRalN,] i. e. an UizaAr [or a waist-wrapper] of [the cloth called] xazR, upon which is an ornamented border, is not good: such is termed murajRalN, with jiym: (K:) the pl. is muraHRalaAtN and maraAHilu; both occurring in traditions; (TA in the present art.;) and the latter of them said in the T to be syn. with maraAjilu, which is pl. of mirojalN [q. v.]. (TA in art. rjl.)

maroHuwlN c
maroHuwlN: see raHiylN.

murotaHalN c
murotaHalN signifies [The act of removing or departing; i. e.] the contr. of maHalRN used in the sense of HuluwlN. (TA.) ― -b2- And sometimes it signifies The place in which one alights, or descends and stops. (TA.) ― -b3- Also The place of the raHol [which may here mean either the saddle or the saddling] of a camel. (TA.)

AlHaAlRu AlmurotaHilu c
AlHaAlRu AlmurotaHilu: see art. Hl.

musotaroHilapN c
musotaroHilapN, applied to a she-camel: see ruHolapN.

1 raHimahu c
1. raHimahu, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
raHama
, (K,) inf. n. raHomapN and ruHomN [and raHamapN and ruHumN] and maroHamapN, (S, * Msb, K, *) [He had mercy, or pity, or compassion, on him; or he treated him, or regarded him, with mercy or pity or compassion; i. e.] he was, or became, tender [or tender-hearted] towards him; and inclined to favour him [and to benefit him]: (S, Msb, K: [see also raximahu and raxamahu:]) and he pardoned him, or forgave him: (K:) said of a man: (S, Msb, K:) and also of God [in the former sense, but tropically, or anthropopathically: or as meaning He favoured him, or benefited him; or pardoned, or forgave, him: see explanations of raHomapN below]: (Msb, K:) and Ealayohi trHRm↓ signifies the same, (MA, [and the same seems to be indicated in the S,]) said of a man: (S:) [and so does trHRmhu↓, (occurring in the S and K in art. rEI, &c.,) accord. to Ibn-Maaroof, for he says that] taraHRumN signifies the regarding [another] with mercy or pity or compassion; or pardoning [him], or forgiving [him]: and also the being merciful or pitiful or compassionate or favourably inclined [EalaI gayorihi to another]. (KL: but respecting this latter verb, see 2.) ＝ -A2- raHumato, and raHimato, (S, K,) and ruHimato, (K,) inf. n. raHaAmapN, (S, K,) which is of the first, (S, TA,) and raHamN, (S, K,) which is of the second, (S, TA,) and raHomN, (K,) which is of the third, (TA,) She had a complaint of her womb after bringing forth, (S, K,) and died in consequence thereof: (K:) said of a camel, (S, TA,) and of a ewe or goat, and of a woman, and of any animal having a womb: (TA:) or she had a disease in her womb, in consequence of which she did not receive impregnation: or she brought forth without letting fall her secundine: (K, TA:) or, accord. to Lh, the bringing forth without letting fall her secundine, by a sheep or goat, is termed ruHaAmN↓. (TA.) ― -b2- raHima, aor.
raHama
, inf. n. raHamN, is also said of a water-skin, meaning It was left, or neglected, by its owners, after its being seasoned with rob, [for gyth, in the phrase bEd gyth, an evident mistranscription, I read, conjecturally, tamotiynihi, as the only word at all resembling gyth, that I can call to mind, having an apposite signification,] and they did not anoint it, or grease it, so that it became spoilt, or in a bad state, and did not retain the water: the epithet applied to it in this case is raHimN↓. (TA.) ― -b3- And raHaAmapN is also an inf. n. [of which the verb, if it have one, is app. raHuma,] signifying The being connected by relationship. (TA.)

2 rHRm Ealayohi c
2. rHRm Ealayohi, inf. n. taroHiymN; and trHRm↓; but the former is the more chaste; He said to him, raHimaka QllRehu [May God have mercy on thee; &c.]. (K.)

5 trHRm Ealayohi c and trHRmhu
5. trHRm Ealayohi trHRmhu: for both see 1; and for the former see also 2. [Accord. to different authorities, it appears that both may be rendered He had mercy, or pity, or compassion, on him; or he pitied, or compassionated, him: (see 1:) or he pitied him, or compassionated him, much: (see what follows:) and the former, he said to him, May God have mercy on thee; &c.; (see 2;) or he expressed a wish that God would have mercy on him; or he expressed pity, or compassion, for him: and also he affected, or constrained himself to have or to show, pity, or compassion.] Though taraHRamotu Ealayohi is mentioned by J, and not raHRamRhu, some say that the former is incorrect: and it is said that taraHRumN implies self-constraint, and therefore is not to be attributed to God: but some repudiate this assertion, because it occurs in correct traditions, and because tafaERulN is not restricted to the denoting peculiarly self-constraint, but has other properties, as in the instances of tawaHRudN and takabRurN, denoting intensiveness and muchness. (TA.)

6 trAHmwA c
6. trAHmwA signifies raHima baEoDuhumo baEoDFA [They had mercy, or pity, or compassion, one on another; &c.]. (S, TA.)

10 AstrHmhu c
10. AstrHmhu He asked, or demanded, of him AlrRaHomap [i. e. mercy, or pity, or compassion; &c.]. (TA.)

raHomN c
raHomN: see its syn. raHimN, in two places.

ruHomN c
ruHomN: see its syn. raHomapN. ― -b2- [Hence,] OumRu ruHomK one of the names of Mekkeh; (S, K; *) as also OumRu AlrRuHomi; (K;) meaning the source of AlrRaHomap [or mercy, &c.]. (TA.) [See also zuHomN.]

riHomN c
riHomN: see its syn. raHimN, in two places.

raHamN c
raHamN The coming forth of the womb, in consequence of a disease. (IAar, TA.) [See also raHimato and raHima, of each of which it is an inf. n.]

raHimN c
raHimN The womb, i. e. the place of origin, (Mgh, Msb, K,) and the receptacle, (Mgh, K,) of the young, (Mgh, Msb, K,) in the belly; (Mgh;) as also riHomN↓, (Msb, K,) a contraction of the former, and raHomN↓, which is of the dial. of Benoo-Kiláb: (Msb:) in this sense, (Msb,) which is the primary signification, (Mgh,) [i. e.] as meaning the raHim of the female, (S,) it is fem.; (S, Msb;) or, as some say, masc.; (Msb;) but IB cites a verse in which riHom is fem.: (TA:) pl. OaroHaAmN. (MA.) ― -b2- Hence, (Mgh, Msb,) as also riHomN↓ (S, Msb, K) and raHomN↓, (Msb,) (tropical:) Relationship; i. e. nearness of kin; syn. qaraAbapN: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) [by some restricted to relationship by the female side; as will be shown below:] and connexion by birth: (Mgh, Msb:) or relationship connecting with a father or an ancestor: or near relationship: so in the T: (TA:) or a connexion, or tie, of relationship: (A, TA:) or the ties of relationship: (M, K, TA:) accord. to the K, AlrRaHimu signifies AlqaraAbapu or OaSoluhaA and OasobaAbuhaA: but in the M it is said, AlrRaHimu OasobaAbu AlqaraAbapi waOaSoluhaA AlrRaHimu AlRatiI hiIa manobitu Alwaladi; in which waOaSoluhaA forms no part of the explanation of AlrHm, as the author of the K asserts it to do: (TA:) as meaning relationship, rHm is in most instances masc.: (Msb:) pl. as above. (K.) It is said in a holy tradition (Hadiyv qudosiIR [i. e. an inspired or a revealed tradition]) that God said, when He created AlrRaHim [meaning “ relationship, ” &c.], OanaA AlRaHomenu waOanota AlrRaHimu Xaqaqotu Qsomaka mini QsomiI famano waSalaka waSalotuhu wamano qaTaEaka qaTaEotuhu (assumed tropical:) [I am AlrHmen and thou art AlrHm: I have derived thy name from my name: therefore whoso maketh thee close, I will make him close; and who severeth thee, I will sever him]. (TA.) [waSala raHimahu means (assumed tropical:) He made close his tie, or ties, of relationship, by kind behaviour to his kindred: and qaTaEa raHimahu, He severed his tie, or ties, of relationship, by unkind behaviour to his kindred: see art. wSl: and see also balRa raHimahu, in the first paragraph of art. bl; and a verse there cited.] ― -b3- cuw AlrRaHimi means (assumed tropical:) [The possessor of relationship, &c.; i. e.] the contr. of AlOajonabiIRu: (Mgh, Msb:) the pl. cawuw AlOaroHaAmi, [or, as in the Kur viii. last verse, and xxxiii. 6, Ouwluw AlOaroHaAmi,] in the classical language, means any relations: and in law, any relations that have no portion [of the inheritances termed faraAYiD] and are not [such heirs as are designated by the appellation] EaSabap [q. v.]; (KT, TA in art. cw;) [i. e.,] with respect to the faraAYiD, it means the relations by the women's side. (IAth, TA in the present art.) cuw raHimK maHoramK and [some say] muHarRamK [and cuw raHimK maHoramN also (see art. Hrm)] mean (assumed tropical:) A relation whom it is unlawful to marry, [whether male or female, the latter being included with the former, but the female, when particularly meant, is termed caAtu raHimK maHoramK &c.,] such as the mother and the daughter and the sister and the paternal aunt and the maternal aunt [and the male relations of such degrees]: and most of the learned, of the Companions and of the generation following these, and Aboo-Haneefeh and his companions, and Ahmad [Ibn-Hambal], hold that when one possesses a person that is termed cuw raHimK maHoramK, this person becomes emancipated, whether male or female; but Esh-Sháfi'ee and others of the Imáms and of the Companions and of the generation following these hold that the children and the fathers and the mothers become emancipated, and not any others than these. (IAth, TA.) ― -b4- [HaAsRapu raHimK means (assumed tropical:) A feeling of relationship or consanguinity, or sympathy of blood; and in like manner, elliptically, raHimN alone. You say, OaTRato lahu minRiI HaAsRapu raHimK; expl. in art. Hs: and OaTRato lahu raHimiI; and OaTRato bika AlrRaHimu; expl. in art. AT. ― -b5- raHimN is also often used for farojN or HayaMCN, meaning (assumed tropical:) The vulva: see, for exs., XuforN, and 1 in art. ZMr, and 8 in art. HwS.] ＝ -A2- As an epithet, with p, applied to a she-camel: see raHuwmN. ― -b2- And as an epithet without p, applied to a water-skin: see 1, last sentence but one.

ruHumN c
ruHumN: see the next paragraph. ＝ -A2- It is also pl. of raHuwmN. (TA.)

raHomapN c
raHomapN (S, Msb, K) and raHamapN↓ (Sb, K) and ruHomN↓ (S, Msb, K) and ruHumN↓, (S, K,) thus in a verse of Zuheyr, (S, TA,) and thus in the Kur xviii. 80 accord. to the reading of Aboo-'Amr Ibn-El-'Alà, (TA,) and maroHamapN↓, (S, Msb, K,) of which last maraAHimu is pl., (TA,) [all inf. ns.; when used as simple substs. signifying Mercy, pity, or compassion; i. e.] tenderness (S, Msb, K, and Bd on the basomalap) of heart; (Bd ibid.;) and inclination to favour, (S, Msb, K,) or inclination requiring the exercise of favour and beneficence: (Bd ubi suprà:) and pardon, or forgiveness: (K:) accord. to Er-Rághib, raHomapN signifies tenderness requiring the exercise of beneficence towards the object thereof: and it is used sometimes as meaning tenderness divested of any other attribute: and sometimes as meaning beneficence divested of tenderness; as when it is used as an attribute of the Creator: when used as an attribute of men, it means tenderness, and inclination to favour [without necessarily implying beneficence]: accord. to El-Káshánee, it is of two kinds; namely, gratuitous, and obligatory: the former is that which pours forth favours, or benefits, antecedently to works; and this is the rHmp that embraces everything: the obligatory is that which is promised to the pious and the doers of good, in the Kur vii. 155 and vii. 54: but this, he says, is included in the gratuitous, because the promise to bestow it for works is purely gratuitous: accord. to the explanation of the Imám Aboo-Is-hák Ahmad Ibn-Mohammad-Ibn-Ibráheem Eth-Thaalebee, it is God's desire to do good to the deserving thereof; so that it is an essential attribute: or the abstaining from punishing him who deserves punishment, and doing good to him who does not deserve [this]; so that it is an attribute of operation. (TA.) The saying in the Kur [xxi. 75] waOadoxalonaAhu fiI raHomatinaA (tropical:) [And we caused him to enter into our mercy] is tropical: so says IJ. (TA.) ― -b2- waQllRehu yaxotaSRu biraHomatihi mano yaXaMCu, in the Kur [ii. 99 and iii. 67], means (assumed tropical:) [And God distinguishes] with his gift of prophecy [whom He will], or his prophetic office or commission. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- raHomapN also means (assumed tropical:) Sustenance, or the means of subsistence: this is said to be its meaning as used in the Kur xli. 50. (TA.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) Rain: (TA:) so in the Kur vii. 55. (Bd, Jel.) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) Plenty; or abundance of herbage, and of the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life: so in the Kur x. 22 and xxx. 35. (TA.)

raHamapN c
raHamapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

ruHomaI c
ruHomaI [The saying raHimaka QllRehu May God have mercy on thee; &c.;] a subst. from raHRama Ealayohi [like buqoyaA from OaboqaI Ealayohi]. (K.)

raHomaMCu c
raHomaMCu: see raHuwmN.

AlrRaHomenu c
AlrRaHomenu [thus generally written when it has the article Al prefixed to it, but in other cases raHomaAnu, imperfectly decl.,] and AlrRaHiymu↓ are names [or epithets] applied to God: (TA:) [the former, considered as belonging to a large class of words expressive of passion or sensation, such as gaDobaAnu and EaToXaAnu &c., but, being applied to God, as being used tropically, or anthropopathically, may be rendered The Compassionate: ↓the latter, considered as expressive of a constant attribute with somewhat of intensiveness, agreeably with analogy, may be rendered the Merciful: but they are variously explained: it is said that] they are both names [or epithets] formed to denote intensiveness of signification, from raHima; like AlgaDobaAnu from gaDiba, and AlEaliymu from Ealima; and AlrRaHomapu, in the proper language, is “ tenderness of heart, ” and “ inclination requiring the exercise of favour and beneficence; ” but the names of God are only to be taken [or understood] with regard to the ultimate imports, which are actions, exclusively of the primary imports, which may be passions: and the former is more intensive in
signification than the latter; the former including in its objects the believer and the unbeliever, and ↓the latter having for its peculiar object the believer: (Bd on the basomalap:) accord. to J, (TA,) they are two names [or epithets] derived from AlrRaHomapu, and are like nadomaAnu and nadiymN, and are syn.; the repetition being allowable when the [mode of] derivation is different, for the purpose of corroboration: (S, TA:) or the repetition is because the former is Hebrew, [originally ???,] and ↓the latter is Arabic: (I'Ab, TA:) but the former is applicable to God only; though Museylimeh the Liar was called raHomaAnu AlyamaAmapi; (S, TA;) and it is said to mean the Possessor of the utmost degree of AlrRaHomap; and accord. to Zj, is a name of God mentioned in the most ancient books: (TA:) whereas ↓the latter is syn. with AlrRaAHimu↓: (S, TA:) or [rather] raAHimN↓ is the act. part. n. [signifying having mercy, &c.], and raHiymN↓ has an intensive signification [i. e. having much mercy, &c.]: (Msb:) the latter is applied also to a man; and so is raHuwmN↓, in the same sense, and likewise to a woman: (TA:) the pl. of raHiymN↓ is ruHamaMCu; (Msb, TA;) occurring in the trad., UinRamaA yaroHamu QllRehu mino EibaAdihi AlrRuHamaMCa, or AlrRuHamaMCu, as related by different persons; [i. e. God has mercy on the merciful only of his servants, or verily those on whom God has mercy, of his servants, are the merciful;] AlrHmAC being in the accus. case as the objective complement of yrHm, and in the nom. case as the enunciative of mA in the sense of AlRaciI. (Msb.)

raHamuwtN c
raHamuwtN is from raHomapN, [with which it is syn.,] (S, TA,) but it is used only coupled with its like in form: (K, TA:) one says, rahabuwtN xayorN laka mino raHamuwtK [Fear is better for thee than pity, or compassion], meaning thy being feared is better than thy being pitied, or compassionated: (S, K: but in the former, without lk:) or, accord. to Mbr, rahabuwtaI xayorN mino raHamuwtaI↓. (Meyd. [See art. rhb.])

raHamuwtaI c
raHamuwtaI: see what next precedes.

ruHaAmN c
ruHaAmN: see 1, last sentence but two.

raHuwmN c
raHuwmN (Lh, S, K) and raHomaMCu↓, (K,) applied to a she-camel, (Lh, S, TA,) and to a ewe or she-goat, and to a woman, (TA,) [and app. to any animal having a womb, (see raHumato)] Having a complaint of her womb (Lh, S, M, K) after bringing forth, (Lh, S, K,) and dying in consequence thereof; (K;) and raHimapN↓, applied to a she-camel, signifies the same: the pl. of raHuwmN is ruHumN, with two dammehs. (TA.) ― -b2- For the first, see also AlrRaHomenu, near the end of the paragraph.

raHiymu c
raHiymu: see AlrRaHomenu, in seven places. ― -b2- Sometimes it is syn. with maroHuwmN↓ [i. e. Treated, or regarded, with mercy or pity or compassion; &c.: see 1, first sentence]: 'Amelles Ibn-'Akeel says, (using it in this sense, Ham p. 628,)
faOamRaA UicaA EaDRato bika AlHarobu EaDRapF
faUinRaka maEoTuwfN Ealayoka raHiymu
(S, and Ham,) i. e. [But at all events,] when war becomes [once] severe to thee, and thine enemy has almost overcome thee, [verily thou art regarded with favour,] treated with mercy, and defended, by us. (Ham.)

raAHimN c
raAHimN: see AlrRaHomenu, in two places, in the latter half of the paragraph. ― -b2- Also, applied to a ewe, and to a she-goat, Having the womb swollen. (Lh, K.)

OaroHamu c
OaroHamu [More, and most, merciful, &c.]. God is OaroHamu AlrRaAHimyna [The Most Merciful of those that have mercy]. (TA.)

maroHamapN c
maroHamapN: see raHomapN.

muraHRamN c
muraHRamN [Treated, or regarded, with much mercy or pity or compassion; &c.]: it is with teshdeed to denote intensiveness of the signification. (S, TA.) ― -b2- [See also 2, of which it is the pass. part. n.]

maroHuwmN c
maroHuwmN: see raHiymN. ― -b2- AlmaroHuwmapu is a name of El-Medeeneh. (K.) ― -b3- [And AlmaroHuwmu, which may be rendered The object of God's mercy, is commonly used in the present day as an epithet applied to the person, whoever he be, that has died in what is believed to be the true faith; as though meaning merely the deceased.]

1 raHati AlHayRapu c
1. raHati AlHayRapu, (S, K,) aor. taroHuw (S) [and app. taroHaI also (see raHoyapN)]; and trHRt↓; (S, K;) The serpent turned round about, (S, K, TA,) and twisted, or wound, or coiled, itself; ISd adds, kaAlrRaHRI [i. e. like the mill, or millstone]; for which reason it is said to be UiHodRI banaAti TibaqK. (TA.) ＝ -A2- raHawotu AlrRaHaA or AlrRaHaI, (S, K,) inf. n. raHowN; (TA;) and raHayotuhaA, (S, K,) inf. n. raHoIN; (TA;) I turned round the rHA or rHI [i. e. the mill, or mill-stone]: (S, K:) or I made it: (K:) in the K, the latter verb is said to be extr.; but not so in the T or S or M: in the M it is said to be the more common. (TA.) ＝ -A3- And raHaAhu He magnified him, or honoured him. (IAar, TA.)

5 ta1a2RaRa
5: see above, first sentence.

raHoyapN c
raHoyapN [or HayRapN raHoyapN meaning A serpent folding, or coiling, itself, so as to resemble a neck-ring]: see raHRapN, in art. rH.

raHaMCN c
raHaMCN: see raHFy, first sentence.

ruHayRapN c
ruHayRapN dim. of raHFy, q. v. (Zj, Msb.)

qaSoEapN raHRaMCu c
qaSoEapN raHRaMCu A shallow, or a wide, [bowl such as is termed] qSEp. (TA. [It is there mentioned in art. rHw, but belongs to art. rH q. v.])

maroHFy c
maroHFy A place of a mill or mill-stone. (MA.) ― -b2- See also raHFy (near the end of the paragraph), in two places. ― -b3- [Accord. to Freytag, it occurs in the Deewán of the Hudhalees as meaning (assumed tropical:) A place where any one stands firmly.]

muraHK c
muraHK A maker of mills or mill-stones. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- And Moisture in the ground to the extent of a palm. (AHn, TA.)

1 raxRa c
1. raxRa, aor.
raxixa
, inf. n. raxRu, said of dough, It had in it much water [so that it was soft: see also 8]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- raxRahu, (JK, T, K,) aor.
raxuxa
, (JK,) inf. n. as above, (TK,) He broke it, or crushed it, (JK, T,) and so made it soft: (T:) or he trod upon it, (T, K,) and so made it soft. (T.) ― -b2- Also He mixed (JK, S, K) what is termed nabiyc, (JK,) or wine, or beverage: (S, K:) and likewise food with condiment. (JK.)

4 ArxRhu c
4. ArxRhu He put much water into it [so as to make it soft]; namely, dough. (TA.) ＝ -A2- [The inf. n.] UiroxaAxN also signifies The exceeding the usual, or ordinary, or the just, or proper, bounds, or degree; or the acting egregiously, or immoderately; or the like; (syn. mubaAlagapN;) in a thing. (K.)

8 ArtxR c
8. ArtxR, (IAar, TA,) inf. n. AirotixaAxN, (IAar, K, TA,) for which, in some copies of the K, is put AstrxAx, but the former is the right reading, (TA,) said of dough, (IAar, TA,) It was, or became, soft, or flaccid. (IAar, K, TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) It (one's opinion) was, or became, unsound, faulty, or confused; syn. AiDoTaraba. (K, TA.)

raxRN c
raxRN [Lax, or flaccid: (Golius, on the authority or Meyd:) or soft]: see its fem., raxRapN, voce raxaAxN.

ruxRN c
ruxRN A certain soft, flaccid, or fragile, plant; (AHn, S, K;) as also raxaAxN↓, with fet-h, (mentioned by ISd,) or rixaAxN↓. (So in the JK.) ＝ -A2- Also A certain great bird, that carries off the karokadRan [or rhinoceros]. (K. [See note 22 to ch. xx. of my translation of the “ Thousand and One Nights. ” The word is of Persian origin, arabicized; as it is said to be by Lth in the sense next following.]) ― -b2- And hence, as being likened thereto, (TA,) One of the pieces with which the game of chess is played; [called by us the rook, castle, and tower:] pl. rixaxapN, (K,) or rixaAxN (JK, A,) or both. (TA.)

raxaAxN c
raxaAxN [app., in its primary acceptation, Softness of a substance, such as earth &c.: and hence,] softness, delicateness, or easiness, of life. (JK, TA.) ― -b2- It is also used as an epithet. (TA.) You say OaroDN raxaAxN Soft land, of which the soil is good; as also raxRapN↓: pl. raxaAYixu: (JK:) or wide and soft land, whether level or not level: (ISh:) or soft, or yielding, land: (S, K, TA:) and raxRaMCu↓, (K, TA,) with teshdeed and medd, (TA,) [in the CK raxAC, without teshdeed,] signifies the like: (IAar, K:) or this last (rxRMC), wide land: (K:) or tumid land or earth, that breaks in pieces beneath the tread: and its pl. is raxaAxayRu. (JK, K.) And raxaAxu AlvRaray What is soft of soil, or of moist earth. (TA.) And EayoXN raxaAxN A life, or state of life, that is ample, unstraitened, or easy, (S, K, TA,) and soft. (TA.) ― -b3- See also ruxRN.

rixaAxN c
rixaAxN: see ruxRN.

raxiyxN c
raxiyxN: see raxoraxN.

raxRaMCu c
raxRaMCu: see raxaAxN.

raxoraxN c
raxoraxN and raxoraAxN↓, applied to mud, or clay, (JK, K,) and to dough, (JK,) Thin, and soft: (JK, K, TA:) and raxiyxN↓ soft, or moist, mud or clay. (KL.)

raxoraAxN c
raxoraAxN: see the next preceding paragraph.

muraxoraxu Alxaloqi c
muraxoraxu Alxaloqi, applied to a man, and to a camel, Lax, or not firm, in make, by reason of fatness. (JK.)

sakoraAnu murotaxRN c
sakoraAnu murotaxRN Intoxicated, full of drink; (K;) as also mulotaxRN. (TA.)

mutaraxorixN c
mutaraxorixN, applied to a man, and to a camel, Flaccid, or flabby, by reason of old age or of emaciation. (JK.)

1 raxuSa c
1. raxuSa, aor.
raxuSa
, inf. n. ruxoSN, It (a thing, Msb, or a price, S, A) was, or became, cheap, low-priced, or low. (S, A, Msb, K, TA.) [Accord. to all of these authorities, this seems to be the primary signification: but Et-Tebreezee (Ham p. 47) thinks it to be from raxoSapN applied to a woman, as meaning “ soft, or tender. ”] Some say raxaSa also; but this is not of established authority. (MF.) ― -b2- raxuSa, aor.
raxuSa
, (M, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. raxaASapN (S, M, A, Msb, K) and ruxuwSapN (S, M, Msb, K) and ruxoSaAnu, (Lth, TA,) It (a thing, K, or the body, S, Msb, or flesh, A) was, or became, soft, or tender; (S, M, A, Msb, K, TA;) and soft to the feel: (Msb:) and in like manner raxuSato said of a girl: (A:) or, said of a woman, inf. n. ruxoSaAnN, she was, or became, soft, or tender, and delicate, or thin, in her external skin: and said of a woman's fingers, they were, or became, soft, or tender: but when said of a plant, inf. n. raxaASapN, it was, or became, soft, flaccid, or easily or quickly broken: (Lth:) [and said of a twig, or rod, it was, or became, fresh, or succulent, and soft, or tender: see raxoSN.]

2 ruxiSa lahu fiy kacaA c
2. ruxiSa lahu fiy kacaA, inf. n. taroxiySN, He had indulgence, license, or facilitation, granted, or conceded, to him in, or with respect to, such a thing. (S, A, * K *) You say, raxRaSa AlXRaroEu lanaA fiy kacaA, inf. n. as above, The law has been indulgent to us in, or with respect to, such a thing; has facilitated it to us; as also ArxS↓, inf. n. UiroxaASN. (Msb.) And raxRaSotu fulaAnAF fiy kacaA wa kacaA, [or, more commonly, lifulaAnK,] I gave license, or permission, to such a one to do such and such things after my forbidding him to do them. (TA.)

4 ArxShu c
4. ArxShu He (God, S, A, Msb, or a man, JK) made it (a thing, Msb, or a price, S, A) cheap, low-priced, or low. (JK, S, A, Msb, K.) raxRaSahu, in this sense, is not known. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also He found it to be cheap, low-priced, or low. (K.) ― -b3- Also, (K,) or ArtxShu↓, (S, A,) He bought it cheap, or at a low price. (S, A, K.) ― -b4- See also 2.

5 trxRS c
5. trxRS He took, or availed himself of, or allowed himself, indulgence, license, or facilitation; (A, TA;) he did not go to the utmost length; (S, Msb, K;) [he relaxed, or remitted;] in (fiy) such a thing; (S;) in affairs; (A;) or in the affair. (Msb.) You say also, trxRS fiy Haqihi He took what was easily attainable, of his right, or due, and did not go to the utmost length. (A.)

8 ArtxShu c
8. ArtxShu: see 4. ― -b2- Also, (S, Sgh, K,) or AstrxShu↓, (A,) He reckoned it cheap, or lowpriced: (S, A, Sgh, K:) and ↓the latter, he saw it, or judged it, to be so. (Lth, K.)

10 AstrxShu c
10. AstrxShu: see 8, in two places.

raxoSN c
raxoSN applied to a thing, (A, K,) or to the body, (S, Msb,) and to flesh, and to a plant, (A,) Soft, or tender; (S, M, A, Msb, K;) and soft to the feel: (Msb:) and raxiySN↓ signifies the same, (AA, M, K,) applied to a garment, or piece of cloth, (AA, K,) as also the former: (TA:) fem. of each with p: (M, TA:) raxoSpN is also applied to a girl, (A,) and to a woman, (K, TA, but omitted in the CK,) and to fingers, signifying not rigid or tough: (K:) or, applied to a woman, it signifies soft, or tender, and delicate, or thin, in her external skin: and applied to a woman's fingers, soft, or tender: but raxoSN applied to a plant, soft, flaccid, or easily or quickly broken: (Lth, TA:) and applied to a twig, or rod, fresh, or succulent, and soft, or tender: (Msb:) the pl.
of raxoSN is rixaASN: (Msb:) and that of raxoSapN is raxaAYiSu, which is irreg. [as such, but reg. as pl. of raxiySapN↓]; (K, TA;) occurring in poetry. (TA.) You say, huwa raxoSu Aljasadi He is soft, or tender, in body. (S.) And AimoraOapN raxoSapu Albadani A woman soft, or tender, in body. (IDrd, TA.)

ruxoSN c
ruxoSN [see 1, of which it is the inf. n., in the first of the senses explained above. ― -b2- Also The act of making cheap;] a subst. from OaroxaSahu in the first of the senses here assigned thereto. (Msb.)

ruxoSapN c
ruxoSapN (S, A, Msb, K) and ruxuSapN (A, Msb, K) Indulgence, license or facilitation; (S, A, Msb, K;) in an affair: (S, A, Msb:) pl. ruxaSN (A, Msb) and ruxoSaAtN and ruxaSaAtN and ruxuSaAtN. (Msb.) You say, laka fiI hecaA ruxoSapN [Thou hast, or shalt have, in, or with respect to, this, indulgence, license, or facilitation]. (A.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Indulgence granted, or conceded, by God to his servant, in a matter which He alleviates to him. (A, K.) ― -b3- [(assumed tropical:) An ordinance of indulgence; such as the shortening of prayer in travelling, and the like: pl. ruxaSN, of which we have an ex. in the following trad.:] AallRehu yuHibRu Oano tuWotaI ruxaSuhu kamaA yuHibRu Oano tuWotaI EazaAYimuhu [(assumed tropical:) God loveth that his ordinances of indulgence be performed, like as He loveth that his obligatory ordinances be performed]. (A.) ― -b4- (tropical:) A portion, or share, of water: (A:) or a time, or turn, in drinking. (K.)

raxiySN c
raxiySN A cheap, or low-priced, thing; (Msb;) a low price. (S, A.) ＝ -A2- (tropical:) A quick death. (Lth, A, K.) ＝ -A3- See also raxoSN, in two places. ― -b2- (tropical:) Soft, without strength or sturdiness, and without endurance: or stupid, dull, wanting in intelligence; syn. baliydN. (TA.)

rixolN c
rixolN A ewe-lamb; (S, K;) as also rixolapN↓ and raxilN↓: (K:) the male is called HamalN: (S:) pl. [of pauc.] OaroxulN (K) and [of mult.] rixaAlN and ruxaAlN (S, K,) which last is of an extr. form, (TA,) and rixolaAnN and raxalapN and rixalapN. (K.)

raxilN c
raxilN: see the preceding paragraph.

rixolapN c
rixolapN: see the preceding paragraph.

mutaraxRilN c
mutaraxRilN A possessor and rearer of ewe-lambs. (S.)

1 raxuma c
1. raxuma, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
raxuma
, (K,) inf.n. raxaAmapN; (S, Msb;) and raxama aor.
raxuma
; (K;) It (the voice, S, TA, and speech, K, TA) was, or became, soft, or gentle, and easy: (S, * K, TA:) [or it (the voice) was, or became, soft, or gentle, plaintive, and melodious: (see raxiymN:)] it (a thing, and the speech,) was, or became, easy: (Msb:) raxaAmap in speech is a good quality in women. (TA.) One says also of a girl, raxumato, (K, TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) meaning She was, or became, easy [and soft or gentle] in speech: (K, TA:) and in like manner, of a [young gazelle such as is termed] xiXof [meaning in voice, or cry]: and raxamato, said of a she-gazelle, means she uttered a [soft or gentle] cry. (TA.) ＝ -A2- raxamato bayoDahaA and EalaI bayoDihaA: see 4. ― -b2- [Hence, perhaps,] raxamato waladahaA, aor.
raxuma
and
raxama
, (assumed tropical:) She (a woman) played with her child: (K:) [or,] accord. to the “ Nawá- dir el-Aaráb, ” trxm SabiyRahaA and trxm Ealayohi, [app. taroxumu and taroxamu in both cases,] said of a woman, mean taroHamuhu (tropical:) [She treats, or regards, her boy with mercy, pity, or compassion; &c.]: (TA:) and raxamotu AlXRaIoCa means raHimotuhu (tropical:) [I treated, or regarded, the thing with mercy, &c.]: (K, TA:) AZ says that raximahu, aor.
raxama
, inf. n. raxamapN, and raHimahu, aor.
raxama
, inf. n. raHomapN, are syn.: (S:) and he says that raxama [thus accord. to the TA] is of the dial. of some of the people of El-Yemen: it is tropical: Lh, also, mentions raxamahu, aor.
raxama
, inf. n. rxamapN, as meaning (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, inclined to favour him, or affectionate to him. (TA.) ＝ -A3- raxima, said of a skin for water or milk, It was, or became, stinking. (TA.)

2 rxRmh c
2. rxRmh, (Msb,) inf. n. taroxiymN, (S, Msb, TA,) He made it soft, or gentle: (S, TA:) or he made it easy: namely, [the voice, (see 1,) or] speech. (Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, (Msb, K,*) or from AltRaroxiymu signifying, as some say, The cutting off [a thing], or cutting [it] at its extremity, or curtailing [it], (S,) the taroxiym of the name, (S, Msb, K,) in the vocative form of speech; (S;) [accord. to general opinion,] because it facilitates the pronunciation thereof; (K;) i. e. the [abbreviating by the] eliding of the end thereof, for the alleviation of the utterance; (Msb;) the curtailing a name of its last letter, or more; (S, TA;) as when, to one whose name is HaArivN or maAlikN, you say yaA HaAri or yaAmaAli: but accord. to Z, in the A, it is from the trxym of the hen; because this is only on the occasion of the cutting short (qaToE) [of the laying] of the eggs: (TA:) [in like manner also] the taroxiym of the diminutive is the [abbreviating thereof by the] cutting off of [one or more of] the augmentative letters [and sometimes of radical letters]; as when, in forming the diminutive of Oasowadu [and that of UiboraAhiymu], one says suwayodN [and burayohu]. (Har p. 334.) ― -b3- rxRm AldRajaAjapa, inf. n. as above, He made the hen to cleave to, or keep to, [or brood upon,] her eggs [for the purpose of hatching them]. (M, K.) ＝ -A2- [rxRm also signifies He constructed, or cased, a building, or a floor &c., with ruxaAm: but this is perhaps post-classical.]

4 Arxmt EalaI bayoDihaA c
4. Arxmt EalaI bayoDihaA; (S, K;) or Arxmt alone; (JK;) and bayoDahaA raxamato↓, and EalaI bayoDihaA, (K,) aor.
raxuma
, (TA,) inf. n. raxomN and raxamN and raxamapN; (K;) She (a domestic hen, JK, S, K, and an ostrich, JK, TA) brooded upon her eggs, to hatch them. (JK, S, K.)

8 Artxmt faSiylahaA c
8. Artxmt faSiylahaA (assumed tropical:) She (a camel) loved, affected, or inclined to, and kept to, or clave to, her young one. (TA.)

raxamN c
raxamN (assumed tropical:) Favour, or affection; or mercy, pity, or compassion: and love: and gentleness; (K, TA;) as also raxamapN↓ [which appears to be the more common, and which is mentioned above as an inf. n]: (S, K,* TA:) the latter is nearly the same as raHomapN. (S.) One says, waqaEato Ealayohi raxamatuhu↓ (assumed tropical:) His love, and his gentleness, fell, or lighted, upon him. (S.) And OaloqaI Ealayohi raxamatahu↓ and raxamahu, (K, TA,) i. e. (assumed tropical:) [He made to fall, or light, upon him, or bestowed upon him,] his love, and his gentleness: this is said of God. (TA.) And Oaloqato Ealayohi raxamahaA and raxamatahaA↓ i. e. (assumed tropical:) [She made to fall, or light, upon him, or bestowed upon him,] her favour, or affection, or her mercy, pity, or compassion. (TA.) And OumRihi Ouloqiyato Ealayohi raxamapu↓, i. e. (assumed tropical:) [upon whom] the love and familiarity of his mother [have been made to fall or light, or have been bestowed], is an explanation given by As of the pass. part. n. maroxuwmN↓. (S, TA.) [But accord. to Z, these significations are from raxamapN as signifying a bird of a certain species described in what follows: for] it is said in the A that OaloqaI Ealayohi raxamapF↓ means (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, affectionate, or pitiful, or compassionate, to him, and attached to him: because the raxamap is vehemently voracious, and fond of alighting upon carcasses: therefore love and affection lighting upon one are likened thereto. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A certain [species of] bird, well known; [the vultur percnopterus; being for the most part white, called by some the white carrion-vulture of Egypt and the neighbouring countries; and also called Pharaoh's hen; in Hebr. ???: (see Bochart, Hieroz., 297-322:)] n. un. raxamapN↓: (K:) the former is the pl. of the latter, (S, Msb,) denoting the genus, (S,) [i. e., its coll. gen. n.,] like as qaSabN is of qaSabapN: (Msb:) the pl. [properly so termed] of raxamapN is ruxomN [like as budonN is of badanapN, or perhaps of raxamN, like as OusodN is of OasadN,] (JK, TA) and also ruxamN↓ [which is anomalous]: (JK:) the raxamap↓ is a partycoloured bird, white and black, (S, TA,) resembling the nasor (JK, S, TA) in form; and also called OanuwqN: (S, TA:) [it is said to be] a bird that eats human dung, a foul bird, not of such as are pursued as game, wherefore no expiation is incumbent on him who kills it when he is in the state of UiHoraAm, for it is not eaten: it is [said to be] thus called because it is too weak to take prey: (Msb:) [various fanciful uses of its gall-bladder and flesh &c. for medicinal and other purposes are described in the K: accord. to some, if not all, it is a term for the female: (see OanuwqN:)] the male is called yaroxumN↓ and yaroxuwmN↓ (JK, K) and taroxuwmN↓. (Kr, K.) ＝ -A3- Also Thick milk. (IAar, K.) ＝ -A4- The raxamap↓ [as written in the JK, but in the TA without any syll. signs,] of the horse is like the rabolap [app. as meaning The inner part of the thigh] of a human being: (JK, TA:) one says, farasN naAtiICu Alrxmpi [A horse having the rxmp protuberant]. (TA.) [If correctly written in the JK, it is probably a n. un. of which raxamN is the coll. gen. n.: and hence, perhaps,] warohaMCu AlrRaxami, applied by the poet ' Amr Dhu-l-Kelb to a ewe abounding with milk, as meaning Soft [in the raxam, and app. protuberant therein, and by reason
thereof, and of the largeness of her udder, waddling,] as though she were mad, or possessed. (TA.)

ruxamN c
ruxamN a pl. of raxamapN q. v. [n. un. of raxamN; like

ruxomN c
ruxomN, but anomalous]. (JK.)

ruxumN c
ruxumN Lumps of biestings. (IAar, K.)

ruxomapN c
ruxomapN, with damm, (TA, [analogously with the generality of words of similar meaning, but this fact may have occasioned some writer's adding “ with damm, ”] or raxamapN↓, (so in the JK, [if correct, app., as being likened to a white vulture,]) A whiteness in the head of a ewe or she-goat: (JK, TA:) and a dust-colour in her face, the rest of her being of any colour. (TA.)

raxamapN c
raxamapN: see raxamN, in nine places: ― -b2- and see also ruxomapN.

raxomaAnu c
raxomaAnu i. q. raHomaAnu. (TA.)

ruxaAmN c
ruxaAmN [commonly applied to Marble: and sometimes to alabaster: the latter application is the more agreeable with the following explanation:] a certain white, soft stone: (JK, S, Mgh, K, TA:) what is of the colour of wine, or yellow, or dappled, is of the kinds of stones, (K, TA,) i. e., not [a sort] of ruxaAm: (TA:) a well-known kind of stone: (Msb:) n. un. with p [meaning a piece, or slab, &c., thereof]. (Mgh, Msb.) [See also maromarN.]

raxiymN c
raxiymN, applied to speech, (S, Msb, K,) &c., (Msb,) Soft, or gentle, and easy: (S,* K:) or [simply] easy: (Msb:) and, applied to the voice, soft, or gentle, plaintive, and melodious. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, applied to a girl, (K,) and so raxiymapN, (As, JK, K,) Easy [and soft or gentle] in speech: (As, K:) and in like manner, AlSRawoti muroxuwampu↓ [a girl soft, or gentle, &c., in voice]: (JK:) and in like manner also the first and second are applied to a [young gazelle such as is termed] xiXof. (TA.) ― -b3- raxiymu AlHawaAXiI Gentle, gracious, or courteous, to his associates. (TA.)

ruxaAmapN c
ruxaAmapN n. an. of ruxaAmN [q. v.]. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- Also A certain plant. (AHn, K.)

ruxaAmaI c
ruxaAmaI A certain plant, (AHn, K,) different from the xDrp [app. xaDirap, with which some probably identify it], having a blossom of a pure white, and a white root, which the [wild] asses dig up with their hoofs, and all the wild animals eat because of its sweetness and pleasantness; and its places of growth are the sands: (AHn, TA:) or, as some say, (TA,) a kind of tree like the DaAl [q. v.]. (S, TA.) [See also rayRiHapN, in art. rwH.] ＝ -A2- Also [or riyHN ruxaAmaI] A soft, or gentle, wind. (K.)

raAximN c
raAximN: see muroximN. ― -b2- UinRahu laraAximN lahu Verily he is inclined to favour him; or is affectionate to him. (Lh, TA.)

Oaroxamu c
Oaroxamu, applied to a horse, and the fem. raxomaMCu applied to a ewe or she-goat, Whose head is white, the rest being black: (S, K:) the latter like muxamRarapN: one should not say muraxRamapN: (S:) or the former, a horse whose face is white: (Mgh:) and the latter, a ewe, or she-goat, having a whiteness on her head. (JK.)

maA OadoriI OaIRu turoxamK huwa c
maA OadoriI OaIRu turoxamK huwa (JK, S, K) and turoxama (JK, K, TA, but not in the CK) and turoxumK (S, K) and turoxuma (K, TA, but not in the CK) and, accord. to the M, taroxum, (TA,) and turoxamapa↓, (accord. to the JK,) or turoxamapK, and turoxumapK, (K,) I know not who of mankind he is. (JK, S, K.)

muroximN c
muroximN (JK, S, K) and muroximapN (S, TA) and raAximN↓ (K) A domestic hen, (JK, S, K,) and an ostrich, (JK,) Brooding upon eggs, for the purpose of hatching. (JK, S, K.)

yaroxumN c
yaroxumN: see raxamN, in the latter part of the paragraph.

turoxamapu c
turoxamapu [or turoxamapN and turoxumapN] i. q. turoxamN and turoxamu [&c.]. (JK.)

taroxuwmN c
taroxuwmN: see raxamN, in the latter part of the paragraph.

maroxuwmN c
maroxuwmN: see raxamN, in the former half of the paragraph. ― -b2- maroxuwmapu AlSRawoti: see raxiymN.

yaroxuwmN c
yaroxuwmN: see raxamN, in the latter part of the paragraph.

1 raxuwa c
1. raxuwa, aor. yaroxuw; and raxiIa, aor. yaroxaI; (S, M, Msb, K;) inf. n. raxaAwapN (M, Msb, K) and raxaMCN, (M, K, but in several copies of the latter raxFA,) or this is a simple subst., (Msb,) and rixowapN, with kesr, (M, K,) which is extr., (M,) and some add ruxowapN, and raxowapN; (MF, TA;) It (a thing, S) was, or became, soft, yielding, flaccid, flabby, lax, slack, uncompact, crummy, fragile, frangible, brittle, friable, easily or quickly broken; i. q. SaAra rixowFA, (S, K, TA,) i. e. haXRaA; (TA;) or laAna; (Msb;) and AstrxI↓ signifies the same. (S,* K.) ― -b2- And raxuwa, and raxiIa, (Msb, K,) and [raxaA] like daEaA [of which the aor. is yadoEuw], and [raxaA] like raEaI [of which the aor. is yaroEaI; in the CK, erroneously, like ruEiIa]; (K, TA;) the aor. [or the first and third] being yaroxuw and [that of the second and fourth being] yaroxaI; (TA;) said of life (EayoX), (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, ample, unstraitened, or plentiful, in its means, or circumstances: (Msb, K: *) or said of a man, inf. n. raxaMCN, (assumed tropical:) he was, or became, in an ample, an unstraitened, or a plentiful, state of life. (TK.)

2 taroxiyapu AlXRaIoCi biAlXRaIoCi c
2. taroxiyapu AlXRaIoCi biAlXRaIoCi The mixing of the thing with the thing. (TA.) [The verb is raxRaI, He mixed; like raxRa, which is mentioned in this sense in the present art. in the JK, app. for raxRaI.]

3 rAxAhu c
3. rAxAhu: see 4, in three places. ― -b2- Also, inf. n. muraAxaApN, i. q. baAEadahu [He was, or became, distant, remote, &c., from him: or he made, or caused, him, or it, to be, or become, distant, remote, &c.]. (K.) ＝ -A2- And rAxt She (a woman, TA) was, or became, near to bringing forth. (K, TA.)

4 ArxAhu c
4. ArxAhu He made it, or rendered it, soft, yielding, flaccid, flabby, lax, slack, uncompact, crummy, fragile, frangible, brittle, friable, easily or quickly broken; i. q. jaEalahu rixowFA; as also rAxAhu↓. (K.) You say, ArxI AlrRibaATa [He relaxed, or slackened, the tie, or bond]; (M, TA;) and rAxAhu↓, inf. n. muraAxaApN. (JK, TA.) And lahu mino xinaAqihi raAxi↓ [lit, Relax thou, or slacken thou, his cord with which he is being strangled]; meaning (assumed tropical:) make thou his circumstances ample and easy to him; ease him; relieve him; or grant him a delay. (TA. [See a similar phrase in art. rbw, conj. 2.]) And Oaroxi lahu qayodahu Make thou his shackle, or shackles, wide, or ample, not strait, to him. (TA.) And Oaroxi lahu AlHabola [lit. Relax thou, or slacken thou, to him the rope]; meaning (tropical:) give thou to him ample scope for using his own judgment, or discretion, in the disposal, or management, of his affairs, so that he may go whither he pleases. (TA.) And ArxI Alfarasa and lilofarasi He lengthened the horse's rope. (K.) And ArxI lahu AlTRiwala [lit. He relaxed, or slackened, his tether]; meaning (tropical:) he left him to his own affair. (A, TA.) And ArxI EimaAmatahu [lit. He slackened, or loosened, his turban]; meaning (assumed tropical:) he became, or felt, in a state of security or safety, tranquil, or at ease; (K, TA;) because the turbans are not slackened, or loosened, (laA turoxaI,) in difficulty, or hardship. (TA.) And ArxI AlsRitori (S, Msb, K) wagayorahu (S) He let loose, let down, or lowered, the veil, or curtain, &c. (S, K.) And ArxI viyaAbahu EalaI rijolayohi [He let, or made, his clothes hang down loosely upon his legs] in riding and in sitting [&c.]. (TA in art. rsl.) [And ArxI dumuwEFA (assumed tropical:) He shed tears.] And ArxAhu xaTobuhu (tropical:) His state, or condition, made him to enjoy an easy, ample, or unstraitened, life, or a life of ease and plenty. (T, TA.) ― -b2- Arxt, said of a she-camel, [app. for Arxt SalaAhaA, i. e. She relaxed the part on either side of her tail, virtually] means SalaAhaA AisotaroxaI↓, (S, K, TA,) i. e. [the part on either side of her tail became relaxed; or] her SalawaAni [or parts on the right and left of her tail] gaped, [or receded from each other,] on the occasion of bringing forth. (T, TA.) ― -b3- UiroxaMCN also signifies A sort of running: (S:) or vehement running: (K:) or running exceeding what is termed taqoriybN: (JK, K: [see 2 in art. qrb:]) or running (HuDorN) that is not ardent, or not impetuous: (A, TA:) or gentleness in running: (Ham p. 158:) accord. to Az, AlUiroxaMCu AlOaEolaI means The most vehement [running termed] HuSor; and AlUiroxaMCu AlOadonaI is less than that: and ArxI fiI Eadowihi, said of a horse, signifies OaHoDara [app. as meaning He rose in his running]; and is from ruxaMCN as an epithet applied to wind. (TA.) ― -b4- You say also, ArxI daAbRatahu, meaning He made his beast to go the pace, or in the manner, termed UiroxaMC, explained above: (Lth, K:) [or,] accord. to A 'Obeyd, AlUiroxaMCu signifies the leaving a horse to follow his own eager desire in running, without fatiguing him. (S.)

6 trAxI c
6. trAxI He (a horse) remitted, or flagged, in his running; or was, or became, remiss, or
languid, therein. (Az, TA.) And [in like manner] fiI AlOamori AstrxI↓ [He remitted, or flagged, in the affair; or was, or became, remiss, or languid, therein]. (K in arts. bnX and fnX, &c.) And trAxI Eano HaAjatihi He remitted, or flagged, in the accomplishment of his want; or he was, or became, remiss, or languid, therein. (TA.) ― -b2- He drew back, held back, or hung back, (JK, K, TA,) EanRiI from me, (TA,) or Eani AlXRaIoCa from the thing. (JK.) ― -b3- He was, or became, slow, sluggish, tardy, dilatory, late, or backward. (JK, TA.) You say also, trAxI AlsRamaMCu The rain delayed; or was tardy, late, or backward. (S, K.) [And trAxI Alwaqotu The time was, or became, late: and it became protracted. And trAxI Eanohu It was, or became, after, or later than, it: see mutaraAxK, below.] And trAxI AlOamoru The affair, or case, was, or became, protracted; the time thereof became extended. (Msb.) And fiI AlOamori taraAxK In the affair, or case, is ample time or scope [for action &c.]; syn. fusoHapN; (Msb, TA;) and extension, or protractedness: (TA:) or remoteness; referring to the case of the resurrection, i. e. the time thereof. (Mgh in art. ntj.)

10 AstrxI c
10. AstrxI: see 1, first sentence. AstrxI SalaAhaA, said of a she-camel: see 4, in the latter half of the paragraph. AstrxI AlsRitoru [The veil, or curtain, hung down; hung down loosely; was pendent, or pendulous: and in like manner the verb is said of a garment, or a portion thereof, and of hair, or a lock of hair, &c.]. (Msb.) ― -b2- AstrxI fiI AlOamori: see 6. AstrxI fiI raOoyihi baEoda quwRapK (assumed tropical:) [He was, or became, weak in his opinion after being strong]. (IAar, TA in art. xrE.) ― -b3- AstrxI bihi AlOamoru, (JK, T, TA,) and Astrxt HaAluhu, (JK,) or Astrxt bihi HaAluhu, (T, TA,) (assumed tropical:) The affair, or case, and his state, or condition, became good with him after straitness; (JK;) or (tropical:) he became in a good state, or condition, (T, TA,) in ample, unstraitened, or plentiful, circumstances, (TA in explanation of the first of these phrases,) after straitness. (T, TA.) A poet says, (S,) namely, Tufeyl El-Ghanawee, (TA,)
faOabRala waQsotaroxaI bihi AlxaTobu baEodamaA
OasaAfa walawolaA saEoyunaA lamo yuWabRili
meaning (tropical:) [And he acquired camels, or numerous camels, and] his state, or condition, became good [after his cattle had perished; and had it not been for our labour, or exertion, he would not have acquired camels, or numerous camels]: (S, TA:) or the phrase AstrxI bh AlxTb means OaroxaAhu xaTobuhu [explained above: see 4]. (T, TA.)

rixowN c
rixowN and raxowN (Lth, S, M, Msb, K) and ruxowN; (M, Msb, K;) but accord. to As and Fr, the first is that which is approved, (TA,) or, accord. to Az, it is that used by the Arabs; (Msb;) the second, accord. to As and Fr (TA) and Az, (Msb,) being post-classical; (Msb, TA;) and the third is of the dial. of the Kilábees; (Msb;) applied to a thing (S, K) of any kind, (K,) Soft, yielding, flaccid, flabby, lax, slack, uncompact, crummy, fragile, frangible, brittle, friable, easily or quickly broken; syn. haXRu; (S, K;) or layRanN saholN; (Msb;) [and musotaroxK↓ signifies the same, as is shown by the explanation of its verb in the first sentence of this art.:] the fem. is with p, i. e. rixowapN and raxowapN and ruxowapN (K) [and musotaroxiyapN]. You say HajarN rixowN or raxowN or ruxowN A stone that is soft, yielding, &c. (Msb.) ― -b2- And farasN rixowapN A mare that is easy, and gentle, moderate, deliberate, or leisurely, in pace. (S.) And farasN rixowu AlEinaAni A horse that is easy to be led, or tractable. (A, TA.) The phrase fahiIa rixowN is used in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb instead of fhI rixowapN because meaning fahiIa XaIoCN rixowN. (S.) ― -b3- AlHuruwfu AlrRixowapu [which may be rendered The lax letters] is said in the K, by an anticipation of the pen, to be applied to the letters exclusive of those comprised in the phrase lamo yuroEuwnaA [for which some say lamo yarowi EanRaA]: Sgh says [correctly] that they are the letters exclusive of those termed AlXRadiydapu and of those in the phrase lm yrEwnA: as is said in the M, they are thirteen; namely, v,H,x,c,z,s,X,S,D,Z,g,f, and h; [to which De Sacy adds, in his Grammar, (2nd ed. i. 29,) A without C, and w and I, which are generally included in an intermediate class between the Xdydp and the rxwp, namely, in the class consisting of the letters in the phrase lm yrEwnA or lm yrw EnRA:] the letter termed rixowN is that in which the sound runs on, as it does, for instance, in the s and X when you say AlmasR and AlrRaXR. (TA.)

ruxowapN c
ruxowapN: see what next follows.

rixowapN c
rixowapN an inf. n. of 1: (M, K:) i. q. AisotiroxaMCN [i. e. Softness, yieldingness, flaccidity, &c.: see 1, first sentence]; as also ruxowapN↓: you say, fiyhi rixowapN and ruxowapN [In him, or it, is softness, &c.]. (K.) ― -b2- See also what next follows.

raxaMCN c
raxaMCN [said by some to be an inf. n. of 1] Ampleness, or freedom from straitness, of the means, or circumstances, of life; (JK, S, Msb, K;) [and so raxaMCu AlbaAli;] as also rixowapN↓. (JK.) raxaMCu AlnRafosi (assumed tropical:) [An easy, or unstraitened, state of mind]. (S in art. bwl.)

ruxaMCN c
ruxaMCN A soft, or gentle, wind: (S, K:) or a soft, or gentle, and quick, wind: (JK:) or a soft, or gentle, wind, that does not move anything. (Har p. 38.) It has the first of these meanings in the Kur xxxviii. 35: (Bd, Jel:) or it there means A wind that does not oppose, or contravene, the will of God. (Bd.)

raxiIRN c
raxiIRN (Msb, K) and raAxK↓, (K,) applied to life (EayoX, Msb, K), (assumed tropical:) Ample, unstraitened, or plentiful, in its means, or circumstances: (Msb, K:) or both applied to a man, (assumed tropical:) in an ample, an unstraitened, or a plentiful, state of life. (TK.) You say, UinRahu lafiI EayoXK raxiIRK (assumed tropical:) [Verily he is in an ample, an unstraitened, or a plentiful, state of life]. (TA.) And huwa raxiIRu AlbaAli (JK, S, Msb, TA) and AlbaAli raAxiI↓ (JK) (assumed tropical:) He is in an ample, or unstraitened, (S,) or an easy, or a pleasant, and a plentiful, state, or condition. (JK, S, * Msb, TA. * [See also other explanations in art. bwl.]) And UinRa celika AlOamoru layacohabu minRiI fiI baAlK raxiIK [Verily that affair passes away from me, I being in an easy state of mind,] is said when you are not disquieted, rendered anxious, or grieved, by the affair. (TA.)

raAxK c
raAxK, and raAxiI: see the next preceding paragraph.

OaroxaI c
OaroxaI [as meaning More relaxing or slackening or loosening] is used in a verse of Hassán Ibn-Thábit for the regular expression OaXadRu UiroxaMCF: it is like maA OaHowajahu meaning maA OaXadRa HaAjatahu. (El- Hareeree's “ Durrat el-Ghowwás, ” in De Sacy's “ Anthol. Gramm. Ar, ” p. 52 of the Ar. text.)

OuroxiyRapN c
OuroxiyRapN A thing, or part of a thing, (as, for instance, a veil, or curtain, TK,) that one has let loose, let down, or lowered. (S, K.)

miroxaMCN c
miroxaMCN, applied to a beast, (daAbRap, K,) or a horse or mare, (faras, S,) and a she-camel, (TA,) and a she-ass, (S,) That runs in the manner termed UiroxaMC: (K: [see 4, in the latter part of the paragraph:]) or that runs much in that manner: (S:) pl. maraAxiIRu. (S, TA.)

mutaraAxK c
mutaraAxK [part. n. of 6, q. v.]. ― -b2- You say jaMCa zayodN mutaraAxiyFA zamaAnuhu Eano zamaAni majiIoCi EamorKw [Zeyd came, his time of coming being after, or later than, the time of the coming of 'Amr]; i. e. jaMCa baEoda EamorKw. (Msb in art. bEd.)

musotaroxK c
musotaroxK; fem. musotaroxayapN: see rixowN, first sentence.

1 radRahu c
1. radRahu, (S, M, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
radada
, (S, M, L,) inf. n. radRN (S, M, Msb, K, &c.) and maradRN (S, M, L, K) and maroduwdN, (S, L, K,) this last an inf. n. like maHoluwfN and maEoquwlN, (S, L,) and ridRapN (S [there said to be an inf. n., like radRN of radRahu, aor.
raduda
