,]) and ridRiydaI, (S, L, K, [but in the S and L merely said to be syn. with radRN,]) an intensive form, (Mgh, TA,) and tarodaAdN, which is [also] an intensive or a frequentative inf. n. of radRahu, (Sb, M, L,) and likewise an inf. n. of rdRdhu; (Sb, S, M, L;) and ArtdRhu↓; (M, L;) He made, or caused, him, or it, to return, go back, come back, or revert; sent, turned, or put, him, or it, back, or away; returned, rejected, repelled, or averted, him, or it; syn. rajaEahu, (S, M, L, Msb,) and Sarafahu, (S, M, L, K) and dafaEahu; (Msb in art. dfE, &c.;) Eano wajohihi [from his, or its, course]. (S, M.) Hence, in the Kur [xxx. 42 and xlii. 46], yawomN laA maradRa lahu [A day which there shall be no repelling, or averting], meaning the day of resurrection. (Th, M, L.) One says, Oamoru QllRehi laA maradRa lahu The command of God, there is no repelling, or averting it. (L.) And layosa liOamori QllRehi maroduwdN i. e. radRN [There is no repelling, or averting, the command of God.] (A.) And
radRahu Eani AlOamori He made him to return or revert, or turned him back or away, with gentleness, from the thing, or affair; as also ladRahu. (T, L.) ― -b2- Accord. to some, radRa is made doubly trans. with UilaI to the second objective complement when honour is intended to be shown, and with EalaI when dishonour is intended; and they adduce as evidence of the correctness of their assertion the sayings in the Kur [xxviii. 12] faradadonaAhu UilaI OumRihi [So we returned, or restored, him to his mother] and [iii. 142] yarudRuwkumo EalaI OaEoqaAbikumo [They will turn you back, or cause you to return, to your former condition]: but instances may be found at variance with this assertion. (MF.) [Such instances are of frequent occurrence; though in others, the distinction pointed out above is observed, as may be seen in what here follows.] You say, radRahu UilaI manozilihi He sent him back to his abode. (S, L, Msb.) And radRa Uilayohi jawaAbFA He returned, or rendered, to him a reply, or an answer; (S, A, * L, Msb;) he sent to him a reply, or an answer. (Msb.) And radRa Ealayohi He replied to him, or answered him, in an absolute sense; (L;) and also, by way of refutation or objection, i. e. he replied against him; faqaAla and said, or biqawolihi by his saying. (TA &c., passim.) And radRa Ealayohi AlsRalaAma He returned to him the salutation. (The Trads. &c., passim.) And radRa Ealayohi AlwadiyEapa He returned, rendered, restored, or sent [back], to him the deposite; (Msb;) and AlmaniyHapa [the she-camel, or sheep, or goat, lent to him for him to milk her]. (S in art. mnH.) And radRa Ealayohi AlXRaIoCa, (S, Mgh, L, K,) inf. n. radRN and maradRN, (Mgh,) He rejected the thing, (such as a gift, A, and bad money, L,) refusing to receive it, or accept it, from him; [as though he cast it back at him;] and so AlXRaIoCa raAdRahu↓. (S, L, K. *) And in like manner, He rejected the thing in reply to him, charging him with error in respect of it. (S, L, K.) And radadotu Ealayohi qawolahu [I rebutted, rejected, or repudiated, in reply to him, his saying, charging him with error therein; I refused him my assent to it]. (A, Msb.) [And radadotu qawolahu I rebutted, rejected, or repudiated, in reply, or replication, his saying, as wrong, or erroneous; refuted it, or refelled it; refused assent to it; controverted it, or contradicted it. And radRa AlOamora He refused assent, or consent, to the thing, or affair. And radRa Ealayohi AlOamora He refused him his assent, or consent, to the thing, or affair.] And radRa AlsRaAYila He turned back, or away, the beggar, or asker, from the object of his want: (A:) [he rebuffed him:] or he sent away, or dismissed, the beggar, or asker, either with refusal or with a gift: occurring in trads. with both of these meanings. (L.) ― -b3- radRa AlbaAba He shut, or closed, the door. (Mgh. [See maroduwdN.]) ― -b4- [radRa yadahu UilaI sayofihi is a phrase of frequent occurrence, meaning He put back his hand to his sword; it being hung behind him: (see 4 in art. xlf:) and hence, simply, he put his hand to his sword.] faradRuwA Oayodiyahumo fiI OafowaAhihimo, in the Kur xiv. 10, means And they put their hands to their mouths by reason of vehement anger or wrath or rage. (Jel.) ― -b5- radRahu fiI OamorK [He made him to enter again into an affair, or a state]. (ISh, TA in art. nks.) ― -b6- radRa AlXRaIoCa He repeated the thing; did it again; syn. OaEaAdahu. (M in art. Ewd.) You say, radRa Ealayohimu AlOayomaAna He repeated to them the oaths. (L in art. jld.) [In this sense, ridRiydaI is one of the inf. ns. in use; as in the following ex.] It is said in a trad., laA ridRiydaI fiI AlSRadaqapi [There shall be no repeating in the case of the poor-rate]; (T, S, L;) meaning that the poor-rate shall not be taken twice (T, L) in one year. (L.) [See also 2, which has a similar signification.] ― -b7- hecaA laA yarudRu Ealayoka, originally laA yarudRu Ealayoka XayoYFA (assumed tropical:) [This will not return anything to thee], means [this will not bring any return to thee, or] this will not profit thee: (Har p. 483:) and maA yarudRu Ealayoka hecaA (tropical:) This does not profit thee. (A.) ― -b8- radRa Uilayohi AlOamora (assumed tropical:) [He referred the affair, or case, to him for management or decision: or] he committed to him the affair, or case; syn. fawRaDahu Uilayohi. (S and A and K in art. fwD.) ― -b9- [radRa AlXRaIoCa UilaI OaSolihi, a phrase of frequent occurrence, He reduced the thing to its original state.] And radRa AlrRuboEa xumosFA [He reduced the fourth part to a fifth part]. (K in art. rbE.) ― -b10- radRa QllRehu nafosiI UilaI waqoti QnotihaMCi mudRatiI [God brought my soul to the time of the end of my duration]. (IB, TA in art. Amr.) ― -b11- radRahu UilaI AlOamori [He reduced him to the thing, or affair]: (M and K in art. qSr, in explanation of qaSarahu EalaI AlOamori:) or he appropriated him [or it, restrictively,] to the thing, or affair. (TK in that art.) ― -b12- radRa Mxira AlXRaIoCi UilaI OawRalihi, (S and K in art. Eks, &c.,) and radRa OawRalahu EalaI Mxirihi, (Msb in the same art., &c.,) [He reversed the thing; made the last part of it to be first, and the first part of it to be last; turned it hind part before, and fore part behind.] And radRa baEoDa AlOamori EalaI baEoDi [He reversed the order of part, or of the parts, of the affair, or case]. (TA in art. rk.) And radadotu Ealayohi Oamorahu i. q. Eakasotuhu Ealayohi [I reversed to him his affair, or case; I made his affair, or case, to become the contrary of what it was to him]. (Msb in art. Eks.) [Hence,] vumRa radadonaA lakumu AlkarRapa Ealayohimo, in the Kur xvii. 6, means [Then we gave to you] the turn to prevail against them, or the victory over them. (Bd, Jel.) ― -b13- [Hence, also, radRahu sometimes signifies He, or it, rendered him, or it; or caused him, or it, to become; (like SayRarahu;) when it has a second objective complement the contrary in meaning to the first; as in the following ex.; and it may have this meaning likewise when it has a second objective complement differing in meaning from the first in a less degree.] A poet says,
ramaI AlHadavaAnu nisowapa Mli HarobK
biOamorK qado samadona lahu sumuwdaA
faradRa XuEuwrahunRa AlsRuwda biyDFA
waradRa wujuwhahunRa AlbiyDa suwdaA
[The casualties of fortune smote the women of the family of Harb with an event whereat they became confounded with great confoundedness; and it rendered their black hairs white, and rendered their white faces black]. (L in art. smd.)

2 rdRdhu c
2. rdRdhu, inf. n. tarodiydN and tarodaAdN, (S, L,) [the latter of which ns. is merely said in the K to be syn. with the former, and is said in the M and L to be also an inf. n. of radRa in an intensive or a frequentative sense,] means more than radRahu; [i. e. He made, or caused, him, or it, to return, go back, come back, or revert; sent, turned, or put, him, or it, back, or away; returned, rejected, repelled, or averted, him, or it; much, frequently, again and again, or time after time;] having an intensive, or a frequentative, signification. (L.) ― -b2- [Also He, or it, made, or caused, him, or it, to go, or move, repeatedly, to and fro; to go and come; to reciprocate: see its quasi-pass., 5. ― -b3- Hence, (assumed tropical:) He, or it, made him, or caused him, to waver, or vacillate, in an affair, or between two affairs: see, again, 5. And hence, (assumed tropical:) He, or it, confounded, or perplexed, him, so that he was unable to see his right course: see, again, 5; and see also muradRadN.] And rdRd AlOamora (assumed tropical:) [He agitated the thing, or affair, to and fro in his mind]. (TA in art. nj, &c.) ― -b4- And He repeated it; iterated it: [or rather] he repeated it time after time; reiterated it: he reproduced it: he renewed it: syn. OaEaAdahu, (W p. 15,) and karRarahu, (A, and W ibid.,) and rajRaEahu. (Mgh in art. rjE. [See also 1.]) You say, rdRd Alqawola He repeated the saying time after time; reiterated it; syn. karRarahu. (A.) [And rdRd Ealayohi AlkalaAma He repeated to him the speech, or sentence, time after time; reiterated it to him.] And rdRd Sawotahu fiI Haloqihi He reiterated his voice in his throat, or fauces; syn. rajRaEahu; (S and K in art. rjE, &c.;) [as camels and other animals do in braying; (the Lexicons passim;) and he quavered, or trilled, rapidly repeating many times one very short note, or each note of a piece;] like [as is done in] chanting, [for so the Arabs generally do in chanting, and in singing and piping, often throughout the whole performance,] (S in that art.,) or in reading or reciting, or in singing, or piping, or other performances, of such as are accompanied with quavering, or trilling. (TA in that art.)

3 rAdRhu c
3. rAdRhu, (L and TA in art. rwd,) inf. n. muraAdadapN, (TA in that art.,) or muraAdRapN, (TK in the present art.,) He endeavoured to turn him [from, or to, a thing]; syn. raAjaEahu and raAwadahu. (L in art. rwd.) ― -b2- rAdRhu AlXRaIoCa: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph. [Hence,] rAdRhu Alqawola [and rAdRhu fiI Alqawoli (occurring in the TA in art. Et)] He disputed with him, rebutting, or rejecting, or repudiating, in reply to him, what he said; he bandied words with him; syn. raAjaEahu. (A.) And rAdRhu AlbayoEa He dissolved, or annulled, with him the sale; syn. qaAyalahu. (A.)

4 ArdRt c
4. ArdRt She (a sheep or goat or other animal) secreted milk in her udder a little before her
bringing forth; syn. OaDoraEato: (S:) [or,] said of a camel, her udder became shining, and infused with milk. (M, L.) And She (a camel) had her udder and vulva inflated, or swollen, in consequence of her lying upon moist ground: or had her vulva swollen in consequence of lust for the stallion: or had her OarofaAg [or groins, or inguinal creases, or the like], or her udder, and her vulva, swollen in consequence of drinking much water. (M, L.) [See also murdRN.] ― -b2- And ArdR [said of a man, app. from the verb as explained in the first sentence of this paragraph, His seminal fluid returned into his back, or he secreted much seminal fluid, in consequence of his having been long without a wife, or absent from his home: see muridRN: and see also 6. And hence, (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, very libidinous: see, again, muridRN. And] (assumed tropical:) He (a man) was, or became, swollen with anger. (M. [In the L and TA, erroneously written, in this sense, ArAdR: see, again, muridRN.]) ― -b3- Also It (the sea) was, or became, tumultuous, with many waves. (M, L.)

5 trdRd c
5. trdRd quasi-pass. of 2; (S, L;) He, or it, was made, or caused, to return, go back, come back, or revert; &c.; or he, or it, returned, went back, came back, or reverted; much, frequently, again and again, or time after time. (L.) You say, taradRadotu UilaI fulaAnK I returned time after time to such a one (Msb.) And huwa yataradRadu UilaI majaAlisi AlEilomi He repairs frequently to, or frequents, the assemblies of science; syn. yaxotalifu. (A.) See also 6. ― -b2- [And as the returning repeatedly involves the going repeatedly, it signifies also, like Axtlf, He, or it, went, or moved, repeatedly, to and fro; so went and came; or reciprocated. Thus,] taradRudu AlXRaIoCi AlmuEalRaqi fiI AlhawaMCi [means The moving to and fro of a thing suspended in the air]. (K in art. cb.) You say, trdRdt AlrRuwHu The soul, or spirit, went and came. (W p. 5.) ― -b3- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) He wavered, or vacillated, fiI AlrRaOoIi [in opinion]: (MA:) and fiI AlOamori [in the affair], (S and K in art. lv, &c.,) and bayona Oamorayoni [between two things, or affairs]. (S and K in art. cb, &c.) And trdRd fiI SadoriI kacaA (assumed tropical:) [Such a thing became agitated to and fro in my mind, or bosom]. (TA in art. rjE.) And trdRd said of a man, (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, confounded, or perplexed, so that he was unable to see his right course. (Bd and Jel in ix. 45.) [And (assumed tropical:) He laboured, or exerted himself, as though going to and fro, or making repeated efforts, in an affair: a meaning well known.] ― -b4- [And It was, or became, repeated time after time, or reiterated: it was, or became, reproduced: it was, or became, renewed.] You say, trdRd Sawotuhu fiI Haloqihi His voice was, or became, reiterated in his throat, or fauces. (The Lexicons passim.) And trdRdfiI AlfaMCi [He reiterated in uttering the letter f; or, as the meaning is shown to be in the K in art. fO, he reiterated the letter f (radRada AlfaMCa)]. (S in art. fO.) And trdRU fiI AljawaAbi wataEavRara lisaAnuhu [He reiterated, or stam- mered, or stuttered, in uttering the reply, and his tongue halted, faltered, or hesitated]. (A.)

6 trAdR c
6. trAdR and trdRU↓ are both syn. with taraAjaEa: (M, L:) [or nearly so; inasmuch as each implies repetition in returning:] you say, trAdRwA fiI masiyrK, meaning taraAjaEuwA [i. e. They returned, retired, or retreated, by degrees, or by little and little, in a journey, or march]. (TA in art. vbjr.) And trAdR AlmaMCu The water reverted (AirotadR↓ [app. by repeated refluxes]) from its channel, on account of some obstacle in its way. (A.) And trAdR AlmaMCu fiI Zahorihi The seminal fluid returned [by degrees] into his back, in consequence of his having been long without a wife. (L. [See also 4.]) ＝ -A2- taraAdRaA Alqawola [or AlkalaAma, and fiI Alqawoli or fI AlkalaAmi, They two disputed together, each rebutting, or rejecting, or repudiating, in reply, what the other said; they bandied words, each with the other]. (A: there immediately following the phrase raAdRahu Alqawola [q. v.].) And trAdRA AlbayoEa They two rejected, (S, Msb,) or dissolved, or annulled, (S,) [by mutual consent,] the sale. (S, Msb.)

8 ArtdR c
8. ArtdR quasi-pass. of 1 as expl. in the first sentence of this art.; (Msb;) He, or it, returned, went back, came back, or reverted; &c.; (S, L, Msb, * K;) [Eano wajohihi from his, or its, course; and] Eano saEodihi wadiynihi [from his state of prosperity and his religion]; (A;) and UilaI manozilihi [to his abode]: (Msb:) or he turned, or shifted; Eanohu [from it]; and Eano diynihi [from his religion]. (M.) [Hence, He apostatized; or revolted from his religion: and particularly] he returned from El-Islám to disbelief; (Msb;) or so ArtdR Eini AlUisolaAmi. (L.) And yarotadRu AlbaSaru Eanohu mino quboHihi [The eye reverts from him by reason of his unseemliness, or ugliness]. (TA.) See also 6. ― -b2- [Hence also,] AirotadRato nafosiI UilaI waqoti QnotihaMCi mudRatiI [My soul was brought, or came, to the time of the end of my duration]. (IB, TA in art. Amr. [See a verse of El-'Ajjáj cited voce OamaArN.]) ― -b3- And AirotadRato EalaI fulaAnK bigoyatuhu [The thing that he sought was refused, or denied, to such a one]: said of one who finds not what he seeks. (TA in art. bgI.) ＝ -A2- ArtdRhu is syn. with radRahu as expl. in the first sentence of this art., q. v. (M, L.) ― -b2- See also 10, (with which it is likewise syn.,) in two places.

10 AstrdR AlXRaIoCa c
10. AstrdR AlXRaIoCa, and ArtdRhu↓, He desired, or sought, or demanded, that the thing should be returned, or restored, to him; revoked, recalled, or retracted, it. (M, L.) You say, hibatahu ArtdR↓ [and AstrdRhA He revoked, recalled, or retracted, his gift: or the former signifies] he took back his gift; repossessed himself of it; restored it to his possession; syn. AirotajaEahaA. (A.) And AstrdRhu AlXRaIoCa He asked him, (S, A, L, K,) and desired, or sought, of him, (K,) that he should return, or restore, the thing. (S, A, L, K.)

radRN c
radRN an inf. n. of radRahu. (S, M, Msb, K, &c.) ― -b2- [Hence,] DayoEapN kaviyrapu AlrRadRi, and AlmaradRi↓, [this being also an inf. n. of the same, (tropical:) An estate] yielding much revenue. (A.) [See also raAdRapN.] ― -b3- [Hence also, app.,] fiI lisaAnihi radRN In his tongue, or speech, is a difficulty of utterance, or a hesitation, (S, K, * TA,) [probably meaning such as occasions the repetition of certain letters.] ＝ -A2- It is also an inf. n. used as an epithet, signifying, (L, Msb,) and so maroduwdN↓, (M, L, Msb,) and radiydN↓, (M, L,) Made, or caused, to return, go back, come back, or revert; sent, turned, or put, back, or away; returned, rejected, repelled, or averted: (M, L, Msb: *) rejected as meaning not received or accepted: rejected as wrong or erroneous; [as] contrary to the precepts, or ordinances, of the Sunneh: (L:) radRN signifies anything returned after it has been taken. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) A dirhem that will not pass; that is not current; (A, Mgh, L;) that is returned to him who offers it in payment: (M, L:) pl. ruduwdN. (M, A, L, K.) ― -b3- And hence, (Mgh,) (tropical:) A thing (S, A) that is bad, corrupt, disapproved, or abominable. (S, A, K.) ― -b4- Also, (TA passim,) and maroduwdN↓, (S in art. rjE, and A, *) and radiydN↓, (A, * [where it is evidently mentioned in this sense, a sense in which it is still often used,] A reply; an answer; syn. marojuwEN, and jawaAbN. (S in art. rjE.) You say, qawolika hecaA maroduwdu↓ and radiyduhu↓ [This is the reply, or answer, to thy saying]. (A: there immediately following the phrase radRa Uilayoha jawaAbFA.) ― -b5- And A camel used for riding or carriage: so called because brought back from the pasture to the dwelling on the day of journeying. (T.)

ridRN c
ridRN A support, or stay, of a thing: (M, K:) a refuge; an asylum. (Kr, M.) A poet says,
fakuno lahu mina AlbalaAyaA ridRaA
yArabRi OadoEuwka UilaAhFA farodaA
meaning [O my Lord, I call Thee one God; then be Thou to him] a refuge from trials: and ridRaA occurs in a reading of verse 34 of ch. xxviii. of the Kur; meaning as above; or thus written and pronounced for ridoCFA, on account of the pause, after suppressing the C. (M.)

radRapN c
radRapN, (T, S, A, K,) or rdRapN↓, (so in a copy of the M,) (tropical:) [A quality that repels the eye:] unseemliness, or ugliness, (IAar, IDrd, S, M, K,) with somewhat of comeliness, in the face: (S:) or somewhat of unseemliness or ugliness (T, A) in the face of a woman who has some comeliness, (T,) or in the face of a comely woman: (A:) or unseemliness, or ugliness, from which the eye reverts: (Aboo-Leylà:) and a fault, or defect, (IAar, IDrd, M,) in a man, (IAar,) or in the face. (IDrd, M.) ― -b2- And the former, (accord. to a copy of the M,) or ↓the latter, (A, K,) (tropical:) A receding (taqaAEasN) in the chin, (M, A, K) when there is in the face somewhat of unseemliness, or ugliness, and somewhat of comeliness. (M.) ― -b3- And the former, (accord. to a copy of the A,) or ↓the latter, (K,) (tropical:) The returned sound of the echo; as in the phrase, samiEotu radRapa AlSRadaI [I heard the returned sound of the echo]: (A:) or the echo of a mountain. (K.) ― -b4- Also the former, A gift, or stipend; syn. EaTiyRapN. (L, from a trad.) ― -b5- And Affection, and desire: so in the phrase,
lahu radRapN fiynaA [He has affection, and desire, for us], in a verse of 'Orweh Ibn-El-Ward. (Sh.)

ridRapN c
ridRapN a subst. from AirotadRa, (S, M, L, K,) signifying [An apostacy: and particularly] a returning from El-Islám to unbelief; (L, Msb;) or so ridRapN Eani AlUisolaAmi. (M.) ― -b2- See also radRapN, in three places. ― -b3- Also Camels' drinking water a second time (M, L, K) and so causing the milk to return into their udders; as also radadN↓. (M, L.) ― -b4- And A swelling of the teats of a she-camel: or their swelling by reason of the collecting of the milk: as also radadN↓, in either sense: and the former, a camel's udder's becoming shining, and infused with milk: (M, L:) or the udder's becoming filled with milk before bringing forth. (As, S, K.) ― -b5- And A remain, remainder, or anything remaining. (M, L.)

radadN c
radadN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

rududN c
rududN: see raAdRN

radaAdN c
radaAdN and ridaAdN substs. from AstrdR AlXRaIoCa and ArtdRhu; [accord. to the K, of radRahu as expl. in the first sentence of this art., but this is a mistake, for the meaning evidently is Desire for the return, or restoration, of a thing;] as in the saying of El-Akhtal,
wamaA kulRu magobuwnK walawo salofa Safoquhu
yuraAjiEu maA qado faAtahu biriadaAdi
[And not every one who has been cheated in a sale, his striking of the bargain having passed, will restore, or bring back, what has escaped him, by a desire for its restoration]. (M, L. [In the M, in art. slf, this verse is differently related; with mubotaAEK, for magobuwnK, and biraAjiEi for yuraAjiEu: and it is there said that salofa is here used by poetic license for salafa.])

radiydN c
radiydN: see radRN, in three places. ― -b2- Also Clouds (saHaAbN) of which the water has been poured forth. (K.) ― -b3- And A compact limb, or member. (M, L. [See also mutaradRidN.])

rudRaI c
rudRaI: see maroduwdN.

radRaAdN c
radRaAdN, (as in the T and in some copies of the K,) or radRaAdiIRN↓, (as in other copies of the K and in the TA,) A setter of broken bones: from radRaAdN as the name of a certain well-known bone-setter. (T, K.)

radRaAdIRN c
radRaAdIRN: see what next precedes.

raAdRN c
raAdRN sing. of rududN↓, (TA,) which signifies Unseemly, or ugly; [or having a quality that repels the eye; (see radRapN;)] applied to men. (IAar, K, TA.) ― -b2- See also what next follows.

raAdRapN c
raAdRapN [the act. part. n. raAdRN converted by the affix p into a subst.]. You say, hecaA AlOamoru laA raAdRapa lahu, (S, L,) or fiyhi, (K,) or fyh lA raAdRa↓, (so in a copy of the A, [but probably a mistranscription,]) and lA maradRapa↓, (K,) (tropical:) This affair has, or will have, or there is in it, or will be in it, no profit, (S, A, L, K,) or no return. (S, L.) [See also radRN.] ＝ -A2- Also The piece of wood, in the fore part of the Eajalap [or cart], that is put across between the naboEaAni [or two shafts, thus called because they were commonly made of wood of the tree called naboE; which piece rests upon the neck of the bull that draws the cart]. (K.)

OaradRu c
OaradRu (tropical:) More, and most, profitable [or productive of a return]. (S, L, K.) So in the saying, hecaA AlOamoru OaradRu Ealayohi (tropical:) [This affair is, or will be, more, or most, profitable to him]. (S, L.)

maradRN c
maradRN: see radRN, second sentence.

muridRN c
muridRN A ewe or she-goat (S, K) or other animal (S) secreting milk in her udder before bringing forth: (S, K:) or a she-camel having her udder shining, and infused with milk; (Ks, M, L;) as also muromidN: (Ks, L:) and any female near to bringing forth, and having her belly and udder large. (M, L.) And A she-camel having her udder and vulva inflated, or swollen, in consequence of her lying upon moist ground: or whose vulva is swollen in consequence of lust for the stallion: or having her OarofaAg [or groins, or inguinal creases, or the like], or her udder, and her vulva, swollen in consequence of drinking much water: (M, L:) and a he-camel, (T, K,) and a she-camel, (T, L,) heavy from drinking much water: pl. maraAdRu. (T, L, K.) ― -b2- Also, [app. from the first of the meanings explained in this paragraph,] A man who has been long without a wife, or absent from his home, (T, * L, * K,) and whose seminal fluid has in consequence returned into his back; (T, L;) as also maroduwdN↓. (K.) And [hence,] (assumed tropical:) Very libidinous; (S, K;) applied to a man. (S.) And (assumed tropical:) [Swollen with anger; see 4: or] angry. (K.) One says, jaMCa fulaAnN muridRa Alwajohi Such a one came angry [in countenance]. (S.) ― -b3- Also A sea (T, S) tumultuous with waves; syn. mawRaAjN: (K:) having many waves: (S:) or having much water. (T.)

miradRN c
miradRN A man who repels much, and often wheels away and then returns to the fight; or who repels and returns much. (M, L.)

maradRapN c
maradRapN: see raAdRapN.

muradRadN c
muradRadN: see the next paragraph. ― -b2- Also, [and mutaradRidN↓, (see 5,)] (tropical:) A man (S, A) confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course. (S, A, K.)

maroduwdN c
maroduwdN: see radRN, in three places. ― -b2- You say also, laA xayora fiI qawolK maroduwdK wamuradRadK↓ [There is no good in a saying rebutted and reiterated]. (A.) ― -b3- And baAbN maroduwdN A door shut, or closed; not opened. (Mgh.) ― -b4- And AimoraOapN maroduwdapN (tropical:) A woman divorced; (T, S, * M, A, K; *) as also rudRaI↓: (AA, K:) because she is sent back to the house of her parents. (A.) [In the present day, also applied to A woman taken back after divorce.] ― -b5- See also muridRN. ＝ -A2- Also an inf. n. [of an unusual form] of radRahu. (S, L, K.)

maroduwdapN c
maroduwdapN [the part. n. maroduwdN converted by the affix p into a subst.,] (tropical:) A razor: [so called] because it is turned back into its handle. (S, A, K.)

murotadRN c
murotadRN, from AirotidAdN meaning “ a returning; ” (S;) [An apostate: and particularly] one who returns from El-Islám to disbelief. (L.)

mutaradRidN c
mutaradRidN: see muradRadN. ― -b2- Also A man compact and short, not lank in make: (M, L:) or extremely short. (L.) [See also radiydN.]

1 radaOa AlHaAYiTa c
1. radaOa AlHaAYiTa, [aor.
radaAa
, inf. n. radoCN,] He supported, propped, or stayed, the wall, (ISh, T, K,) by means of a piece of timber or wood, or a buttress or the like, to prevent its falling; (ISh, T;) as also ArAdOhu↓: (Yoo, T, K:) or radaOa AlHaAYiTa bibinaMCK [he supported the wall by a structure;] he attached a structure to the wall. (M.) ― -b2- Hence, (T,) radaOahu bihi He strengthened and supported him, or it, by means of it, (Lth, T, M, * K,) namely, a person by a thing, (Lth, T,) or a thing by a thing, (M,) like as one strengthens and supports a wall by means of a structure which he attaches thereto; (T;) as also ArAdOhu↓. (T, * K.) And radaOahu, (Mgh, TA,) inf. n. radoCN, (Mgh,) He helped, aided, or assisted, him; (Mgh, TA;) as also ArdOhu↓: (T, S, M, Msb, K:) and radaOotuhu and OarodaOotuhu↓, (T,) or binafosiI OarodaOotuhu↓, (S,) I was, or became, a helper, an aider, or an assistant, to him. (T, S.) ― -b3- Hence also, (i. e., from rdO AlHaAYT,) radaOa AlUibila (tropical:) He took good care of the camels, (A, K, TA,) in tending and pasturing them. (A, TA.) ― -b4- And radaOahu biHajarK He cast a stone at him; (M, K;) like [radaAhu, mentioned in art. rdI, and] daraOahu. (M.) ＝ -A2- raduWa, aor.
raduAa
, inf. n. radaMCapN, (T, S, M, K, &c.,) for which one should not say radaAwapN; (T;) and Th mentions also radaOa and radiICa as syn. with raduWa, but these are strange; and more strange is what is said in the Msb, namely, radaA aor. yaroduw, part. n. radiIRN, [as a dial. var.,] asserted by IDrst, in the Expos. of the Fs, to be erroneous, and peculiar to the vulgar; (MF, TA;) It (a thing, T, S, M, Msb,) [and he, see radiIoCN, its part. n.,] was, or became, bad, corrupt, vitious, depraved, or the like; (S, M, Msb, * K;) or of no rank, or estimation; low, ignoble, vile, or mean; (Msb;) [disapproved, disliked, hated, or abominable: (see radiIoCN:)] and he was, or became, weak, and impotent, so as to be in want or need. (TA from the Expositions of the Fs.)

2 radRaAa
2: see the next paragraph.

4 ArdOhu c
4. ArdOhu: see 1, in five places. ― -b2- Also He settled, established, or confirmed, him, or it, (K, TA,) in his, or its, state. (TA.) ― -b3- He stilled, or quieted, him, or it. (K.) ― -b4- And He let it down; namely, a veil, or curtain. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also He rendered it bad, corrupt, vitious, depraved, or the like; (S, K;) namely, a thing; said of a man; (S;) [and rdRMhu↓ is used in the same sense: (see 1 in art. jXb:)] he made, or asserted, or held,
it (a thing) to be radiIC [or bad, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- And ArdO signifies He did a thing, or a deed, that was radiIoC [or bad, &c.]: or he met with, or experienced, (OaSaAba,) a thing that was radiIoC. (M, K.) ＝ -A3- ArdO EalaI gayorihi It exceeded another thing; as also OarodaI: (M:) [or the latter only:] accord. to IAar, one says ArdO EalaI AlsRitRiyna, with C, (M,) and, accord. to Lth, ElI Alxamosiyna, (TA,) and, [accord. to F,] ElI miAYapK, (K,) meaning He exceeded [the age of sixty, and fifty, and a hundred]: (M, K, TA:) but Az says that ArdO, with C, [in these phrases,] though authorized by Lth, is wrong; (TA;) and accord. to A' Obeyed, one says Oarodayotu. (M. [It is added, however, in the M, that ArdO may perhaps be also used in poetry in the same sense without the prep. ElI.])

5 taradRaWuwA c
5. taradRaWuwA They helped, aided, or assisted, one another. (Lth, M, TA.)

ridoCN c
ridoCN A buttress, or the like, by means of which a wall is strengthened and supported. (T.) [This is the primary signification. See also ridRN, in art. rd.] ― -b2- [Or] the primary meaning is A thing by means of which one is helped, aided, or assisted; such as the difoC [or thing by which one is rendered warm, or protected from the cold wind]. (Bd in xxviii. 34; where it has the meaning next following, as is said in the T and S.) ― -b3- A helper, an aider, or an assistant. (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K.) You say, fulaAnN ridoCN lifulaAnK Such a one is an aider and a strengthener to such a one. (T.) ― -b4- And i. q. maAdRapN [app. as meaning An accession; or a thing that is added, whatever it be, to another thing]. (M, K.) ― -b5- And (tropical:) i. q. EidolN [i. e. A burden that balances another burden on the other side of a beast]; (T, TA;) so called because one such rdC supports another: (TA:) and a heavy Eidol: (T, K, TA:) pl. OarodaMCN. (T, TA.)

ridaMCN c
ridaMCN: see art. rdI.

radiIoCN c
radiIoCN, applied to a thing, (T, S, M, Msb,) and to a man, (M, TA,) Bad, corrupt, vitious, depraved, or the like; (S, M, Msb, * K;) of no rank, or estimation; low, ignoble, vile, or mean; (Msb;) disapproved, disliked, hated, or abominable: and weak, and impotent, so as to be in want or need: and accord to the Msb, one says also radiIRN; [there said to be a dial. var.;] but this is asserted by IDrst, in the Expos. of the Fs, to be erroneous, and peculiar to the vulgar: (TA:) pl. OarodiYaMCu, with two hemzehs, (M, K,) applied to a people, or company of men. (M.)

OarodaOu c
[OarodaOu Worse, and worst; more, and most, corrupt &c.]

mirodaOapN c
mirodaOapN A stone which a strong man can hardly lift with both his hands; (TA;) as also mirodaApN. (ISh, TA in art. rdI.)

UirodabRN c
UirodabRN A well-known mikoyaAl [or measure with which corn is measured], (T,) a large mikoyaAl, (S, M, K,) in Egypt, (K,) [i. e.] of the people of Egypt; (T, S;) or a certain measure of capacity well known in Egypt; (Msb;) not correctly called a mikoyaAl for they do not measure with it, but with the wayobap: (IB, TA:) it comprises, (yaDumRu, [so in the M, but in copies of the K wayuDamRu, which signifies that it is also pronounced with damm,]) as they say, (M,) or it takes, (T,) twenty-four times the measure called SaAE, (T, M, Msb, K,) of wheat, (T,) i. e. sixty-four times the measure called manR, (T, Msb,) the mnR here meant being the mnR of our country, (Az, [app. meaning El-'Irák,]) and the SAE being that of the Prophet: (Msb:) or six wayobaAt: (K:) the ArdbR of Egypt is six wayobaAt; the wayobap being four OarobaAE; the ruboE, four OaqodaAH; and the qadaH, two hundred and thirty-two daraAhim: (EsSuyootee in his “ Husn el-Mohádarah:”) the half of the ArdbR is called qanoqalN: (T:) the word ArdbR is affirmed by some to be arabicized: (MF:) [it is now vulgarly pronounced OarodabR:] the pl. is OaraAdibu. (Msb.) El-Akhtal says,
qawomN UicaA QsotanobaHa AlOaDoyaAfu kalobahumu
qaAluwA liOumRihimu buwliI EalaI AlnRaAri
waAlxubozu kaAlEanobari AlhinodiIRi Einodahumu
waAlqamoHu saboEuwna UirodabRFA bidiynaAri
[Persons who, when the guests induce their dog to bark, (see art. nbH,) say to their mother, “ Make water on the fire: ” and bread is like Indian ambergris in their judgment, while wheat is seventy irdebbs for a deenár]: the former of these two verses [whereof the latter only is cited in the S] is said by As and others to be the most severely-satirical verse uttered by any of the Arabs. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A conduit in which water flows upon the surface of the ground. (M, K.)

UirodabRapN c
UirodabRapN A wide baAluwEap [or sink-hole] made of baked clay: (T, K:) likened to the mikoyaAl above mentioned: pl. as above. (T.) [And Any pipe of baked clay: pl. UirodabRaAtN: see daAxinapN.] ― -b2- And i. q. qiromiydapN [which may mean A large baked brick, or a thing made of baked clay]: (M, TA:) or large baked bricks; (S, K, TA;) which are called qiromiydN. (S, TA.)

1 radaja c
1. radaja, aor.
radija
, inf. n. radojN, He (a mare's foal [or a young ass, or a lamb or kid, or any young solid-hoofed animal only,]) voided the excrement termed radaj. (TA.) ＝ -A2- radaja, inf. n. radajaAnN, i. q. daraja, inf. n. darajaAnN: (K:) one of these is formed by transposition from the other: or, accord. to IJ, each is an original word. (TA.)

radajN c
radajN What comes forth, (S, K,) or what first comes forth, (TA,) from the belly of a lamb or kid, or of a mare's foal, (S, K, TA,) and of a young mule, and of a young ass, (TA,) or of any young solid-hoofed animal only, (AZ, T, TA,) before it eats: like EiqoIN in relation to a child: (S, K:) pl. OarodaAjN. (TA.)

OarodaAjN c
OarodaAjN pl. of radajN: (TA:) ＝ -A2- and used by Ru-beh for Oaranodaj, q. v. (K.)

OaranodajN c
OaranodajN (Lh, S, K) and UiranodajN (K) and yaranodajN↓ (Lh, S) Black skin [or leather], (S, K,) of which boots are made: termed by Ru-beh, in the following hemistich, OarodaAj↓:
kaOanRamaA surowilona fiI AlOarodaAji
[As though they were clad in trousers of Arndj]: (K:) accord. to A' Obeyd, originally Pers., (S,) arabicized, (K,) from ranodaho: (S, K:) one should not say ranodajN: (ISk, S:) accord. to Lh, i. q. daAriXN: or, he adds, as some say, a skin [or leather] different from that termed dArX: or i. q. zaAjN, with which one blackens. (TA. [See what follows.]) With respect to these words of a poet, describing a woman as ignorant, or inexperienced,
qabolahaA lamo tadori maA nasoju Alyaranodaji↓
[She knew not what is the weaving of yrndj before it], it is said that he imagined yrndj to be woven, or that he meant that this woman, by reason of her ignorance, or inexperience, imagined it to be so. (TA.) ― -b2- [It is said, app. on the ground of an assertion mentioned above, that] yaranodajN↓ also signifies A certain black dye; (L;) the black [or blacking] with which boots are blacked: or zaAjN [i. e. vitriol]. (K.) ― -b3- Az mentions Arndj and yrndj↓ as quadriliteral-radical words. (TA.)

yaranodajN c
yaranodajN: see the next preceding paragraph, in four places.

1 radaHa Albayota c
1. radaHa Albayota, (S, K,) aor.
radaHa
, (K,) inf. n. radoHN, (TA,) He inserted an oblong piece of cloth, (S, K,) such as is termed rudoHap, (TA,) in the hinder part of the tent; as also ArdHhu↓: (S, K:) or both signify he widened the tent: (A:) or he lowered, or let down, the curtain (rudoHap, or sutorap,) at the hinder part of the tent. (L, and so in some copies of the K.) ― -b2- Also (thus in the S, but in the K “ or ”) He put a thick coating, or covering, of clay, or mud, upon the house, or structure; and so ArdHhu↓. (S, K.) ― -b3- radoHN also signifies The spreading a thing upon the ground, so that it becomes even; and so tarodiyHN [inf. n. of rdRH↓]; but it is said that the latter occurs only in poetry: or the former, accord. to Az, the spreading a thing so that its back [or upper surface] becomes even with the ground. (TA.) ― -b4- And radaHahu He threw him down prostrate. (L.) ＝ -A2- raduHato, aor.
raduHa
, inf. n. radaAHapN, She (a woman) was, or became, such as is termed radaAH, i. e. heavy in the hips, or haunches; or large in the posteriors, heavy in the hips, or haunches, and perfect in make. (TA.)

2 radRaHa
2: see the preceding paragraph.

4 OarodaHa
4: see 1, in two places.

rudoHapN c
rudoHapN A curtain (sutorap) in the hinder part, of a bayot [or tent]: (S, K:) or a piece, (S, K,) i. e. an oblong piece of cloth, (TA,) that is added in a tent, (S, K,) [in the hinder part thereof, (see 1,)] or inserted therein. (L.) ― -b2- The rudoHap of the lurking-place, or pit, of a hunter consists of Stones set up around; which are also called HamaAYiru, pl. of HimaArapN. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also i. q. saEapN; and so murotadaHN↓: thus in the saying, laka Eanohu rudoHapN and murotadaHN [meaning Thou hast ample scope, freedom, or liberty, to avoid it; or thou hast that which renders thee in no need of it]; (K;) like laka Eanohu manoduwHapN. (TA.)

radaAHN c
radaAHN A great [bowl such as is termed] jafonap: (S, A, * K:) this is said to be the primary signification: (Har p. 609:) pl. ruduHN. (S, A.) ― -b2- A widened tent; as also maroduwHN↓ and murodaHN↓ [of both which see the verbs]. (A.) ― -b3- A woman heavy in the hips, or haunches: (S, K:) or a woman large in the hips, or haunches, and the posteriors: (A:) or a woman large in the posteriors, heavy in the hips, or haunches, and perfect in make; as also raAdiHapN↓ and raduwHN↓. (TA.) And A she-camel, (T, TA,) and a ram, (A, K,) large in the posteriors. (T, A, K, TA.) ― -b4- A camel heavily laden, (K, TA,) that will not be roused, or put in motion or action, and rise. (TA.) ― -b5- An army, or troop, (katiybapN,) marching heavily by reason of numbers, (S, K,) or dragging along the apparatus of war, heavily laden, (K,) great, (TA,) compact, with many horsemen. (A, TA.) ― -b6- A great, wide, spreading tree. (A, K.) ― -b7- [A place, or land,] abounding with herbage, or with the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life; fruitful; or plentiful. (K.) ― -b8- EukuwmN radaAHN Loads balancing one another that are heavy, much stuffed with goods or utensils and furniture; as also ridaAHN↓: so in the Towsheeh &c. (TA.) ― -b9- fitonapN radaAHN (A, K) (tropical:) Heavy and great [conflict and faction, or sedition, or discord, or the like]: pl. ruduHN: whence, in a saying of 'Alee, UinRa mino waraAYikumo OumuwrFA mutamaAHilapF ruduHFA, (K,) meaning (tropical:) [Verily behind you are events whereof the exposition would be long,] great conflicts and factions, or seditions, &c.: (TA:) or, accord. to one relation, rudRaHFA, (K, TA,) pl. of raAdiHapN↓, and meaning heavy, scarcely departing: and accord. to another, fitanFA murodiHapF↓, meaning oppressing by their weight; or covering the hearts; from OarodaHa Albayota [in the latter of the senses assigned to it above: see 1]. (TA.) ― -b10- radaAHN also means (tropical:) Darkness. (A, TA.)

ridaAHN c
ridaAHN: see the next preceding paragraph.

raduwHu c
raduwHu: see the next preceding paragraph.

raAdiHapN c
raAdiHapN: see radaAHN, in two places. ― -b2- maAYidapN raAdiHapN A large table abounding with good things. (TA.)

murodaHN c
murodaHN: see radaAHN. ― -b2- Homeyd says, (S, TA,) i. e. Ibn El-Arkat, (TA,)
binaMCa SaxorK murodaHK biAlTRiyni
meaning [A structure of rocks, or large stones,] thickly coated, or covered, with clay, or mud. (S.) ― -b3- Az says that murodaHN sometimes occurs in poetry in the sense of maroduwHN↓ as meaning Spread so that its back [or upper surface] is even with the ground. (TA.)

murodiHap c
murodiHap: see radaAHN, last sentence but one.

maroduwHN c
maroduwHN: see radaAHN: ― -b2- and murodaHN.

murotadaHN c
murotadaHN: see rudoHapN.

1 radasa Alqawoma c
1. radasa Alqawoma, (S, K,) aor.
radusa
, inf. n. radosN, (S,) He threw a stone at the people, or party; or threw at them and hit them with a stone: (S, K:) or with a great stone: (Ham p. 214:) or radasa, aor.
radisa
, inf. n. as above, he threw at, or shot at; or he threw at and hit, or he shot; (ramaI;) with anything. (M.) [See also 3.] ― -b2- radosN also signifies The act of striking, or smiting. (Sh, M.) ― -b3- And radasahu, (M, K,) aor.
radisa
and
radusa
, inf. n. as above; (M;) or radasahu bimirodaAsK; (A;) He beat it so as to break it, or crush it; (M, A, K;) namely, a thing, (M,) or a wall, and the ground, (K,) and a lump of dry clay; (TA;) with a hard thing, (M,) or with a big stone, (A,) or with a bard and broad thing. (K.) And radasahu, aor.
radisa
and
radusa
, (IDrd, K,) inf. n. as above, (IDrd, TA,) He broke it; namely, a stone with a stone. (IDrd, K.) ― -b4- radasa biraOosihi He pushed, or thrust, or repelled, (dafaEa, [not rafaEa, as Freytag seems to have found it written, as on the authority of Meyd,]) with his head. (TA.) ― -b5- And radasahu, inf. n. as above, He broke, or trained, him; like darasahu, inf. n. darosN. (M.) ＝ -A2- radasa He went away: you say, maA OadoriI Oayona radasa I know not whither he went away, or has gone away. (S, TA.) And radasa biAlXRaIoCi He went away with, or took away, the thing. (K.)

3 rAds Alqawoma c
3. rAds Alqawoma i. q. radasahumo [explained above, in the first sentence]: (S, TA:) [or He threw stones at the people, or party, they doing so at him; or pelted them with stones, they pelting him: for the inf. n.] muraAdasapN is explained in the O and K as meaning muraAyaApN; but the correct explanation may be muraAmaApN. (TA.)

5 trdRs mino makaAnihi c
5. trdRs mino makaAnihi He, or it, fell from his, or its, place. (Ibn-'Abbád, Sgh, K.)

qawolN radosN c
qawolN radosN (assumed tropical:) A saying that is as though it were thrown at one's adversary. (IAar, M.)

raduwsN c
raduwsN: see what next follows.

ridRiysN c
ridRiysN A man who throws stones at others, or pelts them with stones, much, or often: (S: [this meaning is there indicated, but not expressed:]) or, as also raduwsN↓ a man who pushes, thrusts, or repels, much, or vehemently; syn. dafuwEN; (K;) or naTuwHN; and who is strong, as though his enemy were pelted with him. (IAar in explanation of rdws.)

mirodasN c
mirodasN A hard thing with which a thing is beaten so as to be broken, or crushed, thereby: (M:) and mirodaAsN↓ signifies [in like manner] a big stone with which a thing is so beaten: (A:) or each, a hard and broad thing with which a wall and the ground (K, TA) and a lump of dry clay (TA) are so beaten: (K, TA:) or the latter word, a mass of stone, or rock, which one throws; and the former has this meaning also, as well as the first meaning: (M:) or the latter word, (S,) or each, (M,) a stone which is thrown into a well in order that one may know whether there be in it water or not. (S, M. [See also mirojaAsN.])

mirodaAsN c
mirodaAsN: see the next preceding paragraph. ― -b2- Also The head; (AA, K;) because one pushes, or thrusts, or repels, with it. (AA, TA.) ― -b3- And also said to signify A great mountain. (TA in art. rEn.)

1 radaEahu c
1. radaEahu, aor.
radaEa
, inf. n. radoEN, He restrained, withheld, prevented, or hindered, him; made him to restrain himself, withhold himself, refrain, forbear, or abstain; (S, Msb, K;) turned him back, repelled him, or averted him; (K;) Eani AlXRaIoCi from the thing. (S, Msb, K. *) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] radaEa jayobahu Eanohu (assumed tropical:) He cleared his bosom, or heart, of it; syn. farajahu, or farRajahu; (accord. to different copies of the K;) [as though he withheld his mind from it;] meaning, grief, and perturbation; jyb being used to signify the “ bosom, ” and the “ heart: ” (TK:) mentioned by Sgh. (TA.)

6 trAdE Alqawomu c
6. trAdE Alqawomu The people, or company of men, restrained, withheld, prevented, or hindered, one another; made one another to restrain himself, withhold himself, refrain, forbear, or abstain; turned back, repelled, or averted, one another. (TA.)

8 ArtdE c
8. ArtdE He became restrained, withheld, prevented, or hindered; was made to restrain himself, withhold himself, refrain, forbear, or abstain; or he restrained himself, withheld himself, refrained, forbore, or abstained; (S, Msb, K, TA;) he became turned back, repelled, or averted; or he turned back, or reverted. (K.) You say, ArtdE birawaAdiEi AlquroMni [He became restrained by the restrictions of the Kur-án]. (Msb.)

raAdiEapN c
[raAdiEapN, app. for MyapN raAdiEapN A restraining verse of the Kur-án, seems to be the sing. of rawaAdiEu, of which an ex. occurs above: see 8.]

1 radiga c
1. radiga [aor.
radaga
,] inf. n. radagN, It (a place) was, or became, slimy, or miry. (MA.) [See also 4.] ＝ -A2- radaga bihi AlOaroDa He threw him (a man) upon
the ground. (TA.) And rudiga bihi He was thrown down, or prostrated. (TA.)

3 rAdghu c
3. rAdghu [He strove with him, in wrestling, to throw him down]. (TA in art. rsg: see 3 in that art.)

4 Ardgt AlOaroDu c
4. Ardgt AlOaroDu The land, or ground, was, or became, very slimy or miry; [like Arzgt;] or had much stiff slime or mire; (K;) as also ArdEt. (TA.) [See also radiga.] ― -b2- And Ardgt AlsRamaMCu and Arzgt The sky gave water such as moistened the earth or ground. (TA.)

8 Artdg c
8. Artdg He fell into a slimy, or miry, place; (A, TA;) or into ridaAg, (JK, K,) or radagap. (TA.)

radogN c
radogN and radagN: see radagapN, in four places.

radigN c
radigN A slimy, or miry, place; (Mgh, L;) a place in which is radog: (Tekmileh, TA:) or a place in which is much radog. (K.)

radagapN c
radagapN and radogapN Slime, or mire; i. e. water and clay or mud: and stiff slime or mire: (S, K:) or much slime or mire: (JK:) pl. ridaAgN and [coll. gen. ns.] radagN↓ (S, K) and radogN↓: (K:) or ridaAgN↓ signifies thin mud: or, as some say, it is pl. of radogapN: (Mgh:) accord. to Kr, radogN↓ and ridaAgN↓ signify slime, or mire; and are sings. (TA.) [See also razagapN.] Hence, yawomN cuw radogK↓ [A day of slime, or mire, &c.]. (TA, from a trad.) And Eani AljumuEapi manaEanaA hecaA AlrRidaAgu↓ [This slime, or mire, &c., prevented us from attending the prayer of Friday: AlrdAg being here used as a sing. n.]. (TA, from another trad.) ― -b2- [Hence also,] radogapu AlxabaAli and radagapu AlxbAl The [corrupt] fluid squeezed, or wrung, or flowing, from the inhabitants of Hell. (K, TA.) This, it is said in a trad., will be given to drink to him who drinks wine. (TA.) ― -b3- You say also maMCN radogapN and radagapN [app. Slimy, or miry, water]; both meaning the same. (TA.)

ridaAgN c
ridaAgN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

radiygN c
radiygN Thrown down, or prostrated; (IAar, K;) as also radiyEN. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And Foolish, or stupid, (JK, S, K,) and weak: (JK, TA:) this, and radiyEN, the former mentioned on the authority of Sh, and the latter on the authority of AHeyth, are thought by Az to mean foolish, or stupid. (TA.)

marodagN c
marodagN: see the following paragraph.

marodagapN c
marodagapN A rawoDap [i. e. meadow, or garden,] that is beautiful, or goodly; or that is beautiful in appearance, exciting admiration, and satisfying the eye: (IAar, K:) and so marogadapN. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also sing. of maraAdigu, which signifies The parts between the neck and the collar-bone: (S, K;) also called the baMdil. (S.) And The portion of flesh [or muscle] between the waAbilap of the katif [i. e. the extremity in which is the glenoid cavity of the shoulder-blade, or the muscle of the shoulderblade,] and the heads of the ribs of the breast: (IAar, K:) or the maraAdig are [the parts] beneath the two collar-bones, on each side of the breast. (TA.) And you say naAqapN caAtu maraAdiga (K) and jamalN cuw maraAdiga (TA) meaning A fat she-camel (K) and he-camel: (TA:) ISh says, when the camel is satisfied by abundance of herbage, he has mrAdg in his belly and upon the upper parts of his shoulder-blades, i. e. accumulated fat thereon, like hares lying down; but when he is not fat, there is no marodag↓ there. (TA.) marodagapu AlEunuqi means A portion of flesh [or a muscle, app. of a camel,] upon the hinder side of the rising part from the middle of the EaDud [or humerus] to the elbow: or, as some say, the flesh of the breast. (TA.) And maraAdigu AlsRanaAmi means The fat that adjoins the maOonap [q. v., of the hump]: (JK, Ibn- 'Abbád, TA:) sing. marodagapN. (JK.)

1 radifahu c
1. radifahu, (T, S, O, Msb, K &c.,) aor.
radafa
, (K,) inf. n. radofN, (MA, KL,) He rode behind him [on the same beast]; (AZ, Sh, Zj, T, MA, Msb;) [and] so radafahu, [aor.
radufa
;] (M;) and Ardfhu↓; (AZ, Sh, T, M;) said by IAar to signify the same as radifahu: (T:) [or, in other words,] radifahu signifies he became to him a ridof [meaning a radiyf]; and so radifa lahu; for the Arabs often add the l with a trans. v. that governs an accus. noun; so that they say, samiEa lahu and Xakara lahu and naSaHa lahu, meaning samiEahu and Xakarahu and naSaHahu: (Fr, T:) [and also] he, or it, followed, or came after, him, or it; (S, O, K, and Ham p. 148;) and so radifa lahu; (Ham ibid.;) and radafahu, aor.
radufa
; (K;) and Ardfhu↓; (S, K, and Ham ubi suprà;) and Artdfhu↓ also signifies the same as radifahu; (K;) radifahu and Ardfhu↓ being like tabiEahu and OatobaEahu in [form and] meaning: (S:) [radRafahu↓, likewise, appears to be syn. with radifahu; or, probably, rudRifahu, which seems to signify lit. he was made to ride behind him; &c.; for it is said that] the inf. n. tarodiyfN signifies the coming, or going, behind; as also tarodaAfN: (KL:) and radifotuhu also signifies I overtook him and outwent him. (Msb: [explained in my copy by lHqth wsbqth: but I think that sbqth is a mistranscription for tabiEotuhu; and that the meaning therefore is, I overtook him and followed him.]) One says, kaAna nazala bihimo OamorN faradifa lahumo Mxaru OaEoZamu minohu [An event had befallen them, and another, of greater magnitude than it, happened afterwards to them]. (Lth, * T, * S, O.) And OamorN Ardfhu↓ is a dial. var. of radifahu, meaning An event happened to him afterwards: (S, O:) or radifahumu AlOamoru and Oarodafahum↓ signify the event came upon them suddenly, or unexpectedly; or came upon them so as to overwhelm them. (M.) It is said in the Kur [xxvii. 74], EasaI Oano yakuwna radifa lakumo baEoDu QlRaciI tasotaEojiluwna, meaning [Perhaps a portion of that which ye desire to hasten] may have drawn near to you; (Yoo, Fr, T, O,) as though the l were introduced because the meaning is danaA lakumo: or it may mean yakuwna radifakumo [may have become close behind you]; (Fr, T, O;) the l being introduced for a reason mentioned above, as in samiEa lahu &c. for samiEahu &c.: (Fr, T:) El-Aaraj read radafa lkm. (O.) And Khuzeymeh Ibn-Málik Ibn-Nahd says,
AlvRurayRaA UicaA AljawozaMCu Oarodafati↓
Zananotu biMli faATimapa AlZRunuwnaA
[When Orion, or Gemini, shall ride behind, or closely follow, the Pleiades, (an event which will never occur,) I will form in my mind, respecting the family (meaning the father) of Fátimeh, opinions]: (S, O:) cited by Fr [and by J] as an ex. of Ardft in the sense of radifat: (T:) he means Fátimeh the daughter of Yedhkur Ibn-'Anazeh, who [i. e. Yedhkur] was one of the qaAriZaAn. (S, O. [Respecting the qArZAn, see art. qarZ.])

2 radRafa
2: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph.

3 rAdft AldRaAbRapu c
3. rAdft AldRaAbRapu The beast allowed a radiyf [to ride it], and was strong enough to bear him; as also Ardft↓ [accord. to some]. (Msb.) You say, hacihi daAbRapN laA turaAdifu (T, S, M, O, K) and laA turodifu↓, (Lth, M, O, K,) but the latter is rare, (K,) or post-classical, of the language of the people of towns and villages, (T, O,) and not allowable, (T,) This beast will not allow a radiyf (Lth, T, M) to ride it; (Lth, T;) will not bear a rdyf. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- muraAdafapu AljaraAdi signifies The mounting of [locusts one behind, or upon, another;] the male locust upon the female, and the third upon those two. (S, O, K.) ― -b3- And muraAdafapu Almuluwki is [a phrase meaning The acting as a ridof, or as OarodaAf, to the kings,] from AlrRidaAfapu [q. v.]. (O, K.) Jereer, who was of the Benoo-Yarbooa, to whom pertained the ridaAfap in the Time of Ignorance, says,
rabaEonaA waraAdafonaA Almuluwka faZalRiluwA
wTaAba AlOaHaAliybi AlvRumaAma AlmunazRaEaA
[We have taken the fourth part of the spoils, and we have acted as OarodaAf to the kings; therefore shade ye the skins of the camel-loads of milk collected from the camels in the pasture with panic grass plucked up, and so make it cool for us]: (S, * O:) wiTaAb is the pl. of the waTob of milk. (S.) ― -b4- [In the conventional language of lexicology, rAdfhu, inf. n. muraAdafapN, signifies It was synonymous with it; i. e. a word with another word: as though the former supplied the place of the latter, like as the ridof supplied the place of the king. See also 6.]

4 Oarodafotuhu c
4. Oarodafotuhu, (T, S, Msb,) inf. n. UirodaAfN, (Msb,) I made him to ride (Sh, Zj, T, S, Msb) behind me, (Sh, * Zj, T, Msb,) or with me, (S,) on the back of the [same] beast; and so Airotadafotuhu↓: (Msb:) or Artdfhu↓ signifies he placed him behind him on the beast: (M:) and Oarodafotuhu maEahu I made him to ride with him [or behind him, on the same beast]. (O, K.) ― -b2- And Ardf AlXRaIoCa biAlXRaIoCi and Ardfhu Ealayohi He made the thing to follow the thing. (M.) ― -b3- See also 1, in six places. ― -b4- Ardft AlnRujuwmu,
[baEoDuhaA baEoDFA being app. understood,] The stars followed one another. (S, O, K.) [See also 6.] ― -b5- See also 3, in two places.

6 taraAdufN c
6. taraAdufN is syn. with tataAbuEN. (T, S, O.) You say, taraAdafaA They followed each other. (K.) And trAdf Alqawomu The people, or party, followed one another: and in like manner one says of anything following another thing. (Msb.) [See also 4.] And trAdf AlXRaIoCu The thing was, or became, consecutive in its parts; one part of the thing followed another. (M.) ― -b2- It is also a word alluding to a certain foul act: (M, O:) from AlrRidofu signifying AlEajuzu. (M.) You say, (of two boys, or young men, TK,) taraAdafaA meaning tanaAkaHaA. (K.) ― -b3- And taraAdafuwA Ealayohi They aided, helped, or assisted, one another against him. (As, S.) And taraAdafaA They aided, helped, or assisted, each other; (O, K;) as also trAfdA. (O.) ― -b4- As a conventional term in lexicology, taraAdufN signifies Synonymousness; or the being synonymous. (Mz, 27th nwE; and Kull p. 130.) [You say, of two words, yataraAdafaAni They are synonymous. See also 3: and see mutaraAdifN.]

8 Uirotadafa
8: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph: ― -b2- and see also 4, in two places. ― -b3- You say also, Artdfhu meaning He came behind him; syn. Aisotadobarahu. (S, O.) And Artdf AlEaduwRa He took the enemy, or seized him, or took him captive, or gained the mastery over him and slew him, coming from behind him; syn. Oaxacahu mino waraAYihi OaxocFA. (K.) OatayonaA fulaAnFA faQrotada fonaAhu is explained by Ks as meaning OaxaconaAhu &c. as above [i. e. We came to such a one, and took him, &c.]. (T, S, M, * O.)

10 Astrdfhu c
10. Astrdfhu He asked him to make him [or to let him] ride behind him on the back of the beast. (S, * O, Msb, K. *)

ridofN c
ridofN: see radiyfN, in two places. ― -b2- Also A sequent of a thing; (T, S, M, O, Msb, K;) whatever that sequent be: (S, O, Msb, K:) pl. OarodaAfN, which is its pl. in all its senses; (M;) and is particularly applied to the [stars that are] followers of [other] stars; (T, M, O;) [and] its pl. is [also] rudaAfaI; (T;) which is particularly applied to drivers of camels; or drivers who urge camels, or excite them, by singing to them: (T, S, K:) and to aids, assistants, or auxiliaries; (S, K;) [as being a man's followers; or] because, when any one of them is fatigued, another takes his place: (S:) or, as some say, rudaAfaI is syn. with radiyfN: (T:) or it is also syn. with radiyfN, and (O, K) some say, (O,) a pl. thereof. (O, K.) ― -b3- The night: and the day: (K:) AlrRidofaAni signifying the night and the day, (T, S, O, K,) because each of them is a ridof to the other: (T:) and the morning, between daybreak and sunrise, and the evening, between sunset and nightfall; as also AlOaboradaAni and AlbarodaAni. (T in art. brd.) ― -b4- The consequence of an event, or affair; (S, O, K;) as also radafN↓. (O, K.) So the former in the saying, hecaA OamorN layosa lahu ridofu [This is an event, or affair, that has not, or will not have, any consequence, or result]. (S, O.) [So too radiyfN↓; the phrase AlrRadiyfu waAlmaroduwfu↓ meaning The consequence and that of which it is the consequence.] ― -b5- The hinder part of anything. (M.) ― -b6- The posteriors, or buttocks, (S, M, O, Msb,) or peculiarly, accord. to some, (M,) of a woman: pl. OarodaAfN; (M, Msb;) with which rawaAdifu is syn., but [ISd says,] I know not whether it be an extr. pl. of ridofN, or pl. of raAdifapN↓. (M.) ― -b7- ridofu Almaliki He who, in the Time of Ignorance, supplied the place of the king, (T, M,) in the management of the affairs of the realm, like the waziyr in the time of El-Islám, (T,) or like the SaAHibu AlXRuroTap in this our age: (M:) in the Time of Ignorance, (S,) he who sat on the right hand of the king, and, when the king drank, drank after him, before others, and, when the king went to war, sat in his place, (S, O, K, *) and was his vicegerent over the people until he returned, and, on the return of the king's army, took the fourth of the spoil: (S, O:) he also rode behind the king upon his horse: (Har p. 321:) pl. OarodaAfN. (T, S, M.) [See also AlrRidaAfapu.] ― -b8- AlrRidofu [is also a name of] The bright star [a] on the tail of the constellation AldRajaAjap [i. e. Cygnus; which star is also called AlcRanabu, and canabu AldRajaAjapi]; (Kzw;) a certain star near to AlnRasoru AlwaAqiEu [or a of Lyra]; (Lth, M, O, K;) and (M) so AlrRadiyfu↓; (S, M, O;) or this is another star near to Alnsr AlwAqE. (K.) And ridofu AlvRurayRaA i. q. AljawozaMCu [i. e. either Orion or Gemini]. (O.) ― -b9- Lebeed applies the dual ridofaAni to Two sailors in the hinder part of a ship. (O, K.)

radafN c
radafN: see ridofN, in the former half of the paragraph.

bahomN radofaI c
bahomN radofaI Lambs, or kids, brought forth in the xriyf [or autumn], and in the Sayof [meaning spring], in the last part of the period in which sheep, or goats, bring forth. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

ridaAfN c
ridaAfN The place upon which the radiyf, or ridof rides. (S, M, O, K.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph.

radiyfN c
radiyfN One who rides behind another (S, M, O, Msb, K) on the back of the [same] beast; (Msb;) as also ridofN↓ (S, M, O, Msb, K) and murotadifN↓: (S, K:) the pl. (M, K) of the first (M) is rudaAfaI, (M, K, [in my copy of the Msb rdfI, which is app. a mistranscription, and there said to be irreg.,]) or the pl. of radiyfN is ridaAfN, (S, [so in both of my copies,]) and rudafaMCu: (M:) and rudaAfaI↓ is used as a sing., syn. with radiyfN, (T, K,) accord. to some, (T,) as well as pl. [thereof]: (K:) or it is pl. of ridofN [q. v.]. (T.) [Hence,] one says, jaAWuwA rudaAfaI They came following one another. (K.) [Hence,] also, A Haqiybap, and the like, that is [conveyed] behind a man; [i. e. a bag, or receptacle, in which a man puts his travellingprovisions; and any other thing that is conveyed behind a man on his beast;] and so ridofN↓. (M.) ― -b2- See also ridofN, in two places. ― -b3- Also A star rising in the east, when its opposite star is setting in the west. (S, O, K.) And (K) A star facing a rising star: (Lth, M, O, * K:) used in this sense by Ru-beh; who terms the rising star raAkibu AlmiqodaAri. (Lth, M.) ― -b4- Also One who brings his arrow after the winning of one of the players at the game called Almayosir, or of two of them, and asks them to insert his arrow among theirs: (O, K:) or ridaAfN↓ [so in the M accord. to the TT, but app. a mistranscription,] signifies one who brings his arrow after they have divided among themselves the slaughtered camel, and who is not turned back by them disappointed, but is assigned by them a portion of what has become their shares. (M.)

AlrRidaAfapu c
AlrRidaAfapu The function of the ridof of a king, (S, O, K,) in the Time of Ignorance: (S: [see ridofN:]) a term similar to AlxilaAfapu: (K:) it pertained to the Benoo-Yarbooa, in that time; because there were not among the Arabs any who waged war more than they did against the kings of El- Heereh, who therefore made peace with them on the condition that the rdAfp should be assigned to them and that they should abstain from waging war against the people of El-'Irák: (S, O:) it was of two kinds; one being the riding behind the king upon his horse; and the other, what has been explained above, as from the S, voce ridofN. (Har p. 321.)

rudaAfaI c
rudaAfaI: see radiyfN [of which it is said to be a syn. and also a pl., or pl. of ridofN, q. v.].

AlrRaAdifapu c
AlrRaAdifapu, in the Kur lxxix. 7, means The second blast [of the horn on the day of resurrection]: (S, O, Bd, Jel, and K in art. rjf:) or the heaven, and the stars, which shall be cleft and scattered. (Bd.) [See also AlrRaAjifapu.] ― -b2- See also ridofN. ― -b3- rawaAdifu is pl. of raAdifapN and of raAduwfN↓. (K.) It signifies The [shoots that are termed] rawaAkiyb [pl. of raAkuwbN q. v. voce. raAkibN] of the palm-tree. (S, O, K.) And Streaks [or layers] of fat, overlying one another, in the hinder part of a camel's hump: those in the fore part are called rawaAkibu. (O * and K * in the present art., and A and K and TA in art. rkb.)

raAduwfN c
raAduwfN: see the next preceding paragraph.

Almaroduwfu c
[Almaroduwfu as opposed to AlrRadiyfu: see ridofN.]

muraAdifu lafoZK c
muraAdifu lafoZK, in the conventional language of lexicology, A synonym of a word or expression. (Mz, 27th nwE.) [See 3, last signification: and see also mutaraAdifu.]

murotadifN c
murotadifN: see radiyfN, first sentence.

mutaraAdifN c
mutaraAdifN, as a conventional term in lexicology, Synonymous: you say OalofaAZN mutaraAdifapN synonymous words or expressions. (Mz, 27th nwE.) [Loosely explained in the K by the words Oano yakuwna QsomFA liXRIoCK waAHidK, meaning significant of one thing; which is the contr. of muXotarakN, i. e. “ homonymous: ” and in like manner, AlmutaraAdifapu is expl. in the O, An tkwn OasomaMCF lXICK wAHdK; and is said to be post-classical.] mutaraAdifaAtN [its pl. when used
as a subst.] signifies Synonyms; i. e. single, or simple, words denoting the same thing considered in one and the same respect or light: thus the mutaraAdifaAni differ from the noun and the definition [thereof], because these [generally] are not both single words; and from the mutabaAyinaAni [or “ two disparates ”] such as AlsRayofu and AlSRaArimu, because these denote the same thing considered in two different respects, the one in respect of the substance, and the other in respect of the quality: (Fakhred-Deen [Er-Rázee] in the Mz, 27th nwE:) or they may be two simple words, as AllRayovu and AlOasadu; and two compound expressions, as, juluwsu AllRayovi and quEuwdu AlOasadi; and a single word and a compound expression, as AlmuzRu and AlHulowu AlHaAmiDu. (Kull p. 130.) [See also muraAdifu lafoZK.] [This art. is wanting in the copies of the L and TA to which I have had access.]

1 radama c
1. radama, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
radima
, (S, K,) or
raduma
, (M, Msb,) inf. n. radomN, (Lth, T, S, M, Msb,) He stopped up, or closed, syn. sadRa, (Lth, T, S, M, Msb, K,) a door, (Lth, T, M, K,) or a place of entrance, (T,) and a gap, or breach, (Lth, T, S, M, Msb, K,) and the like, (Lth, T, M, Msb,) wholly: (Lth, T, K:) or to the extent of a third thereof: (K:) or it signifies more than sadRa; (M, K;) [i. e. he stopped up by putting one thing upon another; as in building up a doorway or the like;] for AlrRadomu is “ that of which one part is put upon another. ” (M.) ― -b2- And radama, (S, TA,) inf. n. radomN; (TA;) and rdRm↓, inf. n. tarodiymN; (S, TA;) and trdRm↓; (S, K, TA;) He patched, or pieced, a garment, or piece of cloth; or patched, or pieced, it in several places. (S, K, TA.) ― -b3- And rudima It (anything) was put, and joined, or sewed, one part to another. (TA.) ＝ -A2- radama Alqawosa, (M,) inf. n. radomN, He caused the bow to make a sound, [i. e., to twang,] by pulling the string and then letting it go. (M, K. *) And rudimati Alqawosu The bow was so caused to make a sound. (T, M.) ＝ -A3- radama, aor. yarodimu, or yarodumu, with damm, (accord. to different copies of the S, [in one copy raduma, with damm, which is a mistake,]) inf. n. rudaAmN; (S, K; *) or radama, said of a camel, and of an ass, aor. yarodimu, (M,) inf. n. radomN, (M, K, *) and rudaAmN is the subst.; or radama bihaA, inf. n. radomN, used in a general manner; (M;) He broke wind, with a sound. (S, M, K. *) ＝ -A4- See also 4, in two places.

2 radRama
2: see 1. ― -b2- [Hence,] rdRm kalaAmahu, and trdRm↓ [i. e. trdRm klAmh] (tropical:) He considered repeatedly his saying, or speech, so as to rectify it, and repair what was defective thereof. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 5.

4 Oarodamati AlHumRI c
4. Oarodamati AlHumRI The fever continued, or was continuous; (T, S, M, K;) as also radamat↓: and in like manner one says of the saHaAb [or clouds]; and of the wirod [or coming to water, or company of men &c. coming to water, &c.]. (K.) You say, Oarodamato Ealayohi AlHumRaI The fever continued upon him: (M:) did not quit him. (T.) And Ardm Ealayohi AlmaraDu The disease clave to him. (M.) ― -b2- Oarodamati AlXRajarapu The tree became green after it had become dry; as also radamat↓. (K.) ＝ -A2- Ardm AlbaEiyra He felt the camel, to know if he were fat. (K.)

5 taradRama
5: see 1: ― -b2- and 2. ― -b3- Also trdRm fulaAnFA (tropical:) He sought to find in such a one something that he should be ashamed to expose, or some slip or fault, and obtained a knowledge of the state, or case, in which he was; (K, TA;) as though he imputed some error to him. (TA.) ― -b4- And trdRm Alqawomu AlOaroDa (assumed tropical:) The people, or party, consumed, or ate, the pasture (marotaE) of the land time after time [or part after part, app. so as to make the ground appear as though it were patched]. (M.) ＝ -A2- trdRm also signifies It (a garment, or piece of cloth,) was, or became, old, and worn out, requiring to be patched: (S, K: [see also 8:]) this verb being intrans. as well as trans. (S.) ＝ -A3- trdRmt, [or trdRmt EalaI waladihaA, as seems to be implied in the K,] She (a camel, M) inclined to, or affected, her young one; (M, K;) [perhaps from radama Alqawosa, because of her yearning cry;] as also EalaI waladihaA rdRmt↓, inf. n. tarodiymN. (K.) ＝ -A4- trdRmt AlxuSuwmapu The contention, or altercation, was, or became, far-extending, and long. (K. [See also 4.])

8 Artdm c
8. Artdm, said of a place, [a door, or a place of entrance, a gap, or breach, and the like, (see 1, first sentence,)] It was, or became, stopped up, or closed. (Msb.) ― -b2- [And app., said of a garment, or piece of cloth, It was, or became, old, and worn out, and patched, or pieced; or patched, or pieced, in several places: see its part. n., murotadimN: and see also 5.] ― -b3- [Also He put on, or he was, or became, clad with, old and worn-out garments. (Freytag, from the “ Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen. ”)]

radomN c
radomN is an inf. n. and also a subst. [in the proper sense of this term]: (S, M, TA:) as the latter, i. q. sadRN (S, K *) or sudRN (M) [as meaning A thing intervening between two other things, preventing the passage from one to the other; an obstruction; a barrier; any building with which a place is obstructed]; a meaning erroneously assigned in the B to radamN: (TA:) or a thing of which one part is put upon another: (M:) a rampart, or fortified barrier: it is larger than a sdR; and is [said to be] from vawobN muradRamN meaning “ [a garment, or piece of cloth,] having patches upon patches: ” (Bd in xviii. 94:) and signifies also anything having parts put, and joined or sewed, one upon another: (M:) pl. ruduwmN. (M, K.) AlrRadomu also signifies particularly The rampart (AlsRudRu, M, or AlsRadRu, K) that is between us [meaning the people of the territory of the Muslims] and Yájooj and Májooj [or Gog and Magog]: (M, K, * TA:) mentioned in the Kur xviii. 94. (TA.) And What falls, [and lies in a heap, one part upon another,] of a wall in a state of demolition. (M, K.) ＝ -A2- Also A sound, (M, K,) in a general sense: (K:) or particularly the sound [or twang] of a bow. (M, K.) ― -b2- And An emission of wind from the anus, with a sound; (M, K;) as also rudaAmN↓: (S, K:) or this is a subst. from radama said of a camel, and of an ass, meaning “ he broke wind with a sound. ” (M.) ― -b3- And, applied to a man, (M,) (assumed tropical:) One in whom is no good; and so rudaAmN↓, (M, K,) and mirodaAmN↓. (K.)

rudaAmN c
rudaAmN: see the next preceding paragraph, last two sentences.

raduwmN c
[raduwmN One who often breaks wind, with a sound: used in this sense by Jereer. (Freytag.)]

radiymN c
radiymN An old, and worn-out, garment, or piece of cloth: (T, S, K:) and a garment, or piece of cloth, patched, or pieced; or patched, or pieced, in several places; (S;) and so muradRamN↓; (Lth, T, S, K;) like muladRamN: (Lth, T:) or muradRamN↓ signifies having patches upon patches: (Bd in xviii. 94:) or this last, and murotadimN↓ and mutaradRimN↓, a garment, or piece of cloth, old, and worn-out, and patched, or pieced, or patched or pieced in several places: (M:) or mutaradRimN↓, a garment, or piece of cloth, old, and worn out, requiring to be patched: (S:) the pl. of radiymN is rudumN. (Lth, T, K.)

radiymapN c
radiymapN [in some copies of the K radiymaAni, which, as is said in the TA, is a mistranscription,] Two garments, or pieces of cloth, that are sewed together; (M, K;) like what is called lifaAq; (M, TA;) in the copies of the K, erroneously, lifaAf: (TA:) pl. rudumN, (M, K, [in a copy of the M, accord. to the TA, ruduwm,]) as though the p [in the sing.] were imagined to be rejected. (M.) HumRaI murodimN, (S, M,) and saHaAbN murodimN, (S,) and wirodN murodimN, (TA,) [A fever, and clouds, and a coming to water, or a company of men &c. coming to water, &c.,] continuing, or continuous. (S, M, TA.)

muradRamN c
muradRamN: see radiymN, in two places.

mirodaAmN c
mirodaAmN: see radomN, last sentence.

murotadimN c
murotadimN: see radiymN.

mutaradRamN c
mutaradRamN A place, of a garment, or piece of cloth, that is to be patched, or pieced, (T, S, K,) syn. mutaraqRaEN; and to be repaired, or mended, syn. mutaSalRaHN. (T.) 'Antarah says, [commencing his mo'allakah,]
halo gaAdara AlXRuEaraMCu mino mutaradRami
Oamo halo Earafota AldRaAra baEoda tawahRumi
(T, S, M,) i. e. (assumed tropical:) [Have the poets left any deficiency to be supplied? or,] any discourse to be annexed to other discourse? meaning, they have preceded me in saying, and left no say for a sayer [after them]: (M:) or have the poets left any place to be patched, or pieced, which they have not patched, or pieced, and repaired? meaning, the former has not left for the latter anything respecting which to mould his verses; i. e. poets have preceded me not leaving for me any place that I may patch, or piece, nor any place that I may repair: then he digresses, and says, address-
ing himself, [Nay but I have somewhat to say:] hast thou known the abode of thy beloved, 'Ableh, after thy doubting respecting it? (EM pp. 219 — 220.)

mutaradRimN c
mutaradRimN: see radiymN, in two places.

1 radVna
1: [radanato, aor. app.
raduna
, but accord. to Freytag
radina
, inf. n. radonN, She (a woman) spun thread with the mirodan: see radanN:] AlrRadonu and Algazolu are nearly the same [in meaning]. (Ham p. 218. [Hence maroduwnN applied to spun thread.]) ― -b2- [And app. She wove a garment, or piece of cloth, with spun thread such as is termed maroduwnN, or radanN: whence maroduwnN applied to such a garment, or piece of cloth.] ― -b3- The vulgar say of him who is drowsing, drowsy, or heavy with sleep, Eayonuhu trdnu watagozilu [perhaps tarodinu, to assimilate it to tagozilu, app. meaning (assumed tropical:) His eye blinks, twinkles, or moves its lids to and for; like the hand that spins thread in two different directions, or that throws the shuttle to and fro]. (Ham ubi suprà.) ― -b4- And radanotu AlmataAEa, (S,) aor.
raduna
, (JM, PS,) inf. n. radonN, (S, K,) I put the goods, household-goods, or commodities, one upon another; or put them, or set them, together, in regular order, or piled up. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- radonN also signifies The making, or causing, to smoke. (K.) You say, radana AlnRaAra, aor.
radina
, inf. n. radonN, He made, or caused, the fire to smoke. (TK.) ＝ -A3- radina jiloduhu, (S, K, *) aor.
radana
, inf. n. radanN, (S,) His skin became contracted, shrunk, or wrinkled. (S, K. *)

2 radRana
2: see what next follows.

4 Ardn AlqamiySa c
4. Ardn AlqamiySa He put, or made, a rudon [q. v.] to the shirt; as also rdRnhu↓, (S, K,) inf. n. tarodiynN: (S:) or he put, or made, OarodaAn [pl. of rudon] to the shirt. (M.) ＝ -A2- Ardnt Ealayohi AlHumRaI i. q. Ardmt [i. e. The fever continued upon him]. (S: in some copies of which, as in the TA, Elyh is omitted.)

8 Artdnt c
8. Artdnt She (a woman, TA) took to herself, or made, a mirodan [q. v.], (K, TA,) for spinning. (TA.)

Q. Q. 1 rawodana c
Q. Q. 1. rawodana, (K,) inf. n. rawodanapN, (TA,) He was, or became, fatigued, tired, weary, or jaded, (K, TA,) and weak, or feeble. (TA.)

radonN c
radonN The sound of the falling [or clashing] of weapons, one upon another. (S, K.)

rudonN c
rudonN The base (OaSol) of the sleeve: (S, K:) [app. meaning the part thereof that is next to the shoulder: but see what follows:] the fore part of the sleeve of the shirt: (M:) or the lower part thereof: (M, and Har pp. 149 and 390:) or the sleeve altogether: (M:) and it may tropically mean the whole garment: (Har p. 390:) pl. OarodaAnN. (S, M, K. [In the TA is added, and Ardnp; as though another pl. were OarodinapN: but I think that this is a mistake, originating in a copy of the M; for, immediately after OarodaAnN, in the M, is added, waOarodanahu jaEala lahu OarodaAnFA; and I suspect that in some copy thereof, wArdnh has been inadvertently written twice.]) You say qamiySN waAsiEu AlrRudoni [A shirt wide in the rdn]. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, huwa danisu AlOarodaAni (tropical:) [meaning He is foul in character, conduct, or the like; for it is tropical]. (A in art. dns. [See, there, other similar phrases.]) ＝ -A2- See also rudayoniIRN. ＝ -A3- [Also pl. of Oarodanu, q. v.]

radanu c
radanu Spun thread: (Sh, T, S, K:) or spun thread that is not even: (T:) or thread spun [by moving the hand] forwards [upon the spindle against the thigh]: or spun thread that is manokuws [i. e. twisted in a manner the reverse of that which is usual: see XazorN]: thread spun with the mirodan. (M. [See maroduwnN.]) ― -b2- And [Cloth of the kind termed] xazR: (AA, T, S, M, K, and Ham p. 218:) or yellow xazR: (AA, T:) or what is woven from what women spin with the mirodan (mmA trdnh AlnsAC): (Ham ubi suprà: [see, again, maroduwnN:]) or silk; i. q. qazRN; (M;) or HariyrN. (TA.) ― -b3- And The [membrane called] giros [q. v.] that comes forth with the young (S, K, TA) from the belly of its mother. (TA.) The Arabs say, hecaA midoraEu AlrRadani [This is the giros]. (S, TA.) ― -b4- See also raAdinN.

rumoHN rudayoniIRN c
rumoHN rudayoniIRN [meaning A well-straightened spear; lit. a spear of Rudeyneh]: and qanaApN rudayoniyRapN [the same, or a well-straightened spear-shaft]: (S:) and rimaAHN rudayoniyRapN [well-straightened spears]: (M:) accord. to their [the Arabs'] assertion, (S,) so called in relation to a woman named Rudeyneh, (S, M,) wife of Es-Semharee [or Semhar]; both of whom used to straighten spears, or spear-shafts, in Khatt-Hejer: and some say xaTRiyRapN rudonN↓ [wellstraightened spears of El-Khatt], and rimaAHN rudonN. (S.) [See an ex. in a verse cited in art. cwq, 6th conj.]

raAdinN c
raAdinN Saffron; (S, K;) as also radanN↓. (Sgh, TA in art. XEr.)

OaHomaru raAdiniIRN c
OaHomaru raAdiniIRN A camel, (As, T,) or a thing, (S,) of which the redness is mixed with yellowness, (As, T, S, K,) like waros [q. v.]: (As, T:) hence the epithet raAdiniIRN is applied to a he-camel, (S, TA,) and with p to a she-camel: (As, T, S:) or raAdiniIRN is applied to a he-camel as meaning having crisp, or curly, fur, of generous race, (Lth, T, M,) beautiful, (Lth, T,) and inclining a little to blackness: (Lth, T, M:) or intensely red; (TA, and Ham p. 218;) or it has this meaning also: (M:) or between yellow and red: accord. to some, from raAdinN signifying “ saffron; ” (Ham ubi suprà;) but As says, I know not in relation to what thing the camel is called by this epithet. (M.) They said also Oaromaku raAdiniIRN [i. e. Intensely dun or brown or dusky &c.]; to denote intensiveness; like as they said OaboyaDu naASiEN. (IAar, M.)

Oarodanu c
Oarodanu [or xazRN Oarodanu] A sort of [cloth of the kind termed] xazR, (S, K,) red: (S:) [pl. rudonN:] and [hence] viyaAbN rudonN Red garments or cloths. (So in one of my copies of the S.)

OurodunN c
OurodunN, (ISK, T, S, M, and so in some copies of the K,) in some of the copies of the K erroneously said to be with the r musheddedeh, (TA,) [in the CK with the d, which is also a mistake,] A drowsiness, or dozing: (S, K:) or an overpowering drowsiness or dozing: a poet uses the phrase naEosapN OurodunRN: (ISk, T:) or this means an intense drowsiness or dozing: (M:) Yákoot says that it appears to signify intenseness and an overpowering, because there is no meaning in one's saying naEosapN naEosapN. (TA.) It is a word of which no verb has been heard. (S.) Hence, accord. to ISK, AlOurodunRu as the name of a certain province; (T;) a province of Syria, (S, K,) and a river thereof [i. e. the Jordan]; (S;) also without teshdeed. (TA.)

murodinN c
murodinN Dark; (S, M, K;) applied to night. (M.) ― -b2- Also, applied to sweat, Stinking: (K:) or, thus applied, that wets all the skin: (M:) [or] maroduwnN↓ has the latter meaning, thus applied. (T.)

mirodanN c
mirodanN A spindle (S, M, K) with which [the thread termed] radan is spun: (M, TA:) pl. maraAdinu. (TA.)

maroduwnN c
maroduwnN is applied as an epithet to gazol [i. e. spun thread, meaning Spun with the mirodan: see also radanN]. (M.) ― -b2- Also to a garment, or piece of cloth, (M,) meaning Woven (Sh, T, M) with spun thread that is maroduwn. (M.) Aboo-Duwád El-Iyádee says,
OasoOadato layolapF wayawomFA falamRaA
daxalato fiI musarobaxK maroduwni
[She (app. referring to a camel) hastened in her journey, or journeyed on without stopping to rest, a night and a day; and when she entered a desert, or waterless desert, far-extending, wide, or spacious, woven with the mirage, or overspread by a rippling mirage resembling a web: or they (i. e. camels) hastened &c.]: Sh says that maroduwn signifies woven: and the poet means, by msrbx mrdwn, a tract of land in which was the mirage: (T:) or mrdwn here means woven with the mirage: (TA in art. srbx:) or, as some say, by mrdwn he means maroduwm, [app. as signifying conjoined, so as to be uninterrupted, (see radama,)] and has changed the m into n; and msrbx means wide, or spacious: (T:) or mrdwn signifies mawoSuwl [which has the meaning that I have assigned above to mrdwm]: (T, K:) so some say. (T.) ― -b3- See also murodinN.

1 radaA c
1. radaA aor. yarodiw said of a horse: see 1 in art. rdI. ― -b2- And radaAhu biHajarK, aor. yaroduwhu, inf. n. radowN: see 1 in art. rdI.

3 rAdAhu c
3. rAdAhu, said to be formed by transposition from raAwadahu, [and therefore it should properly be
mentioned in this art.,] is explained in art. rdI.

1 radiIa c
1. radiIa aor. yarodaI, inf. n. radFI, He (a man, TA) perished. (S, M, Msb, K.)
