[See an ex. in the Kur xx. 17.] ― -b2- And radiIa (AZ, T, M, and so in a copy of the S,) aor. yarodaI, (AZ, T,) inf. n. radFI; (M;) or radaI; (K, and so in copies of the S;) or both of these verbs; aor. of the latter yarodiI; (TA;) and trdRI↓; (S, M, K;) He fell into a well: (AZ, * T, * S, K:) or he tumbled down into a deep hollow, or cavity, or pit: (M:) or ↓the last of these verbs has this meaning: (Lth, T:) or it signifies he fell into a deep hollow, or cavity, or pit: (Msb:) or he tumbled down (S) from a mountain; (AZ, T, S;) and so the first, or second: (S:) and trdRI↓ signifies he fell from a mountain and died. (TA.) UicaA taradRaI↓, in the Kur [xcii. 11], means When he falls into the abyss of the fire [of Hell]: (T, * TA:) or into the cavity of the grave: or into the lowest depth of Hell: or when he perishes: (Bd:) or when he dies. (T.) ― -b3- And radaI He (a man) went away. (K.) You say, maA OadoriI Oayona radaI I know not whither he went away, or has gone away. (S.) ＝ -A2- radaAhu, (S, M, K,) aor. yarodiI, (M,) inf. n. radoIN, (TK,) He broke it; (M, K;) namely, a thing with a stone: (M:) or he beat it, [or battered it,] namely, a stone with a piece of rock, or with a pickaxe, in order to break it. (S.) ― -b2- And He dashed himself against him, or knocked against him, (S, K, TA,) like as the pickaxe knocks against the stone. (TA.) ― -b3- And radaAhu biHajarK, (T, K,) or biHijaArapK, (S,) aor. yarodiI, inf. n. radoIN; (T;) and radaAhu biHajarK, (K and TA in art. rdw,) aor. yaroduw, inf. n. radowN, (TA,) with w for the final radical; (K, TA;) [like radaOahu, and daraOahu;] He threw at him, or threw at him and hit him, with a stone, or stones. (T, S, M.) [It is also said in the T, with reference to mirodaApN, as signifying a large stone with which other stones are beaten, or battered, AlrRadoIu UinRamaA huwa rafoEN bihaA waramoIN bihaA; but I think that rafoEN is a mistranscription for dafoEN; and that the meaning intended to be expressed by these words is, that radoIN signifies The thrusting with a mirodaAp; and the throwing it, or with it.] ― -b4- [Hence, app.,] radaI said of a horse, (As, ISk, T, S, M, K,) aor. yarodiI, (As, ISk, T, S, K,) inf. n. radoIN and radayaAnN; (ISk, S, M, K;) and radaA, (K and TA in art. rdw, [in the CK, w is omitted before the word lugapN in that art.,]) aor. yaroduw; (TA;) [and, accord. to Freytag, ArtdI↓ is used in the same sense by Jereer;] He beat, or battered, the ground, (rajama AlOaroDa, As, ISk, T, S, ISk, T, S, M, K,) with his hoofs, (M, K, TA,) in running, (As, T,) or in going along, and in running, (M,) or in going a pace between running and vehement walking: (ISk, S:) or radayaAnN signifies the same as taqoriybN: (AZ, T, M: [see 2 in art. qrb:]) or it is [a manner of going] between running and walking: (K:) or the running (T, S, M) of the horse (T) or of the ass (S, M) between his MriIR [or place of confinement, or the loop to which he is tied,] and his mutamaERak [or place of rolling upon the ground]; (T, S, M;) thus explained by El-Munteji' Ibn-Nebhán, (T, S,) to As. (S.) In the K, rajamato is erroneously put for rajama; being app. taken from the M, in which it refers to horses; [not to a single horse;] as does also the pronoun in biHawaAfirihaA, in the same portion of the passage in the K and in the M. (TA.) Accord. to AZ, this is from radayaAnu AljawaAriI, explained in what follows. (Ham p. 221.) ― -b5- You say, radati AljaAriyapu The girl raised one leg and went along upon the other, in play; (K, TA;) and so Airotadat↓: (TA:) and AljawaAriI yurodiyna, inf. n. radayaAnN; (M;) or yarotadiyna↓; (T;) the girls played, (T, M,) raising one leg, (M,) or one of them raising one leg, (T,) and going along upon the other: (T, M:) or radayaAnu AljawaAriI signifies the girls' playing in which one of them raises one leg and steps with the other two steps, and then puts it down and raises the other, doing thus several times. (AZ, Ham p. 221.) And radaI AlgulaAmu The boy raised one leg and leaped, or jumped, [or hopped,] with the other. (S.) And radaI AlguraAbu, (M, K,) aor. yarodiI, (T,) The crow, or raven, raised one leg and hopped on the other; or leaped along. (T, M, K.) ＝ -A3- radato ganamiI My sheep, or goats, increased, or exceeded; as also Oarodato↓. (Fr, M, K.) ― -b2- And radayotu EalaI AlXRaIoCi and Ardyt↓ I exceeded the thing. (M.) And EalaI gayorihi ArdI↓ It exceeded another thing; as also ArdO [q. v.] (M in art. rdO.) And radayotu EalaI Alxamosiyna, (S, M, *) and AlvRamaAniyna, (M,) and Ardyt↓, (S,) I exceeded [the age of fifty, and eighty]. (S, M. *)

2 rdRAhu c
2. rdRAhu, (Msb, K,) inf. n. tarodiyapN, (Msb,) He made him to fall, or threw him down, (Msb, K,) into a deep hollow, or cavity, or pit, (Msb,) or into a well; as also ArdAhu↓. (K.) He (God) overthrew him; as also ArdAhu↓. (M.) ＝ -A2- radRayotuhu, inf. n. as above, I clad him with a ridaMC [q. v.]. (S.)

3 raAdayotu Ean Alqawom c
3. raAdayotu Ean Alqawom, (S, K. *) inf. n. muraAdaApN, (S,) I contended in throwing stones in defence of the people, or party. (S, K. *) ＝ -A2- rAdAhu, (T, S, M, K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) is also syn. with raAwadahu [He endeavoured to turn him; or to turn him by blandishment, or by deceitful arts; or to entice him to turn]; (S, M, K;) formed from the latter by transposition; (S;) or daAwarahu [which means the same]; EalaI AlOamori [to the thing, or affair]: (T as on the authority of A 'Obeyd:) and daAraAhu [which means the same; or he treated him with gentleness, or blandishment; soothed, coaxed, wheedled, or cajoled, him; or he deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted, him; or endeavoured, or desired, to do so]; (S, M, K; the first as on the authority of A 'Obeyd;) or, accord. to AA, i. q. daAjaAhu and daAlaAhu and faAnaAhu [all of which are syn. with daAraAhu]. (T.)

4 ArdAhu c
4. ArdAhu He (i. e. God, M, or another, S, M *) caused him to perish; or destroyed him. (S, M, K.) Hence, (M,) in the Kur [xxxvii. 54], Uino kidota laturodiyni Verily thou almost causedst me to perish, or destroyedst me. (T, M. *) ― -b2- See also 2, in two places. ― -b3- Also He made him (i. e. a horse) to go in the manner signified by the verb radaI [q. v., meaning, beating, or battering, the ground, &c.]: so accord. to the M and K, except that, in both, the fem. pronoun is used, in the M referring to horses, and in the K improperly referring to a single horse. (TA.) ― -b4- See also 1, last four sentences.

5 trdRI c
5. trdRI: see 1, second and third sentences, in four places. ― -b2- He was, or became, overthrown. (M.) ＝ -A2- Also, and ArtdI↓, He put on, or clad himself with, or wore, a ridaMC [q. v.]: (S, K: but in the latter the verbs are fem. [as said of a woman]:) or so trdRI biridaMCK and bihi ArtdI↓. (M, Msb.) ― -b2- And trdRI bisayofihi, and ArtdI↓, (assumed tropical:) He hung upon himself his sword, putting its suspensory belt or cord upon his neck or shoulder; syn. taqalRadahu. (M.) ― -b3- And trdRt AljaAriyapu (assumed tropical:) The girl, or young woman, put on, or decked herself with, a wiXaAH [q. v.], which is also called ridaMC. (T, K.)

8 ArtdI c
8. ArtdI: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph, in three places. ＝ -A2- See also 5, in three places: and see an ex. voce ridaMCN ― -b2- [Hence,] AirotadaAniI He carried me, or bore me, upon his shoulder, in the place of the ridaMC. (Ham p. 471.)

radFI c
radFI an inf. n. of radiIa [q. v.]. (S, M, Msb, K.) ＝ -A2- Also Excess, redundance, or superfluity; syn. ziyaAdapN: so in the saying, maA balagotu radaI EaTiyRatika, i. e. I have not attained to thy excess, &c., in thy gift: and yuEojibuniI radaI qawolika The excess of thy saying pleases me: and so in the saying of Kutheiyir,
lahu Eahodu wudRK lamo yakadRaro yaziynuhu
radaI qawoli maEoruwfK HadiyvK wamuzomini
meaning [He has a covenant of love, or affection, into which he has entered, which has not been sullied, and] which excess of kind speech, on his part, [recent and of long duration,] adorns: (T:) or, [as ISd cites the verse,] qawoli maEoruwfK radiI↓ &c.: [and he adds,] it is said, in explanation thereof, that radiI means ziyaAdap; and I think that it is an inf. n., of the measure faEilN, like DaHikN and HabiqN, or a subst. put in the place of an inf. n. (M.) ＝ -A3- See also radaApN.

radK c
radK [originally radiIN] Perishing; (IAar, T, S, M, K;) applied to a man: fem. radiyapN. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- See also the next preceding paragraph.

ridoyapN c
ridoyapN A mode, or manner, of wearing the ridaMC: (S, M, * Msb: *) like rikobapN from AlrRukuwbu, and jilosapN from Aljuluwsu: (S:) you say, huwa Hasanu AlrRidoyapi [He is comely in respect of the manner of wearing the rdMC] (S, M, Msb.)

radaApN c
radaApN A rock; or piece of rock; or great mass of
stone, or of hard stone: (Fr, T, S, K:) pl. radayaAtN (Fr, T) and [coll. gen. n.] radFI↓. (S, K.)

ridaMCN c
ridaMCN A certain garment; (S, Msb;) a kind of miloHafap [or outer wrapping garment], (M, K,) well known; (K;) one of the garments that are not cut and sewed; (Mgh in art. qTE, and MF voce UizaArN;) [being of a single piece;] covering the upper half of the body; or lying upon the shoulders and back; (MF voce UizaArN;) or falling upon the belly and there ending: (TA voce SiforN:) [a rdAC worn by Mohammad, “thrown over the left shoulder and wrapped round the body under the right arm,” is described as “four cubits long and two cubits and a span wide:” (Sprenger's Life of Mohammad, Part I, English ed., pp. 86 and 87:)] it is of the masc. gender, and it is not allowable to make it fem.: (IAmb, Msb:) the dual is ridaAMni and ridaAwaAni the latter being allowable, (S, Msb,) but the former being preferable: (S:) and the pl. is OarodiyapN: (S, M, Msb:) the ridaMC is also called ridaMCapN↓, (M, K, TA, [in the CK ridAp,]) like as the UizaAr is also called UizaArapq; (M;) and mirodaApN↓, (K, TA, in the CK marodAp,) of which the pl. is maraAdK↓, (TA,) occurring in the saying,
maraAdiIa AlHariyri laA yarotadiI↓
walaA yuraI bisudRapi AlOamiyri
UilRaA liHalobi AlXRaAopi waAlbaEiyri
[He will not wear outer wrapping garments of silk, nor will he be seen at the porch of the commander, or prince, unless for the purpose of milking the sheep, or goat, and the camel]; (M, TA;) AlmaraAdiI meaning AlOarodiyap; (M;) but accord. to Th, it has no sing.: (M, TA:) [or] maraAdK↓ signifies waist-wrappers; syn. OuzurN. (K.) ― -b2- Hence, Siforu ridaAYihaA, in a description of Umm-Zara, in a trad., meaning (assumed tropical:) Lank in her belly; as though her rdMC were empty. (TA in art. Sfr.) ― -b3- And gamoru AlrRidaMCi (tropical:) Abounding in beneficence. (T, M, K, TA.) And EayoXN gamoru AlrRidaMCi (tropical:) A life ample, or plentiful, in its means. (TA.) ― -b4- And ridaMCu AlXRabaAbi (assumed tropical:) The beauty, and softness, tenderness, or delicateness, of youth. (T.) ― -b5- And ridaMCu AlXRamosi (assumed tropical:) The light, (M,) or beauty and light, (T,) of the sun. (T, M.) ― -b6- ridaMCN also signifies (assumed tropical:) A sword; (T, M, K;) [ISd says,] I think, as being likened to the garment thus called; (M;) [i. e.] because it is hung, by its suspensory cords, upon the neck and shoulder [like that garment]. (T.) [See also mirodFI, near the end of the paragraph.] Mutemmem says,
laqado kafRana AlminohaAlu taHota ridaAYihi
fatFI gayora miboTaAni AlEaXiyRaAti OarowaEaA
[Verily El-Minhál has shrouded beneath his sword a young man not voracious in the evenings, when the chief meal is eaten, one who excited the admiration of the beholder]: for El-Minhál had slain his [the poet's] brother Málik; and when a man slew another who was a celebrated man, he used to lay his sword upon him, in order that his slayer might be known. (M. [But see, in relation to this verse, a long story in the Ham pp. 370-372.]) And El-Khansà says,
jaEalota ridaMCaka fiyhaA ximaAraA
wadaAhiyapK jarRahaA jaArimN
[And in many a calamity which a committer of a crime has brought to pass, thou hast made thy sword to be as a covering to the head]; meaning, thou hast smitten, therein, the necks of thine enemies with thy sword like the xmAr [which means a woman's “muffler” and a man's “turban”]. (T.) ― -b7- Also (assumed tropical:) A bow; (AAF, M, IAth;) because it is borne upon the shoulder, which is the place of the rdAC [properly thus called]. (IAth, TA.) ― -b8- And [for the like reason] (assumed tropical:) The [ornament called] wiXaAH [q. v., worn by women]. (T, K.) So in a verse of El-Aashà, cited voce raqoraqa. (T.) ― -b9- And (assumed tropical:) A bier; because it is borne upon the place of the rdAC [properly thus called, i. e., upon the shoulder]. (Ham p. 471.) ― -b10- And (assumed tropical:) Debt; (T, M, K;) because it is [regarded as] a thing that cleaves to the neck of the debtor, like as the rdAC [properly thus called] cleaves to the shoulders of the wearer. (T.) You say, huwa xafiyfu AlrRidaMCi, meaning (tropical:) He is little burdened in respect of debt: and also, in respect of household. (K, * TA.) [See also an ex. voce nasaMCN.] ― -b11- Also (assumed tropical:) Intelligence: ― -b12- and (assumed tropical:) ignorance: (M, K:) both on the authority of IAar: (M:) ― -b13- he says also that it means (assumed tropical:) anything that is the pride, or ornament, of a person; (T, M;) even, (M,) for instance, one's house, and one's father; (T, M;) or one's house and one's beast; (so in the TA;) each of these, he says, is one's rdAC [or (assumed tropical:) pride]: (T:) thus, (M,) it is (assumed tropical:) a thing that graces: and (assumed tropical:) a thing that disgraces: (M, K:) so that it has two contr. meanings: thus in the K, referring to the meanings of “intelligence” and “ignorance:” but this requires consideration. (TA.)

ridaMCapN c
ridaMCapN: see the next preceding paragraph, first signification.

radiIRN c
radiIRN: see radiIoCN, in art. rdO

AlrRaAdiI c
AlrRaAdiI The lion; (K;) because he dashes himself (yarodiI i. e. yaSodimu) [against his prey]. (TA.)

mirodFI c
mirodFI A stone that is thrown; (S, K;) as also mirodaApN↓: (T, S:) or a piece of rock with which date-stones are broken: (Ham p. 417:) and accord. to ISk, ↓the latter signifies a piece of rock with which stones are broken, (S,) or with which one breaks [anything]: (M:) or a stone which the strong man can hardly, or not at all, lift with his hands; [like mirodaOapN; (TA in art. rdO;)] with which stones are broken; and with which they beat and soften a rugged place that they hollow out; and with which the hole of the [lizard called] DabR is broken, or battered, when it is among large stones (fI qlEp [i. e. fiI qalaEapK]), which qlEp it softens and demolishes: (En-Nadr, T:) the same word (mrdAp) also signifies the stone, (T,) or the piece of rock, (M,) by means of which the DabR is guided to its hole: (T, M:) [and accord. to Golius, on the authority of Meyd and the Mirkát el-Loghah, the upper mill-stone:] the pl. of mirodaApN is maraAdK↓: (T:) and this pl. is [also] syn. with maraAmK [app. as pl. of miromaApN, and meaning the arrows thus called; or any missiles]. (M.) Hence the prov., Einoda juHori kulRi DabRK mirodaAtuhu↓ [Near by the hole of every dabb is its stone that is to be thrown at it, or its stone by means of which it guides itself to that hole]; applied to a thing that is near at hand, having no obstacle in the way to it; for the dabb will not be guided to its hole, when it goes forth from it and returns to it, except by means of a stone which it places as a mark to point out its hole: (T:) or kulRu DabRK Einodahu mirodaAtuhu↓ (S, M, Meyd) i. e. Every dabb has near by it its stone that is to be thrown at it; (S, * Meyd;) for the dabb has little knowledge, therefore it prepares not its hole save by a stone that may be a mark thereof, so that he who seeks it finds the stone that is to be thrown at the dabb near to it; therefore the prov. means that thou shouldst not feel secure from accidents, because calamities are prepared with every time, or period; and it is applied to him who exposes himself to destruction. (Meyd.) Hence also, i. e. from mirodFI in the first of the senses assigned to it above, (S,) or in the second of those senses, (Ham p. 417,) said of a courageous man, UinRahu lamirodaI HuruwbK (assumed tropical:) [Verily he is like the missile of wars]; (S;) or fulaAnN mirodaI AlHuruwbi (assumed tropical:) [Such a one is like the crushing stone of the wars]; or mirodaI AlxuSuwmi, i. e. (assumed tropical:) he whom they throw against the antagonists and who crushes them: (Ham ubi suprà:) and humo maraAdiI AlHuruwbi: [maraAdK being pl. of mirodFI, as well as of mirodaApN:] (S:) and fulaAnN mirodaI xuSuwmapK waHarobK (assumed tropical:) Such a one is very patient in the endurance of contention and war. (M.) mirodFI is also used as meaning (assumed tropical:) A horse hard like the stone thus called; thus in a verse of 'Antarah: or it there means a horse that runs swiftly; from AlrRadayaAnu [an inf. n. of radaI, q. v.]: or it is from AlrRadaI [inf. n. of radiIa, and syn. therewith], meaning perdition: or it means, in that verse, [like ridaMCN,] a sword, [as being an instrument of perdition,] from AlrRadaI. (Ham p. 207.) mirodaApN↓, also, (S,) or naAqapN mirodaApN, (TA,) is used as meaning (assumed tropical:) A she-camel like the stone thus called in hardness. (S, TA.) And maraAdK↓ [as pl. of mirodFI or of mirodaApN] means also (assumed tropical:) The legs of camels, (Lth, T, M, K,) and of the elephant (Lth, T, K) or of elephants; as being likened to the stones thus called; (M, TA;) or because of their heaviness, and vehemence of tread. (T, TA.) ― -b2- Also mirodFI, (so in the S,) or murodiIRN↓, with damm [to the l] and with shedd [to the I], (K,) A pole with which a ship, or boat, is propelled, (S, K,) being in the hand of the sailor: (S:) pl. [of the former] maraAdK, (S,) or [of the latter] maraAdiIRu: (K:) in the dial. of the vulgar midorI [pronounced by them midoraI, without tenween, or midoraA, for midoraON]; pl., with the art., AlmadaAriI [and vulgarly pronounced madaAriI also without the art.]. (TA.)

mirodaApN c
mirodaApN, and its pl. maraAdK (which is also pl. of mirodFI): see the next preceding paragraph, in seven places: ― -b2- and see also ridaMCN, in three places.

murodiIRN c
murodiIRN: see mirodFI, last sentence.

AimoraOapN hayofaMCu AlmuradRaI c
AimoraOapN hayofaMCu AlmuradRaI A woman lank, or slender, in the place of the [ornament called] wiXaAH [q. v.]. (T.)

AlmutaradRiyapu c
AlmutaradRiyapu, in the Kur v. 4, means That which falls from a mountain, or into a well, or from an elevated place, and dies. (T.) The sheep or goat thus termed is forbidden [to be eaten] because it has died without having been slaughtered according to the law. (Msb.)

1 racVca
1: see what next follows.

4 ArcRt AlsRamaMCu c
4. ArcRt AlsRamaMCu, (T, S, M, A, K,) inf. n. UirocaAdN; (T, TA;) and racRat↓, (A, K,) inf. n. racaAcN, (TA,) or rucaAcN; (so in the TT as from the T;) The sky rained, or let fall, such rain as is termed racaAc [explained below]. (T, S, M, A, K.) And baAtati AlsRamaMCu turicRunaA The sky during the night rained upon us, or let fall upon us, such rain as is so termed. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ArcR AlsRiqaMCu, (inf. n. as above, T,) (tropical:) The water-skin, or milk-skin, exuded, or let flow, what was in it. (T, A, L, K.) And ArcRt AlXRajRap (tropical:) The wound in the head flowed with what was in it. (T, A, L, K.) And ArcRt AlEayonu bimaAYihaA (tropical:) The eye flowed with its water. (T, A, L.)

racacN c
racacN: see what next follows.

racaAcN c
racaAcN, (T, S, M, A, L, K,) and by poetic license racacN↓, (M, L,) Weak [or drizzling] rain, (S, M, L, K,) but exceeding what is termed qiToqiT: (S, L:) or fine rain, but exceeding what is termed TalR: (A:) or the lightest of rain except what is termed TalR: (As, T:) or, accord. to El-Khattábee, and Suh in the R, rain more than what is termed TaXR and bagoX, but a little less strong than what is termed TalR, or like this last: (MF, TA:) or still, continuous rain, consisting of small drops, resembling dust: or such as is after [app. meaning more than] what is termed TalR: (M, L, K:) n. un. racaAcapN. (M.) To such rain, the poet Bakhdaj, using the abbreviated form of the word, likens some of his verses; not as meaning weak, but as meaning continuous, or uninterrupted, and unruffled; while he likens others of his verses to rain such as is termed waAbil. (M.) One says, yawomunaA yawomu racaAcK wasuruwrK waQloticaAcK [Our day is a day of fine rain, &c., and of happiness, and of delectation]. (A.) ― -b2- Hence, (assumed tropical:) A little wealth or property. (Har p. 57.) One says, naHonu naroDaI biracaAci nayolika waraXaAXi sayolika (tropical:) [We are content with a little of what is obtained of thy bounty, and with the sprinkling of thy torrent of munificence]. (A.)

OaroDN muracRN EalayohaA c
OaroDN muracRN EalayohaA (As, A 'Obeyd, S, M, K) and ArD muracRapN (Ks, T, S, M) and marocuwcapN↓, (Th, M, K,) or the second and third of these are not allowable, but only the first is, (As, A 'Obeyd, S, M,) Land upon which has fallen rain such as is termed racaAc. (As, A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, K.)

muricRN c
muricRN A sky (samaMCN) raining, or letting fall, such rain as is termed racaAc; and so maricRapN. (A, TA.) One says, AlsRamaMCu muricRN waAlsRamaAEu mulicRN fahalo Oanota UilayonaA mugicRN [The sky is raining a fine rain, and what is being heard is delighting: art thou, then, coming to us quickly?]: meaning what is heard of discourse, or narration, and of science; not of singing. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) A day in which is rain such as is termed racaAc. (Lth, El-Umawee, T, S, A, K.) And (tropical:) A water-skin, or milk-skin, exuding, or letting flow, what is in it. (A, TA.) And (assumed tropical:) Anything flowing. (T.)

OaroDN marocuwcapN c
OaroDN marocuwcapN: see muracRN.

1 racula c
1. racula, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
racula
, (T, S, K,) inf. n. racaAlapN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and ruculapN; (S, M, Msb, K;) and racila, aor.
racala
; (Sgh, K;) He (a man) was, or became, low, base, vile, mean, or contemptible; (T, S, M, K;) in his aspect, and in his states, or circumstances: (T:) or it (a thing, M, Msb, K, of any kind, M, K) was, or became, bad, corrupt, vile, base, abominable, or disapproved. (M, Msb, K.) ＝ -A2- racalahu, (S, M, K,) aor.
racula
, inf. n. racolN; (M, TA;) and Arclhu↓; (S, K;) He made, or pronounced, him (a man) to be low, base, vile, mean, or contemptible: (S, * M, K, * TA:) or he made, or pronounced, it (a thing of any kind) to be bad, corrupt, vile, base, abominable, or disapproved. (M, K. *) You say, daraAhima Arcl↓, (T,) or mino daraAhimiI kacaA, (TA,) He (a man, T, or a money-changer, TA) pronounced, or showed, dirhems or pieces of money, or such of my dirhems or pieces of money, to be bad; syn. fasRalahaA. (T, TA.) And ganamiI Arcl↓ [He pronounced my sheep, or goats, to be bad; or he disapproved, or refused, them]. (T, TA.) And mino rijaAlihi kacaA wakacaA rajulFA Arcl↓ (T, TA) He disapproved, or refused, [as low, base, &c.,] of his men, such and such men. (TA.)

4 Arcl c
4. Arcl He had low, base, vile, mean, or contemptible, companions. (K.) ＝ -A2- As a trans. v.: see 1, in four places.

10 Astrclhu c
10. Astrclhu [He reckoned him or esteemed him, or he found him to be, or he desired that he might be, low, base, vile, mean, or contemptible: or he reckoned it or esteemed it, or found it to be, or desired that it might be, bad, corrupt, vile, base, abominable, or disapproved:] contr. of AisotajaAdahu. (O, K.) Hence the trad., maA Qsotarocala QllRehu EabodFA UilRaA HaZara Eanohu AlEiloma waAlOadaba [God desires not that a servant (meaning a man) may be low, base, vile, mean or contemptible, but He withholds from him knowledge, or science, and discipline of the mind, or good qualities and attributes of the mind or soul, &c.]. (O, TA.)

racolN c
racolN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and rucaAlN↓ (S, K) and raciylN↓ and Oarocalu↓ (M, K) applied to a man, Low, base, vile, mean, or contemptible; (T, S, M, K;) in his aspect, and in his states, or circumstances: (T:) or, applied to a thing (M, Msb, K) of any kind, (M, K,) bad, corrupt, vile, base, abominable, or disapproved: (M, Msb, K:) fem. of the first with p: (M, Msb:) pl. [of pauc.], of the first, OaroculN, (Msb,) or [of the same,] OarocaAlN, (T, S, M, O, and so in some copies of the K,) [or this is more probably pl. of raciylN↓, accord. to analogy,] and rucuwlN (S, M, K) and rucaAlN, (M, K,) which is of a rare form, (M,) [in the CK rucRAlN,] and racoluwna, (T,) [which is applied only to rational beings,] and (of raciylN↓, TA) rucalaMCu, (S, M, K,) and, of the pl. OaroculN, (Msb, [but] said in the O to be of [the pl.] OarocaAlN, TA,) OaraAcilu, (T, Msb, TA, and so in some copies of the K in the place of OarocaAlN,) and [of AlOarocalu↓,] AlOarocaluwna, (T, M, K,) [which is applied only to rational beings, and is said in the M and TA to be used only with the article Al prefixed to it, but is written without the Al in the K.] You say rajulN racolu AlvRiyaAbi and AlfiEoli [A man mean, or bad, &c., in respect of clothes and of action]. (T, TA.) And vawobN racolN A dirty, bad, or vile, garment; (TA;) and so vwb raciylN↓: (M, TA:) or vwb racilN↓ [so accord. to a copy of the T, but perhaps a mistranscription for racolN,] a dirty garment: and vwb raciylN↓ a bad, or vile, garment. (T.)

racilN c
racilN: see the next preceding paragraph.

rucaAlN c
rucaAlN: see racolN [of which it is both a syn. and a pl.]. ― -b2- Also, (S,) or rucaAlapN↓, (T,) or both, (M, Msb, K,) The worse or viler, or the worst or vilest, (T,) or the bad, or vile, (S,) of anything: (T, S:) [or the refuse thereof; i. e.] a thing of which the good has been picked out, (M, Msb, K,) and the bad or vile, (M,) or the worse or viler, or worst or vilest, (Msb,) remains. (M, Msb.) You say also, AlnRaAsi humo rucaAlapu↓ and rucaAluhumo [They are the lower or baser &c., or lowest or basest &c., or the refuse, of mankind, or of the people]. (T.)

raciylN c
raciylN: see racolN, in five places.

rucaAlapN c
rucaAlapN: see rucaAlN, in two places.

raciylapN c
raciylapN A low, base, vile, mean, contemptible, or bad, quality; contr. of faDiylapN; (M, K:) pl. racaAYilu. (TA.)

rucaAlaI c
rucaAlaI: see the next paragraph.

Oarocalu c
Oarocalu: see racolN, in two places. ― -b2- Also The worse, or worst: so in the phrase Oarocalu AlEumuri [The worse, or worst, part of life]. (O, K.) [In the K, immediately after the words waOarocala SaAra OaSoHaAbuhu rucalaMCa, we find, in some copies, warucaAlaI kaHubaAraI waOarocalu AlEumuri OasowaWohu; and in other copies, warucaAlaI kaHubaAraI Oarocalu AlEumuri OasowaWuhu: accord. to the former reading, the meaning is, that rucaAlaI↓ is syn. with rucalaMCu; and such SM holds to be the case: accord. to the latter reading, that rucaAlaI is syn. with Oarocalu AlEumuri. I have no doubt that the latter is the
original reading in the K, and that it is taken from the O, where (with a preceding context different from that in the K) the words are, warucaAlaI Aarcali AlEumuri AasowaWuhu; thus, with Arcl in the gen. case: but I believe, as this word thus written suggests, and as some persons, alluded to by MF, have supposed, that kHbArI has been foisted into the text of the K in consequence of a misunderstanding or of a mistranscription of the words in question in some work earlier than the O; that the correct reading is, warudRa UilaI Oarocali AlEumuri OasowaYihi; and that this is taken from what here follows.] It is said in the Kur [xvi. 72 and xxii. 5], waminokumo mano yuradRu UilaI Oarocali AlEumuri, (T, TA,) i. e. [And of you is he who is brought back to] the worse, or worst, [part] of life, (Ksh and Bd and Jel,) and the more, or most, contemptible thereof; (Ksh in xvi. 72;) a state of decrepitude and dotage; (Ksh and Bd and Jel;) which resembles the state of a young infant: (Ksh and Bd:) meaning he who dotes by reason of old age, so that he has no intellect; as is shown by the words in the same [immediately following], likayolaA yaEolama baEoda EilomK XayoYFA or mino baEodi EilomK XayoYFA. (T, TA. *)

marocuwlN c
marocuwlN A man made, or pronounced, to be low, base, vile, mean, or contemptible: (S, * TA:) and a thing made, or pronounced, to be bad, corrupt, vile, base, abominable, or disapproved. (TA.)

1 razRahu c
1. razRahu, [aor.
razuza
, inf. n. razRN,] He pierced, stuck, or stabbed, him. (S, A, K.) ― -b2- He stuck, or fastened, or fixed, it, (S, A, K,) into the ground, (S,) or into another thing; (K;) as, for instance, a nail (TA) or a knife (A) into a wall, (A, TA,) or a knife into the ground, (TA,) and an arrow into the target. (A.) ― -b3- razRati AljaraAdapu, aor.
razuza
(S, K) and
raziza
, (K,) inf. n. razRN (S, TA) and ruzuwzN, (so in a copy of the S, but wanting in another,) The locust stuck her tail into the ground, (AZ, S, K,) and laid her eggs, (AZ, S,) or to lay her eggs; (K;) as also ArzRt↓. (AZ, S, K.) ＝ -A2- razRa AlbaAba, (S, K,) aor.
razuza
, inf. n. razRN, (TA,) He furnished the door with a razRap [or staple to receive the bolt of the lock]. (S. K.) ＝ -A3- razRati AlsRamaMCu, (A, K,) aor.
raziza
, (A, TA,) inf. n. razRN, (TA,) The sky made a sound by reason of rain. (K.) ― -b2- razRa is also said of a stallion [i. e. a stallion-camel, meaning He uttered a low braying]: and of thunder [meaning It made a low sound]. (A.) [See rizRN below.] ― -b3- And razRN signifies also The being instantly silent. (TA.)

2 razRazotu laka AlOamora c
2. razRazotu laka AlOamora, (S,) inf. n. taroziyzN, (S, K,) (tropical:) I arranged, or facilitated, for thee the affair. (S, K. *) And zarRazotu Oamoraka Einoda fulaAnK (tropical:) I arranged, or facilitated, thine affair, and put it in a sound, right, or proper, state, (vabRatRuhu, [or, as in one copy of the A, bayRanotuhu, i. e. made it clear, or plain,]) with such a one. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- taroziyzN also signifies The glazing, or polishing, of paper. (S, K.) ― -b2- [See also the pass. part. n., below: whence it appears that it signifies also The dressing, or preparing, &c., with rice.]

R. Q. 1 razorazahu c
R. Q. 1. razorazahu, (K,) inf. n. razorazapN, (TA,) He put it in motion, or in a state of commotion. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And He equalized it; namely, a load, or burden; (K, TA;) made it to counterbalance. (TA.)

4 ArzRt AljaraAdapu c
4. ArzRt AljaraAdapu: see 1.

8 ArtzR c
8. ArtzR It stuck, or became fastened or fixed, into a thing; (TA;) as, for instance, an arrow into the target, (S, A, K,) and into the ground. (A.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) He (a niggardly man) remained fixed in his place, and was tenacious, (S, * K, * TA,) and was ashamed and confounded, or speechless and motionless through confusion and shame. (TA.)

ruzRN c
ruzRN i. q. OaruzRN [i. e. Rice: see the latter word, in art. Arz]. (S, K.)

rizRN c
rizRN A piercing [pain] and rumbling in the belly: (A:) or pain in the belly; as also rizRiyzaI↓: (S:) or pain, and pressure of the feces: (TA:) or the pressure and motion of the feces in the belly, (Kt, Mgh, TA,) in the effort to pass forth, so that the person who feels it wants to enter the privy; whether it be with a rumbling or without: (Kt, TA:) or a sound of rumbling or the like in the belly. (As, Mgh, * TA.) You say, wajadotu fiI baToniI rizRFA (As, S, A) I felt in my belly a piercing [pain] and rumbling: (A:) or a pain: (As, S: expl. in the KL by the Pers. word darod:) as also rizRiyzaI↓: (As, S:) or pain, and pressure of the feces; &c. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) A vehement burning in the mouth of a camel, arising from thirst, with pain. (TA.) ― -b3- Also A low sound: (TA:) any sound that is not vehement: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) or a sound that one hears from afar; as also rizRiyzaI↓: (K:) or a sound that one hears but knows not what it is: (TA:) or a sound in a more common sense; (K, TA;) vehement or slight: (TA:) or a sound; as of thunder &c.: (S:) or the sound of thunder; (K;) as also raziyzN↓, [in measure] like OamiyrN: or the former has a more general application: and UiroziyzN↓ [in like manner] signifies a sound: and also thunder: (TA:) and rizRN also signifies the braying of a stallion-camel. (K, * TA.)

razRapN c
razRapN A single piercing; a stick, or stab. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And A pain in the back. (Sgh, TA.) ＝ -A2- The iron [meaning the staple] into which [the bolt of] the lock enters: (S, K:) so called because [the bolt of] the lock penetrates it: pl. razRaAtN. (TA.)

razaAzN c
razaAzN i. q. raSaASN [generally meaning Lead]: (Sgh, K:) a dial. var. of the latter word. (TA.)

raziyzN c
raziyzN: see rizRN. ＝ -A2- Also A certain plant, with which one dyes. (S, K.)

razRaAzN c
razRaAzN One who sells, and traffics in, ruzR [or rice]. (TA.)

rizRiyzaI c
rizRiyzaI: see rizRN in three places.

UiroziyzN c
UiroziyzN A piercing, sticking, or stabbing, (K, TA,) such as is firm, or steady. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A tremour. (Th, S, K.) ― -b2- See also rizRN, last sentence. ＝ -A3- Long-sounding. (K.) ＝ -A4- Hail: (Th, TA:) or small hail, like snow. (S, K.)

marazRapN c
marazRapN A place in which ruzR [or rice] is collected together; like the kudos of wheat. (TA.)

murazRazN c
murazRazN Food dressed, prepared, or mixed up, (muEaAlajN,) with ruzR [or rice]. (Sgh, K.) And Paper dressed, or prepared, (muEaAlajN,) with ruzR [or rice]: (A, TA:) or paper glazed, or polished. (S.)

1 razaOahu c
1. razaOahu, aor.
razaAa
, inf. n. ruzoCN and maroziYapN, He got, or obtained, from him good (S, K) of any kind. (S.) And razaOa fulaAnN fulaAnFA i. q. brRh; [a mistake, through an oversight, for qabila birRahu; i. e. Such a one accepted the bounty of such a one;] as also razaAhu, without C: the former said by AM to be the original. (TA.) And razaOa AlXRaIoCa He took from the thing, diminished it, lessened it, or impaired it; (K;) and trAzOhu↓ signifies the same; or he took from it, diminished it, &c., by little and little. (JM.) You say, razaOahu maAlahu, and raziYahu maAlahu, aor.
razaAa
, inf. n. ruzoCN, He got, or obtained, somewhat of his property; as also maAlahu ArtzOhu↓. (K.) And maA razaOotuhu maAlahu, (S,) and maA raziYotuhu maAlahu, (S, K, *) I did not take from him of his property; or did not diminish to him his property. (S, K. *) And maA raziYotuhu XayoYFA I did not take from him, or it, aught. (Mgh.) And maA razaOa fulaAnFA XayoYFA He did not get, or obtain, from such a one aught of his property; and did not take from him aught thereof. (TA.) And maA razaOotuhu zibaAlFA I did not take from him, or it, as much as an ant would carry with its mouth: (Har p. 197:) or thus originally, but meaning, anything. (S in art. zbl.) And maA razaOonaA mino maAYika XayoYFA We took not of, or from, thy water, anything: occurring in a trad. (TA.) In another trad., as some relate it, raziynaA occurs for raziYonaA, which is the original. (IAth.) Accord. to AZ, [however,] one says, ruziYotuhu, meaning [I had it taken, or received, from me; or, virtually,] it was taken, or received, from me; but not ruziytuhu. (TA.) [Hence, when relating to a moral attribute, or the like, it virtually means (assumed tropical:) It was experienced from me: see a verse cited voce mutoladN, in art. tld.] You say also, huwa yurozaOu, [virtually] meaning He is a bountiful person; one whose gratuitous gifts people obtain. (Ham p. 722.) And UinRahu laqalyilu AlrRuzoCi mina AlTRaEaAmi Verily he is one who gets little of the food. (TA.) ― -b2- razaOotuhu also signifies I afflicted him with an affliction, a misfortune, or a calamity. (Msb.) And razaOatohu raziyoYapN An affliction, a misfortune, or a calamity, befell him. (S, Msb.) It is said in a trad., respecting a woman who came asking for her son, Uino OurozaOi QboniI falamo OurozaOo OaHobaAbiI, meaning If I be afflicted by the loss of my son, I have not been afflicted by the loss of my friends. (TA.)

4 ArzO c
4. ArzO: see ArzI, in art. rzI.

6 taraAozaAa
6: see 1.

8 UirotazaAa
8: see 1. ＝ -A2- ArtzO also signifies It (a thing, S) was, or became, diminished, lessened, or impaired. (S, K.) A poet says, (namely, Ibn Mukbil, describing a stallion, S in art. zbl,)
falamo yarotaziICo birukuwbK zibaAlaA
(S, TA) And he had not been lessened [by riding, so as to lose] as much as the gnat will carry: (TA:) or as much as the ant will carry with its mouth; meaning, anything: (S in art. zbl:) but some read trtzIC; [and some, yurotazaOo, as in copies of the S in art. zbl;] and some, birukuwnK. (TA.)

ruzoCN c
ruzoCN, (S, Mgh, K,) [originally an inf. n., and] a subst. from razaOatohu raziyoYapN, (Msb,) and raziyoYapN↓, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) also pronounced raziyRapN, originally with C, (Msb,) and maroziYapN↓, (S, K,) An affliction, a misfortune, or a calamity, (S, Msb, K, TA,) by the loss of things dear to one: (TA:) or a great affliction or calamity or misfortune: (Mgh:) pl. (of the first, S, TA) OarozaMCN (S, K, TA) and (of the second, S, Msb, TA) razaAyaA. (S, Msb, K, TA.)

raziyoYapN c
raziyoYapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

maroziYapN c
maroziYapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

murazRaUN c
murazRaUN; (so in some copies of the S; in others murozaON, which is said in the K to be a mistranscription;) pl. murazRaWuwna: (K:) A generous man, (S, K, * [in the latter of which only the pl. is explained,] and TA,) whose good things men get, or obtain, (S,) or from whom much is gotten, or obtained. (TA.) One says, in praising, fulaAnN murazRaON fiI maAlihi [Such a one is a person from whom much of his property has been obtained]: and in expressing pity and grief, fulaAnN murazRaON fiI Oaholihi [Such a one is a person who has had some one, or more, of his family taken from him]. (Ham p. 176.) And the pl., mentioned above, also signifies Persons of whom the best have died: (K:) or persons of whom death befalls the best. (L.)

1 razabahu c
1. razabahu, (A, K,) aor.
razuba
, inf. n. razobN, (TK,) He kept, or clave, to him, or it, (A, K,) not departing. (K.)

UirozabRN c
UirozabRN, (S, K,) quasi-coordinate to jirodaHolN, (S,) applied to a man, (TA,) Short: (S, K:) and great, or old; syn. kabiyrN: and thick and strong: and big, or bulky: (K:) or short and thick and strong: (TA:) or great in body, and stupid, foolish, or deficient in intellect. (Abu-l-'Abbás, TA.) ― -b2- Also The vulva of a woman; (K;) accord. to Kr, a subst. [properly speaking] applied thereto: (TA:) or an epithet, meaning large, or big, (S, K,) applied thereto, (K,) or applied to a rakab [i. e. pubes]. (S.)

UirozabRapN c
UirozabRapN and mirozabRapN↓, both with teshdeed; (A, K;) or the former only, (S, Msb, K,) of these two, (S, Msb,) and mirozibapN↓, without teshdeed; (S, A, Msb;) ↓the second mentioned by Ks, (Mgh,) but it is vulgar, (Fs, Msb,) and said by ISk to be wrong; (Msb;) A thing with which clods of clay are broken: (S, L:) or a small rod, or batoon, of iron: (A, K:) and the last, mirozabapN↓, without teshdeed, a large blacksmith's hammer: (TA:) or a mallet with which wooden pins or pegs or stakes are knocked into the ground or into a wall; syn. miytadapN: (Mgh:) the pl. of the first is OaraAzibu; (Msb;) and of ↓the last, maraAzibu, (A, Msb,) as also of marozubaAnN [q. v.]. (A.)

marozabapN c
marozabapN [A satrapy; the government of a satrap, or prefect of the Persians;] the headship of the Persians. (K.) You say, fulaAnN EalaI marozabapi kacaA, and lahu marozabapu kacaA, [Such a one is over the satrapy of, or has the office of satrap over, such a province,] like as you say, lahu dahoqanapu kacaA. (S.)

mirozabapN c
mirozabapN and mirozabRapN: see UirozabRapN, in five places.

mirozaAbN c
mirozaAbN i. q. miyzaAbN [and mizoraAbN, i. e. A water-spout; &c.; see art. wzb]; (A, K;) a dial. var. thereof; (S, Msb;) but not a chaste word; (S;) and disallowed by A'Obeyd, (TA,) and by ISk and Fr and AHat. (TA voce mizoraAbN.) ― -b2- Also A great ship: (A, K:) or a long ship: (AZ, S, K:) pl. maraAziybu. (AZ, S.)

marozubaAnN c
marozubaAnN [A satrap; or] a great man, or chief, (A, Mgh, K,) of the Persians: (S, Mgh, K:) or a courageous cavalier who is set over a people, under a king: (TA:) it is said, on the authority of As, that the chief of the Eajam [here meaning Persians] was called marozubaAnN and mazorubaAnN: (IB, TA:) mrzbAn is an arabicized word, (S, Mgh,) [originally Persian,] used anciently: (Shifá el-Ghaleel, TA:) pl. maraAzibapN. (S, A, Mgh, K.) Hence, [and from maraAzibapN as pl. of mirozabapN,] the saying, OaEuwcu biQllRehi mina AlmaraAzibapi wamaA biOayodiyhimo mina AlmaraAzibapi [I seek protection by God from the satraps, and the iron batoons that are in their hands]. (A.) ― -b2- And hence, (S Mgh,) marozubaAnu AlrRaOorapi, (S, Mgh, K,) [lit. The chief of the forest, or the like,] the latter word meaning AlOajamapi, (Mgh, TA,) and also pronounced AlzRaArapi; (Mgh;) an appellation of the lion; (S, Mgh, K;) and so AlmarozubaAniIRu↓; for which ElMufaddal said AlmazobaraAniIRu, as referring to the zuborap of the lion; but As disallowed this. (S.)

AlmarozubaAniIRu c
AlmarozubaAniIRu: see what next precedes.

ruzotaAqN c
ruzotaAqN: see ruzodaAqN, in art. rzdq.

1 razaHato c
1. razaHato, aor.
razaHa
, inf. n. ruzuwHN (S, K) and ruzaAHN, (S, L,) or razaAHN, (K,) She (a camel) fell down (S, L, K) by reason of fatigue, emaciated, (S, L, &c.,) or by reason of fatigue or emaciation, (K accord. to the TA,) or by reason of fatigue and emaciation: (CK:) or clave to the ground, and had not power to rise. (TA.) And razaHa, (Mgh, Msb,) aor.
razaHa
, (Msb,) inf. n. ruzuwHu and ruzaAHN (Mgh, Msb) and razaAHN, (Msb,) He (a camel, Mgh, Msb) fell down by reason of fatigue: (Mgh:) or became much emaciated. (Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, or from marozaHN as meaning low, or depressed, ground or land, razaHa said of a man, (tropical:) He became weak, and what was in his hand went from him. (TA.) ― -b3- And razaHato HaAluhu and OaHowaAluhu trAzHt↓ (A) (tropical:) His state, or condition, was, and his circumstances, were, or became, weak and evil. (A, * and Har p. 489.) ― -b4- [Hence also,] razaHa AlEinabu The grape vine fell down. (TA.) ＝ -A2- razaHa fulaAnFA biAlrRumoHi, inf. n. razoHN, He thrust, or pierced, such a one with the spear, or with the iron at the lower extremity of the spear; syn. zajRahu. (K.)

2 rzRH c
2. rzRH, inf. n. taroziyHN, (S, K,) He made a she-camel to fall down by reason of fatigue, emaciated: (S:) or he emaciated her. (K.) And razRaHatohaA AlOasofaAru Journeys emaciated her. (A, * TA.)

4 ArzH AlEinaba c
4. ArzH AlEinaba He raised [or propped up] the grape-vine [that had fallen down]. (TA.)

6 taraAozaHa
6: see 1.

raAziHN c
raAziHN (S, A, Mgh, Msb, TA) and mirozaAHN↓ (TA) A camel that has fallen down by reason of fatigue: (Mgh:) or much emaciated: (Mgh, Msb:) or much emaciated, that will not move: (TA:) perishing by reason of emaciation: (S, TA:) or that throws himself down by reason of fatigue: or much emaciated, but having power to move: (A, TA:) pl. [of the former] razoHaI (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and ruzRaHN (S, A, Mgh, K) and razaAHaI (S, A, Msb, K) and [of the same or of raAziHapN] rawaAziHu (A, TA) and [of mirozaAHN] maraAziyHu↓. (S, A, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] qawomN ruzRaHN and rzAH [app. ruzRaAHN, agreeably with analogy, or perhaps rizAHN,] (assumed tropical:) A people, or party, emaciated, and falling down [or tottering by reason of weakness]. (Ham p. 227.) ― -b3- And lahu HaAlN raAziHapN (tropical:) [He has a weak and an evil state or condition: see 1]. (A.)

marozaHN c
marozaHN [A place where camels fall down by reason of fatigue: and hence,] a far-extending place of crossing or traversing [of a desert &c.]. (S, K.) ― -b2- And A low, or depressed, tract of land. (K.)

mirozaHN c
mirozaHN The wood, or pieces of wood, (xaXab,) with which a grape-vine is raised from the ground (T, S, K) when one part thereof has fallen down upon another: (T, TA:) or a vine-prop; a piece of wood with which a grape-vine is raised from the ground. (TA in art. jzC.) ＝ -A2- Also, as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates, [but why this is said I do not see, unless the primary meaning be that assigned by EshSheybánee to the next following word,] A voice, sound, or noise; (TA;) and so miroziyHN↓: (K:) accord. to Esh-Sheybánee, the latter signifies
having a vehement voice or sound or noise; (S;) but this [said to be] is a mistake. (K.)

mirozaAHN c
mirozaAHN, and its pl. maraAziyHu: see raAziHN.

miroziyHN c
miroziyHN: see mirozaHN.

razodaqN c
razodaqN A row of palm-trees, and of men: (IF, S, Msb, K:) or [simply] a row: (JK, Mgh:) and an extended cord or string or thread: (JK:) an arabicized word, from rasotaho, (S, K,) which is Persian: (S:) Lth says, What the people [now] call rasotaq we call razodaq, meaning a row: it is an adventitious word. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, AijoEali AlOamora razodaqFA waAHidFA, meaning Make thou the affair, or case, [uniform, or] one uniform thing. (Fr, TA in art. bOH.)

ruzodaAqN c
ruzodaAqN (S, Msb, K, &c.) and ruzotaAqN (Lh, L, TA) and rusodaAqN (ISk, K) and rusotaAqN, (Lh, S, Msb, K, &c.,) but this last disallowed by ISk, (TA,) [though allowed by many others, and of frequent occurrence,] and said by some to be post-classical, and to be correctly ruzodaAqN, (Msb,) arabicized, (S, Msb, K,) of Pers. origin, (S,) from ruwsotaA, (K,) [erroneously] said by IF to be from razodaqN signifying as explained above; (Msb;) A rural district; or district consisting of cultivated land with towns or villages; syn. sawaAdN, (S,) or sawaAdN and qurFy: (K:) Yákoot explains rusotaAq as applied, in his time, in the country of the Persians, to any place [or district] in which are sown fields, and towns or villages; not to cities, like El-Basrah and Baghdád; so that it is, with the Persians, like sawaAdN with the people of Baghdád, and is a more special term than kuwrapN [in Arabic] and UisotaAn [in Persian]: (TA:) or it is used as meaning an outlying district, or a border-district, of a country: (Msb:) [but the correctness of this last explanation is questionable:] the pl. is razaAdiyqu (Msb) [and razaAtiyqu and rasaAdiyqu] and rasaAtiyqu (S, Msb) and ruzodaAqaAtN (Har p. 249) [&c.].

3 raAzagotuhu c
3. raAzagotuhu, (JK,) inf. n. muraAzagapN, (JK, K,) I practised deceit, delusion, guile, or artifice, with him, or towards him; syn. raAwagotuhu; (JK, K; *) and sought, or endeavoured, to induce him; syn. HaAwalotuhu: said [in speaking] of a wolf &c. (JK, TA. *)

4 Arzgt AlOaroDu c
4. Arzgt AlOaroDu The land, or ground, was, or became, very slimy or miry; or had much slime, or mire, and moisture. (K, * TA. [See also 4 in art. rdg.]) ― -b2- Arzg said of a digger, He reached the moist earth or clay. (S, K.) ― -b3- Arzgt AlsRamaMCu The sky gave water such as moistened the earth or ground: (TA:) like Ardgt. (TA in art. rdg.) And Arzgt AlriyHu The wind brought nadFy [i. e. moisture, or rain, &c.]. (IF, K.) And Arzg AlmaTaru AlOaroDu The rain moistened the earth, or ground, (S, K,) and exceeded the ordinary degree, (S,) but did not flow. (S, K.) ― -b4- Arzg AlmaMCu The water was, or became, little in quantity. (JK, Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

razogN c
razogN A small quantity of water in what are termed vimaAd [q. v.] and HisaMC [pl. of HisoyN q. v.] and the like. (TA.) ― -b2- See also razagapN.

razagN c
razagN: see razagapN. ― -b2- Also Moisture. (TA.)

razigN c
razigN Sticking fast in slime or mire: (JK, T, S, * K:) or so murozigN↓ and murozagN↓. (IB.)

razagapN c
razagapN (S, K) and razogapN (Lth, Mgh) Thin mud; (TA;) [i. e.] slime, or mire: (S, K:) or much slime or mire: or, accord. to the M, it is less than what is termed radogapN [or radagapN, q. v.]: (TA:) but accord. to Lth (Mgh) and to the T, (TA,) stiffer than what is termed rdgp: (Mgh, TA:) or slime, or mire, little in quantity: (Ham p. 632:) pl. rizaAgN and [coll. gen. n.] razagN↓ (K) [and razogN↓]: or razagN and razogN signify slime, or mire: (Mgh:) and rizaAgN↓ is also expl. [as a sing., like ridaAgN,] as having this last meaning; and as meaning also moisture of the earth. (TA.)

rizaAgN c
rizaAgN: see what next precedes.

marozagN c
marozagN Rain producing much slime or mire; opposed to masiylN, “ causing much flowing. ” (Ham p. 632.)

murozagN c
murozagN: see razigN.

murozigN c
murozigN Rain that moistens the earth, or ground, exceeding the ordinary degree, but not flowing; opposed to musiylN, “ that causes the valleys and water-courses (tilaAE) to flow. ” (S, and Ham * p. 632.) ― -b2- See also razigN.

1 razaqahu QllRehu c
1. razaqahu QllRehu, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
razuqa
, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. rizoqN, (S,) or razoqN, (IB, K,) the latter being the proper inf. n., (K,) and the former a simple subst. but also used as an inf. n., (TA,) God caused what is termed rizoq [q. v.] to come to him: (K:) or God gave him. (S, IB.) [The verb is doubly trans.: when the second objective complement is implied, the phrase generally means God caused the means of subsistence to come to him; i. e., gave him, granted him, or bestowed upon him, the means of subsistence; or supplied, provided, or blessed, him therewith: when the second objective complement is expressed, this word is generally one signifying the means of subsistence or the like, property, or offspring.] One says also, razaqa AlTRaAYiru faroxahu, aor.
razuqa
, inf. n. razoqN, [The bird fed its young one.] (TA.) And razaqa AlOamiyru Aljunoda The commander gave their subsistence-money, pay, or allowances, to the army: and razaqa Aljunoda razoqapF He gave the army their subsistence-money, &c., once: and ruziquwA razoqatayoni They were given their subsistence-money, &c., twice. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence ruziqa also signifies It (a place) was rained upon.] Lebeed says,
ruziqato maraAbiyEa AlnRujuwmi waSaAbahaA
wadoqu AlrRawaAEidi jawoduhaA warihaAmuhaA
meaning muTirato; (TA;) i. e. They were rained upon with the rain of the OanowaMC [pl. of nawoCN q. v.] of the rabiyE, and the rain of the thundering clouds fell upon them, the copious thereof and the drizzling and lasting thereof. (EM pp. 140 and 141.) ― -b3- And razaqa fulaAnFA He thanked such a one; was thankful, or grateful, to him; or acknowledged his beneficence: of the dial. of Azd, (K,) i. e. Azd-Shanooah. (TA.) One says, faEalotu celika lamRaA razaqotaniI i. e. lamRaA XakarotaniI [I did that since, or because, thou thankedst me]. (TA.) And hence, in the Kur [lvi. 81], watajoEaluwna rizoqakumo OanRakumo takacRibuwna [And do ye make your thanking to be that ye disacknowledge the benefit received, as being from God?]; (K;) i. e., accord. to Ibn-'Arafeh, do ye, instead of acknowledging what God has bestowed upon you, and being thankful for it, attribute it to another than Him? or, accord. to Az and others, [as J also says in the S,] the meaning is, tajoEaluwna Xakora riziqokumu AltRakociyba [do ye make the thanking for your sustenance to be disacknowledgment?]: (TA:) and some read Xakorakumo [for rizoqakumo]. (Bd.)

8 ArtzqwA c
8. ArtzqwA, (S, Msb, K,) said of soldiers, (S,) or of people, (Msb,) They took, or received, their OarozaAq [i. e., when said of soldiers, portions of subsistence-money, pay, or allowances, and when said of others, means of subsistence, &c.]. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- See also what next follows.

10 Astrzqhu c
10. Astrzqhu He asked, or demanded, of him what is termed rizoq [i. e. means of subsistence, &c.; when said of a soldier, subsistence-money, pay, or allowance]; (MA, TA;) as also Artzqhu↓. (TA.)

rizoqN c
rizoqN A thing whereby one profits, or from which one derives advantage; (S, K;) as also murotazaqN↓, (K, TA,) in the pass. form: (TA: [in the CK, erroneously, murotaziq:]) and a gift; and especially, of God: (S:) or [especially, and according to general usage,] the means of subsistence, or of the support and growth of the body, which God sends to [mankind and other] animals; [sustenance, victuals, food, or provisions; or a supply thereof from God:] but with the Moatezileh it means a thing possessed and eaten by the deserving; so that it does not apply to what is unlawful: (TA:) pl. OarozaAqN: (S, Msb, K:) and what are thus termed are of two kinds; apparent, [or material,] which are for the bodies, such as aliments; and unapparent, [or intellectual,] which are for the hearts and minds, such as the several sorts of knowledge and of science: (TA:) or rizoqN properly signifies a portion, share, or lot; or particularly, of something good, or excellent; syn. HaZRN: and is conventionally made to apply to a thing by which an animal is enabled to profit: (Bd in ii. 2:) and [hence] it signifies also a daily allowance of food or the like; and so rizoqapN↓ of
which the pl. is rizaqN: (TA:) [the subsistencemoney, pay, or allowance, of a soldier; or] what is given forth to the soldier at the commencement of every month, or day by day: or, accord. to ElKarkhee, AlEaTaMCu is what is assigned to those who fight; and AlrRazoqu, to the poor: (Mgh: [but see EaTaMCN:]) and razaqaAtN↓, pl. of razaqapN↓, which is the inf. n. of unity of raraqa, signifies the portions of subsistence-money, pay, or allowances, (syn. OaTomaAE,) of soldiers: (S, K:) one says, kamo rizoquka fiI AlXRahori How much is thy allowance of food, or the like, [or thy subsistence-money, or pay,] in the month? (TA:) and OaxacuwA OarozaAqahumo [They took, or received, their portions of subsistence-money, &c.,] (S, Msb, K) is said of soldiers. (S.) AlrRizoqu AlHasanu means A thing [or provision] that comes to one without toil in the seeking thereof: or, as some say, a thing [or provision] that is found without one's looking, or watching, for it, and without one's reckoning upon it, and without one's earning it, or labouring to earn it. (KT.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Rain (S, K) is sometimes thus called; as in the Kur xlv. 4 and li. 22: this being an amplification in language; as when one says, “ The dates are in the bottom of the well; ” meaning thereby “ the [water for] watering the palm-trees. ” (S.)

razoqapN c
razoqapN, and its pl. razaqaAtN: see the next preceding paragraph.

rizoqapN c
rizoqapN: see rizoqN.

AlrRazRaAqu c
AlrRazRaAqu: see what next follows, in two places.

AlrRaAziqu c
AlrRaAziqu and AlrRazRaAqu↓, the latter of which has an intensive signification, are epithets applied to God, meaning [The Supplier of the means of subsistence, &c.; or] the Creator of what are termed AlOarozaAq, and the Giver of their OarozaAq to his creatures. (TA.) [The former epithet is also applicable to a man; but ↓the latter is not.] ― -b2- rawaAziqu [as pl. of raAziqN, agreeably with a general rule relating to epithets of the measure faAEilN when not applicable to rational beings, and of raAziqapN,] Dogs, and birds, that prey, or catch game. (TA.)

raAziqiIRN c
raAziqiIRN [erroneously written by Golius and Freytag raAzaqiIRN] Weak: (Moheet, L, K:) applied to anything. (Moheet, L.) ＝ -A2- Also The species of grapes called mulaAHiIR or mulRaAHiIR; (T, K;) a species of grapes of Et-Táïf, with long berries; they are called EinabN raAziqiIRN. (TA.) ― -b2- And Wine (K, TA) made of the grapes so called; (TA;) as also raAziqiyRapN↓. (K, TA.) ＝ -A3- And raAziqiyRapN↓ [as a coll. gen. n. of which raAziqiIRN is the n. un.] White flaxen cloths. (S, K.) Lebeed says, describing vessels of wine,
lahaA galalN mino raAziqiIRK wakurosufK
biOayomaAni EujomK yanoSufuwna AlmaqaAwilaA
[They have a strainer of white flaxen cloth and of cotton, in the right hands of foreigners that act as servants to the kings]: he means yaxodumuwna AlOaqoyaAla: (S:) and by galalN he means “ a strainer ” (miSofaAp, or fidaAm,) on the heads of the OabaAriyk. (S in art. gl.)

raAziqiyRapN c
raAziqiyRapN [erroneously written by Golius and Freytag raAzaqiyRapN]: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

marozuwqN c
marozuwqN A man possessed of good fortune, or of good worldly fortune. (S, K, TA.) ― -b2- Oabuw marozuwqK was the name of A certain he-goat, mentioned in poetry. (IAar.)

murotazaqN c
murotazaqN: see rizoqN.

Almurotaziqapu c
Almurotaziqapu Those who receive [subsistence-money, pay, or] settled periodical allowances of food or the like: (Mgh, * Msb, * TA:) and they are thus called though they be not written down in the register [of the army &c.]. (Mgh.)

1 razama c
1. razama, said of a camel, (Lh, K,) and of a man, &c.; (Lh, TA;) or razamato, said of a she-camel; (S;) aor.
razuma
and
razima
, inf. n. ruzuwmN and ruzaAmN; (S, K;) He was unable to rise, (Lh, K, TA,) in consequence of his having fallen down by reason of fatigue and emaciation, (Lh, TA,) or in consequence of emaciation (K, TA) arising from hunger or disease: (TA:) or she stood still, or stopped from journeying, in consequence of fatigue and emaciation, and was motionless. (S, TA.) ― -b2- razama, (K, TA,) said of a man, inf. n. razomN, (TA,) He died. (K, TA.) ― -b3- razama EalaI qironihi He overcame his adversary, and kneeled upon him, (K, TA,) and quitted not his place. (TA.) One says of a lion razama EalaI firiysatihi [He lay upon his breast on his prey, not quitting it]. (TA.) ― -b4- Airozimo bihi maA razama Be thou firm, or steadfast, with it as long as it is firm, or steadfast: referring to fortune when it is severe, or rigorous. (Ham p. 362.) ― -b5- And razama biAlXRaIoCi He laid hold upon the thing. (K.) ― -b6- XadiydapF razama AlXRitaMCu razomapF↓ The winter was, or became, intensely cold. (K, * TA.) Hence nawoCu Almirozami↓ [q. v. infrà]. (K, TA.) ― -b7- razamati AlOumRu bihi The mother brought him forth: (K:) and so zaramato bihi. (TA.) ＝ -A2- razama AlXRaIoCa, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
razuma
(Msb, K) and
razima
, (K,) inf. n. razomN, (Msb, TA,) He collected together the thing (S, Msb, K) in a garment, or piece of cloth. (K. [See 2.]) ＝ -A3- See also 4.

2 rzRm Alqawomu c
2. rzRm Alqawomu, (K,) inf. n. taroziymN, (TA,) The people cast, or laid, themselves down upon the ground, (K, TA,) and remained fixed there, (TA,) not quitting their place. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- rzRm AlvRiyaAba, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. as above, (S, K,) He bound the clothes, or tied them up, (S, K,) in rizam [or bundles]: (S:) he made the clothes into rizam. (Msb.)

3 rAzm AldRaAra c
3. rAzm AldRaAra He remained, stayed, or dwelt, long in the house, or abode. (K, TA.) ― -b2- rAzm bayonahumaA He conjoined them two; (K;) [as, for instance, two kinds of food, by taking them in immediate succession:] he mixed them. (TA.) You say, rAzmt AlUibilu The camels mixed two pastures. (S, TA.) And rAzmt AlUibilu AlEaAma The camels pastured upon the HamoD [or salt, or sour, plants] one time, and xulRap [or sweet plants] another time, this year. (TA.) [In the case of a man,] muraAzamapN in eating signifies the making a consecutive, or successive, connexion [between two things]; kamaA yuraAzimu AlrRajulu bayona AljaraAdi waAltRamori [like as when the man makes a consecutive, or successive, connexion between the eating of locusts and that of dates; or makes locusts and dates consecutive, or successive]: (S, TA:) or muraAzamapN in relation to food signifies the making an interchange, by eating one day flesh-meat, and one day honey, (K, TA,) and one day dates, (TA,) and one day [drinking] milk, (K, TA,) and one day [eating] bread without any seasoning or condiment, (TA,) and the like; not keeping continually, or constantly, to one thing: (K, TA:) or the intermixing the [acts of] eating with thanks, and the mouthfuls with praise; (IAar, K, TA;) by saying, between the mouthfuls, Praise be to God: (IAar, TA:) or the mentioning God between every two mouthfuls: (Th, TA:) or the eating the soft and the dry or tough [alternately], and the sweet and the sour, and the unseasoned, or disagreeable in taste, and the seasoned: agreeably with all of these interpretations is explained the saying of 'Omar, UicaA Oakalotumo faraAzmuwA: (K, TA:) as though he said, [When ye eat,] eat what is easy and agreeable to swallow with what is unseasoned, or disagreeable in taste: (TA:) or mix ye, in your eating, what is soft with what is rough, or harsh, or coarse: (IAth, TA:) or make ye praise to follow [your eating]. (S.) ― -b3- muraAzamapu AlsRuwqi means The purchasing in the market less than what will make up the full quantity of the loads. (K.)

4 Arzmt c
4. Arzmt She (a camel) uttered a cry such as is termed razamap [q. v.] when loving, or affecting, her young one: (S:) or she (a camel) uttered a cry of yearning towards her young one: (K:) and in like manner, Arzmt EalaI waladihaA is said of a ewe, or she-goat: but sometimes UirozaAmN means the uttering of a cry, or sound, absolutely: and Arzmt said of a she-camel occurs in a trad. as meaning she uttered a cry. (TA.) One says, laA OafoEalu caAka maA Oarozamato OumRu HaAYilK [I will not do that as long as a mother of a female young camel utters her gentle yearning cry]: (S, K: *) a prov. (K.) And hence, i. e. from Arzmt said of a she-camel, (TA,) Arzm is also said of thunder, (S, K,) meaning (tropical:) It made a vehement sound, or noise: (K, TA:) or it made a sound, or noise, (S, K,) not vehement. (K.) [And it seems that razimato↓ and razima signify the same as Arzmt and Arzm said of a she-camel and of thunder: for] the inf. n. razamN, used in relation to a camel and to thunder, signify The making a sound or noise. (KL.) Arzmt is also said of a cooking-pot, meaning (assumed tropical:) It made a noise by its boiling. (Ham p. 663.) And you say, Arzmt AlrRiyHu fiI Aljawofi (assumed tropical:) The wind made a sound [in the belly]. (K.)

razimN c
razimN Rain accompanied by incessant thunder: a possessive epithet. (Lh, TA.)

ruzamN c
ruzamN Firm, or steadfast, standing upon the ground: (S, K:) and murozimN↓ and raAzimN↓ signify [the same; or] firm, or steadfast, upon the ground: and the pl. of the last is ruzRaAmN, occurring in a verse cited voce rizaAmN, q. v. (TA.) ― -b2- Also The lion; and so murozimN↓; (K, TA;) because he lies upon his breast on his prey, not quitting it: (TA:) or ruzamN (Ham p. 362) and razaAmN↓ (TA, and Ham ibid., [but in the latter without any syll. signs,]) like saHaAbN, and razaAmapN↓ like saHaAbapN, [which is of a form denoting intensiveness of signification,] (TA,) are epithets applied to a lion, meaning that lies upon his breast on his prey, (Ham, TA,) and growls. (Ham.) Accord. to J, it is applied in a verse of Sáïdeh Ibn-Ju-eiyeh to an elephant: but accord. to IB, and the Expos. of Skr, it is there applied to a lion, as meaning That has remained firm, or steadfast, in his place. (TA.)

razomapN c
razomapN: see 1: ― -b2- and see also the next paragraph, in two places. ― -b3- Oakala AlrRazomapN He ate the wajobap [or meal that sufficed for a day and a night, or for four and twenty hours]. (K.)

rizomapN c
rizomapN A quantity remaining in a [receptacle of the kind called] julRap, [a meaning said in the TA, in art. rdm, to be erroneously assigned in the K, in that art, to ridomapN,] of dates, amounting to half thereof, or a third, or thereabout: (TA:) or, accord. to Sh, the third part, or fourth part, of a [sack such as is called] giraArap, (Mgh, TA,) or thereabout, (Mgh,) of dates or flour: or, accord. to Zeyd Ibn-Kuthweh, like qawosN, signifying the quantity of the fourth part of the julRap, of dates: (TA:) or, accord. to the Tekmileh, [the pl.] rizamN signifies the [sacks called] garaAYir, in which is wheat: and hence the rizam of clothes [explained in what here follows. (Mgh.) ― -b2- A kaArap [or bundle, put in one piece of cloth and tied up,] of clothes; (S, Msb, TA;) what are tied up in one piece of cloth, (K, TA,) of clothes: (TA:) or clothes, and other things, put together [in a bundle]; as also razomapN↓: (Mgh:) IAmb explains it as meaning the thing in which are sorts (Durawb) and mixtures of clothes: and hence the author of the K has taken a meaning assigned by him to rizomapN, which, he says, is also written razomapN↓, namely, DarobN XadiydN [a vehement beating], altering and substituting: (TA:) the pl. of rizomapN is rizamN. (S, Msb.)

razamapN c
razamapN A cry, or sound, (AZ, S, K, TA,) a sort of yearning cry, (TA,) of a she-camel, when loving, or affecting, her young one, uttered from her throat, or fauces, (AZ, S, K, TA,) without opening her mouth, not as loud as that which is termed HaniynN. (AZ, S, TA.) It is said in a prov., razamapN walaA dirRapN [A gentle yearning cry of a she-camel, and no flow of milk]: (S:) or laA xayora fiI razamapK laA dirRapa fiyhaA [There is no good in a gentle yearning cry of a she-camel with which is no flow of milk]: (K:) applied to him who promises and does not fulfil: (S, K:) or to him who causes to wish and does not act: (A, TA:) or to him who makes a show of love, or affection, without proving it to be true or without;t its being accompanied by any gift. (M, TA.) ― -b2- Also The cry of a boy, or child. (K, TA: but not in the CK.) ― -b3- And, accord. to IAar, A vehement cry or sound. (TA.) ― -b4- And The cries of beasts of prey. (S, TA.) A poet says,
lilsRibaAEi Hawolahu razamaho
tarakuwA EamoraAna munojadilAF
[They left 'Amrán prostrate upon the ground; there being cries of the beasts of prey around him]. (IB, TA.)

razaAmN c
razaAmN: see ruzamN.

rizaAmN c
rizaAmN A man strong and stubborn. (K.) ruzaAmN, [a mistranscription, app. for razRaAmN↓, for it must be with teshdeed to the z, as is shown by an ex. in a copy of the S, consisting of two verses, of which the former here follows,] as an epithet applied to a man, means Stubborn, behaving with forced hardness or hardiness: it occurs, accord. as some relate it, in the saying of a rájiz, [so in the S and TA, but correctly, a poet using the sixth species of the metre termed AlsRariyE,] which others relate thus:
OayaA baniI Eabodi manaAfi AlrRuzRaAmo↓
Oanotumo HumaApN waOabuwkumu HaAmN
[O sons of 'Abd-Menáf, the firm, or steadfast, upon the ground, (accord. to this reading; but accord. to the reading that seems to be razRaAmo, the stubborn, &c., as a sing., referring to 'AbdMenáf himself;) ye are defenders, and your father was a defender, HaAmo being for HaAmK]: ruzRaAm being pl. of raAzimN. (So in one of my two copies of the S: in the other copy omitted.)

raziymN c
raziymN A roaring, or growling: a poet says,
liOusuwidhinRa EalaI AlTRariyqi raziymu
[There is, or was, a roaring, or growling, of their lions on the road]. (S.)

razaAmapN c
razaAmapN: see ruzamN.

AlrRizaAmiyRapu c
AlrRizaAmiyRapu A sect who said that the office of Imám, after 'Alee, belonged to Mohammad Ibn-El-Hanafeeyeh, and then to his son 'Abd-Allah, and who accounted lawful those things that are [esteemed by the orthodox] forbidden: (KT:) or a sect of the extravagant zealots of the class of innovators, of the schismatics, or followers of 'Alee, who say that the office of Imám belonged to Aboo-Muslim El-Khurásánee, after El-Man- soor, and some of whom arrogated to themselves divinity, one of them being El-Mukanna', who made the moon to appear to them in Nakhshab, and of whose persuasion there is in this day a party in Má-wará-en-Nahr. (TA.)

razRaAmN c
razRaAmN: see rizaAmN. ― -b2- [AlrRazRaAmu, as an epithet applied to the lion, The roaring. (Freytag, from the “ Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen. ”)]

raAzimN c
raAzimN A camel remaining fixed upon the ground, (S, TA,) unable to rise, (Lh, S, K, TA,) in consequence of his having fallen down by reason of fatigue and emaciation, (Lh, TA,) or in consequence of emaciation (S, K, TA) arising from hunger or disease: (TA:) and in like manner applied to a man, &c.: (Lh, TA:) and also, [without p,] applied to a she-camel, meaning standing still, or stopping from journeying, in consequence of fatigue and emaciation, and motionless: (S:) pl. razomaI and rizaAmN, [accord. to Freytag ruzamN,] applied to camels. (TA.) ― -b2- See also marozimN. ― -b3- Also, applied to winter, Cold. (TA.)

murozimN c
[murozimN A prey. (Freytag, from the “ Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen. ”)]

murozimN c
murozimN: see ruzamN, in two places.

Almirozamu c
Almirozamu is a name of The right star [app. γ, i. e. Bellatrix,] in the left arm of AljabRaAr [or Orion]. (Kzw. [Golius says, as on the authority of Kzw, that it is “ a star in the right shoulder of Orion: ” but Kzw says that this star (which is a of Orion) is called manokibu AljawozaMCi and yadu AljawozaMCi; and then he mentions that in the left arm, as being called Almrzm: whence it seems that Golius was misled by the omission of some words in a copy of the work of Kzw.]) And AlmirozamaAni, (S, K,) also called mirozamaA AlXRiEorayayoni, (S,) is the name of Two stars [of which one is commonly known as B of Canis Major, and the other is app. B of Canis Minor, though Golius says, on the authority of Ulugh Beg, that the former is in the right hind leg of Canis Major,] with the XiEorayaAni [by which latter appellation are meant Sirius and Procyon], (K,) or one of which is in [or by] AlXRiEoraI [commonly so called, i. e. Sirius,] and the other is in AlcRiraAE [by which is meant AlcRiraAE AlmaqobuwDap, i. e. the asterism consisting of a and B of Canis Minor]; (S;) or one of them is AlcrAE AlmqbwDp [mentioned above and the other is AlXRiEoraI (q. v.) commonly so called]: thus says Ibn-Kunáseh: both are of the stars of rain: and sometimes the sing. appellation (Almirozamu) is used [app. as applied to Sirius, or to Bellatrix, or perhaps to B of Canis Minor]. (TA.) nawoCu Almirozami [means The auroral setting of some one of the stars above mentioned; for it] is so termed because of its intense cold. (TA. See 1.) AlsRamaAku Almirozamu is another name for AlsRimaAku AlrRaAmiHu [The star Arcturus]. (Az and TA in art. rmH. [This star neither sets nor rises aurorally in the cold season, nor is it one of the Mansions of the Moon; but it rises aurorally during “ the first of the rains, ” the autumnal rain, called AlwasomiIR.]) ― -b2- OumRu mirozamK (tropical:) The north wind: (S, K, TA:) or the cold north wind: (Skr, on a verse of Sakhr-el-Gheí:) from razaAmapu AlnRaAqapi meaning “ the [gentle] yearning cry of the she-camel: ” (TA:) or it signifies, (ISd, TA,) or signifies also, (K,) the wind: (ISd, K, TA:) thus expl. by ISd without any restriction. (TA.)

murazRimN c
murazRimN That has cast, or laid, himself upon the around, and remained fixed, or motionless: or having [or making or uttering] a sound, or cry: and applied to an army, or a military force, agreeably with one or the other of these explanations. (Skr, on a verse of Abu-l-Muthellem.)

tarakotuhu biAlmurotazami c
tarakotuhu biAlmurotazami [I left him in the place where one cleaves to the ground; or] I made him to cleave to the ground. (K.)

1 razuna c
1. razuna, (S, K, &c.,) inf. n. razaAnapN (S, * MA, K, * TA) and ruzuwnN, (TA,) [It (a thing) was, or became, heavy, or weighty: this is the primary signification: see razaAnapN below. ― -b2- And hence,] (tropical:) He (a man) was, or became, grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm; (S, MA, K, TA;) and forbearing: and still, or motionless: (S, * K, * TA:) or firm, or sound, of judgment: (TA:) wise, or sensible. (MA.) ＝ -A2- razana biAlmakaAni [thus in the K, with fet-h to the z,] He remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in the place. (K.) ＝ -A3- razanahu, (S, K,) aor.
razuna
, inf. n. razonN, (S,) He lifted it (namely, a thing, S) in order that he might see what was its weight. (S, K.) ― -b2- Hence, razana AlHajara He lifted the stone from the ground. (TA.)

2 razRana
2: [rzRnhu, inf. n. taroziynN, (assumed tropical:) He pronounced him, or held or reckoned him, to be grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm:] the inf. n. taroziynN is syn. with tawoqiyrN [q. v.]. (S in art. wqr.)

5 trzRn c
5. trzRn i. q. tawaqRara (assumed tropical:) [He showed, exhibited, or manifested, gravity, staidness, steadiness, sedateness, or calmness; or he endeavoured, or constrained himself, to be grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm]; (M, K;) fiI majolisihi [in his sittingplace], (M,) or fiI AlXRaIoCi [in the thing]. (K.)

6 yataraAzaAnaAni c
6. yataraAzaAnaAni, said of two mountains, They are opposite, or facing, each other. (K.)

razonN c
razonN A place that is elevated (S, K, TA) and hard, (TA,) having in it a depression that retains the water [of the rain]: pl. ruzuwnN and rizaAnN: (S, K, TA:) the latter of which pls. is also pl. of rizonapN [q. v.]. (K.) It is also sing. of OarozaAnN signifying [Hollows, or cavities, such as are termed] nuqarN [pl. of nuqorapN] in stone, or in rugged ground, that retain the water [of the rain]; and so is rizonN↓; or, accord. to Ibn-Hamzeh, this latter only; and thus says IB, because a noun of the measure faEolN has not a pl. of the measure OafoEaAlN, except in a few instances. (TA.) [The pl.] ruzawnN also signifies The remains of a torrent in places which it has partially worn away. (TA.)

rizonN c
rizonN: see the next preceding paragraph. ― -b2- Also i. q. naAHiyapN [A side, region, quarter, or tract, &c.]. (K.)

rizonapN c
rizonapN A place where water remains and collects; or where it collects and stagnates; or where it remains long, and becomes altered: pl. rizaAnN [mentioned above as a pl. of razonN, q. v.]: (S, K:) so says AO. (S.)

razaAnN c
razaAnN: see the next paragraph.

raziynN c
raziynN Heavy, or weighty; (S, K;) applied to a thing (S, TA) of any kind. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) Grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm; (S, MA, K, TA;) and forbearing: and still, or motionless: (S, * K, * TA:) or firm, or sound, of judgment: (TA:) wise, or sensible: (MA:) or a man having much gravity, staidness, &c.: (Har p. 227:) and razaAnN↓ signifies the same, applied to a woman; (MA, K;) or, thus applied, grave, staid, &c., in her sitting-place: (S:) the epithet raziynapN is not applied to her unless she be firm, or constant; and grave, staid, &c.; and continent, chaste, or modest; grave, staid, &c., in her sitting-place. (TA.) ― -b3- Oabuw raziynK is a name given to The [kind of sweet food commonly called] xabiyS [q. v.]; because of its excellence among eatables, and its high estimation, and its surpassing cost, and its being put the last thing to be eaten. (Har p. 227.)

razaAnapN c
razaAnapN inf. n. of razuna [q. v.]. (MA, TA.) Heaviness, or weight: this is the primary signification. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) Gravity, staidness, steadiness, sedateness, or calmness; (S, MA, K, TA;) and forbearance: and stillness, or motionlessness: (S, * K, * TA:) or firmness, or soundness, of judgment: (TA:) wisdom, or sensibleness: (MA:) and firmness, or constancy. (Har p. 423.)

rawozanN c
rawozanN, (T, Mgh,) or rawozanapN↓, (ISk, S, M, K,) A hole, a perforation, an aperture, or a window, (ISk, T, S, M, Mgh, K,) syn. kuwRapN, (ISk, S, Mgh, K,) or kuwRapN naAficapN, (T,) [in a wall, or chamber, i. e. a mural aperture,] or in the upper part of a roof: (M, TA:) an arabicized word [from the Pers. rawozano, or rawozanaho]: (ISk, S:) thought by the author of the T to be arabicized, used by the Arabs: (TA:) pl. rawaAzinu. (T, Mgh.)

rawozunapN c
rawozunapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

Oarozan c
Oarozan [accord. to general opinion, being a subst. only, not originally an epithet, OarozanN, or, accord. to some, it may be Oarozanu, as being imagined to possess the quality of an epithet,] A kind of hard tree, (Lth, S, K,) of which staves are made. (Lth, S.)

huwa muraAzinuhu c
huwa muraAzinuhu i. q. muHaAlRuhu [He is his companion in alighting, or descending and stopping or sojourning &c.]: (so in copies of the K:) or muxaAlRuhu [his friendly associate; or true, or sincere, friendly associate]. (So in the K accord. to the TA [which is followed in this instance, as generally, in the TK: but the former I regard as the true reading, from razana biAlmakaAni q. v.].)

1 razaI fulaAnFA c
1. razaI fulaAnFA, aor.yaroziI, (K,) inf. n. razoIN, (TA,) He accepted the bounty of such a one. (K.) [See also razaOahu: and, under the same head, see raziynaA, and ruziytuhu: and see a verse cited voce mutoladN; in which ruziynaA seems to be used for ruziYonaA; or the latter may be the correct reading.]

4 ArzI Uilayohi c
4. ArzI Uilayohi He leaned, or stayed, himself upon, or against, him, or it; and he had recourse, or betook himself, to him, or it, for refuge, protection, covert, or lodging: (K:) or Oarozayotu ZahoriI UilaI fulaAnK I had recourse, or betook myself, to such a one for refuge, protection, covert, or lodging: (S:) or, accord. to Lth, the verb is OarozaOa, with C. (TA.)

raziyRapN c
raziyRapN, for raziyYapN: see the latter, in art. rzO.

1 rasRa AlhuwaI fiI qalobihi c
1. rasRa AlhuwaI fiI qalobihi, and AlsRuqomu fiI jisomihi, [aor., accord. to the general rule,
rasisa
,] inf. n. rasRN and rasysN, Love entered, and established itself, in his heart, and disease in his body; as also ArsR↓. (M.) [It seems also, from explanations of rasRu and rasiysN mentioned below, that one says rasRati AlHumRaI, meaning The fever commenced, or first touched a person.]

4 Oarosasa
4: see above.

rasRN c
rasRN The beginning, or commencement, of a thing. (K.) And hence, (K,) rasRu AlHumRaI, and rasiysuhaA↓, The beginning, or commencement, (M, A, K,) or first touch, (S,) of fever, (S, M, A, K,) before it becomes vehement, or severe; (A;) i. e., when the person attacked thereby stretches on account of it, and becomes languid in his body, and relaxed, or heavy, sluggish, or torpid, or confused in his intellect: (M, TA:) or the first that a man feels of the touch of fever, before it takes him forcibly, and becomes apparent. (As, TA.) Accord. to Fr, you say, Oaxacatohu AlHumRaI birasRK, meaning, The fever became settled in his bones. (TA.) [Hence also,] rasRu AlHubRi, and rasiysuhu↓, The beginning, or commencement, of love: (K:) or a remain, or relic, or trace, of love: (M:) or AlhawaI rasiysu↓ signifies the first, or original, feeling (OaSol) of love. (Aboo-Málik, TA.) [Hence also,] balaganiI rasRN mino xabarK The first of news reached me: (TA:) or somewhat of news reached me: (S, M:) [or news not true reached me: for,] accord. to AZ, you say, OataAnaA rasRN mino xabarK, and mano xabarK rasiysN↓, meaning, News not true came to us: (TA:) or rasiysN↓ [alone] signifies news not true. (K.)

rasiysN c
rasiysN: see rasRN, throughout.

1 rasaba c
1. rasaba, (S, M, A, &c.,) aor.
rasuba
, (M, A, &c.,) inf. n. rusuwbN (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and rasobN; (Msb;) and rasuba, aor.
rasuba
; (M, A, K;) It (a thing, S, Msb) sank, or subsided, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) in water [&c.]. (S, M, A, Mgh, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] rasabato EayonaAhu (tropical:) His eyes sank [in their sockets]. (S, A.) ― -b3- And AlsRayofu yarosubu fiI AlDRarybapi (tropical:) The sword sinks, or disappears, in the thing struck with it. (TA.)

2 rsRb c
2. rsRb It precipitated a substance, or caused it to sink in a liquid: used in this sense in chymical works; but probably post-classical. See what next follows.]

4 Arsb c
4. Arsb It caused [a thing] to sink: hence, in a trad., describing the people of Hell, UicaA Tafato bihimu AlnRaAru Oarosabatohumu AlOagolaAlu When the fire shall raise them, and make them. to appear [or rather to
swim upon its surface], the collars, by reason of their weight, shall make them to sink to the bottom thereof. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And ArsbwA Their eyes sank in their heads by reason of hunger. (K, TA.)

5 trsRb c
5. trsRb It (a substance) became precipitated, or was caused to sink, in a liquid: used in this sense in chymical works; but probably postclassical.]

rasabN c
rasabN and rusabN: see the next paragraph.

rasuwbN c
rasuwbN [What is wont to sink, or subside, in water &c. ― -b2- And hence,] Dregs amid water and blood: in this sense improperly pronounced rusuwbN. (KL. [Golius, as on the same authority, explains it as meaning sedimentum aquæ, urinæ, etc.: hypostasis. See also the next paragraph.]) ― -b3- [Hence also,] (tropical:) A sword (S, M, A, K) that penetrates into, (S,) or that disappears in, (M, A, K,) the thing struck with it; (S, M, A, K;) and so rasabN↓ (M, K) and rusabN↓ (K, TA) and mirosabN↓. (A, K, TA.
