[In the CK, by the omission of wa after the last, this and the last but one are made to be appellations of a sword of Mohammad or of Soloman, and of a sword of El-Hárith Ibn-AbeeShemir.]) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) The glans of the penis: (M, K:) app. because of its disappearance on the occasion of the act of jimaAEi. (M.) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) Forbearing, or element; as also raAsibN↓. (K.)

rusaAbapu AlmaMCX c
rusaAbapu AlmaMCX (JK and Mgh and K in art. tqn [in CK erroneously rasaAbap]) [The sediment of water;] the thick matter that is borne by water [and that sinks to the bottom]. (Lth, Mgh in that art.)

rasuwbiIRN c
[rasuwbiIRN and mutarasRibN↓, terms used by Ibn-Seenà, are explained by Golius as meaning Having, or depositing, a sediment: but the former rather means having the nature of dregs, or sediment: and the latter, becoming, or that becomes, precipitated.]

raAsibN c
raAsibN (tropical:) A firm mountain. (M, A, K.) ― -b2- See also rusuwbN.

rawosabN c
rawosabN A calamity, or misfortune; (K;) as also rawosamN. (TA.)

mirosabN c
mirosabN: see rasuwbN.

maraAsibu c
maraAsibu i. q. OawaAsK [pl. of MsiyapN, and app. here meaning Columns, or props]. (K.)

mutarasRibN c
mutarasRibN: see rasuwbiIRN.

rusotaAqN c
rusotaAqN: see ruzodaAqN, in art. rzdq.

1 rasHa c
1. rasHa, aor.
rasaHa
, inf. n. rasaHN, (L, Msb,) He had little flesh, or was scant of flesh, in his posteriors and thighs: or he had small buttocks, sticking together: (L:) or he had little flesh in his thighs. (Msb.)

4 ArsH c
4. ArsH It rendered a person scant of flesh in the posteriors (S, A) and thighs. (S.)

rasaHN c
rasaHN Paucity of flesh in the posteriors (S, A, L, K) and thighs: (S, L, K:) or smallness of the buttocks, and their sticking together: (L:) or paucity of flesh in the thighs. (Msb.)

rasiHN c
rasiHN Having little flesh in his thighs. (Msb.) [See also what follows.]

OarosaHu c
OarosaHu A man (S, L) having little flesh in his posteriors (S, A, L) and thighs: (S, L:) or having small buttocks, sticking together: (L:) fem. rasoHaMCu; applied to a woman: (S, A, L:) pl. rusoHN. (S, K.) [See also rasiHN.] AlOarosaHu means The wolf: (TA:) [for] every wolf is [termed] OarosaH because of the lightness [of the flesh] of his haunches: (S, A, * K:) and so is the simoE [a mongrel beast, the offspring of a wolf begotten from the hyena]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, the fem., A foul, an ugly, or an unseemly, woman: (K, TA:) though disapproved by MF. (TA.)

1 rasaxa c
1. rasaxa, (S, A, L, &c.,) aor.
rasaxa
, (A, Msb, JM, &c.,) inf. n. rusuwxN, It (a thing, S, Msb) was, or became, firm, steady, steadfast, stable, fixed, fast, settled, or established, (S, A, L, Msb, K,) in its place. (L.) [Hence,] rasaxa AlHiboru fiI AlSRaHiyfapi (tropical:) [The ink became fixed upon the piece of paper or the like]. (A, L.) And AlrRaqRu AldRahiynu laA yurosaxu fiyhi AlHiboru (tropical:) [Ink will not become fixed upon oiled parchment]: (A:) or Alwaraqu AldRahiynu [oiled paper]. (TA.) And rasaxa fiI AlEilomi (tropical:) He became firmly rooted, or grounded, or established, in science, or knowledge. (L.) And AlEilomu yarosaxu fiI qalobi AlUinosaAni (tropical:) Science, or knowledge, becomes firmly rooted, or grounded, or fixed, in the heart of man. (L, A. *) And rasaxa HubRuhu fiI qalobihi (tropical:) [The love of him, or it, became fixed in his heart]. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence also,] said of a pool of water left by a torrent, (tropical:) It sank into the earth, and disappeared: (JK, A, K:) inf. n. as above. (JK, TA.) And, said of rain, (tropical:) It sank into the earth so that the two moistures [meaning that of the rain and that of the soil beneath] met together. (A, K.) ― -b3- rasoxN [as an inf. n.] signifies (assumed tropical:) The connexion of the soul of a human being, after its departure from the body, with an inanimate, not increasing, body: distinguished from nasoxN, which is with the body of another human being: and from masoxN, which is with the body of a beast: and from fasoxN, which is with a plant. (Marginal note in a copy of the KT.) But see 1 (last sentence) in art. fsx

4 Arsxhu c
4. Arsxhu, (JK, K,) inf. n. UirosaAxN, (TA,) He made it firm, steady, steadfast, stable, fixed, fast, settled, or established, (JK, K,) in its place. (JK.)

raAsixN c
raAsixN Anything firm, steady, steadfast, stable, fixed, fast, settled, or established [in its place (see 1)]. (S, A, Msb.) You say jabalN raAsixN A firm, or steadfast, mountain. (A.) And in like manner dimonapN raAsixapN [A black, or dark, patch of compacted dung and urine of cattle sticking fast upon the ground]. (A.) And [hence,] lahu qadamN raAsixapN fiI AlEilomi (assumed tropical:) [He has a firm footing in science, or knowledge; or] he possesses excellence, and large acquirements, in science, or knowledge. (Msb.) AlrRaAsixuwna fiI AlEilomi [in the Kur iii. 5 and iv. 160] means (tropical:) Those who are firmly rooted, or established, in science, or knowledge: (S, Bd, L, Jel, TA:) or who have made a firm advance therein: (L:) or who are far advanced therein: (Khálid Ibn-Jembeh:) or those who study the Book of God: (TA:) or those who have committed [it] to memory, and who call to mind [its doctrines and precepts] one with another. (IAar.)

rusodaAqN c
rusodaAqN: see ruzodaAqN, in art. rzdq.

1 rasagahu c
1. rasagahu, aor.
rasaga
, inf. n. rasogN, [He tethered him by the fore legs; i. e.] he tied the rusog [or pastern] of each of his (a camel's [or an ass's]) fore legs with a string, or cord, which is called rusogN. (TA.)

2 rsRg c
2. rsRg, (S, Msb, &c.,) inf. n. tarosiygN, (IAar, K,) said of rain, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) It rained so that the water reached to the rusog [or pastern, or ankle], (S,) or so that it reached to the place of the OarosaAg [pl. of rusogN]: (Msb:) or it moistened the earth (IAar, K, TA) so that the hands of him who dug for it reached to his OarosaAg [or wrists]; (IAar, TA;) or so that the moisture reached to the measure of the rusog [or wrist] of the digger: (TA:) or it was so much that the rusog [or pastern, or ankle,] disappeared in it; as also Arsg↓, a dial. var., on the authority of IAar. (TA.) ＝ -A2- tarosiygN also signifies The making [the means of subsistence] ample, or abundant. (K.) You say, rsRg AlEayoXa He made the means of subsistence ample, or abundant. (TK.) [Or rsRg Ealayohi fiI AlEayoXi He made ample, or abundant, provision for him in the means of subsistence: see the pass. part. n., below: and see also 8.] ＝ -A3- rsRgtu kalaAmFA, (JK,) inf. n. as above, (K,) i. q. lafRaqotu bayonahu [meaning I interlarded, or embellished, speech. or discourse, with falsehood: accord. to the TK, connected it, and arranged it, or put it in order: but see the pass. part. n., below]. (JK, K, * TA.)

3 rAsghu c
3. rAsghu, (Ibn-'Abbád, K,) inf. n. muraAsagapN and risaAgN, (Lth, Ibn-'Abbád, K,) He took hold of his rusog [meaning ankle] in wrestling with him, the latter doing the like. (Lth, Ibn-'Abbád, K.) One says, raAdagahu vumRa raAsagahu vumRa maAragahu [He strove with him to throw him down: then he took hold of his ankle &c.: then he rolled with him on the ground, or in the dust]. (TA.)

4 Oarosaga
4: see 2.

8 Artsg EalaI EiyaAlihi c
8. Artsg EalaI EiyaAlihi He expended amply, or abundantly, upon his family, or household. (Ibn-Buzurj, K.) [See also 2.]

rusogN c
rusogN and rusugN↓, (S, Msb, K,) of a daAbRap [or beast
of the equine kind], (S, Msb,) [The pastern; i.e.] the slender place [or part] between the solid hoof and the joint of the waZiyf [or shank] of the fore leg, and of the hind leg; (S, Msb, K;) or, [in other words,] of solid-hoofed animals, the part that joins the wZyf of each of the fore legs, and of the hind legs, to the hoof; and of camels, the part that joins the OawoZifap [or shanks] to the OaxofaAf [or feet]: (TA:) and (Msb, and so in some copies of the K, but in other copies of the latter “ or, ” [which is more correct, as will be seen from what follows,]) of a human being, [the wrist, and the ankle; i. e.] the joint between the hand and the fore arm, and between the foot and the shank: (Msb, K, TA:) and of any beast (dAbRh,) the like thereof; (K;) [the part between the shank and hoof or foot, in the fore leg and in the hind leg, of any quadruped:] pl. OarosaAgN [used as a pl. of mult. and of pauc.] (Msb, K) and OarosugN [which is only a pl. of pauc.]. (K.) ― -b2- See also risaAgN: ― -b3- and see mirosagapN.

rasagN c
rasagN A laxness in the legs of a camel. (As, S, K.)

rusugN c
rusugN: see rusogN

risaAgN c
risaAgN A cord, or rope, that is tied (JK, S, K) firmly (S) to the rusog [or pastern] of the camel, (JK, S, K,) or, accord. to the T, to each rusog, [the dual form being there used, meaning to the pastern of each fore leg,] of the camel, (TA,) to prevent him from going away; (S, K;) also called mirosagapN↓; of which the pl. is maraAsigu: (JK:) or, as some say, rsaAgN is pl. of rusogN↓ meaning a cord, or rope, with which a camel, and an ass, is [tethered, or] shackled; or a string, or cord, with which the rusog [or pastern] of each of the fore legs of a camel [or an ass] is tied. (TA.) ― -b2- Also an inf. n. of 3.

EayoXN rasiygN c
EayoXN rasiygN Ample, or abundant, means of subsistence: and TaEaAmN rasiygN Much food or wheat. (Aboo-Málik, K.)

mirosagapN c
mirosagapN sing. of maraAsiygu [probably a mistranscription for maraAsigu] meaning [Bracelets of tortoiseshell or horn or ivory, such as are termed] masak, that are worn by women on their arms; one of which is also called rusogN↓. (TA.) ― -b2- See also risaAgN.

huwa murasRagN Ealayohi fiI AlEayoXi c
huwa murasRagN Ealayohi fiI AlEayoXi He is amply, or abundantly, provided for in respect of the means of subsistence. (JK, * TA.) ＝ -A2- raOoIN murasRagN An unsound opinion or counsel or advice. (JK, Ibn- 'Abbád, K.)

1 rasafa c
1. rasafa, aor.
rasufa
and
rasifa
, inf. n. rasofN and rasafaAnN (S, M, O, Msb, K) and rasiyfN, (M, O, Msb, K,) He walked, or went along, in the manner of him who is shackled: (S, M, O, K:) or he walked, or went along, in shackles, gently, softly, or in a leisurely manner: (M:) or you say, rasafa fiI qayodihi he walked, or went along, in his shackles: (MA, Msb:) or he went along [therein] by leaps; or gently. (MA.) rasiyfN also signifies The making short steps. (O.) And rasafa, aor.
rasufa
, He (a camel) went with short steps, raising and putting down his feet quickly. (Aboo-Nasr, O.)

4 Oarosafotu AlUibila c
4. Oarosafotu AlUibila, (AZ, S,) inf. n. UirosaAfN, (K,) I drove along the camels, they being shackled. (AZ, S, K. * [In one of my copies of the S, instead of muqayRadapF, I find muqayRadFA, i.e. I being shackled.])

8 Artsf c
8. Artsf, inf. n. AirotisaAfN; (K; so in MS. copies, and so in the CK;) or AirotasafRa↓, in measure like AikofaharRa, inf. n., AirotisofaAfN; (O, and in like manner in the TK;) i. q. AirotafaEa [It became raised; or it rose: &c.]. (O, K.)

R. Q. 4 AirotasafRa c
R. Q. 4. AirotasafRa: see what next precedes. [This art. is wanting in the copies of the L and TA to which I have had access.]

1 rasila c
1. rasila, aor.
rasala
, inf. n. rasalN and rasaAla, He (a camel) was, or became, easy in pace. (M, K.) ― -b2- Also, aor.
rasala
, inf. n. rasalN (AZ, Az, Msb, K) and rasaAlapN, as above, (AZ, Az, K,) It (hair) became lank, not crisp; (Msb, K;) and so Astrsl↓: (S, K:) or lank and pendent: (Msb:) or long, and lank or pendent. (AZ, Az, Msb.) laA yajibu mina AlbRiHoyapi gasolu maA Qsotarosala↓ means [The washing] of what hangs down, and descends, [of the beard,] from the chin [is not requisite, or necessary, or incumbent]. (Mgh.) ＝ -A2- [Golius says, as on the authority of the KL, that rasala signifies Nuncium misit: but what I find in the KL is, that rasuwlN, as an inf. n., signifies the bringing a message (PygAm brdn): whence it seems that rasala means he brought a message.]

2 tarosiylN c
2. tarosiylN, in reading, or reciting, (Msb, K,) i. q. tarotiylN; (K, TA;) i. e. (TA) Easy [or leisurely] utterance; without haste: (Yz, Msb, TA:) or, as some say, with consecution of the parts, or portions: (TA:) and tarasRulN↓ therein signifies the same: (Yz, Msb:) or fiI tarasRala↓ qirRMCatihi signifies he proceeded in a leisurely manner in his reading, or reciting, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and was grave, staid, sedate, or calm, (Mgh,) and endeavoured to understand, without raising his voice much. (TA.) It is said in a trad., kaAna fiI kalaAmihi tarosiylN i. e. tarotiylN [There was in his (Mohammad's) speech an easy, or a leisurely, utterance]. (TA.) And in another trad. it is said, waUicaA Oaqamota faQHocimo UcaA OacRanota fatarasRalo↓ [expl. in art. Hcm]. (Mgh.) ＝ -A2- See also 4, last sentence but one. ＝ -A3- rasRalotu fuSolaAniI, inf. n. tarosiylN, I gave to drink [to my young camels, or my young weaned camels,] risol (K, TA,) i. e. milk. (TA.)

3 rAslhu c
3. rAslhu (S, MA,) inf. n. muraAsalapN, (S,) He sent a message, and a letter, or an epistle, to him, (MA, PS,) the latter doing the like: (PS:) [he interchanged messages, and letters, with him.] You say, rAslhu fiI kacaA [He interchanged messages, or letters, with him, in relation to such a thing]: and bayonahumaA muraAsalaAtN [Between them two are interchanges of messages, or of letters]. (TA.) And haIa turaAsilu AlxuTRaAba [She interchanges messages, or letters, with those who demand women in marriage]. (M, K.) And turaAsiluhu biAlxuTRaAbi [She interchanges messages, or letters, with him by means of those who demand women in marriage]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] rAslhu fiI niDaAlK Oawo gayorihi [He acted interchangeably, or alternated, with him in a competition in shooting, or in some other performance]. (S.) And rAslhu fiI AlginaMCi, and AlEamali, He relieved him, or aided him, in singing, and in work, [by alternating with him, i. e.,] in the former case, by taking up the strain when the latter was unable to continue it [so as to accomplish the cadence (see 6)], and in the latter case by taking up the work when the latter person was unable to continue it; or he so relieved, or aided, him in singing with a high voice: or rAslhu fiI Eamalihi he aided him, [or relieved him, by alternating with him,] or he followed him, or imitated him, in his work: (IAar, Msb:) and rAslhu AlginaMCa he emulated him, or imitated him, [by alternating with him,] in the singing. (TA.) And rAslhu fiI AlqiraMCap He aided him, or assisted him, [or relieved him, by alternating with him,] in the reading, or reciting, of the Kur-án &c. (MA.)

4 UirosaAlN c
4. UirosaAlN signifies The act of sending. (K, KL, &c.) Thus is explained UirosaAlu QllRehi OanobiyaMCahu [i. e. God's sending his prophets.] (Th, TA.) You say, Oarosalotu fulaAnFA fiI risaAlapK↓ (S) I sent such a one with a message. (PS.) And Arsl Uilayohi rasuwlFA↓ (MA, Msb *) He sent to him a message, or a letter, (MA,) or a messenger. (Msb.) ― -b2- [The act of sending forth, or starting, a horse for a race: the discharging a thing; as, for instance, an arrow from a bow; and water, or the like, from a vessel &c. in which it was confined: the launching forth a ship or boat; letting it go; letting it take its course:] the act of setting loose or free; letting loose; loosing, unbinding, or liberating. (K.) You say Arsl AlXRaIoCa He set loose or free, &c., the thing. (M.) And Oarosalotu AlTRaAYira mino yadiI I let go, or let loose, the bird from my hand. (Msb.) And [hence,] Arsl AlHuruwfa [He uttered the letters]. (Mgh in art. rtl.) And Arsl AlginaMCa [He uttered the song; he sang]. (TA.) And Arsl AlUiqaAmapa [He chanted the AqAmp]. (Msb in art. drj. [See Oadoraja.]) And Arsl Ealayohi lisaAnahu [(assumed tropical:) He let loose his tongue against him]. (A in art. brd.) And Arsl AlkalaAma (assumed tropical:) He made the speech, or language, to be unrestricted. (Msb.) [In like manner,] UirosaAlN signifies also (assumed tropical:) The making a thing, such as property, and a legacy, absolute, or unrestricted. (Mgh.) ― -b3- [The act of letting down, letting fall, or making to hang down, the hair &c. You say, Arslhu, and Arslhu mino OaEolaI UilaI Oasofala, He let it down, &c., or lowered it.] ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) The act of leaving, leaving alone, or neglecting, (M, K,) a thing. (M.) [Hence,] one says, Arslhu Eano yadihi (tropical:) He left, forsook, or deserted, him; or he abstained from,
or neglected, aiding him, or assisting him. (TA.) ― -b5- Also The act of making to have dominion, or authority, and power; making to have, or exercise, absolute dominion or sovereignty or rule, or absolute superiority of power or force; or giving power, or superior power or force. (M, K.) Hence, in the Kur [xix. 86], OarosalonaA AlXRayaATiyna EalaI AlkaAfiriyna taWuzRuhumo OazRFA, i. e. [We have made the devils to have dominion, &c., over the unbelievers, inciting them strongly to acts of disobedience; or] we have appointed, or prepared, the devils for the unbelievers, because of their unbelief; like as is said in the same [xliii. 35], nuqayRiDo lahu XayoTaAnFA [“ We will appoint, or prepare, for him a devil ” as an associate]: this is the preferred explanation: [or it may be well rendered we have sent the devils against the unbelievers:] some say that the meaning is, we have left the devils to do as they please with the unbelievers, not withholding them, or preserving them, from acceptance from them. (Zj, M.) ＝ -A2- ArslwA [from risolN] They had milk in their cattle: (S:) or their milk became much; as also rsRlwA↓, inf. n. tarosiylN: (K:) or the latter signifies their milk and drink became much. (TA.) ― -b2- Also [from rasalN] They became possessors of herds or flocks. (O, K. *)

5 trsRl c
5. trsRl He acted, or behaved, gently, and deliberately, or leisurely, (M, K, TA,) and with gravity, staidness, sedateness, or calmness. (TA.) AltRarasRulu fiI AlOumuwri is The acting, or behaving, [gently, and] deliberately, or leisurely, and with gravity, staidness, sedateness, or calmness, in affairs. (TA.) See also 2, in three places. ― -b2- AltRarasRulu in riding is The extending one's legs upon the beast so as to let, or make, his clothes hang down loosely upon his legs: and in sitting, the crossing one's legs, and letting, or making, his clothes hang down loosely upon them and around him. (TA.) ＝ -A2- trsRlA bayona Alqawomi [He acted as a rasuwl (or messenger) between the people]. (Msb and TA in art. Alk.)

6 trAslwA c
6. trAslwA They sent, one to another, (MA, Msb, TA,) a message [or messages], (MA, Msb,) or a messenger [or messengers]. (Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, trAslwA fiI AlginaMCi [They relieved, or aided, one another alternately in singing;] i. e. they combined in singing, one beginning, and prolonging his voice, but being unable to continue long enough to accomplish the cadence, and therefore pausing, and another then taking up the strain, and then the first returning to the modulation, and so on to the end. (Msb.) laA taraAsula fiI AlOacaAni means [in like manner] There shall be no relieving, or aiding, one another [alternately], i. e., no combining [of two or more persons, each performing a part alternately], in the chanting of the call to prayer. (Msb.) [In other cases likewise] AltRaraAsulu signifies The doing the like of that which one's companion, or fellow, [or another,] does, in such a manner as that one follows another [alternately]. (Har p. 268.)

10 Astrsl c
10. Astrsl It (a thing) was, or became, loose, or slack; syn. salisa. (M, TA.) ― -b2- Said of hair: see 1, in two places. [In like manner said of a tree, &c., It drooped; or was pendent. Said of a cheek, (to which its part. n. musotarosilN is applied as an epithet in the K voce OasiylN,) It was, or became, lank.] ― -b3- AlAisotirosaAlu in the pace of a beast is The going gently, deliberately, or leisurely. (TA.) [And you say, Astrslt AldRaAbRapN The beast went a gentle, deliberate, or leisurely, pace.] ― -b4- Also, [in other cases,] The being still, and steady. (TA.) ― -b5- Hence, (TA,) Astrsl Uilayohi (tropical:) He acted, or behaved, towards him with freedom, boldness, forwardness, or presumptuousness, and with familiarity; syn. AinobasaTa, and AisotaOonasa; (S, K, TA;) and was at ease, and confided in him, with respect to that which he told him: (TA:) or he acted forwardly, or impudently, towards him: he acted forwardly, impudently, freely, or familiarly, towards him, in the way of coquetry, or feigned disdain. (MA.) ― -b6- And Astrsl AldRahoru fiyhimo faOafonaAhumo [(assumed tropical:) Fate made free with them, and destroyed them]. (TA in art. bhl) ＝ -A2- Also He said, Send thou to me the camels in droves (OarosaAlFA [in the CK, erroneously, AirosAlFA]); (K, TA;) ArsAlA being with fet-h to the hemzeh; i. e. drove after drove: for the camels, when they come to the water, are numerous; and their tender brings them to the watering-trough thus; not all together, as in this case they would press together upon the watering-trough and not satisfy their thirst. (TA.)

rasolN c
rasolN Easy; applied to a pace. (M, K.) ― -b2- Easy in pace; applied to a he-camel: fem. with p: (S, M, K:) or soft, or gentle, in pace; applied to a he-camel and to a she-camel: (Msb:) and mirosaAlN↓, also, applied to a she-camel, has the former of these significations; and its pl. is maraAsiylu: (S, K:) or this pl. signifies light, or active, she-camels, that give thee what they have to give spontaneously; and rasolapN is applied to one thereof: a she-camel is termed mirosaAlN↓ as being likened to the arrow thus called. (TA.) ― -b3- Soft, and lax, or flaccid: [app. applied to a he-camel; for it is added,] one says naAqapN rasolapN AlqawaAYimi, meaning A she-camel loose, or slack, [in the legs, and] soft in the joints [thereof]. (TA. [See also another meaning assigned to this phrase in what follows.]) ― -b4- Applied to hair, i. q. musotarosilN↓; (S, K; in the CK murosal;) which means Lank; not crisp: (Mgh, Msb: [and so accord. to an explanation of Astrsl in the S and K:]) or lank and pendent: (Msb:) or long, and lank or pendent. (AZ, Az, Msb.) ― -b5- And rasolapN, (M,) or rasolapu AlqawAYimi, [of which see an explanation in what precedes,] (L, TA,) and mirosaAlN↓, applied to a she-camel, (M, L, TA,) Having much hair, (M,) or much and long hair, (L, TA,) upon her shanks, or hind legs (fiI saAqiyohaA): (M, L, TA:) but in the K, rasolapN and muraAsilN↓ [not mirosaAlN] are explained as epithets applied to a woman, meaning having much and long hair upon her shanks. (TA.) ― -b6- Also sing. of risaAlN↓, (TA,) which signifies The legs of a camel: (AZ, S, K, TA:) so called because of their length. (AZ, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also muraAsilN. ＝ -A3- And see the paragraph here next following.

risolN c
risolN Gentleness; and a deliberate, or leisurely, manner of acting or behaving; as also risolapN↓; (M, K;) [and perhaps rasolN↓ and rasolapN↓; for] one says AifoEalo kacaA wakacaA EalaI risolika (S, Mgh, * Msb, * CK * [but not in my MS. copy of the K nor in the copies used by SM]) and rasolika and rasolatika, (CK, [but likewise wanting in MS. copies of the K,]) i. e. [Do thou such and such things] at thine ease; (Msb;) or act thou gently, deliberately, or leisurely, (S, Mgh, K, *) in doing such and such things; like as one says, EalaI hiynatika. (S.) Sakhr-el-Ghei says, when despairing of his companions' overtaking him, his enemies surrounding him, and he feeling sure of slaughter, (M,)
lawo OanRa HawoliI mino qurayomK rajolaA
biyDa Alwajuwhi yaHomiluwna AlnRabolaA
lamanaEuwniI najodapF Oawo risolaA
(Skr, M, *) i. e. [If there were around me, of the family of Kureym, men on foot, fair in the faces (app. meant tropically), bearing arrows, they would defend me] by violent means or by gentle means: (Skr:) or with fighting or without fighting. (M.) [See also a phrase cited from a trad. in what follows of this paragraph.] One says also, jaAWuwA risolapF risolapF↓ They came company by company. (M.) ― -b2- And A soft, gentle, saying or speech. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also Milk, (S, M, K,) of whatever sort it be: (M, K:) or, accord. to the Towsheeh, fresh milk. (TA.) One says, kavura AlrRisolu AlEaAma, meaning Milk has become abundant this year: and the people of the desert assert that, when this is the case, dates are few; and that, when dates are abundant, milk is scarce. (TA.) ― -b2- It is said in a trad. [respecting the giving of the poor-rate], UilRaA mano OaEoTaI fiI najodatihaA warisolihaA, (S, TA,) which is explained in two different ways: (TA:) [J says that] it is from risolN in the sense first explained above; meaning straitness and plenty; i. e. Except him who gives when they are fat and goodly, when it is difficult, or hard, to their owner to give them forth, and when they are lean, [or] in a middling condition: (S:) and A'Obeyd says the like; and that it is similar to the saying, qaAla fulaAnN kacaA EamRaA risolihi, meaning Such a one said such a thing holding it (the saying) in light estimation: others say that it is from risolN signifying “ milk; ” which A'Obeyd disallows: IAth says that what is meant by njdp is straitness and drought or barrenness or dearth; and by rsl, plenty, and abundance of herbage or the like; because rsl, i. e. milk, is plentiful only in the case of abundance of herbage; so that the meaning is, except him who gives forth the due of God in the case of straitness and in that of plenty. (TA.) ＝ -A3- The risolaAni of a horse are The extremities of the EaDudaAni [or two arms]. (M, K. *)

rasalN c
rasalN Camels: (M, K:) thus expl. by A'Obeyd, without any epithet: (M:) or a drove, or herd, or a distinct collection or number, of camels, (S, M, * Msb, K,) and of sheep or goats, (S, K,)
accord. to ISk from ten to twenty-five, (TA,) or the rasal of the watering-trough is at least ten, and extending to twenty-five; and the word is masc. and fem.; (M;) and also (assumed tropical:) of horses or horsemen; (S;) applied to (tropical:) a company of men (Mgh, Msb) as being likened to a drove, or herd, of camels: (Msb:) and also a distinct collection or number of any things: (M, K:) pl. OarosaAlN. (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K.) A rájiz says,
yaA caAYidayohaA xawRiSaA biOarosaAlo
walaA tacuwdaAhaA ciyaAda AlDRulRaAlo
[O ye two drivers of them, water some before others, by droves, and drive them not with the driving of those who err from the right way]: (S, TA:) i. e. bring near your camels some after some, and do not let them crowd upon the water-ing-trough. (TA.) And one says, jaMCati AlUibilu rasalFA The camels came [in a drove, or] following one another. (IAmb, TA.) And jaMCati Alxayolu OarosaAlFA, i. e. (assumed tropical:) [The horses, or horsemen, came] in successive distinct companies. (S, TA.) And jaACuwA OarosaAlFA (tropical:) They (men) came in successive companies. (Msb. [And the like is said in the Mgh and in the TA.]) waqiyrN kaviyru AlrRasali qaliylu AlrRisoli, occurring in a trad. relating to a drought, is said by IKt to mean [A collection of sheep or goats] of which many were sent to the pasture, i. e. many in number, but having little milk but the more probable explanation of kvyr Alrsl is that of El-'Odhree, who says that it means much dispersed in search of pasture: for the trad. relates that the camels had died, notwithstanding their ability to endure drought: how then should the sheep or goats be safe, and increase so as to become numerous? (IAth, TA.) ― -b2- Also Animals, or beasts, having milk. (M, TA.)

rusulN c
rusulN A young girl, that has not worn the [muffler, or veil, called] xamaAr. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also a pl. of rasuwlN. (S, M, &c.)

rasolapN c
rasolapN A soft, or delicate condition of life: you say, humo fiI rasolapK mina AlEayoXi They are in a soft, or delicate, condition of life. (M.) ― -b2- And Heaviness, sluggishness, laziness, or indolence: (M, K:) you say rajulN fiyhi rasolapN A man in whom is heaviness, &c. (M.) ― -b3- See also risolN, first sentence.

risolapN c
risolapN: see risolN, in two places.

risaAlN c
risaAlN: see rasolN (of which it is the pl.), near the end of the paragraph: ＝ -A2- and see also muraAsilN.

rasuwlN c
rasuwlN i. q. risaAlapN: (S, M, K:) see the latter, in five places. ― -b2- Hence, as meaning cuw rasuwlK, i. e. cuw risaAlapK [One who has a message; i. e. a messenger]; (TA;) i. q. murosalN↓, (S, M, K,) meaning one sent with a message; (S;) of the measure faEuwlN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN [or rather mufoEalN]: (Msb:) [and often meaning an apostle of God; and with the article Al especially applied to Mohammad:] accord. to IAmb, its meaning in the proper language of the Arabs is one who carries on by consecutive progressions the relation of the tidings of him who has sent him; taken from the phrase jaMCati AlUibilu rasalFA, meaning “ The camels came following one another: ” and the saying of the Muëdhdhin, OaXohadu OanRa muHamRadFA rasuwlu QllReh means I know [or acknowledge] and declare that Mohammad is the relater by consecutive progressions of the tidings from God: (TA:) [or, as commonly understood, I testify that Mohammad is the apostle of God:] a rasuwl is also called mirosaAlN↓, as being likened to the arrow thus termed: (TA:) the pl. of rasuwlN is rusulN (S, M, Msb, K) and rusolN (S, Msb) and rusalaMCN, (M, K,) which last is from IAar, (M,) or Fr, (Sgh,) and OarosulN, (M, K,) which [is a pl. of pauc., and] occurs in the saying of the Hudhalee,
lawokaAna fiI qalobiI kaqadori qulaAmapK
HubFA ligayoriki qado OataAhaA OarosuliI
[Had there been in my heart as much as a nailparing of love for another than thee, my messengers (or, accord. to the TA, app., my messages) had come to her]: respecting which IJ says that he has given to rasuwlN this form of pl., which is [regularly] proper to feminines [of this class of words, consisting of four letter whereof the third is a letter of prolongation], such as OataAnN and EanaAqN and EuqaAbN, because women are meant thereby, as they, generally, are the persons required to serve in cases of this kind: (M:) [for] rasuwlN is applied without variation to a male and a female, and to one [and to two] and to a pl. number; (S, M, Msb, K;) sometimes: (M:) i. e., it is allowable thus to apply it: (Msb:) hence, (S, K,) in the Kur [xxvi. 15], (S,) UinRaA rasuwlu rabRi AlEaAlamiyna [Verily we are the apostles of the Lord of the beings of the whole world]: (S, K:) MF says, in ch. xx. [verse 49], we find UinRaA rasuwlaA rabRika [Verily we are the two apostles of thy Lord]; the dual form being here used: and Z says, in the Ksh, that in this instance it means the messengers, and therefore the dual form is necessarily used; but in ch. xxvi. it means the message, and therefore it is allowable to use it alike, when applying it as an epithet, as sing. and dual and pl.: Aboo-Is-hak the Grammarian says that the meaning here is, UinRaA risaAlapN rabRi AlEaAlamiyna, i. e. cawuw risAlapi [Verily we are those that have the message &c.]: (TA:) [but] rasuwlN [as meaning a messenger] is like EaduwRN and SadyqN [&c.] in its being used alike as masc. and fem. and sing. [and dual] and pl.: (Sgh, TA:) Aboo-Dhu-eyb uses it in the sense of rusul in his saying,
OalikoniI UilayohaA waxayoru AlrRasuw
li OaEolamuhumo binawaAHiI Alxabaro
[Be thou my messenger to her: and the best of messengers is the most knowing of them in respect of the bounds, or limits, of the tidings]. (M.) See 4. The saying in the Kur [xxv. 39], waqawoma nuwHK lamRa kacRabuwA AlrRusula OagoraqonaAhumo [lit. And the people of Noah, when they charged with lying the apostles, we drowned them], Zj says, may mean that they charged with lying Noah alone; for he who charges with lying a prophet charges therewith all the prophets, since they believe in God and in all his apostles; or the general term may be here used as meaning one; like as when you say, Oanota mimRano yunofiqu AldRaraAhima, meaning “ Thou art of those who expend the kind of things termed drAhm. ” (M.) ― -b3- One says also, AlsRihaAmu rusulu AlmanaAyaA (tropical:) [Arrows are the messengers of death, or of the decrees of death]. (TA.) ― -b4- See also the next paragraph.

rasiylN c
rasiylN Easy: occurring in the saying of Jubeyhà El-Asadee,
waqumotu rasiylFA biAlRaciI jaMCa yabotagiI
Uilayohi baliyja Alwajohi lasotu bibaAsiri
[And I undertook, or managed, with ease, that which he came seeking to obtain; bright in countenance to him: I was not frowning]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A stallion-camel (K, * TA) of the Arabian race, that is sent among the Xawol [or she-camels that have passed seven or eight months since the period of their bringing forth] in order that he may leap them: one says, hecaA rasiylu baniI fulaAnK This is the stallion of the camels of the sons of such a one: and Oarosala banuw fulaAnK rasiylahumo [The sons of such a one sent the stallion of their camels]: as though it were of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mufoEalN, from Oarosala. (TA.) ― -b2- And accord. to some, A horse that is started with another in a race. (Har p. 544.) ― -b3- [In the CK and in a MS. copy of the K, voce EamuwdN, it occurs as though meaning The scout, or emissary, or perhaps the advanced guard, of an army: but in other copies of the K, in this instance, accord. to the TA, and in the L, the word is raYiys.] ― -b4- I. q. muraAsilN↓ [as meaning one who interchanges messages or letters with another: see 3]. (S, K.) ― -b5- The person who stands with thee (AlmuwaAqifu laka [in the K (in which this explanation is erroneously assigned to rasuwlN↓) AlmuwaAfiqu laka in a competition in shooting and the like: (M:) [i. e.] rasiylu AlrRajuli signifies he who stands with the man, (yaqifu maEahu, Har p. 544,) or he who acts interchangeably, or alternates, with the man, (yuraAsiluhu, S,) in a competition in shooting, or in some other performance. (S and Har.) And, as also muraAsilN↓, One who relieves, or aids, another, in singing and in work, [by alternating with him, i. e.,] in the former case, by taking up the strain when the other is unable to continue it [so as to accomplish the cadence (see 6)], and in the latter case by taking up the work when the other is unable to continue it; or one who so relieves, or aids, another in singing with a high voice; i. q. mutaAlK: or one who aids another, [or relieves him, by alternating with him,] or who follows him, or imitates him, in his work. (IAar, Msb.) One says, huwa rasiyluhu fiI AlginaMCi wanaHowihi [He is the person who relieves him, or aids him, by alternating with him, in singing and the like thereof]. (TA.) ― -b6- See also risaAlapN, in two places. ＝ -A3- Also Wide, or ample. (K.) ― -b2- A thing little in quantity, or incomplete: AlXRaIoCu AllRaTiyfu in the copies of the K should be
AlXRaIoCu AlTRafiyfu, as in the Moheet (TA.) ― -b3- And Sweet water. (K.)

rasaAlapN c
rasaAlapN: see the next paragraph.

risaAlapN c
risaAlapN (S, M, Msb, K) and rasaAlapN↓ (M, K) and rasuwlN↓ (S, M, Msb, K) and rasiylN↓ (Th, M, K) signify the same, (S, M, Msb, K,) A message; and a letter; (MA in explanation of the first, and KL in explanation of the first and third;) [a communication sent from one person or party to another, oral or written;] substs. from Oarosala Uilayohi: (M, K: *) the pl. of the first is rasaAYilu; (Msb;) and OarosulN is pl. of rasuwlN↓ in the sense of risaAlapN, and of the fem. gender. (TA. [See the former of the two verses cited voce rasuwlN.]) You say, Oarosalotu fulaAnFA fiI risaAlapK: (S:) and Oarosala Uilayohi rasuwlFA↓: (MA:) see 4. A poet says, (S,) namely El-Ash'ar El-Joafee, (TA,)
OalaA Oabolgo OabaA EamorKw rasuwlFA↓
biOanRiI Eano futaAHatikumo ganiIRu
[Now deliver thou to Aboo-' Amr a message, saying that I am in no need of your judging]: (S:) or baniI EamorKw [the sons of ' Amr]: he means, Eano Hukomkumo. (TA.) And hence the saying of Kutheiyir,
laqado kacaba AlwaAXuwna maA buHotu Einodahumo
bisirRK walaA Oarosalotuhumo birasuwli↓
[Assuredly the slanderers have lied: I revealed not in their presence a secret, nor did I send them with a message]: (S, TA:) or, as some relate the second hemistich, (TA,)
bilayolaI walaA Oarosalotuhumo birasiyli↓
[i. e. I revealed not the case of Leyla, nor did I send them with a message]: thus cited by Th. (M, TA.) ― -b2- risaAlapN also signifies [A tract, or small treatise or discourse;] a majalRap [i. e. book, or writing, relating to science, or on any subject.] comprising a few questions, inquiries, or problems, of one kind: pl. rasaAYilu. (TA.) ― -b3- And Apostleship; the apostolic office or function. (MA.) ― -b4- OumRu risaAlapa [in a copy of the K OumRu risaAlapK] The raxamap [or female of the vultur percnopterus, in the CK raHomap]: (M, K, TA:) a surname thereof. (TA.)

AlrRusayolaI c
AlrRusayolaI A certain small beast or reptile or insect; expl. by the word duwayobRapN: (M, K, TA:) in [some of] the copies of the K, erroneously, AlrRusayolaMCu. (TA.)

rusayolaAtN c
rusayolaAtN dim. of rslAt [i. e. risalaAtN] pl. of risolN [or rather of its syn. risolapN]: hence the saying, (TA,) OaloqaI AlkalaAma EalaI rusayolaAtihi, i. e. He held the saying, or speech, in light, or little, or mean, estimation; or in contempt. (M, K, TA.)

AlrRaAsilaAni c
AlrRaAsilaAni The two shoulder-blades: or two veins therein: (M, K:) he who says that they are two veins in the two hands, (K,) pointing to what is found in the copies of the Mj of IF, [in which fiI AlkafRayoni is put in the place of fI Alkatifiyoni,] (TA,) is in error: (K:) or the waAbilataAni [q. v., a word variously explained]: (M, TA:) in the copies of the K, AlrRaAbilataAni is erroneously put for AlwaAbilataAni. (TA.)

murosalN c
murosalN: see rasuwlN, second sentence. ― -b2- Applied to a tradition (HadiyvN), it means (assumed tropical:) Of which the ascription is not traced up so as to reach to its author: (Msb:) [i.e.] AlOaHaAdiyvu Almurosalapu means the traditions which one relates as on the authority of a taAbiEiIR, (K TA,) by tracing up the ascription thereof uninterruptedly to him, (TA,) when the tAbEIR says, “ The Apostle of God (May God bless and save him) said, ” without mentioning a SaHaAbiIR (K, TA) who heard it from the Apostle of God: (TA: [and the like is said in the Mgh:]) maraAsiylu is the [pl. or] quasi-pl. n. of murosalN thus used, [or rather used as a subst., or as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant,] like as manaAkiyru is of munokarN. (Mgh.) ― -b3- In lexicology, it means, like munoqaTiEN, (assumed tropical:) That of which the series of transmitters is interrupted: as a word &c. handed down by IDrd as on the authority of AZ [with whom he was not contemporary, without his mentioning the intermediate transmitters]: and such is not admitted [as unquestionable]; because exactness is a condition of the admission of what is transmitted, and the exactness of him who is not mentioned is not known. (Mz 4th nwE.) ― -b4- majaAzN murosalN: see art. jwz. ― -b5- [See also the next paragraph.]

murosalapN c
murosalapN A qilaAdap [or necklace], (M,) or a long qlAdp, (IDrd, O, K,) that falls upon the bosom: (IDrd, M, O, K:) or a qlAdp upon which are beads &c. (Yz, O, K.) ― -b2- As used in the Kur [lxxvii. 1], (M,) AlmurosalaAtu means The winds (S, M, K, TA) that are sent forth, [by EurofFA, which follows it, being meant consecutively,] like [the several portions of] the mane of the horse: (TA:) or the angels [so sent forth]: (Th, S, M, K, TA:) or the horses (M, K, TA) that are started, [one following another,] in the racecourse. (TA.)

mirosaAlN c
mirosaAlN One who sends the morsel [that he eats] into his fauces: or who throws forth the branch from his hand, (O, K,) when he goes in a place of trees, (O,) in order that he may hurt his companion. (O, K.) ― -b2- A short arrow: (S, O:) or a small arrow. (K.) ― -b3- See also rasolN, in three places. ― -b4- And see rasuwlN.

muraAsilN c
muraAsilN: see rasolN. ＝ -A2- See also rasiylN, in two places. ― -b2- Also A woman who interchanges messages, or letters, with the men who demand women in marriage: or whose husband has become separated from her (M, K, TA) in any manner, (M, TA,) by his having died or his having divorced her: (TA:) or who has become advanced in age, (M, K, TA,) but has in her some remains of youth: (M, TA:) or whose husband has died, or who has perceived that he desires to divorce her, and who therefore adorns herself for another man, and interchanges messages, or letters, with him (S, K, * TA) by means of the men who demand women in marriage, (TA,) and who has in her some remains (K, TA) of youth; but this addition is more properly mentioned in a former explanation. (TA.) The subst. [app. meaning The state, or condition, of a woman such as is thus termed] is risaAlN↓. (M, TA.)

musotarosilN c
musotarosilN: see rasolN. ＝ -A2- musotarosilN lilomawoti i. q. musotamytN and musotaqoitlN [i. e. Seeking, or courting, death or slaughter; resigning, or subjecting, himself to death, and not caring for death]. (A and TA in art. mwt.)

1 rasama AldRaAra c
1. rasama AldRaAra, (M,) or AldRiyaAra, (K,) [aor.
rasuma
, accord. to a rule of the K,] inf. n. rasomN, (M,) It (the rain) rased the house or dwelling, or the houses or dwellings, leaving a relic, or relics, thereof cleaving to the ground. (M, K.) In the saying of El-Hotei-ah,
Oamino rasomi daArK murobiEN wamuSiyfu
liEayonayoka mino maMCi AlXRuWuwni wakiyfu
[Is it in consequence of autumn-rain's and springrain's rasing of a dwelling so as to leave only a relic thereof cleaving to the ground, that there is to thine eyes a distilling of the water of the tearchannels?], mrbE and mSyf are in the nom. case because of the inf. n., i.e. rsm. (M, TA. [But in the latter, maSiyfu: and in a copy of the former, marobaEN and maSiyfu, both of which are evidently wrong.]) ― -b2- [rasama often signifies He marked, or stamped: and he drew, traced, traced out, sketched, sketched out, or planned: and he delineated, or described.] You say, rasama AlTRaEaAma He stamped, or sealed, the corn; (TA in art. rXm;) as also raXamahu. (S, K, TA, all in that art. [See rawosamN.]) And rasamotu AlbinaMCa, aor. and inf. n. as above, I marked out the building. (Msb.) And rasama kitaAbFA walamo yaHoXuhu [He sketched out a book and did not fill it up]. (Mz 1st nwE.) And rasamotu AlkitaAba I wrote the book, or letter, or writing. (Msb.) And rasama EalaI kacaA He wrote upon such a thing; (S, K;) and raXama is a dial. var. thereof. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] rasama lahu kacaA, (S, K, TA,) or bikacaA, (Msb,) (tropical:) [He prescribed to him the doing of such a thing;] he commanded, ordered, bade, or enjoined, him to do such a thing. (S, * Msb, * K, TA.) [And rasama lahu kacaA also means (assumed tropical:) he assigned, or appointed, him such a thing, as a stipend, &c.: often used in this sense.] ― -b4- rasamato said of a she-camel, (S, M, K,) aor.
rasuma
(S, M, [and so accord. to a rule of the K,]) or
rasima
, not
rasuma
, (TA,) inf. n. rasiymN, (S, M, K,) She made marks upon the ground (S, M, K) by the vehemence of her tread. (S, M.) ― -b5- And rasama said of a camel, aor.
rasima
, inf. n. rasiymN, (S, K,) with which mirosamN is syn., (K,) He went a certain pace, (S, K,) exceeding that which is termed camiyl [inf. n. of camala, q. v.]: one should not say of a camel Oarosama, for this latter verb is trans. (S.) ― -b6-
Also rasama naHowahu, inf. n. rasomN, He went, or went away, quickly towards him, or it. (TA.) ― -b7- And rasama fiI AlOaroDi, (K,) inf. n. rasomN, (TA,) He disappeared in the land, or country: (K:) and [hence], used metonymically, (tropical:) he died; like razama. (TA.)

2 tarosiymN c
2. tarosiymN [inf. n. of rasRama] The act of marking, or stamping, [and of drawing, tracing, tracing out, sketching, sketching out, or planning, several things, or of doing so much, or] well:: and writing [much, or] well: and making a garment, or piece of cloth, striped. (KL.)

4 Arsm c
4. Arsm He caused a she-camel to make marks upon the ground (M, K) by the vehemence of her tread. (M.) ― -b2- And He made a camel to go the pace termed rasiym (S. [The meaning is there indicated, but not expressed.]) faOarosamaA ending a verse of Homeyd Ibn-Thowr [which is variously related] refers to two boys, or young men, mentioned therein, and means faOarosamaA baEiyrayohimaA [And they made their two camels to go the pace termed rasiym]. (AHát, TA.)

5 trsRm c
5. trsRm, (K, but omitted in some copies,) or trsRm AlrRasoma, (M,) He looked at the rasomi [or mark, trace, relic, &c.]. (M, K.) And trsRm AldRaAra He considered, or examined, the rusuwm [or marks, traces, relics, &c.,] of the house, or dwelling; (S, TA; *) or did so repeatedly, in order to obtain a clear knowledge thereof. (TA.) ― -b2- And in like manner trsRm signifies He looked, and considered, or examined, or did so repeatedly, in order to know where he should dig, or build. (S, TA.) Hence, tarasRamati AlqanaAficu fiI AlOaroDi (tropical:) The hedge-hogs looked, or considered, or examined, repeatedly, to know where they should make their holes. (TA.) And trsRm AlXRaIoCa (assumed tropical:) He looked, or looked long, at the thing; or considered, or examined, it, or did so repeatedly, in order to obtain a clear knowledge of it. (TA.) And trsRm AlqaSiydapa (tropical:) He considered, or studied, the ode, and retained it in his memory, or sought, or endeavoured, to remember it. (K, * TA.) And OanaA OatarasRamu kacaA (assumed tropical:) I remember, or I seek, or endeavour, to remember, such a thing, but am not sure, or certain, of it. (TA.)

8 AirotisaAmN c
8. AirotisaAmN [in its primary sense, as quasi-pass. of rasomN, inf. n. of rasama, is app. post-classical, but, as such,] is used by the logicians as meaning The being stamped and depicted [in the mind]: (“ Dict. of the Technical Terms used in the sciences of the Musalmans: ”] an image's being fixed in, or upon, a thing. (KL.) [It is used, in this sense, of an image formed by the fancy, and of any ideal image.] ＝ -A2- [Also (tropical:) The obeying a prescript or command &c.] You say, rasamotu lahu kacaA, (S, K,) or bikacaA, (Msb,) faQrotasama, (Msb, K,) or faQrotasamahu, (S,) (tropical:) [I prescribed to him the doing of such a thing; or] I commanded, ordered, bade, or enjoined, him to do such a thing, (K, TA,) and he obeyed (S, Msb, TA) it [i. e. the prescript &c.]. (S, Msb.) And OanaA Oarotasimu maraAsimaka↓ (tropical:) [I obey thy prescripts &c.;] I do not transgress thy mrAsm. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (TA,) Artsm signifies also (tropical:) He said AallRehu Oakobaro [God is great, or most great]: (S, M, K, TA:) and he sought protection or preservation [by God]: (M, K, TA;) and he prayed or supplicated or petitioned [God]: (S, K:) as though [meaning] he took the course prescribed by God, of having recourse to Him for protection or preservation. (TA.) El-Aashà says, [speaking of wine,]
waSalRaI EDlaI danRihaA waQrotasamo
waqaAbalahaA AlriyHa fiI danRihaA
(S, M, TA,) or waOaqobalahaA, (so in some copies of the S in this art. and in art. Slw, and in the Mgh, also, in the latter art.,) i. e. [And he exposed it to the wind, in its jar, and he prayed over its jar,] and petitioned for it (TA in this art. and in art. Slw) that it might not become sour, nor spoil: (TA in the latter art.:) AHn says that Artsm means he stamped its vessel with the rawosam; but this saying is not valid: (M, TA:) [and Mtr, also, says that] Artsm, here, is from AlrRawosamu, and means he stamped it. (Mgh in art. Slw.)

rasomN c
rasomN inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (Msb, &c.) ― -b2- [Hence rasomu AlmuSoHafi The writing of the book of the Kur-án; for which particular rules are prescribed. ― -b3- Hence also rasomN is sometimes used by logicians as meaning A definition, either perfect (taAmRN) or imperfect (naAqiSN); like HadRN.] ― -b4- Also A mark, an impression, a sign, a trace, a vestige, or a relic or remain; syn. OavarN; (S, Msb, K;) and raXamN is a dial. var. thereof, accord. to Aboo-Turáb; as is also rasamN↓, both syn. with OavarN, (TA in art. rXm,) and so is raXomN. (K in that art.:) or a relic, or remain, of what is termed OavarN [as meaning a mark, an impression, a sign, a trace, or a vestige]: or such, of what are termed MvaAr [as meaning relics or remains], as has not substance and height: (M, K:) or such as is cleaving to the ground: (M:) rasomu daArK means remains of a house or dwelling, cleaving to the ground: (S, TA:) or rasomN signifies a remain, or remains, of a ruined dwelling or place of alighting and abiding: (Har p. 607:) and rawosamN↓ is syn. with rasomN: (S, M, K [accord. to the correct copies of this last:]) the pl. [of pauc.] of rasomN is OarosumN and [the pl. of mult. is] rusuwmN. (M, Msb, K.) ― -b5- [I. q. marosuwmN: see maraAsimu. And hence, as being prescribed,] rusuwmu AldRiyni means (assumed tropical:) The ways that are followed in respect of the doctrines and practices of religion. (TA.) ― -b6- And A well which one fills up (M, K) in the ground: (K:) pl. risaAmN. (M, K.) ― -b7- [In some copies of the K, two meanings that belong to rawosamN are, by the omission of a w, assigned to rasomN: see rawosamN.]

rasamN c
rasamN: see the next preceding paragraph. ＝ -A2- Also Goodness, or elegance, of gait, pace, or manner of going. (K.)

rasuwmN c
rasuwmN That makes marks upon the ground by the vehemence of her tread: applied to a she-camel. (S TA.) [See an ex. in a verse cited in the first paragraph of art. jhm.] ― -b2- Also That continues journeying a day and a night: (S, K:) applied to a he-camel. (TK.)

rasiymN c
rasiymN A certain pace of camels, (S, K,) exceeding that which is termed camiylN [q. v.]; (S;) [see rasama, of which it is an inf. n.;] and mirosamN↓ signifies the same. (K.)

rasRaAmN c
rasRaAmN One who engraves [or draws inscriptions or other designs] upon tablets or the like. (TA.)

raAsimN c
raAsimN, (S, K,) or maMCN raAsimN, (TK,) Running water. (S, K.) ― -b2- And raAsimapN A she-camel that goes the pace termed rasiym: pl. rawaAsimu. (Har p. 495.)

rawosamN c
rawosamN: see rasomN. ― -b2- Also A sign, a token, a mark, or an indication, (M, K,) of beauty or of ugliness; as in the saying, UinRa Ealyohi larawosamFA [Verily upon him is a sign, &c.]: so says Khálid Ibn-Jebeleh: (M:) pl. rawaAsimu and rawaAsiymu. (TA.) ― -b3- And as pl. of rawosamu, (TA,) rawaAisymu signifies Certain books, or writings, that were in the Time of Ignorance. (S, K.) ― -b4- Also the sing., A stamp, or seal; i. e. an instrument with which one stamps, or seals; and rawoXamN is a dial. var. thereof: (M:) or, as some say, particularly, (M,) one with which the head [or mouth] of a [large jar such as is called] xaAbiyap is stamped, or sealed; (M, K;) as also raAsuwmN↓, (K,) and raAXuwmN. (TA.) And A piece of wood, (S, M, Msb, K,) or a small tablet, (A,) upon which is some inscription (S, M, A, K) engraved, or hollowed out, (A, K,) with which wheat, (S, M, K,) or corn, or grain, (Msb,) [in its repository,] is stamped, or sealed, (S, M, Msb, K,) or with which collections of wheat or corn are stamped, or sealed: (AA, TA:) as also rawoXamN: pl. rawaAsimu. (Msb.) [In some copies of the K, by the omission of a w, this meaning and the next are assigned to rasomN.] ― -b5- And (as some say, S) A certain thing with which deenárs are polished. (S, K.) A poet says, (S,) namely, Kutheiyir, (TA,)
danaAniyru Xiyfato mino hiraqolK birawosami
[Deenárs, of Heraclius, that were polished with rwsm]. (S, TA.) ＝ -A2- It occurs in poetry as meaning The face of a horse, in the phrase quroHapN birawosamK [A star, or blaze, in the face of a horse]. (M.) ＝ -A3- Also A calamity, or misfortune; (K;) like rawosabN. (TA.)

raAsuwmN c
raAsuwmN: see the next preceding paragraph. [Accord. to rule, its pl. is rawaAsiymu, mentioned above as a pl. of rawosamN.]

murosimN c
murosimN [act. part. n. of 4, q. v.]. In the saying of the Hudhalee,
waQlomurosimuwna UilaI Eabodi AlEaziyzi bihaA
maEFA waXatRaI wamino XafoEK wafurRaAdi
[And those urging them to make marks upon the ground by the vehemence of their tread in their way to 'Abd-El-'Azeez, together and separately, and two by two and one by one], he means AlmurosimuwhaA, inserting the b redundantly between the verb [or part. n., which is often termed a verb,] and its objective complement. (M.)

mirosamN c
mirosamN: see rasiymN.

murasRamN c
murasRamN A garment, or piece of cloth, striped, (S, M, K,) or marked with faint lines. (TA.)

marosuwmN c
marosuwmN [or kitaAbN marosuwmN] A book, or writing, stamped, or sealed: pl. maraAsiymu. (TA.) And TaEaAmN marosuwmN Wheat stamped, or sealed. (TA. [See rawosamN.]) ― -b2- See also the following paragraph.

maraAsimu c
maraAsimu Marks, stamps, impressions, signs, or characters. (KL.) ― -b2- [And (assumed tropical:) Prescripts, commands, orders, biddings, or injunctions: and (assumed tropical:) assignments, or appointments: in both of these senses app. a contraction of maraAsiymu, pl. of marosuwmN↓; thus used in the present day; like rusuwmN, pl. of rasomN↓.] See 8.

1 rasana Alfarasa c
1. rasana Alfarasa (S,) or AldRaAbRapa, (M, Msb, *) and AlnRaAqaha, (M, K, *) aor.
rasuna
and
rasina
, (M, Msb, K,) inf. n. rasonN; (M, Msb;) and Arsn↓; (S, M, Msb, K;) He tied the horse [or the beast and the she-camel] with the rasan [q: v.]: (S:) or he bound upon the [horse or] beast [or she-camel] its rasan: (Msb:) or he made for, or put to, the [horse or] beast or she-camel a rasan: (M, * K: [in the former it is merely indicated that the two verbs signify the same:]) or the former verb [in the CK the latter verb] has the first signification; (M, K, TA;) and the latter verb has the last signification; (M, TA;) thus resembling Hazama and OaHozama. (TA.) ― -b2- And rasana AldRaAbRapa, and ArsnhA↓, He left the beast to itself, to pasture as it pleased. (TA.)

4 Oarosana
4: see above, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also Arsn Almuhoru The colt was, or became, submissive, manageable, or tractable, and gave its head. (TA.)

rasanN c
rasanN A rope, or cord: (S, M, Msb, K:) or [a halter; i. e.] a rope, or cord, with which a camel [or a horse (see 1)] is led: (TA:) and such of the [reins, or leading-ropes, termed] OazimRap [pl. of zimaAmN] as is upon the nose; (M;) [in other words,] such a zimaAm as is upon a nose: (K:) pl. OirosaAnN (S, M, Msb, K) and OarosunN, (M, Msb, K,) [both properly pls. of pauc.,] and sometimes they said rusunN; (Msb;) or, accord. to Sb, it has no other pl. than OarosaAnN; (M, Msb;) [but perhaps he meant of pauc., for SM says,] Sb disallowed OarosunN. (TA.) A poet says, (S,) namely, Ibn-Mukbil, (TA,)
hariytN qaSiyru EicaAri AlilRjaAmi
OasiylN Tawiylu EicaAri AlrRasRno
[Wide-mouthed, short in the cheek-straps of the bridle (or headstall): smooth and long in the cheek, long in the appertenance of the halter corresponding to the cheek-straps of the bridle or headstall; because this appertenance is longer than are the cheek-straps of the bridle or headstall]. (S, TA.) mRrRa AlSRaEaAliyki biOarosaAni Alxayoli [As the passing along of the robbers with the halters of the horses] is a prov., applied to an affair, or event, that is quick and uninterrupted. (TA.) And one says, ramaI birasanihi EalaI gaAribihi [He threw his leading-rope upon his withers], meaning (assumed tropical:) he left his way free, or open, to him; so that God did not withhold him from that which he desired to do. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] rasanu AlbaAziI [The leash of the hawk]. (A in art. rwd.) ＝ -A2- [The pl.] OarosaAnN also signifies Rugged and hard tracts of ground. (K, * TA.)

raAsanN c
raAsanN A certain plant, resembling the plant called zanojabiyl [i. e. ginger]; (M;) i. q. qanasN; [both of which names are applied to the inula helenium, common inula, or elecampane; also called in the present day zanojabiylN XaAmiIRN;] a Pers. word [arabicized]. (K.)

marosinN c
marosinN (S, M, K) and marosanN, (M, K,) or the latter should be mirosanN, [but I think this doubtful,] thus written in some of the copies of the S, and in both ways in the L, (TA,) The part, of the nose of the horse, which is the place of the rasan: (S:) or the nose of a solid-hoofed animal: this is the primary signification: (M:) then, by a secondary application, (S, M,) the nose (S, M, K) in an absolute sense, (M, K,) or, of a human being: (S:) pl. maraAsinu (TA) [which, as stated by Freytag, is used in a sing. sense, in the Deewán of Jereer, as meaning the nose]. salisu Almarosini, a phrase used by the poet El-Jaadee, means (assumed tropical:) Easy to be led, tractable, or compliant. (TA.) And you say, faEalotu celika EalaI ragomi marosinihi (assumed tropical:) [I did that against his wish; in spite of him; or notwithstanding his dislike, or disapproval, or hatred; like as you say, EalaI ragomi Oanofihi]. (S.)

marosuwnN c
marosuwnN A horse [or the like] tied with the rsn: (S:) [or having a rasan bound upon him or attached to him, or made for him: see 1.] You say, Oajorarotu Almarosuwna rasanahu I made the haltered beast to drag his halter. (TA.)

Almarosiynu c
Almarosiynu [The myrtle-tree;] i. q. rayoHaAnu Alqubuwri: of the dial. of Egypt. (TA.) [Also mentioned in art. mrs: for some hold the m to be augmentative; and some, the n.]

1 rasaA c
1. rasaA, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor. yarosuw, (S, Msb,) inf. n. rusuwRN (M, Msb, K) and rasowN, (K,) It (a thing, S, M, Msb) was, or became, stationary, at rest, fixed, fast, firm, steady, steadfast, or stable; (S, M, Msb, K) as also ArsI↓, (M, K,) inf. n. UirosaMCN; and trsRI↓. (TA.) Alrsw and Alrswx [i. e. AlrRusuwRu and AlrRusuwxu] are nearly the same [in meaning]. (Ham p. 51.) You say, rasaA Aljabalu (assumed tropical:) The mountain was firmly based, or firm in its base, upon the ground. (TA.) And vabiyrN maA OarosaI↓ (tropical:) As long as Thebeer [the mountain so called] remains [firm] in its place. (TA.) [Its being said that this is tropical is app. meant to indicate that the verbs above are properly used only in relation to a ship, in senses explained in what follows; which, however, I doubt.] You say also, rasato qadamuhu, meaning His foot stood firm in war: (M:) or rasato OaqodaAmuhumo fiI AlHarobi Their feet stood firm in war. (S, Msb. *) And rasati AlsRafiynapu, (S, M, K,) aor. tarosuw, inf. n. rusuwRN and rasowN (S) [and marosFI, as shown below, see 4], The ship [anchored; cast anchor; lay at anchor; or] rested, or became stationary, upon the anchor: (T, S, K:) in [some of] the copies of the K [and of the S], EalaI AlbaHori is erroneously put for ElI AlOanojari [or ElI AllRanojari]: (TA:) or the meaning is, [in some instances, the ship grounded; i. e.] the lower, or lowest, part of the ship reached the bottom of the water, and she consequently remained stationary. (T, M, TA.) ― -b2- rasaA AlfaHolu biXawolihi (S, M, K,) (tropical:) The stallion [-camel] leaped, or leaped upon, his Xwl [or she-camels that had passed seven or eight months since the period of their bringing forth]: (S, TA:) or brayed to his Xwl, and they became motionless, or still: (M:) or brayed to his Xwl when they had dispersed themselves from him, and they turned aside to him, and became motionless, or still. (K, TA.) ― -b3- rasawotu bayona Alqawomi, (S, M, * Msb,) inf. n. rasowN, (S, M,) I effected an agreement, a harmony, a reconciliation, an accommodation, or an adjustment, between the people, or party. (S, M, * Msb.) ＝ -A2- rasaA lahu rasowFA mino HadiyvK (S, * M, K *) He mentioned to him a part, or portion, of a tradition, or story. (S, M, * K. [See also rasowN below.]) And rasaA Eanohu HadiyvFA, (S, M, K,) inf. n. rasowN, (M,) He related a tradition, or story, as received from him, (S, M, K,) ascribing it to him. (M, K.) And rasaA AlHadiyva fiI nafosihi He related the tradition, or story, to himself. (TA.) ― -b2- rasaA AlSRawoma, (K,) inf. n. rasowN, (TA,) He intended, or purposed, fasting. (K.)

3 rAsAhu c
3. rAsAhu, (T, K,) inf. n. muraAsaApN, (TA,) i. q. saAbaHahu, (T, K,) i. e. He swam with him. (TK.)

4 ArsI c
4. ArsI, inf. n. UirosaMCN: see 1, in two places. ＝ -A2- ArsAhu He made it (a thing, M, Msb) to become stationary, at rest, fixed, fast, firm, steady, steadfast, or stable. (M, Msb, K.) And ArsI AlsRafiynapa, [inf. n. as above and also (as is shown by what follows) murosFI, He anchored the ship;] he made the ship to rest, or become stationary, upon the anchor: (TA:) or the meaning is, [in some instances, he grounded the ship; i. e.] he made the lower, or lowest, part of the ship to reach the bottom of the water, so that she remained stationary. (M, TA.) You say also of a ship, turosaI baAlOanojari [She is made fast by means of the anchor]: (M:) and of the anchor, yurosiI AlsRafiynapa It makes fast the ship, so that it does not go on. (T, TA.) For the words of the Kur [xi. 43], bisomi QllRehi mujoraAhaA wamurosaAhaA, (S, M, * K, *) meaning UijoraAWuhaA waUirosaAWuhaA [i. e. In the name of God be the making it to run and the making it to rest], (Aboo-Is-hák, TA,) from Oajorayotu and Oarosayotu, (so in one copy of the S,) or [its being made to run and its being made to rest,] from Oujoriyato and Ourosiyoto, (so in another copy of the S,) some say majoraAhaA wamarosaAhaA, (S, K,) meaning its running and its resting, (Aboo-Is-hák, TA,) from jarato and rasato, (S, K,) [though] Az says that the readers agree in pronouncing the m of mrsAhA with damm, but differ as to the m of mjrAhA, the Koofees pro-
nouncing this with fet-h, (TA,) or the latter reading may have the same meaning as the former, (Aboo-Is-hák, TA,) or the former reading may mean in the time, or the place, of making it to run, and that of making it to rest, and the latter reading may mean in the time, or the place, of its running, and that of its resting, for in each case each noun may be a n. of time or a n. of place or an inf. n.; (Bd, q. v.;) and some read mujoriyhaA wamurosiyhaA↓, as epithets applied to God, (M, K,) who maketh it to run and who maketh it to rest. (TA.) Accord. to Zj, (M,) yasoOaluwnaka Eani QlsRaAEapi OayRaAna murosaAhaA, in the Kur [vii. 186 and lxxix. 42], means [They will ask thee respecting the sAEp,] when will be its taking place? [or when will be the time of its being made to take place?]; (M, K; *) by the sAEp being meant the time in which all created beings shall die. (M.)

5 tarasRawa
5: see 1, first sentence.

rasowN c
rasowN A part, or portion, of a tradition, or story: (Lth, T, K:) [see an ex. near the end of the first paragraph:] accord. to IAar, i. q. rasRN [app. as meaning the first part or portion]. (T.)

rasowapN c
rasowapN A [bracelet, or one of a particular kind, called] dasotibnaj; (IAar, T, M, K;) so accord. to Kr: (M, TA: but in a copy of the M written dasotabanoj:) a certain thing of strung beads; (S, TA;) like the dstynj; which is an arabicized word [from the Pers. dasotiynaho]: (TA:) a bracelet of beads: (ISK, TA:) or a bracelet of cabol [i. e. turtle-shell, or tortoise-shell]: pl. rasawaAtN: it has no broken pl. (M, TA. [Golius and Freytag say that its pl. is risFI; but on what authority, I know not: the former mentions no authority beside the S and K; and the latter, none but the K.])

rasiIRN c
rasiIRN Firm, or steadfast, in good and in evil. (Az, Sgh, K.) ― -b2- And The pole that is fixed in the middle of the [tent called] xibaMC. (Az, Sgh, K.)

raAsK c
raAsK Stationary, at rest, fixed, fast, firm, steady, steadfast, or stable. (Msb.) You say jibaAlN raAsiyapN (Msb) and raAsiyAatN and rawaAsK (S, Msb) Firm, or steadfast, mountains; (S, Msb;) the sing. of the last said by Akh to be raAsiyapN. (S.) And qidorN raAsiyapN (tropical:) A cooking-pot that will not move from its place, (M, K, TA,) by reason of its greatness, (K, TA,) and that cannot be removed. (M.) quduwr raAsiyaAt in the Kur [xxxiv. 12] means, accord. to Fr, (tropical:) Cooking-pots that would not be lowered from their place, by reason of their greatness. (TA.)

marosFI c
marosFI may be used as an inf. n., or a n. of time, or a n. of place. (Bd in xi. 43 [cited above: see 4].) [As a n. of place, it commonly means An anchorage, or a place of anchoring; a port; or a station for ships: pl. maraAsK.]

murosFI c
murosFI may be used as an inf. n., or a n. of time, or a n. of place. (Bd in xi. 43 [cited above: see 4].)

murosK c
murosK, as an epithet applied to God: see 4, near the end of the paragraph.

mirosaApN c
mirosaApN, The anchor of a ship: (S, M, K:) or a large anchor, which, being tied with ropes and let down into the water, holds fast the ship, so that she does not go on: (T, TA:) pl. maraAsK. (Har p. 111.) [Hence,] one says, OaloqawoA maraAsiyahumo, meaning (assumed tropical:) They remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode. (TA.) And Oaloqati AlsRaHaAbapu maraAsiyahaA (tropical:) The cloud rained continually; syn. daAmat: (S, Msb:) or remained steady, raining: (T, TA:) or remained still, or stationary, and rained. (M, K: * in the latter, AlsRaHaAbu is put in the place of AlsHAbp.)

1 raXRa c
1. raXRa, (A, Msb,) aor.
raXuXa
, (MS,) inf. n. raXRN (S, A, Msb, K) and taroXaAXN, (A, K,) He sprinkled, or scattered in drops, (A, K, TK,) water, (S, A, Msb, K,) and blood, (S, A, K,) and tears, (S, K,) &c. (A.) ― -b2- raXRa AlmakaAna, (S, TA,) or AlmawoDiEa, (Msb,) and Albayota, (A,) inf. n. raXRN, (S, TA,) He sprinkled, or wetted by sprinkling, (TA,) the place, (S, Msb, TA,) and the house, or chamber, or tent, (A,) bimaACK with water. (Msb, TA.) And raXRa AlHaAYiku AlnRasiyja biAlomiraXRapi [The weaver sprinkled the web with the mrXRp]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] raXRati AlsRamaMCu, and OaraXRat↓, (S, A, Msb, K,) The shy rained: (A, Msb:) or let fall a little rain, such as is termed raXRN. (S. [After the former of these verbs, AlOaroDa, or the like, seems to be understood.]) [And hence,] AlTRaEonapu OaraXRati↓ [The spear-wound, or the like, sprinkled forth blood: a signification implied, but not expressed, in the S and A: or] became wide, so that its blood became scattered about: (K:) or passed through, and made the blood to flow, or to appear and flow, or to flow copiously, or with force. (Msb.) ― -b4- [Hence also,] raXRahu bivaMC K HasanK (assumed tropical:) He eulogized him. (TA voce xamRa.) ― -b5- And raXRahu He washed him, or it. (MF, from the Expositions of the “ Muwatta. ”)

2 raXRaRa
2: [rXRX Alqalamu AlHibora The pen spirtled the ink.]

4 OaroXaXa
4: see 1, in two places. ＝ -A2- ArXR Alfarasa, (A, K,) inf. n. UiroXaAXN, (A,) He made the horse to sweat by urging him with his feet. (A, K.)

5 trXRX Ealayohi AlmaMCu c
5. trXRX Ealayohi AlmaMCu, (S,) and Elyh taraXoraXa↓, (A,) [The water became sprinkled, or scattered in drops, upon him or it.] And trXRXt nuqoTapN mina Alqalami [A drop of ink became spirtled from the pen]. (S and K in art. mj)

R. Q. 2 taraXoraXa c
R. Q. 2. taraXoraXa: see 5. ― -b2- Also It (roasted meat) dripped with gravy; or was succulent, and dripping with juice; or was fat. (TA.) ― -b3- And It flowed. (TA.)

raXRN c
raXRN, (S, K,) or raXRN mino maTarK, (A, TA,) A little [sprinkling] rain: (S, K:) [and so raXRapN↓ in the present day:] or the first [or lightest and weakest] of rain: (IAar: [see rakRN:] pl. riXaAXN. (S, K.) ― -b2- Also the former, (assumed tropical:) A painful beating. (Sgh, K.)

raXRapN c
raXRapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

raXaAXN c
raXaAXN What is sprinkled, (S, A, * K,) or scattered, (Msb,) of water, (A, Msb,) and the like, (Msb,) or of blood, (S, A, K,) and of tears, (S, K,) and the like, (K,) and of rain; (TA in art. TX;) what is scattered, or flies about, of blood. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence the saying,] lamo yadoxulo fiI AlXRarRi waOaSaAbahu mino raXaAXihi (tropical:) [He did not enter into evil, or mischief, and yet somewhat thereof, or of its effects, befell him]. (A, TA.) And OalaHRa binaA AlEuTaAXu wamaA naAlanaA minoka UilRaA AlrRaXaAXu [app. meaning Insatiable thirst, or desire, to hear from thee, or the like, remained in us, and there did not reach us from thee aught save a mere sprinkling; or perhaps, what was scattered abroad, of rumours, or the like]. (A, TA. *) [See also an ex. voce racaAcN.]

raXiyXN c
raXiyXN: see maroXuwXN.

raXoraAXN c
raXoraAXN Roasted meat (Aboo-Sa'eed, A, K) dripping with its gravy; (Aboo-Sa'eed, A, TA;) or succulent, and dripping with its juice; (TA;) or fat: (K:) and muriXRN↓ signifies the same. (TA.)

muriXRN c
muriXRN: see what next precedes.

miraXRapN c
miraXRapN A thing with which one sprinkles: (Ibn- 'Abbád:) a thing with which the weaver sprinkles the web: (A, TA:) [in the present day, applied to a long-necked bottle, with a stopper pierced with a hole or holes, for sprinkling scented water.]

maroXuwXN c
maroXuwXN [Sprinkled, or scattered in drops; as also raXiyXN↓, occurring in this sense in a verse in the TA in art. xft]. ― -b2- maHalRN maroXuwXN [A place of alighting sprinkled, or wetted by sprinkling]. (A.) ― -b3- OaroDN maroXuwXapN Land upon which [rain such as is called] AlrRaXR has fallen. (TA.)

1 raXaOa c
1. raXaOa i. q. jaAmaEa [Inivit feminam]. (K.) ＝ -A2- raXaOato She (a gazelle) brought forth. (K.)

raXaON c
raXaON A young gazelle, (S, Msb, K,) that has become active, or in motion, (S, Msb,) or that has become strong, (K,) and has walked (S, Msb, K) with its mother: (K:) pl. OaroXaMCN. (Msb, K.) [In the following saying, I find it written as though with medd; app. for the sake of assimilation to AlnRisaMC:] EinodiI jaAriyapN mina AlnRisaMCi OaXobahu XaIoCK biAlrRaXaMCi, meaning [I have with me a young woman most like to] the [young] gazelle: so in the A. (TA.)

1 raXaHa c
1. raXaHa, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
raXaHa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. raXoHN, (S, Msb,) He, or it, (the forehead, or the side thereof above the temple, A, TA, or the body, Msb,) sweated; exuded sweat; (S, A, Msb, K;) as also ArXH↓, (K,) or ArXH EaraqoA, and EaraqFA trXRH↓. (Fr, TA.) And raXiHa, aor.
raXaHa
, inf. n. raXaHN and raXaHaAnN, He, or it, was, or became,
moist with sweat. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] raXaHati Alqirobapu biAlmaMCi (tropical:) [The water-skin sweated with the water]: and raXaHa bimaA fiyhi (tropical:) [It sweated with what was in it] is said of a [porous] mug, and of any [porous] vessel. (A.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] lamo yaroXaHo lahu biXaIoCK (assumed tropical:) He gave him not anything. (S, K.) And raXaHa jalomaduhu, said of one known to be a niggard, (assumed tropical:) He gave something. (Har p. 95.) ― -b4- raXaHa is also said of a young gazelle, meaning (tropical:) He walked, being trained, or accustomed, to do so by his mother: [because the training him to walk causes him to sweat: see 2: and see also 5.] (A.) Also, said of a gazelle, (assumed tropical:) He leaped, or bounded, and exulted [or was brisk or lively or sprightly]. (K.) Also, inf. n. ruXawHN, said of a young weaned camel, (assumed tropical:) He became strong: [see, again, 5:] and the inf. n. is metaphorically used in relation to small clouds [app. when they collect together to give rain]. (L.) ＝ -A2- See also 2, as said of a she-camel.

2 raXRaHa
2: [rXRH app. He, or it, caused to sweat: this seems to be the primary signification, whence the other significations here following.] ― -b2- raXRaHato waladahaA, inf. n. taroXiyHN, (tropical:) She (a gazelle) trained, or accustomed, her young one to walk, so that he was caused to sweat (fayuraXRaHu [perhaps a mistranscription for fayaroXaHu so that he sweated]): (A, TA:) or she (a wild animal), when her young one became able to walk, walked with him, until, or so that, he was caused to sweat (HatRaI yuraXRaHa EaraqFA), and became strong. (Mtr, on the authority of Kh, in De Sacy's “ Chrest, Ar., ” sec. ed., iii. 231.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) She (a camel) rubbed the root of her young one's tail, and pushed him on with her head; and went before him, and waited for him until he overtook her; and sometimes gently urged him on, and followed him; as also raXaHatohu↓ and ArXHthu↓. (L.) ― -b4- raXRaHato waladahaA biAllRabani Alqaliyl, inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) She (a mother) fed her child with a little milk, putting it into his mouth by little and little, until he became strong enough to such. (S, TA.) ― -b5- taroXyHN also signifies (tropical:) A doegazelle's licking her young one so as to remove the moisture that was upon it at the time of its birth; (K, TA;) and so taraXRuHN↓. (TA.) ― -b6- rXRH AlnRbaAta, (A, TA,) or AlnRabota, inf. n. as above, (Msb,) (tropical:) It (the moisture, or dew, A, Msb, TA, or the rain, TA) fostered the herbage. (Msb, TA.) ― -b7- rXRH waladahu (assumed tropical:) He fed his child well. (Mtr, on the authority of Kh, in De Sacy's “ Chrest. Ar ” ubi suprà.) ― -b8- And ruXRiHa, (S, A, K,) inf. n. as above, (K, TA,) (tropical:) He was reared, brought up, or educated, and rendered fit, (S, A, K, TA,) and prepared, (TA,) lilXRaIoCi [for the thing], and liOamori [for the affair], (TA,) or lilowizArapi [for the office of wezeer], (S,) or lilomuloki [for the office of king], (K,) or liloxilaAfapi [for the office of khaleefeh]; from raXRaHato waladahaA in the sense expl. in the second sentence of this paragraph; (A;) or ruXRiHa liloxilaAfapi means (tropical:) he was made the appointed successor of the khaleefeh: (TA:) and fulaAnu likacaA OuroXiHa↓ and taraXRaHa↓ (tropical:) [Such a one was reared, &c., for such a thing]. (A, TA.) ― -b9- And raXRaHa maAlahu, (A,) inf. n. as above, (K,) (tropical:) He managed, or tended, or took care of, his property, or cattle, well. (A, K.) It is said in a trad., yuraXRiHuwna HaSiydahaA, meaning (tropical:) They tend [the place of seed-produce thereof], and put it into a good, or right, state, or make it to thrive, in order to its becoming productive; like as is done to grape-vines and palm-trees. (TA.)

4 ArXH c
4. ArXH, intrans.: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- OaroXaHato (assumed tropical:) She (a camel, and a woman,) had a young one that associated, or kept company, with her, walking with her and behind her, and not fatiguing her: or had a young one that had become strong. (L.) ＝ -A2- ArXHt waladahaA, said of a camel: ― -b2- and OuroXiHa fulaAnN likacaA: see 2.

5 trXRH c
5. trXRH: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) He (a young weaned camel) was, or became, strong enough to walk, or able to walk with strength: (S, K:) or became strong, and walked with his mother. (As, S.) [See 1.] ― -b3- See also 2, in the middle of the paragraph. ― -b4- trXRH AlnRabotu [or AlnRabaAtu] (assumed tropical:) The herbage became fostered by moisture or dew. (Msb.) ― -b5- trXRH fulaAnN likacaA: see 2, near the end of the paragraph.

10 AstrXH AlbuhomaI c
10. AstrXH AlbuhomaI (assumed tropical:) The [barley-grass termed] buhomaI grew tall. (K.) ＝ -A2- yasotaroXiHuwna AlbuhomaI, so in most of the copies of the K, (TA,) [and so in the L,] (assumed tropical:) They foster the bhmI, in order that it may grow large: (L, K:) in some of the copies of the K Albahoma [i. e. the lambs, or kids, &c.]: (TA:) the place thereof is termed musotaroXaHN↓: (K:) or AlbuhumaI musotaroXaHu↓ signifies the place, or tract of ground, that fosters the bhmI. (L.) And ystrXHwn Albaqola, so in all the copies of the K but some in which is found AlnRafala, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) They wait for the herbs, or leguminous plants, (or the plants called nfl,) to grow tall, in order that-they may pasture thereon. (K.)

raXaHN c
raXaHN The moisture of sweat upon the body. (A, * TA.) [And (assumed tropical:) Fluid, or matter, exuded: see zabaAdN.]

raXiHN c
raXiHN That sweats much. (TA.)

raXoHapN c
raXoHapN [as an inf. n. of un., A sweat, or a sweating: a meaning indicated, though not expressed, in the A. ― -b2- Hence, app., (assumed tropical:) A dew, or fall of dew from the sky. ― -b3- And hence, as being likened thereto, (tropical:) A gift]. You say, OaSaAbaniI biraXoHapK mino samaAYihi (tropical:) [He gave me a gift from his store of bounty]. (A.)

biYorN raXuwHN c
biYorN raXuwHN (assumed tropical:) A well containing little water: (TA:) [pl. ruXuHN.]

raXiyHN c
raXiyHN Sweat. (AA, S, K.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A certain plant: (K:) or (assumed tropical:) plants, or herbage, upon the surface of the ground. (L.)

niHoIN raXRaAHN c
niHoIN raXRaAHN (assumed tropical:) A butter-skin that sweats much. (A in art. ntH.)

raAXiHN c
raAXiHN Sweating; exuding sweat. (A, * Msb.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A mountain moist in the lower part, (K, TA,) and at the base of which there sometimes collects a little water: when this is much [in comparison with what thus collects, though still little abstractedly], it is termed waXalN: (TA:) pl. rawaAXHu. (K.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) What one sees, like sweat, running in the interstices between stones. (K, * TA.) You say, kamo bayona AlfuraAti AlTRaAfiHi waAlwaXali AlrRaAXiHi (tropical:) [How great a difference is there between the overflowing Euphrates and a little water that distils scantily in interrupted drops from a rock or mountain, appearing, like sweat, running in the interstices between stones!]. (A, TA.) ― -b4- The pl. rawaAXiHu also signifies (assumed tropical:) The vuEol [which means a small teat in excess], (K,) or the OaTobaMC [or teats], (TA,) of a ewe or she-goat, particularly. (K, TA.) ― -b5- And the sing., (tropical:) A young gazelle that walks, being trained, or accustomed, to do so by his mother, so that he is caused to sweat. (A.) And (assumed tropical:) A young weaned camel that has become strong enough to walk, or able to walk with strength: (S, K:) or that has become strong, (As, S, L,) and walks with his mother: (As, S:) pl. ruXRaHN. (L.) ― -b6- And (tropical:) What creeps upon the earth, of such as are termed its xiXaAX and its OaHonaAX. (K, TA.) ― -b7- See also muroXiHN.

OaroXaHu c
OaroXaHu [More, and most, sweating]. ― -b2- [Hence,] huwa OaroXaHu fuWaAdFA (tropical:) He is most largely endowed with sharpness, or acuteness, of mind, or with quickness of intelligence, understanding, sagacity, skill, or knowledge: (K, TA:) as though sweating therewith. (TA.)

muroXiHN c
muroXiHN, (S, L, K,) or muraXRiHN↓, (so in one of my copies of the K,) (assumed tropical:) A she-camel having a young one that has become strong enough to walk, or able to walk with strength: (S, K:) or having a young one that has become strong, and that walks with her: (As, S:) or having a young one that associates, or keeps company, with her, walking with her and behind her, and not fatiguing her: or having a young one that has become strong: and in like manner a woman: or each signifies, as also raAXiHN↓, applied to a she-camel, as a possessive epithet, having a young one of which she rubs the root of his tail, pushing him on with her head; and before which she goes, and waits for him to overtake her; and which she sometimes gently urges on, and follows. (L.)

miroXaHN c
miroXaHN and miroXaHapN↓ The inner covering that is beneath the felt cloth of a horse's saddle; so called because it imbibes the sweat: (L:) or the thing that is beneath the miyvarap [q. v. in art. wvr]. (S, L, K.)

miroXaHapN c
miroXaHapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

muraXRiHN c
muraXRiHN: see muroXiHN.

musotaroXaHN c
musotaroXaHN: see 10, in two places.

1 raXada c
1. raXada, aor.
raXuda
; and raXida, aor.
raXada
; (S, A, L, Msb, K;) the former of which is the better known and the more chaste; (TA;) inf. n. ruXodN, (S, L, Msb, K,) which is of the former, (S, L,) and raXadN, (S, L, Msb, K,) which is of the latter, (S, L, Msb,) and raXaAdN, (L, K,) which is also of the latter verb, (TA,) or this last is a simple subst.; (Msb;) He took, or followed, a right way or course or direction; (S, A, L, Msb, K;) as to a road, and also as to an affair: (L:) [and often relating to religion; meaning he held a right belief; was orthodox:] and AstrXd↓ signifies the same: (L, K:) you say, AstrXd liOamorihi, meaning He took, or followed, a right way to conduct his affair: and raXada Oamorahu, meaning He took, or followed, a right course in his affair; this latter being a phrase similar to Oalima baTonahu and safiha raOoyahu &c. (L.) Some say that raXodN relates to the things of the present life and to those of the life to come; and raXadN, only to those of the life to come: but this distinction does not accord with what has been heard from the Arabs, nor with readings of the Kur-án, in which some read ruXod and others raXad in several verses.
