(MF.) The former also signifies The continuing in the way of truth, or the right way, with self-constraining firmness in so doing. (K.) One says to the traveller, raXidota [Mayest thou take, or follow, the right way]. (A.) ― -b2- [See also ruXodN below.]

2 rXRdhu c
2. rXRdhu, inf. n. taroXiydN, said of a kádee, or judge, i. q. jaEalahu raXiydFA [meaning He pronounced him to be one who took, or followed, a right way or course or direction: or to be one who held a right belief; to be orthodox]. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also what next follows.

4 ArXdhu c
4. ArXdhu (S, A, L, Msb, K) and rXRdhu↓, (L,) said of God, (S, L, K,) and of a governor, or commander, (L,) [or of any man,] He made him, or caused him, to take, or follow, a right way or course or direction; or he directed him aright, or to the right way or course or direction; (S, * A, * L, Msb, * K; *) UilaI AlXRaIoCi and Ealayohi and lahu [to the thing]: so says AZ: (Msb:) [often relating to religion; meaning he made him, or caused him, to hold a right belief; to become orthodox.] See also the next paragraph.

10 AstrXd c
10. AstrXd: see 1. ― -b2- Also He sought, or desired, the taking, or following, a right way or course or direction. (So accord. to some copies of the K.) ― -b3- And AstrXdhu He desired of him the taking, or following, a right way or course or direction: (L, and so accord. to some copies of the K, and the TA:) or he asked, demanded, or desired, of him, direction to the right way. (MA.) You say, AisotaroXadotuhu faOaroXadaniI↓ [I asked, demanded, or desired, of him, direction to the right way, and he directed me to the right way] (A, Msb) UilaI AlXRaIoCi and Ealayohi and lahu [to the thing]: so says AZ. (Msb.)

ruXodN c
ruXodN an inf. n. of 1. (S, L, Msb, K.) ― -b2- [As a simple subst., Rectitude.] Also Maturity of in- tellect, and rectitude of actions, and good management of affairs. (TA in art. Ans: see 4 in that art.) [Hence, balaga ruXodahu He attained to years of discretion, when he was able of himself to take, or follow, a right way or course: a phrase of frequent occurrence.]

raXodapN c
raXodapN: see the next paragraph, in four places.

riXodapN c
riXodapN A mode, or manner, [and raXodapN↓ an act,] of raXaAd [or right procedure; &c.]. (Ham p. 463.) [Hence,] huwa liriXodapK, (S, A, L, Msb,) and wulida liriXodapK, (L, K,) and liraXodapK↓, (L, Msb, K,) the latter accord. to AZ and Fr, and said to be the more chaste, but the former allowable accord. to Ks, and preferred by Th in the Fs, (L, TA,) [and seems to be the more common,] (tropical:) He is, or was, trueborn; (A, Msb;) contr. of lizinoyapK, (S, L, K,) or lizanoyapK, (Fr, TA,) and ligayRapK. (AZ, Fr, TA.) And wulida ligayori raXodapK↓ [or riXodapK i. e. (tropical:) He was not trueborn]. (Fr, TA.) And hecaA waladu riXodapK (tropical:) This is an offspring of valid marriage. (TA.) And AidRaEaI waladFA ligayori raXodpK↓ (tropical:) [He claimed, as his, a child not lawfully begotten, or not trueborn]. (TA, from a trad.)

raXadaI c
raXadaI: see raXaAdN.

riXodiynN c
riXodiynN: see raAXidN.

raXaAdN c
raXaAdN an inf. n. of 1, (L, K,) or a simple subst., (Msb,) [signifying Right procedure; or the adoption, or pursuit, of a right way or course or direction; as to a road, and also as to an affair: and often meaning right belief, or orthodoxy: in both these senses] contr. of gaIRN, (S, A, Msb,) and of DalaAlN: (Msb:) and raXadaI↓ is a subst. syn. with raXaAdN. (L, K. *) ＝ -A2- HabRu AlrRaXaAdi i. q. AlHurofu, (K,) in the dial. of El-'Irák; (TA;) they gave it this name as one of good omen, because HurofN is syn. with HiromaAnN: (K:) [raXaAdN and HurofN are names given to several species of Gress; and HabRu AlrRaXaAdi seems to mean the seed of rXAd: accord. to Golius, on the authority of Ibn-Beytár, rXAd is the name of the nasturtium: accord. to Delile, (Flor. AEgypt., nos. 576, 580, 571, 584, and 610,) it is the Arabic name of the lepidium sativum of Linn.; the lepidium hortense of Forsk.: and the cochlearia nilotica: raXaAdu AlbaHori, i. e., nasturtium maritimum, that of the cakile maritima of Tournef.; Desf., a pinnatifida; the bunias cakile of Linn.; the isatis pinnata of Forsk.: AlrRaXaAdu AljabaliIRu, that of the lunaria parviflora: and raXaAdu AlbRrRi, i. e., nasturtium deserti, that of the raphanus recurvatus of Persoon; the raphanus lyratus of Forsk.]

raXiydN c
raXiydN: see raAXidN. ― -b2- AlrRaXiydu, of the measure faEiyl in the sense of the measure mufoEil, (L,) as an epithet applied to God, means The Director to the right way: (L, K:) and He who appoints, or ordains, well that which He appoints, or ordains: (K:) or He whose regulations are conducted to the attainment of their ultimate objects in the right way, without any one's aiding in directing their course aright. (L.)

raAXdN c
raAXdN and raXiydN↓ Taking, or following, a right way or course or direction [as to a road, and also as to an affair: and often meaning holding a right belief; or orthodox]. (A, Msb.) One says to a traveller, raAXidFA mahodiyRFA [May God make thee to be a taker, or follower, of a right way; one directed aright]. (A.) And one says, yaA riXodiynu↓, as meaning yaA raAXidu [O thou who takest, or followest, a right way &c.]. (L) AlxulafaMCu AlrRaAXiduwna [The Khaleefehs who took, or followed, a right course, or the orthodox Khaleefehs,] is an appellation specially applied to Aboo-Bekr, 'Omar, 'Othmán, and 'Alee; but applicable also to any others of the Imáms who pursued the same course as those four. (L.) ― -b2- OumRu raAXidK a surname (S) applied to The female rat or mouse (AlfaOurapu). (S, K.)

AlTRariyqu AlOaroXadu c
AlTRariyqu AlOaroXadu is like AlOaqoSadu [i. e. The more, or most, direct road]. (S.)

AlmaraAXidu c
AlmaraAXidu, a pl. without a sing., like maHaAsinu and malaAmiHu, (L,) The right places to which roads tend; syn. maqaASidu AlTRuruqi. (S, L, K.) You say, huwa yahodiI UilaI AlmaraAXidi [He directs to the right places to which roads tend]. (A.)

1 raXafahu c
1. raXafahu, aor.
raXufa
and
raXafa
, inf. n. raXofN, (S, MA, O, Msb, K,) [and app. raXiyfN also (which see below), and taroXaAfN, which has an intensive signification, mentioned by Freytag as occurring in the “ Mak- soorah ” of Ibn-Dureyd;] and raXifahu, aor.
raXafa
, (AA, O, K,) inf. n. raXofN; (K;) He sucked it in, (S, MA, O, K,) namely, water, (MA, K,) and the saliva of a girl, (IAar, O,) with the two lips; (MA;) as also ArtXfhu↓ (S, MA, O, * K) and trXRfhu↓ (S, * MA, O, * K) and ArXfhu↓ and rXRfhu↓: (IAar, O, K:) or he took it, namely, water, with the two lips in a manner exceeding that which is termed maSRN: (Msb:) and raXafa, (Msb,) or raXafa AlUinaMCa and raXifahu, (K,) inf. n. raXofN, (IF, O,) he drank to the uttermost what was in the vessel, not leaving in it anything: (IF, * O, * Msb, K:) or, accord. to some, raXofN signifies the sucking in the water of the mouth in kissing: (Har p. 271:) you say, raXafahaA, meaning he sucked her (a girl's) saliva from her mouth: (IAar, L in art. mSd:) and ArtXfhA↓ he kissed her and sucked in her saliva; from rXf [i. e. raXafN] meaning “ saliva: ” and trXRf↓ signifies he sucked in much: (Har p. 231:) or i. q. tamaSRaSa. (O.) It is said in a prov., AlrRaXofu OanoqaEu, i. e. The sucking in (trXRf↓) of water by little and little is most effectual to quench thirst. (S, O, K.)

2 raXRafa
2: see above.

4 OaroXafa
4: see above.

5 taraXRafa
5: see 1, in three places.

8 UirotaXafa
8: see 1, in two places.

raXafN c
raXafN A small quantity of water remaining in a watering-trough, or tank: the surface of the water, which the camels suck in with their mouths.
(Lth, O, K.) ― -b2- Saliva. (Har p. 231: but there without the vowel-signs.)

raXuwfN c
raXuwfN Sweet in the mouth; sweet-mouthed; [as though her saliva were sucked in by her lover because of its sweetness;] applied to a woman. (S, O, Msb, K.) ― -b2- Also Dry in the faroj; so applied. (IAar, O, K.) ― -b3- And A she-camel that eats with her lip. (As, O, K.)

raXiyfN c
raXiyfN an inf. n., [like raXofN,] (Lth, O,) The taking of water with the two lips; (Lth, O, K;) exceeding what is termed maSRN. (Lth, O.)

miroXafN c
[miroXafN An instrument with which one sucks in water &c. Its pl. maraAXifu is used in the present day as meaning The lips: thus in the phrase AimoraOapN Eacobapu AlmaraAXifi A woman sweet in the lips; a sweet-lipped woman.] [This art. is wanting in the copies of the L and TA to which I have had access.]

1 raXaqahu c
1. raXaqahu, (S, Msb,) or raXaqahumo, (M,) biAlsRahomi, (M, Msb,) or biAlnRaboli, (S, K,) wagayorihi, (K,) aor.
raXuqa
, (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. raXoqN; (S, M, Msb, K;) as also ArXqhu↓ (Msb) [or ArXqhm]; He shot, or shot at, him, or them, with the arrow, or with the arrows, and other things. (S, M, Msb, K.) It is said in a trad., lahuwa OaXadRu Ealayohimo mino raXoqi AlnRaboli [Verily it is harder upon them, or more severe or distressing to them, than the shooting of arrows at them]. (TA.) ― -b2- And raXaqahumo binaZarihi (assumed tropical:) He cast his look at them. (M.) ― -b3- See also 4, in two places. ＝ -A2- raXuqa, (S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. raXaAqapN, (S, M, Msb,) He (a man) was, or became, goodly, or beautiful, and slender, in stature, or person: (S, K:) or he (a boy) was, or became, just in proportion, (T, A,) and slender; (A;) and in like manner raXuqato is said of a girl: (T:) or he (a boy, M, or a person, Msb) was, or became, light, or active, (M, Msb,) in his work; (Msb;) and in like manner raXoqato is said of a girl. (M. [See also 5.])

3 rAXqhu c
3. rAXqhu, (Moheet, K,) inf. n. muraAXaqapN, (Moheet,) (assumed tropical:) He went, or ran, with him; or vied with him in going, or running; syn. saAyarahu. (Moheet, K.) [And] raAXaqaniI maqoSidiI (tropical:) He vied with me (baAraAniI) in going to the place to which I was repairing. (A, TA.)

4 ArXq c
4. ArXq He shot in one direction; (Zj, K; *) as also raXaqa↓. (Zj, O.) ― -b2- See also 1. ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) He looked sharply, or intently, or attentively: (S, K:) [and] OaroXaqato, inf. n. UiroXaAqN, she looked sharply, &c.; said of a woman, and of a mahaAp [or wild cow]. (M.) You say, OaroXaqotu UilaI Alqawomi (assumed tropical:) [I looked sharply, &c., or] I raised, or cast, my eyes, and looked, at, or towards, the party, or company of men; (L;) and so Alqawoma raXaqotu↓. (JK.) And OaroXaqati AlZRaboyapu UilaI maOorabihaA (assumed tropical:) The she-gazelle looked sharply, or intently, or attentively, at the object of her want. (A, TA.) As some say, (M,) ArXqt AlZRaboyapu signifies (tropical:) The she-gazelle extended, or stretched out, her neck. (S, M, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- maA OaroXaqahaA, said of a bow, (tropical:) How light, and swift in the flight of its arrow, is it! The exclamation mark is unclear in the text. (K, TA.)

5 trXRN fiI AlOamori c
5. trXRN fiI AlOamori He was, or became, sharp in the affair. (M. [See also 1, last signification.])

raXoqN c
raXoqN: see the next paragraph, last sentence.

riXoqN c
riXoqN a subst. from 1 in the first of the senses explained above: (S, K:) [i. e. as signifying] A bout (XawoTN) of the shooting of arrows; (T, M, TA;) when persons, competing in shooting, shoot all the arrows that they have with them and then return [to the butt]: (T, TA:) and a direction in which arrows are shot, (S, M, Msb, K,) when the people, all of them, shoot all the arrows: (Msb:) pl. OaroXaAqN. (Msb, TA.) You say, ramayonaA riXoqFA; (S, K;) or ramawoA riXoqFA, (Msb,) or rmwA riXoqFA waAHidFA and EalaI riXoqK waAHidK, (M,) We shot, all of us, [a bout,] in one direction; (S, K;) or they shot, (M, Msb,) all of them, (Msb,) [a bout,] in one direction, with all their arrows. (M, Msb.) And it is said in a trad. of Fudáleh, kaAna yaxoruju fayaromiI AlOaroXaAqa [He used to go forth, and shoot bouts]. (TA.) Accord. to IDrd, AlrRiXoqu signifies The arrows themselves that are shot. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also The [stridulous] sound of the pen (Lth, M, Z, K) when one writes with it; (Lth, M;) and so raXoqN↓. (Lth, M, Z, K.)

raXaqN c
raXaqN: see the next paragraph but one, in two places.

raXuwqN c
raXuwqN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

qawosN raXiyqapN c
qawosN raXiyqapN (tropical:) A swift-shooting bow; (JK, A, K;) as also raXuwqN↓ (JK) and raXaqN↓. (O, K.) ― -b2- OajalN raXiyqN and raXuwqN↓ (assumed tropical:) [A period] quick [in passing]. (JK.) ― -b3- raXiyqN applied to a boy, (T, TA,) or to a man, (S, K,) and muroXiqN↓, (JK,) and raXiyqapN applied to a girl, (T, TA,) Just in proportion, (JK, T, A,) and slender: (A, TA:) or goodly, or beautiful, and slender, in stature, or person: (S, K:) or raXiyqN (M, Msb) and muroXiqN↓ (M) signify a boy, (M,) or a person, (Msb,) light, or active, (M, Msb,) in his work; (Msb;) and in the same sense are applied to a girl: (M:) the pl. [or rather quasi-pl. n.] of raXiyqN is raXaqN↓, (K,) like as OadamN is of OadiymN, and OafaqN of OafiyqN. (TA.)

raAXiqN c
raAXiqN Shooting. (Har p. 37.) ― -b2- sahomN raAXiqN i. q. cuw raXoqK, i. e. cuw ramoIK [lit. An arrow having propulsion; meaning shot; the latter word being] of the class of [possessive epithets, such as] laAbinN and taAmirN. (Har p. 82.)

jiydN OaroXaqN c
jiydN OaroXaqN An erect neck. (M.)

muroXiqN c
muroXiqN, applied to a woman, (JK, M,) and to a she-gazelle, (M,) or to a wild animal [of any kind], (JK,) Having her young one with her; (JK, M;) as though she were always watching it. (JK.) ― -b2- [Also (assumed tropical:) Having a stretched out, or long, neck. Hence,] AlmuroXiqaAtu (assumed tropical:) [The long-necked ones] is used as meaning the gazelles: but is not applied to the [wild] oxen or cows, because of the shortness of their necks: these are called by Aboo-Du-ád banaAtu EamRi AlmuroXiqaAti [lit. the sons, or daughters, (for banaAt applied to irrational animals is pl. of AibonN as well as of binot,) of the paternal uncle of the long-necked ones, i. e., of the gazelles]: he says,
walaqado caEarotu banaAti EamRi AlmuroXiqaAti lahaA baSaAbiSo
meaning [And verily I have frightened] the wild oxen or cows [having waggings of the tail]. (L.) ― -b3- See also the paragraph commencing with qawosN raXiyqapN, in two places.

miroXaqapN c
[miroXaqapN is explained by Golius, on the authority of Meyd, as signifying A ring used in shooting, by means of which the thumb, it being furnished therewith, more easily draws the tighter sort of bow-string.]

1 raXama c
1. raXama, (S, K,) aor.
raXuma
, inf. n. raXomN, (S,) He stamped, or sealed, wheat. (S, K. [See rawoXamN.]) ― -b2- And He wrote; (K, TA;) Ealayohi [upon it], and Uilayohi [to him]: accord. to the copies of the K, like rXam↓; but this is a mistake for rasama, with the unpointed s [and without teshdeed]. (TA.)

2 raXRama
2: see above.

4 OaroXama
4: see the next paragraph. ＝ -A2- ArXmt It (land) showed its herbage. (TA.) ― -b2- And She (a wild cow) saw and depastured the raXam, (K, TA,) i. e. the first that appeared of the herbage: the epithet applied to her is muroXimN↓ [without p]. (TA.)

8 ArtXm c
8. ArtXm, in the copies of the K erroneously written OaroXama↓, [is expl. as meaning] He stamped, or sealed, his vessel with the rawoXam: thus in the saying of El-Aashà, as some relate it,
waSalRaI EalaI danRihaA waQrotaXamo
but accord. to others, waQrotasamo. (TA. [See art. rsm.])

raXomN c
raXomN: see what next follows.

raXamN c
raXamN i. q. OavarN [A mark, an impression, &c.]; (Aboo-Turáb, K, TA; [in the CK AlmaTaru is erroneously put for AlOavaru;]) as also raXomN↓; (K, TA;) like rasamN (Aboo-Turáb, TA) and rasomN [q. v.]. (S, Msb, K, all in art. rsm.) ― -b2- And [particularly] The mark, or impression, &c., (Oavar,) of rain, upon the ground. (K.) ― -b3- And The first that appears of herbage; (ISk, S, K;) as also rawoXamN↓. (TA.)

rawoXamN c
rawoXamN i. q. rawosamN (S, K, TA) as meaning The [small engraved] tablet, (S, TA,) or the stamp, or seal, (K, TA,) with which collections of wheat or corn [in their repositories] are stamped, or sealed; (S, TA;) as also raAXuwmN↓. (AA, K.) And The thing with which [the mouth of] a vessel is stamped, or sealed; (K;) and raAXuwmN↓ signifies [the same; or] a stamp, or seal, with which the head [or mouth] of a [large jar such as is called] xaAbiyap is stamped, or sealed: (TA in art. rsm:) as also rawosamN (M and K in that art.) and raAsuwmN: (K in that art.:) or a stamp, or seal, in a general
sense; as also rawosamN. (M in that art.) ＝ -A2- See also raXamN.

raAXuwmN c
raAXuwmN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places. muroXimN, an epithet applied to a wild cow: see 4.

1 raXana c
1. raXana, (S, K, TK,) [in the CK raXuna, there said to be like karuma,] aor, and inf. ns. as in the next sentence, (TK,) He (a man) came to a feast uninvited thereto, and entered without permission. (S, K. * [See raAXinN, below.]) ― -b2- And raXana fiI AlUinaMCi, (S, K,) aor.
raXuna
, (S,) inf. n. raXonN and ruXuwnN, (S, K,) He (a dog) put his head into the vessel, (S, K, TA,) to eat and drink. (TA.)

raXonN c
raXonN A turn, or time, for the taking of water; (K;) so in the M; (TA;) as also raXanN↓. (K.)

raXanN c
raXanN: see what next precedes.

ganamN ruXuwnN c
ganamN ruXuwnN Sheep, or goats, pasturing and drinking at pleasure, amid abundance of herbage, and plenty. (K.)

raAXinN c
raAXinN i. q. TufayoliIRN; (S, K;) i. e. One who comes to a feast uninvited thereto: he who watches for the time of food, and then goes in to the party when they are eating, is termed waAriXN. (S.) ― -b2- And One who eats all that is upon the table of food; syn. miqamRN: in the K, Almuqiymu is erroneously put for AlmiqamRu. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A small gift to the pupil of the SaAYig [or goldsmith]; in Pers, called XAkrdAnh [correctly XaAkirodaAnaho]. (K. [mA yuroDaHu in the CK is a mistake for mA yuroDaxu.])

rawoXanN c
rawoXanN i. q. kuwRapN [i. e. A window; so in the present day; or a mural aperture; an aperture in a wall or chamber]: (S, K:) [arabicized:] in Pers. rawozano. (KL, PS,) ― -b2- Also i. q. rafRN [q. v.; app. here meaning A kind of arched construction, upon which are placed vessels and other utensils &c. of the house]. (TA.)

1 raXaA c
1. raXaA, said of a young bird, It stretched forth its head to its mother in order that she should put food into its beak. (Abu-l-'Abbás [Th], Msb, TA.) ― -b2- Hence, [accord. to Th, but see riXowNp, below,] raXaAhu, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. wyaroXuw, inf. n. raXowN, (S, Msb,) He gave him a riXowap [or bribe]. (S, * Mgh, Msb, K.) [See also 3.]

3 rAXAhu c
3. rAXAhu, (S, ISd, K,) inf. n. muraAXaApN, (TA,) i. q. SaAnaEahu [He bribed him; (see also 1;) or endeavoured to conciliate him; or did to him a thing in order that he (the latter) might do to him (the former) another thing]: (K:) and HaAbaAhu [app. as meaning he treated him, or behaved towards him, with partiality]: (ISd, K:) or ZaAharahu [he aided him, or assisted him]. (S.)

4 ArXI AldRalowa c
4. ArXI AldRalowa He put a riXaMC [or rope]. to the bucket. (S, ISd, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ArXI said of the colocynth [or any similar plant (see riXaMCN)] (assumed tropical:) It extended its rope-like branches [or stalks]. (Az, S, K, ↓TA.) ＝ -A2- OaroXayotu AlfaSiyla, (S, K,) inf. n. UiroXaMCN, (S,) I made the young camel to suck, or to be suckled. (S, K.)

5 trXRAhu c
5. trXRAhu He was soft, tender, gentle, bland, or mild, towards him; or he treated him with gentleness, or blandishment. (S, ISd, K.)

8 ArtXI c
8. ArtXI He took, or received, a riXowap [or bribe], (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) minohu from him. (Mgh.)

10 AstrXI c
10. AstrXI He sought, or desired, to be suchled; said of a young camel. (S, K.) ― -b2- And AstrXI maA fiI AlDRaroEi He drew forth what was in the udder. (Az, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence, probably,] AstrXI fiI Hukomihi He sought, or desired, or demanded, a riXowap [or bribe] in the case of his deciding judicially, for his doing so [agreeably with the desire of the briber]. (S, K, ↓TA.)

riXowapN c
riXowapN and ruXowapN (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and raXowapN, (Lth, K,) of which the first is that which is the most commonly used, (TA,) i. q. juEolN [as meaning A bribe]; (K, TA;) i. e. (TA) a thing that one gives to a judge, or to another person, in order that he may judge in his [the giver's] favour, or to incite him to do what he [the giver] desires; (Msb, TA;) or a means of attaining that which one wants, by bribery; not including what is given as a means of obtaining a right or repelling a wrong; for it is related on the authority of several of the leading doctors of the Tábi'ees that there is no harm in man's bribing for the defence of himself and his property when he fears being wronged; so says IAth: and Lth explains the last of these three words as meaning an act of bribery: (TA:) accord. to Abu-l-'Abbás [i. e. Th], (TA), the former meaning is from raXaA said of a young bird, explained in the first sentence of this art.: (Msb, TA:) or it is from AlrRiXaMCu, (IAth, Mgh, TA,) signifying “ that by means of which one obtains water, ” (IAth, TA,) or “ the rope of the bucket: ” (Mgh:) or, accord. to ISd, the reverse of this is the case: (TA:) the pl. (of the first, Msb, TA) is riXFA or riXFI and (of the second, Msb, TA) ruXFA or ruXFI. (S, Msb, K, TA.)

riXaMCN c
riXaMCN A rope: (S, Msb, K:) [or a well-rope; i. e.] the rope of the bucket: (Mgh:) and tiroXaMCN↓, also, with kesr, has the same meaning as riXaMCN: (K:) hence it would seem that this is generally the case; but they have expressly declared that the latter word has not been heard except in relation to the like of an enchantment, or a fascination: so says MF, pointing to the saying of Lh, that among the phrases of women who enchant, or fascinate, men is OaxRacotuhu bidubRaMC mumalRaOK mina AlmaMC muEalRaqK bitiroXaMC [I have enchanted him, or fascinated him, with a gourd, filled with water, suspended by a rope, or well-rope]; and that trXAC, meaning a rope, is not thus said except in this enchantment, or fascination: accord. to ISd, the last radical of rXAC is judged to be w because one obtains water by means of the rXAC, like as one obtains the thing sought by means of the riXowap; which is the reverse what has been said above, that AlrXwp is from AlrXAC: (TA:) the pl. is OaroXiyapN. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b2- AlrRaXaMCu is also the name of (assumed tropical:) A Mansion of the Moon; (K, TA;) [the Twenty-eighth, which is the last, of the Mansions of the Moon;] so called as being likened to a rope; (TA;) [the northern fish, of the constel-lation Pisces, together with the star beta of Andromeda; or, more correctly, delta and epsilon, with some neighbouring stars, of Pisces;] a group of many stars, in the form of a fish, with the tail towards the south and the head towards the north; (Kzw;) many small stars, in the form of a fish, called [also] baTonu AlHuwti, in the navel of which is a bright star, which the moon makes one of its mansions; (S, TA;) [or including bTn AlHwt, which is in the navel of Andromeda; for] bTn AlHwt is the name of the bright star [beta] that is above the drapery round the waist of Andromeda: (Kzw, descr. of Andromeda:] AlrXAC is also called qalobu AlHuwti. (TA in art. qlb.) [See manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl.]

raXiIRN c
raXiIRN A young camel; syn. faSiylN. (K.) [See 4, last sentence.]

raAXK c
raAXK The giver of a riXowap [or bribe]: hence the trad., laEana QllRehu AlrRaAXiIa waAlmurotaXiIa waAlrRaAYiXa, i. e. [May God curse] the giver of a riXowap, who aids another to do what is wrong, and the receiver thereof, and him who is agent between them two, demanding more for this or less for this. (IAth, TA.)

tiroXaMCN c
tiroXaMCN: see riXaMCN, first sentence.

murotaXK c
murotaXK The receiver of a riXowap [or bribe]. (IAth, TA.) [See an ex. above, voce raAXK.]

musotaroXK c
musotaroXK A seeker, desirer, or demander, of a riXowap [or bribe]. (TK.) Hence, (TK,) one says, UinRaka lamusotaroXK lifulaAnK, [in the TA UilaI fulaAnK,] i. e. muTiyEN lahu taAbiEN limasarRatihirS [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) Verily thou art obedient to such a one, subservient to that which gives him happiness]. (K, TK.)

1 raSRahu c
1. raSRahu, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
raSuSa
, inf. n. raSRN, (S, M, Msb,) He stuck it (a thing, S, Mgh) together, one part to another, (S, A, Mgh, K,) so that there might be no interstice in it; (Mgh;) joined it together; (Msb, K;) namely, a building; (Msb;) and rSRShu↓, (S, * Mgh, K,) inf. n. taroSiySN, (S,) signifies the same; (S, Mgh, K;) and so raSoraSahu↓: (TA:) or these three verbs all signify he made it (a building) firm and compact: (M:) or rSrSh↓ signifies he made it (a building) firm and strong: (IDrd, K:) and ruSRa, said of anything, it was made firm, and joined together. (M, TA.) And hence, Alqumoqumapa rSiS↓ He tied (XadRa [perhaps a mistranscription for sadRa he stopped up]) firmly the mouth of the qmqmp [a kind of vessel]. (Mgh.) And raSRa baAbahu He closed, or locked, his door; as also laSRahu, q. v. (TA in art. lS.) ― -b2- raSRato bayoDahaA She (a domestic hen, A, K,
and an ostrich, A) made her eggs even, or level, with her bill (A, K) and her feet, to sit upon them. (A.) ― -b3- See also raSaASpN.

2 raSRaRa
2: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- raSRaSato, (AZ, M,) inf. n. taroSiySN, (AZ, S,) She (a woman) put on, or wore, her niqaAb [a kind of face-veil] in such a manner that nothing was seen but her eyes: (AZ, S, M:) as also waSRaSato, (AZ, TA,) or waSowaSato: (M:) wSRSt is of the dial. of Temeem. (AZ, TA.) ― -b3- rSRS (tropical:) He was importunate, or urgent, in asking, or begging. (Fr, TA.)

5 taraSRaRa
5: see 8.

6 trASRwA c
6. trASRwA They placed themselves close together, (Ks, S, M, A, K,) in a rank, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) in prayer, (A, TA,) and in battle, (TA,) so that there was no intervening space among them; (Ks;) as also ArtSRwA↓: (A:) they placed themselves in a rank, or in ranks, in battle, and in prayer. (M.)

8 ArtSRt AljanaAdlu c
8. ArtSRt AljanaAdlu The stones were stuck, or set close, together; as also trSRSt↓. (A.) ― -b2- See also 6.

R. Q. 1 raSoraSahu c
R. Q. 1. raSoraSahu: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- raSoraSa fiI AlmakaAni He continued, or became fixed or settled, in the place. (IAar, K.)

raSaSN c
raSaSN in the teeth is like laSaSN; (M, TA;) and raSiySN↓ in the teeth signifies [the same, i. e.,] Nearness together. (A, TA. *) ＝ -A2- See also the next paragraph.

raSaASN c
raSaASN (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and riSaASN↓, (M,) or the latter is vulgar, (S,) and not allowable, (K,) or, accord. to AHát, it is correct, and it is quoted by Ez-Zarkashee, and by certain of the Expositors of the Fs, and is the only form mentioned by AHei, (TA,) and, accord. to some of the moderns, ruSaASN↓ also, (MF,) and raSaSN↓, (M, TA,) which is a contraction of the first, (TA,) [Lead;] a certain mineral, (M,) well known; (S, K;) i. q. EalaAbiIRu; (Mgh;) pure Arabic; (IDrd;) so called because of the compactness of its particles: (IDrd, M:) it is of two kinds; the black, which is [also called] OusorubRN, and OabRaArN or UibaArN [accord. to different copies of the K]; and white, which is [also called] qaloEiIRN, and qaSodiyrN [which is applied in the present day to tin, and pewter]: if a little thereof [of the former kind thereof accord. to the TA] be thrown into a cooking-pot, its flesh-meat will never become thoroughly cooked: and if a tree be encompassed by a ring thereof, its fruit will not drop, but will become abundant: (K:) and Abu-l-Hoseyn ElMedáïnee says, it used to be said, the drinking from a vessel thereof is a security against the colic: (TA:) raSaASapN↓ signifies a piece thereof. (Msb.)

ruSaASN c
ruSaASN: see the next preceding paragraph.

riSaASN c
riSaASN: see the next preceding paragraph.

raSuwSN c
raSuwSN: see OaraSRu.

raSiySN c
raSiySN: see maroSuwSN, in two places. ― -b2- A woman's [face-veil of the kind called] niqaAb drawn near to her eyes. (AA, K.) ＝ -A2- See also raSaSN.

raSaASapN c
raSaASapN: see raSaASN. ― -b2- Also, (accord. to a copy of the M,) or raSRaASapN↓, with teshdeed, (K,) Stones cleaving to the circuit of a running spring; and so raSoraASapN↓: (Lth, M, K:) or rSASp [in my copy of the A written ruSaASap↓] signifies a stone: and the pl. is raSaAYiSu [which is reg. as pl. of either of the above-mentioned forms without tesh-deed but not as pl. of that with teshdeed]. (A.) You say, EalaI Alqabori AlrRaSaAYiSu ruSRato↓ The stones were heaped together upon the grave. (A.) ― -b3- Hence, ruSaASapN↓, (as in the A,) or raSRaASapN↓, (accord. to the K,) (tropical:) A niggard: (A, K:) likened to a stone. (A.)

ruSaASapN c
ruSaASapN: see raSaASapN, in two places.

raSRaASN c
raSRaASN [app., accord. to the TA, A manufacturer of lead: or] a seller of lead. (Meyd, in Golius.)

raSRaASapN c
raSRaASapN: see raSaASapN, in two places.

raSoraASapN c
raSoraASapN: see raSaASapN. ― -b2- Hard ground or land. (K.) This is its meaning accord. to IDrd. (TA.)

OaraSRu c
OaraSRu A man whose teeth are near together: (M, A, K:) fem. raSRaMCu. (M, A.) ― -b2- And the fem., applied to a woman, Impervia coëunti; as also raSuwSN↓. (M.) ― -b3- raSRaMCu Alfaxiciyoni A woman whose thighs are close together. (A.) ― -b4- faxicN raSRaMCu A thigh that cleaves, or sticks, to its fellow. (O, K.)

OuroSuwSapN c
OuroSuwSapN A [cap of the kind called] qalanosuwap like a melon. (O, K.)

muraSRaSN c
muraSRaSN: see what follows, in two places.

maroSuwSN c
maroSuwSN A building having its several parts stuck together, (S, A, Mgh, TA,) so that there is no interstice in it: (Mgh:) or a building made firm and compact: (M:) and muraSRaSN↓ signifies the same; (A, Mgh, TA;) and so raSiySN↓. (M, TA.) You say also, bayoDN raSiySN↓ Eggs [set] one upon another. (K.) ― -b2- A thing done over, or overlaid, (maToliIRN,) with raSaAS; as also muraSRaSN↓. (S, K.) biYorN maroSuwSapN A well cased with raSaAS. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

1 raSadahu c
1. raSadahu, (As, S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
raSuda
, (As, S, Msb,) inf. n. raSodN (S, Msb, K) and raSadN; (S, K;) and ArtSdhu↓, (A,) and trSRdhu↓, (S, * K,) or lahu trSRd↓, (A,) He sat [or lay in wait] for him in the road, or way: [see raSadN:] (A, Msb:) or he watched, or waited, for him; (As, S, K;) and so rASdhu↓, (A,) and lahu ArSd↓: (L:) [or] you say, raSadahu biaAlxayori wagayorihi, aor.
raSuda
, inf. n. raSodN, he watched, or waited, for him [with that which was good and otherwise]; and in like manner, raSadahu biAlmukaAfaOapi [he watched, or waited, for him with requital]; (M;) and also raSada lahu, and ArSdhu↓: (Hudot;am p. 89:) or, accord. to some, you say, lahu biAlxayori waAlXRarRi ArSd↓; only with A; not otherwise: [see this verb below:] and accord. to some, one says, raSadahu, meaning he watched, or waited, for him; and lahu AlOamora ArSd↓, meaning he prepared for him the thing, or affair, or event; and AirotiSaAdN↓ is syn. with raSodN. (M.) One says of a serpent (HayRap), taroSudu AlmaArRapa EalaI AlTRariyqi litalosaEa [It watches, or lies in wait, for the passers-by on the road, or way, that it may bite]: (L:) and of a beast of prey, (S, A, K,) or of a wolf, (M,) yaroSudu liyaviba, (S, M, A,) or yaroSudu Alwuvuwba, (K,) i. e. He watches, or waits, to leap, or spring: (TA:) and of a she-camel, taroSudu Xuroba AlUbili vumRa taXorabu [She watches, or waits, for the drinking of the other camels, and then she drinks]; (S, A;) or taroSudu Xuroba gayorihaA litaXoraba hiIa [she watches, or waits, for the drinking of others, that she may drink]. (K.) ― -b2- ruSidati AlOaroDu The land was rained upon by a rain such as is termed raSodapN, (S,) or by rain such as is termed raSadN. (TA.)

3 raAoSada
3: see above, first sentence.

4 ArSdhu EalaI kacaA c
4. ArSdhu EalaI kacaA He charged him with the watching, or guarding, of such a thing. (L.) ― -b2- See also 1, in four places. ― -b3- ArSd lahu also signifies (tropical:) He prepared, or made ready, [a person, or thing,] for him, or it; (As, S, A, K;) as an army for battle, and a horse for charging, and property, or money, for the payment of what was due. (A, TA.) You say, OaroSadotu lahu AlEuqowbapa (tropical:) I prepared for him punishment: properly signifying I put punishment in his road, or way. (L.) And OaroSadotu lahu xayorFA and XarRFA (tropical:) [I prepared for him good and evil]. (A.) UilRaA Oano OuroSidahu lidayonK EalaIRa occurs in a trad. [as meaning (tropical:) Unless I prepare it for a debt that I owe]. (S.) And [hence, app., as seems to be indicated in the TA,] you say, yuroSidu AlzRakaApa fiI Silapi UixowaAnihi (tropical:) He places alms in kind, or good and affectionate and gentle and considerate, treatment of his brethren; [as though meaning he prepares for himself the recompense of alms (vawaAba AlzRakaApi, like as one says yaHotasibu Eamalahu meaning yHtsb vawaAba,) Eamalihi,) in so doing;] reckoning such treatment of them as alms. (TA.) ― -b4- Also (tropical:) He requited him, or recompensed him, with good, (L, K, TA,) accord. to the original application, (L, TA,) or with evil, (L, K, TA,) as some apply it. (L, TA.) ― -b5- And ArSd AlHisaAba (assumed tropical:) He showed, or cast up, or produced, the reckoning. (MF, from the 'Ináyeh.)

5 taraSRada
5: see 1, first sentence, in two places.

8 UirotaSada
8: see 1, in two places.

raSodN c
raSodN: see the next paragraph.

raSadN c
raSadN: see raASidN, in three places. ＝ -A2- Also A road, or way; (Msb;) and so maroSadN↓, (TA,) both signify the same, (M,) and mroSaAdN↓ (S, K, TA) and murotaSadN↓: (TA:) and miroSaAdN↓, (IAmb, K,) or maroSadN↓, (S,) or both, (M, A,) and murotaSadN↓ and raSadN, (A,) a place where one lies in wait, or
watches, (IAmb, S, M, A, K,) for an enemy: (IAmb, K:) the pl. of raSadN is OaroSaAdN; (Msb;) and the pl. of maroSadN↓ is maraASidu, (TA,) which signifies also lurking places of serpents. (M, L.) You say, qaEada lahu biAlmaroSadi↓ and biAlmiroSaAdi↓ and biAlmurotaSadi↓ (A, Msb) and biAlrRaSadi (A) He lay in wait for him in the way. (A, * Msb.) And OanaA laka biAlrRaSadi and biAlmiroSaAdi↓ (tropical:) [I am in the place of lying in wait for thee], meaning thou canst not escape me. (A.) And 'Adee says,
waUinRa AlmanaAyaA lilRrijaAli bimroSadi↓
(tropical:) [And verily deaths are in a place of lying in wait for men, so that they cannot escape them]. (TA.) waQqoEuduwA lahumo kulRa maroSadK↓, in the Kur [ix. 5], means And lie ye in wait for them in every road, or way; (AM, TA;) accord. to Fr, in their way to the Sacred House. (TA.) And UinRa rabRaka labiQlomiroSaAdi↓, in the Kur [lxxxix. 13], means Verily thy Lord is in the way; i. e., in the way by which thou goest; (TA;) so that none of thine actions escapeth Him: (Msb:) or it means that He watcheth, or lieth in wait, to punish him who disbelieveth in Him and turneth away from Him: (Zj, TA:) or that He watcheth every man to recompense him for his deeds: (Ibn-'Arafeh, TA:) or, accord. to El-Aamash, AlmrSAd is here a name applied to three bridges behind the SiraAT; on one of which is security; on another, mercy; and on the third, the Lord. (L, TA.) ＝ -A3- Also A small quantity of rain: (S, K:) one says, bihaA raSadN mino HayFA [In it, namely, the land (AlOaroD), is a small quantity of rain]: (S:) and so raSodN↓: (TA:) or both signify rain that comes after other rain: or rain that falls first, before other rain coming: or the first of rain: or, accord. to IAar, the former word signifies rain such as is termed EihaAd, after which other rain is looked for; and if other rain follow it, herbage is produced: one shower thereof is termed raSadapN↓ and raSodapN↓; the latter mentioned by Th: (M:) or raSodapN↓ signifies a shower, or what falls at once, of rain [app. in any case]: (S, K:) the pl. of raSadN is OaroSaAdN (S, M, K) and riSaAdN, (M,) the latter mentioned on the authority of A'Obeyd: (TA:) [or] the latter is pl. of raSodapN↓. (S.) ― -b2- Also A small quantity of herbage, (S, M, K,) in land upon which one hopes for the fall of the rain of the season called AlrRabiyE. (M.)

raSodapN c
raSodapN an inf. n. of un. of 1: pl. raSadaAtN, whence the saying, laA yuxoTiYuka minRiI raSadaAtu xayorK, or XarRK, (tropical:) [My watchings of good conduct, or of evil, will not miss thee], meaning I will requite thee for thy deeds. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also the latter part of the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

ruSodapN c
ruSodapN A pitfall for a lion; syn. zuboyapN. (S, K.) ― -b2- And A ring of brass, or of silver, in the thongs [or cords] by means of which the sword is suspended. (K.)

raSadapN c
raSadapN: see raSadN, in the latter part of the paragraph.

raSadiIRN c
raSadiIRN One who lies in wait for men in the way, to take their property unjustly; (Msb;) syn. with the Pers. raAhodaAro; and so raSRaAdN↓. (Meyd, accord. to Golius [who, however, explains the Pers. word as meaning viæ custos, et vectigalium pro transitu exactor; which I do not think to be here intended thereby].)

raSuwdN c
raSuwdN A she-camel that watches, or waits, for the drinking of others, (S, A, K,) and then herself drinks, (S, A,) or that she may drink. (K.)

raSiydN c
raSiydN A beast of prey, (S, A, K,) or a wolf, (M,) that watches, or waits, to leap, or spring. (S, M, A, K.) And A serpent (HayRpN) that watches, or lies in wait, to bite persons passing along the road, or way. (L.)

raSaAYidu c
raSaAYidu Snares, or traps, prepared for catching beasts of prey; as also waSaAYidu. ('Arrám, L.)

raSRaAdN c
raSRaAdN: see raSadiIRN.

raASidN c
raASidN Sitting [or lying in wait] for one in the road, or way: (Msb:) or watching, or waiting; liXaIoCK for a thing: (S:) or one lying in wait, or in a place of watching, or in a road or way, for the purpose of guarding: (Mgh:) pl. raASiduwna, (K,) and raSadN↓, like as xadamN is pl. of xaAdimN, (Mgh, Msb,) and HarasN of HaArisN; (Mgh;) or [rather] raSadN is syn. with raASiduwna, (S, * A, * K,) or with murotaSiduwna, [which has the same meaning,] and is a quasi-pl. n., (M,) a word like HarasN (S, A) and xadamN, (A,) and used alike as sing. and pl. [and masc.] and fem.; and sometimes they said OaroSaAdN; (S;) and raSadapN also is used as a pl. of raASiadN, agreeably with analogy; (Mgh;) and ruSRadN likewise appears to be a pl. of the same. (Ham p. 415.) One says, fulaAnN yaxaAfu raSadFA↓ mino qudRaAmihi waTalabFA mino waraAYihi i. e. [Such a one fears] an enemy lying in wait [before him, and pursuers behind him]. (A.) By raSadFA↓ in the Kur lxxii. last verse but one, are meant watchers over an angel sent down with a revelation, lest one of the jinn, or genii, should overhear the revelation and acquaint therewith the diviners, who would acquaint other men therewith, and thus become equal to the prophets. (M, L.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) AlrRaASidu is an appellation of The Lion. (K, TA.)

muroSadN c
muroSadN: see raSadN, in six places.

muroSidN c
muroSidN [i. q. raASidN]. One says, OanaA laka muroSidN biUiHosaAnika HatRaI OukaAfiYaka bihi (tropical:) [I am watching, or waiting, for thee, on account of they beneficence, that I may requite thee for it]. (Lth, A.) ― -b2- OaroDN muroSidapN Land in which is a small quantity (raSadN, M) of herbage: (M, K:) or land which has been rained upon, and which it is hoped will produce herbage: (AHn, M, K:) and land upon which has fallen a rain such as is termed raSodap; (M;) and so maroSuwdapN↓: (S, M:) or, accord. to some, one should not say maroSuwdapN nor muroSdapN; but OaSaAbahaA raSodN and raSadN. (M.)

miroSaAdN c
miroSaAdN: see raSadN, in five places.

OaroDN maroSuwdapN c
OaroDN maroSuwdapN: see muroSidN.

murotaSadN c
murotaSadN: see raSadN, in three places.

1 raSiEa bihi c
1. raSiEa bihi, aor.
raSaEa
, (S, K,) inf. n. raSaEN, (S,) or, as in the L, ruSuwEN, (TA,) It stuck, adhered, or clave, to it; (S, K;) as also ArtSE↓. (Ibn- 'Abbád, K.) You say, OasonaAnuhu AirotaSaEato↓ His teeth were near together, (K, TA,) and stuck, adhered, or clave, together. (TA.) [See also the part. n. of the latter verb, below.] ― -b2- raSiEa biAlTRiybi i. q. Eabiqa bihi [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) He kept, or became addicted to, the use of perfume; syn. OuwliEa bihi: but accord. to the TK, he rubbed, or anointed, himself with perfume]. (IF, K.) ― -b3- raSaEa biAlmakaAni, aor.
raSaEa
, inf. n. raSoEN, He remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in the place. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A2- raSaEa AlXRaIpCa He tied the thing in a complicated treble knot, such as the knots of the tamiymap and the like: [or perhaps this is a mistranscription, for raSRaEa↓; for it is added,] when you take a thong, and tie in it treble knots, this [action] is [termed] taroSiyEN. (TA.)

2 taroSiyEN c
2. taroSiyEN [inf. n. of rSRE] The act of setting, fixing, or putting together, [jewels, precious stones, gems, pearls, &c.;] syn. tarokiybN. (S, K.) [See the pass. part. n., below.] ― -b2- The act of making [a thing] according to a measure; syn. taqodiyrN. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b3- The act of weaving [a thing]; or forming [it] by the inserting of one part within another; like as a bird weaves its nest. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) You say, rSRE AlTRaAYiru EuXRahu biquDobaAnK wariyXK The bird put twigs and feathers near together, and wove with them its nest. (A, TA.) ― -b4- rSRE AlEiqoda biAljawohari, inf. n. as above, He furnished the necklace with jewels, precious stones, or gems, connected, or drawn, together, in a series. (TA.) ― -b5- [Hence,] in rhetoric, AltRaroSiyEu signifies (assumed tropical:) A kind of jinaAs; (TA;) the making the words of a clause of rhyming prose, or at least two of them, conformable in their measures, and agreeing in their latter parts, with the corresponding words of the corresponding clause; as in the saying in the Kur [end of ch. lxxxviii.], UinRa UilayonaA UiyaAbahumo vumRa UinRa EalayonaA HisaAbahumo: and the like in verse; as in the saying of Aboo-Firás [El-Farezdak],
waOamowaAluhu lilTRaAlibiyna nihaAbu
waOafoEaAluhu lilRaAgibiyna kariymapN
(Har p. 9.) ― -b6- See also 1; last sentence.

8 UirotaSaEa
8: see 1, first and second sentences.

raSiyEN c
raSiyEN The button of the loop of a copy of the Kurán. (AA, Z, Sgh, K.) ― -b2- See also what next follows.

raSiyEapN c
raSiyEapN The knot that is in the bridle (AllRijaAm), by the cheek (AlmuEacRar), resembling a [small piece of money such as is called] falos. (K.) ― -b2- A ring, of those with which a sword is ornamented: (S:)
or the round ornament of a sword: (IDrd, K:) or any round ring in the ornamental part of a sword or saddle or other thing: (IDrd, K: *) or a plaited thong between the suspensory thong, or shoulder-belt, and the scabbard, of the sword; as also raSiyEN↓: or [the pl. signifies] plaited thongs in the lower parts of the suspensory thongs of the sword; and a dial. var. is with s; (TA;) i. e. rasaAYiEu, (K and TA in art. rsE,) on the authority of ISh. (TA in that art.) The pl. of raSiyEapN (S, K) in all the senses explained above (K, TA) is raSaAYiEu. (S, K.)

raASiEN c
raASiEN Sticking, adhering, or cleaving. (AZ, L.)

muraSRaEN c
muraSRaEN Adorned with jewels, precious stones, or gems; applied to a crown, and sword: (K:) or you say, taAjN muraSRaEN biAljawaAhiri meaning a crown set with jewels, precious stones, or gems: and sayofN muraSRaEN a sword ornamented with the rings called raSaAYiE, pl. of raSiyEapN. (S.) ― -b2- farasN muraSRaEu AlvRunani A horse having the hairs of the fetlock baEoDuhaA fiI baEaDK [meaning compacted together, as though woven]: (AO, and so in some copies of the K:) in [some of the copies of] the K baEoDuhaA fawoqa baEoDK. (TA.)

OasonaAnuhu murotaSiEapN c
OasonaAnuhu murotaSiEapN His teeth are set close together. (A, TA.)

1 raSafahu c
1. raSafahu, aor.
raSifa
, [or
raSufa
, as appears from what follows,] inf. n. raSofN, He put, or joined, together, or together and in regular order, its several parts. (M.) [Hence,] raSafa AlHijaArapa, (S, O, Msb, in the M AlHajara,) aor.
raSufa
, inf. n. as above, (S, M, Msb,) He put, or joined, together the stones (S, O, Msb) in building, or in the building or structure: (S, O:) or he built, or constructed, and joined together, the stones. (M.) And ruSifato OasonaAnuhu His teeth were disposed in a regular and an even row in their manner of growth; as also raSifato, [aor.
raSafa
,] inf. n. raSafN. (M.) And raSafa qadamayohi He (a man praying, O, K) put his feet together: (S, O, K:) or raSafa maAbayona rijolayohi he put his legs near together. (M.) ― -b2- Also He bound it round with a thing. (Har p. 376.) You say, raSafa AlsRahoma, inf. n. raSofN, He bound, (S, O, K,) or wound, (M,) a sinew (Eaqabap) upon the socket of the head of the arrow, (S, M, O, K,) when it had broken. (M.) ＝ -A2- raSifato OasonaAnuhu: see above. ― -b2- raSifato also signifies She [a woman] was small, or narrow, in the faroj [or vulva]. (M.) ＝ -A3- raSufa, aor.
raSufa
, inf. n. raSaAfapN, said of a deed, or an action, (assumed tropical:) It was firm, or sound; or firmly, or soundly, or well, executed, or performed. (O, K.) ― -b2- [See also raSaAfapN below.] ― -b3- One says also, hedaA OamorN laA yuroSufu bika (assumed tropical:) This is a thing, or an affair, that will not become thee, or be suitable to thee. (S, O, K.)

2 taroSiyfN c
2. taroSiyfN [inf. n. of rSRf] The putting, or placing, together, or constructing, well stones or bricks in a building. (KL.) ― -b2- The connecting well words with words. (KL.) ― -b3- And The binding round an arrow well [at the part in which the head is inserted] with a sinew. (KL.)

4 ArSf c
4. ArSf He mixed his wine (XaraAbahu) with what is termed maMCu AlrRaSafi, i. e. water descending from the mountains, upon the rocks. (O, K.)

5 taraSRafa
5: see 8.

6 taraAoSafa
6: see 8. ― -b2- taraASafuwA fiI AlSRafRi They stood close together, side by side, in the rank. (S, O, K.) taraASufN is syn. with talaASuqN. (O.)

8 ArtSf c
8. ArtSf It had its several parts put, or joined, together, or together and in regular order; as also trSRf↓, [or this means it had its several parts well put, or joined, together, &c., (see 2, of which it is the quasi-pass.,)] and trASf↓. (M.)

raSafN c
raSafN Stones put, or joined, together, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) [whether artificially or naturally, and particularly] in a channel of water: (O, K:) n. un. raSafapN↓. (S, M, O, Msb, K.) A dam constructed for [the purpose of obstructing or retaining] water: [such is now termed raSiyfN↓; which is originally an epithet, but thus used as a subst., and commonly applied to a quay; and a bank, generally of masonry or bricks, raised along the side of a river or of a lake &c.; and any similar mass of masonry:] also (i. e. raSafN) the channel of a [reservoir such as is termed] maSonaEap. (M.) [Hence,] maMCu AlrRaSafi The water descending from the mountains, upon the rocks. (K.) El-'Ajjáj says,
mino raSafK naAzaEa sayolFA raSafaA
meaning that the wine of which he is speaking was mixed with water of a raSaf [or ledge of rocks or stones] that had contended, in flowing, with another raSaf, because of its thereby becoming more clear and more delicate: he suppresses the word signifying water, meaning it to be understood, (saying mino raSafK for mino maMCi raSafK, [but in both of my copies of the S, maMCK is erroneously put for maMCi,]) and he calls its passing (masiyrahu [in the O and in one of my copies of the S masylahu]) from rSf to rSf its contending therewith [i. e. with the latter rSf]. (S, O.) ― -b2- See also raSafapN.

raSofapN c
raSofapN: see the next paragraph. ― -b2- The raSofataAni are Two sinews, or ligaments, (EaSabataAni,) in, or between, the [two bones called] raDofataAni of the two knees. (M.)

raSafapN c
raSafapN n. un. of raSafN, q. v. ― -b2- Also A sinew (EaqabapN) that is wound upon the socket of the head of an arrow, (S, M, O, K,) when it has broken; (M;) as also ruSaAfapN↓ (Lth, O, K) and ruSuwfapN↓, each with damm; (K;) or as also riSaAfapN↓, [thus written with kesr,] of which the pl. is raSaAYifu (M) and [coll. gen. n.] riSaAfN↓; (M, O;) but [ISd says,] I think that AHn has made this last to be a sing.: and raSafN↓ is the pl. of raSafapN, [or rather it is a coll. gen. n.,] and OaroSaAfN I hold to be pl. of raSafN: (M:) or riSaAfN is the pl. of raSafapN. (S, K.) ― -b3- Also, and raSofapN↓, A sinew (EaqabapN) that is bound upon another sinew, and is then bound upon the suspensory (HimaAlap) of the bow. (M.) ― -b4- And raSafataAni [if not a mistake for raDafataAni] Two round bones in the knee of a horse, separate from the other bones. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.

raSofaMCu c
raSofaMCu: see raSuwfN.

raSaAfN c
raSaAfN: see raSafapN. ― -b2- Also A part like stairs, in the side of a mountain; pl. ruSufN. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O.)

raSuwfN c
raSuwfN A woman narrow in the faroj [or vulva]: (S, M, O:) or small therein: (M:) or small in the vulva, and narrow therein, and, consequently, impervia viro; as also raSofaMCu↓ (IAar, * O, * K) and maroSuwfapN↓: (O, * K:) or this last, [syn with marofuwgapN,] a woman whose place of circumcision has cohered [after the operation, when she was young], and, consequently, impervia [viro]. (M.)

raSiyfN c
raSiyfN [Put, or joined, together, or together and in regular order, in its several parts; like maroSuwfN↓]. You say, OasonaAnuhu raSiyfapN and murotaSifapN↓ His teeth are disposed in a regular and an even row in their manner of growth. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) An imitator, or emulator, of another in actions; and an inseparable associate. (O. K.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) A deed, or an action, that is firm, or sound; or firmly, or soundly, or well, executed or performed: (S, O, Msb, K:) and in like manner, an answer, or a reply: (S, O:) or an answer, or a reply, that is strong, or valid; not to be rebutted. (Msb.) ― -b4- Also An arrow having a sinew (Eaqabap) wound upon the socket of its head, when it has broken; and so maroSuwfN↓. (M.) ― -b5- See also raSafN. ＝ -A2- Also sing. of riSaAfN, which signifies The sinews, or ligaments, (EaSab,) of the horse: or this signifies the bones of the side: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K:) and has for its pl. ruSufN, like kutubN [as pl. of kitaAbN]. (K.)

raSaAfapN c
raSaAfapN inf. n. of raSufa. [q. v]. (K.) ― -b2- AlrRaSaAfapu bAliXRaIoCi signifies The being gentle (AlrRifoqu) with the thing: and [hence] it is said in a trad., walamo yakuno binaA minohaA lanaA EimaAdN OaroSafa↓ [And no stay, or support, to us was more gentle, or convenient, (Oarofaqa,) to us than she, or it]: no verb thereof [in this sense] has been transmitted. (M.)

ruSaAfapN c
ruSaAfapN: see raSafapN.

riSaAfapN c
riSaAfapN: see raSafapN.

ruSuwfapN c
ruSuwfapN: see raSafapN.

OaroSafu c
OaroSafu [i. q. Oarofaqu]: see raSaAfapN.

maroSuwfN c
maroSuwfN: see raSiyfN, in two places. ― -b2- maroSuwfapN, applied to a woman: see raSuwfN.

miroSaAfapN c
miroSaAfapN i. q. miToraqapN [q. v.]: (O, K:) because the thing hammered, or beaten, is joined, and made to cohere, therewith. (O.)

murotaSifu AlOasonaAni c
murotaSifu AlOasonaAni A man having the teeth near
together. (O, K.) See also raSiyfN. ― -b2- AlmurotaSifu The lion. (IKh, O, K.) [This art. is wanting in the copies of the L and TA to which I have had access.]

1 raSuna c
1. raSuna, (S, M, K,) inf. n. raSaAnapN, (S, M,) It (a thing, M, or a building, TA) was, or became, firm, stable, strong, solid, compact, or sound. (S, M, * K. *) ― -b2- Also, said of a man, i. q. razuna (assumed tropical:) [He was, or became, grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm; and forbearing: still, or motionless: or firm, or sound, of judgment: wise, or sensible]. (M.) ＝ -A2- raSanahu, (As, S, M, K,) aor.
raSuna
, inf. n. raSanN, (As, S,) He made it complete, entire, or perfect; (As, S, M, K;) namely, a thing. (As, S.) ― -b2- See also 4. ― -b3- And see 2, in two places. ― -b4- raSanahu bilisaAnihi, (S, K,) inf. n. raSonN, (S,) He reviled him, or vilified him. (S, K.)

2 rSRn AlXRaIoCa maEorifapF c
2. rSRn AlXRaIoCa maEorifapF, (K,) thus accord. to some copies of the S, (TA,) inf. n. taroSiynN; (K;) accord. to other copies of the S, raSana↓; (TA; [and accord. to the KL, the inf. n. of the verb in this sense, expl. by gAlb Xdn, is raSonN;]) (assumed tropical:) He overcame the thing by knowledge: (S, K:) so says AZ: (S:) [accord. to the JM, raSanahu↓ signifies He knew it: but] the reading in the K, with teshdeed, is confirmed by the saying of Z, in the A, that raSRino liI hecaA Alxabara means (tropical:) Verify thou for me, or to me, this information; syn. HaqRiqohu; a tropical phrase. (TA.)

4 ArSnhu c
4. ArSnhu He made it, or rendered it, firm, stable, strong, solid, compact, or sound; (S, M, K;) as also raSanahu↓; namely, a thing. (TA.) You say, OuroSina AlbinaMCu The building was made, or rendered, firm, stable, &c. (TA.) And UicaA Eamilota EamalFA faOaroSinohu (tropical:) When thou doest a deed, do it soundly, thoroughly, skilfully, judiciously, or well. (TA.)

raSiynN c
raSiynN Firm, stable, strong, solid, compact, or sound; (S, M, K;) applied to a thing: (M:) and muroSanN↓ and maroSuwnN↓, made, or rendered, firm, stable, strong, &c. (TA.) You say diroEN raSiynN A coat of mail firmly, strongly, or compactly, made. (TA.) And binaMCN muroSanN↓ A building made, or rendered, firm, stable, strong, &c. (TA.) And rajulN lahu raOoIN raSiynN (assumed tropical:) [A man having firm, or sound, judgment]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, applied to a man, i. q. raziynN (assumed tropical:) [Grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm; and forbearing: still, or motionless: or firm, or sound, of judgment: wise, or sensible]. (M.) ― -b3- fulAnN raSiynN biHaAjatika (assumed tropical:) Such a one is gracious, or knowing and gracious, with respect to thy want; or mindful, regardful, or considerate, thereof; syn. HafiIRN bihaA. (S, K. *) ― -b4- raSiynN also signifies Pained, or suffering pain: (S, K:) so in the saying of a poet,
yaquwlu UinRiI raSiynu Aljuwofi faQsoquwniI
[He says, or he saying, Verily I am suffering pain of the belly, or chest, therefore give ye me to drink]. (S.) ＝ -A2- What are termed AlrRaSiynaAni, (S,) or raSiynaA Alfarasi, (K,) are The [two] extremities of the qaSab [or round and hollow bones, meaning here of the arms, (in one of my copies of the S, erroneously, of the EaSab, or sinews,)] that are set in, or upon, the raDofap [n. un. of raDofN, which is evidently the correct reading, meaning the bones that are between the arm and the shank], in the knee. (S, K.)

muroSanN c
muroSanN: see the paragraph next preceding, in two places.

miroSanN c
miroSanN An iron instrument with which beasts (dawaAbR) are cauterized. (K.)

maroSuwnu c
maroSuwnu: see raSiynN. ― -b2- saAEidN maroSuwnN [A fore arm, or an upper arm, of a man, or a fore shank, or an arm, of a beast, (for sAEd has all these meanings,)] marked with a hot iron; syn. mawosuwmN. (K.)

1 raDRahu c
1. raDRahu, (S, A, Msb,) aor.
raDuDa
, (Msb,) inf. n. raDRN, (S, A, Msb, K,) He bruised, brayed, pounded, or crushed, it: (IF, A, Msb, K:) or it signifies, (S,) or signifies also, (K,) he bruised, brayed, pounded, or crushed, it coarsely, not finely; (S, K;) as also raDoraDahu↓: (TA:) or he broke it; (Msb, TA;) and so ↓the latter verb. (S, K, TA.) You say, Darabahu faraDRa EiZaAmahu He beat him, and crushed his bones. (A.) And samiEotu bimaA nazala bika fafatRa kabidiI waraDRa EiZaAmiI (tropical:) [I heard of what befell thee, and it crumbled my liver and crushed my bones]. (A, TA.)

4 ArDR c
4. ArDR, (S, K,) inf. n. UiroDaADN, (TA,) He (a man, S) was, or became, heavy and slow. (S, K.) And He ran vehemently. (ISk, K.) Thus it has two contr. significations. (K.) And ArDR fiI AlOaroDi He went away into the country, or in the land; syn. cahaba [q. v.]. (ISk, TA.) ― -b2- ArDRt AlrRaviyoYapu, (S, K,) inf. n. as above, (S,) The [milk termed] rvyYp became thick. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- ArDR AlEaraqa It (fatigue, TA, or food or drink, AZ, K) made the sweat to flow. (AZ, * K, * TA.)

5 taraDRaRa
5: see the next paragraph.

8 ArtDR c
8. ArtDR It (a thing) broke, or became broken, in pieces; (TA;) and trDRD↓ signifies [the same; or] it became broken, bruised, or brayed; (KL;) [and so, accord. to some, taraDoraDa↓: for you say,] HijaArapN tataraDoraDu EalaI wajohi AlOaroDi, meaning Stones that break in pieces upon the surface of the earth; (S, K; *) as some say: but others say that this means stones that move about, without stopping, upon the surface of the earth. (TA.)

R. Q. 1
R. Q. 1: see 1, above, in two places.

R. Q. 2
R. Q. 2: see 8.

raDRN c
raDRN Dates bruised, or brayed, (S,) or freed from the stones, (K,) or bruised, or brayed, and freed from the stones, (TA,) and steeped in unmixed milk; (S, K, TA;) as also muriDRapN↓ and miraDRapN↓: (K:) or dry dates bruised, or brayed, and thrown into fresh milk; as also raDiyDN↓ (A.)

ruDaADN c
ruDaADN Fragments, or broken particles, (S, IF, Msb,) of a thing: (S:) what is bruised, brayed, pounded, or crushed; or bruised, &c., coarsely; of a thing. (IDrd, K.)

raDiyDN c
raDiyDN Bruised, brayed, pounded, or crushed: (K:) bruised, &c., coarsely: as also muroDuwDN↓. (S, K.) ― -b2- See also raDRN.

raDoraDN c
raDoraDN: see what next follows.

raDoraADN c
raDoraADN Pebbles: (IDrd, A, K:) or small pebbles: (A, K:) as also raDoraDN↓, (K,) which is a contraction of the former: (TA:) or bruised, or crushed, pebbles. (S.) Hence the saying nahorN cuw siholapK wacuw raDoraADK A river, or channel, having a bed of sand upon which the water runs, and having bruised, or crushed, pebbles. (S.) Or raDoraADN signifies Hard, smooth stones. (Kr, L.) And with p, Stones that break in pieces, or that move about without stopping, upon the surface of the earth. (TA.) ― -b2- Land broken up (maroDuwDapN↓) with stones. (IAar, S, K.) ＝ -A2- Small drops of rain. (AA, K.) ＝ -A3- Fleshy; having much flesh; applied to a man; (S, K;) and to a camel: (S:) fem. with p; applied to a woman. (S, K.) ― -b2- kafalN raDoraADN Buttocks that quiver (K, TA) in walking. (TA.)

raDaAriDu c
raDaAriDu Pasturing beasts that crush the herbage in eating: (TA:) or camels pasturing at pleasure; as though they crushed the herbage. (S, TA.)

OaraDRu c
OaraDRu Always sitting still, not quitting his place. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

muriDRapN c
muriDRapN: see raDRN. ― -b2- Also Thick [milk such as is termed] raviyoYap; i. e. fresh milk upon which sour milk is poured, and which is then left awhile, whereupon there comes forth from it a thin yellow fluid, which is poured from it, and the thick is drunk: (S:) or fresh milk drawn from the udder upon sour milk; or before it has become mature: (TA:) or fresh milk poured upon milk that has been collected in a skin: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) or, as described to ISk by one of the Benoo-'Ámir, very sour milk, that causes the man who has drunk it to arise in the morning languid, or loose in the joints. (TA.) ― -b3- And A food, or a drink, that causes the sweat of him who has eaten it, or drunk it, to flow. (AZ, K, TA.) In this explanation, raDRato is put in [some copies of] the K instead of OaraDRato in the explanation given by AZ. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A mare that runs vehemently. (AO, TA.)

miraDRapN c
miraDRapN A thing with which one bruises, brays, pounds, or crushes; or with which one bruises, &c., coarsely. (TA.) [And particularly what is termed in Latin Tribulum; (Golius, on the authority of Meyd;) i. e. a kind of drag used for the purpose of separating the grain of wheat and barley &c. and of cutting the straw; more commonly called nawrajN (q. v.) and midorasN and jarojarN.] ＝ -A2- See also raDRN.

maroDuwDN c
maroDuwDN: see raDiyDN; and raDoraADN.

1 raDaba riyqahaA c
1. raDaba riyqahaA, (A, K,) aor.
raDuba
, (A, TA,) inf. n. raDobN, (TA,) He sucked in, or gently sucked or drew in with his lips, her (a girl's, or young woman's, TA) saliva; (A, K, TA;) as also trDRbihA↓, (A,) or riyqahaA trDRb↓. (K.) ― -b2- And raDaba AlmaTaru The rain poured vehemently, or abundantly and extensively; (K, TA;) as also ArDb↓, inf. n. UiroDaAbN. (TA.) And raDabati AlsRamaMCu The sky poured incessantly with rain in large drops. (AA, TA.) ― -b3- raDubN is also used as a verb, [meaning an inf n. of raDaba signifying It (dew) fell, or formed, in distinct particles upon the trees,] from ruDaAbN applied to dew. (TA.) ＝ -A2- raDabati AlXRaApu i. q. rabaDat, [q. v., app. formed from the latter by transposition,] (K,) but seldom used. (TA.)

4 OaroDaba
4: see the preceding paragraph.

5 taraDRaba
5: see 1, in two places.

raDabapN c
raDabapN: see raADabN.

ruDaAbN c
ruDaAbN Saliva; syn. riyqN: (S:) or saliva (ryq) that is sucked in, or gently sucked or drawn in with the lips; (L, K;) as when a man kisses a girl: (L:) or what one so sucks or draws in, of his own saliva: (L:) or what forms into little bubbles, of saliva, and spreads, or becomes scattered, or sprinkled; what flows being termed buzaAq: (TA:) or particles of saliva in the mouth: (K:) or, as some say, the separation of saliva into distinct particles, and abundance of the water of the teeth: but of each of the last two explanations, AM [or, I believe, ISd] says, "I know not how this is." (TA.) ― -b2- Sweet water. (TA.) ― -b3- Froth of honey. (K, TA.) ― -b4- Particles of dew upon trees. (K) ― -b5- Particles of snow, of hail, and of sugar. (K.) ― -b6- Particles of musk: (K:) or so ruDaAbu misokK. (TA.)

raADibN c
raADibN Vehement, or abundant and extensive, rain: (S, K:) or rain pouring incessantly, in large drops. (AA, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A species of the [lote-tree called] sidor: (S, K:) one of which is called raADibapN, [with respect to which it is a coll. gen. n.,] and raDabapN↓, (K,) with respect to which latter, if this be correct, it is a quasi-pl. n. (TA.)

maraADibu c
maraADibu [in the TK maraADiybu] Sweet salivæ. (K, TA.)

1 raDaHa c
1. raDaHa, aor.
raDaHa
, (L, Msb, K,) inf. n. raDoHN, (S, L, Msb,) He broke, (S, L, Msb, K,) and bruised, brayed, or crushed, (Msb, TA,) pebbles, (S, K,) or date-stones, (S, L, Msb, K,) &c., (Msb,) with a stone [&c.]; (L;) like raDaxa, (S, Msb,) which is a dial. var. (Msb.) And He broke, (Msb, TA,) or bruised, (TA,) a person's head (Msb, TA) with a stone; (TA;) as also raDaxa. (Msb, TA.)

5 trDRH c
5. trDRH (S, K) and ArtDH↓ (L) It (a pebble, S, K, and a date-stone, L, K) became broken, (S, L, K,) [or bruised, brayed, or crushed,] with a stone [&c.]. (L.) Jirán-el-' Owd says,
yakaAdu AlHaSaI mino waToYihaA yataraDRaHu
[The pebbles almost became broken by her tread]. (S.)

8 UirotaDaHa
8: see the next preceding paragraph. ＝ -A2- ArtDH mino kacaA He excused himself, or he urged, or showed, or manifested, an excuse, for such a thing; or he asserted himself to be clear thereof. (K.)

raDoHN c
raDoHN inf. n. of 1. (S, L, Msb.) [Hence,] nawaI AlrRaDoHi Date-stones that fall out from others [in the operation of breaking or bruising]. (S, K.) And raDoHapN↓ A date-stone that flies from beneath the stone [called miroDaAH]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, [or perhaps more properly with x,] A small gift. (TA.) ― -b3- And A little of news or tidings. (TA.)

ruDoHN c
ruDoHN is a subst. from raDaHa; and [as such, as is implied, or rather indicated, in the S,] signifies Broken [or bruised, brayed, or crushed,] datestones; i. q. nawFI maroDuwHN↓; (S, K;) as also raDiyHN↓ [i. e. nawFI raDiyHN]. (K.) [See also raDiyxN, with x.]

raDoHapN c
raDoHapN: see raDoHN.

raDiyHN c
raDiyHN: see ruDoHN.

raDRaAHN c
raDRaAHN [That breaks, or bruises, pebbles &c. much or vehemently]. Abu-n-Nejm says,
bikulRi waOobK liloHaSaI raDRaAHi
layosa bimuSoTarRK walaA firoXaAHi
[With every strong hoof, that breaks the pebbles much or vehemently, that is not contracted, or immoderately narrow, nor spreading]. (S.)

miroDaHapN c
miroDaHapN The thing with which date-stones are broken, or bruised, brayed, or crushed, to serve as provender [for camels]. (R, TA.) [See also what next follows.]

miroDaAHN c
miroDaAHN The stone with which date-stones are broken [or bruised or brayed or crushed, to serve as food for camels]: (S, K:) miroDaAxN [q. v.] is a dial. var. of weak authority. (TA.) [See also what next precedes.]

maroDuwHN c
maroDuwHN: see ruDoHN.

dictScrap.note: See what is said at the end of the next art.

superEntry.entry:
1 raDaxa c
1. raDaxa, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
raDaxa
(A, Msb, K) and
raDixa
, (K,) inf. n. raDoxN, (JK, S, Msb,) He broke, (JK, S, Msb, K,) and bruised, brayed, or crushed, (Msb, TA,) pebbles, (S, K,) and date-stones, (S, Msb, TA,) and a bone, (TA,) and other things, (Msb, TA,) of such as were dry, (TA,) or datestones and the like; (JK;) like raDaHa; (S Msb;) as also rDRx↓ [app. in an intensive sense]. (A.) He broke (S A, Mgh, Msb) another's head, (Mgh, Msb,) or the head of a serpent, (S, TA,) &c., (TA,) with stones; (S, TA;) as also rDRx↓ [app. in an intensive sense]. (A.) And raDaxati AltRuyuwsu The he-goats betook themselves to striking one another with their horns, (JK, K, TA,) so that some of them broke the heads of others. (TA.) And raOayotuhumo yaroDaxuwna Alxuboza and yuraDRixuwnahu↓ I saw them breaking in pieces the bread and eating it: (A:) and ZalRuwA yataraDRaxuwna↓ [i. e. They passed the time, or the day-time,] breaking in pieces bread and eating it and taking it with their hands: (TA:) and kunRaA nataraDRaxu↓ We were eating. (JK.) ― -b2- raDaxa bihi AlOaroDa means jaladahu bihaA [app. for jalada bihi AlOaroDa, i. e. He threw him, or it, down upon the ground]. (JK, K.) ― -b3- raDaxa lahu, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) and raDaxahu, (S, Msb,) aor.
raDaxa
, (Msb,) inf. n. raDoxN, (S, Msb,) He gave him what was not much; (S, Msb, K;) he gave him little; (A, Mgh, TA;) mino maAlihi of his property: (TA:) and raDaxotu lahumo mino maAliI raDoxapF [I gave them, of my property, a small gift]: (A:) and lilrRajuli OaroDaxotu↓ [if not a mistranscription for raDaxotu] I gave the man a little out of much. (TA.) Oamarotu lahu biraDoxK waraDaxotuhu [I ordered the giving of a small gift to him, or I ordered a small gift to him, and I gave him a small gift] occurs in a tradition. (S.)

2 raDRaxa
2: see above, in three places.

3 rADxhu c
3. rADxhu, (S, L, K,) inf. n. muraADaxapN, (L,) He engaged with him in throwing stones, each at the other; (AAF, S, L, K;) so that each broke the other's head: (AAF, L:) or, accord. to ElKhattábee and IAth and others, he engaged with him in the shooting of arrows, each at the other: but AAF questions the correctness of this latter explanation, preferring the former. (L.) [See, however, 6.] ― -b2- And rADx XayoYFA, (JK, L, K,) inf. n. as above, (L,) He gave a thing unwillingly. (JK, L, K.) ― -b3- And raADaxonaA minohu XayoYFA We obtained of him, or it, something. (JK, L.)

4 OaroDaxa
4: see 1, last sentence but one.

5 taraDRaxa
5: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- You say also, humo yataraDRaxuwna Alxabara [They hear the news, but are not sure of it, or are not acquainted with it clearly, or plainly]: from raDoxN in the last of the senses explained below. (K, * TA.)

6 trADxnA c
6. trADxnA We cast, or shot, one at another; syn. taraAmayonaA: (S, K:) or taraADuxN signifies a people's shooting arrows, one at another: (JK, TA:) and trADxnA biAlsRihaAmi We shot, one at another, with arrows: (TA:) and humo yataraADaxuwna biAlnRuXRaAbi They shoot, one at another, with arrows. (A.)

8 huwa yarotaDixu lukonapF EajamiyRapF c
8. huwa yarotaDixu lukonapF EajamiyRapF [He has a foreign vitiousness of speech; or] he, having grown up among foreigners, (K, TA,) a little while, (TA,)
and then become a dweller among the Arabs, inclines to, or resembles, foreigners, in certain words, or expressions, though he strive [to do otherwise, or to speak correctly]. (K, TA.)

raDoxN c
raDoxN, (S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) originally an inf. n., used as a subst. [properly so termed]; or of the measure faEolN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, like Darobu AlOamiyri [applied to a dirhem]; (Msb;) [app., in its primary acceptation when thus used, A fragment: for] you say, Einodahu raDoxN mino xubozK [He has a fragment of bread]: (A: [so in a copy of that work; and this is agreeable with significations of raDaxa: or the right reading may be xabarK: (see the last sentence in this paragraph:) or it may be that which here next follows:]) Einodahu raDoxu xayorK He has somewhat of good, or of good things. (Msb.) Also A small gift; (S, * L, Msb, TA;) and so raDoxapN↓ (JK, A, [in my copy of the Mgh, erroneously, raDixapN,]) and raDiyxapN↓ (Mgh, L) and ruDaAxapN↓: (L:) or a moderate gift, neither good nor bad; and so raDiyxapN↓: (L:) and a small gift, less than one's share, of booty. (Mgh, * MF.) ― -b2- Also, [or raDoxN mino xabarK,] News, or tidings, (K,) or a little thereof, (TA,) which one hears, but of which one is not sure, or with which one is not clearly, or plainly, acquainted: (K, accord. to different copies, and TA:) in some copies of the K, in the place of tasotayoqinuhu, we find tasotabiynuhu. (TA.)

raDoxapN c
raDoxapN: see the next preceding paragraph. ― -b2- One says also, waqaEato raDoxapN mino maTarK (JK, A) A small quantity of rain fell: (JK:) pl. riDaAxN. (JK, A. *)

raDiyxN c
raDiyxN [or nawFI raDiyxN] and maroDuwxN↓ Bruised, or crushed, date-stones, [with which camels are fed, and] which are first moistened with water. (L in art. Hfd.) [See also ruDoHN, with H.]

ruDaAxapN c
ruDaAxapN: see raDoxN.

raDiyxapN c
raDiyxapN: see raDoxN, in two places.

miroDaxapN c
miroDaxapN: see what next follows.

miroDaAxN c
miroDaAxN A stone with which, (K, and Ham p. 615,) or upon which, (Ham,) date-stones are broken [or bruised or crushed; to serve as food for camels]; (K, Ham;) as also miroDaxapN↓: pl. maraADaxu: (TA:) but miroDaAxN is [said to be] a dial. var. of weak authority, of miroDaAHN. (TA in art. rDH.)

maroDuwxN c
maroDuwxN: see raDiyxN. It is allowable to substitute H for x in the words of this art., except in those relating to eating and giving. (L.)

1 raDiEa OumRahu c
1. raDiEa OumRahu, aor.
raDaEa
; and raDaEa, aor.
raDiEa
; (S, Msb, * K;) the former of the dial. of Tihámeh; (O, L;) the latter of the dial. of Nejd; (S, O, L;) or the former of the dial. of Nejd; and the latter of the dial. of Tihámeh, and used by the people of Mekkeh; (Msb;) and raDaEa, (Msb,) i. e. raDaEa vadoIa OumRihi, (IKtt, TA,) aor.
raDaEa
; (IKtt, Msb;) inf. n. raDaAEN, (S, Msb, K,) of the first, (S, TA,) or of the third, (Msb,) and riDaAEN, (K,) [which is also an inf. n. of 3,] and raDaEN, (Msb, K,) of the first, (Msb, TA,) and raDoEN, (S, Msb, K,) of the second, (S, Msb,) and raDiEN, (Msb, K,) said by some to be the original form of the inf. n. of the second, (Msb,) and raDaAEapN, (Msb, K,) of the third, (Msb,) and riDaAEapN; (K;) or the last two are simple substs. form raDaAEN; (IAth;) said of a child; (S, Msb;) He sucked the breast of his mother; (K;) and ArtDE↓ signifies the same. (Msb, TA.) You say, hecaA OaxiI mina AlrRaDaAEapi [This is my foster-brother]; and hecaA raDiyEiI. (S, K. *) The saying, in a trad., AlrRaDaAEapu mina AlmajaAEapi, and AlrRiDaAEapu, means The sucking which occasions interdiction of marriage [with the woman whose milk is sucked and certain of her relations] is that of an infant when hungry; not of a child that is grown up: (IAth:) or that consequent upon hunger which is stopped by the milk in the time of infancy of the child; not when the child's hunger is only to be stopped by solid food. (Mgh in art. jwE.) You also say, of a man, yaroDaEu Uibilahu (S, K) and ganamahu (S) [He sucks the teats of his camels and of his ewes or she-goats, by reason of his sordidness: see raADiEN]. ― -b2- raDiEa AllRuWoma mino vadoIi OumRihi (tropical:) [He sucked meanness, sordidness, or ignobleness, from the breast of his mother]; (K;) i. e. he was born in meanness, sordidness, or ignobleness. (TA.) ― -b3- yaroDaEu AlnRaAsa (assumed tropical:) He begs of men; (K, TA;) asks gifts of them. (TA.) So, accord. to IAar, in the saying of Jereer,
wayaroDaEu mano laA qaI waUino yara muqoEadFA
yaquwdu biOaEomaI faQlofarazodaqu saAYluho
[And he begs of him whom he meets; and if he see a cripple leading a blind person, El-Farezdak asks of him]: but [properly speaking] the muqEad is one who cannot stand, so as to lead the blind. (TA.) ― -b4- huwa yaroDaEu AldRunoyaA wayacumRuhaA (tropical:) [He sucks the sweets of the present world, and dispraises it]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- raDuEa, (S, Z, K,) with damm, as though what the verb denotes were natural to the person of whom it is said, (S, TA,) or the verb has this form because it is changed in meaning so as to be intensive, (Z, TA,) aor.
raDuEa
; and raDaEa, aor.
raDiEa
; (Ibn- 'Abbád, K;) inf. n., (Z, K,) of the former verb, (Z, TA,) raDaAEapF, (Z, K,) with fet- h only; (IAth, TA;) (tropical:) He (a man, S) was, or became, mean, sordid, or ignoble: (S, * K, TA:) or he was, or became, very mean, &c.: (Z, TA:) [see raADaEN:] or one says, laWuma waraDuEa, for the sake of mutual resemblance; and the meaning is, [he was, or became, mean, sordid, or ignoble, and] he sucked from the teat of the she-camel, fearing lest, if he milked, any one should know of his doing so, and demand of him somewhat. (Msb.) ＝ -A3- raDaEato OalobaAnuhaA (tropical:) Their milk became little in quantity; said in reference to milch-camels abounding with milk. (TA. [But the context in the TA suggests that this is a mistake; that the phrase is said of the wind called raDaAEapN; and that the right reading is raDaEato OalobaAnahaA; and the meaning, (assumed tropical:) It rendered their milk little in quantity.])

3 rADEhu c
3. rADEhu, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. muraADaEapN and riDaAEN (Msb, K, TA) and also riDaAEapN, (Msb,) [but this last is anomalous, and, if correct, is probably a simple subst.,] He sucked with him; or had him sucking with him; (Msb, * K, * TA;) he had him as his raDiyE [or foster-brother]. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] bayonahumaA riDaAEu AlkaOosi (tropical:) [Between them two is the sipping of the wine-cup, or cup of wine]. (TA.) ― -b3- muraADaEapN also signifies An infant's sucking the breast of his mother while she has a child in her belly. (K.) ＝ -A2- rADE Qbonahu He gave, or delivered, his son to the woman who should suckle him. (S, K.) [See also 4.]

4 OaroDaEato c
4. OaroDaEato She (a woman) had a child which she suckled. (K.) ― -b2- caAtu UiroDaAEK, also, signifies (assumed tropical:) Having milk, though not having a child that is suckled. (IB.) ＝ -A2- OaroDoEatohu OumRuhu His mother suckled him. (S, Msb, K. *) ― -b2- You say also, OaroDaEa Alwalada [app. meaning He caused the child to be suckled: or, perhaps, he suckled the child, by means of his wife or a female slave; because his semen genitale is considered as the source of the milk of a woman who has borne him a child; accord. to a saying of Lth, cited in an explanation of a usage of the word laqaAHN or liqaAHN]. (K voce malaHa, q. v.) [See also 3.]

6 trADEA c
6. trADEA They both sucked the breast of a woman together; each with the other. (TA.)

8 ArtDE c
8. ArtDE: see 1; first sentence. ― -b2- ArtDEt AlEanozu The she-goat drank [or sucked] her own milk [from her udder]. (S, K.) ― -b3- Hence AirotiDaAEu AlkaOosi (assumed tropical:) The drinking [of the cup] of wine. (Har p. 284: [See also 3.])

10 AstrDE c
10. AstrDE He sought, or demanded, a wetnurse. (K.) It is said in the Kur [ii. 233], waUino Oaradotumo Oano tasotaroDiEuwA OawolaAdakumo And if ye desire to seek, or demand, wet-nurses for your children; i. e., An tstrDEwA AwlAdkm maraADiEa; the second objective complement [accord. to this order of the words], but the first in reality because the wetnurse is the agent with respect to the child, being suppressed; for you say, AisotaroDaEotu AlmaroOapa waladiI, meaning I sought, or demanded, of the woman that she should suckle my child: (IB:) accord. to some, the verb is doubly trans.: accord. to others, the prep. li is suppressed in the Kur; the meaning being liOawolaAdikumo. (El-Howfee, in the “ Burhán fee tefseer-el-Kur-án. ”)

riDoEN c
riDoEN A kind of trees upon which camels feed. (O, K.)

raDaEN c
raDaEN The young ones [or suckers] of palmtrees; (IAar, K;) as also raSaEN, (K,) accord. to Lth and IDrd and the S; (TA in art. rSE;) or the latter, accord. to Az, is a mistranscription: (K * and TA in that art.:) n. un. with p. (TA.) ＝ -A2- (tropical:) Meanness, sordidness, or ignobleness; a subst. from raDuEa; as also raDiEN↓. (K.)

raDiEN c
raDiEN: see raADiEN, in two places: ＝ -A2- : and see raDaEN.

raDiyEN c
raDiyEN A foster-brother; syn. muraADaEN↓: pl. ruDaEaMCu (TA.) You say, hecaA raDiyEiI, (S, Msb, * K, *) i. e. hecaA OaxiI mina AlrRaDaAEapi [This is my foster-brother]. (S, K. *) ― -b2- [A child while it is a suckling;] a child before it is termed faTiymN [i. e. weaned]. (IAar, TA in art. Tbx. [See also raADaEN.]) [In explanations of the words waTobN and XakowapN in the S, it is applied as an epithet to a kid, evidently as meaning Sucking; or a suckling; like raADiEN, q. v., and raDiEN.] ― -b3- See two other significations, voce raADagN, in two places.

raDaAEapN c
raDaAEapN, said in the K to be an inf. n. of 1 in the first of the senses explained in this art., is, accord. to IAth, a simple subst. (TA.) ― -b2- [It is a regular inf. n. of raDuEa, q. v.] ＝ -A2- AlrRaDaAEapu also signifies (tropical:) The [west wind, or westerly wind, called] dabuwr: or a wind between that and the [south wind, or southerly wind, called] januwb: (IDrd, K, TA:) because, when it blows upon the milch-camels abounding with milk, their milk becomes little in quantity. (IDrd, TA.)

riDaAEapN c
riDaAEapN, said in the K to be an inf. n. of 1 in the first of the senses expl. in this art., is, accord. to IAth, a simple subst. (TA.) ― -b2- [It is also said, in the Msb, to be an inf. n. of raADaEahu, q. v.]

raDuwEapN c
raDuwEapN A female that suckles her young: (TA:) or a ewe or she-goat that suckles, or that has a young one which she suckles. (AO, S, K.)

raDRaAEN c
raDRaAEN: see the next paragraph.

raADaEN c
raADaEN Sucking the breast of his mother; a suckling; as also raDiEN↓: pl. of the former ruDRaEN; and of the latter; ruDuEN. (K. [See also raDiyEN, which signifies the same; as is shown below, voce muroDiEN; and by Bd in xxii. 2; &c.]) ― -b2- One who sucks from the teat of the she-camel, fearing lest, if he milked, any one should know of his doing so, and demand of him somewhat: (Msb:) or a pastor who does not take with him a milkingvessel, and, when he is asked for milk, excuses himself on that ground, (K, TA,) and, when he desires to drink, sucks the teat of his milchbeast: (TA:) pl. ruDRaEN. (Msb.) The phrase laYiymN raADiEN [i. e. Mean, sordid, or ignoble; who sucks the teats of his she-camels, &c.,] originated, (S, K,) as they assert, (S,) from a certain man's sucking the teats of his she-camels (S, K) or ewes or she-goats, and not milking them, (S,) lest the sound of his milking should be heard and somewhat should be demanded of him: (S, K:) or the origin was the coming of a guest by night to a certain man of the Amalekites, whereupon the latter sucked the udder of his ewe, lest the guest should hear the sound of the streaming of the milk from the teat. (IDrd.) But when a single epithet is used, one says raDiyEN↓. (Msb. [See, however, what follows.]) ― -b3- [Hence,] (tropical:) Mean, sordid, or ignoble; (K, TA;) as also raDiyEN↓ and raDRaAEN↓: pl. ruDRaEN and ruDRaAEN: (K:) and raDiEuwna, as a pl., [i. e. pl. of raDiEN↓,] has the same signification, of mean, &c. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of Selemeh Ibn-El-Akwa', Alyuwoma yuwomu AlrRuDRaEi, meaning (tropical:) To-day is the day of the destruction of the mean, &c. (TA.) ― -b4- Also (tropical:) Mean, sordid, or ignoble, who has sucked meanness, sordidness, or ignobleness, from the breast of his mother; (ElYemámee, K, TA;) i. e. born in meanness, sordidness, or ignobleness. (TA.) ― -b5- (tropical:) A beggar: (TA:) one who begs of men: (K:) thus Ibn-'Abbád explains laYiymN raADiEN. (TA.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) One who eats the particles of food remaining between his teeth, lest anything [thereof] should escape him: (K:) or such is termed laYiymN raADiEN. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A possessor of milk: after the usual manner of a possessive epithet [like laAbinN]. (TA.)

raADiEapN c
