raADiEapN A central incisor when it falls out: (Msb:) or the raADiEataAni are the two central incisors (S, Msb, K, TA) of a child, (S K, TA,) over which the milk is drunk [or sucked]: (Msb, TA:) pl. rawaADaEu: (S, Msb, K:) or the rawaADiE are the teeth of a child that grow and then fall out in the period of sucking; (Msb, * TA;) and they are said to be six in the upper part of the mouth and six in its lower part: (TA:) [the pl. is applied to all the milk-teeth of a child, and of a horse &c.; it applies to the teeth called rabaAEiyaAt that fall out, as well as to the vanaAyaA, or central incisors, accord. to AO, in a passage relating to a colt, in his ktAb Alxyl quoted in the TA in art. Hfr; and to the teeth called qawaAriH that fall out, accord. to a passage in the S, voce OaHofara, q. v., as well as the extract from the work of AO mentioned above, and in this case likewise relating to a colt.]

maroDaEN c
maroDaEN The breast, as being the place of sucking: pl. maraADiEu. (Ksh and Bd in xxviii. 11.) ― -b2- And [as an inf. n.] The act of sucking the breast: pi. as above. (Ksh and Bd ibid.)

muroDaEN c
muroDaEN Suckled: pl. maraADaEu; which is opposed to fuTumN, pl. of faTiymN. (Mgh.)

muroDiEN c
muroDiEN and muroDaEapN A mother [or other woman] suckling: (Msb:) or one having with her a child which she suckles: the former epithet may with reason be applied to the mother because suckling is performed only by females, like as the epithets HaAYiDN and TaAmivN are applied to a woman; and if muroDaEapN were applied to her who has with her a child, it would be correct: (Fr, TA:) [but see another saying ascribed to Fr in what follows:] or the former, a woman having a child which she suckles; (Kh, S, IB, K;) after the manner of a possessive epithet; (IB;) i. e. having a raDiyE; (Kh, IB;) like AimoraOapN muTofilN “ a woman having a Tifol; ” (Kh;) or ZaboyapN muXodinN “ a doe-gazelle having a XaAdin; ” though muroDiEN has a verb bearing a signification agreeing with this; and it sometimes occurs as meaning having milk, though not having a child that is suckled: (IB:) but the latter is used in describing a woman as performing an action; (Kh;) signifying suckling a child: (S, K:) the former is used when the [abstract] quality is meant: the latter, when the action is meant: but God knows: (Akh:) or the former signifies one who is near to suckling, but has not yet suckled: and one having with her the child that is suckled [by her] (AlSRabiIRu AlrRaDiyEu): and the latter, [in the TA the former, but this is a mistranscription, as is shown by what follows,] one who is suckling, her teat being in the mouth of her child; and in this sense it is used in the Kur, in a passage which see below: (AZ in the TA:) Th says, the latter signifies one who suckles, though she have not a child, or if she have a child: and the former, one who has not a child with her, and sometimes having with her a child: and in one place he says, when the action is meant, the latter is used, and it is made an epithet: and when the p is not added, it is meant as a subst: (TA:) Fr and some others say that it is without p when the proper signification of suckling is meant: and with p when the tropical signification of a subject of the attribute of suckling in time past or future is meant: (Msb:) the pl. [of both, though said in the Mgh and TA to be that of the former,] is maraADiEu (Mgh, Msb, TA) and maraADiyEu. (Msb, TA.) The saying in the Kur [xxii. 2], yawoma tarawonahaA tacohalu kulRu muroDiEapK EamRaA OaroDaEato means [On the day when ye shall see it,] every woman that is suckling;, (AZ, Kh,) in the act of doing so, (Kh,) with her teat in the mouth of her child; (AZ,) [shall neglect, or become heedless of or diverted from, that which she shall have been suckling:] or mrDEp here has the last signification explained in the preceding sentence [so that the meaning is every woman who shall have been suckling or shall be going to suckle]. (Msb.) ― -b2- It is said in a trad., niEomati AlmuroDiEapu wabiYosati AlfaATimapu, meaning (assumed tropical:) Excellent in the office of commander, or governor, and the profit, or advantage, which it brings to its possessor; and very evil is death, which destroys his delights, or pleasures, and stops the profits, or advantages, of that office. (TA.) ― -b3- The pl. maraADiyEu is metaphorically applied as an epithet to bees (jawaAris, i. e. naHol). (TA.)

muraADaEN c
muraADaEN: see raDiyEN. ― -b2- Also An unborn child of a woman who is suckling another child: such a child proves to be meagre in body, slender in the bones, and ill nourished. (En-Nadr, Sgh.)

musotaroDaEN c
musotaroDaEN [for musotaroDaEN lahu, agreeably with an opinion mentioned by El-Howfee, (see 10,) One for whom a wet-nurse has been sought, or demanded]. You say, fulaAnN AlmusotaroDaEu fiI baniI tamiymK [Such a one is he for whom a wet-nurse has been sought, or demanded, among the Benoo-Temeem]. (TA.)

1 raDafahu c
1. raDafahu, aor.
raDifa
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. raDofN, (Msb,) He cauterized him, or it, (namely, a thing, Msb,) with a heated stone. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- And He roasted it (namely, flesh-meat,) upon heated stones. (Msb.) And Az says, rubRamaA raDafati AlEarabu AlmaMCi biAlrRaDofi liloxayoli [Sometimes, or often, the Arabs heated, or warmed, water with heated stones for the horses]. (O.) ＝ -A2- raDafa bisaloHihi He ejected his excrement, or thin excrement. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K.) ＝ -A3- raDafa AlwisaAdapa He folded the pillow. (IDrd, O, K.)

raDofN c
raDofN Heated stones (S, O, Mgh, Msb, K) with which milk is made hot, or is made to boil; (S, O, K;) [and with which one cauterizes; and upon which flesh-meat is roasted; as shown above;] as also miroDaAfapN↓: (O, K:) n. un. with p. (S, O, Mgh, Msb.) It is said in a prov., xuco mina AlrRaDofipi maA EalayohaA [Take thou from the heated stone what is upon it]: (S, O:) i. e. take thou what adheres, of the milk, to the heated stone when it is thrown, with others, therein, to make it hot, or to make it to boil: it is applied to the case of one's taking as spoil a thing from a niggard, though it be little, or paltry. (Meyd, O.) [Hence,] muTofiYapu AlrRaDofi A piece of fat which, when it falls upon the heated stones, melts, and extinguishes their heat: and a serpent of which the poison, when it passes by the heated stones, extinguished their fire: (O, K:) and a lean sheep or goat, that puts out the fire and does not become thoroughly cooked: (M, L, K, all in art. Hds:) or a fat sheep or goat, that slakes the heated stones by its fat: (T and TA in that art.:) and (assumed tropical:) a calamity that makes one to forget that which was before it: (AO, O, K:) or simply (assumed tropical:) a calamity. (K in art. TfO [q. v.].) ― -b2- Also Certain bones in the knee, like fingers put together, holding together one another; (O, K;) above which is the daAgiSap [or patella]: (TA in art. dgS:) in a horse, what are between the shank and the arm: (En-Nadr, O, K:) they are certain small bones, places together, at the head of the upper part of the crAE [app. a mistranscription for kuraAE, i. e. shank]: (En-Nadr, O:) one thereof is termed raDofapN and raDafapN↓. (O, K.)

raDofapN c
raDofapN n. un. of raDofN [q. v.]. (S, O, Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] raDafaAtu AlEarabi an appellation of four [tribes of the Arabs], Sheybán and Teghlib and Bahrà and Iyád. (O, K.)

raDafapN c
raDafapN A certain brand, or mark, made by burning the skin with [heated] stones. (Lth, O, K.) ― -b2- See also raDofN, last sentence.

raDiyfN c
raDiyfN Milk that is boiled by means of the heated stone [or stones]. (S, O, K.)

maroDuwfN c
maroDuwfN Roast meat roasted by means of heated stones: (S, O, K: *) and thoroughly cooked thereby. (K.)

mroDaAfapN c
mroDaAfapN: see raDofN, first sentence.

maroDuwfapN c
maroDuwfapN A cooking-pot [in which the food is] thoroughly cooked by means of heated stones: (S:) or the stomach, or maw, of a ruminant animal, which is washed and cleansed, and carried in a journey; and when the people desire to cook, and there is no cooking-pot, they cut up the flesh-meat, and put it into the stomach, or maw, then they betake themselves to some stones, and kindle a fire upon them so that they become heated, whereupon they put them into the stomach, or maw. (O, K.) It occurs in the saying of ElKumeyt,
wamorDuwfapK lamo tuWoni fiI AlTRaboxi TaAhiyFA
Eajilotu UilaI muHowarRihaA Hiyna garogaraA
(S, O, K,) i. e. [Many a cooking-pot &c., or many a stomach, or maw, &c., has there been,] that did not impede nor delay [in the cooking the cook, to the whiteness of the froth whereof I have hastened when it made a sound in boiling, or broiling]. (S.) [This art. is wanting in the copies of the L and TA to which I have had access.]

1 raDiIa c
1. raDiIa is originally raDiwa; the w being changed into I because of the kesreh: (S:) the tribe of Teiyi said raDaA for raDiIa. (IDrd in his lex., cited by Freytag; and Mughnee voce UilaI there said to be a dial. var. of raDiIa.) You say, raDiIa Eanohu, (S, M, Msb, K,) and Ealayohi, (M, Msb, K,) which is of the dial. of the people of El-Hijáz, (Msb,) the verb being thus made trans. by means of ElI, accord. to Ks, agreeably with the opinion of Sb respecting instances of this kind, for the purpose of making it to accord with its contr., saxiTa, (M, TA,) aor. yaroDaI, (K,) inf. n. riDFI (S, M, Msb, K) and ruDFI (M, K) and riDowaAnN and ruDowaAnN, (S, * M, Msb, * K,) the last of the dial. of Keys and Temeem, (Msb, TA,) and mentioned by Sb, (M, TA,) but all the readers of the Kur read rDwAn with kesr, except 'Ásim, who is related to have read it with damm, (T, TA,) and maroDaApN, (S, * M, K,) originally maroDawapN, (TA,) He was pleased, well pleased, content, contented, or satisfied, with him; regarded him with good will, or favour; or liked, or approved, him; (MA;) [i. e., as said above,] contr. of saxiTa; (M, Msb, K;) the object being a person: (Msb:) and Sb states that they also said raDoyuwA, with the medial radical quiescent, for raDuwA; but it is extr. (M, TA.) The saying in the Kur [v. last verse but one, and ix. 101, &c.] raDiIa QllRehu Eanohumo waraDuwA Eanohu [God is well pleased with them and they are well pleased with Him] means God is well pleased with their deeds and they are well pleased with the recompense that He has bestowed upon them: (M, TA:) or, accord. to Er-Rághib, riDaI AlEabodi Eani QllRehi means The servant's, or man's, being not displeased with that which God's decree has made to happen to him; and riDaI QllRehi Eini AlEabodi, God's seeing the servant, or man, to be obedient to that which He has commanded, and refraining from that which He has forbidden. (TA.) You say also, raDiytuhu, (S, Msb, K,) and raDiytu bihi, (M, Msb,) inf. n. riDFI (Msb, TA) [and ruDFI and riDowaAnN &c., as above]; and AirotaDayotuhu↓; (S, Msb;) I was pleased, well pleased, content, contented, or satisfied, with it; regarded it with good will, or favour; or liked, or approved, it: (MA: [for the verb is there said to have the same signification in the phrases raDiyahu and raDiIa bihi as it has in raDiIa Eanohu and Ealayohi; and ArtDAh is there similarly explained: and the like is implied in the S and K; and is evidently agreeable with general usage:]) or he chose it, or preferred it: (Msb, TA:) the object being a thing: (S, Msb, TA:) or (accord. to explanations of taroDaAhaA in the Kur ii. 139) I loved it, or liked it; (Ksh, Bd, Jel;) inclined to it; (Ksh;) had a desire for it. (Bd.) The saying of the lawyers, [respecting a woman whose consent to her marriage has been asked,] yaXohadu EalaI riDaAhaA means It [i. e. her silence] testifies, or declares, her permission [or consent]; because permission indicates riDFI. (Msb.) You say also, raDiytu bihi SaAHibFA [I was pleased with him, or I liked him, or approved him, or chose him, or preferred him, as a companion]. (S.) And raDiyahu licelika AlOamori, and ArtDAhu↓, [which may be well rendered He approved him for that thing, or affair,] meaning he saw him, or judged him, to be fit for that thing, or affair. (M.) And liSuHobatihi waxidomatihi ArtDAhu↓ (K, TA) He [approved him, or] chose him, or preferred him; and saw him, or judged him, to be fit; for his companionship, and his service. (TA.) And ruDiyato maEyXatuhu [His living, or sustenance, was found pleasing, well pleasing, contenting, or satisfying; or was liked, or approved]: one should not say raDiyatp [in this case]. (S, K.) ― -b2- raDawotuhu, (S, M, K,) aor. OaroDuwhu, (S, K,) signifies I surpassed him in riDFI [i. e. in being pleased, well pleased, content, &c.: see above, second sentence]: (S, * M, K *:) so in the saying, faraDawotuhu raADaAniI↓ [He vied, or contended, with me in being pleased, well pleased, content, &c., and I surpassed him therein]: (S, M, K:) the inf. n. of rADAnI thus used is muraADaApN and riDaMCN; (M;) both these signify the same (K, TA) as inf. ns. of this verb. (TA.)

2 raDRawa
2: see 4.

3 raAoDawa
3: see 1, last sentence. ― -b2- rADayotuhu, inf. n. muraADaApN and riDaMCN, signifies [also] I agreed, consented, accorded, or was of one mind or opinion, with him. (Msb.)

4 ArDAhu c
4. ArDAhu, (M, MA, Msb, K,) inf. n. UiroDaMCN, (Msb,) He, or it, made him to be pleased, well pleased, content, contented, or satisfied; (MA;) [he, or it, pleased, contented, or satisfied, him:] or he gave him that with which he would be pleased, well pleased, content, contented, or satisfied. (M, K: * in the former, OaEoTaAhu maA yaroDaI bihi: in the latter, OaEoTaAhu maA yuroDiyhi.) Hence, in the Kur [ix. 8], yuroDuwnakumo biOafowaAhihimo wataOobaI quluwbuhumo [They will please you, or content you, with their mouths, but their hearts will be incompliant]. (TA.) And OaroDayotuhu EanRiI, and raDRayotuhu↓ with teshdeed, [I made
him to be pleased, well pleased, content, &c., with me,] faraDiIa [and he was pleased, &c.]. (S.)

5 trDRAhu c
5. trDRAhu He sought to please, content, or satisfy, him; (M, K;) as also AstrDAhu↓. (K.) A poet says,
UicaA AlEajuwzu gaDibato faTalRiqo
walaA taraDRaAhaA walaA tamalRaqo
[When the old woman is angry, then divorce thou; and seek not to please, or content, her, nor behave in a loving, or blandishing, or coaxing, manner]: he says taraDRaAhaA instead of taraDRahaA to avoid what is termed xabonN; but some relate it in the manner better known, saying walaA taraDRahaA. (M.) ― -b2- [Also] taraDRayotuhu I pleased, contented, or satisfied, him (OaroDayotuhu) after striving, labouring, or toiling. (S.)

6 taraADayaAhu c
6. taraADayaAhu [They two agreed, consented, accorded, or were of one mind or opinion, respecting it; or were pleased, well pleased, content, contented, or satisfied, with it; they both liked it, or approved it]: (A, K:) and taraADayaA bihi [signifies the same]. (Bd in iv. 28.) And taraADawohu bayonahumo They agreed among themselves in being pleased, contented, or satisfied, with it; or in liking, or approving, it. (MA.) UicaA taraADawoA bayonahumo, in the Kur [ii. 232], means [When they agree, or consent, among themselves; or] when they are pleased, well pleased, content, &c., [among themselves,] every one of them with his [or her] companion. (TA.) Hence the trad., UinRamaA AlbayoEu Eano taraADF [Sel-ling, or buying, is only resultant from mutual agreement, consent, or content, or approval]. (TA.) And you say, waqaEa bihi AltRaraADiI [Mutual agreement, or consent, to it, or mutual content with it, or mutual approval of it, happened, or took place]. (A, K. [In some copies of the K, by the omission of wa, this phrase is made to be as though it were meant as an explanation of taraADayaAhu.])

8 UirotaDawa
8: see 1, in three places.

10 AstrDAhu c
10. AstrDAhu He asked, begged, or petitioned, of him that he would please, content, or satisfy, him, or that he would give him that with which he would be pleased, well pleased, content, contented, or satisfied. (Z, K.) You say, AisotaroDayotuhu faOaroDaAniI [I asked, begged, or petitioned, of him that he would please me, &c., and he pleased me, &c.]. (S.) ― -b2- See also 5.

ruDFI c
ruDFI A certain idol-temple, belonging to [the tribe of] Rabee'ah: (K:) whence they gave the name of Eabodu ruDFI [Servant of Rudà]. (TA.)

riDFI c
riDFI is merely an inf. n., (S,) [as such] syn. with maroDaApN, (K,) meaning The being pleased, well pleased, content, &c.; [see 1;] contr. of saxaTN: (M:) and the simple subst. is riDaMCN↓, with medd.; [signifying a state of being pleased, &c.;] (Akh, S;) or the latter is only an inf. n. of 3, (M,) syn. with muraADaApN: (M, K:) [but] the former [is also used as a subst., signifying content, or approval: and permission, or consent: and] is dualized, app. as meaning the kind [or mode or manner, of being pleased, &c.]: (M:) the dual is riDawaAnK and riDayaAni: (S, M, K:) Ks heard riDawaAni and HamawaAni as duals of riDFI and HimFI; and says that the proper way is to say riDayaAni and HimayaAni, [which in the case of the former is strange, as its final radical is w,] but that the pronunciation with w is the more common: (S:) and accord. to some, maraADK is an irreg. pl. of riDFI; but others say that it is pl. of maroDaApN. (TA.) You say, maA faEalotuhu Eino riDaAhu and riDowatihi: see the latter, below. (Z, K.) ― -b2- See also raADK, latter sentence. ＝ -A2- And rajulN riDFI, (M, K,) and qawomN riDFI, (M,) A man, (M, K,) and a people, or party, (M,) with whom one is pleased, well pleased, contented, or satisfied; regarded with good will, or favour; liked, or approved; syn. maroDiIRN (M, K) and qunoEaAnN: riDFI being, thus used, an inf. n. in the sense of a pass. part. n., like as the inf. n. is used in the sense of an act. part. n. in the instance of EadolN, and xaSomN. (M.) ― -b2- [See also raDiIRN; for which riDFI or riDFA seems to be erroneously substituted, in two senses, in some copies of the K.]

raDK c
raDK: see raADK.

maA faEalotuhu Eano riDowatihi c
maA faEalotuhu Eano riDowatihi means Eano riDaAhu↓ [i. e. I did it not of, or with, his pleasure, good pleasure, content, or approval]. (Z, K.)

riDowaAnN c
riDowaAnN an inf. n. of raDiIa; like ruDowaAnN. (M, K, &c.) ＝ -A2- Also The treasurer, keeper, or guardian, of Paradise. (MA, K.)

riDaMCN c
riDaMCN: see riDFI, first sentence.

raDiIRN c
raDiIRN: see raADK. ― -b2- Also, (K, TA,) i. e. like ganiIRN, (TA,) [in the CK AlrRiDaI, and in my MS. copy of the K AlrRiDaA, are put in the place of AlrRaDiIRu,] One who is responsible, accountable, or answerable; syn. DaAminN: so in the copies of the K, and in like manner in the Tekmileh: accord. to the copies of the T, DaAmirN [lean, or light of flesh, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b3- And Loving; a lover; or a friend. (IAar, K, TA.) ― -b4- And Obeying, or obedient. (IAar, TA.)

raADK c
raADK, of which the pl. is ruDaApN; and raDiIRN↓, of which the pl. is OaroDiyaMCu and ruDaApN, (M, K,) the latter pl. on the authority of Lh, but extr. as pl. of raDiIRN, and in my opinion, [says ISd,] it is pl. of raADK only; (M;) and raDK↓, of which the pl. is raDuwna; (Lh, M, K;) Pleased, well pleased, content, contented, or satisfied; regarding with good will, or favour; liking, or approving. (M, K.) ― -b2- EiyXapN raADiyapN means maroDiyRapN [i. e. A state, or sort, of life that is found pleasing, well pleasing, contenting, or satisfying; or with which one is pleased, &c.; or that is liked, or approved]: (S, K:) or, accord. to Sb, raADiyapN is, in this case, a possessive epithet, meaning caAtu riDFI↓ [i. e. having approvedness; riDFI being here an inf. n. of ruDiyato]. (M, TA.)

maroDaMpN c
maroDaMpN, originally maroDawapN, (TA,) an inf. n. of raDiIa. (S, * M, K.) ― -b2- [Also A cause, or means, or an occasion, of riDFI, i. e., of being pleased, well pleased, conten, &c.: a word of the same class as maboxalapN and majobanapN. Hence the saying,] AlbirRu maroDaApN lilrRabRi masoxaTapN lilXRayoTaAni [Piety is a cause of approbation to the Lord, a cause of disapprobation, or anger, to the devil]. (TA in art. sxT.) The pl. of maroDaApN is maraADK [accord. to rule]: or this is an irreg. pl. of riDFI. (TA.)

maroDuwRN c
maroDuwRN: see what follows.

maroDiIRN c
maroDiIRN and maroDuwRN↓, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) the former the more common, (S, Msb,) the latter erroneously written in [some of] the copies of the K maroDuIRN, (TA,) applied to a thing, (S, Msb,) or a person, (M,) Found pleasing, well pleasing, contenting, or satisfying; or with which, or with whom, one is pleased, &c.; or liked, or approved: (K: [the meaning being there indicated to be the contr. of masoxuwTN; and being well known to be commonly as above:]) or chosen, or preferred: (Msb:) or seen, or judged, to be fit for a thing or an affair: (M:) [see also riDFI, last sentence but one; and raADK, latter sentence.]

riDayaAni c
riDayaAni a dual of riDFI, which see in art. rDw.

1 raTuba c
1. raTuba, (S, A, MA, Msb, K,) aor.
raTuba
; (K;) and raTiba, aor.
raTaba
; (K;) inf. n. ruTuwbapN (S, A, MA, Msb, K) of the former verb (S, A, Msb) and raTaAbapN [also of the former verb]; (MA, K;) It (a thing, S, Msb) was, or became, the contr. of what is termed yaA bis (S, Msb, K) and jaAfR; i. e., (Msb,) it was, or became, moist, humid, succulent, sappy, or juicy: (A, MA, Msb:) or soft, or tender, to chew: (A:) [and fresh, or green; agreeably with the Pers. explanation, taroXudo, in the MA: and supple, pliant, or flexible: all meanings well known, of frequent occurrence, and implied in the first of the explanations above, and in explanations of raTobN and raTiybN:] and soft, or tender, said of a branch, or twig, and of plumage, &c.: (K:) [and trTRb↓, as used in the L in art. Eqd, &c., signifies the same.] ruTuwbapN [used as a simple subst.] signifies A quality necessarily involving facility of assuming shape and of separation and of conjunction. (KT.) ― -b2- [Hence, raTubato said of a girl, (assumed tropical:) She was, or became, sappy, or supple; and soft, or tender: and raTuba said of a boy, (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, sappy, or soft, or supple; and femininely soft or supple: see raTobN, below. ― -b3- Hence also,] raTuba lisaAniI bicikorika and trTRb↓ (tropical:) [My tongue has become supple by mentioning thee; i. e., has been much occupied by mentioning thee: a well-known phrase: (see also 2:) it may also be used as meaning my tongue has become refreshed (lit. moistened) by mentioning thee]. (A.) And xuco maA raTubato bihi yadaAka (tropical:) [Take that by means of the
frequent handling of which thy hands have become supple]; meaning, what thou hast found to be profitable, or useful. (A.) ― -b4- See also 4, in two places. ＝ -A2- raTiba, aor.
raTaba
, He spoke what he had in his mind, right and wrong, or correct and erroneous. (K, TA.) ＝ -A3- raTaba, (aor.
raTuba
, A,) inf. n. raTobN, (A'Obeyd, S, A, K) and ruTuwbN, (A'Obeyd, S, K,) He fed a horse (or similar beast, K) with [the trefoil called] raTobap [q. v.]. (A'Obeyd, S, A, K.) ― -b2- See also 2.

2 rTRb c
2. rTRb, inf. n. taroTiybN, He [or it] made, or rendered, a thing such as is termed raTobN and raTiybN; i. e. [moist, humid, succulent, sappy, or juicy: or soft, or tender, to chew: and fresh, new, or green: and supple, pliant, or flexible: and soft, or tender, as applied to a branch, or twig, and to plumage, &c.:] contr. of yaA bis: (S:) he moistened a garment, or piece of cloth, (A, K, TA,) &c.; (TA;) as also ArTb↓. (K, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, lisaAniI bicikorika maA zilotu OuroTibu↓ (tropical:) [I have not ceased to make my tongue supple by mentioning thee; meaning I have not ceased to employ my tongue frequently in mentioning thee: or mA zlt OuraTRibu Alx: for] one says also maA raTRaba lisaAniI bicikorika UilRaA maA balalotaniI bihi mino birRika (tropical:) [Nothing has made my tongue to become supple by mentioning thee save what thou hast bestowed upon me of thy bounty]. (A. [See also 1.]) ＝ -A2- Also rTRb, (S, A, K,) inf. n. as above, (S,) He fed people with ruTab [or fresh ripe dates]; (S, A, K;) and so raTaba↓. (K.) You say, mano OaroTaba↓ naxoluhu walamo yuraTRibo xabuva fiEoluhu walamo yaTibo [He whose palm-trees have fresh ripe dates and he does not feed people with such dates, his conduct is bad, and is not good]. (A.) ＝ -A3- See also the next paragraph, in two places.

4 ArTb c
4. ArTb as a trans. v.: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places. ＝ -A2- ArTb Albusoru The fullgrown unripe dates became ruTab [i. e. freshly ripe dates]: (S, A:) or so raTaba↓, and raTuba↓, and rTRb↓, (K,) of which last the inf. n. is taroTiybN: or all signify, attained to the time of ripening: (TA:) or ArTbt Albusorapu signifies the full-grown unripe date had ripening (taroTiyb↓) beginning in it. (Msb.) ― -b2- And ArTb AlnRaxolu The palm-trees had upon them, (S,) or produced, (A,) or attained to the time of having, (K,) dates such as are termed ruTab. (S, A, K.) See an ex. in the next preceding paragraph. ― -b3- And ArTb Alqawomu The people had palm-trees that had attained to the time of having such dates: (K:) or ArTb signifies he had abundance of such dates. (A.) ― -b4- [Also] The people became amid fresh green herbage. (Msb.) ― -b5- And ArTbt AlOaroDu, inf. n. UiroTaAbN, The land had such herbage: (Msb:) or abounded therewith. (A.)

5 taraTRaba
5: see 1, in two places.

raTobN c
raTobN and raTiybN↓ Contr. of yaAbisN (S, Msb, K) and jaAfRN; i. e. (Msb) moist, humid, succulent, sappy, or juicy: (A, MA, Msb:) or soft, or tender, to chew: (A:) and [fresh, (agreeably with the Pers. explanation, taro, in the MA,) or] green; applied to herbage: (TA:) or they signify, (Msb,) or signify also, (S, K,) soft, or tender; (S, Msb, K;) applied to a branch, or twig, and to plumage, (S, K,) &c.: (K:) [and] supple, pliant, or flexible. (Msb.) [All these meanings are well known, of frequent occurrence, and implied in the first of the explanations above.] The former occurs in a trad. as an epithet particularly applied to Any article of property [or of provisions] that is not stored up, and will not keep; such as [most kinds of] fruits, and herbs, or leguminous plants: such, IAth says, fathers and mothers and children may eat and give away agreeably with approved usage, without asking permission; but not husbands nor wives [when it belongs to one of them exclusively], without the permission of the owner. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] jaAriyapN raTobapN (tropical:) A soft, or tender, [or a sappy, or supple,] girl, or young woman. (A, K, * TA.) And gulaAmN raTobN (tropical:) A boy, or young man, [sappy, or soft, or supple, or] femininely soft or supple. (A, K.) And rajulN raTobN (tropical:) A soft, or supple, man. (A.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] bicikorika lisaAniI raTiybN↓ (tropical:) [My tongue is become supple by mentioning thee: and it may also be used as meaning my tongue is become refreshed (lit. moistened) by mentioning thee]. (A. [See also 1 and 2.]) ― -b4- And AimoraOapN raTobapN (tropical:) [A pliant, or] a vitious, or an unchaste, woman; a fornicatress, or an adulteress. (A.) One says, in reviling, yaA Qbona AlrRaTobapi (tropical:) [O son of the fornicatress or adulteress]. (A.) And yaA raTaAbi↓, like qaTaAmi, (tropical:) [meaning O fornicatress or adulteress, raTaAbi, being indecl., as a proper name in this sense,] is said in reviling a woman or girl. (A, K.) ― -b5- [And yaHomilu AlHaTaba AlrRaToba (tropical:): see 1 in art. Hml.] ― -b6- And EayoXN raTobN (tropical:) A soft, a delicate, or an easy, life. (A.) ― -b7- And qaraOa AlquroMna raTobFA (assumed tropical:) He read, or recited, the Kur-án softly, or gently; not with a loud voice. (TA from a trad) ― -b8- luWoluWN raTobN is a metonymical expression, meaning (tropical:) Brilliant pearls, beautiful, smooth in the exterior, and perfect in clearness: it does not denote the ruTuwabp that is the contr. of yubuwsap: and similar to this is the expression Almanodalu AlrRaTobu [app. meaning (tropical:) Fresh and fragrant, or fine, aloes-wood]. (TA.)

ruTobN c
ruTobN (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.) and ruTubN↓ (S, K) Herbage, or pasture, (S, A, Mgh,) such as is juicy, fresh, or green: (A, Mgh:) or green pasture, consisting of herbs, or leguminous plants, (T, Msb, K, TA,) of the [season called] rabiyE, (Msb, TA,) and of trees [or shrubs]: (T, K, TA:) [each] a coll. gen. n.: (TA:) or green herbage in general: (K, TA:) accord. to the Kifáyet el-Mutahaffidh, ruTobN signifies fresh, or juicy, herbage or pasture; (TA;) or, as some say, ruTobapN↓, like gurofapN, [though this seems to be the n. un. of ruTobN,] has this last meaning; (Msb;) what is dry being called HaXiyX. (TA.)

ruTabN c
ruTabN [Fresh ripe dates; i. e.] ripe dates (A, Mgh, Msb, K) before they become dry; (Msb, TA;) also called tamorN raTiybN↓ and muroTibN↓ (K, TA) and muraTRibN↓: (TA:) the dates so called are well known: (S:) [it is a coll. gen, n.:] n. un. with p: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) it is not a broken pl. of ruTabapN, being masc. [as well as fem.] like tamorN: you say, hecaA ruTabN [These are fresh ripe dates]; whereas, if it were a broken pl., you would make it [only] fem.: (Sb, TA:) its pl. [of pauc.] is OaroTaAbN (S, Msb) and [of mult.] riTaAbN; and the pl. of the n. un. is ruTabaAtN. (S.) There are two sorts of ruTab: one sort cannot be dried, and spoils if not soon eaten: the other sort dries, and is made into Eajowap [q. v.]. (Msb.) [See also busorN.]

ruTubN c
ruTubN: see ruTobN.

raTobapN c
raTobapN i. q. qaDobN, (S, [in my copy of the Msb qaDobap, but this is the n. un. of qaDobN,]) or qatRN, (A,) or UisofisotN [in Pers. Uisofisot or UisoPisot], (Mgh,) or fiSofiSapN, (K,) [all which signify A species of trefoil, or clover,] specially (S) while juicy, or fresh, or green, (S, A, Mgh, TA,) before it is dried: (Msb:) or, as some say, a meadow of fSfSp, while continuing green: and ruTobapN↓ signifies the same: (TA:) pl. riTaAbN: (S, Mgh, Msb:) which is also said to be applied to the cucumber and melon and bAcnjAn [q. v.] and the like: but [Mtr says] the first is the meaning mentioned in the Lexicons in my hands, and is a sufficient explanation. (Mgh.)

ruTobapN c
ruTobapN: see ruTobN: ― -b2- and raTobapN.

ruTabiIRN c
ruTabiIRN [A seller of ruTab, or fresh ripe dates: mentioned in the K only as a surname].

raTaAbi c
raTaAbi: see raTobN.

raTiybN c
raTiybN: see raTobN, in two places: and ruTabN.

muroTibN c
muroTibN: see ruTabN. ― -b2- OaroDN muroTibapN Land abounding with ruTob [q. v.]. (S, * A, K.)

rakiyRapN maroTabapN c
rakiyRapN maroTabapN A well of sweet water among wells of salt water. (K.)

muraTRibN c
muraTRibN: see ruTabN.

maroTuwbN c
maroTuwbN A horse fed with [the trefoil called] raTobap. (A.) ― -b2- [And A man fed with ruTab (or fresh ripe dates).] ＝ -A2- Also (assumed tropical:) A man in whom is softness, or suppleness; mano bihi ruTuwbapN; (K;) or SaAHibu ruTuwbapK. (S.)

1 raTala c
1. raTala, (O, Msb, K,) aor.
raTula
, inf. n. raTolN, (Msb, TA,) He weighed a thing: (O, TA:) or he put in motion a thing with his hand, (IDrd, O,) or weighed with his hand a thing, (Msb,) or tried a thing, (K,) in order that he might know its weight (IDrd, O, Msb, K) nearly. (Msb.) [See also 2.] But IF says, of this combination of letters and the like, that they are not of the genuine language [of the Arabs]. (O.) ＝ -A2- He ran; syn. EadaA. (O, K.)

2 taroTiylN c
2. taroTiylN The act of weighing by, or with, OaroTaAl [or pound-weights]. (K.) [See also 1.] ＝ -A2- Also The anointing of the hair, (S, O,) or making it soft, or smooth, (K,) with oil, or ointment, and
the crimping (takosiyr) thereof: (S, O, K:) and the making it to be loose, and to hang down: (IAar, IAmb, K:) accord. to IAmb, rTRl XaEarahu means he made his hair to be loose, and to hang down: (O:) but accord. to the T, the saying of the vulgar, raTRalotu XaEariI, as meaning rajRalotuhu, [i. e. I made my hair to be wavy, or somewhat curly; or combed it; or combed it down; &c.;] is a mistake: for trTyl signifies the act of making the hair soft, or smooth, with oil, or ointment; and wiping it so that it becomes soft, or smooth, and glossy. (TA.)

3 rATl cahabFA bicahabK c
3. rATl cahabFA bicahabK, inf. n. muraATalapN, He sold by counterpoising gold for gold, and wariqFA biwariqK coined dirhems for coined dirhems: but [Mtr says] I have not found this except in the “ Muwatta. ” (Mgh.) You say also, baAEa muraATalapF [He sold by counterpoising]. (TA.)

4 ArTl c
4. ArTl He had a child such as is termed raTol [q. v.]: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K:) or his ears became flabby. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

raTolN c
raTolN (S, O, K) and riTolN↓ (K) A man soft, lax, or uncompact; (S, O, K, * TA;) as also muroTilN↓: (K, TA:) and old and weak: or inclining to softness, and laxness, or uncompactness, and old age: (K:) and a boy slender, slim, or lean, (K, TA,) or, as some say, (TA,) near to attaining puberty, or virility: (K, TA:) or whose bones have not become strong: (K:) or the former, applied to a boy, whose strength has not become fully established; as also muroTalN↓ [thus written with fet-h to the T]: (O:) pl. riTalapN: (O, TA:) and the first, i. e. raTolN, a man who is foolish; stupid; unsound, or deficient, in intellect or understanding; (K;) fem. with p: (TA:) one who has not, or possesses not, what suffices; or who is not profitable to any one: and also having flaccid ears: (O:) and, applied to a horse, (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K,) as also riTolN↓, (K,) or, as some say, the latter only, (TA,) light, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K, TA,) and weak: (TA:) fem. with p, (O, K, TA,) in all the senses. (TA.) ＝ -A2- [AlrRaTolu is also explained in the K as syn. with AlEadolu: but perhaps this is a mistranscription for AlEadowu, inf. n. of EadaA: see 1, last sentence.] ＝ -A3- See also the next paragraph.

riTolN c
riTolN and raTolN↓, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) the former of which is the better known, (Msb, TA,) or the more chaste, (O, TA,) [but the latter is that which is now in common use,] A certain thing with which one weighs, (Mgh, O, Msb,) or which one uses as a measure of capacity: (Mgh, Msb:) [or rather both: a pound-weight: and a pint-measure: and also a pound of anything: and a pint of anything:] the half of what is termed manFA: (S:) accord. to the standard of Baghdád, twelve ounces; the ounce (OuwqiyRap) being an UisotaAr and two thirds of an AstAr; and the AstAr being four mavaAqiyl and half of a mivoqaAl; and the mvqAl being a diroham and three sevenths of a drhm; and the drhm being six dawaAniq; and the daAniq being eight HabRaAt and two fifths of a HabRap; so that the rTl is ninety mvAqyl; i. e. a hundred and twenty-eight daraAhim and four sevenths of a drhm (Msb:) or, accord. to A 'Obeyd, a hundred and twenty-eight drAhm of the weight of seven (wazona saboEapK [explained voce dirohamN]): (Mgh:) or twelve ounces; the ounce (OuwqiyRap, i. e. the ounce of the Arabs, TA,) being forty drAhm; (Mgh, K, TA;) so that the whole is four hundred and eighty drAhm: (Mgh, TA:) this is the Syrian rTl: (TA:) and thus it is, accord. to El-Harbee, in the saying, AlsRunRapu fiI AlnRikaAHi riTolN [meaning The usage of the Prophet in the case of marriage was to give a rTl of silver]: (Mgh, TA:) so says Az in the T: (Mgh:) or, as is [also] said by Az, it is in this instance twelve ounces and a naXR; the nXR being twenty [drAhm] so that the whole is five hundred drAhm; as is related on the authority of 'Áïsheh: but in a trad. 'Omar, twelve ounces, without the mention of the nXR: accord. to the lawyers, [however,] when the rTl is mentioned without restriction, what is meant thereby is the rTl of Baghdád: (TA:) [as a measure of capacity, i. e. a pint,] it is said in the A [&c.] to be the eighth part of the SaAE; the half of the mudR; (TA;) [i. e.] the half of the manR: and hence applied to one of the vessels of the vintner [app. because it contains a pint]: (Har p. 650:) pl. OaroTaAlN. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- See also raTolN, in two places.

muroTalN c
muroTalN: see raTolN: ― -b2- and see also what here follows.

muroTilN c
muroTilN, like muHosinN [in measure], (K,) written by Sgh with fet-h, (TA,) i. e. muroTalN↓, (so in the O,) A tall man. (O, K.) ― -b2- See also raTolN.

1 raTamahu c
1. raTamahu, (S, K, TA,) aor.
raTuma
, (TA,) inf. n. raTomN, (S, TA,) He made him to stich fast fiI AlwaHoli [in the mire]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (TA,) [or raTamahu fiI OamorK,] (tropical:) He caused him to be involved in an affair, or a case, from which he could not extricate himself. (K, TA.) ― -b3- [And hence, app.,] ruTima, said of a camel, (assumed tropical:) He had, or was affected with, a suppression of his excrement: (K, TA:) and so, accord. to the K, OuroTima↓; but this is a mistake for ATm [i. e. OuTima or OaTima]. (TA.) ― -b4- raTama bisaloHihi, expl. in the K as meaning He ejected his excrement, is a mistake for OaTama. (TA.) ― -b5- raTama, (S, K, TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) also signifies Inivit; (S, TA;) said of a man: (S:) or, [said of a man, and of an ass,] inivit toto veretro immisso, (K, TA,) mulierem, et asinam. (TA.)

4 ArTm c
4. ArTm (assumed tropical:) He was silent; (Sh, K;) said of a man. (Sh, TA.) ― -b2- See also 1.

5 taraTRama
5: see 8, last sentence.

6 taraAoTama
6: see the next paragraph.

8 ArtTm c
8. ArtTm He stuck fast fiI AlwaHoli [in the mire]. (TA.) You say, ArtTmt AldRaAbRapu fiI AlwaHoli [The beast stuck fast in the mire], and fI AlxabaAri [in the soft ground], (TA in art. tE,) and fI AlrRamoli [in the sand]. (S and K in that art.) And ArtTmt bihi farasuhu His mare's feet sank [in the mire, or soft ground, or sand,] with him. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (TA,) ArtTm fiI OamorK (tropical:) He became involved in an affair, or a case, from which he could not extricate himself (K, * TA) unless with confusion, or perplexity, cleaving to him. (TA.) ― -b3- And ArtTm Ealayohi OamorN, (S,) or AlOamoru, (K,) (tropical:) An affair, or a case, or the affair, or case, was such that he could not extricate himself from it; (S, K;) it wearied him, and the ways thereof were obstructed against him, so that he could not extricate himself from it. (TA.) ― -b4- And ArtTm It (a thing) was, or became, pressed together, or compressed: and it was, or became, heaped up, piled up, or accumulated, one part upon another; (K;) as also trATm↓. (TA.) ＝ -A2- ArtTm AlsRaloHa He suppressed, or retained, the excrement; as also trTRmhu↓. (K.)

ruTomapN c
ruTomapN (assumed tropical:) An affair of which one knows not the end, or result, to which it leads, or tends; (K, TA;) an affair in which one struggles, or is agitated, or disturbed; and so rTwmp↓ [app. ruTuwmapN]; as in the saying, waqaEa fiI ruTomapK and rTwmpK [He fell into an affair in which one struggles, &c.]. (TA.)

ruTaAmN c
ruTaAmN (assumed tropical:) Suppression of the excrement, in a camel. (K.)

raTuwmN c
raTuwmN A woman wide in the vulva; (S, TA;) as in the saying of a rájiz,
yaAQbona raTuwmK caAti farojK Eafolaqi
for he means [O son of] a woman wide in the vulva, having [a vulva with] much moisture; though F says, (TA,) it does not signify thus, but narrow in the vulva: (K, TA:) and applied to a she-camel, it has this latter meaning: (AA, K, TA:) and also, applied to a woman, impervia coëunti; syn. ratoqaMCu [q. v.]. (K.) ― -b2- Also Foolish; stupid; or unsound, or deficient, in intellect. (TA.) ― -b3- And White; applied to a domestic hen. (AA, TA.)

rTwmp c
rTwmp [app. ruTuwmapN]: see ruTomapN.

raATimN c
raATimN Keeping, cleaving, or adhering, to a thing. (S, K.)

maroTuwmapN c
maroTuwmapN Inita; applied to a young woman: or so applied, and also to a she-ass, inita toto veretro immisso. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, applied to a woman, Accused, or suspected, of evil. (K, * TA.)

1 raTana lahu c
1. raTana lahu, (S, K,) aor.
raTuna
, (MS, JM,) inf. n. raTaAnapN and riTaAnapN; (S, * K, * MA, MS, JM, TA;) and rATnhu↓, (S, K,) inf. n. muraATanapN; (TK;) He spoke to him biAlOaEojmiyRapi [i. e. with a barbarous, or vitious, speech]; (S, K;) or, correctly, accord. to Aboo-Zekereeyà, biAlEajamiyRapi [i. e. in a language foreign to the Arabs]: (TA: [and in like manner expl. in the MA and PS and TK:]) or, [as sometimes used,] in a language not generally understood, conventionally formed between two, or several, persons: (JM, TA:) [or he gibbered,
or uttered gibberish or jargon, to him: (see R. Q. 1 in art zm:)] and taraATanuwA↓ (S, K) fiymaA bayonahumo (S) They so spoke (&c.] (S, K) among themselves. (S.) A poet says, (S,) namely, Tarafeh, (TA,)
Alfurosi OaSowaAtuhumo kataraATuni↓
[Their voices were like the barbarous, or vitious, or rather the foreign, speech, among themselves, of the Persians]. (S.) ― -b2- You say also, raTana biXaIoCK, meaning He alluded to a thing, not mentioning its name explicitly, or unequivocally. (JM.)

3 raAoTana
3: see above, first sentence.

6 taraAoTana
6: see 1, in two places.

raTuwnN c
raTuwnN: see the next paragraph.

raTaAnapN c
raTaAnapN, (so in my copies of the S, [like the former of the two inf. ns. of raTana,] and so in copies of the K,) or raTRaAnapN, (so accord. to the TA, as from the K,) and raTuwnN↓, (S, K,) accord. to As, Camels when they are many, (TA,) or, accord. to Fr, camels when they are such as are termed rifaAq [pl. of rufoqapN], and have their owners with them: (S, TA:) or camels when they are many, and are such as are termed rifaAq, and have their owners with them: (K:) and accord. to As, they are also termed TaHRaAnapN and TaHuwnN: by rifaAq being meant those upon which people have gone forth to purvey for themselves wheat, or corn, or other provisions from the towns or villages; each, or every, company being a rufoqap. (TA.)

maA ruTayonaAka c
maA ruTayonaAka and ruTRayonaAka means maA AlcRaI taroTunu bihi [i. e. What is that to which thou alludest, not mentioning it explicitly?]: (JM:) or maA ruTRayonaAka hecihi, and sometimes without teshdeed, means What is [this] thy speech? (K.)

4 OaroTati AlOaroDu c
4. OaroTati AlOaroDu The land produced the kind of trees called OaroTFI [or OaroTaI; as also MraTat, belonging to art. ArT, q. v.]. (S.)

rawaATK c
rawaATK Sands producing the trees called OaroTaI or OaroTRI. (M.)

OaroTFI c
OaroTFI [or, as some say, OaroTaI]: see art. ArT: (K:) it is of the measure OafoEalN [or OafoEalu] for one reason, and faEolFI [or faEolaI] for another reason: for they say OadiymN maOoruwTN as well as maroTiIRN↓, meaning A hide tanned with the leaves of the tree called ArTI.

maroTiIRN c
maroTiIRN: see OaroTFI, above.

1 raERN c
1. raERN The being still, syn. sukuwnN, [a signification contr. to one borne by two other words in this art.,] (IAar, K,) is the inf. n. of raERati AlrRiyHu, aor.
raEuEa
, [probably a mistake for
raEiEa
, which is the regular form of an intrans. verb of this class, notwithstanding the guttural letter,] The wind was, or became, still. (TK.)

R. Q. 1 raEoraEahu c
R. Q. 1. raEoraEahu He (God) caused him [a child, or boy, as is implied in the S,] to grow. (S, Z, K.) ― -b2- raEoraEa daAbRatahu He (a horseman) rode his beast to train it when it was in the first stage of training and as yet refractory. (O, TS, K.) In IN the L we find UicaA lamo takuno rayRiDFA, [meaning when it was not trained, rayRiDFA being here used in the sense of maruwDapF,] in the place of UicaA kaAnato rayRiDFA, which is the reading in the O and TS and K. (TA.) ― -b3- [See also raEoraEapN, below.]

R. Q. 2 taraEoraEa c
R. Q. 2. taraEoraEa He (a child, or boy,) became active (taHarRaka), and grew, grew up, or became a young man, (S, K,) and some add, wakabira [and became big, or attained to full growth]. (TA.) [See its part. n., below.] ― -b2- taraEoraEati AlsRinRu The tooth became loose, and wabbled, or moved about. (K.) ― -b3- AlmaMCu yataraEoraEu fiI wajohi AlOaroDi, [or rather, EalaI wjh AlArD,] The water is in a state of commotion, or agitation, upon the surface of the ground. (TK.) And taraEoraEa AlsRaraAbu (assumed tropical:) The mirage was in a state of commotion, or agitation: being likened to water. (TA.)

raEaAEN c
raEaAEN Young men of the lowest, or basest, or meanest, sort, or of the refuse of mankind; or low, ignoble, mean, or sordid, young men, such as serve for the food of their bellies: (S, K:) or the lowest, basest, or meanest, sort, or refuse, of mankind, or people: or a medley, or mixed or promiscuous multitude or collection, of men, or people; or of the lowest or basest or meanest sort, or refuse, thereof: (Msb:) and raEaAEu AlnRaAsi the lowest, basest, or meanest, sort, or refuse, of mankind, or of the people; the medley of men, or of such men: (TA:) n. un. with p: (Msb, TA:) Az mentions his having read in the handwriting of Sh AlrEAE mn AlnAs, like AlzjAj [in form, app. meaning AlrRuEaAEu↓, like AlzRujaAju, for this is the most chaste form of the latter word, and the most usual with classical writers], as meaning the refuse, and weak, of mankind, or of the people, who, when frightened, fly. (TA.) ― -b2- [The n. un.] raEaAEapN signifies [also] One without heart and without intellect or intelligence. (AA, K.) ― -b3- And An ostrich; (Abu-l-'Omeythil, K;) because always as though frightened. (Abu-l-'Omeythil.)

ruEaAEN c
ruEaAEN: see raEaAEN.

raEaAEapN c
raEaAEapN n. un. of raEaAEN [q. v.].

raEoraEN c
raEoraEN: see raEoraAEN; each in three places.

ruEoruEN c
ruEoruEN: see raEoraAEN; each in three places.

raEoraEapN c
raEoraEapN [originally an inf. n. of R. Q. 1] A state of beautiful youthfulness, and activity, of a boy. (TA.) ― -b2- A state of commotion, or agitation, (IDrd, K,) of clear water, (K,) or of clear shallow water, (IDrd,) upon the surface of the ground. (IDrd, K.)

ruEoruEapN c
ruEoruEapN: see the next paragraph.

raEoraAEN c
raEoraAEN The tall reed or cane, or tall reeds or canes, (K, TA,) in the place of growth thereof, while fresh: so accord. to Az, as heard by him from the Arabs. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, as some say, or, accord. to others, from raEoraEapN in the latter of the two senses assigned to it above, A boy who has attained to youthful vigour, and justness of stature; as also raEoraEN↓: (TA:) or a youth, or young man, of goodly proportions, (S, K,) with beauty of youthfulness; (K;) as also raEoraEN↓ (S, K) and ruEoruEN↓: (Ibn-'Abbád, K:) or arriving at the age of puberty; (TA;) as also ruEoruEN↓ and ruEoruEapN↓: (Kr:) or who has become active, (taHarRaka,) and big, or of full growth: (TA:) [see also mutaraEoriEN:] the pl., (S, TA,) i. e. of raEoraEN↓ [and ruEoruEN↓] and raEoraAEN, (TA,) is raEaAriEu. (S, TA.) ― -b3- A coward. (El-Muärrij, K.) ― -b4- A certain plant: [perhaps the inula Arabica; now called raEoraAE OayRuwb; or, as Forskål (in his Flora Aegypt. Arab., pp. lxxiii. and 150,) designates the plant now thus called, inula dysenterica:] some say that this word is formed by transposition from EaroEaArN. (TA.)

mutaraEoriEN c
mutaraEoriEN applied to a boy, (Mgh, TA,) Almost, or quite, past the age of ten years: (Mgh:) or active; syn. mutaHarRikN. (TA.) [See its verb, R. Q. 2; and see also raEoraAEN.]

1 raEaba c
1. raEaba, aor.
raEaba
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. ruEobN (K, TA) and ruEubN, or the latter of these is a simple subst., (TA,) or each of them is a simple subst., (Msb, TA,) and the inf. n. is raEobN; (Msb;) and raEuba; and ruEiba, like EuniIa; both mentioned by 'Iyád and Ibn-Kurkool, and the last by ISk also; (TA;) and ArtEb↓; (K;) He feared; he was afraid or frightened or terrified: (Msb, K, TA:) or his bosom and heart were filled with fear: or he feared in the utmost degree; was in a state of the utmost terror. (TA.) ― -b2- raEaba said of a valley, [like zaEaba,] aor.
raEaba
, (assumed tropical:) It became filled with water. (L.) ― -b3- raEabati AlHamaAmapN, aor.
raEaba
; and rERbt↓, (K,) inf. n. taroEiybN; (A, TA;) (tropical:) The pigeon raised, and poured forth loudly, or vehemently, its cooing cry. (A, * K, TA.) You say HamaAmN lahu taroEiybN↓ (tropical:) Pigeons, or a pigeon, having a loud, or vehement, cooing. (A.) ― -b4- And raEaba, aor.
raEaba
, [inf. n. raEobN,] (assumed tropical:) He composed, or uttered, rhyming prose. (K.) ＝ -A2- raEabahu, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor. ruEobN, (A, K,) inf. n. raEobN (A, MA) and rERyhu, (MA,) He caused him, or made him, to fear, or be afraid; frightened, or terrified, him: (S, A, Msb, K:) or he filled his bosom and heart with fear: or he put him in the utmost fear, or terror: (TA:) and taroEiybN↓ signifies the same, (Lb, K,) inf. n. taroEaAbN and ArEbhu; (K;) and so does raEaba↓, accord. to Ibn-Talhah El-Ishbeelee, and Ibn-Hishám El-Lakhmee, and Fei in the Msb; but this is disallowed by IAar and Th and J. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] raEobN, aor.
raEaba
, [inf. n. raEobN,] signifies also He threatened. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- Also, aor.
raEaba
, (K,) inf. n. raEobN, (TA,) He charmed, or fascinated, by magical enchantment [or by the eye] or otherwise. (K, * TA.) ― -b4- Also, [like zaEaba,] (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
raEaba
, (K,)
inf. n. raEobN, (TA,) (tropical:) He filled (S, A, Msb, K) a watering-trough, or tank, (S, A,) or a vessel: (Msb:) and it (a torrent) filled a valley. (L, TA.) ＝ -A3- raEabahu, (K,) aor.
raEaba
, (TA,) also signifies He cut it [into pieces, or long pieces, or slices, (see tiroEiybapN, below,)], namely, a camel's hump, or other thing; and so rERbhu↓, (K, TA,) inf. n. taroEiybN. (TA.) ― -b2- And He broke its (an arrow's) ruEob [q. v.]. (K.)

2 raERaba
2: as an intrans. v.: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- The inf. n., taroEiybN, as relating to a camel's hump, accord. to Sh, signifies Its shaking, or quivering, and being fat and thick; as though it shook, or quivered, by reason of its fatness: but it is otherwise explained [as a subst. properly speaking] below. (TA.) ＝ -A2- raERabahu, inf. n. as above, and, in one sense, taroEaAbN also: see 1, in two places. ＝ -A3- Also, inf. n. taroEiybN, He repaired its (an arrow's) ruEob [q. v.]. (K.)

4 OaroEaba
4: see 1.

8 UirotaEaba
8: see 1, first sentence.

raEobN c
raEobN an inf. n. of 1, in senses pointed out above. (M, A, Msb, TA.) ― -b2- A threat, or threatening. (K.) ― -b3- A charm or charming, or a fascination or fascinating, by magical enchantment [or by the eye] or otherwise. (K.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) A rhyming prose of the Arabs. (K.)

ruEobN c
ruEobN (S, A, Msb, K) and ruEubN↓, (A, Msb, K,) both said to be inf. ns., (TA,) or the former is an inf. n. of raEaba as intrans. (K, TA) or as trans., (A, MA,) and the latter is a simple subst., (TA,) or each of them is a simple subst., (Msb, TA,) Fear, fright, or terror: (S, A, Msb, K:) or fear that fills the bosom and heart; as Er-Rághib and Z have indicated, following Aboo-'Alee and IJ: or the utmost fear or terror. (TA.) One says, faEala celika ruEobFA laA rugobFA He did that from fear, not from desire. (A.) ＝ -A2- Also the former, The socket of the head of an arrow; the part into which the head enters, over which are the twists of sinew; syn. ruEoZN: pl. riEabapN. (K.)

ruEubN c
ruEubN: see the next preceding paragraph.

ruEobabN c
ruEobabN: see ruEobuwbapN, last sentence.

ruEobubN c
ruEobubN: see tiroEiybapN.

ruEobwbN c
ruEobwbN: see raEiybN, in two places: ― -b2- and see also ruEobuwbapN.

riEobiybN c
riEobiybN: see what next follows.

ruEobuwbapN c
ruEobuwbapN (S, A, K) and ruEobuwbN↓ (K) and riEobiybN↓ (Seer, K) A woman, (S, A,) or a girl, or young woman, (K,) Tall, and well-formed; soft, thinskinned, and plump; (S, * A, K;) or (A, K) white, or fair; (S, A, K;) goodly, or beautiful; sweet; and tender: (A, K:) or only white, or fair: (TA:) or soft, or tender: (IAar, Lh, K:) and the first, tall: (TA:) pl. raEaAbiybN. (A, TA.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) or the first and second, (TA,) applied to a she-camel, Restless, or unsteady; (K, TA;) light, or active, brisk, lively, or sprightly. (TA.) ― -b3- For another meaning of the first, see tiroEiybapN. ― -b4- Also the first, The base, or lower part, (OaSol,) of the TaloEap [i. e. either the spathe, or the spadix, of a palm-tree]; and so ruEobabN↓. (K.)

raEiybN c
raEiybN Afraid, or frightened, or terrified: (K:) [or filled with fear: or in a state of the utmost fear or terror: (see 1:)] and so maroEuwbN↓, (S, K,) and muraERabN↓, and murotaEibN↓: (TA:) and ruEobuwbN↓ signifies [the same; or] weak and cowardly. (S, K.) [Hence,] rajulN raEiybu AlEayoni and maroEuwbuhaA↓ and ruEobuwbuhaA↓ (tropical:) A cowardly man, who sees nothing without being frightened. (A.) [ragiybu AlEayoni has a different meaning: see art rgb.] ― -b2- Also Fat, as an epithet; (K;) dripping with grease: (S, K:) and so muraEobibN↓. (K.) And applied to a camel's hump as meaning Full and fat. (S.) ― -b3- And Short; as also OaroEabu↓: pl. [of the former] ruEubN and [of the latter] ruEobN. (TA.)

raERaAbN c
raERaAbN: see what next follows.

raAEibN c
raAEibN and raERaAbN↓, [but the latter is an intensive epithet, or denotes habit, or frequency,] One who threatens; a threatener. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- One who charms, or fascinates, by magical enchantment [or by the eye] or otherwise. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- One who composes, or utters, the rhyming prose termed raEobN. (K, TA.) ― -b4- Also the former (rAEb), A torrent that fills the valley: (S:) or (tropical:) that frightens by its abundance and its width and its filling the valley. (A.) It is applied also to rain. (TA.) And A valley filled with water. (L.)

HamaAmN raAEibiIRN c
HamaAmN raAEibiIRN, (S, A,) or raAEibiyRapN, (K,) [or] the latter is the fem. form of the epithet, (S,) A certain kind of pigeons; (S;) accord. to the K, from a land called raAEibN [in the CK raEibN]; but this land is unknown, and is not mentioned by El-Bekree nor by the author of the Marásid; and in the Mj and other old works, AlHamaAmapu AlrRaAEibiyRapu is expl. as meaning (assumed tropical:) the pigeon that is loud, or strong, in its cry, or voice: so says MF; and this is the truth: in the L it is said, AlrRaAEibiIRu, meaning a kind of wild pigeons, or doves, has the form of a rel. n., but is not such; or, as some one says, is a rel. n. from a place of the name whereof I know not the form: in the A it is said that HamaAmN raAEibiIRN means a pigeon that cooes loudly, or vehemently, exciting admiration by its voice, or filling with it the passages thereof. (TA.)

OaroEabu c
OaroEabu: see raEiybN.

tiroEaAbN c
tiroEaAbN: see tiroEaAbapN.

tiroEiybN c
tiroEiybN and taroEiybN: see tiroEiybapN.

tiroEaAbapN c
tiroEaAbapN, (S, A, K,) in the Mj, and in [some of] the copies of the S, tiroEaAbN↓, without p, (TA,) Very fearful: (S:) or most exceedingly fearful (A, K, TA) of everything. (TA.) You say, huwa fiI AlsRilomi taloEaAbapN wafiI AlHarobi tiroEaAbapN [He is in peace most exceedingly playful, and in war most exceedingly fearful]. (A.)

tiroEiybapN c
tiroEiybapN A piece of a camel's hump; (S, K;) as also ruEobuwbapN↓ (K) and ruEobubN↓: (TA:) pl. tiroEiybN↓; (K;) or rather, accord. to AHei, this is a coll. gen. n.: (MF, TA:) it is also pronounced taroEiybN↓; (Sb, AHei;) and is said to signify a camel's hump cut into long pieces, or slices: it is a subst. [properly so termed], not an inf. n.: (TA:) and its t is shown to be augmentative by the fact that there is no [undisputed] word of the measure faEoliylN, with fet-h [to the f]. (MF, TA.)

maroEabapN c
maroEabapN A frightful qaforap [or desert destitute of herbage and of water]. (K. [In the CK and TA, qafozap is erroneously put for qaforap.]) ― -b2- Also A person's springing, or leaping, [towards another,] and seating himself by the other's side, so as to cause the latter, not being aware, to be frightened. (K. [From its measure, it seems to be a simple subst., not an inf. n., signifying this action as being A cause of fear.])

muraERabN c
muraERabN: see raEiybN. ＝ -A2- Also A camel's hump cut into pieces, (S, TA,) or into long pieces, or slices. (TA.)

muraEobibN c
muraEobibN: see raEiybN.

maroEuwbN c
maroEuwbN: see raEiybN, in two places.

murotaEibN c
murotaEibN: see raEiybN.

1 raEivato c
1. raEivato, aor.
raEava
, inf. n. raEavN; and raEavato, aor.
raEava
, inf. n. raEovN; (tropical:) She (a goat, K, TA, and a sheep, XaAp, TA) had white extremities to her zanamataAni [or two wattles] (K, TA) beneath the two ears. (TA.)

5 trERvt c
5. trERvt She (a woman) adorned herself with the [kind of ear-ring, or ear-drop, called] quroT (S, K, TA) and riEaAvN; (TA;) as also ArtEvt↓. (IJ, K, TA.)

8 UirotaEava
8: see what next precedes.

raEovN c
raEovN: see what next follows, in two places.

raEavN c
raEavN and raEavapN↓ and ruEovapN↓ are said to be applied to Anything suspended: or, accord. to some, only to the [kind of ear-ring, or ear-drop, called] quroT, and the [necklace called] qilaAdap, and the like: or, accord. to Az, riEaAvN↓ signifies anything suspended, such as the quroT, and the like, suspended from the ear; or the [necklace called] qilaAdap: and the pl. is raEovN↓ [or rather this is a quasi-pl. n.] and riEaAvN↓ [like the sing.] and ruEovN, which last is a pl. pl.: (TA:) or raEovapN↓ and raEavapN↓ signify the [kind of ear-ring, or ear-drop, called] quroT; (S, A, K, TA;) and any similar pendant to the ear: (TA:) or the rEvp is in the lower part of the ear; and the Xanof, in the upper part thereof; and the rEvp is a pearl, or large pearl, (durRapN,) attacked to the quroT: (IAar, TA:) and the pl. of raEovapN and raEavapN is riEaAvN (S, K, TA) and riEavapN. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] raEavN signifies [also] (tropical:) Wool, or wool died of various colours, (EihonN,) in a general sense: [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. raEavapN: (TA:) or, (S, A, K,) as also raEovN↓ and ruEovapN↓, (K,) such wool (EihonN) suspended to the [kind of
women's camel-vehicle called] hawodaj, (A'Obeyd, S, K, TA,) and the like, for ornament; like what are termed cabaAcib: (TA:) or [pendant] ornaments of the hawodaj, of the kind called cabaAcib, consisting of such wool. (A.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) The blossoms of the pomegranate-tree. (A.)

raEovapN c
raEovapN: see the next preceding paragraph. ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) The Euvonuwn [or wattle] of the cock, (S, K, TA,) that grows forth beneath the bill; i. e. its beard, or barb; (TA;) as also raEavapN↓: (K:) each of the two things that grow forth beneath the bill of the cock. (A.) You say, SaAHa cuwAlrRaEovataAni (tropical:) [The owner of the two wattles cried]; meaning the cock. (A.) And a poet says, (S,) namely, El-Akhtal, (TA,)
maA caA yuWarRquniI waAlnRawomu yuEojibuniI
mino Sawoti ciIraEavaAtK saAkini AldRaAri
[What is this that renders me wakeful, when sleep pleases me, of the voice of an owner of wattles, an inhabitant of the mansion?]. (S, TA. [Another reading, as well as the foregoing, of this verse is given in the Ham, p. 823.]) ― -b3- Also, (Ham ubi suprà,) or raEavapN↓, (L,) (assumed tropical:) The zanamap [or wattle], (Ham,) [i. e.] each of the zanamataAni [or two wattles], (L,) of a sheep or goat (XaAp) [or, accord. to some, of a goat only (see ranamapN)]. (Ham, L.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) A drinking-vessel, such as is called talotalapN, made of the spathe of a palm-tree; (T, M, L, K, TA;) as also raEavapN↓. (K.)

ruEovapN c
ruEovapN: see raEavN, in two places.

raEavapN c
raEavapN: see raEavN, in two places: ― -b2- and raEovapN, in three places.

XaApN raEovaMCu c
XaApN raEovaMCu (tropical:) A sheep, or goat, [or, accord. to some, a goat only (see zanamapN),] having two wattles (zanamataAni), beneath her two ears. (S, A, K.) ― -b2- And AlrRaEovaMCu (tropical:) A species of grape, having long berries; (K, TA;) likened to the zanamataAni [or two wattles of a sheep or goat]. (TA.)

riEaAvN c
riEaAvN: see raEavN, in two places.

muraERavN c
muraERavN A boy adorned with the [kind of earring, or ear-drop, called] raEovapN (S) or quroTN. (TA.) ― -b2- And [hence,] (tropical:) A cock having a raEovap [or wattle]. (S, TA.)

1 raEadati AlsRamaMCu c
1. raEadati AlsRamaMCu, (As, Fr, S, L, Msb,) aor.
raEuda
(L, Msb) and
raEada
, (L,) inf. n. raEodN and ruEuwdN; (Fr, L, Msb;) and OaroEadat↓, (AO, AA, S, L,) but the latter is disallowed by As; (S, TA;) The shy thundered: (S, Msb:) or made a sound [to be heard from the clouds] previously to rain: (L:) and [in like manner] raEada, aor.
raEada
and
raEuda
, is said of the clouds (AlsRaHaAb), or of the angel that drives the clouds. (K.) You say, raEadati AlsRamaMCu wabaraqato, and, accord. to AO and AA, waOaboraqat OaroEadat↓, (S, TA,) which latter As disallows in this case as well as in another mentioned below, (S, * TA,) meaning The sky [thundered and lightened: or] thundered and lightened much before rain. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] raEada, inf. n. raEodN, (tropical:) He threatened, or menaced, with evil; as also ArEd↓, inf. n. UiroEaAdN: (Msb:) or the latter signifies he threatened, or menaced; or he frightened, or terrified: (K:) and raEada wabaraqa he frightened, or terrified, (S, K,) and threatened, or menaced; (S;) as also OarEada↓ waOaboraqa: (AO, AA, S:) and raEadalahu and baraqa lahu he threatened him, or menaced him: (As, TA:) and raEada liI biAlqawoli, aor.
raEuda
, inf. n. raEodN; and ArEd↓; he threatened me, or he frightened me with speech: (TA:) or, accord. to As, ArEd↓ and Abrq are not allowable: when one cited against him the verse of El-Kumeyt,
OaroEido waOaboriqo yaA yaziydu famaA waEiyduka liI biDaAYiro
(tropical:) [Threaten and menace, O Yezeed, but thy threatening is not harming to me], he denied ElKumeyt to be an authority. (S, TA.) [See also an ex. in a verse cited voce jalRa.] Hiyna raEada AlUisolaAmu wabaraqa, occurring in a trad., means When El-Islám came with its threatening and its terrifying. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] raEadato wabaraqato (tropical:) She (a woman) beautified and adorned herself, (S, A, * K,) and showed, or presented, herself, liI to me: (A:) or she exhibited her beauty intentionally: (TA in art. brq:) and [some hold that] OaroEadato↓ [or OaroEadato waOaboraqato] signifies the same. (TA.) ― -b4- See also 8, in two places. ― -b5- And see 4.

4. ArEd He, or it, (a company of men, S, Msb,) was assailed, or affected, by thunder; (Lh, S, Msb, K;) as also ruEida↓: and the former, he heard thunder. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1, in seven places. ＝ -A2- ArEdhu He, or it, (fear, [or cold, see riEodapN,] &c., L,) caused him to tremble, quiver, quake, shiver, or be in a state of commotion. (S, * L.) ― -b2- See also 8, in two places. ― -b3- Also OuroEida (tropical:) It (a hill, or heap, of sand) poured down; or became [shaken, and consequently] poured down. (IAar, K, TA.)

5 taraERada
5: see the next paragraph, in two places.

8 ArtEd c
8. ArtEd He trembled, quivered, quaked, shivered, or became in a state of commotion, (S, A, L, Msb, K,) by reason of fear, (A, L,) or cold, (A,) &c.; (L;) as also rEd, aor. yrEd: (Msb: [written in my copy without any syll. signs; but it seems to be indicated that it is raEada↓ aor. yaroEudu: I believe, however, that ruEida↓ is also used in this sense, and in the sense here following:]) he was affected with a tremour, quivering, quaking, shivering, or commotion; (A, L;) as also OuroEida↓, (S, A, L, K,) and taraEodada↓, (L,) and trERd↓; (TA;) by fear, (A, L,) or cold, (A,) &c. (L.) You say, faraAYiSuhu Einoda OuroEidato↓ AlfazaEi (tropical:) [His muscles called the frAYSa (pl. of fariySapN q. v.) quivered on the occasion of fright]. (S, A, * L.) And AlOaloyapu taraERadati↓, (K,) or, as in some of the Lexicons, taraEodadat↓, (TA,) (tropical:) The Alyp [or buttock, or buttocks, &c.,] quivered, or moved to and fro: (K, TA:) and in like manner one says of anything subject to such motion; as [the kinds of food called] qariys and faAluwc, and a hill or heap of sand, and the like. (TA.)

R. Q. 1 raEodada c
R. Q. 1. raEodada He was importunate in asking, or begging. (S.)

R. Q. 2 taraEodada c
R. Q. 2. taraEodada: see 8, in two places.

raEodN c
raEodN Thunder; i. e. the sound that is heard from the clouds, (S, K, *) or from the sky: (A:) so say the people of the desert: (Akh, TA:) [thus termed as being supposed to be a trembling, or state of agitation, of the clouds, as is implied in the Ksh and the Expos. of Bd in ii. 18, where it is said to be from AlAirotiEaAd, or as being a cause of trembling:] originally an inf. n., and therefore [it is said that] it has no pl.: (Bd ubi suprà:) [but see what follows, in which ruEuwdN occurs, perhaps as its pl.:] or AlrRaEodu is the name of an angel who drives the clouds [with his voice] like as a man drives camels with singing. (I'Ab, Z, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] jaMCa bicaAti AlrRaEodi waAlSRaliyli i. e. (assumed tropical:) [He brought, or brought to pass, that which had thunder and noise; meaning,] (tropical:) war: (S, K, TA:) or calamity: (A, TA:) and bicawaAti AlrRawaAEidi↓ (tropical:) calamities: (A:) [for] caAtu AlrRawaAEidi↓ [in the CK cawAtu] signifies calamity. (S, K, TA.) And fiI kitaAbihi ruEuwdN waburuwqN [which may be rendered In his letter are thunders and lightnings;] meaning, (tropical:) words of threatening. (A.)

raEodapN c
raEodapN: see what next follows.

riEodapN c
riEodapN A tremour, quivering, quaking, shivering, or commotion, (S, A, L, Msb, K,) occasioned by fear, (A, L,) or cold, (A,) &c.; (L;) and raEodapN↓ signifies the same. (K.)

riEodiydN c
riEodiydN Cowardly; (S, A, L, K;) that trembles, or quakes, (A, L,) from fear, (A,) or at fighting, by reason of cowardice; (L;) and in like manner riEodiydapN applied to a woman: (A:) or this has the former signification, [but in an intensive sense,] as also tiroEiydN↓: pl. [of the first or second] raEaAdiydu. (L.) ― -b2- Also the first, (S, K,) or second, (A, L,) applied to a woman, (S, L, K,) or a girl, (A,) (tropical:) Soft, or tender; (S, A, L, K;) whose flesh quivers by reason of its softness: (L:) pl. as above. (A.) ― -b3- And the first, (assumed tropical:) A soft, or tender, plant. (IAar, TA.) ― -b4- And [(tropical:) Anything quivering or quaking: hence, as a subst., particularly applied to The kind of sweet food called] faAluwcaj, (A,) or faAluwc. (K.) It was said to an Arab of the desert, “ Dost thou know what is called fAlwc? ” and he answered, naEamo OaSofaru riEodiydN [Yes: it is yellow, quivering]. (S.) ― -b5- Also, (A,) and muroEadN↓, (IAar, A, K,) (tropical:) A hill, or heap, of sand [shaking, or shaken, and consequently] pouring down. (IAar, A, K.)

ruEayodaMCu c
ruEayodaMCu What is thrown away from wheat when it is picked, or cleansed, (L, K,) as the zuwaAn [or zuWaAn, q. v.,] and the like: by some written rgydMC; but the former is more correct. (L.)

raERaAdN c
raERaAdN [That thunders much]. saHaAbapN raERaAdapN signifies A cloud that thunders much: (TA:) but Ks says, “ We have not heard them say thus. ” (Lh, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] applied to a man, (S,) (assumed tropical:) Loquacious; (S, K;) and so raERaAdapN [but in an intensive sense]. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, [as a coll. gen. n., n. un.
with p, The torpedo: and the silurus electricus, found in the Nile: generally meaning the latter:] a certain fish; when a man touches it, a numbness affects his hand and arm to the shoulders, and a tremour, as long as the fish remains alive: (S, K: *) so called because he who lays hold upon it, when it is alive, trembles with a kind of trembling wherewith he cannot restrain himself; it is a kind of trembling with a coldness, or chilness, and intense numbness, and formication in the limbs, and heaviness, so that he possesses no power over himself, and cannot lay hold of anything at all with his hand; the numbness rising by degrees to his upper arm and his shoulderblade and the whole of his side, when he touches the fish with the slightest touch in the shortest time. (So says 'Abd-El-Lateef. [See “ Abdollatiphi Hist. Aeg. Comp. ” p. 82; and De Sacy's Translation and Notes.])

saHaAbN raAEidN c
saHaAbN raAEidN [Thundering clouds]: and saHaAbapN raAEidapN [a thundering cloud]: (A:) pl. of the fem. rawaAEidu. (Ham p. 440.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce UimRaA.] SalafN taHota AlrRaAEidapi [A lack, or paucity, of rain beneath the thundering cloud], (S, K,) or rubRa SalifK taHota AlrRaAEidapi, (S and K &c. in art. Slf,) or rubRa SalafK (A, and S and K &c. in art. Slf,) [i. e., accord. as we read SalifK or SalafK, Many a cloud lacking, or having little, rain, or oftentimes a lack, or paucity, of rain, is there beneath the thundering cloud,] is a prov., (A,) applied to a loquacious man destitute of good: (S, A, K:) or to a loquacious man who speaks much of that which he has not done: (Nh, TA:) or to one who threatens and does not perform: (S and O and K in art. Slf:) or to the wealthy niggard: (A'Obeyd, K in that art.:) or to him who praises himself much and is destitute of good. (IDrd, K in that art.) ― -b2- See also raEodN, in two places.

muroEadN: see riEodiydN.

muraEodidN Importunate in asking, or begging. (K.)

maroEazN c
maroEazN and maroEizRN: see what here follows.

miroEizRaI c
miroEizRaI (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and maroEizRaI (S, K) and miroEizaMCu↓ and maroEizaMCu (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and miroEizRN↓ (S, Msb, K) and maroEizRN (S, K) and maroEazN↓, the last like jaEofarN, but not miroEizN, (Msb,) The down, (S, Msb, K,) or what resembles wool, (Az, Mgh,) that is beneath, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) or amid, (Az,) the hair of the she-goat: (Az, S, Mgh, Msb, K:) Sb makes miroEizRaI an epithet; meaning soft, applied to wool: and Kr says that this and miroEizaMCu are the only words of these two measures in the language: (TA:) [he seems to have held the m to be a radical letter: but accord. to J,] mrEzRI is of the measure mafoEilRaI, because faEolilRaI does not occur [except in the instance of XifoSilRaI, the name of a certain plant]. (S.)

maroEizaMCu c
maroEizaMCu: see what immediately precedes.

raEaXa
; and raEaXa, aor.

; (A, K;) inf. n. (of the former, S) raEaXN; (S, K;) and [of the latter,] raEoXN; (K;) He trembled, quivered, quaked, or shivered; (S;) as also ArtEX↓: (S, A, * K:) or he was taken with a tremour, quivering, quaking, or shivering: (A, K:) [or he was made to tremble, &c.; for] raEiXato yaduhu is like OuroEiXato↓ [His hand, or arm, was made to tremble, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b4- fulaAnN raEiXN UilaI AlqitaAli, and UilaI AlmaEoruwfi; (En-Nadr, A, K, TA;) and riEoXiyXN↓; (K;) (tropical:) Such a one is quick to fight, and to do good, or confer a favour or benefit. riEoXapN: see ruEaAXN, in two places. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) Haste, or quickness. (A, TA.) You say, bihi riEoXapN UilaI liqaMCi EaduwRihi (tropical:) In him is haste, or quickness, to meet his enemy. (A.)

raEiyXN c
raEiyXN: see raEiXN.

, inf. n. raEaZN, It (an arrow) had its ruEoZ broken; its ruEoZ broke. (S.)

ruEoZN The socket of the head of an arrow, or place into which the head enters, over which are the twists of sinew: pl. OaroEaAZN. (Lth, S, K.) It is said in a prov., UinRa fulaAnFA layakosiru Ealayoka OaroEaAZa AlnRaboli [Verily such a one breaks against thee the sockets of the heads of the arrows]: applied to him whose anger is vehement: as though one said, when he takes the arrow, (K, TA,) being vehemently angry, (TA,) he strikes the ground with its point, in his silent wrath, with such vehemence as to break the socket of its head: or it means (tropical:) he grates the teeth at thee, (K, TA,) by reason of the vehemence of his anger, so that their sockets break; (TA;) the sockets of the dog-teeth being
thus likened to the sockets of arrow-heads: (K, TA:) so in the O and L. (TA.) And it is said in another prov., maA qadarotu EalaI kacaA HatRaI taEaTRafato EalaIRa OaroEaAZu AlnRaboli [I was not able to do such a thing until the sockets of the heads of the arrows became much bent against me]. (O, K.)

raEiZN c
raEiZN An arrow having its ruEoZ broken: (S:) and [in like manner,] marEuwZN↓ an arrow having its ruEoZ broken, and being therefore bound with sinew: (IB:) or the latter signifies a weak arrow. (Aboo-Kheyreh El-'Adawee, Ibn-' Abbád.)

maroEuwZN c

raEafa
and

, (S, K,) inf. n. raEofN, (TK,) He (a horse) preceded; went, or got, before; outwent, outran, or outstripped; as also AstrEf↓, (S, K,) and ArtEf↓. (K.) [This is held by some, and is said in the O, to be the primary signification: see ruEaAfN.] ― -b2- raEifa AldRamu, aor.
raEafa
, The blood flowed. (K.) And raEafa Oanofuhu His nose bled; blood flowed from his nose: this is the chaste form of the verb: ruEifa, from which is formed the part. n. maroEuwfN, is incorrect; (Mgh;) unknown to As: (O:) [or] raEafa alone, aor.

; and ruEifa [mentioned above as incorrect]; (K;) and the inf. n. is raEofN (Msb, K) and ruEaAfN, (K,) or the latter is a simple subst. (Msb.) (O.) ― -b2- [And He, or it, made his nose to bleed, or flow with blood: often used in this sense; as in the S and A and K voce Oanovara, and in the L and K voce laboxapN: and so rERfh↓: accord. to Ibn-Maaroof,] the inf. ns. [Its upper part overflows, or overflowing, by reason of its fulness]. (S.)

[Golius, as on this authority, explains the verb as signifying “ Nasum prehendit: ” but the inf. n. is explained in the KL by the words xwn brMwrdn Az bynI; which I have rendered above.]) ― -b3- [Hence,] AstrEf AlHaSaI manosima AlbaEiyri (assumed tropical:) The pebbles made the toe, or sole, or foot, of the camel to bleed. (O.) ― -b3- The extremity of the Oaronabap [or lower portion, or lobule, of the nose]; (S, O, K;) [because the blood drops from it when the nose bleeds.] (S, K.) ― -b4- And [hence,] (assumed tropical:) A prominence, or projecting part, of a mountain. (S, O, K.) ― -b5- rimaAHN rawaAEifu Spears that are the first to thrust, or pierce: or from which blood is dropping: (S:) or spears are termed rawaAEifu because thrust forward to pierce, or because blood drops from them. (IDrd, O.)

(S, O, K.) It is said in a trad., “ When he (Mohammad) was enchanted, his charm was put into the spathe (jufR) of a palm-tree, and buried beneath the rAEwfp of the well. ” (S, O.)

raEuna

,] inf. n. [of the first] ruEuwnapN, and [of the second, or second and third,] raEanN, (S, * K,) He was, or became, foolish, stupid, unsound in intellect or understanding, or deficient therein, and lax, flaccid, slack, or languid: (S, K:) or ruEuwnapN and raEanN signify the being foolish, or stupid: and also the being soft, weak, relaxed, or languid. [And accord. to Freytag, as on the authority of Meyd, Haste of pace.] ― -b3- And ruEuwnapN signifies also The being beautified, and adorned: and raEanN, the displaying oneself adorned. (KL.) ＝ -A2- raEanatohu AlXRamosu, (S, K,) inf. n. raEonN, (KL,) The sun rendered him relaxed, (S, KL,) or weak, or languid: (KL:) or pained his brain, so that he became relaxed thereby, and swooned. (K.) And ruEina He (a man) became thus affected by the sun. (TA.) Pass. part. n. maroEuwnN↓, signifying Thus affected by the sun; (S, TA;) applied to a man. (TA.)

4 maA OaroEanahu c
4. maA OaroEanahu How foolish, stupid, unsound in intellect or understanding, or deficient therein, and lax, flaccid, slack, or languid, [or how foolish, or stupid, and how soft, weak, relaxed, or languid, (see 1,)] is he! (S, K.)

raEonN c
raEonN A prominence, or projecting part, (S, K,) or such as is large, (TA,) of a mountain: (S, K:) pl. ruEuwnN and riEaAnN. (S, K.) And A long mountain: (K:) or, accord. to Lth, a mountain that is not long: pl. ruEuwnN. (TA.)

raEanRaka c
raEanRaka a dial. var. of laEalRaka. (Lh, K.)

raEuwnN c
raEuwnN Having much motion; or moving itself much. (K.) ― -b2- And Hard, or strong. (K.) ＝ -A2- And (as some say, TA) The darkness of night: (K, TA:) or [simply] darkness. (TA.)

raAEinaA c
raAEinaA in the phrase laA taquwluwA raAEinaA, in the Kur [ii. 98, and occurring again in iv. 48], is said to be a word meant to convey a reviling of the Prophet, derived from [the inf. n.] AlrRuEuwnapu: El-Hasan read raAEinFA, with tenween: and Th says that the phrase means Say not ye a lie, and mockery, and foolishness. (TA.) [See also 4 in art. rEI.]

OaroEanu c
OaroEanu, (S, K,) applied to a man, (S,) Foolish, stupid, unsound in intellect or understanding, or deficient therein, and lax, flaccid, slack, or languid: (S, K:) or, so applied, foolish, or stupid: (KL:) [and also soft, weak, relaxed, or languid: (see 1:)] and foolish, or stupid, and hasty, in speech: (K:) fem., applied to a woman, raEonaMCu: (S:) [pl. ruEonN.] ― -b2- [Its primary application, though I do not find it mentioned, is probably to a mountain, as meaning Having a raEon, or prominence, or projecting part: accord. to Freytag, “ is qui habet rEn: ” and then poetically used, in the Deewán of Jereer, as signifying a mountain. ― -b3- And hence,] also, applied to a man, (assumed tropical:) Having a long nose [likened to a raEon]. (TA.) ― -b4- Also (assumed tropical:) An army having redundant parts, or portions, (K, TA,) like the riEaAn of mountains: (TA:) or an army has this epithet applied to it as being likened to the raEon of a mountain: or, as some say, the epithet thus applied means in a state of commotion by reason of its numerousness. (S.) ― -b5- El-Basrah is termed AlrRaEonaMCu, as being likened to the raEon of a mountain; (IDrd, S, K;) i. e., because of a bend in it: (TA:) or because of the abundant flow of the river there, and its sultry heat: (Az, MF:) or because of the ease and plenty that are in it, and as being likened to the woman to whom this epithet is applied; or because of the languidness and changeableness of its air. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b6- And AlrRaEonaMCu is also a name of A sort of grapes, of Et-Táïf, (K, TA,) white, and long in the berries. (TA.) ＝ -A2- OaroEanu mino hawaMCi AlbaSorapi is a prov., meaning More unsteady and changeable than the air of El-Basrah. (Meyd.)

maroEuwnN c
maroEuwnN: see 1, last sentence.

1 raEaA c
1. raEaA, aor. yaroEuw, (S, TA,) [He refrained, forbore, or abstained: or, used elliptically,] he refrained, forbore, or abstained, (S, TA,) from things, or affairs, (S,) or from ignorance, and reverted therefrom in a good manner; (TA;) [as also AiroEawaI↓; (K;) [for] raEowN and riEowN and ruEuwN (K) and raEowapN and riEowapN (S, K) and ruEowapN (K) are syn. with AiroEiwaMCN↓ (S, K) meaning the refraining, forbearing, or abstaining, from ignorance, and reverting therefrom in a good manner, (K, TA,) [all app. as inf. ns.,] and so are raEuwaI↓ (S, K) and ruEowaI↓ (K) and ruEoyaA↓, (S, K,) [in the last of which the radical w is changed into I as it is in dunoyaA and EuloyaA and quSoyaA,] but these three, as some say, (TA,) or the first and last of these three, (S,) are simple substs.: (S, TA:) you say, fulaAnN Hasanu AlrRaEowapi and AlrRiEowapi and AlrRaEowaI↓ [&c., meaning Such a one is good in respect of refraining, &c.]. (S.) AiroEawaI↓ is of the measure AifoEalala [for AifoEalRa]; the two infirm letters not being incorporated, one into the other, because the I is quiescent: (S: [see also Ham p. 220:]) you say, Eani AlqabiyHi ArEwI↓, (S, Msb,) or En Aljaholi, (Ham ubi suprà,) He refrained, forbore, or abstained, from bad, or foul, conduct, (S, Msb,) or from ignorance, and reverted therefrom: (Ham:) and ArEwI↓ [alone] signifies He refrained, forbore, or abstained; and he repented: (Har p. 240:) [see also an ex. in a verse cited voce OalaA:] accord. to AHei, it is quasi-pass. of raEawotuhu. (TA.) ＝ -A2- [Hence, raEawotuhu app. signifies I caused him to refrain, forbear, or abstain, &c.]

9 AiroEawaI c
9. AiroEawaI, inf. n. AiroEiwaMCN: see the preceding paragraph, in five places.

raEowaI c
raEowaI and ruEowaI: see 1, in three places: ― -b2- and see also art. rEI.

ruEoyaA c
ruEoyaA: see 1: ― -b2- and see also art. rEI.

raEaAwaI c
raEaAwaI and ruEaAwaI: see art. rEI.

raEaAwiyRapN c
raEaAwiyRapN (in some copies of the K raEaAwiyap, without teshdeed); and ruEaAwiyRapN: see art. rEI.

OaroEuwRapN c
OaroEuwRapN: see art. rEI.

OaroEaAwiyRapN c
OaroEaAwiyRapN: see art. rEI.

1 raEati AlmaAXiyapu c
1. raEati AlmaAXiyapu, aor. taroEaI, (Msb, K,) inf. n. raEoIN (S, * Msb, K) and riEaAyapN (K) and maroEFI; (S, * K, * JM;) and ArtEt↓, and trERt↓; (K;) The cattle [pastured, or] pastured by themselves. (Msb.) And raEati AlmaAXiyapu AlkalaOa, inf. n. raEoIN (Mgh, TA) and riEaAyapN [and maroEFI]; and ArtEt↓, and trERt↓; [The cattle pastured upon, or depastured, the herbage;] all signifying the same: (TA:) and of a camel you say, raEaI AlkalaOa binafosihi, inf. n. raEoIN [&c., He pastured upon, or depastured, the herbage by himself]; and in like manner ArtEI↓.
