(S.) ― -b2- The saying of 'Áïsheh faUino kaAnato taroEaI maA hunaAlika is an allusion to the feeling, or touching, of the faroj itself. (Mgh.) ＝ -A2- raEoIN also signifies The keeping, or tending, animals; pasturing, or feeding, them; and defending them from the enemy. (Er-Rághib, TA.) You say, raEayotu AlUibila, (S,) or AlmaAXiyapa, (Msb, K,) or Alganama, (MA,) aor. OaroEaAhaA, (S, Msb,) inf. n. raEoIN (S, MA) [and riEaAyapN, as appears from a phrase mentioned below,] and riEoyapN, (MA,) or this last is a simple subst. from this verb, (K,) I [kept, or tended, or] pastured, (MA, Msb,) or lead to pasture, (MA,) the camels, (S,) or the cattle, (Msb, K,) or the sheep or goats; (MA;) and ArEAhA↓ signifies the same as raEaAhaA. (K.) And SinaAEatuhu riEaAyapu AlUibili [His habitual work, or occupation, is the tending, or pasturing, of camels]. (ISd, K.) And fulaAnN yaroEaI Oabiyhi [Such a one tends, or pastures, for his father;] i. e. yaroEaI ganamahu [tends, or pastures, his father's sheep or goats]. (S.) ― -b2- And hence, as also riEaAyapN, The keeping or guarding [a person or thing]; being mindful or regardful [of him or it]; and managing or ruling or governing [him or it]. (Er-Rághib, TA.) You say, raEayotuhu I kept, or guarded, him, as a ruler or governor, or a prince or commander, who manages, conducts, orders, or regulates, the affairs of the people: (Msb:) and raEaI AlOamiyru raEiyRatahu [The prince ruled, or governed, his subjects], inf. n. riEaAyapN. (S.) And raEoyFA laka [I beg God's keeping, or guarding, for thee]; meaning raEaAka QllRehu May God keep thee, or guard thee. (Har p. 617.) And raEaI Oamorahu, (K,) inf. n. raEoIN (TA) [and riEaAyapN], He was mindful, or regardful, of his affair, or case; as also Amrh rAEI↓, (K, TA,) inf. n. muraAEaApN. (TA.) And riEaMCN [app. as an inf. n. of rAEI↓] signifies The guarding of palm-trees. (TA.) famaA raEawohaA HaqRa riEaAyatihaA, in the Kur [lvii. 27], means But they did not observe it with its right, or due, observance; were not mindful, watchful, observant, or regardful, of it, in the right, or due, manner of being so. (TA.) You say also, raEayotu Ealayohi Huromatahu, inf. n. riEaAyapN, (ISk, S,) i. e. 1 was mindful, regardful, or observant, of his Hrmp [meaning of what was entitled to reverence, respect, honour, or defence, in his character and appertenances]: and in like manner, muraAEaApN↓ AlHuquwqi, mentioned in the S, means The being mindful, regardful, or observant, of rights, or dues. (PS.) This last phrase is from raAEayotuhu↓, inf. n. muraAEaApN, (TA,) which means I regarded him; had regard, or an eye, to him; or paid regard, or consideration, to him; (S, Msb, K, TA;) acting, or behaving, well to him; doing good to him; or conferring a benefit, or benefits, upon him. (K, TA.) [Hence also, fiyhi kacaA ruwEiIa↓ Regard is had, in it, (the meaning of a word or phrase,) to such a thing, as alluded to therein.] And AlOamora raAEayotu↓, (S, K,) inf. n. muraAEaApN, (TA,) signifies also I looked to see what would be the issue, or result, of the affair, or case. (S, Msb, K.) Hence, accord. to Er-Rághib, AlnRujuwmi muraAEaApu↓: (TA:) you say, raEaI AlnRujuwma; (S, K;) and raAEaAhaA↓, (K,) inf. n. muraAEaApN; (TA;) He watched the stars, (S, K, TA,) waiting for the time when they would disappear. (K, TA.) El-Khansà says,
OaroEaI AlnRujwma wamaA kulRifotu riEoyatahaA↓
wataArapF OatagaXRaI faDola OaTomaAriI
[I watch, or I watching, the stars, waiting for the time when they will, or would, disappear, though I am not, or I was not, tasked with the watching of them; and at one time I cover myself, or covering myself, with the redundant parts of my old and worn-out garments]. (S.) ― -b3- riEaAyapN also signifies The being faithful to an engagement, or promise; syn. wafaMCN. (Mgh. [See raAEK, below; last sentence.])

2 rERAhu c
2. rERAhu, inf. n. taroEiyapN, He said [of him], raEaAhu QllRehu [May God keep him, or guard him: or he said to him, raEaAka QllRehu May God keep thee, or guard thee]. (TA.)

3 rAEI AlHimaAru AlHumura c
3. rAEI AlHimaAru AlHumura The ass pastured with the [other] asses: (S, K:) and in like manner one says of camels with wild animals. (TA.) ― -b2- rAEt AlOaroDu, a reading required by the context in the K, is wrong; the correct phrase being ArEt AlOaroDu [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 1, in the latter half of the paragraph, in eight places. ― -b4- AlmuraAEaApu is also syn. with AlmunaAZarapu [app. as meaning The looking towards, or facing, a person or thing: a signification nearly like the last referred to in the
sentence here immediately preceding]. (TA.) ― -b5- See also 4, in three places. ― -b6- warRiEi AllRiSRa walaA turaAEihi, in a trad. of 'Omar, means Restrain thou the thief, or make him to refrain, from taking thy goods, but bear not witness against him: so says Lth: or the meaning is, and do not wait for him. (TA.)

4 ArEI AlmaAXiyapa c
4. ArEI AlmaAXiyapa i. q. raEaAhaA: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph. Said of God, it means He caused to grow, for the cattle, that upon which they might pasture. (S.) One says also ArEt AlOaroDu, [as though AlmaAXiyapa or the like were understood] The land abounded [as though it fed abundantly] with herbage: (Zj, K:) rAEt AlOaroDu, in this sense [as stated above, see 3,] is wrong. (TA.) And ArEAhu AlmakaAna He made the place to be a pasturage for him. (ISd, K.) ― -b2- OarEayotuhu samoEiI means I made my ear, or ears, to be mindful of his speech: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or I gave ear, hearkened, or listened, to him. (S, Msb.) You say, OaroEiniI samoEaka, (Msb, K,) and raAEiniI↓, i. e. Hearken thou, or listen thou, to my speech. (K.) Hence raAEinaA↓ in the Kur [ii. 98 and iv. 48]: Akh says that it is of the form faAEilonaA from AlmuraAEaApu, and means OaroEinaA samoEaka; the I having gone away because it is an imperative: he says also that it is read raAEinFA, as an objective complement, from AlrRuEuwnapu: (S: [see art. rEn:]) the reading in Ibn-Mes'ood's copy of the Kur-án is raAEuwnaA. (TA.) You say also, huwa laA yuroEiI UilaI qawoli OaHadK He will not pay any regard, or attention, to the saying of any one. (TA.) ― -b3- And OaroEayotu Ealayohi I showed mercy to him [by sparing him, or letting him live, or by pardoning him, or otherwise]; had mercy on him; pitied, or compassionated, him; syn. Oaboqayotu Ealayohi and taraHRamotuhu. (S, K.) Aboo-Dahbal says,
Uino kaAna hecaA AlsRiHoru minoki falaA
turoEiI EalaIRa wajadRidiI siHoraA
[app. meaning If this enchantment be from thee, then spare me not, but renew enchantment]. (TA. [It seems to be there cited as an instance of the verb's having a second objective complement; (for which I see no reason;) following the assertion that one says, OaroEaI Ealayohi kacaA, signifying AbqI; and that the verb is made trans. by means of ElI as properly meaning ArEAh mtTlEA Elyh: but I doubt not that the correct reading is OaroEaAhu muTRaliEFA Ealayohi, i. e. He showed mercy to him, coming to him, or getting sight and knowledge of him.]) AlmuraAEaMpu↓, also, [or AlmuraAEaApu EalaI AlXRaIoCi,] signifies AlUiboqaMCu EalaI AlXRaIoCi. (TA.)

5 taraERaIa
5: see 1, first and second sentences.

8 UirotaEaIa
8: see 1, in three places, first two sentences.

10 AstrEI c
10. AstrEI [app. signifies He desired cattle to pasture: and hence, he left them to pasture alone]. You say, AisotaroEayotu maAliIa Alqamara, meaning I left my cattle to pasture without a pastor to take care of them in the night: and [in like manner,] AstrEythu AlXRamosa, in the day. (TA in art. qmr.) ― -b2- AisotaroEayotuhu AlXRaIoCa (S, K *) I asked him, or desired him, to keep or guard, or be mindful of or regardful of, the thing. (K, * TA.) Hence the prov., mani QsotaroEaI AlcRiYoba faqado Zalama [He who asks, or desires, the wolf to keep guard does wrong]; (S, TA;) i. e. he who trusts in one who is treacherous puts trust in a wrong place. (TA.) [And hence also,] AisotaroEaI AlOasomaAEa lixuTobatihi He asked, or desired, the ears [meaning the hearers] to mind his discourse, or oration. (Har p. 361.)

riEoIN c
riEoIN and maroEFI↓ Pasture, or herbage; (S, Mgh, K;) the food of beasts: (Msb:) pl. of the former OaroEaMCN [meaning kinds, or sorts, of pasture or herbage]: (K:) and of ↓the latter maraAEK. (Msb.) It is said in a prov., walaA kaAlsRaEodaAni maroEFI↓ [Pasture, but not like the sEdAn: see art. sEd]. (S.) ― -b2- riEoIu AlHamaAmi waAlUibili A certain herb, having berries like myrtle-berries, in which is the least degree of sweetness; not injurious to the camels that feed upon it, but poison to [venomous or noxious reptiles or the like, such as are termed] hawaAmR: the decoction thereof blackens the hair. (Ibn-Seenà, book ii. p. 252.)

riEoyapN c
riEoyapN a subst. from 1 in the first of the senses mentioned in this art.; i. e. [The act of cattle's pasturing, or their pasturing alone,] from raEati AlmaAXiyapu. (K.) ― -b2- [Also The act, or occupation, of keeping or tending, or of pasturing or feeding, animals.] You say [of a man], yujiydu riEoyapa AlUibili [He performs well the act of keeping or tending, or of pasturing or feeding, camels]. (S, K.) ― -b3- [And The act of watching, and waiting for the time of the disappearance, of the stars.] See a verse cited near the end of the first paragraph. ＝ -A2- Also Land in which are projecting stones that impede the plough. (K, TA.)

raEowaI c
raEowaI and ruEowaI: see the next paragraph. ― -b2- [Both seem to be also substs. from OaroEayotu Ealayohi; and thus to be syn. with baqowaI and buqowaI; and in like manner, ruEoyaA↓ is probably syn. with buqoyaA: the radical I being changed into w as it is in bqwI.] You say, maA liI Ealayohi raEowaI walaA baqowaI [I have no mercy nor pity to bestow upon him]. (JK in art. bqI. [See buqoyaA.]) See also 1 in art. rEw [from which raEowaI in this phrase may also with reason be regarded as derivable].

ruEoyaA c
ruEoyaA a subst. from raEaI as used in the phrase raEaI Oamorahu [expl. in the first paragraph; thus signifying Mindfulness, regardfulness, or observance, of an affair, or a case]; as also raEowaI↓ and ruEowaI↓. (K.) ― -b2- See also the next preceding paragraph. And see art. rEw.

raEiIRN c
[raEiIRN Pastured: ruled, or governed: and kept, or guarded: so accord. to Golius, as on the authority of the KL; but not in my copy of that work. It is agreeable with analogy as syn. with maroEiIRN: and from it is formed the subst. next following.]

raEiyRapN c
raEiyRapN [with p affixed lilnRaqoli, i. e., to transfer the word from the category of epithets to that of substantives,] Cattle pasturing, or pasturing by themselves: and cattle kept, tended, or pastured: (K, TA:) pl. raEaAyaA: (TA:) this latter (the pl.) signifies cattle kept, tended, or pastured, for any one; (K, TA;) for the subjects and for the Sultán; (TA;) as also raEaAwiyRapN↓: (K, TA: in some copies of the K raEaAwiyap, without teshdeed:) and OaroEaAwiyRapN↓ signifies cattle kept, tended, or pastured, for the Sultán, (K, TA,) especially, and upon which are his brands and marks. (TA.) Hence the trad., kulRu raAEK masoWuwlN Eino raEiyRatihi [Every pastor shall be questioned respecting his pastured cattle: or every ruler shall be questioned respecting his subjects; agreeably with what follows]. (TA.) ― -b2- The people ruled or governed; the subjects of a ruler or governor: (Msb, K:) the community; the people in common or in general; or the common people: (S:) [any persons or person, and things or thing, in the keeping, or under the guardianship or rule or government, of a man or woman:] see raAEK, in the latter half of the paragraph: pl. as above. (TA.)

rEACp Alxayoli c
rEACp Alxayoli: see raAEiyapN.

raEaAwaI c
raEaAwaI and ruEaAwaI Camels that pasture around the people and their dwellings (S, K) because they are those upon which they work [or perform their business]: (S:) but in the Tekmileh it is written ruEaAwiyRapN↓, as meaning cattle that pasture around the dwellings of the people. (TA.)

raEaAwiyRapN c
raEaAwiyRapN: see raEiyRapN.

ruEaAwiyRapN c
ruEaAwiyRapN: see raEaAwaI.

raAEK c
raAEK [act. part. n. of 1]. You say maAXiyapN raAEiyapN Cattle [pasturing, or] pasturing by themselves: (Msb:) pl. rawaAEiI [a mistranscription for rawaAEK]. (TA.) ― -b2- raAEiI AlbusotaAni and AlOutuni raAEiyapu↓ are names of Two species of janaAdib [or locusts]; (K;) the latter mentioned by ISd: Sgh says that the former is a large junodab: and the latter is another species, that does not fly. (TA.) ― -b3- raAEK also signifies A keeper, or guarder, (TA,) or pastor, (Msb,) of cattle: (Msb, TA:) an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant: (TA:) pl. ruEaApN, (S, Msb, TA,) but this is said to be mostly used as pl. of raAEK in another sense as will be shown below, (TA,) and riEaMCN [and app. ruEaMCN (mentioned below)] and ruEoyaAnN; (S, Msb, TA;) and ruEaApN has a pl., namely, ruEFI. (TA.) ― -b4- [Hence,] AlrRaAEiI is the name of The star [a] that is upon the head of AlHawRaMC [i. e. Ophiuchus]: that which is upon the head of AlHAwI [a mistranscription in my MS. for AljaAviI, i. e. Hercules, the star a,] being called kalobu AlrRaAEiI. (Kzw.) Also The star [ γ] that is upon the left leg of Cepheus: between whose legs is a star [app. K] that is called kalobu AlrRaAEiI: (Kzw:) [from their longitudes it seems that these two stars are the same as are meant by what here follows:] Alkalobu [or kalobu AlrRaAEiI] is a certain star over against AldRalow [or Aquarius, which latter is] below; in the path of which is a
red [or perhaps another (Mxar instead of OaHomar)] star, called AlrRaAEiI. (TA in art. klb.) [And accord. to Freytag, raAEiI AljawozaMCi is the name of A star otherwise called the Foot of Orion: and raAEiI AlnRaEaAYimi, the name of The star λ in Sagittarius: see Ideler's “ Untersuch. über den Ursprung etc. der Sternnamen, ” to which he refers, pp. 213, 226, for the former; and p. 187 for the latter.] ― -b5- [And hence,] raAEK signifies also A ruler, or governor, (S, K,) or prince, or commander, (Msb,) who manages, conducts, orders, or regulates, the affairs of a people: (Msb, K:) and a ruler, or governor, of himself: (TA:) pl. ruEaApN and ruEoyaAnN, (K,) but it is said that the former is mostly used as meaning rulers, or governors, and the latter as pl. of raAEK in relation to sheep or goats [or the like], (TA,) and riEaMCN and ruEaMCN. (K.) It is said in a trad., kulRukumo raAEK wakulRukumo masoWuwlN Eino raEiyRatihi↓ [Every one of you is a ruler, or governor, and every one of you shall be questioned respecting those, or that, of which he is ruler or governor]: such is the man in respect of his family, and in respect of the property of his father; and the servant in respect of the property of his master; and the wife is a raAEiyap in respect of the house, or tent, of her husband: and every one of these shall be questioned respecting his, or her, raEiyRap. (ElJámi' es-Sagheer of Es-Suyootee.) And one says, kaAlrRaAEiI layosa AlmaroEiIRu↓ [The ruled, or governed, is not like the ruler, or governor]. (S.) ― -b6- In the saying of El-Karkhee, baAEa TayorFA EalaI OanRahu raAEK, relating to [carrier-] pigeons, it is from AlrRiEaAyapu signifying AlwafaMCu; [the saying meaning He sold birds on the condition of their being such as would be faithful to their charge;] for pigeons in El- 'Irák and Syria are bought for high prices, and sent from distant points with letters of informations, and convey them, and bring back replies to them. (Mgh, JM.)

raAEiyapN c
raAEiyapN [fem. of raAEK. ― -b2- Also a subst. formed from the latter word by the affix p; like raEiyRapN from raEiIRN]: see rAEK, third sentence. ― -b3- AlrRaAEiyapu is the name of A certain bird: (TA:) [and] so is raAEiyapu Alxayoli; (TA, and thus in some copies of the K;) thus correctly written, as in the Tekmileh; in [some of] the copies of the K, rAEyp Aljbl; [perhaps the same as the former bird;] a yellow bird, that is found beneath the bellies of horses or similar beasts; thus in the Tekmileh; said by ISh to be a small bird like the sparrow, that alights beneath the bellies of the horses and other beasts, yellow, as though its neck and wings were tinged with saffron, its back having upon it a dinginess, or duskiness, and blackness, its head being yellow, and its zimikRaI [or tail] being neither long nor short; accord. to Sgh, also called Alxyl rEACp↓. (TA [thus written without any syll. signs: if applying to the species in the manner of a coll. gen. n., perhaps a mistranscription for ruEaApu Alxayoli].) ― -b4- raAEiyapu AlXRayobi, and rawaAEiI AlXRayobi, (tropical:) The commencement of hoariness, (K, TA,) and the first marks thereof. (TA.)

OaroEaI c
OaroEaI [app. More, and most, merciful or compassionate; from OaroEayotu Ealayohi, though by rule it should be formed from an unaugmented verb accord. to many of the grammarians: ― -b2- and hence, being nearly syn. with Oarofaqu in the primary sense, syn. with this latter, or nearly so, in a secondary sense]. You say, Oamoru kacaA Oarofaqu biI waOaroEaI EalaIRa [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) This affair is more, or most, easy and convenient to me]. (TA.)

OuroEuwRapN c
OuroEuwRapN The yoke that is placed upon the necks of the two bulls employed in ploughing; (AA, Sgh, K, TA;) of the dial. of Azd-Shanoo-ah. (TA.)

OaroEaAwiyRapN c
OaroEaAwiyRapN: see raEiyRapN.

tiroEiIRN c
tiroEiIRN: see what next follows.

tiroEiyRapN c
tiroEiyRapN and turoEiyRapN (Fr, S, ISd, K) and taroEiyRapN, (ISd, K,) and sometimes without teshdeed, (K,) the first without teshdeed mentioned by Sgh on the authority of Fr, (TA,) and tiroEaAyapN↓ (S, K) and turoEaAyapN↓ (Sgh as from Fr) and turaAEiyapN↓ (Sgh, K) and tiraAEiyapN↓ and tiroEiIRN↓ (K) A man who performs well the act of keeping or tending, or of pasturing or feeding, camels: (S, K:) or whose habitual work, or occupation, or the habitual work, or occupation, of whose fathers, is, or has been, the tending, or pasturing, of camels: (ISd, K:) or who is a good seeker after herbage for the cattle. (ISd, TA.)

turoEaAyapN c
turoEaAyapN: see what next precedes.

turaAEiyapN c
turaAEiyapN: see what next precedes.

maroEFI c
maroEFI an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (S, K.) ― -b2- And A pasturage, or place of pasture; (S, K;) as also maroEaApN↓: (Sgh, K:) pl. maraAEK. (TA.) [Hence,] faUinRa likulRK bugaApN laA tadaEanRa fataApF walaA maroEaApF↓ [Do not thou leave uncared for a young woman nor a pasturage, for there are persons that seek, or endeavour, to find and get each]: a prov. enjoining the availing oneself of an opportunity, and the setting about an affair with prudence, discretion, precaution, or sound judgment. (Meyd.) ― -b3- See also riEoIN, in three places.

maroEaApN c
maroEaApN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

maroEiIRN c
maroEiIRN [Kept, or tended; pastured, or fed: kept, guarded, or minded: and] ruled, or governed; as in an ex. above, voce raAEK, last sentence but one. (TA.)

1 ragiba c
1. ragiba, aor.
ragaba
, inf. n. ragobapN (JK, TA) and ragobaI (JK) [and app. ragabN &c. as in the next sentence but one], He desired a thing [app. in an absolute sense, agreeably with what follows in the next sentence but one: and also,] vehemently, eagerly, greedily, very greedily, with avidity, excessively, or culpably; he coveted a thing, longed for it, or lusted after it. (TA.) ragabu AlnRafosi means The [soul's] hoping largely, and desiring much. (TA.) ― -b2- ragiba fiyhi, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) and ragibahu, (Msb, TA,) aor.
ragaba
, (K, TA,) inf. n. ragobapN (S, A, * Mgh, K) and ragabN (S, Msb) and ragobN (Mgh, Msb, K) and rugobN (K) and rugobaI (A, * Msb) and ragobaI (Msb) and ragobaMCu, (A, * Msb,) He desired it, or wished for it; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also fyh Artgb↓. (S, K.) You say, maA liI fiyhi ragobapN and rugobaI and ragobaMCu [I have not any desire, or wish, for it]. (A.) And ruhobaAka xayorN mino rugobaAka, i. e. The fearing thee is better than the loving thee; rhbAk being an inf. n. prefixed to an objective complement; and so rgbAk: and said to mean, thy being given a thing through fear of thee is better than through desire: a prov., similar to rahabuwtN xayorN mino raHamuwtK. (Meyd. [Freytag explains it otherwise: see his Arab. Prov. i. 542.]) ― -b3- ragiba Eanohu He did not desire it, or wish for it; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) he shunned, or avoided, it; abstained from it; (S, TA;) or left it, relinquished it, or forsook it, (JK, S, TA,) intentionally. (JK, TA.) ― -b4- ragiba Uilayohi, inf. n. ragabN (K) and ragobN and rugobN (TA) and rugobaI (Mgh, * K) and ragobaI (K) and ragobaMCu (A, * K) and ragobapN (Mgh, * TA) and rugobapN and ragabapN and ragabuwtN, and ragabuwtaI and ragabaAnN, (K,) He made petition to him, addressed a petition to him, asked him, petitioned him, sought of him, or demanded of him: (TA:) or he prayed to him, or supplicated him, with humility or abasement, or with sincerity or earnestness or energy: or he humbled, or abased, himself, and made petition to him. (K, A, TA.) You say, ragiba UilaI fulaAnK fiI kacaA He made petition to such a one, petitioned him, or asked him, for such a thing. (TA.) And UilaI QllRehi Oarogabu To God I humble, or abase, myself, and make petition; syn. OaDoraEu: and UilayohX OarofaEu ragobatiI [To Him I raise my humble petition]. (A.) And AlrRuhobaI mina QllRehi waAlrRugobaI Uilayohi [Fear should be of God; (not of a creature;) and petition, &c., should be to Him]. (Lth, TA in art. rhb.) See also another ex. in a verse cited voce ragiybapN. ― -b5- ragiba binafosihi Eanohu [lit. He made himself to be not desirous of, or to shun, or abstain from, or leave, him, or it; the b having the same effect as in cahaba bihi &c.; and hence,] he held himself above, or superior to, him, or it. (K.) And ragibotu bifulaAnK Eano hecaA I made such a one to shun, abstain from, or leave, this, disliking it for him. (MF.) ＝ -A2- raguba (assumed tropical:) It (anything) was, or became, wide, or ample. (TA. [See also 6.]) You say, raguba AlwaAdiI, aor.
raguba
, inf. n. rugobN and rugubN (K) and ragaAbapN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) The valley was large and wide, taking, or receiving, much water. (K, * TA.) And ragubati AlOaroDu, inf. n. rugobN [&c.], (assumed tropical:) The land was soft (S, TA) and wide, with even, or sandy, soil: (TA:) or (S, TA) took much water; (TA;) was such as would not flow unless in consequence of much rain. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And [hence,] raguba, inf. n. rugobN (S, K *) and rugubN, (K, * TA,) (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, voracious, a great eater; (K, TA;) very greedy, or gluttonous; (S, K, TA;) vehemently, excessively, or culpably, desirous of worldly goods, and one who made himself to be large, or abundant, therein: or as some say, large in his hopes,
and desirous of much. (TA.) Accord. to the T, rugobu AlbaToni signifies (assumed tropical:) Voracity: and rugobN, alone, as occurring in a trad., is explained as meaning capaciousness of the belly, and voracity. (TA.) And raguba raOoyuhu, inf. n. rugobN, (tropical:) He was, or became, liberal, or bountiful, and large in opinion or judgment. (A.)

2 rgRbhu fiI XaIoCK c
2. rgRbhu fiI XaIoCK, [inf. n. tarogiybN,] He made him to desire, or wish for, a thing; (S, * MA, K; *) as also fyh Argbhu↓. (S, * K: *) both signify the same. (S.) You say, ragRabotuhu fiI SuHobatihi [I made him to desire, or wish for, his companionship]. (A.) ― -b2- And rgRbhu, inf. n. tarogiybN; (IAar, TA;) and rgRb Uilayohi; (TA;) He gave him what he desired, or wished for. (IAar, TA.) ― -b3- [rgRb is also said by Golius to signify Cupivit avide et expetivit; as on the authority of the KL: but this signification is not in my copy of that work, nor do I find it in any other lexicon.]

3 rAgb c
3. rAgb is said by Golius, as on the authority of the KL, and by Freytag after him, to signify Cupiditatem monstravit: but it is not mentioned in any sense in my copy of the KL, nor have I found it in any other lexicon.]

4 Oarogaba
4: see 2. ― -b2- [Argbhu app. signifies also He made it wide, or ample. ― -b3- And hence,] Oarogaba QllRehu qadoraka means (tropical:) May God enlarge thy power, and make its steps to extend far. (A, TA.)

6 trAgbwA fiyih c
6. trAgbwA fiyih They vied, one with another, in desiring it; or they desired it with emulation; syn. tnAfswA fyh. (A and TA in art. nfs.) ― -b2- trAgb AlmakaAnu (assumed tropical:) The place was, or became, wide, or ample. (TA. [See also raguba.])

8 Uirotagaba
8: see 1, third sentence.

ragibN c
ragibN: see ragiybN, second sentence.

rugubN c
rugubN: see ragaAbN, and raEiybN; with both of which it is synonymous. ― -b2- It is also a pl. of the latter, (L in art. Osd,) and of ragibN. (TA.)

ragobapN c
ragobapN A desire, or wish: pl. ragabaAtN. (Mgh, Msb.) Hence, qalRato ragabaAtu AlnRaAsi [The desires, or wishes, of the people, or of mankind, became few]. (Mgh.) ― -b2- See also ragiybapN.

ragobaI c
ragobaI: see ragiybapN.

ragabuwtN c
ragabuwtN, an epithet applied to a man, [signifying One who makes petition; who asks, petitions, seeks, or demands: or who prays, or supplicates, with humility or abasement, or with sincerity or earnestness or energy: or who humbles, or abases, himself, and makes petition: originally an inf. n. of ragiba Uilayohi; or] from AlrRagobapu. (S, TA. [In one copy of the former erroneously written ragabuwbN; in another, ragobuwbN; and in another, omitted.])

rugobaAnapN c
rugobaAnapN The [knot called] saEodaAnap of a sandal; (K;) i. e. the knot beneath the [appertenance called] XisoE [which passes through the sole and between two of the toes, and to which the XiraAka, also called zimaAm, is attached]. (TA.)

OaroDN ragaAbN c
OaroDN ragaAbN (A'Obeyd, ISk, S, K) and rugubN↓ (K) (assumed tropical:) Land that is soft, (A'Obeyd, S, K, TA,) and wide, with even, or sandy, soil: (K, TA:) or (S, K, TA) that takes much water; (TA;) that will not flow unless in consequence of much rain. (ISk, S, K, TA.)

ragiybN c
ragiybN (assumed tropical:) Wide, or ample; applied in this sense to a watering-trough or tank, and to a skin for water or milk, (S, TA,) &c.: pl. rigaAbN (TA) and rugubN. (L in art. Osd.) You say also TariyqN ragibN↓ (assumed tropical:) A wide road: pl. rugubN. (TA.) And makaAnN muraAgibN↓ (assumed tropical:) A wide, or an ample, place. (TA.) And waAdK rugubN↓ (assumed tropical:) A wide valley; (TA;) [and] so waAdK ragiybN: (JK:) or (tropical:) a wide valley, that takes much water; as also ragiybN; (AHn, K;) contr. of waAdK zhiydN. (TA.) And TaEonapN ragiybapN (assumed tropical:) A wide wound inflicted with a spear or the like. (TA.) And sayofN ragiybN (assumed tropical:) A wide sword, that inflicts a large wound. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A man, or other animal, (K,) having a capacious inside, or belly: (S, K:) pl. rigaAbN. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Voracious; a great eater: (A, K: [but accord. to the former, not tropical in this sense:]) desirous of much eating: (Msb:) very greedy, or gluttonous: (S, K: [see also rigRiybN:]) vehemently, excessively, or culpably, desirous of worldly goods; and one who makes himself to be large, or abundant, therein: or large in his hopes, and desirous of much: (TA:) and ragiybu Aljawofi a man who is a great eater; (TA;) or capacious in the inside, or belly, and a great eater: (JK:) and baTonN ragiybN a belly that devours much. (Ham p. 418.) ― -b4- huwa ragiybu AlEayoni, (T and A and TA in art. zhd,) and lahu EayonN ragiybapN, (A in that art.,) (assumed tropical:) He is not content but with much; contr. of hw zahiydu AlEayoni, (T and A in that art.,) and of lahu EayonN zahiydapN. (A in that art.) [raEiybu AlEayoni has a different meaning: see art. rEb.] ― -b5- farasN ragiybu AlXRaHowapK (S, in a copy of the A and in the TA AlXHw,) (tropical:) A horse of wide step, that takes a large space of ground (A, TA) with his legs: pl. rigaAbN. (TA.) ― -b6- UibilN rigaAbN, the latter word being the pl. form, (assumed tropical:) Camels yielding a copious supply of milk, and very profitable. (IAth, TA) And (assumed tropical:) Many camels. (TA.) ― -b7- HimolN ragiybN and murotagibN↓ (assumed tropical:) A heavy load. (TA.)

ragiybapN c
ragiybapN A thing desired, or wished for; (K;) as also ragobapN↓: (Ham p. 501:) a thing of high account or estimation; that is desired, or wished for: pl. ragaAYibu. (A, Mgh.) You say, UinRahu lawahuwbN, likulRi ragiybapK, i. e. [Verily he is a liberal giver] of everything that is desired. (TA.) [And ragobaI↓ has a similar meaning; for] you say also, OaSabotu minohu AlrRagobaI, i. e. I obtained from him abundance of what I desired. (TA.) ― -b2- A large gift: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) pl. as above. (S, Mgh, Msb.) A poet (En-Nemir Ibn-Towlab, TA) says,
wamataI tuSiboka xaSaASapN faQroju AlginaI
waUilaI AlRaciI yuEoTiI AlrRagaAYiba faQrogabi
[And when poverty befalls thee, then hope thou for competence, and to Him who gives large gifts humble thyself, and make petition]. (S, * TA.) ― -b3- And A large recompense that one desires to obtain [in the world to come] by prayer: (El-Kilábee, TA:) or that which is wished for by one who has large hope and who desires much: whence the prayer called SalaApu AlrRagaAYibi [generally said to be a supererogatory prayer]. (TA.)

AlrRugaAbaI c
AlrRugaAbaI, like AlrRugaAmaI (JK, K) and AlrRuEaAmaI, (TA,) What is called the ziyaAdap of the liver. (JK, K.)

rigRiybN c
rigRiybN Very, or intensely, or exceedingly, desirous of much eating. (Msb.) [See also ragiybN.]

raAgibN c
raAgibN Desiring, or wishing; (K;) [as in the phrase raAgibN fiI kacaA desiring, or wishing for, such a thing;] and so murotagibN↓. (TA.)

marogabN c
marogabN [A place, or time, of desire or wish: and hence, an object thereof]. You say, xaTaba faOaSaAba Almarogaba [app. meaning He demanded a woman in marriage, and attained the object of desire]. (A.)

murogibN c
murogibN (tropical:) Possessing competence or sufficiency; rich, or wealthy; (K, TA;) possessing much property. (JK, TA.)

marogabapN c
marogabapN: see maraAgibu.

maroguwbN fiyhi c
[maroguwbN fiyhi Desired, or wished for. ― -b2- maroguwbN Eanohu Not desired, &c. ― -b3- maroguwbN Uilayohi Petitioned, &c.: see an ex. voce marohuwbN.]

huwa muragRabN lahu kacaA wakacaA c
huwa muragRabN lahu kacaA wakacaA To him are allowed, or permitted, such and such things; like musaERabN and musagRabN. (TA in art. sEb.)

maraAgibu c
maraAgibu [lit. Causes of desire; sing., if used, marogabapN↓, a word of the same class as maboxalapN and majobanapN &c.: and hence,] things that are eagerly desired, or coveted; syn. OaTomaAEN [which also signifies soldiers' stipends, or allowances]: (TA:) and (TA) things that are desired to be gained for subsistence, or sustenance; i. q. mDTrbAt lilomaEaAXi. (K, TA. [In the CK, the former of the two nouns in this explanation is muDoTaribAt: in two MS. copies of the K, it is without the syll. signs: the right reading is evidently muDoTarabaAt, syn. with mukotasabaAt: Freytag renders the explanation personæ quæ in rebus quæ spectant ad victum perturbatæ et anxiæ sunt; deriving this meaning from the rendering in the TK: Golius, with a near approach to correctness, renders it res ad sustentandam vitam necessariæ; but he has given this explanation as on the authority of J, by whom it is not mentioned; and has put maraAgibN for maraAgibu.])

muraAgibN c
muraAgibN: see ragiybN.

murotagibN c
murotagibN: see raAgibN. ― -b2- See also ragiybN, last sentence. ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) A large, big, bulky, or corpulent, man. (JK.)

1 ragavahaA c
1. ragavahaA, (S, A, K,) aor.
ragava
, (K,) inf. n. ragavN; (TK;) and ArtgvhA↓; (K;) said of a kid, (S, A,) [and app. of a lamb, (see 4,) or of any young animal,] He sucked her; (S, A, K;) namely, his mother. (S, A.) ― -b2- Hence, in a trad., cahaba rasuwlu QllRehi SalRaI QllRehu Ealayohi wasalRama waOanotumo tarogavuwnahaA (assumed tropical:) [The Apostle of God (may God bless and save him) has departed from the world, and ye suck the sweets of it]; meaning the world; i. e. taroDaEuwnahaA. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] ragavahu AlnRaAsu (assumed tropical:) The people, or men, asked, or begged, of him so much that all that he had passed away. (TA.) And rugiva, (ElAhmar, JK, S, K,) inf. n. rigaAvN, (JK,) (assumed tropical:) He (a man) was asked of, or begged of, so much that all that he had became exhausted. (El-Ahmar, JK, S, K.) ＝ -A2- rugiva, (K,) or rugivato said of a woman, (TA,) He, (K,) or she, (TA,) had a complaint of, or a pain in, the rugavaMC. (K, TA.) ― -b2- ragavahu He thrust, pierced, stuck, or stabbed, him time after time; and so Argvhu↓. (K. [See also the latter below.])

4 Argvthu c
4. Argvthu, said of a ewe, (S,) [and app. of a she-goat also, (see 1,) or of any female,] She suckled him; (S, K;) namely, her young one. (S.) See also raguwvN. ＝ -A2- Argvhu He thrust, pierced, stuck, or stabbed, him in his rugavaMC. (K.) ― -b2- See also 1, last signification.

8 Uirotagava
8: see 1, first signification.

ragovaMCu c
ragovaMCu: see what next follows.

rugavaMCu c
rugavaMCu A certain duct (EiroqN) in the breast, or mamma, (S, K,) that emits the milk: (S:) or a certain sinew, or tendon, (EaSabapN,) beneath the breast, or mamma: (ISk, T, S, K:) sometimes written ragovaMCu↓: (Fr, T, TA:) or the rugavaAwaAni [dual of rugavaMCu] are the two sinews, or tendons, that are beneath the two breasts, or mammæ: or what are between the two shoulder-joints and the two breasts, next the arm-pit: (TA:) or two portions of flesh, (JK,) or two small portions of flesh, (TA,) between the vunoduWap [q. v.], and the shoulderjoint, (JK, TA,) on either side of the chest: (TA:) or the blackness [app. meaning the areola] of each of the two breasts. (TA.)

OaroDN rugaAvN c
OaroDN rugaAvN Land that does not flow with water except (UilRaA [but this word is omitted in the TA]) from much rain: (JK, K:) [i. e., that sucks in the rain-water, and does not cause it to flow upon its surface, except when it is copious.]

raguwvN c
raguwvN Any female suckling; (JK, S, K;) as also murogivN↓: (K:) or one says XaApN raguwvN and raguwvapN, meaning particularly a ewe suckling: but [the inf. n.] UirogaAvN↓ has been used in relation to the she-camel: or raguwvN applied to a XAp means only that has brought forth: (TA:) and one says birocawonapN raguwvN meaning [a hackney-mare] that is sucked, i. q. maroguwvapN↓; (S, TA;) and that scarcely ever raises her head from the manger: [whence] it is said in a prov., Mkl AldRawaAbRi birocawonapN raguwvN [The most voracious of beasts is a hackneymare that is sucked]: or, as J gives it [in the S, and Z in the A], thus, as verse:
Mklu mino birocawonapK raguwvi
[More voracious than a hackney-mare that is sucked]: and murogivN↓ is applied to a woman as meaning suckling: the pl. of raguwvN is rigaAvN. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A child, or young one, that is suckled; a suckling. (TA.)

murogivN c
murogivN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Possessing much property. (JK.)

muragRavN c
muragRavN [written in the JK marogav, but said in the K to be like muHamRadN,] The part, of the finger, which is the place of the signet-ring. (K.)

maroguwvN c
maroguwvN: see its fem. above, voce raguwvN. ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) A man asked of, or begged of, so much that all that he had is exhausted. (El-Ahmar, JK, S, A, K.) And (assumed tropical:) Possessing little property. (JK.) And OamowaAluhu maroguwvapu (tropical:) [His possessions are exhausted. (A.)

1 ragida c
1. ragida, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
ragada
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. ragadN (Msb) [and ragodN, as seems to be indicated in the K by its being said that the verb is like samiEa]; and raguda, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
raguda
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. ragaAdapN; (Msb;) It (one's life) was, or became, ample in its means or circumstances, unstraitened, or plentiful, (S, Msb, K,) and easy, (Msb,) and pleasant. (S, K.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] fulaAnN daAYibN fiI Oamorihi laA yarogudu [Such a one is striving, labouring, or toiling, in his affair:] he will not flag, or be remiss. (JK.) ＝ -A2- [In the JK, ragadonaA, aor. narogadu, is mentioned immediately after an explanation of ragiydapN, app. to indicate that it signifies We prepared, or we ate, rgydp.]

4 ArgdwA c
4. ArgdwA They became in a state of life ample in its means or circumstances, unstraitened, or plentiful; (S, A;) they had abundance of herbage, or of the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- Argd QllRehu EayoXahumo God made their life to be ample in its means or circumstances, unstraitened, or plentiful, [and easy,] and pleasant. (A.) ― -b2- And ArgdwA mawaAXiyahumo They left their cattle to pasture by themselves, where they pleased. (S, K.)

10 Astrgd AlEayoXa c
10. Astrgd AlEayoXa He found life to be ample in its means or circumstances, unstraitened, or plentiful, [and easy,] and pleasant. (Har p. 657.) One says, Ainozlo Hayovu yusotarogadu AlEayoXu [Alight thou where life is found to be ample in its means &c.]. (A.)

11 ArgAdR c
11. ArgAdR, (S, TA,) inf. n. AirogiydaAdN, (S, K, TA,) It (milk) became commingled, one part with another, but not yet completely thickened. (S, TA.) And in like manner, It (anything) became commingled, or confused, one part with another. (S, K, * TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) He became [confused, or] in doubt, in his opinion, or judgment, not knowing how to utter it. (K.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) He slept without fully satisfying his drowsiness, (K, TA,) so that he awoke heavy. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) He was angry, and changed in colour by reason of anger: (TA:) or he was angry, and would not answer. (K.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) He was sick, not severely affected (lamo yujohado [in the CK lm yajohado]), (L, K,) but suffering depression: (K:) or he showed himself to be depressed, (JK, L,) without emaciation, (JK,) or by emaciation: (L:) and he was oppressed by sickness beyond his power of endurance: (L:) or he began to suffer pain, and exhibited an extenuated state of the belly, and dryness, and languor. (En-Nadr.) ― -b6- ArgydAd also signifies (assumed tropical:) Languidness, or weakness, in the eye, and the ear, and the sight. (JK.)

Q. Q. 3 AirogalRada c
Q. Q. 3. AirogalRada [a verb app. syn. with ragida in an intensive sense;] of the measure AifoEalRala from AlrRagadu [inf. n. of ragida]. (K.) Its l is augmentative; and therefore it should not be mentioned independently as it is in the K. (TA.)

ragodN c
ragodN, applied to property, or water, or life, or herbage, Plentiful; that does not cause one fatigue. (L.) [Being originally an inf. n., it is used without variation as a masc. and fem. and sing. and pl. epithet; as also ragadN↓.] You say EayoXN ragodN and ragadN↓ and raAgidN↓ and ragiydN↓ (A, Msb) and Oarogadu↓, (Lh, TA,) and maEiyXapN ragiydapN↓, (A,) Life that is ample in its means or circumstances, unstraitened, or plentiful, (Lh, A, Msb,) and easy, (Lh, * Msb,) and pleasant. (A, Msb.) And giyXapN ragodN and ragadN↓ A mode of life ample in its means or circumstances, unstraitened, or plentiful, [and easy,] and pleasant. (S, A, K.) And qawomN ragadN↓, (A, L, K,) or ragodN, (JK,) and nisowapN ragadN↓, (A, L, K,) or nisaMCN ragodN, (JK,) People, and women, in a state of life ample in its means or circumstances, &c.; (JK, A, K;) or having abundance of herbage, or of the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life, and having camels abounding with milk. (L.)

ragadN c
ragadN an inf. n. of ragida. (Msb.) You say, huwa fiI ragadK mina AlEayoXi He is in a state of life ample in its means or circumstances, unstraitened, or plentiful, (A, Msb,) [and easy,] and pleasant. (A.) ― -b2- See also ragodN, in five places.

ragiydN c
ragiydN, and its fem., with p: see ragodN.

ragiydapN c
ragiydapN Fresh milk, which is boiled, and upon which some flour is sprinkled, (JK, S, K,) then dates are mixed therewith, (JK,) or then it is mixed and stirred about, (S,) and it is licked up: (S, K:) and also remains of milk: (JK:) or fresh butter: (Msb:) or a piece, or portion, of fresh butter: (A:) pl. ragaAYidu. (JK, A.) You say, AlOamonu fiI AlmaEiyXapi AlrRagiydapi OaToyabu mina AlbaroniIRa biAlrRagiydapi, meaning [Security in the state of life that is ample in its means or circumstances, &c., is sweeter than the dates called baroniIR] with some fresh butter. (A.)

rugayodaMCu c
rugayodaMCu i. q. ruEayodaMCu [q. v.]; (K;) [i. e.] What is taken forth from wheat, and thrown away. (JK.)

raAgidN c
raAgidN: see ragodN.

Oarogadu c
Oarogadu: see ragodN.

marogadapo c
marogadapo [A place abounding with herbage;] a meadow, or a garden; syn. rawoDapN. (L.) See also marodagapN.

murogaAdRN c
murogaAdRN part. n. of 11. (L, K.) Milk [that has become commingled, one part with another, but] not yet completely thickened. (L.) [And in like manner, Anything that has become commingled, or confused, one part with another.] ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) One who is [confused, or] in doubt, in his opinion, or judgment, (JK, S, K,) not knowing how to utter it. (S, K.) ― -b3- [For its other meanings, see the verb.]

1 ragasahu QllRehu c
1. ragasahu QllRehu, aor.
ragasa
, inf. n. ragosN, God blessed, or prospered, him, and made him to increase and multiply: God made his property to increase and multiply. (TA.) You say, kaAnuwA qaliylFA faragasahumu QllRehu They were few, and God multiplied and increased them: and in like manner one says of Hasab [or grounds of pretension to respect], &c. (S, TA.) And ragasahu QllRehu maAlFA, (El-Umawee, S, K,) and waladFA, (TA,) aor. as above, (K,) God multiplied to him his property, (El-Umawee, S, K,) and his offspring, (TA,) and blessed him therein; (ElUmawee, S, K; *) as also maAlFA Argshu↓, (K,) and waladFA. (TA.)

4 Oarogasa
4: see the last sentence above.

ragosN c
ragosN Increase: (S, K:) abundance: (TA:) wealth, or property; or much wealth or property; or good fortune, prosperity, welfare, wellbeing, or weal; syn. xayorN. (S, K.) El-'Ajjáj says,
xaliyfapN saAsa bigayori taEosi
UimaAmu ragosK fiI niSaAbi ragosi
[app. meaning, A khaleefeh who ruled without evil, a prosperous prince, of prosperous origin]: niSaAb is syn. with OaSol. (S.) ― -b2- Also A benefit, favour, boon, or blessing; syn. naEomapN: (K:) or ampleness, or largeness, therein: (TA:) pl. OarogaAsN, (K.)

murogasN c
murogasN: see the next paragraph.

murogisN c
murogisN One who makes himself to have a plentiful and pleasant and easy life; (Ibn-'Abbád, Sgh, K;) as also with X. (TA.) ― -b2- A plentiful state of life; as also murogasN↓, (K,) in the saying hamo fiI murogisK mino EayoXihimo [They are in a plentiful state of life]. (TA.)

maroguwsN c
maroguwsN Blessed; prospered; fortunate: (K, * TA:) applied to a man, blessed, or prospered; (TA;) abounding in wealth or property; (K, TA;) fortunate, or possessed of good fortune: (TA:) and, applied to a face, blessed and fortunate; (S;) or cheerful and fortunate. (TA.) You say also, huwa maroguwsu AlnRaASiyapi (assumed tropical:) He has a blessed, or fortunate, forelock. (TA.) ― -b2- And with p, applied to a woman, (Lth, K,) and to a ewe, or she-goat, (TA,) Prolific; having numerous offspring. (Lth, K, TA.)

1 ragafa c
1. ragafa, (JK, O, Msb,) aor.
ragafa
, (O, Msb,) inf. n. ragofN, (JK, O, Msb, K,) He collected together (JK, O, Msb, K) clay, (JK, O, K,) or dough, (Msb, O, K,) making it into a compact mass, (JK, O, K,) or making it round (Msb) [and flat, but not thin, or not very thin], with his hand. (Msb, O, K.) ― -b2- ragafa AlbaEiyrN, (JK, O, K,) aor. as above, (O, K,) and so the inf. n., (JK, O,) He put into the camel's mouth, by mouthfuls, seeds (bazor), and flour, (JK, O, K,) and the like. (O, K.)

4 Argf c
4. Argf He looked sharply, or intently, or attentively; (JK, O, K;) Uilayohi [at him, or it]; (TK;) said of a man and of a lion. (O.) ― -b2- And He hastened, made haste, or sped, in going, journeying, or pace. (K.)

ragiyfN c
ragiyfN A round cake (MA, KL) of bread, (S, MA, Mgh, KL,) such as is thick, or not thin, (MA,) the contr. of such as is termed raqiyq; (Mgh;) [generally about a span, or less, in width, and from half an inch to an inch in thickness;] of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, (Msb,) from ragafa as expl. in the first sentence above: (JK, O, Msb, K:) pl. [of pauc.] OarogifapN (S, O, Msb, K) and [of mult.] rugofaAnN (JK, S, MA, Mgh, Msb, K) and rugufN (JK, S, O, Msb) and rugofN and taraAgiyfu↓; (JK, O, K;) the last anomalous, (TK,) mentioned by Ibn-'Abbád. (O.)

taraAgiyfu c
taraAgiyfu: see what next precedes. [This art. is wanting in the copies of the L and TA to which I have had access.]

AirogalRada c
AirogalRada: see Q. Q. 3 in art. rgd.

1 ragima AlOanofu c
1. ragima AlOanofu, [and, as will be seen from what follows, ragama, and raguma, inf. n. ragomN and rugomN and rigomN,] His nose clave to the ragaAm [i. e. earth, or dust]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ragama Oanofuhu, aor.
raguma
, inf. n. ragomN [&c. as above]; and ragima, aor.
ragama
; [and raguma, aor.
raguma
;] (tropical:) He was, or became, abased, or humble, or submissive; as though his nose clave to the ragaAm by reason of abasement &c. (Msb.) And ragima OanofiI lilRehi, and ragama, (S, K,) and raguma, (El-Hejeree, K,) inf. n. ragomN and rugomN and rigomN, (S,) [and app. marogamapN also, as seems to be indicated in the S and TA,] (tropical:) My nose [meaning my pride] was, or became, abased, or humbled, to God, against my will; (K, TA;) i. e. liOamorihi [to his command]. (TA.) And fulaAnN rugima OanofFA and gurima OanofFA (assumed tropical:) [Such a one is, or has been, abased, or humbled]. (TA.) ― -b3- And ragama fulaAnN, (S, TA,) or ragima, aor.
ragama
, inf. n. ragomN [&c. as above], (JK,) (tropical:) Such a one was unable to obtain his right, or due; (JK, S, TA;) as also ragama Oanofuhu: the part. n. is raAgimN↓. (Har p. 369.) ＝ -A2- ragama as a trans v.: see 4, [with which it is app. syn. properly as well as tropically,] in three places. ― -b2- [Hence,] ragamotuhu, (K,) inf. n. ragomN; (JK, TA;) and taragRamotuhu↓; (so in the JK; [perhaps a mistranscription for ragamotuhu;]) (assumed tropical:) I did a thing against his will: (JK, K, TA:) or, so as to anger him; and vexed him. (TA.) ― -b3- [And (assumed tropical:) I made him to do a thing against his will; forced him to do a thing: for] AlrRagomu is also syn. with Alqasoru; (IAar, K, TA;) in some copies of the K erroneously written AlqaXoru. (TA.) ― -b4- And ragimahu and ragamahu, aor.
ragama
, (K,) inf. n. ragomN (TA) [and app. rugomN and rigomN and marogamapN, as seems to be indicated in the K] (tropical:) He disliked it, disapproved it, or hated it. (K, TA.) You say, maA Oarogamu minohu XayoYFA (tropical:) I dislike not, &c., of it, anything. (JK, TA.) And ragamati AlsRaAYimapu AlmaroEaI (tropical:) The pasturing beasts disliked, &c., the pasture. (TA.) ― -b5- See also 2. ― -b6- [And see ragomN, below.]

2 ragRama
2: see 4, in three places. ― -b2- rgRmhu, (JK, M, K,) inf. n. tarogiymN, (K,) also signifies He said to him ragomFA; (JK; [see ragomN, below;]) or ragomFA ragomFA; so in the K; but in the M, ragomFA wadagomFA: (TA:) and ragamahu↓ inf. n. ragomN, [in like manner,] he said to him ragomFA: or he did with him that which made his nose to cleave to the earth, or dust, (maA yurogimu Oanofahu,) and that which abased him. (Ham p. 97.)

3 muraAgamapN c
3. muraAgamapN signifies (tropical:) The breaking off from, or quitting, another in anger: (S, K, TA:) and the cutting off another from friendly, or loving, communion; cutting one, or ceasing to speak to him; or forsaking, abandoning, deserting, or shunning or avoiding, one: and the becoming alienated, or estranged; or the going, removing, retiring, or withdrawing, to a distance, far away, or far off, one from another: (K, TA:) [or] rAgmhu signifies (assumed tropical:) He left, forsook, abandoned, or relinquished, him, or separated himself from him, against his [the latter's] wish: (Mgh:) or he broke off from him, or quitted him, in anger: (Msb:) and Oaholahu Argm↓ (tropical:) He cut off his family from loving communion, or forsook them, or deserted them, against their wish. (TA.) It is said in a trad., liyuraAgimu rabRahu Uino Oadoxala Oabawayohi AlnRaAra, i. e. (tropical:) He will assuredly break off in anger from his Lord [if he cause his two parents to enter the fire of Hell]. (TA.) And you say, raAgama fulaAnN qawomahu (tropical:) Such a one retired apart from his people, or party; or disagreed with them; or opposed them; (S, K, * TA;) and went forth from them; (S, TA;) and cut them off from friendly, or loving, communion; or forsook them; and treated them, or regarded them, with enmity, or hostility. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And fulaAnN laA yuraAgimu XayoYFA (assumed tropical:) Such a one does not want, need, or require, and is not unable to attain, anything. (JK, TA.)

4 Argmhu c
4. Argmhu [He cast it upon the ragaAm, i. e. earth, or dust: and he made it to cleave to the earth, or dust]. You say, Argm AllRuqomapa mino fiyhi He cast the morsel from his mouth upon the earth, or dust. (TA.) And it is said in a trad. of 'Áïsheh, respecting the material for dyeing the hair, and the hands of women, Ausolutiyhi waOarogimiyhi [Wipe thou it off
from thy hand, or hands, and cast it upon the earth, or dust]. (S. [There said to be from the phrase here next following.]) You say also, Argm Oanofahu He, (i. e. God, JK, S,) or it, (i. e. abasement, or humility, or submissiveness, K, * TA, *) made his nose to cleave to the ragaAm, i. e. earth, or dust; (JK, * S, TA;) [or may He (i. e. God) make his nose to cleave to the earth, or dust;] and ragama↓ Oanofahu signifies the same [app. in this (the proper) sense, as well as in that next following]. (Mgh, TA.) ― -b2- And [hence] the former of these two phrases means (tropical:) He (i. e. God, Msb) abased him, humbled him, or rendered him submissive, (Msb, TA,) against his will; (TA;) [or may He abase him, &c.;] and so ↓the latter of the same two phrases: and the former, (assumed tropical:) He angered him; likewise said of God; (Ham p. 551;) and so Argmhu alone; (K, TA;) like Adgmhu; (TA;) or both signify (tropical:) he did evil to him, and angered him: (TA in art. dgm:) and Ourogima (assumed tropical:) He was abased, or humbled, or rendered submissive: (Ham p. 617:) and QllRehu bihi AlOunuwfa ragama↓, inf. n. ragomN, (assumed tropical:) God abased, or may God abase, the noses by means of him, or it. (Har p. 369.) [rgRmhu↓, also, signifies (assumed tropical:) He abased him, humbled him, or rendered him submissive: you say,] lahu hecaA tarogiymN↓ (assumed tropical:) This is an abasing, or a humbling, to him: (Msb:) and lilXRayoTaAni tarogiymFA↓ (occurring in a trad., TA) means (assumed tropical:) For the abasing, or humbling, of the devil. (Mgh.) ― -b3- And Argmhu (assumed tropical:) He urged him, or made him, to do that from which he was not able to hold back, or that which he could not refuse to do, or that which he could not resist doing. (JK, TA, and Ham p. 97, from Kh.) ― -b4- See also 3.

5 trgRm c
5. trgRm (assumed tropical:) He became angered, or angry, (S, K, TA,) with speech, and otherwise: (TA:) and sometimes it occurs with z [i. e. tzgRm]. (S, TA.) Hence the saying of El-Hotei-ah, [app. describing a she-camel,]
taraI bayona laHoyayohaA UicaA maA taragRamato
lugaAmFA kabayoti AlEanokabuwti AlumadRadi
[Thou seest between her two jaws, when she is angered, foam like the web of the spider stretched out]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 1.

ragomN c
ragomN and rugomN↓ and rigomN↓ are inf. ns. of ragima and ragama said of the nose; and marogamapN↓ is syn. therewith; (S;) as is also marogamN↓. (TA.) One says to another, [by way of imprecation,] ragomFA [for ragima Oanofuka ragamFA May thy nose cleave fast to the earth, or dust; meant to be understood in the proper sense, or in a tropical sense explained by what follows]; (JK, M, K;) and [sometimes] dagomFA is added, (M,) which is an imitative sequent to ragomFA. (K in art. dgm.) And liOanofihi AlrRagomu and Almarogamapu↓ [May cleaving to the earth, or dust, befall his nose; which may likewise be meant to be understood properly, or tropically]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] the first also signifies, (IAar, K, TA,) and so marogamapN↓ also, (TA,) (tropical:) Abasement. (IAar, Mgh, K, TA.) The Prophet said, buEivotu marogamapF↓, (S,) i. e. (tropical:) I was sent for abasement to the believers in a plurality of gods, [or] by reason of dislike or disapproval [of their state; agreeably with the explanation next following]. (TA.) ― -b3- ragomN and rugomN↓ (Msb, K, TA) and rigomN↓ and marogamapN↓ (K, TA) also signify (tropical:) Dislike, disapproval, or hatred. (Msb, K, TA.) You say, faEalahu ragomFA or rugomFA↓ or rigomFA↓, (TA,) and EalaI ragomK, (ISh, TA,) and ElI ragomihi, and ElI AlrRagomi minohu, (TA,) and ElI ragomi Oanofihi and Oanofihi rugomi↓, (Msb,) and ElI AlrRagomi mino Oanofihi, (S,) i. e. (tropical:) [He did it against his wish; in spite of him; or] notwithstanding his dislike, or disapproval, or hatred. (Msb, TA.) ― -b4- HatRaI yaxoruja manohu AlrRugomu↓, [or AlrRagomu, in the TA without the vowel-sign,] occurring in a trad., means (assumed tropical:) In order that he may become humble and abased, and the pride of the Devil may go forth from him. (Mgh, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also ragaAmN.

rugomN c
rugomN: see the next paragraph above, in six places.

rigomN c
rigomN: see ragomN, in three places.

XaApN ragomaMCu c
XaApN ragomaMCu A sheep, or goat, having upon the extremity of its nose a whiteness, (JK, K,) or a colour different from that of the rest of its body. (K.)

ragomaAnu c
ragomaAnu: see the next following paragraph.

ragaAmN c
ragaAmN Earth, or dust; (S, Msb, K;) as also ragomN↓: (IAar, K:) [or] soft earth or dust, (K, TA,) but not fine: (TA:) or fine earth or dust: (AA, TA:) or sand mixed with earth or dust: (K:) or sand such as does not flow from the hand: (As, TA:) or, as IB says on the authority of AA, sand that dazzles the sight; as also ragomaAnu↓; which latter, accord. to the K, is the name of a certain tract of sands. (TA.)

rugaAmapN c
rugaAmapN A thing that one desires, or seeks; (JK, K;) as also marogamapN↓: (TA:) so in the saying, liI Einodahu rugaAmapN (JK, TA) and marogamapN (TA) [I have a thing that I desire, or seek, to obtain from such a one].

rugaAmaI c
rugaAmaI The nose; as also marogamN↓ and marogimN↓, (K,) of which the pl. is maraAgimu: (TA:) or rugaAmaI signifies the nose with what is around it: (IKoot, TA:) and in this sense also the pl. above mentioned is used; as in the saying, laOaTaOanRa maraAgimaka [I will assuredly trample upon thy nose with the parts around it]. (TA.) ― -b2- And The [appertenance called the] ziyaAdap [q. v.] of the liver; as also ruEaAmaI; (S, K;) but the former is the more approved. (TA.) ― -b3- And, (K,) some say, (S, TA,) [The bronchi, or the windpipe; i. e.] the tubes, (qaSab, S,) or the tube, (qaSabap, K,) of the lungs. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- Also A certain plant: a dial. var. of ruxaAmaI [q. v.]. (K.)

raAgimN c
raAgimN: see 1. You say, huwa raAgimN and raAgimu AlOanofi [He has the nose cleaving to the dust: and hence,] (assumed tropical:) he is abased, or humble, or submissive: and (assumed tropical:) he is unable to obtain his right, or due: and [rugomN is its pl.:] you say, humo rugomu AlOunuwfi. (Har p. 369.) And daAgmN is used as an imitative sequent thereto. (K.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Angry. (TA.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) Disliking, disapproving, or hating. (TA.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) Fleeing. (TA.)

marogamN c
marogamN: see ragomN, first sentence: ＝ -A2- and see also rugaAmaI: ＝ -A3- and muraAgamN.

marogimN c
marogimN: see rugaAmaI, first sentence.

marogamapN c
marogamapN: see ragomN, in five places: ＝ -A2- and see also rugaAmapN. ＝ -A3- Also A certain game of the Arabs. (K.)

muragRamN c
muragRamN: see the next paragraph but one.

mirogaAmapN c
mirogaAmapN (tropical:) A woman who angers her husband. (K, TA.)

muraAgamN c
muraAgamN (S, Mgh, K, TA) and mutaragRamN↓ (JK, TA) and marogamN↓, (JK,) thus accord. to one reading in the Kur iv. 101, (Ksh,) or muragRamN↓, (TA, [perhaps a mistranscription,]) (assumed tropical:) A road by the travelling of which one leaves, or separates himself from, his people, against their wish, or so as to displease them: (Ksh and Bd in iv. 101:) and a place to which one emigrates: (Zj and Ksh and Jel ibid.:) or a place to which one shifts, removes, or becomes transferred: (Bd ibid.:) or a way by which one goes or goes away: (Fr, JK, S, K:) and a place to which one flees; a place of refuge: (Fr, S, Mgh, K:) and i. q. muDoTarabN [meaning a place in which one goes to and fro seeking the means of subsistence: see art. Drb]: (Fr, JK, S, K:) and a fortress, or fortified place; syn. HiSonN. (IAar, K.) It is said in the Kur, [iv. 101, of him who emigrates for the cause of God's religion], yajidN fiI AlOaroDi muraAgamFA kaviyrFA [He shall find in the earth many a road &c.]. (S, TA.) And a poet says,
UilaI baladK gayori daAniI AlmaHalRi
baEiydi AlmuraAgami waAlmuDoTarabo
[To a country not near in respect of the place of alighting, remote in respect of the road &c. and of the region in which people go to and fro seeking the means of subsistence]. (Zj, TA.)

mutaragRamN c
mutaragRamN: see the next preceding paragraph.

1 ragaA c
1. ragaA, (S, Mgh, K,) aor. yaroguw, (S,) said of a camel, (S, Mgh, K,) and of a hyena, and of an ostrich; (K;) or ragato, aor. taroguw, said of a she-camel; (JK, Msb;) inf. n. rugaMCN, (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, * K,) with which raAgiyapN↓ is syn. [either as an inf. n. or as a simple subst.]; (JK;) He grumbled, or uttered a grumbling cry; syn. DajRa; (S;) or uttered a cry, (Mgh, K,) and grumbled; syn. SawRata faDajRa: (K:) or she uttered a cry [&c.]: (Msb:) so camels are wont to do when the loads are lifted upon them; and youthful camels do so much: (TA:) rugaMCN signifies the cry or crying [or grumbling, which is a kind of gurgling growl,] (S, Msb) of the camel [when he is being laden, and on some other occasions of discontent], (Msb,)
or of animals having the kind of foot called xufR: (S:) also of the bird called ragRaMCN [&c.]. (TA.) It is said in a prov., kafaI birugaAYihaA munaAdiyFA [Her grumbling cry suffices as a caller] i. e., the rugaMC of his camel serves instead of his calling in presenting himself for entertainment as a guest: (S:) A'Obeyd says that it is well known to the Arabs as relating to the accomplishment of an object of want before the asking for it: and it is applied also to the case of a man whose aid is wanted and who does not come to thee; excusing himself by saying that he did not know: and to the case of one who stands at a man's door, and to whom it is said, “ Send him who shall ask permission for thee [to go in]; ” whereupon he replies, “ His knowledge of my standing at his door suffices for asking permission for me: if he pleased, he would grant me permission. ” (Meyd. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 328—9.]) And in another prov., Albakori kaAnato Ealayohimo karaAgiyapi↓, (JK, Meyd,) or AlsRaqobi, [i. e. There befell them the like of the grumbling cry of the young camel,] meaning, the rugaMC of the young camel of Thamood [which preceded the destruction of those who heard it]: the prov. relates to the auguring evil from a thing. (Meyd. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 327.]) ― -b2- ragaA said of a boy, or child, means (tropical:) He wept most violently. (K, TA.) ― -b3- [It is also, app., said of a man, as meaning (assumed tropical:) He shouted: and (assumed tropical:) he spoke with a loud voice. (See 6, and ragRaMCN.)] ＝ -A2- See also 2.)

2 rgRI c
2. rgRI, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. tarogiyapN, (S,) said of milk, (S, Msb, K,) It frothed; (S;) it had ragowap [or froth]; as also ArgI↓, (K,) inf. n. UirogaMCN; (TA;) and ragaA↓, (K,) aor. yaroguw, inf. n. ragowN: (TA:) or it had much froth; as also ArgI↓: (TA:) or its froth estuated. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Oamosato Uibiluhumo turagRiI watunaXRifu, i. e. [Their camels became, or became in the evening, so as that they yielded frothy milk; or so as that] they had ragowap and nuXaAfap. (Yaakoob, S.) ＝ -A2- tarogiyapN also signifies (tropical:) The act of angering [another]. (IAar, K, TA.)

4 ArgI c
4. ArgI He made his she-camel to utter the grumbling cry termed rugaMC: (S, K:) [and] he made his camel to do so in order that he might be entertained as a guest. (M, TA. [See a prov. cited in the first paragraph.]) Sebrah Ibn-'Amr El-Fak'asee says,
wamaA yurogaI liXadRaAdK faSiylu
[And a young camel belonging to the family of Sheddád is not made to utter its grumbling cry for the want of its mother]; meaning that they are niggardly; that they will not separate the young camel from its mother by slaughter nor by gift. (S.) And it is said in a prov.,
OaroguwA lahaA HuwaArahaA taqirRu
[Make ye her (the camel's) young one to utter its grumbling cry, then she will be quiet]: for the she-camel when she hears the rugaMC of her young one becomes still: (Meyd:) the prov. means, give him that which he wants, [then] he will be quiet. (JK, Meyd. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 532.]) OarogawoA lilrRaHiyli means They made their saddle-camels to utter the grumbling cry [for removal, or departure, or journeying]; camels being wont to do so when the loads are lifted upon them. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, ArgAhu (assumed tropical:) He subdued, subjected, or oppressed, him; and abased him: because the camel [generally] does not utter the cry termed rugaMC except in consequence of abasement, or humiliation. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] hiIa maliykapu AlUirogaMCi (assumed tropical:) She is the slave (maliykap meaning mamoluwkap) of noise and loquacity, so that she distresses the hearers: or it may mean [she is subject to] the frothing of her lips, by reason of her loquacity; from ragowapN meaning “ froth. ” (TA. [See ragRaMCN.]) ― -b4- You say also, maA OavogaI walaA OarogaI He gave not a sheep or goat, nor a she-camel; (S, K;) like as you say, maA OaHoXaI walaA OajalRa. (S. [See 4 in art. vgw.]) ＝ -A2- See also 2, in two places. ― -b2- [Hence,] ArgI said of him who is discharging his urine, (tropical:) He had much froth to his urine. (K, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] turogiynaA suqaATa HadiyvihaA, a phrase used by a poet, means (assumed tropical:) She feeds us with [or gives us] little discourse, [or the refuse of her discourse,] like froth. (TA.)

6 taraAgawoA c
6. taraAgawoA They uttered the cry termed rugaMC, [or rather (assumed tropical:) a cry, or cries, similar thereto,] one here and one here. (S, K.) It is said in a trad., taraAgawoA Ealayohi faqataluwhu (S, IAth, TA) (assumed tropical:) They shouted, one to another, and called one another, against him, to slay him, and slew him. (IAth, TA.)

8 ArtgI c
8. ArtgI He drank ragowap, i. e. froth: (S, Msb:) or ArtgI ragowapF he took, and sipped, or supped, froth. (K.) It is said in a prov., yusirRu HasowFA fiI QrotigaMCK [He conceals a sipping, or supping, in drinking froth]: applied to him who pretends one thing when he means, or desires, another: (S:) accord. to AZ and As, it originated from a man's having some milk brought to him, and his pretending that he desired the froth, and, while drinking this, taking of the milk; and is applied to a man who pretends to aid thee, and benefits himself: (Meyd:) Esh-Shaabee, to one who asked him respecting a man who kissed his wife's mother, replied in these words; and added, “ His wife has become unlawful to him. ” (S.)

ragowapN c
ragowapN A single uttering of the grumbling cry termed rugaMC. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, and rugowapN↓ and rigowapN↓, (JK, S, Msb, K,) the last mentioned by Lh and others, (S,) and rugaAyapu↓ (JK, S, Msb, K) and rigaAyapN↓, (S, Msb, K,) the latter as heard by Abu-l-Mahdee, (S,) and rigaAwapN↓ (JK, S, Msb, K) and rugaAwapN↓, (S, K,) the latter as heard by Abu-lMahdee, (S,) and rugaAwaI↓, (AZ, TA,) The froth of milk [&c.]; (JK, S, K;) or the first three signify the froth that comes upon a thing when it estuates; and the next three, the froth of milk: (Msb:) pl. of the first ragawaAtN, (Msb, TA,) and of the second rugFI, (S, * Msb, TA,) and of the last ragaAwaI. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Also the first (ragowapN), A rock, or a piece of rock. (IAar, K.)

rugowapN c
rugowapN [The grumbling cry termed raAgiyapN;] a subst. from zugaMCN [inf. n. of ragaA]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also the next preceding paragraph.

rigowapN c
rigowapN: see ragowapN.

ragowaAnu c
ragowaAnu: see ragRaMCN.

rugaMCN c
rugaMCN inf. n. of 1 as explained in the first sentence. (S, K, &c.) [It is often used as a simple subst. like its syn. raAgiyapN.] ― -b2- See also ragRaMCN.

raguwRN c
raguwRN A she-camel that utters much, or often, the grumbling cry termed rugaMC. (S, K.)

rugaAwapN c
rugaAwapN: see ragowapN.

ruigaAyapN c
ruigaAyapN: see ragowapN.

rugaAwaI c
rugaAwaI: see ragowapN.

ragRaMCN c
ragRaMCN (assumed tropical:) Loquacious: or loud in voice: (TA:) and ragowaAnu↓ is [syn. therewith, or nearly so, being] a surname of Mujáshi' (K, TA) the son of Dárim, (TA,) because of his eloquence, (K, TA,) and the loudness of his voice. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A certain bird, (K, TA,) that cries much and uninterruptedly; (TA;) of the kind called duxRal; dust-coloured: its crying is termed rugaMCN↓: and the pl. is ragRaAMtN. (En-Nadr, TA.)

raAgK c
raAgK [part. n. of ragaA]. You say naAqapN raAgiyapN A she-camel that utters the cry termed rugaMC. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] maA lahu vaAgK walaA raAgK [He has not a sheep or goat, nor a camel]: (TA in art. vgw:) and maA lahu vaAgiyapN walaA raAgiyapN He has not a sheep or goat, nor a she-camel: (S:) and maA biAldRaAri vaAgK walaA raAgK (assumed tropical:) There is not in the house any one. (S and TA in art. vgw.) ― -b3- Also, raAgK, A certain bird, begotten between the waraXaAn [q. v.] and the HamaAm [or common pigeon]; an admirable variety: so says Kzw, but he has written the word with the unpointed E: Es-Suyootee says that in the “ Tibyán ” it is with the pointed g: and El-Jáhidh mentions its being prolific, long-lived, and having in its cooing a quality which its parents have not. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also Milk having froth. (JK.)

raAgiyapN c
raAgiyapN fem. of raAgK [q. v.] ― -b2- Also syn. with rugaMCN [as an inf. n. or a simple subst.]: (JK:) see 1, in two places: [as a simple subst., like rugowapN, it has for its pl. rawaAgK:] you say, samiEotu rawaAgiIa AlOibili I heard the [grumbling] cries of the camels. (TA.)

murogK c
murogK [act. part. n. of 4]. ― -b2- [Its fem.] murogiyapN is app. the sing. of maraAgiI [probably a mistranscription for maraAgK, the reg. pl.], (TA,) which is an epithet applied to camels, meaning Whose milk has much froth. (K, TA.)

mirogaApN c
mirogaApN A skimmer; i. e. a thing with which (or in which, as in one copy of the K,) froth is taken: (S, K:) or a wooden thing with which one takes off the froth of milk: pl. maraAgK. (JK.)

kalaAmN muragRK c
kalaAmN muragRK (tropical:) Speech, or language, that does not clearly express its meaning. (S, K, TA.)

1 rafRa c
1. rafRa, (T,) or rafRa lawonuhu, (S, M, O, K,) aor.
rafifa
, inf. n. rafRN and rafiyfN, Its colour shone, or glistened; (T, S, M, O, K;) said of a thing; (T;) as also
ArtfR↓. (K.) Thus rafRato OasonaAnuhu, His teeth shone, or glistened. (M.) El-Aashà says, describing the front teeth of a woman,
yaXofiI AlmutayRama caA AlHaraAraho
wamahFA tarifRu guruwbuhu
[And clean, white, lustrous front teeth, the abundance of their saliva shining, or glistening; that would cure of his malady the enslaved by love who has burning in his heart]. (T, O, S.) And one says also, rafRa Albaroqu, aor.
rafifa
and
rafufa
, (M,) inf. n. rafRN, (M, K,) The lightning gleamed, or shone; or flashed faintly, and then disappeared, and then flashed again. (M, K. *) ― -b2- rafRa AlnRabaAtu, aor.
rafifa
, inf. n. rafiyfN, The plant, or herbage, quivered, or became tall, (AihotazRa,) being green and glistening; and wariyfN is a dial. var. of the inf. n. raciyfN in this sense: (Lth, T:) or quivered, or became tall, (AhtzR,) and was luxuriant, or flourishing, and fresh, or succulent: or, as AHn says, became glistening, or bright, in its sap: (M:) and rafRa AlXRajaru, aor. and inf. n. as above, The trees appeared beautiful and bright in their greenness by reason of their succulence and luxuriance; as also warifa, aor. yarifu, inf. n. wariyfN. (T in art. wrf.) ― -b3- rafRato Eayonuhu, aor.
rafifa
and
rafufa
, inf. n. rafRN, His eye quivered, or throbbed: (M, K:) and in like manner one says of any other member, or part of the person, (M,) or of other things; (IAar, T, K;) as, for instance, of the eyebrow. (IAar, T, M.) ― -b4- rafRa said of a bird: see R. Q. 1, in two places. ― -b5- rafRa, aor.
rafifa
, [said of a man,] He exulted; rejoiced overmuch, or above measure; or exulted greatly, or excessively; and was exceedingly brisk, lively, or sprightly: and behaved proudly, or haughtily; was proud, haughty, or self-conceited; or walked with a proud, or haughty, and selfconceited, gait. (M.) ― -b6- rafRa UilaI kacaA He was, or became, brisk, lively, or sprightly, at, or to do, such a thing; syn. AirotaAHa: (K:) and so said of the heart. (O.) ― -b7- rafRa lahu, (O, K,) aor.
rafufa
and
rafifa
, inf. n. rufuwfN and rafiyfN, (O,) He laboured for him with service, both honourable and mean. (O, K.) ― -b8- rafRa bifulaAnK He treated such a one with honour: (O, K:) [and so, accord. to the TA, rafRa fulaAnFA, as is shown in the first paragraph of art. Hf.] ― -b9- rafRa Alqawomu bihi The people, or party, surrounded, encompassed, or encircled, him; or went round him, or round about him. (O, K.) ― -b10- rafRato Ealayohi AlnRiEomapu Wealth became abundantly bestowed upon him; syn. Dafato. (M.) ＝ -A2- rafRa, aor.
rafufa
(IAar, T, K) and
rafifa
, (K,) [probably trans., or so with the former aor. and intrans. with the latter,] inf. n. rafRN, (O,) He ate (IAar, T, K) soundly, (IAar, T, [see rafRapN, the inf. n. of unity,]) or much, or largely. (O, K.) ― -b2- rafRati AlUibilu, (AHn, M, K,) and Alganamu, (K,) or rfRt Albaqola, (TK,) aor.
rafufa
and
rafifa
, inf. n. rafRN, The camels, (M, K,) and the sheep or goats, (K,) ate, (AHn, M, K,) or ate herbs, or leguminous plants, (TK,) in a certain manner, (K,) without filling the mouth therewith. (TK.) ― -b3- rafRa AllRabana, (TK,) inf. n. rafRN, (K,) He drank milk every day. (K, TK.) ― -b4- [Hence, perhaps,] Oaxacatohu AlHumRaI rafRFA The fever attacked him every day. (O, K.) ― -b5- rafRa, aor.
rafufa
, (A 'Obeyd, T, S, M,) inf. n. rafRN (A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, K) and rafiyfN, (M,) also signifies He sucked (A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, K) a thing: (M:) and he sucked in [saliva &c.] with his lips. (A 'Obeyd, T, S.) You say, rafRa OumRahu He (a young camel) sucked his mother. (K.) And rRfRa AlmaroOapa, (M, O,) or AljaAriyapa, (IAar, L in art. mSd,) aor.
rafufa
, (M, O,) inf. n. rafRN, (O,) He sucked in the woman's, or the girl's, saliva from her mouth: (IAar, M, and L ubi suprà:) or he kissed her with the extremities of his lips. (M, O, K.) And hence, (M,) UinRiI laOarufRu XafatayohaA waOanaA SaAYimN, in a trad. of Aboo-Hureyreh, (T, M, O, Msb,) means Verily I suck in her saliva [from her lips while I am fasting]: (A 'Obeyd, T, M, O:) or I kiss [her lips], and suck [them], and suck in [her saliva from them]. (Msb.) ＝ -A3- rafRahu, (M, O, K,) aor.
rafufa
, (M,) inf. n. rafRN, (M, O, K, *) He did good to him; conferred a benefit, or benefits, upon him. (M, O, K. *) [And He gave to him.] You say, fulaAnN yaHufRunaA wayarofRunaA, meaning Such a one gives to us, and brings us corn or food. (M. [See also other explanations in art. Hf.]) And fulaAnN yarufRunaA Such a one guards us, defends us, or takes care of us. (S.) [Hence,] it is said in a prov., mano HafRanaA Oawo rafRanaA faloyaqotaSido [explained in art. Hf]: and one says, maA lahu HaAfRN walaA raAfRN↓ [also explained in art. Hf]. (S.) ＝ -A4- rafRa Albayota He made to the byt [which here seems from the context to mean tent] what is termed a rafR [q. v.]. (M.) [And hence, app.,] rafRa vawobahu, aor.
rafufa
, inf. n. rafRu, He added to his garment, or piece of cloth, another piece, to enlarge it, at its lower part. (K.) ＝ -A5- rafRahu He fed him [i. e. a beast] with rufRap, i. e. straw, or straw that had been trodden, or thrashed, and cut, and what had been broken in pieces thereof. (M.) ＝ -A6- rafRa AlvRawobu, (M,) inf. n. rafafN, (M, O, K,) The garment, or piece of cloth, became thin: (M, O, K: *) but this is not of established authority. (M.)

4 ArfRt EalaI bayoDatihaA c
4. ArfRt EalaI bayoDatihaA She (a hen) spread, or expanded, the wing over her egg. (O, K.)

8 Uirotafafa
8: see 1, first sentence.

R. Q. 1 raforafa c
R. Q. 1. raforafa, (T, S, M, K,) inf.n. raforafapN, (T, K,) He (a bird) moved, or agitated, his wings, in the air, [or fluttered in the air,] without moving from his place; (T, M;) as also rafRa↓: (M:) or he (a bird, S, or an ostrich, K) did thus around a thing, desiring to alight, or fall, upon it: (S, O, K:) or he (a bird) expanded and flapped his wings without alighting: (TA in art. frX:) and he (a bird) expanded his wings; as also rafRa↓; but this latter is not used. (O, K.) One says also, of an ostrich, yuraforifu bijanaAHayohi vumRa yaEoduw [He flaps his wings, then runs]. (T, S, O.) ― -b2- [See also R. Q. 1 in art. zf, last sentence.] ― -b3- rfrf EalaI Alqawomi He was, or became, affectionate, favourable, or kind, to the people, or party; syn. taHadRaba. (M.) ― -b4- raforafapN also signifies The making a sound: (K:) its verb, raforafa, meaning It (a thing) made a sound. (TK.)

rafRN c
rafRN A thing resembling a TaAq, [i. e. a kind of arched construction, app. like the SufRap described and figured in the Introduction to my work on the Modern Egyptians,] (El-Fárábee, S, Msb, K,) upon which are placed the TaraAYif [or choice articles, such as vessels and other utensils &c.,] of the house; as also raforafN↓: (IAar, T, K:) the rafR that is [commonly] used in houses is well known [as being a wooden shelf, generally extending along one or more of the sides of a room]: IDrd says that the word is Arabic: (Msb:) the pl. is rufuwfN (T, S, O, Mgh, Msb, K) and rifaAfN. (O, Mgh, Msb.) The latter pl. occurs in the saying of Kaab Ibn-El-Ashraf, OamaA UinRa rifaAfiI taqaSRafu tamorFA Verily my shelves are breaking with dates, by reason of the large quantity thereof. (Mgh.) rufuwfu AlxaXabi, also, means The planks of the laHod [or lateral hollow of a grave]. (Mgh.) [And accord. to Golius, on the authority of a gloss. in the KL, rafRN also signifies A small arched window in a wall.] ＝ -A2- [When the rafR of a bayot is mentioned, by byt may sometimes be meant a tent:] see raforafN. ＝ -A3- Also A flock of sheep, (Fr, T, S, M, O, K,) or of sheep or goats. (Lh, M, K.) ― -b2- A herd of oxen or cows. (Lh, O, K.) ― -b3- A row of birds. (IAar, T and TA in art. Abl.) ― -b4- A company of men. (Fr, T.) ― -b5- Large camels; (O, K;) as also rifRN↓: (K:) [or] a large herd of camels. (M.) ＝ -A4- An enclosure (HaZiyrap) for sheep or goats. (M, O, K.) ＝ -A5- Any tract of sand elevated above what is adjacent to it or around it. (K.) ＝ -A6- Wheat, corn, or other provision, which one brings for himself or his family or for sale; syn. miyrapN. (M, K.) ＝ -A7- A soft garment or piece of cloth. (K.) ＝ -A8- And, as some say, (M,) Saliva (M, K) itself [as well as the “ sucking in of saliva: ” see 1]. (M.)

rufRN c
rufRN: see rufRapN.

rifRN c
rifRN A daily Xirob [i. e. drinking, or share of water]. ＝ -A2- See also rafRN.

rafRapN c
rafRapN [inf. n. of unity of rafRa,] i. q. baroqapN [app. as meaning A flash of lightning]: (IAar, T:) or a shining, or glistening. (O.) ― -b2- And A quivering, or throbbing. (IAar, T.) ＝ -A2- Also A sound act of eating; syn. OakolapN muHokamapN. (IAar, T, O, K. [In the CK, in this sense, erroneously written rufRap.]) ― -b2- And A suck. (IAar, T.)

rufRapN c
rufRapN i. q. tibonN [i. e. Straw; or straw that has been trodden or thrashed, and cut]; and what has been broken in pieces thereof; [also written rufapN and rufatN and rufapN;] (M, O, K;) as also. rufRN↓. (K.) [See also rufapN.]

rufaAfu c
rufaAfu What has fallen about of straw, and of dried leaves or branches of the samur [or gumacacia-tree]. (IAar, M.)

rafiyfN c
rafiyfN Shining, or glistening. (KL. [The meaning of “ dispersed ” assigned to it by Golius as on the authority of the KL is not in my copy of that work, nor is any other meaning than that which I have given above; in which sense it is
app. an inf. n. used as an epithet: it is expl. in the KL by the Pers. word drxXndh.]) One says also vagorN rafaAfN [app. rafRaAfN↓] Front teeth shining or glistening. (Har p. 314.) ― -b2- Applied to a garment, or piece of cloth, (S, O,) and to trees (Xajar), (S, O, * K,) and other things, (K,) Moistened [app. by dew or the like, so as to be rendered glossy]. (S, O, K.) ― -b3- Also, applied to a garment, or piece of cloth, Thin. (O.) ＝ -A2- Abundance of herbage, or of the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life. (O, K.) ＝ -A3- The lily. (O, K.) ＝ -A4- The roof (Sh, M, O, K) of a [tent such as is called] fusoTaAT. (Sh, O, M.) ― -b2- See also raforafN. ＝ -A5- caAtu AlrRafiyf Boats upon which a river was crossed, consisting of two or three joined together, for the use of the king. (O, K.)

rifaAfapN c
rifaAfapN, The thing that is put in the lower part of the helmet. (AA, O. [See also raforafN.])

rafRaAfN c
rafRaAfN: see the next preceding paragraph. ― -b2- Also A plant, or herbage, intensely green. (TA in art. wrf.)

raforafN c
raforafN: see rafRN, first sentence. ― -b2- Also A window; or an aperture for the admission of light; syn. rawoXanN; (IAar, T, K;) and so rafiyfN↓. (AA, T, O, K.) ＝ -A2- Also Coverlets (HaAbis, Katádeh, T) for beds: (T:) or beds [themselves]: (AO, T, O, K:) or carpets: (AO, T, K:) or green pieces of cloth, or pieces of cloth of a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour, (viyaAbN xuDorN, [which may have either of these two meanings,] S, M, O, K,) that are spread, (M,) or of which maHaAbis [see above] are made, (S, O, K,) and which are spread; (K;) n. un. with p; (S, O, M;) but some make the former a sing.: (O:) pl. rafaArifu: (M:) or it signifies, (T, O,) or signifies also, (K,) the redundant parts of maHaAbis, (T, O, K,) and of beds; (K;) and anything that is redundant and that is folded: (O, K:) or pieces of thin diybaAj [or silk brocade]: (M, K:) it occurs in the Kur lv. 76: and some say that it there means the meadows, or gardens, (riyaAD,) of Paradise: (Fr, T:) or, as some say, pillows: (T:) or it signifies also a pillow: and meadows, or gardens; syn. riyaADN: (K:) also a carpet: (T:) and sometimes it is applied to any wide garment or piece of cloth. (Bd in lv. 76.) ― -b2- Also The kisor [app. as meaning the lowest piece of cloth, or the part of that piece that is folded upon the ground,] of a [tent of the kind called] xibaMC: (Lth, T, S, M, O, K:) and a piece of cloth (xiroqapN) that is sewed upon the lower part of a [tent of the kind called] fusoTaAT, (Lth, T, M, K,) and of a suraAdiq, (M, K,) and the like; as also rafRN↓, of which the pl. is rufuwfN: (M: [in the CK, AlfusoTATu is erroneously put for AlfusoTaATi:]) or the skirt of a tent: (Bd in lv. 76:) and, accord. to IAar, the extremity, edge, or border, of a fusoTaAT. (T.) ― -b3- Also The redundant portion of the skirt of a coat of mail: (A 'Obeyd, T, O:) or the sides of a coat of mail, (S, K,) and the pendent portions thereof: (S, O, K:) n. un. with p. (S.) And the raforaf of a coat of mail is [The tasobigap, q. v.: or] a piece of mail (zaradN) which is fastened to the helmet, and which the man makes to fall down upon his back. (M, K.) ― -b4- The pendent branches of the [tree called] Oayokap. (T, O, K.) ― -b5- Soft, or tender, and drooping trees. (M, K.) And Certain trees, (K,) certain drooping trees, (As, T, O,) growing in El-Yemen. (As, T, O, K.) ― -b6- Also, [because pendent,] The [caruncle, in the vulva of a girl or woman, called] baZor [q. v.]. (Lh, M, K.) ＝ -A3- And A species of fish (Lth, T, M, O, K) of the sea. (M, K.)

AlrRaforaAfu c
