AlrRaforaAfu The bird called xaATifu ZilRihi. (Ibn-Selemeh, S, O, K. [See art. xTafa.]) And sometimes, (S,) The male ostrich: (T, S, M, O, K:) because (S) he flaps his wings (yuraforifu bijanaAHayohi) and then runs. (T, S, O.) ― -b2- Also The wing of an ostrich and of any bird. (M.)

rufaArifN c
rufaArifN Quick, or swift. (O.)

raAfRN c
raAfRN: see 1, [of which it is the act. part. n.,] in the last quarter of the paragraph.

marafRN c
marafRN i. q. maOokalN [A place, or time, of eating]. (O.) [This art. is wanting in the copies of the L and TA to which I have had access.]

1 rafaOa AlsRafiynapa c
1. rafaOa AlsRafiynapa, (M, Mgh, K,) aor.
rafaAa
, inf. n. rafoCN, (M,) He brought the ship near to the bank of a river; (M, K;) as also OarofaOahaA↓: (S, TA:) or both signify he brought the ship near to the bank of a river and made her still, or motionless: (Mgh:) or the latter, he brought her near to the land; or to the part of the land that was near; or so the former accord. to AZ; (T;) and so the latter: but in the K, ArfO is expl. as signifying simply he made, or drew, or brought, near. (TA.) OarofaWuwA↓ UilaI jaziyrapK occurs in a trad. [as meaning They brought the ship near to an island]: and some say Oarofayotu for OarofaOotu; which latter is the original. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, accord. to ISd in the M, but this I think doubtful,] rafaOa AlvRawoba, (AZ, T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (AZ, T, S, Mgh, Msb,) and so the inf. n., (AZ, T, S, Mgh,) He repaired, or mended, [or darned,] the garment, (S, Msb,) where it was rent; (S;) or he closed up what was rent in the garment, drawing the parts together, (M, Mgh, K,) by texture [with the needle, i. e. darning]: (Mgh:) and sometimes it is pronounced without C; (S;) [i. e.,] one says also [rafaA AlvRawoba, and] rafawotuhu, aor.
rafuAa
, (Msb,) inf. n. rafowN; (IAar, T, Msb;) and rafayotuhu, aor.
rafiAa
, inf. n. rafoIN, which is of the dial. of Benoo-Kaab; (Msb;) but this last is strange. (TA.) [See 1 in art. rfw.] One says, mani MgotaAba xaraqa wamani Qsotagofara rafaOa (tropical:) [He who traduces another, behind his back or otherwise, though with truth, rends, and he who begs forgiveness repairs]: (S, M:) i. e., by AlAigotiyaAb he rends his religion, and by AlAisotigofaAr he repairs it. (M.) ― -b3- And [hence,] rafaOa bayonahumo He effected a reconciliation, or made peace, between them; (M, K;) like raqaOa. (TA.) ― -b4- And rafaOa AlrRajula, (M, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) He appeased quieted, or calmed, the man, (M, K, TA, [like rafaAhu, without C, see art. rfw,]) stilling his fear, or terror, and treated him with gentleness. (TA.) ― -b5- See also 3. ― -b6- rafaOa is also said to signify tazawRaja [He married; or took a wife]; (TA;) or so rafA [without C]. (T.)

2 rfRMhu c
2. rfRMhu, (T, S, M, K,) inf. n. tarofiYapN and tarofiIoCN, (T, S, K,) He said to him, (namely, a man who had had a wife given to him, T, S, M,) biAlrRifaMCi waAlbaniyna; (T, S, M, K; [see rifaMCN, below;]) as also rfRAhu, without C. (TA.)

3 rAfOhu c
3. rAfOhu, (AZ, T, S, M,) inf. n. muraAfaOapN; (AZ, T;) and ArfOhu↓, (K, but there without any objective complement,) and rafaOahu↓; (TA;) He treated him in an easy and a gentle manner; or abated to him the price, or payment; syn. HaAbaAhu; (AZ, T, S, M, K; *) fiI AlbayoEi [in selling]: (AZ, T, S:) or ArfOhu↓ signifies daAraAhu [he treated him with gentleness, or blandishment; soothed, coaxed, wheedled, or cajoled, him; &c.]: (IAar, M:) or ArfO is also syn. with daAraI; and so is rAfO. (K.)

4 ArfO c
4. ArfO He, or it, drew near, or approached. (K.) You say, ArfOti AlsRafiynapu The ship drew near, or approached, (T, TA,) to the land, (T,) or to the part of the land that was near, or to the bank of a river. (TA.) ― -b2- ArfO Uilayohi He inclined to, or towards, him, or it; (Fr, T, K; *) as also ArfI. (Fr, T.) And (K) He had recourse, or he betook himself, or repaired, to him, or it, for refuge, protection, preservation, concealment, covert, or lodging; (S, M, K;) as also ArfI. (TA in art. rfw.) ― -b3- He combed, or combed and dressed, his hair. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A2- As a trans. v.: see 1, in two places: ― -b2- and see also 3, in two places.

6 taraAfaWuwA c
6. taraAfaWuwA They agreed together; or were of one mind or opinion: (S, K:) and they aided, or assisted, one another; or leagued together, and aided one another. (S.) And trAfWwA EalaI AlOamori They agreed together to do the thing: (M:) they agreed together, or conspired, to do the thing, their stratagem and their affair being one. (T, TA.)

rifaMCN c
rifaMCN Close union; coalescence; (ISk, T, S, M, K;) consociation; these being the meanings if the root be with C: (ISk, T:) good consociation: (T:) and composure of disunited circumstances or affairs: (K:) or reparation: (Msb:) and concord, or agreement; (T, S, M;) like muraAfaAtN; [if the root be] without C: (T:) or, if the root be without C, the meaning is tranquillity; or freedom from disturbance, or agitation. (ISk, T, S.) Such are said to be the meanings in the saying, biAlrRifaMCi waAlbaniyna; (ISk, T, S, M, Msb, K; [see 2;]) i. e. [May it (the marriage) be] with close union, &c., (K, TA,) and increase (TA) [or rather the begetting of sons, not daughters]: or with reparation [of circumstances or condition, and the begetting of sons]. (Msb.) It is said, in a trad., that the Prophet forbade the use of this phrase, disliking it because it was a customary form of congratulation in the Time of Ignorance: (T, * TA:) and some relate that he used to say, in its stead, baAraka QllRehu Ealayoka and baAraka fiyka [May God
bless thee], and jamaEa bayonakumaA fiI xayorK [may He unite you two in prosperity]. (T, TA.) Some of them used to congratulate him who had taken a wife by saying, biAlrRifaMCi waAlvRabaAti waAlbaniyna laA AlbanaAti [May it be with close union, &c., and constancy, and the begetting of sons, not daughters]. (Har p. 364.) And one says also, bayona Alqawomi rifaMCN, meaning Between the people is close union, and concord, or agreement. (Msb.)

rafRaMCN c
rafRaMCN [A darner;] one who closes up what is rent in garments, drawing the parts together, (M, Mgh, K,) by texture [with the needle, i. e. darning]; in Pers. rafuwGaro. (Mgh.)

marofaON c
marofaON: see the next paragraph. ― -b2- Also A place where garments are darned. (KL.)

murofaON c
murofaON, (S, Mgh, Sgh, K,) and marofaON↓, (M, K,) [A station of ships;] a place where ships are brought near to the bank of a river [or to the land; see 1, first sentence]; (S, M, K;) i. q. furoDapN. (Mgh.)

yarofaYiIRN c
yarofaYiIRN Heartless, or deprived of his heart, by reason of fright. (M, K.) ― -b2- A male ostrich: (M:) or a male ostrich taking fright, and fleeing, or running away at random. (K.) ― -b3- A gazelle; because of its briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness, and its uninterrupted running: (M:) or a gazelle that leaps, jumps, springs, or bounds, much, or often, (qafuwzN,) and goes back, or retreats, (M, * K, TA,) fleeing. (TA.) ― -b4- And A pastor of sheep or goats: (M, K:) it is said to have this meaning: (T:) or by this is meant a certain black slave so called. (TA.)

1 rafatahu c
1. rafatahu, (T, M, A, K,) aor.
rafita
and
rafuta
, (M, K,) inf. n. rafotN, (M,) He broke it; (T, M, K;) or broke it in pieces: (T:) he crushed, bruised, brayed, or pounded, it: (M, K:) he crumbled it, or broke it into small pieces, with his hand, like as is done with lumps of dry clay, and old and decayed bones. (A.) And rufita It was broken; or broken in pieces; [&c.] (Akh, S.) You say, rafata Eunuqahu, aor.
rafita
, inf. n. as above, He broke, or crushed, his neck. (Lh, M.) And rafata EiZaAma Aljazuwri He broke the bones of the slaughtered camel, in order to cook them and to extract their grease. (T.) And one says of him who does that from which he finds it difficult to liberate himself, AlDRabuEu taroqutu AlEiZaAma walaA taEorifu qadora QsotihaA taOokuluhaA vumRa yaEosuru EalayohaA xuruwjuhaA [The hyena breaks in pieces the bones, but knows not the size of its anus: it eats them; then their exit becomes difficult to it]. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] rafata AlEaTaXa (assumed tropical:) It (water) broke the vehemence of thirst. (Z, TA in art. frt.) ＝ -A2- (See also 9.)

2 rfRthu c
2. rfRthu, inf. n. tarofiytN, He broke it [app. much, or into many pieces]: ― -b2- and hence, (assumed tropical:) He dishonoured, despised, or condemned, him; tarofiytN being syn. with taHoqiyrN, and contr. of tarofiylN and taEoZiymN. (Er-Rághib, TA. *)

9 ArftR c
9. ArftR, as also rafata↓, (M, K,) the latter being intrans. as well as trans., (K, * TA,) It was, or became, broken, broken in pieces, crushed, bruised, brayed, or pounded: (M, K:) said of a bone; i. e., it became what is termed rufaAtN. (M.) And It became cut or broken, cut off or broken off; it broke, or broke off: (K, TA:) the former is said, in this sense, of a rope. (A, TA.)

rufatN c
rufatN i. q. tibonN [i. e. Straw; or straw that has been trodden, or thrashed, and cut: also written rufRapN, and rufapN, and rufapN]. (IAar, T, K.) It is said in a prov., OanaA OagonaI Eanoka mina AltRufahi Eani AlrRufati, (TA,) or UilaI AlrRufati (T,) [I am more free from the want of thee than the badger is from the want of straw, or cut straw]: the tfh is what is called EanaAqu AlOaroDi, which has a canine tooth, and does not procure for itself straw nor herbage; and the word is written with h; but Alrft is with t: (T:) or, accord. to ISk, the two words are correctly without teshdeed, and with the radical h. (TA in art. tfh.) [See also rufahN.] ＝ -A2- Also One who breaks, breaks in pieces, crushes, bruises, brays, pounds, or crumbles, anything, or everything. (K, * TA.)

rifotapN c
rifotapN A mode, or manner, of breaking, breaking in pieces, crushing, &c. (Lh, M.)

rufaAtN c
rufaAtN A thing, (M,) an old and decayed bone, (A, TA,) or anything, (L, TA,) broken, broken in pieces, crushed, bruised, brayed, or pounded; (M, L, TA;) or crumbled, or broken into small pieces with the hand; (A, TA;) or a thing that has become old and worn out, and crumbled, or broken into small pieces: ('Ináyeh, TA: [see marofuwtN:]) or broken, or crumbled, particles; fragments, or crumbs; of a thing that is dry, (T, S, A, K, TA,) of any kind; (T;) [as, for instance,] of musk. (A, TA.) Hence, in the Kur [xvii. 52 and 100], OaYicaA kunRaA EiZaAmFA warufaAtFA When we shall have become bones and broken particles? (S, M, TA.) [Hence also the phrase] laA birofaAtika, meaning No, by thy ancestors who have become broken and crumbled bones in the dust. (Har p. 634.) And [hence one says,] huwa AlRaciI OaEaAda AlmakaArima waOaHoyaA rufaAtahaA waOanoXara OamowaAtahaA (tropical:) [He is the person who has restored generous qualities or actions, and revived such of them as had decayed, and brought to life again such of them as had become dead]. (A, TA.)

marofuwtN c
marofuwtN Broken, broken in pieces, &c. (Akh, S. [See rufaAtN.])

1 rafava c
1. rafava (T, S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K) fiI kalaAmihi (M, A, Mgh) or fiI manoTiqihi (Msb,) aor.
rafuva
, (K, and so in a copy of the S,) or
rafiva
, (T, and so in another copy of the S,) or both, (Msb, TA,) the latter mentioned by 'Iyád in the “ Meshárik; ” (TA;) and rafiva, (M, K,) aor.
rafava
; (K;) and rafuva, aor.
rafuva
; (Lh, M, K;) inf. n. rafovN, which is of rafava, (M, TA,) and rafavN, (T, * S, * M, A, * Mgh, * Msb, K, *) which is of rafiva, (M, TA,) or of rafava, (Msb,) or, accord. to some, this is a simple subst., (TA,) and rufuwvN; (K;) and Arfv↓; (T, S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) and trfRv↓; (A;) He uttered foul, unseemly, immodest, lewd, or obscene, speech, (T, S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) in relation to women: (T:) and talked to a woman, in, or respecting, coition; (S, K, TA;) and (as in the A and Mgh, but in the Msb “ or ”) spoke plainly of what should be indicated allusively, relating to coition. (A, Mgh, Msb.) And rafava biQmoraOatihi, and maEahaA, He compressed his wife: and he kissed her; and held amatory and enticing talk, or conversation, with her; and did any other similar act, of such acts as occur in the case of coition. (M.) And rafava UilaI QmoraOatihi He went in to his wife; i. e. he compressed her; or was with her alone in private, whether he compressed her or not; syn. OafoDaI UilayohaA. (A.) [See also rafavN below.]

3 rAfv SaAHibahu c
3. rAfv SaAHibahu, inf. n. muraAfavapN, [He joined with his companion, or vied with him, in foul, unseemly, immodest, lewd, or obscene, conversation, in relation to women: and in talking plainly of what should be indicated allusively, relating to coition.] (A.)

4 Oarofava
4: see 1, first sentence.

5 tarafRava
5: see 1, first sentence.

6 trAfvA c
6. trAfvA [They two joined mutually, or vied with each other, in foul, unseemly, immodest, lewd, or obscene, conversation, in relation to women: and in talking plainly of what should be indicated allusively, relating to coition]; said of two men. (A.)

rafavN c
rafavN, said by some to be a simple subst., but by others to be an inf. n., (TA,) Foul, unseemly, immodest, lewd, or obscene, speech, (Lth, T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) in relation to women; (T;) this being the primary signification: (Lth, T:) and talk to women in, or respecting, coition: (S, K, TA:) and the speaking plainly of what should be indicated allusively, relating to coition: (Mgh:) or allusion to coition: (M:) or foul, unseemly, immodest, lewd, or obscene, speech addressed to women; (T, S, Mgh, K;) so accord. to I'Ab: (T, S, Mgh:) and coition: (Lth, T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K:) and kissing; and amatory and enticing talk, or conversation; and any other similar act, of such acts as occur in the case of coition: (M:) or with the pudendum, (A, Mgh,) or with respect to the pudendum, (Msb,) it is coition: (A, Mgh, Msb:) and with the tongue, (A, Mgh,) or with respect to the tongue, (Msb,) the making an appointment for coition: (A, Mgh, Msb:) and with the eye, (A, Mgh,) or with respect to the eye, (Msb,) the making a signal of a desire for coition: (A, Mgh, Msb:) or it is a word comprehending everything that a man desires of his wife. (Zj, T.) In the Kur ii. 193, where it is forbidden during pilgrimage, it means Coition: (Zj, T, Mgh, Msb:) and speech that may be a means of inducing coition: (Zj, T:) or foul, unseemly, immodest, lewd, or obscene, speech: (M, Mgh, Msb:) or, accord. to Th, the removal of external impurities of the body, by such actions as the paring of the nails, and plucking out the hair of the armpit, and shaving the pubes, and the like. (M. [In the L and TA, the explanation
of Th is so given as to relate, not to rafavN, but, to laA rafava.]) And in the same, ii. 183, where it is allowed in the night of fasting, it means Coition: (Msb:) or the going in to one's wife; syn. UifoDaMC; wherefore it is made trans. by means of UilaI, like as is UifoDaMC. (M, Mgh.)

1 rafadahu c
1. rafadahu, aor.
rafida
, inf. n. rafodN, He gave him, or gave him a gift: (T, S, M, A, * Msb, K:) or it signifies, (Msb,) or signifies also, (S, M, A,) he aided, helped, or assisted, him: (T, S, M, A, Msb:) and Arfdhu↓, (M, A, Msb,) inf. n. UirofaAdN, (S, K,) signifies the same (S, M, A, Msb, K) in the latter sense, (S, M, A, K,) and in the former sense also: (S, K:) or both signify he aided, helped, or assisted, him, by a gift or by a saying or by some other thing: (Mgh:) [it is said in the Ham p. 128, that the latter verb has been transmitted, but is not the choice one; but in p. 276, that both are chaste:] and you say also rAfdhu↓; (A;) [meaning he aided him; or he aided with him; or he aided him, being aided by him; for] muraAfadapN is syn. with muEaAwanapN. (S, L.) One says, laA Oaquwmu UilRaA rafodFA I will not stand unless I be helped to do so. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] He propped it up; namely, a wall: (Zj, T, A:) and rafadotuhu bihi I propped it up, or supported it, namely, a thing, with it, meaning any other thing used for such a purpose. (Zj, T.) ― -b3- And [hence,] rafadahu, (M, L,) or rafada Ealayohi, aor.
rafida
, inf. n. rafodN, (AZ, T, S, M,) He made for him, (AZ, S, M, *) or put upon him, (T, M, *) namely, a camel, (AZ, S,) an appertenance of the saddle, called a rifaAdap: (AZ, T, S, M:) [and Arfdhu↓, or Arfd Ealayohi, signifies the same; for] UirofaAdN is syn. with rafodN as meaning the putting to a beast, or furnishing him with, a rifaAdap. (K.) [Hence,] yurofadu bixiroqapK [meaning It is furnished with a piece of rag, as a compress,] is said of a wound (S, K) &c. (S.) ― -b4- And rafadahu signifies also It held it fast; namely, any one thing, another thing. (M.)

2 rafRaduwA fulaAnFA c
2. rafRaduwA fulaAnFA, (M, A,) inf. n. tarofiydN, (S, K,) (tropical:) They made such a one a lord, or chief; (S, M, A, K;) made him great, or magnified him, or honoured him; (K; *) and set him over their affairs; (M;) [lit. made him to give gifts;] as also rafRaluwhu: because a man when he becomes a lord, or chief, gives gifts, and drags his skirt upon the ground (UicaA saAda rafada warafala). (A.) And rufRida fulaAnN (tropical:) Such a one was made a lord, or chief; and was made great, or magnified, or honoured. (S, TA.) ＝ -A2- rfRd, (T, L,) inf. n. as above, (T, L, K,) also signifies He went a pace like that called hmolajapN, (T, L,) or like that called harowalapN. (K.) [See 2 in art. rqd.]

3 raAofada
3: see 1.

4 Oarofada
4: see 1, in two places.

6 trAfdwA c
6. trAfdwA They aided, helped, or assisted, one another [by gifts or otherwise]. (S, * M, A, Msb, K. *)

8 Artfd c
8. Artfd He gained, acquired, or earned, (T, S, M, A, K,) property. (T, M, A.) And Artfdtu minohu I obtained a gift, or aid, from him. (A.)

10 Astrfdhu c
10. Astrfdhu He sought, desired, demanded, or asked, aid, help, or assistance, from him [by a gift or otherwise]. (S, * A, Msb, K. *)

rafodN c
rafodN: see the next paragraph.

rifodN c
rifodN A gift; (S, A, Msb, * K;) [and so, app., mirofadN↓ or marofadN↓;] a gratuity: (T, S, A, K:) pl. OarofaAdN (Ham p. 128) [and maraAfidu is pl. of mirofadN or marofadN]. You say, huwa kaviyru AlOarofaAdi and AlmaraAfidi↓ [He is a person of many gifts]. (A.) It is said in a trad., mini QqotiraAba AlsRaAEapi Oano yakuwna AlfaIoCu rifodFA [One of the signs] of the approach of the hour of resurrection shall be, that the tribute shall be a gratuity bestowed according to men's natural desires, and not according to right, or desert. (T, L.) ― -b2- Aid, help, or assistance; (T, M, L, Msb;) as also mirofdN and marofdN [app. mirofadN↓ and marofadN↓]; (M;) by a gift, and by giving milk to drink, and by a saying, and by anything. (T.) ― -b3- A lot, share, or portion. (M, L.) ― -b4- Also, (IAar, Ibn-El-Mubárak, T, S, M, A, L, K,) and rafodN↓, (El-Muärrij, T, S, M, L, K,) and mirofadN↓, (S, M, L, K,) and marofadN↓, (M, L,) A large [drinking-cup, or bowl, of the kind called] qadaH, (T, S, A, L, K,) in which a guest is given to drink: (S, L:) this is the meaning most known; and this meaning is assigned by Zj to the third of the words above, i. e. mirofadN: (T:) or a large EusR, (M, L,) larger than the common EusR, which latter is a large qadaH that holds enough to satisfy the thirst of three men, or four, or more; larger than the gamar: (L:) or a qadaH, (Ibn-El-Mubárak, T, M, L,) of whatever size it be; accord. to some: (M, L:) in a qadaH a she-camel is milked: (T:) or a vessel in which one milks. (El-Muärrij, T.) One says, huriyqa rifoduhu [His drinking-cup, or bowl, was emptied], meaning (tropical:) he was slain; a phrase similar to Safirato wiTaAbuhu, and kufiYato jafonatuhu: (A:) or he died. (K.) And madRa fulaAnN biOarofaAdiI [app. Such a one drew water with my bowls], meaning (tropical:) such a one aided me, or assisted me. (A, TA. [In my copy of the former, biACirofaAdiI; which I think a mistranscription: in the latter, biArofaAdiI])

rifodapN c
rifodapN A company such as is termed EuSobap, of men, (M, L,) [aiding one another: pl. rifadN: see De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., sec. ed., ii. 461.]

rafuwdN c
rafuwdN A she-camel that fills the [vessel called] rifod or rafod at one milking: (S, A, K:) or that is constantly over her milking-vessel: or that yields an uninterrupted supply of milk: (IAar, L:) or that aids her owners by the abundance of her milk: (TA in art. rkd:) pl. rufudN. (L.)

rifaAdapN c
rifaAdapN [A kind of pad, or stuffed thing, beneath a saddle;] a thing like the jadoyap of a horse's saddle, (S, Mgh, K,) for a beast: (K:) a support for the saddle of a horse or camel &c.: (M, L:) it is put beneath a horse's saddle in order that it may become raised thereby. (Lth, T.) ― -b2- A piece of rag with which a wound, (S, K,) &c., (S,) is furnished as a compress (yurofadu bihaA). (S, K.) ― -b3- A contribution which the tribe of Kureysh made among themselves in the Time of Ignorance, for the purpose of purchasing for the pilgrims wheat, and raisins (S, M, K) for [the beverage called] nabiyc: (S, M:) each gave according to his ability, and thus they collected a great sum, in the days of the assembling of the pilgrims; and they continued to feed the people until the end of those days: (M:) the rifaAdap and siqaAyap [i. e. the supplying these provisions and this beverage] pertained to the Benoo-Háshim; and the sidaAnap [or service of the Kaabeh], and the liwaMC [or banner], to the Benoo-'Abd-ed-Dár: (S:) the term rifaAdapN used in relation to the feeding of the pilgrims is from rafadahu signifying “ he aided him by a gift ” &c.: (Mgh:) the first who performed this custom was Háshim Ibn-'Abd-Menáf. (T.) ― -b4- One says also, huwa rifaAdapu SidoqK liI and SidoqK rafiydapu↓, meaning (tropical:) [He is an excellent] aider, or helper, or assistant, to me. (A.)

rafiydapN c
rafiydapN: see what next precedes.

raAfidN c
raAfidN [act. part. n. of rafada; Giving, or giving a gift: and aiding, &c.]: pl. [raAfiduwna and] rufRadN. (TA.) You say, fulaAnN niEoma AlrRaAfidu UicaA HalRa bihi AlwaAfidu [Such a one is an excellent, or a most excellent, giver, or aider, when the comer alights at his abode]. (A, TA.) And OaEoTaI zakaApa maAlihi TayRibapF bihaA nafosuhu raAfidapF Ealayohi He gave the portion of his property that was due as the poor-rate, his soul being well pleased, or content, therewith, aiding him to do so. (L.) ― -b2- One who is next in station to a king, [who aids him,] and who, when the latter is absent, occupies his place. (IB.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A river that flows into, and augments, another river: you say nahorN lahu raAfidaAni (tropical:) A river that has two rivers flowing into it, and augmenting it. (A.) Hence, (A,) AlrRaAfidaAni is an appellation applied to (tropical:) The Tigris and Euphrates. (S, M, A, K.) ― -b4- [Hence,] one says also, fulaAnN yamodRu AlbariyRapa raAfidaAhu (tropical:) Such a one's two hands or arms [afford aid, or succour, to mankind]. (A.)

raAfidapN c
raAfidapN a word of the measure faAEilapN [app. as meaning A thing that aids, helps, or assists,] from AlrRafodu signifying “ the act of aiding, helping, or assisting. ” (TA.) rawaAfidu [is its pl., and] signifies The rafters, or beams, or timbers, (xaXab, S, Mgh, K, or xuXub, M,) of a roof, (IAar, S, M, Mgh, K,) over which are laid [planks, or only] the bundles of reeds, or canes, called HaraAdiIR; (IAar, L in art. Hrd;) as also raAfidaAtN. (S, M.) A poet says, (describing a house, S in art. bx,)
rawaAfiduhu Oakoramu AlrRaAfidaAti
[Its rafters are the most excellent of rafters]. (S, M.)

banuw Oarofadapa c
banuw Oarofadapa, (S, K,) or Oarofidap, which latter is the more common and more approved, (TA,) mentioned in a trad., (S,) A class of the Abyssinians, (S, K,) who danced: (S:) or a surname of them: or they were so called from the name of their chief ancestor, (TA.)

tarofiydN c
tarofiydN, a subst., like tamotiynN, and tanobiytN, The posteriors of a woman. (IAar, M.)

marofadN c
marofadN, and its pl. maraAfidu: see rifodN, in four places.

mirofadN c
mirofadN, and its pl. maraAfidu: see rifodN, in four places. ― -b2- Also A piece of stuff, or a thing like a pillow, with which a woman small in the posteriors makes those parts to appear large. (S, K. *)

maraAfiydu c
maraAfiydu [a pl. of which the sing. (probably mirofaAdN, like migozaArN and midoraArN &c.,) is not mentioned,] Ewes, or she-goats, whose milk does not cease (S, K) in summer nor in winter. (S.)

1 rafashu c
1. rafashu, (S, M, Msb, K, *) or rafasahu birijolihi, (M,) aor.
rafisa
(S, M, Msb, K) and
rafusa
, (M, K,) inf. n. rafosN (S, M, &c.) and rifaAsN, (Jm, K,) or this is a simple subst., (M,) and rufaAsN, (Jm,) [or this also is a simple subst.,] He kicked him, or struck him with his foot or leg, (S, M, Msb, K, *) in an absolute sense, (M, Msb,) or in, or upon, the breast. (Kh, M, Msb.) ― -b2- rafasahu, inf. n. rafosN, He pounded it, or brayed it; namely, flesh-meat, or other food; or anything; but originally, food. (M, TA.) ＝ -A2- rafasa AlbaEiyra, (K,) aor.
rafusa
, inf. n. rafosN, (TA,) He bound the camel with the rifaAs [q. v.]. (K.)

rafosapN c
rafosapN A kick, or blow with the foot or leg, [in an absolute sense, or] in, or upon, the breast. (Lth, K.)

rifaAsN c
rifaAsN The act, or habit, of kicking, or striking with the foot or leg, in an absolute sense, or in, or upon, the breast; as also rafiysN↓ and rufuwsN↓. (M, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also The [cord, or rope, called] UibaAD [q. v.]: (K:) or the bond with which the hind legs of the camel, when lying down, are bound to his thighs. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.)

daAbRapN rafuwsN c
daAbRapN rafuwsN A beast that has a habit of kicking, or striking with the foot or leg, in an absolute sense, or in, or upon, the breast. (M, TA.)

rufuwsN c
rufuwsN: see rifaAsN.

rafiysN c
rafiysN: see rifaAsN.

mirofasN c
mirofasN An instrument with which flesh-meat is pounded. (M, TA.)

1 rafaDahu c
1. rafaDahu, aor.
rafiDa
and
rafuDa
, inf. n. rafoDN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and rafaDN, (S, K,) He left, forsook, relinquished, abandoned, or deserted, him, or it. (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b2- He separated, dispersed, or scattered, it. (L.) ― -b3- rafoDN also signifies The act of breaking [a thing]. (TA.) ― -b4- And The act of driving away. (TA.) ― -b5- And rafaDa He threw, cast, or shot: (K:) whence raAfiDN as explained below. (TA.) ― -b6- And rafaDa Uibilahu, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
rafiDa
(S) and
rafuDa
also, (O,) inf. n. rafoDN and rafaDN, (as in one copy of the S, but the former only in another copy,) He left his camels to separate, or disperse themselves, in their place of pasture, (S, A, Msb, K,) wherever they pleased, not turning them away from what they desired; (S;) as also ArfDhA↓, (Msb, K,) inf. n. UirofaADN: (TA:) or, as the latter is explained by Fr, he sent them away without a pastor. (TA.) ＝ -A2- rafaDati AlUibilu, (Fr, S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
rafiDa
, (Fr, S,) inf. n. rufuwDN, (S,) or rafoDN, (Fr,) The camels separated, or dispersed themselves, (Fr, A, Msb,) in the place of pasture: (Msb:) or pastured by themselves, (Fr, S, K,) the pastor seeing them, (S,) or looking at them, (K,) near or far off, (S,) not fatiguing them, nor collecting them together. (L.) Thus this verb is intrans. as well as trans. (TA.) [See also 9.] ― -b2- rafaDa AlnRaxolu The palm-tree expanded its raceme, and the qiyqaMC [or envelope] thereof fell off. (S, Sgh, K) ― -b3- rafaDa AlwaAdiI The valley widened; became wide; as also ArfD↓, (O, K,) and AstrfD↓. (Ibn- 'Abbád and K.) ― -b4- rafaDa fuwhu He shed his vagor [or front teeth]. (AA, TA.)

2 rfRD fiI Alqirobapi c
2. rfRD fiI Alqirobapi, inf. n. tarofiyDN, He left a small quantity of water remaining in the skin. (AZ, S, K.) [See rafoDN.] ― -b2- rfRD said of a horse, He put forth his veretrum without being vigorously lustful. (K.)

4 ArfD Uibilahu c
4. ArfD Uibilahu: see 1. ＝ -A2- ArfD AlwaAdiI: see 1, last sentence but one.

5 trfRD c
5. trfRD It (a thing, TA) broke, or became broken, in pieces. (O, K.) ― -b2- See also 9, in three places.

9 ArfDR c
9. ArfDR It (a thing) became dispersed, (S, A, K,) and departed, or went away; (S, K, TA;) as also trfRD↓. (A, K, TA.) It (a company of men) separated, or became dispersed; or dispersed themselves; as also ↓the latter verb. (Lth.) ― -b2- ArfDR AldRamoEu, (S, TA,) or AldRumuwEu, (K,) The tears became scattered in drops: (S, K: [in one copy of the S, AirofiDaADu AldRamoEi is explained by taroXiyXuhu; but the right reading is taraXRuXuhu, which I find in two copies; as in the K:]) or flowed and became scattered; and flowed and dropped continuously: or flowed in a scattered manner: (L:) and trfRD↓ signifies the same. (TA.) You say also, ArfDR AlsRayolu [The torrent dispersed itself]. (S, K.) And ArfDR juroHuhu The thick purulent matter of his wound flowed, and became dispersed. (TA.) And ArfDR EaraqFA His sweat ran; and flowed. (TA.) ― -b3- ArfDR AlwajaEu (assumed tropical:) The pain ceased, or went away. (TA.) And ArfDR minohu SaboriI (tropical:) [My patience departed in consequence of it]. (A, TA.)

10 UisotarofaDa
10: see 1, last sentence but one.

rafoDN c
rafoDN Camels in a state of separation, or dispersion; and in like manner, men, and goods, and plants or herbage: (A:) or camels pasturing by themselves, (S, K,) the pastor seeing them, (S,) or looking at them, (K,) near or far off: (S:) you say, UibilN rafoDN (S, K,) and rafaDN↓ also, and raAfiDapN↓: (S, A, K:) and the pl. of rafaDN is OarofaADN: (S, K:) [and rufuwDN↓ seems to be a pl. of rafoDN.] Also A herd of gazelles in a state of separation, or dispersion: pl. rifaADN. (TA.) You say also naEaAmN rafaDN↓ Ostriches in separate flocks. (S.) And fiI AlsRafari AlnRaAsu OarofaADN↓ The men are in a state of separation, or dispersion, in journeying. (TA.) And AlnRaAsi rufuwDu↓ The different parties of men. (S, K.) And mino kalaOK rufuwDN↓ Scattered pieces of herbage or pasturage, (Jm, S, K,) distant one from another. (Jm, S, O.) And AlOaroDi rufuwDu↓ Land which is deserted after having been prohibited to the public: (S:) or which has no possessor: (O, L, K:) so says IDrd; but he adds, or, accord. to some, deserted land (L, TA) between two cultivated pieces of land, (L,) or between two pieces of land belonging to two tribes. (TA.) rafaDN↓ also signifies What is large, and in a state of separation or dispersion, of a thing: pl. OarofaADN. (TA.) ― -b2- And rafoDN, A side, or a part, or portion, (syn. jaAnibN,) of a thing. (TA.) ― -b3- Also rafoDN, (IAar, ISk, Az, Z,) or rafaDN↓, (AZ, Fr, A'Obeyd, S,) the latter said, in a marginal note in the S, to be the correct form heard from the Arabs, (TA,) or both, (Sgh, K,) A small quantity of water; (S, A, K;) and of milk; (A, TA;) remaining in the bottom of a skin or of a mazaAdap; like a juroEap: (TA:) or a little less than is sufficient to fill a skin: (IAar:) pl. OarofaADN↓. (Lh.) ― -b4- And hence, the former, (tropical:) Food that is sufficient to sustain life; syn. quwtN. (TA.)

rifoDN c
rifoDN The persuasion, or creed, or a tenet, of the raAfiDap; as in the saying attributed to the Imám Esh-Sháfi'ee,
Uino kaAna rifoDFA HubRu Mli muHamRadK
faloyaXohadi AlvRaqalaAni OanRiI raAfiDaI
[If the love of the family of Mohammad be a tenet of the Ráfidees, let men and genii bear witness that I am a Ráfidee]. (TA.)

rafaDN c
rafaDN: and its pl. OarofaADN: see rafoDN, in six places.

rajulN rufaDapN c
rajulN rufaDapN, (A, L,) or rajulN qubaDapN rufaDapN, (S, K,) A man who lays hold upon a thing, and then leaves it (S, A, L, K) without delay. (S, A, L.) And raAEK qubaDapN rufaDapN A pastor who collects together the camels, and, when they come to a place which they like, leaves them to pasture where they will. (ISk, S, A. *) [See also art. qbD.]

rafaDaAtN c
rafaDaAtN, in the following saying, is from rafaDati AlUibilu, explained above: liXawoqiI Uilayoka fiI qalobiI rakaDaAtN waliHubRika fiI mafaASiliI rafaDaAtN (tropical:) [app. meaning By reason of my yearning for thee, in my heart are impulses; and by reason of the love of thee, in my joints are loosenesses]. (A, TA.)

Alqawomu rafoDaI fiI buyuwtihimo c
Alqawomu rafoDaI fiI buyuwtihimo The people, or company of men, are in a state of separation, or dispersion, in their tents, or houses: heard by Az from an Arab of the desert. (TA.) [rafoDaI seems to be a pl. of raAfiDN↓; like as halokaI is of haAlikN. See also rafoDN.]

rufaADN c
rufaADN What is broken in pieces, and scattered, or dispersed, of a thing. (IDrd, S, K.)

XarakN rifaADN c
XarakN rifaADN Tracks in a road differing one from another: (S:) or furrows in the middle, or main part, of a road, separating, one from another; or separating to the right and left. (TA.)

rufuwDN c
rufuwDN: see rafoDN, in four places.

rafiyDN c
rafiyDN i. q. marofuwDN↓, applied to a thing; (S, K;) i. e. Left; forsaken; relinquished; abandoned; deserted: (S, TA:) cast away: separated; dispersed; scattered: (TA:) and, applied to a spear, broken in pieces. (K.) ＝ -A2- Sweat; (O, K;) because of its flowing. (TA.)

rafRaADapN c
rafRaADapN Men who pasture their beasts upon land such as is termed rufuwD: (S, K:) or, as in the O, who sow such land. (TA.)

raAfiDN c
raAfiDN in the following saying of 'Amr Ibn-Ahmar El-Báhilee means A thrower: he says,
UicaA maA AlHijaAziyRaAtu OaEolaqona TanRabato
bimayovaMCa laA yaOoluwka raAfiDuhaA SaxoraA
meaning, When the women of El-Hijáz hang their goods and utensils upon the trees, they stretch their tent-ropes and pitch their tent in a soft tract of land, the thrower wherein will not be able to throw a large piece of stone at thee, because of the not finding it. (O, L, K, * TA.) ＝ -A2- See also rafoDaI.

raAfiDapN c
raAfiDapN A party of rawaAfiD: (K:) whence the rel. n. raAfiDaIRN↓ [signifying of, or belonging to, rawaAfiD]. (TA.) rawaAfiDu [is pl. of raAfiDapN, and] signifies An army, or a military force, (S, O,) or any army or military force, (K,) which has deserted its leader: (S, O, K:) or armies which have deserted their leader. (L.) ― -b2- Also AlrRaAfiDapN, A certain sect of the XiyEap (S, Msb, K) of ElKoofeh; (Msb;) so called because they deserted Zeyd the son of 'Alee, (As, S, Mgh, Msb,) when he forbade them to speak against the Companions of the Prophet; (Mgh, Msb;) for they had promised allegiance to Zeyd the son of 'Alee (As, O, L, K) the son of El-Hoseyn the son of 'Alee the son of Aboo-Tálib, (As, O, L,) and then desired him to renounce the two elders, [Aboo-Bekr and 'Omar, (TK,)] and on his refusing to do so they deserted him: (As, O, L, K:) AlOarofaADu is also applied to this sect, as though it were pl. of raAfiDN, like as OaSoHaAbN is of SaAHbN; (TA;) and AlrRawaAfiDu also; but not AlrRufRaADu: (TA:) and the rel. n. [which serves as a n. un.] is raAfiDaIRN↓ [as above]. (K.) Afterwards, this appellation became applied to All persons transgressing in this way, [i. e. all apostates, or schismatics,] speaking against the Companions of the Prophet. (Msb.) ― -b3- UibilN raAfiDpN: see rafoDN.

raAfiDaIRN c
raAfiDaIRN: see raAfiDapN, in two places.

marofaDN c
marofaDN and marofaDapN↓ sings. of maraAfiDu: the former is explained as A place in which water flows, and where it remains: (TA:) or maraAfiDu waAdK signifies the parts of a valley into which the torrent disperses itself. (S, A, * K. *) ― -b2- maraAfiDu AlORroDi The tracts of land where the main quantity of sand ends, becoming thin, at the sides of mountains and the like. (So in some copies of the S and in the TA.)

marofaDapN c
marofaDapN: see marofaDN.

murofaDRN c
murofaDRN Anything becoming dispersed, and departing, or going away. (S.)

marofuwDN c
marofuwDN: see rafiyDN.

1 rafaEahu c
1. rafaEahu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
rafaEa
, (K, TA,) inf. n. rafoEN, (S, Mgh, Msb,) He raised it: [this is generally the best rendering, as it serves to indicate several particular significations which will be found explained in what follows:] he elevated it; upraised it; uplifted it: he took it up: contr. of xafaDahu: (Msb:) or of waDaEahu: (S, Mgh, K:) as also rfREhu↓, (K,) inf. n. tarofiyEN; (TA;) and ArtfEhu↓; (K;) for accord. to the “ Nawádir, ” you say, ArtfEhu biyadihi and rafaEahu [he raised it, lifted it, heaved it, or took it up, with his hand]; but Az says that ArtfE is intrans., and that he has heard no authority for its being trans., in the sense of rafaEa, except that which he had read in the “ Nawádir el-Aaráb:” (TA:) rafoEN is sometimes applied to corporeal things, meaning the raising, or elevating, a thing from the resting-place thereof: sometimes to a building, meaning the rearing it, uprearing it, or making it high or lofty: (Er-Rághib:) or in relation to corporeal things, it is used properly to denote motion, and removal: (Msb:) it signifies the putting away or removing or turning back a thing after the coming or arriving thereof; like as dafoEN signifies the putting away or removing or turning back a thing before the coming or arriving [thereof]: (Kull p. 185:) but in relation to ideal things, it is [tropically used, as it is also in many other cases, and] accorded in meaning to what the case requires. (Msb.) [In its principal senses, proper and tropical, rafoEN agrees with the Latin Tollere..] It is said in the Kur [ii. 60 and 87], rafaEonaA fawoqakumu QlTRuwra We raised above you from its resting-place the mountain: and in the same [xii. 2], AallRehu QlRaciI rafaEa AlsRamewaAti bigayori EamadK tarawonahaA [God is He who raised the heavens without pillars that ye see; or, as ye see them]: and in the same [ii. 121], waUico yarofaEu Uiborehiymu AlqawaAEida mina Albayoti [And when Abraham] was rearing or uprearing or making high or lofty [the foundations of the House of God, at Mekkeh]. (Er-Rághib.) And you say, AirofaEo hecaA Take thou this: (Mgh:) or take it and carry it [away; or take it up and remove it]. (TA.) And rafaEa AlzRarEa, (Lh, K,) or rafaEahu UilaI Albayodari, (Msb,) aor.
rafaEa
, (Lh,) inf. n. rafoEN (Lh, S) and rifaAEapN and rifaAEN [perhaps a mistranscription for rafaAEu, which see below], (Lh, TA,) He removed, or transported, the seed-produce from the place in which he had reaped it, (Lh,) or carried it after the reaping, (S, K,) to the place in which the grain was to be trodden out. (Lh, S, K.) [This last signification is said in the TA to be tropical; but according to a passage of the Msb quoted in the first sentence of this art., it is proper. In most of the phrases here following, the verb is undoubtedly used tropically.] ― -b2- rafaEuwA UilaIRa Euyuwnahumo (tropical:) [They raised towards me their eyes]. (TA.) ― -b3- daxalotu EalaI fulaAnK falamo yarofaEo biI raOosFA (Mgh, TA *) (tropical:) I went in to such a one, and he did not look towards me, nor pay any regard, or attention, to me. (Mgh.) [biI is not here a mistake for liI, for the phrase is often found thus written.] ― -b4- rufiEa liIa AlXRaIoCu (assumed tropical:) [The thing was, as it were, raised into view, i. e. it rose into view, to me;] I saw the thing from afar. (TA.) ― -b5- rafaEa AlsRaraAbu AlXRaxoSa, aor.
rafaEa
, inf. n. rafoEN, (tropical:) The mirage raised, or elevated [to the eye, (see an ex. near the end of the first paragraph of art. zwl)] the figure of a man or some other thing seen from a distance; [or it may be allowable to render it, made it to appear tall, and as though quivering, vibrating, or playing up and down;] syn. zahaAhu [of which, when it relates to the mirage, the meaning is best expressed by the latter of the two explanations here given]. (TA.) ― -b6- warafaEonaA baEoDahumo fawoqa baEoDK darajaAtK, in the Kur [xliii. 31], means (assumed tropical:) And we have exalted some of them above others in degrees of rank, or station: and narofaEu darajaAtK mano naXaMCu, in the same, [vi. 83, and xii. 76,] (assumed tropical:) We exalt in degrees of rank, or station, whom We please: (Er-Rághib:) and waQllRehu yarofaEu mano yaXaMCu wayaxofiDu (assumed tropical:) And God exalteth whom He pleaseth, and abaseth: (S and TA:) and [in like manner,] rafoEu AlcRikori means the exalting of one's fame; as in the Kur xciv. 4. (Er-Rághib.) But the words, waUilaI AlsRamaMCi kayofa rufiEato, in the Kur [lxxxviii. 18], indicate two meanings; And to the heaven, how it is elevated in respect of its place; and (assumed tropical:) how it is exalted in respect of excellence, and exaltation of rank. (Er-Rághib.) [In like manner also,] fiI buyuwtK Oacina QllRehu Oano turofaEa, in the Kur [xxiv. 36], means In houses which God hath permitted to be built; (Bd, TA;) accord. to some: (TA:) or, (assumed tropical:) to be honoured; (Zj, Bd;) so says El-Hasan; (Zj;) or, (assumed tropical:) to be exalted in estimation. (Er-Rághib.) It is said in a trad., UinRa QllReha yarofaEu AlEadola wayaxofiDuhu (assumed tropical:) Verily God exalteth the just, and maketh him to have the ascendency over the unjust, and at one time abaseth him, so that He maketh the unjust to overcome him, in order to try his creatures, in the present world. (Az, TA.) [See also art. xfD.] And you say, rafaEahu EalaI SaAHibihi fiI Almajolisi (assumed tropical:) He advanced him above his companion [in the sitting-place, or sitting-room, or assembly]. (TA.) And rafaEotuka Eano kacaA (assumed tropical:) [I exalted thee, or held thee, above such a thing]: (M voce rabaOa:) and UinRiI laOarofaEoka Eano hecaA AlOamori (assumed tropical:) [Verily I exalt thee, or hold thee, above this thing]. (S voce rabaOa, q. v.) ― -b7- rafaEa QllRehu Eamalahu (assumed tropical:) [God honoured his work by acceptance; or] God accepted his work. (Msb.) It is said in the Kur [xxxv. 11], waQloEamalu AlSRaAliHu yarofaEuhu (assumed tropical:) And righteous
work He will accept: (Jel:) or the meaning is yarofaEu AlEamalu AlSRaAliHu Alkalima AlTRayRaba (assumed tropical:) [righteous work will cause praise, or the like, (mentioned immediately before the above-cited words of the Kur,) to ascend, and obtain acceptance]: (Mujáhid, TA:) Katádeh says, [that the meaning is,] speech will not be accepted without work. (TA.) ― -b8- rafoEN Also signifies (assumed tropical:) The bringing a thing near; or presenting, or offering, it; syn. taqoriybN. (S.) And hence, rafaEotuhu UilaI AlsRuloTaAni, (S, Mgh, K,) and UilaI AlHakami, (TA,) inf. n. rafoEN (S, * TA) and rufoEaAnN (S, K) and rifoEaAnN, (TA,) (tropical:) I presented him to, or brought him before, or brought him forward to, the Sultán, (S, * Mgh, * K, * TA,) and the judge, to arraign him and contest with him: (TA:) and UilaI AlHaAkimi raAfaEahu↓, (S K,) inf. n. muraAfaEapN, (TA,) [in like manner] signifies (tropical:) he preferred a complaint against him to the governor, or judge: (K:) or (tropical:) he presented him to, or brought him before, or brought him forward to, the governor, or judge, to arraign him and contest with him, and preferred a complaint against him: (TA:) [or it denotes the doing so mutually; for, accord. to Mtr,] xaSomahu UilaI AlsRuloTaAni raAfaEa↓ signifies (tropical:) he brought his adversary before the Sultán (qarRabahu Uilayohi), the latter doing the same with him. (Mgh.) [See also 2.] ― -b9- rafaEa AlquroMna EalaI AlsRuloTaAni (tropical:) [He adduced, or brought forward, the Kur-án against the Sultán;] he interpreted the Kur-án against the Sultán, and judged thereby that he should rebel against him. (TA.) ― -b10- rafoEotu AlrRajula also signifies (tropical:) I traced up the man's lineage to his greatest ancestor; or I mentioned his lineage, saying, He is such a one the son of such a one, or He is of such a tribe, or city, &c.; syn. namayotuhu, and nasabotuhu. (TA.) ― -b11- And hence, rafaEa AlHadiyva UilaI AlnRabiIRi (tropical:) [He traced up, or ascribed, or attributed, the tradition to the Prophet, mentioning, in ascending order, the persons by whom it had been handed down, up to the Prophet; in the manner more fully explained in the sentence here next following]. (TA.) You say also, rafaEa AlHadiyva UilaI qaAYilihi, meaning Oasonadahu [i. e. (assumed tropical:) He traced up, or ascribed, or attributed, the tradition to the author thereof, by mentioning him, or by mentioning, uninterruptedly, in ascending order, the persons by whom it had been transmitted, up to the Prophet; or by mentioning the person who had related it to him from the Prophet if only one person intervened, saying, “ Such a one told me, from such a one, ” (and so on if more than one intervened between him and the Prophet,) “ from the Apostle of God; ” or with an interruption in the mention of the persons by whom it had been transmitted]. (S * and Msb in art. snd.) [And hence what next follows.] It is said in a trad., rafaEato UilayonaA mina AlbalaAgi kulRu raAfiEapK↓ faqado HarRamotuhaA Oano tuEoDada OawotuxobaTa, (S, * TA, [in a very old and excellent copy of the former of which I find, as above, UilayonaA, and so in some copies of the K and in the O and TA in art. blg; but in one copy of the S and in the TA in the present art., I find in its place EalayonaA, and so in the CK in art. blg, where the verb preceding it is erroneously written rufiEato; and in the L, in the place of AlynA is put EanRaA; of all which three readings I prefer the first; though the last is agreeable with an explanation of rafaEotuhu given in the Msb and in the sentence next following;]) i. e. (assumed tropical:) Every company of men (jamaAEap, S, TA), or person (nafos, TA), that communicates, or announces, from us, (S, TA,) and makes known, [lit. traces up to us,] what we say, (TA,) [or rather, aught of what is communicated, or announced,] or [aught] of what is communicated, or announced, of the Kur-án and of the [statutes, or ordinances, &c., termed] sunan, (K in art. blg,) or the meaning is mino cawiI AlbalaAgi, i. e., AltRaboliygi, [of those who have the office of communicating, or announcing,] the simple subst. being put in the place of the inf. n., (T, O, K, TA, all in art. blg,) let that company, or person, communicate, or announce, and relate, that I have forbidden [its trees' being lopped, or being beaten with a stick in order that their leaves may fall off,] referring to El-Medeeneh: (S, * TA:) but some relate it differently, saying, mina AlbulRaAgi [of the communicaters, or announcers,] like HudRaAv in the sense of muHadRivuwn: (TA:) and some say, mina AlbilaAgi, meaning mn AlmubaAligiyna fiI AltRaboliygi, i. e. of those who do their utmost in communicating, or announcing. (Hr, and K in art. blg.) ― -b12- [Hence,] rafaEotuhu [alone] signifies (tropical:) I made it known. (Msb.) You say, rafaEa Ealayohi kalaAmFA (assumed tropical:) [He told, or related, a saying against him; informed against him]. (S and K voce raqRaI, q. v.) And rafaEa EalaI AlEaAmili rafiyEapF (tropical:) He communicated, (S,) or made known, (Msb,) [or submitted, or referred,] a case [to the administrator of the law]; (S;) and UilaI AlHaAkimi [to the governor, or judge]. (TA.) And rafaEotu AlOamora UilaI AlsRuloTiAni, inf. n. rufoEaAnN, (tropical:) I made known [or submitted, or referred, by way of appeal,] the affair, or matter, to the Sultán. (Msb.) [See also 2.] ― -b13- [And hence, app.,] rufiEato lahu gaAyapN fasamaA lahaA (tropical:) [An object to be reached, or accomplished, was proposed to him, and he aspired to it]. (TA.) ― -b14- rafaEa AlbaEiyra, (Sb, K,) and AlnRaAqapa, (TA,) or rafaEa AlnRaAqapa fiI AlsRayori, and AldRaAbRapa, (M in art. nS,) inf. n. rafoEN, (TA in that art.,) (tropical:) He made the camel, (S, Msb, K,) and the she-camel, (TA,) and the beast, (M ubi suprà,) to exert himself, or herself, to the full, or to the utmost, or beyond measure, in going, or pace; (S, K, TA;) or to go quickly; (Msb;) or to go with the utmost celerity: (TA in art. nS:) or constrained him, or her, to go the pace termed marofuwE [q. v. infrà], (TA,) which is an inf. n. of the intrans. verb rafaEa [q. v. infrà] said of a camel (S, TA) and of a beast: (TA:) and rfREhu↓, (S, TA,) [and rfREhA,] and rfRE minohu, (TA,) [and minohaA,] inf. n. tarofiyEN, signify the same: (S, TA:) or the phrase used by the Arabs is AirofaEo mino daAbRatika (tropical:) [Make thou thy beast to exert itself, &c.]. (L, TA.) [You say also, app. in like manner, rafaEatoniI OaroDN: or in this case the verb may have a different meaning: see an ex. in the first paragraph of art. xfD.] ― -b15- [Hence,] rafaEotuhu UilaI HadRi maA Einodahu mina AlEilomi (assumed tropical:) [I urged him to tell the utmost of what he knew;] (A in art. nS;) i. e. I went to the utmost point [with him] in questioning him, or asking him. (TA in that art.) ― -b16- [rafaEa AlnRaAra (assumed tropical:) He stirred up the fire; made it to burn up.] ― -b17- rafaEati AlnRaAqapu labanahaA (tropical:) The she-camel [drew up, or withdrew, or withheld, her milk; i. e.,] did not yield her milk: (A, TA:) and rafaEati AllRibaOa fiI DaroEihaA (tropical:) [She (a camel) drew up, & c., or refused to yield, the biestings in her udder]. (As, S, K.) ― -b18- rafaEahu fiI xizaAnatihi, and Sunoduwqihi, (tropical:) He kept it, preserved it, laid it up, stowed it, or reposited it, in his repository, store-room, or closet, and his chest. (TA.) ― -b19- huwa laA yarofaEu AlEaSaA Eano EaAtiqihi, (Msb, TA,) or EaSaAhu En EAtqh, or Eano Oaholihi, (Mgh,) (tropical:) [lit. He does not put away the staff, or stick, or his staff, or stick, from his shoulder, or from his wife,] is an allusion to discipline, chastisement, or punishment, (Mgh, TA,) or to severity thereof, (Msb,) and to beating (Mgh, TA) of women; (Mgh;) not meaning that the staff, or stick, is on the shoulder: (Msb:) or the first is an allusion to many journeyings. (TA.) ― -b20- rufiEa Alqalamu Eano valaAvK; (Mgh, Msb;) so in the “ Firdows, ” on the authority of 'Alee and I' Ab and 'Áïsheh, meaning valaAvi OanofusK; (assumed tropical:) [The pen of the recording angel is withheld from three persons;] a saying of Mohammad, which means that nothing is recorded either for or against three persons; (Mgh, Msb; *) these three being the sleeper until he awakes, the afflicted with disease or the like, or the demented, until he recovers, and the child until he becomes big, or attains to puberty. (El-Jámi' -es-Sagheer of Es-Suyootee; in which we find valaAvapK in the place of valaAvK.) This is like the saying next before mentioned; the pen having never been put [to the tablet to record aught] against the child. (Msb.) ― -b21- [rafaEa often signifies (assumed tropical:) He withdrew, put away, removed, did away or did away with, annulled, revoked, or remitted.] You say, AallRehumRa QrofaEo EanRaA hecihi AlDRugoTapa (assumed tropical:) [O God, withdraw, put away, or remove, from us this straitness, difficulty, distress, or affliction]. (S in art. DgT.) [And in like manner also you say, rafaEa Eanohu AlEacaAba (assumed tropical:) He withdrew, or put away, from him the punishment; he annulled, revoked, or remitted, his punishment.] rafaEuwA AlHaroba [may also be rendered in a similar manner; (assumed tropical:) They gave over, or relinquished, war; as though they put it away; like waDaEuwhaA: but] is used by Moosà Ibn-Jábir [in the contr. sense, (assumed tropical:) they raised, or made, war;] in opposition to wDEwhA. (Ham p. 180.) ― -b22- AixotalafuwA faqaAla baEoDuhumo narofaEu TariyqFA waqaAla baEoDuhumo laA narofaEu means (assumed tropical:) [They disagreed; and some of them said,] We will exclude a way, or passage, from among the portions, or shares, (qisomp, [q. v.,]) of the land, or the house; and [some of them said,] We will not exclude it. (Mgh.) ― -b23- In the conventional language of the grammarians, rafoEN, in the inflection of words, is like DamRN in the non-inflection. (S) [You say, rafaEa AlHarofa, aor.
rafaEa
, inf. n. rafoEN, (assumed tropical:) He made the final letter to have
rafNEa
or
rafuEa
in
its inflection.] ＝ -A2- rafaEa Alqawomu (tropical:) The people, or company of men, went up, or upwards, through the countries, or lands. (As, K, TA.) ― -b2- rafaEa AlbaEiyru, (S, Msb, K,) fiI AlsRayori, (S,) or fiI sayorihi, (Msb, K,) inf. n. marofuwEN (Sb, S, TA) and rafoEN, (S, A, K, all in art. xfD,) the former an inf. n. (Sb, S, TA) of the measure mafoEuwlN, (Sb, TA,) like [its contr. maxofuwDN, and] majoluwdN, and maEoquwlN, (S, TA,) and mawoDuwEN, (Sb, TA,) (tropical:) The camel exerted himself to the full, or to the utmost, or beyond measure, in going, or pace, or in his going, or his pace: (S, K, TA:) or was quick therein: (Msb:) or went the pace termed marofuwE, [q. v. infrà,] which is a running below that termed HuDor: (S, TA:) as though he had that [manner of going] which raised him, as well as that which lowered him. (Sb and TA with reference to the inf. n. mrfwE and mwDwE.) And rafaEuwA fiI masiyrihimo (assumed tropical:) They [namely men] rose above the [easy and quick pace termed] hamolajap in their going, or journeying. (ISk.) ＝ -A3- rafuEa, inf. n. rifoEapN; (S, K;) or, accord. to Aboo-Bekr Mohammad Ibn-Es-Sereé, [so in two copies of the S, but in others, accord. to the TA, Ibn-EsSarráj,] they did not say rafuEa from rafiyEN in the sense of XariyfN; (S, O;) so says Sb; and he adds, but [they said] ArtfE↓; (TA;) (tropical:) He (a man, S) was, or became, high, elevated, exalted, lofty, or eminent, in rank, condition, or state; (S, K, TA;) noble, honourable, glorious, or illustrious. (TA.) And rafuEa fiI Hasabihi wanasabihi (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, of high or exalted rank, or noble, or honourable, in his grounds of pretension to respect, and his relationship, or race, or lineage. (Msb.) ― -b2- rafuEa AlvRawobu (assumed tropical:) The garment, or piece of cloth, was fine, fine in texture, delicate, or thin. (Msb.) ― -b3- rafuEa, (S, K,) inf. n. rafaAEapN, (K,) (tropical:) He (a man, S) was, or became, high, or loud, (rafiyE,) in voice. (S, K.) [See rafaAEapN below.]

2 rfREhu c
2. rfREhu, inf. n. tarofiyEN: see 1, in the first sentence. ― -b2- He took it, namely, a thing, and raised it, (rafaEahu,) the first [part thereof] and then the first [or next in succession]: En-Nábighah EdhDhubyánee says,
xalRato sabiyla OatiIRK kaAna yHobisuhu
warafRaEatohu UilaI AlsRijofayoni faAlnRaDadi
[She had cleared the way of a torrent coming from another quarter, which it (meaning the barrier raised around the tent to keep away the torrent, which barrier is mentioned two verses before,) confined, and raised it by degrees, the first part and then the next, to the two curtains meeting together at the entrance of the tent, and then to the goods piled up therein: or the meaning here intended is, brought it forward, or advanced it; syn. qadRamatohu; agreeably with the next explanation of rafRaEa here following: see some observations on the above-cited verse in De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., 2nd. ed., vol. ii. pp. 430 and 431]. (Lth, TA.) ― -b3- rafRaEahumo He put them, brought them, or sent them, forward; or advanced them; liloHarobi to the war, or fight: or, accord. to Ibn-'Abbád and the K, he put them, sent them, or removed them, far away; [app. meaning, far in advance;] fiI AlHarobi in the war, or fight. (TA.) You say also, rafRaEotu hecaA AlOamora UilaI AlOamiyri (assumed tropical:) I brought forward this affair, or matter, to the commander, governor, or prince. (From an Arabic note on the above-cited verse of En-Nábighah, cited by De Sacy, ubi suprà.) [See also 1, in two places in which reference is made to this paragraph.] ― -b4- rfRE AlbaEiyra, and AlnRaAqapa, and rfRE minohu, and minohaA: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph. ＝ -A2- rfRE AlHimaAru, (Lth, K,) inf. n. as above, (Lth,) (assumed tropical:) The ass ran with a running of which one part was quicker (OarofaE) than another. (Lth, K.)

3 rAfEhu UilaI AlHaAkimi c
3. rAfEhu UilaI AlHaAkimi, inf. n. muraAfaEapN: and rAfE xaSomahu UilaI AlsRuloTaAni: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph. ― -b2- raAfaEaniI fulaAnN waxaAfaDaniI falamo OafoEalo (tropical:) Such a one endeavoured in every way to induce me to turn or incline, or endeavoured in every way to turn me by deceit or guile, but I did not [that which he desired]. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- rAfE bihimo (assumed tropical:) He spared them; or pardoned them, and forbore to slay them. (K.) And raAfaEotuhu (assumed tropical:) I left him; or left him unmolested; or left him, being left by him; or made peace, or reconciled myself, with him; syn. taArakotuhu. (TA.)

5 trfRE c
5. trfRE (tropical:) He exalted himself; he was, or became, haughty, proud, or disdainful; syn. tajaAlRa; (S in art. jl;) [and so fiI nafosihi ArtfE↓, occurring in the S in art. dkl, on the authority of AZ.] You say, fulaAnN yatarafRaEu Eano celika (S ubi suprà, TA *) (tropical:) Such a one exalts himself above that; holds himself above it; disdains it; or is disdainful of it; syn. yatajaAlRu. (S ubi suprà.) And tarafRaEato biI himRatiI Eano kacaA (tropical:) [My ambition raised me above such a thing; made me to hold myself above it, or to disdain it]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 8.

6 taraAfaEonaA UilaI AlHaAkimi c
6. taraAfaEonaA UilaI AlHaAkimi (tropical:) [Each of us preferred a complaint against the other to the governor, or judge: or each of us presented the other to, or brought him before, or brought him forward to, the governor, or judge, to arraign him and contest with him, and preferred a complaint against him: agreeably with explanations of the phrase raAfaEahu UilaI AlHaAkimi]: (S:) or each of us communicated, or made known, his case [against the other] to the governor, or judge. (TA.)

8 ArtfE c
8. ArtfE It became raised; or it rose: it rose high, or became high or elevated or lofty: [it became raised, upraised, uplifted, or elevated, or it rose, from its resting-place: and, said of a building, it became reared, upreared, or made high or lofty:] it became taken up: [it became taken away, put away, or removed; or it went away; after its coming or arriving: thus when said of corporeal things: but when said of ideal things, it is tropically used, as it is also in many other cases, and accorded in meaning to what the case requires:] quasi-pass. of rafaEahu as signifying the contr. of waDaEahu. (S, K.) [See 1; first sentence.] ― -b2- It (the water of a well) rose, by its becoming copious: and also it went away: (A in art. qlS:) [in which latter sense, likewise, it is said of milk in the udder; or as meaning it became drawn up, or withdrawn, or withheld: see 1. See also a usage of this verb voce raqaOa.] ― -b3- (tropical:) Said of a man: see 1, voce rafuEa, near the end of the paragraph. ― -b4- ArtfE qadoruhu (tropical:) [His rank became high, elevated, exalted, lofty, or eminent]. (S, TA.) ― -b5- AirotafiEo, said to a man entering a sittingplace, sitting-room, or assembly, means (tropical:) Advance thou: it is not from AirotifaAEN denoting height. (TA.) ― -b6- See also 5. ― -b7- ArtfEt AlDRuHaI (tropical:) [The morning became advanced; meaning] the sun became high: AlDRuHaI being originally a pl., namely, of AlDRaHowapu; [wherefore the verb is fem.;] but afterwards used as a sing. [as in the next ex. here following]. (Msb.) You say also, AlDRuHaI tarafRaEa↓ (tropical:) [meaning the same]. (TA.) And ArtfE AlnRahaAru (assumed tropical:) [The day became advanced, the sun being somewhat high: a phrase said by the doctors of the law in the present day to be employed when the sun has risen the measure of a rumoH or more]. (S and K in art. mtE; &c.) ― -b8- ArtfE AlsRiEoru waQnoHaTRa (tropical:) [The price rose, or advanced, and became low, or abated]. (TA.) ― -b9- [ArtfEwA (assumed tropical:) They removed from, or to, a place. ― -b10- ArtfE Eanohu, said of a disease, pain, an affliction, and the like, (assumed tropical:) It quitted him; became withdrawn from him.] ― -b11- AlnRaqiyDaAni laA yajotamiEaAni walaA yarotafiEaAni (assumed tropical:) [What are termed nqyDAn cannot be coexistent in the same thing, nor simul taneously nonexistent in the same thing]; as existence itself and nonexistence, and motion and rest. (Kull pp. 231 and 232.) ＝ -A2- ArtfEhu: see 1; first sentence.

10 AstrfEhu c
10. AstrfEhu He desired, required, demanded, or asked, that it should be raised, elevated, taken up, or removed. (K.) You say, AstrfE AlwaAEiZu AlOayodiIa lildRuEaMCi The preacher asked that the hands of the people should be raised for supplication. (TA.) ― -b2- [And hence, as though meaning AstrfE nafosahu i. e. It required that itself should be re moved,] AstrfE AlxuwaAnu (assumed tropical:) What was on the table became consumed, and it was time for it to be taken up, or removed. (K.)

rafoEN c
rafoEN [see rafaEa, (of which it is the inf. n.,) throughout].

rifoEapN c
rifoEapN [see rafuEa, near the end of the first para graph: used as a simple subst., which it seems properly to be accord. to some of the lexicologists,] (tropical:) High, elevated, exalted, lofty, or eminent, rank or condition or state; nobility, honourableness, gloriousness, or illustriousness; (TA;) as also rifaAEapN↓, a subst. from rafuEa. (Msb.)

hecihi OayRaAmu rafaAEK c
hecihi OayRaAmu rafaAEK, and rifaAEK↓; (AA, ISk, Az, S, Mgh, * Msb, * K;) but As disallows the latter; (TA;) and Ks says, I have heard AljiraAm and AljaraAm, and their coordinates, [such as AlSRiraAm and AlSRaraAm, &c.,] but AlrfAE with kesr I have not heard; (S, TA;) These are days of removal, or transport, of seed-produce from the place in
which it has been reaped, (TA,) or of carriage thereof after reaping, (S, Mgh, K,) to the place in which the grain is trodden out. (S, Mgh, K, TA.) [See 1, near the beginning.] ― -b2- rafaAEN, or rifaAEN↓, (accord. to different copies of the K,) or each, (TA,) also signifies The storing-up of seed produce. (K.)

rifaAEN c
rifaAEN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

rafiyEN c
rafiyEN (tropical:) High, elevated, exalted, lofty, or eminent, in rank, condition, or state; noble, honourable, or glorious; (S, Msb, K, TA;) applied to a man: (S, Msb, TA:) fem. with p. (TA.) You say, huwa rafiyEu AlHasabi waAlqadori (tropical:) [He is high, &c., in respect of grounds of pretension to honour, and of rank]. (TA.) And hence the phrase used by letter-writers, AljanaAbu AlrRafiyEu (tropical:) [The exalted object of recourse]. (TA.) Hence also the phrase in the Kur [xl. 15], rafiyEu AldRarajaAti (assumed tropical:) The Exalted in respect of degrees of dignity: (Er-Rághib:) or this means (assumed tropical:) Great in respect of attributes: or the Exalter of the degrees of dignity of the believers in Paradise. (Jel.) ― -b2- Applied to a garment, or piece of cloth, (assumed tropical:) Fine, fine in texture, delicate, or thin. (Msb.) ― -b3- rafiyEu AlSRawoti (tropical:) [High, or loud, in voice]; (K, TA;) applied to a man. (TA.) ― -b4- sayorN rafiyEN (tropical:) [A pace in which a beast is made to exert itself to the full, or to the utmost, or beyond measure; or in which the utmost pos sible celerity is elicited: see rafaEa AlbaEiyra, in the latter half of the first paragraph: and see also marofuwEN]. (K in art. nS.)

rafaAEapN c
rafaAEapN [an inf. n., (see 1, last sentence,)] and rufaAEapN↓, (ISk, S, K,) and rifaAEapN↓, (Sgh, K,) (tropical:) [Highness, or loudness, or] vehemence, (K, TA,) in the voice, (ISk, S,) or of the voice. (K.)

rufaAEapN c
rufaAEapN A string (xayoT) whereby he who is shackled (muqayRad) raises his shackles (qayod), (Yoo, S, K,) to which that string is fastened; (TA;) as also rifaAEapN↓. (K.) ― -b2- Also, (S, K,) and rifaAEapN↓, (Az, K,) A thing by means of which a woman having little flesh in the posteriors makes herself to appear large [in that part]; (S;) i. q. EuZRaAmapN: (K:) pl. rafaAYiEu. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also rafaAEapN.

rifaAEapN c
rifaAEapN: see rifoEapN: ― -b2- and rafaAEapN: ＝ -A2- and see also rufaAEapN, in two places.

rafiyEapN c
rafiyEapN (tropical:) A case which one communicates, or makes known, to the administrator of the law: (S, TA:) pl. rafaAYiEu. (TA.) You say, liI Ealayohi rafiyEapN (tropical:) [I have, against him, a case to communicate, or make known, &c., or which I have communicated, or made known, &c.]. (TA.)

rafRaAEN c
rafRaAEN (tropical:) One who traces up traditions to the Prophet, or to his Companions; or who communicates them, or makes them known. (TA.) [See rafaEa AlHadiyva &c.]

raAfiEN c
raAfiEN act. part. n. of rafaEahu; Raising; &c. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- AlrRaAfiEu, one of the names of God, meaning (tropical:) The Exalter of the believer by prospering [him], and of his saints by teaching [them]. (TA.) xaAfiDapN raAfiEapN, in the Kur lvi. 3, is explained in art. xfD. ― -b3- raAfiEapN, for jamaAEapN raAfiEapN, (S, TA,) or nafosN raAfiEapN: (TA:) see a trad. (commencing with the words kulRu raAfiEapi) in the first paragraph of this art. ― -b4- naAqapN raAfiEN (tropical:) A she-camel [drawing up, or withdrawing, or withholding, her milk; i. e.,] not yielding her milk: (A, TA:) or when she draws up, &c., or refuses to yield, (UicaA rafaEato,) the biestings in her udder. (As, S, K.) [See also daAfiEN, to which it is opposed.] ＝ -A2- (tropical:) A man going up, or upwards, through the countries, or lands: pl. with wn. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Lightning rising. (Lth, K, TA.) ― -b3- rawaAfiEu [pl. of raAfiEpN for jamaAEapN raAfiEapN] (assumed tropical:) People going the pace termed marofwE [on their camels or beasts]. (ISk.) ― -b4- OaroDN raAfiEapu AlsRuqoyaA (assumed tropical:) Land difficult of irrigation; contr. of xaAfiDapN AlsqyA. (TA in art. xfD.)

raAfiEapN c
raAfiEapN [as a subst., or an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates,] A hard and elevated tract of land. (ISh, TA voce xaAfiDapN [which signifies the contr.]) [See also raAfiEN.]

OarofaEu c
OarofaEu [Higher, or more elevated &c.: and highest, or most elevated &c.]. ― -b2- OarofaEu liloHadiyvi (tropical:) More skilled in tracing up, or ascribing, or attributing, a tradition to its author; i. q. OanaSRu, q. v. (TA in art. nS.) ― -b3- EadaA EadowFA baEoDuhu OarofaEu mino baEaDK (assumed tropical:) [He ran with a running of which one part was quicker than another]; said of an ass. (Lth, K.)

marofaEN c
marofaEN [A place of elevation: and hence, ― -b2- ] A chair, or throne; syn. kurosiIRN: of the dial. of El Yemen. (TA.)

mirofaEN c
mirofaEN A thing with which one raises, elevates, or takes up. (TA.)

marofuwEN c
marofuwEN pass. part. n. of rafaEahu. ― -b2- wafuruXK marofuwEapK, (S, K, *) in the Kur [lvi. 32], (S,) means [And beds raised] one upon another: (Fr, S, Bd, K:) or (assumed tropical:) of high estimation: (Bd:) or (tropical:) brought near to them: (S, K:) or wives elevated upon couches: (Bd:) or (assumed tropical:) honoured wives. (S, K.) ― -b3- HadiyvN marofuwEN (tropical:) A tradition related by a Companion of the Prophet, and ascribed, or attributed, to the Prophet himself, by the mention of him as its author, or of the person, or persons, up to the Prophet, by whom it has been handed down. (Kull p. 152.) ＝ -A2- It is also an inf. n.: [see rafaEa AlbaEiyru, in the latter half of the first paragraph:] and signifies (tropical:) A certain pace of a beast, (S, TA,) of a horse and of a camel; (L;) contr. of mawoDuwEN; (S, TA;) and of maxofuwDN; (A in art. xfD;) it is a run below that termed HuDor: (S, TA:) or above that which is termed mawoDuwE, and below that which is termed Eadow: (TA: [but probably Edw is here a mistake for HuDor:]) or a pace of a camel rising above the [easy and quick rate of going termed] hamolajap. (ISk.) You say, layosa lahu marofuwEN (tropical:) He (a beast) has not the pace termed mrfwE. (S.)

jabalN murotafiEN c
jabalN murotafiEN A high mountain. (TA.)

1 rafoga EayoXuhu c
1. rafoga EayoXuhu, [aor.
rafuga
,] inf. n. rafaAgapN, His means of subsistence became ample, or abundant. (S.) [See also rafogN, below.] ＝ -A2- [rafaga, aor.
rafaga
, He made the means of subsistence ample, or abundant. You say,] Oarofagu lakumu AlmaEaAXa I will make ample, or abundant, to you the means of subsistence. (TA.) ＝ -A3- rafaga AlmaroOapa i. q. trfRghA, q. v. (TA.)

5 trfRg c
5. trfRg He (a man) became, or made himself, ample, or abundant, in his means of subsistence; syn. tawasRaEa: (S:) or he exhibited ampleness, or abundance, in his means of subsistence. (PS.) ＝ -A2- trfRg fawoqa AlbaEiyri He (a man), feared that the camel [upon which he was riding] would throw him, and therefore wound his legs next the sheath of his [the camel's] penis: [i. e., pressed his heels against the camel's OarofaAg (or groins):] in the K, as also in the O and Tekmileh, xalofa rijolayohi is erroneously put for falafRa rijolayohi, the reading in the L. (TA.) ― -b2- trfRghA, He sat between her thighs, for the purpose of compressing her; (K;) from the Nawádir el-Aaráb; as also rafagahaA↓, i.e. rafaga AlmaroOapa. (TA.)

rafogN c
rafogN Softness, tenderness, or smoothness: (O, L, K: *) this is the primary signification, accord. to the O and L: accord. to MF, softness, tenderness, or smoothness, and uncleanness, or dirtiness; but this addition is wrong; and he has wrongly ascribed this explanation to Er-Rághib, who mentions in his book only the words of the Kur-án. (TA.) ― -b2- Ampleness, or abundance, of the means of subsistence; and abundance of herbage, or of the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life: (S, K, * TA:) and so rafaAgapN↓, (JK, * S, * TA,) an inf. n., (S,) and rafaAgiyapN↓, [also, app., an inf. n., like rafaAhiyapN;] (JK, * S, * TA;) and rufagoniyapN↓, like bulahoniyapN (K, TA) and rufahoniyapN, (TA,) [in which the last three letters, following the g, are all augmentative,] signifies [the same, or] ampleness, or abundance, of the means of subsistence. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) and rufogN↓, (S, Msb, TA,) the former of the dial. of Temeem, and the latter of the dial. of the people of El- 'Áliyeh and of El-Hijáz, (Aboo-Kheyreh, Msb, TA,) [The groin;] the root of the thigh; (ISk, Jm, Msb, K; and Mgh in art. whm;) and any of the other magaAbin [or places of flexure or creasing]; (ISk, Msb;) and any place of the body in which dirt collects, (ISk, Jm, L, Msb, K,) such as the armpit and the crease of the belly and the like: (L:) or the inner side of the thigh, at the root: (JK:) or the inner side of the root of each thigh, next the upper parts of the sides of the pubes, where the upper parts of the inner sides of the thighs and the upper part of the belly [app. a
mistake for the lower part of the belly] meet: (TA:) [or each of the two inguinal creases; for] the rufogaAni are between the pubes and the thigh, [one on each side,] and are also called the magaAbin: (Zj in his “ Khalk el-Insán: ”) the latter (rufogN) also particularly signifies the armpit: (Fr, Mgh, K:) or, as some say, the root [or innermost part] of the armpit: (TA:) and the same, (ISh, K,) or each, (Msb,) the parts around the faroj [or vulva, or external portion of the organs of generation,] (ISh, Msb, K) of a woman: (ISh, K:) and sometimes the faroj itself: (Msb:) the pl. is OarofaAgN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and rufuwgN (Msb, K) and rifaAgN and [of pauc.] OarofugN, the first of which four is pl. of rufogN, [and is properly a pl. of pauc.,] the rest being pls. of rafogN: (Msb:) [accord. to J,] OarofaAgN signifies the magaAbin [or places of flexure, or creasing,] of the armpits, and of the roots of the thighs: (S:) accord. to As, the armpits, and the [other] magaAbin of the body: (Mgh in art. whm:) IAar says that maraAfigu↓ signifies the roots of the arms and of the thighs, and has no proper sing.: and AlArfAg is the sing. of AlrRufagu (wAHd AlrRufagi [but this is app. a mistranscription for wuAHiduhu AlrRufogu meaning that OarofaAgN has for its sing: rufogN]): and rufagN↓ signifies the magaAbin and maHaAlib [by which latter are app. meant the places that sweat] of the body: accord. to As, what is thus termed is in camels and in human beings. (TA. [But the sing. verb in this last clause suggests that there is another mistranscription here, and a looseness of explanation; and that we should read thus: “ and rufogN (not rufagN) signifies any of the magaAbin and of the maHaAlib of the body. ”]) ― -b2- Also, both words, The dirt of the nail: (K:) or the dirt that is between the end of the finger and the nail, when the nail is not pared, after scratching the OarofaAg [or groins and armpits and the like]: (TA:) or the former [or each] signifies the dirt of the magaAbin [or places of flexure, or creasing, of the body]; (K;) or the dirt and sweat that collect in the mgAbn of the armpits, and of the roots of the thighs, and other places of folding of the limbs. (TA.) ― -b3- Also the former word, (rafogN,) (assumed tropical:) A soft, or plain, tract, or piece, of land: (JK, K: *) pl. rifaAgN. (K.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) Land having much soil or dust. (L, K.) [Hence,] one says, jaMCa fulaAnN bimaAlK karafogi AltRuraAbi (assumed tropical:) Such a one came with, or brought, wealth, or cattle, abundant as the soil, or dust, thus termed. (L.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) A place affected with drought, or barrenness, (L, K,) thin, or shallow, [in its soil,] of middling quality. (L.) ― -b6- (tropical:) The vilest place in a valley, and the worst in re spect of soil: (Aboo-Málik, K, * TA:) the lowest part of a valley and of a desert: (TA:) or OarofaAgu AlwaAdiI signifies the sides of the valley. (AHn, JK, TA.) ― -b7- (tropical:) A side, or lateral part or region: (Akh, IAar, K:) pl. OarofugN. (K.) You say, huwa fiI rafogK mino qawomihi, and mina Alqaroyapi, (tropical:) He is in a side, or lateral part, not in the middle, of his people, or party, and of the town, or village. (IAar, TA.) ― -b8- Also sing. of OarofaAgN meaning (tropical:) The lower, or lowest, baser or basest, meaner or mean est, sort, or the rabble, or refuse, of mankind; (JK, K, TA;) likened to the OarofaAg of a valley: or the sing. of ArfAg in this sense is rufogN↓. (TA.) ― -b9- (assumed tropical:) A skin for water, or for milk, that is thin, or rendered thin, (accord. to different copies of the K,) and of little worth. (K, TA.) ― -b10- (assumed tropical:) The straw of [the species of millet called] curap: so accord. to the author of the L; but accord. to others, it is dafogN, with dAl, if this be not a mis transcription. (TA.) ＝ -A3- As an epithet, rafogN sig nifies Soft; applied to dust, or earth, and to food, or wheat, (TaEaAm,) and to kilos [or quicklime, &c.]. (K, * TA.)

rufogN c
rufogN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

rufagN c
rufagN: see rafogN in the middle of the paragraph.

rafigapN c
rafigapN A she-camel having purulent pustules, ulcers, or sores, in the rufogaAni [meaning groins or armpits]. (A, TA.)

rafogaMCu c
rafogaMCu [fem. of Oarofagu], applied to a woman, (JK, Ibn-'Abbád, L, K,) Small in the mataAE [or vulva]: (L:) or thin in the thighs, small in the han [or vulva], deep in the rufogaAni [or groins]: (JK, Ibn 'Abbád, K:) or a woman narrow in the OarofaAg [or groins, or inguinal creases, or the like]: (TA in art. rbl, from the 'Eyn:) or, applied to a woman, (A,) or to a she-camel, (JK, L,) wide in the rufog [app. meaning the vulva or the parts around the vulva]. (JK, A, L.)

EayoXN rafiygN c
EayoXN rafiygN (JK, S, TA) and raAfigN↓ (S, TA) and Oarofagu↓ (TA) Ample, or abundant, (JK, S, TA,) and pleasant, or good, (S, TA,) means of subsist ence. (JK, S, TA.)

rafaAgapN c
rafaAgapN: see rafogN, second sentence.

rafaAgiyapN c
rafaAgiyapN: see rafogN, second sentence.

rufagoniyapN c
rufagoniyapN: see rafogN, second sentence.

raAfigN c
raAfigN: see rafiygN.

raAfigapN c
raAfigapN, i. q. niEomapN [app. as meaning A benefit, benefaction, favour, boon, or blessing]: pl. rawaAfigu. (TA.)

Oarofagu c
Oarofagu: see rafiygN. ― -b2- Its fem., rafogaMCu, is mentioned above, by itself.

marofuwgapN c
marofuwgapN [syn. with maroSuwfapN] A woman small in the han [or vulva], (JK, Ibn-'Abbád, K,) or whose place of circumcision has cohered [after the operation] when she was young, and, conse quently, (L,) impervia viro. (JK, Ibn-' Abbád, L, K.)

maraAfigu c
maraAfigu: see rafogN, in the middle of the paragraph.

1 rafaqa c
1. rafaqa, (S, O, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
rafuqa
, (S, Msb,) inf. n. rifoqN (S, * O, Mgh, * Msb, * K) and marofiqN and mirofaqN (AZ, O, K,) and marofaqN; (O, K;) and rafiqa, (JK, O, K,) [aor.
rafaqa
,] inf. n. rafaqN; (JK;) and rafuqa; (JK, O, K;) He was, or became, gentle, soft, tender, gracious, courteous, or civil; or he be haved, or acted, gently, softly, &c. (JK, S, O, Mgh, Msb, K.) You say, rafaqa bihi, (AZ, S, O, Mgh, Msb, K,) and Ealayohi, (AZ, O, K,) inf. ns. as above; (O, K;) and rafiqa, and rafuqa; (K;) He was, or became, gentle, &c., or he behaved, or acted, gently, &c., with him, (AZ, S, O, Mgh, Msb, K,) and to him; (AZ, O, K;) and in like manner, bihi trfRq↓, (S, O, Mgh, K,) and Arfqhu↓. (AZ, O, K.) Hence the saying of the Prophet, mano rafaqa biOumRatiI rafaqa QllRehu bihi [He who is gentle, &c., with my people, God will be gentle, &c., with him]. (O.) [Hence, also,] one says, trfRq↓ fiI Oamorihi [and rafaqa fiyhi as is indicated in the O] He used gentleness, or acted gently, in his affair; syn. taOatRaI. (Msb in art. AtI.) And liHaAjatihi trfRq↓ He applied himself with gentleness to his needful affair or business; syn. taOatRaI. (T in art. AtI.) And liloOamori trfRq↓ He applied himself with gentle ness to the affair; syn. talaTRafa. (S in art. lTf.) ― -b2- Hence, rafuqa, in form like faruba, He was, or became, gentle, delicate, nice, neat, or skilful, in work or operation; the contr. of such as is termed Oaxoraq. (Msb.) ― -b3- And rafaqotu AlEamala, with fet-h to the f, aor.
rafuqa
, I did, or made, the deed, or work, soundly, thoroughly, skilfully, judiciously, or well. (Msb.) ― -b4- And rafaqotu fiI AlsRayori I pro ceeded in a right, or a moderate, manner in journeying, or in pace. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- See also 4. ＝ -A3- rafaAqapN is an inf. n. signifying The being a rafayq. (O, K.) Fr says, I heard a man at 'Arafát saying [to the pilgrims there assembled], jaEalakumu QllRehN fiI rafaAqapi muHamRadK SalRaI QllRehu Ealayohi wasalRama [May God make you to be in the companionship of Mohammad: may God bless and save him]. (O.) [And accord. to the TK, one says, rafuqa bihi, inf. n. rafaAqapN, meaning He became a rafiyq with him: but what is commonly said in this sense is raAfqahu, q. v.] ＝ -A4- rafaqa fulaAnFA, He struck the mirofaq [or elbow] of such a one. (K.) ― -b2- And rafaqa AlnRaAqapa, (S, O, K,) aor.
rafuqa
, inf. n. rafoqN, (S, O,) He bound the she-camel's arm [app. together with the shank (for such is the common practice)], (S, O, K,) to prevent her going quickly, (S, O,) when fearing her yearning towards, or longing for, her home, or accustomed place: (S, O, K:) [or] rafaqa AlbaEiyra, aor.
rafiqa
, inf. n. rafoqN, he bound the camel's neck (Eunuq [probably, I think, a mistranscription for EaDud i. e. arm,]) to his pastern, because of a slight lameness therein. (JK.) ＝ -A5- rafiqa said of a camel, aor.
rafaqa
, inf. n. rafaqN, He had his elbow dis torted from his side. (TA and TK. [See rafaqN below, and Oarofaqu: and see also dafiqa.]) ― -b2- [And rafiqato, inf. n.rafaqN, is probably said of a she-camel, as meaning She had, in her teat, or teats, what is termed rafaqN: see, again, this word below.]

2 tarofiyqN c
2. tarofiyqN [as the inf. n. of the verb in the phrase
rufRiqati AlXRaApu, if this verb have been used, means A sheep's, or goat's having the fore legs white to the elbows; for it] is from XaApN murafRaqapN, explained below. (O.)

3 rAfqhu c
3. rAfqhu He was, or became, his rafiyq, or travelling-companion; he accompanied him in a journey; (S, O, Msb, K;) inf. n. muraAfaqapN (TK) and rifaAqN. (TA.) ― -b2- And this latter inf. n. also signifies The being hypocritical, or acting hypocritically. (TA. [See also 3 in art. rmq.])

4 Arfqhu c
4. Arfqhu: see 1, second sentence. ― -b2- Also He profited him, or was useful to him; (S, O, K;) as also rafaqahu↓. (K.) ― -b3- [And in the present day, it means He associated him bigayorihi with another or others.]

5 tarafRaqa
5: see 1, in four places.

6 trAfqwA c
6. trAfqwA They were, or became, travellingcompanions; they travelled, or journeyed, together; as also ArtfqwA↓: (JK:) and trAfqA they two were, or became, travelling-companions; &c.: (K:) and trAfqnA fiI AlsRafari we were, or became, companions in travelling, or journeying. (S, O.)

8 Artfq c
