8. Artfq i. q. Tlb rfqA [i. e. Talaba rifoqFA] and AstEAn [both meaning He sought, or demanded, aid, or help]. (Har p. 395. [See also 10.]) ― -b2- And hence, (Har ibid.,) Artfq bihi He profited, or gained advantage or benefit, by him, or it, (S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) namely, a thing. (Msb.) [This phrase is also often used as meaning He made use of it; namely, a garment, and an implement, &c.] ― -b3- See also 6. ＝ -A2- Also He leaned upon the mirofaq of his arm [i. e. upon his elbow]: (O, Msb, * K:) or upon the pillow [called mirofaqap]. (K.) ＝ -A3- And It was, or became, full, or filled. (K.)

10 Astrfqhu c
10. Astrfqhu He sought, or demanded, his profiting him, or being useful to him. (TA.)

Q. Q. 2 tamarofaqa c
Q. Q. 2. tamarofaqa He took a mirofaqap, i. e. pillow [upon which to lean with his elbow]. (S.)

rifoqN c
rifoqN an inf. n. of rafaqa; (O, K;) Gentleness, softness, tenderness, graciousness, courteousness, or civility; contr. of EunofN; (S, O, Mgh, Msb;) i. q. luTofN, and Husonu SaniyEK, (IDrd, O, K,) or liynu jaAnibK and laTaAfapu fiEolK; and so rafaqN↓; (JK;) and raAfiqapN↓ likewise; whence the phrase OawolaI fulaAnFA raAfiqapF [He treated such a one with gentleness, &c.]. (JK, IDrd, O.) It is also explained as meaning Good submission to that which conduces to what is comely, or pleasing. (TA.) ― -b2- And Gentleness, delicacy, nicety, neatness, or skilfulness, in work or operation; contr. of xuroqN. (Mgh.) ― -b3- Also A thing by means of which one seeks help or assistance. (K.) See also mirofaqN.

rafaqN c
rafaqN inf. n. of rafiqa: see the next preceding paragraph. ＝ -A2- [Also Easy of attainment.] You say marotaEN rafaqN [A place of pasturing, or of unrestrained and plentiful pasturing,] easy to be sought [and attained]. (S, O.) And maMCN rafaqN Water that is easy (JK, S, O, K) to be sought (JK, S, O) and taken: (JK:) or of which the well-rope is short. (K.) And HaAjapN rafaqu Albigoyapi An object of want that is easy [to be sought and attained]. (O, K.) ＝ -A3- Also A distortion of the elbow of a camel from the side. (Lth, S, O, K. [Said to be the inf. n. of rafiqa, q. v.]) ― -b2- And A stoppage of the orifice of the teat, (K,) or of the orifices of the teats, (O,) of a she-camel: (O, K:) so says Zeyd Ibn-Kuthweh: (O:) or a disorder in the orifice of the teat, in consequence of being badly milked, or of the milker's not shaking the teat to remove what remained in it, so that the milk reverts into the udder, and turns to blood, or becomes coagulated and mixed with yellow water. (K. [Perhaps in this sense, also, an inf. n.: see 1, last sentence.]) ＝ -A4- See also rufoqapN.

rafoqapN c
rafoqapN: see what next follows.

rufoqapN c
rufoqapN, (JK, S, O, Mgh, Msb, K,) in the dial. of Temeem, (Msb,) and rifoqapN↓, (S, O, Msb, K,) in the dial. of Keys, (Msb,) and rafoqapN↓, and on the authority of Ibn-Tal-hah rufaAqapN↓, (K, [in which this last is said to be like vumaAmapu, to indicate that it is with damm to the r, but not (as will be shown below, voce rafiyqN,) that it is without tenween, imperfectly decl., and determinate like AlrRufoqapu,]) Persons travelling, or journeying, together; (Mgh;) a company of persons [travelling, or journeying, or] with whom one is travelling, or journeying; but not when they have separated: (S, O, Msb, K:) or persons with whom one travels, or journeys, as long as they are congregated in one place of assembly, and in one journey; but not when they have separated: (JK:) pl. [of mult.] rifaAqN, (S, O, Mgh, Msb, K,) which is pl. of rufoqapN, (Mgh, Msb,) and rufaqN, [which is also pl. of rufoqapN,] and [of pauc.] OarofaAqN; (O, K;) and the pl. of rifoqapN is rifaqN: (Msb:) or rufoqapN is a quasi-pl. n. of rafiyqN↓, or syn. with this last used in a pl. sense; and its pl. is rifaqN and rufaqN and [quasi-pl. n.] rafaqN↓. (K.) [Golius explains the first and second and third, as on the authority of the KL, by the words “ consortium, societas: ” but in my copy of the KL, I find only the first and second; and these are explained only by the words Grwh hmrAhAn, agreeably with the renderings which I have given above.] ― -b2- The pl. rifaAqN also signifies Camels upon which people have gone forth to purvey for themselves wheat, or corn, or other provisions from the towns or villages; each, or every, company being termed a rufoqap. (TA voce raTaAnapN.)

rifoqapN c
rifoqapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

rafiqapN c
rafiqapN as an epithet applied to a she-camel: see Oarofaqu.

rifaAqN c
rifaAqN The cord that is used for the purpose described in the explanation of rafaqa AlnRaAqapa, (S, O, K,) or in the explanation of rafaqa AlbaEiyra. (JK.) [See 1, in the latter part of the paragraph.] So in the saying of Bishr, (S,) i. e. of Bishr Ibn-Abee- Házim, (O,)
faUinRiI waAlXRakaApa mina Ali laOoIK
kacaAti AlDigoni tamoXiI fiI AlrRifaAqi
(O,) or waMla laAmK, (S, O,) accord. to different readings: (O:) [i. e. And verily I, with respect to the fault, or the complaint, of the family of Läy, or and the family of Lám, am like her that yearns towards, or longs for, her home, or accustomed place, going along with her arm and shank in the rfAq]: he says, I am withheld from satirizing them, like as this she-camel that yearns towards, or longs for, her home, or accustomed place, is bound and withheld; but if they do not what I approve, I will let loose my tongue with satirizing them. (O.) ― -b2- Also A thing in form like a finger, made for the teat of a she-camel when she is affected with the [disorder termed] rafaq: it is stuffed with dates, and then the SiraAr [q. v.] is bound over it, in order that it [the teat] may be cured. (JK.)

rafiyqN c
rafiyqN Gentle, soft, tender, gracious, courteous, or civil; (JK, Msb;) as also raAfiqN↓. (JK.) ― -b2- And hence, (Msb,) Gentle, delicate, nice, neat, or skilful, in work or operation; contr. of Oaxoraqu. (S, O, Msb, K.) ― -b3- [Hence, also,] hecaA AlOamoru rafiyqN bika and bika raAfiqN↓ and raAfiqN Ealayoka (assumed tropical:) [This affair, or thing, is easy, or convenient, to thee: see Oarofaqu]. (O.) ＝ -A2- Also A companion (JK, S, O, Msb, K) and companions (JK, S, O, K) in travel-ling, or journeying, and afterwards: (Kh, S, O, Msb, K:) used as sing. and pl., (JK, S, O, K,) like SadiyqN (S, O) and xaliyTN: (O:) pl. rufaqaMCu; (JK, S, O, K;) with which rufaAqapN↓ is syn., as in the phrase fitoyapN rufaAqapN [Young men companions &c.]. (JK.) See also rufoqapN. It is said in the Kur [iv. 71], waHasuna OuwlaAYika rafiyqFA, (JK, S, O,) meaning rufaqaMCa [i. e. And good, or very good, will be those as companions after the journey of life] in Paradise! (JK.) And Mohammad is related by 'Áïsheh to have said, [just before his death,] when he had been given his choice between continuance in the present world and what was with God, and had chosen the latter, bali AlrRafiyqa AlOaEolaI mina AljanRapi [Nay, rather, the highest companions of Paradise]; meaning, I desire the company, or congregation, of the prophets. (O.)

rufaAqapN c
rufaAqapN: see rufoqapN and rafiyqN.

raAfiqN c
raAfiqN: see rafiyqN, in two places.

raAfiqapN c
raAfiqapN: see rifoqN.

Oarofaqu c
Oarofaqu [compar. and superl. of rafiyqN; meaning More, and most, gentle, &c.] ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, hecaA AlOamoru Oarofaqu bika [and Ealayoka] (assumed tropical:) This affair, or thing, is more, or most, easy, or convenient, to thee. (TA in art. Ewd.) [See also an instance voce maHoniyapN (in art. Hnw), last sentence.] ＝ -A2- Also, applied to a camel, Having the elbow (Almirofaq) distorted from the side: (JK, S, O, K:) so says Lth: (O:) and so the fem. rafoqaMCu, applied to a she-camel: (JK, S:) but Az says that the epithet preserved by him in his memory as heard from
the Arabs applied to a camel is Oadofaqu, with dAl. (O.) ― -b2- Accord. to As, (O,) rafoqaMCu applied to a she-camel signifies Having the orifice of her teat stopped up; (O, K;) and so rafiqapN↓: (K:) the latter is said by Zeyd Ibn-Kuthweh to signify, so applied, having the orifices of her teats stopped up. (O.)

marofaqN c
marofaqN: see mirofaqN, in two places.

marofiqN c
marofiqN: see what next follows, in three places.

mirofaqN c
mirofaqN and marofiqN↓ inf. ns. of rafaqa, (AZ, O, K,) of which marofaqN↓ also is an inf. n. (O, K.) ― -b2- Also A thing by which one profits, or gains advantage or benefit. (S, O, Msb, K.) It is said in the Kur [xviii. 15], wayuhayRiYu lakumo mino Oamorikumo mirofaqFA or marofiqFA↓, accord. to different readers, [i. e. And He will prepare for you a condition of your case by which ye shall profit], but no one reads marofaqFA↓, (S, O,) which, however, is allowable, meaning rifoqFA↓. (S. [See rifoqN, last sentence.]) The pl. is maraAfiqu. (Msb.) ― -b3- [Hence,] maraAfiqu AldRaAri Such appertenances [or conveniences] of the house as the privy and the kitchen and the like: (Mgh, Msb:) or the sinks, and the like, of the house: (S, O, K:) and particularly privies: (O:) when used in these senses, the sing. is mirofaqN only, with kesr to the m and fet-h to the f, (Mgh, Msb,) likened to the noun signifying an instrument. (Msb.) [See also HayRizN, in art. Hwz.] ― -b4- And from the same words in the sense expl. in the second sentence above, (Msb,) mirofaqN and marofiqN↓ signify also The elbow, or elbow-joint; the place where the ciraAE joins upon the EaDud; (S, O, K;) [in other words,] the place where the EaDud is connected with the saAEid; (Mgh;) the mrfq of a man: (Msb:) [and in like manner in a beast, the elbow, or elbowjoint, as in the JK, S, O, and K, voce Oarofaqu; and in countless other instances: but in the K voce rukobapN (q. v.), it seems to be applied to the knee of a beast:] pl. as above. (Msb.)

mirofaqapN c
mirofaqapN A pillow (S, O, Mgh, K) upon which one leans [with the elbow]: from mirofaqN in the sense explained in the last sentence of the next preceding paragraph. (Mgh.)

XaApN murafRaqapN c
XaApN murafRaqapN A sheep, or goat, having the fore legs white to the elbows. (O, K.)

mirofaAqN c
mirofaAqN A camel whose elbow hurts (yuSiybu) his side. (O, K.) ― -b2- And A she-camel that is hurt by the SiraAr [q. v.] when her udder is bound therewith, and from whom blood issues (JK, O, K) when she is loosed [therefrom] (UicaA HulRato), (JK,) or when she is milked (AcA Hulibato). (O, K.)

marofuwqN c
marofuwqN A camel having a complaint of his mirofaq [or elbow]. (IDrd, O, K.)

murotafaqN c
murotafaqN A place, or thing, upon which one leans [properly with the mirofaq, or elbow]. (Bd in xviii. 28 and 30.)

murotafiqN c
murotafiqN Leaning upon his elbow. (S, O.) ＝ -A2- Also Full, standing, and continuing, or remaining: (O, K:) or nearly full: so explained by IAar as occurring in the following verse of 'Obeyd Ibn-El-Abras, (O,) describing rain that had filled the low tracts of ground: (TA in art. SwH:)
faOaSobaHa AlrRawoDu waAlqiyEaAnu mumoriEapF
mino bayoni murotafiqK minohaA wamunoSaAHi
[And the meadows, and the plain, or soft, low tracts, became abundant with herbage, partly by what was full, &c., in consequence thereof, and partly by what was flowing, running upon the surface of the ground]: (O:) or, as some relate it, mutoraEapF [i. e. “ filled ”]; and murotatiqK, which means herbage “ of which the blossoms have not yet come forth from their calyxes; ” and munoSaAH [accord. to this reading] meaning herbage “ of which the blossoms have appeared: ” (TA in art. SwH:) [or, accord. to the reading murotatiqK, the meaning may be, “ partly such as were compact thereof, ” i. e. of the meadows &c., “ and partly such as were cracked ” by the heat and drought:] another reading is
mino bayoni murotafiqK minohaA wamino TaAHiI
mn TAHI meaning “ of what was flowing and going away. ” (TA ubi suprà.) [Nearly the whole of this art. is wanting in the copies of the TA to which I have had access.]

1 rafila c
1. rafila, (S, M, K,) aor.
rafala
, (K,) inf. n. rafalN; (S, M;) and rafala, aor.
rafula
, (M, K,) inf. n. rafolN; (M;) He was awkward (S, M, K,) in his manner of wearing his clothes, (S,) or with his clothes [when walking &c. (see rafilN)], and in every work. (M, K.) ― -b2- And rafala, (M, K,) or rafala fiI viyaAbihi, (S, TA,) aor.
rafula
, (S, M,) inf. n. rafolN (Lth, T, M, K) and rufuwlN (T, TA) and rafalaAnN; (M, K;) and Arfl↓; (S, M, K;) He dragged his skirt, and kicked it with his foot: (Lth, T:) or he made his clothes long, and dragged them, walking with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side: (S:) or he dragged his skirt, and walked in the manner described above: or he moved his arm up and down [in walking]: (M, K:) and fiI viyaAbihi trfRl↓ signifies the same as rafala and Arfl: (TA:) or UirofaAlN↓ [inf. n. of 4] signifies a man's having a long garment, such as a skirt and a jubRap: (Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, T in art. cyl:) and one says, fiI miXoyatihaA xroqFA tatarafRalu↓ [She drags her skirt, &c., in her gait, by reason of awkwardness]. (S.) tarofulu AlmaraAfilaA, a phrase used by Ru-beh, [maraAfilu↓ being app. pl. of marofalN, a regular inf. n. of rafala,] means She walks with every sort of rafol or rufuwl [i. e. dragging of the skirt, &c.]. (Lth, T accord. to different copies.) And tarofala↓, inf. n. tarofalapN, He walked with an inclining of his body from side to side (tabaxotara) by reason of pride (kiborFA), or by reason of old age (kibarFA): (K, accord. to different copies:) the t is augmentative. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also the next paragraph, last sentence, in two places.

2 tarofiylN c
2. tarofiylN The making a garment ample, or long towards the ground: the letting it down, or making it to hang down: (TA:) [and so UirofaAlN↓:] you say, viyaAbahu Arfl↓, (Sh, T,) or vawobahu, (M,) or rifolahu, (K, TA, in the CK rafilahu,) He let down, or made to hang down, his garments, or his garment, or his skirt. (Sh, T, M, K.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) rfRlhu, (A 'Obeyd, T, S, M,) inf. n. as above, (Sh, T, S, M, K,) (tropical:) He magnified him, or honoured him: (A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, K:) he made him a king, (A 'Obeyd, T, M, K,) and a lord, or chief, (Sh, T, M, K,) and a commander, and a judge: (TA:) [like rafRadahu:] and he rendered him submissive; made him to submit; or brought him under, or into, subjection: (M, K:) thus it has two contr. meanings; (K;) [like tarRafahu;] for when a man is made judge in an affair, it is as though he were subjected to service therein. (TA.) Dhu-r-Rummeh says,
UicaA naHonu rafRalonaA QmoraOF saAda qawomahu
waUino lamo yakuno mino qaboli celika yucokaru
(assumed tropical:) [When we magnify a man, or make a man a king, &c., he becomes lord, or chief, of his people, though he have been before that not mentioned]. (T, S, M.) And you say, rufRila fulaAnN (assumed tropical:) Such a one was made a lord, or chief, over his people. (Sh, T.) ― -b3- Also (tropical:) He increased, or exceeded, to him that over which he had authority to judge, or to decide. (TA.) ― -b4- And tarofiylN also signifies (tropical:) The leaving a well for its water to collect in it; (S, O, K;) and so rafolN↓: (O, K:) you say, rfRl AlrRakyRap (tropical:) He left the well for its water to collect in it; (Ks, T, M;) as also rafalahaA↓, aor.
rafula
, inf. n. rafolN. (O.)

4 Arfl c
4. Arfl, and its inf. n. UirofaAlN: see 1, in two places: ＝ -A2- and see also 2, in two places.

5 tarafRala
5: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- trfRl also signifies (tropical:) He was, or became, or was made, a lord, or chief. (Sh, T, TA.) Hence, in a trad. of Wáïl Ibn-Hojr, yatarafRalu EalaI AlOaqowaAli Hayovu kaAnuwA mino Oaholi HaDoramawota (tropical:) [He is, or will be, &c., a lord, or chief, over the subordinate kings, wherever they are, of the people of Hadramowt]. (T, * TA.)

Q. Q. 1 tarofala c
Q. Q. 1. tarofala, inf. n. tarofalapN: see 1.

rifolN c
rifolN, (IDrd, O, K, TA,) or, as in some copies of the Jm, rifalRN↓, (O, TA,) or rafalN↓, (accord. to a copy of the M,) or rafilN↓, (accord. to the CK,) [in the K said to be with kesr, which, accord. to a rule observed in that work, indicates that it is rifolN,] The skirt, or lower extremity, of a garment. (M, O, K.) You say, Oarofala rifolahu [explained above: see 2]. (K.) And qamiySN saAbigu AlrRifoli, i. e. [A shirt ample, or long,] in the skirt. (TA.)

rafalN c
rafalN (tropical:) The water that collects after drawing, (jamRap, thus accord. to the T and O and some copies of the K, [and this is said in the TA to be the right explanation,]) or the black mud, or black fetid mud, (HamoOap, thus accord. to other copies of the K, or mukolap [which has the same or
a similar meaning], thus accord. to the M and A and L,) of a well. (T, M, O, A, L, K.) ＝ -A2- See also the next preceding paragraph. ＝ -A3- rafalo rafalo A call to the ewe, to be milked. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

rafilN c
rafilN Awkward (S, M, K) in his manner of wearing his clothes, (S,) or with his clothes [when walking &c.], and in every work; as also Oarofalu↓; fem. [of the latter] rafolaMCu↓. (M, K.) And rafilapN (Lth, T, M, K, TA) and raAfilapN↓ (Lth, T, TA) A woman who drags her skirt (Lth, T, M, K, TA) well, or beautifully, (M, K, TA,) when she walks, and who walks with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side: (Lth, T, TA:) or the former signifies a woman who drags her skirt (tatarafRalu), in her gait, by reason of awkwardness: (S, TA:) and rafolMCu↓, a woman who does not walk well (ADk, T, S, M, K) in her clothes, (ADk, T, S, M,) dragging her garment, (M,) or dragging her skirt: (K:) and raAfilN↓, a man making his clothes long, and dragging them, walking with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side; (S;) in which sense rafilapN may be well used as an epithet applied to a woman: (Lth, T:) or raAfilN↓ (TA) and tarofiylN↓, (Seer, M, K, TA,) in which latter the t is augmentative, (TA,) signify a man who drags his skirt, and walks in the manner last described above; or who moves his arm up and down in walking. (Seer, M, K, TA.) ― -b2- Also, i. e. rafilN, Foolish; stupid; or unsound, or deficient, in intellect, or understanding. (S.) ― -b3- And rafilapN, A foul, or an unseemly, or ugly, woman; (M, K;) as also rifalRapN↓, (M,) or rifilapN↓, with two kesrehs: (K:) and the same epithets are applied likewise in this sense to a man. (M.) ＝ -A2- See also rifolN.

rifilapN c
rifilapN: see the next preceding paragraph, near the end.

rifalRN c
rifalRN Long in the tail; (Lth, T, S, M, K;) applied to a garment: (S:) or, thus applied, wide, or ample: (M, K:) in the former sense, applied to a horse, (Lth, As, T, M,) and to a bull, (Lth, T,) and to a camel, (Lth, T, S, M,) and to a mountaingoat; (M;) and rafanRN signifies the same: (Lth, As, M:) and applied to a horse as meaning also (M) having much flesh; (M, K;) and so rifanRN: (M:) and to a camel as meaning also wide in the skin: (Lth, T, S, M, K:) and, applied to hair, long; (M;) [or] so rafaAlN↓, like saHaAbN; (K;) or rufaAlN↓, or rifaAlN↓; (so accord. to different copies of the T;) and so rafaAlN↓ applied to a garment. (TA.) Also A man having a long skirt. (Ham p. 386.) ― -b2- [Hence,] EayoXN rifalRN, (TA,) or maEiyXapN rifalRapN, (S, M, in one copy of the S rafilapN,) (tropical:) Ample means of subsistence. (S, M, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also rifolN. ＝ -A3- And see rafilN.

rafaAlN c
rafaAlN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

rufaAlN c
rufaAlN: see rifalN.

rifaAlN c
rifaAlN: see rifalRN. ＝ -A2- rifaAlu AltRayosi A thing that is put before the penis of the goat, in order that he may not copulate. (IDrd, M, K.)

raAfilN c
raAfilN; and its fem., with p: see rafilN, in three places.

Oarofalu c
Oarofalu; and its fem., rafolaMCu: see rafilN, in three places.

tarofiylN c
tarofiylN: see rafilN.

UizaArN murofalN c
UizaArN murofalN [A waist-wrapper] made to hang down. (Sh, T.) [Hence, perhaps, what next follows.]

mrflp c
mrflp [written without any syll. signs, app. either murofalapN or murafRalapN, an epithet used as a subst., or converted into a subst. by the addition of p,] A long [dress or garment such as is called] HulRap, in which one drags his skirt, and walks with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait (yurofalu fiyhaA). (TA.)

murafRalapN c
murafRalapN A she-camel having her udder bound with a piece of rag, which is made to hang down over her teats so as to cover them. (M, O, L, K.) ― -b2- [See also the next preceding paragraph.]

mirofaAlN c
mirofaAlN, applied to a woman, means kaviyrapu AlrRufuwli fiI vawobihaA [i. e. Who drags her skirt, &c., much]: (Lth, T:) [and in like manner,] applied to a man, (TA,) kavyru AlrRafalaAni [which means the same: see 1]. (M, K, TA.)

maraAfilu c
maraAfilu [app. pl. of marofalN, an inf. n. of rafala]: see 1.

1 rafuha EayoXuhu c
1. rafuha EayoXuhu, (JK, K,) or AlEayoXu, (Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. rafaAhapN and rafaAhiyapN (JK, Mgh, Msb, K *) and rufohapN, (JK,) His life, or the life, was, or became, ample in its means or circumstances, unstraitened, or plentiful, (JK, Mgh, Msb, K,) and easy, pleasant, soft, or delicate. (JK, * Msb, K.) [See also rafaAhapN, below.] ＝ -A2- rafaha, aor.
rafaha
, inf. n. rufuwhN (JK, Msb, K) and rafohN (Msb, K) and rifohN, (K,) [or this last is perhaps a simple subst.,] said of a man, He led [a plentiful, and] an easy, a pleasant, a soft, or a delicate, life; (K;) he found, or experienced, [or enjoyed, (see the part. n. raAfihN, below,)] an easy, a pleasant, a soft, or a delicate, life, with ampleness of the means of subsistence; and trfRh↓ is [syn. therewith, its part. n. mutarafRihN being syn. with raAfihN, and the verb itself being] quasipass. of rafRaha: (Msb:) or he found, or experienced, rest, or ease, after fatigue. (JK.) [See also 4.] ― -b2- rafahati AlUibilu, (S, Mgh, K,) aor.
rafaha
, (S, Mgh,) inf. n. rafohN and rufuwhN, (S, [and it is implied in the K that rifohN also is an inf. n. of the verb thus used, but it is a simple subst. accord. to the S,]) The camels came to the water to drink (S, Mgh, K) every day, (S,) when they would. (S, Mgh, K.) [See rifohN, below.] ＝ -A3- OamaA tarofahu fulaAnFA Hast thou not, or wherefore wilt thou not have, mercy, or pity, or compassion, on such a one? (TA. [The meaning is there only indicated by the context.])

2 rfRh c
2. rfRh, inf. n. tarofiyhN: see 4, in five places. ― -b2- rfRh nafosahu, inf. n. as above, He rested himself; made himself to be at rest or at ease; or gave himself rest. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b3- rfRh Eanohu, (JK, S, Mgh, K,) or Ealayohi, (so accord. to one copy of the S, [both correct, but the former the more common,]) inf. n. as above, (S, K,) He made his circumstances ample and easy; eased him, or relieved him; and granted him a delay; (JK, * S, * Mgh, K; *) namely, his debtor; (S, Mgh;) or one who was in straitness, or distress: (TA:) and he behaved, or acted, gently, softly, tenderly, graciously, or courteously, with him: (JK, TA: *) and rafRiho EalaIRa Grant thou to me a delay: it is from rifohN as used in relation to camels. (Mgh.) And rufRiha Eanohu AltRaEabu Fatigue was removed from him, or made to quit him. (TA.)

4 Arfh c
4. Arfh He found, or experienced, rest, or ease, (K,) or he remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, and found, or experienced, rest, or ease, (IAar, TA,) EinodinaA at our abode; as also rfRh↓, inf. n. tarofiyhN; (IAar, TA;) and Astrfh↓. (IAar, K.) ― -b2- He kept continually, or constantly, to the eating of dainty food, (K, TA,) and indulged himself largely in eating and drinking: and this is said to be meant in a trad. in which AlUirofaAh is forbidden; because it is one of the practices of the foreigners and of worldly people. (TA.) ― -b3- He anointed himself, (JK, S, K,) and combed, or anointed and combed, his hair, (S,) every day: (JK, S, K:) and this also is said to be meant in the trad. above mentioned: (JK, S, TA:) or by AlArfAh in that trad. is meant [the indulging in] ease and plenty. (JK.) ― -b4- Arfhu AlmaAlu The cattle remained near to the water (K, TA) in the water-ing-trough or tank, pasturing there upon the plants, or trees, called HamoD. (TA.) ― -b5- And ArfhwA Their camels, (JK,) or their cattle, (K,) came to the water to drink (JK, K) every day, (JK,) or when they would. (K.) ＝ -A2- Oarofahahumo He (God) made them to have an easy, a pleasant, a soft, or a delicate, and a plentiful, life; as also rafRahahumo↓, inf. n. tarofiyhN: (K, TA:) and Oarofahotuhu and rafRahotuhu↓ I made him to find, or experience, [or enjoy, (see 1,)] an easy, a pleasant, a soft, or a delicate, life, with ampleness of the means of subsistence. (Msb.) ― -b2- And Arfh AlUibila; (S, K;) and rfRhhA↓, (K,) and EanohaA rfRh↓, inf. n. as above; (TA;) He made the camels to come to the water to drink (S, K, TA) every day, (S, TA,) when they would. (S, K, TA.)

5 tarafRaha
5: see 1.

10 Uisotarofaha
10: see 4.

rifohN c
rifohN [said in the K to be an inf. n. of rafaha said of a man, and app. of rafahat said of camels: or it is] a subst. from rafahat said of camels; (S;) and [thus] signifies The coming of camels to the water to drink (JK, S, * Mgh) every day, (JK, S, *) when they will: (S, * Mgh:) or the shortest and quickest of the times of coming to water. (TA.) [See also vilovN, and EurayojaMCu.] Lebeed uses it metaphorically in relation to palm-trees growing over water, saying,
yaXorabona rifohFA EiraAkFA gayora SaAdiyapK
fakulRuhaA kaAriEN fiI AlmaMCi mugotamiru
[(tropical:) They drink every day, together, not thirsting; and every one of them is sipping the water, dipping therein]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also Small, or young, palm-trees. (JK, K, TA. [By Golius and Freytag written, in this sense, rifahN.])

rufahN c
rufahN i. q. tibonN [i. e. Straw; or straw that has been trodden, or thrashed, and cut: by some written rufRapN; and by some, rufatN]: (Kr, S, K:) whence the prov., OagonaI mina AltRufahi Eani AlrRufahi [More free from want than the badger is from the want of straw]; AltRufahu meaning the beast of prey called EanaAqu AlOaroDi; because it does not feed upon straw: (S:) [by some written AltRufRahu; and by some, AltRufapu; and by some, AltRufRapu:] accord. to some, the former word is with p; and AlrRufarufatN occurs as its pl. in a verse cited by IF: accord to ISk, the two words are correctly without teshdeed, and with the radical h. (TA in art. tfh.) [See also rufatN, in art. rft.]

rafohapN c
rafohapN Pity, compassion, or mercy. (AHeyth, K.) Thus expl. as used in the saying, UicaA saqaTati AlTRarofaho qalRato fiI AlOaroDi AlrRafohah. (TA. [But AlTRarofah is here an evident mistranscription for AlSRarofah, the name of the Twelfth Mansion of the Moon: the meaning is, When AlSrfh sets aurorally, pity becomes little in the earth; because then the cold ends: see art. Srf.])

rafohaAnu c
rafohaAnu: see raAfihN, in two places.

rufahoniyapN c
rufahoniyapN: see rafaAhapN.

rafiyhN c
rafiyhN: see raAfihN, in two places.

rafaAhapN c
rafaAhapN and rafaAhiyapN↓, (S, Msb, K, [both expressly shown in the JK and Mgh and Msb to be inf. ns.,]) like rafaAgapN and rafaAgiyapN, (TA,) and rufahoniyapN↓, (S, K,) like rufagoniyapN, (TA,) the last rendered quasi-coordinate to the quinqueliteral-radical class [partly] by means of A in its latter part, changed into I because of the kesreh before it, (S, [but mentioned also in a separate art., as well as here, in the S and K,]) A state of life ample in its means or circumstances, unstraitened, or plentiful, (S, Msb, K,) and easy, pleasant, soft, or delicate: (Msb, K:) so in the saying, huwa fiI rafaAhapK mina AlEayoXi (S) and rafaAhiyapK (S, Msb) and rufahoniyapK (S) He is in a state of life ample in its means &c. (S, Msb.)

rafaAhiyapN c
rafaAhiyapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

raAfihN c
raAfihN, applied to life, as meaning Ample in its means or circumstances, unstraitened, or plentiful, (Mgh,) [and easy, pleasant, soft, or delicate; like rafiyhN↓: ― -b2- and] applied to a man, (JK, S, Msb,) In a state of ease, and ampleness of the means or circumstances of life; (JK, S;) in a state of rest, or ease; (Mgh, Msb, K;) enjoying an easy, a pleasant, a soft, or a delicate, life; (Msb, K;) as also rafiyhN↓ (K [though this seems to be applied more properly to life itself, being from rafuha,]) and rafohaAnu↓ (K) and mutarafRihN↓: (Mgh, Msb, K:) or rafohaAnu↓ signifies in a state of rest, or ease, after fatigue; and its pl. is rifaAhN and rafaAhaI. (JK.) ― -b3- UibilN rawaAfihu, [the latter word being pl. of raAfihapN,] Camels coming to the water to drink (JK, K) every day, (JK,) when they will. (K.) ― -b4- bayoniI wabayonaka layolapN raAfihapN, (S, Msb, K,) and valaAvu layaAlK rawaAfihu, (JK, S, K, *) [Between me and thee is a night, and are three nights,] of gentle, or easy, journeying. (JK, S, Msb, K.) ― -b5- huwa raAfihN bihi He is affected with mercy, pity, or compassion, for him. (Aboo-Leylà, K.)

huwa Oarofahu minohu c
huwa Oarofahu minohu means Oakovaru rafohFA [i. e. He is one who leads, or enjoys, a more easy, pleasant, soft, or delicate, and plentiful, life than he]. (TA.)

mutarafRihN c
mutarafRihN: see raAfihN.

1 rafawotu AlvRawoba c
1. rafawotu AlvRawoba, (S, M, Msb,) third pers. rafaA, (K,) aor. Oarofuwhu, (S, Msb,) inf. n. rafowN; (S, M, Msb;) and, in the dial. of Benoo-Kaab, rafayotuhu, aor. Oarofiyhi, inf. n. rafoIN; (Msb;) but this latter is strange; (TA in art. rfO;) I repaired, or mended, the garment, (Msb, K, TA,) [where it was rent,] drawing parts thereof together; (TA;) [or rather, as is well known, I darned it; for] rafowN is the finest, or most delicate, kind of sewing; the weaving [over] a rent, or hole, in a garment, so that it appears as though there were in it no rent, or hole: (Har p. 91:) and rafaOutuhu signifies the same: (S, M, Msb:) IAar and AZ say that it is with C; but the latter says that the C is [sometimes] changed into w, so that one says rafawotu: accord. to ISk, [but this is at variance with what follows,] the verbs with and without C have different meanings; for one says, rafaOa AlvRawoba, and rafawotu AlrRajula. (TA.) ― -b2- rafawotu AlrRajula, (ISk, S, M,) third pers. rafaA, (K,) [aor. and inf. n. as above,] (tropical:) I appeased, or quieted, or calmed, the man; (ISk, M, TA;) as also rafaOotuhu; (M and K in art. rfO;) [i. e.] I quieted the man's fear; (S, K, TA;) did away with his fear, like as one does away with a rent, or hole, by AlrRafow [i. e. darning]. (TA.) ― -b3- And rafaA, aor. yarofuw, (tropical:) He married, or took a wife; (TA;) and rafaOa is said to signify the same. (TA in art. rfO.)

2 rafRayotuhu c
2. rafRayotuhu, inf. n. tarofiyapN, I said to him (i. e. to a man taking to himself a wife, S) biAlrRifaMCi waAlbaniyna [expl. below, see 3]: (S, K:) and so rafRaOotuhu. (T, S, M, K; all in art. rfO.)

3 yuraAfiyniI c
3. yuraAfiyniI means He agrees, or is of one mind or opinion, with me; [the inf. n.] muraAfaApN being syn. with AitRifaAqN, (S, TA,) or muwaAfaqapN, (AZ, M, TA,) as also rifaMCN, (AZ, TA,) this latter being thus made by AZ an inf. n. [like the former]: (TA:) [or] rifaMCN↓ [is a simple subst., or is generally used as such, and] signifies close union, or coalescence; and concord, or agreement; (S, K, TA;) and good consociation: (TA:) and hence the saying, to one taking to himself a wife, (S, in the TA llmlk [to the king],) biAlrRifaMCi waAlbaniyna [May it (the marriage) be with close union, &c., further expl. in art. rfO]: (S, TA:) ISk says that it is originally with C; (TA;) but if you will, he says, the meaning may be, with tranquillity, or freedom from disturbance or agitation; from rafawotu AlrRajula “ I appeased, or quieted, or calmed, the man. ” (S, TA.) ― -b2- muraAfaApN is also syn. with mudaAraApN: and with muHaAbaApN: as a dial. var. of muraAfaOapN: [i. e., raAfaAhu signifies, like daAraAhu, He treated him with gentleness, or blandishment; soothed, coaxed, wheedled, or cajoled, him; &c.: and he treated him in an easy and a gentle manner in selling; or abated to him the price, or payment:] and accord. to IAar, ArfAhu↓ [also, like ArfOhu,] is syn. with daAraAhu. (TA.)

4 Oarofayotu Uilayohi c
4. Oarofayotu Uilayohi I had recourse, or I betook myself, or repaired, to him, or it, for refuge, protection, preservation, concealment, covert, or lodging: (TA:) and I inclined to, or towards, him, or it: a dial. var. of OarofaOotu. (Fr, TA.) ＝ -A2- Oarofayotu AlsRafiynapa I brought the ship near to the land; a dial. var. of OarofaOotu. (ISh, TA.) ― -b2- See also 3, last sentence.

6 taraAfawoA EalaI AlOamori c
6. taraAfawoA EalaI AlOamori They agreed together to do the thing; a dial. var. of taraAfaWuwA. (TA.)

rufapN c
rufapN: pl. rufaAtN: see rufahN, in art. rfh.

rifaMCN c
rifaMCN: see 3; and see also art. rfO.

OarofaI c
OarofaI Having large and flabby ears: fem. rafowaMCu; (K, TA;) meaning, whose ears approach each other so that their extremities almost touch one another. (TA.)

OurofiIRN c
OurofiIRN: see art. rfI.

1 rafabotu AlvRawoba c
1. rafabotu AlvRawoba: see 1 in art. rfw.

OurofiIRN c
OurofiIRN Pure milk: (IAar, TA:) or milk of a gazelle: or pure and good milk: (M, K:) ISd says, it may be of the measure OufoEuwlN, or fuEoliIRN; or it may belong to art. rfw, because one says rafawotu, but not [to his knowledge] rafayotu. (TA.)

1 raqRa c
1. raqRa, aor.
raqiqa
, (S, Mgh, * Msb, K,) inf. n. riqRapN, (JK, S, Mgh, K, * TA,) It (a thing, JK, S, Mgh, Msb, TA) had the quality termed diqRapN; (K, TA; [in the CK, AlrRaqRapu is erroneously put for AldRiqRapu;]) [i. e.] it was, or became, the contr. of galiyZN, (S, Msb, TA,) and of vaxiynN: (S, TA:) [or rather, properly, it is the contr. of vaxuna; i. e. it was, or became, thin as meaning of little thickness in comparison with its breadth and length together; little in extent, or depth, between its two opposite surfaces: thin, fine, delicate, flimsy, unsubstantial, or uncompact, in texture &c.; said of a garment and the like: shallow, or of little depth; said of water, and of sand, &c.: thin as meaning wanting in spissitude; said of mud &c.: attenuated: see riqRapN, below; and raqiyqN:] and Astrq↓ [in like manner] signifies the contr. of AstglZ [and therefore contr. of galuZu; for these last two
verbs are syn.]. (S, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] raqRato EiZaAmuhu, [inf. n. riqRapN, or raqaqN, or both, (and if so, the second pers. may be raqaqota and raqiqota, and the aor. yariqRu and yaraqRu,) (assumed tropical:) His bones became weak; or became thin, and consequently (assumed tropical:) weak; meaning] (assumed tropical:) he became aged: (JK:) or it is said of one who has become aged. (TA. [See riqRapN and raqaqN below; and see also raqiyqN.]) ― -b3- And raqRa, [inf. n. riqRapN, (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, weak: and abject, mean, paltry, or contemptible: see raqiyqN: and see also 4:] his patience, or endurance, became weak, or weakened: (TA:) he was, or became, weak-hearted, and fearful; as also raqRa qalobuhu: (Mgh:) and affected with shame, shyness, or bashfulness. (K, TA.) ― -b4- And raqRa lahu, (Mgh, K, *) first pers. raqaqotu, aor.
raqiqa
, inf. n. riqRapN, (K,) (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, [tender-hearted, (see raqiyqN and OaraqRu,)] merciful, compassionate, or pitiful, to him; (Mgh, K;) as also raqRa lahu qalobuhu: (TA:) and lahu trqRq↓ signifies the same as raqR lahu qalobuhu. (S, K.) ― -b5- [And raqRa kalaAmuhu (assumed tropical:) His speech was, or became, soft or tender, or easy and sweet, or elegant, graceful, or ornate: see raqiyqN, and see also 2. ― -b6- And raqR Sawotuhu (assumed tropical:) His voice was, or became, slender, or soft, or gentle. ― -b7- And raqRato HaAluhu (assumed tropical:) His state, or condition, was, or became, narrow in its circumstances, or evil: see riqRapN, below, and 4; and see also 4 in art. xf. ― -b8- And raqRa EayoXuhu (assumed tropical:) His living, or sustenance, was, or became, scanty.] ― -b9- And raqRa Eadaduhu (tropical:) His years that he numbered were for the most part passed, so that the remainder was little (raqiyq) in his estimation. (IAar, TA.) ＝ -A2- raqRa, (Mgh, Msb,) aor.
raqiqa
, (Msb,) inf. n. riqRN, (S, * Mgh, Msb, K,) He was, or became, a slave; (S, * Mgh, Msb, K; *) or he remained a slave. (Mgh.) ＝ -A3- raqRahu and ArqRhu↓ He made him a slave: (Msb:) or ↓the latter signifies he kept him as a slave; (Mgh;) contr. of OaEotaqapu; (S, Mgh;) as also AstrqRhu↓: (S:) or ↓the second and ↓third, he possessed him as a slave; (K;) and so raqRahu; accord. to ISk and Az and others: (TA:) or AstrqRhu↓ signifies he made him, or took him as, a slave; (Mgh;) or he brought him into a state of slavery. (TA.)

2 rqRqhu c
2. rqRqhu, (S, K,) inf. n. taroqiyqN; (TA;) and ArqRhu↓, (S, K,) inf. n. UiroqaAqN; (TA;) contr. of galRaZahu; (K;) or He made it, or rendered it, raqiyq [i. e. thin, as meaning of little thickness in comparison with its breadth and length together; &c.: see 1, first sentence; and raqiyqN, below]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] taroqiyqu AlkalaAmi (assumed tropical:) The making speech to be [soft or tender, or easy and sweet, or] elegant, graceful, or ornate; the beautifying, or embellishing, and adorning, of speech. (S, TA.) And hence, (TA,) it is said in a prov., (S,) OaEano SabuwHK turaqRiqu (S, K, TA) (tropical:) Dost thou allude (K, TA) gracefully, courteously, politely, or delicately, (TA,) to a morning-draught? (K, TA:) [the origin of which prov. was this:] a certain man named Jábán alighted by night at the abode of a people, and they entertained him, and gave him an evening-draught; and when he had finished it, he said, “ When ye shall have given me a morning draught, how shall I enter upon my way and prosecute the object of my want? ” whereupon the saying above was addressed to him: (K, * TA:) it is applied to him who makes an allusion to a thing, like this guest, who desired to oblige the people to give him the morning draught: and was said by Esh-Shaabee to one who spoke of kissing a woman when meaning thereby jimaAE. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] rqRq Sawotahu (K in art. Hzn) or Arqhu↓ (S in that art.) (assumed tropical:) [He made his voice slender, or soft, or gentle]. ― -b4- taroqiyqN also signifies (assumed tropical:) [The pronouncing a word with the slender sound of the lengthened fet-h (like the sound of “ a” in our word “father ”), and with the ordinary sound of the letter l; both as in biAllRehi and llRehi;] the contr. of tafoxiymN. (Kull p. 127.) ― -b5- rqRq AlmaXoIa, said of a camel, (K, TA,) (tropical:) He went an easy pace: and trqRq↓, alone, signifies the same. (TA.) [See also R. Q. 2.] ― -b6- rqRq bayona Alqawomi (assumed tropical:) He created, or excited, disorder, disturbance, disagreement, or dissension, or he made, or did, mischief, between, or among, the people. (TA.)

4 ArqR c
4. ArqR, said of the white grape, (AHn, O, K,) It was, or became, thin in its skin and abundant in its juice: (AHn, TA:) or completely ripe. (O, K.) ― -b2- Said of a man, (tropical:) He was, or became, in a state, or condition, narrow in its circumstances, or evil; i. q. SaAra raqiyqa AlHaAli, (JK,) or saMCato HaAluhu. (K, TA.) ― -b3- OaraqRato bihimo OaxolaAquhumo (tropical:) Their natural dispositions were, or became, niggardly, tenacious, or avaricious. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Arqhu: see 2, in two places. ― -b2- See also 1, last sentence, in three places.

5 taraqRaRa
5: see 1: ― -b2- and see also 2. ＝ -A2- taraqRaqatohu She (a girl) captivated his heart so that his patience, or endurance, became weak, or weakened. (TA.)

entry.key: laA tadoriI EalaI maA yataraAqRu harimuka

superEntry.entry:
6 laA tadoriI EalaI maA yataraAqRu harimuka c
6. laA tadoriI EalaI maA yataraAqRu harimuka (assumed tropical:) Thou knowest not what thing thou wilt choose: (JK:) or to what state, or condition, thy mind will come at the last. (TA.) The origin of the word (ytrAqR) is unknown. (JK.) [See also art. hrm.]

10 Uisotaroqaqa
10: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- [Hence,] AstrqR AlmaMCu The water [became shallow: and hence,] (tropical:) sank into, or disappeared in, the earth, except a little. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And AstrqR AllRayolu (assumed tropical:) The night for the most part passed. (TA.) ＝ -A2- AstrqRhu: see 1, last sentence, in three places.

R. Q. 1 raqoraqahu c
R. Q. 1. raqoraqahu, (S, K,) inf. n. raqoraqapN, (TK,) He poured it forth in small quantity; namely, water &c.: (K:) or he made it to come and go; namely, water. (S.) ― -b2- rqrq AlvRariyda biAlsRamoni He poured a little clarified butter upon the broken bread; (K, TA;) i. e. made it savoury therewith: or, as some say, poured much thereof upon it. (TA.) ― -b3- rqrq AlvRawoba biAlTRiybi He made the perfume to run [to and fro (as is implied in the S)] upon the garment: (TA:) [or he poured and rubbed the perfume upon the garment.] El-Aashà says,
wataborudu baroda ridaMCi AlEaruwsi fiI AlSRayofi raqoraqota fiyhi AlEabiyraA
[And she is cool, with the coolness of the wiXaAH (see ridaMC) of the bride, in summer, upon which thou hast poured and rubbed perfume mixed with saffron &c.]. (S, TA: in the latter, biAlSRayofi.) ― -b4- rqrq Alxamora He mixed the wine. (TA.) ― -b5- rqrq Eayonahu He made his eye to shed tears. (TA.) ― -b6- It is said in a trad., tajiIoCu fitonapN faturaqoriqu baEoDuhaA baEoDFA, meaning [Sedition, or the like, will come, and] one act thereof will cause desire for another by its embellishment thereof, or investing it with charms. (TA.) ― -b7- [See also raqoraqapN, below.]

R. Q. 2 taraqoraqa c
R. Q. 2. taraqoraqa It (water, &c.,) poured forth in small quantity. (TA.) ― -b2- He, or it, ran in an easy manner. (TA.) [See also 2, last sentence but one.] ― -b3- It (water, S, TA) was, or became, in a state of motion, or commotion; (K, TA;) in which sense, [meaning it flickered,] it is [also] said of the saraAb [or mirage]; (O, K; [see also another explanation below;]) [it went to and fro;] it came and went. (S, K, TA.) And in like manner, (S,) trqrq AldRamoEu The tears went round about at the inner edge of the eyelid- (S, K.) And trqrqt AlXRamosu The sun appeared as though it were turning round (A'Obeyd, K, TA) and coming and going, by reason of its nearness to the horizon, and of vapours intervening between it and the eyes; which it does not when it is high. (A'Obeyd, TA.) ― -b4- It (a thing) shone, or glistened; (JK, S, K;) as does the saraAb [or mirage]. (JK.) ― -b5- trqrqt Eayonuhu His eye shed tears. (TA.)

raqRN c
raqRN: see raqiyqN; and ruqRN. ＝ -A2- Also, (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and riqRN↓, (Msb, K,) but the latter is a rare dial. var. though some read thus in the Kur lii. 3, (Msb,) [Parchment; and vellum; so in the present day; or] skin, (Mgh, Msb,) or thin skin, (S, K,) upon which one writes: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) or (so accord. to the Mgh, but in the K “ and ”) a white [i. e. blank] SaHiyfap [which means a paper and a piece of skin, but generally such as is written upon]: (JK, Mgh, K:) or metaphorically applied to (tropical:) a skin written upon: properly one upon which one writes: (Bd in lii. 3:) accord. to Fr, (assumed tropical:) the SaHaAYif [i. e. papers, or pieces of skin, meaning records,] that will be produced to the sons of Adam on the day of resurrection; which indicates that such as is written is also thus termed: (Az, TA:) in the Kur lii. 3, [accord. to some,] applied to (assumed tropical:) the Book of the Law revealed to Moses: or the Kur-án. (Jel.) ＝ -A3- Also, (K,) or the former word [only], (JK, S, Msb,) The tortoise: (JK:) or a great tortoise: (S, K:) or the male tortoise: (Msb:) and the crocodile: (JK:) or, (K,) accord. to Ibráheem El-Harbee, (TA,) a certain aquatic reptile, (K, TA,) [app. the turtle, or sea-tortoise,] having four legs, and claws, or nails, and teeth in a head which it exposes and conceals, and which is killed for food: (TA:) pl. ruquwqN. (A'Obeyd, JK, S, Msb, K.)

riqRN c
riqRN: see raqRN. [It is indicated in the K that it is syn. with the latter word in all of its (the latter's) senses: but I do not find it to be so in any other lexicon.] ― -b2- A thin thing. (S. [There expl. as signifying XaIoCN raqiyqN; but perhaps by this may be meant that it is an epithet syn. with raqiyqN, as it is said to be in the K.]) See raqiyqN. ― -b3- The leaves of trees: or the branches that are easy for the cattle [to eat]. (K.) ― -b4- And A certain thorny plant. (K.) ― -b5- See also raqaAqN. ＝ -A2- Also The state, or condition, of a slave; slavery; servitude; (JK, S, Msb, K;) and so riqRiyRapN↓. (KL.)

raqRapN c
raqRapN Any land by the side of a valley, over which the water spreads in the days of the increase, and into which it then sinks, or disappears, (S, K,) and which therefore produces good herbage: (S:) pl. riqaAqN. (K.) ― -b2- See also raqaAqN.

riqRapN c
riqRapN [an inf. n. of raqRa in several senses, as shown above, in the first paragraph of this art.]: it is explained in the K as syn. with diqRapN: [see 1, first sentence:] but El-Munáwee says, in the “ Tow- keef, ” that the former is like the latter [as meaning Thinness], but that the latter is said with regard to the lateral parts of a thing, and the former with regard to the depth of a thing [or the extent between the two opposite surfaces thereof]: thus, in a material substance, such, for instance, as a garment, or piece of cloth, [&c.,] it is [thinness as meaning little thickness in comparison with the breadth and length together; littleness in extent, or depth, between the two opposite surfaces: fineness, delicateness, flimsiness, unsubstantialness, or uncompactness, in texture &c.:] the contr. of [vaxaAnapN and] SafaAqapN: (TA:) [in water, and sand, &c., shallowness, or littleness of depth: (see ruqRN:) in mud, and anything imperfectly liquid, thinness as meaning want of spissitude: an attenuated state or condition of anything.] ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Weakness; (Mgh;) as in the phrase riqRapu jaAnibK [weakness of resistance; similar to liynu jaAnibK; contr. of gilaZu jaAnibK]; (Ham p. 631;) [and in the phrase riqRapu diynK weakness of religion: (see raqiyqN:) also abjectness, meanness, paltriness, or contemptibleness: and weak-heartedness, and fearfulness: (see 1:)] and shame, shyness, or bashfulness. (K.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) [Tender-heartedness, (see raqiyqN and OaraqRu,)] mercy, compassion, or pity; (K;) and so riqRapu qalobK: (TA in art. Hn:) in the soul, it is the contr. of jafowapN and qasowapN. (ElMunáwee, TA.) ― -b4- [And (assumed tropical:) Softness or tenderness, or easiness and sweetness, or elegance, gracefulness, or ornateness, of speech: see raqiyqN, and see also 2. ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) Slenderness, softness, or gentleness, of voice.] ― -b6- And (assumed tropical:) Evilness [or narrowness of the circumstances] of state or condition: so in the saying, Eajibotu mino qilRapi maAlihi wariqRapi HaAlihi (assumed tropical:) [I wondered at the paucity of his property, and the evilness, or the narrowness of the circumstances, of his state or condition]. (TA.) ― -b7- [And (assumed tropical:) Scantiness of living or sustenance &c.] ― -b8- And riqRapu baTonK (assumed tropical:) [A looseness, or diarrhœa]. (TA in art. xlf.)

raqaqN c
raqaqN, an inf. n., (KL, [see 1,]) [Thinness, and consequently] (tropical:) weakness (JK, S, K, KL, TA) of the bones, (JK,) or in the bones, (TA,) or of the bone, (KL,) or as in the bone, (S,) and in a camel's foot: (TA:) [and] lightness in a horse's hoof. (AO, TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Paucity: thus in the saying, fiI maAlihi raqaqN (tropical:) [In his property is paucity]: (JK, S, K, TA:) mentioned by Fr, (S,) or by A'Obeyd thus, but the saying mentioned by Fr is maA fiI maAlihi raqRqN (tropical:) There is not in his property paucity. (TA.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) Scantiness (riqRap) of food. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also the next paragraph.

raqaAqN c
raqaAqN A [desert tract such as is called] SaHoraMC: (K:) or a wide, or spacious, SHrMC, of soft soil, beneath which is hardness: (TA:) or a level, (S, K, TA,) expanded, (TA,) tract of land, of soft soil, beneath which is hardness: (S, K, TA:) or a tract from which the water has sunk into the ground; as also ruqaAqN↓ and raqRapN↓ [q. v.]: or a soft and wide tract of land; (K, TA;) accord. to As, without sand; (TA;) as also riqRN↓ and ruqRN↓ and raqaqN↓; (K;) the last of which is a contraction of raqaAqN, used by Ru-beh, (S, TA,) by poetic license. (TA.) ＝ -A2- yawomN raqaAqN A hot day. (Fr, K.) [See also raqoraAqN.]

ruqaAqN c
ruqaAqN: see raqiyqN. ― -b2- Also, (JK, S, K,) as a subst., (Th, S,) or xubozN ruqaAqN, (Mgh, Msb,) Thin bread, (xubozN raqiyqN↓, JK, S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) such as is [flat, or flattened, or] expanded: (TA:) n. un. ruqaAqapN, (Mgh, * Msb, K,) meaning a single thin, round cake of bread: (Mgh:) one should not say riqaAqapN, with kesr: (K:) the pl. of ruqaAqN accord. to the K is riqaAqN; but this is pl. of raqiyqN, like as kiraAmN is pl. of kariymN. (TA.) [See also muraqRaqN.] ― -b3- maXaI maXoyFA ruqaAqFA, said of a camel, means raqRaqa AlmaXoIa, (K, TA,) i. e. (tropical:) He went an easy pace. (TA.) ― -b4- See also raqaAqN.

raqiyqN c
raqiyqN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) fem. with p, (TA,) Having the quality termed diqRapN; (K, TA; [see 1, first sentence, respecting a mistranscription in the CK;]) as also ruqaAqN↓, (K,) of which the fem. is likewise with p; (TA;) and ruqRaAqN↓, (K,) like rumRaAnN; (TA;) [i. e.] contr. of galiyZN; (S, Msb, K, TA;) as also raqRN↓ (K, TA) and riqRN↓: (K:) and contr. of vaxiynN: (S, TA:) [or rather this last is the proper explanation of raqiyqN, as well as of all the other epithets above mentioned; (see riqRapN;) i. e. thin as meaning having little thickness in comparison with its breadth and length together; having little extent, or depth, between its two opposite surfaces:] applied to bread that is [flat, flattened, or] expanded; such as is termed ruqaAqN, q. v.: (TA:) and to a garment, or piece of cloth, (Mgh, El-Munáwee, TA,) and the like, as meaning thin, fine, delicate, flimsy, unsubstantial, or uncompact, in texture &c.; contr. of SafiyqN; (El-Munáwee, TA;) as also ruqaAriqN↓: (TA:) and to water [as meaning shallow, or of little depth; and in like manner to sand]: see ruqRN: (IDrd, K, TA:) [thin as meaning wanting in spissitude; applied to mud &c.: attenuated:] pl. riqaAqN (TA) and OariqRapN. (JK.) [Hence,] AlrRaqiyqaAni The part between the xaASirap [or flank] and the rufog [or groin, on either side]: (AA, K:) and the pl. AlOarqRapu the thin parts at the flanks of she-camels. (JK.) Also, the dual, AlrqyqAn, The HiDonaAni [or part between the armpit and the flank, on either side]. (K, TA. [In the CK AlxuSoyAni, q. v.]) And [The two veins called] the OaxodaEaAni [q. v.]. (K.) And, of the nose, The two sides: (K:) so says As: or the raqiyq of the nose is the thin and soft part of the side. (TA.) ― -b2- [Also Thin, or attenuated, and consequently (assumed tropical:) weak, in the bones: see raqaqN.] You say naAqapN raqiyqapN meaning (assumed tropical:) A she-camel whose marrow-bones have become weak and thin (DaEufato waraqRato), and whose medullary canal is wide: pl. riqaAqN and raqaAYiqu. (IAar, TA.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) Weak: and abject, mean, paltry, or contemptible: applied to a man [&c.]. (TA.) And goats are called maAlN raqiyqN [Weak cattle] because they have not the endurance of sheep. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) Weak-hearted. (Mgh.) And raqiyqu Alqalobi (assumed tropical:) Soft, or tender, of heart; contr. of qaAsiI Alqalobi. (El-Munáwee, TA.) ― -b5- [(assumed tropical:) Soft or tender, or easy and sweet, or elegant, graceful, or ornate, speech or language.] raqiyqu AllRafoZi means [(assumed tropical:) Soft or tender, &c., of expression; applied to a man: and also soft or tender or] easy and sweet expression. (Har p. 8.) ― -b6- [(assumed tropical:) Slender, or soft, or gentle, applied to the voice.] ― -b7- rajulN raqiyqu AlHawaAXiI (assumed tropical:) A man gentle, gracious, or courteous, to his associates. (TA in art. HXI.) And EayoXN raqiyqu AlHawaAXiI (tropical:) A soft or delicate, pleasant, or plentiful and easy, life. (TA.) ― -b8- [EayoXN raqiyqN may sometimes mean the same: but it commonly means (assumed tropical:) Scanty living or sustenance.] ― -b9- And fulaAnN raqiyqu AldRiyni waAlHaAli (tropical:) [Such a one is weak in respect of religion, and narrow in the circumstances of, or evil in, his state or condition: see riqRapN]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A slave, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) male and female; (Msb;) [but] the latter is [also] called raqiyqapN: (Lh, JK, TA:) and slaves; for it is used as sing. and pl.; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) like rafiyqN and xaliyTN: (TA:) accord. to Abu-l-'Abbás, so called because they are abject and submissive to their owner: (TA:) the pl. of raqiyqN is OariqRaMCu, (Msb, TA,) erroneously said in the K to be riqaAqN; (TA;) and that of raqiyqapN is raqaAYiqu. (Lh, TA.) Using it as pl., you say, heWulaMCi raqiyqiI [These are my slaves]. (Mgh.) And layosa fiI AlrRaqiyqi SadaqapN, i. e. [There is no poorrate] in the case of slaves used for service [as distinguished from those that are for sale]. (Msb.) [See also muraqRN.]

ruqRaI c
ruqRaI [fem. of OaraqRu, q. v.].

ruqRaAqN c
ruqRaAqN: see raqiyqN, first sentence.

riqRiyRapN c
riqRiyRapN: see riqRN last sentence.

raqoraqapN c
raqoraqapN inf. n. of R. Q. 1. (TK.) ― -b2- Quickness in going and coming. (JK. [If an inf. n. in this sense, its verb is perhaps ruqoriqa.])

raqoraAqN c
raqoraAqN: see ruqaAriqN. ― -b2- Also, applied to a collection of clouds (saHaAbN), Going and coming. (TA.) See also the next paragraph. ― -b3- Applied to tears (damoEN), Going round about at the inner edge of the eyelid. (TA.) ― -b4- Anything shining, or glistening. (S, TA.) [Hence,] raqoraAqapN A woman (As, TA) as though water were running upon her face: (As, K, TA:) or raqoraAqapu AlbaXarapi a girl whose external skin shines, or glistens, (Ham p. 622, and TA,) with whiteness: (TA:) pl. raqaAriqu, applied to soft, or tender, young women. (Ham ubi suprà.) [Hence also,] AlrRaqoraAqu is The name of a sword of Saad Ibn-'Obádeh El-Ansáree. (K.) ― -b5- Applied to a day, i. q. SaArRN [app. a mistranscription for HaArRN, i. e. Hot; like raqaAqN; as though shining, or glistening, with the sunlight]. (Fr, TA.) ＝ -A2- The taraqoruq [or commotion, or moving to and fro, or coming and going, whether real or apparent,] of the saraAb [or mirage], and of anything that shines, or glistens. (JK.)

ruqoruqaAnu AlsRaraAbi c
ruqoruqaAnu AlsRaraAbi What is in a state of commotion, of the srAb [or mirage]: (IDrd, O, K:) and AlsRaraAbi raqoraAqu↓ means [the same, or] what [moves to and fro, or undulates, or] comes and goes, of the srAb. (S.) And saraAbN ruqoruqaAnN [Mirage] that shines, or glistens. (TA.)

ruqaAriqN c
ruqaAriqN: see raqiyqN, first sentence: and ruqRN. Also, applied to the saraAb [or mirage], (so in the CK,) or XaraAb [i. e. wine or beverage], (so in copies of the K and in the O and TA,) [the former of which readings I think the more probably that which is correct, supposing the mirage to be likened to shallow water, which is thus termed, but Freytag prefers the latter reading,] i. q. raqiqu [app. as meaning Shallow, or perhaps thin]; (IDrd, O, K;) and so raqoraAqN↓. (IDrd, O.) ― -b2- And A sword having much maMC [q. v.; i. e. much diversified with wavy marks, streaks, or grain; or having much lustre]: (IDrd, K, TA:) or shining, or glistening, much. (TA.)

OaraqRu c
OaraqRu [compar. and superl. of raqiyqN; i. e. More, and most, thin, &c.]. ruqRaI, [its fem.,] applied to a piece of fat (XaHomapN), means mino OaraqRi AlXRaHomi; [i. e. Of the finest, or most delicate, sort of fat; (in the CK, erroneously, mino OaraqRa AlXRaHomu;)] (JK, K, TA;) such that no one comes upon it without his eating it. (JK, TA.) Hence the prov., wajadotaniI AlXRaHomapa AlrRuqRaI EalayohaA AlmaOotaI [Thou hast found me to be the finest, or most delicate, piece of fat, to which there is a way of access]: said by a man to his companion when he esteems him weak. (JK, Sgh, K.) [See also XaHomuhu AlrRukRaI, or XaHomapu AlrRukRaI, in art. rk.] ― -b2- humo OaraqRu quluwbFA (assumed tropical:) They are more, or most, tender-hearted; and more, or most, inclined to accept admonition. (TA.)

maraqRN c
maraqRN sing. of maraAqRu, (Hr, K,) which signifies The thin, or delicate, and soft, or tender, parts of the belly: (S, K:) or the lower part thereof with what surrounds it, that is thin or delicate [in the skin]: (TA as from the S [but not in my copies of the latter]:) or the lower part of the belly, in the region of the SifaAq [q. v.], beneath the navel: (T, TA:) and metonymically applied in a trad. respecting ablution to the lower part of the belly of a man, together with the rufogaAni [or groins] and the genitals and the [other] places of which the skin is thin or delicate: and, of a camel, the OarofaAg [or groins, and similar places of flexure or creasing]: (TA:) or (K) maraAqRu [thus applied] has no sing. (S, K.) Also The soft part of the nose, (JK, TA,) in the side thereof; [i. e. each of the alæ thereof;] as also musotaraqRN↓: (TA:) pl. as above. (JK.)

muraqRN c
muraqRN and maroquwqN↓, mentioned by ISk, (Msb, TA,) and by Az, and in the 'Ináyeh, therefore the disallowing of the latter by some is not to be regarded, (TA,) or the latter is for maroquwqN lahu meaning “ compassionated, ” (Mgh,) Made a slave: (Msb:) or possessed as a slave: (TA:) [or kept as a slave: (see 1, last sentence:)] fem. of the former with p, (Msb, TA,) and so of the latter. (Msb.) [See also raqiyqN, last signification.]

muriqRN c
muriqRN A horse thin in the hoof: (K:) or light therein. (AO, TA.)

muraqRaqN c
muraqRaqN A cake of bread [made thin and] wide, or broad. (TA.) [See also ruqaAqN.]

miroqaAqN c
miroqaAqN A baker's rolling-pin; (MA;) the thing with which bread is made thin [and flat]; (K;) i. q. miHowarN [q. v.] and SawobajN. (TA, in art. lT.)

maroquwqN c
maroquwqN: see muraqRN.

maAlN mutaraqorqN lilsRimani c
maAlN mutaraqorqN lilsRimani, or lilohuzaAli, (K, TA,) and liOano yaromida, (TA,) Cattle disposed, (K, TA,) and seen to be near, (TA,) to fatness, or to leanness, (K, TA,) and to perishing. (TA.)

musotaraqRN c
musotaraqRN: see maraqRN.

1 raqaOa AldRamoEu c
1. raqaOa AldRamoEu, aor.
raqaAa
, inf. n. raqoCN and ruquwoCN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) The tears stopped, or ceased to flow; (Fs, JK, S, Mgh, Msb;) or dried up, (IDrst, Aboo-'Alee El-Kálee, K,) and stopped, or ceased: (K:) and in like manner, AldRamu the blood: (JK, S, Mgh, Msb:) whence the phrase juroHaAni laA yaroqaMni Two wounds not ceasing to bleed. (Mgh.) And in like manner also, (JK,) raqaOa AlEiroqu, (Fs, JK, K, TA, [not AlEaraqu, as supposed by Golius and Freytag,]) inf. ns. as above, (K,) The vein stopped or ceased [bleeding]; syn. AinoqaTaEa, (Fs, JK, TA,) and sakana, (TA,) or AirotafaEa; (K;) [in all of which explanations, damuhu is understood.] ＝ -A2- raqaOa bayonahumo, (K, TA,) aor.
raqaAa
, inf. n. raqoCN, (TA,) He effected a reconciliation, or made peace, between them; (K, TA;) like rafaOa: (TA:) and [in like manner,] raqaOa maA bayonahumo He arranged, or rightly disposed, or rectified, the matter, or affair, between them. (TA.) And the former phrase (rqObynhm) also signifies He created disorder or discord, or made mischief, between them: thus having two contr. meanings. (K.) ＝ -A3- raqaOa fiI AldRarajapi, (K,) and raqiYa, also, mentioned by Ibn-Málik in the “ Káfiyeh, ” as a dial. var. of raqiIa, and both mentioned by IKtt, aor. of each
raqaAa
, (TA,) He ascended the series of stairs, or the ladder: (K:) on the authority of Kr; but extr. [with respect to usage]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AiroqaOo EalaI ZaloEika (a dial. var. of Airoqa TA) (assumed tropical:) Be gentle with thyself, and impose not upon thyself more than thou art able to perform: (JK, S, TA:) or abstain thou, for I know thine evil qualities or actions: (JK:) or, as some say, rectify thou, or rightly dispose, first thy case, or thine affair. (TA.)

4 ArqO damoEahu c
4. ArqO damoEahu, (S,) or AldRamoEa, (K,) said of God, (S, K,) He caused his, or the, tears to stop, or cease, flowing; (S, TA;) or caused them to dry up, and to stop, or cease. (K.) The saying laA OaroqaOa QllRehu damoEatahu is expl. by El-Mundhiree as meaning May God not remove, or do away with, (laA rafaEa,) his tear. (TA.) You say also, OaroqaOotu AlEiroqa [meaning I caused the vein to stop or cease bleeding: see 1]. (K, TA.)

raquwoCN c
raquwoCN A styptic; or a thing that is put upon blood for the purpose of stanching it, or stopping its flowing: (S, K:) a subst. from raqaOa. (Msb.) Hence the saying, (Msb,) accord. to J, in a trad., but this is a mistake, for it is a saying of Aktham, (K,) or, accord. to the Expositions of the Fs, it was said by Keys Ibn-'Ásim El-Minkaree, (TA,) laA tasubRuwA AlUibila faUinRa fiyhaA raquwoCa AldRami [Revile not ye camels, or it may perhaps mean hock not ye camels, but the former, I am told, is here meant, for in them is a preventive of the flowing of blood]; alluding to their being given in compensation for homicide, and thus preventing the shedding of blood. (S, Msb, K, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] rajulN raquwoCN bayona Alqawomi (assumed tropical:) A man who is a reconciler of the people; or a peacemaker between them: and [so] raquwoCN limaA bayonahumo, a phrase used by a poet. (TA.)

maroqaOapN c
maroqaOapN and miroqaOapN, (K,) the former a n. of place, the latter an instrumental n., and both correct, dial. vars. of maroqaApN and miroqaApN, (TA,) A series of stairs; or a ladder. (K, TA.)

1 raqabahu c
1. raqabahu, (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
raquba
, (S, A, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. rqobapN↓, (JK, S, Mgh, K,) or this is a simple subst., (Msb,) and [the inf. n. is] riqobaAnN (JK, S, K) and ruquwbN (S, K) and raquwbN and raqobapN and raqaAbapN, (K,) He looked, watched, or waited, for him, or it; he awaited, or expected, him, or it; (JK, S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) namely, a man, (JK, A,) or a thing; (S;) as also trqbhu↓; (JK, * S, * A, Msb, K;) and Artqbhu↓; (S, * A, Msb, K;) and rAqbhu↓, (Mgh,) inf. n. muraAqabapN. (JK, S, A, Mgh, Msb.) You say, qaEada yaroqubu SaAHibahu He sat looking, watching, or waiting, for his com-
panion; as also yarotaqibuhu↓. (A.) And kacaA OataraqRabu↓ I look, &c., or am looking, &c., for such a thing. (A.) And yaroqubu mawota SaAHibihi [He looks, &c., for the death of his companion], (JK, S, A, Mgh, Msb,) and Oabiyhi liyarivahu [of his father, in order that he may inherit his property]: (A:) and turaAqibu↓ mawota baEolihaA [She looks, &c., for the death of her husband], (K, TA,) liyamuwta fatarivahu [that he may die and she may inherit his property]. (TA.) And lamo taroqubo qawoliI, in the Kur [xx. 95], means And thou didst not wait, or hast not waited, for my saying [or what I should say]. (JK, TA.) ― -b2- And raqabahu, (Msb, K,) aor. as above, (TA,) inf. n. ruquwbN, (Msb,) He guarded, kept, preserved, or took care of, it; was mindful, or regardful, of it; (Msb, K;) namely, a thing; (TA;) as also rAqbhu↓, inf. n. muraAqabapN and riqaAbN; (K;) [and trqRbhu↓.] You say also OanaA Oaroqubu lakumu QllRayolapa I will guard, or keep watch, for you to-night. (A.) ― -b3- And He regarded it; paid regard, or consideration, to it. (Bd and Jel in ix. 8.) You say, maA laka laA taroqubu cimRapa fulaAnK [What aileth thee that thou wilt not regard the inviolable right or due, &c., of such a one?]. (A. [This phrase is there mentioned as proper, not tropical.]) ― -b4- And (tropical:) He feared him; (A;) and so rAqbhu↓; (S, A, Mgh;) namely, God; (S, Mgh;) fiI Oamorihi [in his affair]; (S;) because he who fears looks for, or expects, punishment (yaroqubu AlEiqaAba): (A, Mgh:) or QllReha raAqabotu↓ signifies (assumed tropical:) I feared the punishment of God. (Msb.) riqobapN↓ [as inf. n. of raqaba app. used intransitively, or perhaps as a simple subst.,] signifies (assumed tropical:) The fearing, or being afraid [of a person or thing]: or fear: and also (assumed tropical:) the guarding oneself; being watchful, vigilant, or heedful: or self-guardance; &c. (K, TA. [See this word below.]) ― -b5- And you say, baAta yaroqubu AlnRujuwma and yuraAqibuhaA↓, like yaroEaAhaA and yuraAEiyhaA (tropical:) [i. e. He passed the night watching the stars and waiting for the time when they would disappear]. (A, TA.) IAar cites the following saying of one describing a travelling-companion of his:
AlnRajoma riqaAba AlHuwti yuraAqibu↓
meaning (tropical:) He watches (yarotaqibu↓) the star, or asterism, with vehement desire for departure, like the [watching with] vehement desire of the fish for water. (TA.) [See also raqiybN.] ＝ -A2- raqaba fulaAnFA He put the rope [or a rope] upon the raqabap [i. e. neck, or base of the hinder part of the neck, &c.,] of such a one. (K.) ＝ -A3- raqiba, [aor.
raqaba
,] inf. n. raqabN, (TA,) or this is a simple subst., (K,) He was, or became, thick in the raqabap [or neck, &c.]. (TA.)

2 raqRabuwA lilnRamiri c
2. raqRabuwA lilnRamiri [They made a ruqobap (q. v.) for the leopard]. (JK.)

3 rAqb c
3. rAqb, inf. n. muraAqabapN and riqaAbN: see 1, in seven places.

4 Arqbhu AldRaAra c
4. Arqbhu AldRaAra, (JK, S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. UiroqaAbN, (Msb,) He assigned the house to him as a ruqobaI↓ [q. v.], (JK, A, * Mgh, K, TA,) and to his offspring after him, in the manner of a waqof [so as to be unalienable]: (TA:) and Arqbhu AlrRuqobaI↓ [he assigned to him the ruqobaI]: (Lh, K:) or Arqbhu daArFA, or OaroDFA, means he gave to him a house, or land, on the condition that it should be the property of the survivor of them two; saying, If I die before thee, it shall be thine; and if thou die before me, it shall be mine: (S:) it is from AlmuraAqabapu; because each of the two persons looks for (yaroqubu) the death of the other; (S, Mgh, Msb;) in order that the property may be his: (Msb:) the subst. is ruqobaI↓ [signifying, as a quasi-inf. n., the act explained above; and, as a subst. properly so termed, the thing given in the manner explained above: the verb being similar to OaEomara; and the subst., in both of its applications, to EumoraI: see these two words]. (S, Msb.)

5 taraqRaba
5: see 1, in three places.

8 Uirotaqaba
8: see 1, in three places. ― -b2- You say also, Artqb AlmakaAna He ascended upon the place. (K, * TA.)

raqabN c
raqabN Thickness of the raqabap [or neck, &c.]: (S, K:) a subst. [as distinguished from an inf. n.: but see 1, last signification]. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also raqabapN.

ruqobapN c
ruqobapN [A pit made for the purpose of catching the leopard]: it is, for the namir, like the zuboyap for the lion. (JK, K.)

riqobapN c
riqobapN: see 1, first sentence: ― -b2- and again, in the latter half of the paragraph. [Hence,] wariva fulaAnN maAlFA Eano riqobapK (tropical:) Such a one inherited property from distant relations; not from his fathers. (K, TA.) And wariva Almajoda Eano riqobapK (tropical:) He inherited glory, or nobility, from distant relations: [it is said of a man] because it is feared that it will not be conceded to him on account of the obscurity of his lineage. (A.) El-Kumeyt says,
kaAna AlsRadaI waAlnRadaI majodFA wamakorumapF
tiloka AlmakaArimu lamo yuwravona Eino riqabi
(tropical:) [The night-dew and the day-dew that nourished his mental growth were nobility and generous disposition: those generous qualities were not inherited from distant relations: riqabN being pl. of riqobapN]: i. e., he inherited them from near ancestors. (TA.)

raqabapN c
raqabapN The neck: or the base of the hinder part thereof: (A, K:) or the hinder part of the base of the neck: (JK, S:) or the upper part of the neck: (TA:) pl. [of mult.] riqaAbN (JK, S, Msb, K) and [coll. gen. n.] raqabN↓ (JK, S, K) and [pl. of pauc.] OaroqubN (IAar, K) and raqabaAtN. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- By a synecdoche, it is applied to (tropical:) The whole person of a human being: as in the saying, canobuhu fiI raqabatihi (tropical:) [His sin, or crime, &c., be on his own neck; meaning, on himself]. (IAth, TA.) [Hence also] one says, hecaA AlOamoru fiI riqaAbikumo (tropical:) [This affair is upon your own selves], and fiI raqabatika (tropical:) [upon thine own self]. (A.) And OaEotaqa QllRehu raqabatahu (tropical:) [May God emancipate him]. (A.) And laka riqaAbuhunRa wamaA EalayohinRa, in a trad., relating to camels, (tropical:) They themselves, and the burdens that are upon them, are thine. (TA.) And [hence], in another trad., lanaA riqaAbu AlOaroDi (tropical:) To us belongs the land itself. (TA.) ― -b3- Hence also, i. e. by a synecdoche, (IAth, Mgh, TA,) (tropical:) A slave, (S, IAth, Mgh, K, TA,) male and female: (IAth, TA:) and a captive: (TA:) pl. riqaAbN. (Mgh.) You say, OaEotaqa raqabapF (tropical:) He emancipated a slave, male or female. (IAth, TA.) And fakRa raqabapF (tropical:) He released a slave, or a captive. (TA.) AlrRiqaAb in the Kur ix. 60 means (tropical:) Those slaves who have contracted with their owners for their freedom. (T, Mgh, Msb, TA.) ― -b4- riqaAbu AlmazaAwidi (tropical:) [lit. The necks of provision-bags] is a nickname which was applied to the Eajam [or Persians, or foreigners in general]; because they were red; (S, A;) or because of the length of their necks; (El-Karáfee, TA in art. zwd;) or rather because of the thickness thereof, as though they were full. (MF in that art.)

ruqobaI c
ruqobaI One's giving to another person a possession, (K,) such as a house, and land, and the like, (TA,) on the condition that, whichever of them shall die, the property shall revert to his [the giver's] heirs: (K:) so called because each of them looks for (yaroqubu) the death of the other: (TA:) or one's assigning it, (K,) namely, a dwelling, (TA,) to another person to inhabit, and, when he shall die, to another: (K:) or one's saying to a man, If thou die before me, my dwelling [or my land, which I give to thee,] shall revert to me; and if I die before thee, it shall be thine: so called for the reason above mentioned. (JK, KT. *) [It also signifies The property so given.] See 4, in three places. The act thus termed is forbidden in a trad., which pronounces that the property so given belongs to the giver's heirs. (JK.) Accord. to the Imám Aboo-Haneefeh, and [the Imám] Mohammad, it is not a hibap: accord. to Aboo-Yoosuf, it is a hibap like the EumoraI; but none of the lawyers of El- 'Irák says so: the Málikees absolutely forbid it. (TA.) You say, daAriI laka ruqobaI [My house is thine as a rqbI]: from AlmuraAqabapu; because each of the two persons looks for the death of the other. (A.)

raqabaAnN c
raqabaAnN: see Oaroqabu.

raqabaAniIRN c
raqabaAniIRN: see Oaroqabu.

raquwbN c
raquwbN (tropical:) A woman (S, A) of whom no offspring lives, or remains, (S, A, K,) and who looks for the death of her offspring, or of her husband [app. that she may have offspring by another]: (A:) and in like manner applied to a man: (S:) because he, or she, looks for the death of the child, in fear for it: (IAth, TA:) in like manner also a she-camel of which no offspring lives: (TA:) or he who has no offspring: (Msb:) or he who has not sent before him [to Paradise, by its dying in infancy,] any of his children: this, says A'Obeyd, is the meaning in the [classical] language of the Arabs; relating only to the loss of children: (TA:) he who has had no child die in infancy: or he who has had children and has died without sending before him any of them [to
Paradise, by its dying in infancy]. (So in the explanations of two trads., each commencing with AlrRaquwbu, in the “ Jámi' es-Sagheer ” of EsSuyootee.)
warivotuhu Eano EamRapK raquwbi
is a prov., expl. by Meyd as meaning [I inherited it from a paternal aunt] of whom no offspring was living: such, he says, is most compassionate to the son of her brother. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A woman who looks for the death of her husband, (S, K,) in order that she may inherit his property. (S.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) An old and a poor man who is unable to earn for himself, and has none to earn for him: so called because he looks for a benefaction or gratuity. (Msb.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) A she-camel that does not draw near to the wateringtrough, or tank, on account of the pressing, or crowding [of the other camels to it], (S, K,) by reason of her generous disposition: (S:) so called because she waits for the others to drink, and drinks when they have done. (TA.) ― -b5- OumRu AlrRaquwbi (assumed tropical:) Calamity, or misfortune. (K.)

raqiybN c
raqiybN, of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure faAEilN, (TA,) A looker, watcher, or waiter, in expectation [of a person or thing]: (S, Msb, K:) pl. ruqabaMCu. (Msb.) ― -b2- A guarder, guardian, keeper, or preserver: (JK, S, A, Msb, K:) a guard of a people; one stationed on an elevated place to keep watch: (TA:) a spy, or scout, of an army: (A, TA:) a watcher, or an observer. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] AlrRqiybu is an appel-lation applied to God; (A, K, TA;) meaning The Guardian, Keeper, Watcher, or Observer, from whom nothing is hidden. (TA.) ― -b4- Also The Oamiyn of the players at the game called Almayosir; (JK, K;) or (K) he who is intrusted with the supervision of the Dariyb [or shuffler of the arrows]: (JK, S, K:) or the man who stands behind the HuroDap [q. v.] in the game above mentioned: the meanings of all these explanations are [said to be] the same: pl. as above. (TA.) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) The third of the arrows used in the game above mentioned: (T, S, K:) it is one of the seven arrows to which lots, or portions, appertain: (TA:) by some it is called AlDRariybu: (Lh, L in art. Drb:) the arrows are ten in number: the first is AlfacRu, which has one notch and one portion; the second, AltRawoCamu, which has two notches and two portions; the third, AlrRaqiybu, which has three notches and three portions; the fourth, AlHilosu or AlHalisu, which has four notches [and four portions]; the fifth, AlnRaAfisu, which has five notches [and five portions]; the sixth, Almusobilu, which has six notches [and six portions]; and the seventh, AlmuEalRaI, the highest of all, which has seven notches and seven portions: those to which no portions appertain are AlsRafiyHu and AlmaniyHu and Alwagodu. (TA.) A poet says,
UicaA qasama AlhawaI OaEoXaAra qalobiI
fasahomaAki AlmuEalRaI waAlrRaqiybu
[When love divides the tenths of my heart, thy two arrows will be the mo'allà and the rakeeb]: by the sahomaAni, [which properly signifies two arrows, and hence (assumed tropical:) two portions gained by two gaming-arrows, and then (assumed tropical:) any two portions,] he means her eyes: and as the mElRI has seven portions and the rqyb has three, the shmAn would gain the whole of his heart. (TA. [See also a verse cited voce EuXorN.]) ― -b6- raqiybu AlnRajomi signifies (tropical:) The star, or asterism, that sets with the rising of that [other] star, or asterism: for example, the rqyb of AlvRurayRaA is AlUikoliylu: [and the former is the rqyb of the latter:] when the latter rises at nightfall, the former sets: (S, TA:) or raqiybN signifies the star, or asterism, which [as it were] watches, (yuraAqibu,) in the east, the star, or asterism, setting in the west: or any one of the Mansions of the Moon is the rqyb of another: (K, TA:) whenever any one of them rises, another [of them] sets: (TA: [see manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl; and see also nawoCN:]) and AlrRaqiybu is (assumed tropical:) a [certain] star, or asterism, of the stars, or asterisms, [that were believed to be the givers] of rain, that [as it were] watches another star, or asterism: (K:) [it was app. applied to AlUikoliylu, as being the rqyb of the most noted and most welcome of all the Mansions of the Moon, namely, AlvRurayRaA: see nawoCN.] The raqiyb of AlvRurayRaA is [also] an appellation applied to AldRabaraAnu (assumed tropical:) [i. e. The Hyades; or the five chief stars of the Hyades; or the brightest star among them, α of Taurus]; because a follower thereof: (A:) [and] AlEayRuwqu (assumed tropical:) [i. e. Capella] is so called as being likened to the rqyb of the game called Almayosir. (TA.) [Hence,] one says, laAMtiyka Oawo yaloqaI AlvRurayRaA raqiybuhaA (tropical:) [I will not come to thee unless their rqyb meet the Pleiades]. (A.) ― -b7- raqiybN also signifies (tropical:) A man's successor, (A, K,) of his offspring, and of his EaXiyrap [i. e. kinsfolk, or nearer or nearest relations by descent from the same ancestor, &c.]. (K.) So in the saying, niEoma AlrRaqiybu Oanota liOabiyka wasalafika (tropical:) [Excellent, or most excellent, is the successor; such art thou to thy father and thine ancestors]: because the successor is like AldRabaraAn to AlvRurayRaA. (A.) ― -b8- And (assumed tropical:) The son of a paternal uncle. (K.) [App. because two male cousins by the father's side are often rivals, and watchers of each other; the son of a girl's paternal uncle being commonly preferred as her husband.] ― -b9- Also (assumed tropical:) A species of serpent: as though it watched by reason of hatred: (TA:) or a certain malignant serpent: pl. raqiybaAtN and ruqubN. (T, K.)

raqRaAbapN c
raqRaAbapN A low, or an ignoble, man, a servant, or a slave, syn. rajulN wagodN, (S, K,) who keeps, guards, or watches, the [utensils and furniture called] raHol of a people when they are absent. (S.)

Oaroqabu c
Oaroqabu and raqabaAniIRN↓, (JK, S, A, K,) the latter irregular (Sb, S, K) as a rel. n., (Sb,) and raqabaAnN↓, (IDrd, K,) applied to a man, (S, IDrd, A,) Thick, (JK, S, K,) or large, (A, Mgh, in which latter only the second epithet is mentioned,) in the raqabap [or neck, &c.]: (JK, S, A, K:) the fem. [of the first] is raqobaMCu, (JK, IDrd,) applied to a female slave, (JK,) not applied to a free woman, nor does one say raqabaAniyRapN. (IDrd.) ― -b2- AlOaroqabu is also [an epithet] applied to The lion; (K;) because of the thickness of his raqabp. (TA.)

maroqabN c
maroqabN and maroqabapN↓ An elevated place upon which a spy, or watchman, ascends, or stations himself: (S, A, * Msb, K: *) [a structure such as is termed] an Ealam, or a hill, upon which one ascends to look from afar: or, accord. to Sh, the latter signifies a place of observation on the top of a mountain or of a fortress: accord. to AA, the pl., maraAqibu, signifies elevated pieces of ground. (TA.)

maroqabapN c
maroqabapN: see what next precedes.

muraqRabN c
muraqRabN A skin, or hide, that is drawn off from the part next to the head (S, K) and the raqabap [or neck, &c.]. (S.)

2 rqRH c
2. rqRH, (S, A,) inf. n. taroqiyHN, (S, K,) He ordered, or put into a good or right or proper state, managed well, tended, or took care of, property, or cattle: (S, A, K:) and in like manner, he ordered, put into a good or right or proper state, or managed well, the means of subsistence; (S, * A, TA;) as also trqRH↓ [app. with the objective complement (AlEayoXa or AlmaEiyXapa) understood]. (TA.) ― -b2- And He gained, acquired, or earned, property. (TA in art. rqE.) ― -b3- It occurs in a trad., in the phrase raqRaHa UinosaAnFA, as meaning rafRaOa [q. v.]. (TA.)

5 taraqRaHa
5: see above. ― -b2- trqRH liEiyaAlihi He gained, acquired, or earned, or he sought, or laboured, to gain or acquire or earn, sustenance for his family, or household; syn. Aikotasaba, (S, [see also 1,]) or takasRaba; (A, K;) on the authority of Lh. (TA.)

raqoHaMCu c
raqoHaMCu A woman who gains her subsistence by prostitution. (MF.)

raqaAHapN c
raqaAHapN Good management of property. (TA.) ― -b2- Gain, acquisition, or earning: and merchandise, commerce, or traffic. (S, K.) Hence, (TA,) the Pagan Arabs, (S, A,) or some of them, (TA,) used to say in the talobiyap, [i. e. in uttering the ejaculation labRayoka, during the performance of the rites of the pilgrimage,] jiYonaAka lilnRaSaAHapi lamo naOoti lilrRaqaAHapi [meaning We have come to Thee for the purpose of sincere worship: we have not come for gain, or traffic]. (S, A, TA.)

raqaAHiIRN c
raqaAHiIRN A merchant, trafficker, or trader, (A, TA,) who manages well his property. (TA.)
