You say, huwa raqaAHiIRN maAlK He is one who orders, or puts into a good or right or proper state, manages well, tends, or takes care of, property, or cattle: (S, K: *) or who gains, acquires, or earns, property, and orders it, puts it into a good or right or proper state, or manages it well. (A, TA.)

huwa raAqiHapu Oaholihi c
huwa raAqiHapu Oaholihi He is the gainer, or earner, of sustenance for his family. (A, L.)

1 raqada c
1. raqada, (S, Msb,) aor.
raquda
, inf.n. ruqaAdN and ruquwdN (JK, S, A, Msb, K) and raqodN (S, Msb, K) and perhaps also maroqadN [q. v.], (TA,) He slept, (JK, S, A, Msb, K,) accord. to some, specially, (Msb, K,) by night; (JK, Msb, K) but it correctly means, whether by night or by day; as is shown by verse 17 of ch. xviii. of the Kur-án: (Msb:) the assertion that it means, specially, by night, is weak: (TA:) accord. to Lth, ruquwdN is by night; and ruqaAdN, by day: but the Arabs used both of these words as meaning the sleeping by night and by day. (T, TA.) You say, maAbiI ruquwdN and ruqAdN [There is not in me any sleep]. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] raqada Eani AlOamori (tropical:) He abstained, or held back, from the affair. (Msb, TA.) And raqada Eano Dayofihi (tropical:) [He neglected his guest;] he did not pay attention, or frequent attention, to his guest. (A, TA.) And raqada AlvRawobu, inf. n. raqodN and ruqaAdN, (TA,) (tropical:) The garment became old and worn out, and no longer of use; (A, * TA;) like naAma. (A.) And raqadati AlsRuwqu (tropical:) The market became stagnant, or dull, with respect to traffic; like naAmat. (Th, TA.) And raqada AlHarRu (tropical:) The heat remitted, or subsided. (TA. [See also rakada.])

2 taroqiydN c
2. taroqiydN A certain manner of going on foot, (JK, K,) with quickness: (JK:) perhaps a mistranscription for tarofiydN. (TA.)

4 Arqdhu c
4. Arqdhu He, or it, caused him to sleep; put him to sleep. (S, K.) It is said of a medicine. (S, A, K.) And you say, Arqdt AlmaroOapu waladahaA The woman put her child to sleep. (A.) ＝ -A2- Arqd AlmakaAna, (K,) or biAlmakaAni, (S,) or biAlbaladi, (A,) or biOaroDi kacaA, (IAar, JK, TA,) (tropical:) He resided, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in the place, or town or country, or in such a land. (IAar, JK, S, A, K.)

6 trAqd c
6. trAqd He feigned himself asleep. (A.)

9 ArqdR c
9. ArqdR, (JK, S, A,) inf. n. AiroqidaAdN, (JK, S, K,) He hastened; or was quick, or swift; (JK, S, M, A, K;) in his pace, or going: (M, A:) or he ran vehemently; as also ArmdR; said of a camel: (AA, T in art. rmd:) or he ran with leaps, or bounds, as though leaping, or bounding, from a thing: (As, L in art. rmd:) or he went at random, heedlessly, headlong, or in a headlong course; and quickly; (As, JK, L in art. rmd;) as also ArmdR. (As, T in that art.)

10 Astrqd c
10. Astrqd He became overpowered by sleep [or drowsiness; and therefore desired to sleep]. (A, TA.)

OaroHaMCu raqodK c
OaroHaMCu raqodK Mill-stones of Rakd; (S) which is the name of a mountain whence mill-stones are hewn; (S, A, K;) or, as some say, a valley in the district of Keys. (TA.) You say also raHFI raqodiyRapN↓ A mill-stone of the mountain [or valley] called raqod. (A.)

raqodapN c
raqodapN A sleep. (S.) One says, maA OaToyaba raqodapa AlsRaHari [How sweet is the sleep of the time a little before daybreak!]. (A.) ― -b2- A state of extinction of vitality (hamodapN) between the present life and the life to come. (JK, A. *) ― -b3- OaSaAbatonaA raqodapN mana AlHarRi (JK, A, K) (tropical:) A period of heat befell us lasting half a month, or less, (A,) or ten days: (JK, K:) or raqodapN signifies a heat that befalls one after days of wind and an abatement of violent heat. (L.)

ruqadapN c
ruqadapN: see raquwdN.

raqadaAnN c
raqadaAnN [an inf. n. of which the verb is not mentioned,] The act of leaping, or leaping up, by reason of briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness, (S, K,) like the lamb and the kid. (S.)

raHFI raqodiyRapN c
raHFI raqodiyRapN: see OaroHaMCu raqodK, above.

raquwdN c
raquwdN and raqRaAdN↓ (A) and yaroquwdN↓ (K) [all signify the same; i. e. A man who sleeps much; as the last is expl. in the K and so ruqadapN↓; as Golius says on the authority of a gloss. in the KL: or] raquwdN signifies a man always sleeping; as also miroqidRaI↓. (TA.) [Hence,] AimoraOapN raquwdu AlDRuHaI [A woman who sleeps much in the morning after sunrise; meaning] (tropical:) a woman that leads an easy, and a soft, or delicate, life; and so naWuwmu AlDRuHaI. (A.)

raqRaAdN c
raqRaAdN: see the next preceding paragraph.

raAqidN c
[raAqidN act. part. n. of 1:] ruqRadN [is its pl., and] signifies Persons sleeping; as also ruquwdN; (S, K;) the last occurring in the Kur xviii. 17. (Msb.)

raAquwdN c
raAquwdN A large vessel of the kind called danR: (K:) or a vessel of the kind so called, (S, K,) or a vessel in form like the danR, (JK,) resembling an UirodabRap, (S, A.) long in the lower part, (JK, S, K,) smeared inside with pitch: (S, A, K:) or an oblong earthen jar, smeared with pitch: (TA:) an arabicized word: (S:) pl. rawaAqiydu. (JK, S.) ― -b2- And A certain fish, (JK, K,) small, (K,) of the size of the finger, and round; (JK;) found in the sea. (TA.)

maroqadN c
maroqadN A sleeping-place: (S, A, K:) pl. maraAqidu. (A.) You say, baEavahu mino maroqadihi [He roused him from his sleeping-place]. (A.) And OaxacuwA maraAqidahumo [They took their sleeping-places]. (A.) ― -b2- It seems, from the manner in which it is used in the Kur xxxvi. 52, [like the former of the two exs. mentioned above,] that it may perhaps also be an inf. n. (TA.)

muroqidN c
muroqidN A medicine that causes him who drinks it to sleep (S, K. [In a copy of the A muraqRidN↓; and thus pronounced in the present day.]) ― -b2- Also A conspicuous road: (JK, K;) thus on the authority of As; but ISd says, “ I know not how it is: ” and others say that it is muraqRidN↓. (TA.)

muraqRidN c
muraqRidN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

miroqidRaI c
miroqidRaI: see raquwdN. ― -b2- Also A man quick in his affairs. (S, K.)

yaroquwdN c
yaroquwdN: see raquwdN.

1 raqaXa c
1. raqaXa, (A,) aor.
raqusa
, (TK,) inf. n. raqoXN, (S, M, A, K,) He variegated; coloured with two or more colours; decorated; embellished; syn. naqaXa; (S, * A, K; *) and zayRana; as also rqRX↓; (Har p. 57;) and taraqRaXa↓. (So in a copy of the A: [but I think that this is a mistranscription, for raqRaXa.]) ― -b2- He wrote: (M, TA:) and he pointed, or dotted, (As, M, TA,) characters, and writing: (As, TA:) as also rqRaX↓, inf. n. taroqiyXN; in both senses: and ↓the latter, he wrote upon, or in, papers or the like, or books. (M, TA.)

2 rqRX c
2. rqRX, inf. n. taroqiyXN: see 1, in three places. ― -b2- He embellished his speech: or embellished it with lies: syn. HasRana, and zawRaqa: (TA:) or zayRana, (A,) and zawRara, (S, K,) and zaxorafa. (S, A, K.) ― -b3- Hence, (A, TA,) (tropical:) He made known, divulged, or told, discourse, or conversation, in a malicious or mischievous manner, so as to occasion discord, dissension, or the like; (S, A, TA;) because he who does so embellishes his speech, or embel-lishes it with lies: (A, TA:) he told a calumny to the object thereof. (M.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) He excited discord, dissension, or animosity. (M.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) He blamed, reproved, or chid; syn. EaAtaba. (M, TA.)

5 trqRX c
5. trqRX He adorned himself: (A, K:) he displayed his beauty, or goodliness. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 1.

8 ArtqXwA c
8. ArtqXwA (assumed tropical:) They became mixed together in fight. (AA, K.)

raqaXN c
raqaXN A good, or beautiful, xaTR [i. e. character, or handwriting]. (TA.) [See also ruqayoXN: and see 1.] ＝ -A2- Also Food. (M.)

raqaXN c
raqaXN and ruqoXapN↓ A colour in which are [intermixed] duskiness, or dinginess, and blackness; and the like of those two hues. (M.) [See OaroqaXu.]

ruqoXapN c
ruqoXapN: see what next precedes.

raqaAXN c
raqaAXN The serpent: (A, Sgh, K:) app. because of the ruqoXap [see raqaXN] upon his back: (TA:) or a serpent speckled with black and white [like HayRapN raqoXaMCu]. (A.)

ruqayoXN c
ruqayoXN dim. of raqoXN, signifying The pointing, or dotting, of characters and writing: (As, TA:) or of OaroqaXu; as also OurayoqiXu↓ [so in the TA, but in some copies of the K, OurayoqiXN]: (AHát, K:) the latter is allowable. (A Hát.)

OaroqaXu c
OaroqaXu; fem. raqoXaMCu; (S, M, &c.;) pl. ruqoXN; (A;) Variegated with duskiness, or dinginess, and blackness; or the like of those two hues; applied to the [species of locust called] junodab: (M, TA:) and the fem., applied to a serpent (HayRap), (S, M, IAth, K,) signifies the same: (M:) or speckled with black and white; (S, K;) and so when applied to a she-goat: (IAar, M:) or, applied to a serpent, it signifies one of the viper-species (OafoEFI); because of the lines and specks upon its back: (IAth:) and OaroqaXu AlOucunayoni having his ears variegated with black and white, and the rest of his hair black; applied to a kid. (S.) ― -b2- Also the fem., A small creeping thing (M, K) that is found in herbs, a variegated and beautiful worm, (M,) resembling [another small creeping thing called] the HumoTuwT, (M, K,) speckled with red and yellow.
(IDrd, TA.) Sgh., or his copyist, has corrupted HmTwT into xuTuwT. (TA.) ― -b3- Also the fem., The XiqoXiqap [i. e. the bursa faucium, or faucial bag,] of the camel: (S, A, K:) or the XqXqp of the camel is sometimes rqXMC, having in it a mixture of colours. (IDrd.)

OurayoqiXu c
OurayoqiXu: see ruqayoXN.

1 raqaSa c
1. raqaSa, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) aor.
raquSa
, (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. raqoSN, (S, M, Msb, CK,) or raqaSN, of the measure faEalN, like TaradN and HalabN, inf. ns. of Tarada and Halaba, (IDrd, IB, TA,) [He danced; this is what is meant by the explanation] he played, or sported; syn. laEiba: (A, K:) said of a raqRaAS [or dancer], (A, K,) or of a laERaAb [or player or sporter], (M,) and of a muxanRav [or effeminate man, or one who affects the manners &c. of women], and of a SuwfiIR [or mystic, in a choral celebration of the praises of God, which is termed a cikor, performed by certain orders of darweeshes, all of whom, more or less, pretend to be mystics]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also raqaSa, (Lth, A,) aor.
raquSa
, (Lth,) inf. n. raqoSN (Lth, M, A, K) and raqaSN, (Lth, M, K,) or the latter only, (IDrd, Ibn-Málik, TA,) and raqaSaAnN, (Lth, M, A, K,) (tropical:) He (a camel, A, TA) went the pace, or in the manner, termed xababN; [i. e. ambled;] (Lth, M, A, K, TA;) or went in a manner which was a kind of xabab: or went quickly. (TA.) One does not say yaroquSu [in speaking of any animate being] except of a player or sporter and of a camel (Lth, K, * TA) and the like: (Lth, TA:) in relation to others, one uses the terms qaqozN and naqozN: (Lth, K, TA:) or sometimes, (Lth, TA,) ― -b3- it is also said of an ass, meaning (tropical:) He played with his she-ass. (Lth, A, TA.) ― -b4- You say also, raqaSa fuWaAduhu bayona janaAHayohi mina AlfazaEi (tropical:) [His heart throbbed, or leapt, between his two sides, by reason of fright]. (A.) ― -b5- raqaSa also signifies (tropical:) It (wine, S, K, and the beverage called nabiyc, A) estuated: (A, K:) or began to do so. (S, A.) ― -b6- And (tropical:) It (the mirage) was, or became, in a state of commotion; [it danced;] (S, M, A, K;) and so it signifies when said of bubbles (HabaAb). (M.) You say, Oanayotuhu Hiyna raqaSa AlsRaraAbu (A) or AlMlu (TA) (tropical:) [I came to him when the mirage danced; in the heat of the day]. ― -b7- And (tropical:) He hasted, or was quick, fiI kalaAmihi in his speech. (A, TA.) You say also, lahu raqoSN fiI Alqawoli (tropical:) He has a haste in speech. (A, TA.) ― -b8- [And (tropical:) He spoke evil against another.] You say, samiEotu raqoSa AlnRaAsi EalayonaA (tropical:) I heard the evil speaking of the people against us. (A, TA.)

2 raqRaSa
2: see 4, in two places.

4 ArqShu c
4. ArqShu [He made him to dance; or to play, or sport;] trans. of 1. (Msb.) You say, OaroqaSato waladahaA, (S, A,) or SabiyRahaA, (M,) She (a woman, S, M) [danced, or dandled, her child; or] made her child to leap or spring or bound [in her arms or on her knee]; (S, M;) as also rqRSthu↓, (S, M, A,) inf. n. taroqiySN: (S, A:) or the latter verb has an intensive signification. (Msb.) ― -b2- ArqS baEiyrahu (tropical:) He made his camel to go in the [ambling] manner termed xababN: (S, M, A, K:) and the same, (TA,) or rqRShu↓, (M,) he made him (i. e. his camel) to leap, spring, or bound. (M, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 5.

5 trqRS c
5. trqRS [lit., He, or it, became danced or dandled. ― -b2- And hence,] (tropical:) He, or it, became raised and lowered; or rose and sank; or went up and down. (K, TA.) You say, trqRSwA fiI masiyrihimo (tropical:) They went up and down in their journeying; (A;) as also ArqSwA↓. (A, TA.) And Er-Rá'ee uses the phrase taraqRaSati AlmafaAzapu, meaning, (tropical:) The desert [in appearance] went up and down; the mirage, only, making it [seem] to rise and sink. (TA.)

raqoSapN c
[raqoSapN A dance, or a dancing: pl. raqaSaAtN. See an ex. voce qaroSapN.]

raqRaASN c
raqRaASN [A dancer; a player, or sporter: one who dances, or plays, or sports, much, or often]: (S, A, Msb, K:) an intensive epithet. (Msb.)

raqRaASapN c
raqRaASapN [A female dancer]. ― -b2- A certain game of the Arabs. (IF, K.) ＝ -A2- OaroDN raqRaASapN (assumed tropical:) Land that does not give growth to anything, though rained upon. (K.)

raAqiSN c
raAqiSN [A man dancing; playing, or sporting]. (Msb.) ― -b2- AlrRaAqiSu The star [ μ] on the tongue of AltRinRiyn [or Draco]. (Kzw.)

kalaAmN muroqiSN c
kalaAmN muroqiSN (tropical:) Speech, or language, that makes one to be affected with a lively emotion of joy, or of grief. (TA.) You say also, hecihi muroqiSapu AlSRuwfiyRapi [app. meaning, (assumed tropical:) This is that poem, or ode, which makes the mystics to dance; or to be affected with a lively emotion of joy: for darweeshes are often seen to be excited to frantic ecstasy, or ecstatic catalepsy, by certain love-songs designed to have a mystic religious sense]. (TA.) ― -b2- falaApN muroqiSapN (tropical:) A desert that makes the traverser thereof to hasten, or go quickly. (A, TA.)

miroqaSN c
miroqaSN (tropical:) A camel that goes much, or often, in the [ambling] manner termed xababN (M, TA.)

2 raqRaTotu EalaI vawobiI c
2. raqRaTotu EalaI vawobiI (tropical:) I made specks, or small spots, [with ink or the like, (see 5,)] upon my garment; syn. naqRaTotu. (A, TA.)

5 trqRT vawobuhu c
5. trqRT vawobuhu (tropical:) His garment became sprinkled with specks, or small spots, of ink or the like. (K, TA.)

9 ArqTR c
9. ArqTR, (S, K,) inf. n. AiroqiTaATN, (S,) He, or it, was, or became, of a black colour speckled with white: or the reverse: (K:) [or speckled with white, and black, and red, and yellow: (see ruqoTapN:)] as also ArqATR↓, (K,) inf. n. AiroqiyTaATN: (TA:) or the former, he (a sheep, or goat,) was, or became, such as is termed Oabogav. (S.) ― -b2- It (the stalk, or twig, of the Earofaj) put forth its leaves, and what resembled nails (OaZaAfiyr) were seen in the place of separation (mutafarRaq) of its stalks, or twigs, and internodal portions; as also ↓the latter verb: (K, * TA:) this is said to be after what is termed tavoqiybN and qamalN, and before what is termed UidobaMCN and UixowaASN: (TA:) or ↓the latter verb, said of the Erfj, signifies it put forth its leaves; and this it does before its UidobaMC: (S:) [see EarofajN:] in a trad. occurs the expression ArqATR EawosajuhaA; but El-Kutabee thinks that it should be EarofajuhaA. (TA.)

11 UiroqaAoTRa
11: see 9, in three places.

raqoTN c
raqoTN A dotting, or speckling: pl. OaroqaATN. (O.)

ruqoTapN c
ruqoTapN Blackness mixed with speckles of white: (S, K:) or the reverse: (M, K:) or speckles of white, and of black, and of red, and of yellow, in an animal: (A, TA:) and the state, or quality, denoted by the epithet OaroqaTu. (TA.)

OaroqaTu c
OaroqaTu Black speckled with white: or the reverse: fem. raqoTaMCu. (K.) Applied to a sheep or goat, Like, (S,) or syn. with, (K,) Oabogavu: (S, K:) or speckled with black and white. (Har p. 303.) And the fem., applied to a domestic fowl or hen (dajaAjap), Black speckled with white: (S:) or party-coloured: (K:) or having patches of white and black: much sought after, and used, by enchanters; and rarely found. (TA.) ― -b2- It is also applied to a man. (TA.) ― -b3- And the fem. is applied to a tract (risaAlapN), and to an ode (qaSiydapN), as meaning Having one of the letters of a word thereof dotted, and another not dotted: from the same epithet applied to a sheep or goat. (Har p. 303.) ― -b4- AlsRilosilapu AlrRaqoTaMCu A certain reptile; the most malignant of the [kind of lizards called] EiZaMC: when it crawls upon food, it poisons it. (TA.) ― -b5- variydapN raqoTaMCu (tropical:) [A mess of crumbled or broken bread] having much oil (Sgh, K *) or clarified butter. (TA.) ― -b6- AlOaroqaTu The leopard: (K:) an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates. (TA.) ― -b7- AlrRaqoTaMCu (tropical:) Civil war; conflict and faction; sedition; or the like; syn. Alfitonapu: (K:) because of its variableness: or such as is not universal; likened to a speckled serpent: occurring in a trad. (TA.)

1 raqaEahu c
1. raqaEahu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
raqaEa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. raqoEN, (Msb, TA,) He patched it; pieced it; put a piece of cloth in the place thereof that was cut or rent; (Msb;) repaired it, (K,) and closed up the hole or holes thereof, (TA,) with [a patch or] patches; (S, K;) namely, a garment, or piece of cloth; (S, Msb, K;) and in like manner, a skin, or hide; (TA;) as also rqREhu↓, (K,) inf. n. taroqiyEN: (TA:) or trqyE signifies the patching a garment, or piece of cloth, in several places. (S, TA.) ― -b2- He stopped it up, or closed it up; namely, any hole, or aperture; and so rqREhu↓; as in the saying of 'Omar Ibn-Abee-Rabee'ah,
wakunRa UicaA OaboSaronaniI OawosamiEonaniI
xarajona faraqRaEona AlkuwaI biAlmaHaAjiri
[And they (referring to women) used, when they
saw me, or heard me, to come forth, (xarajona being used for yaxorujona,) and close up the apertures in the walls with the eyes and the parts immediately around them]. (L.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) [He repaired it in a figurative sense; as also rqREhu↓.] You say, yaroqaEu diynahu bitawobatihi (assumed tropical:) [He repairs his religion by his repentance]. (TA.) And rqRE↓ dunoyaAhu baMxiratihi (assumed tropical:) [He repaired his state, or condition, in the present word by sacrificing his blessings in the world to come]: whence the saying of 'AbdAllah Ibn-El-Mubárak,
nuraqRiEu dunoyaAnaA bitamoziyqi diyninaA
falaAd diynunaA yaboqaI walaA maA nuraqRiEu
(assumed tropical:) [We repair our state, or condition, in the present world by the rending, or marring, of our religion, so that neither our religion remains nor what we repair]. (TA.) And HaAlahu wamaEiyXatahu rqRE↓ (tropical:) He repaired, amended, or put to rights, his state, or condition, and his means of subsistence; syn. OaSolaHa, (TA,) and raqRaHa: (K, * TA:) with which latter rqRE↓ is also syn. as signifying (tropical:) he gained, acquired, or earned, property; accord. to an explanation of its inf. n., trqyE. (TA.) And yaSilu AlkalaAma fayaroqaEu baEoDahu bibaEoDK (tropical:) [He connects the language, and repairs one part thereof by inserting another]: said of a poet. (TA.) And taroqiyEN↓ also signifies (assumed tropical:) [The act of interpolating: or] the adding to a tradition, or story, or narrative. (TA.) ― -b4- maA raqaEa maroqaEFA↓ [lit. He did not patch a place of patching, or place to be patched;] means (tropical:) he did not, or made not, or wrought not, anything. (TA.) ― -b5- kaAna muEaAwiyapu yaloqamu biyadK wayaroqaEu biOuxoraI (assumed tropical:) [Mo'áwiyeh used to put morsels into his mouth with one hand,] and spread another hand in order that the portions of his morsels that fell might become scattered upon it. (IAth, Sgh, K.) ― -b6- raqaEa AlrRakiyRapa, (Ibn-' Abbád, K,) and raqaEahaA biAlrRiqaAEi, inf. n. raqoEN, (TA,) (tropical:) He lined, or cased, the interior of the well for the space of the stature of a man, or twice that measure, fearing its becoming demolished, (Ibn-'Abbád, K, TA,) in its upper part. (TA.) ― -b7- raqaEa xalRapa AlfaArisi [lit. He closed up the interval between him and the horseman;] means (tropical:) he reached, or overtook, the horseman, and pierced him, or thrust him; AlxalRapu signifying the interval, or intervening space, between the piercer, or thruster, and the pierced, or thrust. (O, K, TA.) ― -b8- raqaEa AlgaraDa bisahomK, [and AlrRaqoEapa,] (tropical:) He hit, or struck, the butt, or target, with an arrow. (K, TA.) raqoEu ruqoEapK also signifies (assumed tropical:) Any hitting, or striking. (TA.) And raqaEa (assumed tropical:) He struck, or beat, in any manner; with a whip; and otherwise; as in the phrases raqaEahu kafRFA (assumed tropical:) [He struck him a slap with the hand]; and huwa yaroqaEu AlOaroDa birijolihi (assumed tropical:) [He beats the ground with his foot]. (TA.) And raqaEa AlXRayoxu (tropical:) The old man supported himself, or bore, upon his two palms, [as though meaning he struck the ground with the palms of his hands,] in order to rise. (TA.) ― -b9- [And hence,] raqaEahu, (S, K,) or raqaEahu bqawolihi, (TA,) (tropical:) He censured him, reviled him, or satirized him. (S, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- raquEa, (S, TA,) inf. n. raqaAEapN, (S, K,) (tropical:) He was, or became, stupid, foolish, deficient in sense; (S, K, TA;) shattered, or marred, in his intellect; (TA;) such as is termed raqiyE. (S.)

2 raqRaEa
2: see 1, in seven places. ― -b2- rqRE AlnRaAqapa biAlhinaMCi, inf. n. taroqiyEN, (tropical:) He smeared the traces of mange, or scab, upon the she-camel, one after another, with tar, or liquid pitch. (TA.)

4 ArqE c
4. ArqE: see 10. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) He (a man, S) acted, or spoke, stupidly, or foolishly. (S, K, TA.)

5 trqRo c
5. trqRo (tropical:) He sought, sought after, or sought to gain, sustenance, or the like; or he applied himself, as to a task, to do so. (K, TA.)

10 AstrqE AlvRawobu c
10. AstrqE AlvRawobu The garment, or piece of cloth, required to be patched; (A, TA;) it was time for it to be patched; (S, K;) as also OaroqaEa↓. (K.)

raqoEN c
raqoEN (TA) and AlrRaqoEu (K, TA) The seventh heaven. (K, TA.) So, accord. to some, in a verse of Umeiyeh Ibn-Abi-s-Salt, [where others read biroqiEa instead of raqoEFA,] cited voce sadirN. (TA.) [See also AlrRaqiyEu,]

raqoEapN c
raqoEapN (assumed tropical:) The sound of the arrow in, or upon, the butt, or target. (IAar, K, TA.)

ruqoEapN c
ruqoEapN A patch; i. e. a piece of cloth, or rag, with which a garment, or the like, is patched, or pieced, or repaired: (S, Msb, K:) pl. riqaAEN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and ruqaEN. (TA.) Hence the saying, AlSRaAHibu kaAlrRuqoEapi fiI AlvRawobi faQTolubohu muXaAkilFA [The companion is like the patch in the garment; therefore seek thou the one that is suitable]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A [patch, or] trace, or mark, of mange, or scab: (TA:) the commencement of the mange, or scab: (K, TA: [in some copies of the K, AlHarob is erroneously put for Aljarab:]) pl. riqaAEN. (TA.) ― -b3- ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) A piece of land, or ground, adjoining another piece [which is in some manner distinguished therefrom; i. e. a patch of land, or ground: and in like manner, of herbage]: pl. riqaAEN. (TA.) You say, riqaAEu AlOaroDi muxotalifapN (assumed tropical:) [The patches of the land, or ground, are various, or diverse]. (TA.) And hecihi ruqoEapN mina AlkalaOi (assumed tropical:) [This is a patch of herbage]: and maA wajadonaA gayora riqaAEK mino EuXobK (assumed tropical:) [We found not aught save patches of green herbage]. (TA.) ― -b5- [A note, billet, or short letter: and particularly a short written petition or memorial, addressed to a prince or governor: a ticket: a label:] a certain thing that is written: pl. riqaAEN (S, K) [and accord. to modern usage ruqaEN also]. Hence the saying in a trad., yajiIoCu OaHadukumo yawoma AlqiyaAmapi EalaI raqabatihi riqaAEN taxofiqu [One of you will come, on the day of resurrection, having, suspended upon his neck, billets fluttering]; meaning, by the rqAE, the claims to be made upon him, or the dues incumbent on him, written on the rqAE. (TA.) ― -b6- A butt, or target, at which to shoot; also termed ruqoEapu garaDK. (TA.) ― -b7- A chess-table; also termed ruqoEapu AlXRiToranoji: so called because it is patched [with squares]. (T A.) ― -b8- (assumed tropical:) The original matter; the substance; (S, TA;) of a garment, or piece of cloth; (S, TA;) or of a thing: (TA:) or (tropical:) the thickness of a garment, or piece of cloth. (Mgh.) You say, ruqoEapu hecaA AlvRawobi jayRidapN (tropical:) The [substance or] thickness of this garment, or piece of cloth, is good. (Mgh.) ― -b9- [The pl.] riqaAEN also signifies (tropical:) The lining, or casing, which is constructed in the upper part of the interior of a well when one fears its becoming demolished. (TA.) [See raqaEa AlrRikiyRapa.]

raqiyEN c
raqiyEN Patched; a garment, or the like, having a piece of cloth put in a place thereof that is cut or rent; (Msb;) as also maroquwEN↓. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (O, Msb,) (tropical:) Stupid, foolish, deficient in sense; (S, O, K;) in whose intellect is something needing repair; [so I render fiI Eaqolihi maramRapN;] (S, TA;) shattered, or marred, in his intellect; (TA;) as also OaroqaEu↓, (TA,) and maroqaEaAnN↓; (S, K;) or unsound in intellect; likened to a ragged, or old and worn-out, garment; as though patched: (Msb:) or a man whose judgment, and state of affairs or circumstances, have become shattered, disorganized, dissipated, marred, or impaired: (A, TA:) fem. [of OaroqaEu↓] raqoEaMCu, (K,) but this is post-classical; (L, TA;) and [of maroqaEaAnN] maroqaEaAnapN↓. (K.) ― -b3- Hence also, (TA,) AlrRaqiyEu (tropical:) The first heaven; (K;) i. e. (TA) the heaven of the lower world; (S, TA;) [agreeing with the Hebrew term; an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates; for AlsRamaMCu AlrRaqiyEu; and therefore, properly, fem.; though an instance occurs of its being used as a masc. noun, as will be seen below;] so called because it is [as though it were] patched with the stars, or with the lights which are therein; as also AlOaroqaEu↓: (TA:) or the heaven, or sky: (Msb, K:) and also each one of the seven heavens; (S;) each of them being a cover to that which is next to it [beneath, so that each, except the highest, is as though it were patched over by the next above it, the highest being in like manner covered over by the kurosiIR,] like as the garment is patched with the ruqoEap: (TA:) pl. OaroqiEapN. (S, Mgh, Msb.) It is said in a trad., laqado Hakamotu biHukomi QllRehi mino fawoqi saboEapi OaroqiEapK (S, * Mgh) (tropical:) Verily I have decreed by the decree of God written upon the preserved tablet above seven heavens: (Mgh:) the speaker thus making rqyE masc., as though he regarded it as meaning saqofN. (S, TA.) [See also raqoEN.]

huwa raqaAEiIRu maAlK c
huwa raqaAEiIRu maAlK i. q. raqaAHiIRu (tropical:) [He is a good, or right, orderer, or manager, of property, or of camels, &c.]: because he amends the condition thereof. (TA.)

raAqiEN c
raAqiEN [act. part. n. of raqaEa: see an ex. voce xaroqN]. ― -b2- It is said in a trad., AlmuWominu waAhK raAqiEN fiAlsRaEiydN mano halaka EalaI raqoEihi (tropical:) The believer is one who becomes unsound in his religion by his disobe-
dience, and who repairs it by his repentance: [therefore the happy is he who dies while he is repairing:] (TA in the present art.:) i. e., one who offends [and] who repents. (TA in art. whI.)

OaroqaEu c
OaroqaEu: fem. raqoEaMCu: see raqiyEN, in three places. ― -b2- Also, the fem., applied to a ewe, or she-goat, (tropical:) Having a whiteness in her side. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And, applied to a woman, (assumed tropical:) Having no buttocks: (ISk, K:) or slender in the shanks. (TA.) ＝ -A2- [Also (assumed tropical:) More, and most, stupid, foolish, or deficient in sense.] You say, maA taHota AlrRaqiyEi OaroqaEu minohu (assumed tropical:) [There is not beneath the sky a person more stupid, &c., than he]. (TA.)

maroqaEN c
maroqaEN [A place of patching; or a place to be patched; as also mutaraqRaEN↓]. ― -b2- [Hence,] maA raqaEa maroqaEFA: see 1. ― -b3- And laA Oajidu fiyka maroqaEFA lilokalaAmi (tropical:) [I do not, or shall not, find in thee anything requiring amendment, to speak of]. (TA.) ― -b4- And fiyhi limano yuSoliHuhu mutaraqRaEN↓ (assumed tropical:) (assumed tropical:) In it, or him, is a place, or subject, for patching, or amendment, for him who will rectify it, or him: like as one says, fiyhi mutanaSRaHN, meaning a place for sewing. (TA.) ― -b5- And OaraI fiyhi mutaraqRaEFA↓ (tropical:) I see in him, or it, a subject, or place, for censure, reviling, or satire. (S, TA.)

XAEirN miroqaEN c
XAEirN miroqaEN (tropical:) A poet who connects language [skilfully], and repairs (yaroqaEu) one part thereof by [inserting] another. (TA.)

maroqaEaAnN c
maroqaEaAnN: fem. with p: see raqiyEN, in two places.

muraqRaEN c
muraqRaEN A garment, or piece of cloth, much patched, or having many patches. (Mgh.) ― -b2- [And hence, as being likened to a garment much used,] (tropical:) A man tried, or proved, by use, practice, or experience; expert, or experienced. (TA.)

muraqRaEapN c
muraqRaEapN A certain garment worn by the devout Soofees;; so called because of the [many] patches that are in it. (TA.) [A garment of this kind, a gown, or long coat or cloak, is worn in the present day by many devotees, reputed saints, and darweeshes; and passing from one to another at the death of the former, at length consists almost entirely of patches; and therefore, the more it is patched, the more is it esteemed: it is also called xiroqapN; and dalaqN, or daliqN, or daloqN, or (now generally by the vulgar) diloq, from the Persian dalaho.] ― -b2- Also thought by A'Obeyd to mean A quiver, or a pouch, much patched: whence the prov., zanodaAni fiI muraqRaEapK [Two pieces of stick for producing fire, in a quiver, or pouch, much patched:] an allusion to a poor and unprofitable man. (Meyd.)

maroquwEN c
maroquwEN: see raqiyEN. ― -b2- (tropical:) A camel having [patches,] traces, marks, or commencements, of mange, or scab. (TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A man censured, reviled, or satirized. (TA.)

mutaraqRaEN c
mutaraqRaEN: [so in three copies of the S, and in the TA: in Freytag's Lex., murotaqaEN:] see maroqaEN, in three places: i. q. mutaradRamN. (T in art. rdm.)

1 raqVla
1: see the next paragraph.

4 Arqlt c
4. Arqlt, said of a palm-tree (naxolap), inf. n. UiroqaAlN, It became such as is termed raqolap [q. v.]. (Msb.) ― -b2- Arql, (S, K,) said of a he-camel, (S,) or Arqlt, said of a she-camel, (JK, Msb, TA,) inf. n. as above, (JK, S, Msb,) He, or she, went quickly; (JK, K;) went a sort of quick pace; (Msb;) went a sort of pace of the kind termed xabab [q. v.]: (S, TA:) or went a sort of run exceeding that termed xabab: (TA:) and raqalato↓ signifies the same as Arqlt. (JK.) Arql is also said of a man, (S, K,) meaning (assumed tropical:) He went quickly. (TA.) And you say, ArqlwA fiI AlHarobi, (TA,) or UilaI AlHarobi, (JK,) (tropical:) They went quickly in, or to, war, or battle. (JK, TA.) And fulaAnN yuroqilu fiI AlOumuwri (assumed tropical:) [Such a one is quick in affairs]. (TA.) And Oaroqalato Uilayohi is metaphorically said, by Aboo-Heiyeh En-Numeyree, of spears [as meaning (tropical:) They had been quickly directed towards him]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Accord. to Lth and the K, Arql also signifies He traversed, or crossed, a desert: and Lth cites the following verse of El-'Ajjáj [as his authority for this explanation]:
laAhumRa rabRi Albayoti waAlmuXarRaqi
waAlmuroqilaAti kulRa suhobK samolaqi
but Az says that this is a mistake of Lth; that kulRa is here an adv. n.; and that the meaning is, [O God, by the Lord of the House (of Mekkeh) and of the Musharrak (the mosque of El-Kheyf) and] by the Lord of the swift she-camels in every even plain: and ISd also has notified the same. (TA.)

raqolN c
raqolN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

raqolapN c
raqolapN A tall palm-tree: (S, Msb:) or a palmtree exceeding the reach of the hand; (K, * TA;) above such as is termed jabRaArap: or this latter word, accord. to As, has this meaning; and the former word, a palm-tree higher than such as [just] exceeds the reach of the hand: (TA:) or a palmtree of which the trunk has become such as that one may reach [the fruit] from [the top of] it: (JK:) pl. riqaAlN (JK, S, Msb, K) and raqalaAtN (Msb) and raqolN↓, (K,) or [rather] of this last it is a n. un. (Msb.) Hence the prov.,
wamaA yudoriyka biAldRaxoli
taraI AlfitoyaAna kaAlrRaqoli↓
[Thou seest the youths, or young men, like tall palm-trees, &c.; but what will acquaint thee with the vice, &c., that is, or may be, in them?]. (TA. [See also another reading of this verse voce daxolN.]) [And rawaAqilu, pl. of raAqilN↓, as used by a Hudhalee poet, applied to the trunks of palmtrees, signifies Tall. (“ Abulfedæ Annales, ” vol. i. page 494.)]

raAqilN c
raAqilN; pl. rawaAqilu: see what next precedes.

raAquwlN c
raAquwlN A rope by means of which palm-trees are ascended; (S, TA;) so in one of the dials.; (TA;) i. q. HaAbuwlN [q. v.] (S, K) and karRN. (S.)

muroqilN c
muroqilN (S, K) and muroqilapN (ISd, K) and miroqaAlN↓ (S, K) applied to a she-camel, (S, ISd, K,) That goes quickly: (K:) or that goes in the manner termed UiroqaAl much, or often: (S, TA:) and maraAqiylu [as pl. of the last] is applied [in like manner] to she-camels. (TA.) [Hence,] fiI AlOumuwri fulaAnN miroqaAlN↓ [Such a one is quick in affairs]. (TA.)

miroqaAlN c
miroqaAlN; pl. maraAqiylu: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

1 raqama c
1. raqama, (Msb, K,) aor.
raquma
, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. raqomN, (S, Msb, TA,) He wrote (S, Msb, K) a writing, book, or letter. (Msb.) And He sealed, stamped, imprinted, or impressed. (S, TA.) And raqama AliktaAba, (K,) inf. n. as above, (JK,) He marked the writing with the dots, or points, (JK, K, TA,) and made its letters distinct, or plain. (K, * TA.) One says, huwa yaroqumu AlmaMCa, (S,) or huwa yaroqumu fiI AlmaMCi, (JK, TA,) [He writes, &c., upon the water,] a prov., applied to the skilful and intelligent, (JK, * TA,) meaning he is so skilful that he writes, &c., (yaroqumu) where the writing, &c., (AlrRaqomu,) will not remain fixed. (JK, S, TA.) And one says of a skilful workwoman, clever in sewing skins and the like, hiIa taroqumu AlmaMCa and taroqumu fiI AlmaMCi. (TA.) ― -b2- And raqama AlvRawoba, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (JK, Msb,) and so the inf. n.; (Msb, TA;) and rqRmhu↓, (S, K,) inf. n. taroqiymN; (S, TA;) He figured, variegated, or decorated, the garment, or piece of cloth; (Mgh, Msb, TA;) and (TA) made it striped, or marked it with stripes: (K, TA:) or, accord. to IF, he figured it, variegated it, or decorated it, with a certain, or known, figuring or variegation or decoration, such as became a mark [thereof]. (Msb.) Also the former phrase, (JK, Mgh, TA,) and ↓the latter likewise, (TA,) said of a trader, or dealer, (JK, Mgh,) He marked, or put a mark on, the garment, or piece of cloth, (JK, Mgh, TA,) specifying its price; he put a price-mark upon it: (Mgh:) whence, laA yajuwzu bayoEu AlXRaIoCi biraqomihi [The sale of the thing by the putting a price-mark upon it shall not be allowable, because the express consent of the seller as well as that of the purchaser is necessary to the ratification of the sale]: (Mgh:) [or] raqamotu AlXRaIoCa signifies I marked the thing so as to distinguish it from other things, as, for instance, by writing and the like: and hence, laA yubaAEu AlvRawobu biraqomihi walaA bilamosihi [The garment, or piece of cloth, shall not be sold by the putting a price-mark upon it, for the reason explained above, nor by the feeling it, or touching it: see 3 in art. lms]. (Msb.) ― -b3- [Hence,] huwa yaziydu fiI AlrRaqomi is a phrase used by the relaters of traditions as meaning (assumed tropical:) He adds to his tradition, and lies: from AlrRaqomu signifying the writing upon a garment, or piece of cloth. (TA.) ― -b4- You say also, raqama AlbaEiyra (assumed tropical:) He cauterized the camel. (TA.) [And raqama Alfarasa (assumed tropical:) He (a farrier) marked the horse, making lines upon him, with a hot iron: see maroquwmN, and see also jaAEirapN.]

2 raqRama
2: see above, in two places. taroqiymN signifies [also] The drawing, and the writing, of a line [or lines]. (KL.)

raqomN c
raqomN is originally an inf. n. [of 1, q. v.]: and hence raqomu AlvRawobi The writing [or price-mark, &c.,] upon the garment, or piece of cloth. (S.) [Hence also AlrRaqomu AlhinodiIRu The Indian notation of numerals; adopted by the Arabs; whence is formed the notation which we term “ the Arabic. ”] ― -b2- Also A sort of [the kind of garments called] buruwd: (S:) or a striped sort of [the kind of garments, or cloth, termed] waXoI; or of [the kind of cloth termed] xazR; or of [the kind of garments called] buruwd: (K:) or a garment, or piece of cloth, figured with round forms: (Har p. 416:) or buruwdu AlrRaqomi signifies a sort of figured, or variegated, or decorated, [garments of the kind called] brwd: (Mgh:) or raqomN signifies [cloth of the kind termed] xazR figured, variegated, or decorated; (JK, Msb;) so accord. to El-Fárábee: (Mgh:) but accord. to IF, raqiymN↓ signifies any garment, or piece of cloth, figured, variegated, or decorated, with a certain, or known, figuring or variegation or decoration, such as is a mark [thereof]; and you say burodN raqomN and buruwdN raqomN [a garment of the kind called brd, and garments of the kind called brwd, thus figured, &c.; using the latter word as sing. and pl. because it is originally an inf. n.]: (Msb:) and maroquwmN↓ (Msb, TA) and muraqRamN↓ (TA) signify a garment, or piece of cloth, figured, variegated, or decorated: (Msb, TA:) and striped, or marked with stripes: and marked, or having a mark [specifying its price] put upon it. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also raqimN, in two places.

raqamN c
raqamN: see ruqomapN: ＝ -A2- and see also the paragraph here next following. ＝ -A3- yawomu AlrRaqami The day of Er-Rakam was one of the days [of conflict] of the Arabs, (S,) well known. (K.)

raqimN c
raqimN A calamity, or misfortune; (JK, S, K;) as also raqamN↓ and raqomN↓; (K;) all mean thus, and a thing that one cannot accomplish, or manage; (TA;) and ruqomapN↓ signifies the same as raqimN. (JK.) One says, waqaEa fiI AlrRaqimi, (TA,) and waqaEa fiI AlrRaqimi AlrRaqomaMCi↓, (S,) meaning He fell [into calamity or misfortune, and he fell into great calamity or misfortune, or] into that which he could not accomplish, or manage. (S, TA.) And jaMCa fulaAnN biAlrRaqimi AlrRaqomaMCi↓ Such a one brought to pass that which was a great calamity or misfortune. (As, TA.) And bnotu AlrRaqimi signifies the same as AlrRaqimu, That which is a calamity or misfortune. (S, TA.) ― -b2- One says also, jaMCa biAlrRaqimi and biAlrRaqomi↓ meaning [He brought, or did,] much. (K.)

raqomapN c
raqomapN (assumed tropical:) Any one of several small marks of cauterization upon the shanks of a beast. (JK, T, TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) One of what are termed AlrRaqomataAni: (TA:) this signifies two [horny] things resembling two nails (JK, S, K, TA) in the legs of a beast (JK, K, TA) or in the legs of a sheep or goat, (S,) opposite each other: (JK, S, TA:) and of the ass and horse, two marks in the inner sides of the two arms: (S:) or the jaAEirataAni; (K, TA;) which are two black spots [or marks made by cauterization] upon the rump of the ass: (TA:) or what borders upon the jaAEirataAni of the ass, of the mark made by cauterization: or two portions of [callous] flesh next to the inner side of each of the arms of the horse, having no hair upon them. (K, TA.) Agreeably with all of these renderings has been explained the trad., maA Oanotumo mina AlOumami UilRaA kaAlrRaqomapi mino ciraAEi AldRaAbRapi (assumed tropical:) [Ye are no more, of the nations in general, than such as is the rqmp of the arm of the beast]. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A small quantity of herbage; as in the saying, maA wajadotu UilRaA raqomapF mino kalaOK (assumed tropical:) [I found not save a small quantity of herbage]. (TA.) ― -b4- A herb, or leguminous plant, of those termed OaHoraAr [pl. of HurRN, q. v.]: (S:) a certain plant; said to be a herb, or leguminous plant, inclining to bitterness, and having a small red flower; (JK;) as some say, (JK, TA,) the xubRaAzaI [or mallow]. (JK, K, TA.) ― -b5- A meadow (rawoDapN, S, K) is sometimes thus termed. (S.) ― -b6- Also The side of a valley: (S, K:) or the place where its water collects; (K;) the part, of a valley, in which is the water. (Fr, JK, TA.)

ruqomapN c
ruqomapN The colour of the serpent termed Oaroqam; (JK, TA;) as also raqamN↓. (TA.) ― -b2- See also raqimN.

raqamapN c
raqamapN A certain plant, (K, TA,) resembling the krX [i. e. kariX or kiroX, a plant little known, said to be so called because its leaves resemble the villous coat of the stomach of a ruminant animal]: so says Az: and in one place he says, it is a herb that grows mXHTA [app. a mistranscription for musaTRaHFA, a term often used in descriptions of plants, meaning expanded], juicy, or sappy, and scarcely ever, or never, eaten by the camels, or cattle, except from want: AHn describes the rqmp [perhaps meaning the raqomap, q. v.,] only as a herb, or leguminous plant, of those termed OaHoraAr, of which the particular characteristics were not known to him. (TA.) [Forskål, in his Flora Aegypt. Arab. p. cviii., mentions a plant seen by him in El-Yemen, previously unknown to him, which he calls “ rokama prostrata, ” of the class pentandria; writing its Arabic name rqmh, and the pronunciation “ Rókama. ”]

raqamiyRaAtN c
raqamiyRaAtN Certain arrows, so called in relation to a place in El-Medeeneh, (S, K,) named AlrRaqamu; (K;) or in relation to a place thus named in the way to El-Medeeneh; (JK;) or, accord. to Nasr, in relation to a water thus named, where they were made, by certain mountains of the same name. (TA.)

raquwmN c
raquwmN, used as a fem. epithet, Remaining, staying, dwelling, or abiding; and remaining fixed. (JK.)

raqiymN c
raqiymN: see maroquwmN: and raqomN. It occurs in a trad. of 'Alee, describing the sky, as meaning Figured, or decorated, with the stars. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A book, or writing. (S.) As used in the Kur xviii. 8, AlrRaqiymu is said to mean A tablet (JK, S, K *) of lead, (K,) whereon were inscribed, (JK, * S,) or engraved, (K,) the names of the People of the Cave [commonly called the Seven Sleepers], (JK, S, K,) and their ancestry, (JK, K,) and their story, (S,) and their religion, and what it was from which they fled: (K:) so says Suh, on the authority of Fr: (TA:) or a mass of stone; (Suh, JK, K;) [i. e.] a stone tablet on which were inscribed their names, and which was put upon the entrance of the cave: (Bd:) or the town, or village, from which they came forth: (JK, K:) or their mountain (Zj, K) in which was the cave: (Zj:) or the valley (AO, JK, K) in which was the cave: (AO, JK:) or their dog: (El-Hasán, R, K:) or [in the JK and CK “ and ”] the receptacle for ink: (JK, K, TA:) mentioned by IDrd, but with the expression of uncertainty as to its correctness; (TA;) and said to be of the language of the Greeks: (JK, * TA:) and the tablet: (K:) thus, also, explained as used in the verse of the Kur-án: (TA:) but I'Ab is related by 'Ikrimeh to have said, I know not what is AlrRaqiymu; whether a book or writing, or a building: (S, TA:) it is [said to be] of the measure faEiyl in the sense of the measure mafoEuwl. (TA.) ― -b3- raqiymapN, applied to a woman, (tropical:) Intelligent; such as is termed barozapN [fem. of barozN q. v.]. (Fr, K, TA.) ― -b4- daAhiyapN raqiymN (assumed tropical:) A great calamity or misfortune. (JK.)

Oaroqamu c
Oaroqamu (assumed tropical:) A certain serpent: (JK:) a serpent in which are blackness and whiteness: (S, M, K:) or a serpent [begotten] between two serpents [app. of different varieties], marked with redness and blackness and duskiness and [the colour termed] bugovap [q. v.]: (ISh:) or a serpent upon which are white specks: (Ham p. 784:) or the most malignant of serpents, and the most wont to pursue mankind: (Ibn-Habeeb, K:) or a serpent like the jaAnR in respect of the fear that men have of killing it, though it is one of the weakest and the least irascible of serpents; for one fears, in killing the Arqm and the jAnR, the punishment of the jinR to them who kill them: (Sh:) or, applied to a serpent, i. q. OaroqaXu [q. v.]: (Mgh:) or the male serpent: (K:) the female is not so called, nor is she called raqomaMCu; (TA;) but she is called raqoXaMCu: (K, TA:) when you use the epithet, you say OaroqaXu; but Oaroqamu is [used as] a subst: (Ibn- Habeeb:) the pl. is OaraAqimu, (JK, ISd,) a pl. proper to substs., because the quality of a subst. is predominant in it. (ISd, TA.) ― -b2- See also miroqamN. ― -b3- For the fem., raqomaMCu, see raqimN, in two places.

taroqiymN c
taroqiymN inf. n. of 2 [q. v.]. ― -b2- Also, [as a subst.,] A certain sign, or mark, of the keepers of the register of the [tax, or tribute, termed] xaraAj, (K, TA,) conventionally used by them, (TA,) put upon [the notes, or billets, or petitions, termed] riqaAE [pl. of ruqoEapN, q. v.], and upon [the writings termed] tawoqiyEaAt [pl. of tawoqiyEN, q. v.], and upon accounts, or reckonings, lest it should be imagined that a blank has been left [to be afterwards filled up], in order that no account be put down therein; as also taroqiynN. (K.)

miroqamN c
miroqamN A writing-reed; (K) because it is an instrument for AlrRaqom, i. e. writing: (TA:) also
called Oaroqamu↓ [app. because partly blackened with ink]. (Z, TA.) One says to him who is vehemently angry, (K, TA,) extravagantly, or immoderately, so, (TA,) TagaA miroqamuka, (assumed tropical:) [signifying Thy pen has exceeded its due limit], (K, TA,) in some of the lexicons TamaA, (TA,) and jaAXa mrqmk, (K,) and EalaA, or galaA, accord. to different copies of the K, and faADa, (TA,) and TafaHa, and AirotafaEa, and qacafa mrqmk: (K, TA:) all [virtually] meaning the same. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A thing with which bread is marked (yunoqaXu); (TA;) like minosagapN; in Pers. called Pari naAno [i. e. a feather, or bundle of feathers, with which bread is pricked by the maker]: pl. maraAqimu. (MA.)

muraqRamN c
muraqRamN: see maroquwmN: ― -b2- and raqomN.

muraqRimN c
muraqRimN A writer; as also muraqRinN.

maroquwmN c
maroquwmN Written; (S, Msb, TA;) as also raqiymN↓: (Msb:) and sealed, stamped, imprinted, or impressed: (S:) and a writing marked with the dots, or points, (JK, TA,) and having its letters made distinct, or plain: [i. e. distinctly written:] and muraqRamN↓ signifies the same: (TA:) the first occurs in the Kur [lxxxiii. 9 and 20], in the phrase kitaAbN maroquwmN, (S, TA,) meaning, in both instances, [as some say, a writing] sealed, or stamped. (Jel.) ― -b2- See also raqomN. ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) A beast having small marks of cauterization upon his shanks; every one of which is termed raqomapN: (JK, T, TA:) or daAbRapN maroquwmapN means (assumed tropical:) a beast having lines of cauterization upon its legs. (K.) It is also applied as an epithet to a wild ass, because of a blackness upon his legs: (TA:) or maroquwmu AlqawaAYimi, so applied, and applied to a [wild] bull, means (tropical:) Having lines of black upon his legs. (K, TA.) ― -b4- And maroquwmapN (tropical:) Land (OaroDN) in which is little herbage: (Fr, S, K, TA:) or in which is the plant called raqomap. (JK.)

1 raqaA c
1. raqaA, aor. yaroquw, inf. n. raqowN, said of a bird, It rose, or rose high, in its flight. (Msb, TA.)

taroquwapN Orq rqI rqy trqI trqwh trqwp
taroquwapN, mentioned in this art. in the K, as well as in art. trq: see the latter art.

1 raqiIa c
1. raqiIa, aor. yaroqaI, inf. n. ruqiIRN (JK, K, TA, [but this inf. n. is omitted in the CK,]) and raqoIN, (K, TA, [but this is omitted in my MS. copy of the K,]) He ascended, Uilayohi [to him, or it]; as also ArtqI↓, and trqRI↓: (K:) or he ascended a ladder, or a stair: (JK:) or raqiytu fiyhi, (S, Msb, in the Mgh raqiIa fyh,) inf. n. ruqiIRN (S, Mgh, Msb) and raqoIN; (S, Msb;) and Artqyt↓, (S, Mgh, * Msb,) and trqRyt↓; (Mgh, * Msb;) I ascended it; (S;) namely, a ladder, or a stair, (S, Mgh, Msb,) &c.: (Msb:) and raqiytu Aljabala (Msb,) and AlsRaToHa, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) the verb being thus trans. by itself, (Msb, TA,) without fiI (Mgh,) and likewise with fI, (TA,) I ascended, or mounted, upon the mountain, and upon the house-top: (Msb:) and ArtqI↓ is in like manner trans. without fI; whence the saying, laqadi SaEobFA Qrotaqayota murotaqFI↓ [Thou hast indeed ascended a difficult place of ascent]. (Mgh.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Airoqa EalaI ZaloEika Ascend thou, and go, [according to thy limping, or halting, i. e.] as far as thou art able to do so, and impose not upon thyself that which thou art not able to perform. (S, TA. [Some, instead of Airoqa, say AiroqaOo; and some, Airoqi, from the verb mentioned in the next sentence; and some, q: see 1 in art. rqO; and see also art. ZlE.]) ＝ -A2- raqaAhu, (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. yaroqiI, (JK, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. ruqoyapN (JK, S, Mgh, K) and raqoI (JK, Mgh, Msb, * K) and ruqiIRN (K,) He charmed him, syn. EawRacahu, (JK, Mgh, Msb,) by [invoking] God: (Msb:) and (Mgh) he puffed, or sputtered, upon his charm; syn. nafava fiI Euwcatihi: (Mgh, K:) [it signifies he charmed him from, or against, such a thing; (mino kacaA;) and also he enchanted him, or fascinated him; by uttering a spell; or by tying knots in a thread, or string, and puffing, or sputtering, upon them; or by both these actions combined: see the last chap. but one of the Kur-án:] the epithet applied to the performer is raAqK↓ [meaning Charming; &c.]; (S, Mgh, TA;) and raqRaMCN↓ [A charmer; &c.; or one who habitually practises charming; &c.]: (JK, K, TA:) and the epithet applied to the person who is the object of the performance is maroqiIRN↓ [meaning Charmed; &c.]. (JK, TA.) In the saying Airoqi EalaI raOosiI mina AlSRudaAEi, meaning Charm thou me (EawRiconiI [or rather charm thou my head against the headache]), the verb is made trans. by means of ElI because it is as though it implied the meaning of AiqorROo [i. e. “ recite thou ” a spell] and Aunofuvo [i. e. “ puff, ” or “ sputter, ” upon knots]. (Mgh.)

2 riqRAhu c
2. riqRAhu, inf. n. taroqiyapN, He made him to ascend; syn. SaERadahu. (TA.) [See an ex. in a verse of ElAashà cited in art. vmn, voce vamaAnuwna.] ― -b2- [And hence, He elevated, or exalted, him.] ― -b3- [Hence also,] raqRaI Ealayohi kalaAmFA, inf. n. as above, i. q. rafaEa [meaning He told, or related, a saying against him; he informed against him; as is indicated by what next follows, and by a meaning of trqRI as quasi-pass. of rqRI thus used]. (S, K.) You say also, rqRI EalaI AlbaATila, inf. n. as above, He brought a false accusation against me; said, against me, what was not the case; and exaggerated [in what he said against me]. (JM, TA.)

5 taraqRaIa
5: see 1, first sentence, in two places. ― -b2- [Hence,] trqRI fiIi AlEilomi He rose by degrees, or step by step, in knowledge, or science. (S, TA.) And hence, maA zaAla yataraqRaI bihi AlHaAlu HatRaI balaga gaAyatahu The state, or condition, ceased not to rise with him until he reached the utmost point thereof. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also, the verb being quasi-pass. of 2,] trqRI Uilayohi AlxabarN The news, or information, came to him, or reached him. (MA.)

6 trAqI c
6. trAqI [meaning He exalted himself] is from AlrRuqiIRu signifying AlSRuEuwdu and AlAirotifaAEu. (Har p. 128.)

8 UirotaqaIa
8: see 1, first sentence, in three places. ― -b2- [Hence,] ArtqI baTonuhu His belly became [drawn up, i. e.] lean, or lank; syn. AinoTawaI: said of a camel, and of a sheep or goat. (JK.)

10 AstrqAhu c
10. AstrqAhu He asked him, or desired him, to charm him. (S, * TA.)

ruqoyapN c
ruqoyapN i. q. EuwcapN [as meaning A charm, or spell, either uttered or written], (K, TA,) by which a person having an evil affection, such as fever and epilepsy &c., is charmed: (TA:) when it is in any other language than that of the Arabs, and one knows not what is in it, it is disapproved, lest it should involve enchantment (siHor) and infidelity; but in such as is from the Kur-án or any of the forms of prayer, there is no harm: (Mgh in art. tm: [see tamiymapN:]) [but EuwcapN generally signifies “ an amulet to charm the wearer against the evil eye &c. ”:] 'Orweh says,
famaA tarakaA mino EuwcapK yaEorifaAnihaA
walaA ruqoyapK UilRaA bihaA raqayaAniI
[And they two left not any amulet that they knew, nor any charm, or spell, but with it they charmed me]: (TA:) [sometimes, also, it signifies anything by which one enchants, or fascinates: and hence it is said,] AlmaroOapu ruqoyapN [Woman is a thing by which one is enchanted, or fascinated]: (Msb:) pl. ruqFI. (S, Msb, K.)

ruqoyaA c
ruqoyaA [The act, or practice, or art, of charming: and also, of enchanting, or fascinating; i. e. enchantment, or fascination:] the subst., (Msb,) of the measure fuEolaI, from raqaAhu, aor. yaroqiyhi. (Msb, TA.)

ruqiyRapN c
ruqiyRapN [Ascent; or the act of ascending;] the subst. from raqiIa aor. yaroqaI. (TA.)

raqRaMCN c
raqRaMCN One who ascends mountains much or often. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, last sentence but one.

raAqK c
raAqK: see 1, last sentence but one. The saying in the Kur [lxxv. 27], mano raAqK [Who is one that charms?] means that there is no charmer that shall charm him and protect him: or, accord. to I'Ab, the meaning is, who is he that ascendeth with his soul? shall the angels of mercy [ascend with it] or the angels of punishment? (TA.) In the saying of a rájiz,
laqado Ealimota waAlOajalRi AlbaAqiI
Oano lano yarudRa Alqadara AlrRawaAqiI
[the meaning may be, Assuredly thou knowest, by the Most Majestic, the Everlasting, that the female charmers will not repel, or avert, that which is decreed; or, that the potent charmers will not &c.: for] the pl. may be that of raAqiyapN↓ as an epithet applied to a woman, or of this
same word as an intensive epithet applied to a man. (S.)

raAqiyapN c
raAqiyapN; pl. rawaAqK (with the article AlrRawaAqiI): see what next precedes.

maroqFI c
maroqFI A place of ascent; as also murotaqFI↓; (Msb, TA;) and so maroqaApN↓ and miroqaApN↓: (Msb:) or ↓these last two signify a series of steps or stairs; or a ladder; syn. darajapN; (S, K;) and sulRamN; (M and K in art. slm;) the former of them as being a place of ascent, and the latter of them as being likened to an instrument; (S, Msb;) and both of them are authorized by the M; (TA;) but the latter of them is disallowed by A'Obeyd, and said by him to be not of the language of the Arabs: (Msb, TA:) the pl. of miraqaApN↓ [and of maroqFI] is maraAqK. (TA.) You say jabalN laA maroqaI fiyhi and lA murotaqaI↓ (JK, TA) A mountain in which is no place of ascent. (TA.)

maroqiyaA AlOanofi c
maroqiyaA AlOanofi [in my MS. copy of the K muroqiyaA] The two edges [or alœ] of the nose: (K, TA:) so says Th; but the expression commonly known is maraqRaA AlOanofi, mentioned before [in art. rq]. (TA.)

maroqaApN c
maroqaApN and miroqaApN: see maroqFI, in four places.

maroqiIRN c
maroqiIRN: see 1, last sentence but one.

murotaqFI c
murotaqFI: see maroqFI, in two places; and see an ex. in the first sentence of this article.

1 rakRa c
1. rakRa, (S, K,) aor. yarikRu, (K, JM, TA, in the CK yarakRu,) inf. n. rakaAkapN (K, JM) [and app. rukuwkapN, q. v. infrà,] and rakRN, (CK, [but not in the TA nor in my MS. copy of the K,]) or rkRp [i. e. rikRapN, like riqRapN and diqRapN, with both of which it is syn.], (JM,) It (a thing, S) was, or became, weak, or feeble; syn. DaEufa: and thin, or of little thickness or depth; syn. raqRa: (S, K:) [and little, or small, in quantity; and slender: and (assumed tropical:) feeble, or weak, and incorrect; said of a word or an expression: (see the part. n. rakiykN:) and (assumed tropical:) unsound, invalid, or incorrect; said of information, an announcement, &c.; as is shown by what follows.] Hence the saying, AiqoTaEohu mino Hayovu rakRa [Cut thou it off from where it is weak, or thin]: for which the vulgar say, mn Hyv raqRa. (S.) [And hence also the saying,] fiI hecaA Alxabari rakaAkapN (assumed tropical:) In this information, announcement, piece of news, or narration, is unsoundness, invalidity, or incorrectness; and so, fiyhi ravaAvapN. (A and TA in art. rv.) ＝ -A2- rakRa AlXRaIoCa baEoDahu EalaI baEoDK, (S,) or simply rakRahu, aor.
rakuka
, (K,) inf. n. rakRN, (TA,) He threw one part of the thing upon another. (S, K.) ― -b2- rakakotu AlgulRa fiI Eunuqihi, aor.
rakuka
, inf. n. rakRN, [I put the gulR (or iron collar) upon his neck, and inserted his hand in it; or] I confined his hand to his neck by means of the gulR. (S.) ― -b3- [Hence,] rakakotu AlcRanoba fiI Eunuqihi i. q. Oalozamotuhu UiyRaAhu (assumed tropical:) [I attached to him responsibility for the sin, crime, or misdeed]. (S, K. *) And rakakotu hecaA AlHaqRa fiI Eunuqihi [in like manner] means Oalozamotuhu UiyRaAhu (assumed tropical:) [I attached to him responsibility for the rendering of this right, or due]. (Lth, TA.) ― -b4- And rakRa AlOamora, aor.
rakuka
, inf. n. rakRN, i. q. radRa baEoDahu EalaI baEoDK (assumed tropical:) [He reversed the order of parts, or of the parts, of the affair, or case]. (TA.) ＝ -A3- rakRa AlXRaIoCa biyadihi, (IDrd, K,) [aor.
rakuka
,] inf. n. rakRN, (IDrd, TA,) He felt the thing, or pressed it lightly, with his hand, in order that he might know its bulk. (IDrd, K, * TA.) ― -b2- And rakRa AlmaroOapa, (IDrd, K,) inf. n. as above, (IDrd, TA,) He compressed the woman, and distressed her, or fatigued her, in so doing; (IDrd, K, * TA:) and so bakRahaA, inf. n. bakRN; and dakRahaA, inf. n. dakRN. (IDrd, TA.) ＝ -A4- rakRa QllRehu namaMCahu God lessened, or diminished, or may God lessen, or diminish, his, or its, increase. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.)

2 rakRaRa
2: see 4, in two places.

4 OarakRati AlsRamaMCu c
4. OarakRati AlsRamaMCu The sky rained such rain as is termed rikR; (S, K;) as also rakRakat↓. (Ibn- 'Abbád, K.) ― -b2- And OurikRati AlOaroDu The land was rained upon with such rain as is termed rikR, (S,) or with such rains as are termed rikaAk; as also rukRikat↓. (TA.)

8 ArtkR c
8. ArtkR, (K,) inf. n. AirotikaAkN, (TA,) [He was indistinct in his speech; said of a drunken man: (see its part. n., murotakRN, below:) or,] though seen to be eloquent [when alone (see again the part. n.)], he was impotent in speech in a case of altercation: (K:) or he was, or became, weak, or feeble; (TA;) [like rakRa.] ― -b2- Artka fiI Oamorihi He doubted in, or respecting, his affair, or case. (Yaakoob, K.) ― -b3- Artka is also syn. with AirotajRa [He, or it, was, or became, in a state of commotion or agitation; or of convulsion, or violent motion; or shook, quaked, or quivered]: (K:) accord. to Yaakoob, it is an instance of substitution [of k for j]. (TA.) One says, marRa yarotakRu [He passed by in a state of commotion &c.]. (TA.)

10 AstrkRhu c
10. AstrkRhu He esteemed him weak, or feeble. (S, K.)

R. Q. 1 rakoraka c
R. Q. 1. rakoraka He was, or became, cowardly, or weak-hearted. (IAar, TA.) [See also rakorakapN, its inf. n., below.]

R. Q. 2 tarakorukuhu c
R. Q. 2. tarakorukuhu, (K,) relating to a skin [of milk], (TA,) means tamaxRuDuhu [i. e. Its being agitated] with the butter. (K, TA. [In the CK, tarakorakahu and tamaxRaDahu are put for tarakorukuhu and tamaxRuDuhu.])

rakRN c
rakRN: see the next paragraph.

rikRN c
rikRN, with kesr, Lean, or emaciated: mentioned by J [and in the K] in art. zk, [and there written zakR,] but Sgh says that this is a mistranscription, and that it is correctly with r [and with kesr]; (TA in the present art.;) and Az says that zkR is a mistake, and is correctly with r. (TA in art. zk.) ＝ -A2- Also, (S, K,) and rakRN↓ and rakiykapN↓, (K,) Weak rain: (T, S:) or rain little in quantity: [and rakRapN↓ is expl. in like manner by Freytag, as meaning pluvia tennis, pauca; but it seems to be a n. un. of rakRN, and so rikRapN↓ of rikRN:] or exceeding what is termed davRN [q. v.]: (K:) accord. to IAar, the first [or lightest and weakest] of rain is that called raXRN; then, the TaXR; then, the bagoX; and then, the rikR: (TA:) or the TaXR exceeds the rikR: (TA in art. TX:) the pl. [of pauc. of rkR] is OarokaAkN (K) and rikaAkN (S, K) and rikRaAnN; (Sgh, TA;) and the pl. of rakiykapN↓ is rakaAYiku. (TA.) ― -b2- rikRN applied to a land, or a place: see murakRN.

rakRapN c
rakRapN and rikRapN: see rikRN.

rukaAkN c
rukaAkN: see the next paragraph.

rakiykN c
rakiykN Weak, or feeble: (S, JM, KL:) so as applied to a man: (TA:) and thin, or of little thickness or depth: (JM:) anything little, or small, in quantity; and slender: applied to water [that is little in quantity, and shallow], and to herbage, and to science: (Sh, TA:) feeble, or weak, and incorrect; applied to a word or an expression; (PS in art. jzl;) contr. of jazolN: (S and K in that art.:) [and unsound, invalid, or incorrect; applied to information, an announcement, &c.: see 1.] You say vawobN rakiyku AlnRasoji A garment, or piece of cloth, weak in respect of texture. (S, * TA.) And UinRahu yubogiDu AlwulaApa AlrRakakapa [Verily he hates weak rulers, or magistrates]: occurring in a trad.: rakakapN being pl. of rakiykN, like as [its syn.] DaEafapN is pl. of DaEiyfN. (TA. [See also a similar saying in what follows.]) And rajulN rakiyku AlEilomi, (K,) and AlEaqoli, (TA,) A man having little knowledge, (K,) and intelligence. (TA.) And rakiykN and rukaAkN↓, (K,) the latter of which has a stronger signification than the former, like TuwaAlN in relation to TawiylN, (TA,) and rukaAkapN↓, (K,) which has a still stronger signification, (TA,) and OarakRu↓, (K,) all applied to a man, (TA,) signify Low, ignoble, vile, mean, sordid, or possessing no manly qualities; weak in his intellect, and in his judgment or opinion: or one who is not jealous (K, TA) of his wife; i. q. dayRuwvN: (TA:) or one who is not revered, respected, or feared, by his wife, or his family: (K:) accord. to AZ, rakiykN and rukaAkapN↓ signify one esteemed weak by the women, not revered or respected or feared by them, and not jealous of them: (TA:) the epithet similarly applied to a woman is rakiykN likewise, and rukaAkapN↓: and the pl. is rikaAkN. (K.) It is said in a trad., UinRahu laEana AlrRukaAkapa↓, (S, * TA, [in one of my copies of the S written AlrRakaAkapa, and in the other copy without the vowel-signs,]) meaning Verily he cursed him who is not jealous of his wife. (S.) And in another trad., UinRa QllReha yubogiDu AlsRuloTaAna AlrRukaAkapa↓, i. e. [Verily God hateth the sovereign, or ruling, power] that is weak. (TA.) ― -b2- rakiykapN, [fem. of rakiykN,] as an epithet applied to land: see murakRN. ＝ -A2- Also Felt, or pressed [lightly with the hand; see 1]; and so marokwkN↓. (TA.)

rukaAkapN c
rukaAkapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in five places.

rukuwkapN c
rukuwkapN [app. an inf. n., see 1, first sentence,] Weakness, or feebleness. (TA. [See also rakorakapN.])

rakiykapN c
rakiykapN, as a subst., see rikRN, in two places.

XaHomuhu AlrRukRaI c
XaHomuhu AlrRukRaI, (so in one of my copies of the S, and in the O, and in my MS. copy of the K,) or XaHomapu AlrRukRaI, (so in one of my copies of the S, and in the TA and CK,) meaning [His fat is, or a piece of fat of,] such as melts quickly, is a prov., (S, O, K,) applied to him who does not fatigue, or weary, thee, (laA yuEanRiyka, so in my copies of the S, or laA yuEoniyka, so in the O,) or to him who does not aid thee, (laAyuEiynuka, so in the TA and CK, [in my MS. copy of the K it reads either lA yuEnyk or lA yuEynk,]) in needful affairs, (S, O, K,) nor avail thee, or profit thee, or stand thee in any stead. (O, TA.) [See also ruqRaI, voce OaraqRu.] ― -b2- Accord. to AA, rukRaI signifies A wide Eafolaq [or vulva, or flabby vulva]. (O, TA.)

rakRaMCu c
rakRaMCu The sound of the echo, (K, TA,) which it returns to one from the mountain, imitating what one utters. (TA.)

rakorakapN c
rakorakapN [inf. n. of R. Q. 1,] Weakness, or feebleness, in anything. (K. [See also rukuwkapN.])

rakoraAkapN c
rakoraAkapN A woman large in the posteriors and thighs. (S, K.)

OarakRu c
OarakRu: see rakiykN.

murakRN EalayohaA c
murakRN EalayohaA, applied to land (OaroDN), Rained upon with such rain as is termed rikR; (K;) as also murakRapN, alone, and murakRakapN↓ (TA) and rakiykapN↓, (K,) the last two meaning also rained upon by such rain as is termed rikR and containing but little pasturage, (TA,) and rikRN↓, (K,) which last is mentioned by ISh, and explained as meaning a place upon which has fallen only a little, or weak, rain. (O.)

murakRakapN c
murakRakapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

marokuwkN c
marokuwkN A siqaMC [or skin for milk or water] dressed, or prepared, (Euwlija,) and put into a good, or proper, state. (S, K.) ― -b2- See also rakiykN, last sentence.

murotakRN c
murotakRN A soft, or flabby, camel, having diluted marrow (mamocuwqu AlnRiqoIi). (O, K. [In the CK, AlnRaqiIRu is erroneously put for AlnRiqoIi; and in my MS. copy of the K, AlnqIR.]) ― -b2- And A drunken man indistinct in his speech: (S:) or a man seen to be eloquent (K, TA) when alone, (TA,) but impotent in speech when he engages in altercation. (K, * TA.)

1 rakibahu c
1. rakibahu, (S, * A, K,) and rakiba Ealayohi, (A,) aor.
rakaba
, (A, K,) inf. n. rukuwbN (S, A, K) and marokabN; (A, K;) and Artkbhu↓; (K;) I. q. EalaAhu (A, K, TA) and EalaA Ealayohi [explained by what follows]. (TA.) You say, rakibotu AldRaAbRapa, (Msb,) or Alfarasa, (Mgh,) and rakibotu EalayohaA, [or Ealayohi,] inf. n. rukuwbN and marokabN [as above, meaning I rode, or rode upon, and I mounted, or mounted upon, the beast, or the horse]. (TA. [See also raAkibN.]) [And rakibotu AlsRafiynapa, or fiI AlsRafiynapi (agreeably with the Kur xi. 43 and xviii. 70 and xxix. 65), I embarked in the ship; went on board the ship.] And one says, of anything, rakibahu [and Artkbh↓] as meaning EalaAhu [i. e. (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, upon, or over, it; got upon it; came, or arose, upon it; overlay it; was, or became, superincumbent, or supernatant, upon it; overspread it]; namely, another thing. (TA.) [In like manner,] one says also, of anything, rukiba and Aurotukiba↓ as meaning EuliIa [i. e., when said of a horse or the like, He was ridden, or ridden upon, and was mounted, or mounted upon: whence other significations in other cases, indicated above]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] rakiba baEoDuhu baEoDFA i. q. trAkb↓ (tropical:) [It lay one part upon another; it was, or became, heaped, or piled, up, or together, one part upon, or overlying, another:] said of fat [as meaning it was, or became, disposed in layers, one above another: see raAkibapN]. (A, TA.) [And hence, rakiba AlnRaAsu baEoDuhumo baEoDFA (assumed tropical:) The people bore, or pressed, or crowded, (as though mounting,) one upon another; a phrase well known, and of frequent occurrence: or meaning (assumed tropical:) the people followed one another closely; from what next follows.] ― -b3- rakibahu also means [(assumed tropical:) He came upon him, or overtook him; or] he followed closely, or immediately, after him: and rakibotu Oavarahu and Tariyqahu (assumed tropical:) I followed close after him. (L.) ― -b4- [rakiba AlTRariyqa, and AlrRamola, and AlmafaAzapa, (assumed tropical:) He went upon, or trod, or travelled, the road, and the sand or sands, and the desert: and rakiba AlbaHora (assumed tropical:) He embarked, or voyaged, upon the sea. Hence,] rakiba AllRayola, and Alhawola, (tropical:) [He ventured upon, encountered, or braved, the night, and that which was terrible or fearful,] and the like thereof. (TA.) [And rakiba OamorFA and Artkbhu↓ (assumed tropical:) He ventured upon, embarked in, or undertook, an affair: and (assumed tropical:) he surmounted it, or mastered it: the former meaning is well known: the latter is indicated by an explanation of the phrase rakRaAbN liloOumuwri, which see below.] And rakiba canobFA (A, K) and Artkbhu↓ (S, A, MA, K) (tropical:) He committed a sin, or crime, or the like. (S, MA, TA.) And rakiba fulaAnN fulaAnFA biOamorK (assumed tropical:) [Such a one did to such a one a thing]. (TA.) And rakibahu bimakoruwhK and Artkbhu↓ (tropical:) [He did to him an evil, or abominable, or odious, deed]. (A.) And rakibotu AldRayona and Artkbthu↓ (tropical:) I became much in debt: and rakibaniI AldRayonu and ArtkbnI↓ (tropical:) [Debt burdened me]. (Msb.) ― -b5- rakiba raOosahu (tropical:) He went at random, heedlessly, or in a headlong manner, (maDaI EalaI wajohihi, A, Msb,) [i. e.,] without consideration, (A,) or without any certain aim, or object, (Msb,) not obeying a guide to the right course. (A.) You say, yurokabu raOosahu laA yadoriI Oayona yatawajRahu (assumed tropical:) [He goes at random, &c., not knowing whither to direct himself]. (S and K in art. kmh.) [See also rakobapN. In like manner also, you say, rakiba raOoyahu (K voce AisotahajRa &c.) (assumed tropical:) He followed his own opinion. And rakiba hawaAhu (S in art. jmH) (assumed tropical:) He followed his own natural desire, without consideration, and not obeying a guide to the right course of conduct.] ― -b6- rakibotu dubRatahu and dubRahu (assumed tropical:) I kept to his state, or condition, and his way, mode, or manner, of acting &c.; and did as he did. (M in art. db.) And rakibatohu AlHumRaI (assumed tropical:) [The fever continued upon him] is a phrase similar to OagobaTatohu AlHumRaI and AimotaTatohu and AirotaHalatohu. (A and TA in art. gbT) ＝ -A2- rakabahu, aor.
rakuba
, (S, A, K,) inf. n. rakobN, (TA,) [from rukobapN,] He struck, or smote, his knee: (S, A, K:) or it signifies, (K,) or signifies also, (S, A,) he struck him, or smote him, with his knee: (S, A, K:) or he took him by his hair, (K,) or by the hair of each side of his head, (TA,) and struck his forehead with his knee. (K, TA.) Hence, in a trad., rakabotu Oanofahu birukobatiI I struck his nose with my knee. (TA.) And in another trad., OamaA taEorifu AlOazoda warakobahaA AitRaqi AlOazoda laA yaOoxucuwka fayarokubuwka [Knowest thou not El-Azd, (the tribe so called,) and their striking with the knee? Beware thou of El-Azd, lest they take thee, and strike thee with their knees]: for this practice was notorious among El-Azd; in the dial. of whom, OumRu kayosaAna was a metonymical appellation of the knee. (TA.) ＝ -A3- rukiba, like EuniIa, [pass. in form, but neut. in signification,] He (a man) had a complaint of his knee. (TA.) ＝ -A4- rakiba, aor.
rakaba
, (K,) inf. n. rakabN, (TA,) He was large in the knee. (K.)

2 rkRbhu Alfarasa c
2. rkRbhu Alfarasa, [inf. n. as below,] He lent him the horse, [or mounted him on the horse,] to go forth on a warring and plundering expedition, on the condition of receiving from him one half of the spoil: (K, * TA:) or for a portion of the spoil that he should obtain. (TA.) [See also 4.] ― -b2- And rkRbhu, inf. n. tarokiybN, He put, or set, one part of it upon another: (K:) [he set it, or fixed it, in another thing: he composed it; constituted it; or put it together.] tarokiybN signifies The putting together, or combining, things, whether suitable or not, or placed in order or not: it is a more general term than taOoliyfN, which is the collecting together, or putting together, suitable things. (Kull p. 118.) You say, rakRaba AlfaSRa fiI AlxaAtami (S, A) He set the stone in the signet-ring: and rkRb AlsRinaAna fiI AlqanaApi He fixed the spearhead in the shaft; (A;) and AlnRaSola fiI AlsRahomi [the arrow-head in the shaft]. (S.) And XaIoCN Hasanu AltRarokiybi [A thing good, or beautiful, in respect of composition or constitution; well, or beautifully, composed or constituted or put together]. (TA.) ― -b3- Also He removed it from one place to another in which to plant it; namely, a shoot of a palm-tree. (Mgh.)

4 Arkb c
4. Arkb He (a colt) became fit for being ridden; attained to the fit time for being ridden. (S, Msb, K.) [See also murokibN.] ＝ -A2- Arkbhu He gave him, appointed him, or assigned him, an
animal on which to ride. (S.) [See also 2.] ― -b2- OarokabaniI xalofahu [He mounted me, or made me to ride, behind him]. (A.) And OarokabaniI marokabFA faArihFA [He mounted me on a quick, brisk, sharp, or strong, beast]. (A.) ― -b3- [Hence, Arkbhu OamorFA (assumed tropical:) He made him to venture upon, embark in, or undertake, an affair. And Arkbhu canobFA (assumed tropical:) He made him to commit a sin, or crime, or the like.]

5 trkRb c
5. trkRb It had one part of it put, or set, upon another; as also trAkb↓: (K:) [it was, or became, composed, constituted, or put together: see 2.] You say, trkRb AlfaSRu fiI AlxaAtami [The stone was set in the signet-ring]: and trkRb AlnRaSolu fiI AlsRahomi [The arrow-head was fixed in the shaft]. (S.)

6 trAkb c
6. trAkb: see 1: and 5. You say, trAkb AlsRaHaAbu The clouds were, or became, [heaped, or piled, up,] one above, or upon, [or overlying,] another; as also trAkm. (TA.)

8 Uirotakaba
8: see 1, in eight places.

10 Astrkbhu faOarokabahu c
10. Astrkbhu faOarokabahu [He asked him to give him, appoint him, or assign him, an animal on which to ride, and he gave him, appointed him, or assigned him, one]. (A.)

rakobN c
rakobN: see raAkibN, in three places.

rakabN c
rakabN The EaAnap: (ISk, Msb, K:) or the place of growth of the EaAnap, (S, K,) or of the hair of the EaAnap: (Mgh:) [i. e. it signifies the pubes; either as meaning the hair of the mons Veneris, or the mons Veneris itself: generally the latter; and this is often meant by the term EAnp alone:] or the part that slopes down from the belly, and is beneath the vunRap [q. v.] and above the pudendum: in all these senses said by Lh to be masc.: (TA:) or the pudendum (Az, Msb, K) itself: (TA:) or the external portion thereof: (K:) or the rakabaAni are the roots of the two thighs, upon which is the flesh of the pudendum, (K, TA,) or upon which are the two portions of flesh of the pudendum: (TA:) the rkb is masc.: (Msb:) it is common to the man and the woman, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, *) accord. to Fr: (S, Msb:) or peculiar to the woman, (S, Mgh, K,) accord. to Kh: (S:) ElFarezdak makes it plainly common to both, saying,
Hiyna QltaqaI AlrRakabu AlmaHoluwqu biAlrRakabi
[When the shaven pubes met the pubes]: (TA: [and a similar ex. is given in the S and Msb, as cited by Fr:]) the pl. is OarokaAbN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and OaraAkiybu; (K;) the latter being pl. of the former; but in some copies of the K OaraAkibu, like masaAjidu. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also Whiteness in the rukobap [or knee]. (TA.)

rakobapN c
rakobapN A single ride, or act of riding: pl. rakabaAtN. (IAth, L.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, huwa yamoXiI AlrRakobapa (tropical:) [i. e. yarokabu raOosahu He goes at random, heedlessly, or in a headlong manner, &c., (see 1,)] and humo yamoXuwna AlrRakabaAti (tropical:) [They go at random, &c.]. (A. [The meaning is there indicated by the context, and is shown by what here follows.]) Respecting the phrase tmoXuwna AlrRakabaAti, occurring in a trad., meaning tarokabuwna ruWuwsakumo (assumed tropical:) [Ye go at random, &c.], in that which is false, wrong, or vain, and in factions, or seditions, or the like, following one another without consideration, IAth says that rakobapN [properly] signifies as explained above in the first sentence of this paragraph, and that the pl. AlrkbAt is here governed in the accus. case by a verb understood, and [with that verb] is a denotative of state relating to the agent in tmXwn: it supplies the place of that verb, which it does not require to be expressed; and the implied meaning is tamoXuwna tarokabuwna AlrRakabaAti. (L.)

rukobapN c
rukobapN a word of well-known meaning, (S, Msb,) [The knee; i. e., in a man,] the joint between the lower parts of the thigh and the upper parts of the shank: (A, K:) or [in a quadruped,] the joint between the metacarpus and the radius (mawoSilu AlwaZiyfi waAlcRiraAEi): this is the right explanation: in the K, mawoDiE is erroneously put for mawoSil: [this explanation is evidently given accord. to the terms employed in the anatomy of quadrupeds as compared to human beings: in that which next follows, there is certainly an omission, which I have endeavoured to supply:] or the rukobataAni of the fore legs of the camel are the two joints that [project forwards, in like manner as do, in the hind legs, those that] are next the belly [meaning the stifle-joints] when he lies down upon his breast with folded legs: the two joints that project behind [in the hind legs, namely, the hocks,] are called the EuroquwbaAni: in every quadruped, the rkbtAn are in the fore legs, and the ErqwbAn are in the hind legs: and the Erqwb is what is called mawoSilu AlwaZiyfi [i. e. the upper joint of the metatarsus]: (TA:) or the rkbp is the mirofaq [which in a man is the elbow, but here seems to mean the lower joint] of the ciraAE [or radius] of anything [i. e. of any beast]: (K:) [from its being said in the S and Msb that the rukobap is “ well known, ” I conclude that there is no real discrepancy in the foregoing explanations: it is perhaps needless to add that the term rukobap is now universally applied to the knee of a man and to what we commonly call the knee of a horse and the like:] the pl. is rukabN, (S, Msb, K,) i. e. the pl. of mult., and the pl. of pauc. is rukobaAtN and rukabaAtN and rukubaAtN. (S.) Lh mentions the phrase baEiyrN musotawoqiHu AlrRukabi [meaning A hardkneed camel]; as though the term rukobapN were applied to each part, and the pl. used accord. to this application. (TA.) ― -b2- One says [of an agitating affair or event], OamorN QSoTakRato fiyhi AlrRukabu waHakRato fiyhi AlrRukobapu AlrRukabapa (tropical:) [An affair, or event, in which the knees knocked together, and in which the knee rubbed the knee]. (A.) ― -b3- And of one who has the mark of prostration in prayer on his forehead, between his eyes, (L,) bayona Eayonayohi mivolu rukobapi AlEanozi [Between his eyes is the like of the knee of the she-goat]. (A, * L.) And of any two things that are alike, or correspondent, humaA karukobataI AlEanozi [They are like the two knees of the she-goat]; because her two knees fall together upon the ground when she lies down. (L.) ― -b4- And it is said in a prov., XarRu AlnRaAsi mano miloHuhu EalaI rukEbatihi [The worst of men is he whose fat is upon his knee]: applied to him who is quickly angered; and to the perfidious: (Meyd, TA:) the phrase miloHuhu EalaI rukobatihi is also used as meaning The smallest thing makes him angry: (TA:) and a poet says,
laA talumohaA UinRahaA mino EuSobapK
miloHuhaA mawoDuwEapN fawoqa AlrRukabo
[Blame her not; for she is of a set of people whose fat is placed above the knees: perhaps meaning, for she is but a woman; as women are generally fat in the part above the knee]: (TA:) or mino nisowapK [in the place of mino EuSobapK], meaning of women whose object of anxiety, or care, is fatness and fat: (Meyd, TA:) so that the prov. seems to mean that the worst of men is he who has not such intelligence as bids him to do that which is praiseworthy, but only bids him to do that in which is inconstancy and levity, and an inclining to the dispositions of women, to the love of fatness and fat. (Meyd.) [See other explanations in art. mlH.] ＝ -A2- Also The lower part (OaSol) of the plant SilRiyaAnap, when it has been cut. (K.)

rikobapN c
rikobapN A mode, or manner, of riding. (S.) You say, huwa Hasanu AlrRikobapi He has a good mode, or manner, of riding. (A, * TA.) ― -b2- [It is said in the K to be a subst. from rakibahu; as though signifying A riding.]

rakabapN c
