rakabapN A company of riders upon camels, (K,) or of owners of camels on a journey, or travellers upon camels, exclusively of other beasts, (S,) but less in number than the company called rakobN: (S, K:) [and probably also a company of riders upon any beasts, but less than what is called rakobN:] accord. to MF, it is a pl. of raAkibN. (TA.) [See also OurokuwbN.]

rakobaI c
rakobaI and rakobaApN: see rakuwbN.

rakabuwtN c
rakabuwtN and rakabuwtaI: see rakuwbN.

rakobaAnapN c
rakobaAnapN: see rakuwbN, in two places.

rikaAbN c
rikaAbN [Travelling-camels, used for riding; i. e.] camels (S, K, TA) upon which people journey; (S, TA;) i. q. maTiIRN: (Msb:) or camels fit for carrying: (Har p. 22:) it has no proper sing.: (S:) the word used for the sing. is raAHilapN: (S, Msb, K:) or, as ISh says, in the “ Book of Camels, ” rikaAbN and EiyrN are applied to camels that go forth for corn (TaEaAm) to be brought back upon them, both when they go forth and after they have come back: and the former term is applied also to camels upon which people journey to Mekkeh, on which maHaAmil are borne: and hired [or other] camels that carry the goods and corn of merchants: but camels are not called Eyr, though bearing corn, [unless] if hired: [I insert
the words “ or other ” and “ unless ” because it is further said,] Eyr are not those that bring corn for their owners; but these are called rikaAbN: (L, TA:) the pl. is rukubN, (S, K,) accord. to A'Obeyd, (TA,) and rikaAbaAtN and rakaAYibu; (K;) or, accord. to IAar, rukubN is not pl. of rikaAbN; and others say that it is pl. of rakuwbN↓, signifying any beast on which one rides, [an epithet] of the measure faEuwlN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN; (TA;) but called by ISd a subst.; (TA voce jazuwzN;) and rakuwbapN↓ is a more special term than rakuwbN. (TA in the present art.) ― -b2- [Hence,] rikaAbu AlsRaHaAbi (tropical:) [The bearers of the clouds; i. e.] the winds. (A, K.) Umeiyeh says,
taradRadu waAlrRiyaAHu lahaA rikaAbu
[It (referring to a cloud) goes to and fro (taradRad being for tataradRadu), the winds being its bearers]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also [The stirrup of a horse's saddle;] a well-known appertenance of a horse's saddle; (S;) the same with respect to a horse's saddle as the garoz with respect to a camel's: pl. rukubN. (K.)

rakuwbN c
rakuwbN and rakuwbapN↓: see rikaAbN: both signify A beast that is ridden: (S:) or a she-camel that is ridden: (K:) or the latter has this meaning: and is metaphorically applied to anything ridden: (Msb:) or the former signifies any beast that is ridden: and the latter is a name for everything that is ridden; applied to one, and to a pl. number: (TA:) or the former signifies ridden, as a fem. epithet: and the latter, one specially appointed for riding; and that is constantly kept to work; of beasts (K, TA) of any kind: (TA:) and the latter and rakobaAnapN↓ and rakobaApN↓ and rakabuwtN↓ (K) and rakobaI↓ and rakabuwtaI↓, (K * and TA in art. Hlb, [see HaluwbN in several places,]) a she-camel that is ridden; or that is broken, trained, or rendered submissive or manageable: (K:) or rakuwbN has this last signification, accord. to AZ: and its pl. is rukubN: (TA:) the pl. of rakuwbapN being rakaAYibu: (TA voce jazuwzN:) and rakobaAnapN↓ signifies [also] a she-camel fit to be ridden; (S, TA;) like as HalobaAnapN signifies fit to be milked: the A and n are [said to be] added in order to give intensiveness to the signification: (TA:) [and all the other epithets mentioned above seem also, accord. to some, to have an intensive sense: see HaluwbN.] You say, maA lahu rakuwbapN walaA HamuwlapN walaA HaluwbapN He has not a she-camel to ride, nor one to carry burdens, nor one to be milked. (S, TA.) ― -b2- Also baEiyrN rakuwbN A camel having marks of galls, or sores, on his back, produced by the saddle. (TA.) ― -b3- And TariyqN rakuwbN A road ridden upon, (S, TA,) and trodden so as to be rendered even, or easy to be travelled. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also rakRaAbN.

rakiybN c
rakiybN One who rides with another; a fellowrider. (K.) rakiybu AlsRuEaApi, mentioned in a trad., and there promised a place in Hell, means He who accompanies tyrannical EumRaAl [or collectors of the poor-rates]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also marakRabN. ― -b3- naxolN rakiybN (K) and rakiybN mino naxolK (TA) Palmtrees planted in a row by a rivulet, or not by a rivulet. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A maXaArap, (K,) i. e. saAqiyap [or channel of water for irrigation]: (TA:) or a rivulet between [two pieces of sown ground such as are termed] daborataAni: (K:) or between two gardens of palm-trees and grape-vines: (so accord. to the text of the K in the TA:) or what is between two gardens of palm-trees and grape-vines: (so accord. to the CK and my MS. copy of the K:) or grape-vines between two rivers or rivulets: (TA:) or a place of seed-produce: (K:) or a clear, or cleared, piece of land, in which one sows: (T:) pl. rukubN. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Oaholu AlrRakiybi The people who stay, or dwell, by water; syn. AlHuDRaAru. (TA.)

rukayobN c
rukayobN dim. of rakobN. (TA.) See raAkibN.

rakuwbapN c
rakuwbapN: see rakuwbN.

zayotN rikaAbiIRN c
zayotN rikaAbiIRN [Olive-oil:] so called because brought on camels from Syria. (S, A, * K.)

rakRaAbN c
rakRaAbN and rakuwbN↓, applied to a man, (K, TA,) the latter on the authority of Th, (TA,) signify the same, (K, TA,) Who rides much; a great rider: and so rakRaAbapN applied to a woman. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] rakRaAbN liloOumuwri (assumed tropical:) A man who surmounts, or masters, affairs; [or who often does so; or accustomed to embark in, or undertake, or to surmount, or master, them; or who often embarks in, or undertakes, them, and therefore surmounts, or masters, them;] by his knowledge, and repeated experience, and good judgment. (K and TA in art. TlE.)

EalAhu AlrRukRaAbu c
EalAhu AlrRukRaAbu (tropical:) The nightmare, or incubus, came upon him. (A.)

rakRaAbapN c
rakRaAbapN: see the latter part of the next paragraph.

raAkibN c
raAkibN Riding; or a rider: (Mgh, Msb, K:) or properly only a rider upon a camel: (ISk, S, K:) or the latter is its meaning when it is not used as a prefixed noun, as explained below; and is said to be the original signification: IB says that it may signify a rider upon a camel, ass, horse, or mule, when used as a prefixed noun; as when you say riAkibu jamalK and raAkibu HimaArK &c.: (L:) accord. to ISk, you term a rider upon an ass faArisN EalaI HimaArK, (S, TA,) and a rider upon a mule faArisN EalaI bagolK; (TA;) but 'Omarah says, I do not call the owner or rider of the ass fArs, but HamRaArN; and the reason of his saying so is manifest, for fArs is an epithet of the measure faAEilN from Alfarasu “ the horse, ” meaning “ an owner, or a rider, of the horse: ” (S, TA:) the pl. is rukRaAbN (S, K) and rukobaAnN (S, * Mgh, Msb, K) and rukuwbN (Mgh, K) and rikabapN, (K,) or this last is a mistake for rakabapN [q. v.], (MF, TA,) and rakobN↓, (Akh, Msb, K, TA,) as some say; (TA;) or this last is a quasi-pl. n., (K, TA,) not a broken pl. of raAkibN; (TA;) and signifies riders upon camels; (K;) or owners of camels on a journey, or travellers upon camels; (S;) consisting of ten or more: (S, K:) and sometimes it signifies riders upon horses: (IB, K:) or riders upon horses and camels: (IB, L, TA:) or a company of riders upon horses; or upon horses and camels: (TA:) [or, accord. to Kh, riders upon any beasts: (De Sacy's Anthol. Gram. Ar. p. 54 of the Arabic text:)] in the Kur viii. 43, AlrRakobu may signify the riders upon horses, or the riders upon camels, or the army composed of both these: (TA:) the pl. of rakobN is OarokubN, (S, K,) [a pl. of pauc.,] and rukuwbN. (K.) Accord. to IB, you do not say UibilK rakobu↓ nor rukobaAnu UibilK: but it is said that rukRaAbu UibilK and rukRaAbu xayolK &c. are allowable. (L.) An instance of rukobaAn as distinguished from furosaAn occurs in a verse cited as one of the exs. of the preposition bi. (TA.) rukayobN↓ [properly signifying A small company of riders upon camels, &c.,] occurs as meaning collectors of the poorrates: it is the dim. of rakobN↓; and shows that this latter is not a pl. [properly speaking] of raAkibN; for, were it so, the word used as its dim. would be ruwayokibuwna. (TA.) [See also rakabapN, and OurokuwbN.] ― -b2- [Also A person on board of a ship or boat: pl. rukRaAbN.] You say rukRaAbu AlsRafiynapi (S, TA) The persons on board of the ship, or boat: and rukRaAbu AlmaMCi the voyagers upon the water: and Ibn-Ahmar has used in this sense the pl. rukobaAnN; but it is said that this is not allowable; nor is OurokuwbN; nor rakobN. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, and raAkuwbN↓, (assumed tropical:) A shoot germinating upon the trunk of a palm-tree, not having any root in the ground: (S:) or a shoot on the upper part of a palm-tree, hanging down, but not reaching the ground; and so raAkibapN↓ and raAkuwbapN↓ and rakRaAbapN↓: (K:) or, as some say, the last of these words is not thus applied, but means a woman “ who rides much: ” AHn, however, says that it signifies a palm-shoot, or the like thereof, growing forth at the top of the trunk of a palm-tree, and, in some instances, bearing with its mother; but when it is cut off, it is better for the mother: and raAkibN is also explained in the L as meaning small palm-trees that grow forth at the lower parts of large palmtrees: (TA:) or it means a shoot of a palm-tree not cut off from its mother: (Ham p. 66:) accord. to As, when a palm-shoot grows from the trunk, and does not adhere to the ground, it forms a vile kind of palm-tree; and the Arabs call it raAkibN and raAkuwbN↓: the pl. of this last [and of raAkuwbapN↓] is rawaAkiybu. (TA.) ― -b4- rukobaAnu AlsRunobuli means (tropical:) What first appear, or grow forth, from the qunobuE, (A, K, TA,) i. e. the envelope of the grain, (TA,) of the ear of wheat. (K, TA.) ― -b5- raAkibN also signifies (assumed tropical:) The head [or summit] of a mountain (jabal), as in [most of] the copies of the K; in some of which is found Habol [or rope]. (TA.)

raAkibapN c
raAkibapN: see the next preceding paragraph. ― -b2- Also sing. of rawaAkibu (TA) which signifies (tropical:) Streaks [or layers] of fat, (A, K, TA,) overlying one another, (K, TA,) in the fore part of a
camel's hump: those in the hinder part are called rawaAdifu, (A, K, TA,) of which the sing. is raAdifapN. (TA.)

raAkuwbN c
raAkuwbN and raAkuwbapN: see raAkibN, latter part, in four places.

Oarokabu c
Oarokabu Large in the rukobap [or knee]. (S, K.) ― -b2- A camel having one of his knees larger than the other. (S, K.)

OurokuwbN c
OurokuwbN A company of riders upon camels, (K,) or of owners of camels on a journey, or of travellers upon camels, exclusively of other beasts, (S,) but more in number than the company called rakobN: (S, K:) pl. OaraAkiybu. (TA.) [See also rakabapN.]

marokabN c
marokabN an inf. n. of rakiba. (A, K, TA.) ― -b2- And also a noun of place [properly signifying A place of riding, &c.]. (TA.) [Hence, Anything upon which one rides; and upon, or in, which one is borne or carried:] one of the maraAkib of the land; and [more commonly] of the sea: (S, K:) [i. e.] a beast [on which one rides]; (A, TA;) and a vessel, i. e. a ship or boat: (A, Mgh, Msb, TA:) a saddle; and any kind of vehicle borne by a camel or other beast: (the lexicons passim:) maraAkibu is the pl. (Mgh, Msb.) You say, niEoma Almarokabu AldRaAbRapu [Excellent, or most excellent, is the thing upon which one rides, the beast]. (A.) And jaMCato maraAkibu Alyamani The vessels, or the ships or boats, of El-Yemen came. (A.) ― -b3- [And hence Almarokabu as the name of (assumed tropical:) The principal star (a) of Pegasus; because in the place of the saddle.]

murokibN c
murokibN A colt that has become fit for being ridden. (TA.) And daAbRapN murokibapN A beast that has attained the age at which one may ride him during a warring and plundering expedition. (TA.)

murakRabN c
murakRabN A man to whom a horse is lent for a portion of the spoil that he may obtain: (IAar, TA:) or a man who borrows a horse upon which to go forth on a warring and plundering expedition, and who receives one half of the spoil, the other half being for the lender: (K:) or one to whom a horse has been given for him to ride, and who has put his foot into the stirrup. (A.) [Also] Weak in the art of horsemanship, or the management of horses, and the riding of them. (Ham p. 441.) ― -b2- [Also Put, or set, one part upon another: set, or fixed, in another thing: composed; constituted; or put together: see its verb, 2.] The stone [set] in the signet-ring is termed murakRabN and rakiybN↓; and so the arrowhead [fixed] in the shaft: (S:) or rakiybN signifies, (K, TA,) as a subst., (TA,) a thing set (murakRabN) in a thing, such as a ring-stone in the bezel, or collet, of the signet-ring. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A2- Also (tropical:) Origin: and place of growth or germination or vegetation. (S, K, TA.) You say, fulaAnN kariymu AlmurakRabi (tropical:) Such a one is generous, or noble, in respect of the origin of his rank among his people. (S, A. *)

1 rakada c
1. rakada, (S, A, Msb,) aor.
rakuda
, (Msb,) inf. n. rukuwdN, (S Msb, K,) It was, or became, still, or motionless; (S, A, Msb, K;) said of water: (S, A, Msb:) and fixed, or stationary. (K.) And in like manner, using the verb in the former sense, one says of the wind: (S, A:) [whence] one says also, rakudato riyHuhumo [lit. Their wind became still, or calm] meaning (tropical:) their good fortune ceased, and their affairs, or circumstances, began to retrograde by degrees: and [in like manner,] Tafiqato riyHuhumo tataraAkadu↓ (tropical:) [their good fortune began to cease by degrees]. (A.) So too one says of the expressed juice of grapes, meaning It ceased to estuate. (L.) And of the heat, i. e. It remitted, or subsided. (L. [See also raqada.]) And rakadati AlsRafiynapu The ship became still, or motionless, (S, * A, * Msb, TA,) or aground. (TA.) And rakada AlmiyzaAnu The balance was, or became, in a state of equilibrium. (S, A, K.) And rakadati Albakorapu The sheave of the pulley was, or became, fixed: and also the sheave of the pulley turned, or revolved: thus bearing two contr. significations. (L.) And rakadati AlXRamosu The sun was, or became, at its midday-height: (S:) or continued overhead; as though not quitting its place. (A.) And rakada Alqawomu The people were, or became, still, motionless, or silent. (S, A.)

4 Arkdhu c
4. Arkdhu He rendered it still, or motionless; namely, water [&c.]. (Msb.)

6 trAkd c
6. trAkd [app., in its proper sense, It became still, or motionless, by degrees]. See 1.

jafonapN rakuwdN c
jafonapN rakuwdN (tropical:) A bowl that is full, (K,) or filled; (S;) or heavy; (A;) or filled and heavy. (L.) And naAqapN rakuwdN (tropical:) A she-camel whose supply of milk is constant, (A, K,) unceasing. (K.)

raAkidN c
raAkidN [Still, or motionless: and] anything remaining fixed in its place; stationary. (S.) You say maMCN raAkidN Water that is not running: and riyHN raAkidapN a wind becoming still, or calm; pl. riyaAHN rawaAkidu. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AlrRawaAkidu [and also, accord. to Reiske, as mentioned in Freytag's Lex., AlrRukRadu,] The three pieces of stone upon which a cooking-pot is set: so called because they remain in their places. (L.)

maraAkidu c
maraAkidu [pl. of marokadN, like marokazN,] Places in which a man, or some other thing, remains still, or motionless. (S, A, * L.) And Much depressed parts of the earth. (L.) Usámeh Ibn-Habeeb El-Hudhalee says, describing an ass [i. e. a wild ass] that had been chased by horses, or horsemen, and had fied for refuge to the mountains, whence, from their ravines, he saw the sky like streaks,
Oarotohu mina AljarobaMCi fiI kulRi mawoTinK
TibaAbFA famavowaAhu AlnRahaAra AlmaraAkidu
[They (the ravines) showed him, in every spot where he stopped, streaks of the shy, and the much-depressed parts of the earth were his places of abode all the day]. (S, * L.) [J quotes this verse, in the S, but with manozilK in the place of mwTn, and maroEaAhu in the place of mvwAh, as an ex. of mrAkd in the former of the senses explained above.]

1 rakaza c
1. rakaza, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
rakuza
(S, Msb, K) and
rakiza
, (K,) inf. n. rakozN, (S, A, Msb,) He stuck, or fixed, a spear, (S, A, Msb, K,) and a stick, (A,) or some other thing, (TA,) into the ground, (S, A, Msb, K,) upright; (TA;) as also rkRz↓, (K,) inf. n. tarokiyzN. (TA.) You say also, rakaza AlHarRu AlsRafaI, aor.
rakuza
, inf. n. rakozN, The heat made the thornbushes fast in the ground [by hardening the soil]. (TA.) And rakaza QllRehu AlmEaAdina fiI AljibaAli God fixed the metals, or minerals, in the mountains: (A, TA:) or caused them to exist therein. (K, * TA.) And rakaza AlmaAla, inf. n. as above, He buried the property. (TA.)

2 rakRaza
2: see the preceding paragraph.

4 Arkz c
4. Arkz He (a man) found what is termed rikaAz: (S, A, * K:) or his mine yielded him abundance of silver &c.: (TA:) or he found a [quantity of gold or silver equal to a sum of money such as is termed] badorap, collected together, in the mine. (Es-Sháfi'ee, TA.) ― -b2- It (a mine) had in it what is termed rikaAz: (K:) or what is so termed was found in it. (IAar, TA.)

8 Artkz c
8. Artkz It (a spear) became stuck, or fixed, in the ground. (Msb.) ― -b2- (tropical:) He became fixed (K, * TA) in his place of abode. (TA.) You say, daxala fulaAnN faQrotakaza fiI maHalRihi laA yaboraHu (tropical:) [Such a one entered, and remained fixed in his place of abode, not quitting it]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- Artkz EalaI Alqawosi (tropical:) He put the extremity of the bow upon the ground and leaned upon it. (S, A, * TA.) And Artkz ElI rumoHihi (assumed tropical:) He bore (taHaAmala) upon the head of his spear, leaning upon it, in order that he might die. (Mgh, from a trad.)

rikozN c
rikozN A sound: (Fr, TA:) or a low sound; (S, A, K;) i. q. HisRN: (K:) or a sound that is not vehement: or the sound, or voice, of a man, which one hears from afar; such as that of the hunter talking to his dogs. (TA.) So in the Kur [xix. last verse], OawotasomaEu lahumo rikozFA [Or dost thou hear a sound of them? &c.]. (S, TA.) [See fahara.] ― -b2- [Golius assigns to it also the signification of Beauty (pulchritudo); app. from his having found, in a copy of the K, waAlHusonu in the place of wAlHisRu.] ＝ -A2- Also An intelligent, forbearing, liberal or munificent, man: (AA:) or a learned, intelligent, liberal or munificent, generous, man. (K.)

rikozapN c
rikozapN: see riakaAzN. ― -b2- (tropical:) Firmness of understanding; (Fr, K;) strength thereof. (A, TA.) Fr says, I heard one of the Benoo-Asad say, kalRamotu fulaAnFA famaA raOayotu lahu rikozapF(tropical:) I spoke to such a one, and I found him not to have firmness of understanding. (TA.)

rikaAzN c
rikaAzN Metal, or other mineral; (A, Mgh, TA;) what God has caused to exist (rakazahu, i. e. OaHodavahu,)
in the mines; (K;) meaning tibor that is created in the earth; (TA;) as also rakiyzapN↓: (K:) the former is pl. of rikozapN↓: (K:) or it is pl. of rakiyzapN↓: (Ahmad Ibn-Khálid, TA:) and pieces (K, TA) of large size, like [stones such as are called] jalaAmiyd, (TA,) of silver and of gold, (K, TA,) that are extracted from the earth, (TA,) or from the mine: (K, TA:) accord. to the people of El- 'Irák, any metals or other minerals: (TA:) or [so in the A and Mgh, and accord. to the TA, but in the K “ and, ”] buried treasure (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) of the people of the Time of Ignorance: (S, Msb, K:) the first of the significations given above is the primary one: and ancient wealth [buried in the earth] is likened to metals or minerals: or, accord. to certain of the people of El- Hijáz, it signifies specially property buried by men before the period of El-Islám; and not metals or other minerals. (TA.) It is said in a trad., that the fifth part of what is termed rikaAzN is for the government-treasury: (S, * TA:) or, accord. to another relation, of what is termed rakiyzN↓: as though it [the latter] were pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of rakiyzapN↓, or [the former] of rikaAzapN↓. (TA.)

rakiyzN c
rakiyzN: see rikaAzN, last sentence.

rikaAzapN c
rikaAzapN: see rikaAzN, last sentence.

rakiyzapN c
rakiyzapN: see rikaAzN, in three places: ＝ -A2- see also marokazN.

raAkizN c
raAkizN A thing that is firm, or fixed. (Mgh.) [Hence,] one says, EizRuhumo raAkizN (tropical:) Their might, or glory, is firmly established. (A, TA.)

marokazN c
marokazN A place where a spear or other thing is stuck, or fixed, into the ground, upright: (TA:) a place of firmness, or fixedness. (Msb.) ― -b2- (tropical:) The place of a man; his place of alighting or abiding. (S, K.) ― -b3- (tropical:) The station of an army, or of a body of troops or soldiers, to which its occupants are commanded to keep. (K, TA.) You say, hecaA marokazu Alxayoli (tropical:) [This is the fixed station of the cavalry]. (A.) Pl. maraAkizu. (A.) ― -b4- The centre of a circle. (S, K.) ― -b5- rakiyzapN↓ signifies the same as marokazN [but in what sense I do not find pointed out]. (TA.)

UinRahu marokuwzN fiI AlEuquwli c
UinRahu marokuwzN fiI AlEuquwli (tropical:) [Verily it is firmly fixed in the minds, or understandings]. (A, TA.)

1 rakasahu c
1. rakasahu, (S, Msb,) aor.
rakusa
, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. rakosN, (S, A, Msb, K,) He turned it over, or upside down; (S, A, Msb, K;) as also Oarokasahu↓: (S:) or the former, (TA,) or ↓latter, (Msb,) he turned it over upon its head: (Msb, TA:) and the former, he reversed it; made the first part of it to be last; or turned it fore part behind. (Lth, A, Msb, K.) It is said in the Kur [iv. 90], bimaA kasabuwA waQllRehu Oarokasahumo↓ Since God hath subverted them [for what they have done, or committed]; syn. takRasahumo: (IAar, K:) or hath made them return to their unbelief; (Fr, S, K;) and rakasahumo signifies the same: (Fr, TA:) or hath separated, or dispersed, them, for what they have done of their disbelief, and acts of disobedience: (Jel:) rakasotu AlXRaIoCa and Oarokasotuhu↓ both signify I separated the thing; or set it apart. (TA.) You say also, QllRehu EaduwRaka Oarokasa↓ May God overturn thine enemy upon his head: or change, or reverse, the state, or condition, of thine enemy. (A.) And fiI AlXRarRi Oarokasahu↓ He turned him back, or caused him to return, to evil. (A.) And Oarokisi↓ AlvRawoba fiI AlSRibogi Return thou the garment, or piece of cloth, to the dyeing-liquor. (A.)

4 Oarokasa
4: see 1, throughout.

8 Artks c
8. Artks He, or it, became turned over, upside down, or upon his, or its, head; became inverted, subverted, or reversed; became turned fore part behind: (K, TA:) he returned, reverted, or went back, from one thing or state to another: (TA:) he fell. (K.) You say, Artks fulaAnN fiI OamorK kaAna qado najaA minohu (S, A, TA) Such a one fell [again] into a case from which he had escaped. (TA.)

rikosN c
rikosN i. q. rijosN [Uncleanness, dirt, or filth; or an unclean, a dirty, or a filthy, thing]: (S, A, Msb, K:) and anything that is disliked, or hated, for its uncleanness, dirtiness, or filthiness; (Msb;) as also rakiysN↓: (TA:) the former is similar in meaning to rajiyEN [dung of a man, or of a horse and the like, or of a wild beast]; (A 'Obeyd, TA;) and rakiysN↓ [also] is syn. with rajiyEN. (TA.)

rakiysN c
rakiysN: see marokuwsN, throughout: ＝ -A2- see also rikosN, in two places.

marokuwsN c
marokuwsN A thing turned over, or upside down; turned over upon its head; turned fore part behind; as also rakiysN↓. (TA.) ― -b2- Turned, or sent, back, or away; as also ↓the latter epithet. (TA.) ― -b3- One who goes back, or reverts, from his state or condition; like manokuwsN: (IAar, TA:) and ↓the latter epithet (rkys), a weak person, who returns, or reverts, from one thing or state to another; syn. DaEiyfN murotakisN. (TA.)

1 rakaDa c
1. rakaDa, aor.
rakuDa
, inf. n. rakoDN, He moved, (S, A, K,) or struck with, (Msb,) his leg, or foot: (S, A, Msb, K:) or he struck and hit therewith, like as one strikes and hits therewith a beast. (IAth.) Hence, (S, A, K,) the phrase in the Kur [xxxviii. 41], (S,) AurokuDo birijolika [Strike thou the ground with thy foot]: (S, A, K:) or strike thou, and tread, the ground with thy foot. (Sgh.) You say also, rakaDa AlrRajulu (tropical:) The man struck the ground with his foot: and rakaDati Alxayolu (tropical:) The horses struck the ground with their hoofs: and jaMCati Alxayolu rakoDFA (tropical:) [The horses came striking the ground with their hoofs]: and rakaDati Aljunodabu AlrRamoDaMCa bikuraAEayohaA (tropical:) [The locusts termed jndb struck the vehemently-hot ground with their two legs]: and tarakotuhu yarokuDu birijolihi lilomawoti (tropical:) [I left him striking the ground with his foot previously to death: see also 8]. (A.) [The above-mentioned phrases marked as tropical are so marked on the authority of the A: but the reason of their being so I do not see.] ― -b2- They also said, sometimes, rakaDa AlTRaAYiru, meaning (assumed tropical:) The bird moved his wings in flying: (S:) the inf. n., rakoDN, signifying (tropical:) the act of moving the wing: (K, TA:) and AlTRaAYru yarokuDu bijanaAHayohi (tropical:) The bird moves his wings, and puts them back against his body: (A, TA:) or the former of these two phrases means (assumed tropical:) the bird was quick, or swift, in his flying. (TA.) ― -b3- rakoDN also signifies The act of impelling; syn. dafoEN: and the urging a horse to run, (A, K, TA,) [by striking] with his foot or leg: (TA:) the striking a beast with one's feet or legs, to urge him: (Mgh:) or putting him in motion, whether he go on or not. (As.) You say, rakaDotu Alfarasa birijoliI I urged the horse to run, with my foot or leg. (S, O, Msb. *) And rakaDa AldRaAbRapa, aor.
rakuDa
, inf. n. rakoDN, He struck the sides of the beast with his foot or leg. (TA.) And rakaDa AldRaAbRapa birijolK, and birijolayoni, He struck the beast to urge it with a foot or leg, and with two feet or legs. (A.) ― -b4- And from frequency of usage of the phrase rakaDotu Alfarasa, originated the saying rakaDa Alfarasu, (AZ, * S, Mgh, Msb,) meaning (tropical:) The horse ran: (S, Mgh: *) which some disallow; but without reason, since it has been transmitted by a good authority: (Msb:) it is disallowed by As: (TA:) [and J says,] the correct phrase is rukiDa Alfarasu: (S:) or you say, rukiDa Alfarasu farakaDa huwa, meaning [The horse was urged to run,] (assumed tropical:) and he ran: (K:) and rakoDN signifies (assumed tropical:) the act of running: (K, in another place in this art.:) and (assumed tropical:) the act of fleeing: whence, [in the Kur xxi. 12], UicaA humo minohaA yarokuDuwna (K) (assumed tropical:) lo, they fled from it, from punishment: (Zj:) or (assumed tropical:) were routed, and fled from it: (Fr:) or they ran from it: (Mgh:) [for] rakaDa AlrRajulu signifies (assumed tropical:) The man fled, and (assumed tropical:) ran. (ISh.) [Hence,] rakaDati AlnRujuwmu fiI AlsRamaMCi (tropical:) The stars moved along in the sky. (A, TA.) [And hence,] rakoDN also signifies (assumed tropical:) A man's going along by both his legs together. (TA.) ― -b5- You also say, rakaDahu AlbaEiyru (S, A, Msb) (tropical:) The camel struck him with his kind leg: (S, Msb:) like as you say, ramaHahu Alfarasu: (A, Msb: *) but you should not say, [when a camel is the agent,] ramaHahu. (Yaakoob, S.) And rakaDa AlOaroDa, and AlvRawoba, (assumed tropical:) He struck the ground, and the garment, or piece of cloth, with his foot or leg. (TA.) And AlmaroOapu tarokuDu cuyuwlahaA waxaloxaAlahaA birijolayohaA UicaA maXato (tropical:) [The woman kicks her skirts and her anklets with her feet when she walks]. (A, TA.) ― -b6- And rakaDati Alqawosu AlsRahoma (tropical:) The bow propelled the arrow. (A, TA.) ― -b7- And rakaDotu Alqawosa (tropical:) I shot with the bow. (A, TA.) ― -b8- And huwa laA yarokuDu AlmiHojana (assumed tropical:) He does not defend himself: (K:) or (assumed tropical:) he is not angry and vexed at a thing, nor does he defend himself. (IAar, L.) ― -b9- And rakaDa AlnRaAra baAlmirokaDi (tropical:) [He stirred the fire with the markaD]. (A.)

3 rAkDhu c
3. rAkDhu, (S, K,) or rAkDhu Alxayola, (A,) He
contended with him in a race, each making his horse to run. (S, K.)

4 ArkDt c
4. ArkDt, said of a woman, (K,) or of a mare, (A 'Obeyd, S, O, L,) (tropical:) Her fœtus became large in her belly, and moved about: (S, O, L, K:) or her fœtus moved about in her belly: (A 'Obeyd;) and so ArtkDt↓, said of a she-camel. (A, TA.)

6 xarajuwA yataraAkaDuwna c
6. xarajuwA yataraAkaDuwna [They went forth contending together in urging their horses]. (A.) And trAkDwA Uilayohimo xayolahumo [They contended together in urging towards them their horses] (S, A) HatRaI Oadorakuwhumo [until they overtook them, or came up to them]. (A.) And fiI AlHalobapi ArtkDwA↓ [app. signifies They urged their horses in the raceground]. (A, TA.)

8 UirotakaDa
8: see 6. ― -b2- tarakotuhu yarotakiDu lilomawoti (tropical:) [I left him struggling with, or convulsed in, his legs, previously to death: see also 1, near the beginning]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- ArtkD also signifies (tropical:) It was, or became, in a state of commotion or agitation: (S, A, K:) said of a fœtus in the belly (S, A) of a mare: (S:) and of water in a well. (A, TA.) ― -b4- ArtkD fulaAnN fiI Oamorihi (tropical:) Such a one was, or became, agitated, or disturbed, or disquieted, in his affair: (S, TA:) and, which implies the same, (TA,) he exercised art, or cunning, (taqalRaba,) in his affair, and strove thereby to accomplish or effect it. (A, TA.) ― -b5- Hence AirotikaADN signifying (assumed tropical:) The travel-ling through, or traversing, countries, or regions. (Har p. 660.) ― -b6- See also 4.

rakoDapF c
rakoDapF An impulse: a motion: (K:) [pl. rakaDaAtN: see an ex. voce rafaDaAtN.] Hence, (TA,) it is said in a trad. of I'Ab, that the blood which continues to flow after menstruation is rakoDapN mina AlXRayoTaAni, (S, * TA,) i. e. An impulse from the devil; (S;) whereby he finds a way of putting the woman in doubt respecting the affairs of her religion, and her state of pureness, and her prayer. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence also,] one of the names of [the well of] Zemzem is rakoDapu jiboriyla [The impulse of Gabriel; because it is fabled to have gushed forth on the ground's being struck by Gabriel's wings]. (TA.)

rakuwDN c
rakuwDN, applied to a bow (qawos), (tropical:) That sends the arrow swiftly: (S, TA:) or that impels it vehemently: and murokiDapN↓ [or perhaps mirokaDapN↓] signifies the same. (AHn, TA.) ― -b2- See also raAkiDN.

rakRaADapN c
rakRaADapN: see the next paragraph.

raAkiDN c
raAkiDN, applied to a horse, (tropical:) Running; as also rakuwDN↓: (K:) or the correct epithet is marokuwDN↓: (S:) and rakRaADapN↓ signifies the same, applied to a mare. (TA.) [Hence,] bitRu OaroEaI AlnRujuwma wahoIa rawaAkiDu (tropical:) I passed the night observing the stars while they moved along in the sky. (A, TA.)

tarokaDaI c
tarokaDaI and tirokiDaMCu, the former incorrectly written in the K tarokaDaMCu, [or, in some copies, tarokuDaMCu, and the latter in one copy written tarokiDaMCu,] are there said to be used as examples by the grammarians, but not explained; and the author offers his opinion that they are syn. with rakoDN: (TA:) but this is a strange defect: for AHei explains them as signifying A certain gait, in which is a proud and self-conceited air, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side: and he asserts the t to be augmentative: (MF, TA:) and in the L they are expl. as signifying a particular kind of gait: or meaning as above. (TA.)

marokaDN c
marokaDN The part of the flank of a horse which the rider strikes with his heel or foot, (A, TA, the latter in this art. and also voce yaEosuwbN,) on either side: (TA:) pl. maraAkiDu. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] maraAkiDu HawoDK (tropical:) The sides of a watering-trough, (A, K,) against which the water strikes. (A, TA.)

murokiDN c
murokiDN, applied to a mare, (A 'Obeyd,) or a she-camel, (A,) (tropical:) Whose fœtus moves about in her belly; (A 'Obeyd, A;) [or whose fœtus is large, and moves about in her belly; (see 4;)] as also murokiDapN; (A 'Obeyd;) or murotakiDapN↓. (A.) ― -b2- See also rakuwDN.

mirokaDN c
mirokaDN: see mirokaDapN, in two places. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) An instrument for stirring a fire. (A, K.)

mirokaDapN c
mirokaDapN (tropical:) A mare that beats the ground with her legs (K, TA) when she runs. (TA.) ― -b2- See also rakuwDN. ― -b3- Also (tropical:) A certain part of a bow; well known; one of [the two parts called] its mirokaDataAni; (S;) or mirokaDaAni↓: (IB:) each of the two curved extremities thereof; as also mirokaDN↓: (A:) or the side thereof: (K:) pl. maraAkiDu. (TA.)

marokuwDN c
marokuwDN: see raAkiDN.

murotakaDu AlmaMCi c
murotakaDu AlmaMCi (tropical:) The place in which water collects. (S, A, K.)

murotakiDapN c
murotakiDapN: see murokiDN.

1 rakaEa c
1. rakaEa, (Th, S, &c.,) aor.
rakaEa
, (Th, TA,) inf. n. rukuwEN (Th, S, Mgh, Msb, K) and rakoEN, (Th, TA,) He bowed, or bent, himself; or became bowed or bent: (Th, S, Mgh, Msb:) so says Er-Rághib, adding that it is sometimes used to denote a particular manner of doing so in prayer, and sometimes to denote humility and self-abasement either in worship or in other cases: (TA:) he lowered his head: (Th:) and he (an old man) bowed himself, or bent himself, or became bowed or bent, by reason of age: (S, Msb, K:) this is [said to be] the primary signification: (TA:) or he fell upon his face; (IDrd, IB, K;) and stumbled. (IB.) ― -b2- And hence, from rakaEa as used in the first of the senses explained above, (S, Mgh,) or as used in the first of the senses assigned to it above when said of an old man, (TA,) or as used in the last sense explained above, (IB,) rukuwEu AlSRalaApi, (S, IB, Mgh, TA,) or AlrRukuwEu fiI AlSRalaAp, The lowering of the head, (K, TA,) by a person praying, (TA,) [or in prayer,] after the act of standing in which the recitation [of portions of the Kur-án] is performed, so that the palms of the hands reach the knees; or, so that the back becomes depressed; (K, TA;) accord. to the doctors of practical law, so that if a cup full of water be placed upon the back, it will not be spilled. (TA.) ― -b3- rakaEa UilaI QllRehi He lowered his head, or he humbled himself, to God; syn. AiTomaOanRa. (Z, TA.) ― -b4- rakaEa, also signifies He prayed; (Mgh;) and so trkRE↓. (TA.) Thus in the Kur [ii. 40], waQrokaEuwA maEa AlrRaAkiEiyna, And pray ye with those who pray. (Mgh.) You say also, rakaEa rakoEapF, and rakoEatayoni, and valaAva rakaEaAtK, He prayed a rek'ah, and two rek'ahs, and three rek'ahs. (K.) [See rakoEapN, below.] ― -b5- Also, accord. to IKoot and several others, He stood to prayer. (Msb) ― -b6- lagibati AlUibilu HatRaI rakaEato (tropical:) The camels became fatigued, or fatigued in the utmost degree, or languid in consequence of fatigue, so that they lowered their heads, and fell upon their faces. (TA.) ― -b7- rakaEati AlnRaxolapu (assumed tropical:) The palm-tree inclined: a phrase which may be of classical authority, but [Mtr says,] I have not found it. (Mgh.) ― -b8- Said of a man, (TA,) rakaEa, also signifies (tropical:) He became poor after richness, or competence, or sufficiency; and his state, or condition, became lowered, or abased. (K, TA.)

5 tarakRaEa
5: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.

rakoEapN c
rakoEapN, [inf. n. of un. of 1: and particularly signifying] A single act of standing in prayer: and in its legal acceptation, used in a more particular sense; (Msb;) meaning a single act of standing in prayer, followed by the rukuwE [or lowering of the head in the manner described above (see AlrRukuwEu fiI AlSRalaApi in the first paragraph)] and two prostrations: (TA:) [and hence, by a further extension of the meaning, for SalaApu rakoEapK, the prayer of one bowing of the head and body; the previous act of standing, and the two subsequent prostrations, being understood as included in this expression:] pl. rakaEaAtN. (Msb, K.) [Using it in the last of these senses,] you say, SalRaI rakoEapF [He performed the prayer of one bowing of the head and body]: (K:) and SalRaI rakoEatayoni [he performed the prayers of two bowings of the head and body]. (Msb, K.) [A full description of the act of prayer thus termed may be seen in my work on the Modern Egyptians.]

rukoEapN c
rukoEapN A deep hollow (huwRapN) in the ground: (IDrd, K:) asserted to be of the dial. of ElYemen. (IDrd, TA.)

raAkiEN c
raAkiEN part. n. of 1, Bowing, or bending himself; or becoming bowed or bent: [&c.:] (Mgh:) anything, or anybody or any person, (accord. to different copies of the K,) lowering its, or his, head: (K:) or falling upon its, or his, face, so that the knees touch the ground, or do not touch it, after lowering the head: (TA:) ― -b2- prostrating himself in thanksgiving; used in this sense in the Kur xxxviii. 23: (Mgh:) ― -b3- praying: (Mgh:) ― -b4- and applied by the Arabs in the Time of Igno-
rance to a follower of the true religion, not worshipping idols: (TA:) ― -b5- pl. raAkaEuwna (Mgh) and rukRaEN and rukuwEN. (TA.) ― -b6- UibilN rawaAkiEu, [pl. of raAkiEapN,] (tropical:) Camels lowering their heads, and falling upon their faces, in consequence of fatigue, or the utmost fatigue, or languor arising from fatigue. (TA.)

marokaEN c
marokaEN [A place in which one bows, or bends himself: and particularly, in prayer: pl. as below]. ― -b2- A hard and long stone upon which one grinds wheat or the like: pl. maraAkiEu. (TA.)

1 rakalahu c
1. rakalahu, aor.
rakula
, (S, TA,) inf. n. rakolN, (S, K, TA,) He kicked him; i. e., struck him with his foot, or leg; namely, a horse; in order that he should run: (K, TA:) and (K) he struck him with one foot, or leg: (S, K, TA:) and some say, he struck him with the feet, or legs. (TA.) One says, laA taOokulu baEodahaA baEodahaA OakolapF laOarokulanRaka rakolapF↓ [I will assuredly kick thee with one kick after which thou shalt not eat one meal]. (TA.) And AlfaArisu yarokulu AldRaAbRapa birijolihi The horseman puts the beast in motion with his foot, or leg, for the purpose of [his] running. (S.) And tarokiylN, also, [inf. n. of rkRl↓, in like manner] signifies The striking a thing with the foot or hoof. (KL.)

2 rakRala
2: see what next precedes.

3 raAokala
3: see 6, in two places.

5 trkRl bimisoHaAtihi c
5. trkRl bimisoHaAtihi He struck his msHAp [or spade] with his foot, (S, K, TA,) and pressed upon it with his haunch, (TA,) in order that it might enter into the earth. (S, K, TA.)

6 trAklwA c
6. trAklwA They kicked one another: (S, * K, * TA:) said of boys, meaning they struck (rakaluwA) one another with their feet, or legs: and muraAkalapN↓ signifies the same as taraAkulN: you say, rAkl↓ AlSRabiIRu SaAHibahu [The boy kicked his companion, or fellow, being kicked by him]. (TA.)

rakolapN c
rakolapN: see 1 [of which it is the inf. n. of un].

marokalN c
marokalN The part, of a beast, where one strikes him with the foot, or leg, (K, TA,) when putting him in motion for the purpose of [his] running: (TA:) the two such parts are termed the marokalaAni: and the pl. is maraAkilu. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And A road: (S, K:) because it is beaten with the foot. (TA.)

mirokalN c
mirokalN The foot, or leg, [as being the instrument with which the action termed rakolN is performed:] in the copies of the K, AlrRajulu is erroneously put for AlrRijolu: or, accord. to the L, the foot, or leg, of the rider. (TA.)

OaroDN murakRalapN c
OaroDN murakRalapN Ground trodden by the hoofs of horses or similar beasts. (S, K.)

1 rakama AlXRaIoCa c
1. rakama AlXRaIoCa, aor.
rakuma
, (S, M,) inf. n. rakomN (M, K,) He heaped up, piled up, or accumulated, the thing; i. e. he collected together the thing, and put, or threw, one part of it upon another; (S, K; *) or he put, or threw, one part of the thing upon another. (M, TA.)

6 trAkm c
6. trAkm and Artkm↓ It (a thing) was, or became heaped, or piled, up, or together, or accumulated; i. e., collected together, (S, K, TA,) one part upon [or overlying] another. (TA.) You say, trAkm AlsRaHaAbu The clouds were, or became, [heaped, or piled, up,] one above, or upon, [or overlying,] another; as also trAkb. (TA in art. rkb.) And trAkm laHomu AlnRaAqapi [lit. The flesh of the she-camel became accumulated]; meaning the she-camel became fat. (TA.) [And trAkmt AlZRalomapu (assumed tropical:) The darkness became condensed, or dense: for the Arabs describe thick darkness as “ darknesses one above another: ” see Kur xxiv. 40.] And trAkmt AlOaXogaAlu and Artkmt↓ (tropical:) [Occupations, or the occupations, became accumulated]. (TA.)

8 Uirotakama
8: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

rakamN c
rakamN: see rukaAmN.

rukomapN c
rukomapN, (S, K, [so in my copies of the S,]) with damm, (K,) in [some of] the copies of the S rakamapN, (TA,) Clay, or mud, (S, K, TA,) and earth, or dust, (TA,) collected together [and app. heaped up]. (S, K, TA.)

rukaAmN c
rukaAmN (S, K) and rakamN↓ (IAar, K) and mutaraAkimN↓ (S, K) and murotakimN↓ and marokuwmN↓ (TA) Clouds (saHaAbN) collected together, and heaped, or piled, up; (IAar, S, K, TA;) and so sand; (S, TA;) and the like: (S:) [or, as the explanations seem to indicate, the first and second are used as substs., implying what is collected together &c.; and the rest only as epithets:] and you say also rukaAmu saHaAbi (TA) and rukaAmu ramolK: (K, TA:) and XaIoCN rukaAmN means a thing accumulated, one part upon another. (TA.) ― -b2- And qaTiyEN rukaAmN (tropical:) A large herd or flock or the like; (K, TA;) likened to the rkAm of clouds or of sand. (TA.)

marokuwmN c
marokuwmN: see the next preceding paragraph. ― -b2- [Hence,] naAqapN marokuwmapN (tropical:) A fat she-camel. (TA. [See 6.]) ― -b3- marokuwmN is applied by Dhu-r-Rummeh as an epithet to midnight (jawozu AllRayoli) [meaning marokuwmN ZulumaAtuhu, i. e. Densely dark, as though its darknesses were heaped one upon another: see 6]. (TA in art. xfq.)

murotakamN c
murotakamN (tropical:) The main part, or middle, of a road. (S, K, TA.)

murotakimN c
murotakimN: see rukaAmN.

mutaraAkimN c
mutaraAkimN: see rukaAmN.

1 rakana Uilayohi c
1. rakana Uilayohi, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
rakuna
; (S, Msb, K;) of the dial. of the lower (sufolaI) [app. in territory] of Mudar, and said by Az to be not chaste [thought it, or the third, seems to be the most common of the dial. vars. here mentioned]; (Msb;) and rakina aor.
rakana
; (S, Msb, K;) mentioned by AZ; (S;) and rakana, aor.
rakana
; (S, Msb, K;) which is a combination of two dial. vars., [namely, the first and second of those above mentioned,] (S, Msb,) because neither the medial nor the final radical letter is faucial; (Msb;) said to be the only instance of its kind except OabaI aor. yaOabaI; (T in art. AbI;) and rakina, aor.
rakuna
; which is likewise an instance of the commixture of two dial. vars., like faDila and HaDira and naEima, aor. yafoDulu and yaHoDuru and yanoEumu; (TA;) inf. n. rukuwnN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and rakaAnapN and rakaAniyapN; (TA;) He inclined to him, or it; syn. maAla: and he trusted to, or relied upon, him, or it, so as to be, or become, easy, or quiet, in mind; syn. sakana: (S, Mgh, K:) or he leaned, rested, or relied, upon him; syn. AiEotamada Ealayohi: (Msb:) or he inclined to him in the least degree; (Bd in xi. 115;) rukuwnN signifying slight inclining. (Ksh and Bd ibid.) It is said in the Kur [xi. 115], walaA tarokanuwA UilaI QlRaciyna ZalamuwA [And incline ye not, &c., to those who have acted wrongfully]: (S, Msb:) or, incline ye not in the least degree [&c.]: (Bd:) thus generally read; and also tirokanuwA, (Ksh, Bd, TA,) accord. to the dial. of Temeem; and turokanuwA↓, in the pass. form, from Oarokanahu. (Ksh, Bd.) ― -b2- rakina fiI Almanozili, aor.
rakana
, inf. n. rakonN, He kept tenaciously to the place of alighting, or abode, (DanRa bihi,) and did not relinquish it. (TA.) ＝ -A2- rakuna, inf. n. rakaAnapN (S, K) and rukuwnapN (K) and rakaAniyapN, (TK,) [primarily, it seems, said of a mountain, meaning It was inaccessible, or difficult of access, having high, or strong OarokaAn i. e. sides or angles: see Har p. 561; and see rakiynN, below; and 5. ― -b2- And hence,] (tropical:) He (a man) was, or became, firm, (Har p. 561,) still, or motionless, (TA,) grave, staid, steady, sedate; or calm. (S, K, TA.)

2 rkRn c
2. rkRn is said by Golius, as on the authority of the KL, to signify He made like, “ similem fecit: ” and hence Freytag also thus explains it: but it is zkRn that has this signification. In my copy of the KL, tazokiynN (not tarokiynN) is expl. by mAnnd krdn.]

4 Arknhu c
4. Arknhu He made him to incline [UilaI gayorihi to another]; syn. OamaAlahu: [and to trust to, or rely upon, another, so as to be, or become, easy, or quiet, in mind: or to lean, rest, or rely, upon another: see 1:] whence a reading in the Kur xi. 115. (Ksh, Bd. *) See 1.

5 trkRn c
5. trkRn said of a man, (TA,) [or primarily and properly, of a thing, like rakuna,] He, [or it] was, or became, firm, or strong, (K, TA,) and inaccessible, or difficult of access. (TA.) ― -b2- And [hence,] (assumed tropical:) He endeavoured, or constrained himself, to be grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm; syn. tawaqRara, (K,) and tarazRana. (TA.)

rakonN c
rakonN The jurac [or large field-rat]: and the faOor [or common rat or mouse]; as also rukayonN↓. (K.)

rukonN c
rukonN The jaAnib [meaning side, or outward part,] of a thing: (Msb:) or the strongest jaAnib
[i. e. side, or outward part,] (S, K, TA) of a thing (S, TA) of any kind: (TA:) the corner, or angle, (zaAwiyap,) of a house or room or the like: (K in art. zwI:) [and this is perhaps what is meant by the “ strongest jAnb; ” for the strongest outward part of the house is unquestionably the corner, or angle: thus the angle in which is the Black Stone, of the Kaabeh, is specially called rukonu Albayoti, i. e. rukonu bayoti QllRehi:] the rukon of a qaSor [or palace, or pavilion, &c.,] is its jaAnib [or its strongest jAnb], and so of a mountain: (TA: [see rakuna, and rakiynN:]) the pl. is OarokaAnN and OarokunN [each properly a pl. of pauc., but the former is used as a pl. of mult.]: (Msb, TA:) the OarokaAn of anything are is jawaAnib [or sides, or outward parts, or its corners, or angles,] upon which it rests, and by which it is supported: (TA:) and the OarokaAn of a land are its extremities [or sides or corners]. (Ham p. 478.) ― -b2- [Hence, (assumed tropical:) A stay, or support, of any kind: see an ex. voce mirojamN: whence, perhaps,] one says, tamasRaHotu biOarokaAnihi, meaning tabarRakotu bihi (tropical:) [i. e. I looked for a blessing by means of him, or it]. (TA.) (assumed tropical:) A thing whereby one is strengthened (maA yuqawRaI bihi [in the CK mA taqawRaIbh]), such as dominion (mulok [in the CK malik]), and an army, or a military force, &c.: (K:) and thus it has been explained as occurring in the Kur [li. 39], where it is said, fatawalRaI birukonihi, (TA,) i. e. (assumed tropical:) And he turned away from belief with his forces; because they were to him like the rukon [properly so termed]. (Jel.) (assumed tropical:) A man's kinsfolk; or nearer, or nearest, relations; or clan; or tribe; syn. EaXiyrapN: (AHeyth, TA:) (assumed tropical:) a man's people, or party; and the higher among them; and the persons by whom he is aided and strengthened: thought by ISd to be thus called by way of comparison [to a rukon properly so termed]: and thus it has been explained as used in the Kur [xi. 82], where it is said, Oawo MwiIa rukonK XadiydK (assumed tropical:) [Or that I might have recourse to a strong people, or party, &c.]: (TA:) or it here means EaXiyrap [explained above]. (Jel.) And (assumed tropical:) A noble, or high, person; as in the saying, huwa rukonN mino OarokaAni qawomihi (assumed tropical:) [He is a noble, of the nobles of his people]. (TA.) And OarokaAnu AlUinosaAni means (assumed tropical:) The members, or limbs, of the man, with which things are gained or earned, or with which he works; as the hands or arms, and the feet or legs. (TA.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) Might, and resistance: (S, K:) so in the saying, huwa yaOowiI UilaI rukonK XadiydK (assumed tropical:) [He has recourse to strong, or vehement, might and resistance]: (S:) and so it has been explained as used in the words of the Kur last cited above. (TA.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) A thing, an affair, a case, an event, or an action, of great magnitude or moment, momentous, formidable, or terrible. (AHeyth, K.) Thus AHeyth explains it as used in the saying of En-Nábighah [Edh-Dhubyánee],
laA taqocifanRiI birukonK laA kifaMCa lahu
[By no means reproach thou me with a momentous, or a formidable, thing or action, or an enormity, that has not its equal; though (he proceeds to say) the enemies incite thee, with companies of men aiding one another]. (TA.) ― -b5- In the conventional language [of the schools], rukonu AlXRaIoCi means (assumed tropical:) [The essence of the thing; or] that whereby the thing subsists: from AltRaqawRumu; because the qiwaAm [or subsistence] of the thing is by its rukon: not from AlqiyaAm: else it would necessarily be the case that the agent would be a rukon to the action; and the substance, to the accident; and the thing to which a quality is attributed, to the quality: (KT:) it is (assumed tropical:) that without which the thing has no subsistence: (Kull:) and is [also] applied to (assumed tropical:) [an essential, or essential part, of the thing; i. e.,] a part of the maAhiyRap [or essence] of the thing, (Kull, [and in like manner OarokaAnu AlXRaIoCi is explained in the Msb as meaning the parts of the mAhyRp of the thing,]) as when we say that AlqiyaAm is a rukon of AlSRalaAop; as well as to (assumed tropical:) the whole maAhyRp [of the thing]: (Kull:) [thus] OarokaAnu AlEibaAdaAti means (assumed tropical:) the fundamentals [or essentials] of the services of religion, by the neglect, or non-observance, of which they are ineffectual, or null, or void: (TA:) or, as some say, rukonu AlXRaIoCi means that whereby the thing is complete; and this is intrinsic therein; differing from the XaroT [or condition] thereof, which is extrinsic thereto. (KT.)

rakiynN c
rakiynN A mountain having high OarokaAn [i. e. sides, or angles]: (S, K:) or having strong ArkAn: (TA:) or inaccessible, or difficult of access, having ArkAn. (Har p. 561.) ― -b2- And hence, (Har ibid.,) (tropical:) A man (S, K, &c.) firm, (Har,) still, or motionless, (TA,) grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm. (S, K, Har, TA.)

rukayonN c
rukayonN: see rakonN.

OarokuwnN c
OarokuwnN A great dihoqaAn, (K, TA,) i. e. headman, or chief, of a village or town: [app. from the Greek ἄρχω ν; though it is said that] he is thus called because the people of the village or town trust to him and incline to him. (TA.)

mirokanN c
mirokanN A kind of vessel, well known, (K, TA,) like a tawor [q. v.], of leather, used for water: (TA:) or i. q. UijRaAnapN [q.v.], (S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) in which clothes and the like are washed; (TA;) called in Pers. tagaAro: (Mgh:) pl. maraAkinu and maraAkiynu. (TA.) One says, zaraEuwA AlrRayaA Hiyna fiI AlmaraAkiyni [They sowed the sweet-smelling plants in the mrAkyn]. (TA.)

murakRanN c
murakRanN A thing having OarokaAn [here meaning corners, or angles]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] DaroEN murakRanN A great udder; as though having ArkAn: (S, TA:) and an udder that has opened [or expanded] in its place so as to fill the OarofaAg [or groins], and is not very long. (TA.) Tarafeh says,
waDarRatuhaA murakRanapN daruwru
[And her udder is great, having much milk: or,] accord. to AA, mrkRnp [here] signifies mjmREp [app. meaning collecting much]. (TA.) And you say also naAqapN murakRanapu AlDRaroEi (S, TA) [A she-camel great in the udder; or] whose udder has OarokaAn by reason of its greatness. (TA.)

1 rakaA c
1. rakaA (ISd, K,) [aor. yarokuw,] inf. n. rakowN, (ISd, TA,) He dug, or excavated, (ISd, K, TA,) the ground, forming an oblong hollow. (ISd, TA.) ― -b2- He made, formed, or fashioned, in a suitable manner, a small watering-trough such as is termed marokuwR, (AZ, TA,) or a watering-trough [in an absolute sense]; as also ArkI↓. (TA.)

4 Oarokawa
4: see what next precedes.

rakowapN c
rakowapN (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.) and rikowapN and rukowapN, (K,) all well known, but the first is the most chaste, (MF,) A certain thing for water: (S:) it is [a small drinking-vessel] like a tawor, of leather; (ISd, TA;) a small drinking-vessel of skin: (Nh, TA:) or a small dalow [or bucket, generally of leather], (Mgh, Msb,) well known: (Msb:) all of these explanations have been strangely neglected by the author of the K: (TA:) pl. rikaMCN (S, Mgh, Msb) and rakawaAtN; (S,) Msb;) the latter allowable. (Msb.) The prov. (S) SaArati Alqawosu rakowapF [lit. The bow became a rkwp, app. meaning the bow became exchanged for a vessel such as is called rkwp, but see what follows,] is applied in relation to the retiring of good fortune, and reverse in the state of affairs. (S, K.) ― -b2- A small zaworaq [or skiff]. (ISd, K.) ― -b3- A ruqoEap [or piece of cloth, or rag,] beneath the EawaASir, (K,) which means three stones [with which grapes are pressed so as to force out the juice,] placed one above another: so in the M. (TA.) [Hence, accord. to the TK, the prov. above mentioned: but I see not why.] ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) The faloham of a woman; i. e. her faroj [or vulva]: so in the copies of the K: but in the T, her qulofap [i. e. the prepuce of the clitoris], on the authority of IAar; as being likened to the rkwp of water: (TA:) the pl. [app. in all its senses] is rikaMCN and rakawaAtN [as above], (K,) or in the last sense rukFI. (TA.)

rakiIRN c
rakiIRN: see what next follows, in two places.

rakiyRapN c
rakiyRapN A well: (S, Msb, K:) or a well containing water; (MA;) otherwise a well is not thus called: (Durrat el-Ghowwás, in De Sacy's Chrest. Ar. ii. 332:) or a well not made neat; or not constructed [or cased] with bricks [&c.]: (MA:) pl. rakaAyaA (S, Msb, K) and rakiIRN↓, (S, and so in some copies of the K,) or the former is the pl. and ↓the latter is [properly speaking] a gen. n., [i. e. a coll. gen. n.,] and often occurs as a sing. and as a pl., (Nh, TA,) or the pl. is also rukiIRN: (so in some copies of the K and in the TA:) accord. to ISd, it is from rakaA in the first of the senses assigned to this verb above. (TA.)

marokuwRN c
marokuwRN [pass. part. n. of 1: ― -b2- and hence, as a subst.,] A large watering-trough or tank: (AA, T, S, K:) [in the S and K is added, waAljuromuwzu AlSRagiyru, which may mean either that the small watering-
trough is called jrmwz, and such is the case, or that marokuwRN also signifies a small jrmwz, agreeably with what here follows, and with an explanation of this word in the TA voce HawiIRN:] Az, after mentioning AA's explanation given above, says, but what I have heard from the Arabs is, that the mrkwR is a small watering-trough or tank, which a man makes, or forms, or fashions, in a suitable manner, with his hands, at the head of the well, when he has not, and cannot procure, a vessel in which to give water to a camel or to two camels: and that which is large is not thus called. (TA.) [But see an ex. voce salosN.]

1 ramRahu c
1. ramRahu, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. yarumRu (T, S, M, Msb, K) and yarimRu (S, Msb, K,) the latter [irreg. as aor. of a trans. v. of this class, and] said by MF to be unknown, but there are other instances of the same kind, as harRahu, aor. yahurRu and yahirRu and EalRahu, aor. yaEulRu and yaEilRu, (TA,) inf. n. ramRN (Lth, T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and maramRapN, (Lth, T, S, Mgh, K,) He repaired it; or put it into a good, sound, right, or proper, state; (Lth, T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) after a part thereof had become in a bad state; (Lth, T;) namely, a thing, (Lth, T, S,) as, for instance, a rope becoming old and worn-out, or a house, (Lth, T,) or a building, (Mgh,) or a wall, &c.; (Msb;) as also ramRa XaOonahu, (S,) or XaOonahaA referring to a house (daAr): (Lth, T:) and in like manner, he rectified it, namely, an affair, after it had become disorganized, or disordered: (Lth, T:) and rmRm↓ signifies the same in an intensive sense; [i. e. he repaired it, &c., much, or well:] (Msb:) and ramorama↓ he repaired, or rectified, his affair, case, state, or condition. (TA.) The saying, kunRaA Oahola vamRihi waramRihi, (T, S,) occurring in a trad., (S,) accord. to the relaters thereof vumRihi warumRihi↓, but A'Obeyd holds the former reading to be the right, (T, S,) means, accord. to AA, We were the fit persons to put it into a good, sound, right, or proper, state: (T:) or, accord. to A'Obeyd, to put it into such a state, and to eat it. (T, S. [See another explanation of the verb in what follows.]) ― -b2- You say also, ramRa sahomahu, meaning (tropical:) [He made his arrow even, or straight, by means of his eye; or] he looked at his arrow until he made it even, or straight. (TA.) ＝ -A2- ramRN also signifies The act of eating; and so AirotimaAmN↓. (ISh, T.) You say, ramRahu, (T, S, K,) aor. yarumRu (T, S,) inf. n. ramRN, (TA,) He ate it. (T, S, K.) And it is said in a trad., Ealayokumo biOalobaAni Albaqari faUinRahaA tarumRu mino kulRi AlXRajari [Keep ye to the milk of cows, for they eat of all the tress]; (T, S, * TA;) i. e. taOokulu: or, accord. to one reading, it is tarotamRu↓. (TA.) ramRati AlXRaApu AlHaXiyXa aor. tarumRu, inf. n. ramRN, means The sheep, or goat, took the dry herbage, or fodder, with its lips. (M.) And ramRati AlXRaApu mina AlOaroDi, and ArtmRt↓, The sheep, or goat, ate from the land. (S.) And ramRati Albahomapu, (M,) or Albahiymapu, (K,) inf. n. as above; (TA;) and ArtmRt↓; i. e. [The lamb, or kid, or the beast, or quadruped,] reached and took the branches (M, K) with its mouth. (K.) And kulRa rumaAmK huwa yataramRamu↓ He eats every [kind of] rumaAm [q. v.]. (T.) And AlEaZoma trmRm↓ He ate off the flesh from the bone; syn. taEarRaqahu: or he left the bone like the rimRap [q. v.]: in [some of] the copies of the K, taramRama is erroneously explained by taEazRaqa; [in my MS. copy, by taEarRafa; and in the CK, by tafarRaqa;] the right reading being taEarRaqa, as in the A. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., respecting the she-cat, walaA mino xaXaAXi AlOaroDi OarosalotuhaA turamorimu↓, meaning [And I did not send her] for her to eat [of the creeping things of the earth]. (TA.) ＝ -A3- ramRa AlEaZomu, aor. yarimRu (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. ramRN (T, M,) or rimRapN, (S,) or both, (K, TA, [the former written in the CK rimR]) and ramiymN; (M, K;) and ArmR↓; (M, K; [but see what follows;]) The bone became such as is termed rmRap; (M, TA;) [i. e.,] became old and decayed; (MA, KL;) syn. baliIa. (T, S, Mgh, Msb, K.) Accord. to IAar, one says, ramRato EiZaAmuhu, and OaramRato↓, meaning His bones became old and decayed; syn. baliyato: but others explain AlEaZomu ArmR↓ differently, as below: see 4. (T.) In the saying, mentioned in a trad., yaA rasuwla QllRehi kayofa tuEoroDu SalaAtunaA Ealayoka waqado Oaramota↓, meaning baliyta [i. e. O Apostle of God, how shall our blessing be offered, or addressed, to thee when thou shalt have become decayed in the grave?], the last word is originally Oaromamota; one of the two m s being rejected; like as is done in OaHasota, for OaHosasota: (IAth, K, * TA: [in the CK, taEoraDu is put in the place of tuEoraDu:]) accord. to one relation, it is OaramRata; accord. to another, ramamota; and accord. to another, Ourimota: but the first is the proper manner of relation. (TA.) And ramRa AlHabolu The rope became [old and worn out or rotten, (see rumRapN,) or] ragged, or dissundered. (M.)

2 ramRaRa
2: see 1, first sentence.

4 ArmR c
4. ArmR, said of a bone, It had in it, or contained, rimR, i. e. marrow, (T, S, K,) running therein. (S.) One says of a sheep or goat (S, M) that is lean, or emaciated, (S,) and of a she-camel, (M,) maA yurimRu minohaA maDoribN, (S, M,) meaning Not a bone of her that is broken and from which the marrow is [sought to be] extracted [contains any marrow]: (M:) i. e., if any of her bones be broken, no marrow will be found in it. (S.) And ArmRt is said of a she-camel in the first stage of fatness when becoming in good condition of body, and in the last stage thereof when becoming lean; (M, TA;) meaning She had in her somewhat of marrow. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1, in the latter part of the paragraph, in four places. ＝ -A2- Also, (T, S, M, K,) inf. n. UiromaAmN, (T,) He (a man, T) was, or became, silent; (T, M, K;) in a general sense; or, as some say, from fear, or fright: (M:) [and in like manner a bird: see its part. n. murimRN:] or they (a company of men) were, or became, silent. (S.) [See also R. Q. 2.] ＝ -A3- ArmR UilaI AllRahow He inclined to diversion, sport, or play. (IAar, M, K.) ― -b2- And ArmR likacaA He was cheered, or delighted, and pleased, or was diverted, by reason of such a thing; like OaranRa lahu. (T in art. rn.)

5 trmRmhu c
5. trmRmhu He proceeded gradually, by degrees, step by step, or time after time, with the repairing of it; or with the putting it into a good, sound, right, or proper, state. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, near the middle of the paragraph, in two places.

8 Uirotamama
8: see 1, in the middle portion of the paragraph, in four places. ― -b2- ArtmR is also said of a young camel as meaning He began to be in that state in which one could feel his hump. (K.)

10 AstrmR c
10. AstrmR It (a wall, S, MA, Mgh, K, or a building, KL) needed, or required, its being repaired; (M, MA, K, KL; expl. in the M and K by daEaA UilaI UiSolaAHihi;) having become old: (MA:) or attained to the time in which it should be repaired; (S, Mgh;) a long period having elapsed since it was plastered with mud. (S.)

R. Q. 1 ramorama c
R. Q. 1. ramorama: see 1, in two places.

R. Q. 2 taramorama c
R. Q. 2. taramorama He moved his lips, (T,) or his mouth, (S,) to speak: (T, S:) or taramoramuwA they put themselves in motion to speak, but spake not: (M, K:) but it is said to be mostly used in negative phrases. (TA.) One says, maA taramorama fulaAnN biHarofK Such a one uttered not [a letter, or a word]: (T, TA:) or put not himself in motion [therewith]. (IDrd, TA.) And kalRamahu famaA taramorama [He spoke to him and] he returned not a reply. (M, TA.)

ramRN c
ramRN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (Lth, T, S, &c.) ― -b2- One says, maAliI minohu HamRN walaA ramRN There is not for me any avoiding it, or escaping it: (S:) or maA lahu Eano celika AlOamori HamRN walaA ramRN (T, TA) There is not for him any avoiding, or escaping, that thing, or affair: (TA:) and some say HumRN walaA rumRN↓: (S:) so says Lth: (T:) [accord. to ISd,] in the saying maA Eano celika HumRN walaA rumRN↓, meaning There is no avoiding, or escaping, that, rumRN is an imitative sequent; (M;) and so says Lth. (T. [But see the next paragraph.]) ― -b3- See also another signification assigned to ramRN in the last sentence but one of the next paragraph. ― -b4- [And see the last sentence also of that paragraph.]

rumRN c
rumRN: see 1, second sentence: ― -b2- and see also the paragraph next preceding this, in two places. ― -b3- Also i. q. bayotK maramRapu↓, (ISk, T, S, M,) i. e. Household-goods; or the utensils and furniture of a house or tent. (M. [This explanation, from the M, I have found, in the TT, since I composed art. vm; in which I have said that, accord. to analogy, maramRapu Albayoti app. signifies the means by which a house, or tent, is put into a good state; and therefore good furniture and utensils.]) So in the saying, maA lahu vumRN walaA rumRN, (ISk, T, S, M,) and maA yamoliku vumRFA walaA rumRFA, (ISk, T, S,) i. e. He has not,
and he possesses not, such household-goods as water-skins, or milk-skins, and vessels, (ISk, T, M,) nor any of the utensils and furniture of the house or tent. (ISk, * T, * M.) This explanation is better than the saying of Lth [that rumRN is an imitative sequent: see the next preceding paragraph]. (T.) One says also, maA lahu HumRN walaA rumRN, meaning He has not anything: (S:) or he has neither little nor much. (TA voce HamRN [q. v.]) [See also vumRN.] ― -b4- Also i. q. hamRN [as meaning An object, or a thing intended or meant or determined upon or desired, in the mind: and perhaps also anxiety; or disquietude, or trouble, of mind]. (M, K. [This signification, hamRN, Freytag has assigned to ramRN, not to rumRN; rendering it “ cura, sollicitudo; ” as from the K; in which the word bearing it is expressly said to be “ with damm. ”]) So in the saying, maA lahu rumRN gayoru kacaA [He has not any object in his mind except such a thing]. (M.) And so in the saying, maA lahu HumRN walaA rumRN gayoruka and HamRN walaA ramRN↓ [He has not any object in his mind except thee]. (TA in art. Hm.) ＝ -A2- Also A company of men: occurring in a trad. applied to a company of [the people called] OakoraAd, abiding [in a place] like a HaI [or tribe] of the Arabs of the desert: [perhaps correctly ramRN, from the Pers. ramo:] said by Aboo-Moosà to be app. a Pers. word. (TA.)

rimRN c
rimRN The herbage and other things that are upon the land: whence the current saying, jaMCa fulaAnN biAlTRimRi waAlrRimRi, meaning Such a one brought everything of what is on the land and in the sea: [or, of what is in the sea and on the land; for] AlTRimRu means “ the sea; ” and is originally AlTRmRu, but is pronounced [in this case] AlTRimR to assimilate it to AlrRimR. (T.) [Or] i. q. varFI [app. as meaning Good of any kind; and particularly wealth; as appears from what immediately follows]: one says, jaMCahu biAlTRimRi waAlrRimR, meaning He brought him much wealth. (S.) [Or] jaMCa biAlTRimRi waAlrRimRi means He brought what was of the sea and what was of the land: (biAlbaHoriIRi waAlbarRiIR, K: [so in MS. copies and in the CK: in the copy of the K followed in the TA, and in like manner in the M, bAlbHr wAlvrI, which, I think, is evidently a false reading:]) or moist and dry: or earth and water: (M, K:) or much wealth; (K;) as in the S: (TA:) and it is said in the copies of the K, [and in the M,] that AlrRimRu signifies what is borne [on its surface] by the water; but this is a signification of AlTRimRu; and AlrRimRu signifies what is borne by the wind: (TA:) or what is upon the ground, of fragments of dry herbage. (M, K.) [See also art. Tm.] ― -b2- Also Marrow. (T, S, M, K.)

rumRapN c
rumRapN The remains of a rope after it has become ragged, or dissundered: (T:) or a piece of a rope (S, M, Msb, K) that is old and worn out or rotten; (S;) as also rimRapN↓: (M, K:) pl. [of mult.] rumamN (T, S,) or rimamN (M, K,) and rimaAmN (S, M, K) and [of pauc.] OaromaAmN: (M, K:) and they said also HabolN OaromaAmN and rimamN [or rumamN] and rimaAmN; (M, K;) [like HabolN OaromaAvN and vawobN OaxolaAqN &c.;] thus using the pl. as though every part [of the rope] were termed a single thing. (M.) ― -b2- Hence the saying, OaEoTayotuhu AlXRaIoCa birumRatihi (assumed tropical:) I gave him the thing altogether: (T:) or dafaEa Uilayohi AlXRaIoCa birumRatihi (assumed tropical:) He gave him the thing altogether: (S:) or Oaxacahu birumRatihi (assumed tropical:) He took it altogether: (M; and the like is said in the Msb:) and Oatayotuka biAlXRaIoCi birumRtihi (assumed tropical:) I brought thee, or have brought thee, the thing altogether: (M:) or OaEoTaAhu birumRatihi (assumed tropical:) He gave it altogether: (K:) originally meaning the rope that is put upon the neck of the camel: (T:) [i. e.] originating from the fact that a man gave to another a camel with a rope upon his neck: (S, K:) or from the fact that a man sold a camel with a rope upon his neck; and it was said, Give him with his rumRap: (Msb:) or, as some say, from the bringing a captive bound with his rumRap; but this is not a valid assertion. (M.) In all the copies of the K, AlrRumRapu is also expl. as syn. with Aljabohapu; but [SM says,] I have not found it in the originals from which it is derived; and may-be the right reading is Aljumolapu. (TA.) 'Alee said, dispraising the present world, OasobaAbuhaA rimaAmN, meaning (assumed tropical:) [Its ties (lit. ropes) are] old and worn out or rotten. (TA.) ― -b3- OaromaAmN↓ [perhaps as pl. of rumRapN] also signifies (assumed tropical:) The last remains of herbage. (M, TA.)

rimRapN c
rimRapN Old and decayed bones: (AA, T, S, M, Msb, K:) or the old and decayed, of bones: (Mgh:) pl. rimamN and rimaAmN. (S, Msb.) The performance of the act termed AlAisotinojaMC therewith is forbidden. (Mgh, TA.) [See also ramiymN.] ― -b2- [And A bone in which is marrow. (Freytag, from the “ Kitáb el-Addád. ”)] ― -b3- See also rumRapN, first sentence. ＝ -A2- Also A two-winged ant: (M, K:) so accord. to Aboo-Hátim; but disallowed by ElBekree. (TA.) ― -b2- And The OaraDap [or woodfretter], (M, K,) in some one or more of the dialects. (M, TA.)

rumumN c
rumumN Clever, ingenious, skilful, or intelligent, girls, or young women: (IAar, K:) app. pl. of raAmRapN↓, [as it is said to be in the TK, whence Freytag (who has mentioned it as from the K, explaining it as an epithet applied to a girl meaning “ ingeniosa, prudens, ”) appears to have taken it,] which signifies a female skilful in repairing. (TA.)

rumaAmN c
rumaAmN: see ramiymN. ― -b2- It is applied as an epithet to vumaAm, in a saying of 'Omar, explained in art. vm: accord. to some, it means that whereof the heads are grown, so that they are eaten (turamRu, i. e. tuWokalu): it is also applied to a herb, or leguminous plant, such that the cattle pluck it with their mouths, obtaining but little thereof: and to herbage that had dried up when becoming green. (T.)

XiAopN ramuwmN c
XiAopN ramuwmN A sheep, or goat, that eats that by which it passes. (M, TA.)

ramiymN c
ramiymN A bone old and decayed: (S, M, Msb, K:) and rumaAmN↓ signifies the same (K, TA) in an intensive sense: (TA:) or the former is like rimRapN; (A 'Obeyd, T, and Ksh in xxxvi. 78;) i. e. it is a subst., signifying the old and decayed, of bones; (Ksh and Bd ibid.;) not of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure faAEilN or mafoEuwlN: (Ksh ibid.:) or it is used in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, [meaning eroded,] from ramamotuhu [“ I ate it ”]: (Bd ibid.:) its pl. is in most instances OarimRaMCu [when it is used as a subst. or as an epithet], like OadilRaMCu pl. of daliylN [or OaqoribaMC pl. of qariybN]; and rimaAmN also occurs [when it is used as a subst., for rimRapN, of which rimaAmN is a pl., or when it is used as an epithet], like kiraAmN pl. of kariymN: (Msb:) or you say OaEoZumN ramaAYimu, and ramiymN also; or ramiymN may have the meaning of a gen. n., and therefore be used in the place of a pl. (M.) It is said in the Kur ubi suprà, mano yuHoyiI QloEiZaAma wahiIa ramiymN [Who will quicken the bones when they are old and decayed &c.?]; the last word being without p because it is a subst., as expl. above, (Ksh, Bd, Jel,) not an epithet; (Ksh, Jel;) or because it is used in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, as stated above; (Bd;) or because words of the measures faEiylN and faEuwlN are sometimes used alike as masc. and fem. [and sing.] and pl., like SadiyqN and rasuwlN and EaduwRN. (S.) And Hátim, or some other, says,
OamaA waAlRaciI laA yaEolamu AlsRirRa gayoruhu
wayuHoyiI AlEiZaAma AlbiyDa wahoIa ramiymu
[Verily, or now surely, by Him beside whom none knoweth the secret, and who quickeneth the white bones when they are old and decayed &c.]; in which rmym may have the meaning of a gen. n., as observed above. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) Anything old and decayed or worn out. (M.) One says, OaHoyaI ramiyma AlmakaArimi (tropical:) [He revived what had become decayed of generous qualities or actions or practices]. (TA.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) The remains of the herbage of the next preceding year: (Lh, M:) from the same word in the sense first expl. above. (M.) ＝ -A2- ramiymu is one of the names of The east, or easterly, wind; AlSRabaA: and is also a proper name for a woman. (M.)

rumaAmapN c
rumaAmapN A sufficiency of the means of subsistence, (K, TA,) whereby life becomes, or is held to be, in a good, or thriving, state. (TA.)

ramRaMCu c
ramRaMCu, applied to a ewe, White, (S, M,) without any colour upon her. (M.)

ramRaAmN qaXRaAXN c
ramRaAmN qaXRaAXN One who collects what has fallen of food, and the worst thereof, to eat it, not preserving himself from its uncleanness. (T, as heard by its author from the Arabs.)

rumRaAnN c
rumRaAnN is of the measure fuEolaAnN accord. to Sb: accord. to Abu-l-Hasan [i. e. Akh], of the measure fuERaAlN, (M, TA,) and is [therefore] mentioned in the S and K in art. rmn [q. v.]: (TA:) the n. un. is with p. (M.)

ramoraAmN c
ramoraAmN The HaXiyX [or herbs, or dry herbage,] of the [season called] rabiyE: and also a certain species of trees, (S, M,) of sweet scent: n. un. with p: (M:) or ramoraAmapN signifies a certain well-known
sort of HaXiyX in the desert; and ramoraAmN, much thereof: (T:) or this latter signifies a certain herb having prickly branches and leaves, that forbid the touch, rising to the height of a cubit; long in the leaves, broad, and intensely green, having a yellow flower, and eagerly desired by the cattle: (AHn, M:) or a certain dust-coloured plant, (Aboo-Ziyád, M, K,) which people use as a remedy for the sting of the scorpion. (Aboo-Ziyád, M.)

riAmRapN c
riAmRapN: see rumumN, of which it is thought to be the singular.

OaromaAmN c
OaromaAmN a pl. of rumRapN as signifying “ a piece of a rope: ” (M, K:) ― -b2- and perhaps also in another sense: see the latter word, last sentence.

murimRN c
murimRN Containing rimR, i. e. marrow; applied to a bone. (T.) And, [in like manner without p,] applied to a she-camel, (S, M, K,) in the first stage of fatness when becoming in good condition of body, and in the last stage thereof when becoming lean, (M,) meaning Having in her somewhat of marrow. (S, M, * K. *) ＝ -A2- Also Silent; (A 'Obeyd, T, S;) in a general sense; or, as some say, from fear, or fright; (TA;) applied to a man, (A 'Obeyd, T,) and to a bird, as in the saying of a rájiz, (S,) namely, Homeyd El-Arkat, (TA,).
muroxFI riwaAqaAhu hujuwdN saAmiruho
yaridona waAllRayolu murmRN TaAYiruhu
[They come to the water when the bird of night is silent, when its curtains (lit. its two curtains) of darkness are let down, when the holders of discourse therein are sleeping]. (S, * TA.) ＝ -A3- [The pl.] murimRaAtN signifies Calamities, or misfortunes: (T, K:) so accord. to AZ in the saying, ramaAhu biAlmurimRaAti [He smote him, or afflicted him, with calamiites, or misfortunes]: or, accord. to Aboo-Málik, it signifies AlmusokitaAt [i. e. silencing words or acts]. (T.)

maramRapN c
maramRapN [originally maromamapN, a noun of the same class as majonbanapN and maboxalapN &c., meaning A cause of repair: and hence, a thing needing repair; as in a phrase mentioned voce raqiyEN]. ― -b2- See also maramRapu bayoti, voce rumRN. ― -b3- And see what here follows.

miramRapN c
miramRapN, (Th, T, S, M, TA,) accord. to the K, marimRapN, but this is a mistake, (TA,) The lip of any cloven-hoofed animal, (Th, T, S, M, K, TA,) such as the cow &c.; because it eats therewith; (S;) like miqamRapN; (Th, T;) as also maramRapN↓ [like maqamRapN]. (S, M, K.)

maromuwmN c
maromuwmN sing. of maraAmiymN, (TA,) which is [an epithet] applied to arrows, meaning Having the feathers repaired, or put into a good state. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And (tropical:) An arrow [made even, or straight, by means of the eye; or] looked at until made even, or straight. (TA.) ― -b3- You say also, Oamoru fulaAnK maromuwmN [i. e. The affair, or case, of such a one is rectified, or repaired]. (TA.)

1 ramava c
1. ramava, (S, TA,) aor.
ramuva
, (TK,) inf. n. ramovN, (K,) He put a thing into a right, or proper, state, or adjusted it; and wiped it with his hand. (S, K, * TA.) He collected together a thing, and put it into a right, or proper, state, or adjusted it. (As, TA.) ＝ -A2- ramivati AlUibilu, (T in art. TlH, S, M,) aor.
ramava
, (TA,) inf. n. ramavN, (S, M, K,) The camels ate rimov alone, without any change of food: (T in art. TlH:) or had a complaint from eating rimov: (S, M, K:) AHn says that the complaint thus caused is a looseness, or flux of thin excrement from the bowels, consequent upon eating rmv when hungry; and that one fears for the camels in this case. (M.) ― -b2- ramiva Oamoruhumo, aor.
ramava
, (K,) inf. n. ramavN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) Their affair, or case, or state of things, became confused. (K.) ＝ -A3- ramiva, aor.
ramava
; and ramava, aor.
ramuva
; inf. n. of each ramavN; He stole. (T.)

2 rmRv c
2. rmRv He mixed, or confounded, a thing with another thing. (IAth, TA.) ＝ -A2- rmRv naAqatahu He left some milk remaining in his she-camel's udder after milking; (M;) as also OaromavahaA↓. (T, * M.) ― -b2- And rmRv fiI AlDRaroEi, inf. n. taromiyvN, He left somewhat [of milk] remaining in the udder; as also Armv↓. (S, K.) And in like manner one says, (TA,) fulaAnN fiI maAlihi Armv↓ (K, TA, in the CK and in a MS. copy of the K fulaAnFA,) Such a one left a residue, or remainder, in his property, or among his cattle; as also Astrmv↓. (K, TA. [Had fulaAnFA been the right reading, the author of the K would, or should, have said “ as also Astrmvhu. ”]) ― -b3- rmRv Ealayohi He, or it, exceeded him, or it; (IAth, TA;) as also Armv↓. (IAth, K, * TA.) You say, rmRv EalaI Alxamosiyna He exceeded the [age of] fifty [years]: (M, K:) and in like manner one says of other numbers, relating to age. (M.) And ramRavato ganamuhu EalaI AlmiAYapi His sheep, or goats, exceeded the [number of a] hundred. (M.) And in like manner, rmRvt AlnRaAqapu EalaI miHolabihaA [The she-camel yielded more than the contents of her milking-vessel]. (M.) And Ealayohi fiI AlmanoTiqi Armv↓ He exceeded him, or surpassed him, in speech. (TK.)

4 Armv c
4. Armv: see 2, in five places. ＝ -A2- Also i. q. layRana [He, or it, rendered soft, &c.]. (K.)

10 Uisotaromava
10: see 2.

rimovN c
rimovN [A certain shrub, resembling a dwarftamarisk;] a certain pasture of camels; (S, A, Msb, K;) a species of tree [or shrub], (T,) of the kind termed HamoD, (T, S, A, Msb, K,) growing in plain, or soft, ground, (Msb,) the leaves of which fall, [or droop], like the OuXonaAn [i. e. kali, or glasswort]; eagerly desired by the camels when they are satiated with, and tired of, the [sweet pasture termed] xulRap: (T:) it is a species of tree [or shrub] resembling that called gaDFA, (M, K,) which does not grow tall, but the leaves of which spread, [app. meaning that its sprigs spread out flat, and (as described above) droop, like those of the common tamarisk,] and it resembles the OuXonaAn: (M:) like the gDA and AXnAn, it is burned for making qiloI [or potash]: (TA &c. in art. qlI:) AHn says that it has long and slender hadab [generally, and app. here, meaning sprigs garnished with minute leaves overlying one another like the scales of a fish], and is a pasture upon which camels and sheep or goats will live when they have nothing else with it; sometimes there comes forth upon it a white honey, [a species of manna,] resembling jumaAn [i. e. pearls, or silver beads like pearls], very sweet; it affords firewood, and wood for other uses; its kindled firewood is hot; and its smoke is beneficial as a remedy for the rheum: AHn also says in one place, that, accord. to certain of the Basrees, the rmv occupies the space of a man sitting, and grows in the manner of the XiyH [a species of wormwood]: also that he had been told by certain of [the tribe of] Benoo-Asad that it rises not so high as the stature of a man, and is used as firewood: (M, TA:) [a coll. gen. n.:] the n. un. is with p. (T, M.) [See a prov. cited voce cuWonuwnN, in art. cOn.] ― -b2- Also A man whose clothes are old and worn out: (A, K:) said by MF to be tropical, but not said to be so in the A. (TA.) ― -b3- And Weak in the maton [i. e. the back, or the flesh on either side of the back-bone]. (K.)

ramavN c
