ramavN A raft, constructed of pieces of wood or timber (As, T, S, M, Msb, K) put together (T, S, M, Msb, K) and bound, (T,) upon which one embarks (T, S, M, Msb, K,) on the sea or a great river: (S, M, Msb, K:) of the measure faEalN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, from ramava “ he collected together ” a thing, “ and put ” it “ into a right, or proper, state, ” or “ adjusted ” it: (As, TA:) pl. OaromaAvN. (T, S, M, Msb.) ＝ -A2- An old, wornout, rope; pl. OaromaAvN. and rimaAvN: (M:) and one says HabolN OaromaAvu, (S, M, A, K,) meaning as above, (A,) i. e. OaromaAmN; (S, K;) like as one says vawobN OaxolaAqN: (M:) or ramavN signifies a rope undone, or untwisted. (IAar, T.) ― -b2- And The thong, or the like, by which is suspended the skin of churned milk. (K.) ＝ -A3- Also Remains, of milk, in the udder, (T, S, M, K,) after milking; and so rumovapN↓: pl. of the former OaromaAvN. (M.) ― -b2- And i. q. HalabN [app. as meaning Milk, or fresh milk, drawn from the udder]. (T.) ＝ -A4- An An excel-lence, or excellent quality. (T, K.) So in the saying, in the “ Nawádir el-Aaráb, ” lifulaAnK EalaI fulaAnK ramavN [To such a one belongs an excellence over such a one]. (T.)

ramivN c
ramivN [part. n. of ramiva]. You say UibilN ramivapN, (S, M, K,) and ramaAvaI (S, K) and ramovaI, (M, K,) [which are pls.,] Camels having a complaint from eating rimov. (S, M, K. [See 1, third sentence.])

rumovapN c
rumovapN: see ramavN.

OaroDN ramovaMCu c
OaroDN ramovaMCu: see maromavapN.

ramRaAvN c
ramRaAvN [from ramavN] The maker of a raft or rafts: and one who draws, or tows, [or propels,] a raft. (MA.)

OaroDN maromavapN c
OaroDN maromavapN [in the CK muromivapN] Land producing [the shrubs called] rimov; (M, K;) and ArD ramovaMCu↓ [signifies the same, or] land in which are rimov. (Ham p. 99.)

humo fiI maromuwvaMCa c
humo fiI maromuwvaMCa They are in a state of confusion. (K.)

1 ramaHahu c
1. ramaHahu, (S, A, L, K,) aor.
ramaHa
, (L, K,) inf. n. ramoHN, (L,) He thrust him, or pierced him, with a rumoHN [i. e. spear, or lance]. (S, A, L, K.) ― -b2- And ramaHa, aor. and inf. n. as above, He (a solid-hoofed animal) struck with his hind leg. (Msb.) You say, of a horse, (S, A, K,) and of an ass, and of a mule, (S, A, *) or any solid-hoofed animal, (TA,) ramaHahu, (S, A, K,) aor. as above, (K,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) He kicked him; (K;) or struck him with his hind leg, (S, A, TA,) or with both his hind legs: (TA:) and accord. to Az, it is sometimes metaphorically said of a camel, (Msb, TA,) and ramaHato is sometimes said of a she-camel. (TA.) ― -b3- [In the vulgar modern language, it means He (a horse or the like) galloped.] ― -b4- [Hence,] said of the [locust termed] junodab, (tropical:) It struck the pebbles: (so in three copies of the S:) or it struck the pebbles with its hind leg, (L and A, and so, accord. to the TA, in the S,) or with its two hind legs. (K.) ― -b5- And, said of lightning, (tropical:) It gleamed (A, K) with gleams slight and near together. (A.)

3 rAmHhu c
3. rAmHhu, inf. n. muraAmaHapN, He contended with him in thrusting, or piercing, with the spear, or lance. (A, TA. [The meaning is indicated in both, but not expressed.])

6 trAmHwA c
6. trAmHwA They contended, one with another, in thrusting, or piercing, with the spear, or lance. (A, TA. [The meaning is indicated in both, but not expressed.])

rumoHN c
rumoHN A certain weapon, (L, TA,) well known; (L, Msb, K;) [i. e. a spear, or lance; one with which one thrusts, not which one casts; accord. to El-Hareeree, (cited by De Sacy in his “ Chrest. Ar, ” sec. ed., ii. 332,) not so called unless having its iron head mounted upon it:] pl. rimaAHN and OaromaAHN, (S, L, Msb, K,) the former of mult. and the latter of pauc. (L.) [Hence the saying,] kasaruwA bayonahumo rumoHFA [lit. They broke a spear between them, or among them; meaning] (tropical:) evil, or mischief, [or enmity, or contention,] happened between them, or among them. (A, TA.) And muniynaA biyawomK kaZilRi AlrRumoHi (tropical:) We were tried with a long and distressing day. (A, TA.) And humo EalaI baniI fulaAnK rumoHN waAHidN (tropical:) [They are in league against the sons of such a one as one man]. (A, TA.) And kaOanRa Eayonayohi fiI rumoHayoni [As though his two eyes were upon two spears] is said of one in fear and fright, and looking hardly, or intently; and sometimes of one in anger. (TA.) [The dim. is rumayoHN↓. And hence the saying,] Oaxaca rumayoHa OabiI saEodK (assumed tropical:) He (a man, K, TA, or an old man, TA) stayed himself upon a staff by reason of extreme old age, or decrepitude: by AbwsEd is meant Lukmán the Sage, (K, TA,) who is mentioned in the Kur-án: (TA:) or Marthad Ibn-Saad: or it is a surname applied to old age, and decrepitude. (K, TA.) ― -b2- See also raAmiHN. ― -b3- [As a measure in astronomy, accord. to modern Arabian astronomers, it is Four degrees and a half; the eightieth part of a great circle; and accord. to various works on practical law, it consists of twelve OaXobaAr (or spans): but there is reason to believe that ancient usage differed from the modern, with respect to both these measures, and was not precise nor uniform: in an instance mentioned voce zubaAnaI, it appears to be about twice the measure stated above; i. e., about nine degrees; and to consist of five cubits, a measure perhaps equal to twelve spans.] ― -b4- Oaxacato rimaAHahaA, said of the [species of barley-grass called] buhomaI, (T, S, A, TA,) and of any similar pasture, (T, TA,) (tropical:) It assumed, or put forth, its prickles, (A, * TA,) or became dry in its prickles, (T, TA,) and thus (T, A, TA) resisted the attempts of animals to pasture upon it. (T, S, A, L, TA.) Also, said of camels, (tropical:) They became fat, (S, K, TA,) or yielded milk plentifully; (S, TA;) as though they prevented one's slaughtering them; (K;) or because their owner is prevented from slaughtering them: (S:) or they became goodly in the eye of their owner so that he was prevented from slaughtering them; (A, * TA;) and so Oaxacato OasoliHatahaA. (TA.) One says also naAqapN caAtu rumoHK (tropical:) A fat she-camel; and UibilN cawaAtu rimaAHK (tropical:) fat camels; because their owner, when desiring to slaughter them, looks at their fatness and their goodly appearance, and is prevented from slaughtering them. (A, * TA.) ― -b5- rimaAHu AljinRi (tropical:) [The pestilence termed] AlTRaAEuwnu. (A, K.) [See the following verses.] ― -b6- rimaAHu AlEaqorabi i. q. XawolaAhaA [evidently a mistranscription for XawolaAtuhaA, i. e. (assumed tropical:) The stings of scorpions, with which they strike; AlEqrb being here used, as it seems to be in some other instances, as a coll. gen. n.: that such is the case is shown by the verses here following, quoted in the TA as an ex. of rimaAHu AljinRi]. (K.) A poet, cited by Th, says,
laEamoruka maA xaXiytu EalaI OubaIRK
rimaAHa baniI muqayRidapi AlHimaAri
walekinRiI xaXiytu EalaI OubaIRK
rimaAHa AljinRi Oawo UiyRaAka HaAri
[By thy life, or by thy religion, I feared not, for Ubeí, the stings of the scorpions; but I feared, for Ubeí, the pestilence, or thee, O Harith; HaAri being for HaArivu]; by bnI mqyRdp AlHmAr he means the scorpions. (TA.) ― -b7- [The dim.] rumayoHN↓ is a proper name of (assumed tropical:) The penis; (K, * TA;) like as XurayoHN is a proper name for “ the vulva of a woman. ” (TA.) ― -b8- cuw AlrRumayoHi↓ means (assumed tropical:) A species of jerboa, (K, TA,) long in the hind legs, in the middle [?] of each waZiyf [here meaning metacarpus] having a nail in excess [of those of the hind feet; for the fore feet have each five toes of which one only has no nail, and the hind feet have each but three toes, all of which have nails]: or it means any jerboa: and its rmH [evidently a mistranscription for rumayoH] is its tail. (TA. [It is there added, wrmAHh XwlAthA; another mistranscription, and an obvious solecism; or probably some words which should have preceded these have been omitted by the copyist.])

ramoHapN c
ramoHapN: see ramRaAHN: ― -b2- and see also the paragraph here following.

rimaAHN c
rimaAHN a pl. of rumoHN. (S &c.) ＝ -A2- Also [The vice of kicking, or striking with the hind leg or with both the hind legs;] a subst. from ramaHa said of any solid-hoofed animal: (Msb, TA:) it is a vice for which an animal that has been sold may be returned. (TA.) One says, huwa cuw rimaAHK [He has a vice of kicking]. (A.) And OaboraOu Uilayoka mina AljimaAHi waAlrRamaAHi [I am irresponsible to thee for the vice of overcoming the rider and running away with him, and the vice of kicking]. (TA.) [And ramoHapN↓, in like manner, signifies A trick of kicking: see an ex. voce jamoHapN.]

ramuwHN c
ramuwHN and ramRaAHN↓ [A horse, or the like, that has a habit of kicking]. You say daAbRapN ramuwHN EaDuwDN and EaDRaADapN ramRaAHapN↓, [A kicking, biting, beast]. (A.) And naAqapN ramuwHN (tropical:) A kicking she-camel. (TA.)

rumayoHN c
rumayoHN: see rumoHN, [of which it is the dim.], in three places.

rimaAHapN c
rimaAHapN, The art of making rimaAH [spears, or lances]. (S, A, * K.) See the next paragraph.

ramRaAHN c
ramRaAHN A maker of rimaAH [spears, or lances]. (S, A, * Msb, K.) You say, huwa ramRaAHN HaAciqN fiI AlrRimaAHapi↓ [He is a maker of spears or lances, skilful in the art of making them]. (A.) ― -b2- See also raAmiHN. ＝ -A2- See also ramuwHN, in two places. ― -b2- qawosN ramRaAHapN A bow that propels [the arrow] vehemently. (K.) The word rmRAHp used [app. in this sense, without a subst.,] by Tufeyl El-Ghanawee is expl. by some as meaning A thrust, or piercing, with the rumoH; but no way of resolving this is known, unless it be used in the place of ramoHapN↓, as the inf. n. of un. of ramaHa. (L.) ＝ -A3- Also (tropical:) Poverty, need, or want. (K, TA. [This meaning is erroneously assigned in Freytag's Lex. to rumoHN.])

raAmiHN c
raAmiHN Thrusting, or piercing, another with a rumoH [i. e. spear, or lance]. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- Also (S [in the Msb “ or ”]) A man having a rumoH [spear, or lance]; (S, Msb, K;) and so ramRaAHN↓: (L:) the former an epithet [of the possessive kind,] similar to laAbinN and taAmirN, having no verb. (S.) ― -b3- AlsRimaAku AlrRaAmiHu is the name of (tropical:) [The star Arcturus;] a certain star, before, or preceding, AlfakRap [or Corona Borealis], preceded by another star, [the star η in the left leg of Bootes,] which is called its rumoH↓ [or spear, i. e. rumoHu AlsRimaAki and simply AlrRumoHu], (S, K,) whence its name: it is one of two stars which are together called AlsRimaAkaAni; and is not one of the Mansions of the Moon: (S:) it is also called AlsRimaAku Almirozamu: (Az, TA:) the other smAk [is Spica Virginis, the Fourteenth Mansion of the Moon, and] is called AlOaEozalu, because it has no star [near] before
it: AlrAmH is more red. (TA.) ― -b4- raAmiHN also signifies (tropical:) A bull; so called because of his pair of horns: (A:) [i. e.] a wild bull; thought by ISd to be so called because of his horn: (TA:) or vaworN raAmiHN signifies a [wild] bull having a pair of horns. (S, K.)

1 ramaduwA c
1. ramaduwA, (Sh, T, M, A, L,) [aor., app.,
ramida
,] inf. n. ramodN; (M, L;) and ArmdwA↓; (Sh, T, M, L;) for which A 'Obeyd erroneously says ramiduwA, with kesr to the m; and ArmduwA↓, with teshdeed to the d; (T, L;) They (a people, or party,) perished: (Sh, T, M, A, L:) or became like ramaAd [or ashes]: (A:) and ramada EayoXuhumo, (L,) or Armd↓ EyXhm, (TA,) has the former meaning. (L, TA.) And ramada [so in the T and L and TA, not ramuda,] aor.
ramuda
, inf. n. rumuwdapN, It (a garment, En-Nadr, T, or a thing, TA) perished by becoming old and wornout, and had no goodness and lastingness. (En-Nadr, T, L, TA.) ― -b2- ramadati Alganamu, (S, M, K,) aor.
ramida
, (S, K,) inf. n. ramodN, (S,) The sheep, or goats, perished by reason of cold, or of hoar-frost or rime. (S, M, K.) ＝ -A2- ramada, (AZ, ISk, T, S, Nh, Msb,) aor.
ramuda
, (AZ, T,) or
ramida
, (Msb,) or both, (ISk, S,) inf. n. ramodN; (AZ, ISk, T, S, Msb;) or rmRd↓; (M, TT;) and Armd↓; (M, Nh, L;) He, (God, M, TA, or a man, Msb,) or it, (a company of men, ISk, S,) destroyed (AZ, ISk, T, S, Msb) a person or thing, (L, Msb,) or people: (AZ, ISk, T, S, M:) or destroyed, and rendered like ashes. (Nh.) ＝ -A3- ramida, (S, M, L, K) aor.
ramada
, (S, L,) inf. n. ramadN; (S, M, L;) and Ouromida↓, or AiromadRa↓; (accord. to different copies of the K;) He (a man, S) was, or became, affected with pain and swelling of the eye; (M;) with inflammation thereof; or with ophthalmia; syn. haAjato Eayonuhu. ramada
, (L, Msb,) inf. n. ramadN; (T, A, L, Msb, K;) and Oaromidato↓; (T, Msb;) or AiromadRato↓, (TA,) inf. n. AiromidaAdN; (K, TA;) His eye was, or became, painful and swollen, inflamed, or affected with ophthalmia; syn. haAjato. (L, K, * TA.)

2 rmRdhu c
2. rmRdhu, (M, A,) inf. n. taromiydN, (S,) He put ashes into it, (M, * A,) or upon it; (M;) namely, roast meat: (M, A:) or he put it (a thing) into ashes. (S.) It is said in a prov., XawaI Oaxuwka HatRaI UicaA OanoDaja ramRada [Thy brother roasted, until, when he had thoroughly cooked the meat, he put ashes into it, or put it into the ashes]: (T, S, M, A:) meaning (tropical:) Thy brother did a good deed and then marred it: (A:) [i. e.] it is applied to him who mars, or corrupts, that which he has put into a good, or right, state: (T:) or to him who does a kind act, and then mars it by reproach, or cuts it short. (IAth.) ― -b2- Also He put it (namely, flesh-meat to be roasted,) into live coals. (M.) ― -b3- See also 1. ＝ -A2- ramRadato, (AZ, T, S, M, K,) inf. n. taromiydN; (S) and Armdt↓; (S, K;) said of a ewe, or she-goat, (AZ, T, S, M,) and of a she-camel, (S, M, K,) and of a cow, (S,) She secreted milk in her udder a little before her bringing forth; syn. OaDoraEato: (S, K:) or she showed herself to be pregnant, and became large in her udder; as also OaDoraEato: (AZ, T:) or she secreted a little milk at the time of bringing forth: (T:) or she showed herself to be pregnant, and became large in her belly and swollen in her udder and her vulva: or she secreted somewhat [of milk] at the time of bringing forth, or a little before it: the epithet applied to her in this case is muramRidN↓ [without p]. (M.) [See also rabRadato.] One says, ramRadati AlDRaOonu farabRiqo rabRiqo [The ewes have secreted milk in their udders, &c.]: (I Aar, T, S:) therefore prepare thou the OarobaAq: prepare thou the ArbAq: [i. e., the loops into which their heads are to be inserted:] for the ewes secrete milk in their udders only EalaI raOosi Alwaladi [i. e. at the time of bringing forth, or when about to produce the young]. (S.) And [in like manner,] ramRadati AlmiEozaI faranRiqo ranRiq. (IAar, T. [See also arts. rmq and rnq.])

4 Armd c
4. Armd, as an intrans. v.: see 1, first sentence, in two places. ― -b2- Also, (S, K,) inf. n. UiromaAdN, said of a man, (S,) He was, or became, poor, needy, or indigent. (S, K.) And Armd Alqawomu The people were, or became, afflicted with drought, barrenness, or dearth, (A, K, TA,) and their cattle perished (K, TA) in consequence thereof. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, last two sentences. ＝ -A3- And see 2. ＝ -A4- As a trans. v.: see 1, in the middle of the paragraph. ＝ -A5- Armd Eayonahu He, (God, S, M, L, K,) and it, (weeping, A, TA,) caused his eye to become painful and swollen, inflamed, or affected with ophthalmia. (S, M, L, K, TA.)

9 ArmdRwA c
9. ArmdRwA: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- ArmdR, said of a man's face, i. q. ArbdR [as meaning It became like the colour of ramaAd or ashes; or it became altered by reason of anger]. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, last two sentences. ＝ -A3- Also, inf. n. AiromidaAdN, said of a camel, accord. to AA, He ran vehemently; and so ArqdR: or, accord. to As, both signify he went at random, heedlessly, headlong, or in a headlong course; and quickly: (T:) or he went quickly, or a quick pace; accord. to some, specially said of the ostrich: (M, L:) or he ran in the manner of the rumod [meaning ostriches]. (A.

Q. Q. 4 AiromiYodaAdN c
Q. Q. 4. AiromiYodaAdN [inf. n. of AiromaOadRa] The going, or acting, vigorously, or with energy. (M, TA.)

ramodN c
ramodN: see ramaAdapN.

ramidN c
ramidN, applied to water, Turbid: (T:) or altered for the worse in taste and colour, though still drinkable; (Es-Sijistánee, S, A, K;) as also muromidN↓. (Lh, L.) ― -b2- And, applied to a garment, or piece of cloth, Faded; syn. faAsxN; as also Oaromadu↓ [q. v.]. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, (S, L. Msb, K,) and Oaromadu↓, (S, M, A, L, Msb, K,) and muromadN↓, or muromadRN↓, (accord. to different copies of the K,) A man affected with pain and swelling of the eye; with inflammation thereof; or with ophthalmia: (S, M, A, * L, Msb, * K:) fem. of the first ramdapN, (Msb,) and of the second ramodaMCu↓, (M, Msb,) [and pl. of the second rumodN↓.] And EayonN ramidapN (S, M, L) and ramodaMCu↓ (M, A, L) An eye painful and swollen, inflamed, or affected with ophthalmia: (S, M, A, * L:) pl. of the latter EuyuwnN rumodN↓. (A.)

rumodapN c
rumodapN Ash-colour; the colour of ramaAd; as also rubodapN: (A in art. rbd:) a colour like wuroqapN, inclining to blackness; and so rubodapN: (T in that art.:) a colour inclining to that of dust. (M.)

maA tarakuwA UilRaA rimodapa HatRaAna, or HatRaAnK, (as in different copies of the K,) a phrase expl. in art. Ht.

ramaAdN rimodidN c
ramaAdN rimodidN (S, M, K) and rimodadN, (K,) which latter is abnormal, (TA,) or ramodadN, (so accord. to a copy of the T,) and rimodiydN↓ and Oaromadu↓, (M, K,) Ashes perishing, or coming to nought: (S, K:) or much in quantity, and very fine or minute: (M, K:) or reduced to the finest, or most minute, state: (T, TA:) or rimodidN signifies burnt to the utmost degree, and reduced to the finest, or most minute, state. (IAth, TA.)

rimodidaMCu c
rimodidaMCu: see ramaAdN.

rimodiydN c
rimodiydN: see rimodidN.

ramaAdN c
ramaAdN Ashes; i. e. charcoal reduced to particles T, M) by being burnt; (T;) burnt coals that have become mixed with dust, and extinguished, and reduced to particles: (M:) and rimodidaMCu↓ signifies the same; (S, M, K;) as also OaromidaMCu↓, like OarobiEaMCu, (so in some copies of the K, and in a copy of the S,) or OaromadaMCu↓, like OarobaEaMCu, (so in other copies of the K,) or UiromidMCu↓; (so in two copies of the S, there said to be like UirobiEaMCu, and so in the M;) as some say; or OaromidaMCu↓ is a pl. of ramaAdN, as is also OaromdapN; and UiromidaMCu↓, which is mentioned on the authority of Kr, and which is [said to be] the only word of its measure, [though UirobiEaMCu also is mentioned by IHsh,] is a quasi-pl. n.: (M:) [ramaAdN is a coll. gen. n.;] and ramaAdapN↓ [is its n. un., and as such] signifies a portion thereof. (M.) [Hence] one says, fulaAnN kaviyru ramaAdu Alqidori [lit. Such a one has many ashes of the cooking-pot]; meaning (assumed tropical:) such a one is very hospitable; has many guests: (Mgh in art. ErD:) [and so huwa kaviyru AlrRamaAdi:] and huwa EaZiymu AlrRamaAdi (assumed tropical:) he has many guests: because the ashes become much in quantity in consequence of cooking. (L, from a trad.) And sufiIa AlrRamaAdu fiI wajohihi [lit. Ashes were blown and scattered in his face]; meaning (tropical:) his face became altered. (A, TA.) ― -b2- [maMCu AlrRamaAdi is a term applied in the present day to Lixivium, or lye; i. e. water infused with wood-ashes.]

ramaAdapN c
ramaAdapN Perdition, destruction, or a state of destruction; (S, Msb;) as also ramodN↓ (T, S.) Hence, (S Msb,) EaAmu AlrRamaAdapi The year of perdition or destruction, (S, Msb. K,) or of drought, (A,) in the days of 'Omar, (S, Msb, K,) the seventeenth or eighteenth year of the Flight, (TA,) in which men perished (S, M, Msb, K) in great numbers, (M,) and cattle also, (S, K,) in consequence of drought (S, Msb) long con-
tinuing, (S,) wherefore it was thus called, (S, M,) because the earth became like ashes by reason of the drought; (Msb;) or, as some say, because the drought continued so as to render the earth and the trees like the colour of ashes: but the first reason assigned above, for its being thus called, is preferable. (M.) ― -b2- See also ramaAdN.

ramaAdiIRN c
ramaAdiIRN A sort of grapes, of Et-Táif, of a dusty black colour. (M.)

raAmidN c
raAmidN [Perishing: or becoming like ramaAd, or ashes: or] perishing by becoming old and wornout, and having no goodness and lastingness. (En-Nadr, T, L, TA.)

Oaromadu c
Oaromadu Of the colour of ramaAd [or ashes]; (S, M, K;) [ash-coloured; ashy;] of a dusty colour in which is a duskiness, or dinginess: (S:) [fem. ramodaMCu: and pl. rumodN.] Hence ramodaMCu applied to A female ostrich: (S, K:) [and rumodN applied to ostriches: (see 9, last sentence:)] and hence also rumodN applied to gnats (T, S, A, L, K) of a certain species: (T:) and you say naEaAmapN ramodaMCu (M, A) i. e. [an ostrich or a female ostrich,] of an obscure black hue, like the colour of ashes: (M:) and ZaliymN Oaromadu [a male ostrich of such a colour]: (M:) and naEaAmN rumodN [ostriches of such a colour]: (A:) and viyaAbN rumodN garments, or pieces of cloth, of a dusty colour in which is a duskiness, or dinginess; from ramaAdN. (T.) Lh asserts that the m in this word is a substitute for b. (M, L. [See Oarobadu.]) ― -b2- See also ramidN, in six places. ― -b3- And see rimodidN.

OaromadaMCu c
OaromadaMCu and OaromidaMCu and UiromidaMCu: see ramaAdN, in five places.

muromadN c
muromadN: see ramidN.

muromidN c
muromidN A she-camel, (Ks, T, TA,) and a cow, and a ewe, or she-goat, (TA,) secreting milk in her udder a little before her bringing forth; (Ks, T, TA;) as also muridRN: (Ks, T:) or both signify a she-camel having her udder shining, and infused with milk. (Ks, L in art. rd.) [See also muramRidN, in the second paragraph of this art.] ― -b2- See also ramidN.

muromadRN c
muromadRN: see ramidN.

muramRadN c
muramRadN Flesh-meat roasted in live coals. (T, S. *)

muramRidN c
muramRidN: see 2.

muromaYidRN c
muromaYidRN Going, or acting, vigorously, or with energy: (K, * TA:) AljaAriI, in the explanation given in the K, is a mistake for AljaAdRu. (TA. [See Q. Q. 4.])

1. ramaza, (S, A, &c.,) aor.
ramuza
, and
ramiza
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. ramozN (S, A, Msb, K) and rumozN and ramazN, (K,) He made a sign, (S, A, Msb, K, TA,) in indication of a thing that might be shown or pointed out by utterance, with anything: (L, TA:) or with the lips; (S, A, K, TA;) as also trmRz↓; (TA in art. nfS;) putting them in motion by speech not understood by means of utterance; not vocally manifested: (TA:) or with the lip: (Msb:) or with the eyebrow: (S, A, Msb:) or with the eyebrows: (K:) or with the eye: (Msb:) or with the eyes; (K;) as also trmRz↓: (TA in art. nfS:) or with the mouth: or with the hand or arm: (K:) or with the tongue, (K, TA,) by uttering a low voice: (K, B, TA:) but also applied to signify he made any sign or indication. (B, TA.) You say, ramaza Uilayohi He made a sign to him with the lips, or eyebrow. (A.) And ramazatohu AlmaroOapu biEayonihaA The woman made a sign to him with her eye. (TA.) And kalRamahu ramozFA [He talked to him by making signs &c.]. (A.)

6. trAmzwA [They made signs, or indications, in one or other of the manners described above, one to another]. You say, daxalotu Ealayohimo fatagaAmazuwA wataraAmazuwA [I went in to them, and they made signs and indications, &c., one to another]. (A, TA.)

ramazN c
ramazN: see raAmizN.

ramuwzN c
ramuwzN: see raAmizN.

ramRaAzN [Making frequent signs, in one or other of the manners described above; like ramuwzN]. You say, AimoraOapN ramRaAzapN A woman who makes frequent signs. &c.; who has a habit of doing so; syn. gamRaAzapN. (TA.) And jaAriyapN gamRaAzapN biyadihaA hamRaAzapN biEayonihaA lamRaAzapN bifamihaA ramRaAzapN biHaAjibihaA [A girl who makes frequent signs with her hand or arm, who does the like with her eye, who does the like with her mouth, who does the like with her eyebrow]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (S, TA,) ramRaAzapN signifies [also] An adulteress, or a fornicatress: (Sh, S, K:) a prostitute: (A:) because she makes signs with her eye. (S, TA.) [See also zamRaArapN.]

raAmizN c
raAmizN Making a sign, as [with the lips, &c., as described above, or] with the hand, or arm, or with the head: pl. [or rather quasi-pl. n.] ramazN↓. In the Kur iii. 36, instead of ramozFA, some read ramazFA; meaning as here explained: and some read rumuzFA, meaning doing so mutually; pl. of ramuwzN↓ [which is an intensive form, meaning, making frequent signs &c.; like ramRaAzN]. (Bd.)

1 ramasahu c
1. ramasahu, (S, M, Mgh, Msb,) aor.
ramusa
(M, Mgh, Msb) and
ramisa
, (M, Msb,) inf. n. ramosN, (A, Msb, K,) He buried him, or it; (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) namely, a dead person; a corpse: (S, Mgh, Msb:) this is [said to be] the primary signification: (A:) as also Armshu↓: (S, Msb:) or he buried him, and made the earth even over him. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of Zeyd Ibn-Soohán, vumRa QromusuwniI Then do ye bury me: or it may mean, conceal my grave, and make it even with the ground. (Mgh.) ― -b2- He poured, (M,) or scattered, (A,) dust, or earth, upon it; (M, A;) namely, anything. (M.) You say also, ramasahu biAltRuraAbi [in this sense]. (A.) And ramasonaAhu biAltRurobi We filled it up with dust, or earth. (M.) And it is said in a trad. of Ibn-Maakil, AuromusuwA qaboriI, meaning Make ye my grave even with the ground; not gibbous, or elevated. (TA.) ― -b3- He concealed, and covered, him, or it: this is [also said to be] the primary signification. (TA.) You say, ramasa AlXRaIoCa, aor.
ramusa
, inf. n. ramosN, He, or it, effaced, or obliterated, the traces, or remains, of the thing. (M.) And AlrRiyHu taromusu AlMvaAra bimaA tuviyruhu [The wind effaces the traces, or remains, by what it raises, of dust or sand &c.]. (A.) And ramasuwA qabora fulaAnK They concealed the grave of such a one, and made it even with the ground. (S.) And ramasotu Alxabara, (K, * Msb,) and AlHadiyva, (TA,) I concealed the news, or information, (K, * Msb,) and the story. (TA.) And ramasotu Ealayohi Alxabara, (S, M,) and AlOamora, (As A,) I concealed from him the news, or information, (S, M,) and the affair. (As, A.) ― -b4- rumisa HubRuka fiI qalobiI The love of thee hath become vehement, and firmly settled, [as though buried,] in my heart. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- ramasotuhu biHajarK, (S,) inf. n. ramosN, (K,) I cast a stone at him. (Ibn- 'Abbád, S, K. *)

4 Oaromasa

8 Artms fiI AlmaMCi c
8. Artms fiI AlmaMCi i. q. Ainogamasa (Mgh, Msb) or Aigotamasa (K) [He immersed himself in the water]; or so that his head and whole person became concealed therein; the doing of which by one fasting is forbidden in a trad.: (Sh, Sgh;) or not remaining long in the water; (Mgh, TA;) whereas Angms and Agtms denote [the doing so and] remaining long in the water; and agreeably with this explanation of the difference, the two verbs are used in another trad., where it is said, AlSRaAYimu yarotamisu walaA yanogamisu The faster may immerse himself not remaining long in the water, but not immerse himself and remain long therein. (TA.)

ramosN c
ramosN Dust, or earth: (Msb:) or dust with which the wind effaces traces or remains: (M:) or dust, or earth, that is scattered upon a corpse: (A:) or dust, or earth, of a grave: (S, Mgh, K:) an inf. n. used as a subst. (S, * Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, (Msb,) A grave; (M, A, Msb, K;) as also raAmuwsN↓ and maromasN↓: (K:) or a grave that is made even with the surface of the ground; not elevated: (TA:) and maromasN↓ signifies the place of a grave; (S;) or of a ramos: (TA:) the pl. [of pauc.] of ramosN is OaromaAsN (M, K) and [of mult.] rumuwsN. (M, Msb, K.) ＝ -A2- A low, gentle, or soft, sound or voice. (M, TA.)

ramiysN c
ramiysN: see maromuwsN, in two places.

AlrRaAmisaAtu c
AlrRaAmisaAtu (AHn, M, A, K) and AlrRawaAmisu, (AHn, S, M, &c.,) [each pl. of AlrRaAmisapu,] The winds that bury traces or remains; (K;) the winds that raise the dust, and [spread it so as to] bury traces or remains: (S:) or the winds that transport the dust from one district to another which is some days distant from the former, and sometimes cover the whole face of a land with the dust of another land. (AHn, M.) ― -b2- rawaAmisu also signifies Flying things (TayorN) that fly by night: or any creeping thing (daAbRap) that comes forth by night (ISh, K)
is called raAmisN. (ISh.) ― -b3- It also occurs as a possessive epithet, or as an act. part. n. in the place of a pass. part. n. (M.)

raAmuwsN c
raAmuwsN: see ramosN; for the latter, in two places.

maromasN c
maromasN: see ramosN; for the latter, in two places.

maromuwsN c
maromuwsN Buried; as also ramiysN↓: (M, TA:) having dust, or earth, poured upon it; as also ↓the latter epithet. (TA.) ― -b2- xabarN maromuwsN Concealed news or information. (TA.)

waqaEuwA fiI maromuwsapK mino Oamorihimo c
waqaEuwA fiI maromuwsapK mino Oamorihimo They fell into a state of confusion in respect of their affair, or case. (IAar, M.)

1 ramiSato Eayonuhu c
1. ramiSato Eayonuhu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
ramaSa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. ramaSN, (Msb,) His eye had in it what is termed ramaSN [q. v.]. (S, Msb, K.) And ramiSa, [aor. and] inf. n. as above, He had what is termed ramaSN. (M.) ＝ -A2- ramaSotu Uilayohi, aor.
ramuSa
, inf. n. ramoSN, I looked towards him, or at him, with the most secret look. (O, TA.)

4 ArmShu c
4. ArmShu It (disease) caused him to have what is termed ramaSN. (M.)

ramaSN c
ramaSN Filth, [or foul matter,] (S, Mgh,) or white filth, (K,) or tough, or dry, white filth, (A,) that collects, (S, A, K,) or concretes, (Mgh,) in the inner corner of the eye: (S, A, Mgh, K:) if fluid, it is called gamaSN: (S:) or it is in the side of the eyelashes: (ISh, TA in art. gmS:) or what is fluid; what is concrete being termed gamaSN: or i. q. gamaSN, i. e. dirt which the eye emits: or smallness and sticking of the eye. (M.) You say, mano OasaMCahu AlrRamaSu sarRahu AlgamaSu [Him whom tough, or dry, white filth collecting in the inner corner of the eye vexes, fluid matter therein rejoices]: for gamaS is a fresh fluid; and that is better than the tough, or dry. (A, TA.)

rumayoSaMCu c
rumayoSaMCu [dim. of ramoSaMCu, fem. of OaromaSu]. ― -b2- AlXRiEoraI AlrRumayoSaMCu [i. q. AlXRiEoraI AlgumayoSaMCu, i. e., Procyon; (see AlXRaEoraI;)] one of the two stars of the ciraAE: so called because of its smallness and its littleness of light [in comparison with the other XiEoraI, which is Syrius]. (M.)

OaromaSu c
OaromaSu A man (S, Mgh, Msb) having, in his eye, what is termed ramaSN: (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K:) fem. ramoSaMCu: (Msb, K:) and pl. rumoSN. (TA.)

1 ramDat AlOaroDu c
1. ramDat AlOaroDu, (Mgh,) and AlHijaArapu, (A, Mgh,) [aor.
ramaDa
,] inf. n. ramaDN, (A,) The earth, or ground, (Mgh,) and the stones, (A, Mgh,) became vehemently heated by the sun. (A, Mgh.) ― -b2- ramiDa yawomunaA, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (S, Msb,) and so the inf. n., (S, A, Msb,) Our day became intensely hot. (S, A, Msb, K.) ― -b3- ramiDa said of a man, (A, Mgh, TA,) aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. n., (Mgh, TA,) He had his fast burnt (A, Mgh, TA) by the ground, or stones, vehemently heated by the sun, (A,) or by the vehemence of the heat: (Mgh, TA:) or he was smitten, or affected, by the heat of the sun: (Ham p. 173:) and ramiDato qadamuhu his foot was burnt by the ground, or stones, vehemently heated by the sun. (S, Msb, K.) In like manner you say, ramiDati AlfiSaAlu The young camels, or young weaned camels, felt the heat of the sun from the ground, or stones, vehemently heated thereby: then is the prayer of the period called AlDRuHaI: (S:) or had their feet burned by the ground, or stones, thus heated: (Mgh, Msb:) or lay down in consequence of the intense heat of the sand, and the burning of their feet. (IAth.) And ramiDati Alganamu The sheep, or goats, from pasturing in intense heat, had their livers ulcerated, (S, K,) and their lungs affected with dropsy: (S:) or had their lungs and livers affected with dropsy, and ulcerated. (L.) And ramiDato Eayonuhu His eye became hot, so that it almost burned: the verb occurs in this sense in a trad., as some relate it, with D [instead of S]. (TA.) ― -b4- Also, said of a man fasting, His inside became vehemently hot (Fr, K) by reason of intense thirst. (Fr, TA.) ― -b5- And, said of a man, He went upon ground, or stones, vehemently heated by the sun. (TA.) ― -b6- And He returned from the desert to the region of cities, towns, or villages, and of cultivated land. (L, TA.) ― -b7- You say also, ramiDotu mina AlOamori and ramiDotu lahu and AirotamaDotu↓ (tropical:) [meaning I was distressed and disquieted by reason of the thing, or affair: or I grieved for it]: (A:) [for] mino kacaA ArtmD↓ signifies (tropical:) he was distressed and disquieted by reason of such a thing: (S, K, TA:) and ArtmD↓ lifulaAnK (tropical:) he grieved for such a one; i. q. Hazina lahu, accord. to the [S and] L [and CK]: or i. q. Hadiba lahu, [but this I think a mistranscription, for you say Hadiba Ealayohi, not Hadiba lahu,] accord. to the O and [some copies of the] K. (TA.) ＝ -A2- ramaDahu AlHarRu: see 4. ― -b2- s ramaDa Alganama, (K,) aor.
ramiDa
, inf. n. ramoDN, (TA,) He pastured the sheep, or goats, upon ground vehemently heated by the sun, (K, TA,) and made them to lie down upon it; (TA;) as also ArmDhA↓; and rmRDhA↓, (K, TA,) inf. n. taromiyDN. (TA.) ― -b3- ramaDa AlXRaApa, aor.
ramiDa
, (S, M, K,) inf. n. ramoDN, (S, M,) He clave the sheep, or goat, leaving its skin upon it, and threw it upon heated stones, and put hot ashes upon it, in order that it might become thoroughly cooked: (S, K:) or he kindled a fire upon stones, then clave the sheep, or goat, with its skin upon it, then broke its ribs from within, in order that it might lie steadily upon the ground, with the heated stones beneath it, and hot ashes above it, a fire being kindled over it: when it is thoroughly cooked, they skin it and eat it: (M, TA:) you say also ArmD↓ AlXRaApa: ― -b4- and rumiDa AllRaHomu [The flesh was dressed in the manner above described]. (TA.) ＝ -A3- ramuDa, if used, is the verb whereof ramaADapN↓, which is mentioned by Sh and in the K, is the inf. n.; and accord. to the explanation of the latter in the K, signifies It (a large or broad knife or blade) was, or became, sharp. (TA.) ＝ -A4- ramaDa AlnRaSola, (S, K,) or AlmuwsaI, (A,) aor.
ramiDa
, and
ramuDa
, (S, K,) He put the blade between two smooth stones, and then beat it, to make it thin: (ISk, S, K: [but in the text of the K, as given in the TA, the word rendered “ stones ” is omitted:]) or he beat the razor between two stones, in order that it might become thin; as also ArmD↓. (A.)

2 rmRDhu c
2. rmRDhu, inf. n. taromiyDN, (S, A, K,) originally signifies He attributed to him UiromaAD [meaning the causing one to be burnt by the heat of the sun, or by the vehemently-heated ground: or (assumed tropical:) the giving pain:] and hence, as this results from tardiness, (A, TA,) ― -b2- (tropical:) He waited expecting him a while: (Ks, Jm, S, A, O:) or a little while, and then went away. (Sh, * K.) IF says that the m may be original, or it may be a substitute for b. (TA.) ― -b3- rmRD Alganama: see ramaDa. ＝ -A2- ramRaDotu AlSRawoma I purposed fasting or the fast [app. during the month of ramaDaAn]. (Sgh, K.)

4 OaromaDatoniI AlrRamoDaMCu c
4. OaromaDatoniI AlrRamoDaMCu The ground, or stones, vehemently heated by the sun, burned me. (S.) And ArmDhu AlHarRu The heat burned him; (K, * TA;) as also ramaDahu↓, aor.
ramiDa
. (TA.) And ArmD AlHarRu Alqawoma (Jm, A, K) The heat distressed the people, or company of men; (Jm, K;) so that it hurt them. (K.) You say also, gawRiruwA binaA faqado OaromaDotumuwnaA (Jm, A) Make ye the camels to lie down with us during the vehement midday-heat [for ye have caused us to be burnt by the heat of the sun, or by the vehemently-heated ground]. (Jm, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ArmDhu (tropical:) It (anything, AA) pained him. (AA, K.) And ArmDhu AlOamoru (tropical:) [The thing, or affair, pained him] is a phrase which has originated from the first of the phrases mentioned in this paragraph. (S, TA.) ― -b3- ArmD Alganama: see 1. ― -b4- ArmD AlXRaApa: see 1. ＝ -A2- ArmD AlmuwsaI: see 1, last signification.

5 trmRD AlZRibaMCa c
5. trmRD AlZRibaMCa He drove the gazelles upon the ground, or stones, vehemently heated by the sun, until their hoofs became dissundered, or dislocated, and so they were taken: (A:) or he hunted them during the vehement midday-heat, (S, K,) pursuing them until, their legs being dislocated by the vehemently-heated ground, he took them. (S, TA.) ＝ -A2- AltRaramRuDu also signifies The heaving of the soul [or stomach]; or its being agitated by a tendency to vomit; syn. gavayaAnu AlnRafosi. (IAar, K.)

8 ArtmD c
8. ArtmD He burned by reason of vehement heat, or (assumed tropical:) of grief. (Har p. 442.) ― -b2- ArtmDt kabiduhu His liver became in a corrupt, or disordered, state. (S, O, K.) And ArtmD AlrRajulu The man became in a corrupt, or disordered, state, in his belly and his stomach. (IAar, L.) ― -b3- See also ramiDotu mina AlOamori, in three places. ＝ -A2- ArtmDt Alfarasu bihi The horse, or mare, leaped with him: (K:) so said Mudrik El-Kilábee: as also Artmzt. (A boo-Turáb, TA.)

ramaDN c
ramaDN The vehemence of the action (lit. of the falling) of the sun upon the sand &c.: (S, A, K:) or vehemence of heat; (Mgh, Msb;) as also ramoDaMCu↓: (Mgh, TA:) or the heat of the stones, arising from the intense heat of the sun: or the burning of the intense heat of summer: or heat. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence the saying,] tadaAxalaniI mino hacaA AlOamori ramDN (tropical:) [Distress and disquietude, or grief,
crept into me from, or in consequence of, this thing: see ramiDotu mina AlOamori.] (A, TA.)

HaSFI ramiDN c
HaSFI ramiDN, (TA,) and OaroDN ramiDapN, (A, TA,) [Pebbles, and ground or land,] vehemently heated by the sun; or intensely heated by the vehement action of the sun thereupon. (A.) And OaroDN ramiDapu AlHajaArapK Land of which the stones are vehemently heated by the sun. (S.) [See also ramoDaMCu↓.] ― -b2- ramiDapN (assumed tropical:) A woman whose thighs rub each other. (Ibn-' Abbád, Sgh, K.)

wajadotu fiI jasadiI ramaDapN c
wajadotu fiI jasadiI ramaDapN (assumed tropical:) I felt in my body what resembled maliylap [or fever in the bones]. (TA.)

ramoDaMCu c
ramoDaMCu, a subst., (TA,) [or rather an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates,] Ground or land, (S, K,) or stones, (A, Mgh, Msb,) or sand, (IAth,) vehemently hot: (K:) or vehemently heated by the sun: (S, A, Mgh, Msb:) or vehemently hot and burning. (IAth.) [See also ramiDN.] ― -b2- It is also syn. with ramaDN as expl. above: see the latter word. (Mgh, TA.)

saHaAbN ramaDiIRN c
saHaAbN ramaDiIRN, and maTarN ramaDiIRN, Clouds, and rain, in the end of summer and the beginning of autumn: (K, TA:) because arriving at the period when the sun is [intensely] hot. (TA.) ― -b2- Almiyrapu AlrRamaDyRapu The wheat, or corn, that is brought, or purveyed, when the earth becomes burnt [by the sun, about July]. (M in art. dfO.) [See art. myr.]

Xahoru ramaDaAna c
Xahoru ramaDaAna, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and ramaDaAnu, alone, for the latter, though disapproved by some of the learned, occurs in a trad., (Mgh, Msb, TA,) and in poetry, (TA,) but not AlrRamaDaAnu, for this is incorrect, (Mgh,) The ninth of the Arabian months: (TA:) so called because, when they changed the names of the months from the ancient language, they named them according to the seasons in which they fell, (Jm, S, K,) and this month, (Jm, S,) or naAtiqN, (K,) for this was its ancient name, (TA,) agreed with the days of vehement heat: (Jm, S, Mgh, Msb, K:) [see zamanN:] or from ramiDN said of a man fasting, expl. above: (Fr, K:) or because [its effect is as though] it burned [and annulled] sins; (K;) from ramaDahu AlHarRu, expl. above; but [SM says,] I know not how that is; for I have not seen any one [except F] mention it: (TA:) the pl. is ramaDaAnaAtN (S, Msb, K) and OaromiDaMCu (S, Msb) and OaromiDapN (L, K) and ramaDaAnuwna (K) and ramaADiynu, (Yoo, Sgh, L, Msb,) like XaEaAbiynu, (Msb,) and OaromuDN, which is anomalous, (IDrd, K,) is asserted by some of the lexicologists to be another pl., but this is not well established nor received. (IDrd.) ― -b2- It is said in a trad. that ramaDaAnu is One of the names of God; but this trad. is pronounced by El-Beyhakee to be of weak authority; and that it is so is evident; as no learned man has transmitted this word as such; (Msb;) [except Mujáhid; for] it is related that Mujáhid disapproved of forming a pl. from it, saying, It has been told me that it is one of the names of God: (TA:) if it be so, it is not derived (K, TA) from what has been here mentioned; (TA;) or it refers to the meaning of (assumed tropical:) The Forgiving; or He who obliterates sins. (K.)

ramiyDN c
ramiyDN: see maromuwDN. ＝ -A2- Also Made thin by being beaten between two stones: (A:) sharpened: (S, K:) sharp: (K, TA:) applied to a knife; (Sh;) and to such as is termed Xaforap; (S, K;) and to a naSol [or blade]; (S;) and to a razor (muwsaI), as also ramiyDapN; (A, TA;) and in the last of the above-mentioned senses, to anything: (S:) it is of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: (TA:) or it may be in the sense of the measure faAEilN, from ramuDa, though this verb may not have been heard. (Sgh, TA.)

ramaADapN c
ramaADapN: see ramuDa.

OaromuDN c
OaromuDN said to be an anomalous pl. of ramaDaAnu, q. v. (IDrd, K.)

maromiDN c
maromiDN The place in which a sheep, or goat, is dressed in the manner described above in the explanation of ramaDa AlXRaApa. (S, TA.)

maromuwDN c
maromuwDN Flesh-meat dressed in the manner described above in the explanation of ramaDa AlXRaApa: (S:) or roasted flesh-meat, such as is termed kaniys, [a word with which I have not met except in this place,] which is nearly the same as Haniyc, save that what is called by this last epithet is divided into fragments, and then a fire is kindled over it; as also ramiyDN↓. (TA.)

1 ramaqahu c
1. ramaqahu, (S, Mgh, K,) aor.
ramuqa
, (S, Mgh,) inf. n. ramoqN, (S,) He looked at him, or it; (S, TA;) as also raAmqhu↓: (TA:) or he glanced lightly at him, or it; looked at him, or it, lightly, from the outer angle of the eye: (IDrd, K, TA:) or he looked long at him, or it; (Mgh;) or so ramaqahu biEayonihi, aor. and inf. n. as above: (Msb:) whence, in a trad., faramaqahu AlnRaAsu biOaboSaArhimo [And the people looked long at him]: (Mgh:) or ramaqotuhu bibaSariI and raAmaqotuhu↓ signify I followed him with my eye, paying attention to him, and watching him: (TA:) and rAmqhu↓, (TA,) inf. n. rimaAqN, (K, * TA,) he looked at him from the outer angle of the eye with a look of enmity: (K, * TA:) and rmRqhu↓, inf. n. taromyqN, he looked at him long from the outer angle of the eye with anger or aversion: (TA:) and rmRq↓, inf. n. as above, he continued looking; like rnRq. (S, TA.)

2 rmRqhu c
2. rmRqhu He, or it, stayed, or arrested, what remained in him of life. (TA.) [Hence,] humo yuramRiquwnahu biXaIoCK They give him something sufficient to stay, or arrest, what remains in him of life. (O, TA.) ― -b2- [The inf. n.] taromiyqN also signifies The scanting of fodder and drink. (JK.) ― -b3- [And The drinking little by little.] One says, ramRadati AlmiEozaI faramRiqo ramRiqo, meaning [The she-goats have secreted milk in their udders: therefore] drink thou their milk little by little; drink thou &c.: (IF, K, TA:) because they secrete milk some days before their bringing forth: (IF, TA:) or because they will bring forth after a while. (K, TA. [See also arts. rmd and rbq and rnq: and see 5 in the present art.]) ― -b4- Also The doing a work not well, yet so as to satisfy oneself, or to attain one's desire, thereby. (K, TA. [See also 3.]) You say, huwayuramRiqu fiI AlXRaIoCi He does not exert himself, or take pains, or exceed the usual bounds, in doing the thing. (TA.) And ramRiqo EalaI mazaAdatayoka Repair thou thy pair of leathern water-bags sufficiently to satisfy thyself. (O, TA.) ― -b5- And The interlarding, or embellishing, of speech, or discourse, with falsehood; taromiyqu AlkalaAmi signifying taloqiyquhu; (Ibn-'Abbád, K;) as also tarobiyquhu. (Ibn-'Abbád and K in art. rbq.) You say, rmRq AlkalaAma He interlarded, or embellished, the speech, or discourse, with falsehood, (lafRaqahu, Z, or lafRaqa bayonahu, JK,) [adding] thing after thing, or thing by thing. (Z, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, in two places.

3 raAomaqa
3: [rAmq seems to signify He strove, or contended, to retain what remained in him of life. And hence, as implying this meaning, He was at the last gasp: see muraAmiq, below. Whence, app.,] the inf. n. muraAmaqapN signifies (assumed tropical:) The having little friendship [remaining in the heart]. (KL. [See, again, muraAmiqN.]) One says, hecihi AlnRaxolapu turaAmiqu biEiroqK laA taHoyaA walaA tamuwtu; or laA yaHoyaA walaA yamuwtu; [as though meaning, accord. to the former reading, This palm-tree strives to retain life with a root, being neither alive nor dead; or, accord. to the latter reading, with a root that is neither alive nor dead;] (S; [in one of my copies of which I find only the former reading; and in the other, both readings;]) or hecihi AlnRaxolapu turaAmiqu biEiroqK means this palm-tree is neither alive nor dead. (K.) And fulaAnN yuraAmiqu EayoXahu i. e. yudaAriyhi [app. meaning Such a one strives by artful means to preserve his life]. (TA.) ― -b2- [The inf. n.] rimaAqN also signifies The being hypocritical, or acting hypocritically; (K, TA;) [like rifaAqN; see 3 in art. rfq;] which is nearly the same in meaning as mudaAraApN; because the hypocrite strives to deceive by lying: mentioned by Hr in the “ Ghareebeyn. ” (TA.) ― -b3- rAmq AlOamora, (S, K,) inf. n. muraAmaqapN, (TA,) He did, or performed, the thing, or affair, unfirmly, or unsoundly. (S, K, TA. [See also 2.]) ＝ -A2- See also 1, in three places.

4 Oaromaqa
4: [Armq is said by Golius, on the authority of a gloss in the KL, to signify He rendered water turbid; for Arnq.]

5 trmRq c
5. trmRq He drank milk little by little. (K. [See also 2.]) And He supped, or sipped, water, (S, K,) &c., sup after sup, or sip after sip. (K.)

9 ArmqR c
9. ArmqR It (a skin, or hide, UihaAbN,) was, or became, thin. (K.) ― -b2- Hence, said of life or the means of subsistence (AlEayoXu) [as meaning (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, narrow in its circumstances, or scanty; like raqRa]. (TA.) ― -b3- It (an affair, S, or a thing, IDrd, K,) was, or became, weak; (IDrd, S, K;) and so ArmAqR↓ said of a rope: (S, K:) or the former verb, said of a rope, it was, or became, weak in its strands. (IDrd, TA.) ― -b4- ArmqRt Alganamu The sheep, or goats, died: (IDrd, K:) and ArmAqRt↓ they (sheep, or goats,) perished, or died,
by reason of leanness, or emaciation: (Ibn- 'Abbád, TA:) or ArmAqR signifies he perished, or died, by reason thereof. (K.) ― -b5- ArmqR AlTRariyqu The road was, or became, long. (TA: but the verb is there written without the sheddeh.)

11 UiromaAoqRa
11: see 9, in two places.

ramaqN c
ramaqN The remains of life, (Lth, K,) or of the spirit, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or of the soul; (IDrd, TA;) or the last breath: (TA:) and applied also to strength: (Msb:) pl. OaromaAqN. (K.) It is said that a man in a case of necessity may eat of that which has died a natural death maAyasudRu AlrRamaqa, i. e. [What will stay, or arrest, the remains of life; or] what will maintain, and preserve, the strength. (Msb.) [In like manner, also,] one says, of sustenance, yumosiku AlrRamaqa [It stays, or arrests, the remains of life; or maintains the strength]. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- See also rumoqapN. ＝ -A2- Also A flock of sheep, or herd of goats: (S, K:) a Pers. word, (S,) arabicized, (S, K,) from ramaho. (K.)

EayoXF ramiqN c
EayoXF ramiqN Sustenance that stays, or arrests, the remains of life; or that maintains the strength; expl. by yumosiku AlrRamaqa. (IF, Msb, K.) ＝ -A2- [And accord. to Golius, on the authority of a gloss in the KL, ramiqN is used for rawonaqN, as signifying Fairness, beauty, or brightness: and also as meaning Bright, and clear.]

rumuqN c
rumuqN, a pl., signifying Poor men, who are satisfied with little sustenance, such as suffices to stay, or arrest, the remains of life, or to maintain the strength: ― -b2- and envying persons: sing. raAmiqN↓ and ramuwqN↓: (IAar, K, TA:) which signifies one. who looks at men from the outer angle of the eye and with envy. (IAar, TA.)

maA fiI EayoXihi UilRaA rumoqapN c
maA fiI EayoXihi UilRaA rumoqapN, (JK, K,) with damm, (K,) or ramaqapN↓, (S, [so in both of my copies,]) and rimaAqN↓, (S,) or ramaAqN↓, (JK,) or both, and ramaqN↓, (K,) There is not in his means of subsistence save what is but just sufficient: (S, K:) or a small supply, that may stay, or arrest, the remains of life, or that may maintain the strength. (K.) The Arabs said, mawotN laA yajurRu UilaI EaArK xayorN mino EayoXK fiI ramaAqK↓ [Death that does not lead to disgrace is better than life with a bare sufficiency of sustenance]. (Yaakoob, TA.)

ramaqapN c
ramaqapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

ramaAqN c
ramaAqN: see rumoqapN, in two places.

rimaAqN c
rimaAqN, Straitness, or narrowness, of the means of subsistence. (K. [In the CK, for AlDRiyqu is put AlDRayRiqu, which makes the meaning to be “ strait, ” or “ narrow, ” as applied to the means of subsistence.]) ― -b2- See also rumoqapN.

ramuwqN c
ramuwqN: see rumuqN.

rumRaqN c
rumRaqN Weak; (K;) applied to a man. (TA.)

raAmiqN c
raAmiqN, applied to a man, i. q. cuw ramaqK [i. e. Having, or retaining, remains of life: a possessive epithet, of the class of laAbinN and taAmirN & c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also rumuqN. [And see muraAmiqN.] ＝ -A2- Also The bird that the sportsman sets up in order that the falcon, or hawk, may alight upon it and so he may capture it; (K;) also called raAmijN and milowaAHN: he takes an owl, and ties something black to its leg, and sews up its eyes, and ties to its shanks a long string; and when the falcon, or hawk, alights upon it, he captures it from his lurking-place: mentioned by Lth and by IDrd; and thought by the latter to be not a genuine Arabic word. (TA.)

HabolN OaromaAqN c
HabolN OaromaAqN [in which the latter word is a pl., like OaromaAvN in the phrase HabolN OaromaAvN,] A rope that is weak, (S, K, TA,) old and worn out. (TA.)

EayoXN muromaqRN c
EayoXN muromaqRN and muramRaqN↓ Mean, paltry, or scanty, means of subsistence. (S, O.) And huwa muromaqRu AlEayoXi, (A 'Obeyd, K,) and muramRaquhu↓, (IDrd, K,) He is one who has mean, paltry, or scanty, means of subsistence: (A 'Obeyd, K:) or he is straitened in the means of subsistence. (IDrd, K.) ― -b2- muromaqRN also signifies Anything bad, or corrupt. (TA.)

muramRaqN c
muramRaqN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

muraAmiqN c
muraAmiqN One who is at the last gasp. (TA.) [See also raAmiqN.] ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) One who has but little love, or affection, for thee remaining in his heart. (S, K.)

yaromuwqN c
yaromuwqN A weak-sighted man. (IDrd, K.)

1 ramaka biAlmakaAni c
1. ramaka biAlmakaAni, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
ramuka
, (S,) inf. n. rumuwkN, (S, K,) He remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in the place, (S, Msb, K,) not quitting it: or he did so being fatigued, or wearied, or distressed: (K:) or ramaka signifies he (a man) made his home, or constant residence, in a country, or town. (AZ, TA.) ― -b2- ramakati AlmaAXiyapu, (O,) or AlUibilu, (K,) inf. n. as above, (O,) The cattle were confined, (O,) or the camels kept constantly, (K,) at the water, (O, K,) and were fed with fodder. (O.) ― -b3- ramaka fiI AlTRaEaAmi, aor. and inf. n. as above, [app. He kept constantly to the food;] he loathed nothing of the food: and so rajana, aor.
ramuka
, inf. n. rujuwnN: (L, TA:) both mentioned by Lh. (TA in art. rjn.) ＝ -A2- ramaka, said of a man, also signifies He was, or became, lean, or emaciated, and what was in his hands went away. (O, TA. [See also 9: and see ramakapN, as applied to a man.]) ― -b2- [It seems also that this verb is used in a similar sense in relation to a beast; like ArmkR said of a camel: for it is immediately added in the O and TA without any explanation, that one also says, hecihi daAbRapN raAmikapN↓, as though meaning This is a lean beast: and ramakato, inf. n. rumuwkN, as though meaning It was, or became, lean.]

4 Oaromakotuhu c
4. Oaromakotuhu I made him to remain, stay, dwell, or abide, in a place, (S, K,) not quitting it. (K.) ― -b2- And Armk AlUibila He (a pastor) kept the camels constantly at the water, and fed them with fodder. (TA.)

9 ArmkR c
9. ArmkR He was, or became, of the colour termed rumokapN: said of a camel in this sense [and in another expl. in what follows]. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- It (a thing, Ibn-'Abbád, O) was, or became, thin, or slender. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) And He (a camel) was, or became, lean, lank, light of flesh; slender; or lean, and lank in the belly; and emaciated. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K. [In the CK, nahika is erroneously put for nuhika.])

10 Aisotaromaka Alqawomu c
10. Aisotaromaka Alqawomu (tropical:) The people were deemed ignoble; (K, TA;) as being likened to the ramakap. (TA.)

ramakN c
ramakN: see ramakapN. ― -b2- In the saying of Ru-beh,
yarobiDu fiI AlrRawovi kabirocawoni AlrRamako
[That lies down upon his breast in the dung of horses, or similar beasts, like the jade, or hack, of the ramak], AA says, Alrmk, here, is from the Pers. ramaho [which means a “ herd," ” “ flock, ” “ troop, ” or the like]; and he adds that the people's saying that it means AlrRamakap is a mistake. (O, TA. [Perhaps, however, AA knew not ramakN as a coll. gen. n. of which ramakapN is the n. un.; for as such it seems to me more reasonable to regard it in this instance.])

rumokapN c
rumokapN A certain colour of camels; accord. to A 'Obeyd, a dun colour; i. e. a kNmotap [or brown hue] so intense as to have in it a blackness: (S:) thus explained by As: (TA:) or, in the colours of camels, brownness; i. e. redness intermixed with blackness: (Kr, TA:) or a colour more dusky, or dingy, than that which is termed zuroqap [q. v.]: (Msb:) or the colour of ashes: (K:) or wuroqapN [which is a colour like that of ashes] inclining to blackness: or, as some say, duwna Alwuroqapi [less intense than what is termed warqp]: (TA:) it sometimes has for its pl. rumukN, with two dammehs. (ISd, TA.)

ramakapN c
ramakapN A mare: and [particularly] a birocawonap [or mare of mean breed], (Lth, Mgh, K,) the female of the baraAciyn, (S, Msb,) that is taken for breeding: (Lth, Mgh, K:) pl. rimaAkN, (S, Mgh, Msb,) accord. to rule, (Mgh,) and, ramakaAtN, (S,) and OaromaAkN, (Fr, S, Mgh,) formed on the supposition of the elision of the p, (Mgh,) or this is a pl. pl., and the pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] is ramakN↓. (K.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) A weak man. (K.)

raAmakN c
raAmakN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

raAmikN c
raAmikN Remaining, staying, dwelling, or abiding, in a place, (Msb, K,) not quitting: or especially, when fatigued, or wearied, or distressed. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, last sentence. ＝ -A3- Also, and raAmakN↓, (S, Msb, K,) the former of which is the more usual, or more approved, (TA,) A certain thing, black, (S, Msb, K,) like pitch, (Msb,) that is mixed with musk, (S, Msb, K,) and is then called (yujoEalu) musk. (Msb.) [Freytag, as on the authority of the K, in which nothing more is said respecting it than what I have given above, describes it thus: “ Res ex aliis rebus composita, nempe atramento sutorio, mali Punici cortice, gummi Arabico aliisque rebus, quibus admisceri solet muscus. ”] A poet says, (S,) namely, Khalaf Ibn-Khaleef El-Akta', (O, TA,)
UinRa laka AlfaDola EalaI SuHobatiI
waAlmisoku qado yasotaSoHibu AlrRaAmakaA
[Verily thou hast such excellence as renders thee above my companionship; but musk sometimes unites with rAmk]. (S, O.) ― -b2-
[raAmakN↓, from the Pers. raAmako, is also the name of A certain astringent medicine, used as a remedy for dysentery &c. In the printed edition of the “ Kánoon ” of Ibn-Seenà (Avicenna), book ii. p. 253, it is erroneously written rmk.]

Oaromaku c
Oaromaku Of the colour termed rumokapN: (S, Msb, K:) applied to a camel: fem. ramokaMCu. (S, Msb.) The rmkMC is said by Honeyf-el-Hanátim, who was one of the most skilled of the Arabs respecting camels, to be the most beautiful of she-camels. (TA.) The fem. is also applied, tropically, to a woman. (Th, TA.) ― -b2- A poet says, [applying it to dust,]
waAlxayolu tajotaAbu AlgubaAra AlOaromakaA
[And the horses, or horsemen, cleave the dark brown, or ash-coloured, &c., dust]. (TA.) ― -b3- And it is said in a trad., [but to what it relates I know not,] The name of the higher, or highest, land is AlrRamokaMCu; said by IAth to be fem. of AlOaromaku. (TA.)

1 ramala c
1. ramala as syn. with ramRala: see the latter in two places. ＝ -A2- ramala AlHaSiyra, [aor. app.
ramula
, and inf. n. ramolN;] and Armlhu↓; He wove (nasaja, A 'Obeyd, T, or safRa, A 'Obeyd, S) the mat [of palm-leaves or the like]. (T, S.) [Or] ramala AlsRariyra, and [so in the M, but in the K “ or ”] AlHaSiyra, aor.
ramula
, inf. n. ramolN, He ornamented the couch, and the mat, with jawohar [i. e. jewels, precious stones, gems, &c.], and the like. (M, K.) [Or] AlHaSiyra Arml↓, and ramalahu, He made the weaving of the mat thin (Har p. 55.) And ramala AlnRasoja, (M, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above; (TA;) and Armlhu↓, and rmRlhu↓; (M, K; the last omitted in the TA;) He made the woven thing, or the weaving, thin. (M, K.) And ramala AlsRariyra, (S, K,) [aor. and] inf. n. as above; (TA;) and Armlhu↓; He wove (ramala) XariyT [or palm leaves split and then plaited together], (S, O, K,) or some other thing, (S, O,) and made the same a back (jaEalahu ZahorFA) to the couch. (S, O, K. [What is here called the “ back ” of the couch is app. so called as being likened to the back of a beast on which one rides: see rumaAlN.]) Accord. to IKt, ramalotu Alsyr [app. a mistranscription for AlsRariyra] and Oaromalotuhu↓ signify I wove the syr [or the sryr] with a XariyT of leaves, or fibres, of the palm-tree. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ramalotu Alqawola and AlwaSofa [(assumed tropical:) I wove, i. e. composed, the saying and the description]. (Phrases cited in the TA from two modern poets.) ＝ -A3- ramala, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
ramula
, (T, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. ramalaAnN (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and ramalN (S, M, &c.) and maromalN, (K,) said of a man, i. q. harowala [i. e. He went a kind of trotting pace, between a walk and a run]; (S, Mgh, Msb, K; [in the M said to be “ less than AlmaXoIu and above AlEadowu; ” app., as is remarked in the TT, through inadvertence of a writer;]) i. e. (TA) he was quick in his manner of walking, (T, TA,) and shook his shoulder-joints, (TA,) leaping, (so in the T accord. to the TT,) or not leaping, (so in the TA,) in doing so; (T, TA;) while performing the circuitings round the Kaabeh, (T, Mgh, TA,) but only in some of those circuitings, exclusively of others, (TA,) which one does in imitation of the Prophet and his Companions, who did thus in order that the people of Mekkeh might know that there was in them strength; (T, TA;) and in going between Es-Safà and El-Marweh. (S, TA.) [It is also said of a camel: see rataka.] ＝ -A4- ramalN as an inf. n. [app. of ramila AlEaAmu or ramilati AlsRanapu] signifies The year's having little rain. (KL.) ― -b2- ramilato mino zawojihaA: see 4.

2 rmRlhu c
2. rmRlhu, (M, TA,) inf. n. taromiylN, (TA,) He put ramol [i. e. sand] into it; namely, food; (M, TA;) and (TA) so ramalahu↓, (Ibn-'Abbád, K, TA,) aor.
ramula
, inf. n. ramolN; but the former verb is the more chaste. (TA.) Hence, in a trad. respecting [the eating of the flesh of] domestic asses, Oamara Oano tukofaOa Alquduwru waOano yuramRala AllRaHomu biAltRuraAbi, meaning [He ordered that the cooking-pots should be turned upside-down, and] that the flesh should be stirred about and mixed with dust, in order that no use might be made of it. (TA.) ― -b2- And He defiled, or smeared, him, or it, with blood; (S, M, TA;) namely, a man, (S,) or a garment, and the like; (M, TA;) and (TA) so ramalahu↓; (K TA;) but in this sense also the former verb is the more chaste. (TA.) And rumRila fulaAnN biAldRami Such a one was defiled, or smeared, with blood. (T, TA. [See also 4 and 5.]) ― -b3- In relation to speech, or language, (TA,) AltRaromiylu signifies (tropical:) i. q. AltRazoyiyfu; (K, TA; [in the CK, erroneously, AltRaroniyfu;]) i. e., [as inf. n. of ramRala, The adulterating it, corrupting it, or rendering it unsound, or untrue; and as inf. n. of rumRila,] its being [adulterated, corrupted, or] unsound, or untrue. (TA. [See the pass. part. n., below.]) ― -b4- See also 1. ＝ -A2- And see 4.

4 Arml c
4. Arml It (a place) became sandy; had ramol in it or upon it. (Msb.) ― -b2- [And He clave to the sand.] ― -b3- And [hence,] (assumed tropical:) He became poor: (Mgh:) or (assumed tropical:) his provisions, or travelling-provisions, became difficult to obtain, and he became poor: (Msb:) or his travelling-provisions went: (Mgh:) and OaromaluwA (tropical:) their provisions, or travel-ling-provisions, became exhausted, or consumed: (A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, K, TA:) from AlrRamolu; (Mgh, TA;) as though [he or] they clave to the sand; (TA;) like OadoqaEa, (Mgh,) or OadoqaEuwA, (TA,) from AldRaqoEaMCu: (Mgh, TA:) or from ramalN meaning “ little rain: ” or from Oaromala AlHaSiyra and ramalahu meaning “ he made the weaving of the mat thin: ” (Har p. 55:) and ArmlwA zaAdahumo (tropical:) They exhausted, or consumed, their provisions, or travelling-provisions. (K, * TA. [In the TT, as from the M, Atxcwh is erroneously put for Oanofaduwhu, the explanation in the TA.]) ― -b4- And [hence,] Armlt, (Yz, T, S, Msb,) or, accord. to Sh, Armlt mino zawojihaA, or mn zwjhA ramilatN↓; (T, accord. to different copies;) and ramRalato↓ [alone], (K, TA, [said in the latter to be on the authority of Sh, and therefore it may perhaps be taken from a copy of the T,]) inf. n. taromiylN; (TA;) (tropical:) She (a woman) became such as is termed OaromalapN, (T, Msb, K, TA,) i. e. without a husband; (T, Msb;) because of her being in need of one to expend upon her; [for] Az says that she is not thus called unless she be also poor: (Msb:) or [she became a widow;] she lost her husband by his death. (S.) ― -b5- And Arml said of an arrow, It became defiled, or smeared, with blood, (Ibn- 'Abbád, K, TA,) and had the mark thereof remaining upon it; (Ibn-'Abbád, TA;) and so Artml↓. (TA. [See also 2 and 5.]) ＝ -A2- Said of a poet, it is from AlrRamalu, like Oarojaza from AlrRajazu; (TA;) i. e. He versified, or composed verses, in the metre termed AlrRamalu. (Ibn-Buzurj, L in art. qSd.) ＝ -A3- As a trans. v.: see 1, in five places. ― -b2- Also He lengthened, or made long, a rope, or cord: (K:) and in like manner, he lengthened, and widened; or made long, and wide; a shackle, or shackles: you say, Arml lahu fiI qayodihi He lengthened, and widened, or made long, and made wide, for him his shackle, or shackles. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.)

5 trmRl c
5. trmRl He became defiled, or smeared, (T, S,) with his blood, (T,) or with blood; as also Artml↓. (S. [See also 2 and 4.])

8 Uirotamala
8: see 4 and 5. ＝ -A2- You say also, Artmlt fulaAnapu fiI baniyhaA (assumed tropical:) Such a woman maintained, or undertook the maintenance of, her children, her husband having died. (O, TA. [But in both I find fI bythA, an obvious mistranscription, for which I read fI baniyhaA; and in the explanation, in both, AqAmt Elyhm, for which I read qaAmato Ealayohimo.])

ramolN c
ramolN [Sand;] a kind of dust or earth, (M,) well known: (Lth, T, M, Msb, K:) ramolapN↓ is its n. un.; (M, K;) a more special term than the former; (S;) signifying a piece, or portion, [or tract, or collection,] thereof: (Lth, T, TA:) [and the former word is also sometimes used as meaning a tract, or collection, of sand:] the pl. [of mult.] is ramaAlN (Lth, T, S, M, Msb, K) and [of pauc.] OaromulN; (M, K;) [and Oaramilu is used as a pl. pl., i. e. pl. of OaromulN; occurring in a verse cited in the TA, art. hj.] ― -b2- [Hence,] OumRu rimaAlK a name of The hyena. (ISk, S.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] AlrRamolu, (TA in this art., [in the Lexicons of Golius and Freytag, erroneously, ramalN,]) or Eilomu AlrRamoli, i. q. Eilomu AlxaTRi, (IAar, TA in art. xT,) [Geomancy,] a certain well-known science. (TA in the present art. [See a description of it voce xaTRa.])

ramalN c
ramalN Weak rain: (IAar, T:) or little rain: (Har p. 55:) or a small quantity of rain: (ElUmawee, T, S, M, K:) one says, OaSaAbahumo ramalN mino maTarK A small quantity of rain fell upon them: (El-Umawee, T, M:) but Sh says, “ I have not heard ramalN in this sense except on the authority of El-Umawee: ” (TA:) the pl. is OaromaAlN. (T, S, M.) ― -b2- [Hence, perhaps,] OaromaAlN mino UibilK A number of camels in a state of dispersion. (TA.) ― -b3-
Also, the sing., [as a coll. gen. n.,] Lines, or streaks, upon the legs of the wild cow, (S, M, K,) upon her fore legs and kind legs, (M,) differing from the rest of her colour: (S, M, K:) n. un. ramalapN↓. (TA. [See also rumolapN.]) ― -b4- And A redundance, or an excess, (ziyaAdapN,) in a thing. (K.) ＝ -A2- AlrRamalu is also the name of A certain kind of metre of verse; (T, S, M, K;) [the eighth kind;] the measure of which is [originally] composed of faAEilaAtuno (T, TA) six times; (TA;) so called from AlrRamalu signifying “ a certain kind of walk or pace, ” inf. n. of ramala [q. v.]: (M, K: *) and Kh says that it is also applied to any meagre verse or poetry, incongruous in structure; such being so named by the Arabs without their defining anything respecting it; as, for instance, the saying [of 'Abeed Ibn-El-Abras (TA in arts. cnb and qTb)],
faAlquTabiyRaAtu faAlcRanuwbu
Oaqofara mino Oaholihi maloHwbu
[Melhoob (the name of a place, K in art. lHb) has become destitute of its inhabitants, and El- Kutabeeyát, (by which is meant a certain water, called AlquTabiyRapu, with its environs, K* and TA in art. qTb,) and Edh-Dhanoob (the name of a place, TA in art. cnb)]: he says also that, generally, the majozuwoC [i. e. what is curtailed of two of the original feet, or what consists of two feet only,] is thus called by them: accord. to IJ, it is applied by them to verse, or poetry, that is incongruous, unsound, or faulty, in structure, and such as falls short of the original [standard so as not to answer completely to any regular kind or species]: (M, TA:) thus it signifies as first explained above, and also any verse, or poetry, that is not such as is termed qaSiyd [as meaning that of which the hemistichs are complete] nor such as is termed rajaz [which some hold to be not verse, or poetry, but a kind of rhyming prose]. (IJ, M, K. *) [See also zamalN.]

ramolapN c
ramolapN: see ramolN, of which it is the n. un.

rumolapN c
rumolapN sing. of rumalN, which signifies The diversity of colours (waXoIN) upon the legs of the wild bull: (T: [see also ramalN:]) or rumolapN signifies a black line or streak, (IKh, M, IB, K,) as some say, (M,) such as is upon the back and thighs of the gazelle: (IKh, IB:) pl. [of mult.] rumalN and [of pauc.] OaromaAlN. (K.)

ramalapN c
ramalapN: see ramalN.

ramoliIRN c
[ramoliIRN Of, or relating to, ramol (or sand): sandy.]

rumaAlN c
rumaAlN The woven work of a mat. (K, TA.) It is said in a trad., of the Prophet, that he was lying upon his side on the rmAl of a mat, which had made an impression upon his side: (T, TA: *) or, as some relate it, of a couch; meaning, in this case, that its face was woven of palm-leaves, and that it had nothing spread upon it to lie upon, but the mat only. (TA. [See ramala AlsRariyra.])

ramiylapN c
ramiylapN Land (OaroD) rained upon with AlrRamal, i. e. little rain. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.)

ramRaAlN c
ramRaAlN A practiser of the science called AlrRamolu [i. e. geomancy]. (TA.)

raAmilapN c
raAmilapN sing. of rawaAmilu, (TA,) which signifies Female weavers of mats. (T, TA.)

Oaromalu c
Oaromalu i. q. muromilN↓, meaning (assumed tropical:) A man whose provisions, or travelling-provisions, have become difficult to obtain, [or exhausted, or consumed, (see 4,)] and who has become poor: [as though he were cleaving to the sand: (see again 4:)] pl. OaraAmilu: (Msb:) or Oaromalu is applied to a man, and OaromalapN↓ to a woman, (M, K,) and the latter also to a pl. number, (M,) as meaning needy, needing, or in want: (M, K:) or as meaning [misokiynN and] misokiynapN [and masaAkiynu, i. e. destitute, or indigent, &c.]: (K:) and the pl. is OaraAmilu and OaraAmilapN; (M, K;) after the manner of substs., because the quality of a subst. is predominant therein: (M:) OaromalapN↓ is applied to any collective number of men and women, or men without women, or women without men, after they have become in need or want: (M:) [and] it is applied [also] to a man and to a woman as meaning poor so as to be unable to obtain anything: (T, and Mgh as from the T:) accord. to ISk, OaraAmilu is applied to a number of men and women, as meaning masaAkiynu [expl. above]; (T, S, Mgh;) or so to a number of persons whether men or women; (Msb;) and to men though there be not among them women; (T, S, Mgh;) and so OaromalapN↓: (T, Mgh:) or this last, to a number of men and women needy, needing, or in want; (S;) and to men needy, needing, or in want, and weak, (S, K,) though there be not among them women. (S.) Ibn-Buzurj mentions the saying, UinR bayota fulaAnK laDaxomN maA yuHomRiluwnahu UilRaA maA QsotafoqaruwA lahu waUinRahumo laOaromalapu↓, meaning [Verily the household of such a one is large, and verily they are destitute of what camels they may load therewith except] what they borrow [for that purpose]; (T, * TA;) i. e., they are a party not possessing camels, and unable to make a journey except upon camels that they borrow; [AstfqrwA being] from Oufoqira Zahora baEiyriI signifying “ he was lent the back of my camel. ” (TA.) See also OuromuwlapN. ― -b2- OaromalapN↓ is also applied to a woman as meaning Having no husband: (T, S, M, Msb, K:) or a widow; one whose husband has died: (IAmb, Mgh:) or not if she possesses competence, or wealth: (Ibn-Buzurj, T, Mgh, Msb, K:) it is applied to her who has no husband because she is in need of him who would expend upon her; (Msb;) or to her whose husband has died because her provision has gone and she has lost him who earned for her (IAmb, Mgh) and by means of whom her state of life had been good: (IAmb:) in like manner, also, Oaromalu is applied to a man as meaning having no wife, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) accord. to Kt (T, Mgh) and Sh; (Mgh;) like as OayRimN is applied to a man [as well as to a woman], and OayRimapN to a woman: (T:) or a widower; one whose wife has died: (TA:) or Oaromalu is not applied in this sense except in cases of deviation from the usual course of speech, (IAmb, Mgh, Msb, [and the like is said in the Mgh also as on the authority of Lth, and in the M as on the authority of IJ,]) because the man's provision does not go in consequence of the death of his wife, since she is not his maintainer, (IAmb, Mgh, Msb,) whereas he is her maintainer: (IAmb:) Jereer says,
kulRu AlOaraAmili qado qaDayota HaAjatahaA
famano liHaAjapi hecaA AlOaramali AlcRakari
(M, TA,) or heciI AlOaraAmilu Alx; (S, Mgh; [in the former ascribed in one of my copies to an unnamed poet, and in the other, to El-Hotei-ah; but in the Mgh, to Jereer, as in the M;]) [i. e. All the widows, or these widows, thou hast accomplished their want; but who is there for the want of this male widowed person]; meaning thereby himself. (M, TA.) It is said that, if one bequeath his property to the OaraAmil, some of it is to the men whose wives have died: (Mgh:) IB says, on the authority of IKt, that when a man says, “ This property is for the OaraAmil, ” it is for the men and the women, because AlOaraAmilu applies to the males and the women; but he adds, IAmb says that it is to be given to the women exclusively of the men, because AlArAml generally applied to the women. (TA. [This is cited in the TA as though relating to ArAml as meaning masaAkiyn: but IAmb evidently uses it here as applying to women whose husbands have died; and this is its predominant meaning.]) ― -b3- It is also applied to a [lizard of the kind called] DabR, in the following saying of a rájiz,
OuHbRu Oano OaSoTaAda DabRFA saHobalaA
raEaI AlrRabiyEa waAlXRitaMCa OaromalaA
(T, TA,) meaning [I love to hunt out, or catch, a large DbR, that has pastured during the autumn and the winter,] having no female, so that he may be fat. (TA.) ― -b4- And one says also EaAmN Oaromalu (ISk, T, S, M, K) and sanapN ramolaMCu (ISk, T, S, M) meaning (tropical:) A year of little rain (ISk, T, S, M, K, TA) and of little good or benefit. (T, M, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also i. q. Oabolaqu [i. e. Black and white: or white in the kind legs as high as the thighs]: (AA, T:) or a sheep or goat of which all the legs are black: fem. ramolaMCu: (A 'Obeyd, S:) or the latter is applied to a ewe as meaning of which the legs are black, the rest of her being white. (AZ, T, M, K.)

OaromalapN c
OaromalapN as fem. of Oaromalu, and as an epithet applied to a pl. number of persons: see the next preceding paragraph in five places.

OuromuwlapN c
OuromuwlapN, as an epithet applied to a boy, or young man, (gulaAmN, Lth, T, Ibn-'Abbád, K,) i. q. Oaromalu↓ [as meaning Poor, needy, or the like]; (Ibn- 'Abbád, K;) accord. to Lth, (T, TA,) i. q. zaAraho [i. e. abject] in Persian: (T, M, TA: [but in two copies of the T zaAcaho; and in the TT, as from the M, zaAzaho:]) but Az says, I know not AlOuromuwlapu, nor the Persian rendering thereof. (T.) ＝ -A2- Also The stump (jucomuwr) of the [plant, or tree, called] Earofaj: pl. OaraAmilu and OaraAmiylu: (K:) or OaraAmilu AlEarfaji signifies the stocks, or stems, (OuSuwl, [but
this sometimes means stumps, as well as roots, &c.,]) of the Erfj. (M.)

muromalN c
muromalN: see maromuwlN.

muromilN c
muromilN A man whose provisions, or travellingprovisions, are exhausted, or consumed. (A'Obeyd, T.) See also Oaromalu, first sentence. ＝ -A2- See also AlmuramRilu.

miromalN c
miromalN A small qayod [i. e. shackle or pair of shackles]. (IAar, T, K.)

TaEaAmN muramRalN c
TaEaAmN muramRalN [Food, or wheat,] into which sand (AlrRamol) has been thrown. (TT, as from the T.) And xabiySN muramRalN [A mess of dates and clarified butter mixed together] into which dust, or earth, and sand, have been put: (so in a copy of the T: [but this seems to be a mistake, occasioned by the omission of what here follows:]) [or] such as has been much stirred about and turned over (K, TA, and so in the TT, as from the T) [app. with coarse flour (see jariyXN)] so that it has complicated streaks. (TA, and so in the TT, as from the T.) ― -b2- And kalaAmN muramRalN (tropical:) [Speech, or language, adulterated, corrupted, or] rendered unsound, or untrue: like TaEaAmN muramRalN. (TA.)

AlmuramRilu c
AlmuramRilu The lion; [app. because he smears his prey with blood;] as also Almuromilu↓. (O, K.)

maromuwlN c
maromuwlN A mat woven [of palm-leaves or the like (see 1)]; as also muromalN↓. (A 'Obeyd, T, TA.)

yaromuwlN c
yaromuwlN Palm-leaves (xuwSN) woven together. (K, * TA.)

rumRaAnN c
rumRaAnN [The pomegranate;] a certain fruit, (T,) the produce of a certain tree, (M,) well known: (T, S, M, K:) n. un. with p: (S, M, Msb, K:) the sweet sort thereof relaxes the state of the bowels, and cough; the sour sort has the contrary effect; and that which is between sweet and sour is good for inflammation of the stomach, and pain of the heart: the rmRAn has six flavours, like the apple; and is commended for its delicacy, its quick dissolving, and its niceness, or its elegance: (K:) rumRaAnN is of the measure fuEolaAnN accord. to Sb: (M in art. rm:) Kh, being asked by Sb respecting AlrRumRaAn, (S,) or [rather] respecting rumRaAn, (M in art. rm,) when used as a proper name, (S,) said that he declined it imperfectly (S, M) when [thus made] determinate; (S;) and that he made it to accord to the majority, because its derivation is unknown, (S, M, *) i. e., that he regarded its A and n as augmentative: (S:) but accord. to Akh, the n is radical, (S,) [i. e.] he held it to be of the measure fuERaAlN, making it to accord to many similar names of plants, (M,) like HumRaADN &c., (S, M,) fuERaAlN being more common than fuEolaAn; (S;) he meant, as applied to plants; for otherwise the contr. is the case: (TA:) [Fei says,] the measure is fuERaAlN, the n being radical, and therefore the word is perfectly decl., unless when used as a proper name, in which case it is imperfectly decl., being made to accord to the majority [of proper names ending with A and n, as EuvomaAnu &c.]. (Msb.) [Freytag mentions several varieties of rmRAn, as follows: but the names, as given by him and here transcribed, require verification or correction: “ rmAn AlqsTysI, rmAn AlmrsI, rmAn AlEdsI, rmAn AlxzAynI, rmAn AltrHyn, rmAn AlmrwnI, qui ad speciem dulcium pertinent: tum rmAn XErI dulce et corticem tenuissimum habens: rmAn AmlysI Malum Punicum maximum, esu gratissimum et acinorum expers: rmAn AlsHI, rmAn AldlwI, rmAn AldwArI, sunt minoris magnitudinis, formæ rotundæ: rmAn AlsfryA Malum Punicum magnitudine et sapore præstantissimum, a viro Sefri dicto ita appellatum, quod a Syria Cordubam regnante Abd-Alrahmano hanc speciem transtulerat: ” and he refers to “ Casiri, Bibl. Ar. Hisp. T. i. p. 329; and Avicenn. L. ii. p. 254; ” the latter of which authors only mentions the properties of the rmRAn.] ― -b2- rumRaAnu AlsRaEaAliI [in the CK AlsRuEAlaI] The white xaXoxaAX [or poppy]: or a species thereof. (K. [The heads of the poppy are called rumRaAnu AlxaXoxaAXi because of their resemblance to pomegranates.]) ― -b3- rumRaAnu AlOanohaAri [Androsæmum; or hypericum majus;] the large species of hayuwfaAriyquwn. (K.) ― -b4- [In the present day, rumRaAnN and more properly rumRaAnataAni are used as meaning (assumed tropical:) A young woman's breasts, when small and round; they being likened to pomegranates. In a saying of Umm-Zara, (mentioned in the M in art. rm,) rumRaAnataAni seems to be used in this sense, or as meaning a woman's posteriors.] ― -b5- The n. un., rumRaAnapN, is also used, vulgarly, as meaning (assumed tropical:) The qaTinap [or third stomach, commonly called the manyplies, and by some the millet, of a ruminant animal]: (K in art. qTn:) or it signifies (assumed tropical:) the thing [or part] in which is the fodder, of the horse. (M and TA in art. rm and in the present art.) One says, malaOati AldRaAbRapu rumRaAnatahaA (assumed tropical:) [The beast filled its rmRAnp]. (TA.) And Oakala HatRaI nataOato rumRaAnatahu, meaning (assumed tropical:) He ate until his navel with the parts around it projected. (TA.) ― -b6- [(assumed tropical:) A knob of metal, of wood, and of silk, &c.: so called as resembling in shape a pomegranate.] ― -b7- And [for the same reason] (assumed tropical:) The weight of a steelyard, or Roman balance. (MA.) [Also applied in the present day to (assumed tropical:) The steelyard itself; and so ruwmaAnap.]

rumRaAnapN c
rumRaAnapN n. un. of rumRaAnN [in the proper sense of this word, and also in several tropical senses expl. in the latter part of the next preceding paragraph]. (S, M, Msb, K.)

rumRaAniIRN c
rumRaAniIRN [Of, or relating to, the pomegranate. ― -b2- ] A seller of rumRaAn [or pomegranates]. (TA.) ― -b3- [Of the colour of the pomegranate. ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) Rubycoloured. ― -b5- And, accord. to Golius, on the authority of a gloss in a copy of the KL, (assumed tropical:) The ruby itself.]

rumRaAniyRapN c
rumRaAniyRapN A kind of food prepared with pomegranates. (KL.)

rumayomiynapN c
rumayomiynapN dim. of rumRaAnN [or rather of rumRaAnapN, the n. un.]. (TA.)

maromanapN c
maromanapN A place of growth of rumRaAn [or pomegranates], (T, K,) when they, (K,) or their stems, (T,) are numerous therein. (T, K.)

rimFA c
rimFA, mentioned under this head in the M, see the art. here following.

1 ramaI AlXRaIoCa c
