1. ramaI AlXRaIoCa, (T, * S, M, K,) aor. yaromiI, (T,) inf. n. ramoIN; (T, M;) and ramaI bihi; (M, K;) He threw, cast, or flung, the thing, (S, K,) mino yadihi from his hand; (S, TA;) as also ArmI↓; (M, K;) i. e. ArmI AlXRaIoCa mino yadihi: (M: [in the K it is implied that one says also bahi ArmI↓; agreeably with a phrase mentioned in what follows:]) you say, AlHajara mino yadiI Oaromayotu↓ I threw the stone from my hand: (S:) and Alfarasu biraAkibihi ArmI↓ The horse threw, or threw down, [i. e. threw off,] his rider: (T:) ramayotu AlrRajula is said UicaA ramayotahu biyadika; [i. e., as meaning ramayotuhu biyadiI; which may be rendered I threw him (the man) with my hand; and also I threw, or shot, at him (the man) with my hand;] but when you remove him from his place, you say, Eani Alfarasi wagayorihi Oaromayotuhu↓ [I threw him, or threw him down or off, from the horse &c.]: (Msb:) and Eano farasihi TaEanahu faOaromaAhu↓, meaning [He thrust him, or pierced him, with his spear,] and threw him, or threw him down [or off], from his horse: (El-Fárábee, S, Msb:) and AlHimola Eano Zahori AlbaEiyri Oaromayotu↓ I threw down the load from the back of the camel. (T.) wamaA ramayota Uico ramayota walekinRa QllReha ramaI, in the Kur [viii. 17], is said by Aboo-Is-hák to be tropical, and to mean (tropical:) And thou didst not cast [in effect, or] so as to attain the point that was attained, [when thou didst cast,] but God [cast in effect, i. e.,] overruled the casting: or, accord. to Abu-l-' Abbás, the meaning is, (assumed tropical:) thou didst not cast fear, or terror, into their hearts, when thou didst cast the pebbles, [but God cast the fear, or terror:] or, accord. to Mbr, (assumed tropical:) thou didst not cast with thy strength, when thou didst cast, but with the strength of God thou didst cast [so that in effect God cast]. (T. [See also another explanation in what follows.]) ― -b2- [ramaI bisaloHihi He cast forth his excrement, or ordure, or properly, in a thin state, is a phrase of frequent occurrence.] ― -b3- You say also, ramayotu biAlsRahomi [I shot the arrow], inf. n. ramoIN and rimaAyapN. (S.) And ramaI Eani Alqawosi, (S, M, Msb,) or ramaI AlsRahoma Ean Alqawosi, (Mgh, * K,) and EalayohaA, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. ramoIN (Mgh, Msb, K) and rimaAyapN, (Mgh, K,) [He shot, or shot the arrow, from, and upon, meaning with, the bow;] and accord. to El-Ghooree, bihaA also; (Mgh;) but one should not say ramaI bihaA, (S, M, Msb, K,) unless meaning “ he threw it from his hand; ” though some make it to mean [ramaI EanohaA or] ramaI EalayohaA, making the b to be instead of En or ElI. (Msb.) ― -b4- And ramaI AlqanaSa, (S, M,) or AlSRayoda, [He shot, or shot at, the animal, or animals, of the chase,] inf. n. ramoIN and rimaAyapN, (Msb,) or ramoIN, and none other. (M.) [And ramaAhu bikacaA He threw at him, cast at him, or shot at him, with such a
thing; i. e. he threw it, cast it, or shot it, at him: and, more commonly, he threw at him, or cast at him, and hit him, or he shot him, with such a thing: namely, with a stone, an arrow, &c. And ramaAhu biHijaArapF He threw at him with stones, threw stones at him: and he pelted him with stones, i. e. threw at him and hit him with stones.] And ramaI fiI AlOagoraADi [He shot, or cast, at the butts]. (ISk, T, S, M.) ― -b5- [Hence,] one says, in cursing a person, ramaI QllRehu fiI yadihi, and Oanofihi, (assumed tropical:) [May God aim at, and smite, with some bane, or malady, his hand, or arm, and his nose,] and in like manner in relation to other members. (M, K. *) [And ramaAhu QllRehu bikacaA, sometimes meaning (assumed tropical:) God smote him, or afflicted him, with such a thing: but generally, may God smite him, or afflict him, with such a thing; as in the saying,] ramaAhu QllRehu bidaMCi AlcRiYobi (assumed tropical:) [May God smite him, or afflict him, with the disease of the wolf]; a prov., meaning may God destroy him, or cause him to perish; because [it is said that] the wolf has no disease but death: or, as some say, the meaning is, ramaAhu QllRehu biAljuwEi [may God afflict him with hunger]; because the wolf is always hungry. (Meyd.) And ramaAhu bidaAhiyapK (assumed tropical:) [He (God) sent upon him, or against him,. or smote him with, a calamity: and also] (assumed tropical:) he (a man) made a very sagacious and crafty and politic man to be his assailant. (L in art. Hjr. [See also, in that art., rumiIa fulaAnN biHajiri AlOaroDi, and biHajarihi.]) [And ramaAhu bikacaA (assumed tropical:) He assailed him with such a thing; as, for instance, reproach, and an argument, &c. Hence,] ramaAhu biqabiyHK, (TA,) or biOamorK qabiyHK, (IAar, T,) or biAlqabiyHi, (Msb,) (assumed tropical:) He reproached him, or upbraided him, with a thing, or with that, which was bad, evil, abominable, or foul: (IAar, T, Msb, TA:) whence the usage of the verb alone [in this sense, adultery being understood,] in the Kur xxiv. 4 and 6. (T, TA.) [And ramaAhu bisuwoCK (assumed tropical:) He cast an evil imputation upon him; accused him, or suspected him, of evil: see maromiIRN. And ramaAhu alone (assumed tropical:) He accused him, or suspected him.] And ramaAhu biAlHaqRi (assumed tropical:) [He accused him with truth]. (L in art. qrH, in explanation of qaraHahu biAlHaqRi.) [And ramaAhu bilisaAnihi (assumed tropical:) He spoke against him.] ― -b6- ramaI QllRehu laka means (tropical:) May God aid thee, or aid thee against thine enemy, and work [good] for thee: (AO, S, TA: *) and ramaI QllRehu lahu (tropical:) God aided him, or aided him against his enemy, (AAF, M, K, TA,) and wrought [good] for him: (AAF, M, TA:) and [it is said that] the verb has this meaning in the words of the Kur, wamaA ramayota Uico ramayota walekinRa QllReha ramaI [of which other explanations have been given above]; because, when God aids a person against his enemy, He aims at, and smites, (yaromiI,) that enemy. (M, TA.) [In like manner, also, fulaAnN yaromiI mino waraMCi fulaAnK means (assumed tropical:) Such a one defends such a one.] ― -b7- rumiytu bikacaA (tropical:) I had such a thing offered, or presented, to me, the meeting with it being appointed, or prepared; [I had it as it were thrown to me, or thrown in my way; as though I were thrown at therewith;] like nubicotu bihi. (A in art. nbc.) ― -b8- ramaAniI Alqawomu biOaboSaArihimo (assumed tropical:) The people, or party, [cast their eyes, on me: or] looked at me sideways, or did so with anger, or aversion: or looked at me hardly, or intently. (Mgh.) [And ramaI bibaSarihi AlOaroDa (assumed tropical:) He cast his eyes on the ground.] ― -b9- ramaI biAlqawomi (assumed tropical:) He, or it, caused, or made, the people, or party, to go forth; expelled them; [or cast them forth;] from one country, or the like, to another. (M, TA.) [See also 6.]) [And ramaI binaAqatihi AlfalaApa (assumed tropical:) He urged forth his she-camel, or went forth with her, or journeyed with her, or directed his course with her, into the desert; agreeably with what precedes or with what follows.] ramoIN signifies also (assumed tropical:) The going forth from one country, or the like, to another. (Th, M, TA.) And ramaI AlrRajulu (assumed tropical:) The man journeyed. (IAar, T, TA.) And Az says, (TA,) I heard an Arab of the desert say to another, Oayona taromiI, meaning (assumed tropical:) Whither dost thou direct thy course. (T, TA.) One says, raOayotu naAsFA yaromuwna AlTRaAYifa (assumed tropical:) I saw men directing their course to, or towards, Et-Táïf. (Har p. 54.) [See also an ex. in a verse of Dhu-r-Rummeh cited in p. 78.] ― -b10- ramawohaA biOavowaAbK xifaAfK, in a verse cited voce vawobN, [They cast upon them light, or agile, bodies,] means they mounted them with their [light, or agile,] bodies; referring to camels. (T and TA in art. vwb.) ― -b11- rumiIa fiI jinaAzatihi He has been carried, or lifted, and put, into, or upon, his bier, means (assumed tropical:) he died, or has died: (TA:) it is said in giving information of a man's death. (TA in art. jnz.) ― -b12- [ramaI also app. means (assumed tropical:) He (a governor) imposed an impost upon his subjects: see ramiyRapN.] ― -b13- And ramaI, aor. yaromiI, means also (assumed tropical:) He misconjectured; thought wrongly; or formed a wrong opinion: (IAar, T:) [and app. he threw out a conjecture: or he spoke conjecturally; for Az adds,] it is like the phrase rajomFA biAlgayobi [or rajama biAlgayobi or qaAla rajomFA biAlgayobi]. (T.) ― -b14- ramaI AlsRaHaAbu: see 6. ― -b15- ramaI EalaI Alxamosiyna: see 4. ＝ -A2- ramuwa is a verb of the same kind as qaDuwa and hayuWa, [invariable as to person, time, and mood,] and means Excel-lent [or how excellent] is he in his throwing, or shooting! (IJ, TA voce hayuWa, q. v. [See also baTuWa, voce buToMna.])

3 raAmayotuhu c
3. raAmayotuhu, (S, K,) and raAmayotuhu biAlsRihaAmi, (TA,) inf. n. muraAmaApN and rimaMCN (T, S, K) and taromaMCN↓, (K,) or this last is like the two preceding ns. [in meaning, but is a quasi-inf. n.], (T,) [I threw, or shot, (generally the latter,) and I shot arrows, with him, or at him; (see 6;) mostly meaning in competition, or contention; i. e. I competed, or contended, with him, in throwing, or shooting, and in shooting arrows: and raAmayotuhu alone often means raAmayotuhu biAlHijaArapi, or biAlsRihaAmi; whence it is said that] muraAmaApN signifies the shooting arrows, and throwing stones, with any one. (KL.) It is said in a prove., respecting an affair in which one is forward before doing it,
qabola AlrRimaMCi tumolaOu AlkanaAYinu
[Before shooting arrows with another, or doing so in competition or contention, the quivers are to be filled]. (A 'Obeyd, T.)

4 OaromaIa
4: see 1, first sentence, in seven places: ― -b2- and see also 6. ＝ -A2- ArmI, (M, Mgh,) inf. n. UiromaMCN, (Mgh,) also signifies It (a thing, Mgh) exceeded. (M, Mgh.) You say, ArmI Ealayohi It (anything) exceeded it, namely, another thing. (M.) Hátim- Teiyi says,
waOasomara xaTRiyRFA kaOanRa kuEuwbahu
nawaI Alqasobi qado OaromaI ciraAEFA EalaI AlEaXori
[And a tawny spear of El-Khatt, as though its knots, or joints, were hard date-stones; one that exceeded a cubit over the ten]: (T, S:) i. e., qado zaAda EalayohaA. (T.) And hence, (T,) you say, ArmI EalaI Alxamosiyna, i. e. He exceeded [the age of fifty]; (AZ, A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, K;) [like ArbI;] as also ramaI↓; (AZ, T, S, M, K;) [for] ramoIN signifies the exceeding in age: and one says also OaromaOa and ramaOa in the same sense. (IAar, T.) And ArmI fulaAnN signifies the same as OarobaI [meaning Such a one took usury or the like]. (S.) See also ramaMCN, below. You say also, saAbRahu faOaromaI Ealayohi, i. e. [He reciprocated reviling, or vilifying, with him, and] he exceeded him. (S.)

5 trmRI c
5. trmRI He shot, or cast, at the butts, and at the trunks of trees. (ISk, T, S, M.)

6 taraAmayonaA c
6. taraAmayonaA and AirotamayonaA↓ [We cast, or shot, (generally the latter,) one with another, or one at another; mostly meaning in competition, or contention; i. e. we competed, or contended, together in throwing, or shooting]: (S, K:) and trAmI Alqawomu biAlsRihaAmi and ArtmwA↓ The people, or party, shot arrows, [one with another, or] one at another. (T.) ― -b2- [Hence,] trAmt bihi AlbilaAdu (tropical:) The countries cast him forth, or expelled him; (M, K, TA;) [as though they bandied him, one to another;] as also Artmt↓, (so in a copy of the M, [which I think correct,]) or Armt↓. (K.) ― -b3- And trAmI AlsRaHaAbu (assumed tropical:) The clouds became drawn, or joined, together, (M, K, TA,) [as though thrown, one at another,] and heaped, or piled, up; (TA;) as also ramaI↓. (M, TA.) ― -b4- And trAmI Oamoruhu UilaI AlZRafari; or UilaI AlxicolaAni; i. e. (assumed tropical:) [His affair, or case,] came eventually [to the attainment of what was desired, or sought; or to abandonment by God]. (T, K, TA.) Hence, (TA,) it is said in a trad., of Zeyd Ibn-Háritheh, subiIa fiI AljaAhiliyRapi fataraAmaI AlOamoru Oano SaAralixadiyjapa, (T, TA,) i. e. (assumed tropical:) [He was made a captive in the Time of Ignorance, and the case] came eventually, and led, [to his becoming the property of Khadeejeh, (UilaI being understood before Oano SaAra,)] as though the decrees [of God] cast him thereto. (IAth, TA.) One says also, trAmI AlOamoru, meaning taraAxaI [i. e. (assumed tropical:) The affair was sluggish, or backward]: (K:) [or] one says of a [purulent swelling such as is termed] Hiyon, (T,) or of a wound, (S,) trAmI UilaI fasaAdK, (T,) or AlI AlfasaAdi, (S,) i. e. (assumed tropical:) It was in a sluggish, or backward, state, (taraAxaI,) and became putrid and corrupt. (T.) And trAmI Uilayohi Alxabaru (assumed tropical:) The
news, or information, came to him; or came to him by degrees. (MA.) ― -b5- trAmt saforatuhu (assumed tropical:) His journey was, or became, distant, or far-extending. (Har p. 34.) ― -b6- trAmAhu AlXRabaAbu Youthfulness, or youthful vigour, attained its full term [in him]. (Skr, M.)

8 ArtmI c
8. ArtmI It was, or became, thrown, cast, or flung. (S, K, TA.) It fell to the ground: so in the saying, ArtmI AlHimolu Eano Zahori AlbaEiyri [The load fell to the ground, or it may mean was thrown down, from the back of the camel]. (T.) ― -b2- Also He shot, or shot at, an animal, or animals, of the chase. (T, S, M.) ― -b3- See also 6, in three places.

ramoIN c
ramoIN [originally an inf. n.]: see ramiIRN.

rimFI c
rimFI The sound of a stone (T, K) thrown at a boy (so accord. to a copy of the T) or thrown by a boy; (K;) on the authority of IAar. (T.) ＝ -A2- rimFA [thus written in the M]: see ramaMCN.

ramoyapN c
ramoyapN A single throw, or cast, or fling: and a single shot: (Mgh, Msb, TA:) pl. ramayaAtN. (Msb, TA.) rubRa ramoyapK mino gayori raAmK [Many a hitting shot, or scarce any hitting shot, is there without a skilled shooter] is a prov. [applied to the case of an unexpected success obtained by an inexperienced person;] meaning many a [hitting] shot, or scarce any [hitting] shot, originates from a shooter that [usually] misses. (Meyd)

ramaMCN c
ramaMCN, (S, IAth, K, in a copy of the T and in a copy of the S without any vowel-sign,) with fet-h and medd, (IAth, and so in a copy of the S, in which it is added that it is said by Ks to be with medd,) like samaMCN; (K;) or rimaMCN↓; (Mgh, and so in a copy of the T;) or rimFA↓, said by Lh to be formed by substitution [of m for b, as is shown by what follows]; (M;) An excess, or an addition; i. e., (A 'Obeyd, T, Mgh,) i. q. ribFA, (A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, K,) or ribFwA, (Mgh, and thus written in some copies of the S and K, or in most of the copies of the K, [meaning usury, and the like,]) or an excess, or addition, over what is lawful. (T, IAth.) Hence the trad. of 'Omar, laA tabiyEuwA, (A 'Obeyd, T,) or he said laA taXotaruwA, (S,) AlcRahaba biAlfiDRapi UilRaA yadFA biyadK haA wahaA, [or haOo wahaOo, (see art. hwO,)] or haMC wahaMC, [i. e. haMCa wahaMCa,] (accord. to different copies of the T and S,) adding, (T, S,) UinRiI OaxaAfu Ealayokumu AlrmMCa; (T, S, Mgh;) [i. e. Exchange not ye gold for silver, except it be done hand with hand, meaning, except there be no delay between the giving and receiving, take and take: verily I fear for you the practice of usury;] or he said, UilRaA haMCa wahaMCi, meaning, except [by saying] take and give: (Az, TA in bAb AlAlf AllyRnp:) and, as some relate it, he said, AnRI AxAf Elykm AlUromaMCa↓; [which means the same;] using the inf. n. (T, Mgh.)

rimaMCN c
rimaMCN: see the next preceding paragraph.

ramiIRN c
ramiIRN, applied to the male of the goat-kind, or mountain-goat, or of the gazelle, [and any male animal of the chase,] and likewise, without p, to the female, i. q. maromiIRN↓ [i. e. Thrown at, or cast at, or shot at, or shot]: but when they do not distinguish a male from a female, the word applied to the male and to the female is [ramiyRapN↓,] with p [added lilnRaqoli, i. e. to transfer it from the category of epithets to that of substantives]: or, accord. to Lh, ramiIRN and ramiyRapN↓ are both applied, as epithets, to the female; but the former is the more approved: the pl. of the former [and of the latter also] is ramaAyaA. (M, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, (M,) accord. to As, i. q. saqiIRN, i. e., (T, S,) A cloud of which the rain-drops are large, and vehement in their fall, (T, S, M, K, *) of the clouds of the hot season and of the autumn: (S:) or, (M, K,) accord. to Lth, (T,) small portions of clouds, (T, M, K,) of the [apparent] size of the hand, or somewhat larger; but the approved explanation is that given by As: (T:) and ramoIN↓ is a dial. var. thereof: (TA:) the pl. is OaromiyapN, (T, S, M, K,) like as that of saqiIRN is OasoqiyapN, (S,) and OaromMCN, (Lth, T, M, K,) [each, properly, a pl. of pauc.,] and ramaAyaA. (M, K.)

ramiyRapN c
ramiyRapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places. [As a subst.,] it signifies A thing, (S, M,) meaning (S) an animal (As, T, S, M, * Mgh, Msb) of the chase, (As, T, S,) that is thrown at, or cast at, or shot at, or shot, (As, T, S, M, Mgh, Msb,) by its pursuer; and any beast thrown at, cast at, shot at, or shot; (As, T;) applied to the male and the female: (As, T, Mgh, Msb:) it is originally a word of the measure faEilaypN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN: (Msb:) [or rather] it is made fem., (As, T,) [i. e.] it has p, (S,) because it is made a subst., (As, T, S,) not an epithet: (As, T:) it is not maromiyRapN converted into ramiyRapN: (S:) or, accord. to Sb, the p, in general, is affixed to show that the act has not yet been executed upon the object thereof; [so that the meaning is, an animal to be thrown at, cast at, shot at, or shot;] and thus cabiyHapN is applied to “ a sheep, or goat, [to be slaughtered or sacrificed,] not yet slaughtered [or sacrificed]; ” but when the act has been executed upon it, it is [said to be] cabiyHN: (M:) the pl. is ramiyRaAtN and ramaAyaA. (Msb.) One says, biYosa AlrRamiyRapu AlOaronabu, meaning Very bad is the thing of those that are [or are to be] thrown at, or cast at, or shot at, or shot, the hare. (S, M.) ― -b2- Also, (assumed tropical:) An impost which the governor imposes [so I render maA yaromiyhi AlEaAmilu] upon his subjects. (TA.)

rimRiyRaA c
rimRiyRaA, (S, TA,) thus correctly written, like EimRiyRaA; in the copies of the K like EimiyRaA, (TA,) [and in two copies of the T written rimiyRaA; in a copy of the M, rimRiyaA;] i. q. taraAmK: (T, S: *) or muraAmaApN: (K:) or ramoIN: (M:) or it is an intensive inf. n. from AlrRamoIu, of the measure fiERiylaI, like hijRiyarI and xiSRiySaI: (Nh, TA:) one says, kaAnato bayonahumo rimRiyRaA (T, * S, M, * TA) vumRa Hajazato bayonahumo HijRiyzaI, (T,) or vumRa SaAruwA UilaI HijRiyzaI, (S, TA,) i. e. There was between them a reciprocal throwing of stones, (T, TA,) [or shooting of arrows or the like, or a great, or vehement, throwing, &c.,] then there intervened between them [an intervention, or a vehement intervention, or] a person, or persons, who withheld them, one from another, (T,) or then they withheld themselves, [or withheld themselves much,] one from another. (TA.)

raAmK c
raAmK act. part. n. of 1; (Lth, T, TA;) Throwing, &c.: (TA:) [pl. rumaApN.] ― -b2- [Hence, AlrRaAmiI a name of The constellation Sagittarius; the ninth of the signs of the zodiac: thus called in the present day; but more commonly, Alqawosu.] ― -b3- [Hence likewise,] raAmK also signifies (assumed tropical:) [One who assails with reproach, &c.:] (assumed tropical:) one who reproaches, or upbraids; or who gives an ill name: (KL:) [(assumed tropical:) one who accuses, or suspects, another: see maromiIRN.]

OaromaI c
OaromaI [More, and most, skilled in throwing, or casting, or shooting]: see an ex. voce tiqonN.

taromaMCN c
taromaMCN: see 3 [of which it is a quasi-inf. n.].

maromFI c
maromFI A place [of throwing, or casting, or] of shooting arrows; (KL;) the place of the butt at which arrows are shot: (TA:) [pl. maraAmK.] ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) i. q. maqoSidN [meaning A place, and an object, to, or towards, which one directs his aim or course]: (TA, and Har p. 54:) pl. maraAmK: (Har ibid.:) whence the trad., layosa waraMCa QllRehi maromFI, i. e. (assumed tropical:) [There is not, beyond God,] any object (maqoSid) towards which to direct hopes. (TA.)

miromFI c
miromFI An instrument for throwing, or casting, or shooting: pl. maraAmK. (Har p. 54.) [Hence,] maraAmiI niyraAnK [Engines for throwing fire upon the enemy]. (S and K voce HarRaAqapN.) [See also miromaApN.]

maromaApN c
maromaApN i. q. galowapN [as meaning The limit of a shot or throw]. (K in art. glw.) ＝ -A2- See also the next paragraph.

miromaApN c
miromaApN An arrow with which one shoots (As, IAar, T) at a butt: (As, T, Mgh:) an arrow with which one learns to shoot; (M, K, TA;) which is the worst kind of arrows: (TA:) or a small, weak arrow: (AHn, M, K:) or an arrow with its [head of] iron: (Th, TA in art. Hsb:) or, like sirowapN, a round arrow-head: (AA, [so in the S, but in the TA it is IAar,] S, TA:) [and app. a missile of any kind: (see mirodFI:)] pl. maraAmK. (M.) When they see many maraAmK in the quiver of a man, they say,
wanabolu AlEabodi OakovaruhaA AlmaraAmiI
[And the arrows of the slave, most of them are those that are small and weak]: a prov., said to mean that the free man purchases arrows at a high price, buying the broad and long iron head, because he is a man of war and of the chase; but the slave is only a pastor, and therefore is content with what are termed maraAmK, because they are cheaper if he buy them; and if he ask for them as a gift, no one gives him aught but a miromaAp. (M.) [See also the last sentence of this paragraph.] ― -b2- It is also used, tropically, as meaning (tropical:) A manojaniyq [or kind of engine for casting stones
at the enemy; app. such as was called by the Romans “ onager, ” or the like thereof]: because, like the miromaAop before mentioned, it is an instrument for casting, or shooting. (Mgh.) [See also miromFI.] And [the pl.] maraAmK also signifies (assumed tropical:) Thunderbolts; syn. SawaAEiqu. (Bd in xviii. 38.) ― -b3- Also A cloven hoof (S, Mgh, K) of a sheep or goat; because it is of the things that are thrown away: (Mgh:) [or,] accord. to A 'Obeyd, (T, S,) a thing that is between the two hoofs of a sheep or goat; (T, S, M, K;) as also maromaApN↓: (A 'Obeyd, T, M, K:) thus, he says, it is explained; but I know not what is its meaning: (T, S:) its dual occurs in the following trad.: lawo OanRa OaHadahumo duEiIa UilaI miromaAtayoni laOajaAba wahuwa laA yujiybu UilaI AlSRalaApi; (T, S; related also, with some variations, in the M and Mgh;) in which it is said to be the dual of miromaApN in the former of these two senses; [i. e. If any one of you were invited to partake of two hoofs of a sheep or goat, he would obey the invitation, but he will not obey the invitation to prayer;] (S, Mgh;) or, accord. to A 'Obeyd, it is here the dual of this word in the latter of the same two senses: (T, S:) accord. to IAar, (T, TA,) or Aboo-Sa'eed, it here means the kind of arrow called miromaApN: (T, Mgh, TA:) but in another, and similar, trad., mrmAtyn is followed by OawoEaroqK [i. e. “ or a bone with some meat remaining upon it ”]. (T, Z, TA.)

maromiIRN c
maromiIRN pass. part. n. of 1; Thrown, &c.: (TA:) [thrown at, or cast at, or shot at, or shot:] see ramiIRN. ― -b2- [Hence, (assumed tropical:) Smitten, or afflicted, with some bane, or malady, &c.: (assumed tropical:) assailed with reproach, &c.: (assumed tropical:) reproached, or upbraided, or stigmatized with an ill name: (assumed tropical:) accused, or suspected.] You say AimoraOapN maromiyRapN bisuwoCK (assumed tropical:) A woman accused, or suspected, of evil. (TA in art. rTm.)

murotamK c
murotamK A scout (T, K) liqawomK [to a people or party]: (T, K: *) and so murotabiYN. (T.)

1 ranRa c
1. ranRa, aor. yarinRu, inf. n. raniynN; and ArnR↓; (Msb, K;) It (a thing) emitted a sound: (Msb:) or he cried aloud; (K;) or ranRato, aor. and inf. n. as above; and ArnRt↓; she cried aloud, said of a woman: (S:) or ranRa and ArnR↓ signify he raised his voice in weeping: (Ham p. 11:) or raniynN signifies the crying aloud in weeping; (Lth, T;) or the uttering a plaintive, or mournful, voice or sound or cry: (M:) and UironaAnN↓, [inf. n. of ArnR,] the uttering a loud, or vehement, sound or cry; (Lth, T, M;) or the uttering of the sound of reiterating the breath with weeping: (IAar, T:) or raniynN and UironaAnN↓ signify the crying out loudly, or vehemently; and the uttering a plaintive, or mournful, voice or sound or cry, in singing, or in weeping: (M:) you say of a woman, ranRato, inf. n. as above; and ArnRt↓; (T, M;) and rnRnt↓, inf. n. taroniynN and taroniyapN [which is properly inf. n. of ranRato as belonging to art. rnw]; all meaning she cried out loudly, or vehemently; and she uttered a plaintive, or mournful, voice or sound or cry, in singing or in weeping: (M:) and AlnRisaMCu OaranRati↓ fiI niyaA HatihinRa [the women cried loudly, or vehemently, in their wailing]. (T.) See also 4. ＝ -A2- ranRa Uilayohi, and ArnR↓, He gave ear, hearkened, or listened, to him, or it. (K.)

2 ranRanotu Alqawosa c
2. ranRanotu Alqawosa, inf. n. taroniynN, [I twanged the bow;] I made the bow to produce a sound [by pulling the string and letting it go suddenly]. (S.) ＝ -A2- See also 1.

4 ArnR c
4. ArnR, inf. n. UironaAnN: see 1, in seven places. OaranRato is said of a woman in her wailing [as expl. above]; and of a pigeon (HamaAmap) in its cooing [app. as meaning It uttered plaintive sounds]; (M;) and of a bow (qawos), (T, S, M, Msb, TA,) on the occasion of its string's being pulled and let go, (T,) accord. to the K ranRato↓, but this is a mistake, (TA,) meaning it [twanged, or] produced a sound, (S, M, Msb,) accord. to AHn, above what is termed HaniynN; (M;) and of a cloud (saHaAbap) in its thundering [app. as meaning it resounded]. (M.) And ArnR is also said of an ass in his braying; (T, M;) and of water in its murmuring, or gurgling, or running vehemently. (M.) ＝ -A2- ArnR fulaAnN likacaA Such a one was cheered, or delighted, and pleased, or was diverted, by reason of such a thing; as also OaramRa lahu, and ranaA lh, and AstrnI. (T.) ＝ -A3- ArnR Uilayohi: see 1, last sentence.

ranRahN c
ranRahN A sound, voice, or cry, (IAar, T, S, K,) [in an absolute sense, or] in joy or sorrow: (IAar, T:) or a plaintive, or mournful, cry; whence one says EuwdN cuw ranRapK [a lute having a plaintive sound]: (Lth, T:) [or a moaning:] or a cry; (Msb;) or a loud cry: (M, Msb: *) and also a plaintive, or mournful, voice or sound or cry, in singing, or in weeping: (M:) pl. ranRaAtN. (IAar, T.)

rananN c
rananN A certain thing that utters a cry [or sound] yaSiyHu [in one of my copies of the S yaTiyHu]) in the water, (S, K,) or in still water, (so in one copy of the S,) in the Sayof [i. e. spring or summer], (S,) or in winter. (K.) A poet says,
walamo yaSodaHo lahu AlrRananu
[And the rnn did not raise its voice at him, or it]. (S.) ― -b2- Also A small quantity of water. (TA.)

raniynN c
raniynN inf. n. of 1. (T, S, M, &c.) ― -b2- [Accord. to Golius, El-Meydánee explains it also as meaning A woman afflicted and oppressed by misfortune; and Golius adds, as though moaning, or lamenting.]

AlrRunRaI c
AlrRunRaI Mankind, or all created beings. (AA, T, K.) One says, maA fiI AlrRunRaI mivoluhu [There is not among mankind, or all created beings, the like of him]. (AA, T.) ＝ -A2- Also, (AA, T,) or runRaI, without Al, (K,) The month Jumádà: (AA, T:) or a name of Jumádà-l-Ákhireh; (K;) and so runapu, [said to be from ruwnapN, (see art. rwn,) though app. belonging to art. rnw, being] without teshdeed: pl. runanN: Aboo-' Amr Ez-Záhid disallowed rubRaI, and pronounced it to be a mistranscription: but accord. to Ktr and IAmb and Abu-t-Teiyib 'AbdEl-Wáhid and Abu-l-Kásim Ez-Zejjájee, it is rubRaI only; because in it were known the results of their wars; from rubRaI applied to a ewe or she-goat: and AlHaniynu was a name of Jumádà-l-Oolà: see also art. rb, in which is said what somewhat differs from the statement here. (TA.)

runRaMCN c
runRaMCN, like rumRaAnN, with teshdeed, accord. to Th, i. q. TarabN: (TA:) or so runaMCN, without teshdeed, (M, TA,) accord. to A 'Obeyd: the latter is mentioned in its proper place [in art. rnw, q. v.]. (TA.)

OarowanaAnN c
OarowanaAnN, an epithet applied to a day, meaning Vehement in respect of anything, is of the measure OafowaEaAlN, from AlrRaniynu, accord. to IAar; but accord. to Sb, of the measure OafoEalaAlN, from ruwnapN, meaning “ hardness, ” and “ grievousness, ” of a thing, or an affair, or event: it is mentioned in art. rwn. (M.)

murinRapN c
murinRapN is applied as an epithet to birds [app. as meaning Uttering plaintive sounds]: (S:) and, as also mironaAnN↓, as an epithet to a bow [as meaning twanging], and so to a cloud (saHaAbap) [app. as meaning resounding with thunder]: (M:) and each is applied to a bow [itself]; (S, K;) and the latter, to a cloud [itself]; as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant [so as to imply, app., the meaning of resounding with thunder, or because it is hoped that it will resound with thunder, or because it often does so]. (M.)

mironaAnN c
mironaAnN: see the next preceding paragraph.

OaronabN c
OaronabN [The hare; and now applied to the rabbit also;] a certain animal, (TA,) well known, (M, A, K, TA,) like the EnAq [?], having short fore legs and long hind legs, that treads the ground with the hinder parts of its [hind] legs: (TA:) a certain very prolific animal, called in Pers. xrkwX [or xaroGuwXo]: it is said that it is one year a male and another year a female, and menstruates like women; and its fore legs are shorter than its hind legs: when it sleeps, it keeps its eyes open; and when it is sick, it eats green canes (qaSab), and its sickness ceases: (Kzw:) the word is a gen. n., (TA,) of the fem. gender, (Msb, TA,) accord. to El-Jáhidh; (TA;) but (Msb) applied to the male and the female; (M, A, K, TA;) as is also OaronabapN↓, (Msb,) which is a dial. var.: (Mgh, Msb:) or to the female [only]; the male being called xuzazN; (T, M, K, TA;) accord. to Lth; but others allow its application to the male: (T:) the female is also called EikoriXapN: and the young, xironiqN: (TA:) the pl. is OaraAnibu (T, S, M, Msb, K) and OaraAnK, (Lh, S, M, K,) the latter, like vaEaAlK for vaEaAlibu, occurring in poetry, (S, M, *) and not allowed by Sb except in poetry. (M.) The A in OaronabN is augmentative, accord. to Lth: accord. to most of the grammarians it is disjunctive, (so in a copy of the T and in the TA,) or radical: (so in another copy of the T:) Lth says that no word commences with a radical A but such as
is triliteral; as OaroDN and OaroXN. (T, TA.) [Hence,] one says of the low, abject, or ignominious, and weak, UinRamaA huwa OaronabN [He is only a hare]; because that animal cannot defend itself, and even the lark will endeavour to make it its prey. (A, TA.) See another ex. below, voce OaronabapN. [Hence, also,] AlOaronabu is the name of (assumed tropical:) A certain constellation, [Lepus,] comprising twelve stars in its figure, having no observed stars around it, situate beneath the feet of AljabRaAr [i. e. Orion], and facing the west. (Kzw.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) or maronabN↓ accord. to the L, (TA,) or both, (M,) and yaronabN↓, A jurac [or large field-rat], (M, L, K,) like the jerboa, (M, L,) having a short tail. (M, L, K.) ― -b3- AlOaronabu AlbaHoriIRu, accord. to Kzw, A certain marine animal, the head of which is like that of the Oaronab [or hare], and the body like that of a fish: or, accord. to Ibn-Seenà, a small testaceous animal, which is of a poisonous quality when drunk [app. meaning in water]: so that, accord. to this explanation, the resemblance [to the Arnb commonly so called] is in the name, not the form. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A sort of ornament worn by women. (M, K.)

OaronabapN c
OaronabapN The end, or tip, [i. e. the lower portion, or lobule,] of the nose: (T, S, A, K:) this is [also] called Oaronabapu AlOanofi: (Mgh, Msb:) it is one of the parts that touch the ground in prostration [in prayer]: (TA:) pl. OaraAnibu. (T, A, TA.) You say, jadaEa Oaronabatahu [lit. He cut off the end of his nose;] meaning (assumed tropical:) he held him in mean estimation, or in contempt. (A, TA.) And wajadotuhumo mujadRaEiI AlOaraAnibi OaXadRa fazaEFA mina AlOaraAnibi↓ (assumed tropical:) [I found them to be held in contempt, (lit. having the ends of their noses cut off,) more fearful than hares]. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also OaronabN.

OaronabaAniIRN c
OaronabaAniIRN [Cloth of the kind called] xazR of a blackish colour (Oadokanu). (K.) ― -b2- See also maronabaAniIRN.

maronabN c
maronabN A large faOorap [or rat]: (K:) omitted in some copies of the K. (TA.) See OaronabN. ― -b2- See also muWaronabN.

muronabN c
muronabN: see muWaronabN.

maronabapN c
maronabapN A villous [garment of the kind called] qaTiyfap. (T, K.) ＝ -A2- See also OaroDN muWaronibapN.

kisaMCN maronabaAniIRN c
kisaMCN maronabaAniIRN A [garment of the kind called] ksAC that is of the colour of the Oaronab [or hare]; (T, M, A, K;) as also OazonabaAniIRN↓. (A.) See also the next paragraph.

kisaMCN muWaronabN c
kisaMCN muWaronabN A [garment of the kind called] ksAC of which the thread is intermixed with the soft hair of the Oaronab [or hare]; (T, S, M, K;) as also muronabN↓, (so in a copy of the M,) or maronabN↓, like maqoEadN: (A, K:) or, as some say, i. q. maronabaAniIRN↓. (T.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph.

OaroDN muWaronibapN c
OaroDN muWaronibapN A land in which are OaraAnib [or hares]: (S:) or abounding therewith; (T, Kr, M, and so in some copies of the K;) as also muWaronabapN↓, (M, and so in some copies of the K, and in a copy of the A,) and maronabapN↓. (T, M, A.)

yaronabN c
yaronabN: see OaronabN.

raAnijN c
raAnijN, (El-Fárábee, S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) or raAnajN, (Msb,) The Indian nut, or cocoa-nut: (AHn, S, A, Mgh, Msb, K, TA:) thought by AHn to be an arabicized word: (TA:) [J says,] “ I do not think it to be Arabic: ” (S:) pl. rawaAniju. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also A kind of smooth date, (Msb, K,) so some say, (Mgh,) like that called taEoDuwD: [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p. (K.) ― -b3- waladu AlrRaAniji is a name given by the children of Mekkeh to The muqol [or fruit of the dawom, i. e. cucifera Thebaïca, or Theban palm]. (A.)

2 rnRHhu c
2. rnRHhu, [inf. n. as below,] said of wine (XaraAb), It made him to incline from side to side. (A, TA.) [Also, as appears from what follows, It made him to incline and go round. It made him giddy in the head, and confused: it affected him with giddiness in the head like one in a swoon.] It deprived him of his strength by reason of its potency. (Ham p. 562.) [And, said of a beating, and app. of intoxication &c., It made him to swoon, or faint: for,] when you have beaten a person so that he swoons, or faints, you say, Darabotuhu HatRaI ranRaHotuhu. (Ham ibid.) [Hence, runRiHa He was made to incline from side to side: ranRaHa is expl. in the TA in a similar sense, as said of a man &c.; but it is app. a mistranscription for runRiHa]: see 5. He was made to incline and go round. (L.) It is said, by Imra-el-Keys, of a dog gored by a wild bull. (S, * L.) He was giddy in the head, and confused: and runRiHa bihi he was affected with giddiness in the head like one in a swoon. (L.) Also, (L,) and runRiHa Ealayohi inf. n. taroniyHN, (S, L, K,) He swooned, or fainted; or was affected by a weakness of the bones, (S, L, K,) and of the body; by reason of beating or fright or intoxication, and sometimes by reason of anxiety, and grief, or sorrow; (L;) and inclined from side to side. (S, L, K.) ― -b2- ranRaHati AlrRiyHu AlguSona (tropical:) The wind made the branch to incline from side to side. (A.)

5 trnRH c
5. trnRH He inclined from side to side, by reason of intoxication &c.; (S, A, K;) as also ArtnH↓, (K,) and ranRaHa↓ [app. a mistranscription for runRiHa]. (TA.) He inclined, and went round. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) It (a branch) inclined from side to side, being blown by the wind. (A.) ― -b3- trnRH bayona Oamorayoni (tropical:) He wavered between two things. (A.) ― -b4- trnRH EalaI fulaAnK (tropical:) He was, or became, inimical to such a one, domineering, and exalting himself. (A.) ― -b5- And trnRH He sipped wine (XaraAb) by little and little. (AHn, K.)

8 UirotanaHa
8: see 5, first signification.

ranoHN c
ranoHN Vertigo, or giddiness in the head; (K;) and confusion. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A certain appertenance of the brain, separate, or distinct, therefrom, like, or of the size of, the EuSofuwr [q. v.]. (K.)

maronaHapN c
maronaHapN The prow, or fore part, of a ship. (Az, K.)

muronaHN c
muronaHN: see what follows.

muranRaHN c
muranRaHN Swooning, or fainting; or affected by a weakness of the bones, (S, L, K,) and of the body; by reason of beating or fright or intoxication, and sometimes by reason of anxiety, and grief, or sorrow; (L;) and inclining from side to side. (S, L, K.) ＝ -A2- Also, (A, K,) or muronaHN↓, (so in the L,) (tropical:) Aloes-wood, (A, L, K,) of the best kind, (L, K,) used for fumigation. (A, L, K.)

ranodN c
ranodN [a coll. gen. n.] A kind of tree of sweet odour, (AO, T, S, A, Msb, K,) which distils much (sayRaAlN); (A;) of the trees of the desert; (AO, T, S, A, Msb;) a kind of tree of the desert, of sweet odour, with the wood of which the teeth are cleaned; not large; and having a berry; (HabRap); called [i. e., the tree is called, and not the berry, for the verb is masculine,] gAr [a name commonly and properly applied to the laurus nobilis, or sweet bay]: n. un. ranodapN: (M:) or the myrtle (Ms); (M, A;) this is also called rnd, (Kh, Msb, K,) on account of its sweet odour; (Kh, Msb;) and Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà says that the rnd is the Ms accord. to all the lexicologists except Aboo- 'Amr Esh-Sheybánee and IAar, who assert that the rnd is the plant called Hanowap, and is of sweet odour; but AO also denies it to be the Ms; (T;) and so does As: (S:) or aloes-wood, (Euwd,) with which one fumigates; (M;) Ewd (or Euwdu AlTRiybi, with which one fumigates, AO, and T,) is also thus called, (AO, As, T, S, K,) sometimes: (AO, As, T, S:) [and accord. to Forskål, (Flor. Aeg. Ar., cxix.,) the artemisia pontica bears this name.]

runozN c
runozN i. q. OaruzRN [and ruzRN, i. e. Rice]; (S, K; [incorrectly said in the TA to be omitted by J;]) in the dial. of 'Abd-el-Keys: (ISd, TA:) as though the first z were changed into n, (S, TA,) as j in UinojaASN for UijRaASN. (TA.) [See HaZRN.]

1 raniqa c
1. raniqa, (S, Sgh, K,) aor.
raniqa
; (K;) and ranaqa, aor.
ranuqa
; (ISd, K;) inf. n. (of the former, S) ranaqN (S, K) and [of the latter] ranoqN and runuwqN; (K;) It (water) was, or became, turbid, thick, or muddy; (S, K;) as also trnRq↓. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also 4, in two places.

2 rnRq c
2. rnRq, (S, K,) inf. n. taroniyqN, (IAar, S,) He rendered water turbid, thick, or muddy; (IAar, S, K;) as also Arnq↓. (S, K.) ― -b2- And the former, He cleared it; rendered it clear: thus it bears two contr. significations. (IAar, K.) [Hence,] one says, rnRq QllRehu qacaAtaka May God
clear away thy qcAp [or mote in the eye; probably meaning (assumed tropical:) that which annoys thee]. (IAar, K) ＝ -A2- Also, as an intrans. verb, He was, or became, confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course. (TA.) And taroniyqN signifies A man's standing, not knowing whether to go or come. (TA.) And The being weak, or infirm, [and, app., disordered, or perturbed,] in sight, and in body, and in an affair or case. (S, K.) Hence, (TA,) rnRqwA fiI AlOamori They confused the judgment, or opinion, [that they formed, or they were confused in judgment or opinion,] in, or respecting, the affair, or case. (S, K.) ― -b2- Also He paused and waited. (TA.) [Hence the saying,] ramRadati AlmiEozaI faranRiqo ranRiqo, (JK, S, K,) i. e. The she-goats have secreted milk in their udders; (JK;) but wait thou, wait thou, (JK, S, TA,) for their bringing forth, (S, TA,) for they show signs, but do not bring forth until after some time: (S:) thou wilt have to wait long for them: (TA:) sometimes it is said with m [in the place of n], and also with d [in the place of r]: (S, TA:) it is mentioned in art. rbq [q. v.]. (K. [See also art. rmq.]) ― -b3- Also He continued looking; (S, K, TA, in this art. and in art. rmq;) like rmRq. (S and TA in the same two arts.) And you say also, rnRq Uilayohi AlnRaZura and dnRq [meaning He continued looking at it]. (S in art. dnq.) And rnRq AlnRaZara meaning [He looked covertly, or clandestinely; or] he concealed the looking. (TA.) ― -b4- Said of a company of men, They remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in a place (bimakaAnK), (S, K,) and confined themselves therein. (S.) ― -b5- Said of a bird, He flapped his wings in the air, (S, K,) and remained steady, (S,) not flying: (S, K:) or flapped his wings in the air without alighting and without quitting his place: or it has two meanings: i. e. he expanded his wings in the air without moving them: and he flapped his wings. (TA.) Hence, said of a captive, He stretched out his neck on the occasion of slaughter, like the bird expanding his wings. (TA.) [Hence also,] rnRqt AlsRafiynapu (JK, TA) fiI makaAnihaA (JK) The ship turned round in its place without proceeding in its course. (JK, TA.) ― -b6- rnRqt AlXRamosu The sun became near to setting. (TA. [See also dnRqt.]) And rnRqt minohu AlmaniyRapu (tropical:) Death was near to befalling him: a metaphorical phrase from rnRq said of a bird. (TA.) ― -b7- rnRN AlnRawomu (S, K) fiI Eayonayohi (K) (tropical:) Sleep pervaded (xaAlaTa) his eyes, (S, Z, Sgh, K,) without his sleeping. (Z, TA.) ＝ -A3- taroniyqN also signifies The breaking of the wing of a bird by a shot or throw, or by disease, so that he, or it, falls. (Lth, K.) [You say of the bird runRiqa or runRiqa janaAHuhu His wing was broken &c. See the pass. part. n., below.]

4 Arnq c
4. Arnq: see 2. ＝ -A2- Also He moved about, or agitated, [or waved,] his banner, previously to a charge, or an assault, in war or battle; (IAar, K;) and [in like manner,] ranaqa↓, inf. n. ranoqN, he moved about, &c., the banner. (TA.) ＝ -A3- And It (a banner) was moved about or agitated [or waved]; (IAar, K;) and [in like manner,] ranaqa↓ it (a banner) was moved about &c. over the heads. (TA.)

5 taranRaqa
5: see 1.

ranoqN c
ranoqN Turbid, thick, or muddy, water; (S, K;) as also raniqN↓ and ranaqN↓. (K.) ― -b2- Also (TA) Dust in water, consisting of motes, or particles of rubbish, and the like, that fall into it [and render it turbid]; (JK, TA;) and so ranaqN↓. (JK.) Accord. to IB, ranoqN has for pl. ranaAYiqu; as though this were pl. of raniyqapN: (TA:) or AlrRayaAniqu is pl. of AlmaMCi ranoqapu↓, (Ibn-'Abbád, K, TA,) or of ranoqapN, (JK,) and is formed by transposition, (JK, Ibn- 'Abbád, K, TA,) being originally AlrRanaAYiqu. (Ibn- 'Abbád, TA.) One says, maA fiI EayoXihi ranaqN↓ (assumed tropical:) [There is not in his life anything that renders it turbid]. (JK.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) Lying, or falsehood, or a lie; syn. kacibN. (TA.)

ranaqN c
ranaqN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

raniqN c
raniqN: see ranoqN. ― -b2- [Hence,] EayoXN raniqN (assumed tropical:) Turbid life. (S.)

ranoqapN c
ranoqapN A small quantity of turbid water remaining in a watering-trough or tank. (TA.) [And accord. to Freytag, ranoqaMCu↓ occurs in the Deewán El-Hudhaleeyeen as meaning A small quantity of turbid water.] Accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, (TA,) one says, SaAra AlmaMCu ranoqapF, (K, TA,) or ruwonaqapF↓, (JK, and so in the CK and in my MS. copy of the K,) meaning The water became such that mud predominated in it: (JK, K, TA:) but the correct phrase, as given in the “Nawádir” by Lh, is, SaAra AlmaMCu ranoqapF waAHidapF [The water became one puddle in which mud predominated]. (TA.) See also ranoqN.

ranoqaMCu c
ranoqaMCu: see the next preceding paragraph. ― -b2- Also Land (OaroDN) that does not give growth (JK, Ibn-'Abbád, K) to anything: (JK, Ibn- 'Abbád:) pl. ranoqaAwaAtN. (JK, Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b3- And A female bird sitting on eggs. (K.)

rawonaqN c
rawonaqN The maMC [or water] of a sword; (S, K, TA;) i. e. its firinod [or diversified wavy marks, streaks, or grain]; (TA;) and its beauty; (S, K;) or the semblance of water that is seen upon a sword. (JK.) ― -b2- And (hence, S) of the DuHaI [or early part of the forenoon], (S, K,) &c.; (S;) meaning (tropical:) The first, or beginning, thereof; (JK, * TA;) and its clearness. (TA.) One says, Oatayotuhu fiI rawonaqi AlDRuHaI I came to him in the first, or beginning, of the DHI; like as one says fiI wajohi AlDRuHaI. (TA.) And rawonaqu AlXRabaAbi means (tropical:) The prime of youth; and its freshness, or brightness, and beauty. (TA.)

rawonaqapN c
rawonaqapN: see ranoqapN.

turonuwqN c
turonuwqN (JK, S, K) and taronuwqN and turonuwqaMCu (K) The mud that is in rivers, and in a channel of water, (S, K,) when the water has sunk therefrom into the earth: (K:) or the thin, and viscous, cohesive, or slimy, mud remaining in a pool of water left by a torrent: (JK:) or the slime of a well, and of the channel of a torrent, mixed with black, or black and fetid, mud. (Mgh voce tiqonN, from the “Jámi'” of El-Ghooree.)

muranRaqu AljanaAHi c
muranRaqu AljanaAHi A bird having the wing broken by a shot or throw, or by disease, so that he, or it, falls. (K.)

laqiytu fulaAnFAmuranRiqapF EayonaAhu c
laqiytu fulaAnFAmuranRiqapF EayonaAhu (so in one of my copies of the S, and in the PS and JM; in the other of my copies of the S muranRaqapF;) (assumed tropical:) I met such a one having his eyes languid by reason of hunger or from some other cause. (S.)

1 ranima c
1. ranima: see 5, with which it is syn., in two places.

2 ranRama
2: see the next paragraph, in four places.

5 trnRm c
5. trnRm; and ranima↓, (S, Msb,) aor.
ranama
, (Msb,) inf. n. [ranamN and] raniymN; (TK;) i. q. rajRaEa Sawotahu (S, Msb) i. e. [He trilled, or quavered; or] he reiterated his voice in his throat, or fauces, (S and K and TA in art. rjE,) like [as is done in] chanting, (S in that art.,) or in reading or reciting, or singing, or piping, or other performances, of such as are accompanied with quavering, or trilling: (TA in that art.:) both said of a singer: (Msb:) and the former said of a bird, in its hadiyr [or cooing]; (S, Msb;) and of a bow, when it is twanged: (S:) and taroniymN [inf. n. of rnRm↓] signifies the like: (S:) or AltRaroniymu signifies taToriybu AlSRawoti [i. e. the trilling, or quavering, and prolonging the voice; or prolonging the voice, and modulating it sweetly, or warbling]; (T, * M, K;) and so raniymN [mentioned above as inf. n. of ranima↓]; (Lth, T, M, K;) whence AltRaranRumu [which signifies the same, as is shown by what follows]: (Lth, T:) rnRm↓ is said of the pigeon, (M, K,) and of the [bird called] mukRaAC, (M,) and of the [locust, or species of locust, called] junodab [meaning it chirped], and of the bow [meaning it emitted a musical ringing sound, or a plaintive sound (see taronamuwtN, below,) when twanged], (M, K,) and [in like manner] of the lute, (M,) and of a thing (M, K:) of any kind (M) of which the sound is esteemed pleasant, or delightful; and taranRama likewise: (M, K:) or you say, AlHamaAmapu tataranRamu [The pigeon trills, or quavers, or cooes]: and of the mukRaMC you say, fiI Sawotihi taroniymN↓ [In its voice, or cry, is a trilling, or quavering]: and of the bow, and the lute, and a thing [of any kind] of which the sound is esteemed pleasant, or delightful, lahu taroniymN↓ [It has a musical ringing sound, or a plaintive sound]. (Lth, T.) It is said in a trad., maA Oacina QllRehu liXaIoCK Oacanahu linabiIRK Hasani AltRaranRumi biAlquroMni [God has not listened to anything as He listens to a prophet having a good manner of trilling, or quavering, or prolonging and modulating sweetly his voice, in reciting the Kur-án]: or, as some relate it, Hasani AlSRawoti yataranRamu biAlquroMni [good in respect of the voice, trilling, &c., in reciting the Kur-án]. (TA.)

ranamN c
ranamN i. q. SawotN [as meaning A voice, or sound; or, more probably, the uttering thereof: see ranima, of which it is an inf. n., in the next preceding paragraph]. (S, K.)

runumN c
runumN [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned; app. pl. of raAnimapN↓; like as rumumN is supposed to be of raAmRapN, originally raAmimapN;] Good, or excellent, female singers. (IAar, T, K.)

ranomapN c
ranomapN, (M, and so in copies of the K.) thus it seems to be accord. to [a rule observed in] the K, but accord. to Z it seems to be ranamapN↓, (TA, and thus it is written in the CK,) and taronamuwtapN↓, (M, and so in the K accord. to the TA,) or taronamuwtN↓, (S, [and so in my MS. copy of the K,]) or this last also, (M,) or taronuwmapN↓ or turonuwmapN, (accord. to other copies of the K,) i. q. taranRumN [i. e. A trilling, or quavering, &c.: see 5]. (S, M, K.) Thus in the phrases, samiEa ranomapF HasanapF and taronamuwtapF↓ [He heard a good, or pleasing, trilling, &c.]: (M:) and lahu ranomapN HasanapN or ranamapN↓ and taronamuwtapN↓ &c. (accord. to different copies of the K) [i. e. He, or it, has a good, or pleasing, trilling, &c.]. taronamuwtN↓ is formed by the addition of w and t, like as is malakuwtN: (S:) it is said to be the only instance in which t is added at the beginning and end of a word: (MF:) and it is used in relation to a bow [as meaning A musical ringing sound on the occasion of twanging]. (S, M.) [raniymN↓, also, said in the TK to be an inf. n. of ranima, and in the M and K to be syn. with taroniymN, is used in a similar manner:] you say, samiEotu lahu raniymFA [I heard him to have a trilling, or quavering, sound proceeding from him; or I heard it to have a musical ringing sound proceeding from it]; taken from the taranRum of the bird in its cooing. (Msb.)

ranamapN c
ranamapN A certain slender plant, (T, K,) well known; (T;) said by As to be one of the plants growing in plain, or soft, ground: (A'Obeyd, T:) IAar is related to have said that the ranamap, with n, is a certain species of tree: Sh knew not this word, and supposed it to be a mistranscription for ratamap; but the ratam are [comparatively] large trees, [or rather shrubs, of the broom-kind,] having trunks; whereas the rnmp is of the slender kind of plants [as is said above]. (T.) ＝ -A2- See also the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

raniymN c
raniymN: see ranomapN.

raAnimapN c
raAnimapN: see runumN.

taronamuwtN c
taronamuwtN: see ranomapN, in two places. ― -b2- Also an epithet applied to a bow, meaning Having a plaintive sound (HisRN, so in a copy of the M, or HaniynN, K, TA) on the occasion of shooting. (M, K.)

taronamuwtapN c
taronamuwtapN: see ranomapN, in three places.

taronuwmapN c
taronuwmapN or turonuwmapN: see ranomapN.

1 ranaA UilayohaA c
1. ranaA UilayohaA, (Lth, T,) or Uilayohi, (S, M,) and [ranaAhaA, or] ranaAhu, (M, TA,) aor. yaronuw, (Lth, T, S, Msb,) inf. n. runuwRN (Lth, T, S, M, Msb, K) and ranFA, (Lth, T, M, K,) He gazed, i. e., looked continually, (Lth, T, S, M, K,) without any motion of the eyes, (M, K,) at her, (Lth, T,) or at him, or it: (S, M:) or ranaA Uilayohi signifies [simply] he looked at him, or it; as also ranaOa; but the former is said to be the original word. (TA in art. rnO.) [See also 5.] ― -b2- runuwRN also signifies The being cheered, or delighted, and pleased, or being diverted, together with occupation of the heart and eyes, and with predominance of love and desire. (M, K.) You say, yaronuw UilaI HadiyvihaA [He is cheered, or delighted, &c., with her discourse]. (M, K.) And ranawotu UilaI Hadiyvihi I was cheered, or delighted, and pleased, or was diverted, with his discourse. (T.) And ranaA likacaA and lahu AstrnI↓ He was cheered, &c., as above, by reason of such a thing: and so OaranRa lh. (T in art. rn.) And ranaA, (K,) aor. as above, (TA,) is syn. with Tariba [app. as meaning He was, or became, affected with a lively emotion of joy, moved with delight, mirthful, joyful, glad, or delighted]. (K.) [See runaMCN, below, which is perhaps an inf. n.]

2 rnRAhu c
2. rnRAhu: see 4. ― -b2- Also, (TA,) inf. n. taroniyapN, (K,) i. q. TarRabahu [app. as meaning He, or it, affected him with a lively emotion of joy; moved him with delight; rendered him mirthful, joyful, glad, or delighted: see also 4]. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A2- taroniyapN signifies also The act of singing. (K.) And i. q. HaniynN [app. as meaning The uttering a plaintive sound, or plaintive sounds]. (K.) A woman's crying out loudly, or vehemently; and uttering a plaintive, or mournful, voice or sound or cry, in singing or in weeping; like taroniynN. (M in art. rn.)

3 rAnAhu c
3. rAnAhu, (K,) inf. n. muraAnaApN, (TA,) He treated him with gentleness, or blandishment; soothed, coaxed, wheedled, or cajoled, him: (K, TA:) he treated him in an easy and a gentle manner. (TA.)

4 ArnAhu c
4. ArnAhu; (S, M, Msb, K;) and rnRAhu↓, (M, K,) inf. n. of the latter taroniyapN; (TA;) It (beauty, K, or beauty of aspect, M, or the beauty of a thing that he saw, S, Msb) made him to gaze, i. e., to look continually, (S, M, K,) without any motion of the eyes: (M, K:) or pleased him: (Msb:) or pleased him, and made him to gaze, &c. (TA.) And the former, It (a thing) cheered, or delighted, him, and pleased him; or diverted him. (T in art. rn.) [See also 2.] ― -b2- ArnAhu UilaI AlTRaAEapi He (God, T) reduced him to obedience, so that he became still, and continued obedient: (T, TA:) from a trad. (T.)

5 trnRI c
5. trnRI He continued looking at the thing that he loved. (IAar, T, K.) [See also 1.]

6 taraAnawotu Eanohu c
6. taraAnawotu Eanohu I feigned myself unmindful of, or inadvertent to, him, or it. (A, TA.) [The primary meaning seems to be, I feigned myself looking steadily away from him, or it.]

10 Uisotaronawa
10: see 1.

ranFA c
ranFA A thing at which one looks (S, M, K) continually, [or gazes,] without any motion of the eyes, by reason of its beauty: (M, K:) an inf. n. used as a subst. properly so termed. (M.)

runapN c
runapN, or ArRunapu, a name of The month Jumádà-'l- Ákhireh: see AlrRunRaI in art. rn, and ruwnapN in art. rwn.

ranowapN c
ranowapN A piece of flesh or flesh-meat: pl. ranawaAtN, (IAar, T, K, TA,) like as XahawaAtN is pl. of XahowapN. (TA. [In the CK, the pl. is erroneously written ranowAtN.])

ranaMCN c
ranaMCN, with fet-h, (T,) like saHaAbN, (TA,) i. q. jamaAlN [Beauty, goodliness, comeliness, &c.]: (T, K:) so says AZ. (T.)

runaMCN c
runaMCN, with damm, i. q. TarabN [app. as meaning A lively emotion of joy; mirth, joy, gladness, or delight]. (K. [See also runRaACN, in art. rn: and see the last signification of 1 in the present art.]) ― -b2- Also A sound, voice, or cry: (El-Umawee, T, K:) [like ranRapN as expl. in the S and K:) pl. OaroniyapN. (T.)

ranuwRN c
ranuwRN in the following phrase is like EaduwRN: (K:) you say, huwa ranuwRu fulaAnapa He is one who gazes, or looks continually, at such a woman or girl: (Lth, T, S: [see also ranRaMCN:]) or he is one who is cheered, or delighted, or diverted, and pleased, with the discourse of such a woman or girl. (M, K. *) And fulaAnN ranuwRu AlOamaAniI Such a one is a person who expects things for which he wishes. (Lth, T, M. *)

rajulN ranRaMCN c
rajulN ranRaMCN A man who gazes, or looks continually, at women. (S. [See also ranuwRN.])

kaOosN ranawonaApN c
kaOosN ranawonaApN [A cup of wine] lasting, or continuing, syn. daAYimapN, (IAar, T, S, M, Msb, K,) to the drinkers; (EalaI AlXRarobi; IAar, T, K; AlXrb being with fet-h to the X, pl. [or rather quasipl. n.] of XaAribN; TA; [in the CK, and in one copy of the T, erroneously, ElyI AlXRurobi;]) still, or motionless; syn. saAkinapN: (S, Msb:) [were it not for this addition, the meaning might be thought to be, a cup of wine circling to the drinkers:] or pleasing: (Msb:) pl. ranawonayaAtN: (IAar, T, K:) the word rnwnAp is of the measure faEaloEalapN; (S;) [originally ranawonawapN;] and it occurs in the poetry of Ibn-Ahmar, (T, S, M,) but (as some say, S) has not been heard except in that poetry. (S, M.)

turonaI OrnI rOI rn rnA rnI trnI trny wrI
turonaI A fornicatress, or an adulteress: (M, K:) [accord. to ISd,] of the measure tufoEalu, from AlrRunuwRu; i. e., that is gazed at, or looked at continually; because she is made an object of suspicion, or evil opinion: (M:) [whence,] Aibonu turonaI One that is base-born. (S.) [See more in art. trn.]

muranRK c
muranRK A singer. (AA, K.)

1 rahiba c
1. rahiba, aor.
rahaba
, inf. n. rahabN (S, A, * Msb, K) and ruhobN (S, K) and ruhubN (Ksh and Bd in xxviii. 32) and rahobN (K) and rahobapN, (S, A, * K,) or this is a simple subst, (Msb,) and ruhobaAnN and rahabaAnN, (K,) He feared: (S, A, Msb, K:) or he
feared with caution. (TA.) You say, fiI qalobiI minohu rahobapN and rahabN [In my heart is fear, or cautious fear, of him, or it]. (A.) ― -b2- And rahibahu, inf. n. rahobapN (JK, Mgh) and ruhobapN and ruhobN and rahabN; (JK;) [and app. rahiba minohu, as seems to be indicated above;] He feared him, or it; (JK, Mgh;) [or feared him, or it, with caution;] namely, a thing. (JK.) ＝ -A2- See also the next paragraph, in two places.

2 rahRaba
2: see 4. ― -b2- [Hence, rhRbhu Eano kacaA, inf. n. tarohiybN, He made him to have no desire for such a thing; to relinquish it, or abstain from it; contr. of ragRabahu fiyhi: used in this sense by postclassical writers, and perhaps by classical authors also. ― -b3- And rhRbhu He made him a raAhibi, or monk: in this sense likewise used by post-classical writers; and mentioned by Golius as so used in El-Mekeen's History.] ＝ -A2- rahRaba, said of a man, He was, or became, fatigued, tired, weary, or jaded. (JK.) And rhb, [so in the TA, app. rahRaba, but perhaps rahaba↓, without teshdeed,] said of a camel, He rose, and then lay down upon his breast, by reason of weakness in his back-bone. (TA.) You say also, rahRabati AlnRaAqapu faqaEada yuHaAyiyhaA, (K, TA,) [or, accord. to some copies of the K, yuHaAbiyhaA,] inf. n. tarohiybN, (K,) but in some copies the verb is an unaugmented triliteral, [app. rahabat↓,] (TA,) The she-camel was fatigued, or jaded, by travel, so he sat feeding her and treating her well until her spirit returned to her. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A3- ruhRiba It (an iron head or blade of an arrow &c.) was rubbed [app. so as to be made thin: see rahobN]. (JK.)

4 Arhbhu c
4. Arhbhu (JK, S, A, K) and Astrhbhu↓ (S, A, K) He, or it, frightened him, or caused him to fear; (S, K;) as also rhRbhu↓: (MA:) or disquieted him, or agitated him, by frightening. (A.) You say, yaqoXaEirRu AlUihaAbu UicaA waqaEa minohu AlUirohaAbu [The skin quivers when frightening befalls from him]. (A, TA.) And Oarohaba AlnRaAsa Eanohu baOosuhu wanajodatuhu (tropical:) [His valour and courage frightened men away from him]. (A.) And lamo Ourohabo bika [lit. I was not frightened by thee]; meaning (tropical:) I did not see in thee what induced in me doubt, or suspicion, or evil opinion. (A, TA.) And Arhb AlUibila, (JK, A,) inf. n. UirohaAbN, (JK, K,) (tropical:) He drove away, (A,) or repelled, (JK,) or withheld, (K,) the camels, (JK, A, K,) Eani AlHawaDi [from the watering-trough or tank]. (A, K.) ＝ -A2- Arhb (said of a man, TA) also signifies He rode a camel such as is termed rahob. (K.) ＝ -A3- Also He was, or became, long in the rahab, i. e. sleeve. (IAar, K. *)

5 trhRb c
5. trhRb He (a man) became a raAhib [or monk], fearing God, or fearing God with reverence or awe: (TA:) or he devoted himself to religious services or exercises (JK, S, A, K) in his SawomaEap [or cell]: (A:) or he (a monk) detached himself [from the world. or became a recluse,] for the purpose of devoting himself to religious services or exercises. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- trhRbhu He threatened him. (K.)

10 Astrhbhu c
10. Astrhbhu He called forth fear of him, so that men feared him. (TA.) waQsotarohabuwhumo, in the Kur [vii. 113], has been expl. as meaning And they called forth fear of them, [i. e. of themselves,] so that men feared them. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 4.

rahobN c
rahobN An emaciated she-camel; (As, S, K;) or so [the fem.] rahobapN: (JK:) or the former, a she-camel much emaciated; as also rahobaI↓; or, as some say, this last, occurring in a verse, is the name of a particular she-camel: and the first also signifies a she-camel lean, and lank in the belly: (TA:) or tall; applied to a he-camel; (K;) fem. with p: (TA:) or one that has been used in journeying, and has become fatigued, or jaded; (JK, TA;) fem. with p: and rahobaMCu↓ signifies a she-camel fatigued, or jaded: and the first, a he-camel large, wide in the belly-girth, broad in make between the shoulder-joints: (JK:) or wide in the bones, broad in make between the shoulder-joints. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A slender arrow: or a great arrow: (TA:) and a thin iron head or blade (S, K, TA) of an arrow: (S, TA:) pl. rihaAbN. (S, K.)

ruhobN c
ruhobN: see what next follows, in two places.

rahabN c
rahabN (Zj, K, TA) and ruhobN↓ (Zj, TA) A sleeve: (T, K:) accord. to Z, (TA,) of the dial. of Himyer; but one of the innovations of the expositions [of the Kur-án]: (Ksh in xxviii. 32, and TA: [not, as Golius says, referring to the Ksh as his authority, of the dial. of the Arabs of El- Heereh:]) said in the Jm to be not of established authority: but signifying thus accord. to AA: and so accord. to Zj, (L, TA,) and Mukátil, (T, L, TA,) in the Kur xxviii. 32; [though generally held to be there, accord. to all the various readings, (which are AlrRahab and AlrRuhob and AlrRuhub and AlrRahob,) an inf. n. of rahiba;] and Az says that this is a correct meaning in Arabic, and the most agreeable with the context. (L, TA.) One says, waDaEotu AlXRaIoCa fiI ruhobiI↓, meaning I put the thing in my sleeve [to carry it therein, as is often done] (TA.)

rahobapN c
rahobapN: see what next follows: ― -b2- and see also rahobaAniyRapN.

rahobaI c
rahobaI and ruhobaI↓ and rahobaMCu↓ and ruhobaMCN↓ [which last I write with tenween accord. to a general rule applying to words of the measure fuEolaMC] and rahabuwtN↓ and rahabuwtaI↓, each a simple subst., (K,) as also rahobapN↓, (Msb, [but accord. to the S and K, this last is an inf. n. of rahiba,]) signifying Fear: (Msb, K:) or fear with caution. (TA.) One says, xayorN mino raHamowtK rahabuwtN↓, (S, Meyd, K,) or, accord. to Mbr, xayorN mino raHamuwtaI rahabuwtI↓, (Meyd,) [Fear is better than pity, or compassion,] meaning thy being feared is better than thy being pitied, or compassionated: (S, Meyd, K:) a proverb. (Meyd. [See 1 in art. rgb.]) And ruhobaAka↓ xayorN mino rugobaAka, a similar prov. [expl. voce ragiba]. (Meyd.) And mina QllRehi wAlrRugobaI Uilayohi AlrRuhobaI↓ [also expl. voce ragiba]. (Lth, TA.) ＝ -A2- For the first word, see also rahobN.

ruhobaI c
ruhobaI: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

rahobaMCu c
rahobaMCu: see rahobaI: ＝ -A2- and see also rahobN.

ruhobaMCN c
ruhobaMCN: see rahobaI.

rahobaAnu c
rahobaAnu Excessively fearful. (Bd in lvii. 27.)

rahobanapN c
rahobanapN: see rahobaAniyRapN.

rahabuwtN c
rahabuwtN: see rahobaI, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also Fearful; applied to a man. (S.)

rahabuwtaI c
rahabuwtaI: see rahobaI, in two places.

rahobaAniyRapN c
rahobaAniyRapN, (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) written in an exposition of the Makámát [of El-Hareeree] without teshdeed, (Mgh,) [Monkery; asceticism; the life, or state, of a monk or an ascetic;] the state of a raAhib, (A, Msb,) or Christian devotee; (Mgh;) the masdar of raAhibN, (JK, S, K,) as also rahobapN↓: (S, K:) or it is originally from AlrRahobapu; and by a secondary application is used as a noun signifying excess, or extravagance: (AAF, TA:) or it is from rahobanapN↓, [which has the same signification, of the measure faEolanapN from rahobapN, or faEolalapN on the supposition that the n is a radical letter: (IAth, TA:) or it signifies excess in religious services or exercises, and discipline, and the detaching oneself from mankind; and is from rahobaAnu, signifying “excessively fearful:” so in the Kur lvii. 27; where it is said, warahobaAniyRapF QbotadaEuwhaA, (Bd,) meaning waQbotadaEuwA rahobaAniyRapF QbotadaEuwhaA [And they innovated excess &c.: they innovated it]: (AAF, Bd, TA:) and some read with damm, [ruhobaAniyRapF,] as though from ruhobaAnN, pl. of raAhibN. (Bd.) It is said in a trad., (TA,) laA rahobaAniyRapa fiI AlUisolaAmi [There is no monkery in El-Islám]; i. e., no such thing as the making oneself a eunuch, and putting chains upon one's neck, and wearing garments of hair-cloth, and abstaining from flesh-meat, and the like. (K.) And in another trad., Ealayokumo biQlojihaAdi faUinRahu ruhobaAniyRapu OumRatiI [Keep ye to the waging of war against the unbelievers, for it is the asceticism of my people]. (TA.)

rahaAbN c
rahaAbN and ruhaAbN: see what next follows.

rahaAbapN c
rahaAbapN (S, K) and ruhaAbapN and rahRaAbapN↓ and ruhRaAbapN accord. to El-Hirmázee, (K, TA,) [The ensiform cartilage, or lower extremity of the sternum;] a certain bone, (S, K,) or small bone, (TA,) in the breast, impending over the belly, (S, K, TA,) resembling the tongue, (S,) or like the extremity of the tongue of the dog: (TA:) or a certain cartilage, resembling the tongue, suspended in the lower part of the breast, impending over the belly: (TA:) the tongue of the sternum, at the lower part: (ISh, TA:) or, accord. to IAar, the extremity of the stomach: (TA:) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] rahaAbN↓ [and ruhaAbN]. (K.)

rahRaAbapN c
rahRaAbapN and ruhRaAbapN: see what next precedes.

raAhibN c
raAhibN Fearing; [or a fearer; or fearing with caution; or a cautious fearer;] as in the phrase huwa raAhibN mina QllRehi [He is one who fears God; or a fearer of God; &c.]: whence the signification
next following. (Msb.) ― -b2- A Christian [monk, ascetic, religious recluse, or] devotee; (Mgh, Msb;) one who devotes himself to religious services or exercises, in a SawomaEap [or cell]; (TA;) one of the ruhobaAn of the Christians: (S, K:) [i. e.] the pl. is ruhobaAnN (A, Mgh, Msb) and rahabapN; (A;) or, sometimes, ruhobaAnN is a sing.; (K;) as in the following ex., cited by IAar:
lawo kalRamato ruhobaAna dayorK fiI Alqulalo
laQnoHadara AlrRuhobaAnu yasoEaI fanazalo
[If she spoke to a Christian monk in a monastery among the summits of a mountain, the Christian monk would come down running, and so descend]: but he says that the approved way is to use it as a pl.: (TA:) and rahaAbiynu is a pl. (A, Msb, K) of ruhobaAnN, (K,) and rahaAbinapN is another pl. (A, K) of the same, and so is ruhobaAnuwna. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also marohuwbN.

raAhibapN c
raAhibapN A state, or condition, that frightens. (TA.)

OarohaAbN c
OarohaAbN Birds that are not rapacious; that do not prey. (K.) [App. so called because timid; as Golius supposes.]

murahRibN c
murahRibN, applied to a she-camel, [though of a masc. form,] Fatigued in her back. (TA. [See its verb, 2.])

marohuwbN c
marohuwbN Feared: (Mgh, Msb:) [or feared with caution:] applied to God. (Msb.) In the phrase labRayoka marohuwbN wamaroguwbN Uilayoka [At thy service time after time: Thou art feared, and petitioned, or supplicated with humility, &c.], it is in the nom. case as the enunciative of an inchoative [Oanota] suppressed. (Mgh.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Almarohuwbu, as also AlrRaAhibu↓, [the latter in this case being like raADK in the sense of maroDiIRN,] The lion. (K.)

4 Arhj c
4. Arhj, (K,) or Arhj AlgubaAra, (S, Mgh,) He, or it, raised the dust. (S, Mgh, K.) You say, Oarohajato HawaAfiru Alxayoli The hoofs of the horses raised the dust. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence, because a heavy rain raises the dust,] Arhjt AlsRamaMCu (tropical:) The sky poured, or flowed, with rain. (A, K.) ― -b3- And Arhj bayonahumo (tropical:) He raised, or excited, conflict and faction, or sedition, or discord or dissension, between them, or among them. (A.) ― -b4- And ArhjwA fiI AlkalaAmi waAlSRaxabi (tropical:) [They raised a tumult in talking and clamouring]. (A.) ― -b5- And Arhj He had in his house, or chamber, much baxuwr [or incense]. (IAar, K.)

rahojN c
rahojN: see what next follows.

rahajN c
rahajN (S, A, Mgh, K) and rahojN↓ (K) Dust, syn. gubaArN, (S, A, Mgh, K,) raised. (Mgh.) In the phrase Ealayohi rahaju AlgubaAri [Upon him, or it, is raised dust], AlgbAr is subjoined by way of explanation. (Mgh.) It is said in a trad., mano daxala jawofahu AlrRahaju lamo yadoxulohu HarRu AlnRaAri [He into whose inside the dust raised in fighting in the cause of God has entered, the heat of the fire of Hell will not enter it]. (TA. [The meaning is shown by another trad. there cited.]) ― -b2- Also, (K,) or the former word, (TA,) Clouds, (K,) or thin clouds, (TA:) without water, (K,) resembling dust: (TA:) n. un. with p. (K.) ― -b3- Also, (K,) or the former word, (TA,) (tropical:) Excitement of evil or mischief, of conflict and faction, of sedition, or of discord or dissension. (IAar, L, K, TA.)

ruhojuwjN c
ruhojuwjN: see what next follows.

rihojiyjN c
rihojiyjN Weak; (K;) applied to a young weaned camel; (TA;) or to a man and an animal [of any kind]: (TK:) and soft; as also ruhojuwjN↓, (K,) with damm; (TA; in the CK [erroneously] rahojuwj;) applied to a man. (TK.)

maXoIN rahowajN c
maXoIN rahowajN (S) An easy, gentle, pace: (TA:) the latter app. a Pers. word, arabicized; (S;) [from rahowaA or rahowaAro, or] its Pers. original is rahowaho. (L.)

rahowajapN c
rahowajapN A certain [easy] kind of pace. (S, K.)

nawoCN murohijN c
nawoCN murohijN (tropical:) [A star, or an asterism, of the Mansions of the Moon, or of any that were believed to bring rain,] attended by much rain [as though it raised the dust]. (A, K.)

Q. 1 rahodana c
Q. 1. rahodana, (TA,) inf. n. rahodanapN, (K, TA,) He circled in walking [like the bird called rahodanN]: (K, TA:) or he was as though he circled in his gait. (Az, TA.) See rahodanN. ― -b2- He was, or became, slow, tardy, dilatory, late, or backward. (K, TA.) And He was, or became, restricted, or limited. (K, TA.) A poet, cited by IAar to Th, says,
fajiYotu biAlnRaqodi walamo Ourahodino
i. e. [And I brought the cash, or ready money, and] was not slow, or tardy, &c., and was not restricted, or limited, with it. (TA.)

rahodanN c
rahodanN (S, K) and ruhodanN↓ and rihodanN↓ (K) A certain bird, in Mekkeh, like the EuSofuwr [or sparrow]; (S, K;) as also rahodanapN↓, and ruhodunRapN↓ and ruhoduwnN↓: (K:) and a certain bird resembling the jumRar, [which is said by Es-Sakháwee, cited in the Msb in art. Hmr, to be the qubRar, i. e. lark,] except that it is Oadobas [i. e. brown, or of a colour between black and red, or of a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour, in which are redness and blackness], and is larger than the HumRar; as also rahodanapN↓: (S, TA:) pl. rahaAdinu: (S, K:) and rahodalN, pl. rahaAdilu, signifies the same: (TA:) or the ruhodunRap↓ is a bird resembling the qunoburap [or lark], that moves as though circling (kaOanRahaA tasotadiyru turahodinu↓) in her gait: (JK:) and accord. to the L, in art. HDb, the rahodan is the qunobur [or lark]. (TA in that art.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A coward: (K, TA:) as being likened to the bird so called. (TA.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) Foolish; stupid; or unsound, or deficient, in intellect or under- standing: (K:) or so the first word (rahodanN): or a weak man: (JK:) pl. rahaAdinapN. (TA.)

ruhodanN c
ruhodanN: see the next preceding paragraph.

ruhodunN c
ruhodunN, without teshdeed, (assumed tropical:) A heavy [or slow] man. (JK.)

rihodanN c
rihodanN: see rahodanN.

rahodanapN c
rahodanapN and ruhodunRapN: see rahodanN; for each in two places.

ruhoduwnN c
ruhoduwnN: see rahodanN. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) A liar. (K.)

1 rahVTa
1: see what next follows.

8 naHonu cawuw QrotihaATK c
8. naHonu cawuw QrotihaATK We are collected together, or congregated; as also naHonu cawuw rahoTK↓: (K, TA:) [the last word in each of these phrases being an inf. n.; unless that in the latter be a mistake for OarohuTK, (a pl. of rahoTN,) which I find put in the place of rahoTK in a MS. copy of the K:] from Ibn-'Abbád. (TA.) ― -b2- In a trad. occurs the phrase, faOayoqaZanaA wanaHonu QrotihaATN [And he waked us,] we being parties collected together, or congregated: the last word being an inf. n. put in the place of the verb [or rather of the part. n., or for cawuw QratihaATK]. (TA.)

rahoTN c
rahoTN (Lth, S, Msb, K, &c.) and rahaTN↓, (Lth, Msb, K,) but the former is the more chaste, (Lth, Msb,) A man's people, and tribe, (S, Msb, K,) consisting of his nearer relations: (Msb:) [i. e. his near kinsfolk:] and a number of men less than ten, among whom is no woman; (AZ, S, Msb, K;) as also nafarN: (AZ, Msb:) or from seven to ten; (IDrd, Msb, K;) and sometimes a little more; (IDrd;) less than seven, to three, being called nafarN: (Msb:) or from three to ten: (K:) or i. q. EaXiyrapN: (ISk, Msb:) or more than ten, to forty: (As, IF, Msb:) a pl., (S, Msb,) or a word having a pl. meaning, (Th, Az, Msb,) without any proper sing.; (Th, Az, S, Msb, K;) like nafarN and qawomN and maEoXarN and EaXiyrapN; all applied to men, exclusive of women: (Th, Msb:) and OurohuwTN↓ signifies the same: (ISh, TA:) the pl. of rhT is OarohuTN (Lth, S, K) and OarohiTapN (Lth) and OarohaATN, (S, K,) [all pls. of pauc.,] the last of these being pl. either of rahaTN or of rahoTN, (TA,) and OaraAhiTu, (S, ISd, K,) as though pl. of OarohuTN, (S, ISd,) though Sb makes it pl. of rahoTN, because of the rareness of the pl. pl., (ISd,) and OaraAhiyTu [which is app. pl. of OarohaATN]. (S, K.) You say, humo rahoTuhu dinoyapF They are his people, and his tribe, closely related. (S, TA.) And it is said in the Kur [xxvii. 49], wakaAna qiI Almadiynapi tisoEapu rahoTK, (S,) but this means, [And there were in the city] nine persons, (Bd,) or nine men. (Jel.) ― -b2- You also say rahoTN mino EuXarK [A collection of plants of the kind called EXr]. (IAar, Sh, TA in art. Ayk.) ＝ -A2- An enemy; syn. EaduwRN; (K, TA; [in the CK Eadow;]) mentioned by Sgh, on the authority of Ibn- 'Abbád. (TA.) ＝ -A3- A skin, (K,) or a waistwrapper (UizaAr) made of leather, (Jm,) the sides
of which are slit in several places in their lower parts, so that one may walk in it; (Jm, K;) or made of skin, and also of wool; (Aboo-Tálib the Grammarian;) or a skin of Et-Táïf, slit in several places; (M, TA;) or a skin of a size equal to the space between the navel and the knee; (S;) or a skin slit into a number of thongs or strips; (ISh, S, K;) or a skin cut into a number of thongs or strips, these being one above another; (AHeyth;) or a waist-wrapper (miYozar) made of skin, or leather, slit in several places, except in the place of the pudendum; (TA;) or a skin slit into strips, each strip being of the breadth of four fingers; (IAar;) worn by children, (M, K,) or by a young girl before she has arrived at puberty, (IAar,) and by a woman in menstruis: (IAar, S, M, K, &c.:) [in Nubia, the rahoT, still called by that name, is very neatly made, consisting of a great number of slender thongs: it is worn there by young girls, and is generally their only covering, completely surrounding and concealing the pelvic portion of the body, and the whole or part of the thighs:] in the Time of Ignorance, the men used to perform their circuitings [around the Kaabeh] naked, and the women wearing [only] the rhT: (S:) [see also HawofN, in two places:] the pl. is OarohaATN [a pl. of pauc.] (S, TA) and rihaATN: (ISh, S, K:) or this last is a sing. also, (K,) signifying a piece of leather of a size equal to the space between the place of the waist-band and the knee, slit in several places like the [thongs called] Xuruk [of the sandal, pl. of XiraAk]; worn by a girl of seven years: or a garment worn by the boys of the Arabs of the desert, consisting of overlapping folds or plies, one above another, like fans: (TA:) pl. OarohiTapN [a pl. of pauc.]. (K.)

rahaTN c
rahaTN: see rahoTN.

rahoTiIRN c
rahoTiIRN Of, or relating to, or belonging to, a rahoT, meaning a man's people, and tribe, &c. (L.)

ruhaTapN c
ruhaTapN: see what next follows.

ruhaTaMCu c
ruhaTaMCu: see what next follows.

raAhiTaMCu c
raAhiTaMCu and ruhaTapN↓ (S, K) and ruhaTaMCu↓, (K,) like daAmRaMCu, (S,) One of the holes of the jerboa, from which it takes forth the earth or dust, (S, K,) and collects it; (S;) it is the first hole that it excavates; (TA:) and is between the qaASiEaMC and the naAfiqaMC; and therein it hides its young: (Az, TA:) or, as AHeyth explains the first of these words, what the jerboa makes, or puts, at the mouth of the qASEAC, and what is behind that, covering its hole except enough to admit the light from it. (TA.)

OurohuwTN c
OurohuwTN: see rahoTN.

1 rahufa c
1. rahufa, aor.
rahufa
, inf. n. rahaAfapN (JK, MA, K) and rahafN (JK, K) and rahofN, (TA,) It (a sword, K, or a thing [of any kind], JK, TA) was, or became, thin, and slender; (JK, K, TA;) it (a sword) was, or became, thin in the edge or point; (Ham p. 349;) it was, or became, sharp, or keen; contr. of kalRa. (MA.) ＝ -A2- rahafahu: see what next follows.

4 Arhfhu c
4. Arhfhu, (JK, S, K, &c.,) inf. n. UirohaAfN; (Ham p. 93;) and rahafahu↓, aor.
rahafa
, (K,) inf. n. rahofN; (TA;) He made it (a sword, S, K, &c., or a thing [of any kind], JK) thin, (S, MA, K,) or sharp or pointed; (JK, MA;) he made it (a sword) thin in the edge or point; (Ham p. 93;) he made it sharp, or keen. (MA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Oarohafota EalayonaA lisaAnaka (tropical:) [Thou hast sharpened against us thy tongue]. (A, TA.) And Oarohifo garoba cihonika limaA Oaqwlu (tropical:) [Sharpen the edge of thine intellect for what I say]. (A, TA.)

rahiyfN c
rahiyfN Thin; slender; (JK, TA;) applied in this sense to a sword; (TA;) and also to a neck: (ISh, TA in art. btE:) or thin in the edge or point; applied to a sword: (Ham p. 349:) or sharp, or keen; thus applied: (JK, * MA:) but Az says that it is seldom used; murohafN↓ being used in its stead. (TA.)

murohafN c
murohafN (JK, S, TA) and marohuwfN↓ (JK, TA) Made thin; (JK, S, TA;) applied to a sword, (S, TA,) or to an arrow: (JK:) and the former, [or each,] made sharp or pointed: (JK:) [or made thin in the edge or pointed: or made sharp or keen: see 4:] and see also rahiyfN. ― -b2- OucunN murohafapN (assumed tropical:) A slender ear. (TA.) And xaSorN murohafN (assumed tropical:) A slender waist. (Ham p. 93.) And rajulN murohafu Aljisomi (JK, TA) and Albadani↓ marohuwfu↓, but the former is the more common, (tropical:) A man slender in the body. (TA.) ― -b3- farasN murohafN (assumed tropical:) A horse lank in the belly, having the ribs near together: which is a fault. (IDrd, K, TA.)

murohafapN c
murohafapN [as a subst., or an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant,] Swords; (Ham p. 93;) and so murohafaAtN: (S and TA in art. brd:) or swords made thin in the edge or point. (Ham p. 349.) One says murohafaAtN bawaAridu Sharp, or cutting, swords: (TA in art. brd:) or slaying swords. (S in that art.)

marohuwfN c
marohuwfN: see murohafN, in two places.

1 rahiqahu c
1. rahiqahu, (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
rahaqa
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. rahaqN, (S, Mgh, Msb,) He, or it, came upon, properly as a thing that covered, him, or it; or came to him, or it; syn. gaXiyahu: (S, K:) and (K) reached, or overtook, him, or it: (ElFárábee, Msb, K:) or it signifies, (K,) or signifies also, (S,) he drew near to, or approached, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) whether he took, or did not take, (S, K,) him, or it: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) or he followed him, and was near to reaching, or overtaking, him. (JK.) It is said in the Kur [x. 27], walaA yarohaqu wajuwhahumo qatarN walaA cilRapN, meaning (assumed tropical:) And there shall not come upon, or overspread, their faces [blackness, or darkness, nor abjectness, or ignominy]. (S, TA.) And you say, rahiqahu AldRayonu, (Msb, TA,) or dayonN, (Mgh,) Debt, or a debt, came upon him. (Mgh, Msb, TA.) And rahiqatonaA AlSRalaApu, (inf. n. ruhuwqN, Msb, or rahaqN, TA,) (tropical:) The time of prayer came upon us. (Mgh, * Msb, TA.) And it is said in a trad., UicaA SalRaI OaHadukumo UilaI AlXRaIoCi faloyarohaqohu, i. e. [When any one of you prays towards the thing,] let him come near to it. (JK, S.
