[In the Mgh, UilaI sutorapK faloyarohaqohaA, i. e. towards a thing that he has set up for that purpose, &c.]) One says also, Talabotu fulaAnFA HatRaI rahiqotuhu, inf. n. rahaqN, I sought such a one until I drew near to him, and, as it sometimes means, took him, or, as it sometimes means, did not take him. (S.) And Talabotu AlXRaIoCa HatRaI rahiqotuhu wakidotu Mxucuhu Oawo Oaxacotuhu [I sought the thing until I came near to it, and I almost took it, or I took it]. (Az, Msb.) And rahaqa XuxuwSu fulaAnK, i. e. (assumed tropical:) [Such a one's going, or going forth or away,] drew near. (S.) Oarohaqotuhu↓ also signifies I drew near to it; syn. daAnayotuhu. (Msb.) And one says, AllRayolu Oarohaqakumu↓ faOasoriEuwA, i. e. (tropical:) The night has drawn near [to you, therefore hasten ye]; syn. danaA. (TA.) ― -b2- You say also, rahiqahu bimaA yakorahu, inf. n. rahaqN, He did to him that which he disliked, or hated. (JK.) ― -b3- And rahiqotu UivomFA: see 4. ＝ -A2- rahiqa as an intrans. v.: see rahaqN, which is its inf. n., below.

2 ruhRiqa c
2. ruhRiqa He was one to whom rahaqN [q. v.] was attributed. (Mgh.) [He was one to whom ignorance was attributed; an object of suspicion in respect of his religion: (see the part. n., below:) or he was suspected of evil conduct.] It is said in a trad., SalRaI EalaI QmoraOapK turahRaqu, (S, Mgh,) meaning [He prayed over a woman] suspected of evil conduct. (S.)

3 rAhq c
3. rAhq, (S, Msb, K,) and rAhq AlHuluma, (JK, Az, K, all in art. xlf,) inf. n. muraAhaqapN, (Msb,) He (a boy) was, or became, near to attaining puberty, or virility; (S, Msb, K;) as also Arhq↓, inf. n. UirohaAqN. (Msb.) And rAhqt AlEiXoriyna [She nearly attained the age of twenty]. (K in art. ESr.)

4 Arhqhu TugoyaAnFA c
4. Arhqhu TugoyaAnFA i. q. OagoXaAhu UiyRaAhu [i. e. He made excessive disobedience to come upon him, properly as a thing that covered him]; (S, K;) and OaloHaqahu bihi [i. e. made it to reach him, or overtake him, or befall him]. (K.) It is said in the Kur xviii. 79, faxaXiynaA Oano yurohiqahumaA TugoyaAnFA wakuforFA, meaning [And we disapproved] that he should make excessive disobedience, and ingratitude, to come upon them twain, by his undutiful conduct, so bringing evil upon them: or that he should couple with the faith of them twain his excessive disobedience and his ingratitude, so that there would be in one house two believers and one who was excessively disobedient and ungrateful: or that he should communicate to them twain his excessive disobedience and his ingratitude. (Ksh, Bd. [See also xaXiIa.]) And one says, OarohaqaniI fulaAnN UivomFA HatRaI rahiqotuhu↓, meaning Such a one made me to hear the burden of a sin, [as though he made the sin to come upon me as a burden,] so that I bore it. (S.) And Oarohaqotu AlrRajula OamorFA I made, required, or constrained, the man to bear, or endure, a thing, or an event. (Msb.) And rAhqhu EusorFA He made, required, or constrained, him to do a difficult thing: (AZ, S, Mgh, K:) or he made a difficulty to come upon him, properly as a thing
that covered him; syn. OagoXaAhu UiyRaAhu. (Ksh and Bd in xviii. 72.) And Arhqhu, alone, He demanded of him a difficult thing. (S, Msb, K.) You say, laA turohiqoniI laA Oarohaqaka QllRehu Demand not thou of me a difficult thing: may God not demand of thee a difficult thing. (AZ, S, K.) And UirohaAqN signifies also The inciting, or urging, a man to do a thing that he is not able to do. (Az, K, TA.) ― -b2- You say also, OarohaqonaAhumu AlxRayola We made the horsemen to overtake them, or come up with them: (TA:) or to be near doing so. (JK.) ― -b3- And Arhq AlSRalaApa (tropical:) He delayed the prayer (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA) until it approached the other [next after it], (JK,) or until it almost approached the other, (Mgh, K, TA,) or until the time of the other approached. (S, Msb.) ― -b4- And Oarohaqotuhu Oano yuSalRiIa i. q. OaEojalotuhu EanohaA [i. e. I hurried him so as to prevent him from praying: see similar phrases in art. Ejl]. (K.) ― -b5- See also 1, near the end of the paragraph, in two places: ― -b6- and see 3. ＝ -A2- Arhqt AldRaAbRapu AlsRaroja: see 4 in art. zhq.

rahaqN c
rahaqN The doing of forbidden things: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) wrongdoing; wrongful, unjust, in jurious, or tyrannical, conduct: (Fr, S, K:) it has this meaning in the Kur lxxii. 13, (S, TA,) accord. to Fr; or, as some say, the former mean ing: (TA:) the doing evil: (AA, K:) and a subst. from UirohaAqN signifying the inciting, or urging, a man to do a thing that he is not able to do: (Az, K:) lightwittedness; or lightness and hastiness of disposition or deportment; (S, K;) and excessive disobedience: so in the Kur lxxii. 6, (S, TA,) accord. to some: (TA:) foolishness, or stupidity: lightness, or levity: (K:) or ignorance, and lightness of intellect: (JK:) and illnature, or evil disposition: (TA:) and haste: (K:) and lying: (Mgh, K:) in all these senses, [i. e. in all that have been mentioned above as from the K, and app. in others also, above and below,] its verb is rahiqa↓, aor.
rahaqa
, [meaning He did forbidden things: acted wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically: &c.:] (K, TA:) of which it is the inf. n.: (TA:) and the following meanings also are assigned to it [app. by interpreters of the passages in which it occurs in the Kur]: sus picion, or evil opinion: and sin: accord. to Katádeh: lowness, vileness, or meanness; and weakness; accord. to Zj: error; accord. to Ibn El-Kelbee: and bad, or corrupt, conduct: and pride: and so rahoqapN↓, in these two senses: and the commission of a sin or crime or fault; syn. EanatN: and the act of reaching, or overtaking [app. of some evil accident]: and perdition. (TA.)

rahiqN c
rahiqN A man in whose conduct, or character, is rahaqN [expl. above: i. e. one who does forbidden things: &c.]: (O:) hasty: quick to do evil: and self-conceited; proud, or haughty. (TA.) And rahiqapN A vitious woman; or an adulteress, or a fornicatress. (TA.)

rahoqapN c
rahoqapN: see rahaqN.

yaEoduw AlrRahaqaI c
yaEoduw AlrRahaqaI He runs quickly, so as to require his pursuer to do what is difficult or what is beyond his power (HatRaI yurohiqa TaAlibahu, or, as in the CK, HtRI yurohaqa TaAlibuhu [which is virtually the same]): (M, K, TA:) or he runs quickly, so that he almost reaches, or overtakes, (HtRI yakaAda yarohaqu,) the object of his pursuit. (JK.)

ruhoqaAnu miAYapK c
ruhoqaAnu miAYapK: see what next follows.

ruhaAqu miAYapK c
ruhaAqu miAYapK and rihaAqu miAYipK As many as a hundred; (AZ, ISk, JK, S, K;) as also mAYp ruhoqaAnu↓: (so in one of my copies of the S:) such are said to be a man's camels, (JK,) or such is said to be a company of men. (AZ, ISk, S.)

rahuwqN c
rahuwqN A wide-stepping, and quick, or excellent, she-camel, that comes upon him who leads her so as almost to tread upon him with her feet. (En Nadr, K.)

rahiyqN c
rahiyqN Wine: (K:) a dial. var. of raHiyqN, like as madohN is of madoHN. (TA.)

raAhiqN c
raAhiqN applied to a boy, and raAhiqapN applied to a girl, From ten to eleven years old. (TA.) [See also muraAhiqN.]

rayohuqaAnN c
rayohuqaAnN Saffron. (JK, IDrd, S, K.)

murohaqN c
murohaqN Reached, or overtaken, (JK, S, O, K,) to be slain. (S, O.) ― -b2- Straitened. (Ham p. 682.)

OatayonaA fiI AlEuSayori Almurohiqapi c
OatayonaA fiI AlEuSayori Almurohiqapi (tropical:) [app. We came when the time of the afternoon-prayer was drawing near; AlEuSayor being the dim. of AlEaSoru: see the phrase Oarohaqakumu AllRayolu faOasoriEuwA, near the end of the first paragraph]. (TA.)

murahRaqN c
murahRaqN One to whom men come (S, K, TA) often, (TA,) and at whose abode guests alight. (JK, S, K, * TA.) ― -b2- Also One to whom rahaqN [q. v.] is attributed: (JK, K:) [said in the TA to have no verb; but this is not the case: see 2:] one of whom evil is thought: (JK, S, K:) or who is suspected of evil, or of lightwittedness: (TA:) one to whom ignorance is attributed: (Mgh;) an object of suspicion in respect of his religion: (Mgh, TA:) corrupt [in conduct]: one in whom is sharpness [of temper] and lightwittedness. (TA.)

muraAhiqN c
muraAhiqN Near to attaining puberty; applied to a boy: (JK, Mgh, TA:) and with p applied to a girl. (TA.) [See also raAhiqN.] ― -b2- [Hence,] daxala makRapa muraAhiqFA (tropical:) He entered Mekkeh nearly at the end of the [proper] time [to do so as a pilgrim], so that he almost missed the halt at 'Arafát. (Nh, O, K, TA.) And SalRaI AlZRuhora muraAhiqFA (tropical:) He performed the noon-prayer nearly missing the time. (TA.)

1 rahila laHomuhu c
1. rahila laHomuhu, (S, K,) [aor.
rahala
,] inf. n. rahalN, (JK, TA,) His flesh was, or became, quivering, and flaccid, or flabby: (S, K:) and (some say, TA) his flesh was, or became, inflated, or puffy, or swollen, (K, TA,) in any part: (TA:) or it was, or became, swollen without disease; (JK, K, TA;) he being flaccid by reason of fatness, (JK, TA,) and inclining to weakness. (TA.) [See also 5.]

2 rhRlhu c
2. rhRlhu, inf. n. tarohiylN, It (flesh-meat) rendered it (i. e. his flesh) quivering, and flaccid, or flabby: (S, K:) or inflated, or swollen: or swollen without disease: (K: [see 1:]) or it (much sleep) rendered his face swollen, and the parts below, or around, his eyes puffy. (TA.)

5 trhRl c
5. trhRl He was, or became, soft in the flesh: and it (the flesh of a limb or member) was, or became, soft. (KL.) [See also 1.]

riholN c
riholN [in the Lexicons of Golius and Freytag rihalN] Thin clouds, resembling [falling] dew, (K, TA,) in the sky. (TA.)

rahalN c
rahalN Yellow water [or fluid] in the suxod [app. here meaning the membrane that encloses the fœtus of a beast]. (IDrd, K.)

rahilN c
rahilN Quivering, and flaccid, or flabby, flesh. (TA.) And rahilN AlSRadori A horse quivering, and flaccid, or flabby, in the breast. (S, TA.)

OaSobaHa murahRalFA c
OaSobaHa murahRalFA He was, or became, in the morning, swollen (K, TA) in his face, by reason of much sleep. (TA. [See 2. In some copies of the K, tahayRaja is erroneously put, in this explanation, for tahabRaja.])

1 ruhimati AlOaroDu c
1. ruhimati AlOaroDu The land was rained upon [with such rain as is termed rihomap]. (Z, TA.)

4 Arhmt AlsRamaMCu c
4. Arhmt AlsRamaMCu, (JK, K,) or AlsRaHaAbapu, (S,) The sky, or the cloud, shed the sort of rain, or rains, termed rihomp, or rihaAm. (JK, S, K.)

rihomapN c
rihomapN A drizzling and lasting rain; i. e. a lasting, or continuous, rain, consisting of small drops: (JK:) or weak and lasting rain, (S, K,) said by AZ to be such as falls with more force, and passes away more quickly, than that which is termed diymapN: (S:) pl. rihamN and rihaAmN: (JK, S, K:) El-Ámidee seems to have held that rihaAmN is pl. of rahamapN; for he likens these two words to UikaAmN and OakamapN; but this is at variance with what is held by the leading lexicologists. (TA.) [See an ex. of the pl. rihaAmN in a verse of Lebeed cited in the first paragraph of art. rzq.]

OaroDN rahomaMCu c
OaroDN rahomaMCu Land upon which rains such as are termed rihaAm have fallen: (Ham p. 99:) and rawoDapN marohuwmapN↓, [from ruhimat, Meadows] watered by the rain termed rihomapN: (JK, S, K:) one should not say murohamapN. (K.)

rahomaAnu c
rahomaAnu: see rahuwmN.

rahamaAnN c
rahamaAnN, in the going of camels, A bearing, and leaning, on one side, or sideways. (JK, * K. [In the former, it is implied that the word is rahomaAn, which is at variance with an express statement in the K.])

rahaAmN c
rahaAmN (assumed tropical:) A sheep, or goat, [XaApN,] lean, or ema ciated; (JK, K; [in the former written ruhaAm, but said in the latter to be like saHaAbN;]) and so
rahuwmN↓: (TA:) [i. e.] you say also XaApN rahuwmN, (JK, K, TA,) meaning (assumed tropical:) a sheep, or goat, lean, or emaciated: (TA:) from [rahuwmN, or perhaps rahaAmN, or both, as meaning] clouds (saHaAbN) that have discharged their water. (JK.)

ruhaAmN c
ruhaAmN, applied to a bird, That does not prey: (K:) or the bird called guronuwq. (JK.) ＝ -A2- Also A large number. (JK, K.)

rahuwmN c
rahuwmN: see rahaAmN. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) A man weak in seek ing, or searching, [to find what is best to be done;] who follows mere opinion; as also rahomaAnu↓. (JK, K.)

Oarohamu c
Oarohamu More [and most] fruitful, or plentiful, or abundant in herbage or in the goods or conveniences or comforts of life: [as though meaning more, and most, watered by rain such as is termed rihomap:] so in the saying, nazalonaA bifulaAnK fakunRaA fiI Oarohami jaAnibayohi [We alighted at the dwelling of such a one, and we were in the more fruitful, &c., of the two sides of his place of abode; meaning, and we were entertained by him in the best, or most bountiful, manner]. (S.)

marohamN c
marohamN [A place upon which has fallen rain such as is termed rihomapN: pl. maraAhimu: see an ex. in what follows. ― -b2- Also] A certain application for wounds; (S;) a soft plaster or dressing, (K, TA,) the softest of medicaments, (TA,) [i. e. an unguent, or the like,] with which a wound is plastered, dressed, overspread, or anointed: (K, TA:) [pl. as above:] it is an arabicized word [from the Pers. marohamo]: (S:) or derived from AlrRihomapu, [as some say,] because of its softness. (K.) You say, maraAhimu AlgawaAdiI maraAhimu AlbawaAdiI [The places watered by the drizzling and lasting rains of the early morning-clouds are the soft plasters, or unguents, of the deserts]. (A, TA.)

rawoDapN marohuwmapN c
rawoDapN marohuwmapN: see OaroDN rahomaMCu, above.

1 rahana c
1. rahana, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
rahana
, (Msb,) inf. n. rahonN, (S, TA,) or ruhuwnN, (Msb,) It (a thing, S, Msb, TA) continued, subsisted, lasted, endured, remained, or remained fixed or stationary; it was, or became, permanent, constant, firm, steady, stead fast, stable, fixed, fast, settled, or established. (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA.) This is the primary signification. (Mgh, TA. *) ― -b2- Hence, (Mgh,) rahana biAlmakaAni (tropical:) He remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in the place. (A, Mgh, TA.) ― -b3- And rahana, (JK, S, K,) aor.
rahana
, (K, TA,) or
rahuna
, (JK, [but this I think to be a mis take,]) inf. n. ruhuwnN, (K,) said of a man, and of a camel, (JK, S, * TA,) and of any beast (TA,) He was, or became, lean, or emaciated; (JK, S, K, TA;) and fatigued, tired, weary, or jaded. (JK, TA.) You say, rakiba HatRaI rahana He rode until he became lean, or emaciated. (ISh, TA. [See raAhinN.]) ＝ -A2- As trans., see 4, first signification. ― -b2- [Hence,] as a law term, rahonN signifies The putting, or placing, an article of real property [to remain] as a pledge, or security, or making it to be such, for a debt that is obligatory or that will become obligatory. (TA.) You say, rahanahu AlXRaIoCa, and rahanahu Einodahu, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
rahana
, (K,) inf. n. rahonN (Msb, TA) [and rahiynapN, q. v. voce rahonN]; and Arhnhu↓ AlXRaIoCa; (S, K;) all signify the same; (S;) i. e. He deposited the thing with him (Msb, K) [as a pledge] to be in lieu of that which he had taken, or received, from him: (K:) [i. e. he pledged the thing to him, or with him:] and rahanotu AlmataAEa biAldRayoni, inf. n. rahonN, I restricted the commodity or placed it in custody, for, or by reason of, the debt; and bAldyn Arhnthu↓ is a dial. var. thereof, but of rare occurrence, and disallowed by those who are held in esteem: (Msb:) for, properly, they say, (Msb,) zayodFA AlvRawoba Oarohanotu↓ signifies I gave to Zeyd the garment, or piece of cloth, in order that he should deposit it as a pledge (Msb, K *) with some one. (Msb.) 'Abd-Allah Ibn Hemmám Es-Saloolee says, (S,) or Hemmám Ibn-Murrah, (TA,)
maAlikaA najawotu wa Oarohanotuhumo↓
falamRaA xaXiytu OaZaAfiyrahumo
[And when I dreaded their nails, I escaped, and gave them, or left with them, as a pledge, Málik]: thus, says Th, all relate the verse, except As, who says wa Oarohanuhumo mAlkA [i. e. leaving with them, as a pledge, Málik]: he likens this phrase to the say ing qumotu wa OaSukRu wajohahu; and this is a good way of explaining it; for the w is that which is a deno tative of state; the meaning being SaAkRFA wajohahu: [accord. to the former reading, in the opinion of Th,] the poet means I left Málik remaining with them; not as a pledge; because [when the leaving a thing as a pledge is meant, in his opinion,] one does not say, AlXRaIoCa Oarohanotu↓, but only rahanotuhu. (S, TA.) [See, however, 4.] You say also, rahanahu Eanohu, inf. n. rahonN, meaning He made him, or it, to be a pledge in lieu of him, or it: a poet, asserted by IJ to be a pagan, says,
Airohano baniyka Eanohumu Oarohano baniIo
[Make thou thy sons to be pledges in lieu of them: in that case I will make my sons to be pledges: baniI being for baniIRa]. (TA.) And rahanotuhu lisaAniI (assumed tropical:) [I made my tongue to be as though it were a pledge to him, to be restrained, or to be used, for his sake or benefit]: in this case one should not say Oarohanotuhu↓; (IAar, K;) though one says thus of a garment, or piece of cloth, [&c.,] as well as rahanotuhu. (TA.)

3 raAhunotu fulaAnFA EalaI kacaA c
3. raAhunotu fulaAnFA EalaI kacaA, (S, Msb,) inf. n. muraAhanapN, (S,) or rihaAnN, (Msb,) or both, (K, and so in a copy of the S,) I laid a bet, or wager, or stake, with such a one, for such a thing, (S, Msb, K, *) mostly (TA) said in relation to horses running a race, (JK, TA, *) to be taken by him who should outstrip, or overcome. (Msb.) ― -b2- The inf. ns. also signify (tropical:) The contending [of two persons] to outstrip [in a race] upon horses, (K, TA,) and otherwise. (TA.) Hence the prov., humaA kafarasaIo rihaAnK [explained in art. frs]. (JK.)

4 Arhn c
4. Arhn He made (a thing, Msb,) to continue, subsist, last, endure, remain, or remain fixed or stationary; to be, or become, permanent, can stant, firm, steady, steadfast, stable, fixed, fast, settled, or established; (S, * Mgh, * Msb, K; *) and so rahana↓; (K;) but the former is the more ap proved: (TA:) and also he found it to be so. (Msb.) You say, Arhn lahumu AlTRaEaAma, (T, S, K, TA,) and AlXRaraAba, (T, S, TA,) and AlmaAla, (TA,) (tropical:) He continued, or made permanent, to them the food, (T, S, K, TA,) and the beverage, (T, S, TA,) and the property. (TA.) [And accord. to an expla nation of Ourohinato (referring to dates), by 'Alee Ibn Hamzeh, cited in a marginal note in a copy of the S, in art. Oarohana, whb signifies He prepared food, and continued it, or made it permanent.] ― -b2- [Hence Arhnhu as used by some in another sense of rahanahu:] see 1, in six places. [That it is allowable to use it thus may be inferred from phrases here following.] ― -b3- You say, Oarohanotu maAliI I staked my property. (JK.) And OarohanuwA bayonahumo xaTarFA They gave, of their own free will, what the party approved, whatever were its amount, to be to them a stake at a race. (TA.) And Oarohanotu bihi waladiI (S, K, *) inf. n. UirohaAnN, (S,) (assumed tropical:) I made my children to be as a stake for him, or it. (S, K. *) And Arhnhu lilomawoti (assumed tropical:) He resigned him to death. (IAar, TA.) And Arhn AlmayRita Alqabora (tropical:) He deposited the dead body in the grave [as a pledge to be rendered up on the day of resurrection]. (K, TA.) ― -b4- Accord. to AZ, (S, TA, in one copy of the S it is A'Obeyd,) Oarohanotu fiI AlsRiloEapi signifies I bought the commodity for a dear, or an excessive, price; (S, K, TA;) gave largely for it until I obtained it: (TA:) accord. to ISk, I paid in advance for the commodity; syn. Oasolafotu; (S, TA;) and in the T it is said, [and in like manner in the JK,] that Arhn fiI kacaA wa kacaA signifies Aslf fiyhi: (TA:) [in the K it is said that Oarohanahu signifies Oasolafahu, as though it meant he lent him a sum of money &c.:] accord. to Er-Rághib, the proper meaning [of UirohaAnN] is one's giving a com modity before [the full payment of] the price, and so making it to be pledged for the completion of its price. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Arhnhu also signifies He, or it, weakened him: (K:) [like Oawohanahu:] and rendered him lean, or emaciated. (TA.) And Arhn QllRehu quwRatahu God weakened him; syn. Oawohanahu. (JK.)

6 trAhnA c
6. trAhnA They two laid bets, wagers, or stakes, each with the other; syn. tawaADaEaA AlrRuhuwna. (TA.) And trAhn Alqawomu The party contended together, every one of them laying a bet, wager, or stake, in order that the person outstripping should take the whole when he overcame. (Msb.)

8 Arthn minohu c
8. Arthn minohu He took, or received, from him a pledge. (K.) [Or] Arthnhu He took, or received, it as a pledge: (JK, Mgh:) or Arthnhu minohu he took, or received, it from him; namely, a pledge. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Accord. to Freytag, Arthnhu bihi signifies He had him, or held him, as a pledge to him for it. And Aurotuhina He, or it, was given as a pledge. But for neither of these has he mentioned any authority.]

10 Uisotarohana
10: [Astrhnhu He asked him, or desired him, to pledge a thing with him: and, to give a pledge.] You say, AisotarohananiI kacaA farahanotuhu Einodahu [He asked me, or desired me, to pledge such a thing, or to
deposit such a thing as a pledge, and I pledged it with him, or deposited it with him as a pledge]. (Mgh.)

rahonN c
rahonN, originally an inf. n., (Msb,) is syn. with marohuwnN↓; (Mgh, Msb;) i. e. (Msb) it signifies [A pledge;] a thing deposited with a person (Msb, * K) to be in lieu of a thing that has been taken, or received, from him; (K;) or a thing that is deposited as a security for a debt: and rihaAnN↓ has a similar meaning, but is specially applied to a thing that is deposited as a bet, or wager, or stake; and is likewise originally an inf. n.: (Er-Rághib, TA:) rahiynapN↓, also, is syn. with rahonN [as meaning the act of giving as a pledge], like as XatiymapN is syn. with XatomN; the p being added to give intensiveness to the significa tion: then, like rahonN, it is used as syn. with marohuwnN [in the sense explained above, as will be seen in what follows in this paragraph]; (IAth, TA;) [i. e.] rahiynapN is an inf. n. like XatiymapN, applied to denote the pass. part. n. [used as a subst. pro perly so termed] like rahonN, not as an epithet; (Bd in lxxiv. 41;) [or, in other words,] rahiynapN signifies anything by reason of which a thing [such as a debt or the like] is restricted, or appro priated, to oneself; as also murotahanapN↓: (K: [I here follow two copies of the K, in which it is said, kulRu maA QHotubisa bihi XaIoCN farahiynapN wa murotahanapN: in the CK, and in the copy of the K followed in the TA, farahiynuhu wa murotahanuhu, which perverts the meaning, though rahiynN↓ and murotahanN↓ may be used in the same sense as rahiynapN and muzotahanapN, as will be seen in the course of this paragraph: and in the TA, in the place of QHotubisa, is put yHbs, meaning yuHobasu: there is, however, this difference between rahiynapN↓ and murotahanapN↓; that the former properly signifies a thing deposited as a pledge; and the latter, a thing taken, or received, as a pledge:]) the pl. of rahonN is rihaAnN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and ruhuwnN (Mgh, Msb, K) and ruhunN, (Mgh, K,) this last said to be a pl. of rahonN by Aboo-' Amr Ibn-El-' Alà, but disap proved by Akh, because a word of the measure faEolN has not a pl. of the measure fuEulN except in rare and anomalous instances, though he says that it may be [as it is said to be in the Msb] pl. of rihaAnN, which is pl. of rahonN, (S,) and Fr says that ruhunN is pl. of rihaAnN, but this is denied in the M, because any pl. may not be pluralized except when there is express authority for it and when the case does not admit of any other decision; (TA;) and ruhonN, also, is another pl. of rahonN, (TA,) [or rather it is a contraction of ruhunN;] and another pl. of rahonN [or rather a quasi-pl. n.] is rahiynN↓, (IJ, K,) like as EabiydN is of EabodN: (TA:) the pl. of rahiynapN↓ is rahaAYinu. (S, K.) galiqa AlrRahonu bimaA fiyhi. [The pledge became, or has become, per manent as a possession, with what was, or is, comprised in it,] is a prov., applied to him who has fallen into a case from which he cannot hope to escape: it is said in a trad., laA yagolaqui AlrRahonu, (Meyd,) [i. e. The pledge shall not remain, or let not the pledge remain, in the hand of its receiver when its depositer is able to release it; for] lA is here either negative or prohibitive: you say, galiqa AlrRahonu, aor. yagolaqu, inf. n. guluwqN [or galaqN], meaning The pledge remained in the hand of the receiver when the depositor was able to release it: (Nh, cited in a copy of the “ Jámi' es-Sagheer: ”) the trad. means that the receiver of the pledge shall not have a right to it when the depositer has not released it within a certain time: for it was a custom in the Time of Ignorance for the receiver to keep possession of the pledge in this case; but El-Islám abolished it. (Meyd, * Nh.) You say also, huwa rahonN bikacaA and bkcA rahiynapN↓ He, or it, is [a person, or thing,] pledged for such a thing: (IAth, TA:) or taken [as a pledge] for such a thing; as also rahiynN↓ and murotahanN↓. (TA.) And OanaA rahonN bikacaA and rahiynN↓ and rahiynapN↓ I am taken [as a pledge] for such a thing. (Mgh.) And [hence,] OanaA laka rahonN bikacaA (JK, TA) and rahiynapN↓ (TA) I am responsible, or a surety, to thee for such a thing. (JK, TA.) And biqayodihi rijoluhu rahiynapN↓ [His leg, or foot, is a pledge for the safe-keeping of his shackle: for if the meaning were marohuwnapN it would be rahiynN, without p]. (TA.) And Alxaloqu Almawoti rahaAYinu↓ [Mankind, or all created beings, are the pledges of death]. (TA.) And huwa rahonu yadi AlmaniyRapi [He is the pledge of the hand of death, or of fate, or destiny]; said of one when he has sought, or courted, death. (TA.) And yadiI laka rahonN [My hand is a pledge to thee]; by which is meant responsibility, or suretiship. (TA.) And qaborK UinRahu larahiynu↓ [Verily he is the pledge of a grave, which will render him up on the day of resurrection]. (TA.) It is said in the Kur lxxiv. 41, kulRu nafosK bimaA kasabato rahiynapN↓, meaning [Every soul is a thing] pledged with God [for what it shall have wrought; its works being regarded as a debt, for which it will be either released or held in custody to be punished everlastingly]: rhynp being an inf. n. like XatiymapN applied to denote the pass. part. n. [in a manner before mentioned] like rahonN; for if it were an epithet [i. e. used in the proper sense of a pass. part. n.] the word would be rahiynN. (Bd.) And in lii. 21 of the same, kulRu QmoriYK bimaA kasaba rahiynN↓, i. e. [Every man is] pledged (marohuwnN, Bd, Jel) with God (Einoda QllRehi) for what he shall have wrought; so that if he have done good, He will release him; but other wise, He will destroy [or hold in confinement and punish] him; (Bd;) or to be punished for evil, and recompensed for good. (Jel.) And it is said in a trad., biEaqiyqatihi kulRu gulaAmK rahiynapN↓ [Every boy that is born is a pledge for his Eqyqp, i. e. for the victim that is to be sacrificed for him when his head is shaven the first time; which is com monly regarded as his ransom from the fire of Hell]: i. e., the Eqyqp is absolutely necessary for him; wherefore he is likened, when not released from it, to a pledge in the hand of the receiver: El-Khattábee says that the best explanation of it is that of Ahmad Ibn-Hambal; that if the Eqyqp be not sacrificed for the boy and he die an infant, he will not intercede for his parents. (TA.) ― -b2- See also what next follows.

huwa rihonu maAlK c
huwa rihonu maAlK, (JK, K, TA,) with kesr, (K,) and rahonuhu↓, (JK,) He is a manager, tender, or superintendent, of cattle, or camels &c.; or a good pastor thereof. (K, * TA.)

rihaAnN c
rihaAnN, as a sing: see rahonN. ― -b2- It is also a pl. of the latter word. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.)

rahiynN c
rahiynN: see marohuwnN: and see also rahonN in six places.

rahiynapN c
rahiynapN, and its pl. rahaAYinu: see rahonN, in ten places.

raAhinN c
raAhinN Continuing, subsisting, lasting, enduring, remaining, or remaining fixed or stationary, permanent, constant, firm, steady, steadfast, stable, fixed, fast, settled, or established. (S, * Mgh, Msb.) You say TaEaAmN raAhinN (S, Mgh) Food that continues, or is permanent, &c. (Mgh.) And xamorN raAhinapN Wine of which there is a con tinual, or constant, supply; uninterrupted, or unfailing. (TA.) And niEomapu QllRehi raAhinapN, i. e. [The bounty of God is] continual, permanent, or constant. (TA.) And HaAlapN raAhinapN A state, or condition, continuing; remaining to the present time. (Es-Semeen, TA.) And hecaA raAhinN laka meaning This is continual, or permanent, to thee; beloved by thee; and also as explained below. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Remaining, staying, dwelling, or abid ing, in a place. (JK.) ― -b3- Prepared. (K.) One says, hecaA raAhinN laka meaning as explained above, and also This is prepared for thee. (TA.) ― -b4- As an epithet applied to a man, and a camel, (JK, S, TA,) and any beast, (TA,) Lean, or emaciated; (JK, S, K, TA;) accord. to ISh, in consequence of riding, or disease, or some [other] accident: (TA:) and fatigued, tired, weary, or jaded. (JK, TA.) ― -b5- And UibilN raAhinapN Camels that will not, or do not, pasture upon the [plants, or tress, termed] HamoD. (JK.)

raAhinapN c
raAhinapN The navel, with what surrounds it, (JK, Az, K,) in the outer part of the belly (JK) of the horse. (JK, Az, K.)

UirohaAnN c
UirohaAnN A thong, or strap, that is bound upon the middle of the niyr [or yoke] that is upon the two bulls [drawing a plough]. (JK.)

OurohuwnN c
OurohuwnN A girl, or young woman menstruating: (K:) seen by Az in the handwriting of Aboo Bekr El-Iyádee, but not seen by him on any other authority. (TA.)

marohuwnN c
marohuwnN [Pledged; deposited as a pledge; or] restricted, or placed in custody, for, or by reason of, a debt; (S, * Msb;) originally marohuwnN biAldRayoni [or bidayonK]; (Msb;) and rahiynN↓ signifies the same; (S, Msb;) and the fem. of this [or rather the subst. formed from it, for when it is used as a fem. epithet, having the sense of a pass. part. n., it is without p, as remarked above, voce rahonN,] is rahiynapN. (S.) AlOumuwru marohuwnapN biOawoqaAtihaA is expl. by makofuwlapN [app. meaning Events are guaranteed, or pledged, for their times, to which they are limited by the decrees of God]. (TA.) See also rahonN.

murotahanN c
murotahanN: see rahonN, in two places.

murotahinN c
murotahinN One who takes, or receives, a rahon [or pledge]. (S.)

murotahanapN c
murotahanapN: see rahonN, in two places.

1 rahaA bayona rijolayohi c
1. rahaA bayona rijolayohi, aor. yarohuw, (AO, JK, S,) inf. n. rahowN, (AO, S, K,) He parted, or made an opening between, his legs: (AO, S, K:) or he parted widely, or made a wide opening between, his legs. (JK.) Hence the saying in the Kur [xliv. 23], wa Qtoruki AlbaHora rahowFA [expl. in art. trk, and below]. (S.) ― -b2- rahowN also signifies The going easily: (S, K:) one says, jaMCati Alxayolu rahowFA [The horses, or horsemen, came pacing along easily]: and accord. to IAar, rahaA fiI AlsRayori, aor. as above, mean He was gentle in going, or pace: (S:) or, as some say, rahowN in going, or pace, is the being soft, or gentle, with continuance: (TA:) or the going along quietly: (JK:) and one says, jaMCati AlUibilu rahowFA, meaning The camels came following one another. (TA.) Also The going lightly: (JK:) you say, rahato, aor. and inf. n. as above, They, [i. e. camels or the like,] or she, went lightly. (TA.) And The going vehemently. (TA.) [Thus it has two contr. significations.] ― -b3- Also The being still, quiet, motionless, calm, allayed, or assuaged. (K, TA.) You say, rahaA AlbaHoru The sea became still, or calm. (S.) And rahaA AlHarRu The heat became allayed, or assuaged. (TA.) Hence some explain wa Qtoruki AlbaHora rahowFA [mentioned above] as meaning And leave thou the sea motionless, or calm: some, as meaning dry. (TA.) And you say, AifoEalo celika rahowFA Do thou that quietly, or calmly. (S.) And faEala celika sahowFA rahowFA He did that quietly, or calmly, without being hard, or difficult: (TA:) or voluntarily; without its being asked, or demanded; (K and TA in art. shw;) and without constraint. (TA in that art.) And OaEoTayotuhu rahowFA I gave to him voluntarily; without being asked; or without con straint. (JK.) ― -b4- rahaA, (JK, TA) aor. as above, (TA,) inf. n. rahowN, (JK, K,) said of a bird, He spread his wings, (JK, K, TA,) without flapping them. (JK.)

3 rAhAhu c
3. rAhAhu, (K,) inf. n. muraAhaApN, (TA,) He ap proached it, or drew near to it. (K, TA.) [App. a dial. var. of raAhaqahu, which is better known.] You say, raAhayotu AlAiHotilaAma I approached, or drew near to, puberty, or virility. (JK.) ＝ -A2- Also He aided him in his foolishness, or stupidity; syn. HaAmaqahu. (K, TA: in the CK jaAmaEahu.)

4 ArhI c
4. ArhI He found, or met with, a wide, or an ample, place. (M, K.) ― -b2- He took to wife a woman wide in the vulva. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- He continued the food to his guests by reason of liberality. (TA.) And Oarohayotu lahumu AlTRaEaAma wa AlXRaraAba I continued to them the food and the beverage; (Yaakoob, S, K;) like Oarohanotu. (S.) ― -b4- He did well: they say to the shooter, or thrower, when he does ill, Oarohiho, i. e. Do thou well. (TA.) ― -b5- Oarohi EalaI nafosika Be gentle with, or to, thyself: (S, K, TA;) [in the CK Arohu; and (hence, perhaps,) thus in the printed edition of Har, p. 498; where it is said to be from rhA fI Alsyr, meaning rfq: but the right reading is Oarohi, for] one says also maA Oarohayota UilRaA EalaI nafosika Thou wast not, or hast not been, gentle, save with, or to, thyself: (TA:) or thou didst not show, or hast not shown, mercy, save to thyself. (JK.) ― -b6- ArhI laka AlXRaIoCu The thing became, or has become, within thy power, or reach; or possible, or practicable, to thee. (TA.) ― -b7- And Oarohayotuhu laka I made it, or have made it, to be within thy power, or reach; or possible, or practicable, to thee. (TA.) ― -b8- maA Oarohayotuhu I did not leave it still, or motionless: and Oarohi caAka Leave thou that until it become still, or motionless. (TA.) ＝ -A2- He kept continually, or constantly, to the eating of the [rahow, or species of crane called] kurukiIR. (K.)

6 taraAhayaA c
6. taraAhayaA, (JK, K,) inf. n. taraAhK, (JK,) They two made peace, or became reconciled, each with the other; syn. tawaAdaEaA. (JK, K, TA: in the CK twArEA.)

9 AirotahawoA c
9. AirotahawoA They became commingled, confounded, or confused. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also, (K,) or ArthwA rahiyRapF, (TA,) They made rahiyRap; i. e. they took ears of corn, and rubbed them with their hands, then bruised, or pounded, them, and poured milk thereon, and then cooked this mixture. (K, TA.)

rahowN c
rahowN inf. n. of 1. (S, K, &c.) ― -b2- Also An intervening space (JK, TA) between two things, (JK,) as, for instance, between the two humps of a camel of the species termed faAlij. (TA.) ― -b3- A place where water remains and collects or stagnates: (JK, TA:) a jawobap [i. e. a depressed place, or a hollow, or an excavation, or such as is round and wide,] in the place of abode of a people, into which flows the rain-water or other fluid: (A 'Obeyd, S:) or, as also rahowapN↓, a depressed place (S, K) in which water collects: (S:) and, both words, an elevated place: thus they have two contr. significations: (S, K:) or rahowapN↓ signifies an elevation like a hillock, upon a hard and elevated, or an elevated and plain, tract of ground, or upon a mountain, (JK, TA,) where hawks and eagles alight: (TA:) or a hillock inclining to softness, two or three cubits in height, but only in a soft tract of ground, and in hard, or hard and level, ground consisting of earth, mould, or clay; not upon a mountain: (TA:) [and accord. to some, it signifies a mountain itself; for] Ghatafán are called in a trad. tanobaEu maMCF rahowapN↓, meaning a mountain welling forth water: or it means that in them were roughness and hardness: (TA:) the pl. [accord. to the S app. of rahowN, and accord. to the TA app. of rahowapN↓, in each case agreeable with analogy,] is rihaMCN. * (S, TA.) ― -b4- [Also, accord. to Golius, as on the authority of the KL, A way through a market-place, at the sides of which sit the sellers: but not in my copy of the KL.] ＝ -A2- Also Wide, ample, or spacious. (TA.) ― -b2- A well (biYorN) wide in the mouth. (TA.) ― -b3- A woman (S) wide in the vulva; (Lth, ISh, S, K;) as also rahowaI↓ (Lth, K) and rahaMCN↓: (IAar, K:) [or] a woman who will not refrain from vitious conduct, or adultery, or fornication; as also rahowaI↓: (JK, TA:) or (TA) a woman that is not approved on the occasion of jimaAE, (JK, TA,) because of her being wide [in the vulva]. (JK.) ― -b4- A thing dispersed, or scattered. (TA.) ― -b5- And sometimes, Quick, or swift. (TA.) ― -b6- And Still, quiet, or motionless. (TA.) ― -b7- And [hence, or maTarN rahowN,] A still rain. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Also A company of men (JK, K, TA) following one another. (TA.) And gaArapN rahowN [A company of horsemen making a raid, or an inroad, or incursion,] following one another. (TA.) And one says, AlnRaAsu rahowN waAHidN maA bayona kacaA wa kacaA i. e. mutanaAZiruwna [app. meaning The people are disposed consecutively in one double rank, partly such and partly such, facing one another]. (TA.) ＝ -A4- Also A certain species of bird; as some say, (S,) the [species of crane called] kurokiIR: (JK, S, K, TA:) or a certain aquatic bird resembling the krkIR: (TA:) pl. rihaMCN. (JK.) ＝ -A5- And A headcovering which is next to the head, and which very soon becomes dirty. (TA.)

rahowapN c
rahowapN A state of elevation: and a state of depression: thus having two contr. significations. (TA.) ― -b2- See also the next preceding paragraph, in four places.

rahowaI c
rahowaI: see rahowN, as applied to a woman, in two places: ― -b2- and see also mirohaApN.

rahowaAnN c
rahowaAnN A depressed piece of land or ground. (TA.) ― -b2- And applied to A birocawn [or horse for ordinary use and for journeying] that has an easy back in going along: a genuine Arabic word: (TA:) or rahawaAnN [thus I find it written, but it is commonly pronounced rahowaAn, or raHowaAn with H,] is a vulgar term applied to a pacing horse. (MF voce himolaAjN.)

rahaMCN c
rahaMCN A wide place. (K.) ― -b2- A wide tract of land: (S, TA:) or what is wide of land: (M, TA:) [or] an even tract of land, seldom free from the saraAb [or mirage]: (JK, TA:) and what is even of anything. (TA.) ― -b3- See also rahowN, as applied to a woman. ＝ -A2- It is also [app. A hue, or a haze,] like dust-colour and smoke. (TA.)

rahiyRapN c
rahiyRapN Wheat which is ground between two stones, and upon which milk is poured: (M, TA:) or ears of corn rubbed with the hands, then bruised, or pounded, and then milk is poured thereon, and it is cooked. (K.)

raAhK c
raAhK A life (EayoXN) ample in its means or circumstances, unstraitened, or plentiful, easy, pleasant, soft, or delicate; (S, K;) and quiet, or calm. (S.) Easy; as an epithet applied to a [journey such as is termed] ximos. (S.) And Anything still, or motionless; as also raMCK. (TA.) ― -b2- TaEaAmN raAhK Food that continues, or is permanent; like raAhinN: (AA, S:) and [in like manner (see raAhinN)] the fem. of each, with p, is applied to wine. (S.) [Freytag adds, “ Inde dicitur rAhI AlAbAjl Celer de equo: ” but rAhI is here a mistranscription for waAhiI: see Oabojalu.]

raAhiyapN c
raAhiyapN [the epithet raAhK converted by the affix p into a subst.,] A bee; because of its quiet manner of flying. (JK, K.)

farasN mirohaApN c
farasN mirohaApN, with kesr, (K, TA,) like misoHaApN [in form], (TA,) or mirohaMCN, (JK, and so in the CK, [like miroxaMCN in form, and, as most explain the latter, similar also in meaning, whence it seems that mirohaMCN is the more probably correct,]) A quick, swift, or fleet, mare: (JK, * K, TA:) pl. maraAhiI, (JK, K,) [or rather maraAhK if the sing. be mirohaApN, and maraAhiIRo if the sing. be mirohaMCN,] like masaAHiI [or rather masaAHK], (TA,) or like maraAxiI [or rather maraAxiIRo, pl. of miroxaMCN]: (JK:) but in the M, it is rahowaI↓, [app. meaning that the sing. is thus,] like sakoraI; and in like manner in the Tekmileh and the Jm. (TA.)

2 rwRO fiI AlOamori c
2. rwRO fiI AlOamori, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) inf. n. tarowiYapN, (S, Mgh, K,) or tarowiyapN, (so in one of my copies of the S,) after the manner of a verb with an infirm final radical, like tazokiyapN, inf. n. of zakRaI, (TA,) and tarowiIoCN, (S, K,) agreeably with analogy; (TA;) and, accord. to IDrst, in his Expos. of the Fs, rawRaI also is allowable; but the former is the original; or, accord. to the L, the former is anomalous, like HalRaOotu in the phrase HalRaOotu AlsRawiyqa; (TA;) He looked into the thing, or affair, or case; inspected it; examined it; considered it; or thought upon it; (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) and thought upon it repeatedly; syn. taEaqRabahu; (M, L, K, TA;) i. e. radRada fiyhi fikorahu; (TA;) not hastening to reply: (S, K:) and rayRaOa signifies the same; (K in art. ryO;) i. q. fakRara; (T;) or, accord. to some, it is a mispronunciation. (MF.) ― -b2- Hence, yawomu AltRarowiyapi The eighth day of [the month] Dhu-l-Hijjeh; originally with C: its derivation from AlrRuWoyapu is a mistake; and its derivation from AlrRiIRu requires consideration. (Mgh.) [See 2 in art. rwI.]

4 OarowaOa c
4. OarowaOa It (a place) abounded with the [kind of plant, or tree, called] raMC: (AZ, AAF, K:) or so OarowaOato, said of land (OaroD). (M.)

raMCN c
raMCN A kind of [plant, or] tree, (T, * S, M, K, &c.,) that grows in plain, or soft, land, (T, M, TA,) having a white fruit: or, as some say, a kind of dust-coloured tree, having a red fruit: (M, TA:) n. un. raMCapN: (T, S, M, K:) and dim. ruwayoYapN↓: (M, TA:) AHn says that the rMCp is not taller nor broader than a sitting man: and accord. to one of the Arabs of the desert of 'Omán, it is a tree that rises on a stem, and then there branch forth [so in the M, but accord. to the TA, rise,] from it round, rough leaves: others, he adds, say that it is a small tree of the mountains, resembling an EZlmp [q. v.], having a soft white flower like cotton: (M, TA: [but in the latter, the word rendered “ soft ” is omitted:]) some say that it is a species of the kind of tree called TaloH [acacia, or mimosa, gummifera], and is the tree that grew at the cave in which were the Prophet and Aboo-Bekr: so say Suh and others: it is, they say, of the height of a man, and has white flowers, resembling cotton, with which cushions are stuffed, like feathers in lightness and softness: it is said by IHsh to be the same [tree] that is called OumRu gayolaAn [see art. gyl]; but they have found fault with him. [for so saying]: it is not the EuXar [asclepias gigantea], as one author has supposed; but a tree resembling this: (MF, TA:) such is the truth: the rMC is not the EXr: I have seen them both [says SM] in El-Yemen; and with the fruit of each of them cushions and pillows are stuffed: but the fruit of the EXr commences small; then increases to the size of the bAcnjAnp [or fruit of the egg-plant, and much larger, like a bladder]; and then breaks open, disclosing what is like cotton: and the fruit of the rMC is not thus: the EXr [he adds] is not found in Egypt; but it and the rMC are peculiar to El- Hijáz and the neighbouring parts; [in saying this, however, he errs; for I have seen the EXr in abundance in the deserts of the upper part of the Sa'eed;] and the saddles of camels &c. are stuffed with the fruit of the rMC in El-Hijáz. (TA.) ― -b2- Also The foam of the sea. (AHeyth, K.) ＝ -A2- And One of the letters of the alphabet. (TA.) [See the letter r.] ＝ -A3- See also art. ryO.

raMCapN c
raMCapN n. un. of raMCN. (T, S, M, K.) ＝ -A2- See also raAyapN, in art. rI.

rawiyoYapN c
rawiyoYapN, or, as some say, only rawiyRapN, without C; (M;) the latter was the usual form, without C; (S, Msb;) or each; (K;) a subst. from rawRaOa fiI; AlOamori; (S, K;) meaning Inspection, examination, consideration, or thought; (S, * M, Msb, K; *) and repeated inspection or examination or consideration; (M, * Msb, K, * TA;) or consideration of the issues, or results, of an affair; (Msb;) without haste to reply. (S, * K, * TA.) You say, fulaAnN layosa lahu rawiyRapN [Such a one has no inspection, &c.]. (T.) It precedes what is termed EaziymapN [i. e. resolution, or determination, &c.], and follows what is termed badiyhapN [i. e. intuitive knowledge, &c.]: one has well said,
badiyhatuhu taHulRu EuraI AlmaEaAniI
UicaA Qnogalaqato fatakofiyhi AlrRawiyRaho
[His intuitive knowledge undoes the loops of meanings when they are fast closed, and inspection suffices him]. (Har p. 8.) [See also rawiyRapN in art. rwI.]

ruwayoYapN c
ruwayoYapN dim. of raMCN, q. v. (M, TA.)

qaSydapN raAYyRapN c
qaSydapN raAYyRapN and raAwiyRapN and rayRiyRapN A qSydp of which the rawiIRa is r. (TA in bAb AlAlf AllyRnp.)

1 raAba c
1. raAba, (T, S, M, &c.,) aor. yaruwbu, (T, S, &c.,) inf. n. rawobN, (Lth, T, Msb,) or ruWuwbN, (S,) or both, (T, M, Mgh, K,) said of milk, (T, S, M, &c.,) It was, or became, thick, or coagulated: (M, A, Msb, K:) or was churned, and deprived of its butter: (M, * A, K: *) or it was, or became, fit to be churned: (T:) or thick, (S,) or having a compact pellicle upon its surface, and thick, or resembling liver so that it quivered, (Lth, T,) and fit to be churned: (Lth, T, S:) or such as had become thick; (Fr, A'Obeyd, T, S, * Mgh;) until its butter was taken forth; (Fr, A'Obeyd, T, S; *) or before and after it had been deprived of its butter. (Mgh.) ― -b2- [Hence,] raAba damuhu, (T, M, A, K,) aor. as above, (T,) inf. n. rawobN, (M,) (tropical:) [His blood is about to be shed;] his death, or destruction, is at hand: (M, K:) said of one who has exposed himself to that which will cause his blood to be shed; (T;) of one who has exposed himself to slaughter: (A:) like the phrase yafuwru damuhu; (T;) or like yagoliI damuhu: his blood being likened to milk that has become thick, and fit to be churned. (A.) ― -b3- And raAba AlrRajulu, (As, T, S, &c.,) aor. as above, (TA,) inf. n. rawobN (S, M, K) and ruWuwbN, (M, K,) (tropical:) The man was, or became, confused, or disturbed, (As, T, S, K,) in his affair, or case, (As, T,) or in his reason, or intellect, (S, K,) and his opinion: (As, T, S:) or confounded, or perplexed; unable to see his right course: (M, K:) and languid in spirit, by reason of satiety, or drowsiness, (M, A,) or intoxication; as also raAbato nafosuhu: (A:) or he arose (M, K, TA) from sleep (M, TA) disordered in body and mind: (M, K, TA:) or he was intoxicated with sleep: (M, K:) or he was lazy, sluggish, or slothful. (Aboo-Sa'eed, T.) ― -b4- And raAba, (Th, M, K,) inf. n. rawobN; (TA;) and rwRb↓, (Th, M,) inf. n. tarowiybN; (K;) (assumed tropical:) He (a man, Th, M) was, or became, fatigued, or jaded. (Th, M, K.) And maTiyRapu fulaAnK rawRabato↓ (assumed tropical:) The riding-camel of such a one was, or became, fatigued, or jaded. (T.) ― -b5- And raAba (assumed tropical:) He, or it, was, or became, quiet, still, or motionless. (IAar, T.) ― -b6- It is said in a prov., of him who does wrong and does right, [or of him who does right and does wrong,] huwa yaXuwbu wa yaruwbu, meaning, accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed, (assumed tropical:) He defends his companion [at one time], and is lazy or sluggish or slothful [at another time]: or it means he defends without energy at one time, and at another time is lazy or sluggish or slothful, so that he defends not at all: or, as some say, he mixes water with the milk, and so spoils it, and he makes it good; from the saying of IAar that raAba signifies OaSolaHa; but if it have this meaning, it is originally raOaba, with hemz. (T. [See more in art. Xwb.]) ＝ -A2- Accord. to IAar, raAba also signifies He suspected. (T. [But in this sense it seems to belong to art. ryb.]) ＝ -A3- Also He lied. (K. [But in the T, this signification is assigned to XaAba, not to raAba; app. in relation to the prov. above cited.])

2 rwRb AllRabana c
2. rwRb AllRabana, (S, M, A, K,) inf. n. tarowiybN, (AZ, M,) He made the milk to be such as is termed raAYib; (S, M, A, K;) as also ArAbhu↓: (M, A, K:) or he put the milk into the skin, and turned it over, in order that it might become fit for churning, and then churned it, when it had not thickened well. (AZ, M.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, in two places.

4 ArAb AllRabana c
4. ArAb AllRabana: see 2. ＝ -A2- [ArAb as an intrans.
verb app. signifies He had much milk such as is termed raAYib: see its part. n. muriybN, below.]

raAbN c
raAbN The equal in quantity or measure or the like: so in the saying, hacaA raAbu kacaA [This is the equal in quantity &c. of such a thing. (K, * TA.)

rawobN c
rawobN: see raAYibN, in two places. ― -b2- Hence, (M,) laA Xawoba wa laA rawoba, (IAar, T, M,) occurring in a trad., meaning (assumed tropical:) There is, or shall be, no dishonesty, nor any mixing: (TA:) it is a saying of the Arabs, in a case of selling and buying, respecting the commodity which one sells, and means I am irresponsible to thee for its faults, or defects. (IAar, T, M.)

rawobapN c
rawobapN: see what next follows, in three places.

ruwbapN c
ruwbapN The ferment of milk, (T, S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) consisting of a sour portion, (S, TA,) which is put into milk in order that it may become such as is termed raAYib; (T, S, Mgh, Msb, TA;) and rawobapN↓ signifies the same as ruwbapN in this sense, (Kr, M, A, K,) and in the other senses which follow: (M:) this is the primary signification: (TA:) or ferment of milk which contains its butter, and when its butter has been taken forth; as also raAYibN↓ in both of these two senses; (T;) or in the latter state it is termed raAYibN↓: (TA:) or (so in the A and K, but in the M “ and, ”) remains of milk (M, A, K, in the second of which, as in the last, this applies also to rawobapN↓,) that has become such as is termed raAYib: (M:) or remains of milk left in the [skin or vessel called] mirowab in order that fresh milk, when poured upon it, may quickly become raAYib: (T:) and milk containing its butter: and also milk from which its butter has been taken forth: (Aboo-' Amr ElMutarriz, MF, TA.) It is said in a prov., Xubo XawobFA laka ruwbatuhu [Mix thou a mixture, app. of thick and fresh milk: thine shall be what will remain of it]: (S:) or laka baEoDuhu [thine shall be some of it]: (so Meyd:) it is like the saying AuHolubo HalabFA laka XaToruhu [expl. in art. XTr]: (S, Meyd:) and is applied in inciting to aid him in whom one will find profit, or advantage. (Meyd.) ― -b2- I. q. durodiIRN [as meaning A ferment] such as is put into [the beverage called] nabiyc [to make it ferment]. (TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) What has collected of the seminal fluid (T, S, M, A, K) of a horse, (S, A,) or of a stallion, (M, K,) after resting from covering; (T, S, M, K;) and rawobapN↓ in this sense is mentioned by Lh: (M:) you say, OaEironiI ruwabapa faHolika, (T,) or farasika, (S, A,) when you ask a person to lend you a stallion, or a horse, to cover: (T, S, A:) or the collecting thereof: or the seminal fluid of the stallion in the womb of the camel: (M, K:) it is thicker than that which is termed muhaAp, and more remote in respect of the place into which it is injected. (M.) ― -b4- (tropical:) Strength of a horse to run: so in the phrase farasN baAqiI AlrRuwbapi (tropical:) [A horse whose strength to run remains]. (A.) ― -b5- (tropical:) Intellect (IAar, S, A) of a man (IAar, S) when it has attained to full vigour: (A:) [app. as being likened to the rwbp of the stallion:] so in the saying, huwa yuHadRivuniI wa OanaA Uico caAka gulaAmN layosa liI ruwbapN (tropical:) [He would talk to me, I being then a boy, not having full intellect]. (IAar, S, A: in one of my copies of the S, and in the TA, layosato.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) The main, or most essential, part, syn. jumRaAE, of an affair: (M, K:) so in the saying, maA yaquwmu biruwbapi Oamorihi (assumed tropical:) [He does not undertake, or superintend, or attend to, the main, or most essential, part of his affair]: app. from the rwbp of the stallion. (M.) ― -b7- (assumed tropical:) Means of subsistence: (M, K:) (assumed tropical:) food, or sustenance: (TA:) (assumed tropical:) anything that puts a thing into a good, right, or proper state; from the same word as signifying “ a sour ferment that is put into milk to make it ferment: ” (JM:) (tropical:) a want, or thing that is needed [to put one into a good, or right, state]: (S, M, A, K:) and want as meaning poverty. (Ibn-Es-Seed, K, TA.) You say, laA yaquwmu biruwbapi Oaholihi, (S, A,) or maA yaquwmu Alx, (M, TA,) i. e. (assumed tropical:) [He will not, or does not, undertake, or take upon himself, or attend to,] the food, or sustenance, of his family: or (assumed tropical:) their case, and the putting them into a good, right, or proper, state: (TA:) or (tropical:) [the supplying of] what they require of him. (S, M, A, TA.) ― -b8- (tropical:) A part, or portion, or small portion, (TaAYifapN, S, M, or qiToEapN, K, or saAEapN, T, M, A,) of the night: (T, S, M, A, K:) [app. from the same word signifying “ remains of milk; ” as seems to be implied in the A:] so in the saying, maDato ruwbapN mina AllRayoli (tropical:) A period, or short portion, (sAEp,) of the night passed: (T, M, TA:) and baqiyato ruwbapN mina AllRayoli (tropical:) A period, or short portion, (sAEp,) of the night remained: (M, A, TA:) and hariqo EanRaA mino ruwbapi AllRayoli, (S, A,) i. e. Aikosiro EanRaA saAEapF minohu [app. for Aikosiro jahodanaA or the like, i. e. (tropical:) Abate thou, or allay thou, our fatigue, or the like, or relieve thou us, for a period, or short portion, of the night; mn before rwbp being redundant]. (A.) ― -b9- (assumed tropical:) A piece of flesh-meat: (M, K:) so in the saying, qaTaEa AllRaHoma ruwbapF ruwbapF (assumed tropical:) [He cut the flesh-meat into pieces; or cut it piece by piece]. (M.) ＝ -A2- (assumed tropical:) Heaviness, sluggishness, or torpidness, (T, K,) or laxness, or confusedness of the intellect, (T,) and languor, feebleness, or faintness, (K,) from drinking much milk. (T.) ＝ -A3- Good and fertile land, abounding with plants, or herbage, (T, M, K,) and with trees: (T, M:) that kind of land in which the herbage, or pasturage, remains longest. (T.) ― -b2- Accord. to Aboo-' Amr Esh-Sheybánee, i. q. maXaArapN, which means A saAqiyap [or channel of water for irrigation: but it has also other meanings, which see in art. Xwr]. (TA.) ― -b3- The tree called nulok; (T, K, TA;) expl. by Ibn-Es-Seed as meaning the tree called zuEoruwr [q. v.]. (TA.) ＝ -A4- A kind of hooked instrument (kalRuwb) by means of which an animal that is hunted is drawn forth from its hole: (M, K:) accord. to Abu-l-'Omeythil, the miHoraX [app. meaning the same, or an instrument used for drawing forth the lizard called DabR from its hole]. (M.) ＝ -A5- It is also mentioned by IAar as [syn. with rubapN and OurobapN,] meaning A knot. (T.) ＝ -A6- A piece of wood with which a wooden bowl, or other vessel, is repaired, or mended; or with which a breach, or broken place, therein is stopped up: (T, TA:) and, accord. to AZ, a patch, or piece, with which a camel's saddle (raHol) is patched, or pieced, when it is broken: (TA:) pl. ruwabN: but this is [properly, or originally, ruWobapN,] with C: (T, TA:) so says ISk. (T.) [See art. rOb.]

rawobaAnu c
rawobaAnu: see the next paragraph.

raAYibN c
raAYibN, applied to milk, (Lth, T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) and rawobN↓, so applied, (Lth, T, M, K,) Thick, or coagulated: (M, Msb, K:) or churned, and deprived of its butter: (As, T, M, K:) see also ruwbapN, in two places: or thick, (S,) or having a compact pellicle upon its surface, and thick, or resembling liver so that it quivers, (Lth, T,) and fit to be churned: (Lth, T, S:) or such as has been churned, and such as has not been churned: (S:) or such as has become thick; (Fr, A 'Obeyd, T, S, Mgh;) until its butter is taken forth; (Fr, A 'Obeyd, T, S;) or before and after its butter has been taken forth; (Mgh;) like as the epithet EuXaraMCu is applied to a she-camel when pregnant and when she has brought forth. (A 'Obeyd, T, S.) A poet, cited by As, says,
wa mano laka biAlrRaAYibi AlxaAviri
saqaAka Oabuw maA EizK raAYibFA
(T, S Mgh) meaning Aboo-Má'iz gave thee to drink churned [milk], (T, S,) but how wilt thou obtain, (T,) or [rather] but who will be answerable to thee for, (S,) the unchurned (T, S) [that is thick, or] that has not had its butter taken forth from it? (S. [Or raAYib in the former instance may be from raAba of which the aor. is yariybu; so that it may there mean what occasioned doubt, or evil opinion: see raAYibN in art. ryb: and if so, this word as belonging to the present art., and applied to milk, may signify only thick, or unchurned.]) And one says, maA Einodahu XawobN wa laA rawobN↓, (T,) or maA EinodiI Alx, (M,) i. e. He has not, or I have not, mixed honey, nor milk such as is termed raAYib: (T, M:) or, as some say, honey nor milk; thus explaining the two words Xwb and rwb without restriction. (M. [See also art. Xwb.]) ― -b2- [Hence,] raAYibN applied to a man, (T, S, M, A, K,) as also rawobaAnu↓, (T, M, K,) and Oarowabu↓, (M, K,) (tropical:) Confused, disturbed, or disordered, (T, S, A,) in mind, by reason of drowsiness, or satiety, or intoxication: (A:) or confounded, or perplexed; unable to see his right course: (M, K:) and languid in spirit, by reason of satiety, or drowsiness: (M:) or who has arisen (M, K) from sleep (M) disordered in body and mind: or intoxicated with sleep: (M, K:) or raAYibN signifies (assumed tropical:) confused in his intellect and his opinion and his affair: (TA:) and a man (tropical:) fatigued, wearied, distressed, embarrassed, or troubled: (A:) fem. [of the first] raAYibapN: (Lh, M:) pl. of the first, (S, M, A, * Mgh,) accord. to As, (S,) or of the second, rawobaI: (S, A, Mgh:) you say qawomN rawobaI (tropical:) a people, or company of men, confused, disturbed, or disordered, in minds, (T, S, Mgh,) by reason of drowsiness: (Mgh:) accord. to Sb, (M,) rendered heavy, or weak, or languid, by journeying, (S, M,) and by pain, (M,) and heavy with sleep: (S:) or intoxicated by drinking [milk such as is termed] raAYib. (S, Mgh.) ― -b3- And raAYibN
also signifies (tropical:) A thing, or an affair, that is clear, or free from dubiousness or confusedness; (Th, T and TA in art. ryb;) like the milk so termed. (TA in art. ryb. See an ex. in that art.)

Oarowabu c
Oarowabu: see the next preceding paragraph.

mirowabN c
mirowabN A vessel, (T, S,) or receptacle, (A,) or skin, (M, K,) in which milk is made to be such as is termed raAYib. (T, S, M, A, K.) [See also murawRabN.]

muriybN c
muriybN Having much milk such as is termed raAYib. (Har p. 416.)

murawRabN c
murawRabN Milk that has not as yet been churned, and that is in the skin, not having had its butter taken from it. (As, T.) ― -b2- And siqaMCN murawRabN A skin in which milk has been made such as is termed raAYib: (M, K:) or a skin that is wrapped up [in order that its milk may thicken more quickly by its being kept warm] until it attains the fit time for the churning. (S.) It is said in a prov., Oahowanu maZoluwmK siqaMCN murawRabN, (T, S, M, A,) meaning [The lightest in estimation] of what is drunk, or given to be drunk, [of milk,] before its butter comes forth from it (As, T) [is that in] a skin that is wrapped up &c., as expl. above: (S:) [or (assumed tropical:) the least to be esteemed of the wronged is he who remains quiet, or inert, like milk not yet in a state of fermentation:] AZ mentions it as applied to him who is low, abject, or contemptible; who is held to be weak: and he says that Zalamotu AlsRiqaMCa means “ I gave [the milk of] the skin to be drunk before it had attained to maturity [so as to be fit for the process of churning]: ” (T:) or murawRabN signifies not churned, but having in it its ferment; and the prov. is applied to him who is constrained to do something that is difficult, and to become in a state of abasement, or ignominy, and does not manifest any disapproval. (Meyd.)

1 raAva c
1. raAva, (T, S, M, &c.,) aor. yaruwvu, (T, A, Msb,) inf. n. rawovN, (T, M, A, Msb,) said of a horse (S, Msb, K) and the like, (Msb,) [i. e.] of a solid-hoofed animal (T, M, A) of any kind, (T,) He dunged. (M, Msb. *) It is said in a prov., OaHuXRuka wa taruwvuniI, (S,) or OaHuXRuki wa taruwviynaniI. (TA in art. HX, in which it is explained.)

rawovN c
rawovN, (T, S, M, &c.,) originally an inf. n., (Msb,) The dung (M, Msb *) of the horse (S, Msb, K) and the like, (Msb,) [i. e.] of a solidhoofed animal (T, M, A, Mgh) of any kind: (T, Mgh:) [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. rawovapN↓: (S, Msb, K:) and pl. OarowaAvN. (S, M, A, Mgh, K.)

rawovapN c
rawovapN: see what next precedes. ＝ -A2- Also The end, or tip, (S, M, A, K,) of the nose, (M,) [i. e.,] of the Oaronabap [or lower portion, i. e. lobule, of the nose], (S, A, K,) where the blood that flows from the nostrils drops, or drips: (M, A:) or the fore part of the nose altogether: (M:) or the end, or tip, of the nose, in the fore part thereof. (TA.) You say, fulaAnN yaDoribu bilisaAnihi rawovapa Oanofihi, (S, TA,) meaning [Such a one strikes with his tongue] the tip of his nose, or the tip of his nose in the fore part thereof. (TA.) It is said in a trad. that the mulet for mutilating a person by depriving him of this part is a third of the whole price of blood. (TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) The bill of the eagle: Aboo-Kebeer El-Hudhalee terms the eagle's bill rawovapu OanofihaA. (M.) ― -b3- And rawovapu AlsRayofi, occurring in a trad., is expl. as meaning (assumed tropical:) The upper part [of the kilt] of the sword, that is next to the little finger of the person grasping it. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Also The remains of the culms of wheat in the sieve, when it is sifted. (K. [Not found by SM in any other lexicon.])

maraAvN c
maraAvN and marowavN↓ (M, K) The part whence the rawov (or dung) issues; (M;) the xaworaAn [i. e. the rectum, or the tuel,] of a horse. (K.)

marowavN c
marowavN: see what next precedes.

murawRavN c
murawRavN A man having a large nose. (A, TA.)

1 raAja c
1. raAja, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor. yaruwju, (S, A, Msb,) inf. n. rawaAjN, (S, A, K,) or this is a simple subst., and the inf. n. is rawojN, (Msb,) It (a thing, S, or a commodity, Msb) had an easy, or a ready, sale; was, or became, saleable; easy, or ready, of sale; or in much demand. (S, * A, * Msb, K. *) ― -b2- And raAjati AldRaraAhimu, inf. n. rawojN, The dirhems, or money, passed, or had currency, among men, in buying and selling. (Msb, TA.) ― -b3- And rAj AlOamoru, inf. n. rawojN and rawaAjN, accord. to IKoot, The thing, or affair, was, or became, quick, speedy, or expeditious: (L, Msb:) or came quickly. (MF.) ― -b4- And rAj It was, or became, present, or ready, and prepared: so in the saying, xuco maA raAja [Take thou what is present, or ready, and prepared]. (Har p. 116.) ― -b5- See also 2. ― -b6- rAjt AlrRiyHu, (K,) or rwRjt↓, (Msb, [app. a mistranscription, unless ruwRijat be meant,]) The wind was, or became, confused, (Msb, K,) not continuing from one direction, (Msb,) so that one knew not whence it came. (K.)

2 rwRj c
2. rwRj, (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. tarowiyjN, (A, Msb, K,) He made a commodity to have an easy, or a ready, sale; to be saleable; easy, or ready, of sale; or in much demand. (S, A, K. *) ― -b2- He made money to pass, or be current. (S, * A, * Msb.) ― -b3- rwRj AlXRaIoCa, and rwRj bihi, He made the thing to be quick, speedy, or expeditious; or was quick with it. (L.) ― -b4- rawRajotu is also syn. with OarRajotu: so in the saying, rawRajotu AlOamora faraAja↓, aor. of the latter yaruwju, and inf. n. rawojN, [app. meaning I excited the affair, or event, and it became excited.] (TA.) ― -b5- rwRj kalaAmahu He embellished his speech, or language, and made it vague, so that one knew not its true meaning: (Msb, TA:) from raAjati AlrRiyHu, (TA,) or from rwRjt AlrRiyHu. (Msb.) ― -b6- For rwRjt AlryH see 1, last sentence. ― -b7- rwRj AlgubaAru EalaI raOosi AlbaEiyri [perhaps ruwRija] The dust continued, or went round, upon, or over, the head of the camel; syn. daAma. (TA.)

5 trwRj c
5. trwRj He [app. a camel] went round about the watering-trough, or tank, thirsting, and not getting to it. (K.)

rawojapN c
rawojapN Haste, quickness, speed, or expedition. (IAar.)

rawaAjN c
rawaAjN [an inf. n., (see 1,) or] a subst., meaning The state, or quality, of having an easy, or a ready, sale; of being saleable; or in much demand. (Msb.)

rawRaAjN c
rawRaAjN [app. applied to a camel] Going round about the watering-trough, or tank, thirsting, and not getting to it. (K.)

OamorN murawRajN c
OamorN murawRajN A confused thing or affair. (TA.)

fulaAnN murawRijN c
fulaAnN murawRijN Such a one is a person who makes commodities to have an easy, or a ready, sale; to be saleable; easy, or ready, of sale; or in much demand: or who makes money to pass, or be current. (S.)

1 raAHa c
1. raAHa, (S, Msb, K,) sec. pers. riHota, (Msb,) aor. yaraAHu, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. riyHN; (K;) and aor. yaruwHu, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. rawoHN, (Msb,) or ruWuwHN; (TA;) It (a day) was violently windy. (S, Msb, K.) And rAH, aor. yaruwHu, inf. n. ruWuwHN, It (a day) was one of good, or pleasant, wind. (TA.) ― -b2- rAH, aor. yaraAHu, inf. n. rawoHN, It was, or became, cool and pleasant [by means of the wind]. (L.) It (a house, or tent, the door being opened,) [was, or became, aired by the wind; or] was entered by the wind. (L.) ― -b3- rAH AlXRajaru The trees felt the wind. (AHn, K.) [See also another meaning below.] ― -b4- [Hence, perhaps,] rAH, aor. yaraAHu, inf. n. raAHN, (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, brisk, lively, sprightly, active, agile, prompt, or quick; [as though he felt the wind and was refreshed by it;] (L;) as also ArtAH↓: (S, A, L, K:) raAHN and AirotiyaAHN↓ signify the same: (S, L, K: [in the CK, AlAirotiyAHi is erroneously put for AlAirotiyaAHu:]) and AisotarowaHa↓ (assumed tropical:) he (a man) became light, or active, and quick; syn. XamRara. (Msb.) You say, rAH lilXRaIoCi [and UilaI AlXRaIoCi] and ArtAH↓ [and ArtAH bihi] (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, brisk, lively, &c., as above, at the thing, [or betook himself with briskness, liveliness, &c., to the thing,] and was rejoiced by it. (Lth, TA.) A poet says,
wa zaEamota OanRaka laA taraAHu UilaI AlnRisaA
[(assumed tropical:) And thou assertedst that thou dost not, or wilt not, betake thyself with briskness, &c., to women, nor be rejoiced by them]. (Lth, TA.) And rAH liloOamori i. q. ArtAH↓ [He betook himself with briskness, &c., to the thing, or affair; or was brisk, &c., to do it]. (TA.) And rAH licelika AlOamori, (L,
K,) and Uilayohi, (L,) aor. yaraAHN, inf. n. rawaAHN and ruWuwHN and raAHN and riyaAHapN (L, K) and raAHapN and OaroyaHiyRapN, (L,) (assumed tropical:) He brightened in countenance at that thing, (L, [there explained by OaXoraqa lahu, and this I regard as the right reading, rather than that which I find in the copies of the K, which is OaXorafa lahu, perhaps meaning the same as OaXorafa Ealayohi, i. e. he became acquainted with that thing, or knew it, syn. AiTRalaEa Ealayohi,]) and rejoiced in it, or at it, (L, K,) and was thereby affected with alacrity, cheerfulness, briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness, disposing him to promptness in acts of kindness or beneficence: said of a generous man when he is asked to confer a gift; and sometimes, metaphorically, of dogs when called by their owner, and of other animals. (L.) [It is also said that] rawaAHN and rawaAHapN and raAHapN and rawoHapN and rawiyHapN [all app. inf. ns. of raAHa, or some of them may be simple substs.,] and muraAyaHapN [as though inf. n. of raAyaHa↓] (L, K) signify (assumed tropical:) The experiencing relief from grief or sorrow, after suffering therefrom: (L:) or the experiencing the joy, or happiness, arising from certainty. (K. [See also rawoHN, below.]) You say also, UilaI Hadiyvihi AisotarowaHotu↓ [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) I was affected with cheerfulness, liveliness, or the like, at his discourse, or narration; as seems to be indicated by the context in the place where it is mentioned: or perhaps, he trusted to his discourse, and became quiet, or easy, in mind; agreeably with an explanation of the verb which see below]: (A:) or AlI Hdyvh AstrAH↓ (assumed tropical:) he inclined to his discourse. (MA.) And rAH lilomaEoruwfi, (S, A, L, K,) sec. pers. riHota, (L,) aor. yaraAHu, inf. n. raAHapN (S, L, K) and riyHN; (L;) and lh ArtAH↓; (A, L;) (tropical:) He was affected with alacrity, cheerfulness, briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness, disposing him to promptness to do what was kind or beneficent: (As, S, L, K:) he inclined to, and loved, kindness or beneficence. (L.) And lilnRadaI ArtAH↓ (assumed tropical:) [He was affected with alacrity, &c., and so disposed to bounty or liberality]. (S, K.) And nazalato QllRehu biraHomatihi faOanoqacahu minohaA bihi baliyRapN faQrotaAHa↓ (tropical:) [A trial, or an affliction, befell him, and God was active and prompt with his mercy, and delivered him from it]: (T:) but ISd disapproves of thus speaking of God; and El-Fárisee says that it is an instance of the rudeness of speech characteristic of Arabs of the desert. (TA.) [Hence seems to have originated, as is app. implied in the TA, the assertion that] AlAirotiyaAHu↓ signifies (assumed tropical:) The being merciful: and QllRehu lahu biraHomatihi ArtAH↓, (assumed tropical:) God delivered him from trial, or affliction: (K:) or QllRehu lifulaAnK ArtAH↓ (assumed tropical:) God was merciful to such a one. (S.) One also says, rAHt yaduhu likacaA, (K,) or bikacaA, (S L,) (tropical:) His hand was active, prompt, or quick, (S, L, K, TA,) to do such a thing, (K, TA,) or with such a thing; (S, L, TA;) as, for instance, with a sword, to strike with it. (L.) Hence the saying of the Prophet, mano raAHa UilaI AljumuEapi fiI AlsRaAEapi AlOuwlaI fakaOanRamaA qadRama badanapF (tropical:) [Whosoever is brisk, or prompt, or quick, in repairing to the Friday-prayers in the first hour, he is as though he offered a camel, or a cow or bull, for sacrifice at Mekkeh]: (K, * TA:) the meaning is, xafRa UilayohaA, (K, TA,) and maDaI; (TA;) not the going in the latter part of the day. (K, * TA.) [See also what follows.] ― -b5- raAHa, aor. yaruwHu, inf. n. rawaAHN; and trwRH↓; both signify the same; (S, Msb, K, &c.;) contr. of gadaA; (S;) said of a man, (TA,) and of a company of men, (K, TA,) He, and they, went, or journeyed, or worked, or did a thing, in the evening, (K, TA,) or in the afternoon, i. e., from the declining of the sun from the meridian until night: (IF, Msb, K, TA:) this is said to be the primary meaning: (TA:) but they also mean he, or they, returned: (Msb:) and went, or journeyed, at any time: (Msb, * TA:) [for] AlrRawaAHu is not, as some imagine it to be, only [the going, or journeying,] in the last, or latter, part of the day; but is used by the Arabs as meaning the going, or journeying, at any time of the night or day; as also AlguduwRu: so say Az and others: (Msb:) or rAH, inf. n. rawaAHN, signifies he came, or went, after the declining of the sun from the meridian: but is sometimes used as meaning he went in an absolute sense: (Mgh:) and thus it means in the trad. commencing mano raAHa UilaI AljumuEapi [mentioned above, where a different explanation of the verb is given]: (Mgh, * Msb:) and [in like manner] one says to his companion or companions, tarawRaHo↓ or tarawRaHuwA as meaning Go, or journey: (TA:) but raAHati AlUibilu, (S, L, K,) aor. taruwHu and taraAHu, inf. n. rawaAHN (L) and raAYiHapN, (AZ, L, K,) signifies only The camels returned in the evening, or afternoon, (S, * Msb,) when their pastors drove or brought them back to their owners: so says Az. (Msb.) You say, ruHotu Uilayohimo and Einodahumo, inf. n. rawoHN and rawaAHN, I went, (K, TA,) and I came, (TA,) to them in the evening, or afternoon; [or at any time, as appears from what has been said above;] and so ruHotuhumo, (K, TA,) inf. n. rawoHN; (TA;) and rawRaHotuhumo↓, (K, TA,) inf. n. tarowiyHN; (TA;) and tarawRaHotuhumo↓: (K, TA:) and OanaA OugaAdiyhi wa OuraAwiHuhu↓ [I go, or come, to him early in the morning, in the first part of the day, or between the time of the prayer of daybreak and sunrise, and I go, or come, to him in the evening, or afternoon, app. he doing the like to me]. (A. [See also 6.]) And raAHato Ealayohi Uibiluhu, and ganamuhu, and maAluhu, His camels, and his sheep or goats, and his cattle, returned to him after the declining of the sun from the meridian; only at that time: and ArAHt↓ may perhaps be a dial. var. thereof: (L, TA:) or rAHt biAlEaXiIRi EalaI OaholihaA they (i. e. camels) returned from the place of pasture in the evening, or afternoon, to their owners. (S, * Msb.) ― -b6- rAH AlXRajaru, (S, A, K,) aor. yazaAHu; (S, A;) and trwRH↓; (S, A;) [said in the TA to be tropical, but not so in the A;] The trees broke forth with leaves: (S, A, K:) or the former, the trees broke forth with leaves before the winter, when the night became cold, without rain; (As, TA;) and so the latter: (L:) or the latter, the trees broke forth with leaves after the close of the Sayof [or summer]: (S, TA:) and AlguSonu trwRH↓ The branch put forth leaves after other leaves had fallen from it. (R, TA.) [See another meaning of rAH AlXjr near the beginning of this art.] ― -b7- rAH, (S, K,) aor. yaraAHu, inf. n. raAHapN, (S,) said of a horse, [perhaps from the same verb as signifying “ he was, or became, brisk, lively, ” &c.,] He became a stallion, or fit to cover. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- raAHatohu AlrRiyHu, aor. taraAHu, The wind smote it; namely, a thing; (L, K;) as, for instance, a tree, and said of a tempestuous wind. (L.) And riyHa, said of a pool of water left by a torrent, It was smitten [or blown upon] by the wind. (S, A, K.) In like manner also it is said of other things. (TA.) One says, riyHati AlXRajarapu The tree was blown upon by the wind: or was blown about, or shaken, by the wind, so that its leaves were made to fall: or had the dust scattered upon it by the wind. (L.) And riyHuwA They (a people, or party,) were smitten and destroyed by the wind: (K, TA:) or they entered upon [a time of] wind; (K;) as also, in this latter sense, OaraAHuwA↓, (S, K,) or OarowaHuwA↓. (A.) ― -b2- rAH AlXRaIoCa, (A 'Obeyd, S, K,) first pers. riHotu, (A 'Obeyd, S,) aor. yaraAHu (A 'Obeyd, S, K,) and yariyHu, (AA, S, K,) [inf. n., app., of the former rawoHN and of the latter riyHN as in the phrase of similar meaning following;] and OaraAHahu↓, (Ks, S, K,) and OarowaHahu↓; (AZ, K;) He smelt the thing; perceived its smell, or odour; (S, K, &c.;) as also AstrAHhu↓ and AisotarowaHahu↓: (Ham p. 228:) and rAH AlrRiyHa, aor. yaraAHu, inf. n. rawoHN; and aor. yariyHu, inf. n. riyHN; and OaraAHahaA↓; He smelt the odour. (Msb.) You say of an object of the chase, OaraAHaniI↓, (S,) and OarowaHaniI↓, (AZ, S, A,) inf. n. of the latter UirowaAHN, (AZ, TA,) He smelt me; perceived my smell, or odour: (AZ, S, A, TA:) and of the same, ArAH↓, (K,) and OarowaHa↓, (T, S, K,) and AisotarowaHa↓, and AstrAH↓, (T, S,) He smelt a human being; perceived his smell, or odour: (T, S, K:) and the second of these four, (K, TA,) and the third and fourth, (TA,) he smelt gently, that he might perceive the odour of a thing: (K, TA:) or the third and fourth of the same, he smelt, or perceived, odour: (A:) and these two, said of a stallion, he perceived the smell of the female: and of a beast of prey you say, AlrRiyHa OarowaHa↓, and OaraAHahaA↓, and AstrAHhA↓, and AisotarowaHahaA↓, meaning he smelt, or perceived, the odour; and accord. to Lh, some say, raAHahaA; but this is seldom used. (TA) [It is asserted (in Har p. 324) that AstrAH↓ is only from AlrRaAHapu; but this assertion is of no weight against the authorities cited above.] It is said in a trad., mano qatala nafosFA muEaAhidapF lamo yaraHN raAYiHapa AljanRapi, (A 'Obeyd, S, Mgh, * Msb, *) or lm yariHo, (AA, S, Msb,) or lm yuriHo↓, (Ks, S, Mgh, Msb,) i. e. [He who slays a person with whom he is on terms of
peace, (or, as in' the TA, muWominFA, i. e. a believer,)] he will not perceive the odour of Paradise: (S, Mgh, Msb:) As says, I know not whether it be from riHotu or from OaraHotu. (S.) You say also, minohu TiybFA OarowaHotu↓ I perceived from him (a man, S) a sweet odour. (S, A.) ― -b3- [And hence, app.,] rAH minoka maEoruwfFA, and ArAHhu↓, (assumed tropical:) He obtained from thee a favour, or benefit. (K.) ＝ -A3- rawiHa, aor. yarowaHu, inf. n. rawaHN, He (a man) had the quality termed rawaHN, [explained below, i. e. width in the space between the thighs or legs; &c.; or] a spreading in the fore part of each foot. (Lth, TA.) And rawiHato qadamuhu His foot had the quality so termed. (TA.)

2 rwRH c
2. rwRH [He fanned]. You say, rwRH Ealayohi biAlmirowaHapi [He fanned him with the fan]. (A, TA.) And AiHotaAjuwA UilaI AltRarowiyHi mina AlHarRi biAlmirowaHapi [They required to be fanned, by reason of the heat, with the fan]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, (A, Msb,) inf. n. tarowiyHN, (Msb,) He perfumed oil; rendered it sweet in odour, (A, Msb,) by putting perfume in it. (Msb.) ― -b3- rwRH Eanohu; and rawRiHuwA binaA: see 4. ― -b4- rwRH bihimo, (A, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. as above, (A, Msb,) He performed with them the prayers termed AltRaraAwiyH. (A, Mgh, Msb.) ― -b5- rwRH having for its objects camels, and sheeep or goats: see 4. ― -b6- rawRaHotuhumo: see ruHotu Uilayohimo, in the latter half of the first paragraph.

3 OanaA OugaAdiyhi wa OuraAwiHuhu c
3. OanaA OugaAdiyhi wa OuraAwiHuhu: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph. ― -b2- AlmuraAwaHapu fiI AlEamalayoni, (S,) or bayona AlEamalayoni, (Mgh, K,) signifies The doing the two deeds, or works, alternately; this one time, and that one time: (S, Mgh, K:) as, for instance, reading, or reciting, at one time, and writing at another time: (Mgh:) and AlmrAwHp byn AlrRijolayoni the standing upon the two legs alternately; upon each in turn: and AlmrAwHp byn Aljanobayoni the turning over [upon the two sides alternately, or] from side to side. (K.) You say, rAwH bayona Eamalayoni [He did two deeds, or works, alternately; he alternated them]. (A.) And rAwH bayona rijolayohi He stood upon one of his legs one time and upon the other another time: (S, Mgh:) it is said also of one walking [as meaning he moved his legs alternately]. (A.) And it is said in a trad., kaAna yuraAwiHu bayona qadamayohi mino Tuwli AlqiyaAmi He used to rest upon one of his feet one time and upon the other another time to give relief to each of them [in consequence of long standing]. (TA.) One says also, rAwHhu He did a thing with him by turns, each of them taking his turn [and so relieving the other: for AlmuraAwaHapu signifies the giving mutual relief, or rest]. (TA in art. Eqb.) [See also 6.] ＝ -A2- raAyaHa, inf. n. muraAyaHapN: see 1, in the former part of the paragraph.

4 ArAH c
4. ArAH He breathed: (S, A, K:) said of a man, (A,) and of a horse. (S.) ― -b2- [It emitted an odour:] it (a thing, Msb) stank; (S, Msb, K;) as also OarowaHa: (Msb, TA:) the former said of flesh-meat, (S, K,) and of water; (K;) and so the latter: (TA:) or the latter, it became altered [for the worse] in odour; (Lh, S, M, A, Msb;) said of flesh-meat, (Lh, M, A, * Msb,) and of water, (Lh, S, M, A, Msb,) &c.; (S;) and so the former, said of water: (L, TA:) ISd makes a distinction between ArwH and trwRH↓ [q. v., as does also J,] said of water. (Msb, TA.) ― -b3- Also, (inf. n. UiraAHapN, L,) He (a man, S, and a beast, Lh) revived, or his spirit returned to him, after fatigue; (Lh, S, K;) like AstrAH↓, q. v.: (TA:) and he had rest. (K.) ― -b4- And [hence], (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. UiraAHapN, (TA,) or UirowaAHN, (Msb,) (assumed tropical:) He (a man) died; (S, Msb, K;) as though he found rest: and he (a camel) died, or perished. (TA.) You say, OaraAHa faOaraAHa [He rested, i. e. had rest, and so rested others], meaning (assumed tropical:) he died, and so people became at rest from him.
