(A.) ― -b5- [Hence also,] OaraHonaA biAlSRalaApi We performed the act of prayer: because its performance is [a cause of] rest to the soul; the waiting for the time thereof being troublesome. (Msb.) ― -b6- OaraAHato said of camels &c. [as though meaning They returned in the evening, or afternoon, to rest]: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph. ― -b7- ArAH, inf. n. UiraAHapN and UiraAHN, said of a man, His camels, and sheep or goats, and cattle, returned to him in the evening, or afternoon, from pasture. (L.) ― -b8- And ArAH, [app. for ArAH baEiyrahu,] like wise said of a man, He alighted from his camel to rest him and to alleviate him. (L.) ― -b9- OaraAHuwA, or OarowaHuwA: see 1, in the last quarter of the paragraph. ＝ -A2- OaraAHahu and OarowaHahu, and ArAH AlrRiyHa, &c.: see 1, in the last quarter of the paragraph, in twelve places. ― -b2- ArAHhu, (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. UiraAHapN, (Msb, TA,) and raAHapN↓ is a subst. used as an inf. n., [i. e. a quasi-inf. n.,] like TaAEapN and EaArapN used as inf. ns. of OaTaAEahu and OaEaArahu, (TA,) said of God, (S, K,) or of a man, (A, Msb,) He rested him, made him to be at rest or at ease, or gave him rest; (S, * A, * Msb;) namely, a hired man, (Msb,) or any man; as also Eanohu rwRH↓: (TA:) and the former, He (God) caused him to enter into a state of rest, (K, TA,) or of mercy. (TA.) And binaA rawRiHuwA↓ (K in art. lv) Give ye us rest. (TK in that art.) And ArAH baEiyrahu He revived, or recovered, his camel. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] ArAH AlnRaAsa biAlSRalaApi He chanted the call to prayer, and so made the people to ease their hearts by performing the act of prayer. (L.) ― -b4- And ArAH, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. UiraAHapN; (M, Mgh;) accord. to one dial., haraAHa, aor. yuhariyHu; (TA;) and rwRH↓, (S, * A, TA,) inf. n. tarowiyHN; (S;) He (the pastor, Msb) drove back, or brought back, (S, M, Msb, K,) camels, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) and sheep or goats, (M, A, * Mgh,) and cows or bulls, (A, * Mgh,) in the evening, or afternoon, (M, Msb,) after the declining of the sun from the meridian, (S,) [from their place of pasture,] to their nightly resting-place, (S, M, K,) or UilaI OaholihaA [and EalaI OaholihaA (for you say raAHato EalaI OaholihaA) i. e. to their owners]. (Msb.) ― -b5- [Hence,] ArAH Ealayohi HaqRahu (assumed tropical:) He restored to him his right, or due; (S, K;) as also OarowaHa. (K.) And the saying, in a trad., of Umm-Zara, ArAH EalaIRa naEamFA variyRFA (assumed tropical:) He gave me much cattle: because she was [as though she were] a muraAH for his bounty. (L.)

5 trwRH c
5. trwRH [He fanned himself]. (A, TA.) And trwRH bimirowaHapK [He fanned himself with a fan]. (S, Msb, K.) raOayotuhumo yatarawRaHuwna fiI AlDRuHaI, occurring in a trad., means I saw them requiring the being fanned with the fan (AltRarowiyH biAlmirowaHap) by reason of the heat [in the morning after sunrise]: or it may mean returning to their tents or houses: or seeking rest. (TA.) ― -b2- trwRHt AlrRaAYiHapu The odour exhaled, or diffused itself. (Msb.) ― -b3- trwRH said of water, It acquired the odour of another thing by reason of its nearness thereto. (S, A, Msb, K.) See also 4. ― -b4- See also 10: ― -b5- and see 1, in five places. ― -b6- trwRH said of herbage, It became tall: (S, K:) and in like manner said of trees; as well as in well as in another sense explained in the first paragraph. (TA.) ― -b7- tarayRuHN, thought by ISd to be an inf. n., of which the verb is tarayRaHa: see OaroyaHiyRapN.

6 taraAwaHaA EamalFA c
6. taraAwaHaA EamalFA (TA) and AirotawaHaAhu↓, (K, TA,) [like taEaAwaraAhu and AiEotawaraAhu,] They two did a deed, or work, by turns, [resting by turns,] or alternately; syn. taEaAqabaAhu. (K, TA.) And trAwHwA OamorFA They did a thing by turns; syn. tEAwrwhu. (TA.) [Hence,] UinRa yadayohi latataraAwaHaAni biAlmaEoruwfi (S, A *) [in the S, the context implies that the meaning is, Verily his two hands are occupied alternately in doing that which is kind, or beneficent: in the A, it is said to be tropical, and the context seems to indicate that the meaning is, (tropical:) his two hands vie, one with the other, in promptness to do that which is kind, or beneficent]. ― -b2- trAwHwA libuyuwtihimo and trAwHwA buyuwtahumo [They went in the evening, or afternoon, to their tents, or houses, app. meaning one to another's tent, or house, by turns]. (A.) [See also 3.]

8 ArtAH c
8. ArtAH, and its inf. n. AirotiyaAHN: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph, in ten places: ― -b2- and see also 10. ＝ -A2- AirotawaHaA EamalFA: see 6.

10 AisotarowaHa c
10. AisotarowaHa, said of a branch, (Msb, TA,) It became shaken by the wind: (TA:) or it inclined from side to side. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also 1, near the beginning of the paragraph; and see AisotarowaHotu UilaI Hadiyvihi, and AstrAH AlI Hdyvh, in the former part of the same paragraph. ― -b3- Also, (K,) and AstrAH, (S, A, Msb, K,) [which latter is the more common in this sense,] and ArtAH↓, (TA,) and sometimes ArAH↓, q. v., (Msb,) [and trwRH↓, as quasi-pass. of rawRaHa Eanohu or bihi,] said of a hired man, (Msb,) [and of any man,] He found, or experienced, rest, or ease; [was, or became, at rest, or at ease; rested;] (S, * A, * Msb, * K;) minohu [from him, or it], (A,) and bihi [by means of it]; (Msb;) from AlrRaAHapu; (S;) quasi-pass. of OaraHotuhu,
(A, Msb,) and of OaraAHahu QllRehu. (S.) ― -b4- AstrwH Uilayohi (accord. to the S and K, but in other lexicons AstrAH, TA) He trusted to, or relied upon, him, or it, and became quiet, or easy, in mind. (S, K, TA.) ― -b5- See also 1, in the last quarter of the paragraph, in seven places. ＝ -A2- AstrwH AlmaTaru AlXRajara The rain revived the trees. (L.)

raAHN c
raAHN Windy; applied to a day: (TA:) or, so applied, violently-windy; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also raAYiHN↓, which is the original form, (Msb,) or may be so: (TA:) fem. of the former with p, applied to a night (layolapN). (A, TA.) [See also rayRiHN.] One says, hecihi layolapN raAHapN lilomakoruwbi fiyhaA raAHapN [This is a windy night: the oppressed in mind has rest therein]. (A.) ＝ -A2- It is also syn. with AirotiyaAHN. (S, L, K. [See 1, near the beginning of the paragraph.]) ― -b2- And [hence,] Wine; (S, A, * K;) as also rayaAHN↓: (S, K:) so called because the drinker thereof becomes brisk, lively, or sprightly; or, accord. to IHsh, because he becomes affected with briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness, disposing him to generous actions: in the L, [which mentions these two words in art. ryH,] the A in the former word is said to be substituted for I [and hence the I in the latter if such be the case]. (TA.) ＝ -A3- See also raAHapN, in four places.

rawoHN c
rawoHN, as an epithet; fem. with p: see rayRiHN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also A gentle wind; a gentle gale; a breeze; the commencement of a wind before it becomes strong; or the breath of the wind when weak: (S, K, TA:) or the cold, or coolness, of such gentle wind. (A, TA.) ― -b2- I. q. nfs [app. nafasN i. e. Breath; like ruwHN]: said to be the primary signification: (MF:) or spirit; [like ruwHN;] syn. nafosN; as in the saying, OaHoyaA AlnRaAsa birawoHihi [He (meaning God) hath quickened, or vivified, mankind with his spirit: or perhaps the right reading is biruwHihi]. (A.) ― -b3- See also raAHapN, with which it is syn. (S, K.) ― -b4- Also (assumed tropical:) Joy, happiness, or gladness; (AA, MF, TA;) said to be a metaphorical meaning, from the same word as syn. with nfs; (MF;) and ruwHN↓ likewise has this meaning: (IAar, TA:) or the former, rest, or ease, from grief, or sorrow, of heart. (As, TA.) In the saying of 'Alee, fabaAXaruwA rawoHa Alyaqiyni or Alyqyn ruwHa↓, the phrase rwH Alyqyn is thought by ISd to mean (assumed tropical:) The joy and happiness that arise from certainty. (TA. [See art. bXr.]) ― -b5- Also (assumed tropical:) Mercy (S, K, TA) of God; thus called as being a cause of rest, or ease; (TA;) and so riyHN↓; (K;) and rayoHaAnN↓; (L;) and ruwHN↓ is said by Az to have this meaning in the Kur iv. 169: the pl. of the first of these three words [and of the last, and accord. to some a pl. of the second also,] is OarowaAHN. (TA.)

ruwHN c
ruwHN The soul, spirit, or vital principle; syn. nafosN; (IAar, IAmb, L, Msb, TA, and S and K &c. in art. nfs; [but there is a difference between these two words, for they are not always interchangeable, as I have shown in art. nfs;]) [i. e.] maA bihi HayaApu AlOanofusi; (K; [see also rawoHN, third sentence;]) often occurring in the Kur and the Traditions in different senses, but generally signifying [as explained above, i. e.] the vital principle; (IAth, TA;) [or the nervous fluid; or animal spirit;] a subtile vaporous substance, which is the principle of vitality and of sensation and of voluntary motion; also called the ruwH HayawaAniIR; (KT in explanation of the term nafosN;) or a subtile body, the source of which is the hollow of the corporeal heart, and which diffuses itself into all the other parts of the body by means of the pulsing veins, or arteries: (KT in explanation of the term AlrRuwHu AlHayawaAniIRu: [so too nafosN; q. v.: see also Gen. ix. 4: many of the ancients believed the soul to reside in the blood: see Aristotle, De Anim. i. 2, and Virgil's Æn. ix. 349:]) or the vital principle in man: (Fr, TA:) or the breath which a man breathes, and which pervades the whole body: [and this seems to be the original idea expressed by the word:] after its exit, he ceases to breathe; and when it has completely gone forth, his eyes remain gazing towards it until they close; called in Pers. jaAno: (AHeyth, TA:) accord. to the Sunnees, the rational soul, (AlnRafosu AlnRaATiqapu, [also termed AlrRuwHu AlUinosaAniIRu,]) which is adapted to the faculty of making known its ideas by means of speech, and of understanding speech, and which perishes not with the perishing of the body, being a substance, not an accident; as is shown by the words in the Kur iii. 163, which refer to the rwH: (Msb:) most of the doctors of the fundamentals of religion forbid the diving into this matter, because God has abstained from making it known: (TA:) the philosophers say that it is the blood, by the exhausting of which the life ceases: (Msb:) the word is masc., (IAar, IAmb, Az, S, M, A, Msb, K, *) thus, with the Arabs, differing from nafosN, for this they make fem., (IAar, IAmb, Msb,) but the former is also fem., (S, M, A, Msb, K,) app. as meaning nafosN, (Msb,) as is said in the R; (TA;) and most hold it to be as often fem. as it is masc.: (MF:) one says xaraja ruwHuhu (IAar, Az, TA) [and also xarajato ruwHuhu, meaning His soul departed, or went forth]: the pl. is OarowaAHN. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- Also i. q. nafoxN (K) [properly A blowing with the mouth; but here] meaning wind that issues from the ruwH; (TA;) wind, or breath. (ADk, TA.) Dhu-r-Rummeh says, respecting fire that he had struck, and upon which he bade his companion to blow, OaHoyihaA biruwHika Give life to it, or enliven it, with thy wind [or breath]. (TA.) And one says, malaOa Alqirobapa mino ruwHihi He filled the skin with his wind; with his breath. (ADk, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] AlrRuwHu also signifies (assumed tropical:) Inspiration, or divine revelation; (Zj, Th, K;) such as is imparted by means of an angel: thus in the Kur xvi. 2 and xl. 15: so called because it quickens from the death of infidelity, and thus is, to a man, like the ruwH which is the vital principle of his body: (T:) or (so says Zj accord. to the L, but in the K “ and ”) the prophetic commission. (Zj, K.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) The Kur-án; (IAar, Zj, S, * A, * K;) whereby God's creatures are [spiritually] quickened, and guided to the right way. (TA.) So in the trad., taHaAyawoA bicikori QllRehi wa ruwHihi (tropical:) [Revive yourselves with God's book of religion and religious laws, (or cikor may here have some other meaning,) and his Kur-án]. (TA. [Mentioned also in the A; in a copy of which, in the place of taHaAyawoA, I find taHaAbuwA, an evident mistranscription.]) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) What God ordains and commands (K, TA) by means of his assistants and angels. (TA.) ― -b6- Also Jibreel [i. e. Gabriel]; (S, * A, * K;) called in the Kur [xxvi. 193] AlrRuwHu AlOamiynu, and [in ii. 81] ruwHu Alqudusi or Alqudosi, as related by Az on the authority of Th. (TA.) [The last of these appellations, or generally, but incorrectly, AlrRuwHu Alqudusu, is applied by the Eastern Christians among the Arabs to The Holy Spirit; the Third Person of the Trinity.] ― -b7- And [sometimes Our Lord] Jesus. (S, * A, * K.) ― -b8- And A certain angel, (I'Ab, K,) in the Seventh Heaven, (I'Ab, TA,) whose face is like that of a man, and his body like that of the [other] angels: (I'Ab, K:) or certain creatures resembling mankind, but not men: so in the Kur lxxviii. 38: (Zj:) or the watchers over the angels who are watchers over the sons of Adam, whose faces are said to be like the faces of men, and whom the other angels see not, like as we see not the watchers nor the [other] angels. (Th.) ― -b9- See also rawoHN, in three places. ＝ -A2- Also pl. of raWuwHN: (L:) ― -b2- and of OarowaHu. (S &c.)

rawaHN c
rawaHN: see raAYiHN, of which it is said to be a quasi-pl. n., in three places. ＝ -A2- Also Width, wideness, or ampleness. (S, K.) El-Mutanakhkhil [in the TA El-Muntakhal] El-Hudhalee says,
lekino kabiyru bonu hinodK yawoma celikumu
futoxu AlXRamaAYili fiI OayomaAnihimo rawaHu
(S, TA,) meaning But Kebeer Ibn-Hind, a tribe of Hudheyl, on that day, were lax in the joints of the left hands by reason of vehement pulling [of the bows], having wideness in their right hands by reason of vehement striking with the sword. (TA.) ― -b2- And [particularly] Width, or wideness, in the space between the thighs: (TA:) or width, or wideness, (S, Mgh, K,) in, (S, K,) or of, (Mgh,) [or between,] the two legs, (S, Mgh, K,) less than what is termed faHajN, (S, K,) or less than fajajN, (A, Mgh,) with wideness between the fore parts of the feet, and nearness of the heels, each to the other: (S:) or [simply] wideness between the fore parts of the feet, and nearness of the heels, each to the other: (Msb:) or a spreading in the fore part of each foot: (Lth, Mgh, Msb:) or a turning over of the foot upon its outer side: IAar says that rawaHN in the legs is less than fadaEN, and this is less than EaqalN. (TA.) ＝ -A3- hecaA AlOamoru bayonanaA rawaHN means This is a thing, or an affair, which we do by turns; as also EawarN. (TA.)

riyHN c
riyHN originally riwoHN, the w being changed into I because of the preceding kesreh, (T, S, Msb,) as is shown by its dim. mentioned below; (T, Msb;) Sb held it to be of the measure fiEolN; and
Abu-l-Hasan, fiEolN and fuEolN; [if the latter, originally ruyoHN;] (TA;) [Wind; i. e.] the air that is made to obey [the will of God] and to run its course between heaven and earth: (Msb, TA:) or the breath (nasiym) of the air; and in like manner, of anything: (L, TA:) said to be thus called because it generally brings rawoH and raAHap [i. e. rest, or ease]: (IAmb, MF:) one says riyHN and riyHapN↓, like daArN and daArapN; (S;) [using the latter as a more special term; for] riyHapN signifies a portion of wind (TaAYifapN mino riyHK) [meaning a wind of short duration; or a breath, puff, blast, or gust, of wind]; (Sb, M;) but riyHN and riyHapN↓ may be used in the same sense; i. e. the latter may be used as syn. with the former, and they are mentioned by some [as analogous] with kawokabN and kawokabapN: (Sb, L:) riyoH is of the fem. gender (IAmb, L, Msb) in most cases; (Msb;) and all the other names for wind are fem. except UiEoSaArN, which is masc.; (IAmb, Msb;) but ryH is sometimes made masc. as meaning hawaMCN: (AZ, Msb:) [it is used by physicians as signifying flatus, flatuosity, or flatulence; as in the phrase riyHN galiyZapN a gross flatus:] the pl. [of pauc.] is OarowaAHN (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.) and OaroyaAHN, (S, Msb, K,) the latter used by some, but disallowed by AHát because there is in it no kesreh to cause the w to be changed into I, (L, Msb,) and [the pl. of mult. is] riyaAHN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) with I because of the kesreh, (Msb,) and riyaHN; (K, but not found by SM in any other lexicon;) and the pl. pl. is OaraAwiyHu [pl. of OarowaAHN] and OaraAyiyHu [pl. of OaroyaAHN]: (K:) the dim. of riyHN is ruwayoHapN↓. (T, Msb.) riyaAHN, or another form of pl., is often used in a good sense; and the sing., in an evil sense; because the Arabs say that the clouds are not made to give rain save by diverse winds blowing together; and this distinction is observed in the Kur-án. (L.) Hence, it is related in a trad., that he [Mohammad] used to say, when wind rose, AallRehumRa QjoEalohaA riyaAHFA wa laA tajoEalohaA riyHFA [O God, make it to be winds, and made it not to be a wind]. (TA.) [But this distinction is not always observed.] One says, fulaAnN yamiylu maEa kulRi riyHK (tropical:) [Such a one inclines, or turns, with every wind]. (TA.) And fulaAnN kaAlrRiyHi Almurosalapi [Such a one is like the wind that is sent forth to drive the clouds, and produce rain; (see the Kur xxv. 50;)] meaning, (tropical:) quick, or prompt, to do acts of kindness, or beneficence. (A.) And rajulN saAkinu AlrRiyHi (tropical:) A man who is calm, sedate, staid, or grave. (A.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Predominance, or prevalence; and power, or force. (S, K.) A poet says, (S,) namely, Suleyk Ibn-Es-Sulakeh, or Taäbbata-Sharrà, or Aashà of the tribe of Fahm, (TA, and so in one of my copies of the S,)
OatanoZuraAni qaliylFA rayova gafolatihimo
Oawo taEoduwaAni faUinRa AlrRiyHa liloEaAdiI
(assumed tropical:) [Will ye two await, a little, the time of their inadvertence, or will ye act aggressively? for prevalence is for the aggressor]. (S.) And hence the phrase in the Kur [viii. 48], wa tacohaba riyHukumo (assumed tropical:) [And your predominance, or power, depart]: (S:) [or in this latter instance it has the meaning next following.] ― -b3- (tropical:) Aid against an enemy; or victory, or conquest: (K, TA:) and (tropical:) a turn of good fortune. (A, K, TA.) One says, cahabato riyHuhumo (tropical:) Their turn of good fortune departed. (A.) And UicaA habRato riyaAHuka faQgotanimohaA (tropical:) [When thy turns of good fortune come, avail thyself of them]. (A.) And AlrRiyHu liMli fulaAnK (tropical:) Aid against the enemy, or victory or conquest, or the turn of good fortune, is to the family of such a one. (TA.) ― -b4- See also rawoHN. ― -b5- And see raAYiHapN (with which it is syn.), in four places. ― -b6- Also (assumed tropical:) A good, sweet, or pleasant, thing. (K.) ― -b7- The pl. OarowaAHN occurs in a trad. as meaning (tropical:) The jinn, or genii; because they are [supposed to be often] invisible, like the wind. (TA.)

raAHapN c
raAHapN Rest, repose, or ease; contr. of taEabN; (TA;) cessation of trouble, or inconvenience, and of toil, or fatigue; (Msb;) [or freedom therefrom;] and rawoHN↓ signifies the same as raAHapN, (S, A, K,) from AlAisotiraAHapu; (S, A;) like rawaAHN↓ [mentioned in the first paragraph as an inf. n. in a similar sense, as are also raAHapN and rawoHapN↓ and rawaAHapN↓ and rawiyHapN↓, i. e., as meaning the experiencing relief from grief &c.]. (TA.) You say, maA lifulaAnK fiI hecaA AlOamori mino rawaAHK↓ i. e. raAHapK [There is not, for such a one, in this affair, or case, or event, any rest, &c.]. (TA.) And AifoEalo celika fiI saraAHK wa rawaAHK↓ (tropical:) Do thou that in a state of ease (S, A, K) and rest. (A.) ― -b2- See also 4, near the middle of the paragraph. ＝ -A2- (assumed tropical:) A wife; syn. EirosN: (K:) because one trusts to her, or relies upon her, and becomes quiet, or easy, in mind. (TA.) ＝ -A3- The hand; syn. kafRN: (S, K:) or [rather] the palm of the hand; (Msb, MF;) for the term kafR includes the rAHp with the fingers: (MF:) pl. raAHN↓, (S, A, * Msb, K, *) [or rather this, said in the K to be syn. with raAHaAtN, is a coll. gen. n., of which raAHapN is the n. un.,] and [the pl. is] raAHaAtN. (Msb, K.) You say, dafaEuwhu biAlrRaAHi↓ [They pushed him with the palms of the hands]. (A.) The saying of a poet,
UicaA dalakato Xamosu AlnRahaAri biraAHi↓
is explained as meaning When the sun of day has set, and men, looking towards it, shield themselves from its rays with the palms of their hands: or, accord. to IAar, when the [sun of] day has become dark, by reason of the dust of battle, and it is as though it were setting, and people have found rest from its heat. (L. [See also baraAHN, in art. brH; where other readings are mentioned.]) ― -b2- [Hence, app., as seems to be indicated in the TA,] raAHapu Alkalobi (tropical:) A certain plant. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And cuw AlrRaAHapi (assumed tropical:) A sword of El-Mukhtár Ibn-Abee-' Obeyd (K, TA) Eth-Thakafee. (TA.) ― -b4- raAHapN also signifies A court, an open area, or a yard, (K, TA,) of a house. (TA.) One says, tarakotuhu OanoqaI mina AlrRaAHapi (K, TA) i. e. I left him, or it, more clear than the court, open area, or yard, [of a house,] or than the palm of the hand; (TA;) meaning, (assumed tropical:) without anything. (K, TA.) ― -b5- And raAHN↓ signifies also Plain and open tracts of land, producing much herbage, (ISh, K,) hard, but comprising soft places and [what are termed] jaraAviym [pl. of jurovuwmapN, q. v.], not forming any part of [the bed of] a torrent nor of a valley; (ISh;) one whereof is termed raAHapN. (ISh, K.) ― -b6- Also The plicature of a garment, or piece of cloth: (K, TA:) or the original plicature thereof: so in the saying, in a trad., respecting a new garment, or piece of cloth, AiTowihi EalaI raAHatihi [Fold thou it in the manner of its original plicature]. (TA.)

rawoHapN c
rawoHapN: see raAHapN. ― -b2- Also A journey in the evening, or afternoon: an inf. n. of un. of raAHa: (L:) pl. rawoHaAtN. (Ham p. 521.) And The space of a journey in the afternoon, or evening. (L.) ＝ -A2- [Also, as seems to be indicated in the TA, The outer side of each of the legs of a man when bowed: see rawaHN.]

riyHapN c
riyHapN: see riyHN, in two places: ＝ -A2- and see also rayRiHapN.

riyHiIRN c
[riyHiIRN Of, or relating to, wind: flatulent; as in the phrase qawolanojN riyHiIRN flatulent colic.]

rayoHaAnN c
rayoHaAnN a word respecting the formation of which there are different opinions; many saying that its medial radical letter is w, and its original form rayowaHaAnN, as may be argued from the form of its dim., mentioned below; (Msb;) others, that its original form is rawoyaHaAnN; (MF;) and others, that its medial radical letter is I, and that it is of the same measure as XayoTaAnN, as may be argued from the form of its pl., mentioned below; (Msb;) A certain plant, (S, K,) well known, (S,) of sweet odour; (K;) the XaAhasofaram [or XaAhisofaram, i. e. basil-royal, or common sweet basil, ocimum basilicum, the seed of which (called bizoru AlrRayoHaAni) is used in medicine]: (Mgh: [see also HabaqN:]) or any sweet-smelling plant; (T, Mgh, Msb, K;) but when used absolutely by the vulgar, a particular plant [that mentioned above] is meant thereby: (Msb:) or the extremities thereof; (K;) i. e. the extremities of any sweet-smelling herb, when the first of its blossoms come forth upon it: (TA:) or the leaves thereof: (K:) or the leaves of seed-produce: so, accord. to Fr, in the Kur lv. 11: (S, TA:) [it is a coll. gen. n.:] the n. un. is with p; (TA;) and is applied to a bunch (TaAqapN) of rayoHaAn; and, with the article Al, (as a proper name, TA,) the Hanowap [a certain plant respecting which authors differ]: (K:) the dim. of rayoHaAnN is ruwayoHiynN: (Msb:) and the pl. is rayaAHiynu. (Mgh, Msb) rayoHaAnu AlHabaAHimi: and rayoHaAnu AlXRuyuwxi: see HabaqN. rayoHaAnu Alqubuwri is a name of The mirosiyn [or myrtle-tree]. (TA in art. mrs.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Offspring; (L, K, TA;) from the same word as signifying “ any sweet-smelling
plant; (Ham p. 713;) or from the same word in the sense next following: (L:) [a coll. gen. n.: n. un. with p; whence,] riyoHaAnanaIRa [meaning (tropical:) My two descendants] occurs in a saying of Mohammad as applied to El-Hasan and El-Hoseyn. (TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A bounty, or gift, of God; such as the means of subsistence, &c.; syn. rizoqN: (S, L, K, TA:) said to be of the dial. of Himyer. (MF.) So in the saying, xarajotu OabotagiI rayoHaAna QllRehi (tropical:) [I went forth seeking, or seeking diligently, the bounty, &c., of God]. (AO, S, TA.) And in a verse of En-Nemir Ibn-Towlab cited voce dirRapN. (S, TA.) And in the saying, in a trad., Alwaladu mino rayoHaAni QllRehi (tropical:) [Offspring are of the bounty of God]. (S, TA.) ― -b4- It is also used (S, K) in the accus. case as an inf. n. [forming an absolute complement of a verb understood], (S,) in the sense of AisotirozaAq: so in the saying, suboHaAna QllRehi wa rayoHaAnahu (assumed tropical:) [I extol, or celebrate, or declare, the absolute perfection, or glory, or purity, of God, and beg his bounty, or his supply of the means of subsistence]. (S, K.) ― -b5- See also rawoHN.

rawoHaAniIRN c
rawoHaAniIRN, with fet-h to the r, applied to a place, Good, or pleasant [app., like rayRiHN, in respect of wind or air]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- See also what next follows.

ruwHaAniIRN c
ruwHaAniIRN, with damm to the r, (S, A, K, &c.,) and rawoHaAniIRN↓, with fet-h, but this latter is deemed strange by the lexicologists [as syn. with the former], (MF,) app. rel. ns., from rawHN [in the former instance], or from rawoHN meaning the “ breath of the wind when weak ” [in the latter instance], extraordinary in form, with A and n added to the usual form of the rel. n.: (TA:) Of, or relating to, the angels and the jinn or genii: (S, A, * K:) in this sense Abu-l-Khattáb asserts himself to have heard the former used: (S:) accord. to AO, it is applied by the Arabs to anything having in it a soul, or spirit, (Sb, S,) whether a human being or a beast: (Sb:) or it has this signification also: (K:) accord. to Wardán Aboo-Khálid, as related by ISh, among the angles are those who are termed ruwHaAniyRuwna, and those who are created of light; and of the former are Jibreel and Meekáeel and Isráfeel: and ISh adds that the rwHAnyRwn are souls, or spirits, which have not bodies; [spiritual beings;] and that the term rwHAnIR is not applied to anything save what is of this description, such as the angles and the jinn and the like: and this is the correct explanation; not that of Ibn-El-Mudhaffar, that it signifies that into which, a soul, or spirit, has been blown. (T, TA.)

AlHabaqu AlrRayoHaAniIRu c
AlHabaqu AlrRayoHaAniIRu: see HabaqN.

rawaAHN c
rawaAHN: see raAHapN, in three places. ― -b2- It is also an inf. n. of raAHa, [q. v.,] signifying the contr. of guduwN. (S.) ― -b3- And it signifies also The evening; (K;) or the afternoon, from the declining of the sun from the meridian until night. (S, K.) One says, saAruwA rawaAHFA [They journeyed in the evening, or afternoon]. (TA.) And laqiytuhu raAYiHapF↓ I met him in the evening, or afternoon. (A.) And xarajowA birawaAHK mina AlEaXiIRi, (S, K,) and mn AlEXIR biriyaAHK↓, (so in the T, A, L, and K,) or birayaAHK↓, (so in the S,) and mn AlEXIR biOarowaAHK↓, (A, K,) using a pl. form, (TA,) meaning the same, (S,) or They went forth in the beginning of the evening, (K,) or (tropical:) when there were yet some remains of the evening. (A.) And OataI fulaAnN wa Ealayohi mina AlnRahaAri riyaAHN↓, and OarowanHN↓ (tropical:) [Such a one came when there were yet some remains for him of day]. (A.)

rayaAHN c
rayaAHN: see raAHN: ＝ -A2- and see also rawaAHN.

riyaAHN c
riyaAHN: see rawaAHN, in two places.

raWuwHN c
raWuwHN: see raAYiHN.

rayuwHN c
rayuwHN: see rayRiHN, below.

rawaAHapN c
rawaAHapN: see raAHapN.

rawiyHapN c
rawiyHapN: see raAHapN.

ruwayoHapN c
ruwayoHapN dim. of riyHN, q. v. (T, Msb.)

yawomN rayRiHN c
yawomN rayRiHN A day of good, or pleasant, wind; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also yawomN rawoHN↓ and rayuwHN↓; (TA;) or these two signify a good, or pleasant, day: (S:) and layolapN rawoHapN↓ a good, or pleasant, night; (K;) or a night of good, or pleasant, wind; as also rayRiHapN and raAYiHapN↓: (TA:) and makaAnN rayRiHN a place of good, or pleasant, wind: (S: [see also rawoHaAniIRN:]) or, accord. to Lth, (TA,) and the Kifáyet el-Mutahaffidh, (Msb,) yawomN rayRiHN signifies a violently-windy day; like yawomN raAHN [before mentioned]. (Mgh, Msb, TA.)

rayRiHapN c
rayRiHapN and riyHapN↓ A certain plant that appears at the roots, or lower parts, of the EiDaAh, remaining from the preceding year: or what grows when affected by the cold, without rain: (K:) in the T, the former is expl. as signifying a plant that becomes green after its leaves and the upper parts of its branches have dried: (TA: [see also rabolN:]) this term is applied to the HulRab, the naSiIR, the ruxaAmaI, and the makonaAn. (TA in art. Hlb.)

rawRaAHN c
rawRaAHN [(assumed tropical:) Very brisk, lively, sprightly, active, agile, prompt, or quick]. ― -b2- See also raAYiHN.

rawRaAHapN c
rawRaAHapN A flock of sheep or goats. (L.)

raAYiHN c
raAYiHN, applied to a day; and raAYiHapN, applied to a night (layolapN): see raAHN; and rayRiHN. [In each case it probably has both of the meanings assigned under these two heads.] ― -b2- Also Going, or returning, [or journeying, or working, or doing a thing, (see its verb, 1,)] in the evening, or in the afternoon: (L:) [and going, or journeying, at any time of the night or day: (see, again, its verb:)] and in like manner, [but in an intensive sense,] raWuwHN↓, of which the pl. is ruwHN; and rawRaAHN↓, of which the pl. is rawRaAHuwna, it having no broken pl.: (L:) rawaHN↓ is pl., (S, K,) or [rather] a quasi-pl. n., (L,) of raAYiHN, (S, L, K,) like as xadamN is of xaAdimN. (S, L.) qawomuka raAYiHN [Thy people, or party, are, or is, going, &c.] is a phrase of the Arabs mentioned by Lh on the authority of Ks; but he says that it is only used thus, with a determinate noun; i. e., that one does not say qawomN raAYiHN [though this is agreeable with analogy, as well as qawomN raAYiHapN and qawomN raAYiHuwna]: one says also qawomN rawaHN↓ and ruwHN. (L, TA.) And one says UibilN raAYiHapN Camels returning in the evening, or afternoon, from pasture. (Msb.) [Hence,] maA lahu saAriHapN wa laA raAYiHapN [lit. He has not any camels, &c., that go away to pasture, nor any that return from pasture], meaning (assumed tropical:) he has not anything: (S:) and sometimes it means (assumed tropical:) he has not any people, or party. (Lh, TA in art. srH.) OaEoTaAniI raAYiHapK zawojFA occurs in a trad. as meaning He gave me, of every kind of cattle that returned to him from pasture, a portion, or sort: and in another, maAlN raAYiHN, as meaning (assumed tropical:) [Property, or cattle,] of which the profit and recompense return to one: or in each, as some relate it, the word is with b [i. e. raAbiHap and raAbiH]. (TA.) TayorN rawaHN↓ means Birds in a state of dispersion: or returning in the evening, or afternoon, (S, K,) to their places, (S,) or to their nests: (K:) or, accord. to the T, rawaHN in this case is for rawaHapN, [a pl. of raAYiHN,] like kafarapN and fajarapN, [pls. of kaAfirN and faAjirN,] and means, in this instance, in a state of dispersion. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, [used as a subst., or an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant,] A wild bull: so in the saying of El-' Ajjáj,
EaAlayotu OanosaAEiI wa juiloba Alkuwri
EalaI saraApi raAYiHK mamoTuwri
i. e. [I put my plaited thongs, and the curved pieces of wood, or the cover, of the camel's saddle, upon the back of (a camel like)] a wild bull rained upon; for when he is rained upon, he runs vehemently: (S, TA:) but the reading commonly known is,
balo xilotu OaEolaAqiI wa juiloba kuwri
[Nay, or nay rather, I fancied my bags for travelling-provisions &c. that were hung upon my camel, and the curved pieces of wood of my camel's saddle]. (IB, TA in art. jlb. [AElAqI is there explained as meaning “ my things that I held in high estimation: ” but the rendering that I have given I consider preferable.])

raAYiHapN c
raAYiHapN [fem. of raAYiHN, used as a subst.,] and riyHN↓ both signify the same; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) i. e. An accidental property or quality that is perceived by the sense of smelling; [or rather an exhalation that is so perceived; meaning odour, scent, or smell;] (Mgh, Msb;) syn. nasiymN; whether sweet or stinking: (K:) and the former, a sweet odour which one perceives in the nasiym [or breath of the wind]: (L:) ↓the latter is fem. [like the former]: (Msb:) the pl. of the former is rawaAYiHu; and El-Hulwánee mentions OaraAyiyHu as pl. of OaroyaAHN [which is pl. of riyHN↓, under which see its other
pls.]. (Mgh.) You say, AlXRaIoCi wajadotu riyHa↓ and raAYiHatahu in the same sense [i. e. I perceived the odour of the thing]. (S.) And lihecihi Albaqolapi raAYiHapN TayRibapN [This herb, or leguminous plant, has a sweet odour]. (L.) ― -b2- It is said in the K, that maA fiI wajohihi raAYiHapN means (tropical:) There is not in his face any blood: but [SM says that] this requires consideration; for, accord. to A'Obeyd, one says, OataAnaA fulaAnN wa maA fiI wajohihi raAYiHapu damK mino Alfaraqi (tropical:) [Such a one came to us not having in his face any tinge of blood by reason of fright, or fear]: and accord. to the A [and the Mgh], one says of a person who has come in fright, or fear, OataAnaA wa maA fiI rajohihi raAYiHapu damK: (TA:) [accord. to Mtr, however,] one sometimes says, wa maA fiI wajohihi raAYiHapN, without adding dm; and an instance of this occurs in a trad. of Aboo-Jahl. (Mgh.) ― -b3- raAYiHapN also signifies A rain of the evening or afternoon: (Lh, K:) or, as Lh says on one occasion, [simply] rain: (TA:) pl. rawaAYiHu. (Lh, K.) ― -b4- [And] A cloud (saHaAbapN) that comes in the evening or afternoon. (Har p. 667.) ― -b5- See also rawaAHN.

OarowaAHu c
OarowaAHu [More, and most, conducive to rest or ease]. (K in art. mxr.) ＝ -A2- Also Having the quality termed rawaHN [q. v.] (Lth, A, Mgh, Msb, K) in the thighs, (TA,) or in the legs, (S, A, * Mgh, * K,) and feet, (S,) or in the feet: (Lth, Mgh, Msb:) fem. rawoHaMCu: (S, Msb:) and pl. ruwHN. (S.) Such was 'Omar; (K, TA;) appearing as though he were riding when others were walking: (TA:) and such is every ostrich. (S, TA.) You say also qadamN rawoHaMCu, meaning A foot spreading in its fore part: (Lth, Mgh, TA:) or turning over upon its outer side. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, and OaroyaHu↓, (K,) or the latter only is correct in this case, (TA,) Wide; applied to a maHomil [q. v.]: (K, TA:) and so the latter applied to anything: (Lth, TA:) so too the former applied to a [bowl such as is termed] qadaH: and the same also signifies shallow; applied to a vessel: (TA:) and so rawoHaMCu; applied to a [bowl such as is termed] qaSoEap. (S, A, K.)

OaroyaHu c
OaroyaHu: see the next preceding paragraph.

OaroyaHiIRN c
OaroyaHiIRN (tropical:) Large, or liberal, in disposition; (S, K, TA;) characterized by alacrity, cheerfulness, briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness, disposing him to promptness in acts of liberality, kindness, or beneficence: (S, * A, L, K: *) the former I is said by AAF to be substituted for w: (TA. Mentioned in the L in the present art. and in art. ryH.) The Arabs have many epithets like this, [as OajowaliIRN and OaHowaciIRN and OaHowaziIRN and OalomaEiIRN,] of the meansure OafoEaliIRN, as though they were rel. ns. (TA.) ― -b2- It is also an epithet applied to a sword, meaning (assumed tropical:) That shakes, (TA, and Ham p. 358,) as though brisk, or prompt, to strike: (Ham:) or meaning of Aryah, a town of Syria, (TA and Ham, [in the latter of which the phrase suyuwfa OaroyaHa is cited in confirmation from a poem of Sakhr el-Ghei,]) or a tribe of El-Yemen. (TA.)

OaroyaHiyRapN c
OaroyaHiyRapN (tropical:) Largeness, or liberality, of disposition; (S, K, TA;) alacrity, cheerfulness, briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness, disposing one to promptness in acts of liberality, kindness, or beneficence: (S, * A, L, K: *) the former I is said by AAF to be substituted for w: (TA:) tarayRuHN↓, accord. to Lh, signifies the same, and ISd thinks it to be an inf. n., of which the verb is tarayRaHa. (L: in which these two ns. are mentioned in the present art. and in art. ryH. [See also raAHN: and see 1.]) You say, Oaxacatohu AlOaroyaHiyRapu, (S, L, K,) or OaroyaHiyRapN UilaI AlnRadaI, (A,) i. e. (tropical:) Alacrity, cheerfulness, &c., disposing him to promptness in acts of liberality, affected him. (S, A, L, K.) [See also 1, near the begin ning, where it is mentioned as an inf. n.]

OarowaAHN c
OarowaAHN [pl. of rawoHN, and of ruwHN, and of riyHN]. ― -b2-

xarajuwA biOarowaAHK mina AlEaXiIRi c
xarajuwA biOarowaAHK mina AlEaXiIRi: and OataI fulaAnN wa Ealayohi mino AlnRahaAri OarowaAHN: see rawaAHN.

tarowiyHapN c
tarowiyHapN A single rest: pl. taraAwiyHu. (Mgh, * Msb, * TA.) ― -b2- Hence, the tarowiyHap of the month of Ramadán, (K, TA,) or SalaApu AltRaraAwiyHi [A form of prayer performed at some period of the night in the month of Ramadán, after the ordinary prayer of nightfall, consisting of twenty, or more, rek'ahs, according to different persuasions]; (Mgh, * Msb, TA;) so called because the per former rests after each trwyHp, which consists of four rek'ahs; (Mgh, * Msb, K, * TA;) or because they used to rest between every two [pairs of] salutations. (TA.) [See De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., sec. ed., i. 167-8.] You say, SalRayotu bihimu AltRaraAwiyHa [I performed with them the prayer of the trAwyH]. (A, * Mgh, Msb.)

maraAHN c
maraAHN a n. of place from 1: (Msb:) A place from which people go, or to which they return, in the evening or afternoon [or at any time: see 1]. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] maA taraka fulaAnN mino Oabiyhi magodFI wa laA maraAHFA, (S, and K in art. gcw,) and magodaApF wa laA maraAHpF↓, (K in that art.,) (assumed tropical:) Such a one resembled his father [without exception,] in all his states, conditions, or circumstances. (S, K. *) See also what next follows.

muraAHN c
muraAHN a n. of place from 4; (Msb;) meaning The place to which camels, and sheep or goats, and cows or bulls, are driven, or brought, back [from their place of pasture] in the evening, or afternoon; (Mgh;) the nightly resting-place or resort (S, Msb, K) of cattle, (Msb,) or of camels, (S, K,) and sheep or goats [&c.]. (S.) maraAHN↓, with fet-h, in this sense, is wrong. (Mgh, Msb.)

maruwHN c
maruwHN and mariyHN↓, applied to a pool of water left by a torrent, (S,) and to a place, &c., (TA,) and the former, (A,) or the latter, (S,) to a branch, (S, A,) Smitten [or blown upon] by the wind: (S:) and maruwHapN and mariyHapN↓, the latter originally maroyuwHapN, applied to a tree (XajarapN), blown upon by the wind: or blown about, or shaken, by the wind, so that its leaves have been made to fall: or having the dust scattered upon it by the wind. (L.)

mirowaHN c
mirowaHN: see mirowaHapN.

mariyHN c
mariyHN, and its fem., with p: see maruwHu.

maraAHapN c
maraAHapN: see maraAHN.

marowaHapN c
marowaHapN A place in which, or through which, the winds blow, (S, *, K, TA,) and in which they efface the traces of dwellings: (TA:) and [hence,] a desert, or waterless desert: (S, K:) pl. maraAwiyHu [for maraAwiHu]. (S.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce tadalRaI, in art. dlw.]

mirowaHapN c
mirowaHapN (S, A, Msb, K) and mirowaHN↓ (Lh, K) A fan; a thing, or an instrument, with which one fans himself (yutarawRaHu): (S, A, Msb, K:) pl. maraAwiHu. (S.)

murawRaHN c
murawRaHN Perfumed; applied to oil; (S, A;) and to Uivomid [q. v.], (A'Obeyd, S,) which latter is per fumed with musk. (A'Obeyd.)

naAqapN muraAwiHN c
naAqapN muraAwiHN A she-camel that lies down behind the other camels. (IAar, Az.)

AlmurotaAHu c
AlmurotaAHu The fifth of the horses that run in a race; (K, TA;) the number of which is ten. (TA.)

miroyaAHN c
miroyaAHN, applied to food, That occasions much flatulence in the belly. (A, TA.)

musotaraAHN c
musotaraAHN a n. of place: and as such meaning (assumed tropical:) The grave [as being a place of rest or ease]. (Ham p. 228.) [And as such] (assumed tropical:) A privy; syn. maxorajN. (S.) ― -b2- Also, accord. to rule, a n. of time [i. e. A time of rest or ease]. (Ham ubi suprà.) ― -b3- And a pass. part. n. of 10. (Id. ibid.) [As such] meaning (assumed tropical:) Dead [for musotaraAHN minohu]; as also musotaryiHN↓ [lit. at rest or ease]. (Id. p. 251.) ― -b4- And it may also be used as an inf. n. of 10. (Ham p. 228.)

musotariyHN c
musotariyHN: see the next preceding paragraph.

1 raAda c
1. raAda, aor. yaruwdu, (T, S, A,) inf. n. rawadaAnN (A, TA) and rawodN, (K, TA,) He, or it, (a thing, S,) came and went; (T, S, A, K;) [went to and fro;] was restless, or unsettled. (T, TA.) One says, maA liI OaraAka taruwdu munocu Alyawomi [What aileth me that I see thee coming and going, or going to and fro, during this day?]. (A, TA.) And raAdato, (S, M, A, K,) aor. taruwdu, (S, A,) inf. n. rawadaAnN (S, M, K) and rawodN and ruWuwdN, (M,) She (a woman) went about to and from the tents, or houses, of her female neighbours. (S, M, A, K.) And rAdt AlUibilu, aor. taruwdu, (AHn, M,) inf. n. riyaAdN (AHn, S, M, K) [and app. rawadaAnN &c. as above], The camels went to and fro in the place of pasture. (AHn, S, M, K.) And rAd AlnRaEamu fiI AlmaroEiI, inf. n. ryaAdN, The cattle went to and fro in the place of pasture. (A.) And rAdt AldRawaAbRu, inf. n. rawodN and rawadaAnN [and app. riyaAdN also]; and AstrAdt↓; The beasts pastured [going to and fro]. (M.) And rAdt AlrRKyHu, (T, M,) aor. taruwdu, (TA,) inf. n.
rawadaAnN (T, TA) and rawodN and ruWuwd, (TA,) The wind became in motion, or in a state of commotion: (T, TA:) or veered about. (M, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] rAd wisaAduhu [lit. His pillow moved to and fro; meaning] (tropical:) he was, or became, restless, (S, A,) by reason of disease or anxiety: (A:) [or he was, or became, sleepless: for] a poet uses the phrase raAca wisaAduhaA as expressive of an imprecation, mean ing (assumed tropical:) May she be sleepless, so that her pillow may not remain still. (TA.) [And rAd xurotu Alqawomi and rAdt OaxoraAtuhumo: see xurotN.] ＝ -A2- rAd, aor. yaruwdu, (Msb,) inf. n. riyaAdN (Msb, K) and rawodN; (K;) and ArtAd↓, (Msb,) inf. n. AirotiyaAdN; (K;) and AstrAd↓; (TA;) He sought, sought after, or desired; or he sought, or desired, to find and take, or to get; (Msb, K;) a thing. (Msb.) [It seems to imply the going to and fro in seeking.] You say, rAd AlkalaOa, (S, A, Mgh, L,) and AlmaMCa, (Mgh,) aor. yaruwdu, (S, A, Mgh, L,) inf. n. riyaAdN and rawodN: (S, L;) and ArtAdhu↓; (S, A, Mgh, L;) [and Astrdhu↓, as appears from what follows;] and simply rAd; (L;) He sought after herbage, (S, Mgh, L,) and water. (Mgh.) And rAd Oaholahu kalaOF, and manozilFA, (M, L,) and rAd lahumo kalaOF, and manozilFA, inf. n. rawodN (T, M, L) and riyaAdN; (M;) and ArdtAd↓; (T, M, L;) and AstrAd↓; (M, L;) He looked for, (T,) and sought after, herbage, and a place in which to alight, (T, M, L,) and chose the best [that he could find], (T,) for his family. (T, M, L.) And AlTRayoru tasotariydu↓ The birds seek after their sustenance, going to and fro in search of it. (A.) [Hence,] libawolihi ArtAd↓ He sought a soft place, (S, Mgh, L,) or a sloping place, (S, L,) for his urine. when he desired to void it, (S, Mgh, L,) lest it should return towards him, or sprinkle back upon him: (L:) from a trad. (S, L.) ― -b2- rAd AldRaAra, aor. as above, He questioned, or interrogated, [respecting a person beloved,] the house, or abode. (M.) ― -b3- rudotu AldRawaAbRa I pastured the beasts; as also OaradotuhaA↓. (M.)

3 rAwdhu c
3. rAwdhu He endeavoured to turn him [to, or from, a thing]; as in the phrase rAwdhu EalaI AlUisolaAmi He endeavoured to turn him, or convert him, to El-Islám; occurring in a trad., in which the agent of the verb is Mohammad, and the object is his uncle Aboo-Tálib;. syn. raAjaEahu and raAdRahu: (L:) or raAwadotuhu EalaI kacaA, (S,) or EalaI AlOamori, (Msb,) inf. n. muraAwadapN and riwaAdN, (S, Msb, K,) [primarily] signifies I desired, (S, Msb, K, *) or sought, (Msb,) of him that he should do such a thing, or the thing; (S, * Msb;) AlmuraAwadapu implying contention (AlmuxaASamap), because he who desires, or seeks, affects gentle, or bland, behaviour, like him who deceives, or beguiles, and, like him, strives, or labours, to attain his object: (Msb:) and [hence,] rAwdhu Eani AlOamori, and Ealayohi, He endeavoured to turn him by blandishment, or by deceitful arts, or to entice him to turn, from the thing, and to it; syn. daAraAhu, (M, L,) or raAdaAhu. (TT, as from the M.) sanuraAwidu Eanohu OabaAhu, in the Kur xii. 61, means [We will endeavour to turn his father from him, by blandishment, or artifice, and to make him yield him to us: or] we will strive, or labour, to obtain him of his father. (Bd, Jel.) And raAwadatohu Eano nafosihi [in the Kur xii. 23] (assumed tropical:) She desired, or sought, of him, copulation, or his lying with her, using blandishment, or artifice, for that purpose; she tempted him to lie with her: (T, and Bd in xii. 23:) [more literally, she endeavoured to turn him, or entice him, by blandishment, or deceitful arts, from his disdain, or disdainful incompliance, and to make him yield himself to her:] and raAwadahaA Eano nafosihaA (assumed tropical:) he desired, or sought, of her, copulation, &c. (T.) And raAwadahu Eano nafosihi (tropical:) He endeavoured to deceive him, or beguile him, and to turn him [from his disdain, or purpose, or will,] by blandishment, or artifice. (A.)

4 Oarowada c
4. Oarowada, (S, A, K,) inf. n. UirowaAdN and murowadN and [quasi-inf. n.] marowadN↓ (S, K) and ruwayodN↓ (TA as from the K [but omitted in my MS. copy of the K and in the CK]) and ruwayodaMCu↓ and ruwayodiyapN↓ or ruwayodiyRapN↓, (accord. to different copies of the K,) He acted, or proceeded, gently, softly, or in a leisurely manner, (S, A, K, TA,) in going, or pace. (S, A, TA.) ＝ -A2- Oarowadahu, (S,) inf. n. UirowaAdN, (M,) He acted gently, softly, or in a leisurely manner, towards, or with, him; or granted him a delay, or respite; let him alone, or left him, for a while; syn. Oamohalahu. (S, M. *) ― -b2- Oaradotu AldRawaAbRa: see 1, last sentence. ＝ -A3- OaraAdahu, (M, L, Msb,) inf. n. UiraAdapN, (S, M, L, Msb, K,) originally with w, [i. e. Oarowadahu,] because you say raAwadahu (S, L) in a similar sense, (L,) He willed, wished, or desired, it: (S, * M, L, K: *) he loved, or liked, it; and cared for, or minded, it; or was rendered thoughtful, careful, or anxious, by it: (M, L:) or he desired it; sought it, or sought after it; (Talabahu;) and chose it: (Msb:) [or] it differs from Talabahu, inasmuch as UiraAdapN is sometimes merely conceived in the mind, not apparent; whereas TalabN is never other wise than apparent, either by act or by word: (Aboo-'Obeyd El-Bekree, TA:) Th says that it sometimes denotes loving, or liking, and some times it does not [as will be shown by what follows]: and Lh mentions the saying harodtu AlXRaIoCa, aor. Ouhariyduhu, inf. n. hiraAdapN, with h substi tuted for C [as in haraqotu for Oaraqotu, &c.]. (M.) You say, Oaradotu minohu kacaA [I desired, of him, such a thing]. (A.) And maA Oaradotu UilRaA maA faEalota [I desired not aught save what thou didst, or hast done]. (A.) [And ArAd bihi kacaA He desired to do to him, or he intended him, such a thing; whether good or evil: see Kur xxxiii. 17, &c.] And Kutheiyir says,
Ouriydu liOanosaI cikorahaA fakaOanRamaA
tumavRalu liI layolaI bikulRi sabiyli
[I desire to forget the remembrance of her, or the mention of her; but it seems as though Leylà were imaged to me in every road]; meaning Ouriydu Oano OanosaI. (M.) [And ISd says,] I think that Sb has mentioned the phrase OaraAdaniI bihecaAlika, i. e. He intended, or meant, me by that. (M.) [ArAd often signifies He intended, or meant, such a thing by a saying or an action.] fawajadaA fiyhaA jidaArFA yuriydu Oano yanoqaDRa, in the Kur xviii. 78, means (tropical:) [And they found therein a wall] that was near, or about, to fall down, (Bd, Jel,) or that was ready to fall down; though AlUiraAdap is only from an animate being, and not properly predicable of a wall: and there are many similar instances; as the saying of a poet,
yuriydu AlrRumoHu Sadora OabiI baraMCK
wa yaEodilu Eano rimaMCi baniI Euqayoli
[The spear is ready to pierce the breast of Aboo Barà, but it turns away from the bloods of the sons of 'Okeyl]. (M.) [In like manner also] one says, ArAd AlbukaMCa (assumed tropical:) [He was about, or ready, to weep: a phrase of frequent occurrence; like tahayRaOa lilobukaMCi, and hamRa biAlobukaMCi]. (TA in art. jhX, &c.) ― -b2- You say also, ArAdhu EalaI AlXRaIoCi, (M,) or ElI AlOamori, (A, Mgh,) He endeavoured to induce him, (M,) or he incited him, or made him, (A, Mgh,) to do the thing. (M, A, Mgh.) And ArAdhu EalaI Oano yakotuba He incited him, or made him, to write. (Mgh.) And ArAdhu UilaI AlkalaAmi He constrained, or necessitated, him to speak. (M, * TA.)

5 trwRd c
5. trwRd He trembled, or quaked, by reason of extreme softness, or tenderness, and fatness. (KL.)

8 Uirotawada
8: see 1, in four places.

10 Uisotarowada
10: see 1, in five places. ― -b2- AstrAd liOamori QllRehi occurs in a trad. as meaning He returned, and became gentle and submissive to the command of God. (TA.)

raAdN c
raAdN: see raAYidN, with which it is syn. (S, M, K.) raAdapN [is its fem.: and] is a pl. of raAYidN. (L.) ― -b2- AimoraOapN raAdapN A woman who goes about to and from the tents, or houses, of her female neighbours; (AZ, As, S, M, A, K;) as also raAdN (TA) and rawaAdN↓ (S M) and raWuwdN↓ (Aboo-' Alee, M) and ruwaAdapN↓, like vumaAmap, and raAYidapN↓. (K.) You say AimoraOopN raOodapN gayoru raAdapK A soft, or tender, woman; not one that roves about: in which the former rAdp may be without C, and the latter must be so. (A and TA in art. rOd.) [See ruWodN; where it is stated that raAdN and raAdapN and ruwdapN↓, as epithets applied to a girl or woman, are syn., one with another, meaning Soft, or tender, &c., like raOodN and raOodapN and ruWodapN.] ― -b3- riyHN raAdapN A wind blowing violently to and fro: (TA:) [and riyHN raAYidapN↓ signifies the same; or wind in motion, or in a state of commotion.; or veering about: see 1.] [And] A wind blowing gently; (A;) and so rawodN↓ and raAYidapN↓ (K) and rawaAdN↓. (TA. [See also art. ryd.])

rawodN c
rawodN: see what next precedes.

ruwdN c
ruwdN Gentleness; or a leisurely manner of acting or proceeding. (S, M, A, K.) [And accord. to the TT, as from the M, so ruWodN; but this is a mistranscription, for ruWodN: see this last, in art. rOd.] You say, yamoXiI EalaI ruwdK He walks, or goes, gently, softly, or in a leisurely manner. (S, A,
K.) And its dim. is ruwayodN↓. (S, A, K. [But see what follows.]) They said ruwayodFA↓, meaning Gently, softly, or in a leisurely manner; (T, S, M, A, K;) with tenween: (T:) and AimoXi ruwayodFA↓ Walk thou, or go thou, gently, &c.: (T, A:) so accord. to the lexicologists [in general]: but accord. to Sb, it is a verbal n.: [for] they said, zayodFA ruwayoda↓, meaning Act thou gently, softly, or in a leisurely manner, towards, or with, Zeyd; or grant him a delay, or respite; let him alone, or leave him, for a while; syn. Oamohilohu: hence it has no dual nor pl. nor fem. form: and hence they say that it is for UirowaAdFA, in the sense of Oarowido; as though it were an abbreviated dim., formed by the rejection of the augmentative letters: this is the opinion of Sb; for he holds it to be a substitute for Oarowido; though it has a nearer resemblance to UirowaAdN because it is a noun: others hold it to be the dim. of ruwdN, and cite the saying [of a poet],
kaOanRahu mivolu mano yamoXiI EalaI ruwdi
[As though he were like him who walks, or goes, gently, &c.]: but this is a mistake; for ruwdN is not put in the place of a verb, as UirowaAdN is. (M.) Accord. to Ibn-Keysán, ruwayod↓ seems to have two contr. significations; for they said, ruwayoda zayodFA, meaning Leave thou Zeyd, or let him alone; and also meaning act thou gently towards, or with, Zeyd, and retain him, or withhold him. (TA.) One says also, EamorFA ruwayodaka↓, meaning Act thou gently, &c., towards, or with, 'Amr; syn. Oamohilohu: (T, * S, M, * K:) the k in this case being a denotative of allocution, (T, S, M,) and having no place in the desinential syntax: (S, M: *) it is added only when rwyd is used in the sense of an imperative; (T, S, K;) and to prevent confusion of him who is meant to be addressed with him who is not meant, because rwyd applies to one and to more than one and to the male and to the female; though sometimes one says rwydk to a person when one does not fear his being confounded with another, using the k as a corroborative. (T.) In this case, rwyd↓ is an abbreviated dim. of UirowaAd, the inf. n. of Oarowada. (S.) In like manner also one says, (K, TA,) to a male, (TA,) ruwayodakaniI↓ [Act thou gently, &c., towards, or with, me]; and to a female, ruwayodakiniI↓; and ruwayodakumaAniI↓ (K, TA) to two persons; (TA;) and ruwayodakumuwniI↓ (K, TA) to males more than two; (TA;) and ruwayodakunRaniI↓ (K, TA) to females more than two. (TA.) ruwayod↓ is used in four different manners: first, as a verbal n.; as in EamorFA ruwayoda↓, (S, K, *) i. e. Oarowido EamorFA, (S,) meaning Oamohilohu [expl. above]: (S, K:) secondly, as an inf. n.; as in EamorKw ruwayoda↓ [virtually meaning the same]; the former word being prefixed to the latter, governing it in the gen. case; (S, M, * K; *) like faDaroba AlrRiqaAbi, in the Kur [xlvii. 4], (S, M, *) in which the inf. n. is put for its verb; (Jel;) and like Eaciyra AlHaIRi [expl. in art. Ecr]: (M:) thirdly, as an epithet; as in saAruwA sayorFA ruwayodFA↓ [They went, or journeyed, at a gentle, or leisurely, rate of going, or journeying]; (Sb, S, K;) and saAruwA ruwayodFA↓, in which sayorFA is suppressed: (T:) fourthly, as a denotative of state; as in saAra Alqawomu ruwayodFA↓ [The people, or party, went, or journeyed, going, or journeying, gently, or leisurely]; it being here in connection with a determinate noun, and therefore a denotative of its state. (S, K.) When it is used as a threat, it is with nasb, without tenween; (Lth, T, M; *) as in the saying of a poet,
taSaAhalo biQloEiraAqi jiyaAdunaA ruwayoda↓
kaOanRaka biAlDRaHRaAki qado qaAma naAdibuho
[Act thou, or proceed thou, gently, lest our coursers neigh, one to another, in El-'Irák: it is as though thou wert with Ed-Dahhák, his summoner to battle having already risen]. (Lth, T.) Sb mentions his having heard the saying, waQllRehi maA AlXRiEora lawo Oaradota AldRaraAhima laOaEoTayotuka ruwayoda↓ [By God, hadst thou desired the money, I had given thee: let alone the poetry: mA being here redundant]: (T, M:) like the phrase, fadaEi AlXRiEora: (M:) and similar to this is the saying, AlXRiEora yagibRa ruwayoda↓ [explained in art. gb]. (T.)

riydN c
riydN [originally riwodN] Will, wish, or desire; (K;) and so riydapN↓ [originally riwodapN]: (M, L:) or the former signifies a thing that one wishes, or desires, and strives to obtain: (T in art. ryd:) and the latter, love, or liking, for a thing; and solicitude respecting it: (M, L:) or the latter signifies a kind, or manner, of wishing or desiring; as in the saying, Oaradotuhu bikulRi riydapi [I wished it, or desired it, with every kind, or manner, of wishing or desiring]. (M.)

ruwdapN c
ruwdapN: see raAdN.

riydapN c
riydapN: see riydN.

rawaAdN c
rawaAdN: see raAdN, in two places.

AlrRiyaAdu c
AlrRiyaAdu, originally an inf. n., and cabRu AlrRiyaAdi, The wild bull; [a species of bovine antelope;] (M;) called cbR AlryAd because he goes to and fro, not remaining in one place; (M in art. cb;) or because he pastures going to and fro; (T and S * and M in that art.;) or because his females pasture with him, going to and fro. (T in that art.) Also, the latter, (tropical:) A man who comes and goes. (Kr, M and TA in art. cb.) And (tropical:) A man who is in the habit of visiting women. (AA, T and K in that art.)

raWuwdN c
raWuwdN: see raAdN.

AlrRiwanodu AlSRiyniIRu c
AlrRiwanodu AlSRiyniIRu, (K,) or AlrRiywanodu AlSRiyniIRu, (L,) [mentioned in this art. though the n should be regarded as radical, for] it is not genuine Arabic, (L,) [China-rhubarb;] a well-known medicine; (K;) a certain cool medicine, good for the liver: (L:) the physicians add an A to it, (K,) saying raAwanod: (TA:) there are four kinds thereof; the best of which is the SiyniIR; and inferior to this is the xuraAsaAniIR, which is [commonly] known by the appellation of raAwanodu AldRawaAbRi, used by the veterinarians: it is a black [app. a mistake for red, or yellow,] wood, of compound powers, but its predominant qualities are heat and dryness. (TA.)

ruwayodN c
ruwayodN: see 4, first sentence: and see also ruwdN throughout.

ruwaAdapN c
ruwaAdapN: see raAdN.

ruwayodaMCu c
ruwayodaMCu and ruwayodiyapN or ruwayodiyRapN: see 4, first sentence.

raAYidN c
raAYidN [act. part. n. of 1, Coming and going; moving to and fro; &c.]. [Hence,] AimoraOapN raAYidapN: see raAdN. And dawaAbRu rawaAYidu [pl. of daAbRapN raAYidapN] Beasts pasturing at pleasure: (T:) or going to and for [in the place of pasture]: or pasturing together while the rest are debarred from the pasture, or tied. (M.) And riyHN raAYidapN: see raAdN, last two sentences. And raAYidu AlwisaAdi [lit. Whose pillow moves to and fro; meaning] (tropical:) a man restless by reason of disease or anxiety; (A;) or uneasy on his pillow by reason of anxiety that disquiets him: (TA:) [or sleepless: see 1.] And raAYidu AlEayoni The EuwRaAr of the eye, [i. e. the mote, or the like, that has fallen into it, or the foul, thick, white matter that collects in its inner corner, and] that moves to and fro (yaruwdu) therein. (S.) ― -b2- The handle of the hand-mill, (S, M, A, K,) which the grinder grasps (S, M, A) when he turns round the mill-stone (S, A) therewith. (A.) ― -b3- See also mirowadN. ― -b4- One who is sent (S, M, A, Mgh, L, K) before a people or party (Mgh) to seek for herbage (S, M, A, Mgh, L, K) and water (Mgh) and the places where rain has fallen; (L;) or one who looks for, and seeks, herbage, and a place in which to alight, and chooses the best thereof; (T;) and raAdN↓ signifies the same; (S, M, K;) the latter occurring in the poetry of Hudheyl; (M;) [originally rawadN,] of the measure faEalN in the sense of the measure faAEilN, (S, K,) like faraTN in the sense of faAriTN, (S,) or of the measure faAEilN deprived of its medial radical letter, or of the measure faEilN, [originally rawidN,] but if so, it is a kind of rel. n., not an act. part. n.: (M:) the pl. of the former is ruwRaAdN (M, A, L) and raAdapN. (L.) One says, AlrRaAYidu laA yakocibu Oaholahu, (T, Mgh,) or laA yakocibu AlrRaAYidu Oaholahu, (S,) [The seeker of herbage, &c., will not lie to his family,] for if he lie to them he perishes with them: (Ham p. 547:) a prov. applied to him who will not lie when he relates a thing. (M.) And hence the saying, AlHumRaI raAYidu Almawoti (tropical:) Fever is the messenger that precedes death; like the messenger that goes before a people, or party, to seek for herbage and water. (Mgh, TA.) Hence, likewise, raAYidN is also applied to (tropical:) One who goes before with some abominable deed or design. (TA.) And to (assumed tropical:) A seeker of science or knowledge. (L, from a trad.) [Hence also,] OanaA raAYidu HaAjapK and murotaAduhaA↓ (tropical:) [I am the seeker of an object of want]: and OunaAsN ruwRaAdu AlHaAjaAti (tropical:) [Men who are the seekers of the objects of want]. (A.) ― -b5- Also One who has no place in which to alight or abide. (T in art. ryd and TA.) ＝ -A2- [See also art. rOd.]

raAYidapN c
raAYidapN a subst. that is put in the place of AirotiyaAdN [inf. n. of 8], and of UiraAdapN [inf. n. of 4]. (T in art. ryd.)

Oarowadu c
Oarowadu Gentle, or quiet, and unnoticed in operation: so in the saying, AldRahoru Oarowadu giyarK [Time, or fortune, is gentle, or quiet, and unnoticed in operation; characterized by changing accidents]. (S, TA.) ＝ -A2- Ouroyadu↓ [More, and most, desirous], occurring in the prov., Uino kunoti turiydiyna faOanaA laki Oaroyadu [If thou desire me, I am more desirous of thee], is said by Akh to be altered from Oarowadu; and thus to be like OaHoyalu, in the phrase huwa OaHoyalu AlnRaAsi, originally OaHowalu. (MF.)

Oaroyadu c
Oaroyadu: see what next precedes.

maraAdN c
maraAdN A place where camels go to and fro in pasturing; (S, K;) as also musotaraAdN↓. (K.) And maraAdu AlrRiyHi The place where the wind [blows to and fro, or] goes and comes. (S, TA.)

muraAdN c
muraAdN [What is willed, or wished;] desired; sought, or sought after; and chosen: (Msb:) loved, or liked. (L.) [Intended, or meant, by a saying or an action.]

marowadN c
marowadN: see 4, first sentence.

mirowadN c
mirowadN A certain well-known instrument, (Msb,) [resembling a bodkin, or small probe, tapering towards the end, but blunt, generally of wood or bone or ivory or silver,] with which the [black powder called] kuHol is applied to the eyes; (TA;) syn. miylN, (S, M, A, K,) and mikoHaAlN: so called [because it is passed to and fro along the edges of the eyelids,] from raAda signifying “he, or it, came and went:” (Mgh:) pl. maraAwidu. (Msb.) ― -b2- The pivot of the sheave of a pulley, if of iron. (S, K. *) ― -b3- A wooden pin, peg, or stake; syn. watidN. (M, K.) ― -b4- An iron [swivel] that turns round in the lijaAm [i. e. bit, or bit and bridle]: (S, K:) or an iron [swivel] which is attached to the rasan of the colt [or horse] and of the hawk, [i. e., to the halter, or leading-cord, of the colt or horse, and the leash of the hawk,] and which, when he turns round, turns round with him: (A:) or the mirowadaAni, also called the raAYidaAni↓, are the two rings in [either of] which is the extremity of the EicaAr [or side-piece of the headstall of the horse]. (IDrd, in his “Book on the Saddle and Bridle.”) You say, daAra Almuhoru wa AlbaAziI fiI Almirowadi [The colt, and the hawk, went round, attached to the mrwd]. (A.) ― -b5- A joint; syn. mafoSilN. (M.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) A limit, or an extent, to which one runs: so in a trad. of 'Alee, in which it is said, UinRa libaniI OumayRapa mirowadFA yajoruwna Uilayohi [Verily there is a limit, or an extent, for the sons of Umeiyeh, to which they run]: from UirowaAdN as signifying UimohaAlN. (TA.)

muriydN c
[muriydN as meaning A candidate for admission into a religious order, during his state of probation, is a conventional post-classical term. So too as meaning A devotee, whose sole endeavour is to comply with the will of God.]

murotAdu HaAjapK c
murotAdu HaAjapK: see raAYidN.

musotaraAdN c
musotaraAdN: see maraAdN. ＝ -A2- [Also pass. part. n. of 10.] The sayings fulaAnN musotaraAdN limivolihi and fulaAnapu musotaraAdapN limivolihaA are expl. as meaning (tropical:) The like of such a man, and the like of such a woman, is sought after, and coveted, by reason of the high estimation in which he, and she, is held: and it is said that the meaning is, mstrAd mvlh and mvlhA; the l being redundant. (M, TA. [The latter clause seems to indicate a different meaning from that before expressed: but for this I see no reason.])

2 rawRasa c
2. rawRasa: see raORasa.

8 yarotaAsu c
8. yarotaAsu: see yarotaYisu.

rawRaAsN c
rawRaAsN and rawRaAsiIRN: for both, see raORLsN: and for the latter, see also OaroOasu.

1 raADa c
1. raADa, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) aor. yaruwDu, (S,) inf. n. riyaADapN (S, M, A, Msb, K) and riyaADN, (S, M, K,) or the latter is used poetically for the former, and rawoDN, (M,) He broke, or trained, (M, K, Msb,) a colt, (S, K,) or beast, (M, A, Msb,) and made it easy to ride upon: (M:) or he taught it to go: (TA:) and rwRD↓, inf. n. tarowiyDN, he did so well, or vigorously. (S, TA.) ― -b2- Hence, raADa SaAHibahu (assumed tropical:) [He made his companion easy and tractable]. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] raADa nafosahu (assumed tropical:) [He trained, disciplined, or subdued, himself: or] he became clement, or forbearing. (Msb.) And nafosaka biAltRaqowaI rawRiDo↓ (tropical:) [Train, discipline, or subdue, thyself well by piety]. (A, TA.) ― -b4- [Hence also,] raADa AlXRaAEiru AlqawaAfiIa (tropical:) [The poet rendered rhymes, or verses, easy to him by practice]. (A, TA.) And lahu OamorFA rwRD↓ (assumed tropical:) He made an affair easy to him; syn. sawRasahu, q. v. (TA in art. sws.) ― -b5- [Hence also,] ruDotu AldRurRa, inf. n. riyaADapN, (tropical:) I bored the pearls: and huwa SaEobu AlrRiyaADapi, and saholu AlryADp, (tropical:) It is difficult to bore, and easy to bore. (A, TA.)

2 rawRaDa
2: see 1, in three places. ＝ -A2- rwRD, (K,) inf. n. tarowiyDN, (TA,) He kept to the riyaAD [pl. of rawoDap, q. v.]. (K.) ＝ -A3- rwRD AlqaraAHa, (S, K,) or AlOaroDa, (M, A,) He, or it, (a man, S, or a torrent, M, or the rain, A,) made the clear or bare land, (S, K,) or the land, (M, A,) a rawoDap. (S, M, K.) And QllRehu AlOaroDa ArAD↓ God made the land riyaAD. (M.)

3 rAwDhu c
3. rAwDhu, (S, A, K,) EalaI Oamori kacaA, (S,) or EalaI kacaA, (A,) inf. n. muraAwaDapN, (Mgh,) (tropical:) He coaxed, wheedled, beguiled, or deluded, him; (S, A, Mgh, K;) and he endeavoured to deceive or beguile him; like as he does who is training a beast not yet rendered perfectly tractable; (Mgh;) in order to make him enter into such a thing or affair; (S;) or until he entered into such a thing. (A.) ― -b2- Hence, (Mgh,) bayoEu AlmuraAwaDapi (tropical:) That mode of selling which is termed bayoEu AlmuwaASafapi; (Mgh, K; *) which is when one describes to a man an article of merchandise not present with him: (Sh, K:) this is said in a trad. to be an action that is disapproved: (K:) but some of the professors of practical law allow it when the article of merchandise agrees with the description. (L.)

4 ArAD c
4. ArAD (Yaakoob, S, A) and OarowaDa (Yaakoob, S) It (a place) became abundant in its riyaAD [pl. of rawoDapN, q. v.]; (Yaakoob, S, A;) as also AstrAD↓. (A.) And OarowaDati AlOaroDu and OaraADat The land became clad with plants, or herbage (M.) ― -b2- [And hence,] ArAD (tropical:) It (a valley) had water stagnating, or remaining, or collecting, in it; (S, A, Msb, K;) concealing its bottom; (A;) as also AstrAD↓: (S, M, A, Msb, K:) and so the former verb, (S,) or ↓both, (A,) said of a watering-trough: (S, A:) or, when said of a watering-trough, the former verb signifies (assumed tropical:) it had its bottom, or lower part, covered with water: (M:) and ↓the latter, (assumed tropical:) the water spread widely upon the surface thereof; (M;) and so the former too: (TA:) or ↓the latter, (tropical:) it had a sufficient quantity of water poured into it to conceal its bottom; (O, K;) or to cover its bottom, or lower part. (L, TA.) ― -b3- And from ArAD, said of a watering-trough, has originated the saying, (S,) XaribuwA HatRaI OaraADuwA (assumed tropical:) (assumed tropical:) They drank until they thoroughly satisfied their thirst. (S, K. *) And ArAD also signifies (assumed tropical:) He drank a second draught after a first. (K.) ＝ -A2- ArAD QllRehu AlOaroDa: see 2. ― -b2- [Hence,] ArAD AlHawoDa (assumed tropical:) He poured into the watering-trough a sufficient quantity of water to conceal its bottom. (TA.) ― -b3- And hence, (TA,) OaraADahumo, said of a vessel, (tropical:) It satisfied their thirst: (S, * K:) or it satisfied their thirst in some degree. (M, TA.) Hence the saying, fadaEaA biUinaMCK yuriyDu AlrRahoTa (tropical:) And he called for a vessel which would satisfy (K, TA) in some degree (TA) the [number of men termed a] rahoT; (K, TA;) occurring in a trad., (TA,) accord. to one relation, but the more common is yurobiDu, (K, TA,) with the singlepointed b. (TA.) ― -b4- ArAD also signifies (assumed tropical:) He poured milk upon milk; (K;) accord. to A 'Obeyd; but he deems it strange. (TA.)

6 AltRaraAwuDu c
6. AltRaraAwuDu in selling and buying is syn. with AltRaHaAciI; i. e. (tropical:) The increasing [of the sum offered] and diminishing [of the sum demanded] which take place between the two parties bargaining; as though each of them were making his companion easy and tractable; from AlrRiyaADapu as inf. n. of raADa in the first of the senses expl. above. (TA.) In the phrase taraAwaDaA AlsRiloEapa, meaning (assumed tropical:) They coaxed, wheedled, beguiled, or deluded, each other, with respect to the article of merchandise, [in the manner explained above, or otherwise,] the omission of the prep. [fiI] requires consideration. (Mgh.) You say also, taraAwaDaA fiI AlOamori (assumed tropical:) They practised dissimulation, or showed feigned affection, each to the other, in, or respecting, the thing, or affair; as also tanaAZaraA: (TK in art. nZr:) AltRaraAwuDu fiI AlOamori is syn. with AltRanaAZuru. (M and K in art. nZr.)

8 ArtAD c
8. ArtAD, said of a colt, (K,) and ArtADt, (S, A,) said of a she-camel, (S,) or of a beast
(daAbRap), (A,) It became broken, or trained. (S, A, * K, TA.) ― -b2- [And hence,] ArtADt AlqawaAfiI lilXRaAEiri (tropical:) [The rhymes, or verses, became rendered easy by practice to the poet]. (A, TA.)

10 AstrAD c
10. AstrAD: see 4, in five places. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) It (water) stagnated, or remained, or collected, in a place. (TA.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) It (a place, S, M, K) was, or became, wide, ample, or spacious. (S, M, Msb, K.) ― -b4- And [hence (see its part. n. below)] AstrADt AlnRafosu (tropical:) The mind was, or became, dilated, free from straitness, cheerful, or happy. (K, TA.)

rawoDN c
rawoDN: see the paragraph next following, near the middle, in three places; and again, in the last sentence of the same.

rawoDapN c
rawoDapN (S, M, A, Msb, K) and riyDapN↓ (AA, A, K) and riyRiDapN↓ (TA) [seem to be best rendered, in general, A meadow; meaning, a verdant tract of land, somewhat watery; or (as in Johnson's dictionary) ground somewhat watery, not ploughed, but covered with grass and flowers: and sometimes, a garden: accord. to the following explanations:] verdant land: a place where water collects, and the herbage becomes abundant, without trees: or fresh green herbage, with water, or having water by its side; not otherwise: or, accord. to Aboo-Ziyád El-Kilábee, a tract of plain land, producing [lote-trees of the kind called] sidor; which may be of the extent of Baghdád: and also, of herbs, or leguminous plants, and fresh green herbage: (M:) or this last [only]: (S:) or a tract of plain land, in which are jaraAviym [perhaps here meaning ants' nests, as these are generally found in soft soil,] and soft hillocks, in the low, or best and most productive, parts of a country, where water stagnates, or remains, or collects, at least a hundred cubits in extent: (M:) or a tract of sand, and of fresh green herbage, where water stagnates, or remains, or collects; so called because of the stagnation, or remaining, or collecting, of the water therein: (A, K, TA:) it is said that rawoDapN is mostly applied to a place where beasts pasture at pleasure: some say that it signifies a land having waters and trees, and sweet, or pleasant, flowers: (TA:) or a place that is pleasant with flowers; said to be so called because the waters that flow thither rest there: (Msb:) it is said in the 'Ináyeh, that rawoDN↓ [perhaps a mistake for rawoDapN] signifies a garden; and in common conventional language, one having rivers, or rivulets: MF says that rivers, or rivulets, do not necessarily belong to the signification; but that having water does; though not in common conventional language: (TA:) accord. to Th, rawoDapN signifies a beautiful garden: (M:) the pl. of rawoDapN is rawoDN↓, (S, M, K,) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.,] and riyaADN, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) originally riwaADN, (S,) and riyDaAnN, (Lth, M, K,) originally riwoDaAnN, (TA,) or rather riyDaAnN is pl. of rawoDN↓, (M,) and rawoDaAtN, (M, Msb,) in the dial. of Hudheyl rawaDaAtN: (Msb:) Az says that the ryAD of the hard and stony and rugged tracts in the desert are low level places, in which the rainwater stagnates, or remains, or collects, and which consequently produce various kinds of herbage, that do not quickly dry up and wither: that sometimes a rawoDap contains thickets of wild sidor: and sometimes it is a mile in length and breadth: but such as are very wide are termed qiyEaAn. (TA.) It is said in a prov., OaHosanu mino bayoDapK fiI rawoDapK [More beautiful than an egg in a meadow, or garden]. (A, TA.) And one says, OanaA Einodaka fiI rawoDapK (tropical:) [I, in thy presence, am as though I were in a meadow, or garden]: and majolisuka rawoDapN mino riyaADi AljanRapi (tropical:) [Thy sittingplace is like a meadow, or garden, of the meadows, or gardens, of Paradise]. (A, TA.) Mohammad is related to have said, “Between my grave, or between my house, and my pulpit is a rawoDap of the riyaAD of Paradise:” meaning, accord. to Th, that he who abides in this place is as though he abode in a rwDp of the ryAD of Paradise. (M.) [See another tropical meaning of riyaADu AljanRapi voce rataEa, last sentence.] ― -b2- rawoDapN also signifies (assumed tropical:) Any water that collects in pools left by torrents, or the like, and in places in land or in the ground to which the rain-water flows and which retain it. (K, * TA. [In the CK, AlAaxRAcAt and AlmusRAkAt are erroneously put for AlUixaAcaAt and AlmasRaAkaAt.]) ― -b3- Also, (K,) or rawoDN↓, (S, M,) (assumed tropical:) About the half of a firobap [or water-skin] (S, M, K) of water: (S:) and the former, (tropical:) as much of water as covers the bottom of a watering-trough. (S, M, A.)

riyDapN c
riyDapN: see rawoDapN. [It is implied in the K that the former is syn. with the latter in all its senses: but accord. to the TA, this is not the case.]

raAYiDN c
raAYiDN A breaker, or trainer, (M, Msb, K,) of colts, (K,) or of beasts (dawaAbR): (M, Msb:) pl. raADapN and ruwRaADN (S M, K) and ruwRaDN. (M.)

rayRiDN c
rayRiDN, originally rayowiDN, (S,) [in its primary sense seems to be syn. with maruwDN↓. ― -b2- And hence it signifies] (assumed tropical:) Clement, or forbearing. (Msb.) ― -b3- [Also, and more commonly,] applied to a she-camel, (S, K,) and to a he-camel, (S,) In the first stage of training, as yet refractory: (S, K:) and in like manner applied to a boy: (S:) or a colt, (A,) or beast, (L,) that has not received training, nor become skilled in going, or pace, (A, L,) nor become submissive to its rider: (L:) and a she-camel not trained: (A:) or, applied to a horse or the like, and to a camel, to a male and to a female, refractory; contr. of caluwlN; app. designed as an epithet of good omen, because the beast is so called only before being skilfully trained. (M.) ― -b4- [Hence,] qaSiydapN rayRiDapu AlqawaAfiI (tropical:) An ode of difficult rhymes; such rhymes as the poets have not extemporaneously composed: (TA:) or qaSiydapN rayRiDapN means (tropical:) an ode not well, or not skilfully, composed. (A.) And OamorN rayRiDN (tropical:) An affair not well, not skilfully, or not soundly, managed, conducted, ordered, or regulated. (A, TA.)

rayRiDapN c
rayRiDapN as a subst.: see rawoDapN

maraADN c
maraADN Hard ground in the lower, or lowest, part of a plain, or of soft ground, which retains water: pl. maraAYiDu and maraADaAtN. (Az, K.)

maruwDN c
maruwDN, (S, K,) and its fem., with p, (S, Msb,) A colt, (S, K,) and she-camel, (S,) or beast (daAbRap), (Msb,) broken, or trained. (S * Msb, K.) See also rayRiDN.

OaroDN musotarowiDapN c
OaroDN musotarowiDapN Land which has produced good herbage or plants, and of which the herbs, or leguminous plants, have become erect, or strong and erect: and nabaAtN musotarowiDN plants which have attained their utmost size and height. (M.) ― -b2- AifoEalo caAka maA daAmati AlnRafosu musotariyDapF (tropical:) Do thou that while the mind is free from straitness, cheerful, or happy, (S, M, * Msb, TA, [in the second of which, however, Alnfs is strangely made masc.,]) is from AstrAD said of a place, as explained above. (S.) ― -b3- musotariyDN is also applied, by a poet, (S, M,) El-Aghlab El-'Ijlee, (S,) or Homeyd ElArkat, (AHn, M, IB,) to poetry, and to the metre termed rajaz; (S, M;) as meaning (assumed tropical:) Easy; practicable. (M, TA.)

1 raAEahu c
1. raAEahu, (IAar, Az, S, Msb, K, *) aor. yaruwEu (Mgh,) inf. n. rawoEN (Msb, TA) and ruwEN and ruwuwEN and ruWuwEN, (IAar, TA,) [He, or it, affected his ruwE, i. e. heart, or mind, with fright, or fear;] fear of it (namely an affair or event) reached his ruwE; (Az, TA;) he, or it, (a man, S, or an affair or event, IAar, TA, or a thing, Msb,) frightened him; put him in fear; made him afraid; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also rwREhu↓, (S, Msb, K, *) inf. n. tarowiyEN: (TA:) or its beauty and abundance or multitude frightened him: (Lth, TA:) and ↓the latter also, it frightened him by its abundance or multitude, or its beauty. (TA.) Hence the saying, in a trad., UicaA XamiTa lUinosaAnu fiI EaAriDayohi facelika AlrRawoEu, as though meaning [When the man becomes grizzled in the hair of the two sides of his face, that is] the warning of death. (TA.) You say also, [using the pass. form,] riyEa, aor. yuraAEu, (TA,) inf. n. rawoEN, (S, K,) He was, or became, frightened, or afraid; or he feared; (S, * K, * TA;) as also ArtAE↓, and trwRE↓. (S, K, TA.) And raAEa minohu, aor. yaruwEu, inf. n. rawoEN, He was, or became, frightened at it, or afraid of it; or he feared it. (TK. [But I know of no authority on which this is founded, except a prov. (cited in art. jEr), in which some read ruwEiI jaEaAri instead of ruwgiI.]) To a man, you say, laA turaEo [Be not thou frightened;] fear not thou; let not fear overtake thee: and to a woman, laA turaAEiI. (S, TA.) And hence the saying, in a trad., lano turaAEawoA maA raOayonaA mino XaIoCK [Ye shall not be frightened, or afraid: we saw not, or have not seen, anything]. (TA.) You also say, minohu ArtAE↓ and lahu He was, or became, frightened at, or afraid of, him, or it; or he feared him, or it. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) [It affected his ruwE, i. e. heart, or
mind, with a sudden surprise; it took him by surprise.] One says, maA raAEaniI UilRaA majiyWuka meaning (tropical:) [Nothing took me by surprise but thy coming; i. e. I was surprised by thy coming; or] I knew not save thy coming; as though he said, nothing struck my ruwE but thy coming. (TA.) And xarajotu wa maA raAEaniI UilRaA fulaAnN liAlbaAbi (assumed tropical:) [I went forth, and nothing took me by surprise but such a one at the door]; which is equivalent to saying, and lo, such a one was at the door. (Har p. 207.) And it is said in a trad. of I'Ab, falamo yaruEoniI UilRaA rajulN MxicN bimanokibiI, i. e. I knew not [save a man taking hold of, or seizing, my shoulder-joint]; as though he came upon him suddenly, or unexpectedly, without any previous appointment, and without knowledge, and so that event frightened him. (TA.) ― -b3- [It affected his ruwE, i. e. heart, or mind, with admiration, or pleasure;] it excited his admiration and approval; it pleased him, or rejoiced him; (S, Msb, K;) said of beauty [&c.]. (Msb.) It is said in a trad., describing the people of Paradise, fayaruwEuhu maA Ealayohi mina AllRibaAsi And what is upon him, of apparel, excites his admiration &c., by its beauty. (TA.) ― -b4- [It (drink) cooled it, (namely, the heart,) or allayed its thirst.] A poet says,
saqatoniI XarobapF raAEato fuWaAdiI
saqaAhaA QllRehu mino HawoDi AlrRasuwli
[She gave me to drink a draught that cooled, or allayed the thirst of, my heart: may God give her to drink from the pool of the Apostle in Paradise]. (TA.) You say also, hecihi XarobapN raAEa bihaA fuWaAdiI [which may be rendered This is a draught by which he has cooled, or allayed the thirst of, my heart; and it is implied in the TA that this is the right meaning: or it means] this is a draught by which the thirst, or vehement thirst, of my heart has been allayed: (so accord. to the pointing in the copies of the K:) mentioned by Az.
