(TA.) ＝ -A2- The verb from rawaEN [q. v. infrà] is one and the same [whether trans. or intrans.; i. e., you say raAEahu, aor. yaruwEu, inf. n. rawoEN, meaning “He,” or “it, excited his admiration and approval,” &c., as expl. above; and raAEa, app. with the same aor. and inf. n., meaning He possessed the quality of exciting admiration and approval by his beauty and the pleasingness of his aspect, or by his courage, &c.; and in like manner, raAEato, said of a woman]; the trans. verb [in this case] being like the trans. [in other cases], and the intrans. [in this case] like the intrans. [in other cases]: but the regular form, accord. to Az, of the [intrans.] verb hence derived is rawiEa, aor. yarowaEu, inf. n. rawaEN. (TA.) ＝ -A3- raAEa fiI yadiI kacaA: see art. ryE. ― -b2- And raAEa, aor. yaruwEu, and yariyEu, inf. n. of the former ruwaAEN, and of the latter rayoEN: see art. ryE.

2 rawRaEa
2: see 1, first sentence, in two places.

5 tarawRaEa
5: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph.

8 UirotawaEa
8: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph, in two places. ― -b2- ArtAE liloxayori i. q. ArtAH lahu [He was affected by alacrity, cheerfulness, briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness, disposing him to promptness to do good; he inclined to, and loved, doing good]. (AZ.)

rawoEN c
rawoEN [see 1, of which it is an inf. n. ― -b2- ] Fright, or fear; (S, K;) as also rawEN↓ [accord. to some, but this seems to be little known]. (TA.) Hence the saying, Oaforaxa rawoEuhu His fright, or fear, departed. (S.) Az says, All the lexicologists whom I have met say Oaforaxa rawoEuhu, with fet-h to the r [in rwEh], except El-Mundhiree, who informs me that AHeyth used to say, It is only Afrx rawoEuka↓, with damm. (TA.) Accord. to different relations of a trad., you say, Oaforaxa ruwEuka↓, meaning Fright, or fear, hath departed from thy heart; or may fright, or fear, depart from thy heart; (K, TA;) thus expl. by AHeyth; (TA;) and Afrx rawoEuka, with fet-h; or this latter, only, is the right, and means what thou fearest hath quitted thee, and departed from thee, and become removed; or may what thou fearest quit thee, &c.; as though it were taken from the young bird's going forth from the egg, (K, TA,) and the darkness' becoming removed from it; thus expl. by Aboo-Ahmad El-Hasan Ibn-' Abd-Allah Ibn-Sa'eed El-' Askeree; and AO says that Afrx rwEk [thus in the TA, without any syll. signs,] means let thy fright, or fear, depart, for the case is not as thou fearest it to be. (TA.) It is also said, in a trad. of Mo'áwiyeh, that he wrote in a letter to Ziyád, liyuforixo ruwEuka↓, with damm; (K, TA;) but the opinion commonly obtaining with the leading lexicologists is, that it is with fet-h; except AHeyth, who relates it thus, with damm; (TA;) meaning Dismiss thou the rawoE from thy ruwE; (K, TA;) i. e., the fright, or fear, from thy heart: (TA:) for you say Oaforaxati AlbayoDapu when the young bird quits the egg; and rawoE is fright, or fear, which does not depart from itself, but from its place, which is the ruwE, with damm; (AHeyth, K;) the rawoE in the ruwE being like the young bird in the egg: in like manner also one says Oaforaxa fuWaAdu AlrRajuli when a man's fright, or fear, departs: but Dhu-r-Rummeh, though knowing the meaning, has made an inversion, saying,
qado Oaforaxato Eano ruwEihi Alkurabu
[for qado Oaforaxa Eani Alkurabi ruwEuhu His heart had freed itself from griefs]. (AHeyth, TA.) AHeyth adds, (TA,) one also says, Eani AlOamori Oaforixa ruwEaka↓, or EalaI AlOamori, [accord. to different copies of the K, the latter being the reading in the TA, but the former probably the right,] meaning [Free thy heart from the affair; i. e.] be thou tranquil, and without fear. (K, TA.) Az observes, What AHeyth says is clear; but I am averse from it because of his being alone in his saying; though sometimes later authorities correct things in which the earlier have erred; therefore the correctness of AHeyth may not be [absolutely] denied in this matter, seeing that he had an ample share of knowledge. (TA.) [See also art. frx, in several places.] ― -b3- Also (tropical:) War, or battle; as in the phrase, Xahida AlrRawoEa (tropical:) [He witnessed, or was present at or in, war, or battle]. (TA.) [See also an ex. in a verse cited voce saEafN.]

ruwEN c
ruwEN The heart: (S, Msb, K:) or the part thereof which is the place of rawoE, i. e. fear: (K, * TA:) or the sawaAd [or core, &c.,] thereof: (K:) and the mind: (S, Msb, K, * TA:) and the understanding; or intellect. (S, K.) See rawoEN, in five places. You say, waqaEa celika fiI ruwEiI That came into my mind. (S, Msb, * TA.) And it is said in a trad., UinRa AlrRuwHa nafava fiI ruwEiI [Verily the Trusted, or Trusty, Spirit (meaning Gabriel) inspired into my mind, or heart]. (S.) You say also, vaAbi ruwEuhu, meaning (assumed tropical:) He went to [app. a mistake for from] a thing, and then returned to it. (TA.)

rawaEN c
rawaEN The quality of exciting admiration and approval by beauty (S, K) and pleasingness of aspect, or by courage; (K;) the quality denoted by the epithet OarowaEu, applied to a man, (S, K, *) and rawoEaMCu, applied to a woman. (S.) [See also 1, near the end of the paragraph.]

rawiEN c
rawiEN: see raAYiEN; last sentence.

rawoEapN c
rawoEapN A fit of fright or fear: (S, K, TA:) pl. rawaEaAtN; (TA;) which is applied by Tarafeh to the frights occasioned by a stallion-camel to a she-camel when he desires to cover her. (EM, p. 66.) It is said in a trad., faOaEoTaAhumo birawoEapi Alxayoli, meaning And he gave them something for the fright occasioned to their women and their children by the horsemen. (TA.) ― -b2- A trait, or sign, or mark, of beauty [that affects the ruwE, or heart]: (IAar, K:) beauty that excites admiration and approval, or pleases, or rejoices. (TA.)

ruwaAEu AlfuWaAdi c
ruwaAEu AlfuWaAdi and ruwaAEapu AlfuWaAdi, applied to a she-camel, Quick, spirited, vigorous; sharp in spirit; syn. XahomapN cakiyRapN: (K:) and [in like manner] rawoEaMCu↓, applied to a she-camel and a mare, (S, K,) but not to a male [in this sense, i. e. its masc. form, OarowaEu, is not thus used], (S,) sharp in spirit; syn. Hadiydapu AlfuWaAdi: (S, K:) in the T, ruwaAEN, without p, is applied as an epithet to a mare: and IAar says that rawoEaMCu↓, thus applied, is not from raAYiEapN, but means one that is as though she were fearful, by reason of her sharpness, and briskness, or lightness, of spirit: he says also, that OarowaEu↓, applied to a horse, is like this epithet applied to a man; and IB says, in art. Ejs, that, applied to a man, it signifies quickly frightened or afraid: it is also applied to a heart, meaning that is frightened, [or startled,] by reason of its sharpness, at everything that is heard or seen; and so ruwaAEN. (TA.) [See also raAYiEN, and OarowaEu mentioned and expl. therewith.]

raAYiEN c
raAYiEN [act. part. n. of raAEahu, q. v.,] Frightening; putting in fear; making afraid; [and particu-
larly] by its beauty and abundance or multitude. (Lth, TA.) ― -b2- Applied to beauty, That excites admiration and approval in the ruwE [i. e. heart, or mind,] of him who beholds it, and pleases him, or rejoices him. (TA.) Applied to a man, (K, * TA,) as also OarowaEu↓ (S, K, TA) so applied, (S, TA,) Who excites admiration and approval by his beauty (S, K, TA) and pleasingness of aspect, (K, TA,) with generousness, or nobleness, and excellence, and lordly condition; (TA;) or by his courage: (K, TA:) or the former, beautiful in countenance, who excites admiration and approval by his pleasingness of aspect and by the goodliness of his form or figure or state of apparel and the like: or, as some say, who frightens men by his aspect, inspiring reverence or awe: but the former explanation is the more reasonable: and ↓the latter epithet, a beautiful man, who excites admiration and approval in him who beholds him: or, as some say, sharp; lively in spirit, and sharp in intellect: (TA:) [see also the next preceding paragraph:] the fem. of the former is with p: (TA:) that of the latter, rawoEaMCu↓: (S:) the pl. of raAYiEN is OarowaAEN, (K, * TA,) applied to men, like as rawaAYiEu [the pl. of raAYiEapN] is to women: (TA:) and the pl. of OarowaEu and rawoEaMCu is ruwEN↓, (K, TA,) applied to men and to women. (TA.) You say also, farasN raAYiEN A beautiful horse, that frightens (yuruwEu, i. e. yuxawRifu, [or rather startles, but better rendered excites admiration and approval in, or pleases, or rejoices,]) the beholder by his beauty: (Mgh:) and farasN raAYiEapN, and rawoEaMCu↓, [but see, respecting the latter, a remark of IAar in the next preceding paragraph,] a mare that excites admiration and approval, or pleases, or rejoices, (taruwEu,) by her generousness, or excellence, or high blood, and her description. (TA.) [See also art. ryE, to which, as well as to the present art., raAYiEN, applied to a horse, is said, in the TA, to belong.] And ziynapN raAYiEapN Beautiful ornament. (TA.) And kalaAmN raAYiEN (tropical:) Surpassing, or excelling, speech, or language. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also Frightened, or afraid; and so rawiEN↓, with the w unaltered, as though it were of the measure faEiylN: [or both signify having fright or fear: for] each is a possessive epithet: or the former may be of the measure faAEilN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN [and therefore have the signification first given]. (TA.)

OarowaEu c
OarowaEu: fem. rawoEaMCu: pl. ruwEN: see the two paragraphs next preceding; the former in three places; the latter, in five.

1 raAga c
1. raAga, (S, Msb, K,) aor. yaruwgu, (S, Msb,) inf. n. rawogN (S, Msb, K) and rawagaAnN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) said of a fox, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and of a man, (K,) He turned aside or away from a thing: (K:) or went this way and that, (Mgh,) or to the right and left, quickly, (Msb,) and deceitfully, or guilefully: (Mgh, Msb:) [or turned aside to deceive him who was behind him: for] the primary signification of rawogN is the turning aside to deceive him who is behind one. (Er-Rághib, TA.) It is said in a prov.,
ruwgiI jaEaAri wa QnoZuriI Oayona Almafiro
[for AlmafirRu, i. e. Turn aside or away, or go this way and that, &c., O she-hyena, and look where is the place to which to flee: or, as some relate it, the first word is ruwEiI: see art. jEr]. (S, TA. [Freytag seems to have found AlmEz for Almfr; and has explained ruwgiI jaEaAri as meaning “ Vide ubi capræ sint, hyæna! ”]) And you say, rAg AlSRayodu The game, or object of the chase, went away this way and that, or hither and thither. (TA. [There said to be tropical; but I see not wherefore.]) And one says, rAg Eano fulaAnK He turned aside, or away, from such a one [and particularly with deceit or guile; eluded him; dodged him]. (JK.) And huwa yaruwgu Eani AlHaqRi [He deviates from the truth, or from that which is right or just]. (TA.) And rAg AlTRariyqu The road turned aside or away, or deviated. (Msb.) And rAg mino kacaA He turned away from such a thing, and returned, concealing his return: (Har p. 21:) [for,] accord. to Fr, rAg is not said of one who has returned unless he concealed his return. (Har ibid., and TA.) And rAg UilaI kacaA, (S, Msb,) or AlI fulaAnK, (TA,) He turned aside (S, Msb, TA) to such a thing, (S, Msb,) or to such a one, (TA,) secretly. (S, Msb, TA.) Hence, in the Kur [li. 26], farAga UilaI Oaholihi fajaMCa biEijolK samiynK And he turned aside, (Jel, TA,) or went away, (Bd,) to his family secretly [and brought a fat calf]: (Bd, Jel, TA:) or he returned to his family concealing his return. (Fr, TA.) And in the Kur [xxxvii. 91], faraAga Ealayohimo DarobFA biQloyamiyni And he turned against them (Fr, S, Bd, TA) secretly, (Bd, TA,) smiting them with the right hand, or because of the oath that he had sworn; (Bd;) as though the rawog in this case consisted in his employing a pretext against them in order that he might do to their gods what he did: (S, L:) or the meaning is, he advanced against them. (S, TA.) ― -b2- rAg HaAjapF UilaI fulaAnK, aor. as above, He sought to obtain quickly an object of want of such a one. (JK, TA. [See also 4.]

2 rwRg c
2. rwRg, (IAar, K,) inf. n. tarowiygN, (TA,) (tropical:) He smeared, seasoned, imbued, or soaked, a mess of variyd [i. e. broken, or crumbled, bread], (IAar, K, TA,) or a morsel, or mouthful, (TA,) with grease, or gravy, or dripping; (IAar, K, TA;) as also marRaga, and sagobala, and rawRala: (TA:) or you say, rawRagotu AllRuqomapa biAlsRamoni, inf. n. as above, I smeared, seasoned, imbued, or soaked, the morsel, or mouthful, with clarified butter; as also rayRagotu: (Msb:) or rawRagotu Alxuboza fiI Alwadaki I soaked the bread in grease, or gravy, or dripping; syn. rawRalotuhu fiyhi. (JK.)

3 rAwghu c
3. rAwghu, (MA, TA,) inf. n. muraAwagapN (KL, TA) and riwaAgN, (TA,) He practised deceit, delusion, guile, or artifice, (MA, KL, TA,) with him, or towards him; (MA, TA;) or strove, endeavoured, or desired, to deceive, delude, beguile, circumvent, or outwit, him; syn. xaAdaEahu; as also ArAghu↓, inf. n. UiraAgapN: and both signify he endeavoured to turn him; or endeavoured to turn him by blandishment, or by deceitful arts, or to entice him to turn; syn. raAwadahu. (TA.) It is said when its object is a person who has turned away from, or shunned, or avoided, that which one has devised, planned, or plotted, against him. (TA.) You say, fulaAnN yuraAwigu fiI AlOamori [Such a one practises deceit, &c., in the affair], inf. n. muraAwagapN. (S.) And maA zilotu OuraAwiguhu Eano kacaA I ceased not to endeavour to turn him, or to entice him to turn, from such a thing, syn. OuraAwiduhu; (TA in this art;) and Ealayohi to it: (TA in art. mnE:) and [in like manner] you say, EalaI OamorK fulaAnN yuriyguniI↓ Such a one endeavours to turn me, or to entice me to turn, to a thing; and Eano OamorK from a thing; syn. yuraAwiduniI; and seeks, or demands, my doing so. (TA.) ― -b2- muraAwagapN also signifies The act of wrestling together; (S, K;) like taraAwugN↓. (K.) You say, raAwghu He wrestled with him: (TK:) or rwAg baEoDuhumo baEoDFA One of them wrestled with another; [or they wrestled, one with another; or they wrestled together;] as also trAwgwA↓. (S, TA.)

4 Oarowaga
4: see 3, in two places. ― -b2- ArAg, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. UiraAgapN, (Msb, TA,) also signifies He sought, sought for or after, sought to find and take or get, or pursued after, and desired, (S, Msb, K,) a thing; (Msb;) or a thing that was difficult to take; as though it turned aside or away, or went this way and that, &c., (kaOanRahu yaruwgu,) before him; (Har p. 21;) and ArtAg↓, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. AirotiyaAgN, (Msb,) signifies the same. (S, Msb, K.) [OariyguwniI UiraAgatakumo is expl. in one of my two copies of the S by the words AuTolubuwniI Talibatakumo: in the other of those copies, the latter of these words is written Tlibtakm: I think that the right reading is Tilobatakumo; and the meaning, Seek ye me with, or in, your mode, or manner, of seeking: the proper meaning is seek ye me with your seeking.] Khálid Ibn-Jaafar Ibn-Kiláb says, speaking of his mare Hicoqap,
OariyguwniI UiraAgatakumo faUinRiI
wa Hicoqapa kaAlXRajaA taHota Alwariydi
[Seek ye me with your seeking; but ye will not be able to take me; for I, with Hidhkah, am like the bone sticking fast in the throat beneath the carotid artery]. (TA.) And you say, Oaragotu AlSRayoda [I sought, or pursued, the game, or object of the chase]. (S.) And ArAgt AlEuqaAbu AlSRayoda The eagle pursued the game this way and that, as the latter went. (Mgh and TA in art. hwI.) And xarajotu Ouriygu baEiyrFA Xarada minRiI I went forth seeking in every road, or way, a camel that had run away from me. (TA, from a trad.) And maA caA turiygu What is this that thou seekest and desirest? or that which thou seekest and desirest? (S, TA.) And fulaAnN yuriygu kacaA wa kacaA Such a one
eeks, and devises or plans or plots, such and such things. (T, TA.)

5 trwRg c
5. trwRg He (a beast) rolled, or turned himself over. (JK, IDrd, K.) And trwRg fiI AlTRiyni He became befouled, or bedaubed, in the mud. (JK.)

6 taraAowaga
6: see 3, last two sentences.

8 Uirotawaga
8: see 4, second sentence.

raAgapN c
raAgapN: see riyaAgapN.

rawaAgN c
rawaAgN [The act, or quality, of turning aside or away from a thing: or of going this way and that, or to the right and left, quickly, and deceitfully, or guilefully: or of turning aside to deceive him who is behind one: or of eluding, or dodging:] a subst. from raAga. (S, Msb, K.) ＝ -A2- xayorN rwAgN, (so in the TA, the vowel of the r in rwAg not indicated,) or xayorN lahu rawaAgaMCu↓ and ruwaAgaMCu↓, (so in the JK,) Abundant [wealth, or good of any kind]. (JK, TA.)

riyaAgN c
riyaAgN [originally riwaAgN] A state of plenty; or of abundance of herbage, or of the goods or conveniences or comforts of life. (JK, Ibn-'Abbád, K.) You say, fulaAnN fiI AlrRiyaAgi Such a one is in a state of plenty, &c. (JK.) ＝ -A2- See also art. ryg.

riwaAgapN c
riwaAgapN: see what next follows.

riyaAgapN c
riyaAgapN The wrestling-place of a people; (Yz, JK, S, K;) as also riwaAgapN↓, (K,) which is the original form, the w being afterwards changed into I because of the kesreh before it, though this, as Sgh says, is not a necessary sort of conversion; (TA;) or raAgapN↓. (So in the JK.)

ruwayogapN c
ruwayogapN i. q. HiylapN [meaning An evasion or elusion, a shift, a wile, an artifice, an artful contrivance or device, a plot, or a stratagem]: (Ibn-'Abbád, K:) from AlrRawogu [inf. n. of raAga]: so in the saying, OaxacotaniI biAlrRuwayogapi [Thou tookest me by an artifice, &c.]. (JK, Ibn-'Abbád, K.) [It has a similar meaning also in a saying cited voce HawojaMCu, q. v.]

rawaAgaMCu c
rawaAgaMCu and ruwaAgaMCu: see rawaAgN.

rawRaAgN c
rawRaAgN [Wont to turn aside or away from a thing: or to go this way and that, or to the right and left, quickly, and deceitfully, or guilefully: or to turn aside for the purpose of deceiving him who is behind: or to elude, or dodge]. Mo'áwiyeh said to 'Abd-Allah Ibn-Ez-Zubeyr, UinRamaA Oanota vaEolabN rawRaAgN kulRamaA xarajota mino juHorK QnojaHarota fiI juHorK [Thou art only a fox wont to elude: whenever thou comest forth from a burrow, thou enterest into a burrow]. (TA.) [Hence,] AlrRawRaAgu is an appellation of The fox. (JK, K.)

TariyqN raAYigN c
TariyqN raAYigN A deviating road. (S, TA.) Hence raAYigapN↓ [as a subst.] A road deviating from the main road: pl. rawaAYigu. (TA, from a trad.)

raAYgap c
raAYgap: see what next precedes.

Oarowagu c
Oarowagu [More, and most, wont to turn aside or away from a thing: to go this way and that, or to the right and left, quickly, and deceitfully, or guilefully: to turn aside for the purpose of deceiving him who is behind: or to elude, or dodge]. Tarafeh Ibn-El-'Abd said to 'Amr Ibn-Hind, censuring his companions,
kulRuhumu Oarowagu mino vaEolabK
maA OaXobaha AllRayolapa biAlbaAriHaho
[Every one of them is more wont to elude than a fox: how like is this night to yesternight! meaning, how like are they, one to another! see art. brH]: Oarowagu mino vaEolabK is a prov. (TA.)

1 raAfa c
1. raAfa, (IDrd, K,) aor. yaraAfu, (K,) or yaruwfu, inf. n. rawofN, (IDrd,) is a dial. var. of raOafa, (IDrd, K,) aor. yaroOafu: (K:) or, as some say, (IDrd,) rawofN signifies The being still; and is not from AlrRaOofapu: (IDrd, K:) [ISd says,] raAfa, inf. n. rawofN, signifies sakana [he, or it, was, or became, still, &c.] and raOafa [q. v.] is a dial. var. thereof [signifying thus]; and is not from raWuwfN syn. with raHiymN. (M.)

3 rAwf c
3. rAwf: see raOafa.

raAfN c
raAfN Wine; a dial. var. of raOofN. (TA.)

rawofapN c
rawofapN Mercy, or compassion: (O, K:) so accord. to IAar. (O.)

1 raAqa c
1. raAqa, (S, Msb, TA,) aor. yaruwqu, (S, Msb,) inf. n. rawoqN, (S,) It (wine, or beverage, S, or water, Msb, TA, and a thing, TA) was, or became, clear. (S, Msb, TA.) ＝ -A2- rAq Ealayohi, (JK, K,) aor. as above, (JK,) and so the inf. n., (K,) He, or it, exceeded him, or it: (JK:) [and] he, or it, exceeded him, or it, in excellence. (K.) You say, rAq fiI yadiI kacaA Such a thing was redundant, or remained over and above, in my hand; like raAEa; syn. zaAda. (L in art. ryE.) And rAq fulaAnN EalaI Oaholihi Such a one was, or became, above, or superior to, his family; surpassed, or excelled, his family. (JK.) ＝ -A3- raAqaniI, (JK, S, MA,) or rAq liI, (so in my copy of the Msb, [perhaps a mistranscription, for only the former is commonly known,]) and rAqahu, (K,) aor. as above, (JK, S,) and so the inf. n., (JK, K,) It (a thing) induced in me, and him, wonder, or admiration, and pleasure, or joy; excited my, and his, admiration and approval; pleased, or rejoiced, me, and him. (JK, S, MA, Msb, K.) ＝ -A4- rawiqa, [aor. yarowaqu,] inf. n. rawaqN, He was, or became, long-toothed: (MA:) [or he had long teeth, the upper of which projected over the lower: or his upper central incisors were longer than the lower, and projecting over them: see rawaqN, below.]

2 rwRq c
2. rwRq, (JK, S, Msb,) inf.n. tarowiyqN, (S, K,) He cleared, or clarified, (S, Msb, K,) wine, or beverage, (S,) or water; (Msb;) he cleared, or clarified, wine, or beverage, with the raAwuwq. (JK, TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) He (a drunken man) made water in his clothes. (AHn, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- rwRq Albayota, (JK, TA,) inf. n. as above, (JK,) He made, or put, to the tent, a riwaAq, (JK, TA,) meaning a curtain extended below the roof. (TA. [See riwaAqN.]) ― -b2- Hence, (Har p. 50,) rwRq AllRayolu (assumed tropical:) The night extended the riwaAq [or curtain] of its darkness; (S, Msb, Har ubi suprà, TA;) became dark; (Har, TA;) as also Oarowaqa↓. (TA.) ＝ -A3- tarowiyqN also signifies The selling a commodity and buying one better than it, (IAar, K, TA,) or longer than it, and better: (TA:) or the selling an old and wornout thing and buying a new one: (Th, TA:) or the selling one's garment, and adding something to it, and buying [with that garment and the thing added to it] another garment better than it: (JK:) [or the buying, with a thing and something added thereto, a better thing: for] one says, baAEa siloEatahu farawRaqa [He sold his commodity, and bought with it and something added thereto a better commodity]. (TA.) ― -b2- One says also, rawRaqa lifulaAnK fiI siloEatihi He named a high price to such a one for his commodity, not desiring it [himself, but app. desiring to induce another to give a high price for it]. (JK, K: expl. in the former by rafaEa lahu fiI sawomihaA wa laA yuriyduhaA; and in the latter by rafaEa lahu fiI vamanihaA wa huwa laA yuriyduhaA.)

4 Oarowaqa c
4. Oarowaqa: see 2. ＝ -A2- ArAqhu, (Msb in art. ryq, and K in that and the present art.,) inf. n. UiraAqapN, (S in the present art., and so in the K accord. to the TA,) He poured it out, or forth; (S, Msb, K;) namely, water and the like, (S,) or water and blood: (Msb:) and one says also haraAqahu, (Msb, TA,) changing the O into h, originally haroyaqahu, like daHorajahu, in measure, (Msb,) said by Lh to be of the dial. of El-Yemen, and afterwards to have spread among Mudar, (TA in art. ryq,) aor. yuhariyquhu, (Msb, TA,) with fet-h to the h, imperative hariqo, originally haroyiqo, like daHorijo, (Msb,) inf. n. hiraAqapN; (S and K in art. hrq;) and OahoraAqahu, aor. yuhoriyquhu, (Msb, TA,) with the h quiescent, like yusoTiyEu aor. of UisoTaAEa; or, accord. to the T, Oahoraqotu is wrong as being anomalous; and some say, haraqotuhu, aor.
rawaqa
, inf. n. haroqN, as though the h were radical. (Msb.) It is said in a trad., UinRa QmoraOapF kaAnato tuharaAqu AldRimaMCa or tuhoraAqu, the verb being in the pass. form, and the h either meftoohah or quiescent, and AldmAC being in the accus. case as a specificative; [so that the meaning is, Verily a woman used to pour forth with blood; for thrAq is equivalent to tariyqu; but by rule the specificative should be without the article Al;] or AldmAC may be in the nom. case, AldRimaMCu being for dimaAWuhaA [i. e. her blood used to pour forth]. (Msb.) ISd says that OaraAqa is judged to be originally Oarowaqa because the medial radical letter of a verb is more commonly w than I; and because, when water is poured forth, its clearness appears, and it excites the admiration and approval of its beholder; [to which may be
added, also because one says, humA yataraAwaqaAni AlmaMCa;] though Ks states that raAqa AlmaMCu, aor. yariyqu, signifies The water poured out, or forth: IB says that Oaraqotu AlmaMCa is from rAq AlmaMCu, aor. yariyqu, inf. n. rayoqN, signifying the water went to and fro upon the surface of the earth. (TA.) One says also, of a man, ArAq maMCa Zahorihi and haraAqahu and OahoraAqahu [meaning He poured forth his seminal fluid]. (TA.) ― -b2- And Oariqo Eanoka mina AlZRahiyrapi and hariqo meaning (assumed tropical:) Stay thou until the mid-day heat shall have become assuaged, and the air be cool; syn. Oaborido. (IAar, TA in art. fyH.) ― -b3- [See more in art. hrq.]

5 trwRq c
5. trwRq It (wine, or beverage, [&c.,]) became clear [or rather cleared] without pressing, or expressing. (TA.)

6 humaA yataraAwaqaAni AlmaMCa c
6. humaA yataraAwaqaAni AlmaMCa They two pour the water out, or forth, by turns. (TA.)

rawoqN c
rawoqN [an inf. n. of raAqa, used as an epithet,] Clear; applied to water &c. (IAar, K. [See also raAYiqN.] ― -b2- [Hence, app., as a subst.,] Pure, or sincere, love. (K.) ＝ -A2- [Also, as an epithet originally an inf. n.,] Inducing wonder, or admiration, and pleasure, or joy; exciting admiration and approval; pleasing, or rejoicing; (IAar, K;) as also raAYiqN↓ (JK) and rayRiqN↓. (IAar, TA.) And, applied to a horse, Beautiful in make, that induces wonder, or admiration, and pleasure, or joy, in his beholder; excites his admiration and approval; or pleases, or rejoices, him; as also rayRiqN↓. (K.) ＝ -A3- A horn (JK, S, K, TA) of any horned animal: (TA:) pl. OarowaAqN. (S, TA.) [Hence,] rawoqu Alfarasi (assumed tropical:) The spear which the horseman extends between the horse's ears: (K:) [for] spears are regarded as the horses' horns. (Ham p. 90.) And daAhiyapN caAtu rawoqayoni (tropical:) A great calamity or misfortune; (K, TA;) lit. twohorned. (TA.) And HarobN caAtu rawoqayoni (tropical:) A vehement war. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) [A] courageous [man], with whom one cannot cope. (K.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A chief (IAar, JK, K) of men. (JK.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) A company, or collective body, (As, O, K,) of people: so in the saying, jaMCanaA rawoqN mino baniI fulaAnK (assumed tropical:) [A company of the sons of such a one came to us: or, app., a numerous and strong company; for it is added that this is] like the saying raOosu jamaAEapi Alqawomi [which means “ the numerous and strong company of the collective body of the people ”]. (As, O.) ― -b5- Also syn. with riwaAqN in several senses, as pointed out below: see the latter word in six places. ― -b6- Also (assumed tropical:) The foremost part or portion of rain, and of an army, and of a number of horses or horsemen. (TA.) And (tropical:) The first part of youth; as also rayRiqN↓, (S, O, K,) originally rayowiqN, (O, K,) and rayoqN↓, (S, O, K,) which is a contraction of rayRiqN: (O:) you say, faEalahu fiI rawoqi XabaAbihi and XbAbh rayRiqi↓ and XbAbh rayoqi↓ (tropical:) He did it in the first part of his youth: (S, TA: *) and maDaI mina AlXRabaAbi rawoquhu (tropical:) The first part of youth passed. (TA.) ― -b7- Also (assumed tropical:) The youth [itself] of a man. (TA.) ― -b8- And (assumed tropical:) Life; i. e. the period of. life: whence the saying, Oakala rawoqahu (assumed tropical:) [He consumed his life; or] he became aged: (K:) or this saying means (assumed tropical:) his life became prolonged so that, or until, his teeth fell out, one after another. (S, O.) ― -b9- (assumed tropical:) A part, or portion, of the night: (S, K:) pl., accord. to IB, OarowuqN: but accord. to Aboo- 'Amr Esh-Sheybánee, this is pl. of riwaAqN: (TA:) [or the pl. of rawoqN in this sense is OarowaAqN.] You say, maDaI rawoqN mina AllRayoli (assumed tropical:) A part, or portion, of the night passed. (TA.) And OarowaAqu AllRayoli means (tropical:) The folds (OavonaMC) of the darkness of night. (K, TA.) And OarowaAqu AlEayoni (tropical:) The sides of the eye: so in the saying, Oasobalato OarowaAqu AlEayoni (tropical:) The sides of the eye shed tears. (O, K, * TA.) ― -b10- Also (assumed tropical:) The body: (K, TA:) and [in like manner the pl.] OarowaAqN signifies the (assumed tropical:) extremities and body, of a man: (TA:) and his self; (JK, * TA;) as also the singular. (JK, TA.) You say, ramawonaA biOarowaAqihimo (assumed tropical:) They threw themselves upon us. (TA.) And OaloqaI EalayonaA OarowaAqahu (assumed tropical:) He covered us with himself [by throwing himself upon us]. (TA.) And ramaAhu biOarowaAqihi (assumed tropical:) He threw his weight upon him. (TA.) And ramaI biOarowaAqihi Eani AldRaAbRapi (assumed tropical:) He mounted the beast: and ramaI biOarowaAqihi Eani AldRaAbRapi (assumed tropical:) He alighted from the beast. (O, K.) And OaloqaI OarowaAqahu (assumed tropical:) He remained at rest in a place; (S, O, K;) like as one says, OaloqaI EaSaAhu: (S, O:) a meaning said in the K to be app. the contr. of what here next follows: but this requires consideration. (TA.) Also (assumed tropical:) He ran vehemently: (A 'Obeyd, S, O, K:) not known, however, to Sh, in this sense; but known to him as meaning (assumed tropical:) he strove, laboured, toiled, or exerted himself, in a thing. (TA.) [Agreeably with this last explanation, it is said that] rawoqN also signifies (assumed tropical:) A man's determination, or resolution; his action; and his purpose, or intention. (K, TA.) And hence the saying, OaloqaI Ealayohi OarowaAqahu [meaning (assumed tropical:) He devoted his mind and energy to it, or him]: (TA:) [or] you say thus, and OaloqaI Ealayohi XaraAXirahu, meaning his loving it, or him, (Oano yuHibRahu,) vehemently [i. e. (assumed tropical:) he loved it, or him, vehemently; agreeably with explanations of the saying AlqI Elyh XrAXrh in art. Xr, q. v.]. (Thus in the JM. [In my two copies of the S, and in the O and K, and hence in the TA, in the places of Ealayohi and yuHibRahu we find Ealayoka and tuHibRahu; evidently mistranscriptions which have been copied by one lexicographer after another without due consideration: or, if we read Ealayoka, we should read yuHibRaka; for in this case the meaning of the saying would certainly be he loved thee vehemently. Freytag, misled by the reading tuHibRahu in the S and K, renders AlqI Elyk ArwAqh as meaning Magno amore erga ipsum te accendit. Golius gives, in its place, Drb AwrAqh Elyh (for ArwAqh), as meaning Valde amavit eum.]) ― -b11- You say also, Oaloqati AlsRaHaAbapu OarowaAqahaA, (JK, S, O, K,) or Alqt AlsHAbp EalaI AlOaroDi ArwAqhA, (TA,) (tropical:) The cloud cast down its rain, and its vehement rain consisting of large drops, (S, O, K, TA,) upon the earth: (TA:) or persevered with rain, and remained stationary upon the land: (JK, TA:) or Oaloqati AlsRamaMCu biOarowaAqihaA The sky cast down all the water that was in it: (IAmb, O, TA:) or this saying, (O, TA,) or the former, (K,) means cast down its clear waters; (O, K, TA;) from raAqa AlmaMCu signifying “ the water was, or became, clear: ” but IAmb deems this improbable, because the Arabs did not say maMCN rawoqN and maAMni rawoqaAni and OamowaAhN OarowaAqN: (O, TA:) [i. e. they said rawoqN only, in all cases when they used it as an epithet meaning “ clear, ” because it is originally an inf. n., like EadolN &c.:] or, as some say, by bArwAqhA is meant its waters rendered heavy by the clouds: and one says, Oaroxati AlsRamaMCu OarowaAqahaA and EazaAliyhaA (assumed tropical:) [The sky loosed, or let down, its spouts; the clouds being likened to leathern water-bags]: (TA:) [for] rawoqu AlsRaHaAbi means (assumed tropical:) The masiyl [or channel by which flows the water] of the clouds. (TA in another part of the art. [See also riwaAqN, as used in relation to clouds.]) ＝ -A4- rawoqN also signifies A substitute for a thing, (O, K,) accord. to [the JK and] Ibn-'Abbád. (O.) ＝ -A5- And AlrRawoqu means The breathing of [i. e. in] the agony of death (nafosu AlnRazoEi). (O, K, TA. [In the CK and in my MS. copy of the K, nafosu AlnRazoEi, which means the agony of death itself.])

ruwqN c
ruwqN is said to be pl. of ruwqapN, and of raAYiqN, and of Oarowaqu. (TA.) [See these three words.]

rawaqN c
rawaqN Length of the teeth, with a projecting of the upper over the lower: (JK:) or length of the upper incisors exceeding that of the lower, (S, O, K, TA,) with projection of the former over the latter. (TA.) [See also 1, last sentence.]

rayoqN c
rayoqN: see rawoqN, in two places, in the former half of the paragraph: ― -b2- and see also riyRiqN.

rawoqapN c
rawoqapN i. q. jamaAlN raAYiqN [i. e. Beauty, comeliness, or elegance, &c., that induces wonder, or admiration, and pleasure, or joy; or surpassing beauty, &c.]. (K.)

ruwqapN c
ruwqapN Choice, or excellent: (Fr, O:) or goodly, or beautiful: (K:) applied to a boy and to a girl, (Fr, O, K,) and to a he-camel and to a she-camel: (Fr, O:) and very beautiful or comely or elegant; (K;) applied to one and more of human beings: (TA:) used alike as masc. and fem. and sing. and pl. (O, TA) and dual: (TA:) [and also said to be pl. of raAYiqN, q. v.:] and it has a pl., [or coll. gen. n.,] namely, ruwoqN; (IDrd, O, TA;) applied to she-camels; (IDrd, O;) or sometimes applied to horses and camels, absolutely accord. to IAar, or particularly when on a journey. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A little, or paltry, thing: (JK, IDrd, O, K:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (IDrd, O.) You say, maA OaEoTaAhu UilRaA ruwqapF He gave him not save a little, or paltry, thing. (IDrd, O.)

rawaAqN c
rawaAqN: see what next follows.

ruwaAqN c
ruwaAqN: see what next follows.

riwaAqN c
riwaAqN (Lth, S, Mgh, O, Msb, K, &c.) and ruwaAqN↓ (MA, K) and rawaAqN↓ (MA) A bayot [or tent] like the fusoTaAT [q. v.], (Lth, JK, O, Msb, K,) supported upon one pole in the middle thereof; (Lth, O, Msb;) as also rawoqN↓; (K, * TA; expl. in the
former as signifying a fusoTaAT; and its pl. OarowaAqN is expl. in the S as signifying fasaATiyTu;) accord. to Lth: (TA:) or a roof in the front, or fore part, of a bayot [or tent]; (S, O, K;) as also rawoqN↓: (S:) or a curtain that is extended below the roof; as also rawoqN↓; which latter is expl. in the K as signifying simply a curtain: (TA:) or the riwaAq of a bayot [or tent] is the curtain of the front, or fore part, thereof, extending from the top thereof to the ground: (AZ, TA:) a [piece of cloth such as is called] kisaMC let down upon the front, or fore part, of a bayot, from the top thereof to the ground: (Mgh:) rawoqN↓ signifies the same as riwaAqN: (K:) and each signifies the XuqRap [or oblong piece of cloth] that is beneath the upper, or uppermost, XuqRap of a bayot [or tent]: (Az, O, K:) or sometimes the rwAq is one such piece of cloth, and sometimes of two such pieces, and sometimes of three: (TA:) and, (Msb,) or as some say, (Mgh, TA,) riwaAqN signifies (assumed tropical:) the front, or fore part, of a bayot [or tent]; (Z, Mgh, Msb, TA;) as also rawoqN↓; (JK, Z, K;) its hinder part being called its kifaMC, and its two sides being called its xaAlifataAni; (TA;) whence the saying, bayotihi qaEaduwA fiI rawoqi↓ and riwaAqi bayotihi, i. e. (tropical:) [They sat in] the front or fore part [of his tent]: (Z, TA:) and rawoqN↓ also signifies a tent; as in the saying, Daraba rawoqahu [He pitched his tent]: (S:) and [hence] the place of the huntsman [in which he conceals himself to lie in wait]; (K;) as being likened to the rwAq: (TA:) and rwAq signifies also a place that affords shelter in rain: (MA:) [and a portico; and particularly such as surrounds the court of a mosque; (see sudRapN;) in some of the large collegiate mosques, as, for instance, in the mosque El-Azhar, in Cairo, divided into a number of distinct apartments for students of different provinces or countries, each of which apartments by itself is termed a riwaAq:] the pl. of rwAq is OarowiqapN and ruwqN; (S, O, Msb, K;) the former a pl. of pauc. and the latter of mult. (S, O.) ― -b2- [Hence, AlrRiwaAqu mina AlsRaHaAbi, expl. in the TA as meaning mA dAr minohu kariwaAqi Albayoti: but dAr is here evidently a mistranscription for kaAna; and the meaning is, (assumed tropical:) The part, of the clouds, that resembles the rwAq of the tent. See also rawoqu AlsRaHaAbi, near the end of the paragraph commencing with rawoqN.] ― -b3- [Hence also,] riwaAqu AllRayoli (assumed tropical:) [The curtain of night: and] the first part of night; and the greater, or main, part thereof. (ISd, K. [It is implied in the latter that one says also in this instance and in the next ruwaAq.]) You say, of night, madRa riwaAqa Zulomatihi (assumed tropical:) [It extended the curtain of its darkness]: (S, Msb:) and OaloqaI Oarowiqatahu (assumed tropical:) [It let fall its curtains]. (S.) [See also an ex. in a verse cited voce murimRN, in art. rm.] ― -b4- And riwaAqu AlEayoni (assumed tropical:) The eyebrow. (JK, K.) ＝ -A2- riwaAqu [imperfectly decl. as being a proper name and of the fem. gender, though it is implied in the K that it is AlrRiwaAqu and AlrRuwaAqu,] is a name for The ewe, (O, K,) by which she is called to be milked, by the cry riwaAq riwaAq; (O;) but not unless she be rawoqaMC↓ [app., if not a mistranscription for waroqaMC, formed from this latter by transposition, and thus meaning dusky: see Oarowaqu]. (O, K.)

raAYiqN c
raAYiqN Cleared, or clarified, [or rather murawRaqN↓ has this meaning, and raAYiqN signifies clear,] wine, or beverage. (TA.) And Pure musk. (TA.) [See also the same word in art. ryq: and see rawoqN.] ＝ -A2- [Also Exceeding, surpassing, or superlative: see 1, second and next two following sentences.] ― -b2- See also rawoqN, third sentence. [Hence,] Goodly, or beautiful: (S, K, TA:) from raAqaniI signifying as expl. in the first paragraph of this art.; (S;) or from raAqa signifying “ it was, or became, clear: ” (TA:) pl. ruwqapN, (S, K,) like as furohapN and SuHobapN are pls. of faArihN and SaAHibN, (S,) [or rather quasi-pl.,] applied to boys, (S, K,) and to girls; (S;) [and also (as expl. above) an epithet used alike as masc. and fem. and sing. and pl. and dual;] and ruwqN is another pl. of raAYiqN, like as buzolN is of baAzilN. (S.) ruwqapu AlmuWominiyna, in which rwqp is [quasi-] pl. of rAYq, means the best, and the manly and noble or generous, of the believers. (TA.)

rayRiqN c
rayRiqN: see rawoqN, in four places, in the former half of the paragraph. ― -b2- Also The most excellent of anything; (JK, S;) as, for instance, of wine, or beverage, and of rain. (JK.) ― -b3- And it is said to signify also, (JK, Ibn-'Abbád, O,) or so rayoqN↓, (accord. to the copies of the K,) A scanty fall of rain: thus bearing two contr. meanings. (JK, Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

raAwuwqN c
raAwuwqN A clarifier, or strainer, (S, Msb, K,) syn. miSofaApN, (S, K,) for wine or beverage: (S:) the naAjuwd [q. v.] with which wine, or beverage, is cleared, (Lth, JK, K, TA,) without pressing, or expressing: (TA:) and (sometimes, S) the [kind of wine-vessel called] baATiyap. (S, K.) Accord. to IAar, (O, TA,) who is said by Sh to differ herein from all others, (TA,) AlrRaAwuwqu signifies also The kaOos [or drinking-cup, or cup of wine,] itself. (O, K, TA.) And Dukeyn uses it metaphorically in relation to youth; saying,
OasoqaI biraAwuwqi AlXRabaAbi AlxaADibi
[app. meaning (assumed tropical:) He gave to drink of the cup of ruddy youth: see xaADibN as an epithet applied to an ostrich]. (TA.)

Oarowaqu c
Oarowaqu [app. originally signifying Horned: ― -b2- and hence,] (assumed tropical:) A horse between whose ears the rider extends his spear: when the rider does not thus, he [the horse] is said to be OajamRu. (K.) ― -b3- Also, applied to a man, (S, Mgh, K,) Having long teeth, with a projecting of the upper over the lower: (JK:) or having long incisors: (Mgh:) or whose upper incisors are longer than the lower, (S, K, TA,) and project over the latter: (TA:) fem. rawoqaMCu: (JK, TA:) and pl. ruwqN; (K, TA;) which is also said to be pl. of ruwqapN, and of raAYiqN. (TA.) [In the K is added, after the mention of the pl., wa kacelika qawomN ruwqN wa rajulN Oarowaqu: an addition altogether redundant.] ＝ -A2- [It seems that it is also syn. with Oaworaqu, as being formed from the latter by transposition; and that hence] one says sanapN rawoqaMCu and sinuwna ruwqN [meaning (assumed tropical:) A rainless year and rainless years], and EaAva fiyhimo EaAmN Oarowaqu kaOanRahu ciYobN Oaworaqu [meaning (assumed tropical:) A rainless year made mischief, or havock, among them, as though it were a dusky wolf]. (TA.) See also riwaAq, last sentence.

UiraAqapN c
UiraAqapN inf. n. of 4. (S.) ― -b2- And [hence,] The maMC [meaning seminal fluid] of a man; as also hiraAqapN and UihoraAqapN. (TA.) [See OaraAqa maMCa Zahorihi.]

maraAqN c
maraAqN: see art. ryq.

maMCN muraAqN c
maMCN muraAqN [Water, and hence, seminal fluid, poured forth]. (TA. [There immediately followed by OaraAqa maMCa Zahorihi, q. v.])

rajulN muriyqN c
rajulN muriyqN [A man pouring forth water, and hence, his seminal fluid]. (TA. [There immediately followed by maMCN muraAqN, q. v.])

murawRaqN c
murawRaqN: see raAYiqN: ＝ -A2- and see murayRaqN, in art. ryq. ＝ -A3- Also A tent (bayotN, S, K, and xibaMCN, S) having a riwaAq [q. v.]. (S, K. [Said in the TA to be tropical; but why, I do not see.])

huwa muraAwiqiI c
huwa muraAwiqiI He has the riwaAq of his tent fronting, or facing, that of mine; (JK, A, O, K; *) and so huwa jaAriI muraAwiqiI. (A, TA.)

2 rwRl c
2. rwRl, (Lth, T, S,) inf. n. tarowiylN, (S,) He (a horse) slavered in his mixolaAp [or nose-bag]. (Lth, T, S.) [See also raAla in art. ryl.] ― -b2- He discharged his urine interruptedly and convulsively. (Sh, T.) ― -b3- He (a horse) put forth his yard for the purpose of staling. (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, K.) And (M, in the K “ or, ”) He extended his penis feebly: (M, K: *) or he emitted his semen before access to the woman. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also, (inf. n. as above, T, S, K,) He seasoned a cake of bread with grease or fat, or melted grease or fat, or the like, (M, K,) and with clarified butter: (M:) or he rubbed it with clarified butter, (As, T, M, K,) and with grease, or gravy, or dripping: (As, T, M:) or he rubbed it hard, or much, with clarified butter: (S:) or he soaked bread in clarified butter; and the like: (Ham p. 114:) or he made his food, (M,) or a cake of bread, (K,) very greasy: (M, K:) i. q. rawRaga [q. v.]. (JK and TA in art. rwg.)

ruwaAlN c
ruwaAlN and raAwuwlN↓, (As, T, S, M, K,) the former also with C, [ruWaAlN,] as mentioned in art. rAlN, (TA,) but not the latter, for the Arabs do not pronounce a word of this [class and] measure with C, (S, TA,) and A'Obeyd says that it is without C, or, accord. to ISk, it is [also] with C, (M and TA in art. rOl,) Slaver: (IAar and T in explanation of the former, and S in explanation of both:) [like riyaAlN, mentioned in art. ryl:] one says rajulN kaviyru AlrRuwaAli A man having much slaver: (IAar, T: in one copy of the T AlrRuWaAl:) and
fulaAnN yasiylu ruwaAluhu Such a one, his slaver flows: (S:) or both signify the slaver of horses and similar beasts, (As, T, M, K,) and of children: (As, T:) or the former signifies peculiarly the froth, or foam, of the horse: (M, K: *) accord. to Lth, the saliva of the horse or similar beast. (T.) [See ruWaAlN, in art. rOl.] ＝ -A2- See also the next paragraph.

raAYilN c
raAYilN Falling in drops. (AA, T, K.) ruwaAlN raAYilN means Slaver falling in drops. (AA, T.) And (K) it has an intensive signification, [app. meaning Much slaver,] (M, K,) like XiEorN XaAEirN. (M.) ＝ -A2- Also, (M, K,) and raAwuwlN↓, (S, TA,) but disallowed in this sense by As, (T, S,) in the K, erroneously, ruwaAlN↓, (TA, [see also ruWaAlN, in art. rOl,]) A redundant tooth, (S, M, K,) in a man and a horse, (S,) not growing in the manner of the OaDoraAs [or other teeth]: (M, K:) or raAYilN and raAYilapN↓ signify a tooth that grows to a horse or similar beast, preventing him from drinking [with ease] and from [eating in the manner termed] qaDomN: (Lth, T:) accord. to ISh, rawaAYilu [pl. of raAYilapN↓] signifies small teeth that grow at the roots of the large teeth, and excavate the roots of the latter so that these fall out: (T:) [and] so rawaAwiylu: (TA:) or this last, which is pl. of raAwuwlN↓, signifies redundant teeth that are behind the [other] teeth; as also rawaAwilu, with the I elided. (Ham p. 818.)

raAYilapN c
raAYilapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

raAwuwlN c
raAwuwlN: see ruwaAlN: ＝ -A2- and see also raAYilN, in two places.

mirowalN c
mirowalN, (IAar, T, K, in one copy of the T murawRilN,) like minobarN, (K,) A man having much slaver. (IAar, T, K.) ― -b2- And [Bread, or food,] soft with seasoning. (IAar, T, TA.) ― -b3- And A horse much affecting to act as a stallion. (IAar, T, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A piece of a weak rope: (AHn, M, K:) and a piece of a rope of which no use is made. (AHn, M.)

murawRilN c
murawRilN [see 2, of which it is a part. n.:] One whose penis is, or becomes, flaccid: so accord. to IAar. (T.)

1 raAma c
1. raAma, (T, S, M, Msb,) aor. yaruwmu, (T, S, Msb,) inf. n. rawomN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and maraAmN, (Msb, K, TA,) He sought, sought for or after, or desired, syn. Talaba, (T, * M, Msb, K, *) a thing. (S, M, Msb.) ― -b2- [And hence, He attempted another person in fight &c., and a thing.] ― -b3- And [hence also] AlrRawomu, (K,) or rawomu AlHarakapi, mentioned by Sb, (S,) [as though signifying The desiring to pronounce the vowel-sound without fully accomplishing that desire,] means [the pronouncing] a vowel-sound (Harakap) slurred (muxotalasap) and rendered obscure, (S, K,) for, or by, [accord. to different copies of the S,] a sort of alleviation [of the utterance]; (S;) it is more [in effect] than what is termed AlUiXomaAm, because it is heard; (S, K;) and it is of the same measure [in prosody] as the vowel-sound [fully pronounced]; as [in the case of what is termed] hamozapN bayona bayona, such as in the saying of the poet,
OaAano zumRa OajomaAlN wafaAraqa jiyrapN
wa SaAHa guraAbu Albayoni Oanota Haziynu
[Is it because that camels have had the nose-reins attached to them, and neighbours have separated, one from another, and the raven of disunion has uttered its cry, thou art mourning?]; OaAano zumo being scanned as faEuwluno; and it not being allowable to make the E [in fEwln] quiescent: it is such also as in the phrase in the Kur [ii. 181] Xahoru ramaDaAna with him who makes [the dammeh] obscure; it being only with a slurred vowel-sound (Harakap muxotalasap); and it not being allowable for the former r [i. e. the r of Xhr] to be quiescent, because the h before it is quiescent, for this would lead to the combination of two quiescent letters in a case of continuity, [i. e. when there is no pause after them,] without there being before them a soft letter [i. e. A or w or I, as in dawaAbR &c.], which is not found in any of the dialects of the Arabs: and it is such also as in the instances in the Kur [xv. 9 and x. 36 and xxxvi. 49] UinRaA naHonu nazRalonaA QlcRikora and OamRano laA yahidRiI and yaxiSRimuwna [for yahotadiI and yaxotaSimuwna], and the like thereof: no regard should be paid to the saying of Fr, that in this [last] and the like instances a letter [which in this instance and in the next preceding it is t] is incorporated into another [following it]; for they [i. e. the Arabs] do not realize this mode [of incorporation]; and he who combines two quiescent letters in an instance in which the slurring of the vowel-sound (AixotilaAsu AlHarakapi) is not proper errs; as in the reading of Hamzeh, in the Kur [xviii. 96], famaA QsTRaAEuwA; for the s of AlAisotifoEaAlu may not be made movent in any manner [and therefore it may not be incorporated into the following letter]. (S, TA.) AlrRawomu is [also] in a case of pausing after a word ending with any letter except the fem. p, [in like manner] meaning The indicating the vowel with an obscure sound: (I' Ak p. 351:) rawomu AlHarakapi in pausing after a word that is marofuwE or majoruwr is from raAma AlXRaIoCa signifying Talabahu: Sb says that those of whom one says raAmuwA AlHarakapa [They slurred the vowel-sound] are induced to do what this signifies [instead of suppressing the vowel-sound entirely] by eagerness to exclude it from the case of that which is necessarily made quiescent in every instance, and to show that its case is, in their opinion, not like the case of that which is made quiescent in every instance. (M.) [See also 4 in art. Xwr.]

2 rwRm fulaAnFA c
2. rwRm fulaAnFA (Msb, K) followed by AlXRaIoCa, (Msb,) and (K) rwRm bifulaAnK, (IAar, S, K,) He made such a one to seek, seek for or after, or desire, the thing. (IAar, S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- And rwRm raOoyahu He meditated, intended, purposed, desired, or endeavoured, to do one thing after another. (K.) ＝ -A2- And rwRm He tarried; paused; tarried and waited or expected; or was patient, and tarried and waited or expected. (K.) Quasi 4. Oaramota, for Oaromamota: see the latter, near the end of the first paragraph of art. rm.

5 trwRm bihi c
5. trwRm bihi, or bihaA, accord. to different copies of the K, (TA,) He mocked at, scoffed at, laughed at, derided, or ridiculed, him, or her. (K, TA.)

raAmN c
raAmN A certain species of trees. (S, K. *)

rawomN c
rawomN inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (T, S, M, &c.) ＝ -A2- See also what next follows.

ruwmN c
ruwmN The lobe, or lobule, of the ear; (M, K;) as also ruwmN↓. (K.) ＝ -A2- AlrRuwmu A certain nation, (M, K,) well known; (M;) [said by the Arabs to be] descendants of Er-Room, the son of Esau (EySuw [so called by the Arabs]), (T, * S, K,) the son of Isaac the Prophet; (TA;) [i. e. the Greeks; generally meaning, of the Lower Empire; but sometimes, only those of Asia; and sometimes those of the Lower Empire together with all the nations of Europe beside: the ancient Greeks are more properly called by the Arabs AlyuwnaAnu:] one says ruwmiIRN↓ and ruwmN; (S, K;) the former of these two appellations being applied to a single person, (M, K,) and the latter being the pl., (S, K,) [or rather a coll. gen. n.,] like zinojiIRN and zinojN; (AAF, S, M;) the former being distinguished from the latter only by the doubled I, like as tamorapN is distinguished from tamorN its pl. [or coll. gen. n.] only by the p: (S:) and ruwmiIRN has for [its proper] pl. OarowaAmN↓. (TA.) [It is also applied to The country of the nation, or people, so called, both in Europe and Asia, and sometimes only in Asia. Hence, baHoru AlrRuwmi The Sea of the Greeks; meaning the Mediterranean Sea.]

ruwmapN c
ruwmapN Glue, with which the feathers of an arrow are stuck: (M, K:) said by A'Obeyd to be [thus] without C; but mentioned by Th with C. (M, TA. [See art. rOm.])

ruwmiIRN c
ruwmiIRN The sail of an empty ship: (AA, T, K:) that of a full ship is called murobiEN. (AA, T.) ＝ -A2- See also ruwmN.

ruwaAmN c
ruwaAmN i. q. lugaAmN [The foam of the mouth of a camel]: (K:) mentioned also in art. ruWaAmN [as written ruWaAmN, and signifying slaver]. (TA.)

ruwRaAmN c
ruwRaAmN [pl. of raAYimN↓, which signifies Seeking, &c.; act. part. n. of 1:] i. q. TulRaAbN [pl. of TaAlibN]. (TA.)

raAYimN c
raAYimN: see what next precedes.

OarowaAmN c
OarowaAmN pl. of ruwmiIRN. (TA.) See ruwmN.

maraAmN c
maraAmN i. q. maTolabo (S, M, K) [accord. to the PS A place of seeking or searching: but it should be observed that maTolabN is an inf. n., and also a n. of place and of time: also that maraAmN is expressly said in the Msb and TA to be an inf. n. of raAma, though not in the S nor in the M: and that it is mentioned in the K in the beginning of this art. as syn. with rawomN in the sense of TalabN, and at the end of the art. as signifying the same as maTolabN]. One says, huwa vabotu AlmaqaAmi baEiydu AlmaraAmi [which may mean
He is firm, or steady, in respect of the place of standing; far-aiming in respect of the place of seeking: or, agreeably with an explanation voce vabotN, he is one who does not quit his station, or abode, without necessity, though far-aiming &c.: but it is obvious that both AlmqAm and AlmrAm may here be inf. ns.]. (TA.)

maruwmN c
maruwmN Sought, sought for or after, or desired. (Msb.)

1 raAna c
1. raAna, [aor. yaruwnu,] inf. n. rawonN It (an affair, or event,) was, or became, hard, difficult, or severe. (TA.) ― -b2- And raAnato layolatunaA Our night was, or became, very cloudy and hot. (Th, M, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also raAna in art. ryn.

rawonN c
rawonN, (so accord. to a copy of the T, [if correct, an inf. n. used as a simple subst., see above, first sentence,]) or ruwnN↓, (so in another copy of the T, and accord. to the K,) with damm, (K,) Hardness, difficulty, severity, vehemence, or intenseness: (T, K:) pl. ruWuwnN, (T, and so in a copy of the K,) or ruWuwnN. (CK.) [See also ruwnapN.] ＝ -A2- rawonN signifies [or signifies also] The furthest part of a maXaArap [q. v.]. (Yoo, K.)

ruwnN c
ruwnN: see the next preceding paragraph.

ruwnapN c
ruwnapN The greater, main, principal, or chief, part of a thing. (M, K.) ― -b2- And Hardness, difficulty, or severity, of a thing, or an affair, or event; and grievousness thereof: so in the saying, kaXafa QllRehu Eanoka ruwnapa hecaA AlOamori [May God remove from thee the hardness, &c., and the grievousness, of this thing, or affair, or event]. (M.) [See also rawonN.] ― -b3- And The utmost limit, reach, or degree, of a thing, in respect of heat, or cold, or in other respects, as when said of grief, or of war, or the like: and hence is said to be taken the name AlrRunapu [or runapu, without Al, (see AlrRunRaI, in art. rn,) as though it were a contraction of ruwnap,] given to [the month] Jumádà-l-Ákhireh, because of its intense cold [when it was so named]. (TA.)

OarowanaAnN c
OarowanaAnN: see the opinions of IAar and Sb respecting its derivation in art. rn. [It is said in the S and K in art. nbj, that there is no word like it except OanobajaAnN.] You say yawomN OarowanaAnN (T, S, M, K) and OarowunaAniIRN↓, (S, M,) and layolapN OarowanaAnapN (T, S, M, K) and OarowanaAniyRapN↓, (M,) A day, and a night, hard, difficult, severe, distressing, or grievous: (S, K, * TA:) or vehemently hot and grievous: (T, TA:) or that has reached the utmost point, or degree, in respect of joy, or grief, or heat: or hard, difficult, or severe, in respect of everything; in respect of heat, or cold, or clamour, cries, shouts, or noises [&c.]. (M, TA.) You say also yawomu OarowanaAnK, [virtually] meaning the same: (K:) [or this may mean A day of clamour, &c.; as will be seen from what follows.] yawomu OarowanaAniI↓ occurs at the end of a verse of a rájiz: this may be [by poetic license] for yawomu OarowanaAnK, or for yawomu OarowaAnaAniIRK: and yawomN OarowanaAniI↓ occurs at the end of a verse of En-Nábighah El-Jaadee, for yawomN OarowanaAniIRN. (S.) Accord. to Sh, as is said in the T, (TA,) yawomN OarowanaAnN, (K, TA,) as also yawomu OarowanaAnK, (K,) signifies A day that is easy, (K, TA,) or pleasant: (TA:) thus having two contr. meanings: (K:) and Sh cited a verse of En-Nábighah ElJaadee as an ex.: but AHeyth disallowed ArwnAn as having any other meaning than grief, and difficulty or the like; and he disallowed also the verse cited by Sh [as being an ex. of the meaning that he assigned to it]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A voice, or sound: (S, K:) and cries, shouts, or noises, and clamour. (TA. [In one place, in the TA, rwn, thus written, without any vowel-sign, has also this latter meaning assigned to it: but the context seems to show that this is a mistranscription.])

OarowanaAniIRN c
OarowanaAniIRN; and its fem., with p; and OarowanaAniI: see the next preceding paragraph, in four places.

huwa maruwnN bihi c
huwa maruwnN bihi He is overcome, subdued, or subjected. (K.) [maruwnN here is a contraction of marowuwnN, from raAna having for its aor. yaruwnu as a dial. var. of raAna having for its aor. yariynu: see art. ryn.]

AlrRiwanodu c
AlrRiwanodu, or AlrRiywanodu, and raAwanod: see art. rwd.

1 rawiIa mina AlmaMCi c
1. rawiIa mina AlmaMCi, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) and AllRabani, (M, K,) aor. yarowaI, (T, S, Msb, K,) inf. n. riIRN (T, S, M, Mgh, * K) and raIRN, (S, K,) or the former is a simple subst. and the latter is the inf. n., (Msb,) or the latter is an inf. n. and also a simple subst., (M, K,) and riwFI, (S, M, K,) the last erroneously written, in [some of] the copies of the K, rawaI, as though it were a pret. verb [like rawiIa]; (TA;) and ArtwI↓ and trwRI↓; (S, M, Msb, K;) all signify the same; (T, S, M, * Msb, K;) [or the last probably has an intensive meaning;] He was satisfied, or he satisfied himself, with drinking of water [and of milk]; he drank thereof enough to quench, or satisfy, his thirst; contr. of EaTiXa. (Mgh in explanation of the first.) ― -b2- And rawiIa AlnRabaAtu, (M,) or AlXRajaru, (K,) mina AlmaMCi; (TA;) and trwRI↓; (M, K;) [The plant, or herbage, or the trees, had plentiful irrigation: or] i. q. tanaERama [i. e., became flourishing and fresh, luxuriant, juicy, succulent, or sappy]; (M, K;) or became bright and fresh, by reason of plentiful irrigation. (TK.) ― -b3- rawiIa and ArtwI↓ and trwRI↓ are also used metaphorically, as meaning (tropical:) He was, or became, in a good state or condition; and in the enjoyment of much ease, pleasantness, softness, or delicacy, of life. (Har p. 100.) ― -b4- XabiEotu mino hecaA AlOamori wa rawiytu is likewise metaphorical, meaning (tropical:) I have become, or I became, disgusted [or satiated to loathing] with this thing, or affair. (S * and TA in art. XbE.) ― -b5- See also a verse cited voce UilaI, (p. 85,) in which yarowaI is made trans. by means of that particle in the place of mino. ＝ -A2- rawaI EalaI Oaholihi, (T, S, M, K,) and liOaholihi, (S, M, K,) aor. yarowiI, inf. n. rayRapN, or riyRapN, (accord. to different copies of the T, [the former app. indicated to be the right by what is said in the next sentence,]) or raIRN, (M, [probably also correct,]) He brought water to his family: (S, M, K:) [but in the T it is implied that the meaning is like that of the phrase here following:] rawaI Alqawoma, (ISk, T, S, K,) aor. as above, (ISk, T, S,) inf. n. ryRp, (so in the TA,) He drew water for the people, or party. (ISk, T, S, K.) You say, mino Oayona rayRatukumo, with fet-h to the r, (S,) or riyRatukumo, (so in the T,) meaning Whence is your providing of yourselves with water? (AlmaMCa mino Oayona tarotawuwna↓: T, immediately after the latter of the foregoing phrases; and S, immediately after the former of them:) so says ISk. (T.) And rawaI EalaI AlyaEiyri He drew water upon the camel. (M. [See saAniyapN.]) ― -b2- And rawaI AlmaMCa, aor. yarowiI, [inf. n., app., riwaAyapN,] He (a camel) bore, carried, or conveyed, water. (Msb, TA.) ― -b3- Hence, (Msb, TA,) rawaI AlHadiyva, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) and AlXRiEora, (T, S, M, Mgh,) Eanohu, (MA,) aor. yarowiI, (T,) inf. n. riwaAyapN; (T, S, M, Mgh, K;) and trwRAhu↓; (M, K;) both signify the same; (K;) He bore in his memory, knowing by heart, (Hamala,) and transmitted [orally], related, recited, or rehearsed, the tradition, narrative, or story, (Msb, TA,) and the poetry, (TA,) [as learned, or heard, or received,] from him; (MA;) [he related, recited, or rehearsed, the tradition, &c., and the poetry, by heart from him:] you say to a man, OanoXidi AlqaSiydapa [ “ Recite thou the ode ”]; but you do not say, AirowihaA unless you mean thereby Relate thou it by heart. (S, TA.) [One says also, ruwiIa Eanohu, meaning It has been related as heard, or received, from him. And ruwiIa kacaA, and yurowaI kacaA, meaning It has been related, and it is related, (otherwise, i. e.) thus; with the substitution of such a word &c.: and often meaning it has been read, and it is read, &c. And fiI riwaAyapK kacaA, meaning According to one relation, or way of relation or relating, thus: and often meaning according to one reading, thus.] ＝ -A3- rawaI AlHabola, (M, K,) [aor. yarowiI,] inf. n. raIRN, (M,) He twisted the rope: (M, K:) or he twisted the rope well, or thoroughly, or soundly. (M.) ― -b2- rawaI EalaI AlrRajuli, (S, M, TA,) in the copies of the K, erroneously, AlrRaHoli, (TA,) He bound the man (S, M, K, * TA) with the rope called riwaMC (M, TA) upon the back of the camel, (S, K, *) lest he should fall (S, M, K, * TA) from the camel (M) in consequence of his being overcome by sleep. (S, M, * TA.) And rawayotu EalaI AlrRaAwiyapi, aor. OarowiI, inf. n. raIRN, I bound the riwaMC upon the leathern water-bag, or pair of leathern water-bags, called rAwyp. (T.) You say, rawaI Ealayohi, inf. n. raIRN; and ArwI↓; He bound him, or it, with the rope [called riwaMC, as is implied in the M]. (M, * TA.) And AlrRiwaMCa EalaI AlbaEiyri ArwI↓ [He bound the rwAC upon the camel]; like rawaAhu. (TA.) And rwAI↓ He bound a load with the riwaMC. (TA.)

2 rwRI c
2. rwRI, inf. n. tarowiyapN: see 4, in two places: ― -b2- and 5. [Hence,] yawomu AltRarowiyapi [The day of providing oneself with water;] the eighth day of Dhu-l-Hijjeh; (T, Msb;) the day before that of 'Arafeh: (M:) so called because they (the pilgrims, T) used to provide themselves (yatazawRaduwna, T, M, or yatarawRawona↓, Msb, and so in a copy of the T, or yarotawuwna↓, S, K) on that day with water (T, S, M, * Msb, K) for the aftertime, (S, Msb, K,) and to rise and go, or when rising to go, to Minè, where is no water, [or, accord. to the Msb, where was little water,] therefore they provided themselves fully with water, or therefore they provided themselves with water from Mekkeh for the alighting and abiding at Minè: (T, accord. to two different copies:) or [it means the day of consideration, or thought; (from another signification of the verb, as will be seen from what follows;) and is so called] because Abraham was considering, or thinking upon, his dream (wa yatafakRaru fiI ruWoyaAhu kaAna yatarawRaI↓) [on that day], and on the ninth he knew [that his dream was from God], and on the tenth he desired to act [according to his dream] (AisotaEomala). (K. [And in a similar manner it is explained in the Ksh and by Bd in xxxvii. 101. See also 2 in art. rwO]) ― -b3- rwRI raOosahu biAldRuhoni, and AlvRariyda biAldRasami, (T, TA,) He moistened [his head, app. much, or saturated it, i. e. its hair, with oil, or grease, and the broken, or crumbled, bread with grease, or gravy]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- rwRAhu AlXRiEora, (T, S, M, Mgh, K,) and AlHadiyva, (M, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. as above; (S;) and UiyRaAhu ArwAhu↓; (S, K;) He made him to relate by heart the poetry, (S, M, * Mgh, * K, * TA,) and the tradition, narrative, or story; (M, Mgh, TA;) he made him to bear in his memory, knowing by heart, and to transmit, relate, recite, or rehearse, (Msb, TA,) the poetry, (TA,) and the tradition, narrative, or story; (Msb, TA;) [or he taught him to do so; i. e.] he related to him by heart (rawaI lahu) the poetry, (T, TA,) and the tradition, narrative, or story, (TA,) until he retained it in his memory, for the purpose of relating it by heart [as learned, or heard, or received,] from him. (T, TA. *) And ruwRiynaA AlHadiyva [We had the tradition, narrative, or story, related to us by heart; and in like manner, AlXRiEora the poetry]. (Msb, TA.) ＝ -A3- rawRayotu fiI AlOamori, (S, K, [though Freytag represents the verb as being in the K without teshdeed, and Golius explains the verb nearly in the same manner with and without teshdeed,]) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He looked into the thing, or affair, or case; inspected it; examined it; considered it; or thought upon it; (S, M, K, TA;) deliberately, or leisurely; without haste; a dial. var. of rawRaOotu [q. v.]: (M, TA:) [and fiyhi tarawRayotu↓ app. signifies the same:] see yatarawRaI in the former half of this paragraph, in an explanation of yawomu AltRarowiyapi.

4 ArwAhu c
4. ArwAhu (M, MA, Msb, K) mina AlmaMCi (MA) [and mn AllRabani], inf. n. UirowaMCN; (KL, and Har p. 67;) and rwRAhu↓ (MA, Msb) minohu, (MA,) inf. n. tarowiyapN; (KL;) He satisfied him, or made him to be satisfied, with drinking of water [and of milk]; he satisfied, or quenched, his (another's) thirst, by a drink, or draught, of water [and of milk]; (M, * MA, Msb, * K, * KL; *) he did away with his thirst [thereby]. (Har ubi suprà.) One says of a she-camel abounding in milk, hiIa turowiI AlSRabiIRa [She satisfies the thirst of the young child]: because he sleeps in the beginning of the night, and they desire that her flow of milk may be early, before his sleeping. (M, TA.) [And in like manner, ArwAhu is said of water, and of milk, &c., meaning It satisfied his thirst.] ― -b2- [Hence, ArwI and rwRI↓ signify also He watered, or irrigated, plentifully a plant, or herbage, or a tree; or rendered it flourishing and fresh, luxuriant, succulent, or sappy, by plentiful irrigation: see 1, second sentence.] ＝ -A2- See also 2, in the middle of the paragraph. ＝ -A3- And see 1, last three sentences.

5 trwRI c
5. trwRI: see 1, first three sentences. ― -b2- You say also, tarawRawoA and rawRawoA↓, meaning They provided themselves with water. (M.) And kaAnuw yatarawRawona mina AlmaMCi; (Msb, and so in a copy of the T; see 2, second sentence;) or mn AlmMC yarotawuwna↓; (S and K; see again 2, second sentence;) [They used to provide themselves with water:] and AlmaMC mino Oayona tarotawuwna↓ [Whence do ye provide for yourselves water?]. (T and S; see 1, in the middle of the paragraph.) ― -b3- And tarawRati AllRuqomapu biAlsRamoni [The morsel was imbued, or soaked, with clarified butter]. (En-Nadr, TA in art. ryg.) ＝ -A2- trwRI AlHadiyva, and AlXRiEora: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph. ＝ -A3- tarawRato mafaASiluhu: see 8. ＝ -A4- trwRI fiyhi: see 2, in two places.

8 ArtwI c
8. ArtwI: see 1, first and third sentences: ― -b2- and see also 5, in two places. ― -b3- Artwt AlnRaxolapu The palm-tree, having been planted in a hollow dug for the purpose, was watered at its root. (Lth, T.) ＝ -A2- It (a rope) was twisted: (M, K:) or was twisted well, or thoroughly, or soundly: (M:) or was thick in its strands: (S:) or was composed of many strands, and thick, and very compact. (Lth, T.) ― -b2- And Artwt mafaASiluhu His joints (those of a beast, T, or those of a man, S) were, or became, well-proportioned and thick; (T, S, K;) and so trwRt↓. (M, K.)

rawRN c
rawRN: see rawaMCN.

ruIRN c
ruIRN: see what next follows: ＝ -A2- and see also art. rI.

riIRN c
riIRN, said by Esh-Shámee, in his “Seereh [of the Prophet],” to be also with damm [i. e. ruIRN↓, which is anomalous, like ruyRaA, for ruWoyaA], (MF, TA,) is an inf. n. of rawiIa: (T, S, M, Mgh, * K:) and also (M, K) a simple subst. from that verb [meaning The state of being satisfied with drinking of water and of milk; the state in which one is satisfied with drinking or drink; the state of having drunk enough to quench, or satisfy, the thirst]. (M, Msb, K.) One says, fulaAnN fiI riIRK wa maXobaEK [Such a one is in a state in which he is satisfied with drink and food]. (T, A, TA, all in art. nZr.) ― -b2- [Also, as is indicated in the K &c., in relation to plants or herbage, or to trees, The state of having plentiful irrigation; or of being flourishing and fresh, luxuriant, juicy, succulent, or sappy, by reason of plentiful irrigation.] ＝ -A2- EayonN ribRapN A source abounding with water. (S.) ＝ -A3- See also art. rI.

riwFI c
riwFI: see rawaMCN. ― -b2- ruTabN riwFI Dates when they ripen [after they have been cut off,] not upon their palm-trees; as also murowK↓. (TA.)

ruwyaA c
ruwyaA: see ruWoyaA, in art. rOI.

rawaMCN c
rawaMCN and riwFI↓ (T, S, M, K [in this last improperly said to be like UilaI, which is without tenween,]) and rawiIRN↓ (M, K) Sweet water: (S:) or water that causes him who comes to it to return with his thirst satisfied; (T, S; *) applied only to water that has a continual increase, and does not become exhausted, nor cease: (T:) or abundant water, that satisfies the thirst. (M, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AlrRawaMCu is a name of The well of Zemzem. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- And rwAC, (so in the TA, as from the K, and as mentioned by Az on the authority of IAar, [but I have looked for it in vain in two copies of the T, app. rawaMCN, or perhaps riwaMCN↓, like the Pers. riwaA, for one of these two may be from the other,] or rawRN↓, (so accord. to my MS. copy of the K and accord. to the TK, [but this I think very dubious, and still more strange is the reading in the CK, which is riw,]) Abundance of herbage, or of the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life. (K.)

ruwaMCN c
ruwaMCN [for ruWaMCN, (see riYoIN, in art. rOI,) or of the measure fuEaAlN from AlrRiIRu, (see Har p. 24,)] i. q. manoZarN [as meaning A pleasing, or goodly, aspect; or beauty of aspect]: so in the phrase rajulN lahu ruwaMCN [A man having a pleasing, or goodly, aspect]. (S.)

riwaMCN c
riwaMCN A rope with which the two leathern water-bags are bound upon the camel: (T:) or a rope with which goods, or furniture, or utensils, &c., are bound upon the camel; (S, K;) and with which a man is bound upon a camel, lest he should fall in consequence of his being overcome by sleep: (M, and Ham p. 321:) or one of the ropes of the [tent called] xibaMC: and sometimes the load is bound therewith upon the camel: accord. to AHn, it is thicker than well-ropes: (M:) and mirowFI↓ signifies the same: (T, K:) pl. of the former OarowiyapN; (T, S, K;) and of ↓the latter mrAwI, (T, K,) i. e. maraAwaI, and maraAwK. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also rawaMCN.

rawiIRN c
rawiIRN: see rawaMCN. ― -b2- Also A full, or complete, drink. (K, TA.) You say, Xaribotu XurobFA rawiyRFA (S, TA) I drank a full, or complete, drink. (TA.) ― -b3- And A cloud of which the rain-drops are large, (S, K,) and vehement in their fall; like saqiIRN: (S:) pl. OarowiyapN. (TA.) ― -b4- And, accord. to IAar, One who gives to drink; or a waterer; syn. saAqK: [in one copy of the T, in the place of AlsRaAqiI as explanatory of AlrRawiIRu, I find AltRaOanRiI, which I think an evident mistranscription:] ― -b5- and Weak: ― -b6- and Sound in body and intellect. (All three from the T.) ＝ -A2- Also The [funda-
mental] rhyme-letter; (S, M, K;) the letter upon which the ode is founded, and which is indispensable in every verse thereof, in one place; as, for instance, the [final] E in the verse here following:
UicaA qalRa maAlu AlmaroCi qalRa Sadiyquhu
wa Oawomato Uilayohi biAlEuyuwni AlOaSaAbiEu
[When the wealth of the man becomes little, his friends become few, and, together with the eyes, the fingers make signs to him]: (Akh, M:) [when two or more letters are indispensable to the rhyme, only one of them is thus termed, according to rules fully explained in the M and in the treatises on versification:] IJ mentions rawiyRaAtN as its pl.; but [ISd says,] I think him to have stated this carelessly, and not to have heard it from the Arabs. (M.) One says qaSiydataAni EalaI rawiIRK waAHidK [Two odes constructed upon one rhymeletter; or having one fundamental rhyme-letter]. (S.)

riwaAyapN c
riwaAyapN [an inf. n. of rawaI, q. v., when used as a subst., meaning A relation, or recital, &c.,] has for its pl. rawaAyaA. (JM.) See raAwiyapN, last sentence but one.

rawiyRapN c
rawiyRapN A want, or thing wanted: (A 'Obeyd, T, S:) so in the saying, lanaA Einoda fulaAnK rawiyRapN [We have a want to be supplied to us on the part of such a one; meaning we want a thing of such a one]: (A 'Obeyd, T:) and lanaA qibalaka rawiyRapN [We have a want to be supplied to us on thy part; we want a thing of thee]. (S.) ― -b2- And The remainder of a debt and the like. (S.) ＝ -A2- Also, (S,) or rawiyRapN fiI OamorK, (M, K, *) thus usually pronounced without C, (S,) [originally rawiyoYapN,] Inspection, examination, consideration, or thought, of an affair; (S, M, K;) without haste: (M:) pl. rawaAyaA. (JM, TA.) You say, maDaI EalaI wajohihi bigayori rawiyRapK [He went at random, heedlessly, or in a headlong manner, without consideration]. (A in art. rkb.) See raAwiyapN, near the end. [See also rawiyoYapN in art. rwO.)

rajulN rawRaMCN c
rajulN rawRaMCN A man whose habitual work, or occupation, is the drawing of water by means of the raAwiyap [q. v.]: you say, jaMCa rawRaMCu Alqawomi [The people's habitual drawer of water by means of the rAwyp came]. (T.)

rayRaA c
rayRaA [originally rawoyaA] A sweet odour (T, M, K) of anything. (T.) One says of a woman, UinRahaA laTayRibapu AlrRayRaA, meaning Verily she is sweet in the odour of her body: and hence the saying of Imrael-Keys,
UicaA qaAmataA taDawRaEa Almisoku minohumaA
nasiyma AlSRabaA jaMCato birayRaA Alqaranofuli
[When they stand, the fragrance of musk is diffused from them, like the breath of the east wind that has brought the sweet odour of the clove]. (T.) ＝ -A2- It is also fem. of rayRaAnu. (T, S, M, &c.)

rayRaAnu c
rayRaAnu [originally rawoyaAnu] an epithet from rawiIa; (T, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) Satisfied with drinking [of water and of milk &c.]; having drunk [thereof] enough to quench, or satisfy, his thirst; contr. of EaToXaAnu: (S, Mgh: *) fem. rayRaA, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) in which the I is not changed into w because the word is an epithet; for it is changed into w only in a subst., of the measure faEolaI, of which I is the final radical, as in taqowaI; so that if it were a subst., it would be rawRaI; (S, M;) originally rawoyaA: (M:) as to rayRaA that is thought to be used as the proper name of a woman, it is, thus used, an epithet, like AlHaArivu and AlEabRaAsu, though without the article Al: (S, * M:) the pl. is rwaMCN, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) with kesr and medd., (S,) in measure like kitaAbN, (Msb,) masc. and fem. (Mgh, Msb.) You say qawomN riwaMCN mina AlmaMCi [A people, or party, satisfied with drinking of water]. (S.) ― -b2- And nabotN rayRaAnu and XajarN riwaMCN [A plant, or herbage, and trees, having plentiful irrigation: or flourishing and fresh, luxuriant, juicy, succulent, or sappy, by reason of plentiful irrigation: see the verb]. (M.) ― -b3- [Hence,] rayRaAnu signifies also (assumed tropical:) Full of fat and flesh. (JM.) And you say wajohN rayRaAnu (tropical:) [A plump face]; an expression of dispraise [app. when relating to a man, but not otherwise; for rayRaAnu, or rayRaA, applied to a youth, or to a woman, or a limb of a woman, meaning plump and juicy, is used by way of praise]: opposed to wajohN ZamoMnu. (A and TA in art. ZmO.) And AimoraOapN rayRaA Almuxaloxali (assumed tropical:) [A woman full, or plump, in the place of the anklet]. (JM.) And farasN rayRaAnu AlZRahori (assumed tropical:) A horse fat in the portion of flesh and sinew next the back-bone on each side. (T.)

raAwK c
raAwK [as the act. part. n. of rawaI] is used in relation to water [as meaning Bringing, or one who brings, water to his family: and drawing, or one who draws, water for others: and a camel carrying, or that carries, water; whence the subst. raAwiyapN, q. v.]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And [hence] it is used also in relation to poetry (T, S, M) and to traditions or narratives or stories (T, M, Mgh, K) [as meaning A relater, reciter, or rehearser, by heart, of poetry, and of traditions, or narratives or stories, learned, or heard, or received, from another]: and in like manner raAwiyapN↓, but in an intensive sense [as meaning a large, or copious, relater or reciter or rehearser, &c.]; (T, S, M, Mgh, K;) i. e. kaviyru AlrRiwaAyapi; (T, * TA;) as in the phrase rajulN raAwiyapN lilXRiEori [a man who is a large, or copious, relater &c. of poetry]: (S:) the pl. of raAwK is ruwaApN. (S, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also One who has the superintendence, management, or care, of horses (mano yaquwmu EalaI Alxayoli [strangely rendered by Freytag, who seems to have read EalaI Aljamali, “ constrictus fune et stans super cameli dorso ”]). (M, K.)

raAwiyapN c
raAwiyapN A camel, (A 'Obeyd, T, S, K,) or a mule, or an ass, (S, and so in the K with the exception of “ and ” for “ or, ”) upon which water is drawn: (A 'Obeyd, T, S, K: [see saAniyapN:]) or a camel that carries water; (M, * Mgh, Msb;) and then applied to any beast upon which water is drawn: (Msb:) [but it is disputed whether this be the primary or proper signification, or whether it be secondary or tropical, as will be shown by what follows:] and also a man who draws water (A 'Obeyd, T, TA) for his family: (TA:) the p is affixed [lilnRaqoli, i. e. for the purpose of transferring the word from the category of epithets to that of substantives; or] to give intensiveness to the signification: (Msb:) pl. rawaAyaA [by rule rawaMCK, being originally of the measure fawaAEilu, not faEaAYilu]. (S, M, TA.) Also A mazaAdap [or leathern water-bag] (A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, Mgh) composed of three skins, (Mgh,) containing water; (M, K;) so called as being the receptacle in which is the water borne by the camel [thus called]; (A 'Obeyd, T;) or the mzAdp is thus termed by the vulgar, but this application of the word is allowable as metaphorical: (S:) or it signifies a pair of such water-bags (mazaAdataAni [see mazaAdapN in art. zyd]): (T:) [accord. to ISd,] it is applied to the mzAdp, and then to the camel, because of the nearness of the latter to the former: (M:) or its primary application is to the camel: (S, Mgh:) accord. to some, its application to the camel is proper; and to the mzAdp, tropical: accord. to others, the reverse is the case: (MF, TA:) the pl. is rawaAyaA, as above. (Mgh, TA.) ― -b2- One says of a weak person who is in easy circumstances, maA yarudRu AlrRaAwiyapa, meaning He is unable to turn back the rAwyp [or camel bearing a water-bag or pair of water-bags,] notwithstanding its being heavily burdened by the water that is upon it. (M.) ― -b3- And the Prophet applied the appellation rawaAyaA AlbilaAdi [The camels bearing water for the irrigation of the countries, or the water-bags borne by camels for the irrigation of the countries,] to (assumed tropical:) the clouds, by way of comparison. (TA.) ― -b4- rawaAyaA is also applied as an appellation to (assumed tropical:) The chiefs of a people; (IAar, Th, T;) as pl. of raAwiyapN; the chief who bears the burden of the bloodwits owed by the tribe being likened to the camel thus termed. (T, M. *) A Temeemee, mentioning a party that had attacked his tribe, said, laqiynaAhumo faqatalonaA AlrRawaAyaA wa OabaHonaA AlzRawaAyaA meaning [We encountered them, and] we slew the chiefs, and gave permission to occupy, or to plunder, the houses, or tents. (T.) ― -b5- rawaAyaA also occurs in a trad., in which it is said, XarRu AlrRawaAyaA rawaAyaA Alkacibi, and accord. to some, it is, in this instance, pl. of raAwiyapN (JM, TA) in the first of the senses explained above; so that the meaning is, (assumed tropical:) The worst of those who carry tidings are those who carry false tidings; such persons being likened to the beasts so called, in respect of the fatigue that they undergo: (JM:) or it is pl. of rawiyRapN↓; (JM, TA;) and the meaning is, the worst of thoughts are those that are untrue, not right, nor tending to good: or it is pl. of riwaAyapN↓; and the meaning is, the worst of relations, or recitals, are those that are untrue. (JM.) ― -b6- See also raAwK.

OarowaI c
OarowaI: see the next paragraph, in two places.

OurowiyRapN c
OurowiyRapN, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) originally [OurowuwyapN,] of the measure OufoEuwilapN, (S, M, Msb,) and UirowiyRapN, (Lh, M, K,) The female of the wuEuwl, (El-Ahmar,
A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, Msb, K,) which means mountain-goats: (TA:) or the female and the male; the former of which is also called EanozN, and the latter waEilN; (AZ, T, Msb;) and which are of the [kind called] XaMCN; not of the [kind called] baqarN: (AZ, T:) pl.
