OaraAwiIRN, (El-Ahmar, A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, Msb, K,) of the measure OafaAEiylu, (S,) a pl. of pauc., Msb,) applied to three (El-Ahmar, A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, K) and more, to ten [inclusive], (El-Ahmar, A 'Obeyd, T, M, K,) and OarowaI↓, applied to many, (El-Ahmar, A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, Msb, K,) of the measure OafoEalu, (S, M, Msb,) erroneously held by Abu-l-'Abbás to be of the measure faEolaI; (M;) an irregular pl.; (Msb, K;) or [rather] it is a quasi-pl. n.; (M, K;) and OarawiIRu is a broken pl. (M.) It is also a proper name of a woman: and so is OarowaI↓. (S.)

murowK c
murowK: see riwFI

mirowFI c
mirowFI: see riwaMCN, in two places.

1 rayayotu c
1. rayayotu and rayRayotu↓, inf. n. of the former raIRN and of the latter taroyiyapN, are both of them verbs relating to AlrRaAyapu: (T:) you say, AlrRaAyapa rayRayotu↓ [and rayayotuhaA] I made the raAyap [q. v.]: (M, TA:) the imperative of rayayotu is Airoyaho, and that of rayRayotu↓ is rayRiho: and the pass. part. ns. are maroyiIRN↓ and muraIRN↓, each applied to a banner. (T.)

2 raIRaRa
2: see 1, in three places. ＝ -A2- You say also, rayRayotu raMCF I made a r; (M;) or I wrote a r. (TA in bAb AlAlf AllyRnp.)

4 Oaroyayotu AlrRaAyapa c
4. Oaroyayotu AlrRaAyapa; accord. to Lh, OaroOayotuhaA, [and so in the K, (see 1 in art. rOI, near the end of the paragraph,]) but [ISd says,] I hold that this is anomalous, and that it is properly only OaroyayotuhaA; I stuck, or fixed, [into the ground,] the banner, or standard. (M, TA.)

8 Airotayotuhu c
8. Airotayotuhu, [as though a contraction of Airotayayotuhu,] for AirotaOayotuhu: see raOaI, first signification.

10 Aisotarayotuhu c
10. Aisotarayotuhu, [as though a contraction of Aisotaroyayotuhu, like as AisotaHayotu is a contraction of AisotaHoyayotu,] for AisotaroOayotuhu: see raOaI, first signification.

raIRN c
raIRN, said in the CK, in art. rOI, to be a pl. of raOoIN: see this latter word.

ruIRN c
ruIRN: see art. rwI. ＝ -A2- It is also said in the K, in art. rOI, to be pl. of raOoIN: see this latter word.

riIRN c
riIRN: see art. rwI ＝ -A2- It is also said in the K, in art. rOI, to be a pl. of raOoIN: see this latter word. ― -b2- Also Beauty of aspect; (K; and M in art. rwI;) accord. to him who holds it to be without C; said by AAF to mean beauty as implying namoEapN [and therefore belonging to art. rwI]. (M in art. rwI. [See also riYoIN, in art. rOI.])

riyapN c
riyapN: see riYapN, in art. rOI.

riyFA c
riyFA: see riYoIN, in art. rOI.

riyRapN c
riyRapN an inf. n. of raOaI [q. v.]. (T, M, K; all in art. rOI.)

rayRaA c
rayRaA: see art. rwI.

ruyRaA c
ruyRaA: see ruWoyaA, in art. rOI.

riyRaA c
riyRaA: see ruWoyaA, in art. rOI.

riyRFA c
riyRFA: see riYoIN, in art. rOI.

rayRaAnu c
rayRaAnu: see art. rwI.

raAIN c
raAIN: see what next follows.

raAyapN c
raAyapN, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) and raMCapN, mentioned by Sb on the authority of Abu-l-Khattáb, the A of raAyapN, though a substitute for the medial radical, [i. e. I,] being likened by him to the augmentative A, and therefore the final radical is made C, like as is done in the case of siqaMCN &c., (M,) A banner, or standard, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) of an army: (Msb:) accord. to some, (Msb,) originally with C, [see raOoyapN, in art. rOI,] though pronounced by the Arabs without C; (T, Msb;) but others deny this, and say that it has not been heard with C: (Msb:) pl. raAyaAtN (M, Msb, K) and [coll. gen. n.] raAIN↓. (M, K.) ― -b2- Also A qilaAadp [app. here meaning collar]: (K:) or a thing that is put upon the neck (Lth, T, M, K) of a runaway male slave, (M, K.) to show that he is a runaway: it is an iron ring, of the size of the neck. (TA.) ＝ -A2- It is also said to be an inf. n. of raOaI: see this latter word.

ruyayRapN c
ruyayRapN dim. of raAyapN. (Lth, T.)

qaSiydapN rayRiyRapN c
qaSiydapN rayRiyRapN An ode of which the rawiIR [or fundamental rhyme-letter] is r. (TA in bAb AlAlf AllyRnp.)

tariyRapN c
tariyRapN and tiriyRapN: see taroYiyapN, in art. rOI.

muraIRN c
muraIRN: see the first paragraph.

maroyiIRN c
maroyiIRN: see the first paragraph.

1 raMCa c
1. raMCa (like xaAfa, TA, [app. indicating that its aor. is yaraMCu, like yaxaAfu,]) a dial. var. of raOaI [He saw; &c.]. (M, K.)

2 ryRO fiI AlOamori c
2. ryRO fiI AlOamori i. q. rawRaOa [q. v.]. (T, * K.) ＝ -A2- ryROhu, inf. n. taroyiYapN, i. q. fasaHa Eanohu mino xinaAqihi [app. meaning He relaxed the compression of his throat: or he relaxed the cord by which he was being throttled]: (M:) or fasaHa Eano xunaAqihi [which app. has the former meaning: or perhaps means he, or it, relieved his quinsy, so that he had room, or freedom, to breathe]. (K.) ＝ -A3- ryRO raMCFA He wrote a r. (TA.)

3 rAyO fulaAnFA c
3. rAyO fulaAnFA, (M, K, *) said to be formed by transposition, [i. e. from raMCaI,] inf. n. muraAyaOapN, (TA,) He feared, or was on his guard against, such a one. (M, K. *) ― -b2- See also 3 in art. rOI.

riIoCN c
riIoCN a subst. from raMCa mentioned above: (M, K:) [i. e., it signifies Sight; &c.; like ruWoyapN:] and raMCN is said by MF to be like it; but this is a mistake, occasioned by his finding AlrRaMC, in a verse, miswritten for AldRaMC. (TA.) ― -b2- [See also riYoI.]

qaSiydapN raAYiyRapN c
qaSiydapN raAYiyRapN: see art. rwO.

1 raAbaniI c
1. raAbaniI, (T, S, M, &c.,) aor. yariybu, (M, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. rayobN (T, M, Mgh, Msb, &c.) and riybapN, (M, K,) or the latter is a simple subst., (S, Msb,) It (a thing) occasioned in me disquiet, disturbance, or agitation, of mind: (Ksh and Bd in ii. 1:) [this is the primary signification; (see riybapN;) a signification also borne by OaraAbaniI↓; (see the verses of Khálid cited in this paragraph;) whence the other significations here expl. in what follows:] it (a thing) made me to doubt: (Msb: and in like manner raAbahu is expl. in the Mgh:) or it (a thing, M) caused me to have what is termed riybap [i. e. doubt, or suspicion or evil opinion, or doubt combined with suspicion or evil opinion]; as also OaraAbaniI↓: (M, K: in both of which this meaning is indicated, but not expressed:) but the latter is said by Lth to be bad: (T:) or, (T, M, Msb,) accord. to AZ, (T, Msb,) the former signifies he, (T, M, *) or it, i. e. his case, (M, * Msb,) made me to know that there was on his part what is termed riybap [i. e. something occasioning doubt, or suspicion or evil opinion, or doubt combined with suspicion or evil opinion]; (T, M, Msb;) made me to be certain, or sure, of it: (Msb:) and ↓the latter signifies made me to think that there was in him what is so termed; (Sb, T, M, Msb, K;) without my being certain, or sure, of it: (Msb:) [Az says that] these are the right explanations of the two phrases: (T:) [or] the latter signifies also jaEala fiIRa AlrRiyabapa [he put into me, i. e. into my mind, doubt, or suspicion &c.]; (Sb, M, K; and in a similar manner Oarabotuhu is expl. in the latter;) or OawohamaniI AlrRiybapa [he made me to think that which occasioned doubt, or suspicion &c.]: (K: and in like manner ArAbhu is expl. in the Ham p. 363:) and ribotuhu signifies OawoSalotu Uilayohi AlrRiybapa [I made doubt, or suspicion &c., or that which occasioned doubt, or suspicion &c., to come to him, or to reach him]; (K;) [app. by some act; for it is said that] raAbahu signifies OataAhu biriybapK [he did to him a thing that occasioned doubt, or suspicion &c.]: (Ham ubi suprà:) or, (K,) accord. to Lh, the Arabs say, (M,) raAbaniI Oamoruhu, aor. yariybuniI, inf. n. rayobN and riybapN: when they speak allusively [with respect to the cause of doubt &c., not expressing it,] (UicaA kanawoA [misinterpreted in the TA as meaning “ when they affix a pronoun to the verb, ” for the meaning here intended is clearly shown by what follows,]) they prefix A [to the verb, saying OaraAba↓, and Oarabotu, &c., expl. in the latter part of
this paragraph]; and when they do not speak allusively [with respect to the cause of doubt &c., but express it,] (UicaA lamo yakonuwA) they reject that letter; but [so accord. to the M, but in the K “ or, ”] it is allowable to say, AlOamoru OaraAbaniI↓; (M, K;) i. e., to prefix the A when the verb is made trans.: (M:) accord. to As, (T,) raAbaniI [signifies he did what made me to doubt, or to have doubt, or suspicion &c., and what I disliked, or hated; for it] is said of a man when thou seest, on his part, what makes thee to doubt, &c., (maA yuriybuka, [or maA yariybuka,]) and what thou dislikest, or hatest: (T, S:) and Hudheyl say, OaraAbaniI↓, (T, S, Msb,) or ArAbnI Oamoruhu, as As says on the authority of 'Eesà Ibn-'Omar; (M;) and ribotu and Airotabotu↓, meaning I doubted: (Msb:) accord. to IAth, raAbaniI AlXRakRu [an evident mistranscription for rAbnI AlXRaIoCu] and ArAbnI↓ both mean XakRakaniI wa OawohamaniI AlrRiybapa bihi [i. e. the thing made me to doubt, and caused me to think that there was that which occasioned doubt, or suspicion &c., in it]; but when you are certain, or sure, of it, you say [only] raAbaniI, without [an incipient] A: (TA:) accord. to Lth, raAbaniI AlOamoru, inf. n. rayobN, signifies the thing, or event, [app. said only of that which is evil,] betided me, or befell me: and raAbaniI Oamoruhu, his affair, or case, brought upon me doubt (XakRFA [in the TA XarRFA i. e. evil]) and fear. (T.) It is said in a trad., of Fátimeh, yariybuniI maA yariybuhaA, meaning That displeases and disquiets me which displeases and disquiets her. (TA.) And in another, respecting a gazelle lying curled in sleep, laA yariybuhu OaHadN biXaIoCK, meaning No one shall oppose himself to it and disquiet it, or disturb it. (TA.) And in another, maA raAbaka UilaI qaToEihaA, i. e. What disquieted thee and constrained thee to cut it off? as Aboo-Moosà thinks the phrase may be read: but see another reading voce raAbN. (TA.) And in another, daEo maA wa UinRa yariybuka UilaI maA laA yarybuka faUinRa Alkaciba riybapN↓ AlSRidoqa TumaOoniynapN, (Mgh, TA, *) or, as some relate it, yuriybuka↓, (TA,) i. e. Leave thou that which causeth thee to doubt, (Mgh, TA, *) and occasioneth in thee AlrRiybap, which originally signifies disquiet, or disturbance, or agitation, of mind, [and hence suspicion &c., and betake thyself to that which will not cause thee to doubt, &c., for verily lying is a thing that occasions disquiet of mind, or doubt, or suspicion &c., and verily veracity is a thing that occasions tranquillity;] because the mind is not at rest when it doubts, but becomes tranquil when it is certain, or sure. (Mgh.) And the Hudhalee, (S, TA,) Khálid Ibn-Zuheyr, (TA,) says,
yaA qawomi maA liI wa OabaA cuWayobi
kunotu UicaA Oatawotuhu mino gayobi
yaXumRu EiTofiI wa yajurRu vawobiI
birayobi kaOanRaniI Oarabotuhu↓
[O my people, what aileth me with Aboo-Dhueyb? I was (such that) when I came to him after absence, or from being absent, he would smell my side, or my armpit, and pull my garment, as though I disquieted his mind with doubt, or suspicion &c.]: (S and TA, in this art. and in art. bz; but in the latter with yabuzRu in the place of its syn. yajurRu:) it is said in the L that ArAb is trans. and intrans.; and that he who makes it trans. makes it syn. with raAba; and thus it is in the saying of Khálid cited above; the last hemistich of which is also related thus:
kaOanRaniI qado ribotuhu birayobi
but ArAb↓ when intrans. signifies OataI biriybapK [meaning he did an act that occasioned doubt, or suspicion &c.]; like as OalaAma signifies OataI bimaA yulaAmu Ealayohi [he did an act for which he was to be blamed]: and agreeably with this signification is expl. the verse ascribed to El-Mutalemmis, or to Beshshár Ibn-Burdeh,
Oaxuwka AlRaciI Uino ribotahu qaAla UinRamaA
wa Uino laAyanotahu laAna jaAnibuho Oarabotu↓
[Thy brother is he who, if thou make him to doubt, &c., (or if thou do to him an act occasioning doubt, or suspicion &c., as expl. in the Ham p. 363, where EaAtabotahu is put in the place of laAyanotahu,) says, Only I have done what occasions doubt, &c.; and if thou act gently with him, becomes gentle]: thus the verse is correctly related: he who relates it differently, saying Oarabota, [and thus I find it in two copies of the T,] asserts that Uino ribotahu means if thou make him of necessity to have doubt, or suspicion &c.; and Arbt↓ [here said in the TA to be “ with damm, ” but this is evidently a mistranscription for “ with fet-h, ” for it cannot mean with damm to the A, as Ouribota does not bear an appropriate signification, nor can it mean with damm to the t, as the explanation relates to the reading of Arbt with fet-h to the t,] means thou hast caused [me] to think that there was that which occasioned doubt, or suspicion &c., when it was not decidedly necessary. (TA.)

4 ArAb c
4. ArAb, as a trans. verb: see 1, in eight places. ＝ -A2- As intrans., it signifies He (a man) was, or became, one in whom was something occasioning doubt, or suspicion or evil opinion, or doubt combined with suspicion or evil opinion; i. e. SaAra caA riybapi: (Sb, T, S, M:) and he did a thing that occasioned doubt, or suspicion &c.: (As, T:) it is said when one is told something of a person, or thinks it, or imagines it: (Msb:) see 1, in the former half of the paragraph; and also, in three places, in the latter part of the same paragraph. Also It (a thing, or an affair, or a case,) was, or became, one in which was something occasioning doubt, or suspicion &c.; i. e. SaAra caA rayobK (T, K) or cA riybapK. (M.)

5 tarayRaba
5: see the next paragraph.

8 ArtAb c
8. ArtAb He doubted, (S, Msb, K,) fiyhi [respecting him, or it]. (S.) See 1, in the former half of the paragraph. And ArtAb bihi He suspected him, or thought evil of him: (T, M, K:) or he saw on his part [or in him] what caused him to have doubt, or suspicion &c.; as also bh tryRb↓; (Har p. 257;) and bh AstrAb↓; i. e. raOaI minohu maA yariybuhu: (S, K, and Har ubi suprà:) the last used by [the tribe of] Hudheyl. (TA.) ― -b2- [It often means particularly He was sceptical in matters of religion.]

10 AstrAb c
10. AstrAb He fell into that which occasioned doubt, or suspicion or evil opinion; meaning he feared so that he doubted of safety or security: (Har pp. 256 and 257:) [he conceived doubt, or suspicion or evil opinion:] he doubted: and became infected with suspicion or evil opinion. (Idem p. 309.) See also 8.

raAbN c
raAbN Want, or need. (TA.) Hence, in a trad., maA rabukumo Uilayohi What is [the reason of] your want of him? or your wanting to ask him? (TA.) And, in another trad., maA raAbuka UilaI qaToEihaA What is [the reason of] thy wanting to cut it off? thus, says El-Khattábee, they relate it, with damm to the b: but IAth says that it is properly maA Oarabuka, meaning the same: or, accord. to Aboo-Moosà, the right reading may be mA raAbaka, expl. in the preceding paragraph. (TA.)

rayobN c
rayobN is an inf. n. of 1, (T, M, Mgh, Msb, &c.,) as also riybapN↓, (M, K,) or the latter is a simple subst.: (S, Msb:) the primary signification of the latter [and of the former also when it is used as a simple subst.] is Disquiet, disturbance, or agitation, of mind: (Ksh and Bd in ii. 1:) [and hence] the former signifies doubt; (T, S, Msb;) as also ↓the latter; (S, Mgh;) because doubt disquiets, or disturbs, the mind: (Ksh and Bd ubi suprà, and Mgh:) and opinion; syn. ZanRN: (Msb:) and ↓the latter, (S, M, A, Mgh, K,) and the former also, (M, A, K,) doubt, or suspicion or evil opinion; syn. tuhamapN (S, M, A, Mgh, K) and ZinRapN: (M, A, K:) or the former, [and ↓the latter also,] doubt combined with suspicion or evil opinion: (IAth, TA:) and a thing, or an event, or a case, that occasions one doubt, or suspicion or evil opinion, or doubt combined with suspicion or evil opinion; i. e. maA raAbaka mino OamorK: (S, TA:) [in this last sense, the latter is the more common: hence,] lying is termed riybapN in a trad. cited above: see 1: (Mgh:) the ↓pl. of the latter is riyabN. (Msb.) A man, and a thing or an event or a case, is said to be cuw riybapK↓ [as meaning Having in him, or it, something occasioning doubt, or suspicion &c.]. (A.) [laA rayoba often occurs as meaning There is no doubt; without doubt; undoubtedly.] ― -b2- Hence, rayobu AlzRamaAni The accidents, or evil accidents, of time, (Ksh and Bd ubi suprà, [in Fleischer's ed. of the latter riyab AlzmAn, which is more agreeable with the explanation, but rayob AlzmAn is more usual,]) that disquiet, or disturb, the minds and hearts: (Ksh:) and rayobu Almanuwni (S, A) [which likewise signifies] the accidents, or evil accidents, of time: (S:) and rayobu AldRahori signifies the same; i. e. Sarofuhu, (M, K,) or Suruwfuhu, (T, Msb,) and HawaAdivuhu. (T. [This is said in the TA to be tropical; but I do not find
it so characterized in the A.]) ― -b3- [Hence, likewise,] rayobN also signifies A want; a needful, or requisite, thing, affair, or business; syn. HaAjapN. (S, A, Msb, K.) A poet says, (S,) namely, Kaab Ibn-Málik El-Ansáree, (TA,)
qaDayonaA mino tihaAmapa kulRa rayobK
wa xayobara vumRa OajoyayonaA AlsRuyuwfaA
[We accomplished, from Tihámeh, every want, and from Kheyber: then we gave rest to our swords]. (S.) ＝ -A2- [ryb mentioned by Freytag as applied in art. dls of the S to a certain plant, and written rayob in both of my copies of the S in that art., is a mistake for rabab, which is the reading in the TA, pl. of ribRapN.]

riybapN c
riybapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in six places. ― -b2- [It often means particularly Scepticism in matters of religion.]

OamorN rayRaAbN c
OamorN rayRaAbN A thing, or an event, or a case, that frightens, or terrifies. (M, K.)

raAYibN c
raAYibN [act. part. n. of 1; Causing, or occasioning, doubt, or suspicion or evil opinion, &c.] IAar says that Aboo-Bekr is related to have said, in his charge to 'Omar, Ealayoka biAlrRaAYibi mina AlOumuwri wa UiyRaAk wa AlrRaAYiba minohaA, which Th explains as meaning Keep thou to what is clear, free from dubiousness or confusedness, of affairs, and beware thou of, or avoid thou, what has in it dubiousness, or confusedness, thereof: (T, TA:) the first is from raAba of which the aor. is yaruwbu, said of milk; and the second is from raAba of which the aor. is yariybu. (TA.) [See also a verse cited voce raAYibN in art. rwb, and my remark thereon.]

muriybN c
muriybN, applied to a man, (T, S, A,) and to a thing or an event, (M, A,) i. q. cuw riybapK [expl. above, voce rayobN]. (T, S, M, A.) UinRahumo kaAnuwA fiI XakRK muriybK, in the Kur xxxiv. last verse, means Verily they were in doubt causing to fall into suspicion or evil opinion: or it means ciI riybapK [having in it something occasioning suspicion &c.]: (Ksh and Bd:) or ciI rayobK [which means the same: or attended with disquiet, or disturbance, or agitation, of mind]: (M, TA:) [see its verb, 4:] it may be from the trans. or from the intrans. verb. (Ksh.)

murotaAbN c
murotaAbN Doubting [or suspecting]. (Msb.) ― -b2- [It often means particularly Sceptical, or a sceptic, in matters of religion. ＝ -A2- And murotaAbN fiyhi, or bihi, Doubted of, or suspected.]

1 raAva c
1. raAva, (T, S, M, &c.,) aor. yariyvu, (S, Msb,) inf. n. rayovN, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) He, or it, was, or became, slow, tardy, dilatory, late, or backward; (T, S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also tryRv↓. (T, K.) You say, raAva EalaIRa xabaruka, (S, A,) or rAv EalayonaA xabaruhu, (T,) Thy news or the news of thee, or his news or the news of him, was slow, &c., in coming to me, or to us. (T, S, A.) And EalayonaA fulaAnN tryRv↓ Such a one was slow, &c., in coming to us. (T.) And rubRa EajalapK wa habato rayovFA, or, accord. to one relation of the saying, tahabu rayovFA, the meaning in both cases being the same, from Alhibapu; [i. e. Many an act of haste causes (lit. gives) slowness, &c.;] (S;) or tuEoqibu rayovFA [occasions, as its result, slowness, &c.]: (A:) a proverb. (S, A.) And it appears from the following saying of Maakil Ibn-Khuweylid,
laEamoruka laloyaOosu gayoru Almuriyvi xayorN mina AlTRamaEi AlkaAcibi
[By thy life, or by thy religion, assuredly despair that is not slow in its issue is better than hope that gives a false promise, if this be his meaning,] that ArAv↓ may be a dial. var. of raAva: but the poet may mean [that does not make a man slow, i. e.] gayoru Almuriyvi AlmaroCa. (M.)

2 rayRava
2: see 4. ― -b2- [Hence,] yurayRivu AlnRaZara, or, accord. to one relation, yurayRivu UilaIRa AlnRaZara, [meaning He is long in looking or he prolongs the looking, and he is long in looking &c. at me,] is mentioned as a phrase used by one of the companions of Ks. (M.) ― -b3- One says also, rayRava EamRaA kaAna Ealayohi He fell short, or failed, of doing, or accomplishing, what was incumbent on him: and in like manner, rayRava Oamorahu [He fell short, or failed, of accomplishing his affair]. (M.) ― -b4- And taroyiyvN signifies The being fatigued, tired, weary, or jaded: (K:) its verb, ryRv, is said of a man or of a horse. (TK.) ＝ -A2- taroyiyvN is also syn. with taloyiynN [The rendering a thing soft, &c.]. (K.)

4 Oaroyava
4: see 1, last sentence. ＝ -A2- [It is generally transitive.] You say, maA OaraAvaka (K) and mA rayRavaka↓ (A) What made thee, or hath made thee, slow, tardy, dilatory, late, or backward? retarded, or delayed, thee? or kept, or held, thee back? (A, K.) And maA OaraAvaka EalayonaA What retarded, or delayed, thee, or what kept, or held, thee back, from us? or what hath retarded, &c.? (S.)

5 tarayRava
5: see 1, in two places.

10 AstrAvhu c
10. AstrAvhu He deemed, or reckoned, him, or it, (namely, a person, A, TA, or information, news, or tidings, TA,) slow, tardy, dilatory, late, or backward. (S, * M, A, K, * TA.) You say, Aisotagavotuhu famaA Qsotaravotuhu [I sought, or desired, aid, or succour, of him, and I did not deem him slow, &c.]. (A, TA.)

rayovN c
rayovN A space, or measure, [of time,] syn. qadorN, (T, Msb,) or miqodaArN; (A, K;) or a time, a while, syn. saAEapN. (Mgh.) You say, Oamohalotuhu rayovamaA faEala kacaA, i. e. qadora maA faEalahu (Msb) or saAEapa fiEolihi (Mgh) [I granted him a delay during the space of his doing such a thing]. And lamo yalobavo UilRaA rayovamaA qulotu, i. e. qadora celika [He tarried not save during the space that, or as long as, or while, I said such a thing]. (TA, from a trad.) And so in the saying, maA qaEada EinodanaA fulaAnN UilRaA rayova Oano HadRavanaA biHadiyvK tumRa marRa [Such a one sat not with us, or at our abode, save during the space that, or as long as, or while, he related to us a story, or tradition; then he went away]. (T, TA.) And it is used without mA and without An: (TA:) Aashà Báhileh says,
laA yuSoEibu AlOamora UilRaA rayova yarokabuhu
wa kulRa OamorK siwaI AlfaHoXaMCi yaOotamiru
[He finds not the affair difficult save while he is embarking in it; and every command but that which exceeds the bounds of rectitude he obeys]: (M, TA:) this mode of expression is common in the dial. of El-Hijáz; accord. to which one says, yuriydu yafoEalu, i. e. Oano yafoEala. (TA.) [See also an ex. in a verse cited voce raAjilapN, and another in a verse cited voce riyHN.]

rayovapN c
rayovapN Slowness, tardiness, dilatoriness, lateness, or backwardness; contr. of EajalapN; like [the inf. n.] rayovN; (Ham p. 503;) i. q. UiboTaMCN. (Idem p. 640.)

raAYivN c
raAYivN: see what next follows.

rayRivN c
rayRivN, applied to a man, (IAar, S, M,) and, as some say, to anything, (M,) Slow, tardy, dilatory, late, or backward; (IAar, T, S, M, A, K;) as also raAYivN↓; (A, TA;) the latter occurring in a trad. (TA.)

murayRavu AlEayonayoni c
murayRavu AlEayonayoni, (Fr, S, K,) or AlEayoni, (A,) A man (Fr, S, A) slow of sight. (Fr, S, A, K.)

maA fulaAnN bimusotaraAvi AlnRuSorapi c
maA fulaAnN bimusotaraAvi AlnRuSorapi [Such a one is not a person whose aid is deemed slow, tardy, &c.]. (A, TA.)

dictScrap.label: ryH: For several words mentioned under this head in some of the Lexicons, see art. rwH.

superEntry.entry:
2 taroyiydN c
2. taroyiydN, in agriculture, The raising, with the [implement called] mijonab, the ridges that form the borders of streamlets for irrigation. (M.)

rayodN c
rayodN A ledge of a mountain, (T, S, M, * A, K,) in [any of] the sides thereof, (A,) resembling a wall; (M;) i. q. HayodN: (S, M, A:) pl. [of pauc.] OaroyaAdN (M) and (of mult., M) ruyuwdN. (T, S, M, A, K.) tahowiydN EalaI ruyuwdK, (Meyd, TA,) meaning A resting, or sleeping, upon ledges of mountains, (Meyd,) is a prov., applied to him who enters upon an affair [dangerous or] insalutary in its result. (Meyd, TA.)

riydN c
riydN: see art. rwd. ＝ -A2- Also An equal in age; syn. tirobN; for riYodN: so in a verse of Kutheiyir cited voce OuSodapN. (TA.)

riyHN raAdapN c
riyHN raAdapN: see what next follows: and see raAdN in art. rwd.

riyHN rayodapN c
riyHN rayodapN A wind blowing gently; as also rayodaAnapN↓ (T, S, M, A, K) and raAdapN↓: (S, M, A, K:) or the first, as some say, that blows much. (M.) [See also raAdN in art. rwd.]

riydapN c
riydapN: see riydN, in art. rwd.

riyHN rayodaAnapN c
riyHN rayodaAnapN: see rayodapN.

AlrRiyaAdu c
AlrRiyaAdu: see art. rwd.

Oaroyadu c
Oaroyadu: see art. rwd.

1 raAra c
1. raAra His (a man's) marrow became thin. (TA.)

4 ArAr muxRahu c
4. ArAr muxRahu He, (God, S, K,) and it, (emaciation, TA,) made his marrow to become thin. (S, K, TA.)

raArN c
raArN: see what next follows.

rayorN c
rayorN and raArN↓ (Fr, S, K) and riyrN (AA, K) Marrow in a melting or fluid state, (K,) and corrupt, by reason of emaciation: (TA:) or thin: (AA:) or corrupt, and in a melting or fluid state, by reason of emaciation: (Fr, S:) or in a melting or fluid and thin state, by reason of emaciation and severe dearth or drought: (TA:) or what was fat, in the bones, and has become black and thin water. (Lh, K.)
wa AlsRaAqu minRiI baAdiyaAtu AlrRayori
[And my shanks (lit. shank) are such that the melting marrow, &c., in them is manifest] means my emaciation is manifest: the poet says bAdyAt because by AlsRAq he means AlsRaAqaAni; and it is allowable to make the enunciative of a dual like that of a pl.: accord. to one relation, it is baAridaAtu. (S.) ― -b2- rayorN also signifies The water that comes forth from the mouth of a child. (K.)

riyaAsN c
riyaAsN: see riYaAsN, voce raOosN.

rayRisN c
rayRisN: see raYiysN, in two places.

1 raAXahu c
1. raAXahu, aor. yariyXu, (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. rayoXN, (S, Mgh, TA,) He feathered it, namely, an arrow; stuck the feathers upon it: (S, A, * K:) or he repaired it, or put it into a right state, by putting the feathers upon it: (Mgh:) or he repaired, or put into a right state, its feathers: (Msb:) and ryRXhu↓, (K,) inf. n. taroyiyXN, (TA,) signifies the same; (K;) and so ArtAXhu↓. (TA.) It is said in a prov., fulaAnN laA yariyXu wa laA yaboriI [lit., Such a one neither feathers nor pares arrows]; meaning, (assumed tropical:) Such a one neither profits nor injures. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) He fed him, and gave him drink, and clad him; namely, a friend: (K:) (assumed tropical:) he clad him, and aided him; namely, a poor man; because such is like a bird with a clipped wing: (TA:) (assumed tropical:) He (God) restored him, from a state of poverty, to wealth, or competence: (TA:) (tropical:) he strengthened his wing, [or power,] by beneficence to him: (A:) (tropical:) he rectified, or made good, or amended, his state, or condition, (S, K,) and profited him: (K:) (assumed tropical:) he did that which was a means of good to him: or he caused him to attain good: (Msb:) (assumed tropical:) he did good to him: (assumed tropical:) he strengthened him, and aided him to obtain his subsistence. (TA.) In the saying of Dhu-r-Rummeh,
raAXa AlguSuwna XakiyruhaA
(assumed tropical:) [Their shoots clad the branches: or surpassed in length the branches:] it is said to mean kasaA: or, accord. to AA, TaAla: but the former meaning is the better known. (TA.) [It is also doubly trans.:] you say, raAXahu QllRehu maAlFA (assumed tropical:) God gave him property. (TA, from a trad.) ＝ -A2- raAXa, (K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) [seems to have originally signified, when used intransitively, He became feathered. ― -b2- And hence,] (assumed tropical:) He collected ryX, meaning, property, and OavaAv [or household goods, or furniture and utensils, &c.]. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- And He (a man) became rich, or in a state of competence: (Fr:) and tryRX↓ (assumed tropical:) he became wealthy, or abundant in wealth. (Bd in vii. 25.) [See also 8]. ＝ -A3- He (a bird) shed many feathers. (TA.)

2 rayRaXa
2: see 1, first sentence.

5 tarayRaXa
5: see 8, in two places: and see 1, last sentence but two.

8 ArtAX c
8. ArtAX (tropical:) He became strengthened in his wing, [or power,] by being an object of beneficence; as also tryRX↓: (A:) he became in a good state, or condition: (S:) he attained good: (Msb:) he obtained good, and the effect thereof was seen upon him; as also ↓the latter verb. (TA.) [See also 1, last sentence but two.] ＝ -A2- ArtAXhu: see 1, first sentence.

raAXN c
raAXN A bird whose feathers have grown. (TA.) ― -b2- [And hence,] (assumed tropical:) A man possessing property and clothing; as also OaroyaXu↓. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also the next paragraph.

riyXN c
riyXN [Feathers; plumage;] a certain appertenance of birds, (S, A, Msb, K,) well known, (A, Msb,) constituting their clothing and ornament; (A, TA;) as also raAXN↓: (Kt, K:) n. un. of the former with p: (S, Msb:) pl. [of pauc.] OaroyaAXN (S, K) and [of mult.] riyaAXN. (IJ, K.) ― -b2- Hence, (B,) (tropical:) Clothing: (ISk, B:) or superb, or excellent, clothing; as also riyaAXN↓: (S, K:) or both signify what appears of clothing: (Kt:) the former occurs in the Kur vii. 25, accord. to one reading; (S;) and ↓the latter accord. to another reading: (TA:) and hence also, the former signifies (tropical:) ornament; and beauty: (A, TA: *) or ↓both signify (assumed tropical:) property; and plenty, or abundance of the produce of the earth and of the goods or conveniences and comforts of life: (S:) or the former signifies (assumed tropical:) good; or prosperity; or wealth: (Msb:) and (assumed tropical:) state; or condition: (TA:) and ↓the latter, (assumed tropical:) property: (Msb:) and (tropical:) goodness of state or condition; (A, TA;) or a goodly state or condition: (Msb:) or the former signifies, (K,) and ↓the latter also, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) plenty, or abundance of the produce of the earth and of the goods or conveniences and comforts of life; and the means of subsistence: (K, TA:) and (assumed tropical:) property which one has acquired for himself: and OavaAv [or (assumed tropical:) household-goods, or furniture and utensils, &c.]: (TA:) the Benoo-Kiláb say that ↓the latter word means (assumed tropical:) household-goods of whatever kind, consisting of clothes, or stuffing for mattresses or the like, or outer garments: and sometimes it means (tropical:) clothes, exclusively of other articles or kinds of property. (ISk, TA.) You say, UinRahu laHasanu AlrRiyXi (tropical:) Verily he is goodly in clothing, or apparel. (TA.) Respecting the saying, OaEoTaAhu miAYipF biriyXihaA, it is said, (S, A, * K,) by AO, (S,) that kings, when they gave a gift, put upon the humps of the camels [that bore it] ostrich-feathers, (S, K,) or [other] feathers, (A, TA,) in order that it might be known to be the king's gift; (S, A, K;) and the meaning is, accord. to As, [He gave him a hundred camels] with their saddles (S, A *) and their coverings: (S:) or with their coverings and their cloths beneath the saddles. (K.)

riyaAXN c
riyaAXN: see riyXN, (of which it is a syn. as well as a pl.,) in several places.

raAYiXN c
raAYiXN: see mariyXN. ＝ -A2- Also (tropical:) An agent between two persons, (A, Mgh, K,) namely, the briber and the accepter of a bribe, (Mgh, K,) who composes their affair, (Mgh,) or who gives (yariyXu) this one of the property of that. (A.) Such Mohammad cursed. (Mgh, TA.) [See raAXK, in art. rXw.)

OaroyaXu c
OaroyaXu: see raAXN.

mariyXN c
mariyXN, applied to an arrow, Feathered; or having the feathers stuck upon it; (S, A, * K;) as also murayRaXN↓: (A, K:) or having its feathers repaired, or put into a right state: (Msb:) and raAYiXN↓ signifies [the same: (see raAXa:) or] having feathers; (K;) being like daAfiqN applied to water [in the sense of cuw dafoq]. (TA.) Hence the saying, maA lahu OaqacRu wa laA mariyXN [lit., He has not a featherless arrow nor a feathered one]; meaning, (assumed tropical:) he has not anything. (S.)

murayRaXN c
murayRaXN: see mariyXN. ― -b2- Also, applied to the kind of garment called burod, (A, K,) an epithet similar to musahRamN: (A:) signifying (tropical:) Figured (Lh, K) with marks in the forms of feathers. (Lh.)

rayoTN c
rayoTN: see what follows.

rayoTapN c
rayoTapN Any [covering for the body such as is called] mulaMCap not of two pieces (S, Mgh, Msb, K) joined together (Mgh, TA) by sewing or the like, (TA,) but a single piece, (S, K,) all one web: (K:) it is said by Az to be, without exception, white: (TA:) or it signifies, (Mgh, K,) or signifies also, sometimes, (Msb,) any garment, or piece of cloth, that is thin (Mgh, Msb, K) and soft; (Mgh, K;) so says ISk, on the authority of certain of the Arabs of the desert; (TA;) as also raAYiTapN↓: (K:) and a napkin with which the hands are wiped after food: (TA, from a trad., expl. by Sufyán:) [in Har p. 294, q. v., it seems to be applied to a kind of woollen cloth used as a turban:] pl. rayoTN↓ [or this is rather a coll. gen. n. of which rayoTapN is the n. un.] and riyaATN. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- You say, xaraja muXotamilFA birayoTapi AlZRalomaMCi (tropical:) [He went forth enveloped with the mantle of darkness]. (TA.) And huwa yajurRu riyaATa AlHamodi (tropical:) [app. meaning He is prolix in praise]. (TA.) ― -b3- The pl. riyaATN
also signifies (assumed tropical:) Something resembling the saraAb [or mirage] in the desert. (TA.)

raAYiTapN c
raAYiTapN: see above.

1 raAEa c
1. raAEa, aor. yariyEu, (Msb, K,) inf. n. rayoEN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and ruyuwEN (TA) and riyaAEN (Lh, TA) and rayaEaAnN, (TA,) It increased, or augmented; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) said of wheat and other things: or, as some say, it denotes ziyaAdap [i. e. it signifies it became redundant, or it exceeded, as will be seen in what follows; but the truth is, that it has both of these significations; the latter] in relation to flour, and to bread. (TA.) You say, raAEati AlHinoTapu, (S, Msb, K,) aor. tariyEu, inf. n. rayoEN [&c.]; (Msb;) and OaraAEat↓, (S, K,) which latter is said by Az to be more commonly used than the former; (TA;) and AlTRaEaAmu rayRaEa↓ [which is the same as rayRaEati AlHinoTapu]; (TA;) The wheat increased, or augmented; or received increase and blessing from God; or throve by the blessing of God: (S, Msb, K, TA:) and in like manner one says of other things. (Msb.) And raAEati AlXRajarapu, and ArAEt↓, but the former is rare, The tree became abundant in its produce, or fruit. (AHn.) And sometimes they said, (S,) AlUibilu ArAEt↓ (S, IF, K) (tropical:) The camels had many young ones; (S;) they increased, and had many young ones. (IF, K.) One says also, raAEa AlTRaEaAmu, and ArAE↓, The wheat became redundant; or had a part, or portion, redundant; [app. meaning, over and above the original measure;] in the kneading and the making of bread; syn. SaAra lahu ziyaAdapN. (S.) [See the first sentence above; and see rayoEN, below.] And raAEa fiI yadiI kacaA Such a thing was redundant, or remained over and above, in my hand; as also raAqa; syn. zaAda: (L in this art., and TA in art. rwE:) Sgh has mistranscribed the explanation, zAd, in his two books, [the TS and the O,] writing faAda; and the author of the K has imitated him in mentioning this in art. rwE, instead of the present art., which is its proper place, but has written for the explanation OafaAda. (TA.) ＝ -A2- raAEa, aor. yariyEu, (IDrd, S, K,) inf. n. rayoEN, (S, TA,) He, or it, returned; went, or came, back; reverted: (IDrd, S, K:) and raAEa, aor. yaruwEu, (IDrd, and K in art. rwE,) inf. n. ruwaAEN, (K in that art.,) signifies the same; (IDrd, and K in art. rwE;) or it returned to its place: (TA in that art.:) but the former verb is the more common. (TA in the present art.) One says, of camels that have run away, SaAHa EalayohaA AlrRaAEiI faraAEato Uilayohi [The pastor cried out at them, and] they returned to him. (TA.) And waEaZotuhu faOabiI Oano yariyEa [I exhorted him, but he refused] to return, or revert. (TA.) And fulaAnN maA yariyEu bikalaAmika walA biSawotika Such a one does not return, or revert, by reason of thy speech nor by reason of thy voice. (TA.) And you say of vomit, raAEa minohu XaIoCN Somewhat of it returned: (S:) and raAEa Ealayohi it returned to his inside. (TA.) And in like manner one says of anything that returns to him, raAEa, aor. yariyEu. (TA.) ― -b2- raAEuwA, They drew, gathered, or collected, themselves together; (Ibn- 'Abbád, TA;) as also tryREwA↓; and ryREwA↓, (Ibn-'Abbád, K,) inf. n. taroyiyEN. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 5. ＝ -A3- It became rent: so in the saying of El-Kumeyt,
UicaA HiySa minohu jaAnibN raAEa jaAnibN
[When a side thereof is sewed up, a side becomes rent]. (S.) ＝ -A4- [It is also said that] raAEa, aor. yariyEu, is like radRa [app. as signifying He returned a reply, or an answer, to a person; for it is mentioned immediately after rayoEN as syn. with marojuwEN]. (TA.)

2 ryRE AlTRaEaAmu c
2. ryRE AlTRaEaAmu: see 1; second sentence. ― -b2- ryREwA They ascended, or ascended upon, the riyEap [n. un. of riyEN, q. v.]. (Ibn- 'Abbád.) ― -b3- See also 1, near the end of the paragraph. ＝ -A2- ryREhu: see 4. ＝ -A3- [See also ruyRiha (in art. ryh), with which ruyRiEa seems to be syn.]

4 ArAEvi AlHinoTapu c
4. ArAEvi AlHinoTapu; &c.: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph, in four places. ― -b2- ArAEwA Their wheat increased, or augmented; or received increase and blessing from God; or throve by the blessing of God: (Ibn-'Abbád, K:) and in like manner, their seed-produce [in general]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- ArAE AlXRaIoCa He increased, or augmented, the thing; or made it to increase, or augment; as also ryREhu↓. (TA.)

5 tryREwA c
5. tryREwA: see 1, near the end of the paragraph. ― -b2- tryRE said of grease, or gravy, (TA,) or oil, (S,) and of clarified butter, when much thereof has been put into food; (S, TA;) or of melted grease in a bowl; (A, TA;) or of clarified butter upon a cake of bread; (ISh, TA;) It flowed, or ran, hither and thither, having no direct course; (S, TA;) or went to and fro; (A, TA;) or portions thereof followed a little after other portions: (ISh, TA:) and, said of water, it ran, or flowed. (TA.) ― -b3- In like manner, (S,) said of the mirage (saraAb), [It quivered, vibrated, or moved to and fro;] it came and went; (S, K;) as also tarayRaha: (TA:) and raAEa↓, aor. yariyEu, (TA,) inf. n. rayoEN (K, TA) and rayaEaAnN, (TA,) said of the same, it was, or became, in a state of commotion or agitation; it quivered, vibrated, or moved to and fro. (K, TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) He became confounded, or perplexed, [as though vacillating, or wavering,] and unable to see his right course; as also AstrAE↓. (Ibn- 'Abbád, K.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) He paused; or waited: (O, L, K:) or (so in the L, but in the O and K “ and ”) he paused; or hesitated; or held, refrained, or abstained. (O, L, K.) [See the part. n., below.] ― -b6- tarayRaEato yadaAhu biAljuwdi (tropical:) His two hands overflowed with bounty, [as though they went hither and thither,] for one cause after another. (TA.)

10 UisotaroyaEa
10: see 5.

rayoEN c
rayoEN [see 1, of which it is an inf. n.] Increase; syn. ziyaAdapN [which may be meant to include the third of the significations here following]; as in the saying, hecaA TaEaAmN kaviyru AlrRayoEi [This is wheat of much increase]. (Mgh.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Revenue arising from the increase of land: because it is an augmentation. (Mgh.) ― -b3- (tropical:) Milk; as in the phrase, naAqapN kaviyrapN rayoEuhaA (tropical:) [A she-camel whose milk is abundant]. (A, TA.) ― -b4- Redundance; a part, or portion, redundant; a surplus; or a residue; syn. faDolN; of anything; as of flour, or meal, (Msb, K,) over and above the measure of the wheat; (Msb;) and of dough [when it has risen]; and of seed for sowing [when it has been sown]; and the like. (K.) Hence it is said, in a trad. of I'Ab, respecting the expiation of an oath, likulRi misokiynK mudRN mino HinoTapK rayoEuhu UidaAmuhu [To every poor man, a mudd of wheat: the redundance, or redundant part or portion, thereof shall be for its seasoning]: i. e., it is not necessary for the person to give, with the mudd, seasoning; but the redundance that shall arise, of the flour, or meal, of the mudd [of wheat], when he shall have ground it, therewith shall the seasoning be bought. (TA.) Hence also, the trad. of 'Omar, AimolikuwA AlEajiyna faUinRahu OaHadu AlrRayoEayoni (assumed tropical:) Knead ye well, or thoroughly, or soundly, the dough; for this action is one of the rayoEaAni [here meaning the two causes of redundance; the other cause being the grinding]. (TA.) [Hence also,] rayoEu AldRiroEi The redundant parts of the two sleeves of the coat of mail, (S, A, K, TA,) over [and beyond] the ends of the fingers; (TA;) and of the skirt thereof. (A, TA.) ― -b5- See also riyEN. ― -b6- Also, (K,) and rayoEaAnN↓, [which latter is the more common in this sense,] (S, K,) (tropical:) The first (S, K) and most excel-lent (K) part of anything: (S, K:) said in the B to be a metaphorical application from rayoEN as signifying a high, or an elevated, place. (TA.) Hence, (S, TA,) rayoEu AlXRabaAbi, by poetic license written rayaE↓, (TA,) or AlXRabaAbi rayoEaAnu↓, (S, A, L, TA,) (tropical:) The first, or prime, (S, A, TA,) and most excellent, (A, TA,) part, or period, of youth or youthfulness or youthful vigour: (S, A, TA:) or this is from rayoEN in relation to wheat: (A, TA:) or from AlmaTari rayoEaAnu↓ (assumed tropical:) the first of rain. (L, TA.) Hence also, (S,) AlsRaraAbi rayoEaAnu↓ (S, Sgh, L) (assumed tropical:) The first of the mirage; (S, Sgh;) what comes and goes thereof; (Sgh;) or such as is in a state of commotion or agitation, quivering, vibrating, or moving to and fro. (L.) [Hence also,] rayoEu AlDRuHaI (tropical:) The whiteness, and beautiful splendour, of the first part of the day after sunrise. (K, TA.) ― -b7- naAqapN lahaA rayoEN (tropical:) A she-camel having one pace, or rate of going, [app. a quicker pace,] after another. (TA.) ― -b8- fulaAnN layosa lahu rayoEN i. e. marojuwEN [app. meaning Such a one has no reply, or answer, to give: or, perhaps, to such a one there is no reply, or answer, to be given]. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A2- Also Fright, or fear; (K;) like rawoEN. (TA.)

riyEN c
riyEN (Fr, S, Msb, K, &c.) and rayoEN↓, (Fr, K,) the former occurring, (S,) or the latter accord. to one reading, (TA,) in the Kur [xxvi. 128], (S, TA,) High, or elevated, land or ground: (S, K:) or a high, or an elevated, place; (so in some copies of the S and in the Msb;) which latter
signification is also assigned to riyEapN↓; (TA;) and whence the phrase, kamo riyEu OaroDika, meaning what is the elevation of thy land? [a phrase not to be mistaken for kamo rayoEu OaroDika, in which the meaning is “ increase: ”] (Az, TA:) or any [road such as is termed] fajR: (K:) or (so accord. to the Msb and K, but in the S “ and ”) a road (S, Msb, K) of any kind, (K, TA,) to which some add, whether travelled or not: (TA: [see an ex. in the first paragraph of art. smt:]) or a road opening so as to form a gap in a mountain; (Zj, K;) or, as in some copies of the K, from a mountain; but the former is what is termed fajRN, before mentioned: (TA:) or a mountain; (S, Msb;) so accord. to 'Omárah: (S:) or, as in some copies of the S, a small mountain: (TA:) or signifying also a high mountain: (O, K:) n. of un. with p [i. e. riyEapN↓, as it is written in the S; and rayoEapN↓ also, as implied in the K]: (S, K: [in the former immediately following the signification of “ mountain; ” and in the latter, so following that of “ high mountain; ” whence it seems that riyEN and rayoEN are sometimes used, at least in one sense, as coll. gen. ns.:]) pl. [of mult.] riyaAEN, (S, TA,) which is extr., (TA,) and ruyuwEN, and [of pauc.] OaroyaAEN: (TA:) but AO says, contr. to J, that riyEapN↓ is pl. of riyEN: (IB, TA:) or riyEN and rayoEN signify the channel of the torrent of a valley from any, or every, high, or elevated, place. (K.) Also the former, A high mound, or heap of sand, or hill: and a Christian's cloister or cell; syn. SawomaEapN: and a pigeon-turret. (IAar, K.)

rayaEu AlXRabaAbi c
rayaEu AlXRabaAbi: see rayoEN.

rayoEapN c
rayoEapN: see riyEN.

riyEapN c
riyEapN: see riyEN, in three places. ＝ -A2- Also A number of men who have drawn, gathered, or collected, themselves together: (Ibn-'Abbád, K: *) otherwise, they are not so called. (Ibn-'Abbád.)

rayoEaAnN c
rayoEaAnN: see rayoEN, in four places.

rayoEaAnapN c
rayoEaAnapN (tropical:) A she-camel abounding with milk. (A, K, TA.)

farasN raAYiEN c
farasN raAYiEN A fleet, or swift, and excellent, horse. (S, TA.) [See also art. rwE, to which, as well as to the present art., it is said in the TA to belong.]

tariyEN OrAE rAE ryE tryE
tariyEN A register in which is written the rayoE [i. e. increase, or revenue arising from the increase, of the lands] of districts: the t being augmentative: but it is a post-classical word. (TA.)

OaroDN mariyEapN c
OaroDN mariyEapN, with fet-h to the m, A land [of much rayoE, or increase;] abounding with herbage; fruitful; or plentiful. (S, Msb, TA.)

murayRaEN c
murayRaEN, as an epithet applied to the saraAb [or mirage]: see murayRahN, in art. ryh.

miroyaAEN c
miroyaAEN A she-camel that goes away in the place of pasturing and returns by herself; (K;) or such is termed misoyaAEN miroyaAEN: (S, TA:) or upon which one repeatedly journeys: or upon which one journeys and returns: (Az, TA:) or (assumed tropical:) that quickly yields an abundant flow of milk: or (assumed tropical:) that quickly becomes fat: (K:) sometimes used in this sense. (Jm, TA.)

mutarayRiEN c
mutarayRiEN (tropical:) A slippery man, who anoints himself with oils. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b2- OanaA mutarayRiEN Eano hecaA AlOamori (assumed tropical:) I am holding, refraining, or abstaining, from this affair. (TA.)

2 ryRg c
2. ryRg (assumed tropical:) He smeared, seasoned, imbued, or soaked, a mess of variyd [i. e. broken, or crumbled, bread, biAldRasami] with grease, or gravy, or dripping; i. q. rawRagahaA (En-Nadr, K, TA) biAldRasami (En-Nadr, TA.)

5 tryRgt AllRuqomapu biAlsRamoni c
5. tryRgt AllRuqomapu biAlsRamoni (assumed tropical:) The morsel, or mouthful, was [smeared, seasoned,] imbued, or soaked, (tarawRat,) with clarified butter. (En-Nadr, TA.) [In the CK, and in some MS. copies of the K, this verb is mentioned as quasi-pass. of 2.]

riygN c
riygN: see what next follows.

riyaAgN c
riyaAgN, as in the [T and] O and Tekmileh and L; in the K, erroneously, riygN↓; (TA;) Dust, or dust raised: (Sh, K:) or, as some say, (TA,) dust, or earth, (K, TA,) in a general sense: or such as is comminuted. (TA.) Ru-beh says, describing an ass [i. e. a wild ass] and his females,
waUino OavaArato mino riyaAgK samolaqaA
tahowiI HawaAmiyhaA bihi mudaqRaqaA
using an inversion, for he means OavaArato riyaAgFA mino samolaqK [i. e. And if they raise earth from a level plain, the sides of their hoofs make it to fall down reduced to powder]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And i. q. nifaArN [The act of fleeing, going away or aside or apart or to a distance, retiring to a distance, shrinking, &c.; inf. n. of nafara, q. v.]: (K:) so some say. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Sgh says that this word may belong to the present art. and to art. rwg, q. v. (TA.)

maraAgN c
maraAgN, signifying The place in which beasts roll, or turn themselves over, is thought by Az to be so called from riyaAgN in the first of the senses assigned to it above. (TA.)

murayRagN c
murayRagN A thing defiled with dust or earth, or much sprinkled with dust. (El-'Azeezee, K.)

1 raAfa c
1. raAfa, aor. yariyfu, He (a man of the desert) came to the riyf; (T, O, K;) as also Oaroyafa↓ and tryRf↓: (K:) or he entered the region, district, or tract, of cities, towns, or villages, and of cultivated land: or raAfuwA signifies they approached the riyf; and so tryRfwA↓: (Ham p. 676:) or this last, they journeyed to the riyf; (M;) and so OaroyafuwA↓: (S, * M:) or tryRfnA↓, we abode, or stayed, in [a region of] cities, towns, or villages, and where water was reached by digging, or where it was apparent, running upon the surface of the earth. (T.) ― -b2- And raAfati AlmaAXiyapu The cattle pastured in the riyf. (S, K.)

3 rAyf lilZRinRapi c
3. rAyf lilZRinRapi He was, or became, near to [having, or incurring] AlZRinRap [i. e. suspicion, or evil opinion]; syn. qaArafahaA, and TanRafa lahaA. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K.) [Freytag, app. misled by the TK, renders rAyf, followed by l, as meaning “ Falsa protulit, calumniis accusavit. ” He also assigns to rAyf the signification of “ Adpropinquavit regioni ryf, ” as on the authority of the Ham; in which I do not find it.]

4 Oaroyafa
4: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- ArAft AlOaroDu, (S, M, K,) inf. n. UiraAfapN and [accord. to some] riyfN↓; like AxSbt, inf. n. UixoSaAbN and xiSobN; but, [ISd says,] in my opinion, UiraAfapN is the inf. n., and riyfN is the subst.; and in like manner one should say of UixoSaAbN and xiSobN; (M, TA;) The land abounded, or became abundant, with herbage, and with the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life; (S, M, * K;) as also Oaroyafat. (K.)

5 tarayRafa
5: see 1, in three places.

raAfN c
raAfN Wine: (T, K:) more properly mentioned in art. rwf. (TA.)

riyfN c
riyfN Land in which are sown fields, or seedproduce, and abundance of herbage and of the goods or conveniences or comforts of life: (S, O, K:) and (K) the part that is near to water, of the land of the Arabs, (M, O, L, K,) and of other lands: (M, L:) or the part that is near to the Sawád (AlsRawaAd), of the land of the Arabs: (IDrd, Ham p. 676:) or a tract in which are green herbs, and waters, (T, O, K,) and level lands of seed-produce, (T,) or sown fields, or varieties of seed-produce: (O, K:) [generally,] a region, district, or tract, [of cultivated fields; or] of towns, or villages, and of cultivated land: (Ham p. 676:) pl. OaroyaAfN (T, S, M, TA) and ruyuwfN. (M, TA.) ― -b2- Also (M, K) Abundance (Lth, T, M, O, K) of herbage, and of the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life, and (Lth, T, M) in respect of food (Lth, T, M, O, K) and drink: (O, K:) pl. [in this sense] OaroyaAfN (M, K) only. (M.) See also 4.

riyfiIRN c
riyfiIRN [Of, or belonging to, the riyf, or region of cultivated land; opposed to barRiIRN;] applied to a plant [&c.]. (M, voce EuSofurN.) And OaroDN riyfiyRapN Cultivated land; contr. of barRiyRapN. (IAar, and M and K * and TA in art. br.)

OaroDN rayRifapN c
OaroDN rayRifapN Land abounding with herbage, and with the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life. (S, O, K.)

1 raAqa c
1. raAqa, (JK, S, K,) aor. yariyqu, inf. n. rayoqN, (JK, S,) said of the saraAb [or mirage], It was agitated, and moved to and fro, (JK, K,) or it shone, or glistened, (S,) above the ground; (JK, S, K;) and tryRq↓ signifies the same. (S, O, K.) [And in the former sense, rAq may be said of water; for the inf. n.] rayoqN signifies also The going to and fro (Lth, JK, K) of water, (JK,) or of
shallow water and the like, (Lth, K,) upon the surface of the earth. (Lth, JK, K.) ― -b2- Also, (Ks, JK, Msb, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Ks, Msb,) said of water, (Ks, JK, Msb, K,) and of blood, (Msb,) It poured out, or forth. (Ks, Msb, K.) ― -b3- huwa yariyqu binafosihi, (JK, S, K,) inf. n. ruyuwqN (S, K) and rayoqN, (TA,) (tropical:) He gives up his spirit; or gives away his life; syn. yajuwdu bihaA; (JK, S, K;) at death: (S, K:) mentioned by Ks. (TA.)

2 rayRaqotuhu AlXRaraAba c
2. rayRaqotuhu AlXRaraAba I gave him to drink the wine, or beverage, fasting; when he had not yet eaten. (TA.)

4 ArAqhu c
4. ArAqhu He poured it out, or forth. (Msb, K.) See art. rwq.

5 tarayRaqa
5: see 1, first sentence.

6 humaA yataraAyaqaAni AlmaMCa c and yataraAwaqaAnihi
6. humaA yataraAyaqaAni AlmaMCa yataraAwaqaAnihi (JK) They two pour the water out, or forth, by turns. (TA in explanation of the latter in art. rwq.)

rayoqN c
rayoqN A shining, or glistening, (K, TA,) of a sword [&c.]. (TA.) Hence, in a trad. respecting [the battle of] Bedr, faUicaA birayoqi sayofK mino waraAYiI [And lo, the shining, or glistening, of a sword behind me]: thus written by El-Wákidee: if the reading bariyqu [from baraqa] had been transmitted, it would be evidently reasonable. (IAth, TA.) ― -b2- And i. q. baATilN [as meaning False, or vain, speech or conduct]. (K.) One says, OaqoSiro Eano rayoqika [Desist thou from thy false, or vain, speech or conduct]. (TA.) ― -b3- rayoqu AllRayoli, with fet-h [to the r], The saraAb [or mirage]. (TA.) ― -b4- rayoqN also signifies Water: (K:) or water that is drunk in the state of fasting, in the early morning, or first part of the day; (TA;) [and] so raAYiqN↓, which is [said to be] not applied [in this sense] to anything but water: you say maMCN raAYiqN. (S.) [But see raAYiqN.] ― -b5- And xubozN rayoqN (IDrd, K) and raAYiqN↓ (As, JK, K) Dry bread; i. e. bread without seasoning, or condiment, to render it pleasant, or savoury. (As, JK, IDrd, K.) ― -b6- See also rayRiqN: both are also mentioned in art. rwq q. v.

riyqN c
riyqN Saliva; syn. ruDaAbN; (S, K, TA;) i. e. (TA) the water of the mouth; (JK, Msb, K, TA;) its luEaAb: (TA:) or the water of the mouth in the early morning, or first part of the day; (Lth, TA: [but this rendering is often inapplicable:]) or the water of the mouth while it is therein; for when it has gone forth from the mouth it is termed buSaAqN and buzaAqN and busaAqN: (K in art. bSq:) and riyqapN↓ signifies the same, in poetry: (Msb, TA:) or this has a more particular meaning; (S, Msb, * K;) [i. e. it means somewhat of saliva; or a little saliva:] the pl. is OaroyaAqN [a pl. of pauc.] (S, K, TA) and riyaAqN [a pl. of mult.]. (TA.) [Hence,] one says, OaboliEoniI riyqiI [Suffer thou me to swallow my saliva;] give thou me time to swallow my saliva: (K and TA in art. blE:) or (assumed tropical:) grant thou me some delay, or let me alone for a while, that I may say, or do, such a thing. (Har p. 164.) [And AibotalaEa riyqah He swallowed his saliva: meaning (assumed tropical:) he restrained his anger: see 1 in art. blE.] And Xuriba EalaI AlrRiyqi [It was drunk in the state of fasting; before breakfast]: (S, K:) and in like manner Oukila [It was so eaten]. (K.) And huwa EalaI AlrRiyqi, (AO, S, K,) or EalaI riyqihi, (TA,) and huwa rayRiqN↓, (AO, S, K,) of the measure fayoEilN, (S,) and raAYiqN↓, (K,) i. e. [He is fasting;] he has not breakfasted. (TA.) And Oatayotuhu EalaI riyqK (ISk, S) and EalaI riyqi nafosiI, (S, TA,) and Oatayotuhu rayRiqFA↓ and raAYiqFA↓, I came to him [fasting,] not having eaten anything. (ISk, S, TA.) [Hence also riyqu AlXRamosi, likewise called luEaAbu AlXRamosi and muxaATu AlXRamosi and riyqu AlXRayaATiyni and muxaATu AlXRayoTaAni, (tropical:) The fine filmy cobwebs termed gossamer: see arts. lEb and mxT.] ― -b2- Also Strength: and the remains of life, or of the spirit, or of the soul: syns. quwRapN and ramaqN [which latter, it should be observed, has both of these meanings, so that possibly only the former meaning may be here intended]. (K.) You say, kaAna hecaA AlOamoru wabinaA riyqN This event happened when there was in us strength. (TA.)

rayoqapN c
[rayoqapN, accord. to Freytag, as occurring in the Deewán El-Hudhaleeyeen, signifies The beginning of youth: but perhaps this may be a mistake, occasioned by some one's saying that the beginning of youth is termed ryqh, meaning rayoquhu.]

riyqapN c
riyqapN: see riyqN. ― -b2- cw Alryqp is said by Z to be the name of a sword of Murrah Ibn-Rabee'ah. (TA: but the vowel-signs are not there written.)

raAYiqN c
raAYiqN Anything eaten, or drunk, EalaI AlrRiyqi [i. e. in the state of fasting; before breakfast]. (K.) See also rayoqN, in two places. ― -b2- And see riyqN, likewise in two places. ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) Empty-handed. (K.) You say, jaMCa raAYiqFA (assumed tropical:) He came empty [-handed]. (JK.) ＝ -A2- Also Pure; (As, K;) applied to musk, and to anything. (As, TA.) [Mentioned also in art. rwq.] ＝ -A3- Also said to signify vwb Ejn bAlmsk [i. e. Eujina biAlmisoki, app. meaning that it is an epithet applied to a garment as signifying Sprinkled with musk and then pressed, or kneaded]. (TA.)

rayRiqN c
rayRiqN: see riyqN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also, (S,) and rayoqN↓, (S, K,) which is a contraction of the former, sometimes used, (S,) and rayRuwqN↓, (AO, K,) The first part, (S, K,) and the most excellent, of anything, as, for instance, of youth, and of rain. (S.) [The first and second are also mentioned in art. rwq, q. v. J cites here, and ascribes to Lebeed, as an ex. of the second of these words, a verse which I have cited in the third paragraph of art. ErD, but with rawoqa in the place of rayoqa, from the TA, in which it is ascribed to ElBa'eeth.]

rayRuwqN c
rayRuwqN: see the next preceding paragraph.

tiroyaAqN tryAq
tiroyaAqN, said in the T to be so called because containing the saliva of serpents, is explained in art. trq. (TA.)

maraAqN c
maraAqN [app. a n. of place from raAqa having for its aor. yariyqu said of water; though anomalous; for by rule it should be mariyqN;] The part, of the throat, which is the place of passage of the water. (T and TA in art. drO: see the last sentence of the first paragraph of that art.)

murayRaqN c
murayRaqN One in whom a thing ceases not to induce wonder, or admiration, and pleasure, or joy; or whom a thing ceases not to please, or rejoice: (K:) occurring in a verse of Ru-beh: but Sgh says that it should by rule be murawRaqN. (TA.)

1 raAla c
1. raAla, aor. yariylu, He (a child) slavered. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K.) [See also art. rwl.]

riyaAlN c
riyaAlN Slaver; (Ibn-'Abbád, K;) [like ruwaAlN;] without C. (TA.)

1 rayomN c
1. rayomN is syn. with baraAHN; (Lth, T, M, K;) and the verb is raAma, aor. yariymu, [He went away, or departed; and he quitted a place: and he ceased doing a thing:] (Lth, T, TA:) rayomN being the inf. n. (TA.) IAar used to say, in relation [or reply] to the saying maA rimotu [I did not go away, &c., or I have not gone away, &c.], balaI qado rimotu [Nay, I did go away, &c., or I have gone away, &c.]: but others use the verb only with a negative particle: (T:) or it is mostly used in negative phrases. (TA.) You say, raAmahu, aor. yariymuhu, (S, Mgh,) inf. n. as above, (S,) He went away from it, departed from it, or quitted it; syn. bariHahu; (S;) or zaAla minohu, and faAraqahu; namely, his place. (Mgh.) And rimotu fulaAnFA and ramotu mino Einodi fulaAnK [I went away from such a one]: both meaning the same. (S.) And laA tarimohu Go not thou away from him, or it; syn. laAtaboraHohu. (S.) And maA rimotu AlmakaAna and maA rimotu minohu (M, K) I went not from the place; syn. maA bariHotu. (K.) And maA rimotu OafoEalu celika (M, * K, * TA) I ceased not doing that; syn. maA bariHotu. (TA.) ― -b2- And i. q. tabaAEudN [The being, or becoming, distant, remote, far off, or aloof; &c.]: (T, K:) [you say,] maA yariymN [He does not become distant, &c.]. (T.) [Accord. to the TK, it is, in this sense, inf. n. of raAmahu, aor. as above, meaning He was, or became, distant, &c., from it.] ― -b3- And An inclining, or a leaning, in the load of a camel, (K, TA,) by reason of excess and heaviness thereof. (TA.) One says, lihecaA AlEidoli rayomN EalaI hecaA [There is to this side-burden an inclining, or a leaning, by reason of an excess of weight over this: or,] a heaviness [exceeding that of this], by reason of which it inclines, or leans. (TA.) [And accord. to the TK, you say of the load of a camel, raAma, meaning It inclined, or leaned.] ― -b4- And The becoming drawn together, of the mouth of a wound, in order to heal; as also rayamaAnN. (K.) [Both are said in the TK to be inf. ns. of raAma, aor. as above, said of a wound, meaning Its mouth became drawn together, in order to heal.] ＝ -A2- riyma bihi i. q. quTiEa bihi [He was
or became, disabled from prosecuting, or unable to prosecute, his journey]. (S, K.) A rájiz says,
wariyma biAlsRaAEiI AlRaciI kaAna maEiI
[And the messenger that was with me became disabled from prosecuting his journey]. (S, TA.)

2 ryRm Ealayohi c
2. ryRm Ealayohi, (T, K,) inf. n. taroyiymN, (TA,) He exceeded him; (T, K, TA;) i. e., one man, another; (T;) in journeying, or pace, and the like: from rayomN as signifying ziyaAdapN and faDolN [i. e. “ excess, ” &c.], or as signifying baraAHN [expl. above]. (TA.) ― -b2- ryRm biAlmakaAni, (ISk, S, M,) inf. n. as above, (ISk, S,) He (a man, ISk, S) remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in the place. (ISk, S. M.) And rayRamati AlsRaHaAbapu faOagoDanato The cloud remained without clearing away [and rained continually]. (S, TA.) ― -b3- And ryRm, inf. n. as above, He journeyed all the day. (TA.)

rayomN c
rayomN Excess, redundance, or superiority; syn. faDolN, (ISk, T, S, M, K,) and ziyaAdapN, (S, K,) which is like faDolN. (TA.) One says, lihecaA rayomN EalaI hecaA This has excess, or superiority, (faDolN, ISk, T,) over this. (ISk, T, S. *) AlrRayomu EalaIAlmazojuwri, a phrase used by El-'Ajjáj, means mano zujira faEalayohi AlfaDolu [which may be rendered He who is chidden, it is incumbent on him to exceed; or he who is chidden is exceeded]: (T, S:) such being always the case; for one is chidden only on account of an affair in which he has fallen short of doing what was requisite. (S.) ― -b2- A thing such as is termed EilaAwap [q. v.] between the two side-loads of a camel. (IAar, T, K.) Hence the saying, AlrRayomu Oavoqalu EalaI AldRawaAbRi mina AlHimoli [The additional burden that is put between the two side-loads is more onerous to the beasts than the (usual) load]. (TK) after the flesh of the slaughtered camel has been distributed (T, S) in the game called Almayosir, (T,) and which is given to the slaughterer: (M, K:) accord. to Lh, the camel for slaughter is brought, and its owner slaughters it, then puts it upon something laid upon the ground to preserve it from pollution, having divided it into ten portion, namely, the two haunches, and the two thighs, and the rump, and the withers, and the breast, and [the part of the back called] the maloHaMC [q. v.], and the two shoulders together with the two arms; then he betakes himself to the TafaATif [or soft parts, such as the flanks, or the soft parts of the belly], and the vertebræ of the neck, and distributes them upon those portions equally; and if there remain a bone, or a small piece of flesh, that is the rayom: then the slaughterer waits with it for him who desires it, and he whose arrow wins, his it is; otherwise, it is for the slaughterer. (M, TA.) ― -b3- The last portion of the day-time, extending to the confusedness (AixotilaAT, for which AixotilaAf is erroneously put in the copies of the K, TA) of the darkness. (M, K, TA.) A long [indefinite period such as is termed] saAEap: (S, K:) so in the saying, qado baqiIa rayomN mina AlnRahaAri [A long period of the day-time had remained; or, emphatically, remains]. (S.) And nahaArN rayomN means A long day or day-time: so in the saying, Ealayoka nahaArN rayomN [app. meaning A long day is appointed thee for the performance of a work or task]. (AZ, T.) ＝ -A2- Also i. q. darajapN [as meaning A series of stairs:] (IAar, Jm, T, S, M, K:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (S.) Aboo-'Amr Ibn-'Alà says, as related by As, I was in El-Yemen, and I came to the house of a man, inquiring for him, and a man of the house said to me, Ausomuko fiI AlrRayomi, meaning AiSoEadi AldRarajapi [Ascend thou the stairs]. (JM, cited in the PS.) ― -b2- And i. q. dukRaAnN [meaning A kind of wide bench, of stone or brick; and also a shop]: (M, TA:) likewise of the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.) ― -b3- And Small mountains. (IAar, T, K.) ― -b4- And A grave: (IAar, T, S, M, K:) or the middle thereof. (M, K.) ＝ -A3- See also what next follows.

riymN c
riymN, (Jm, T, PS,) with kesr, (Jm, PS,) [accord. to the K, erroneously, rayomN↓, The antilope leucoryx;] a white antelope; (Jm, PS;) an antelope (ZaboIN) that is purely white: (IAar, T, K:) written with and without C: [see riYomN, in art. rOm:] pl. OaroMmN (Jm, PS) [and MraAmN].

maroyamN c
maroyamN A woman who loves the discourse of men, but does not act vitiously or immorally, or commit adultery or fornication. (K.) Also a [female] proper name. (K.) It is said by AA to be of the measure mafoEalN from raAma, aor. yariymu: (S, Sgh, Msb, TA:) but some say that, as a proper name, it is arabicized, from maAriyap. (TA.)

1 raAna c
1. raAna, [aor. yariynu,] inf. n. rayonN, [in its primary acceptation, app. signifies It was, or became, rusty, or covered with rust. And hence,] It (a garment, or piece of cloth,) was, or became, dirty, or filthy; syn. taTabRaEa. (M, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence also,] rAnt nafosahu, (S, M, K, *) aor. tariynu, inf. n. as above, (S,) His soul [or stomach] became heavy; or heaved, or became agitated by a tendency to vomit; syn. gavato, (S, M, K,) and xabuvato. (S, K.) ― -b3- And rAn Ealayohi, (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Msb,) It (anything) covered it; namely, a thing: (M:) or it (anything) overcame him; (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, * Mgh, Msb, K;) as also rAn bihi; (A'Obeyd, T, S, Mgh, K;) and raAnahu. (A'Obeyd, S, Mgh, K.) [And raAna with yaruwnu for its aor. signifies the same; as will be seen from a verse cited below.] You say of a sin, misdeed, or transgression, (canob,) rAn EalaI qalobihi, (Zj, T, S, Mgh, K,) aor. as above, (Zj, T, S,) inf. n. rayonN (Zj, T, S, M, K) and ruyuwnN, (S, M, K,) It covered his heart: (Zj, T, M:) or it overcame his heart. (S, Mgh, K.) raAna EalaI quluwbihimo maA kaAnuwA yakosibwuna, in the Kur [lxxxiii. 14], means [What they used to do] hath become like rust upon the clearness of their hearts, so as to make the knowledge of good from evil to be obscured to them: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or hath covered their hearts: (Zj, T:) or hath overcome their hearts: [or hath spread a blackness upon their hearts; for,] accord. to El-Hasan, it means that sin has followed upon sin so that the heart has become black: (S:) and accord. to Aboo-Mo'adh the Grammarian, and a saying of the Prophet, AlrRayonu means the heart's becoming black in consequence of sins. (T.) You say also, riyna EalI qalobihi His heart became covered [&c.]. (M.) And riyna bihi He was overcome: (T, Mgh:) or his property was beset by debt: (T:) or he fell into grief, by reason of debt: (M:) or he fell into that from which he could not escape, (AZ, T, S, Mgh, K,) and with which he had not power to cope: (AZ, T, S:) or i. q. AunoquTiEa bihi [i. e. he became disabled from prosecuting his journey, his means having failed him, or his beast breaking down with him or perishing]; (T, S, M;) so says El-Kanánee El-Aarábee: (T, S:) and he died. (M.) And raAnato bihi Alxamoru, (T,) or rAnt Ealayohi Alxamoru, (S, M, [in one copy of the S AlHumRaI,]) The wine overcame him; (S, M;) and overwhelmed him: (M:) or overcame his heart and his reason: (T:) and in like manner one says of drowsiness, and of anxiety; by way of comparison. (M.) And rAn AlnRuEaAsu fiI AlEayoni Drowsiness overcame the eye: (S, TA: *) or infected, or pervaded, the eye. (Msb.) Et-Tirimmáh says,
maxaAfapa Oano yaruwna AlnRawomu fiyhimo
bisukori sinaAtihimo kulRa AlrRuyuwni
[In fear that sleep might overcome them, by reason of the intoxication of their sensations of drowsiness, with every degree of overcoming]. (TA. [This, together with a signification assigned to maruwna in art. rwn in the K, shows that raAna signifying “ he, or it, overcame, ” &c., has yaruwna as well as yariynu for its aor.]) And you say also, rAn Ealayohi Almawotu, and rAn bihi, Death took him away. (M.)

4 ArAnwA c
4. ArAnwA Their cattle perished, or died: (ElUmawee, T, S, M, K:) and (so in the T, but in the M “ or ”) their cattle became lean, or emaciated. (El-Umawee, T, M.) This also, says A'Obeyd, is from an event that has happened to them and overcome them, and which they have not been able to bear. (T.)

raAnN c
raAnN: see the next paragraph. ＝ -A2- Also [A kind of legging;] a thing like a xufR [or boot], but longer, and without a foot: (K:) described by the author of the Msb, in his handwriting upon the margin, as a piece of cloth made like the xufR, stuffed with cotton, worn beneath it on account of the cold: not a genuine Arabic word: (MF:) it is a Persian word, arabicized. (TA.)

rayonN c
rayonN, originally an inf. n.: (Msb:) Rust that overspreads the sword and the mirror; (M;) rust that overspreads a polished thing: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or much dirtiness from rust: or simply dirt, filth, soil, or pollution: syn. TabaEN and canasN: (S, K: [in a copy of the S, and in the CK, AlTRaboEu is erroneously put for AlTRabaEu:]) or a cover, or covering. (Msb.) [And hence,] The like of rust, covering the heart: (Zj, T:) black-
ness of the heart: pl. riyaAnN. (T.) And raAnN↓ signifies the same as rayonN. (TA.)

rayonapN c
rayonapN i. q. xamorapN [i. e. Wine, or some wine, or a kind of wine]: pl. rayonaAtN: (IAar, Th, T, K:) so called because it overcomes the reason. (TA.)

rajulN mariynN Ealayohi c
rajulN mariynN Ealayohi A man beset, or encompassed. (TA.)

muriynuwna c
muriynuwna Persons whose cattle have perished, or died: (El-Umawee, T, S, K:) and whose cattle have become lean, or emaciated. (El-Umawee, T.)

1 raAha c
1. raAha, aor. yariyhu, (K,) inf. n. rayohN, said of the saraAb [or mirage], (TA,) It came and went; (K, TA;) [or went to and fro; or appeared to do so;] or ran upon the surface of the earth: (TA:) and tryRh↓, likewise said of the srAb, [signifies the same,] i. q. tarayRaEa: (S, K, TA:) or tryRh signifies it was made to run hither and thither, in no uniform manner: (IAar, TA:) or it glistened uninterruptedly. (TA in art. rh.) ― -b2- And He, or it, returned; like raAEa, aor. yariyEu. (TA in art. ryE.)

2 ruyRaha c
2. ruyRaha, said of the saraAb [or mirage]; and rayRahatohu AlhaAjirapu: see murayRahN, below.

5 tarayRaha
5: see 1.

murayRahN c
murayRahN, (S, K,) as an epithet applied to the saraAb [or mirage], (TA,) i. q. murayRaEN, (S, K, TA,) [meaning] kaOanRahu ruyRiha Oawo rayRahatohu AlhiAjirapu [As though it were made to come and go, or go to and fro, or run upon the surface of the earth; or as though the vehement midday-heat made it to come and go, &c.]. (TA.)
